summary_generated: Amends the Water Resources Development Act of 1992 to authorize appropriations for projects for the elimination or control of combined sewer overflows in: (1) Jackson County, Mississippi; (2) Manchester, New Hampshire; (3) Atlanta, Georgia; (4) Paterson, Passaic County, and Passaic Valley, New Jersey; (5) Elizabeth and North Hudson, New Jersey; and (6) the Delaware River, Pennsylvania and Delaware. Prohibits construction on a project authorized to be carried out by the Secretary of the Army until the Secretary determines that the project is technically sound, environmentally acceptable, and economically justified. <n>(Sec. 4) Repeals a provision prohibiting construction on a project authorized to be carried out by the Secretary until the Secretary determines that the project is technically sound, environmentally acceptable, and economically justified. <n>(Sec. 5) Requires a project cooperation agreement for the Comite River Diversion Project to include a provision that specifies that any reduction in the non-Federal share that results from the modification of the project shall be credited toward the share of project costs to be paid by the Amite River Basin Drainage and Water Conservation District. <n>(Sec. 7) Authorizes appropriations for a project for which a District Engineer's Report is completed by the date of enactment of this Act. <n>(Sec

Federal Forage Fee Act of 1993 - Makes all grazing operations conducted on Federal lands subject to all applicable Federal, State, and local laws, including, but not limited to: (1) Animal Damage Control Act; (2) the Clean Air Act; (3) the Endangered Species Act; (4) the Federal Advisory Committee Act; (5) the Federal Grant and Cooperative Agreement Act; (6) the National Forest Management Act of 1976; (7) the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976; (8) the Federal Water Pollution Control Act; (9) the Granger-Thye Wilderness Act; (10) the Independent Offices Appropriations Act of 1952; (11) the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969; and (12) the Public Rangeland Improvement Act. <n>Amends the: (1) Western States' Update Act of 1973 to set forth the fee schedule for grazing operations in Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Kansas, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming; and (2) Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to set forth the fee schedule for livestock grazing on Federal lands in Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Kansas, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming. <n>

. Merchant Marine of World War II Congressional Gold Medal Act (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to award a Congressional Gold Medal to the U.S. Merchant Marine in honor of their dedicated and vital service during World War II. (Sec. 4) The medal shall be given to the American Merchant Marine Museum for display.

Small Business Tax Modernization Act of 2004 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to prohibit any new S corporation elections after December 31, 2004. Terminates S corporation status after 2014. Allows an eligible corporation to elect to be treated as a partnership. Defines partnership" to include a syndicate, group, pool, joint venture, or other unincorporated organization through or by means of which any business, financial operation, or venture is carried on, and which is not a trust or estate or a corporation."

. Fair Access to Investment Research Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to establish and implement a safe harbor" for certain investment fund research reports published by brokers and dealers. Such reports shall be deemed not to be "offers" under specified provisions of securities law, even if the broker or dealer participates in the registered offering of the investment fund\\'s securities. In implementing the safe harbor, the SEC must prohibit a self-regulatory organization from maintaining or enforcing a rule that would prevent a member from: (1) publishing or distributing a covered investment fund research report solely because the member is also participating in a registered offering or other distribution of the fund\\'s securities, or (2) participating in a registered offering or other distribution of the fund solely because the member has published a research report about it. The bill restricts the SEC from conditioning the safe harbor upon specified requirements."

Prescription Drug Monitoring Act of 2016 This bill requires a state that receives grant funds under the prescription drug monitoring program (PDMP) or the controlled substance monitoring program to comply with specified requirements, including a requirement to make its PDMP data available to other states through a data-sharing single technology solution. The Department of Justice (DOJ) or Department of Health and Human Services may withhold grant funds from a state that fails to comply. To facilitate data sharing among states, the bill directs DOJ to award a grant under the PDMP competitive grant program to establish and maintain a data-sharing hub.

Strategic Gasoline and Fuel Reserve Act of 2005 - Amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to direct the Secretary of Energy to establish, maintain, and operate a Strategic Gasoline and Fuel Reserve (the Reserve). Prohibits the Reserve from being a component of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to determine not less than three Reserve sites, and not more than five Reserve sites, throughout the United States that are regionally strategic.<n><n>Instructs the Secretary to obtain the concurrence of the Secretary of Homeland Security with respect to physical design and operational security.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) acquire storage and related facilities and storage services; (2) use, lease, maintain, sell, or otherwise dispose of storage and related facilities acquired under this Act; (3) store gasoline and fuel in facilities not owned by the United States; and (4) sell, exchange, or otherwise dispose of gasoline and fuel from the Reserve.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on October 6, 2003. However, because action occurred on the measure, the summary has been expanded.)Special Agent Scott K. Carey Public Safety Officer Benefits Enhancement Act - Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 (Omnibus Act) to make an eligible dependent of a Federal, State, county, or local public safety officer who dies in the line of duty on or after January 1, 1978, or who becomes permanently and totally disabled as the direct result of a catastrophic injury sustained in the line of duty on or after January 1, 1978, eligible for assistance under the public safety officers' disability benefits program.(Sec. 102) Revises application requirements for the public safety officers' disability benefits program to make eligible for assistance an eligible dependent (currently, a dependent of the officer) who: (1) dies in the line of duty on or after January 1, 1978; or (2) becomes permanently and totally disabled as the direct result of a catastrophic injury sustained in the line of duty on or after January 1, 1978.(Sec. 103) Makes an eligible dependent eligible for assistance retroactively if such an officer: (1) dies in the line of duty on or after January 1, 1978; or (2) becomes permanently and totally disabled as the

Promoting Financial Literacy and Economic Opportunity Act of 2015 Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a business-related tax credit for 50% of the amount paid or incurred for the promotion of economic and financial literacy by eligible for profit organizations pursuant to a qualified program. Defines "eligible for profit organization" as a organization that: (1) has a qualified program in effect for the taxable year, and (2) has been determined by the Secretary of the Treasury to be an organization to whom the credit is allowed.

Amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to prohibit the entry of cigarettes or smokeless tobacco products into the United States in connection with a delivery sale. Defines delivery sale" as any sale of cigarettes or smokeless tobacco products to a consumer if: (1) the consumer submits the order for such sale by means of a telephone, other method of voice transmission, the mail, or the Internet or other online service, or the seller is otherwise not in the physical presence of the buyer when the request for purchase or order is made; or (2) the cigarettes or smokeless tobacco product is delivered by use of a common carrier, private delivery service, or the mail, or the seller is not in the physical presence of the buyer when the buyer obtains personal possession of the delivered cigarettes or smokeless tobacco product.<n><n>Entitles a state, through its Attorney General, to obtain copies of any certification required by the United States for the importation of such products in connection with a delivery sale.<n><n>Authorizes persons who hold a permit under the Internal Revenue Code to bring actions in U.S. district courts against any person, other than a state, local, or tribal government to prevent and restrain violations of this Act."

Outer Continental Shelf Revenue Sharing Act of 2005 - Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to instruct the Secretary of the Interior to delineate the lateral boundaries between coastal states in areas of the Outer Continental Shelf under exclusive federal jurisdiction to the extent of the exclusive economic zone of the United States.<n><n><n><n>Authorizes a state's governor to petition the Secretary for a resource assessment of any area within the seaward boundary of the state.<n><n>Prohibits the Secretary from offering for offshore leasing, preleasing, or any related activity: (1) any area located on the outer Continental Shelf that is designated as a marine sanctuary under the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972; or (2) during the period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act and ending on June 30, 2012, any affected area.

Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act Amendments of 1993 - Amends the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act to replace title I with part A: Provisions for Individuals With Developmental Disabilities; and part A with findings and policy. Declares U.S. policy with respect to State Developmental Disabilities Councils, protection and advocacy systems, university-affiliated programs, and other nationally significant activities.

Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 (HEA) to revise provisions that require State agencies that accredit educational institutions to apply procedures throughout the accrediting process that comply with due process, including the right to: (1) adequate specification of the agency's accrediting requirements; (2) written notice of deficiencies at the institution of higher education or program being examined and a reasonable time period to correct such deficiencies; (3) advance notice of and an opportunity for a hearing by any such institution before the agency's decision making body prior to the agency's final consideration of the adverse action; (4) appeal any adverse action by the agency against any such institution to an independent and impartial arbitration panel conducted at the location of the institution; (5) appeal, at a minimum, the adequacy of the evidence supporting the adverse action decision, the adequacy of the agency's compliance with its own policies and procedures, and the extent to which the decision was tainted by bias or prejudice of any agent or official of the agency; (6) representation by counsel for any such institution; (7) an arbitration panel decision that may affirm or reverse, but not modify, the decision appealed by the institution; and (8) an allocation of the costs of the appeal that requires the agency and institution to each bear its own attorney, witness, and other costs

Robert S. Walker and George E. Brown, Jr. Hydrogen Energy Act of 2001 - Amends the Spark M. Matsunaga Hydrogen Research, Development, and Demonstration Act of 1990 to include among its purposes the development of methods of hydrogen production that minimize adverse environmental impacts.Directs the Secretary of Energy to report annually to Congress on the status and progress of the programs and activities authorized under this Act.Requires the Secretary, in conducting the hydrogen research and development program, to: (1) give particular attention to developing an understanding and resolution of critical technical issues preventing the introduction of hydrogen into the marketplace; (2) initiate or accelerate existing research and development in critical technical issues that will contribute to the development of more economical hydrogen production, storage, transportation, and use; (3) survey private sector and public sector hydrogen research and development activities worldwide; and (4) ensure that research and development activities do not duplicate any available research and development results or displace or compete with the privately funded hydrogen research and development activities of U.S. industry.Requires the Secretary to: (1) evaluate whether to undertake or fund research and development activities; and (2) carry out or fund such activities only on a competitive basis using peer review.Requires the Secretary to require a commitment from non-Federal sources of at least 20 percent of the cost

Mercury Health Advisory Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to promulgate a final rule establishing an advisory level for methylmercury that is equal to, or greater than, the action level limit established by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. Requires the advisory level to: (1) be based on testing conducted since 1993 by the Food and Drug Administration; and (2) warn women of childbearing age, nursing mothers, and young children about the potential adverse effects of methylmercury exposure from the consumption of specified fish.Directs the Secretary to work with other Federal agencies to achieve this goal.Requires the Administrator to contract with the National Research Council for technical review of the advisories.

Authorizes the Secretary of Energy to enter into one or more long-term contracts, for up to 30 years each, for the procurement, from a facility located within 25 miles of a current or former Department of Energy defense nuclear facility, of products and services necessary to support waste cleanup and modernization activities at such facilities.

Prohibits the Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA) from implementing any new evaluation and management guidelines under the Medicare program unless HCFA: (1) has provided for an assessment of the proposed guidelines by physicians; (2) has established a plan for improving participation of physicians; (3) has carried out a minimum of four pilot projects in at least four different HCFA regions to test such guidelines; and (4) finds that the objectives will be met in the implementation of such guidelines. Requires each pilot project to: (1) be of sufficient length to allow for preparatory physician and carrier education, analysis, and use and assessment of potential E&M guidelines; and (2) be conducted, throughout the planning and operational stages of the project, in consultation with national and State medical societies.

State Innovation Pilot Act of 2011 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA) to revise the process for state educational agencies (SEAs), local educational agencies (LEAs), and Indian tribes to request waivers from certain ESEA requirements. Requires a waiver request to include a plan that will improve instruction for students, advance student academic achievement, and contribute to student mastery of knowledge and skills consistent with the state's college and career ready academic content standards and student academic achievement standards. Requires the plan to include the methods the SEA, LEA, or tribe will use to: (1) monitor the effectiveness of the implementation of the plan; and (2) assure regular evaluation and continuous improvement. Requires the SEA, LEA, or tribe's process for making valid and meaningful accountability determinations based on student academic achievement to review the success of schools and LEAs or Indian tribes in implementing the state's college and career ready academic content standards and student academic achievement standards to: (1) describe its process for accurately and meaningfully identifying, supporting, and intervening in underperforming schools; and (2) include information on how the SEA, LEA, or tribe will maintain and improve transparency in reporting to parents and the public on student achievement and school performance. Directs the Secretary of Education to

(Sec. 1) Expresses the sense of the Congress that: (1) any individual convicted of murder should receive the death penalty or be imprisoned for life without the possibility of parole; and (2) any individual convicted of rape or a dangerous sexual offense involving a child under 14 should be imprisoned for life without the possibility of parole.(Sec. 3) Directs the Attorney General, in a case in which a State convicts of murder, rape, or a dangerous sexual offense a person who has a prior conviction for one such offense in another State, to administer the transfer of specified amounts from Federal law enforcement assistance funds to the State that convicted such person of the first offense and to the State that convicted of a subsequent offense. Directs that half of the amounts transferred be paid to the State designated to administer crime victim assistance and half be deposited in a State account that collects Federal law enforcement funds.Provides that, in a case in which a State convicts of murder, rape, or a dangerous sexual offense a person who has a prior conviction for one of these offenses in more than one State, the Attorney General shall administer the transfer of specified amounts from Federal law enforcement assistance funds of each State that convicted of a prior offense.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that for purposes of determining estate tax the value of the taxable estate shall be determined by deducting from the value of the gross estate an amount equal to the value of any qualified historic property. Defines qualified historic property as any building designated as a National Historic Landmark throughout the ten-year period ending on the date of the decedent's death, which was owned by the decedent or a member of the decedent's family, and which was originally used for residential purposes.

Contributions Legally Interdicted from Noncitizens To Our Nonprofits Act of 2016 or the CLINTON Act of 2016 This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to terminate the tax-exempt status of a federal official organization that knowingly or willingly: (1) accepts a contribution from a person connected to a foreign government, or (2) receives a contribution from such a person if the contribution is returned to such person within 30 days after the organization learns the person's status. A federal official organization is any organization which knowingly or willingly accepts any contribution from any person connected to any foreign government in an amount equal to the amount of such contribution. The bill also imposes a tax on any federal official organization which knowingly or willingly accepts any contribution from any person connected to any foreign government in an amount equal to the amount of such contribution.

Reduce Expenditures in Nuclear Infrastructure Now Act or the REIN-IN Act Prohibits using funds appropriated to the Department of Defense (DOD) for FY2014-FY2023: (1) for the research, development, test, and evaluation or procurement of a long-range penetrating bomber aircraft; (2) to make the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter aircraft capable of carrying nuclear weapons; (3) until the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Energy jointly certify that the total cost of the B61 life extension program has been reduced to not more than $5 billion; (4) for the W78 life extension program; (5) for the reduction of nuclear-armed submarines, beginning in FY2020; or (6) for the National Nuclear Security Administration for FY2024.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income all excess campaign contributions received by certain political organizations. Declares that the contribution limitations of this Act are satisfied by any candidate for any election cycle if: (1) the sum of the cash and fair market value of other property held by campaign committees of such candidate as of the beginning of such election cycle plus the aggregate amount of political contributions accepted by such candidate or by such candidate's campaign committees during such election cycle does not exceed $300,000; and (2) the aggregate amount of political contributions from multicandidate political committees accepted by such candidate or by such candidate's campaign committees during such election cycle does not exceed $300,000. Applies the provisions of this Act to any political organization if: (1) it is a campaign committee of a candidate for election as a Member of the House of Representatives or as a Delegate or Resident Commissioner to the House; and (2) such candidate certifies, at the time of entering into a contract for the use of such broadcasting station, that such candidate has not obtained any excess campaign contributions for the current election cycle. Applies the provisions of this Act to third-class mail rates as well.

Clinical Laboratory Compliance Improvement Act of 2004 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act with respect to protections for employees of providers and laboratories providing clinical diagnostic laboratory tests. Requires each provider or clinical laboratory approved for participation under Medicare to post a notice in a conspicuous place to employees that indicates the manner in which to report instances of noncompliance with conditions of participation, including deficiencies with respect to testing, quality, and inadequately trained personnel. Requires such notice to include: (1) the name and contact information of the appropriate entity, accreditation organization, or State or Federal agency to report instances of noncompliance; and (2) a description of the rights and protections under this Act of individuals who report instances of noncompliance. Prohibits any such provider or laboratory from discriminating or retaliation against an employee because that employee has presented a grievance or complaint, or has initiated or cooperated in any investigation or proceeding of any kind, relating to the clinical diagnostic laboratory tests performed by the provider or laboratory. Entitles such an employee who has been discriminated or retaliated against in employment in violation of this Act to reinstatement, reimbursement for lost wages and work benefits caused by the unlawful acts of the employing provider or laboratory. Prohibits such an action from being brought more than two years after the discrimination or retaliation with respect

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that the determination of whether any pre-effective date electric output facility bond is a private activity bond (or an industrial development bond under the Code) shall be made without regard to any permissible competitive actions taken by the issuer. Defines permissible competitive actions" as any action taken by the issuer regarding: (1) transmission property owned by the issuer if the issuer is subject to an order of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission requiring nondiscriminatory, open access to transmission facilities in a manner consistent with rules promulgated by the Commission under the Federal Power Act; or (2) generation property or distribution property owned by the issuer if the issuer implements retail competition under the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 or enters into a contract for the sale of electricity or use of its distribution property which will not become effective prior to the date that the issuer implements retail competition."

United States-Afghanistan Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) Act of 2011 - Directs the President to seek to negotiate and enter into a bilateral status of forces agreement with the government of Afghanistan. Requires such agreement to: (1) prohibit the permanent basing or military presence of U.S. Armed Forces in Afghanistan, (2) provide a date for the complete, safe, and orderly redeployment of all U.S. Armed Forces from Afghanistan, and (3) establish that the temporary presence of U.S. Armed Forces in Afghanistan is at the request and invitation of the sovereign government of Afghanistan. Expresses the sense of Congress that the President should submit to Congress the status of forces agreement either as a treaty or alternatively for statutory authorization.

Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA), in providing counseling and other mental health services authorized by law to veterans who have limited proficiency in English, to ensure that such counseling and services are available to such veterans in both English and a language other than English in which they are proficient, if requested by the veteran. Directs the Secretary, in connection with the service of a veteran in the active military, naval, or air service, to provide such counseling and mental health services to an individual who has limited proficiency in English, except to the extent that the Secretary determines that such counseling and mental health services are not needed. Directs the Secretary to: (1) implement a system by which persons with limited English proficiency can meaningfully access VA services consistent with the fundamental mission of the VA; and (2) implement a plan to improve access to VA programs and activities by eligible persons with limited English proficiency.

Ensuring Defense Support to Catastrophic Incident Response Act of 2008 - Directs the Secretary of Defense, in conjunction with the Secretary of Homeland Security, to develop comprehensive plans for civil support operations in response to catastrophic incidents in the United States. Requires such plans to include strategies for the use of the armed forces, including units and personnel of the National Guard. Requires the Secretary, in implementing such plans, to: (1) ensure that the Department of Defense (DOD) is organized and equipped with the capabilities and resources required to execute such plans; and (2) ensure that any DOD capabilities and resources identified are available, accessible, and maintained at the appropriate readiness status to enable deployment in accordance with such plans.

Energy Security Act of 2011 - Establishes in the Executive Office of the President the national energy security program to coordinate the activities and policies of the federal government to ensure that the United States meets: (1) goals for reducing oil dependence, oil imports, and oil consumption; and (2) other energy policy goals, including goals for enhancing U.S. competitiveness in clean energy technology, strengthening U.S. clean energy technology manufacturing, reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and reducing hazardous pollutants.<n><n>Declares the goal of the United States to reduce oil consumption by the quantity that is equal to or greater than the quantity of oil imported by the United States from outside of North America by calendar year 2030 (as compared to the rate of oil consumption projected for calendar year 2030 as of this Act's enactment date).<n><n>Directs the President: (1) in coordination with the National Energy Security Council, to develop a national oil independence plan that describes programs and activities that will be implemented to meet or exceed the national oil independence goal and other goals established by this Act; (2) to review existing federal programs and authorities and other applicable policies to determine which could be used to accelerate reductions in oil dependence and which would require modification to maximize such reductions; and (3) to submit an updated national oil independence plan to Congress

Return of Talent Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish the Return of Talent Program to permit eligible aliens to temporarily return to their country of citizenship (or certain family members) in order to make a material contribution if the country is engaged in post-conflict reconstruction activities.

Revises provisions concerning educational assistance under the Montgomery GI Bill to terminate the 45-month limitation on: (1) the use of such assistance for eligible veterans' survivors and dependents; and (2) the use of such assistance for special restorative training. Makes survivors and dependents eligible for educational assistance until their 30th (currently 26th) birthday. <n>Makes the aggregate amount of educational assistance $80,000. (Currently, there are monthly limits for full-time, three quarter-time, or half-time educational pursuit.) Includes within authorized educational pursuits in such amounts: (1) a program of education consisting of institutional courses and alternate phases of training in a business or industrial establishment with such training being strictly supplemental to the institutional portion; and (2) a farm cooperative program consisting of institutional agricultural courses prescheduled to fall within four weeks of any period of 12 consecutive months that is pursued by an eligible person who is concurrently engaged in agricultural employment. <n>Makes the amount of educational assistance payable for a licensing or certification test the lesser of $2,000 or the fee charged for such test.

Strategic Withdrawal of Agencies for Meaningful Placement Act of 2018 or the SWMP Act This bill repeals federal law that requires executive agencies to maintain their headquarters in the Washington metropolitan area. The General Services Administration (GSA) shall establish a process through which: (1) an agency head may submit a request for the GSA to issue a solicitation for the relocation of the agency's headquarters, or (2) if determined necessary, the GSA may issue a solicitation for the relocation. The GSA shall: allow any state and any political subdivision of a state to submit a bid for the relocation of such headquarters, provide the public with notice and an opportunity to comment on such solicitation, and select a state, or a political subdivision of a state, for the relocation using competitive bidding procedures that consider the extent to which such relocation would impact the economy and workforce development of a state or political subdivision, whether the state or political subdivision has expertise in carrying out activities substantially similar to the agency's mission and goals, and the extent to which the relocation would implicate national security interests.

Minority Business Development Improvements Act of 2010 - Directs the Director of the Minority Business Development Agency to establish the Minority Business Development Program to assist qualified minority businesses. Requires the Director to certify any entity as a qualified minority business any entity that: (1) not less than 51% of the entity is directly and unconditionally owned or controlled by historically disadvantaged individuals; (2) each officer or other individual who exercises control over the regular operations of the entity is a historically disadvantaged individual; (3) the net worth of each principal of the entity is not greater than $2 million; (4) the principal place of business of the entity is in the United States; (5) each principal maintains good character in the Director's determination; (6) the entity engages in competitive and bona fide commercial business operations in not less than one sector of industry that has a North American Industry Classification System code; and (7) submits reports to the Director at such time. Terminates a certification for a term of five years.<n><n>Authorizes the Director to enter into agreements with persons to provide technical assistance under this Act. Authorizes the Director to enter into agreements with the federal government and any department, agency, or officer having procurement powers for purposes of providing for the fulfillment of procurement contracts and providing opportunities for qualified minority businesses in contracts exceeding $10 million each

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on February 24, 2015. Climate Change Drinking Water Adaptation Research Act (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Department of Energy (DOE) to establish and provide funding for a program of research and applied research conducted through a nonprofit water research foundation and sponsored by drinking water utilities to assist suppliers of drinking water in adapting to the effects of climate change. The program must include research into: (1) probable impacts of water source impacts from extreme events; and (2) increasing ranges of pathogens algae and nuisance organisms resulting from warmer temperatures.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to reduce by 20 percent the amount otherwise allowed as a deduction for interest paid or accrued by certain corporations. Exempts from such limitation any corporation substantially all of the assets of which are used in the active conduct of a farming business. Declares that the limitation shall not apply to any corporation the earnings and profits of which for such taxable year (computed as of the close of the taxable year without diminution by reason of any dividend distributions made during such taxable year) do not exceed the lesser of: (1) the corporation's tax liability for such taxable year; or (2) $100,000. Declares that all component members of a controlled group shall be treated as one corporation. Applies the same limitation to any corporation substantially all of the assets of which are used in the active conduct of a farming business. Declares that the limitation shall not apply to any corporation allowed a deduction as a deduction for dividends paid. Allows such deduction as a deduction equal to 50 percent of the dividends paid by such corporation during the taxable year. Limits the amount of the dividends paid during any taxable year which may be taken into account under this section to the amount in the corporation's qualified dividend account as of the close of such taxable year but before the

Directs the Secretary of Labor to make a grant to an eligible university to establish the Center for the Study of Women and Workplace Policy to: (1) compile and analyze available data and data sets on the difference between the earnings of men and women; (2) analyze factors which affect differences in earnings; and (3) disseminate its findings annually to the public and maintain a website to serve as a clearinghouse for the data and findings of relevant recent studies.Directs the Center to publish best practices guides for: (1) businesses; and (2) families.

Small Business Access to Capital Act of 2009- Amends the Small Business Act to increase maximum amounts of loans under the following Small Business Administration (SBA) loan programs: (1) the section 7(a) (general small business loans) guaranteed loan program; (2) the section 504 (state and local development business loan) program; and (3) the Microloan (small-scale loans to start-up, newly-established, and growing small businesses) program.<n><n>Amends the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 to authorize a project that does not involve the expansion of a small business to include the refinancing of existing indebtedness if: (1) the amount of the financing is not more than 80% of the value of the collateral for the financing; (2) the small business has been in operation for all of the two-year period ending on the date of the financing; (3) the existing indebtedness was not incurred during the two-year period ending on the date of the financing; (4) the existing indebtedness is not subject to a guarantee by any federal agency; and (5) for a loan for which the Administrator determines there will be an additional cost for making a loan that includes the refinancing of the existing indebtedness, the borrower agrees to pay a fee equal to the anticipated additional cost. Prohibits such a financing

National Commission on Fairness in the Workplace Act - Establishes the National Commission on Fairness in the Workplace to study and report to the President and the Congress on the impact of part-time employment on wage levels, benefits, earning potential, and productivity. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Propane Education and Research Act of 1993 - Directs the Secretary of Energy to: (1) conduct a referendum among producers and retail marketers to authorize the creation of the Propane Education and Research Council and the levying of an assessment on odorized propane; and (2) issue an order establishing the Council. <n>Requires the Council to develop programs (including programs to enhance consumer and employee safety and training) and enter into contracts for: (1) propane research and development; (2) consumer education; and (3) payment for program costs with funds collected under this Act. <n>Requires the Council to reimburse the Secretary annually for any costs incurred by the United States, but not more than the average annual salary of two Department of Energy employees. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Renewable Energy Act for Credit on Taxes - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a refundable tax credit for 35 percent of the expenditures for renewable energy property made by a taxpayer during the taxable year. Limits the amount of such credit to the lesser of $6,000 ($50,000 in the case of renewable energy property used for nonresidential business purposes) for each system of renewable energy property or $4.50 per watt of rated system electricity output or equivalent.

Census Improvement Act - Limits the participation in the Planning Partnership Program for the 2010 census of population to an organization which has been indicted for a violation under federal or state law relating to an election for federal or state office or which employs applicable individuals. Declares that no bill or joint resolution, amendment, or conference report containing a provision which would have the effect of repealing, suspending, or otherwise limiting the application of confidentiality provisions regarding information as confidential shall be considered as passed or agreed to by either House of Congress, unless so passed or agreed to by a vote of at least two-thirds of the Members of such House voting. Requires the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to review and report to Congress on the questions proposed to be included in the 2010 census and the American Community Survey. Prohibits any officer, employee, or other person from seeking answers to any questions relating to any household or any member of such household from any person who is not a member of such household.

Electronic Campaign Disclosure Act of 1998 - Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 (FECA) to direct the Federal Election Commission (Commission) to establish a public Internet site with specified features by January 1, 1999, with the following features: (1) any person filing a report required by FECA may post the report directly on the site; (2) any member of the public may obtain the reports posted on the site (together with any other information the Commission may make available through the site) at any time; and (3) any information in a report posted on the site shall be subject to the same prohibition on sale and use as information from a report or statement. <n>Directs the Commission to: (1) permit each person required to file a report under FECA to file it directly on the Internet site, or by filing it by such electronic method as the Commission may designate to enable it to post the report on such site immediately upon receipt; and (2) require a person to file a report in accordance with such specified methods during an election cycle if the aggregate amount of contributions or expenditures reported previously by the person during the cycle exceeds $25,000. <n>Directs the Commission to provide for one or more methods (other than requiring a signature on the report being filed) for verification of reports filed in

Pharmaceutical Products Price Equity Act - Directs the President to issue orders and regulations and establish procedures and reporting requirements to ensure that no pharmaceutical product is sold in the United States at a price more than six percent above the average retail price at which such product is sold in the five most industrialized, free-market countries, other than the United States. Authorizes the President to delegate the performance of any function under this Act to any Federal department or agency officer appointed by the President, by and with the consent of the Senate. Declares that all information reported to or otherwise obtained by any person exercising any authority under this Act shall be considered confidential for purposes of this Act, except that such information may be disclosed to any other U.S. officer or employee solely for the purpose of carrying out, and enforcing compliance with, this Act. Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) subpoena power and production of documents; and (2) jurisdiction, fees and travel expenses.

Prepaid Card Consumer Protection Act of 2010 - Amends the Electronic Fund Transfer Act to define account" to mean: (1) a demand deposit, savings deposit, or other asset account (other than an occasional or incidental credit balance in an open end credit plan) established primarily for personal, family, or household purposes, including a payroll card account; and (2) a spending card account. Excludes from such definition an account held by a financial institution pursuant to a bona fide trust agreement. (Current law refers to an account held by a financial institution pursuant to a bona fide trust agreement.) Defines "spending card account" to mean: (1) an asset account established by a consumer (or on behalf of a consumer) for use primarily for personal, family, or household purposes, including a payroll card account; and (2) an asset account operated or managed by a financial institution, or any other person, that: (1) is pooled with the funds of a person other than the person who established the account; or (2) is held in a name other than that of the person who established the account. Excludes from such definition: (1) a nonreloadable general-use prepaid card in an amount under $250; (2) a general-use prepaid card solely associated with a certain kind of health plan"

Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2002 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 to state that the Appalachian region should be able to take advantage of eco-industrial development, which promotes both employment and economic growth and the preservation of natural resources.(Sec. 3) Requires the Appalachian Regional Commission to: (1) support the formation and use of eco-industrial development technologies; and (2) seek to coordinate the economic development activities of, and the use of economic development resources by, Federal agencies in the region.(Sec. 4) Directs the President to establish the Interagency Coordinating Council on Appalachia.(Sec. 5) Authorizes the Commission to provide technical assistance, make grants, enter into contracts, or otherwise provide funds to persons or entities in the region for projects to: (1) increase affordable access to advanced telecommunications, entrepreneurship, and management technologies or applications; (2) provide education and training in the use of telecommunications and technology; (3) develop programs to increase the readiness of industry groups and businesses in the region to engage in electronic commerce; or (4) support entrepreneurial opportunities for businesses in the information technology sector. Limits the Federal share to 50 percent (or 80 percent in the case of a project to be carried out in a county for which a distressed county designation is
Directs the Secretary of the Air Force to appoint a National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol (a volunteer auxiliary of the Air Force). Limits Board members to a minority.

Removal of Terrorist Criminal Aliens Act of 2003 - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to authorize the Secretary of Homeland Security to determine whether an alien is deportable and issue a final order of removal pursuant to specified procedures, if: (1) the alien was convicted of a terrorist-related offense without regard to the date of commission of such offense; and (2) the Secretary certifies that the alien is engaged in any activity that endangers U.S. national security. Prohibits any court other than a court of appeals from reviewing or setting aside any order, action, or decision taken or issued pursuant to this Act. Provides for expedited removal proceedings.

Teenage Pregnancy Reduction Act of 1996 - Mandates evaluation (directly or through grants or contracts) and dissemination of information regarding promising programs designed to prevent pregnancy in teenagers, including a National Clearinghouse on Teenage Pregnancy Prevention Programs. Authorizes appropriations.

Children's Bicycle Helmet Safety Act of 1993 - Authorizes the Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to make grants to States, State political subdivisions, and nonprofit organizations for programs that require or encourage individuals under the age of 16 to wear approved bicycle helmets. Declares that such a grant may be used to: (1) enforce a law that requires individuals under the age of 16 to wear approved bicycle helmets while riding on bicycles; (2) assist individuals under that age to acquire approved helmets; (3) develop and administer a program to educate individuals under that age and their families on the importance of wearing such helmets in order to improve bicycle safety; or (4) carry out any combination of such activities. Specifies that bicycle helmets manufactured nine months or more after this Act's enactment shall conform to: (1) any interim standard designated by the American National Standards Institute standard designated as Z90.4-1984; (2) the Consumer Product Safety Commission standard designated as B-90; and (3) any other standard the Commission determines is appropriate. Directs the Commission to: (1) review such requirements and establish a final standard based on them; (2) include in the standard a provision to protect against the risk of helmets coming off the heads of bicycle riders; (3) include in the final standard provisions that address the risk of injury to children

Electronic Employment Verification Reauthorization Act of 2008 - Amends the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 to: (1) permanently extend the E-Verify Pilot Program (Program); (2) revise Program provisions; and (3) direct the Director of United States Citizenship and Immigration Services to establish a small business demonstration program to assist small businesses in verifying the employment eligibility of their newly hired employees.

Stopping Abuse and Fraud in Electronic Lending Act of 2018 or the SAFE Lending Act of 2018 This bill amends the Electronic Fund Transfer Act to declare that a remotely created check may only be issued by a person specifically designated in writing by a consumer to the insured depository institution at which the consumer maintains the account from which the check is drawn. A consumer may revoke such designation at any time. The bill prohibits issuance of any payment order in response to a consumer's exercise of federal consumer financial rights or any other provision of federal consumer financial law. Any voluntary electronic fund transfer to repay a small-dollar consumer credit transaction shall be treated as preauthorized under the Truth in Lending Act.

National Advisory Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification Act of 2001 - Establishes within the legislative branch a National Advisory Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification, which shall report to Congress on its results and recommendations for fundamental reform and simplification of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.

Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to direct the President, by November 1 of 2001, and 2003, to identify each country, if any, that the President proposes to be subject to assistance prohibitions in the fiscal year in which the country is so identified, if such country: (1) is not cooperating fully with the United States in achieving full compliance with the goals and objectives of the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances; (2) is not taking adequate steps on its own to achieve full compliance with the goals and objectives of a bilateral agreement with the United States on illicit drug control; or (3) is not taking adequate steps to achieve full compliance with the goals and objectives of a bilateral agreement with the United States on illicit drug control. Requires the President to report annually to the appropriate congressional committees during FY 2002 and 2003 on each country so identified.Authorizes the President to withhold bilateral assistance and multilateral assistance from a country so identified, and requires Congress to enact a joint resolution to do so.

Veterans Health Care Facilities Capital Improvement Act of 2011 - Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out major medical facility projects (projects) in FY2012 in: (1) Seattle, Washington; (2) West Los Angeles, California; (3) Fayetteville, Arkansas; (4) San Juan, Puerto Rico; (5) Palo Alto, California; (6) Missouri; and (7) St. Louis, Missouri.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to carry out a project in Orlando, Florida, previously authorized in connection with the Capital Asset Realignment Initiative.<n><n>Amends the Veterans Benefits, Health Care, and Information Technology Act of 2006 to increase the amount of authorization of FY2012 major medical facility projects in: (1) Fayetteville, Arkansas; (2) Orlando, Florida; and (3) Puerto Rico.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to carry out a project in San Juan, Puerto Rico.<n><n>Amends the Veterans' Mental Health and Other Care Improvements Act of 2008 to increase the authorization of appropriations for projects and leases authorized to be carried out in San Juan, Puerto Rico.<n><n>Limits the Secretary's authority to use bid savings on projects to expand the purpose of major medical facility projects.<n><n>Extends permanently: (1) a grant program for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent

Requires Federal public land and water to be open to access and use for fishing and hunting except: (1) as limited by the State in which the Federal public land or water is located; or (2) as limited by the Federal agency responsible for the Federal public land or water for national security, public safety, or for reasons specifically authorized in applicable statutes.Prohibits any closure of Federal public land or water to fishing or hunting from continuing in effect only during the period in which the specific circumstances for which the closure is established exist.Declares that any authority of a Federal agency to close particular land or water to hunting or fishing shall not be construed as authority to protect or manage fish or wildlife.Amends the Federal Aid in Wildlife Restoration Act to authorize the Secretary of the Interior (Secretary) to cooperate with the Secretary of the Interior of Puerto Rico (currently, Secretary of Agriculture of Puerto Rico) in the conduct of wildlife-restoration projects. Prohibits the amount of funding made available to the Secretary for expenses in the administration and execution of wildlife-restoration projects and the Migratory Bird Conservation Act from being made available for use as a supplement to decreased funding for any other expense under the Secretary's authority.Amends the Federal Aid in Fish Restoration Act to prohibit the amount

VA Major Construction Authorization and Expiring Extension Act of 2012 - Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out major medical facility projects in FY2013 in: (1) Seattle, Washington; (2) Dallas, Texas; and (3) Miami, Florida. Authorizes the Secretary to carry out the renovation of the surgical suite and operating rooms at the VA Medical Center in Miami, Florida. Extends through FY2013 the authority to: (1) calculate the net value of real property securing a defaulted loan for purposes of liquidation, (2) operate a VA regional office in the Republic of the Philippines, (3) provide treatment, rehabilitation, and certain other services for seriously mentally ill and homeless veterans, (4) provide housing assistance for homeless veterans, and (5) perform medical disability examinations by contract physicians.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on May 21, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Selected Reserve Home Loan Equity Act - Makes permanent the authority for housing loans made through the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to qualifying members of the Selected Reserve and active duty veterans for the purchase or construction of a home. (Currently, such authority terminates on September 30, 2009.) Revises the loan fee table to include fees for loans made to such veterans between October 1, 2011, and October 1, 2013.

Native American $1 Coin Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue $1 coins in commemoration of Native Americans and important contributions made by Indian tribes and individual Native Americans to the development and history of the United States.<n><n>Requires, effective beginning January 1, 2009, that such coins have designs: (1) on the so-called Sawea design"; and (2) on the reverse bearing images celebrating important contributions made by Indian tribes and individual Native Americans to the history and development of the United States.<n><n>Requires edge-incusing of the inscriptions "E Pluribus Unum" and "In God We Trust" in a manner that preserves the distinctive coin denomination so that it is readily discernible, including by individuals who are blind or visually impaired."

Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act or the SECURE Act - Amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to authorize a court to award injunctive relief to require compliance with such Act's requirements with respect to any consumer. Requires a court, in addition to any other remedy set forth in such Act, to award to the prevailing party costs and reasonable attorney fees (as determined by the court) incurred during an action for injunctive relief against a consumer reporting agency or reseller, in the event of any successful action for such injunctive relief. Revises violations of the Act to make it an unfair or deceptive act or practice for a consumer reporting agency or reseller to charge or provide a consumer reporting agency or reseller for consumer reports in connection with a credit or insurance transaction not initiated by the consumer. Requires the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to: (1) review and consider all relevant information provided by a consumer reporting agency relating to consumer disputes; and (2) prescribe rules for the gathering of information relating to such disputes received by consumer reporting agencies.

Rural Rental Housing Act of 2003 - Authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture, directly or through specified intermediaries, to provide rural rental housing assistance. Gives priority to very low-income families, low-income communities, communities lacking affordable rental housing, or certain other applicants.

Telecommunications Economic Opportunity Act of 1995 - Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to require each provider of telecommunications services to submit annually a detailed and verifiable plan for increasing its procurement from business enterprises owned by minorities or women. <n>Directs the FCC to: (1) establish regulations for implementing programs pursuant to this Act that will govern providers of telecommunications services and their affiliates; (2) develop and publish regulations setting forth criteria for verifying and determining the eligibility of business enterprises owned by minorities or women for procurement contracts; and (3) require each provider of telecommunications services and its affiliates to develop and implement an outreach program to inform and recruit such business enterprises to apply for such contracts. <n>Prohibits: (1) any person or corporation, through its directors, officers, or agents, from falsely representing that a business is owned by minorities or women in the procurement of any telecommunications service contract or subcontract; and (2) the provider of telecommunications services or its affiliates from awarding any such contract or subcontract to any such person or corporation. <n>Sets forth civil penalties for violations of this Act.

RCAF-RAF-Americans Congressional Gold Medal Act - Directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to arrange for the presentation of a single congressional gold medal in commemoration of all U.S. nationals who joined the Royal Canadian Air Force or the Royal Air Force during World War II, both before and after Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor, in recognition of their contributions to the Nation. Requires the medal to be given to the Smithsonian Institution for display. Expresses the sense of Congress that the medal should be made available for display elsewhere, particularly at appropriate locations associated with the U.S. nationals.

Appalachian Regional Commission Reform Act This bill requires the Appalachian Regional Commission to: (1) relocate its headquarters from the District of Columbia to a more affordable location in the Appalachian region, and (2) increase the percentage of its area development grant allocations for distressed counties in the Appalachian region.

New Aid for Trustworthy, Affordable Drugs Act (NAFTA Drugs Act) - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to direct the United States Trade Representative (USTR), consistent with the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), to seek to enter into agreements with other NAFTA countries to harmonize regulatory requirements for drugs such that drugs approved for commercial distribution in any NAFTA country may be imported or exported from any NAFTA country into any NAFTA country. Sets forth conditions under which the USTR may enter into such an agreement.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 2, 2016. Imperial Valley Desert Conservation and Recreation Act (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of the Interior to transfer certain Bureau of Land Management (BLM) land in San Diego County, California, to the state of California upon termination of all mining claims. The transferred land shall be managed in accordance with the California Wilderness Act. The bill also requires Interior to seek a conveyance from the Department of Transportation of approximately 3,500 acres of BLM land adjacent to the Imperial County Holtville Airport for the purposes of airport expansion. (Sec. 4) The bill establishes the Vinagre Wash Special Management Area in California, which shall consist of specified public land in Imperial County. Interior shall allow hiking, camping, hunting, and sightseeing and the use of motorized vehicles, mountain bikes, and horses on designated routes in the Management Area.

Workplace Employee Stock Option Act of 2002 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to qualify for the special tax treatment of employee stock purchase plans any transfer of stock meeting specified requirements, including that: (1) the price paid by the individual for the stock is paid only through payroll deductions in substantially equal amounts over a period of between 12 and 60 months; (2) such payroll deductions are held in a trust; (3) the price of the stock acquired under the option is not less than the fair market value of the stock at the time the option is granted; (4) ownership of the stock is transferred to the individual at the end of the payroll deduction period; (5) the individual's election to commence withholding to purchase such stock pursuant to the option is made during the 30-day period beginning on the earliest date that the individual could have made the election to commence withholding to acquire stock pursuant to such option; and (6) the stock acquired by the individual is held by the trust until the individual elects to dispose of such stock or at the election of the individual.Excludes from the gross income of an individual any amount equal to such deductions. Allows a deduction to the person whose deduction was reduced.

Climate Change Investment Act of 2006 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal tax incentives for the oil and gas industry, including: (1) the election to expense certain refineries; (2) the enhanced oil recovery tax credit; (3) the credit for production of low sulfur diesel fuel; (4) the deduction for capital costs incurred in complying with Environmental Protection Agency sulfur regulations; and (5) the tax deduction for intangible drilling and development costs.<n><n>Allows a tax credit for investment in a greenhouse gas intensity reduction project approved by the Secretary of Energy. Terminates such credit after 2011.

Staffing for Adequate Fire and Emergency Response Act of 2001 or the SAFER Act of 2001 - Amends the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to authorize the Secretary of Labor to make grants to States, local governments, tribal organizations, and Indian tribal organizations for firefighter salaries and benefits. Sets forth a formula for determining the Federal share and the non-Federal share of project costs.

Competitiveness Tax Credit Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an investment tax credit for manufacturing and other productive equipment for the period after December 31, 2008 and before January 1, 2009.

Keep Americans Working Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require a state agency to approve a short-time compensation program, under which: (1) an employer reduces the number of hours worked by employees through certifying that such reductions are in lieu of temporary layoffs; (2) such employees whose workweeks have been reduced by at least 10% are eligible for unemployment compensation; (3) the amount of unemployment compensation payable to such employees is a pro rata portion of the unemployment compensation which would be payable to the employee if such employee were totally unemployed; (4) such employees are not expected to meet the availability for work or work search test requirements while collecting short-time compensation benefits, but are required to be available for their normal workweek; (5) eligible employees may participate in an employer-sponsored training program to enhance job skills if such program has been approved by the state agency; (6) the state agency shall require an employer to certify that continuation of health benefits and retirement benefits under a defined benefit pension plan is not affected by participation in the program; (7) the state agency shall require an employer (or an employer's association which is party to a collective bargaining agreement) to submit a written plan describing the manner in which requirements of this Act will be implemented and containing such other information as the Secretary of Labor determines

Prescription Drug Fairness for Seniors Act of 1998 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to furnish to each Medicare beneficiary a drug benefit card that enables the beneficiary to purchase covered prescription drugs from participating pharmacies at reduced prices. <n>Authorizes any qualified pharmacy to enter into an agreement with the Secretary that enables the pharmacy to sell covered outpatient drugs to holders of Medicare drug benefit cards at a reduced price, by authorizing the pharmacy to operate as a participating pharmacy under this Act. <n>Requires the Secretary to: (1) administer this Act in a manner that uses existing methods of obtaining and distributing drugs to the maximum extent possible, consistent with efficiency and cost effectiveness; and (2) report to the Congress annually regarding the effectiveness of this Act in protecting Medicare beneficiaries from discriminatory pricing by drug manufacturers, and in making prescription drugs available to Medicare beneficiaries at substantially reduced prices.

Energy Freedom and Economic Prosperity Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal tax credits for: (1) alcohol fuel, biodiesel, and alternative fuel mixtures; (2) alcohol used as fuel; (3) biodiesel and renewable diesel used as fuel; (4) electricity produced from certain renewable resources; (5) oil and gas produced from marginal wells; (6) carbon dioxide sequestration; (7) advanced coal projects; and (8) gasification project projects. Reduces the corporate income tax rate.

Treatment of Children\\'s Deformities Act of 1998 - Amends the Public Health Service Act, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, and the Internal Revenue Code to require a group health plan, and a health insurance issuer offering group coverage, that cover surgical benefits to also cover outpatient and inpatient diagnosis and treatment of a congenital or developmental deformity, disease, or injury of a minor child (defined as child under the age of 21). <n>Requires that such coverage: (1) be subject to pre-authorization or pre-certification requirements of the plan or issuer; and (2) include any surgical treatment deemed by the treating physician to be medically necessary to approximate a normal appearance. Defines treatment" to include reconstructive surgical procedures that are performed on abnormal structures of the body caused by congenital defects, developmental abnormalities, trauma, infection, tumors, or disease, including: (1) procedures that do not materially affect the function of the body part being treated; and (2) procedures for secondary conditions and follow-up treatment. Excludes cosmetic surgery performed to reshape normal structures of the body to improve appearance or self-esteem."

Biennial Appropriations Act - Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require biennial (instead of annual) appropriations Acts, with the exception of annual defense appropriation bills. Defines the budget biennium as the two consecutive fiscal years beginning on October 1.

Psoriasis and Psoriatic Arthritis Research, Cure, and Care Act of 2011 - Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to undertake psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis data collection efforts, including incorporating public health surveys, questionnaires, and other databases in existence on the date of enactment of this Act to collect information on: (1) the prevalence of psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis in the United States; (2) the age of onset; (3) health-related quality of life; (4) health care utilization; (5) burden of such disease (such as with respect to employment); (6) comorbidities and the natural history of such disease; and (7) health disparities, including with respect to age, gender, race, and ethnicity. Expresses the sense of Congress that the psoriasis research community has made significant strides in proving the seriousness of psoriasis as well as the potential for new treatments.

National Commission for the New National Goal: The Advancement of Global Health Act - Establishes the National Commission for the New National Goal: The Advancement of Global Health to recommend to the Congress a national strategy for coordinating governmental, academic, and public and private health care entities for the purpose of the global eradication of disease.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on December 7, 2016. Veterans Mobility Safety Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to ensure that veterans are given the opportunity to make personal selections relating to vehicles or other conveyances provided through the VA. (Sec. 3) The VA shall develop a comprehensive policy regarding quality standards for providers who provide modification services to veterans under the automobile adaptive equipment program. The policy shall cover: the VA-wide management of the program; the development of standards for safety and quality of equipment and installation of equipment through the program; the consistent application of standards for safety and quality of both equipment and installation throughout the VA; the certification of a provider by a manufacturer if the VA designates the manufacturer quality standards as meeting or exceeding the standards developed under this Act; the certification of a provider by a third party, nonprofit organization if the VA designates the organization quality standards as meeting or exceeding the standards developed under this Act; the education and training of VA personnel who administer the program; the compliance of the provider with the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 when furnishing automobile adaptive equipment at the provider's facility; and the allowance, where technically appropriate, for veterans to receive modifications at their

Older and Disabled Americans Criminal Protection Act of 1998 - Authorizes: (1) a shared housing (a residential arrangement involving a caretaker and at least one elderly or disabled person) referral agency to request the Attorney General to conduct and share criminal background checks respecting shared housing caretaker applicants; and (2) the Attorney General to charge a fee for such service. <n>Provides a criminal penalty for the knowing use of such information for other than housing determinations. <n>States that an agency that reasonably relies upon such information shall not be liable for damages based on such information's inaccuracy.

Amends Federal civil service retirement provisions to include a law enforcement officer of the Refuge Division of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service as a member of the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees Retirement System.

Assault Weapons Prohibition Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit: (1) the transfer of an assault weapon within 90 days; or (2) possession of an assault weapon after 90 days. Specifies the definition of an assault weapon.

Women's Business Procurement Assistance Act of 1993 - Amends the Small Business Act to include small businesses owned and controlled by women among those small businesses that are eligible to participate in Small Business Administration (SBA) procurement contracts. Requires the SBA to report to the small business committees on information obtained from such contracts and subcontracts. Adds to the list of small businesses eligible for such contracts those small businesses owned and controlled by women: (1) at least 51 percent of the stock of which is owned by one or more women; or (2) whose management and daily business operations are controlled by such women. Declares that the contractor shall presume that women have been subjected to gender based discrimination and may determine whether a small business meets the percentage requirements without regard to the community property laws of any jurisdiction.

Open Our Democracy Act of 2014 - Requires all candidates for election to the House of Representatives to run in a single open primary, regardless of political party preference. Limits the ensuing general election to the two candidates receiving the greatest number of votes in the single open primary. Gives candidates the option, at the time of filing to run for office, to declare a political party preference, which does not constitute or imply endorsement of the candidate by the party designated. Treats the general election day in the same manner as a legal public holiday for purposes of federal employment. Expresses the sense of Congress that private employers in the United States should give their employees a day off on the Tuesday next after the first Monday in November in 2016 and each even-numbered year thereafter to enable the employees to cast votes in the elections held on that day. Directs the Comptroller General (GAO) to study the feasibility and desirability of enacting national standards and criteria for congressional redistricting.

Twenty-First Amendment Enforcement Act - Amends the Webb-Kenyon Act to authorize a state attorney general, if he or she has reasonable cause to believe that a person is engaged in, or has engaged in, any act that would constitute a violation of a state law regulating the importation or transportation of intoxicating liquor, to bring a civil action in federal district court for injunctive relief against such person as the attorney general determines to be necessary to: (1) restrain the person from engaging in, or continuing to engage, in the violation; and (2) enforce compliance with the state law. Grants jurisdiction to the U.S. district courts over such an action by an attorney general against any person, except one licensed or otherwise authorized to produce, sell, or store intoxicating liquor in such state. Sets forth requirements for injunctive relief, notice to the adverse party, and judicial review.

Natural Gas Reserve Act of 2001 - Authorizes the Secretary of Energy to establish, maintain, and operate a Natural Gas Reserve, which is not a component of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.Authorizes the Secretary to sell products from the Reserve upon a finding that there is a natural gas supply shortage.Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to establish a Natural Gas Reserve Account in the Treasury to accept disposition of natural gas from the Reserve.

Technology for the Classroom Act of 1993 - Directs the Secretary of Education to make competitive grants to eligible consortia, consisting of State or local educational agencies in partnership with businesses and institutions of higher education or other public or private nonprofit organizations, to develop instructional programs or technology-based systems for complete courses or units of study for a specific subject and grade level, if such programs or systems are commercially unavailable in the local area served by such consortia. <n>Gives priority in awarding grants to applications describing programs or systems that are developed: (1) so that the program or system may be adapted and applied nationally; and (2) to raise the achievement levels of students, particularly disadvantaged students who are not realizing their potential. <n>Requires eligible consortia to agree that, with respect to the costs to be incurred in carrying out the program or system for which the grant was awarded, the eligible consortium will make available (from private sources) non-Federal contributions in an amount not less than 25 percent of the Federal funds provided under the grant. <n>Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) application requirements; (2) criteria for awarding grants; and (3) permissible activities for States to carry out under this Act. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to award grants to States to enable them to carry out activities submitted in plans under

Frontline Medical Education Act - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to include services of interns and residents at any federally-qualified health center under any program paid for by a hospital in determining Medicare payments for graduate medical education (GME costs). Declares that the Secretary of Health and Human Services shall provide for payment to such a center for direct GME costs in accordance with this Act.

Acquisition Savings Reform Act of 2011 - Directs the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council to amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) to require the heads of executive agencies to use online reverse auction or an equivalent method, in the procurement of commercial items above the simplified acquisition threshold whenever doing so would be expected to result in savings to the agencies. Requires such guidance to: (1) address the circumstances in which use of reverse auction is appropriate and to direct agencies, in deciding whether to use or an equivalent method, to consider the dollar volume of the acquisition and potential to streamline the procurement for the agency and vendors; and (2) include the administrative cost of the acquisition. Requires: (1) such Council to amend FAR to require the consideration of Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicles in the priorities for use of government supply sources" list, by including a listing of such Vehicles in the "Priorities for Use of Government Supply Sources" list; and (2) the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to maintain a website with the current list of such Vehicles. Defines "Federal Strategic Sourcing Vehicle" as a kind of government-wide interagency acquisition contract or agreement designated by OMB to leverage the federal government\\'s buying power and save taxpayers money.<n><n>Requires: (1) each executive agency to submit to the Council a"

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Alternative Fuels--General <n> Title II: Alternative Fuels--Non-Federal Programs <n> Title III: Availability and Use of Replacement Fuels, , Alternative Fuels, and Alternative Fueled Vehicles <n>Biodiesel Energy Development Act of 1997 - <n>Title I: Alternative Fuels--General (Sec. 101) Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to revise the definition of alternative fuels" to include biodiesel. <n>(Sec. 102) Amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to revise the definition of "vehicles converted to use alternative fuels" to: (1) allow the acquisition of existing fleet vehicles that have been converted to use alternative fuels at the time of a major vehicle overhaul or rebuild; and (2) permit a Federal fleet to acquire one heavy duty alternative fueled vehicle in place of two light duty alternative fueled vehicles. Authorizes a Federal fleet to take an additional credit for the purchase and documented use of alternative fuel used in an alternative fueled vehicle. <n>(Sec. 103) Directs the Secretary of Energy to permit: (1) a Federal fleet to acquire one heavy duty alternative fueled vehicle in place of two light duty alternative fueled vehicles; and (2) a Federal agency to take"
