Air Travelers Fair Treatment Act of 2001 - Amends Federal aviation law to define unfair or deceptive practice" as: (1) the failure of an air carrier or foreign air carrier to provide a passenger with an accurate explanation of the reasons for a flight delay, cancellation, or diversion from a ticketed itinerary; and (2) the failure of an air carrier or foreign air carrier, in the case of a termination, cancellation, nonrenewal, or substantial change in the competitive circumstances of the appointment of a ticket agent, to provide the ticket agent with written notice, and a full statement of reasons for the action, on or before the 90th day preceding the action, and to provide the ticket agent with at least 60 days to correct any deficiency claimed.Directs the Secretary of Transportation to prescribe regulations to establish minimum standards for resuscitation, emergency medical, and first-aid equipment and supplies to be carried on board an aircraft operated by an air carrier in air transportation that is capable of carrying at least 30 passengers.Prohibits air carriers or foreign air carriers operating an aircraft in air transportation from preventing or hindering any passenger from exiting the aircraft if: (1) the aircraft is parked at an airport terminal gate with access to ramp or other facilities through which passengers are customarily boarded and deplaned; (2)"

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 9, 2013. Medicare Fraud Enforcement and Prevention Act of 2013 - Amends title XI of the Social Security Act (SSA) with respect to criminal penalties for both felony and misdemeanor fraud under SSA titles XVIII (Medicare) and XIX (Medicaid). Increases criminal penalties for: (1) knowingly purchasing, selling, or unlawfully distributing, or arranging for the purchase, sale, or unlawful distribution of two or more Medicare or Medicaid beneficiary identification numbers or billing privileges; and (2) conspiring to commit such a violation. Amends SSA title XI, as amended by the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, to provide civil monetary penalties for: (1) conspiracy to make false statements or commit other specified offenses with respect to Medicare or Medicaid claims; and (2) knowing creation or use of a false record or statement material to an obligation to transmit money or property to a federal health care program.

Education Tax Credit Simplification Act of 2004 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to combine the Hope Scholarship and Lifetime Learning tax credits into a single $3,000 tax credit for qualified higher education expenses and for qualified tuition programs.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Improvement the Federal Helium Program <n> Title II: Improvement of the Minerals Management Service Royalty Management <n> Program <n> Title III: Miscellaneous <n>Department of the Interior Reform and Savings Act of 1993 - <n>Title I: Improvement the Federal Helium Program <n> - Amends the Helium Act Amendments of 1960 to direct the Secretary of the Interior to: (1) reduce costs and increase operational efficiencies, especially in operations that do not produce revenue; (2) establish and adjust fees charged private industry for storage, transmission, and withdrawal of privately-owned helium from Government storage facilities to compensate fully for all costs incurred; and (3) improve Federal helium program operations over a multi-year period. <n>(Sec. 102) Directs the Secretary to prepare and develop a long-term, comprehensive plan to: (1) cancel the outstanding debt owed to the Treasury by the Department of the Interior related to the Federal helium program; and (2) improve Federal helium program operations over a multi-year period. Authorizes the President to cancel such debt upon a finding that such debt cancellation is in the national interest. <n>Title II: Improvement of the Minerals Management Service Royalty Management Program <n> - Amends the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management

Authorizes appropriations.<n>Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award National Math and Science Teacher Scholarships through a pilot program to qualifying higher education institutions with graduate programs in teacher training, in order to provide 500 scholarship awards to outstanding students enrolled in such programs who are committed to pursuing careers teaching math and science at an urban or rural secondary level classroom.<n>Requires the Secretary to give priority to institutions with one or more of the following: (1) a year-long internship program in a professional development school; (2) mentoring programs for novice teachers in their first three years; (3) a history of placing graduates in rural and urban schools; and (4) a high retention rate of teachers that the institution places in teaching positions. Sets the scholarship amount at $10,000 per student for any academic year, except that in no case shall the total amount of the scholarship exceed the total cost of attendance.

Irrigation Subsidy Reduction Act of 1996 (sic) - Amends the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 to direct the Secretary of the Interior, for each parcel of land to which irrigation water is delivered or proposed to be delivered, to identify a single individual or legal entity as the owner, lessee, or operator. <n>Allows irrigation water to be delivered at less than the normal per-acre cost to either: (1) a qualified recipient that reports gross farm income from a single farm operation in excess of $500,000 per taxable year; or (2) a limited recipient that received such water on or before October 1, 1981, and that reports gross farm income in excess of such amount. <n>Requires lessees and operators of an irrigation district to furnish such district a certification of compliance with the Act. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to require a lessee or operator to submit for examination a copy of a tax return for any taxable year in which the single farm operation of the lessee or operator received irrigation water at less than full cost.

Hospital Price Disclosure Act of 2005 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require hospitals and ambulatory surgical centers to report to the Secretary of Health and Human Services: (1) the frequency with which the hospital performed, or administered the drug in an inpatient setting, or the center performed the procedure during a quarter; and (2) the average and median price charged for such procedure or drug during such quarter. Directs the Secretary to promptly post data reported on the Department of Health and Human Services public Internet site in a manner that promotes price comparison among hospitals and ambulatory surgical centers. Requires a hospital and ambulatory surgical center to post at each admission site a notice of the availability of such data.

Preserving Equitable Access to Community-based Home Health (PEACH) Act of 2009 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to establish the PEACH fund from which home health agencies meeting specified criteria shall be paid supplemental amounts in addition to their statutory payment amounts under Medicare.

Long Island Sound Stewardship Act of 2004 - Establishes: (1) the Long Island Sound Stewardship System Region, which shall encompass the immediate coastal upland and underwater areas along Long Island Sound, including those portions of the Sound with coastally influenced vegetation; and (2) the Long Island Sound Stewardship Coordinating Committee.

Strengthening the Transition and Reintegration Of the National Guard and Reserves Act or the STRONGR Act - Extends transitional health care coverage for members of reserve components for mental health care to an additional 180 days. Increases the amount of basic educational assistance for members of the Selected Reserve and reserve components supporting contingency operations. Increases the rate of educational assistance for such members. Provides for the nonreduction in pay of federal employees serving on active duty in a reserve component. Assistance for state and local governments that continue to pay employees who serve on active duty in a reserve component.

Medicaid Cash and Counseling Program Act of 2005 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) with respect to the provision of self-directed personal assistance services under the Medicaid program (title XIX of the Social Security Act). Allows states to provide payment for part or all of the cost of self-directed personal assistance services under the plan which are provided pursuant to a written plan of care to individuals who would require and receive personal care services under the plan, or home and community-based services provided pursuant to a waiver. Prohibits such services from being provided to individuals who reside in a home or property that is owned, operated, or controlled by a provider of services, not related by blood or marriage.

Manhattan Project National Historical Park Act - Requires the Department of the Interior to establish the Manhattan Project National Historical Park as a unit of the National Park System in the state of Tennessee.

Afghanistan and Central Asian Republics Sustainable Food Production Act of 2001 - Directs the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development to provide assistance to develop sustainable food production for Afghanistan and the mountainous regions of other countries of Central Asia through restocking seed, replacing breeding livestock, restoring basic irrigation systems, and providing access to credit for food production, processing, or marketing enterprises through rural microenterprise loan programs.Expresses the sense of Congress that the Administrator should establish criteria for the selection of projects to receive support under this Act, standards and criteria regarding qualifications of recipients, and implementation of program objectives.Prohibits the use of funds made available under this Act for any activity in Afghanistan unless the Secretary of State certifies for the fiscal year that there has been substantial progress made toward the establishment of a government in Afghanistan that meets specified requirements.

Requires the FCC to conduct an experimental program to test whether low-power FM radio stations will result in harmful interference to existing FM radio stations if such stations are not subject to the minimum distance separations for third-adjacent channels. Directs the FCC to submit a report on the experimental program and field tests to specified congressional committees.

Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2010 - Repeals current Department of Defense (DOD) policy concerning homosexuality in the Armed Forces. Prohibits the Secretary of Defense, and the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) with respect to the Coast Guard when it is not operating as a service in the Navy, from discriminating on the basis of sexual orientation against any member of the Armed Forces or any person seeking to become a member. Authorizes the re-accession into the Armed Forces of otherwise qualified individuals separated on the basis of sexual orientation.

Putting Main Street FIRST Act or the Putting Main Street FIRST Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose a .03% excise tax on the purchase of a security if: (1) such purchase occurs on, or is subject to the rules of, a qualified board or exchange located in the United States, or (2) the purchaser or seller is a U.S. person. Exempts from such tax: (1) initial issues of securities; and (2) notes, bonds, debentures, or other evidences of indebtedness which are traded on a qualified board or exchange located in the United States and have a fixed maturity of not more than 100 days.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the tax credit allowed to holders of qualified zone academy bonds to provide that such bonds shall be used for constructing public school facilities and for acquiring the land on which such facilities will be constructed.Repeals the limitation on the eligibility for the tax credit of qualified zone academy bonds. Allows the credit to be held by a regulated investment company. Permits the separation of the ownership of such bonds and the entitlement to the credit.Allocates the national zone academy bond limitation for 1998 through 2002 among the States in proportion to the respective amounts each State received for basic grants under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA).Allocates the limitation amount allocated to a State to qualified zone academies within such State.

First Responders Support Act of 2008- Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to: (1) increase public safety officer disability benefits to $350,000; (2) provide that such benefits shall be paid in an amount equal to the benefit that is payable in the applicable year multiplied by the level of disability of the public safety officer; and (3) require the Director of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to adopt and apply a schedule of levels of disability of public safety officers associated with specific injuries or combinations of injuries, based upon the average impairments of earning capacity resulting from the injuries concerned.<n><n>Revises the Act to: (1) define catastrophic injury" as a catastrophic injury sustained in the line of duty which substantially diminishes an individual\\'s ability to perform gainful work; and (2) require the Bureau of Justice Assistance of the Department of Justice (DOJ) to determine, within three months after submission of a claim, whether a claimant is eligible to receive such benefits.<n><n>Authorizes appropriations to the Attorney General in FY2009-FY2013 to hire employees for the Bureau of Justice Assistance and obtain the technology and equipment necessary to expedite the processing of claims and make disability determinations under such Act.<n><n>Provides educational benefits for an eligible dependent of a"

Turkish Human Rights Act - Prohibits the provision of foreign assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 for the Government of Turkey for FY 1998 unless the Secretary of State determines that there has been significant progress in allowing: (1) domestic and international human rights monitoring organizations to monitor and report on the human rights situation within its territory without fear of reprisal or prosecution; (2) the recognition of the civil, cultural, and human rights of its Kurdish citizens; (3) the ceasing of military operations against Kurdish civilians, and the provision of support for a settlement for the Republic of Cyprus based on a constitutional democracy with key U.S. principles of majority rule, the rule of law, the protection of minority and human rights, and the provision for and implementation of three basic freedoms, namely freedom of movement, property, and of settlement; and (4) the ceasing of its blockade of United States and international assistance to Armenia.

Microbicide Development Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to support research and development of microbicides to prevent the transmission of sexually transmitted infections, including HIV/AIDS.

Environmental Finance Act of 1995 - Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish: (1) an Environmental Financial Advisory Board to provide expert advice on issues affecting the costs and financing of environmental activities at the Federal, State, and local levels; and (2) Environmental Finance Centers in institutions of higher education to carry out activities to improve the capability of State and local governments to manage environmental programs. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Effective Terrorists Prosecution Act of 2006 - Amends the federal criminal code as enacted by the Military Commissions Act of 2006 to revise the definition of unlawful enemy combatant" to: (1) mean an individual who directly participates in hostilities as part of an armed conflict against the United States who is not a lawful enemy combatant; and (2) be used solely to designate individuals triable by military commission. Excludes from the definition of "unlawful enemy combatant" a statement obtained by use of coercion, except against a person accused of coercion as evidence that the statement was made.<n><n>Requires that a statement obtained by use of coercion be excluded from trial by military commission, except against a person accused of coercion as evidence that the statement was made.<n><n>Revises requirements with respect to the disclosure of evidence to a military judge who determines that the evidence is unreliable or lacking in probative value, to authorize the military judge to take certain actions to protect the right of a defendant to a fair trial if such substitute is insufficient to protect such right.<n><n>Directs the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces to review the record in each case referred to it by the convening authority with respect to any matter of law raised by the accused."

Protecting Consumer Phone Records Act - Makes it unlawful for any person to: (1) acquire or use the customer proprietary network information of another person without that person's affirmative written consent, which shall include electronic consent that meets the requirements of the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act; (2) misrepresent that another person has consented to the acquisition or use of such other person's customer proprietary network information in order to acquire such information; (3) obtain unauthorized access to the data processing system or records of a telecommunications carrier or an IP-enabled voice service provider in order to acquire such information; (4) sell, or offer for sale, such information; or (5) request another person to obtain such information from a telecommunications carrier or IP-enabled voice service provider, knowing that the other person will obtain the information from such carrier or provider in any manner that is unlawful. Declares that this Act does not prohibit any act or practice otherwise authorized by law, including any lawfully authorized investigative, protective, or intelligence activity of a law enforcement agency or a U.S. intelligence agency, as well as the use of caller identification services by any person to identify the originator of telephone calls received. Allows a telecommunications carrier or IP-enabled voice service provider to bring a civil action in a State

Entitles a surviving spouse to a benefit for the month of a veteran's death if the veteran was receiving veterans' compensation or pension at the time of his or her death and such benefit claim is pending at the time of such veteran's death. Provides that: (1) any such benefit payable on behalf of a veteran who was not in receipt of such benefits as of such month shall be paid to the surviving spouse as accrued benefits; and (2) if such a claim for entitlement to compensation or additional compensation or pension is pending at the time of a veteran's death and the check or other payment issued to the veteran's surviving spouse is less than the amount of the benefit the veteran would have been entitled to for the month of death pursuant to the adjudication of such pending claim, the difference between the amount to which the veteran would have been entitled to receive such benefits had the veteran not died shall be treated as an accrued benefit.Prohibits the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) from requiring the surviving spouse to return certain checks and payments issued to a veteran as a benefit payment if they are negotiated, deposited, or otherwise accessed by the surviving spouse in the month in which death occurs, to the extent that such check or payment equals the amount which would otherwise be

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Authorization of Appropriations <n> Title II: Program Authorization <n> Title III: Other Provisions <n>National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Atmospheric and Satellite Program Authorization Act of 1993 - <n>Title I: Authorization of Appropriations <n> - Authorizes appropriations for FY 1994 and 1995 to the Secretary of Commerce to enable the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to carry out: (1) the operations and research duties of the National Weather Service; and (2) the public warning and forecast systems duties of such Service, including the development, acquisition, and implementation of major public warning and forecast systems. Prohibits the use of such funds for the purposes for which funds are authorized under the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 (the Act). Prohibits the expenditure of such funds until specified requirements under the Act have been fulfilled by the Secretary, including that: (1) it is identified as a National Weather Service NEXRAD installation in the National Implementation Plan for modernization of the Service for FY 1994; (2) the Secretary has made a determination of technical and programmatic necessity with respect to such installation and a period of 60 legislative days after the transmittal to the Congress of such determination, or the period between such transmittal and the next October 1, whichever period

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to create a tax-exempt State tuition program under which a person: (1) may purchase tuition credits or certificates on behalf of a designated beneficiary which entitle the beneficiary to the waiver or payment of qualified higher education expenses; or (2) may make contributions to an account established for the sole purpose of meeting such beneficiary's education expenses. Subjects such program to the taxes imposed by section 511 (relating to imposition of tax on unrelated business income of charitable organizations).

After Care Act of 2007 - Amends the federal criminal code to require: (1) the Attorney General to cause each individual about to be released from a sentence of imprisonment for a federal offense, other than those who have already tested positive for the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), to be tested for the presence of that virus; and (2) the court to order the defendant, as explicit conditions of supervised release, to accept treatment through the after care program and provide notice to any prospective sexual partner that the defendant has tested positive for the presence of the HIV virus before engaging in any sex act with such partner. Directs the Attorney General and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting jointly, to establish a program to provide eligible individual treatment for HIV/AIDS throughout the treatment period.

Trade Accountability Study Act - Establishes the Trade Impact Review Commission to study and report to Congress on: (1) the extent to which exports of goods of the United States to North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) countries, and imports of goods of NAFTA countries into the United States, have increased or decreased since January 1, 1994; and (2) the number of jobs in the United States that have been created as a result of increased exports of goods of the United States to NAFTA countries, and the number of jobs in the United States that have been lost as a result of increased imports of NAFTA countries into the United States, since January 1, 1994.Requires the Commission to determine and report to Congress on the extent to which exports of goods of the United States to the People's Republic of China, and imports of goods of the People's Republic of China into the United States, have increased or decreased since December 11, 2001; and (2) the number of jobs in the United States that have been created as a result of increased exports of goods of the United States to China, and the number of jobs in the United States that have been lost as a result of increased imports of goods of the People's Republic of China into the Untied States, since December 11, 2001.

Animal Disease Risk Assessment, Prevention, and Control Act of 2001 - Authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to prohibit the importation into the United States, except under special conditions or under permits issued by the Secretary, of: (1) animals, animal products, or persons from a country where bovine spongiform encephalopathy is a human spongiform disease; (2) a country where foot and mouth disease is a human spongiform disease; or (3) any animal, animal product, or person for the purpose of managing foot and mouth disease, bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or other animal disease.

. Department of Veterans Affairs Information Security Protection Act (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to submit quarterly a plan of action to address critical known information security vulnerabilities, a plan for identifying and replacing operating systems that are out-of-date or unsupported, and a report on incidents of failure to comply with established information security policies. The plan must address: (1) methods of protecting the sensitive personal information of veterans while not unduly interfering with the VA's ability to provide benefits and services to veterans and their dependents; (2) how the VA can improve its compliance with information security requirements; and (3) steps taken to ensure the security of the Veterans Health Information Systems and Technology Architecture that allows for an integrated inpatient and outpatient electronic health record for patients and provides administrative tools to VA employees. (Sec. 3) The VA shall submit to Congress a strategic plan for improving its information security.

College Literacy in Finance and Economics Act of 2011 or College LIFE Act - Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to require institutions of higher education (IHEs) to provide student borrowers under the Federal Family Education Loan, Direct Loan, and Perkins Loan programs with financial literacy counseling within 45 days of their first receipt of such a loan and prior to their completion of the course of study for which they are enrolled. Requires such counseling to include information on the Financial Education Core Competencies as determined by the Financial Literacy and Education Commission.

Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to prohibit payment for medical equipment and supplies furnished by a supplier unless such supplier meets national standards specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services and possesses a valid supplier number. <n>Directs the Secretary to revise national standards for suppliers of medical equipment and supplies to include requirements that such suppliers: (1) comply with all applicable State and Federal licensure and regulatory requirements; (2) maintain a physical facility on an appropriate site; (3) have proof of appropriate liability insurance; and (4) meet such other requirements as the Secretary may specify. Applies such revised standards to medical equipment and supplies applying for a supplier number or renewing such supplier's number after December 31, 1995. <n>Directs the Secretary to develop one or more standardized certificates of medical necessity for such medical equipment and supplies. Applies such standardized certificates to the extent that they contain only information completed by the supplier and the beneficiary to whom such medical equipment and supplies are furnished, a description of such medical equipment and supplies, any product code identifying such medical equipment and supplies, and any other administrative information identified by the Secretary. <n>Prohibits a supplier from distributing to physicians or to individuals entitled to benefits under Medicare for commercial purposes any completed or partially completed certificates of medical necessity.

Fusion Energy Research Authorization Act of 1994 - Directs the Secretary of Energy to carry out a Fusion Energy Research Program to demonstrate the technical and economic feasibility of producing safe, environmentally sound, and affordable energy from fusion. Declares that the goal of the Program is to demonstrate by the year 2010 the practicability of commercial electric power production and to lead to commercial production of fusion energy by the year 2040. Sets forth Program elements.

Declares that it is the purpose of this Act to: (1) promote the coordination of existing agricultural and related programs within the Department of Agriculture to provide the maximum benefit to Indian tribes and their members; (2) encourage inter-tribal trade and business development to assist in increasing productivity and living standards for Indian tribes and improving economic self-sufficiency; (3) improve access of Indian tribes to capital, export promotions, and marketing assistance that non-Indian agriculture producers currently have access to; (4) improve the development and coordination of Indian agriculture and related value-added industries to promote self-sufficiency and political self-determination for Indian tribes and members of Indian tribes; and (5) promote economic self-sufficiency and political self-determination for Indian tribes and members of Indian tribes.

High School Sports Information Collection Act of 2009 - Amends the Education Sciences Reform Act of 2002 to require the Statistics Commissioner to collect, annually, from each coeducational secondary school that receives federal financial assistance for an athletic program specified information about: (1) the number of male and female students that attended the school and for each student an identification of such student's race and ethnicity; (2) a listing of the teams that competed in athletic competition and for each such team the season in which the team competed; (3) the total number of participants as of the day of the first scheduled contest for the team, and for each participant an identification of their gender, race, and ethnicity; (4) the total expenditures for the team and for facilities; (5) the total number of coaches, and for each coach an identification of such coach's gender, employment status, and qualifications; (6) the expenditures for publicity for competitions; (7) the total number of competitions scheduled, and for each scheduled competition an indication of what day of the week and time the competition was scheduled; (8) the total number of practices scheduled, and for each scheduled practice an indication of what day of the week and time the practice was scheduled; and (9) whether such team participated in postseason competition, and the success of such team in any postseason competition.

Venezuelan Refugee Assistance Act This bill permits a qualifying national of Venezuela who is not inadmissible or deportable under certain criminal or security grounds or who did not participate in persecution to apply for adjustment to lawful permanent resident status before January 1, 2019.

Elementary and Secondary School Counseling Improvement Act of 2001 - Amends title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to make grants to local educational agencies to establish or expand elementary and secondary school counseling programs.Amends the Department of Education Organization Act to direct the Secretary to establish an Office of Pupil Services in the Department of Education.

Full Faith in Veterans Act of 2008 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to accept as sufficient proof of service-connection of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) alleged to have been incurred in or aggravated by service in the active military, naval, or air service, a diagnosis by a mental health professional together with a written determination by the professional that such disorder is related to the veteran's service, if consistent with the circumstances, conditions, or hardships of such service, notwithstanding the fact that there is no official record of such incurrence or aggravation in such service, and to resolve every reasonable doubt in favor of the veteran. Directs the Secretary to: (1) require such an employee to successfully complete a certification program established by the Secretary; and (2) make all documents related to the veteran's disability available to the veteran.

Beneficiary Access to Care Act of 2003 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to treat as a separate group of covered outpatient department (OPD) services any drug or biological that was treated as such a group as of December 31, 2002, and any drug or biological that has ceased to be eligible for transitional, pass-through payments due to a limited period of payment. Revises the calculation of Medicare OPD fee schedule amounts for non-pass-through drugs and biologicals.

Generating American Income and Infrastructure Now Act - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to sell distressed notes and other USDA obligations, with 50% deposited in an account specifically designated for infrastructure projects in low-income communities and 50% retained in the Treasury for deficit reduction.

National Youth Summer Jobs Act of 2011- Directs the Secretary of Labor to award competitive five-year grants to local governments for expanding existing youth summer jobs programs to provide job placement for out-of-school youths, including work experiences and job placement. Defines eligible youth" as individuals aged 14 but not 22 who: (1) have attained age 14 but not age 22; or (2) are enrolled in public or private secondary school or have received a secondary school diploma or its equivalent but are basic-skills deficient, unemployed, or underemployed."

Freedom from Equifax Exploitation Act This bill amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to define credit freeze" as a restriction placed at the request of a consumer or a personal representative on the consumer\\'s report that prohibits a consumer reporting agency from releasing the consumer report for the extension of credit without the consumer\\'s express authorization. A credit freeze shall not apply to the use of a consumer report by: a person or the subsidiary, affiliate, agent, subcontractor, or assignee of the person with whom the consumer has, or prior to assignment had, an account, contract, or debtor-creditor relationship for the purposes of reviewing the active account or collecting the financial obligation owed on the account, contract, or debt; a person, or the subsidiary, affiliate, agent, subcontractor, or assignee to whom access has been granted pursuant to a consumer request for purposes of facilitating the extension of credit or other permissible use; a federal, state, or local government, or an agent or assignee thereof; any person acting pursuant to a court order, warrant, or subpoena; any person for the sole purpose of providing a credit monitoring or identity theft protection service to which the consumer has subscribed; or any person or entity for insurance purposes, including use in setting or adjusting a"

Medicare Pharmacist Services Coverage Act of 2001 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act, as amended by the Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000, to provide for Medicare coverage of pharmacist services.

Gun Show Background Check Act of 2008 - Amends the federal criminal code to prohibit any person from organizing, planning, promoting, or operating a gun show without: (1) registering with the Attorney General and paying a registration fee; (2) verifying the identity of each gun show vendor participating in the show by examining a valid identification document containing a vendor's name and address; (3) first verifying the identity of each show vendor participating by examining a valid identification document containing a vendor's name and address; (4) first requiring each vendor to sign a ledger with identifying information and a notice advising the vendor of his or her obligations; (5) notifying each attendee of requirements under this Act; and (6) maintaining a copy of the records described above at the permanent place of business of the show promoter for such period of time and in such form as the Attorney General shall require. Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) responsibilities of transferors and transferees other than licensees, including criminal background check requirements; and (2) records of licensee transfers.

Reducing Barriers to Veterans\\' Benefits Act - Considers diagnosed hearing loss, tinnitus, or both of a veteran who was assigned to a military occupational specialty or equivalent or who served in combat against a hostile force during a period of hostilities to have been incurred in or aggravated by service, notwithstanding that there is no record of evidence of such hearing loss or tinnitus, for purposes of eligibility for veterans\\' disability compensation, even if there is no record of evidence of such hearing loss or tinnitus during the period of service. Defines military occupational specialty or equivalent" as a military occupational specialty or equivalent that the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) determines is a military occupational specialty or equivalent in which individuals assigned to such specialty or equivalent in the active military, naval, or air service are or were likely to be exposed to a sufficiently high level of acoustic trauma as to result in permanent hearing loss, tinnitus, or both. Requires the Secretary to: (1) issue a determination that such a presumption is warranted within 60 days after such determination, and (2) report to Congress on such determination. Requires the Secretary, under regulations prescribed by the Secretary of Defense (DOD), to ensure that a member of the armed forces receives an audiometric test at the 8000 frequency (or other test that the Secretary determines"

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to terminate until December 31, 2001, the tax subsidies for large producers of ethanol used as a fuel. Denies a credit for alcohol used to produce any ether.Repeals: (1) the reduced rate on ethanol fuel produced other than from petroleum or natural gas; and (2) the tax exemption for off-highway business use on liquids sold for use or used in an off-highway business use. Repeals the reduced rate on ethanol fuel produced from natural gas.Includes fuel alcohol in the definition of taxable motor fuel.

Coal Cleanup Taxpayer Protection Act - Amends the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 to authorize the Secretary of the Interior to approve as part of a state or federal program an alternative system that will: (1) achieve the objectives and purposes of the bonding program pursuant to such Act; and (2) result in no greater risk of financial liability to the federal government or a state government than the bonding program. Prohibits the Secretary from accepting the bond of an applicant itself (referred to as a self-bond") effective on the date of enactment of this Act. Authorizes the Secretary to accept a separate surety or collateral bond. Directs the Secretary to: (1) notify all state regulatory authorities that allow applicants to self-bond that the approved state regulatory programs must be amended to remove the authority for applicants to self-bond and to require coal mining operations covered by a self-bond accepted by the state regulatory authority to replace the self-bond with another form of bond acceptable by the earlier of the date of renewal of the coal mining permit or the date of any major permit modification; and (2) issue rules establishing limitations on surety bonds accepted under such Act to minimize the risk of financial liability to the federal government or a state government."

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Civil Rights Act of 1964 Commemorative Coin Act - Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue, during 2014, up to 350,000 one-dollar coins emblematic of the enactment of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and its contribution to civil rights in America. Permits the Secretary to initiate sales of such coins, without issuance, before 2014. Terminates such minting authority after December 31, 2014.

Pension Plan Participant Protection Act of 1998 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) with respect to the duties of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC) as trustee of a terminated pension plan. Subjects the PBGC to the same requirements of reporting and disclosure, as well as fiduciary duties, in connection with such a plan as those of any plan administrator of an employee pension benefit plan under title I of the Act. Specifies that: (1) the PBGC shall maintain such separate books and records and retain such separate counsel on its behalf as may be necessary for carrying out such duties; and (2) for purposes of applying certain enforcement provisions of ERISA, any civil monetary penalty assessed by the Secretary of Labor against the PBGC shall be assessed in the full amount specified in such provision, a civil action against the PBGC as fiduciary for relief shall be brought by any affected party, and in any such action by an affected party in which the PBGC is removed as trustee, the replacement trustee shall be selected by the court from any list of qualified candidates which may be provided by such affected party, and any review by a U.S. district court of a benefit determination by the PBGC shall be de novo. Declares that in any case

Promoting Students Using the Camp Community for Enrichment, Strength, and Success Act or the Promoting SUCCESS Act This bill directs the Department of Education to award competitive grants to local educational agencies, educational service agencies, or nonprofit organizations to carry out summer learning pilot programs that reduce summer learning loss and increase on-time promotion to the next grade level for students in kindergarten through grade 10.

United Nations Oil-for-Food Accountability Act of 2004 - Withholds from amounts appropriated for U.S. contributions to international organizations until the President certifies to Congress that: (1) the United Nations (UN) has in effect procedures that provide the General Accounting Office access to all documents relating to the oil-for-food program so that the Comptroller General may perform nationally mandated reviews of UN operations; (2) the UN Secretary General has formally confirmed that the UN will not assert the inviolability of UN papers and internal records that concern the oil-for-food program or a sanction imposed on Iraq related to the program; (3) the UN Secretary General has authorized the release to the law enforcement authorities of any member State of the UN authentic copies of any document in the possession of a person who was engaged on a contract basis to provide goods or services to the UN that concerns the program or a sanction imposed on Iraq; (4) the UN has waived any immunity enjoyed by any UN official from the judicial process in the United States for any civil or criminal acts or omissions in connection with the oil-for-food program; and (5) any UN official who benefitted from the program has reimbursed the Government of Iraq and any other entity affected by the illicit activity of such official the full amount that such official

TANF Recipients' Lifeline Act - Amends part A (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) (TANF) of title IV of the Social Security Act (SSA) to repeal the five year limit on benefits under the TANF program for qualified aliens.Amends the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 to exempt benefits under the TANF program for qualified aliens from the five year limit on benefits for qualified aliens under SSA title XVI (Supplemental Security Income) (SSI).Requires States to use appropriate bilingual personnel and printed material in the administration of their TANF programs in those portions of the political subdivisions in which a substantial number of TANF recipients speak a language other than English.Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to reduce by two percent the State family assistance grant for any State that fails to use such bilingual personnel and printed material.Amends SSA title IV part A to extend the TANF block grant program through FY 2005.Provides for an inflation adjustment of the TANF block grant amount for FY 2002 through 2005.

NSA Internal Watchdog Act - Amends the Inspector General Act of 1978 to direct the President to nominate an Inspector General (IG) of the National Security Agency (NSA), who shall be appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate. Permits an individual serving as IG on the date of the enactment of this Act to continue so serving until the President makes such an appointment, and to remain subject to such Act that, immediately before enactment, applied with respect to the IG and suffered no reduction in pay. Establishes an Office of the General Counsel to the IG, who shall: (1) serve as the chief legal officer of the Office, (2) provide legal services only to the IG, (3) perform such functions as the IG may prescribe, and (4) serve at the discretion of the IG. Requires the IG to submit to specified congressional committees the reasons for any prohibition against the IG initiating, carrying out, or completing any audit or investigation. Establishes within the IG's Office: (1) an Office of the General Counsel, (2) an Office of the Inspector General to compel testimony and issue subpoenas, and (3) an Office of the General Counsel to serve as staff of the General Counsel.

Medicare Ambulance Access, Fraud Prevention, and Reform Act of 2014 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) with respect to the Medicare ambulance fee schedule to increase by specified percentages the conversion factor for ground ambulance services. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to study how the conversion factor applicable to ground ambulance services under the ambulance fee schedule should be modified, if at all, to take into account the cost of providing services in urban, rural, and super-rural areas. Directs the Secretary, for applicable ambulance services furnished on or after January 1, 2016, by an ambulance provider, to establish and implement a process under which the Secretary shall determine, in advance of furnishing such a service to an individual, whether payment for such service may not be made because it is not covered or because it meets the applicable requirements for coverage. Prohibits Medicare payment for such ambulance services unless the Secretary determines pursuant to such process that the service meets the applicable requirements for coverage.

Displaced Older Worker Assistance Act of 2001 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) exclude from gross income a limited amount of qualified severance pay; and (2) permit a limited credit for qualified job training expenses for certain individuals over the age of 50 who have been laid off.

Provides for temporary designation of Poland as a program country for purposes of the visa waiver program. Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to determine whether Poland permanently, but conditionally, shall be designated a program country.

Film Disclosure Act of 1993 - Amends the Lanham Act to require a distributor or network that proposes to exploit a materially altered motion picture to: (1) make a good faith effort to notify each artistic author of the motion picture in writing and by registered mail and in a reasonable amount of time prior to such exploitation; (2) determine the objections of any artistic author so notified to any material alteration of the motion picture; (3) determine the objection of any artistic author so notified by the questionnaire set forth in section 9 to any type of future material alterations which are in addition to those specifically proposed for the motion picture to be exploited; (4) include the applicable label in, or affix such label to, all copies of such motion picture before the public performance of it, or the initial distribution of it to any exhibitor or retail provider, and in the event of objections by an artistic author to any future material alterations, include or affix such objections to any copy of the motion picture distributed or transmitted to any exhibitor or retail provider; and (5) not be required to satisfy the requirements of this Act if the distributor or network does not further materially alter the motion picture.

Health Care Safety Net Act of 2008 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize appropriations for the community health centers program through FY2012.<n><n>Requires the Comptroller General to study the economic costs and benefits of school-based health centers and their impact on the health of their students.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), to report to Congress on agency efforts to expand and accelerate quality improvement activities in community health centers. Requires such report to focus on: (1) federal efforts regarding health care quality in such centers; (2) identification of effective models for quality improvement; (3) efforts to determine how effective quality improvement models may be adapted for implementation by such centers; (4) types of technical assistance and resources provided to such centers; (5) proposed or adopted methodologies for community health center evaluations of quality improvement interventions; (6) dissemination of information that may assist health care quality improvement efforts in such centers; and (7) a study by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) on the integrated health systems model for the delivery of health care services to medically underserved populations.

Strengthen And Fortify Existing Bridges Act of 2013 or the SAFE Bridges Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) to establish a program to assist states to rehabilitate or replace bridges found to be structurally deficient, functionally obsolete, or fracture critical. Requires states to use apportioned program funds for projects to rehabilitate and replace such bridges. Sets the federal share of project costs at 100%.

Stop Assistance to Counterfeiters Act - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to prohibit assistance from being provided to a person seeking U.S. assistance until such person certifies to the President that: (1) such assistance will not be used to intentionally traffic in goods or services that contain counterfeit marks; (2) such assistance will not be used by any person that has had an administrative or judicial determination issued against the person for infringement, counterfeiting, or piracy of intellectual property in the United States or a foreign country; (3) any material or product, including a material or product in electronic form, that was developed, in whole or in part, using such assistance will not be imported into the United States in violation of the Tariff Act of 1930; and (4) if such assistance will be used for a contract, grant, cooperative agreement, or other agreement that includes use of any intellectual property, provides evidence of the right to use such property, and any registration for the use with an appropriate government.<n><n>Directs the President to: (1) suspend or terminate such assistance if he determines that the person has used it for activities in violation of the certification requirement; and (2) notify Congress of the reasons for any such waiver.

Restricted Weapons Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit possessing or transferring a restricted weapon, with exceptions. Defines such a weapon as any firearm which is on a list most recently published by the Secretary of the Treasury. Directs the Secretary to: (1) designate a semiautomatic rifle or shotgun as a restricted weapon; and (2) compile and publish a list of the firearms so designated. <n>Sets forth penalties for: (1) the unlawful possession or transfer of a restricted weapon; and (2) the use or possession during crime of violence or drug trafficking crime.

Developing Resources Immediately and Long-Term through Leases on Our Nation's Offshore Waters Act of 2008, or the DRILL NOW Act of 2008 - Declares without force or effect all federal prohibitions against the spending of appropriated funds to conduct natural gas leasing and preleasing activities for any area of the Outer Continental Shelf.<n><n>Revokes all withdrawals of federal submerged lands from leasing for oil and natural gas exploration and production.<n><n>Revokes all authorities given to the President for the leasing of federal submerged lands for oil and natural gas exploration and production, except in the interest of national security.<n><n>Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to authorize the governor of a state to petition the Secretary of the Interior for authorization to conduct oil and natural gas exploration and extraction activities in any area that is at least 50 miles beyond the state's coastal zone.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to deposit into: (1) a Clean and Alternative Energy Fund in the Treasury 25% of all rentals, royalties, bonus bids, and other sums due and payable to the United States from leases entered into under this Act for natural gas exploration and extraction activities; (2) a special account in the Treasury from which the Secretary shall disburse 37.5% of such qualified revenues to the state;

Apprenticeship and Jobs Training Act of 2014 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow employers a business-related tax credit for up to $5,000 for the training of a qualified individual in a qualified apprenticeship program. Defines qualified individual" as an individual who: (1) is an apprentice participating in a qualified apprenticeship program with an employer that is subject to a valid apprenticeship agreement; (2) has been employed under such program for at least seven months that ends within the taxable year; (3) is not a highly compensated employee; and (4) is not a seasonal worker."
Retirement Account Distribution Improvement Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to waive in 2008 and 2010 required distributions from certain individual retirement (IRA) plans.

AmeriCorps Disaster Relief Corps Act of 2005 - Establishes an AmeriCorps Disaster Relief Corps to carry out full- or part-time service projects that provide food, clothing, shelter, and other humanitarian assistance for victims of major disasters and emergencies, projects involving cleaning, repair, and reconstruction of structures, facilities, and lands located within the disaster area, and other projects arising from the consequences of major disasters and emergencies. Directs the Corporation to: (1) endeavor to recruit up to 10,000 additional eligible participants for the national service program; and (2) transfer funds to the National Service Trust.

Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to: (1) designate not more than five facilities of the Department of Veterans Affairs as locations for centers of mental illness research, education and training, and clinical activities; (2) subject to appropriations, establish and operate such centers; (3) designate one such center by January 1, 1996; and (4) ensure that such centers are located in various geographic regions. <n>Requires the official within the Central Office of the Veterans Health Administration responsible for mental health and behavioral sciences matters to establish a panel to assess the scientific and clinical merit of proposals submitted to the Secretary for the establishment of new centers. Requires the panel to review each proposal and submit its views on the relative scientific and clinical merit of each proposal to the official.

Recovery Through Building Renovation Act of 2010 - Amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to authorize the Secretary of Energy to provide credit support through September 30, 2012, for the installation of efficiency or renewable energy measures in buildings that are expected to increase the energy efficiency of the building.

Makes technical amendments to the San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park Act of 1988 and the Golden Gate National Parks Act of 1972 regarding the establishment of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area and the San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park.<n><n>Increases the amount that may be spent without further appropriation for the administration, maintenance, repair, and related expenses of the properties and for major renovation and park rehabilitation of those buildings included in the Fort Mason Foundation Agreement.<n><n>Increases the amount that may be spent without further appropriation for the administration, maintenance, repair, and related expenses of the leased property and the vessels, equipment, piers, and other assets within the Park.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to make minor revisions of the boundary of the Park for which fee revenue is permitted to be used under the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2005.<n><n>Increases the amount that may be spent without further appropriation for the administration, maintenance, repair, and related expenses of the vessels, equipment, piers, and other assets within the Park.<n><n>Renames the Golden Gate National Recreation Area as the Golden Gate National Parks.

Children's Hospital GME Support Reauthorization Act of 2006 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize appropriations through FY2011 for: (1) payments to children's hospitals that operate graduate medical education (GME) programs; and (2) reductions in payments for a hospital's failure to provide required information in its annual report to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

Miners Pension Protection Act This bill amends the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 to direct the Department of the Treasury, if the aggregate amount required to be transferred to the trustees of the 1974 United Mine Workers of America (UMWA) Pension Plan for a fiscal year exceeds the aggregate amount required to be transferred to that plan for the same fiscal year, to transfer an additional amount equal to the difference between those amounts and those aggregate amounts to pay pension benefits required under that plan. The transfers shall cease as of the first fiscal year for which the funded percentage of the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan is at least 100%. During a fiscal year in which the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan is receiving such transfers, no amendment of such plan which increases the liabilities of the plan by reason of any increase in benefits, any change in the accrual of benefits, or any change in the rate at which benefits become nonforfeitable may be adopted unless the amendment is required as a condition of qualification under the Internal Revenue Code. The bill: (1) disregards the amount of any such transfer (and any earnings attributable thereto) in determining the unfunded vested benefits of the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan and the allocation of such unfunded vested benefits to an employer for purposes of determining the employer's withdrawal liability

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on January 7, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.)Veterans Information and Benefits Enhancement Act of 2003 - (Sec. 2) Includes cardiovascular disease, cerebrovascular disease (stroke), or chronic liver disease among the conditions which will be considered service-connected (and therefore compensable) if the veteran has any such disease while serving on active duty during the Vietnam era.(Sec. 3) Directs the Secretaries of Veterans Affairs and Defense to review: (1) the mission, procedures, and administration of the Dose Reconstruction Program of the Department of Defense; and (2) the mechanisms of the Program for communication and interaction with veterans. Requires the Secretaries to appoint an advisory board to provide review and oversight of the Program.(Sec. 4) Directs the Secretary to carry out a study to determine the appropriate disposition of the Air Force Health Study, an epidemiologic study of Air Force personnel responsible for conducting aerial spray missions of herbicides during the Vietnam era. Requires the Secretary to seek an agreement with the National Academy of Sciences, or another appropriate scientific organization, to carry out such study.

Refinancing Education Funding to Invest (REFI) for the Future Act of 2013 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to establish lending, purchase, and other credit facilities to: (1) accommodate reasonable refinancing opportunities or other loan adjustments that improve the sustainability of payments for the borrower and reduce the likelihood of delinquency and default on private education loans, (2) benefit borrowers that are most likely to have private student debt service obligations that represent a disproportionate share of their income, and (3) ensure that borrowers pay lower interest rates that are commensurate with credit risk in order to pursue more economically productive activities, such as home purchases and small business formation.

Energy-Efficient Roof Jobs Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish, for depreciation purposes: (1) a 20-year recovery period for qualified energy-efficient cool roof replacement property; and (2) a special depreciation allowance for qualified energy-efficient cool roof replacement property.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on October 1, 2015. Offshore Fracking Transparency and Review Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill prohibits any person from engaging in hydraulic fracturing or acid well stimulation treatment in the Pacific Outer Continental Shelf Region until the Department of the Interior has published a report on the conduct and impacts of such treatments in that region and issued a final environmental impact statement. (Sec. 3) Interior must report to Congress and publish a report on the conduct and impacts of hydraulic fracturing and acid well stimulation treatments in that region. (Sec. 4) Interior must issue an environmental impact statement under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 regarding the impacts on the marine environment and public health of offshore hydraulic fracturing and acid well stimulation treatments conducted in that region. (Sec. 5) Interior must notify all relevant state and local regulatory agencies and publish a notice in the Federal Register within 30 days after receiving any application for a permit that would allow the conduct of offshore hydraulic fracturing or an acid well stimulation treatment in that region. The notice must include: (1) the date the treatment was conducted; (2) the location where it was conducted; (3) the chemicals used; (4) the total volume of fluid used in the treatment; (5) the volume of wastewater generated; and (6) the intended

Anti-Corruption Act of 1995 - Amends the Federal criminal code to set penalties for depriving or defrauding, or endeavors to deprive or to defraud, the inhabitants of a State or political subdivision of the honest services of an official or employee of the State or political subdivision through one or more specified means, or otherwise: (1) through the procurement, casting, or tabulation of ballots that are materially false, fictitious, or fraudulent or that are invalid under State law or through paying or offering to pay any person for voting; (2) through the procurement or submission of voter registrations that contain false information or omit material information; (3) through the filing of any report required to be filed under Federal or State law regarding an election campaign that contains false information or omits material information; or (4) through engaging in intimidating, threatening, or deceptive conduct, with intent to prevent or unlawfully discourage any person from voting for the candidate of that person's choice, registering to vote, or campaigning for or against a candidate. <n>Imposes a fine and/or prison term of up to ten years on any official, public official, or person selected to be a public official who, being an official, public official, or person who has been selected to be a public official, directly or indirectly discharges

Local Innovation and Coastal Protection Act of 1993 - Amends the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 to require the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency to make grants, with amounts made available from the Coastal Erosion Control Fund, to demonstrate the feasibility of innovative mitigation activities designed to minimize coastal erosion, preserve shorelines, and avoid environmental degradation. Authorizes the Director to make such grants to: (1) any State; and (2) any community participating in the national flood insurance program that has suffered recurring flood damages and claims and is in full compliance with program requirements. <n>Sets forth grant application and matching requirements. <n>Authorizes appropriations. <n>Establishes the Coastal Erosion Control Fund.

Lead-Safe Housing for Kids Act of 2016 This bill requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to promulgate regulations to update the standards for lead-contaminated dust and lead-contaminated soil. The Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) must promulgate regulations to update the standards for such dust and soil in accordance with health-based standards. The bill amends the Residential Lead-Based Paint Hazard Reduction Act of 1992 to require HUD to promulgate regulations that: (1) require an initial risk assessment for all housing in which a family with a child of less than six years of age will reside or be expected to reside, and (2) establish a process for enforcing compliance with lead-based paint hazard reduction standards in such housing.

Uranium Resources Stewardship Act or Uranium Resources Stewardship Act - Amends Federal law to permanently withdraw all Federal lands from location and entry for uranium mining.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to: (1) divide any Federal lands that are not withdrawn from mineral leasing and that are otherwise available for uranium leasing under applicable law into leasing tracts of such size as the Secretary finds appropriate and in the public interest; and (2) offer such lands for uranium leasing and award uranium leases thereon by competitive bidding.<n><n>Prohibits any bid for a uranium lease from being accepted that is less than the fair market value of the uranium subject to the lease.<n><n>Requires the Secretary, before issuing any uranium lease, to consider effects that mining under the proposed lease might have on an impacted community or area, including impacts on the environment, on agricultural, on cultural resources, and other economic activities, and on public services.<n><n>Prohibits lease sales for lands until after a notice of the proposed offering for lease has been given once a week for three consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the county in which the lands are situated, or in electronic format, in accordance with regulations prescribed by the Secretary.<n><n>Requires all lands to be leased to the highest responsible qualified bidder

Preventing Tragedies Between Police and Communities Act of 2016 This bill requires a state or local government that receives funding under the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant (JAG) program to require all individuals enrolled in an academy of a law enforcement agency and all law enforcement officers of the agency and local government to fulfill a training session on de-escalation techniques each fiscal year. The Department of Justice (DOJ) shall maintain a list of evidence-based practices it determines is successful in enhancing de-escalation skills of law enforcement officers.

Amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to require the Secretary of the Interior to publish a complaint in a readily accessible manner, including electronically, within 30 days after serving it on the defendant (any person, including a business entity, or any State, tribal government, or local subdivision the rights of which may be affected by a determination made under such Act in a suit brought for an endangered or threatened species). Bars the failure of the Secretary to meet such deadline from being the basis for an action (but allows each affected party to move to intervene in such action, after such period, until the end of which a party may not file a motion for a consent decree or to dismiss the case pursuant to a settlement agreement). Directs the court, if it grants a motion to intervene, to refer the action to: (1) the mediation program of the court; or (2) a magistrate judge. Requires the court to ensure that a proposed covered settlement does not include payment to any plaintiff for litigation costs and prohibits it from granting any motion, including a motion to dismiss, based on the proposed settlement if such payment includes payment to any plaintiff. Authorizes the court, in issuing any final order in such an action, to award costs of litigation to any party, whenever the court determines such award

Federal Propaganda Prohibition Act of 2005 - Requires an executive agency to submit to specified congressional committees: (1) a written notification containing the name, amount, and purpose of, and any modifications to, a contract with an agency for public relations, media relations, advertising, or public opinion research services or any subcontract for such services under a Federal contract; and (2) upon request by the Comptroller General or the chairman or ranking minority member of such committee, a copy of the contract and any materials produced under it. Defines covered contract" as a contract with an agency for public relations, media relations, advertising, or public opinion research services, or any subcontract for such services under a Federal contract.<n><n>Prohibits any U.S. Government officer or employee from making or authorizing an expenditure or obligation of funds for publicity or propaganda purposes within the United States unless authorized by law. Sets forth penalties for violations.<n><n>Requires each advertisement or other communication paid for by an executive agency to disclose the source and amount of funds used for that communication."

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 5, 2007. The summary of that version is repeated here.) National Urban Search and Rescue Response System Act of 2007 - Amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to direct the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to: (1) continue to administer the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System; (2) provide for a national network of standardized search and rescue resources to assist states and local governments in responding to hazards; (3) designate urban search and rescue teams to participate in the System; and (4) determine the criteria for participation. Provides for the appointment of System members into federal service for a period of service to provide for their participation in exercises, pre-incident staging, major disaster and emergency response activities, and training events sponsored or sanctioned by the Administrator.

Confederate Commemorative Works Inventory and Joint Resource Study Act - Requires the Director of the National Park Service (NPS) to conduct a special resource study that: (1) examines works commemorating and interpreting the Civil War, the Battle of the Blood Banner, the Confederate States Navy flag, the battle flag of the Army of Northern Virginia, any state or regimental flag as such flag was depicted during 1861-1865, and the people on the home front; and (2) identifies related locations in the United States from 1861 through 1865, including properties that could meet criteria for listing in the National Register of Historic Places or criteria for designation as National Historic Landmarks. Directs the Secretary of the Interior to submit to specified congressional committees a report containing the findings of the study and any related recommendations.

Make Education Local Act of 2018 This bill authorizes states to submit to the Department of Education decisions permitting them to receive federal funds on a consolidated basis that would otherwise be directed toward specific programs furthering the stated purpose of title I (Improving the Academic Achievement of the Disadvantaged) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Each state may choose to include within its scope any program for which Congress makes funds available under title I that is for a purpose described in that Act. Funds made available to a state pursuant to a state management decision shall be used for any educational purpose permitted by state law. Each state educational agency that operates under a state management decision may modify or eliminate state fiscal and accounting barriers that prevent local educational agencies and schools from easily consolidating funds from other eligible federal, state, and local sources in order to improve educational opportunities and reduce unnecessary fiscal and accounting requirements.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 19, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Republican Form of Government Guarantee Act - Amends the federal criminal code to prohibit assaulting or threatening a state or local government officer or employee. Increases penalties for assault and for Extortion and Threats. Reaffirms the right to participate in a republican form of state government free from interference from unlawful violence and the reasonably perceived threat of unlawful violence.

VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to establish and carry out a scholarship program to provide educational assistance to individuals who are accepted for enrollment or currently enrolled in programs of study leading to a degree or certificate in visual impairment or orientation and mobility, or a dual degree or certification in both areas, at an accredited educational institution that is in a state, and who enter into an agreement with the Secretary.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to publicize the scholarship program to educational institutions throughout the United States, with an emphasis on disseminating information to such institutions with high numbers of Hispanic students and to historically black colleges and universities.

Ozone National Ambient Air Quality Standard Deadline Harmonization Act of 2015 This bill amends the Clean Air Act by requiring states to designate areas as attainment, nonattainment, or unclassifiable with respect to the 2015 ozone standards by October 26, 2024. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) must promulgate final designations for all areas in all states with respect to the 2015 ozone standards, including any modifications to the designations submitted. States must submit a state implementation plan by October 26, 2026, to meet the deadline for submitting the national ambient air quality standards for ozone promulgated by the EPA in 2008. The 2015 ozone standards shall not apply to the review and disposition of a preconstruction permit application if: (1) the EPA or the state, local, or tribal permitting authority determines the application to be complete on or before the date of promulgation of final designations; or (2) the EPA or the authority publishes a public notice of a preliminary determination or draft permit for the application prior to the date that is 60 days after promulgation of final designations. The EPA may not complete, before October 26, 2025, any review of the criteria for ozone published in the Federal Register on March 27, 2008, or the national ambient air quality standard for ozone promulgated by the EPA in 2008.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on December 10, 2015. Department of Energy Laboratory Modernization and Technology Transfer Act of 2015 TITLE I--INNOVATION MANAGEMENT At Department of Energy (DOE) (Sec. 101) This bill directs DOE to report annually to Congress on: (1) its current ability to carry out the goals of the Energy Policy Act of 2005, including an assessment of the role and effectiveness of the Director of the Office of Technology Transitions; and (2) recommended departmental policy changes and legislative changes to improve DOE's ability to successfully transfer new energy technologies to the private sector. (Sec. 102) The bill expresses the sense of Congress that DOE should encourage the National Laboratories and federally funded research and development centers to inform small businesses of the opportunities and resources that exist pursuant to this Act. (Sec. 103) DOE shall report to Congress assessing its capabilities to authorize, host, and oversee privately funded fusion and non-light water reactor prototypes and related demonstration facilities at DOE-owned sites. The report shall include: (1) DOE's capabilities to facilitate privately-funded prototypes up to 20 megawatts thermal output; (2) potential sites capable of hosting research, development, and demonstration of prototype reactors and related facilities for the purpose of reducing technical risk; (3)

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 19, 1999. The summary of that version is repeated here.)Title I: Macau policy (sic) - Expresses the sense of the Congress that: (1) the United States should play an active role before, on, and after December 20, 1999, in maintaining the same's cultural heritage and prosperity, its people's confidence, and the ability to maintain a high degree of autonomy in matters other than defense and foreign affairs; and (2) the United States should contribute to the continuation in force of all treaties and other international agreements, particularly carrying out trade, commerce, law enforcement, monetary policy, aviation, shipping, communications, tourism, cultural affairs, and participation in international organizations, consistent with the national security and other interests of the United States.(Sec. 101) Declares the sense of the Congress that: (1) the United States should play an active role before, on, and after December 20, 1999, in maintaining the same's cultural heritage and prosperity, its people's confidence, and the ability to maintain a high degree of autonomy in matters other than defense and foreign affairs; and (2) the Congress approves the continuation in force on and after December 20, 1999, of all treaties and other international

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 9, 2014.
