Federal Spectrum Incentive Act of 2013 - (Sec. 2) Amends the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to require the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) to notify the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) of: (1) estimated relocation or sharing costs and timelines for such relocation or sharing, or (2) that, instead of relocation or sharing costs, a federal entity will receive payment under the Spectrum Relocation Fund because it is discontinuing the operations on eligible frequencies without relocating such operations to other frequencies or relocating such operations to frequencies assigned to another federal entity in order for such entities to share such frequencies. Requires a federal entity authorized to use any eligible frequency to submit to NTIA and to a specified Technical Panel a transition plan in which it declares the intention to: (1) share such eligible frequencies with a non-federal user, or to relocate to other frequencies, and to receive relocation or sharing costs from the Spectrum Relocation Fund; or (2) discontinue such operations, without relocating such operations to other frequencies, or to relocate such operations to frequencies assigned to another federal entity in order for such entities to share such frequencies. Directs the NTIA to specify, after public input, a common format for all

Construction Quality Assurance Act of 2009 - Requires each solicitation by an executive agency for the procurement of construction in an amount exceeding $1 million to require each bidder to submit as part of such bid the name, business location, and nature of work of each subcontractor with whom such bidder, if awarded the contract, will subcontract for work in excess of $100,000. Prohibits a contractor from substituting a subcontractor in place of the subcontractor listed in the original bid or proposal, except with the consent of the contracting officer for good cause.

Endangered Species Community Advisory Board Act of 1995 - Amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to direct the Secretary of the Interior, in connection with the designation of an area as critical habitat or a National Wildlife Refuge, to establish an Endangered Species Community Advisory Board. <n>Directs the Secretary to make available funds to facilitate the participation of individuals from the private sector on such boards to ensure public input into the designation of areas as critical habitat or National Wildlife Refuges. Makes the private individuals eligible for funding assistance only if they reside in the vicinity of the area for which the community advisory board is established. Permits individuals who are local community members of such a board to use funds made available only: (1) to obtain technical assistance of experts in interpreting scientific data, material, and issues regarding protection of endangered species; and (2) to educate the local community in understanding such data, material, and issues. <n>Requires the Secretary, before designating any area as critical habitat or National Wildlife Refuge, to consult with and seek the advice and recommendations of the board regarding: (1) identifying the needs and concerns of the affected local community and individual landowners; (2) monitoring scientific studies and surveys used to determine the need for designation of the area as critical habitat or a National Wildlife Refuge, before that designation; and

Freedom ton in Peace Act of 2011 - Amends the federal criminal code concerning the prohibition on demonstrations where a funeral, memorial service, or other ceremony for a veteran is held to prohibit any person from carrying out such a demonstration on the property where a funeral is held unless such demonstration has been approved by the cemetery or the owner of the property on which the funeral is held. Includes within such prohibition a demonstration during the period beginning 60 minutes before and ending 60 minutes after such funeral, any part of which demonstrates: (1) taking place within 150 feet of a road, pathway, or other route beginning 150 feet of a road or other route to or from such cemetery or other property; and (2) including as part of such demonstration any sign which tends to impede or interfere with any individual making egress from such cemetery or property, if there is such a sign which conspicuously states that a funeral will be held on such cemetery or property.

Sex Offender Registration Tips Program Act of 2009 or the SORT Act of 2009- Authorizes the Attorney General to make grants to Parents for Megan's Law, Inc., to operate a national website as a clearinghouse for information related to sex offender registration, notification, abuse and abduction prevention, and crime victims' support and referrals, providing the public with confidential tips regarding registered sex offenders failing to comply with child registration requirements, supervision, or employment restrictions or who are in positions of trust where potential child victims can be accessed.

Helping to Encourage Real Opportunities (HERO) for At-Risk Youth Act This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the work opportunity tax credit, to: (1) allow such credit for employees under the age of 21 who are employed for not more than 20 hours per week during any period between September 16 and April 30 in which they are regularly attending any secondary school, (2) increase the credit amount for such employees, (3) extend through 2019 the tax credit for hiring at-risk youth, and (4) expand the definition of at-risk youth" to include any individual who is certified as having attained age 16 but not age 25 on the hiring date, as not regularly employed during the six-month period preceding the hiring date, as not readily employable by reason of lacking a sufficient number of basic skills, or as an eligible foster child who was in foster care during the 12-month period ending on the hiring date. The bill extends the designation of an empowerment zone, for purposes of such credit, through December 31, 2019."

Amends House Concurrent Resolution 67 with respect to discretionary spending reductions in the Department of Defense (DOD) for FY 1996 through 2000 to revise the assumptions included in the conference report on House Concurrent Resolution 67 (concerning reductions in DOD discretionary spending for FY 1996 through 2000) to include the following: (1) limit DOD discretionary spending in FY 1996 to $244 billion, in FY 1997 to $248 billion, in FY 1998 to $254 billion, in FY 1999 to $261 billion, and in FY 2000 to $261 billion; (2) terminate the production of Trident D5 submarine ballistic missiles after 1996; (3) phase out over five years the equivalent of two Army light divisions; (4) deny unemployment to service members who voluntarily leave the service; (5) close the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences; (6) increase reliance on private-sector housing for military families by making service personnel eligible for a cash housing allowance regardless of whether they are DOD or private-sector units and charging agricultural market-driven rent for DOD housing; (7) reduce the Intelligence budget by $300 million in each of FY 1996 through 2000; (8) encourage private ownership of industrial assets used in defense production by granting the General Services Administration clear authority to negotiate sale of equipment to the holding contractor in situations in which continued DOD ownership is not necessary

International Development Act of 1994 - Amends the Bretton Woods Agreements Act to authorize the U.S. Governor of the Inter-American Development Bank to contribute on behalf of the United States up to $400 million to the Global Environment Facility. Authorizes appropriations. <n>Amends the African Development Fund Act to authorize the U.S. Governor of the African Development Fund to contribute on behalf of the United States up to $315 million to the seventh replenishment of the resources of the African Development Fund. Authorizes appropriations. <n>Amends the Inter-American Development Bank Act to authorize the U.S. Governor of the Inter-American Development Bank to vote for resolutions pending before the Board of Governors of the Bank which provide for: (1) an increase in the authorized capital stock of the Bank and the resources of the Fund for Special Operations; and (2) contributions on behalf of the United States to the Fund.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on February 11, 2016. Foreign Business Bribery Prohibition Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977 to make any person that violates the Act's prohibition on foreign bribery liable in any court of competent jurisdiction to any issuer that is subject to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, a domestic concern that is subject to the Act, or any U.S. person that is damaged by the violation. The bill prohibits treble damages against any person that violates such prohibition if the plaintiff alleges that: (1) the defendant violated the Act by preventing the plaintiff from obtaining or retaining business for or with any person, and (2) the defendant assisted the defendant in obtaining or retaining such business. The court may not find for the plaintiff in an action unless the plaintiff alleges and proves that: (1) the defendant violated, and (2) the defendant's violation prevented the plaintiff from obtaining or retaining business for or with any person. The bill sets forth a measure of damages that a plaintiff may obtain that is equal to the higher of: (1) the total amount of the contract or agreement that the defendant gained in obtaining or retaining business by means of the violation, or (2) the total amount of the contract or agreement that the

Veterans' Health Care Policy Enhancement Act of 2008 - Prohibits a veteran who is catastrophically disabled from being required to make any payment otherwise required for the receipt of hospital or nursing home care under provisions authorizing the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to pay for nonservice-connected treatment for family members receiving such care.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to develop and implement a comprehensive policy on the management of pain experienced by veterans enrolled for Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) health care services. Requires the Secretary to establish within the VA a consolidated patient accounting center to track and manage all VA health care expenditures for treatment of veterans with acute or chronic pain.

Emergency Drought Relief Act of 1998 - Amends the Agricultural Market Transition Act to revise marketing assistance loan rates for: (1) wheat; (2) feed grains (corn); (3) upland cotton; (4) extra long staple cotton; and (5) oilseeds. <n>(Sec. 3) Authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture, during 1999 through 2002, to provide technical assistance and cost-share payments to agricultural producers who undertake on eligible lands in a designated disaster area a project intended to alleviate or otherwise respond to the effects of drought on crop or livestock production. Authorizes such assistance to include: (1) the installation of water wells; (2) the dredging of ponds or other small bodies of water; and (3) the extension of public water supply lines to serve eligible lands.

Educational Empowerment Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for qualified educational empowerment zone contributions. Allows the designation of up to 30 such zones. Bases designations on the degree of poverty.Establishes a teacher loan forgiveness program for mathematics and science teachers.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on October 6, 2015. Cyber Defense of Federal Networks Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), in coordination with the Office of Management and Budget, to develop and implement an intrusion detection and response plan to detect, identify, and remove intruders in agency information systems. The plan shall not apply to the Department of Defense or an element of the intelligence community. DHS must also: (1) include in its efforts to continuously diagnose and mitigate cybersecurity risks advanced network security tools to improve visibility of network activity, and (2) develop and implement a plan to ensure advanced network security tools to detect and mitigate intrusions and activity are available for use by each agency. DHS must regularly assess and require implementation of best practices for: (1) securing agency information systems against intrusion, and (2) preventing data exfiltration from such systems in the event of an intrusion. DHS must increase transparency to the public on agency cybersecurity postures, including by increasing the number of metrics available on federal government performance websites and, to the greatest extent practicable, displaying metrics for agencies. (Sec. 3) The bill requires the Office of Management and Budget to include in the President's annual budget submission a

Save America's Utility Infrastructure and Secure America Now Act of 2008 - Amends the Federal Power Act to repeal the authority of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) to: (1) impose penalties for failure to comply with reliability standards; and (2) prohibit disturbances (other than planned maintenance) lasting more than five days from the date of enactment of this Act.<n><n>Directs FERC to issue a rule amending its reliability standards to provide that any person who violates such a standard shall be subject to a fine, up to five years in prison, or both.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, acting through the Assistant Secretary of the Office of Infrastructure Protection, to conduct a study to examine gaps in emergency planning management for vulnerable populations.

Preserve Rights Of States and Political subdivisions to Encourage Retirement Savings Act or the PROSPERS Act Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to define an employee pension benefit plan" and "pension plan" to exclude an individual retirement plan established and maintained pursuant to a payroll deduction savings program of a State or qualified political subdivision, provided that: (1) the program is specifically established pursuant to State or qualified political subdivision law; (2) the program is implemented and administered by the State or qualified political subdivision establishing the program, which is responsible for investing the employee savings or for selecting investment alternatives for employees to choose; (3) the State or qualified political subdivision assumes responsibility for the security of payroll deductions and employee savings, including by requiring that amounts withheld from wages by the employer be transmitted to the program promptly and by providing an enforcement mechanism to assure compliance with this requirement; (4) the State or qualified political subdivision adopts measures to ensure that employees are notified of their rights under the program, and creates a mechanism for enforcement of those rights; (5) participation in the program is voluntary; (6) all rights of the employee, former employee, or beneficiary under the program are enforceable only by the employee, former employee, or beneficiary, an authorized representative of such a person, or by the State or"

Amends the Technical and Miscellaneous Revenue Act of 1988 to revise rules concerning the filing of a joint tax return by a Native Corporation and a buyer corporation with respect to income assigned, transferred, or otherwise made available by the buyer corporation through the use of a corporation as a profit subsidiary, by reason of such transaction for a period in which the profit subsidiary qualified as a member of the affiliated group of which the Native Corporation was the common parent. Declares that the election shall be irrevocable and shall be made by filing with the district director for the Anchorage district office of the Internal Revenue Service a written statement signed by responsible officers of the Native Corporation and the buyer corporation that: (1) identifies the Native Corporation, the profit subsidiary, and the buyer corporation; (2) states the amount of income assigned, transferred, or otherwise made available to the profit subsidiary for the taxable year by reason of the Native Corporation transaction; (3) if profit subsidiaries related to a buyer corporation other than the electing buyer corporation were members of the affiliated group of which the Native Corporation was the common parent, describes the order and the amount of losses and credits of the Native Corporation affiliated group that were used to offset the income of each profit subsidiary; (4) states the agreement of the buyer corporation to consent to extend the periods of limitations

Amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require prescription drug formularies to cover all drugs in six specified therapeutic categories and classes.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2014. Connect with Veterans Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to establish a program to facilitate VA outreach to veterans, primary state agencies for the administration of veterans' benefits and services, political subdivisions of states, and Indian tribes. Requires the Secretary, to carry out such program, to: (1) establish a national veterans directory, and (2) share directory information with any such entities from which a participating individual has expressed interest in receiving information. Prohibits: (1) the Secretary from selling any information collected under this Act, (2) the Secretary or any participating entity from sharing any information with any third-party or for-profit entities, or (3) any participating entity from sharing any information with any individual or family member as a condition of participation in the program. Requires a participating entity, as a condition of participation, to agree not to share any information received from the entity with any third-party or for-profit entities and to purchase any product or service from such entity.

Safe NOW Act of 2006 - Establishes the National Sex Offender Risk Classification Task Force to create guidelines for the establishment of a risk-based sex offender classification system. Requires the Task Force to: (1) create preliminary guidelines for such establishment; (2) administer the demonstration program for such system; and (3) create final guidelines for such system.

Sports Agent Responsibility and Trust Act Declares it unlawful for an athlete agent to: (1) recruit or solicit a student athlete to enter into an agency contract; (2) enter into an agency contract with such athlete without providing such athlete with a disclosure document prior to such contract; or (3) enter into an agency contract with a student athlete without providing such athlete with such disclosure document. Requires an athlete agent to provide a disclosure document to a student athlete, or, if the student athlete is under age 18, to the student athlete's parent or legal guardian. Requires the disclosure document to be signed by the student athlete, or, if the student athlete is under age 18, by such student athlete's parent or legal guardian.

Social Security Administration Accountability Act of 2012 - Amends title VII (Administration) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to direct the Commissioner of Social Security to prepare and submit an annual budget estimate for the Social Security Administration (SSA) directly to the President and Congress.<n><n>Requires the Commissioner, not later than 90 days before a revision of the comprehensive work force plan, to submit to specified congressional committees the document setting forth the revision, including: (1) the total number of cases pending at each hearing office, listed by hearing office, and an aggregate total of all cases pending at all hearing offices; (2) the total number of cases pending for over the preceding year at each hearing office, listed by both hearing office and presiding administrative judge; (3) the average duration of time to process each case at each hearing office, listed by hearing office; and (4) the staffing levels at each hearing office and field office, including a listing of job titles, classifications, and the number of staff within each title and classification.<n><n>Prohibits the Commissioner from taking any action to close or consolidate field or hearing offices of SSA or to otherwise impose any new limitation on access to such offices until after the Commissioner submits a detailed report to Congress outlining and justifying the process for selecting field or hearing offices

Emergency Port of Entry Personnel and Infrastructure Funding Act of 2007 - Directs United States Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to hire, train, and assign to duty during FY2009-FY2012: (1) 2,000 full-time officers to serve on primary inspection lanes at land ports of entry on the northern and southern borders of the United States; (2) 1,000 full-time officers to serve on primary inspection lanes at air and sea ports of entry on such borders; (3) 600 supervisory full-time officers to serve on such borders and 200 support staff for ports of entry along such borders; and (4) 750 full-time officers to serve on primary inspection lines at land ports of entry in Texas and 500 full-time officers to serve on primary inspection lines at air and sea ports of entry in Texas. Authorizes the Secretary of Homeland Security to waive any limitation on the number of full-time equivalent personnel assigned to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in order to fulfill such requirements.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) ensure that all CBP agents and officers are equipped with secure two-way communication and satellite-enabled devices to ensure communication between agents and ports of entry, patrol, and inspection stations, and other federal, state, local, and tribal law enforcement agencies; (2) provide

Mark O. Hatfield- Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Act of 2004 - Establishes as an independent entity in the executive branch the Mark O. Hatfield- Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation.

Welfare Integrity and Data Improvement Act - Amends part A (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) (TANF) of title IV of the Social Security Act (SSA) to extend through FY2012 the TANF program, including grants for: (1) family assistance grants; (2) healthy marriage promotion and responsible fatherhood grants; (3) maintenance of effort requirements; (4) studies and demonstrations; (5) tribal grants; and (6) child care entitlement.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to: (1) designate standard data elements for any category of information required to be reported under TANF; and (2) adopt a uniform standard for such information throughout the TANF program.

Energy Productivity Innovation Challenge Act of 2015 or the EPIC Act of 2015 This bill requires the Department of Energy (DOE) to: issue an invitation to states to submit plans to participate in an electric and thermal energy productivity challenge to promote the goal of doubling electric and thermal energy productivity by January 1, 2030; and use funds made available under this bill to provide an initial allocation of grants to no more than 25 states. States must submit applications to receive such grants by submitting revised energy conservation plans under the Energy Policy and Conservation Act. DOE shall rank such revised plans submitted in order of the greatest to at least likely contribution to improving energy productivity in the state. Recipients may use grants to promote: the expansion of policies and programs that will advance industrial energy efficiency, waste heat recovery, combined heat and power, and waste heat-to-power utilization; the expansion of policies and programs that will advance energy efficiency construction and retrofits for public and private commercial buildings; the expansion of residential policies and programs that implement best practice policies and tools for residential retrofit programs that reduce administrative and delivery costs for energy efficiency projects, encourage streamlining and automation to support contractor engagement, and implement systems that encourage private investment and market innovation; the establishment or expansion of incentives in the electric utility sector to enhance demand response and energy

Small Company Capital Formation Act of 2011 - Amends the Securities Act of 1933 to direct the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to add a class of securities to the small issue exemption from its registration requirements, which limit the aggregate offering amount of all securities offered and sold within the prior 12-month period in reliance on such exemption to $50 million. Allows the securities to be offered and sold publicly. Declares that the securities shall: (1) not be restricted securities within the meaning of federal securities laws, (2) apply to any person offering or selling such securities, (3) apply to an issuer before filing any offering statement, and (4) be required to file audited financial statements with the SEC annually.<n><n>Directs the SEC to: (1) require an issuer to file audited financial statements with the SEC annually, and (2) set forth other terms, conditions, or requirements as it determines necessary in the public interest and for the protection of investors, including a requirement that the issuer prepare and electronically file with the SEC and distribute to prospective investors an offering statement and related documents, including audited financial statements. Authorizes the SEC to require periodic disclosures regarding the issuer and file with the SEC periodic disclosures regarding its business operations, financial condition, corporate governance principles, its use of investor funds, and other appropriate matters.

Federal Election Integrity Act of 2004 - Amends the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 to require an applicant for voter registration to provide proof of U.S. citizenship in accordance with guidelines established by the Election Administration Commission in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of State. Amends the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to prohibit the appropriate State or local election official from providing a ballot for a Federal election (including a provisional ballot) to an individual who desires to vote in person unless the individual presents to the official a current and valid photo identification. Prohibits the appropriate State or local election official from accepting any ballot for a Federal election provided by mail unless the individual submits with the ballot a copy of a current and valid photo identification.

Federal Repeal of Expensive Exchanges Act or the FREE Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to health insurance, to repeal the provision requiring the advance determination and payment of premium tax credits and cost-sharing reductions under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA). Amends the Public Health Service Act, with respect to health insurance exchanges, to repeal provisions requiring the Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality to report to Congress on the impact of provisions of PPACA on health care coverage.

Economic Growth and Stabilization Financing Demonstration Act 1994 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to study and report to the Congress on the feasibility and desirability of a program of loan guarantees for economic growth and stabilization in communities facing economic distress, including: (1) a loan guarantee program for private lending institutions, community development financial institutions, and other lenders; and (2) an equity financing program for private U.S. businesses or nonprofit organizations and associations.
Expresses the sense of Congress that the United States Mint Facility in Denver, Colorado, should strike such coins unless the Secretary determines that it would be technically or cost-prohibitive.

Federal Facilities Clean Water Compliance Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (the Act) to waive immunity of the United States with respect to Federal, State, interstate, and local requirements, administrative authorities, sanctions, and penalties concerning water pollution control. <n>Absolves Federal employees of personal liability for civil penalties under water pollution control laws for acts or omissions within the scope of official duties. Makes Federal employees subject to criminal sanctions under Federal or State water pollution control laws, but prohibits applying criminal sanctions to Federal agencies. Permits the imposition of criminal penalties but prohibits applying criminal sanctions to Federal agencies. <n>Authorizes the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), upon determining that a Federal agency has violated specified water pollution control or permit conditions or is in violation of a State permit to propose an order to assess a civil penalty or to require compliance immediately or within a specified time period. Authorizes the suspension or revocation of permits. <n>Requires the Administrator or the Secretary of the Army, upon determining that a Federal agency has violated or is in violation of a permit condition or limitation, to propose an order to assess a civil penalty or to require compliance immediately or within a specified time period. <n>Permits the suspension or revocation of permits. <n>

Amends Federal firearms provisions to prohibit a licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer from transferring a firearm to any other person who is not licensed, unless: (1) before the completion of the transfer, the licensee contacts the national instant criminal background check system (established under the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act) and the system provides the licensee with a unique identification number or three business days have elapsed since the licensee contacted the system and the system has not notified the licensee that the receipt of a firearm by such other person would violate Federal or State law; and (2) the transferor has verified the identity of the transferee by examining a valid identification document of the transferee containing a photograph of the transferee. Requires the system, if receipt of a firearm would not violate such provisions, to immediately: (1) assign a unique identification number to the transfer; (2) provide the licensee with the number; and (3) destroy all records of the system with respect to the call and the date the number was assigned. Provides that such provisions shall not apply if: (1) the other person has presented to the licensee a permit that was issued not more than five years earlier by the State in which the transfer is to take place and that the law of the State provides that such a permit is to be issued only after an authorized

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on December 10, 2014. Department of Veterans Affairs Major Medical Facility Lease Authorization Act of 2013 (Sec. 2) This bill authorizes the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out specified major medical facility leases in New Mexico, New Jersey, Charleston, South Carolina, Cobb County, Georgia, Honolulu, Hawaii, Johnson County, Kansas, Louisiana, Lake Charles, Louisiana, New Port, Florida, Puerto Rico, San Antonio, Texas, Vista, California, West Haven, Connecticut, Houston, Texas, and Worcester, Massachusetts. The bill sets the amount for each lease not to exceed the amount shown for such location (not including any estimated cancellation costs). (Sec. 3) The VA shall record either: (1) the full cost of its contractual obligation against funds available at the time a contract is executed; or (2) the amount sufficient to cover first year lease payments plus cancellation costs.

Protection of Homes, Small Businesses, and Private Property Act of 2005 - Prohibits the power of eminent domain from being available only for public use. Defines public use" to mean all exercises of eminent domain power by State and local governments through use of Federal funds. Directs that, nevertheless, all exercises of eminent domain power by State and local governments through use of the power of eminent domain preclude action to voluntarily limit their own power of takings power."

Safe Highways and Infrastructure Preservation Act of 1997 - Amends the Surface Transportation Assistance Act of 1982 to prohibit States from allowing the operation on federally assisted highways of any trailer, semi-trailer, container, or other cargo carrying unit longer than 53 feet, with specified exceptions. Declares that nothing in this Act shall be construed to affect State laws with respect to such vehicles less than 53 feet long. <n>(Sec. 3) Amends Federal highway law to prohibit States from allowing the operation of any vehicle or combination (other than longer combination vehicles) that are not in conformance with the Interstate weight limits, unless the Department of Transportation, another Federal agency, or the State has determined such vehicles could lawfully operate on July 1, 1956 (except in the case of the overall gross weight of any group of two or more consecutive axles on the date of the enactment of the Federal-Aid Highway Amendments of 1974.) Prohibits the operation of such vehicles on the basis that a State law or regulation could have authorized such operation at some prior date by permit or otherwise. Declares that nothing in this Act shall be construed to prevent a State from reducing its gross vehicle weight limitation or its single or tandem axle weight limitations on the Interstate System for operations on the list published but in no

Full Employment Opportunity and Infrastructure Improvement Act of 1994- Amends the Job Training Partnership Act to add a new title, title VIII: Public Works and Public Service Job Training Program. Directs the Secretary of Labor to allot appropriations under such title to the States for allocation to service delivery areas within each State. Sets forth requirements for the use of such funds by service delivery areas.

Preventing Overdoses While in Emergency Departments Act of 2018 This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services to establish a program to award competitive grants to up to 20 health care sites to develop protocols for discharging drug overdose patients and enhance the integration and coordination of care and treatment options for individuals after discharge.

True Cost of War Act of 2011 - Directs the President, with contributions from the Secretary of Defense (DOD), the Secretary of State, and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA), to submit a report containing an estimate of the long-term costs of Operation New Dawn (the successor contingency operation to Operation Iraqi Freedom) and Operation Enduring Freedom for each scenario in which the number of members of the Armed Forces deployed in support of such operations is reduced from roughly 190,000 in 2011 to 150,000 in 2012, 65,000 in 2013, and 30,000 by the beginning of 2014, and remains at 30,000 through 2020. Requires the President, in preparing such report, to make estimates and projections through at least FY2020, and to take into account specified cost factors.

Minority National Security Scholarship Act of 2002 - Directs the Secretary of Education to establish a program to: (1) award scholarships to minority undergraduate and graduate students to enable such students to study, for at least one academic semester, in foreign countries that are critical countries; (2) award fellowships to minority graduate students to enable such students to pursue education in the United States in the disciplines of foreign languages, area studies, and other international fields that are critical to U.S. national security; and (3) award grants to institutions of higher education to enable such institutions to establish, operate, or improve programs in foreign languages, area studies, and other international fields that are critical to U.S. national security.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 6, 2017. ANCSA Unrecognized Community Landless Community Authorization Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to authorize certain Native villages in Alaska to organize as Urban Corporations and to receive specified settlement land. The Native residents of each of the Native Villages of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell may organize as Urban Corporations and receive specified settlement stock. The Department of the Interior shall enroll to each of the Urban Corporations for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell those individual Natives who enrolled under the Act to the Native Villages of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell as of March 30, 1973. Each Native who is enrolled to an Urban Corporation for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell shall receive 100 shares of Settlement Stock in the respective Urban Corporation. If a Native received shares in the Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska through inheritance from a Native who originally enrolled to the Native Village of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell and the decedent Native was not a shareholder in a Village or Urban Corporation, the Native shall

Child Care Lending Pilot Act of 2003 - Amends the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 to allow proceeds of loans made through the Small Business Administration (SBA) to be used by the borrower to assist, in addition to other eligible small business concerns, small, non-profit child care businesses, provided that: (1) the loan will be used for a sound business purpose approved by the SBA; and (2) each such business receiving financial assistance meets all of the same eligibility requirements applicable to for-profit businesses under the Act, except for status as a for-profit business. Directs the SBA Administrator to report on the implementation of the child care business loan program. Directs the Comptroller General to report to specified congressional committees on the child care business loan program. Terminates the authority for such loans on September 30, 2006.

Understanding the True Cost of College Act of 2012 - Amends the Higher Education Opportunity Act and the Higher Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to develop a standard format for financial aid offer forms based on recommendations from representatives of students, students\\' families, institutions of higher education, secondary school and postsecondary counselors, and nonprofit consumer groups.<n><n>Requires such form to include, in a consumer-friendly manner, specified details and disclosures regarding: (1) the cost of attendance based on the most current costs for the academic period covered by the financial aid offer form; (2) the amount of financial aid that a student does not have to repay, including a disclosure that the aid does not have to be repaid; (3) the net amount that the student, or the student\\'s family on behalf of the student, will have to pay for the institution for such academic period; (4) work study assistance; (5) the types and amounts of loans under title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 that the institution recommends for the student for such period, a disclosure that such loans have to be repaid, a clear use of the word loan" to describe the recommended loan amounts, the interest rates, fees, the expected monthly repayment amounts assuming a 10-year repayment plan, and"

Flexible Refinancing for American Families Act of 2012 - Directs the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) (government sponsored enterprises or GSEs) each to carry out a program to provide for the refinancing of qualified mortgages on single-family housing they own or guarantee through a refinancing mortgage having a 50-year term, and for the purchase of and securitization of such refinancing mortgages. Defines qualified mortgage" as an existing first mortgage: (1) made for purchase of, or refinancing another first mortgage on, a one- to four-family dwelling occupied by the mortgagor as his or her principal residence; (2) owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac; and (3) originated on or before this Act\\'s enactment."
Older Workers' Rights Restoration Act of 2001 - Amends the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1975 to  waive the State's immunity from suit for discrimination claims arising under such Act.

Rural Veterans Health Care Access Act of 2007 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to establish and carry out a pilot program to provide mental health counseling to eligible veterans at facilities other than medical facilities of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) if: (1) served on active duty in support of a contingency operation; (2) is eligible to receive hospital care and medical services; (3) has been diagnosed with a mental health condition for which a certified mental health provider has recommended the veteran receive counseling; and (4) resides at least 30 miles from a VA medical facility that employs a full-time mental health professional. Outlines provisions concerning vouchers.

Expand School Meals Act of 2009 - Amends the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act to raise the eligibility level for free meals under the school lunch and breakfast programs to 185% of the poverty level. (Currently it is set at 130%.) Increases the income guidelines for determining eligibility at that level to 185% of the poverty level.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on December 7, 2005. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Chesapeake Bay Program Reauthorization and Environmental Accountability Act of 2005 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to: (1) complete an implementation plan for achieving the nutrient and sediment reduction goals described in the agreement entered into by the Chesapeake Executive Council entitled Chesapeake 2000" dated June 28, 2000; (2) publish and widely circulate annually a tributary health report card to evaluate progress, during the preceding year, and overall progress made in achieving and maintaining nutrient and sediment reduction goals for each major tributary of the Chesapeake Bay and each separable segment of such a tributary; and (3) submit to the Administrator information for each jurisdictional tributary strategy basin located in the states of Delaware, Maryland, New York, Pennsylvania, Virginia, West Virginia, and the District of Columbia describing for each preceding year the nutrient and sediment cap load allocation of such basin, the principal sources of nutrients and sediment in such basin, and the technologies or practices used to achieve reductions. Requires the Inspector General of EPA to audit and report to Congress on the progress made by states in achieving the nutrient and sediment"

Requires new discretionary budget authority for certain Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) medical care accounts, provided in an appropriations Act, to be made available for the fiscal year involved and to include new budget authority first available after the end of such fiscal year for the subsequent fiscal year. Directs the Comptroller General to study the adequacy and accuracy of the budget projections made by the Enrollee Health Care Projection Model, or its equivalent, for the purpose of estimating and projecting VA health care expenditures.

(Sec. 1) This bill directs the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to report to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and Congress on: (1) the filing requirements for telecommunications carriers or service providers that receive universal service support under specified provisions of the Communications Act of 1934, and (2) the financial impact of those requirements on those carriers participating in a Universal Service Fund program. The FCC is required to: (1) initiate a rulemaking to consolidate redundant filing requirements for covered carriers participating in a Fund program; and (2) seek comment on, and consider whether the benefit of each recommendation is outweighed by any potential increased risk of waste, fraud, and abuse in the program affected by the recommendation.

State and Local Government Economic Empowerment Act - Entitles each State, county, incorporated municipality, and Indian tribe to obtain a loan, unless such government is delinquent in repaying a prior loan, as long as the total amount of money entitled to borrow does not exceed the product of: (1) the resident population in the case of a State, $200; (2) a county in the case of an incorporated municipality, $200; and (3) an Indian tribe, $1,000.Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to issue interest-free loans to such government units if the Secretary obtains assurances that the proceeds of such loan will be used solely for the purpose of funding capital projects of such units, including the construction of or improvements to streets, highways, bridges, and tunnels, waste water and sewer systems, and infrastructure and other public facilities. Requires that: (1) loans be disbursed by the Secretary in a lump sum for the full amount of the loan or if partial disbursements are appropriate in order to accommodate a greater number of loan requests; and (2) the period to maturity of any loan be the estimated number of years of the useful life of the infrastructure installation (if any) which is financed by the loan, but be a minimum of ten years and a maximum of 30 years.Sets forth provisions regarding

Methamphetamine Awareness and Prevention Act of 2006 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to establish within the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration the Methamphetamine Awareness and Prevention Office. Requires the Office director to establish a program to award competitive grants to eligible entities for the establishment and implementation of successful methamphetamine education and awareness campaigns to reduce the spread of methamphetamine use.

Makes eligible for Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) health care for any disability, notwithstanding insufficient medical evidence to conclude that such disability is attributable to duty, members of the Armed Forces who are performing duty in response to a disaster or emergency declaration between August 28, 2005, and December 31, 2005, in an area affected by Hurricane Katrina or Hurricane Rita, in any county designated by the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) as a federal disaster county for individual or public assistance as the result of such hurricanes, if there is insufficient medical evidence to conclude that such disability is attributable to such duty. Prohibits such hospital care, medical services, and nursing home care with respect to a disability found to have resulted from a cause other than duty.

Suburban and Community Forestry and Open Space Initiative Act of 2001 - Amends the Cooperative Forestry Assistance Act of 1978 to establish within the Forest Service the Suburban and Community Forestry and Open Space Initiative, which shall provide cost-share grants to States or nonprofit organizations, including Indian tribes, to preserve private forest land or contain suburban sprawl.

Hunt Unrestricted on National Treasures Act or the HUNT Act This bill requires each head of a federal public land management agency (the National Park Service, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, the Forest Service, and the Bureau of Land Management) to make available to the public on the agency website an annual report that includes: a list of the location and acreage of land under the agency's jurisdiction on which the public is allowed to hunt, fish, or use the land for other recreational purposes; a list of the locations and acreage on land that the agency determines have significant potential for use for hunting, fishing, and other recreational purposes; and a plan for land that identifies how public access and egress could reasonably be provided to the legal boundaries of the land in a manner that minimizes the impact on wildlife habitat and water quality, specifies actions recommended to secure access and egress, and is consistent with the travel management plan in effect on such land. The bill amends the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965 to provide funding for public access to federal land for recreational purposes.

North Korean Counterterrorism and Nonproliferation Act - States that certain restrictions against the government of North Korea imposed by reason of its support of international terrorism shall remain in effect, unless the President certifies to Congress that North Korea: (1) is no longer engaged in the illegal transfer of missile or nuclear technology, particularly to the governments of Iran, Syria, or any other country; (2) is no longer engaged in training, harboring, supplying, financing, or supporting in any way the governments of Hamas, Hezbollah, or the Japanese Red Army, any organization designated by the Secretary of State as a foreign terrorist organization, or any person included on the Annex to Executive Order 13224 whose property and interests in property are blocked by such order; (3) is no longer engaged in the counterfeiting of United States currency supernotes"; (4) has made inoperable Bureau No. 39 under the North Korean Workers Party headed by Kim Jong Il; (5) has released specified U.S. permanent resident Kim Dong-who was abducted by North Korean agents on the Chinese border in January 2000; (6) has released the 15 Japanese nationals recognized as abduction victims by the National Police Agency (NPA) of Japan; (7) has released an estimated 600 surviving South Korean POWs, comrades-in-arms of United States and Allied forces"

Displaced Aircraft Manufacturers Workers Relief Act of 2001 - Authorizes a petition for a certification of eligibility to apply for adjustment assistance under this Act to be filed with the Secretary of Labor by a group of workers or their certified or recognized union or other duly authorized representative. Directs the Secretary to certify a group of workers as eligible to apply for adjustment assistance under this Act if the Secretary determines that a significant number or proportion of the workers in such workers' firm or an appropriate subdivision of the firm are eligible employees.Requires the Secretary to determine, with respect to an eligible employee covered by a certification issued under this Act, whether: (1) the employee is unlikely to return to the industry involved; (2) the employee is likely to return to the employee's previous occupation in the industry; or (3) the employee is likely to return to that occupation.Requires that an eligible employee who has become totally or partially separated, or is threatened to become totally or partially separated, from employment with an aircraft manufacturer as a consequence of reductions in production as a result of a terrorist action or security measure or a closure of an airport in the United States as a result of a terrorist action or security measure be provided, in the same manner and to the same extent as an employee covered under a certification under the Trade

(Sec. 3) Requires the Administrator to: (1) transmit to Congress an analysis of the monitoring data needed for development and implementation of TMDLs, including an estimate of the cost of collecting such data; and (2) solicit comments from each State regarding the impact of such revisions on implementation and effectiveness of existing State programs. (Sec. 4) Directs the Administrator to make arrangements with the National Academy of Sciences to study the scientific bases underlying the development of TMDLs, including an evaluation of: (1) the information required to identify sources of pollutant loadings and their respective contributions to water quality impairment; (2) the information required to allocate reductions in pollutant loadings among sources; and (3) whether such information is available for use by States. Requires the Academy to provide appropriate Federal, State, and public and private sector interests an opportunity to review and submit written comments on the report. Authorizes appropriations.(Sec. 5) Requires the Administrator, with respect to such revisions, to: (1) prepare a written statement containing specified information, including an assumption that accurately reflects the water quality data currently available for the development and implementation of TMDLs and conduct a sensitivity analysis to assess the effect of different assumptions on the analyses; (2) quantify benefits using the same baseline assumptions used to quantify costs; and (3) conduct such

Education for Democracy Act - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to award grants to, or enter into contracts with, the Center for Civic Education to carry out civic and economic education activities. <n>Requires the Citizen and the Constitution program to: (1) continue and expand its educational activities relating to the Constitution and of the United States; and (2) enhance student attainment of challenging content standards in civics and government. Requires such program to provide: (1) a course of instruction on the basic principles of our Nation's constitutional democracy and the history of the Constitution of the United States and the Bill of Rights; (2) at the request of a participating school, school and community, simulated congressional hearings following the course of study; and (3) such other educational activities as the Secretary may award. <n>Directs the Center to award grants to, and enter into contracts with, the National Council on Economic Education to carry out economic education activities. <n>Directs the Secretary to use not more than 50 percent of the amount appropriated for each fiscal year to carry out economic education activities. <n>Requires the Center to use such funds to carry out The Citizen and the Constitution program.

Angeles and San Bernardino National Forests Protection Act - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to continue to administer the Angeles and San Bernardino National Forests in California as provided under the California Wilderness Act of 1984. Directs the Secretary to continue to administer such Areas as provided under the California Wilderness Act of 1984. Expands the boundaries of such Areas. Prohibits anything in this Act from: (1) establishing a protective perimeter or buffer zone around the Areas; or (2) restricting an activity from being conducted outside of such Areas.

American Indian Equal Justice Act - Amends the Federal judicial code to grant the district courts of the United States original jurisdiction in any civil action or claim against an Indian tribe for which the matter in controversy arises under the Constitution, laws, or treaties of the United States. Declares that a State may bring an action in a U.S. district court to enforce this Act. Declares that the district courts shall have jurisdiction of civil actions in claims against an Indian tribe for money damages, accruing on or after this Act's enactment for injury or loss of property, personal injury, or death caused by the negligent or wrongful act or omission of an Indian tribe under circumstances in which the Indian tribe is liable for the acts or omissions of its members.

FHA Improvement Act of 1994 - Amends the National Housing Act to revise single family housing mortgage insurance program provisions regarding: (1) loan floor; (2) downpayment calculations and family loans; (3) mortgage insurance by mortgagees; and (4) new construction.

Helicopter Medical Services Patient Safety, Protection, and Coordination Act - Declares that nothing in Federal law shall prohibit a State from: (1) requiring medical licenses for the provision of helicopter medical services between locations within the State; or (2) prescribing regulations relating to the provision of such services if such regulations are prescribed pursuant to this Act. Declares that no State health-related regulation established pursuant to this Act shall supersede or be inconsistent with any Federal operating requirement with respect to aviation safety.Authorizes a State to prescribe regulations relating to the provision of helicopter medical services with respect to: (1) the medical qualifications and medical training of helicopter medical personnel; and (2) the obligation of providers of helicopter medical services to comply with the health planning, patient safety, and medical service requirements of the State.

Human Tissue for Transplantation Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to permit the Secretary of Health and Human Services, in order to prevent the transmission of infectious disease by the use of banked human tissue, to require that: (1) the screening of donors and tissue donated and recordkeeping by human tissue banks include records that provide a method to track tissue from a donor to a donor, taking into account the privacy interest of donors, donor families, and recipients; and (2) the Secretary prescribe requirements for the labeling, advertising, and promotion of banked human tissue by human tissue banks, including information about results from the use of such tissue according to directions or under customary and usual conditions. Authorizes the Secretary to require human tissue banks to acquire a permit for operation.

Clean Alternatives for Energy Independence Act of 2005 - Repeals provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 relating to: (1) the expensing of equipment used in refining of liquid fuels and accelerated depreciation of natural gas distribution and gathering lines; (2) the pass through of tax deductions for environmental compliance costs; (3) the small refiner exception to limitations on the oil depletion tax deduction; and (4) the two-year amortization of geological and geophysical expenditures.<n><n>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the tax credits for: (1) residential and business use of fuel cell property; and (2) alternative motor vehicles.

Airport Security Act of 2010 - Directs the Assistant Secretary of Homeland Security (Transportation Security Administration) (TSA) to establish a program to prohibit all but specified authorized individuals from possessing a firearm at a covered airport, including any individual who enters the airport, or exits public transportation at it, for air travel, meeting another individual, picking up cargo, or employment. Directs the Assistant Secretary to require airport operators to: (1) display conspicuous notices summarizing the program at each airport entrance; and (2) require law enforcement personnel to monitor the airport to prevent violations and escort air travelers who are authorized to carry a firearm.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 21, 2015. Fixed Asset Relief Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to make permanent: (1) the 100% bonus depreciation allowance for certain business property, including computer software, water utility property, and leasehold improvement property; and (2) the alternative depreciation system for listed property with limited business use. The bill defines "qualified property" to mean property to which the depreciation allowance applies (with a recovery period of 20 years or less) and which is either: (1) computer software for which the depreciation allowance is allowable without regard to the alternative depreciation system, (2) water utility property, or (3) qualified leasehold improvement property. The term excludes property to which the alternative depreciation system applies and listed property with limited business use. For sale-leasebacks of qualified property, the bill treats such property as originally placed in service not earlier than the date on which it is used under a leaseback if: (1) the property is originally placed in service by the lessor of such property, (2) the property is sold by such lessor or any subsequent purchaser within three months after the date such property was originally placed in service, or (3) the user of such property after the last sale during such three

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on March 16, 2016. (Sec. 1) This bill amends the Siletz Tribe Indian Restoration Act to authorize the Department of the Interior to accept title to any additional number of acres of real property located within the boundaries of the original 1855 Siletz Coast Reservation established by Executive Order dated November 9, 1855, comprised of land within the political boundaries of Benton, Douglas, Lane, Lincoln, Tillamook, and Yamhill Counties in Oregon, if such real property is conveyed or otherwise transferred to the United States by or on behalf of the Siletz Tribe. Interior must consider and evaluate such real property as an on-reservation acquisition and become part of the tribe's reservation. All real property taken into trust under this Act must be considered and evaluated as: (1) an on-reservation acquisition; and (2) part of the tribe's reservation. Real property taken into trust in Oregon may not be used for any gaming activity carried out under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act.

Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to carry out projects to reduce the incidence of traumatic brain injury through grants or contracts to public or nonprofit entities. Authorizes the following activities: (1) the conduct of research into identifying effective strategies for the prevention of traumatic brain injury; and (2) the implementation of public information and education programs for the prevention of such injury and for broadening the awareness of the public concerning the public health consequences of such injury. <n>(Sec. 2) Requires the National Institutes of Health research program on trauma to include the authority to award grants or contracts to public or nonprofit entities for the conduct of basic and applied research regarding traumatic brain injury. <n>(Sec. 3) Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to States for the purpose of carrying out demonstration projects to improve access to health and other services regarding traumatic brain injury. Mandates State advisory boards. Authorizes appropriations.

Social Investment and Economic Development Fund for the Americas Act of 2003 - Authorizes the President to establish a Social Investment and Economic Development Fund for the Americas to promote market-based principles, economic integration, social development, and trade in and between countries of the Americas by: (1) modernizing public-private partnerships and microenterprise development; (2) improving the quality of life and investing in human capital, specifically targeting education, health and disease prevention, and housing; (3) strengthening the rule of law; and (4) promoting peace and justice.

Poll Tape Transparency Act of 2008 - Amends the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to require states to meet certain requirements for the publication of poll tapes.<n><n>Requires the appropriate election official, under the observation of certified tabulation observers admitted to the polling place, upon the closing of the polls, to: (1) announce the vote orally, post a copy of the poll tape reflecting the totals from each voting machine upon which votes were cast in the election, and prepare and post a statement of the total number of individuals who appeared at the polling place to cast ballots; (2) ensure that each of the certified tabulation observers admitted to the polling place has full access to observe the process by which the poll tapes and statement are produced and a reasonable period of time to review the tapes and statement before the polling place is closed; (3) provide such observers with identical duplicate copies of the poll tapes and statement; and (4) display at a prominent location accessible to the public during regular business hours and in or within reasonable proximity to the polling place a copy of each poll tape and statement prepared pursuant to this Act, as well as the name of the designated voting official who entered the information and the date and time the information was entered. Requires that such information be displayed on the official public websites of the

Directs the Secretary of Energy to make incentive payments for electric energy generated and sold by a qualified hydroelectric facility for a period of ten fiscal years beginning with the fiscal year in which electric energy generated from the facility is first eligible for such payments.

Lower Yellowstone Reclamation Projects Conveyance Act - (Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary of the Interior to convey the works, facilities, and lands of the Lower Yellowstone Irrigation Project, the Intake Irrigation Project, and the Savage Unit to the Lower Yellowstone Irrigation Districts One (Montana) and Two (North Dakota), the Intake Irrigation District (Montana), and the Savage Irrigation District (Montana), respectively, pursuant to the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding (the Memorandum) reached between the Districts and the Bureau of Reclamation on November 16, 1999.States that all lands, easements, and rights-of-way that are to be conveyed under this Act shall be conveyed by quitclaim deed. Subjects such conveyances to permits, licenses, and other arrangements outstanding in third parties on, over, or across such lands, easements, and rights-of-way. States that the United States shall retain the mineral rights on the lands being conveyed, subject to the mineral rights heretofore reserved by or in favor of third parties.Directs the Secretary to transfer to the respective Districts, in accordance with and subject to the law of the State of Montana, the water rights held in part or wholly in the name of the United States that are used to serve the lands within the Districts.Requires the Districts to buy Reclamation withdrawn

Measuring the Economic Impact of Broadband Act of 2018 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Department of Commerce to conduct a biennial assessment and analysis regarding the contribution of the digital economy to the U.S. economy, including by considering: (1) the digital-enabling infrastructure that a computer network needs to exist and operate; and (2) the roles of e-commerce and digital media.

Federal Energy Price Protection Act - Makes it unlawful for any supplier to increase the price for crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates in an area covered by a presidential proclamation by an unconscionable amount for a specified period of time.<n><n>Makes such prohibition inapplicable to the extent that the increase is substantially attributable to: (1) an increase in the wholesale cost of crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates to a supplier; (2) an increase in replacement costs for crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillate sold; (3) an increase in operational costs; or (4) local, regional, national, or international market conditions.<n><n>Authorizes the President to issue an emergency proclamation when an abnormal market disruption has occurred or is reasonably expected to occur.<n><n>Empowers the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and state attorneys general to enforce this Act.<n><n>Sets forth civil penalties for violations of this Act.

Increasing Medical Oversight in the Department of Veterans Affairs Act of 2014 - Establishes within the Office of the Under Secretary for Health of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) the Office of the Medical Inspector, which shall have functions to: review the quality of health care provided to veterans by the VA and through contracts with non-VA health care providers; review offices of the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) that have an impact on the quality of health care provided to veterans and the performance of the VA in providing such care; review offices and facilities of the VHA to ensure that policies and procedures of the VA and VHA are applied consistently at all such offices and facilities; investigate systemic issues within VHA, including improper issuance of credentials and privileges to health care providers, impediments to veterans' access to health care, wait times for appointments by veterans at VA medical facilities in excess of wait-time goals, and intentional falsification by VA employees; establish temporary investigative teams to carry out reviews or investigations of complaints by a veteran, a family member, or another individual that may require a visit to a VA facility or facilities; recommend policies to promote economy and efficiency in the administration of, and to prevent and detect criminal activity, waste, abuse, and mismanagement in, VA programs

hab and Ahmed Amer Foster Care Improvement Act of 2012 - Amends part E (Foster Care and Adoption Assistance) of title IV of the Social Security Act to require states to follow specified procedures in placing a child removed from the custody of his or her parents, including notice to all adult grandparents and other adult relatives of such child, subject to exceptions due to family or domestic violence.

Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow individual and business taxpayers a tax credit for 25% of their qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures up to $5,000 for any taxable year.

Airport Streamlining Approval Process Act of 2002 - Directs the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration to take action to encourage the construction of airport capacity enhancement projects at congested airports.Directs the Secretary of Transportation to develop and implement a coordinated review process for airport capacity enhancement projects at congested airports. Requires that such process provide that all environmental reviews, analyses, opinions, permits, licenses, and approvals that must be issued or made by a Federal agency or airport sponsor for such a project will be conducted concurrently, to the maximum extent practicable, and completed within a time period established by the Secretary in cooperation with specified Federal and State agencies with respect to the project.Authorizes a State to choose to participate in such process and provide that all State agencies that have jurisdiction over environmental-related matters that may be affected by the project or be required by law to conduct an environmental-related review or analysis of the project be subject to the process.

Small Business Health Insurance Options Act of 2007 - Directs the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) to establish a pilot program to make grants to small business development centers to provide neutral and objective information and educational materials regarding health insurance options to small businesses. Directs the Administrator to select up to 20 centers to receive such grants. Sets the maximum individual grant limit at $300,000 per fiscal year.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on February 11, 2016. Federal Supervisor Training Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Office of Personnel Management to issue guidance to federal agencies on specific training programs that supervisors are required to receive in order to effectively manage, and be accountable for managing, the performance of employees. The training programs must: (1) provide training on developing and discussing relevant performance goals and objectives with the employee, communicating and discussing progress on performance goals and objectives, and conducting performance appraisals; (2) foster a work environment characterized by fairness, respect, equal opportunity, and attention paid to the merit of the work of employees; (3) effectively manage employees with unacceptable performance, including training to understand disciplinary options and procedures; (4) effectively use the probationary period to examine whether an employee has demonstrated successful performance or conduct to continue past the probationary period; (5) address reports of a hostile work environment, retaliation, or harassment; (6) meet supervisor competencies established by OPM or the employing agency; (7) collaborate with human resources employees to recruit, select, appraise, and reward employees to build a workforce based on organizational goals, budget considerations, and staffing needs; and (8) otherwise carry out the duties or responsibilities of a supervisor. Each agency shall: (1) measure the effectiveness of the

National Strategic Gasoline Reserve for Purposes of National Security Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Energy to: (1) establish a Strategic Gasoline Reserve system with a total capacity of 10 million barrels of regular unleaded gasoline; and (2) determine strategic locations for no less than three and no more than five Gasoline Reserve sites, each located in a different geographical region of the United States. Requires the Secretary, in establishing the Gasoline Reserve, to confer with the Secretary of Transportation and the Secretary of Homeland Security with respect to physical structures' security, the transportation security, and operational security.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) transmit to Congress, the Secretary of Homeland Security, and the governor of each state in which a Gasoline Reserve will be sited a plan for the transportation of the contents of the Gasoline Reserve to wholesale or retail markets in the event of an emergency sale; (2) complete the process of filling the Gasoline Reserve to a minimum of 90% within two years of submitting a transportation plan; (3) conduct an annual review of the gasoline supply to ensure the reserves in the Gasoline Reserve do not exceed their shelf life; and (4) have in place a plan for assuring that the inventory is sold and replaced in a manner that assures the integrity of the product at all times.<n><n>Instructs the

Technology Administration Authorization Act of 1995 - Authorizes appropriations to the Secretary of Commerce for the activities of the Under Secretary for Technology/Office of Technology Policy. <n>(Sec. 2) Authorizes appropriations for FY 1996 through 1998 to the Secretary for the following activities of the National Institute of Standards and Technology: (1) for Scientific and Technical Research and Services; (2) for Industrial Technology Services; and (3) for Construction of Research Facilities. <n>(Sec. 3) Amends the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to direct the Secretary to establish an Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Technology (EPSCOT) to award grants on a competitive and peer-reviewed basis to qualified institutions in eligible States. Requires the Secretary, in evaluating a grant application under EPSCOT, to consider: (1) the application's merit and relevance to Institute mission; (2) the potential for the grant to serve as a catalyst to enhance the ability of researchers in the State to become more competitive for regular civilian research funding; (3) the potential for the grant to improve the environment for science, mathematics, and engineering education in the State; and (4) the need to assure the maximum distribution of grants among eligible States. Requires the Secretary to endeavor, where appropriate, to supplement grants for fellowships, traineeships, equipment, or instrumentation as practicable

Authorizes the registration of a trade dress which functions as a mark without the need to show that it has become distinctive if the relevant public is likely to identify the source of the product or service by reference to the subject matter claimed as trade dress. Provides that, in determining whether the relevant public is likely to identify the source of the product or service by reference to the subject matter claimed as trade dress, factors shall include: (1) whether the trade dress is unique or unusual in the particular field to which the subject matter pertains; (2) whether the trade dress comprises a common basic shape or design; (3) whether the trade dress is a mere refinement of commonly adopted and well known forms of ornamentation for that particular class of goods or services viewed by the public as a dress or ornamentation for the goods or services; and (4) whether the dress is capable of creating a commercial impression distinct from any accompanying words.<n>Revises the definition of mark" to include any trademark, service mark, collective mark, or certification mark, including any trademark, service mark, collective mark, or certification mark that includes any symbol, name, word, slogan, phrase, surname, geographical name, numeral, device, color, label, any matter that is not functional, but that must be capable distinguishing the applicant"

Requires the Secretary to prescribe regulations requiring operators of skill games to: (1) ensure that an individual participant is physically located in a jurisdiction that does not bar participation in the particular Internet games of skill in which the individual participates at the time of deposit or wagering; (2) ensure that all taxes relating to Internet games of skill are collected as required by the Secretary or the Secretary; and (3) protect the privacy and security of any person engaged in Internet games of skill. Provides that no provision of this Act, or any other provision of law, shall be construed as prohibiting the acceptance of both sports and non-sports betting through a communications device.

. Sfish Canyon and Bismarck Lake Land Exchange Act (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Department of Agriculture (USDA), if South Dakota conveys four parcels of land known as the "Bismarck Lake Area" in the Black Hills National Forest to USDA, to convey to South Dakota approximately 1,468 acres of federal land in the Forest (known as the "Sfish Canyon Area") and approximately 524 acres of non-federal land in the Forest (known as the "Bismarck Lake Area"). The bill requires USDA and South Dakota to select an appraiser to conduct appraisals of the federal and non-federal lands. The costs of the land exchange shall be paid by South Dakota. If the final appraised value of the federal lands exceeds the final appraised value of the non-federal lands, USDA shall complete any environmental analysis required under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969.
