Troubled Asset Relief Program Enhancement Act - Amends the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 to require that the Comptroller General (GAO) have access, upon request, to specified information, data, schedules, books, accounts, financial records, reports, files, electronic communications, or other papers, things, or property belonging to or in use by the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP), any entity established by the Secretary of the Treasury, or any entity participating in a TARP program, and to the officers, employees, directors, independent public accountants, financial advisors, and all other agents and representatives thereof, at such time as the Comptroller General may request. Requires: (1) each contract, term sheet, or other agreement between the Secretary or the TARP and an entity participating in a TARP program to provide for access by the Comptroller General; and (2) the Comptroller General to verify transactions with the balances or securities held by, among others, depositories, fiscal agents, and custodians.

Agricultural Equity Act of 1995 - Expresses the sense of the Congress that: (1) the continuation of significant Federal budgetary deficits harms U.S. economic well-being and is detrimental to the development of sound, long-term agricultural policy; (2) agricultural price support and production adjustment programs are necessary for the continued economic health of U.S. agriculture, which must compete in international markets against subsidized foreign competition; and (3) such programs should be implemented in a manner consistent with the primary goal of the concurrent resolution on the budget for FY 1996 to end Federal budget deficits. <n>Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to make nonrecourse loans and deficiency payments for the 1996 through 2002 crops of rice, upland cotton, feed grains, wheat, and oilseeds.

Amends the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (PRWORA) to make permanent resident alien children eligible for Medicaid. <n>Extends the eligibility period for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) and Medicaid (SSA title XIX) benefits for refugees and asylees from five to seven years. <n>Makes blind or disabled aliens who were admitted to the United States before attaining the age of 18 (and who were blind or disabled for whom the onset of blindness or disability occurred) eligible for SSI and Medicaid, subject to specified requirements. <n>Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide for expedited removal of certain permanent resident alien children who are under 19 years old.

Cardiac Arrest Survival Act of 1999- Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to: (1) assist in providing for an improvement in the survival rates of individuals who experience cardiac arrest in Federal buildings by publishing in the Federal Register for public comment the recommendations of the Secretary with respect to placing automatic external defibrillators in such buildings; and (2) in addition assist Federal agencies in implementing programs for such placement. Requires Federal agency heads that occupy Federal buildings that meet specified criteria to submit to the Secretary an assessment of their ability to meet such goals. Requires the Secretary to publish, as part of such recommendations, recommendations for: (1) implementing appropriate nationally recognized training courses in performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation and the use of automatic external defibrillators; and (2) ensuring direct involvement of a licensed medical professional and coordination with local emergency medical services in the oversight of training and notification of incidents of the use of such defibrillators.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) United States Commission on International Religious Freedom Reform and Reauthorization Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) Amends the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 to provide that, at the first meeting of the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom (USCIRF) after May 30, 2015, a majority of the Members of USCIRF shall elect as: (1) Chair a Commissioner appointed by an elected official of the political party that is not the political party of the President, and (2) Vice Chair a Commissioner appointed by an elected official of the political party that is not the political party of the President. Directs USCIRF, at the first meeting after May 30, 2016, to elect: (1) Chair a Commissioner appointed by an elected official of the political party that is not the political party of the President, and (2) Vice Chair a Commissioner appointed by an elected official of the political party that is not the political party of the President. Provides that positions of Chair and Vice Chair shall continue to rotate on an annual basis between Commissioners appointed by elected officials of each political party. (Sec. 3) Requires USCIRF to give advance notice of all USCIRF meetings and may attend all USCIRF meetings as a non-voting Member

Wildlife Disease Emergency Act of 2010 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with governors of potentially affected states, to declare a wildlife disease emergency for any disease occurring within the United States or, if outside the United States, with the potential to enter the United States. Requires the Secretary, in making such a declaration, to consider: (1) the level of threat the disease poses to affected wildlife populations; (2) the relative strength of the contagion and spread of the disease; (3) the observed rate of morbidity or mortality of the disease; and (4) priority of affected species or ecosystems, including species listed under the Endangered Species Act of 1973, species protected by the Migratory Bird Treaty Act, Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972, or other federal statutes, species and habitats identified as priorities through the National Fish and Wildlife Climate Adaptation Plan or other federal, state or local laws, regulations, and conservation plans, and wildlife located on federal lands.<n><n>Establishes in the Treasury a Wildlife Disease Emergency Fund. Allows the Secretary to establish a Wildlife Disease Committee to assist in increasing U.S. preparedness to address emerging wildlife diseases.

Temporary Worker Registration and Visa Act of 2005 - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide for the issuance of temporary worker visas to certain undocumented workers who have been continuously unlawfully present in the United States from January 1, 2005, and who are not known to officials of the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement at any time prior to filing the registration application.

American Cures Act This bill amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 to require certain adjustments to discretionary spending limits in FY2016-FY2021 to accommodate increases in appropriations for agencies that perform biomedical research, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the Department of Defense health program, and the Department of Veterans Affairs medical and prosthetics research program.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 9, 2013. United States-Israel Strategic Partnership Act of 2013 - (Sec. 4) Expresses the sense of Congress that Israel is a major strategic partner. (Sec. 5) Amends the Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2005 to extend authority to transfer certain obsolete or surplus Department of Defense (DOD) items to Israel. Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to extend authority to make additions to foreign-based defense stockpiles for use as war reserve stocks through FY2015. (Sec. 6) Directs the Secretary of Commerce to take steps to include Israel in the list of countries eligible for the strategic trade authorization exception to the requirement for a license for the export, reexport, or in-country transfer of an item subject to export controls. (Sec. 7) Authorizes the President to carry out United States-Israel cooperative activities and to provide assistance promoting cooperation in the fields of energy, water, homeland security, and alternative fuel technologies.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) American Livestock Protection and Ranching Opportunity Act This bill amends the Animal Health Protection Act to prohibit the importation of fresh meat and meat products from a country whose foot-and-mouth disease has not been vaccinated. (Currently, the Department of Agriculture [USDA] may allow importation of fresh meat and meat products from a country if it certifies that it does not have such disease.) The bill also amends the Agricultural Research, Extension, and Education Reform Act of 1998 to establish a livestock disease initiative of competitive grants for research and development relating to brucellosis. Priority in awarding grants shall be given to research and development relating to brucellosis, tuberculosis, and other bovine diseases in livestock covered by a high-priority research and extension initiative authorized under the Food Security Act of 1990.

Survivors' and Dependents' Educational Assistance Adjustment Act of 2002 - Increases the rates of educational assistance payable to veterans and their dependents under the Montgomery GI Bill for months occurring during FY 2003 and 2004. Increases similarly the rates for: (1) full-time, three-quarter-time, or half-time courses; and (2) apprenticeship training.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 9, 2014. Strengthening Entrepreneurs' Economic Development Act of 2013 - Directs the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) to: (1) establish and carry out a loan program under which a small business that has less than 20 employees may apply to the Administrator for a loan of up to $150,000, (2) issue guidance regarding prudent underwriting standards that must be used for such loans, (3) establish a process under which the Administrator makes available to lenders each loan application submitted for the purpose of such lenders originating, underwriting, closing, and servicing the loan for which the applicant applied, and (4) consider any such loan for origination, underwriting, closing, and servicing by the SBA within 10 business days if the lender does not agree to do so. Directs the Administrator to offer to sell loans made by the SBA under the program through the semi-annual public solicitation (in the Federal Register and in other media) of offers to purchase. Prohibits the Administrator from selling any loan under the program for less than 90% of the net present value of the loan, as determined and certified by a qualified third party. Requires the Administrator to charge a fee of up to 1% for each loan approved in excess of $2 million for which

Amends the Federal Law Enforcement Pay Reform Act of 1990 to revise the special pay adjustments for (percentage differentials payable to) Federal law enforcement officers in specified consolidated metropolitan statistical areas. Includes Capitol Police as law enforcement officers under such Act. <n>Directs the Office of Personnel Management to study and report to the Congress on the need for, and potential benefits to be derived from, the establishment of a separate pay, evaluation, and promotion system for Federal law enforcement officers. Requires the Office to: (1) implement a demonstration project to determine whether such a system would result in improved Federal personnel management; and (2) report its findings and recommendations to the Congress.

Durham Woods Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1995- Amends Federal pipeline safety law to require inspections of gas pipeline facilities in high-density population areas at least once every seven years. Directs the Secretary of Transportation (Secretary) to prescribe regulations requiring that each owner or operator of a gas transmission pipeline facility establish: (1) a program for observing from the air, or inspecting from the ground, at least once every month, the surface conditions on and adjacent to the right-of-way of all such facilities for indications of leaks, construction, and other circumstances affecting safety or operation; and (2) place line markers at suitable intervals along the rights-of-way of all such facilities, unless such placement is impractical. <n>Increases penalties for pipeline facility damage reporting. <n>Directs the Secretary to make grants to States for the promotion of public awareness of the dangers of excavating near pipeline facilities by advertising in the media and other means. <n>Directs the Secretary to conduct a comprehensive study on the safety of all gas transmission pipeline facilities in New Jersey. Requires the Secretary to make grants to States for the promotion of public awareness of the dangers of excavating near pipeline facilities.

Oil Independence, Limiting Subsidies, and Accelerating Vehicle Efficiency (OILSAVE) Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for the purchase of a new qualified fuel-efficient motor vehicle. Defines new qualified fuel-efficient motor vehicle" as a passenger automobile with a fuel economy rating of not less than 34.5 miles per gallon or a light truck with a 27.5 miles per gallon rating which are manufactured for model years 2007-2011."

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on June 17, 2015. Improving Regulatory Transparency for New Medical Therapies Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and the Public Health Service Act to delay the effective dates for Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval of certain new drug applications and biological products until the interim final rule controlling the Controlled Substances Act is issued. The interim final rule controlling the Controlled Substances Act must be issued within 90 days after the Secretary of Health and Human Services gives notice to the sponsor of a drug, biological product, or animal drug that the Secretary intends to issue a scientific and medical evaluation and recommend controls. Applications for these drugs or products may provide notice to the sponsor that the Secretary intends to issue a scientific and medical evaluation and recommend controls, but if the Secretary does not issue the rule before the date of approval for the drug or product, the application or product may not be approved until the later of: (1) the date an application is approved, or (2) the date of issuance of the interim final rule controlling the drug.

Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Security Authorization Act of 2011 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) to maintain, and revise as necessary, regulations to protect chemical facilities against terrorism and potential terrorist attacks, including: (1) risk-based performance standards for chemical facility security; (2) requirements for chemical facility security vulnerability assessments; and (3) requirements for the development and implementation of chemical facility site security plans.<n><n>Requires such regulations to apply to any chemical facility that the Secretary determines presents a high level of security risk with respect to acts of terrorism, except that the Secretary may not apply such regulations to: (1) any facility owned or operated by the Department of Defense (DOD), (2) any facility owned or operated by the Department of Energy (DOE), (3) any facility subject to regulation by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC), (4) a public water system, or (5) a treatment works.

Notch Fairness Act of 1996 - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to revise the formula for the computation of minimum Old Age Insurance benefits for individuals who reached age 65 in or after 1979 and to whom applies the 15-year transition period for the changes in benefit computation rules enacted in the Social Security Amendments of 1977. <n>Sets forth a schedule of additional benefit increases for such beneficiaries (and related beneficiaries), with percentages declining from 55 percent to five percent and keyed to the year an individual became eligible for such benefits between 1979 and 1988. <n>Allows such beneficiaries, in the alternative, to receive lump sum payments over four years totaling $5,000.

Voluntary Certification Program Act of 2014 - Amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to require the Secretary of Energy (DOE) and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to rely on voluntary certification programs for certifying compliance with energy conservation standards and Energy Star specifications for consumer products and industrial equipment. Defines "basic model group" to mean a set of models that share characteristics that allow the performance of one model to be generally representative of the performance of other models within the group and in which the group does not necessarily have to share discrete performance. Directs the Secretary and the Administrator, for the purpose of testing to verify the performance rating of, or receiving test reports from manufacturers certifying compliance with energy conservation standards and Energy Star specifications, to rely on such programs that: are nationally recognized; maintain a publicly available list of all certified products and equipment; annually test not less than 10% and not more than 30% of the basic model group of a program participant; require the changing of the performance rating or removal of a product or equipment from the program if verification testing determines that the performance rating does not meet the levels the manufacturer has certified to the Secretary; require the qualification of new participants in the program through testing and production test reports; allow for challenge testing products and

Affordable Housing Preservation and Revitalization Act of 2009 - Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to direct the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to ensure that funds in the residual receipts account of an eligible multifamily housing property are transferred, at the time of a qualified sale or exchange, to preservation entities to facilitate the transfer of multifamily housing projects with expiring housing assistance payments contracts to such entities by allowing expanded access to existing residual receipts to assist with the acquisition and rehabilitation of the project.

Health Care Access for Small Businesses Act of 2003 - Amends title XXI (State Children's Health Insurance Program) (SCHIP) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration, to promulgate regulations for the certification of three-share (three-way health insurance premium sharing between employer, employee, and the community) programs. Directs the Administrator to require a three-share program to: (1) be either a nonprofit or local governmental entity; (2) define a region in which the program will provide services; (3) have the capacity to carry out administrative functions of managing health plans; and (4) have community involvement.Authorizes the Administrator to award startup grants to eligible entities to establish three-share programs.

District of Columbia Government Improvement and Efficiency Act of 1996 - Amends Federal law to reduce the minimum number of members of the Board of Trustees of the American University to 25 (currently 20). <n>(Sec. 3) Amends the Service Contract Act of 1965 to repeal the requirement that any contract between the District of Columbia and the Bureau of Prisons provide for specified reimbursements to the District of Columbia for the cost of the care and custody of District of Columbia convicts in any Federal penitentiary during the five-year period beginning October 1, 1996. <n>(Sec. 4) Amends the District of Columbia Self-Government and Governmental Reorganization Act to authorize the Mayor and the Director of the Bureau of Prisons to enter into an agreement waiving the requirements of a prior sentence or establishing an alternative amount to be charged against the District for such convicts, so long as the Director provides notice of the intent to enter into the agreement to the House and Senate Appropriations Committees not later than 15 days before entering into it. <n>(Sec. 5) Amends the District of Columbia Self-Government and Governmental Reorganization Act, 1996 to exempt specified contracts entered into by the Washington Convention Center Authority, the District of Columbia Water and Sewer Authority, and the highway improvement project carried out

Liberian Refugee Immigration Fairness Act of 2009 - Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) to adjust the status of Liberian nationals who have been continuously present in the United States from January 1, 2009, through the date of application for adjustment (or the spouse, child, or unmarried son or daughter of such aliens) if: (1) application is made before April 1, 2011; and (2) the alien is otherwise eligible for an immigrant visa and admissible as a permanent resident, except that certain specified grounds of inadmissibility do not apply.

Medicare Drug Savings Through Choice Act of 2007 - Amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to offer a Medicare operated prescription drug plan in addition to any plans offered under Medicare part D. Allows the plan to offer supplemental prescription drug coverage in the same manner as other qualified prescription drug coverage by other prescription drug plans.

Children's Express Lane to Health Coverage Act of 2003 - Amends titles XIX (Medicaid) and XXI (State Children's Health Insurance) (SCHIP) of the Social Security Act to give States the option to provide for simplified determinations of a child's financial eligibility for medical assistance under Medicaid or SCHIP.

Worker Rights and Labor Standards Trade Act of 1994 - Declares that it shall be a principal objective of the United States in trade negotiations to secure the recognition of fundamental worker rights and fair labor standards under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the Revised Charter of the Organization of American States, and other specified international agreements. Declares that it shall be a principal objective of the United States in trade negotiations to secure the recognition of fundamental worker rights and fair labor standards under GATT, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, and other specified international agreements. Declares that it shall be a principal objective of the United States in trade negotiations to secure the recognition of fundamental worker rights and fair labor standards under GATT, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, and other specified international agreements.

State Prescription Drug Discount Act of 2002 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to require a manufacturer of drugs and biologicals to enter into an agreement with the State to make rebate payments for drugs covered by a State prescription drug discount program in the same amounts as are paid by the manufacturer to the State for such drugs under a rebate agreement. Defines State prescription drug discount program" as a State program under which, with respect to a rebate period, not less than the amount equal to 95 percent of all the rebates paid to the State under agreements entered into under this Act during such period is provided to eligible State residents in the form of discounted prices for the purchase of outpatient prescription drugs."

Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1998 - Establishes the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site, South Dakota, as a unit of the National Park System. <n>Requires the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a general management plan for the Site and to consider coordinating or consolidating appropriate administrative, management, and personnel functions with Badlands National Park. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Independent Commission on Medicare <n> Title II: Controling outlays under Medicare <n> Title III: Bipartisan Commission on Medicare <n> Title IV: Miscellaneous Provisions <n>Spending Control and Budget Control Act of 1995 - <n>Title I: Independent Commission on Medicare<n> - Directs the Independent Commission on Medicare to submit to the Congress recommendations for methods to control outlays under the Medicare program for FY 1997. <n>Title II: Controling outlays under Medicare<n> - Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 (Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act) to provide for the sequestration of Medicare outlays if the Congress has not enacted a joint resolution approving the Commission's recommendations. <n>Requires the President to: (1) reduce payments under Medicare by a uniform percentage sufficient to reduce 50 percent of the estimated Medicare outlays; and (2) increase premiums, deductibles, copayments, and coinsurance required to be paid under Medicare by a uniform percentage sufficient to reduce 50 percent of the Medicare outlays. Applies such sequestrations with respect to discretionary appropriations and sequestrations under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act.

Theodore Roosevelt Wildlife Legacy Act of 1997 - Establishes as the overall mission of the National Wildlife Refuge System the conservation and management of fish, wildlife, and plants of the United States for the benefit of present and future generations. <n>(Sec. 4) Directs the Secretary of the Interior to: (1) ensure that the mission and purposes of the System are carried out (except that if a conflict exists between a primary purpose of a refuge and any purpose of the System, the conflict shall be resolved in a manner that first fulfills the primary purpose of the refuge and also achieves the purposes of the System); (2) ensure that opportunities for specified uses that are consistent with the mission and purposes of the System receive priority attention in planning and management within the System; (3) plan, propose, and direct expansion of the System to accomplish such mission and purposes and to contribute to the conservation of U.S. ecosystems; and (4) inventory and monitor the status and trends of fish, wildlife, and plants in each National Wildlife Refuge. <n>(Sec. 5) Prohibits the Secretary from initiating or permitting a new use of a National Wildlife Refuge, expanding, renewing, or extending an existing allowed use unless the Secretary determines that such use is compatible with the primary purposes of the refuge and the purposes of

Immigrant Labor Policy Review Act - Establishes the High Level Commission on Immigrant Labor Policy to study and report to the Congress on the interactions between Federal immigration policy and the U.S. labor markets.

Government Shutdown Prevention Act - Provides for automatic continuing appropriations if any regular appropriation for a fiscal year (or, if applicable, for each fiscal year in a biennium) does not become law before the beginning of such fiscal year, or a joint resolution making continuing appropriations is not in effect. Appropriates amounts necessary to continue any project or activity for which funds were provided in the preceding fiscal year: (1) in the corresponding regular appropriation Act for such preceding fiscal year; or (2) if such legislation did not become law, then in the joint resolution making continuing appropriations for such preceding fiscal year. Requires the appropriations and funds made available, and authority granted, for any fiscal year for a project or activity to be available for the period beginning with the first day of a lapse in appropriations and ending with the earlier of: (1) the date on which the applicable regular appropriation bill for such fiscal year becomes law (whether or not such law provides for such project or activity), or a continuing resolution making appropriations becomes law, as the case may be; or (2) the last day of such fiscal year.

International Megan\\'s Law to Prevent Demand for Child Sex Trafficking Act - Establishes the Angel Watch Center within the Department of Justice (DOJ) to notify federal, state, and local law enforcement officials when a child-sex offender: (1) is traveling abroad and engages in sexual activity with a child in that country; and (2) in the United States, is a child-sex offender convicted of a child-sex offense. Defines child-sex offense" to include certain offenses, including sexual conduct involving a minor, or the use of the Internet to facilitate or attempt such conduct. Directs the Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of State, to establish a process under which a child-sex offender convicted of a child-sex offense who is traveling abroad and engages in sexual activity with a child in that country will be notified by DOJ of his or her arrival in the United States. Requires: (1) a child-sex offender who is convicted of a child-sex offense in the United States to be notified by DOJ of his or her arrival in the United States; and (2) a child-sex offender who is convicted of an offense in a foreign country to be notified by the foreign government of his or her arrival in"

Agricultural Credit Expansion Act This bill amends the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act to modify the Department of Agriculture (USDA) farm credit program. The bill modifies the eligibility rules for farm ownership and operating loans, conservation loans, and direct and counter-cyclical loans with respect to limited liability companies and other legal entities.

Domestic Violence Prevention, Education, and Awareness Act - Directs the Attorney General, acting through the Violence Against Women Office, to make grants to public or private nonprofit entities, States, and Indian tribes and tribal organizations to carry out public information campaigns for the purpose of educating racial and ethnic minority communities and immigrant communities about domestic violence, including its effects, methods of preventing or reducing it, and available services.

Department of Energy High Energy and Nuclear Physics Authorization Act of 1994 - Authorizes appropriations for FY 1996 through 1999 to the Secretary of Energy for certain Department of Energy high energy physics and nuclear physics activities, including funds for: (1) preparation for decontamination and decommissioning of the Los Alamos Meson Physics Facility; and (2) operation of the Los Alamos Meson Physics Facility. <n>Prohibits the expenditure of funds authorized in this Act for any: (1) Department high energy and nuclear physics facility construction project, with total project expenditures projected to exceed $100 million; or (2) Department construction project with total project expenditures projected to be in excess of $100 million, unless funds are specifically authorized in an Act that is not an appropriations Act. <n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) enter into negotiations with representatives of the European Organization for Nuclear Research concerning U.S. participation in the planning and construction of the Large Hadron Collider project at Geneva, Switzerland; and (2) transmit to specified congressional committees a plan for Department operations of high energy and nuclear physics activities as adjusted to reflect the amounts appropriated for such purposes by this Act. <n>Requires the Secretary to contract with an independent organization to review the governance of all elements of the Department's departmental high energy and nuclear physics programs.

Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), the Internal Revenue Code, and the Public Health Service Act to eliminate: (1) the 18-month limitation on continuation coverage under the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA) and the 24-month limitation on continuation coverage under the Public Health Service Act (PHSA); and (2) the increase in the monthly premium permitted for additional coverage under IRC and PHSA.

Alternative Fuel Vehicles Intermodal Transportation Act - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to establish a competitive grant program to assist states, localities, and governmental authorities to purchase, operate, and facilitate the use of alternative fuel vehicles in linked transportation systems. Defines alternative fuel vehicle" to mean a motor vehicle that is powered by: (1) electricity, including that supplied by a fuel cell that is not powered by gasoline or diesel; (2) liquefied natural gas; (3) compressed natural gas; (4) liquefied petroleum gas; (5) hydrogen; or (6) methanol at no less than 85% by volume."

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 12, 2011. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Truck Safety Act - (Sec. 2) Amends federal transportation law to increase the minimum level of financial responsibility for commercial motor vehicles and motor vehicle owners and operators to $1.5 million (currently $750,000). Directs the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) to increase any minimum level of financial responsibility if, after an opportunity for notice and comment, the current amount is insufficient to satisfy liability amounts covering claims for personal injuries, property damage, or death arising from a motor vehicle accident involving a gross vehicle weight rating greater than 26,000 pounds (currently $750,000). Directs the Secretary to initiate a rulemaking to establish a federal motor vehicle safety standard requiring motor vehicles with a gross vehicle weight rating greater than 26,000 pounds be equipped with crash avoidance and mitigation systems. Directs the Secretary to finalize regulations to require a motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating greater than 26,000 pounds to be equipped with an electronic control module requiring the speed to be set at no more than 70 miles per hour by the manufacturer. (Sec. 5) Requires the Secretary to ensure that a review is completed on each motor carrier that demonstrates through performance data that it poses the highest safety risk. Requires a review,

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow employers an income tax credit with respect to employees who participate in the military reserve components, and to allow a comparable credit for participating self-employed individuals.

Small Business Health Plans Act of 2006 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a small business health benefits program (SBHBP) under which small employers may offer health insurance coverage to employees and their dependents. Outlines program elements and coverage requirements, including that small employers are provided access to qualified health pooling arrangements under which their employees may elect self-only or family health insurance coverage.

Investment Tax Incentive Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow the depreciation deduction to be computed based on a neutral recovery ratio for certain property placed in service after December 31, 1992. Decreases the alternative minimum tax deduction for depreciable property.

Reclamation Recreation Management Act of 2002 - Amends the Federal Water Project Recreation Act to make non-Federal entities responsible for the cost of recreation facilities on Reclamation project lands and waters. Authorizes the collection, retention, and use by such entities of fees and charges for the operation, maintenance, and replacement of such facilities.Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Commissioner of Reclamation, in the absence of a non-Federal managing partner, to investigate, plan, construct, replace, manage, operate, and maintain project lands, facilities, and water areas in a manner coordinated with other project purposes, with the costs of which are nonreimbursable.Authorizes the Secretary to modify or expand existing facilities, with the costs of which are nonreimbursable.

Geriatric Care Act of 2001 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) with respect to payments to hospitals, rural health clinics, and Federally qualified health centers for direct graduate medical education costs and the limitation on the number of full-time-equivalent residents in allopathic and osteopathic medicine. Provides for the disregard of up to three geriatric residents in applying such limitation.Amends SSA title XVIII, as amended by the Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000, to provide for Medicare coverage of care coordination and assessment services.

Federal Reserve Reform Act of 1995 - Amends the Federal Reserve Act to reestablish a Federal Open Market Advisory Committee to advise the Federal Reserve Board on the conduct of open-market operations. <n>Requires the Board to consult with the Secretary of the Treasury, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers before appointing the Chairman and Vice Chairman. <n>Requires the Board to submit annually to the President its estimated receipts and proposed expenditures for the current year, and the next two succeeding years (including those of the Federal Reserve Banks).

Significant Regulation Oversight Act of 1996 - Prohibits a significant rule from taking effect before the enactment of a joint resolution described in this Act comprising solely of the text of such rule. Specifies reporting and review requirements before a significant rule would take effect as a final rule. Declares that, if Congress fails to enact a joint resolution approving the proposed rule, no court or agency may infer any intent of the Congress from any action or inaction with regard to such rule or related statute. Specifies congressional approval procedures for significant rules.

Agricultural Market Promotion Program Amendments Act of 1993 - Amends the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 to set as a goal for agricultural market promotion assistance that 30 percent of the total funds available for FY 1994 and 1995 be used for activities involving small-sized and medium-sized commercial entities that are beginning exporters. Specifies that such assistance may be used only for activities in addition to activities for which a commercial entity expends a specified amount on all market promotion activities in a foreign country. Requires a commercial entity receiving more than $50,000 a year in assistance to provide for an independent audit as a condition of eligibility. Declares that no assistance may be used for the development, maintenance, or expansion of an agricultural export market for tobacco. Declares that an eligible trade organization shall contribute 50 percent of the cost of a marketing plan for a foreign country in each year the organization conducts activities in such country and shall pay the remaining 50 percent.

Gasoline Price Reduction and Refinery Tax Fairness Act of 2004 - (Sec. 2) States that it is the policy of the United States to take all actions necessary in the areas of conservation, efficiency, alternative sources, technology development, and domestic production to reduce the United States dependence on foreign energy sources by January 1, 2014, to 45 percent of the Nation\\'s total energy needs.<n><n>(Sec. 3) Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to define oil and gas exploration, production, processing, or treatment operations or transmission facilities" as all field activities or operations associated with exploration, production, processing, or treatment operations, or transmission facilities, including activities necessary to prepare a site for drilling and for the movement and placement of drilling equipment, whether or not such field activities or operations may be considered to be construction activities.<n><n>(Sec. 4) Directs the President to establish the Office of Federal Energy Project Coordination within the Executive Office of the President in the same manner and with the same mission as the White House Energy Projects Task Force.<n><n>Requires the Office to transmit an annual report to Congress that describes the activities put in place to coordinate and expedite Federal decisions on energy projects, including any additional recommendations or systemic changes needed to establish a more effective and efficient Federal permitting process"

Deter Revolving-door Appointments In our Nation; Stop Washington Appointees from becoming a political appointee at any time (pulative Petitioners Act) or the DRAIN the SWAMP Act This bill amends the federal criminal code to impose a five-year post-employment ban on a political appointee of the executive branch serving as a registered lobbyist, and a lifetime ban on serving as an agent of a foreign principal if such appointee has knowingly made, with intent to influence, any communication or appearance before an officer or employee of the department or agency in which such appointee served on behalf of any other person (except the United States). The Office of Government Ethics may waive such ban if it determines that: (1) the imposition of such ban would create an undue hardship on the department or agency in obtaining qualified personnel to fill such position or positions, and (2) granting the waiver would not create the potential for use of undue influence or unfair advantage. The bill also amends the Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938 to: (1) prohibit an individual from registering or otherwise serving as a political appointee or as an agent of a foreign principal if such individual served as a principal appointee of a foreign entity, and (2) increase the civil penalty for registration violations.

Declares that any event data recorder in the vehicle and any data recorded on such recorder shall be the property of the owner of the vehicle. Defines event data recorder" as any device or means of technology installed in an automobile that records information such as vehicle speed, seatbelt use, application of brakes, or other information pertinent to the operation of the automobile. Prohibits any person from manufacturing for sale, selling, offering for sale, introducing or delivering into interstate commerce, or importing into the United States, an automobile manufactured after 2008 that is equipped with an event data recorder, unless the consumer has the option to enable or disable such recording function. Treats a violation of the requirements of this Act as an unfair or deceptive act or practice under the Federal Trade Commission Act."

Stabilize Medicaid and CHIP Coverage Act This bill amends titles XIX (Medicaid) and XXI (Children's Health Insurance Program [CHIP]) of the Social Security Act to: (1) require a state Medicaid plan to provide that an individual who is determined to be eligible for Medicaid benefits shall remain eligible and enrolled for such benefits through the end of the month in which the 12-month period ends; and (2) require a state CHIP plan to provide that an individual who is determined to be eligible for CHIP benefits shall remain eligible and enrolled for such benefits through the end of the month in which the 12-month period ends.

Iran Sanctions Enabling Act of 2009 - States that it is the policy of the United States to support the decision of state governments, local governments, and educational institutions to divest from, and to prohibit the investment of assets they control in, persons that have investments of more than $20 million in Iran's energy sector. Authorizes a state or local government to adopt and enforce measures to divest its assets from, or prohibit investment of its assets in, any person that it determines engages in specified investment activities in Iran, including: (1) having an investment of $20 million or more in the energy sector of Iran; (2) providing oil or liquified natural gas tankers, or products used to construct or maintain pipelines used to transport oil or liquified natural gas, for the energy sector in Iran; or (3) being a financial institution that extends $20 million or more in credit to another person, for 45 days or more, if that person will use the credit to invest in Iran's energy sector. Requires: (1) such state or local government to provide written notice to each person to whom it intends to apply the measure; (2) such government to provide each such person with an opportunity to demonstrate that the person does not engage in such investment activities in Iran; and (3) such government to notify the

Bioterror and Pandemic Preparedness Protection Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to be solely and exclusively responsible for the administration of liability protections applicable to the design, development, clinical testing and investigation, manufacture, distribution, sale, purchase, donation, dispensing, administration, or use of a security countermeasure or a qualified pandemic or epidemic product. Provides for: (1) an exclusive federal cause of action for claims arising out of, relating to, or resulting from the design, development, clinical testing and investigation, manufacture, labeling, distribution, sale, purchase, donation, dispensing, administration, and use of such a product; (2) an action solely and exclusively against the United States for claims against a manufacturer, distributor, or health care provider; (3) no cause of action shall be maintained against a manufacturer, distributor, or health care provider for claims identified in this Act; and (4) the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia to have sole and exclusive jurisdiction over any claim for loss of property, personal injury, or death arising out of, relating to, or resulting from the design, development, clinical testing and investigation, manufacture, labeling, distribution, sale, purchase, donation, dispensing, administration,

Cleaning Product Right to Know Act of 2011 - Requires cleaning products manufactured for sale, offered for sale, distributed in commerce, or imported to the United States to bear a label with a complete and accurate list of all the product's ingredients, including the individual ingredients in dyes, fragrances, and preservatives. Allows the Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) to exempt from such labeling requirement an ingredient that is present in a cleaning product at such low levels that detection of the ingredient is not technologically feasible. Allows an ingredient to be exempt from such labeling requirements if the manufacturer demonstrates to the CPSC that such ingredient is a trade secret, and allows such exemption for a period of five years after which the manufacturer may again submit a claim for an additional five-year exemption.

Commission on the Review of the Overseas Military Facility Structure of the United States Act of 2011 Establishes the Commission on the Review of the Overseas Military Facility Structure of the United States to: (1) study matters relating to the military facility structure of the United States overseas; and (2) report review results to the President and Congress, including a proposal for an overseas basing strategy to meet current and future mission requirements of the Department of Defense (DOD).

9/11 Commission Review Act - Establishes in the legislative branch a National Commission to Review the National Response Since the Terrorist Attacks of September 11, 2001 (9/11 Review Commission). Requires the 9/11 Review Commission to conduct a comprehensive review of the implementation of the recommendations proposed in the report issued by the National Commission on Terrorist Attacks Upon the United States.

Restoring Investor Confidence Act of 2002 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to revise rules concerning capital gain for taxpayers other than corporations to establish a new general rule which provides that if for any taxable year a taxpayer other than a corporation has a capital gain, 55 percent of such gain shall be a deduction from gross income.Reduces the alternative capital gain tax for corporations.Allows such capital gain deduction in computing adjusted gross income.

Agricultural Credit Equity Act of 1993 - Amends the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act to provide for the indexation of guaranteed loan limits in counties with above-average land costs. <n>(Sec. 2) Provides for the indexation of guaranteed operating loan limits in counties with above-average land costs. <n>(Sec. 3) Provides for the elimination of the ceiling on the price of property which may be acquired under the down payment loan program. <n>(Sec. 4) Provides for the indexation of real estate and operating loan limits in counties with above-average land costs. <n>(Sec. 5) Eliminates the prohibition on providing beginning farmer direct operating loans to persons who have operated a farm or ranch for more than five years.

National Milestones to Measure Progress in Ending the Opioid Epidemic Act of 2018 This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services to develop national indicators to measure success in curtailing the opioid epidemic, with the goal of significantly reversing the toll of opioid misuse and opioid-related morbidity and mortality in the United States within five years.

Aviation Disaster Family Assistance Act of 1996 - Amends Federal transportation law to direct the Chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB), after being notified of an aircraft accident within the United States involving an air carrier or foreign air carrier and resulting in a major loss of life, to: (1) designate and publicize the name and phone number of a director of family support services who shall be an employee of the NTSB and shall be responsible for acting as a point of contact within the Federal Government for the families of passengers involved in the accident and a liaison between the air carrier or foreign air carrier and such families; and (2) designate an independent nonprofit organization for coordinating the emotional care and support of such families. Grants the NTSB primary Federal responsibility for facilitating the recovery and identification of fatally-injured passengers. Specifies responsibilities of the designated organization with respect to the families of passengers involved in the accident, including: (1) mental health and counseling services; (2) meeting with the families who have traveled to the location of the accident, to contact the families unable to travel to such location, and to contact all affected families periodically until the organization determines that further assistance is no longer needed; (3) communicating with the families as to the roles of the organization, government agencies, and the air carrier or foreign air carrier

Amends the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act to designate specified segments of the Taunton River in Massachusetts as components of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. Requires the river segments to be managed in accordance with the Taunton River Stewardship Plan, dated July 2005, and any amendment to such Plan that the Secretary of the Interior determines to be consistent with this Act.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary, in order to provide for the long-term protection, preservation, and enhancement of each river segment, to enter into cooperative agreements with: (1) the Commonwealth of Massachusetts; (2) the Taunton River Stewardship Council; and (3) any appropriate nonprofit organization.<n><n>Prohibits each river segment from being: (1) administered as a unit of the National Park System; or (2) subject to the laws (including regulations) that govern the administration of such System.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to only acquire parcels of land by: (1) donation; or (2) with the consent of the owner. Prohibits the Secretary from acquiring any parcel of land by condemnation.

Deems the full equalization of allotments under the Agua Caliente Equalization Act of 1959 to have been completed. Rescinds regulations governing such equalization from the Department of the Interior, effective March 31, 1983.

Special Needs Trust Fairness and Medicaid Improvement Act - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to require that state Medicaid plans cover tobacco cessation services for mothers of newborns. Declares that a woman shall continue to be treated as a pregnant woman through the end of the one-year period beginning on the date of the birth of a child. Amends SSA title XIX to eliminate federal financial participation with respect to expenditures under Medicaid for agents used for cosmetic purposes or hair growth.

Cavernous Angioma Research Resource Act of 2013 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to expand and intensify NIH programs for research and related activities concerning cavernous angioma, including by: (1) conducting basic, translational, and clinical research on cavernous malformations; (2) identifying and supporting the development of a clinical and research coordinating center with the potential of coordinating a multi-site clinical drug trial for cavernous angioma; (3) providing a model for additional clinical trial sites; and (4) maintaining programs dedicated to education, outreach, and awareness of the disease and the potential for its treatment. Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to engage in public awareness and education activities to increase understanding and recognition of cavernous angioma.

Amends the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act to exempt a member of a reserve component ordered to report for military service for more than 90 days, and who resides at such property, from the rent requirement for any period of such military service during which the member is assigned to duty at a location sufficiently distant from such property that the member is unable to reside there. Declares that a member who resides at such property and who is ordered to report for military service shall not be required to make any payment of principal or interest on the mortgage during such period of service. <n>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a refundable tax credit for lessors with respect to rent relief for reserve members ordered to active duty.

Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 2002 - Authorizes appropriations to the United States Patent and Trademark Office for salaries and necessary expenses for each of FY 2003 through 2008.Directs the Director of the Office to complete development of an electronic system for the filing and processing of patent and trademark applications that is user-friendly and includes the necessary infrastructure to: (1) allow examiners and applicants to send all communications electronically; and (2) allow the Office to process, maintain, and search electronically the contents and history of each application.Requires the Secretary of Commerce to report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees on: (1) the progress made in implementing the 21st Century Strategic Plan; and (2) any amendments made to the plan.Amends Federal patent law to declare that the existence of a substantial new question of patentability is not precluded by the fact that a patent or printed publication was previously cited by or to the Office or considered by the Office.Authorizes a third-party requester to appeal in an inter partes reexamination proceeding and to be a party to any appeal taken by the patent owner.Amends Federal patent law to revise provisions concerning appeals in inter partes reexamination proceedings by allowing an appeal to the Federal Circuit by a third-party requester in an inter partes reexamination
Amends the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States to suspend temporarily the duty on certain three-ring paper, polyester fabric, and letter-sized paper.
African Development Foundation Act of 2006 [sic] - Amends the African Development Foundation Act to rename the African Development Foundation as the United States African Development Foundation.

Wholesale Motor Fuel Fairness and Competition Restoration Act - Declares that it shall be unlawful for an owner or operator to sell motor fuel from its terminal facility to a distributor or retailer at a price in excess of the price it charges any other distributor or retailer, including a distributor or retailer which it owns or with which it is affiliated. Exempts from such prohibition certain franchises or sales contracts entered into before October 17, 2000.Establishes civil and criminal penalties for violations of this Act.Directs the Federal Trade Commission to: (1) issue regulations requiring full disclosure by refiners and distributors of their wholesale motor fuel pricing policies, including rebates, incentives, and market enhancement allowances; and (2) report to Congress on a study and report on the practices of the oil companies with respect to the wholesale sale of motor fuel.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on September 17, 2013. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Expiring Authorities Act of 2013 - (Sec. 2) Extends through December 31, 2013, the authority of the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to pay monthly assistance to veterans with disability invited by the United States Olympic Committee. Extends through FY2014: (1) the authority of the Secretary to collect copayments for VA hospital care and nursing home care, (2) the authority of the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to enter into contracts for the provision of nonservice-connected disability recovery services, (3) the authority of the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out a program of referral and counseling for veterans at risk of homelessness, and (4) the VA comprehensive recovery from third parties of cost-of-care contracts for veterans with health-related disabilities. Extends through FY2014: (1) the authority of the Secretary to furnish assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing, (2) a VA grant program for homeless veterans with special needs, and (3) the VA comprehensive recovery from third parties of cost-of-care contracts for veterans with health-related disabilities. Extends through FY2014: (1) the authority of the Secretary to

Nuclear Security Act of 2003 - Amends the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 to direct the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to: (1) establish a nuclear security force to provide for the security of all sensitive nuclear facilities against the design basis threat; and (2) develop and implement a security plan for each sensitive nuclear facility to ensure the security of all sensitive nuclear facilities against such threat.

Foreign Medical School Accountability Fairness Act of 2013 - Amends title I (General Provisions) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to revise institutional eligibility criteria for a foreign graduate medical school to participate in federal student aid programs. Requires a foreign graduate medical school to meet certain requirements—a minimum pass rate threshold on the medical licensing exam and a minimum percentage of foreign students—to participate in the Federal Direct Loan (DL) program, unless the Department of Education (ED) establishes alternative standards or the school has a grandfathered clinical training program.

Taxpayer Protection Act of 1997 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to replace provisions regarding the Office of the Taxpayer Advocate with provisions establishing a National Taxpayer Advocate in the Internal Revenue Service.

Training and Research in Urology Act of 2004 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a Division Director for Urologic Diseases in the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (the Institute). Requires the Director of the Institute (the Director) to give particular attention to supporting research and training programs geared to the needs of urology residents and fellows. Directs the Director to submit to Congress a national urologic research plan, and to review such plan every three years.Requires the Director to establish a National Urologic Diseases Data System for collecting and disseminating data from patients with urologic diseases, and a National Urologic Diseases Information Clearinghouse to facilitate and enhance knowledge and understanding of urologic diseases.Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to form a Urologic Diseases Interagency Coordinating Committee to further urology research, and a National Urologic Diseases Advisory Board. Directs that of the centers developed for research in kidney and urologic diseases under the Act, at least 15 shall focus exclusively on urologic diseases.Establishes within the advisory council for the Institute a subcommittee on urologic diseases. Directs the Secretary to establish a loan repayment program for urology research, with certain provisions of the Act to apply to the new program as such provisions apply to the National Health Service Corps Loan

habeas corpus revision Act of 1994 - Amends the Federal judicial code to require that an application for habeas corpus relief be filed in the appropriate district court not later than one year after: (1) the date of denial of a writ of certiorari, if a petition for a writ of certiorari to the highest court of the State on direct appeal or unitary review of the conviction and sentence is filed within the time limits established by law in the Supreme Court; (2) the date of issuance of the mandate of the highest court of the State on direct appeal or unitary review of the conviction and sentence, if a petition for a writ of certiorari is not filed within such time limits; or (3) the date of issuance of the mandate of the Supreme Court, if on a petition for a writ of certiorari, it grants the writ and disposes of the case in a manner that leaves the capital sentence undisturbed. Specifies that the time requirements established by this Act shall be tolled: (1) during any period in which the State has failed to provide counsel as required; (2) during the period from the date the applicant files an application for State post-conviction relief until final disposition of the application by the State appellate courts, if all filing deadlines are met

Directs the Secretary to facilitate the enhanced use of the technology, and the research and development services, of the Russia Ministry of Atomic Energy (MINATOM) by: (1) fostering the commercialization of peaceful, non-threatening advanced technologies of MINATOM through the development of projects to commercialize research and development services for industry and industrial entities; and (2) authorizing the Department of Energy and other Federal agencies to utilize such research and development services for activities appropriate to their mission of the Department and such agencies, including activities relating to: (1) remediation of the environmental consequences of U.S. nuclear weapons activities and Russian nuclear weapons activities; (2) nonproliferation (including the detection and identification of weapons of mass destruction and verification of treaty compliance); (3) global energy and environmental matters; and (4) nonproliferation of nuclear weapons.

Family Living Wage Act Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) increase the earned income tax credit to a maximum of $8,000 in any taxable year, and (2) allow an additional credit for each school age qualifying child and for each preschool age qualifying child.

. Disclosures, Cleaning, and Efficiency Act of 2017 or the Disclosures Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act by requiring a manufacturer of a medical device to give the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) premarket notification of changes to the design or reprocessing instructions of its device. Medical device manufacturers must also notify the FDA within five days of widely disseminating to health care providers in a foreign country communications relating to a change to the recommended reprocessing protocols, if any, for their device, or a safety concern about the device. The bill bans the devices if the manufacturers violate the notification requirements concerning those design or reprocessing changes or communications to foreign health care providers. (Sec. 4) The FDA must publish a list of the types of rapid assessment tests of reusable devices for which premarket notification must include proposed labeling, including validated instructions regarding sanitizing reusable devices.

Hedge Fund Transparency Act - Amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 to exclude from its registration requirements certain issuers: (1) whose outstanding securities are beneficially owned by not more than 100 persons, and which is not making and does not presently propose to make a public offering of its securities; (2) whose outstanding securities are owned exclusively by persons who, at the time of the acquisition of such securities, are qualified purchasers, and which is not making and does not propose to make a public offering of such securities; and (3) whose securities are owned by persons who received the securities from a qualified purchaser as a gift or bequest, or in a case in which the transfer was caused by legal separation, divorce, death, or any other involuntary event.

ESA Improvement Act of 2014 - Amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 (ESA) to prohibit the Secretary of the Interior from including any population of a species in a state if the Secretary has approved a state protective action for such population. Requires the Secretary to: (1) notify each state in which a population of the species occurs of the opportunity to submit to the Secretary a proposed state protective action for such species in that state, and (2) provide guidance to the state regarding preparation of such a proposed action. Authorizes each state notified, or group of such states, to submit to the Secretary a proposed state protective action for the species in such state or states within the period specified by the Secretary for the submission of public comment regarding the inclusion of the species in the list. Requires the Secretary to: (1) approve or disapprove a proposed state protective action within 45 days of submission, (2) approve such action if it meets the criteria specified for approval in the notification, (3) provide the written comments explaining specifically why the action was not approved, (4) allow the proposed action to be resubmitted at any time before the end of the 45-day period beginning on the date such comments are provided, and (5) issue a final decision regarding the proposed action within 30 days after the end of such period. Prohibits

Security and Liberty Preservation Act - Establishes the Commission on Enhancing Security and Preserving Freedom to: (1) advise the President and Congress on how to ensure that additional security measures can be implemented without compromising the privacy and dignity of individuals within the United States; and (2) report to the President and Congress recommendations on how to ensure that additional security measures can be implemented without compromising the personal dignity, liberty, and privacy of individuals within the United States.

Exempts from certain fire-retardant material requirements passenger vessels having berth or stateroom accommodations for at least 50 passengers that are operating before December 1, 2028, and operating only within the Boundary Line.

Renewable Fuels Pipelines Act of 2009 - Amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to allow federally-guaranteed loans for renewable fuel pipeline construction without regard to whether an appropriation for the cost has been made. Includes ethanol and biodiesel as renewable fuel.<n><n>Allows a maximum guarantee by the Secretary of Energy of 90% of the project cost and more than one guarantee for a project (as long as the total guaranteed amount does not exceed 90%).<n><n>Sets forth factors to be considered in guarantee determinations, including volume and quality of fuel, size of markets served, experience of the entity working with renewable fuel, and associated terminal, production, and storage facilities.

Health Care for Young Adults Act of 2005 - Amends titles XIX (Medicaid) and XXI (State Children's Health Insurance) (SCHIP) of the Social Security Act to give States the option of providing SCHIP and Medicaid coverage, with an additional allotment, to low-income youth up to age 23.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on May 2, 2017. Pet and Women Safety Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the federal criminal code to prohibit threats or acts of violence against a person's pet under the offenses of stalking and interstate violation of a protection order. The bill defines "pet" to mean a domesticated animal that is kept for pleasure rather than for commercial purposes. Veterinary services relating to physical care for the victim's pet may be provided free of charge. (Sec. 3) The Department of Agriculture shall award grants to eligible entities to carry out programs to provide emergency and transitional shelter and housing assistance, and related support services, to victims of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking and their pets.

Chesapeake Bay Environmental Education Pilot Program Act - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to establish the Chesapeake Bay Environmental Education and Training Grant Pilot Program to make grants to eligible institutions to pay the Federal share of the cost of developing, demonstrating, or disseminating information on practices, methods, or techniques relating to environmental education and training in the Chesapeake Bay watershed.

Firefighters Pay Fairness Act of 1994 - Amends Federal law to include Federal employees in or under the judicial branch, the Office of the Architect of the Capitol, the Botanic Garden, and the Library of Congress, for whom a basic administrative workweek is established, as well as individuals employed by the District of Columbia government, in the computation of basic pay for employment during 26 administrative biweekly work periods of up to 106 hours each. <n>(Sec. 4) Applies to Federal firefighters the provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 (FLSA) regarding overtime pay, providing that in the case of a firefighter subject to FLSA overtime provisions, the biweekly pay for that period shall be the greater of the employee's annual rate of basic pay or the number of hours of work deemed to be hours of work so as to ensure that no employee receives less pay because of this Act. <n>(Sec. 5) Sets forth similar provisions for Federal fire fighters who are not employees of the District of Columbia government. Provides that for pay purposes affecting a firefighter, the annual rate of basic pay established by or under statute is deemed the annual basic pay to be used in calculating payment for employment during 26 administrative biweekly work periods of up to 106 hours each. <n>(Sec. 6

Internet Fairness and Interstate Responsibility Act (or Net FAIR Act) - Prohibits any State or political subdivision from imposing, assessing, or attempting to collect a tax directly or indirectly on: (1) Internet or Internet-related services; or (2) the use of the Internet or Internet-related services if such taxes are applied uniformly to all businesses, do not apply to fairly apportioned business license taxes applied to businesses having Internet-related services, and are applied uniformly to all businesses. Terminates this moratorium on December 31, 2001.Establishes the Commission on Taxation of Internet and Internet-related Services.

Lower Colorado River Multi-Species Conservation Program Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to manage and implement the Lower Colorado River Multi-Species Conservation Program (LCR MSCP) in accordance with the Habitat Conservation Plan, Biological Assessment and Biological and Conference Opinion, Environmental Impact Statement/Environmental Impact Report, Funding and Management Agreement Implementing Agreement, and Permit issued in connection with the Lower Colorado River Multi-Species Conservation Program Program Documents (Program Documents). Directs the Secretary to enter into an agreement with the states of Arizona, California, and Nevada for the use of water from the Lower Colorado River for habitat creation and maintenance in accordance with the Program Documents. Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) invest portions of appropriations and any non-federal contributions made pursuant to the Program Documents in interest-bearing obligations of the United States; and (2) expend all amounts appropriated to and expended by the Secretary for the date MSCP shall be non-reimbursable and non-returnable. Provides that all amounts appropriated to and expended by the Secretary for the date MSCP shall be non-reimbursable and non-returnable. States that: (1) nothing in this Act shall impair any right to the delivery or beneficial consumptive use of Colorado River water under

Rocky Mountain Nation Park Wilderness Act of 1997 - Designates certain lands in Rocky Mountain National Park, Colorado, as wilderness (to be known as the Rocky Mountain National Park Wilderness) and as components of the National Wilderness Preservation System. Directs that such lands and certain lands within the Indian Peaks Wilderness that were transferred to the Park be included in, and administered as part of, such Wilderness. Declares that this Act shall not be construed to prevent or impede activities under the surface of the lands designated as wilderness by this Act to operate, maintain, repair, or replace the Alva B. Adams Tunnel of the Colorado- Big Thompson Project.

Assessing Progress in Haiti Act of 2014 - Directs the Secretary of State to report to Congress within 120 days, and every 180 days thereafter through September 30, 2015, on the status of post-earthquake recovery and development efforts in Haiti.

National Intelligence Education and Training Act - Directs the Attorney General to: (1) maintain an Academy for Law Enforcement Intelligence for the training of Federal, State, and local law enforcement officers and analysts in the analysis, dissemination, and management of intelligence; (2) establish an Advisory Board on Law Enforcement Intelligence; and (3) carry out a pilot program, to be known as the Law Enforcement Analyst Training Assistance Program, to assess the feasibility and advisability of providing for the preparation of selected students for availability for employment as intelligence analysts for Federal, State, and local law enforcement agencies.

American Eagle Palladium Bullion Coin Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to issue a $25 coin that bears, on the obverse and reverse, the designs of famed American coin designer and medallic artist Alexander Weinman. Requires the Secretary to submit to Congress and the Secretary of the Treasury an analysis of the market for palladium bullion investments conducted by a reputable, independent third party that demonstrates that there would be adequate demand for palladium bullion coins produced by the United States Mint to ensure that such coins could be minted and issued at no net cost to taxpayers.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 16, 2016. The Water Recycling and Reclamation Act of 2006 (sic) is amended to authorize the Secretary of the Interior to promulgate regulations to carry out the following activities under which the Secretary may enter into agreements: (1) to plan, design, and construct recycling projects within the boundaries of the Riverside and San Bernardino Counties, California; and (2) in cooperation with the Empire Utilities Agency, the Riverside Valley Water District, and the Cucamonga Valley Water District, to reclaim and construct wastewater facilities within the boundaries of such counties. The federal share of each project shall be limited to 50%.

Skilled Worker Immigration and Fairness Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to increase the annual H-1B immigrant visa (specialty occupation) cap from 20,000 to 20,000 beginning in FY2007. Exempts from such cap an alien who has been awarded a medical specialty certification based on post-doctoral training and experience in the United States. Exempts from H-1B caps an alien who has earned a masters or higher degree in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics from an institution of higher education outside of the United States.<n><n>Establishes annual H-1B market-based visa limits of 115,000 in FY2007 and 180,000 in each subsequent fiscal year.<n><n>Revises H-1B provisions with respect to: (1) employment-based immigrant status adjustment; and (2) related fraud protections.

Liberian Refugee Immigration Fairness Act of 2015 This bill directs the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to adjust the status of Liberian nationals who have been continuously present in the United States between January 1, 2013, and the date on which they apply for adjustment (or the spouse, child, or unmarried son or daughter of such aliens) if: (1) application is made within one year after enactment of this Act, and (2) the alien is otherwise eligible for an immigrant visa and admissible as a permanent resident, except that certain specified grounds of inadmissibility do not apply. An alien shall not be eligible for adjustment of status if DHS determines that the alien: has been convicted of any aggravated felony; has been convicted of two or more crimes involving moral turpitude; or has ordered, incited, assisted, or otherwise participated in the persecution of any person on account of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group, or political opinion.

Comprehensive Immunosuppressive Drug Coverage for Kidney Transplant Patients Act of 2007 - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to: (1) continue entitlement to prescription drugs used in immunosuppressive therapy furnished to an individual who receives a kidney transplant for which payment is made under Medicare; and (2) extend Medicare secondary payer requirements for end stage renal disease beneficiaries.<n><n>Amends the Public Health Service Act, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), and the Internal Revenue Code to require a group health plan to provide coverage of immunosuppressive drugs in connection with a kidney transplant that is at least as comprehensive as coverage provided on the day before enactment of this Act.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on September 21, 2015. Congenital Heart Futures Reauthorization Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to replace the authorization for a National Congenital Heart Disease Surveillance System with a requirement for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to enhance and expand research and surveillance infrastructure to study and track the epidemiology of congenital heart disease (CHD).
