(Congenital heart disease is a condition caused by a heart defect that is present at birth.) The CDC must report on a cohort study to improve understanding of CHD across the lifespan, including regarding: health care utilization, natural history, demographic factors, and outcome measures. Data from the study must be made available to the public. (Sec. 3) The National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute must expand, intensify, and coordinate research and related activities of the Institute with respect to congenital heart disease, including regarding: causation, long-term outcomes, and treatment or prevention.

Small Business Lending to Entrepreneurs for Growth in Underserved Populations Act of 2011 or the Small Business Leg-Up Act of 2011 - Requires, upon the expiration of investment authority for the Small Business Lending Fund Program provided in the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010, that all unobligated funds in the Small Business Lending Fund be transferred to the Community Development Financial Institutions (CDFI) Fund.

United States Armed Forces Protection Act of 1996 - Expresses the sense of the Congress that: (1) the President should fully comply with all applicable law governing the deployment of the Armed Forces to United Nations (UN) peacekeeping operations; (2) the President should consult closely with the Congress regarding any UN peace operation that could involve U.S. combat forces and that such consultations should continue; (3) the President should consult with the Congress before a vote within the UN Security Council on any resolution which would authorize, extend, or revise the mandate for any such activity; (4) the United States should participate in such operations only when it is clearly in the national security interest to do so; (5) U.S. combat forces should be under the operational control of qualified commanders and should have clear and effective command and control arrangements and rules of engagement; and (6) none of the Armed Forces should be under the operational control of foreign nationals in UN peace enforcement operations except in the most extraordinary circumstances. <n>Amends Federal law to prohibit funds appropriated or otherwise made available for the Department of Defense (DOD) from being obligated or expended for activities of any element of the armed forces that after enactment of this Act is placed under UN operational or tactical control, except in specified circumstances. Provides that such prohibition shall not:

Interstate Transport Act of 2018 This bill entitles a person who is not otherwise prohibited by federal law from possessing, transporting, shipping, or receiving a knife to transport a knife for any lawful purpose from any place where such person may lawfully possess, carry, or transport such a knife to any other place where such person may lawfully do so: (1) by motor vehicle if the knife is not directly accessible from the passenger compartment or is contained in a locked container other than the glove compartment or console, and (2) by other means over land or on or through water if the knife is contained in a locked container. The bill shall not apply to the transport of a knife or tool in the cabin of a passenger aircraft subject to Transportation Security Administration rules and regulations. A person may carry a knife or tool that consists only of a blunt tipped safety blade, a guarded blade, or both in the passenger compartment of a mode of transportation and shall not be required to secure a knife or tool in a locked container. Such bill shall not apply to the transport of a knife or tool in the cabin of a passenger aircraft. A person who is transporting a knife in compliance with this bill may not be arrested for violation of state or local laws related to the possession, transport, or carrying of a knife unless there

Hurricane Katrina Disaster Inquiry Commission Act of 2005 - Directs the President to establish an independent, nonpartisan Commission within the executive branch to discover and assess the circumstances related to the damage caused by Hurricane Katrina on or between Friday, August 26, 2005, and Tuesday, August 30, 2005.<n><n>Directs the President to issue an executive order establishing such a Commission within 30 days after the enactment of this Act.<n><n>Sets forth the process for the selection of Commission members.<n><n>Prohibits any Commission member from having, or having pending, a contractual relationship with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA).<n><n>Prohibits the President from appointing any individual as a Commission member who has a current or former relationship with FEMA that would constitute a conflict of interest.<n><n>Requires the Commission to: (1) Chronicle the trajectory of Hurricane Katrina, including the timetable and locations of its path, and the responses made by the federal, state, and local governments; (2) issue a statement of an estimate as to the loss of life, physical and structural damage, and displacement of residents as a result of the disaster; (3) make recommendations for corrective actions; and (4) prepare a report to Congress, the President, and the public.

Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to permit easements or rights-of-way for energy and related purposes on the outer Continental Shelf for purposes including: (1) supporting exploration, development, production, transportation, or storage of oil, natural gas, or other minerals; and (2) producing or supporting production, transportation, or transmission of energy from sources other than oil and gas.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 6, 2017. Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty Preservation Act of 2017 This bill states that it is U.S policy to: (1) suspend the operation of the Treaty between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on the Elimination of Their Intermediate-Range and Shorter-Range Missiles (INF Treaty) if the Russian Federation continues to violate the treaty, and (2) encourage the Russian Federation to return to compliance. The bill requires the Department of Defense to submit annual reports on: the status of the Russian Federation's ground-launched cruise missile, its capabilities, and the threat it poses to the United States and its allies in the region; whether the United States faces significant military disadvantages with the introduction of the INF range missile; gaps in the current U.S. missile defense infrastructure; gaps in capability that a new U.S. intermediate range missile, that is not compliant with the treaty, would address in Europe and Asia; and the time line for fielding, and the cost for deployment of, an INF range missile. The Department of State must submit an annual report that includes a plan: (1) describing how the United States will coordinate with its European allies to enhance missile detection

Radiation Experimentation Compensation Act of 1995 - Declares that it is the purpose of this Act to establish a procedure to make partial restitution to the individuals used in certain Federal radiation experiments for the burdens they have borne for the Nation as a whole, although monetary compensation can never fully compensate them. Declares that the Congress apologizes on behalf of the Nation to such individuals and their families for the hardships they have endured because of the experiments. <n>Establishes the Radiation Experimentation Compensation Trust Fund in the Treasury. Directs that amounts in the Fund be: (1) invested in accordance with specified law; and (2) available only for disbursement by the Attorney General (AG) under this Act. Terminates the Fund not later than the earlier of: (1) the date on which the amount authorized to be appropriated to it and any income earned on such amount have been expended; or (2) 22 years after this Act's enactment. Requires deposits in the Fund, if all of the amounts in it have not been expended, to be deposited in it, and all funds remaining in the Fund to be deposited in the miscellaneous receipts account in the Treasury. Authorizes appropriations. <n>Entitles any individual who, without the individual's informed consent, was intentionally injected with plutonium or

Fair Trade in Motor Vehicle Parts Act of 1993 - Declares that the United States Trade Representative (USTR) shall immediately proceed to determine what action to take with respect to any act, policy, or practice of a deficit foreign country that adversely affects the access to such country's market of motor vehicle parts produced by U.S. motor vehicle parts manufacturers (including, but not limited to, any act, policy, or practice utilized in such country's motor vehicle distribution system). Requires that any such act, policy, or practice: (1) guarantee for sales in the deficit foreign country's market of motor vehicle parts produced by U.S. motor vehicle parts manufacturers if the unfair act, policy, or practice did not exist; (2) eliminate or modify the aspects of the deficit foreign country's motor vehicle distribution system that adversely affect such access; or (3) impose any other act, policy, or practice that adversely affects such access.

Judicial Amendments Act of 1994- Amends the Federal judicial code to: (1) expand the scope of activities for which fees may be collected from the Judicial Automation Fund; (2) authorize all agencies of the judiciary to make deposits into the Fund to meet their automatic data processing needs; (3) increase the amount authorized to be deposited into the Fund; and (4) require the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Court to develop and report annually to the Congress on a long range automation plan and strategic business plan. <n>Authorizes the transfer of up to $1 million from the Fund into the account to which the funds were originally appropriated for the development of a long range automation plan. Limits any such transfer to compliance with reprogramming procedures under the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State, the Judiciary, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1989. <n>Requires the Director to: (1) develop an overall strategic business plan which would identify the judiciary's missions, goals, and objectives; (2) develop a long range automation plan based on the strategic business plan and user needs assessments; (3) establish effective Administrative Office oversight of court automation efforts to ensure the effective operation of existing systems and control over developments of future systems; (4) expedite efforts to complete the development and implementation of life cycle management standards; (5) utilize the

Internet Freedom Preservation Act of 2008 - (Sec. 3) Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to declare it to be the policy of the United States to: (1) maintain the freedom to use for lawful purposes broadband telecommunications networks, including the Internet, without unreasonable interference from or discrimination by network operators; (2) ensure that the Internet remains a vital force in the United States economy; (3) preserve and promote the open and interconnected nature of broadband networks that enable consumers to reach, and service providers to offer, lawful content, applications, and services of their choosing, using their selection of devices, as long as such devices do not harm the network; and (4) safeguard the open marketplace of ideas on the Internet by adopting and enforcing baseline protections to guard against unreasonable discriminatory favoritism for, or degradation of, content by network operators based upon its source, ownership, or destination on the Internet.<n><n>(Sec. 4) Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to commence a proceeding on broadband services and consumer rights. Requires the FCC, as part of such proceeding, to assess: (1) whether broadband network providers adhere to the FCC's Broadband Policy Statement of August, 2005; (2) whether such providers add charges for quality of service, or other similar additional fees or surcharges, to certain Internet applications and service

Water Infrastructure Improvement Act This bill amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (commonly known as the Clean Water Act) to allow municipalities to develop a plan that integrates all requirements under the Act addressed in the plan, including requirements relating to a combined sewer overflow, a capacity, management, operation, and maintenance program for sanitary sewer collection systems, a municipal stormwater discharge, a municipal wastewater discharge, and a water quality-based effluent limitation to implement an applicable wasteload allocation in a total maximum daily load. An integrated plan may include the implementation of projects, including innovative projects, to reclaim, recycle, or reuse water and green infrastructure. A permit issued under the Act that incorporates an integrated plan may include a schedule of compliance, under which actions taken to meet any applicable water quality-based effluent limitation may be implemented over more than one permit term if the schedule: (1) is authorized by state water quality standards; and (2) meets federal regulations concerning implementation of water quality-based effluent limitations over more than one permit term.

Minority Entrepreneurship and Innovation Pilot Program of 2006 - Directs the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) to make grants to historically Black colleges and universities, Tribal Colleges, and Hispanic serving institutions to: (1) assist in establishing an entrepreneurship curriculum for undergraduate or graduate studies; and (2) placement of small business development centers on the physical campus of the institution. Requires an institution receiving such a grant to develop a curriculum that includes training in various skill sets needed by successful entrepreneurs, including: (1) business management and marketing, financial management and accounting, market analysis and competitive analysis, innovation and strategic planning; and (2) additional entrepreneurial skill sets specific to the needs of the student population and the surrounding community. Requires each institution receiving such a grant to open a small business development center that: (1) performs studies, research, and counseling concerning the management, financing, and operation of small businesses; (2) performs management training and technical assistance regarding the participation of such businesses in international markets, export promotion and technology transfer, and the delivery or distribution of such services and information; (3) offers referral services for entrepreneurs and small businesses to business development, financing, and legal experts; and (4) promotes market-specific innovation, niche marketing, capacity building, international trade, and strategic planning as keys to long-term growth for

Congressional Responsibility Act of 1999 - Prohibits a regulation from taking effect before the enactment of a bill comprised solely of the text of the regulation. <n>Requires an agency, whenever it promulgates a regulation, to submit to each House of the Congress a report containing its text and an explanation. <n>Outlines expedited congressional procedures for consideration of agency regulations.

Child Safety Lock Act of 2001 - Amends the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act to prohibit any licensed manufacturer, importer, or dealer from selling, delivering, or transferring a handgun to any person other than a licensed manufacturer, importer, or dealer, unless the transferee is provided with a locking device for that handgun. Makes an exception where the transferee is a Federal, State, or local government, a law enforcement officer, or a rail police officer.Authorizes civil penalties.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Black Metropolis National Heritage Area Study Act (Sec. 1) This bill designates Chicago's Black District as a National Heritage Area. The bill states that the area includes the first public secondary school in Illinois built specifically to accommodate the educational needs of African-American students, the first African-American hospital in the United States, and the first African-American political center in Chicago. (Sec. 2) The Department of the Interior may enter into a cooperative agreement with the National Park Service (NPS) to carry out a study on the history and influence of the Black District in Chicago and the National Heritage Area.

. Serving our Rural Veterans Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) relies on agreements with the Indian Health Service (IHS) and tribal health organizations to serve native and non-native veteran populations in certain areas, especially rural areas, due to limited infrastructure or personnel of the VA in those areas; (2) the VA should support the practice of rural health care in the United States because such care is crucial to fulfilling the VA's mission to provide the highest quality care for veterans; and (3) education regarding the unique health needs of veterans is necessary for all health care providers and is especially important for providers in rural health care delivery systems, including those affiliated with Indian tribes and tribal health organizations that care for a significant number of veterans. (Sec. 3) The bill authorizes the VA to pay for the costs associated with establishing graduate medical education residency training programs at facilities operated by an Indian tribe or a tribal organization, operated by the IHS, or a federally-qualified health center. The VA shall carry out a pilot program that establishes such programs at not more than four such facilities that have been selected by the VA for purposes of the program. The VA shall reimburse each such facility participating in the program for costs

Durham Woods Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1994- Amends the Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968 to require owners or operators of natural gas pipeline facilities to make inspections at least once every seven years on the surface conditions on and adjacent to their right-of-way for indications of leaks, construction, and other circumstances affecting safety or operation. <n>Requires the Secretary of Transportation (Secretary) to issue regulations requiring that each operator of transmission pipelines: (1) establish a program for observing from the air, or inspecting from the ground, or both, at least once every month the surface conditions on and adjacent to the right-of-way of all of the operator's transmission pipelines identified for indications of leaks, construction, and other circumstances affecting safety or operation; and (2) place line markers along the rights-of-way of all of the operator's transmission pipelines, unless such placement is impractical. <n>Increases criminal and civil penalties for pipeline safety violations. <n>Requires the Secretary to make grants to States for the promotion of public awareness of the dangers of excavating near natural gas pipelines by advertising in the media and other means. <n>Directs the Secretary to conduct a comprehensive study on the safety of all natural gas transmission pipelines in New Jersey.

Directs the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to transmit to Congress: (1) a report containing the results of the Independent Safety Assessment conducted at Indian Point Nuclear Power Plant, New York, including a detailed explanation of the factual basis upon which the NRC and the Federal Emergency Management Agency relied upon the radiological emergency plan; (2) a comprehensive evaluation of the radiological emergency plan for Indian Point Energy Center, Units 2 and 3, conducted by the NRC and the Department of Homeland Security; and (3) a detailed explanation of what criteria, if any, can be provided to protect the public health and injuries including reasonable assurance in determining whether or not reasonable assurance can be provided to protect the public and the safety of these agencies.<n><n>Directs the NRC to conduct an Independent Safety Assessment Team at Indian Point Nuclear Power Plant.<n><n>States that the applicant for licenses to operate at Indian Point Nuclear Power Plant, New York, shall not be allowed to operate current reactors through administrative review plans until the final decision is made on whether to renew the licenses.<n><n>Authorizes appropriations to carry out this Act for FY2008.<n><n>Requires the NRC, before making a final decision on whether to renew a license for Indian Point, to consult with the New York State Department of Environmental Protection, and New York State

527 Reform Act of 2004 - Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 (FECA) to redefine a political committee" as any committee, club, association, or other group of persons that: (1) during one calendar year receives contributions aggregating in excess of $1,000 or makes expenditures aggregating in excess of $1,000; and (2) has as its major purpose the nomination or election of one or more candidates. Excepts from this definition any such committee, club, association, or other group of persons organized to influence: (1) the selection, nomination, election, appointment, or confirmation of one or more candidates to non-Federal or non-elected office; or (2) State or local ballot initiatives, State or local referenda, State or local bond issues, or other State or local ballot issues.<n><n>Declares that a committee, club, association, or other group of persons that makes disbursements for a public communication that promotes, supports, attacks, or opposes a clearly identified candidate for Federal office during the period beginning on the first day of the calendar year preceding the calendar year in which the general election for the office sought by the clearly identified candidate occurs and ending on the date of the general election; or (2) voter registration activity, voter identification, get-out-the-"

Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act - Amends provisions of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (ANCSA) that allow certain Alaska Native Vietnam veterans to file for allotments of up to two parcels of federal land totaling up to 160 acres.<n><n>Eliminates the requirement that limits the allotments to lands that were vacant, unappropriated, and unreserved on the date when the person eligible for the allotment first used and occupied them. Allows allotments to be selected from vacant federal lands or lands that have been selected or conveyed to the state of Alaska or an Alaska Native corporation, if the state or corporation voluntarily relinquishes or conveys the land to the United States for allotment.<n><n>Excludes allotments from land located within: (1) a right-of-way of the TransAlaska Pipeline; or (2) an inner or outer corridor of such a right-of-way.<n><n>Authorizes a person who qualifies for an allotment to select an alternative allotment from land that is: (1) located within the boundaries of specified withdrawn federal land, and not selected, or relinquished after selection, except for vacant, unappropriated, and unreserved land within a National Park; or (2) contiguous to an outer boundary of land withdrawn (unless that land is within a National Park) or

. Clean Water Compliance and Ratepayer Affordability Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to carry out a pilot program to work cooperatively with and facilitate the efforts of municipalities to develop and implement integrated plans to meet their wastewater and stormwater obligations under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (commonly known as the Clean Water Act) in a cost-effective and flexible manner and consistent with the Integrated Municipal Stormwater and Wastewater Approach Framework issued by EPA in May 2012. The pilot program must facilitate the efforts of at least 15 municipalities each fiscal year. A municipality is eligible to participate in the pilot program if it is: (1) a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit holder or designee; or (2) operating under an administrative order, administrative consent agreement, or judicial consent decree to comply with the requirements of the Clean Water Act. The EPA must focus on municipalities: (1) facing compliance issues under the Clean Water Act, (2) affected by affordability constraints in planning and implementing control measures to address wet weather discharges from their wastewater and stormwater facilities, and (3) with a history of knowledgeable, detailed, and comprehensive efforts to develop integrated and adaptive clean water management practices, without regard to the municipality's status in the process of planning or implementing them. In approving a municipality's

Lord's Resistance Army Disarmament and Northern Uganda Recovery Act of 2009 - Directs the President to submit to Congress a regional strategy to guide U.S. support for multilateral efforts to: (1) protect civilians from attacks by the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA); (2) eliminate the threat to civilians and regional stability posed by the LRA; and (3) enforce the rule of law and ensure full humanitarian access in LRA-affected areas.<n><n>Authorizes the President to provide assistance to respond to the humanitarian needs of populations in northeastern Congo, southern Sudan, and Central African Republic affected by the LRA.<n><n>Expresses the sense of Congress that the President should support efforts by the people of northern Uganda and the government of Uganda to: (1) assist internally displaced people in transition and returnees to secure durable solutions by spurring economic revitalization, supporting livelihoods, helping to alleviate poverty, and advancing access to basic services at return sites; (2) enhance the accountability and administrative competency of local governance institutions and public agencies in northern Uganda with regard to budget management, provision of public goods and services, and related oversight functions; (3) strengthen the operational capacity of the civilian police in northern Uganda to enhance public safety, prevent crime, and deal sensitively with gender-based violence; (4)

National Heroes Credit Protection Act - Amends the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act to authorize a member of the reserves who serves on active duty outside the continental United States in support of a contingency operation to request that a consumer reporting agency include a military service deployment explanation in his or her file. Requires the agency, upon receiving such request, to: (1) include such explanation in the servicemember's file; (2) provide the explanation to each person who requests the credit score or consumer report of the servicemember; and (3) notify the servicemember in writing that the inclusion of any explanation or notation in the servicemember's file could potentially negatively affect the servicemember's credit rating and may not mitigate a low credit score. Requires a reseller to include in any report on a servicemember any military service deployment explanation placed in the servicemember's file by another consumer reporting agency. Requires any prospective user of a consumer report containing a military service deployment explanation to acknowledge such explanation.

Requires a coalition, to be eligible for consideration, to submit to the Attorney General or the Attorney General's designee: (1) a comprehensive plan for reducing violent juvenile crime; and (2) a system to measure and report outcomes consistent with common indicators and evaluation protocols, and a detailed model for measuring and evaluating the success of the coalition in reducing violent juvenile crime. Sets forth grant priorities.

Authorizes appropriations. Provide<n>s a 25<n> percent matching funds requirement. Prohibits the Secretary from making any grant or providing any assistance under this Act beyond 15 years after the Secretary and the management entity enter into a cooperative agreement.

Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish a program to provide priority review for devices: (1) representing breakthrough technologies; (2) for which no approved alternatives exist; (3) offering significant advantages over existing approved or cleared alternatives; (4) offering significant advantages over existing approved or cleared alternatives; or (5) the availability of which is in the best interest of patients. Sets forth the process for the priority review of a request made by a device sponsor.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 16, 2015. EIN Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to deploy, operate, and maintain, to make available for use by any federal agency, with or without reimbursement, capabilities to protect federal agency information and federal civilian information systems, including technologies to diagnose, detect, prevent, and mitigate against cybersecurity risks involving federal agency information or federal civilian information systems. Federal agency heads may: (1) disclose information traveling to or from or stored on a federal civilian information system to DHS, which may also be disclosed to the DHS; (2) enter into contracts or other agreements, or otherwise request and obtain the assistance of, private entities to deploy, operate, and maintain technologies in accordance with this Act; and (3) retain, use, and disclose information obtained through the conduct of such activities only to protect federal agency information and federal civilian information systems from cybersecurity risks or in furtherance of the national cybersecurity and communications integration center's authority, or, with the approval of the Department of Justice (DOJ), and if disclosure is not otherwise prohibited by law, to law enforcement only to investigate, prosecute, disrupt, or otherwise respond

Amends the Revised Statutes to declare that, if a plaintiff produces prima facie evidence to support a claim alleging a violation of the Free Exercise Clause or this Act, the government shall bear the burden of persuasion on any element of the claim, except that the plaintiff shall bear the burden of persuasion on whether the law (including a regulation) or government practice that is challenged by the claim substantially burdens the plaintiff's exercise of religion.

Medicare/Medicaid Solvency Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish the Tobacco Product Health Care Cost Reimbursement Trust Fund from which contributions shall be made by tobacco product manufacturers to reimburse the Government for health care costs attributable to the use of tobacco products.

Clean Vehicles Incentive Act of 2013 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow certain businesses located in areas designated as nonattainment areas under the Clean Air Act a general business tax credit for the cost of certain clean-fuel vehicle property and clean-burning fuel. Allows the credit to be taken against regular and alternative minimum tax liabilities. Allows a tax deduction for any unused clean fuel credit amounts.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 5, 2012. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Improving Access to Child Care for Homeless Families Act of 2012- Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) Congress has enacted successful policies to increase homeless children's access to and stability in public elementary and secondary schools and Head Start programs; and (2) such policies should be applied to federal child care programs.- Amends the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to make grants to states and local educational agency liaisons for programs serving homeless children and youths, and services for homeless veterans, that include: (1) Head Start and Early Head Start programs under the Head Start Act; (2) programs and services of partners that serve vulnerable populations, including homeless children and youths; and (3) programs and services of entities receiving grants to provide to homeless veterans services consisting of housing, employment-related services, or supportive services.

Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security, acting through the Under Secretary for Science and Technology, to operate extramural research, development, demonstration, testing, and evaluation programs so as to: (1) ensure that colleges, universities, private research institutes, and companies (and consortia thereof) from as many areas as practicable participate; (2) ensure that the research funded is of high quality; and (3) distribute funds through grants, cooperative agreements, and contracts. Directs the Secretary, acting through the Under Secretary, to designate university-based centers or several university-based centers for homeland security to establish a coordinated, university-based system to enhance the Nation's homeland security. Sets forth criteria for the designation of colleges or universities as centers.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: prohibition on use of funds for the participation of certain Chinese officials <n> in conferences, exchanges, programs, and activities <n> Title II: authorization of appropriations for increased funding for international broadcasting to China <n>Title I: prohibition on use of funds for the participation of certain Chinese officials in conferences, exchanges, programs, and activities <n> Title II: authorization of appropriations for increased funding for international broadcasting to China <n>Title I: prohibition on use of funds for the participation of certain Chinese officials in conferences, exchanges, programs, and activities

Medicare Drug Formulary Protection Act - Amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to prohibit prescription drug plan (PDP) sponsors, beginning with 2006, from removing a covered Medicare part D drug from the plan formulary, or imposing a restriction or limitation on its coverage, other than at the beginning of each plan year except as the Secretary of Health and Human Services may permit. Makes an exception to such prohibition for covered part D drugs that: (1) are brand name drugs for which there is a generic drug approved under the Food and Drug Cosmetic Act; (2) go off-patent; (3) are a drug for which the Commissioner of Food and Drugs issues a clinical warning that imposes a restriction or limitation on the drug; or (4) have been determined to be ineffective during the period in which there are such limitations. Requires PDP sponsors to provide appropriate notice to the Secretary, affected enrollees, physicians, pharmacies, and pharmacists of any removal or change.

Title III: Rural Health Care Improvements - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to revise the methodology for calculating the disproportionate share hospital payment amount for discharges occurring in FY 2003 and 2004, and to establish a frequency for revising the weights used in the hospital market basket to reflect the most current data available more frequently than once every five years.States that, for discharges occurring in FY 2003, the average standardized amount for hospitals other than in a large urban area shall be increased by one-half of the difference between the average standardized amount for hospitals located in large urban areas and such amount for other hospitals. Directs the Secretary to compute an average standardized amount for hospitals located in any area within the United States and within each region equal to the average standardized amount computed for the previous fiscal year for hospitals located in a large urban area (or, beginning with FY 2005, for hospitals located in any area) increased by the applicable percentage increase.

Rail Merger Reform and Customer Protection Act - Amends Federal transportation law to condition the Surface Transportation Board's approval of any rail carrier consolidation, merger, or acquisition of control upon a finding that the transaction: (1) will increase competition among rail carriers; (2) will not reduce transportation alternatives available to current railroad customers; (3) will provide additional transportation alternative options for railroad customers; (4) will improve service to customers; and (5) is in conformity with the antitrust laws.Declares that rail carriers and rail transportation subject to the jurisdiction of the Board shall also be subject to the antitrust laws.Repeals the exemption of rate agreements from the Sherman Act, the Clayton Act, the Federal Trade Commission Act and specified parts of the Wilson Tariff Act (thus subjecting such agreements to Federal antitrust laws). Repeals the mandate that the Federal Trade Commission report to the Board periodically on possible anticompetitive features of approved rate agreements, or agreements submitted for approval, and any organization operating under such agreements.Prohibits a person proceeding against a rail carrier, and a person proceeding against a rail carrier pursuant to other Federal or State law, from proceeding against the same rail carrier pursuant to the Sherman Act, the Clayton Act, the Federal Trade Commission Act, or specified parts of the Wilson Tariff Act, unless the

American Super Computing Leadership Act Amends the Department of Energy High-End Computing Revitalization Act of 2004 with respect to: (1) exascale computing (computing system performance at or near 10 to the 18th power floating point operations per second); and (2) a high-end computing sytem with performance substantially exceeding that of systems commonly available for advanced scientific and engineering applications. Directs the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to: (1) coordinate the development of high-end computing systems across DOE; (2) include among the multiple architectures researched any computer technologies that show promise of substantial reductions in power requirements and substantial gains in parallelism of multicore processors, concurrency, memory and storage, bandwidth, and reliability; and (3) partner with universities, DOE National Laboratories, and industry to ensure the broadest possible application of the technology developed to other challenges in science, engineering, medicine, and industry. Repeals authority for establishment of at least one High-End Software Development Center. Directs the Secretary to conduct a coordinated research program to develop exascale computing systems to advance DOE missions. Requires establishment through competitive merit review of two or more DOE National Laboratory-industry-university partnerships to conduct integrated research, development, and engineering of multiple exascale architectures and: (1) conduct mission-related co-design activities

Truancy Prevention and Juvenile Crime Reduction Act of 1998 - Directs the Attorney General to make competitive grants to partnerships composed of a local educational agency and one or more local governmental units, for programs to reduce truancy and the incidence of daytime juvenile crime. <n>Allows grant funds to be used for: (1) parental responsibility activities, including meaningful incentives for parental involvement; (2) sanctions, including community service and drivers license suspension for students who are habitually truant; (3) in-school truancy prevention programs, including alternative education and in-school suspension; (4) involvement of the local law enforcement, social services, judicial, business, and religious communities, and nonprofit organizations; (5) technology, including automated telephone notice to parents and attendance system; or (6) elimination of 40-day count incentives to allow students to be truant after a certain time of school year. <n>Authorizes the Attorney General to give priority to programs that attempt to replicate: (1) the Truancy Intervention Project of the Fulton County, Georgia, borough, parish, village, or other general purpose political subdivision of a State, or any Indian tribe; and (2) the programs of the Institute of Medicine and the National Academy of Sciences under the Public Health Service Act.

Regional Infrastructure Accelerator Act of 2017 This bill requires the Department of Transportation to establish a regional infrastructure accelerator program to provide initial and subsequent grants for eligible state, local, and regional public entities to carry out covered infrastructure projects. A "covered infrastructure project" is as an infrastructure project sponsored by a public project sponsor, a construction or real estate development entity, a stakeholder association, or an organized labor association or association of workers representing labor and workplace negotiators that involves the construction, consolidation, alteration, or repair of rail, bus, or public transportation facilities or equipment, highway facilities (including bridges and tunnels), airports, port or marine facilities and equipment, pipelines, inland waterways, intermodal facilities and equipment, water treatment and solid waste disposal facilities, storm water management systems, dams and levees, and facilities or equipment for energy transmission, distribution, or storage. To be eligible to receive a grant, a proposed plan must describe how the plan will promote investment in such projects.

Biological Agents Control and Tracking Act of 2001 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish and maintain a list of each biological agent and toxin that has the potential to pose a severe threat to public health and safety. Requires the Secretary, in determining whether to include an agent or toxin on the list, to: (1) consider the effect on human health of exposure to the agent or toxin, the degree of contagiousness of the agent or toxin and the methods by which it is transferred to humans, the availability and effectiveness of immunizations to prevent and treatments for any illness resulting from infection by the agent or toxin, and any other criteria that the Secretary considers appropriate; and (2) consult with appropriate Federal departments and agencies and with scientific experts representing appropriate professional groups.Requires the Secretary to: (1) provide for the establishment and enforcement of safety standards and procedures for the possession, use, and transfer of listed biological agents and toxins, including measures to ensure proper training and skills to handle such agents and toxins and proper laboratory facilities to contain and dispose of them; (2) establish and enforce safeguards and security standards and procedures to prevent access to such agents and toxins for use in domestic or international terrorism or for any other criminal purpose, including procedures to protect the public safety in

Abraham Lincoln Bicentennial 1-Cent Coin Redesign Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury, during 2009, to issue one-cent coins with the reverse side bearing four different designs representing different aspects of the life of Abraham Lincoln.

Energy Efficient Buildings Act of 2007 - Requires the Secretary of Energy to establish a pilot program to award grants to businesses and organizations for new construction of energy efficient buildings, or major renovations of buildings that will result in energy efficient buildings, to demonstrate innovative energy efficiency technologies, especially those sponsored by the Department of Energy (DOE).<n><n>Requires the Secretary to award such grants competitively to those applicants whose proposals: (1) best demonstrate the likelihood to meet or exceed specified energy efficiency standards, the likelihood to maximize cost-effective energy efficiency opportunities, and advanced energy efficiency technologies; and (2) maximize the leverage of private investment for costs related to increasing the energy efficiency of the building.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to give due consideration to proposals for buildings that are likely to serve low and moderate income populations.<n><n>Limits grant amounts to $50,000 per building.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to pay the remaining 50% of such grant only after independent certification that operational buildings are energy efficient.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on December 10, 2015. Health Coverage Tax Credit Extension Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend through 2020: (1) the tax credit for premium assistance for health insurance coverage, and (2) the authority for advance payments of such credit to health insurers. The bill allows a taxpayer to elect to have the tax credit apply for any eligible coverage month by making an election to have such credit apply for all subsequent eligible coverage months in the taxable year. An eligible coverage month to which an election applies shall not be treated as a coverage month for purposes of the tax credit. Such an election shall: (1) not be irrevocable, and (2) apply for all subsequent eligible coverage months in the taxable year. The bill increases the amount of the tax credit for advance payments of the credit by the excess of: (1) the sum of advance payments made on behalf of the taxpayer under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act for months during such taxable year, over (2) the sum of the tax credits allowed for such year. If the taxpayer received any advance payments for any month in such taxable year and is later allowed a tax credit for such taxable year, the tax credit shall be increased by the excess of the amount of

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 2, 2014. Urban Flooding Awareness Act of 2014 - Directs the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to enter into an agreement with the National Research Council to conduct a study on urban flooding. Defines urban flooding" as the inundation of property in a built environment, particularly in more densely populated areas, caused by rain falling on increased amounts of impervious surface and overwhelming the capacity of drainage systems. Requires the study to include an evaluation of the latest research, laws, regulations, policies, best practices, procedures, and institutional knowledge regarding urban flooding."

Nationalised Explosive Device Prevention and Preparedness Act of 2008 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to establish within the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) an Office for Bombing Prevention to have the primary responsibility within the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for enhancing the ability of the nation to deter, detect, prevent, protect against, intercept, and respond to improvised explosive device attacks, including by: (1) coordinating national strategic goals and standards; and (2) providing the analysis derived from a specified database on the capabilities of improvised explosive device first responders and intergovernmental bombing prevention activities.

Uzbekistan Freedom Promotion Act of 2005 - Directs the President to apply specified entry, asset seizure, and investment sanctions to Uzbekistan until the President certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that Uzbekistan: (1) permits opposition parties to freely choose their own party leaders and candidates; (2) provides for independent human rights monitoring of political parties, journalists, human rights defenders, and other civil society activists; (3) does not engage in gross violations of internationally recognized human rights; and (4) has released all political prisoners. (Requires such certification not later than 30 days after the date of enactment of this Act.)<n><n>Authorizes the President to waive such sanctions if: (1) in the national interest; or (2) a new president is elected in Uzbekistan in 2004 who has corrected human rights abuses.

Lake Pontchartrain Basin Restoration Act of 1999 - Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to direct the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to establish within EPA the Lake Pontchartrain Basin Restoration Program to: (1) coordinate efforts among and provide resources to the various Federal, State, and local governmental agencies and nonregulatory organizations to reduce pollution in the Lake Pontchartrain Basin and restore it to ecological health; and (2) restore such Basin to ecological health. <n>Requires the Administrator to: (1) establish the Lake Pontchartrain Executive Council to advise the Administrator on the Program; (2) develop and implement a watershed management plan for the Basin; and (3) establish the Lake Pontchartrain Basin Restoration Grant Program. <n>Authorizes the Administrator to provide grants for restoration projects in the Basin, using amounts in the Lake Pontchartrain Basin Restoration Grant Program to pay up to 50 percent of the costs of the project. <n>Directs the Administrator to: (1) report to Congress on the restoration efforts of the Basin; and (2) establish a technical assistance program to provide technical assistance to nonregulatory organizations with respect to restoration efforts in the Basin. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Prosperous and Secure Neighbor Alliance Act of 2007 - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to direct the President, acting through the Director of Foreign Assistance, to provide assistance to improve security and promote economic development in Mexico by: (1) professionalizing Mexican law enforcement personnel to prepare them to more effectively combat illicit drugs and drug-related violence and other criminal activities; (2) providing technology to assist Mexican law enforcement personnel to more effectively combat illicit drugs and drug-related violence; (3) strengthening the Mexican judicial branch through the training of judges and prosecutors; (4) supporting anti-corruption programs in Mexico, including the vetting of Mexican law enforcement personnel who are working with U.S. government personnel; and (5) reducing poverty through targeted funding to enhance social development in Mexico, including micro-lending and trade capacity building.

Bias Crimes Compensation Act of 1993 - Declares that all individuals within the United States, and its special maritime and territorial jurisdiction, shall have the right to be free from bias-motivated crimes of violence. Declares that any person, including one who acts under color of any statute, ordinance, regulation, custom, or usage of any State, who deprives an individual of such right, shall be liable to the individual injured, in a civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction, for compensatory damages of not less than $100,000, punitive damages, injunctive relief, declaratory relief, or any combination thereof. Declares that nothing in this Act: (1) entitles an individual to a claim herein for random acts of violence unrelated to bias or for acts that cannot be demonstrated, by a preponderance of the evidence, to be bias-motivated crimes of violence; and (2) requires a prior criminal complaint, prosecution, or conviction to establish the necessary elements of such a claim. Grants the Federal and State courts concurrent jurisdiction over actions brought under this Act. Specifies that nothing in this Act shall be construed to confer on the courts of the United States supplemental jurisdiction of any State law claim seeking the establishment of a divorce, alimony, equitable distribution of marital property, or child custody

Amends the Microenterprise for Self-Reliance Act of 2000 to make as one of its purposes that in implementation of this Act at least 50 percent of all microenterprise assistance be targeted to the very poor, that is, those persons living either in the bottom 50 percent below the poverty line or on less than the equivalent of one dollar per day.Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to authorize the President to provide assistance to increase the availability of financial services (not just credit) to microenterprise households lacking full access to credit, including through: (1) loans and guarantees to microfinance institutions to expand the availability of savings and credit to poor and low-income households; (2) training programs to enable them to better meet the financial services needs of their clients; and (3) training programs to enable clients to make better use of credit, increase their financial literacy, and to better manage their enterprises to improve their quality of life.Declares that Congress finds and declares that: (1) access to financial services and the development of microenterprise are vital factors in the stable stability of the country; and (2) grant assistance provided under such Act should be targeted to microentrepreneurs and their households, especially those residing in the bottom 50 percent below the poverty line.

Social Security Lock-Box Act of 2005 - Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to make it out of order in the House of Representatives or the Senate to consider any concurrent budget resolution that would set forth totals for any fiscal year with respect to the Social Security Trust Funds that are less than the totals of such Funds for that fiscal year as calculated in accordance with a current services baseline. Makes an exception to the extent that a violation would result from an assumption in the resolution, amendment, or conference report of an increase in outlays or decrease in revenues and disbursements relative to the baseline underlying the resolution for social security reform legislation for any such fiscal year.

Highway Trust Fund Integrity Act of 1997 - Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 (Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act) and the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to define revenue constrained fund" as the budget authority, outlays, and receipts of the Highway Account of the Highway Trust Fund which are deposited into each revenue constrained fund. <n>(Sec. 4) Makes it out of order in either chamber to consider any measure that would have the effect of increasing any specific new budget authority for a fiscal year for a revenue constrained fund above the amount made available by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act. <n>Requires a reduction in amounts available from a revenue constrained fund by the amount necessary to eliminate any amount by which budget authority in the budget year from the revenue constrained fund exceed the amount deposited in the previous fiscal year. <n>Directs the Office of Management and Budget to: (1) estimate the total amount of revenues deposited into each revenue constrained fund during the fiscal year; and (2) prepare an estimate of the total amount of revenues projected to be deposited into such fund during each fiscal year. <n>Requires a point of order against any measure that would increase budget authority in a revenue constrained fund above the amount made available by the Gram"

Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity, and Training Act of 2002 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to: (1) establish a national performance-based job-search assistance program to provide high-quality, job-search service to veterans, servicemembers, and other eligible persons, focused on assisting such individuals in obtaining and maintaining employment, as well as reducing the duration of individual's unemployment; (2) assist employers in locating and hiring qualified veterans, servicemembers, and other eligible persons; and (3) be accessible to such individuals.Directs the Secretary to establish a competitive grants program to be referred to as the Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity and Training Program through which State Governors or other entities, as may be appropriate, would receive grants for the purpose of providing employment services to veterans, servicemembers, and other eligible persons within each State.

Neighborhood Rescue and Stabilization Act of 2008 - Authorizes FY2008 appropriations for emergency assistance to states, qualified metropolitan cities, and units of general local government for the redevelopment of abandoned and foreclosed homes.<n><n>Allocates such funds among states on the basis of each state's share of foreclosures on mortgages for homes occurring in such state during the most recently completed two calendar quarters, as determined by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). Requires a state, qualified metropolitan city, or local government receiving such funds to give priority to those metropolitan areas, metropolitan cities, urban areas, rural areas, low- and moderate-income areas, and other areas with the greatest need.<n><n>Permits funds to be used only to make grants, loans, and other financing mechanisms to community development financial institutions, national intermediaries, and nonprofit housing or community development organizations.

Defense Reinvestment and High-Tech Job Creation Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a defense conversion investment credit in an amount equal to ten percent of the qualified wages paid or incurred by a qualified employer for conversion employees from a defense-related business to a nondefense-related business. Specifies the applicable percentage of the defense conversion investment credit for qualified employers.

Community-Based Mental Health Infrastructure Improvements Act - Amends Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to award matching grants to states or Indian tribes to expend funds for the construction or modernization of facilities used to provide community-based mental health and behavioral health services to individuals.

Economic Recovery Through Responsible Homeownership Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an individual taxpayer a refundable tax credit, up to $10,000, for the purchase of a principal residence in 2009 or 2010. Requires repayment of such credit if the taxpayer sells or fails to occupy the residence within 24 months after the date of purchase.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Grants to Tribes and Tribal Organizations <n> Title II: Miscellaneous <n> Title III: Effective Dates <n>Native American Census Participation Enhancement Act of 1999 - <n>Title I: Grants to Tribes and Tribal Organizations <n> Title II: Miscellaneous <n> Title III: Effective Dates <n>Native American Census Participation Enhancement Act of 1999 - Authorizes the Secretary of Commerce to provide grants to Indian tribes and tribal organizations to improve Native American participation in the 2000 census. <n>(Sec. 2) Requires each entity wishing to receive such a grant to submit an application at such time, in such form, and complete with such information as the Secretary shall require, except that any such application shall include at least: (1) a statement of the objectives for which the grant is sought; and (2) a description of the types of programs and activities for which the grant is sought. <n>(Sec. 3) Prohibits a grant from being made unless the grantee agrees, with respect to the costs to be incurred, to make available non-Federal contributions in an amount equal to not less than 50 percent of the Federal funds provided under the grant.  <n>(Sec. 4) Directs the Secretary to allocate the amounts appropriated to carry out this Act

United States-Mexico Transboundary Aquifer Assessment Act - (Sec. 4) Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the United States Geological Survey, to carry out a United States-Mexico transboundary aquifer assessment program to characterize, map, and model transboundary groundwater resources along the U.S.-Mexico border, in consultation and cooperation with the States of Arizona, California, New Mexico, and Texas (border States), the water resources research institutes (WRRIs) within the border States established under the Water Resources Research Act of 1984, Sandia National Laboratories, and other appropriate entities in the United States and Mexico.<n><n>Sets forth as the objectives of the program to: (1) develop and implement an integrated scientific approach to assess transboundary groundwater resources, including by prioritizing aquifers for further analysis; (2) expand existing agreements between the USGS, the border States, the WRRIs, and appropriate authorities in the United States and Mexico to conduct joint scientific investigations, archive and share relevant data, and carry out activities consistent with the program; and (3) produce scientific products for each priority aquifer that are capable of being broadly distributed and that provide the scientific information needed by water managers and natural resource agencies on both sides of the border to effectively accomplish border water resource goals.<n>

Creating Opportunities for Rural Economic Expansion Act or the CORE Act Amends the Internal Revenue Code to set aside at least 5%, for calendar years after 2016, of the limitation on the new markets tax credit for investment in distressed coal communities. Defines "distressed coal community" as any low-income community located in a county which was one of the 30 counties with the biggest employment decrease among coal operators in an applicable period or is contiguous to a county which contains at least one low-income community.

Requires that an end-use certificate be included in the documentation covering the entry of any foreign commodity. Requires a consignee of any imported foreign commodity to submit quarterly reports to the Secretary of Agriculture certifying what quantity of the foreign commodity was used by the consignee and that the commodity was used for the purpose stated in the end-use certificate. <n>Requires the end-use certificates and quarterly reports to be in such form, and require such information as the Secretary considers necessary or appropriate to carry out this Act, including: (1) the name and address of the importer of record of the foreign commodity; (2) the name and address of the consignee of the commodity; (3) the identification of the country of origin of the commodity; (4) a description by class and quantity of the commodity covered by the certificate; (5) the sales price of the commodity in the country of origin, if the Secretary considers such datum necessary to facilitate the enforcement of the trade laws and international agreements of the United States; (6) the specification of the purpose for which the consignee will use the commodity; and (7) the identification of the transporter from the port of entry to the processing facility of the consignee. <n>Directs the Commodity Credit Corporation to provide a person with an opportunity for a hearing before suspending or de

Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to issue a new term grazing permit without regard to whether the environmental analysis required by the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 and other applicable laws has been completed or final agency action respecting such analysis has been taken if: (1) the holder of an expiring term permit has waived such permit; or (2) the purchaser of such a permit is eligible and qualified to hold such permit.

Government Travel Cost Reduction Act - Amends Federal civil service law to require the General Services Administration (GSA) or any agency entering into a contract with an air carrier for travel on official business to include as a term of such contract that such air carrier shall: (1) establish a separate air travel business account for any employee, designated by the agency head, for travel on official business; (2) deposit any award or bonus awarded to such employee for such travel into such employee\\'s air travel business account; and (3) apply any such award or bonus from such employee\\'s account to any travel on official business by such employee on such air carrier, except that such awards or bonuses shall not be used for seating upgrades. Requires all air travel business accounts established under this Act to be separate from any personal account of an employee. Allows any award or bonus from such account to be used only for travel on official business, except that such awards shall not be used for seating upgrades.Directs the GSA to include the term air travel business account" in a contract to maximize travel costs savings to employees. Requires such regulations to include a requirement that employees: (1) travel on official business with air carriers awarding awards and bonuses for official business travel, regardless of whether such travel is on an air carrier"

Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to jointly investigate and report to the Congress on the billing practices of telecommunications carriers. Declares the purpose of this Act to be to require the FCC and the FTC to protect consumers by assuring accurate cost reporting and billing practices by telecommunications carriers nationwide.

Higher Education Accrediting Agency Responsibility Act of 2002 (sic) - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to repeal provisions authorizing the National Advisory Committee on Institutional Quality and Integrity to review and make recommendations to the Secretary of Education concerning the accreditation process of institutions of higher education (IHEs).Eliminates the requirement that an IHE be accredited before it may be eligible to participate in the Federal student aid programs of the Department of Education.Eliminates the requirement that an IHE be accredited before it may be eligible to participate in the Federal student aid programs of the Department of Education.Eliminates: (1) the requirement that an IHE be accredited before it may be eligible to participate in the Federal student aid programs of the Department of Education; and (2) the sunset date for such accreditation requirements (thus making them permanent).Eliminates the requirement that an IHE be accredited before it may be eligible to participate in the Federal student aid programs of the Department of Education.Eliminates the requirement that an IHE be accredited before it may be eligible to participate in the Federal student aid programs of the Department of Education. Makes conforming amendments to title III (General Provisions) and title IV (Student Assistance) of the Act.

Advanced Nuclear Fuel Availability Act This bill requires the Department of Energy (DOE) to establish and carry out a program to support the availability of low-enriched uranium ( HA-LEU) for domestic commercial use through financial assistance to commercial entities to design and license transportation packages for HA-LEU and by encouraging the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to have such transportation package designs certified by January 1, 2023. DOE may also: (1) encourage the NRC to have such transportation package designs so certified by January 1, 2023; and (2) report to Congress on DOE's uranium inventory that may be available to be processed to HA-LEU for purposes of the program. The bill requires DOE: (1) to conduct a survey of stakeholders to estimate the quantity of HA-LEU necessary for domestic commercial use for each of the five subsequent years; (2) to assess options available for DOE to acquire HA-LEU for the program, including the cost and amount of time required; (3) to establish a consortium to partner with DOE to support the availability of HA-LEU for domestic commercial use, including by providing information and purchasing HA-LEU made available by DOE under the program; (4) prior to acquiring HA-LEU, to develop a schedule for cost recovery of HA-LEU made available

Debt Relief and IMF Reform Act of 1999 - Amends the Bretton Woods Agreements Act to prohibit any U.S. director appointed to represent the United States at the International Monetary Fund (IMF) from voting for any proposal to sell or otherwise convert or liquidate gold unless: (1) the Congress has enacted a joint resolution authorizing the approval of such proposal; (2) the IMF has canceled all debts owed to the IMF by the countries eligible for debt relief under the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) Initiative and Haiti; (3) the most recent operational budget of the IMF has been published, with any information that could disrupt financial markets or adversely affect the national security of any country redacted, and the publicly available financial statements of the IMF are reorganized and restated in a manner consistent with its code of good practices and with the principles of transparency and accountability; (4) the Congress has enacted a joint resolution certifying that the IMF is in full compliance with the conditions imposed or required to be imposed by title VI of the Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 1999; (5) the proposal is to sell gold held by the IMF on the effective date of the Second Amendment to the Articles of Agreement of the IMF, only to the member countries that were member countries on August 31,

Directs the Election Assistance Commission to establish a program for making grants to participating states and local governments for carrying out programs to make backup paper ballots available in the case of the failure of a voting system or voting equipment or some other emergency situation in the administration of the regularly scheduled general election for federal office held in November 2008.

Harbor Environmental Dredging and Management Act of 1993 - Amends the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1973 to establish procedures with respect to permits for the disposal of dredged material. <n>Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to develop a national standard for the disposal of sediments contaminated with dioxin.

Clean for Kids Online Act of 2018 This bill amends the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 to require an operator of a website or online service directed to children to delete personal information collected from or about a child under age 13, regardless of whether a parental consent was provided. The bill authorizes states to bring civil actions on behalf of residents for violations of such requirements.

. Cleaning Product Labeling Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill requires cleaning products to bear a label with, and requires manufacturers to include on their websites, a list of all of the product's ingredients, including individual ingredients in dyes, fragrances, and preservatives. Ingredients shall be listed in descending order of predominance in the product by weight, other than ingredients that constitute less than 1% of the product, which may be listed at the end in any order. The list of ingredients on the manufacturer's website shall: (1) include the CAS Registry Number of each ingredient, (2) include an explanation of each ingredient's purpose, and (3) be available in English, Spanish, and any other language the Consumer Product Safety Commission or the Occupational Safety and Health Administration determines necessary to ensure that users of the product are informed as to the complete list of the product's ingredients and their function. A product that is not in conformity with the labeling and Internet website listing requirements shall be treated as a misbranded hazardous substance under the Federal Hazardous Substances Act. A cleaning product under the jurisdiction of the Consumer Product Safety Commission that is not in conformity with the labeling and Internet website listing requirements shall be treated as a product in violation of a rule promulgated under the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970.

Access to Inpatient Rehabilitation Therapy Act of 2017 This bill amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services to include recreational therapy services among the therapeutic modalities that constitute an intensive rehabilitation therapy program in determining whether inpatient services in an inpatient rehabilitation facility are reasonable and necessary.

This bill amends the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to establish the Marketplace Health Insurance Corporation as a nonprofit corporation to: administer the federal health care exchange, the state health care exchange, and health insurance oversight; and establish a board of directors to advise the chief executive officer on the operation of the federal and state health care exchanges and health insurance oversight.

America's Cup Act of 2011 - Authorizes eligible competing or supporting vessels operating only in preparation for, or in connection with, the 34th America's Cup commencing in 2011 in the United States to position competing vessels and transport individuals, equipment, and supplies for such competition in and around U.S. ports. Prohibits vessels from operating unless issued an Eligibility Certification from the Administrator of the Maritime Administration of the Department of Transportation (DOT). Authorizes the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) to issue a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement for the LNG GEMINI, LNG LEO, and LNG VIRGO. Terminates such coastwise endorsements upon the sale of such vessel by its owner.

Precision Agriculture Research, Education, and Information Dissemination Act of 1996 - Amends the Competitive, Special, and Facilities Research Grant Act to require the Secretary of Agriculture, in collaboration with the National Agricultural Research, Extension, Education, and Economics Advisory Board, to ensure that research, education, and information dissemination grants are designed to develop and demonstrate precision agriculture, where appropriate, consistent with the development and promotion of such agriculture.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt from the special limitation on contributions of capital gain property any qualified conservation contribution or any other contribution of capital gain property which is real property if the contribution is of the donor's entire interest in such property and is to a qualified organization which is organized for conservation purposes. Permits the unlimited carryover (for both qualified conservation contributions and qualified conservation contributions) for such contributions.Revises the rules relating to the estate tax exclusion for land subject to a qualified conservation easement to: (1) repeal certain restrictions on where land is located; and (2) provide that the applicable percentage of the value of land subject to such easement shall be such values as of the date of the contribution.

Campaign Truth and Fairness Act of 1997- Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 (FECA) to prohibit national and congressional campaign committees of political parties from soliciting or accepting contributions or transfers not subject to the limitations, prohibitions, and reporting requirements of FECA. <n>Subjects any amount solicited, received, expended, or disbursed directly or indirectly by a national, State, district, or local committee of a political party with respect to any of the following activities to the limitations, prohibitions, and reporting requirements of FECA: (1) any get-out-the-vote activity conducted during a calendar year in which an election for the office of President is held; (2) any other get-out-the-vote activity unless it applies to the activity; (3) any generic campaign activity; (4) voter registration; (5) development and maintenance of voter files during an even-numbered calendar year; and (6) any other activity that significantly affects a Federal election or that is not otherwise described in FECA. <n>Subjects any get-out-the-vote activity for a State or local candidate, or for a ballot measure, conducted by a State, district, or local committee of a political party to the limitations, prohibitions, and reporting requirements of FECA.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on June 2, 2016. (Sec. 1) This bill directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to arrange for the posthumous presentation of a Congressional Gold Medal in commemoration of World War II veteran Thomas Wallenberg in recognition of his achievements and heroic actions during the Holocaust. Such medal shall be displayed at the Smithsonian Institution, which is urged to make the medal available for display at other locations associated with Wallenberg.

Reinvigorating Antibiotic and Diagnostic Innovation Act of 2015 Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a general business tax credit for 50% of qualified clinical testing expenses for a qualified infectious disease product. Defines qualified infectious disease product" as any drug or biological product for human use that is intended to treat a serious or life-threatening infection and is intended to treat an infection for which there is an unmet medical need."

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 4, 2013. Somalia Stabilization Act of 2013 (Sec. 1) Expresses the sense of Congress that: the government of Somalia and its national security forces and African Union peacekeeping forces should be supported; the United States should continue to support the efforts of the government of Somalia and the African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) to maintain peace and stability in Somalia; the people and government of Somalia should develop professional and regional tactics based on terrorist threats and preventing human rights abuses; and the United States should continue to support the international community's efforts to provide humanitarian services to Somalia and the African Union peacekeeping force should be maintained. States that it is in the national interest of the United States to support the government of Somalia and its national security forces and African Union peacekeeping force. (Sec. 2) Authorizes the President to provide assistance to the government of Somalia and its national security forces and African Union peacekeeping force for FY2014-FY2017. States that such assistance shall: (1) be provided solely for the purpose of providing advice, assistance, training, or military equipment to the government of Somalia and its national security forces; and (2) be conditioned on such government submitting to the United Nations (U.N.) and

Public Broadcasting Reauthorization Act of 2004 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to authorize appropriations to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting for FY 2007 through 2011 for: (1) 40 percent of the total amount of non-Federal financial support received by public broadcasting entities during the second fiscal year preceding each fiscal year; and (2) the transition from the use of analog to digital technology for the provision of public telecommunications services and for the acquisition or production of digital programming of local, regional, and national interest.<n><n>Authorizes appropriations for FY 2005 through 2011 to the Satellite Interconnection Fund, with specified amounts available if the amount appropriated to the Fund for FY 2005 is less than $250 million.
