Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to make such funds available to the Corporation, at the beginning of FY 2005 and of each succeeding fiscal year thereafter, such funds as have been appropriated to that Fund for the fiscal year in which such disbursement is to be made.<n><n>Revises requirements concerning the recovery of funds by the Corporation as it ceases to provide public telecommunications services or transfers or assigns its broadcast license or permit to an entity that will not provide public telecommunications services. Requires, upon request by the Corporation, such an entity to: (1) return any or all unexpended funds for all grants made

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 2, 2017. Portable Fuel Container Safety Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) to promulgate a final rule for flame mitigation devices in portable fuel containers that impedes the propagation of flame into the container, except as provided in the bill. The rule shall be treated as a consumer product safety rule and shall not apply if the CPSC determines that: there is a voluntary standard for flame mitigation devices in such containers that impedes the propagation of flame into the container; the standard is, or will be in effect within 18 months after enactment of this bill; and the standard is developed by a standard development organization that the CPSC determines has met the intent of this bill. Any determination made by the CPSC shall be published in the Federal Register. The requirements of a voluntary standard shall be treated as a consumer product safety rule promulgated under the Consumer Product Safety Act if the standard meets the conditions of the bill. If a voluntary standard meets the conditions of the bill, the standard shall become enforceable as a consumer product safety rule unless the CPSC determines that the revised standard does not meet the requirements. The CPSC may initiate a rulemaking to modify

Social Security Preservation through Individual Choice Enhancement Act - Amends the Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010 to allow an individual taxpayer an election to take a payroll tax cut during a payroll tax holiday period beginning in or after 2012. Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to extend the increase in retirement age by one month for taxpayers who elect to take an employee payroll tax cut.

Directs the Secretary to establish a panel to determine the fair market value of the coal reserves of any withdrawn application.<n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) issue to the Navajo Nation patents to the land, including the mineral estate, subject to the coal preference right lease application withdrawn in satisfaction of the right of the Navajo Nation to select land in New Mexico to facilitate land consolidation and facilitate mineral development in northwest New Mexico; and (2) issue a certificate of bidding rights in the amount of such fair market value.

Columbia River Restoration Act of 2010 - Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish a Lower Columbia River Estuary Program within the National Estuary Program to: (1) restore and sustain fish and wildlife habitat in the Lower Columbia River Estuary; and (2) promote the health of fish, wildlife, and humans in the Columbia River Basin.

Alternative Minimum Tax Repeal Act of 1995 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal the alternative minimum tax. Limits the aggregate amount of the tax credit allowed for the taxable year to the taxpayer's regular tax liability for the taxable year. (Currently, the credit is limited to 25 percent of the taxpayer's net regular tax liability as exceeds $25,000.)

United States-Panama Security Act of 1997 - Prohibits U.S. assistance from being provided to the Republic of Panama if former U.S. military facilities in Panama are conveyed to a foreign government-owned entity. <n>Directs the President to instruct the U.S. representative to each international financial institution to which the United States is a member to use the vote of the United States to oppose any loans or other forms of assistance to Panama any period of time during which the Government of Panama is in violation of the requirements of this Act, including the control by Hutchison Whampoa of ports and Balboa and San Cristobal in Panama, of the Panama Canal, and of how the strategic interests of the United States will be protected after Panama assumes sole responsibility for the defense of the Canal. <n>Requires the President to report to the Congress: (1) a description of how the control by Hutchison Whampoa of ports and San Cristobal in Panama poses a threat to the security of Panama; and (2) how the strategic interests of the United States will be protected after Panama assumes sole responsibility for the defense of the Canal.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 21, 2015. Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) Directs the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), in order to provide timely and effective disaster warnings, to modernize and implement the integrated United States public alert and warning system to ensure that the President is able to alert governmental authorities and the civilian population in areas endangered by disasters under all conditions. Directs FEMA, consistent with the final recommendations of the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Advisory Committee (established by this Act), to: establish or adopt common alerting and warning protocols, standards, terminology, and operating procedures; include in such system the capability to adapt the distribution and content of communications on the basis of geographic location, risks, or personal user preferences and to alert, warn, and provide the equivalent amount of information to individuals with disabilities and individuals with access and functional needs; ensure that training, tests, and exercises for such system are conducted and the system is incorporated into other training and exercise programs of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS); establish and integrate into the National Incident Management System a comprehensive and periodic training program to instruct and educate federal, state, tribal, and local government officials in the use of the Common Alert

Authorizes the Director of the National Science Foundation (NSF), in cooperation with the Secretary of Education and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), to provide assistance for the creation and support of regional centers for the utilization of educational technologies (ETU Centers). Allows ETU Centers to be established at any intermediate school district, regional education service agency, institution of higher education, or consortium of such entities. Declares that the objective of ETU Centers is to enhance the use of educational technologies in elementary and secondary education through: (1) advising teachers, administrators, and school board members on the adoption and utilization of new educational technologies and the utility of local schools' existing educational technology assets and infrastructure; (2) participation of individuals from the private sector, universities, State and local governments, and other Federal agencies; (3) active dissemination of technical and management information about the use of educational technologies; and (4) utilization of the expertise and capabilities that exist in Federal laboratories and Federal agencies.Requires ETU Centers' activities to include: (1) active transfer and dissemination of research findings and ETU Center expertise to local school authorities; (2) training of teachers in the integration of local schools' existing educational technology infrastructure into their instructional design; (3) training and advising teachers, administrators, and school board members

Directs the Secretary of the Air Force to carry out a demonstration program to assess the feasibility and advisability of permitting individuals with auditory impairments (including deafness) to access as officers of the Air Force. Requires the total number of candidates to be at least 15 individuals or more than 20. Requires all participants to undergo, at the election of the Secretary, the Basic Officer Training course or the Commissioned Officer Training course at Maxwell Air Force Base, Alabama. Requires: (1) the Secretary to publicize the program nationally and create a process whereby interested individuals can apply; and (2) the Secretary to select program participants from among a pool of applicants.

Designer Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2014 - Amends the Controlled Substances Act to: (1) expand the list of substances defined as anabolic steroids"; (2) authorize the Attorney General to issue a temporary order adding a drug or other substance to the list of anabolic steroids; (3) impose enhanced criminal and civil penalties for possessing or trafficking in any anabolic steroid, or product containing an anabolic steroid, unless it bears a label clearly identifying the anabolic steroid by the nomenclature used by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry; and (4) authorize the Attorney General to collect data and analyze products to determine whether they contain anabolic steroids and are properly labeled."

Protect Adolescent Video Game Sex Violence Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit the sale or rental to minors of video games that contain sexual or violent content, or that depict human nudity or other explicit human sexual behavior, including rape or other sexual conduct, sexual intercourse, or fondling of genitals. Sets fines of up to $1,000 and up to $5,000 for the first and subsequent violations. Authorizes the Attorney General to bring a civil action against violators of this Act.

HOPE VI Program Reauthorization and Small Community Mainstreet and Housing Act of 2003 - (Sec. 2) Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to revise selection criteria for the HOPE VI public housing reconstruction program.(Sec. 3) Authorizes the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to make grants to smaller communities to assist in the development of affordable housing for low-income families in connection with main street revitalization or redevelopment projects in such communities. Authorizes appropriations.(Sec. 4) Revises the definition of severely distressed public housing" to specify that such housing is lacking in sufficient appropriate transportation, supportive services, economic opportunity, schools, civic and religious institutions, and public services, resulting in severe social distress in the project.(Sec. 5) Extends the program through FY 2005.(Sec. 6) Authorizes appropriations for FY 2004 and 2005 for the HOPE VI program.(Sec. 7) Directs the Secretary to establish criteria for the award of grants under such program that include: (1) the extent to which the applicant can commence and complete the plan expeditiously; (2) the extent to which the plan minimizes temporary or permanent displacement of current public housing residents who wish to remain in or return to the revitalized community and provides for community and supportive services to residents prior to any relocation"

Theodore Roosevelt Commemorative Coin Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue five-dollar gold coins, one-dollar silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins emblematic of Theodore Roosevelt and his commitment to the protection and conservation of the Nation's natural resources. <n>Mandates that all surcharges received from the coin sales be promptly paid by the Secretary to the Theodore Roosevelt Association to further its conservation efforts.

Iran Refined Petroleum Sanctions Act - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the United States should continue to support diplomatic efforts in the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and the United Nations Security Council (UN Security Council) to prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapons capability; (2) diplomatic efforts with Iran are more likely to be effective if the President is empowered with the explicit authority to impose additional sanctions on the government of Iran; (3) it should be the policy of the United States to encourage foreign governments to direct state-owned entities to cease all investment in, and support of, Iran's energy sector and all exports of refined petroleum products; (4) the President is urged to impose sanctions on the Central Bank of Iran and any other Iranian bank or financial institution engaged in proliferation activities or support of terrorist groups; (5) the President is urged to impose sanctions on the Central Bank of Iran and any other Iranian bank or financial institution engaged in activities that could contribute to the enhancement of Iran's ability to import refined petroleum products; and (6) the President should consider imposing sanctions on a foreign bank or financial institution that aids Iran acquire or develop a nuclear weapons capability.

Free Speech Protection Act of 2008 - Authorizes any U.S. person against whom a lawsuit is brought in a foreign country for defamation on the basis of the content of any writing, commentators, or other speech by that person that has been published, defamation, or otherwise disseminated in the United States to bring an action in a U.S. district court against any such person if the writing, commentators, or other speech issue does not constitute in the United States an action for defamation or otherwise based on speech that occurs in the United States. Requires the United States to establish jurisdiction over the person or entity bringing such an action and seeks only to protect the First Amendment rights of Americans in connection with speech that occurs in the United States.

NATO Expansion Act of 1994 - Expresses the sense of the Congress that: (1) the leaders of the NATO member nations are to be commended for reaffirming that NATO membership remains open to European countries emerging from communist domination and for eventual expansion of NATO to include such countries; (2) Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovakia should be in a position to further the principles of the North Atlantic Treaty and to contribute to the security of the North Atlantic area not later than January 10, 1999, five years from the date of the establishment of the Partnership for Peace; and (3) the United States, other NATO member nations, and NATO itself should furnish appropriate assistance to facilitate the transition of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovakia to full NATO membership not later than January 10, 1999, and at the appropriate time they should be invited to become full NATO members. <n>Authorizes the President to establish a program to assist in the transition to full NATO membership of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and other European countries emerging from communist domination. Requires the program to facilitate such transition by supporting and encouraging: (1) joint planning, training, and military exercises with NATO forces; (2) greater interoperability of military equipment, air defense systems, and command, control, and communications systems; and

Reduce Unnecessary Spending Act of 2010 - Amends the Impoundment Control Act of 1974 (ICA) to require the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to transmit, within 45 days after the enactment of the funding in question, a message to Congress with specified information requesting any rescission the President proposes under the procedures in this Act. OMB shall deliver such message to the Secretary of the Senate if the Senate is not in session and to the Clerk of the House of Representatives if the House is not in session.<n><n>Authorizes the President, after enactment of either a joint resolution making continuing appropriations, a supplemental appropriations bill, or an omnibus appropriations bill, to propose as many as two packages rescinding funding contained in that legislation, each within 45 days of the enactment of the funding. OMB shall not include the same rescission in both packages, and if the President requests the rescission of more than one discrete amount of funding under the jurisdiction of a single subcommittee, include each of those discrete amounts in the same package.<n><n>Sets forth requirements for timing and packaging of rescission requests.

ED 1.0 Act - Establishes within the National Telecommunications and Information Administration a pilot program under which the Administrator of such Administration shall award four grants to eligible educational institutions to develop digital and wireless networks for online educational programs of study within such institutions. Defines eligible educational institution" as a historically Black college or university, a Hispanic-serving institution, a tribally controlled college or university, an Alaska Native-serving institution, or a Native Hawaiian-serving institution. Requires the Administrator to give the highest priority to an institution that serves a county in which: (1) 50 percent of the residents are members of a racial or ethnic minority; (2) less than 18 percent of the residents have obtained a baccalaureate degree or a higher education; (3) has an unemployment rate of 7 percent or greater; (4) 19 percent or more of the residents of the county live in poverty; (5) has a negative population growth rate; or (6) has a median family income of $32,000."

Corporate Tax Fairness and Shareholder Rights Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to treat acquiring corporations incorporate expatriation transactions" as domestic corporations. Defines a "corporate expatriation transaction" as, with certain exceptions, one in which a "nominally foreign corporation" acquires substantially all of the properties held by a domestic corporation and in which, immediately after the transaction, more than 80 percent of the stock of the acquiring corporation is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation. Lowers the 80 percent threshold to 50 percent when the acquiring "nominally foreign corporation" lacks substantial business activities in the foreign country in which it was created and organized and the stock is publicly traded, with the principal market of trading being the United States. Defines the terms "nominally foreign corporation" and "expanded affiliated group."Requires the Securities and Exchange Commission to require a series of related transactions to be treated as one transaction, and stock held by members of the expanded affiliated group which includes the acquiring corporation shall not be taken into account in determining ownership.Applies the amendments made by this Act to transactions completed after September 11, 2001."

Amends Federal civil service law with respect to participation in the Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) of the Federal Employees' Retirement System. Allows any employee or Member of Congress who elects to make TSP contributions and separates from Government employment to elect to have the nonforfeitable account balance paid to the participant in a single payment unless the employee or Member elects, at such time and otherwise in such manner as the Executive Director of the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board prescribes, one of the following options: (1) pay the nonforfeitable account balance to the participant in a single payment unless the employee or Member elects, at such time and otherwise in such manner as the Executive Director prescribes, one of the options available; or (2) make an election to receive an annuity directly from an eligible retirement plan or plans (as defined under the Internal Revenue Code).

Improved Medical Decision Incentive Act of 2007 - Allows a state health department to approve best practices in a course of, or as a means of treatment for, a particular condition, illness, or procedure as the qualifying standard of care for the state in order to take advantage of the differential rates of payment implemented under titles XVIII (Medicare) and XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act and a private insurance incentive.

Medicare Patient Empowerment Act - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to allow any Medicare beneficiary to enter into a contract with a participating or non-participating physician or practitioner for any item or service covered by Medicare. Allows such beneficiaries to submit a claim for Medicare payment in the amount that would otherwise apply if the claim had been filed by a participating physician or practitioner in the payment area where the physician or practitioner covered by the contract resides. Requires a Medicare beneficiary to agree in writing in such a contract to: (1) pay the physician or practitioner for a Medicare-covered item or service; and (2) submit (in lieu of the physician or practitioner) a claim for Medicare payment. Allows a beneficiary, however, to negotiate, as a term of the contract, for the physician or practitioner to file such claims on the beneficiary's behalf.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 16, 2015. Child Nicotine Poisoning Prevention Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill requires liquid nicotine provided in a liquid nicotine container sold, manufactured for sale, distributed in commerce, or imported into the United States to be packaged in accordance with certain standards for child-resistant packaging. This requirement shall not be construed to limit or otherwise affect the authority of the Department of Health and Human Services to regulate, issue guidance, or take action regarding the manufacture, marketing, sale, distribution, importation, or packaging of nicotine, liquid nicotine containers, electronic cigarettes, electronic nicotine delivery systems, or other similar products that contain or dispense liquid nicotine, or any other nicotine-related products, including: authority under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act; authority for the rulemaking entitled "Deeming Tobacco Products to be Subject to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, as Amended by the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act; regulations on the Sale and Distribution of Tobacco Products and the Required Warning Statements for Tobacco Products; and subsequent actions by the Department of Health and Human Services regarding packaging of liquid nicotine containers. If the Department adopts, maintains, enforce

Hospital Price Reporting and Disclosure Act of 2005 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require hospitals and ambulatory surgical centers to report to the Secretary of Health and Human Services specified data regarding: (1) the frequency with which the hospital performed each service in an inpatient or outpatient setting and the frequency with which the hospital administered a drug in an inpatient setting; (2) the total number of times the service was performed or the drug was so administered; and (3) the average and the median charge by the hospital for such service or drug. Requires the Secretary to promptly post data reported on the Department of Health and Human Services public Internet site in a manner that promotes charge comparisons among hospitals and ambulatory surgical centers. Requires a hospital and an ambulatory surgical center to prominently post at each admission site a notice of the availability of such data.

Directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President Pro Tempore of the Senate to arrange for the presentation of a congressional gold medal to the family and community of Raul Julia in recognition of his contributions to American culture and the Puerto Rican community.

Junk Fax Prevention Act of 2004 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit a person from using any telephone facsimile (fax) machine, computer, or other device to send, to another fax machine, an unsolicited advertisement: (1) to a person who has made a request to such sender not to send future unsolicited advertisements; or (2) to a person not described above, unless the sender has an established business relationship and the advertisement contains a conspicuous notice on its first page that the recipient may request not to be sent any future unsolicited advertisements, and that failure to comply with such request is unlawful. Requires such request to: (1) identify the telephone number of the sender to which the request relates; (2) be made to the telephone or facsimile number of the sender or by any other method of communication; and (3) have not been provided express invitation or permission to send such advertisements. Requires the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to report annually to Congress on the enforcement of such prohibition.

Sudan and Lasting Peace in Sudan Act of 2008 - (Sec. 4) Declares that sanctions imposed against the government of Sudan that were imposed pursuant to any provision of law, including sanctions against the government of Sudan pursuant to any executive order or other administrative action, shall not be lifted until the President certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that the government of Sudan: (1) has met specified conditions; (2) has implemented the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) and the Abyei Boundary Commission (ABC) recommendations; (3) has hands over to the International Criminal Court (ICC) all indicted individuals and allows deployment of the United Nations African Union Mission in Sudan (UNAMID) and access to humanitarian workers; (4) has taken actions to protect civilians in Darfur and other parts of Sudan consistent with theCPA and the ABC; (5) has made substantial progress toward achieving peace in Darfur, including implementing the Abyei Boundary Commission and allowing humanitarian access; and (6) is respecting the sovereignty and right to self-defense of the people of Sudan as required under the Comprehensive Peace Agreement and has taken actions to demobilize the Janjaweed militia. (Sec. 5) Prohibits presidential waiver of the requirements of this Act until the President certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that: (1) the government of Sudan has

Eliminating Improper and Abusive IRS Audits Act of 2014 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to civil damages for negligence or reckless or intentional disregard of revenue laws, to increase the amount of damages and extend from 2 to 5 years the period for bringing a civil action against the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) for such negligence or intentional disregard. Increases penalties for: (1) unauthorized inspection or disclosure of tax returns and return information; and (2) unauthorized disclosures of tax returns and return information. Extends from 9 to 3 years the period in which a taxpayer may contest a levy of tax property. Increases monetary penalties for unauthorized disclosures of tax returns and return information. Prohibits: (1) the Administrator of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) from raising new issues on an appeal of a decision by the Commissioner of the IRS, and (2) the Administrator from entering into a new contract with a private, nonprofit social welfare organization without the organization's consent. Extends from 2 to 5 years the period for terminating a taxpayer's eligibility for social welfare benefits based upon misconduct by an IRS employee. Directs the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration to review the use of declaratory judgment procedures by federal agencies in cases involving misconduct by employees in connection with revenue laws and

Nuclear Innovation Act (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Department of Energy (DOE) to carry out a program to enhance the nation's capabilities to develop new reactor technologies through high-performance modeling and simulation techniques. (Sec. 4) DOE must also implement a program to enable the testing and demonstration of reactor concepts to be proposed and funded by the private sector. The program must leverage the technical expertise of federal agencies and DOE National Laboratories to minimize the time required to enable construction and operation of privately funded experimental reactors at National Laboratories or other DOE-owned sites while ensuring reasonable safety for persons working within those sites. DOE must submit a report to Congress assessing its capabilities to authorize, host, and oversee privately funded fusion and advanced fission experimental reactors.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 5, 2014. Oregon Coastal Land Conveyance Act (Sec. 3) This bill requires 14,804 acres of federal land in Oregon administered by the Bureau of Land Management and located in the Coos Bay District, the Eugene District, the Medford District, the Roseburg District, the Salem District, and the Klamath Falls Resource Area of the Lakeview District to be held in trust by the United States for the benefit of the Confederated Tribes of Coos, Lower Umpqua, and Siuslaw Indians and part of their reservation. Federal law applies to the export of unprocessed logs harvested from such land and to any real property taken into trust under this bill that shall not be eligible for any gaming activity carried out on it. Any commercial forestry activity carried out on such land shall be managed in accordance with all applicable federal laws. (Sec. 7) The Department of the Interior and the Department of Agriculture (USDA) shall identify any land owned by the Oregon and California Railroad that is conveyed under this bill and shall apply to the export of unprocessed logs harvested from such land and to any real property taken into trust under this bill.

Broadband Deployment and Competition Enhancement Act of 2001 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to provide that an incumbent local exchange carrier shall not be subject to specified network management requirements with respect to any optical fiber facility, or any technology of like functionality, in the carrier's network that is used to provide service to residential customers, and that is or was deployed: (1) where no outside telephone distribution plant previously existed; or (2) from any structure or premise to a customer premises.Requires any provider of facilities capable of providing advanced service to have the duty to coordinate and cooperate with other local exchange carriers to provide access to rights of way consistent with this Act.Declares that nothing in this Act shall preclude the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) or a State from requiring that an incumbent local exchange carrier provide an existing copper loop to another local exchange carrier upon request.Prohibits an incumbent local exchange carrier from being subject to specified requirements with respect to its packet switching capability, or any successor technology, or with respect to the resale of advanced service or high-speed Internet access service.Requires such carrier to: (1) provide collocation at its central offices in accordance with FCC rules; and (2) build-out, within five years after this Act's enactment, all of its local exchange service customers in

Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA) to establish a pilot program to allow States, local educational agencies, and schools to use and combine Federal, State, and local funds as part of systemic educational reform plans to improve the educational achievement of elementary and secondary school students by waiving certain statutory and regulatory requirements.Authorizes the Secretary of Education to waive certain statutory and regulatory requirements for States that can demonstrate that such waivers are part of a systemwide education reform plan and where such States and local educational agencies have implemented similar waiver plans, including requirements relating to: (1) the Head Start Act; (2) the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act; (3) the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act; (4) the National School Lunch Act; (5) the School Breakfast Program; (6) the Child and Adult Care Food Program; (7) the Special School Milk Program; (8) the Summer Food Service Program; and (9) the Community Services Block Grant Program.

Truth in Tuna Labeling Act of 2003 - Amends the Dolphin Protection Consumer Information Act to make it a violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act for any producer, importer, exporter, distributor, or seller of any tuna product exported from or offered for sale in the United States to include the term Dolphin Safe" or any other term or symbol that claims or suggests that the tuna contained in the product was harvested using a method of fishing that is not harmful to dolphins if the tuna product contains tuna harvested: (1) on the high seas by a vessel engaged in driftnet fishing; (2) outside the eastern tropical Pacific Ocean by a vessel using purse seine nets; (3) in a fishery in which the Secretary of Commerce has determined that a regular and significant association occurs between dolphins and tuna (similar to the association between dolphins and tuna in the eastern tropical Pacific Ocean), unless the product is accompanied by a written statement certifying that no purse seine net was intentionally deployed on dolphins or used to encircle dolphins and that no dolphins were intentionally chased or harassed during the particular voyage on which the tuna were caught and no dolphins were killed or seriously injured in the sets in which the tuna were caught; or (4) in any other fishery (other than a fishery in which the Secretary has determined that no purse seine net was intentionally"

Setting Aside for a Valuable Education (SAVE) Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from income distributions from qualified State tuition programs used to pay qualified higher education expenses.Amends the Code to permit private qualified tuition programs established and maintained by eligible educational institutions to be used to pay the qualified higher education expenses of the designated beneficiary.

Teachers Professional Development Institutes Act - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to award grants for the establishment and operation of Teachers Institutes, partnerships or joint ventures between institutions of higher education and local educational agencies (LEAs) that serve one or more schools with significant low-income student populations. Includes among selection criteria the extent to which a proposed Teachers Institute will serve schools that have significant low-income student populations.

International Statistical Information and Analysis Act of 1993 - Amends Federal law to require the Secretary of Commerce (Secretary) to prepare and submit to the Congress an annual report analyzing the progress being made by the independent states of the former Soviet Union and the Baltic states in establishing a free market economy. <n>Requires the President to establish the International Statistical Assistance Coordinating Committee to coordinate the collection and analysis of economic statistical information regarding such states.

Preventing Scams for Seniors Act of 2010 or the PASS Act of 2010- Requires each financial institution to: (1) educate its customers and staff about affinity scams and how to identify such scams; and (2) provide educational materials and other information to seniors who maintain a deposit account with it about affinity scams and how to identify transactions that may be part of such a scam. Defines af scam" as a transaction in which a person trusted by a senior (such as a caregiver, relative, service provider, or new friend) establishes a relationship with the senior and uses that relationship to defraud the senior."

Declares that nothing in this Act prohibits the discontinuance or modification of any such proceeding, proposed rule, or application under the same terms and conditions and to the same extent that such proceeding, proposed rule, or application could have been discontinued or modified if this Act had not been enacted.

Alcohol Tax Equalization Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the rate of tax on wine and beer. Provides for the treatment of floor stocks. Mandates a cost-of-living adjustment for the tax rates on distilled spirits, wine, and beer. Establishes the Substance Abuse Prevention Trust Fund. Appropriates amounts to the Fund equivalent to the amounts received as a result of this Act. Makes amounts in the Fund available to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration for alcohol abuse prevention programs.

Children's Media Protection Act of 1995 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to direct the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to prescribe rules: (1) on the basis of recommendations from an advisory committee established by the FCC that is composed of television broadcasters, television programming producers, cable operators, public interest groups, and other interested individuals that is fairly balanced in terms of the points of view represented and the functions to be performed by the committee, rules to identify and rate sexual, violent, and indecent television programming that is clearly inappropriate for children; and (2) for the transmission by distributors of television programming of signals that contain an identification of the rating of the programming being distributed and that permit television viewers to block sexual, violent, and indecent television programming that is clearly inappropriate for children. <n>Directs the FCC, in the case of apparatus designed to receive television signals and that have a picture screen 13 inches or greater in size (measured diagonally), to require that such apparatus: (1) be equipped with circuitry designed to enable viewers to block the display of channels, time slots, and programs; and (2) enable viewers to block display of all programs with a common rating. Prohibits any person from shipping, manufacturing, assembling, or importing any television not so equipped, except in accordance

Amends the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act to direct the Administrator of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy (OFPP) to establish and promote a government-wide program to encourage and recognize contractor innovation and excellence in facilitating the defense of the United States against or recovery from terrorism or nuclear, biological, chemical, or radiological attack. Requires the Administrator to: (1) issue agency announcements seeking unique and innovative solutions to advance the defense of the United States against such attack; and (2) convene a multiagency technical assistance team to assist in screening proposals to provide such solutions. Provides for monetary awards to recipients of proposals in recognition of unique and innovative solutions with the potential to significantly advance such defense. Directs the Administrator to establish a pilot program under which the Secretaries of Defense, Energy, Commerce, Transportation, and the Treasury may test the innovative use of streamlined acquisition authorities and procedures and the feasibility of rapidly entering into contracts with private entities to carry out immediate solutions to key homeland security needs.

Fighting Medicare Payment Fraud Act of 2009 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act with respect to part A (Hospital Insurance) and part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance) claims to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to extend the number of days in which such claims are required to be paid in order to prevent or combat fraud, waste, or abuse involving a particular category of providers or suppliers.

Vaccine Accessibility for Children and Seniors Act of 2005 or the VACS Act of 2005 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a federal cause of action for claims arising from a vaccine-related injury or death associated with the administration of a vaccine after October 1, 1988. Requires all procedures and expert testimony to be subject to the rules and requirements set forth by the U.S. Supreme Court in Daubert v. Dow Pharmaceuticals, Inc.

Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2008 - Amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to direct the President, acting through the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), to modernize and implement the integrated United States public alert and warning system to ensure that the President can alert governmental authorities and the civilian population in areas endangered by disasters under all conditions. Requires the Director to: (1) assign responsibility for modernization and implementation of the system to the National Continuity Programs Directorate; and (2) conduct pilot programs to demonstrate the feasibility of using a variety of methods for achieving such system requirements.

Healthy School Meals Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to conduct a pilot program evaluating the use of plant-based alternate protein products in school lunches. Defines plant-based alternate protein product" as an alternate protein product that: (1) meets certain nutritional requirements for meat and meets the nutritional requirements for nondairy fluid milk; and (2) contains no animal-based foods, products, or byproducts."

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on September 19, 2007. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe Fish Springs Ranch Settlement Act (Sec. 3) Ratifies the agreement entitled Fish Springs Ranch Water Rights Settlement Agreement" dated May 20, 2007. (This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on September 19, 2007.)<n><n>(Sec. 4) Requires the execution of the Agreement by the Secretary of the Interior and the Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe, acting on behalf of the Tribe, to waive and release: (1) all claims against Fish Springs Ranch, LLC, for damage, loss, or injury to water rights or claims of interference with or diversion or taking of water rights; and (2) any claims against the United States relating to the use of water by Fish Springs under the Agreement for the Project.<n><n>Requires the Tribe to waive and release any claim of the Tribe against the United States relating in any manner to the negotiation or adoption of the Agreement."

Common Sense Product Liability Reform Act of 1995 - States that this Act governs any product liability action brought in State or Federal court against a manufacturer or product seller on any theory for harm caused by a product only to the extent that State law applies to an issue covered by this Act. Declares that this Act supersedes State law only to the extent that State law applies to an issue covered by this Act. Declares that this Act shall: (1) waive or affect any defense of sovereign immunity asserted by any State under any law; (2) supersede any Federal law, except the Federal Employers Compensation Act and the Longshore and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act; (3) affect the applicability of any provision of Federal law with respect to claims brought by a foreign nation or a citizen of a foreign nation; (4) preempt State choice-of-law rules with respect to claims brought by a foreign nation or a citizen of a foreign nation; (5) affect the right of any court to transfer venue or to apply the law of a foreign nation or to dismiss a claim of a foreign nation on the ground of inconvenient forum; or (6) supersede any Federal law that prescribes a specific regimen for punitive damages. Declares that a product seller shall be liable for harm to a claimant only if the claimant establishes that

Medicare Assurance of Rx Transitional Assistance Act of 2004 - Amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to provide for the automatic enrollment of Medicare part D beneficiaries receiving medical assistance for Medicare cost-sharing under Medicaid into the Medicare prescription drug discount card program, thereby making them eligible for the program as well.

Congressional Coverage for Discrimination and Family Leave Act - Amends the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 to apply such Act's provisions to the employing authorities and employees of the House of Representatives and the instrumentalities of the Congress.

Student Success Act of 2001- Authorizes individuals to enter into human capital investment contracts (HCICs) for the purposes of obtaining funds for the payment of tuition and other related expenses of postsecondary education by agreeing to pay to the holder of the contract a specified percentage of the individual's future earned income.(Sec. 101) Makes any HCIC that complies with required terms and conditions under this Act a valid, binding, and enforceable contract notwithstanding any State law limiting or otherwise regulating assignments of future wages or other income.(Sec. 102) Sets forth terms and conditions of HCICs, including requirements relating to: (1) specification of the percentages of future earned income which the student will be obligated to pay and of the maximum amount of earned income for each year to which such specified percentage shall apply; (2) schedule of reductions in such percentage if the student's earned income from full-time employment is less than such amounts; and (3) provision of a schedule of increases in such percentage if the student obtains a deferral.Prohibits an eligible student from entering into any HCIC if the total percentage of such student's future earned income that the student agrees to pay under that contract, and any other HCICs of such student, exceeds 20 percent of such future

Small Business, Family Farms, and Constitutional Protection Act - Prohibits the use of Federal funds to: (1) propose or issue rules, regulations, decrees, or orders or used to propose or issue rules, regulations, decrees, or orders or for programs designed to implement, or in preparation for implementing, the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change before the date on which the Senate gives its advice and consent to ratification; or (2) promulgate regulations to limit emissions of carbon dioxide unless a law is enacted after enactment of this Act that specifically grants such authority.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on December 10, 2009. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Amends the Defense Production Act of 1950 to reauthorize through FY2019 the Department of Defense (DOD) Production Act of 1950. Requires the Chairperson of the Defense Production Committee to: (1) head an agency to which the President has delegated primary responsibility for government-wide coordination of the priorities and allocations authorities under such Act; and (2) appoint one person to coordinate all of the Committee's activities. Requires the Committee to report by March 31 on contingency planning for events that might require the use of the priorities and allocations authorities under such Act. Requires the Committee to make recommendations for legislation to support the effective use of the priorities and allocations authorities under such Act. Prohibits the taking of any action or actions under such Act to correct an industrial resource shortfall to exceed $50 million, unless such action or actions are authorized to exceed such amount by an Act of Congress. Requires the President, before taking any action that would cause the aggregate outstanding amount of all such actions for such industrial resource shortfall to exceed $50 million, to: (1) determine with appropriate explanatory material and in writing the most cost effective, expedient, and practical alternative method for meeting

Bar Removal of Individuals who Dream and Grow our Economy Act or the BRIDGE Act This bill amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide provisional protected presence for an alien who: (1) is in deferred action status pursuant to the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) Program, (2) was born after June 15, 1981, (3) entered the United States before attaining 16 years of age, (4) continuously resided in the United States between June 15, 2007, and the date on which the alien files an application under this bill; (5) was unlawfully present in the United States on June 15, 2012; and (6) on the date on which the alien files an application for provisional protected presence, is enrolled in school or in an education program assisting students in obtaining a regular high school diploma or its recognized equivalent under state law, has graduated or obtained a certificate of completion from high school, is eligible for provisional protected presence, and shall have employment authorization. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) shall: (1) grant provisional protected presence to an alien who files an application demonstrating that he or she meets eligibility criteria, (2) may not remove the alien from the United States during the period in which such status is in effect unless such status is rescinded, and (3) provide such alien with employment authorization. An alien is eligible for provisional protected presence and employment

Veterans' Health Care Eligibility Reform Act of 1994 - Requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to furnish a continuum of health care to veterans, including specialized treatment and rehabilitative services, as well as hospital and outpatient medical services, on an outpatient or ambulatory basis and noninstitutional long-term care. <n>Directs the Secretary to provide institutional nursing home care to any veteran who is eligible for payment under a State plan title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act for the costs of nursing home care. Entitles the Secretary to recover from a State plan the amount that it would pay for such care if provided by an authorized provider. Deems a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center or group of medical centers to be a Medicare provider. Directs the Secretary, under Medicare provisions, to reimburse a Department health-care facility providing services as a Medicare provider or Medicare HMO in the same amounts and under the same terms and conditions as that Secretary reimburses other Medicare providers or Medicare HMOs. <n>Directs the Secretary to develop a plan to implement over a specified period the provision of institutional long-term care for any veteran eligible for benefits under the Medicare program under title XVIII of the Social Security Act.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 7, 2016. Preventing Iran's Access to United States Dollars Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill prohibits the President from issuing any license under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act that permits a person to: (1) conduct an offshore United States dollar clearing system for transactions involving the government of Iran or an Iranian person, or (2) provide United States dollars for any offshore United States dollar clearing system conducted or overseen by a foreign government or a foreign financial institution for transactions involving the government of Iran or an Iranian person. The bill requires the Department of the Treasury to submit to Congress and publish in the Federal Register: (1) a list of any financial institutions that Treasury has identified as operating an offshore United States dollar clearing system that conducts transactions involving the government of Iran or an Iranian person, or participating in such a transaction through such a system; and (2) a detailed assessment of Treasury's status of efforts to prevent such transactions. The President shall block and prohibit all transactions in property and property interests of any financial institution specified in the most recent list if such property and property interests are in the United States or within the possession or control of a U.S. person. The President may impose additional sanctions on a financial institution

Defines applicable oversight entity" as any entity with responsibility for oversight of the activities of the Internal Revenue Service, including Congress, the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration, the Comptroller General, and the Internal Revenue Service Oversight Board. Prohibits the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) from conducting any audit, investigation, or examination of a taxpayer that is primarily for the purpose of research. Directs the IRS Commissioner to repurpose resources for the National Research Program to combat tax refund fraud and identity theft."

Hurricane Katrina Employment and Training Assistance Act - (Sec. 2) Allows national emergency grant funds to states under the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 (WIA) for addressing the effects of Hurricane Katrina (Katrina) to be used to provide disaster relief employment on projects that provide assistance in areas outside of the Katrina-disaster area. Allows such funds to be used to provide disaster relief employment and other WIA assistance, or temporary general public sector employment, to: (1) individuals who were unemployed at the time of the emergency or major disaster involved, in addition to individuals who are without employment history; and (2) workers affected by Katrina, including workers who have relocated from areas for which an emergency or major disaster was declared due to its effects. Authorizes the Secretary of Labor to extend the six-month maximum duration of employment under this Act and WIA for up to an additional six months due to extraordinary circumstances.<n><n>Directs the Secretary, in awarding WIA national emergency grants for disaster relief employment, to give priority: (1) first, to states with major disaster areas; and (2) second, to the remaining states that have been most heavily impacted by the demand for services by Katrina-affected workers.<n><n>Prohibits an entity, in providing disaster relief employment under this Act, from denying

Every Child Deserves a Family Act - Prohibits an entity that receives federal assistance and is involved in adoption or foster care placements from categorically denying to any person the opportunity to become an adoptive or a foster parent solely on the basis of the sexual orientation, gender identification, or marital status of the person; delaying or denying the placement of a child for adoption or into foster care, or otherwise discriminating in making a placement decision, solely on such basis; or denying or limiting the parental rights of an adoptive parent based on such parent's sexual orientation, gender identification, or marital status.

Directs the Secretary of Labor, within two years after enactment of this Act, to issue a final rule relating to ergonomic disorders in the workplace which shall: (1) address such disorders and workplace ergonomic hazards; (2) not apply to musculoskeletal disorders that are not related to work; (3) set forth requirements for an employer's compliance obligations, including the prevention of injuries before they occur; and (4) cover all industries where workers are exposed to workplace ergonomic hazards and there are economically and technologically feasible measures to control these hazards.Requires the Secretary, in promulgating the standard, to: (1) consider existing standards on or preventing such disorders established by national consensus or recognized private organizations and other countries; and (2) develop information outreach program and other initiatives to provide compliance assistance to employers and employees.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose an excise tax on the windfall profit from the removal of any domestic crude oil or product of crude oil as exceeds a reasonable profit. Defines windfall profit to mean so much of the profit on such removal as exceeds a reasonable profit.

Independent Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Investigative Commission Act - Establishes the Independent Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Investigative Commission to conduct investigations and report its findings, conclusions, and recommendations to the President and Congress.

Directs such carrier to: (1) make available advanced service to 80 percent of its telephone exchange service customers in a State within three years of this Act's enactment and to make available advanced service to 100 percent of its telephone exchange service customers in a State within five years; and (2) continue to receive all regulatory relief provided by this Act, for any service or combination of services that consists of, or includes, the offering of a capability to transmit information using a packet-switched or successor technology downstream from a provider to a provider at a rated speed of 128 kilobits per second or more where advanced service cannot be provided using an industry-approved standard and existing loop facilities. Declares that, except as provided in this Act, no advanced service offered by an incumbent local exchange carrier nor the facilities used to provide such service shall be subject to common carrier regulation by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) or any State in any exchange where advanced service is being provided by an unaffiliated advanced service provider. Allows such carrier to file a petition with the FCC seeking such relief if the FCC does not act on it within 30 days after it is filed. Requires the FCC, if it determines that such advanced service is being offered by an unaffiliated provider in the manner described, to approve the petition

Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that, in the case of an individual, there shall be allowed a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year an amount equal to 60 percent of the amount paid during the taxable year for coverage for the taxpayer, his spouse, and dependents under qualified health insurance.

Community Health Improvement Councils Act of 2010 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish a program for the creation of State Health Improvement Technical Assistance Centers and Community Health Improvement Councils. Requires the Secretary to award grants, on a competitive basis, to five eligible entities to establish State Health Improvement Technical Assistance Centers designed to: (1) improve individual and community health status, especially in communities and regions with poor health status performance; (2) slow annual growth in health care utilization and medical spending; (3) coordinate best practices among networks of local coalitions that result in accelerated locally driven issue identification and creative ways to align improvement efforts with payment reforms; (4) partner with the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) to design and produce the annual report on health care quality; (5) serve as a resource to communities to provide assistance in identifying reliable national resources and research tools to promote health, improve health literacy, and accelerate the diffusion of innovations to improve health outcomes; (6) partner with organizations to design and implement locally driven payment innovations to improve quality and productivity; and (7) educate state policymakers on the benefits of locally driven community health improvement councils that engage community stakeholders. Defines Community Health Improvement Council" as a locally driven, private nonprofit entity that"

Broadband Regulatory Parity Act of 2002 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to prescribe regulations to ensure that: (1) all broadband services, and all broadband access services, are subject to the same regulatory requirements, or no regulatory requirements; (2) all providers of broadband services, and all providers of broadband access services, are subject to the same regulatory requirements and the facilities and equipment used to provide such services; and (3) such requirements are implemented without increasing the regulatory requirements applicable to any provider of broadband services, or broadband access services, on any such service or on any facilities or equipment used to provide such service. Prohibits State jurisdiction over such services. Requires each incumbent local exchange carrier to provide all Internet service providers with the telecommunications necessary for such provider to provide broadband access service to its subscribers.

Water Quality Protection and Job Creation Act of 2017 This bill amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (commonly known as the Clean Water Act) to reauthorize through FY2022 and revise specified wastewater infrastructure programs and water pollution control programs, including the clean water state revolving fund program and a grant program for protecting groundwater quality.

Financial Privacy and National Security Enhancement Act - Establishes the Presidential Commission on Financial Privacy and National Security to study and report to the President and the Congress on the practices in the financial service industry for protecting the privacy of consumer financial information, the manner and extent to which such practices are regulated by financial service regulators, and ways to improve and strengthen financial information privacy while preserving effective financial information flow for national security.

Stop the Misuse of ITINs Act of 2007 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require the Secretary of the Treasury to provide the Secretary of Homeland Security with information on the taxpayer identification number (ITIN) of individuals not authorized to work in the United States if the Secretary receives a return from an employer showing wages and the TIN of such employee. Requires the Secretary to: (1) notify the employer and employee that such an employee is not authorized to work in the United States and that the employee's employment should be terminated not later than the 30th day after the notice is received; and (2) provide the employer with a copy of such notice and the employee's right to contest the determination that the employee is not authorized to be employed in the United States.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior to take certain lands in Michigan into trust for the Bay Mills Indian Community and certain lands to be held in trust for the Sault Ste. Marie Tribe of Michigan as settlement of claims of the Community and Sault Ste. Marie Tribe for the Charlotte Beach Lands.

Military Savings Act of 2012 - Directs the Under Secretary of Defense (DOD) to carry out a five-year pilot program to develop innovative consumer financial products that encourage savings and wealth-creation among active-duty servicemembers. Allows such financial products to seek to: (1) increase the rate of savings among active-duty servicemembers by providing automatic deposit into a savings account of special pay and allowances received by a servicemember, including special pay and allowances received on account of the servicemember's deployment; (2) reduce the need for high-cost short-term lending services by providing alternatives to servicemembers, such as financial institutions providing an option for servicemembers to receive advances on their salary payments, such that servicemembers receive pay in more frequent installments and where any interest or fees on such advances shall not exceed the lowest rate of basic pay provided under federal law and shall adhere to the Affordable Small Dollar Lending Guidelines of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC); (3) address obstacles to traditional consumer banking and lending for servicemembers with limited credit history; and (4) otherwise encourage savings and wealth-creation among active-duty servicemembers.
Domestic Violence Screening and Treatment Act of 2002 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to provide for coverage of domestic violence screening and treatment services.

Rural Law Enforcement Act of 1997- Amends the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 to establish: (1) the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement at the University of Arkansas, at Little Rock; and (2) the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement Advisory Board. <n>Directs the Attorney General to appoint the Executive Director of the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement. Authorizes the Center to procure temporary and intermittent services for the Advisory Board.

Detainee Basic Medical Care Act of 2008 - Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to: (1) establish procedures for the timely and effective delivery of medical and mental health care to all immigration detainees in Department of Homeland Security (DHS) custody; and (2) report to the House and Senate Judiciary Committees on the death of any immigration detainee in DHS custody.

Spring Mountain Exchange Act of 1998 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to convey to Rhodes Design and Development Corporation specified Federal lands in Nevada in exchange for specified lands and interests of the Corporation. Directs the Secretary to make such conveyance only if the Corporation conveys to the United States all right, title, and interest of the Corporation in and to approximately 490 acres of lands in Nevada depicted on a map entitled Spring Mountain Land Exchange Map 2 dated August ____," 1998."

National Cheese Exchange Oversight and Improvement Act of 1997- Amends the Commodity Exchange Act to direct the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) to regulate a concentrated cash market (the National Cheese Exchange in Green Bay, Wisconsin) and a futures market regulated under the Act as either a cash market or an exchange if the CFTC determines that: (1) the cash market is geographically centralized in the form of a market or exchange; (2) the cash market is very thinly traded or highly illiquid; (3) the price established by the cash market functions as a reference price for a majority of commercial transactions off the cash market for the commodity being traded; (4) trading in the cash market is concentrated among relatively few buyers and sellers; (5) the cash market is substantially unregulated by any other regulatory structure; (6) a futures market regulated under the Act also exists for the commodity that is being traded on the cash market; and (7) the instability, illiquidity, or potential for manipulation for on the cash market could be a deterrent to the use of the futures market for that commodity.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 14, 2013. Critical Infrastructure Protection Act or the CIPA (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), to the extent practicable, to: (1) include in national planning frameworks the threat of electromagnetic pulse (EMP) events and conduct outreach to educate owners and operators of critical infrastructure, emergency planners, and emergency response providers at all levels of government of such threats; and (2) conduct research and development to mitigate the consequences of such events. The scope of such research and development shall include: an objective scientific analysis of the risks to critical infrastructures from a range of EMP events; the determination of the critical national security assets and vital civic utilities and infrastructures that are at risk from EMP events; an evaluation of emergency planning and response technologies that would address the findings and recommendations of experts, including those of the Commission to Assess the Threat to the United States from Electromagnetic Pulse Attack; an analysis of technology options that are available to improve the resiliency of critical infrastructure to EMP; and the restoration and recovery capabilities of critical infrastructure under differing levels of damage and disruption from various EMP events. DHS must submit: (1) a recommended strategy to protect and prepare the critical infrastructure of

Amends part A (Aid to Families with Dependent Children) (AFDC) of title IV of the Social Security Act to require States, to avoid a 50 percent reduction in Federal funding for AFDC administrative expenses, to implement workfare programs for able-bodied residents on welfare aged 18 or over with no dependents.

Pay Disclosure Act - Amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to require employers to provide an initial disclosure to employees when they are hired that includes: (1) the rate or rates of pay and whether the employee is paid by the hour, shift, day week, or job, or by salary, piece rate, commission, or other form of compensation; (2) the name of the employer and any other name used by the employer to conduct business; and (3) the physical address and telephone number of the employer's main office or principal place of business, and its mailing address if such address is different from that of the employer's main office or principal place of business. Requires such disclosure to include: (1) the employee's Social Security number and the last four digits of the employee's Social Security number; (2) the total hours worked during each work period and the hourly rate of pay for each such work period; (3) the total gross and net wages paid, and the rate of pay for each hour worked; (4) any additional compensation paid or benefits provided, including an explanation of each type of compensation or benefit; and (5) the amount of salary paid during the pay period. Requires employers to disclose also in each pay period: (1) the amount of salary paid during the pay period,

Sound Science Saves Species Act of 2002 - Amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to direct the Secretary of the Interior, after receiving a petition from an interested person to add a species to, or to remove a species from, either the endangered or threatened list, to: (1) publish in the Federal Register a notice indicating receipt of such petition and inviting interested persons to submit any relevant scientific information regarding the status of the species concerned; (2) promptly publish the petition on the Internet website of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service; (3) provide notice of such receipt to each private owner of land or water on or in which the species may exist by publication of such notice in an appropriate newspaper of general circulation; and (4) notify the Governor of each State that could be affected by the petition.Directs the Secretary to: (1) appoint and convene an independent review board to conduct an independent scientific review of the data included in the petition; and (2) appoint and convene an independent review board within 90 days after publication of a finding that a petition is warranted.

Health Care Fraud Prosecution Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal criminal code to subject to a fine and/or prison term of up to ten years any person who: (1) knowingly in or affecting interstate commerce executes, or attempts to execute, a scheme or artifice to defraud to obtain a health care payment; or (2) presents to any person any statement as part of, or in support of, a claim for such a payment knowing that it contains any false or misleading information concerning any fact or thing material to such claim. Applies the same penalties to anyone who: (1) knowingly or recklessly causes serious bodily injury to an individual or knowingly or recklessly endangers the life of a person; or (2) knowingly or recklessly causes the death of an individual. <n>Prescribes penalties for illegal remunerations in connection with health care fraud. <n>Authorizes any person injured in business or property by a violation of this Act to recover treble damages in a civil action. Authorizes the court to award the prevailing party a reasonable attorney's fee as part of the costs. <n>Authorizes the Attorney General to pay a reward for information leading to a prosecution or civil recovery under this Act.

National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare Act of 1997 - Establishes the National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare to: (1) review and analyze the long-term financial condition of the Medicare program under title XVIII of the Social Security Act (SSA); (2) identify problems that threaten the financial integrity of the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund; (3) analyze potential solutions to such problems that will ensure both Medicare financial integrity and the provision of appropriate benefits; (4) make recommendations to restore the solvency of the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the financial integrity of the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund through the year 2030, when the last of the baby boomers reaches age 65; (5) make recommendations for establishing the appropriate financial structure of the Medicare program as a whole; (6) make recommendations for establishing the appropriate balance of benefits covered and beneficiary contributions to the Medicare program; (7) make recommendations for the time periods during which the recommendations should be implemented; and (8) review and analyze such other matters as the Commission deems appropriate. <n>Requires a report to the President and the Congress.

National Labor Relations Reorganization Act of 2011- Abolishes the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB).<n><n>Transfers the functions and responsibilities of the NLRB, and any related authorities and functions under the National Labor Relations Act (NLRA), to the Office of Labor-Management Standards of the Department of Labor.<n><n>Establishes within the Department of Justice (DOJ) a Bureau of Labor Relations Enforcement to carry out the enforcement duties and functions currently carried out by the NLRB, as well as the prevention of unfair labor practices.

Guantanamo Bay Detention Facility Safe Closure Act of 2009 - Prohibits federal funds from being used to transfer any detainee at the Naval Station Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to any facility in the United States or its territories.

Rural Energy for America Act of 2006 - Amends the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 to reauthorize and extend the renewable energy systems and energy efficiency improvements program.<n><n>(Sec. 3) Revises the program, including by requiring the Secretary of Agriculture, upon request of an eligible applicant, to make production-based payments in lieu of grants to encourage the production of electricity from renewable energy systems. Limits the total net present value of a production-based incentive to the lower of: (1) 25% of the eligible project costs; and (2) any other limits that the Secretary establishes by rule or guidance.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to provide assistance to eligible applicants to conduct feasibility studies of projects for which assistance may be provided. Directs the Secretary to use not more than 10% of funds made available to carry out such assistance to make such payments in lieu of a grant.<n><n>Requires a recipient to contribute at least 75% of the amount of non-federal funds received.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to establish a program to provide rebates to rural school districts for electricity produced from renewable energy systems. Requires that at least 75% of the electricity produced by a renewable energy system be provided by rural school districts.

Commission to Study the Federal Statistical System Act of 1996 - Establishes the Commission to Study the Federal Statistical System to conduct a comprehensive study of all matters relating to the Federal statistical infrastructure, including longitudinal surveys conducted by private agencies and partially funded by the Federal Government. Authorizes appropriations.

Securing Affordable Vocational and Collegiate Education (SAVE) Act- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) allow a deduction, of up to $5,000, for payments to a qualified State tuition program for the benefit of a designated beneficiary; and (2) exclude from gross income distributions from such programs used for qualified higher education expenses.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose a 50 cents per tire tax on the manufacture or importation of tires. Exempts solid and pneumatic tires from such tax. Establishes the Waste Tire Recycling, Abatement, and Disposal Trust Fund in the Treasury.

Environmental Improvement Timber Contract Extension Act of 1996 - Amends the Tongass Timber Reform Act to extend by 15 years the timber contract between the United States and the Ketchikan Pulp Company.

Legacy IRA Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income up to $400,000 of distributions made directly from an individual retirement account to a specified charitable organization or a split-interest entity. Sets forth related tax rules.

Fair Accountability and Innovative Research Drug Pricing Act of 2016 This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require manufacturers of certain drugs and biological products with sales for Medicare and Medicaid enrollees to report to the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) price increases that result in a 10% or more increase in the average manufacturer price over a 12-month period. Reports are required for prescription drugs and drugs commonly administered in hospitals, except vaccines, drugs for rare conditions, and drugs with annual sales for Medicare and Medicaid enrollees of less than $1. Reports must contain specified information including pricing history and a justification for each price increase in the relevant period. Manufacturers that do not submit a required report are subject to a civil penalty. Collected penalty funds must be used to carry out activities related to this reporting requirement and to improve consumer and provider information about drug value and drug price transparency.

Requires the Director to: (1) promote and advance scientific understanding of pain management and palliative care; and (2) collect and disseminate protocols and evidence-based practices regarding pain management and palliative care, with priority given to pain management for terminally ill patients, and make such information available to public and private health care programs providers, health professions schools, and hospices. Defines pain management and palliative care" to include the active, total care of patients whose disease or medical condition is not responsive to curative treatment or whose prognosis is limited due to progressive, far-advanced disease.Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants, cooperative agreements, and contracts to health professions schools, hospices, and other entities for the development and implementation of programs to provide education and training to health care professionals in pain management and palliative care."
