Prohibits the entry into a covered ozone nonattainment area from a foreign country bordering the United States and contiguous to such area more than twice in a single calendar month period if State law has requirements for inspection and maintenance of such vehicles under the applicable implementation plan in the nonattainment area. Applies such prohibition only if the operator presents documentation at the U.S. border entry point establishing that the vehicle has complied with such requirements as are in effect and applicable to motor vehicles of the same type and model year. Authorizes the President to impose and collect a civil penalty of up to $200 for the second violation or attempted violation and $400 for the third and each subsequent violation or attempted violation. Makes such prohibition inapplicable in any State that elects to be exempt from it. Provides that such prohibition shall not apply in a State, and the President may implement an alternative approach to facilitate the compliance by some or all foreign-registered motor vehicles, with such requirements related to emissions of air pollutants that are practicable in effect under the applicable implementation plan in the covered ozone nonattainment area and applicable to motor vehicles of the same types and model years as the foreign-registered motor vehicles. Declares that nothing in this Act shall require action that is inconsistent with U.S

Navajo Nation Higher Education Act of 2004 - Authorizes appropriations to Dine College for the operation and maintenance of the College. Directs the Secretary of the Interior to fund the operation and maintenance of the College separately from tribal colleges and universities recognized and funded by the Tribally College or University Assistance Act of 1978. Authorizes the College to expend money received from such appropriations on renovations and repairs, and on capital projects.

Federal Asthma Assessment and State Tracking Act of 2002 (FAAST Act) - Amends the Head Start Act to authorize early Head Start and Head Start programs to carry out asthma screening programs.Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to local educational agencies for asthma health screening and case management programs for public school children.States that nothing under any law relating to a program that provides health benefits coverage for children and including the payment limitation known as the free care rule" shall be construed as prohibiting or restricting assistance for children receiving asthma screening tests."

Treat and Reduce Obesity Act of 2017 This bill authorizes the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) to cover intensive behavioral therapy for obesity furnished by: a physician who is not a qualified primary care physician; any other appropriate health care provider; a clinical psychologist, a registered dietitian or nutrition professional; or an evidence-based, community-based lifestyle counseling program approved by the CMS. In the case of such therapy furnished by a provider upon referral from, and in coordination with, a physician or primary care practitioner operating in a primary care setting or any other setting specified by the CMS, the CMS shall cover it only if it is furnished: (1) in an office setting, a hospital out-patient department, a community-based site that complies with the federal regulations concerning the privacy of individually identifiable health information, or another CMS-specified setting; and (2) in an office setting, a hospital out-patient department, a community-based site that complies with the federal regulations concerning the privacy of individually identifiable health information.

Makes eligible for such grants States that have in effect laws that penalize computer crime, provide assurances that they have in effect penal laws prohibiting fraudulent schemes executed by means of a computer system or network, the unlawful damaging, destroying, altering, deleting, removing of computer software, or data contained in a computer, computer system, computer program, or computer network, or the unlawful interference with the operation of or denial of access to a computer, computer program, computer system, or computer network; an assessment of the State and local resource needs, including criminal justice resources being devoted to computer crime investigation and enforcement; and a plan for coordinating funded programs with other federally funded technical assistant and training programs, including directly funded local programs such as the Local Law Enforcement Block Grant program (described under the heading Violent Crime Reduction Programs, State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance" of the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State, the Judiciary, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1998). Limits the Federal share of a grant received to 90 percent unless the Attorney General waives requirements of this Act. Authorizes the Attorney General to use amounts made available under this Act to make grants to Indian tribes."

Smoke Free Mothers and Babies Act of 2006 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to require coverage of counseling and pharmacotherapy for cessation of tobacco use by pregnant women under the Medicaid program.

Authorizes appropriations to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Bureau of Reclamation, to undertake capital projects for the Recovery Implementation Program for Endangered Fish Species in the Upper Colorado River Basin and the San Juan River Basin Recovery Implementation Program. Limits to $100 million the total costs of such projects. Declares that: (1) the Secretary may accept contributed funds from the Upper Division States or political subdivisions or organizations with the Upper Division States pursuant to agreements that provide for the contributions to be used for capital project costs; and (2) the Secretary of Energy, acting through the Western Area Power Administration, and the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Bureau, may utilize power revenues collected pursuant to the Colorado River Storage Project Act to carry out this Act.

21st Century Global Health Technology Act - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to establish within the Health and Infectious Diseases and Nutrition Section of the Global Health Bureau of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) a program to develop technologies designed to: (1) improve the health and nutrition of populations in developing countries; (2) reduce maternal, newborn, and child mortality in such countries; and (3) improve the diagnosis, prevention, and reduction of disease, especially HIV/AIDS, malaria, tuberculosis, and other infectious diseases in such countries. States that such program shall be carried out under a cooperative agreement between USAID and one or more institutions with a successful record of advancing the technologies described in this Act and integrating practical field experience into the research and development process.

Minimum Tax Reform Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to replace the current 150-percent declining balance method with a straight line method for determining the depreciation allowance for certain alternative minimum taxable income property.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on June 22, 2016. Anti-terrorism Information Sharing Is Strength Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the USA PATRIOT Act to expand the responsibilities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the Department of the Treasury, and other federal agencies regarding the sharing of information regarding the financing of terror to include activities that may involve terrorist acts, money laundering activities, or specified unlawful activities. The bill expresses the sense of Congress that, in furtherance of efforts to stop the financing of terror and other forms of illicit financing through increased sharing of information, and consistent with the need to prevent inappropriate dissemination of such information, federal law enforcement agencies and regulators should share information about terrorist activities, money laundering activities, and other specified unlawful activities to the fullest extent possible and in a timely fashion and financial institutions, including nonbank financial institutions, should share information about such acts and activities with each other. (Sec. 3) Treasury must report to Congress on: (1) Treasury's assessment of the risks and benefits of allowing sharing of information between U.S. financial institutions and foreign financial institutions, between U.S. subsidiaries of foreign financial institutions and their parent financial institutions, and between U.S. subsidiaries and their

Amends the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 to provide that for purposes of a lobbying firm only, the term lobbying activities" includes paid communications campaigns to influence the general public to lobby Congress. <n>Requires any person or entity that qualifies as a lobbying firm to register with the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives not later than 45 days after such lobbying firm is first retained by a client to engage in paid communications campaigns to influence the general public to lobby Congress. <n>Requires any such person or entity to file a separate good faith estimate of the total amount of income relating specifically to paid communications campaigns to influence the general public to lobby Congress, if such income from the client exceeds $50,000 during the quarterly filing period. <n>Sets forth reporting requirements concerning paid communications campaigns to influence the general public to lobby Congress."

Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013 - Requires a Border Patrol agent to make a voluntary election as to whether such agent shall: (1) be assigned to the level 1 border patrol rate of pay, (2) be assigned to the level 2 border patrol rate of pay, or (3) decline both levels of pay. Directs the Director of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to establish procedures for such an election. Requires: (1) Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to provide each Border Patrol agent with information regarding each type of election available under this Act, and (2) a Border Patrol agent who fails to make a timely election to make such election to be deemed to have made an election. Expresses the sense of Congress that CBP should take such action as is necessary to ensure that not more than 10% of the Border Patrol agents stationed at a location decline to be assigned to the level 1 or level 2 border patrol rate of pay.

Direct Check for Education Act - Directs the Secretary of Education to make direct awards to local educational agencies (LEAs) for kindergarten through grade 12 (K-12) programs and activities. Authorizes appropriations. Requires the Secretary to use funds appropriated under this Act for each fiscal year to continue to make payments to eligible recipients pursuant to any multiyear award made prior to this Act's enactment date. Repeals provisions of law under the Goals 2000: Educate America Act, the Department of Education Appropriations Act, 1999, Title III of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, Part B of title VI of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and the School-to-Work Opportunities Act of 1994.

Indian Employment and Training Improvement Act of 1997 - Amends the Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 (the Act) to revise requirements regarding: (1) plan approval; (2) employment opportunities; (3) Federal responsibilities; (4) personnel; and (5) advisory committees. <n>Requires the head of each Federal agency that otherwise has jurisdiction over an integrated program under the Act to permit a tribal government that carries out that program to establish a consolidated advisory committee to carry out the duties of each advisory committee that would otherwise be required under applicable law. Directs each agency head to waive any statutory requirement, regulation, or policy requiring the establishment of such a committee.

Job Creation and Energy Efficiency Act - Amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to authorize the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to provide credit support through September 30, 2016, for projects for the installation and implementation of efficiency, advanced metering, distributed generation, or renewable energy technologies and measures for buildings that are expected to increase the energy efficiency of the building. Includes as eligible projects commercial, multifamily residential, industrial, municipal, government, institution of higher education, school, and hospital facilities that satisfy specified criteria established by the Secretary. Directs the Secretary to: (1) establish guidelines for credit support, (2) publish such guidelines in the Federal Register, and (3) provide for public comment.

Duck Stamp Conservation and Design Program Act of 1994 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to carry out a Duck Stamp Conservation and Design Program to accomplish the goals of: (1) providing school children environmental education opportunities relating to the conservation and management of migratory birds; and (2) increasing the capacity for schools, States, and other educational programs to conduct conservation and education programs. <n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) seek to conduct the Program in all States; and (2) annually submit a report to the Congress on Program status. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to annually conduct a competition to solicit the submission by students at elementary and secondary schools of designs relating to conservation of migratory birds and select winning designs for use for licensing and marketing, including: (1) license and market winning designs; and (2) license and market stamps bearing those designs, which shall be known as Junior Duck Stamps. <n>Permits the Secretary to accept and use any gift bequest of personal property or proceeds thereof, for the purpose of funding activities described in this Act. Authorizes appropriations. <n>Authorizes the Secretary, acting through the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, to transfer a bequest to the John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge facility on lands located within the refuge to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service upon completion

Russian Weapons Embargo Act of 2014 - Prohibits the head of an executive agency from entering into a contract, subcontract, memorandum of understanding, or cooperative agreement with, or making a grant to, or providing a loan or loan agreement to Rosoboronexport, any subsidiary or affiliate of Rosoboronexport, or any entity that has a business relationship with Rosoboronexport related to the design, manufacture, or sale of military equipment. Directs each executive agency to immediately terminate any such contract, subcontract, memorandum of understanding, cooperative agreement, loan, or loan agreement. Authorizes the President to waive such prohibition if he certifies to Congress that: Rosoboronexport has ceased the transfer of lethal military equipment to, and the maintenance of existing lethal military equipment for, the government of the Syrian Arab Republic; the armed forces of the Russian Federation have withdrawn from Crimea (other than military forces present on military bases subject to agreements in force between the government of the Russian Federation and the government of Ukraine); and agents of the Russian Federation are not taking active measures to destabilize the control of the government of Ukraine over eastern Ukraine. Authorizes the President to reprogram funds appropriated or otherwise made available for Economic Support Fund assistance or security assistance for the government of a country that enters into

Transparency in Judgment Payments Act of 2011 - Amends federal monetary law to require the Secretary of the Treasury to publish electronically, in a manner consistent with applicable federal privacy law, within 30 days after the payment of a final judgment, award, or compromise settlement: (1) the agency responsible for paying the claim; (2) a citation to the provision of law under which the claim was made; (3) the amount to be paid; (4) the amount of any interest to be paid; (5) the amount of any attorney fees to be paid; and (6) for any case filed in a court the case number and the court in which the case was filed. Requires the Secretary to submit quarterly reports to Congress describing such information for claims filed in court and administrative claims.

Amends Federal law to provide that the per annum rate of salary of the Vice President (exclusive of any previous adjustment) shall be adjusted by an amount, rounded to the nearest multiple of $100 (or if midway between multiples of $100, to the next highest multiple of $100) equal to the percentage of such per annum rate which corresponds to the percentage adjustment becoming so payable with respect to General Schedule employees within the District of Columbia. Sets forth that if an adjustment is scheduled to take effect on the same date as an adjustment for such District employees, the adjustment shall be made first. Treats such adjusted salary as the rate of salary of the Vice President for all purposes.

Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to establish a task force to: (1) raise awareness of, and define the study of, modeling and simulation; (2) provide grants to institutions of higher education to develop new and enhance existing modeling and simulation degree programs; and (3) create grants for such institutions to enhance existing programs.

Building Bridges and Transforming Resentment and Unfairness to Support and Trust for Municipal Law Enforcement Act of 2014 or the Build TRUST Act of 2014 - Requires a unit of local government which, during the previous three fiscal years, funded an amount that, on average, was greater than 18% of its operating budget using revenue generated from collecting fines and other fees related to violations of traffic laws to receive only 25% of the grant award that would have otherwise been awarded to it under the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program. Requires a unit of local government for which, during the previous fiscal year, the percentage of individuals who identify as a race who were employees of the law enforcement agency for that unit and the percentage of individuals who identify as that race who live in the jurisdiction which that law enforcement agency serves, differs by greater than 30% to receive only 5% of the grant award that would have otherwise been awarded to that state. Exempts states that receive such a grant award from these requirements.

Dual Incentive Education Act of 2002 - Authorizes the head of each employing office in the legislative branch to make payments to reimburse an eligible employee of the office for tuition and fees paid to an institution of higher education during a semester for enrollment in a program of post-baccalaureate study leading to a graduate degree. Limits the amount of such payment to $3,000, except that such amount may not exceed $3,000.Requires such an employee to be eligible for such a payment if: (1) the employee has been continuously employed by an employing office for not fewer than 12 consecutive months; (2) the employee meets specified student assistance eligibility requirements under the Higher Education Assistance Act of 1965; (3) the employee provides the head of the employing office with a certification from the institution of higher education in which the employee is enrolled of the employee's enrollment in a graduate program and of the amount of tuition and fees paid by the employee to the institution; (4) the employee has not received a payment under this Act for enrollment in another such program; and (5) the employee provides the office with such other information and assurances as the head of the office may require.Provides that any payment made to an eligible employee under this Act shall be in addition to basic pay and any other form of compensation otherwise payable to the employee involved.

Amends the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States to suspend, through December 31, 2009, the duty on: (1) front panels for television picture tubes with a viewable measurement of 80.01 cm, an outer panel radius of less than 500 cm, and an aspect ratio of 90 % or more; (2) front panels for television picture tubes with a viewable measurement of 76.00 cm, an outer panel radius of greater than 500 cm, and an aspect ratio of 90% or more; (3) front panels for television picture tubes with a viewable measurement of 85.50 cm, an outer panel radius of greater than 500 cm, and an aspect ratio of 90% or more; (4) 32V funnel for use; and (5) flat screen panels for television picture tubes with a viewable measurement of 94.12 cm, an outer panel radius of less than 500 cm, and an aspect ratio of 90% or more.

Prescribes procedures for congressional consideration of a joint resolution disapproving the President's notification to Congress under the China Nonproliferation Act concerning the export of defense articles or services and the provision of such articles or services to China.

Federal Aviation Administration Research, Engineering, and Development Act of 2002 - (Sec. 2) Amends Federal transportation law to authorize appropriations for FY 2003 through 2005 for aviation safety, air traffic control, environmental impact reduction, and mission support.(Sec. 3) Requires the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Administrator, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), and the Under Secretary of Transportation for Security to prepare and transmit an updated integrated civil aviation research and development plan to specified congressional committees.(Sec. 4) Requires the FAA Administrator to continue the program to consider awards to nonprofit concrete and asphalt pavement research foundations to improve the design, construction, rehabilitation, and repair of concrete and asphalt airfield pavements to aid in the development of safer, more cost-effective, and more durable airfield pavements.(Sec. 5) Directs the FAA Administrator to: (1) review and determine whether FAA standards used to determine the appropriate thickness for asphalt and concrete airfield pavements are in accordance with the FAA's standard 20-year-life requirement using the most up-to-date available information on the life of airfield pavements; and (2) report to specified congressional committees if such standards are not in accordance with that requirement.(Sec. 6) Requires the FAA Administrator to participate in a national initiative to define and develop an air traffic management system

Fort Sumner Project Title Conveyance Act - Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to convey to the Fort Sumner Irrigation District, located in De Baca County, New Mexico, all works, land, and facilities of the Fort Sumner reclamation project in accordance with the Memorandum of Agreement between the United States and the Fort Sumner Irrigation District Concerning Principles and Elements of Proposed Transfer of Title to Fort Sumner Irrigation District Facilities.

Voluntary Adoption Protection Act - Amends the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 to define involuntary" with respect to a child custody proceeding the absence of a written consent by a parent or legal guardian (other than a tribal court) of the Indian child.<n><n>Declares that this Act shall thereafter not be the basis for determining jurisdiction over any child custody proceeding involving an Indian child.<n><n>Declares that, upon written consent by a parent or legal guardian (other than a tribal court) of an Indian child to a voluntary child custody proceeding, this Act shall thereafter not apply to any child custody proceeding involving the Indian child."

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on January 8, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.)Authorizes the Attorney General to make grants to eligible States: (1) for use by the State to carry out sexual assault nurse examiner programs and to train law enforcement personnel and first responders in the handling of sexual assault cases and the collection and use of DNA samples for use as forensic evidence; and (2) for inclusion in the Combined DNA Index System of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, DNA analyses of samples from crime scenes.Amends the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 to authorize the Attorney General to make grants to eligible States for: (1) collecting and processing, for use as forensic evidence, samples on which DNA analysis may be carried out; and (2) carrying out, for inclusion in such System, DNA analyses of samples from crime scenes.

Gila Bend Indian Reservation Lands Replacement Clarification Act - Amends the Gila Bend Indian Reservation Lands Replacement Act to state that no class II or class III gaming activities may be conducted on the lands acquired by the Tohono O'o Nation pursuant to the Act if such land is located north of latitude 33 degrees, or 25 minutes after any determination by the Secretary of the Interior or any court, administrative agency, or department of the Interior made pursuant to such Act that such land is not eligible for Class II or class III gaming as part of a settlement of a land claim. (The Tohono O'o Nation currently operates three gaming facilities in the area.)

Public Retiree\\'s Investment Act of 2009 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to guarantee or reguarantee eligible investments of a public pension bank capital infusion fund, or qualified equity offering, in any preferred stock investment which meets the requirements of this Act by any public pension bank capital infusion fund. Defines eligible investment" as any preferred stock investment which meets the requirements of this Act by any public pension bank capital infusion fund."

Family Entertainment Protection Act - Prohibits any business from selling or renting any video game with a Mature, Adults-Only, or Ratings Pending rating from the Entertainment Software Ratings Board to any individual who has not attained the age of 17 years. Makes it a defense to any prosecution for a violation that a business: (1) was shown an identification document which it reasonably believed to be valid indicating that the individual purchasing or renting the video game had attained such age; or (2) had an established ratings enforcement policy.

Campus Fire Safety Right to Know Act - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to require each eligible institution participating in any program under title IV (Student Assistance) to: (1) prepare, publish, and distribute to all current students and employees, and to any applicant for enrollment or employment upon request, an annual fire safety report which discloses specified types of information about that institution's campus fire safety standards and practices; (2) make timely reports to the campus community on fires reported to local fire departments and the incidence of false fire alarms on campus; and (3) record all fires reported to local fire departments, including the nature, date, time, and general location of each fire, and all false fire alarms.Directs the Secretary of Education to: (1) review such statistics; (2) make copies available to the public; (3) identify exemplary fire safety policies, procedures, and practices, and disseminate information concerning those policies, procedures, and practices that have proven effective in the reduction of campus fires; and (4) report to the Congress analyses of the current status of fire safety systems in college and university facilities, and of the appropriate fire safety standards to apply to these facilities, as well as cost estimates and recommendations.

Partial Hospitalization Services Integrity Act of 1997 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for the following: (1) denial of Medicare coverage for partial hospitalization services (for psychiatric treatment) furnished in a skilled nursing facility or in an individual's personal residence; (2) new qualifications for community mental health centers (centers) as the Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to specify to ensure the health and safety of individuals being furnished such services, the effective or efficient furnishing of such services, and the compliance of such centers with the criteria described above; and (3) periodic re-certification of providers of partial hospitalization services under Medicare. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to establish a prospective payment system for partial hospitalization services provided by a center or by a hospital to its outpatients.

Amends Federal law to continue appropriations automatically if a regular appropriations bill covering a project or activity does not become law by the beginning of a fiscal year. Continues appropriations at the funding level of the preceding fiscal year or, if the relevant Act did not become law, in accordance with criteria prescribed in this Act. Declares it to be out of order in the House of Representatives or in the Senate to consider or to vote on the question of agreeing to any continuing appropriations legislation. Permits a waiver of this restriction in the Senate by a three-fifths vote.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 19, 2014. Victims Protection Act of 2014 - Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2014 to include within the duties of the Staff Judge Advocate in the Department of Defense (DOD) the senior trial counsel detailed to a case stemming from a sexual-related offense. (Currently, the Staff Judge Advocate must only advise victims of sexual assault on the advantages and disadvantages of prosecution by court-martial or by a civilian court.) Requires a Special Victims' Counsel to provide advice to victims of sexual assault on the advantages and disadvantages of prosecution by court-martial or by a civilian court over the offense before such victims express their preference as to prosecution. Directs the Secretaries of the military departments to establish a process to ensure consultation with victims regarding their preference as to whether the offense should be prosecuted by court-martial or by a civilian court. Requires the Secretaries to ensure that: (1) written performance appraisals of members of the Armed Forces (members) under their jurisdiction include an assessment of the extent to which each such member supports the sexual assault prevention and response program of the Armed Force concerned; (2) performance appraisals of commanding officers indicate the extent to which each such officer has or has not established a command climate in

Secondary Metal Theft Prevention Act of 2009- Expresses the sense of Congress that federal, state, and local government agencies should work with representatives of the secondary metal recycling industry to develop and improve effective countermeasures to combat the theft and sale of stolen secondary metal.<n><n>Makes it unlawful for a secondary metal recycling agent to purchase for recycling any secondary metal unless the seller establishes by written documentation that the seller is the owner, or an employee, agent, or other person authorized to sell on behalf of the owner: (1) marked with name, logo, or initials of a railroad, an electric, gas, or water company, a telephone company, cable company, or a public utility or that has been altered to remove, conceal, or obliterate such a name, logo, or initials; (2) marked with the name of a city, county, or state government entity; (3) a street light pole or fixture; (4) a road or bridge guard rail; (5) a highway or street sign; (6) a water meter cover; (7) a storm water grate; (8) unused or undamaged building construction or utility material; (9) a grave marker or cemetery urn or sheathing; (10) a utility access cover; or (11) a bulk container for beer with a capacity of 7.75 gallons or more. Requires the record of each secondary

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on June 3, 2014. Investing for Tomorrow's Schools Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to enter into cooperative agreements with states for the establishment of state infrastructure banks and multistate infrastructure banks for making loans to: local educational agencies (LEAs) for building or repairing public elementary or secondary schools; public libraries for building or repairing library facilities; eligible charter school entities for use under the Impact Aid program for charter schools which serve a high proportion of disadvantaged children; and community learning centers to connect and improve broadband services. Grants congressional consent to states to enter into a cooperative agreement with the Secretary for the establishment of a multistate infrastructure bank. Directs the Secretary to make grants to state infrastructure banks and multistate infrastructure banks in a state to provide initial capital for such loans. Requires each state establishing the bank to: contribute, at a minimum, at least 25% of the amount of each capitalization grant made to the state and contributed to the bank; identify an operating entity of the state as recipient of the grant if the entity has the capacity to manage loan funds and issue debt instruments of the state for purposes of leveraging the funds; allow such funds to be used as reserve for

Amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to require the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency to establish an emergency preparedness demonstration program to research and promote the capacity of disadvantaged communities to carry out programs to provide data, information, and awareness education by providing grants to or executing contracts or cooperative agreements with eligible nonprofit organizations to establish and conduct such programs. Permits an eligible nonprofit organization to use such awarded grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements to: (1) conduct research into the status of emergency preparedness and disaster response awareness in households of disadvantaged individuals located in urban and rural communities, particularly in States and regions most impacted by natural and manmade disasters and emergencies; and (2) develop and promote awareness of emergency preparedness education programs within disadvantaged communities, including development and preparation of culturally competent educational and awareness materials that can be used to disseminate information to organizations and institutions serving disadvantaged individuals. Makes eligible for such grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements nonprofit organizations whose primary mission is to provide services to disadvantaged communities and that can demonstrate a partnership with a disadvantaged business enterprise, including enterprises located in a HUBZone (heavily underutilized business zone).

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 5, 2016. Clear Creek National Recreation Area and Conservation Act (Sec. 3) This bill establishes the Clear Creek National Recreation Area in California as the Clear Creek National Recreation Area, which shall promote environmentally responsible off-highway vehicle recreation and also support other public recreational uses, such as hunting, hiking, and rock collecting. (Sec. 4) The Department of the Interior shall: prioritize environmentally responsible off-highway vehicle recreation and also facilitate hunting, hiking, collecting, and the use of motorized vehicles, mountain bikes, and horses in accordance with the management plan prepared under this bill; issue special recreation permits for motorized and non-motorized events; and reopen the Area to such uses as soon as practicable following enactment of this bill and in accordance with the management guidelines outlined in this bill and other applicable law. Interior shall use the 2006 Clear Creek Management Area Resource Management Plan Amendment and Route Designation Record of Decision as modified by this bill or the Interior to incorporate natural resource protection information not available in 2006, as the basis of an interim management plan to govern off-highway vehicle recreation within the Area pending the completion of the long-term management plan. Interior shall create a comprehensive management plan for the Clear Creek Recreation Area that:

Consumer and Retail Sales Stimulus Act of 2001 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to reimburse each State for the amount of State and local sales tax payable and not collected during the sales tax holiday period, as specified.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 5, 2016. Territorial Economic Growth and Recovery Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal the limitation on the coverage by the distilled spirits tax credit of distilled spirits brought into the United States after December 31, 2015. (Sec. 3) The bill directs the Department of the Treasury to pay periodically, but not less frequently than annually: (1) to each possession of the United States with a mirror code tax system amounts equal to the loss to such possession due to the implementation of such system after December 31, 2015; and (2) to each possession of the United States which does not have such a system amounts estimated by Treasury as being equal to the aggregate benefits that would have been provided to residents of such possession by reason of such application for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015. The bill prohibits such payments with respect to any possession of the United States unless such possession has a plan under which such possession will promptly distribute such payments to the residents. No credit shall be allowed for any taxable year to any person: (1) to whom a credit is allowed against taxes imposed by the possession by reason of this bill, or (2) who is eligible for a payment under such a plan.

Homeland Security Information Sharing Partnerships Act of 2006 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish a State, Local, Tribal, and Regional Information Fusion Center Initiative to establish partnerships with state, local, tribal, and regional information fusion centers. Requires the Secretary to: (1) coordinate with the principal official of each such center and the official designated as the Homeland Security Advisor of the state; (2) provide Department of Homeland Security (DHS) operational and intelligence advice and assistance to such centers; (3) support efforts to include such centers into efforts to establish an information sharing environment; (4) conduct table-top and live training exercises to regularly assess the capability of individual and regional networks to integrate their efforts with DHS efforts; (5) coordinate with other relevant federal entities engaged in homeland security-related activities; (6) provide analytic and reporting advice and assistance to such centers; (7) review homeland security information gathered by such centers and incorporate relevant information with DHS information; (8) provide management assistance; (9) serve as a point of contact to ensure the dissemination of relevant homeland security information; (10) facilitate close communication and coordination between such centers and DHS; (11) provide centers with expertise on DHS resources and operations; (12) provide training to such centers and encourage them to participate in DHS terrorist threat-related exercises; and

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) National All Schedules Prescription Electronic Reporting Reauthorization Act of 2010 - Amends the National All Schedules Prescription Electronic Reporting Act of 2005 to include as a purpose of such Act to foster the establishment of state-administered controlled substance monitoring systems in order to ensure that appropriate law enforcement, regulatory, and state professional licensing authorities have access to prescription history information for the purposes of investigating drug diversion and prescribing and dispensing practices of errant prescribers or pharmacists. Amends the Public Health Service Act to revise and update the controlled substance monitoring program, including to: (1) allow grants to be used to maintain and operate existing state controlled substance monitoring programs; (2) require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to redistribute any funds that are returned among the remaining grantees; (3) require a state receiving a grant to provide the Secretary with aggregate data and other information necessary to enable the Secretary to evaluate the success of the state's program or to prepare and submit a report to Congress; and (4) require a state receiving a grant to: (1) facilitate prescriber use of the state's controlled substance monitoring system; and (2) educate prescribers on the benefits of the system both to them and society.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for increases in the maximum taxable income for the 15 and 28 percent rate brackets, as well as for use of the national average wage index for cost-of-living adjustments.

Amends the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act (ANILCA) to require all Federal public land managers in Alaska, or a region containing Alaska, to participate in an ANILCA training class within 120 days after enactment of this Act. Requires all future appointed Federal public land managers in Alaska, or a region containing Alaska, to complete such training within 60 days of appointments.Declares that: (1) substantive uses by local residents shall be permitted in the park where such uses are traditional; and (2) opportunities for fish and wildlife dependent recreation shall be provided opportunities for fish and wildlife dependent recreation, including fishing and hunting.Prohibits the Secretary of the Interior from imposing unreasonable fees or charges on those seeking to secure their rights under this Act. Permits individuals and entities possessiong rights under this Act to not be required to waive, forfeit, or relinquish their possessory or personalty interests in a cabin or structure.

Urban Recovery and Growth Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an extension of up to $1 billion in tax-exempt economic development bonds issued before January 1, 2011, for certain cities whose average unemployment rates exceed 150% of the national average and whose population has lost at least 20% between 2000 and 2010. Defines specified cities" as principal cities for a metropolitan statistical area that: (1) has an average unemployment rate of at least 150% of the national average rate for the last year ending before enactment of this Act; and (2) has lost at least 20% of its population between 2000 and 2010."

Export Promotion Enhancement Act of 2008 - Amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to establish the Office of Trade Promotion within the Executive Office of the President. Requires the Office to: (1) advise the President on trade promotion policies and programs of the federal government; (2) oversee implementation of trade promotion efforts; and (3) develop a strategic plan for federal trade promotion efforts.

Comprehensive Holocaust Accountability in Insurance Measure - Authorizes a State to establish requirements on insurers as a condition of doing insurance business that are consistent with the due process guarantees of the Constitution. Declares that a State may require an insurer to provide to the State specified information regarding Holocaust era insurance policies, including: (1) whether the insurer, or any affiliate or predecessor company, sold any such policies; (2) the number and number of such policies sold by the insurer, and any affiliates and predecessor companies, and the number they currently have in their possession; (3) the identity of the holder and beneficiary of each such policy; and (4) if an insurer has no such policies to report because records are no longer in its possession, a statement explaining the reasons for the lack of possession of such records. Authorizes a State to require an insurer to certify that with respect to any Holocaust era insurance policies sold or at any time held by the insurer: (1) the proceeds of the policy were paid; (2) the beneficiaries of the policy or heirs or such beneficiaries could not be located and the proceeds were distributed to Holocaust survivors or charities; (3) a court of law has certified a plan for the distribution of the proceeds; or (4) the proceeds have not been distributed. Declares that this Act constitutes a Federal cause of

Consumer Protection and Choice Act - Amends the Truth in Lending Act to prohibit a deferred presentment transaction except as authorized by this Act.<n><n>Declares that, if the Director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) determines that a state has in effect a covered deferred presentment law, any regulations of the CFPB regarding deferred presentment transactions and deferred presentment providers shall not apply in such state.<n><n>Defines covered deferred presentment law" to mean a law or regulation of a state that provides for the licensing of deferred presentment providers and the regulation of deferred presentment transactions, which may be accomplished through existing state authority, and that meets specified requirements with respect to deferred presentment providers and the database established by such law.<n><n>Requires the law or regulation to require a deferred presentment provider to: (1) be licensed by the state; (2) provide to the state the results of a background check, including fingerprinting, of each officer and principal of the deferred presentment provider; (3) secure a copy of a valid state-issued form of identification from a consumer before entering into a deferred presentment transaction; (4) verify through the state deferred presentment transaction database that a consumer entering into a deferred presentment transaction does not have an outstanding deferred presentment transaction"

Access to Quality Diabetes Education Act of 2013 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for the recognition of state-licensed or -registered health care professionals who are certified diabetes educators in an outpatient setting as authorized providers of Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services, including in an emergency department, for individuals with diabetes.

National Spaceport Act - Establishes within the Department of Transportation a National Spaceport Office to: (1) administer the application and assistance program under this Act; and (2) establish procedures for the competitive awarding of grants and the transfer of excess Federal property to spaceports.Requires a State or State-designated entity, including a nonprofit organization, desiring assistance under this Act to submit an application to the Office requesting specifically the Federal assistance sought and setting forth a comprehensive plan for spaceport development, including the educational components.Requires the Office to approve meritorious applications and provide to the successful applicants assistance, including: (1) grants; (2) the use of excess Federal launch, recovery, launch vehicle, and support assets, consistent with applicable international agreements, for educational launches; and (3) excess Federal property, including research facilities, by transfer.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for the tax-exempt financing of spaceports.

Hudson-Fulton-Champlain Commemoration Commission Act of 2002 - Establishes the Hudson-Fulton-Champlain Commemoration Commission to plan, develop, and execute programs and activities appropriate to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the voyage of Robert Fulton in the steamboat Clermont, the 400th anniversary of the voyage of Henry Hudson in the vessel Half Moon, and the 400th anniversary of the voyage of Samuel de Champlain.

Trade Adjustment Assistance Reform Act of 1998 - Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to authorize appropriations to the Department of Labor for FY 1999 through 2003 for trade adjustment assistance (TAA) for workers. <n>(Sec. 2) Repeals the North American Free Trade (NAFTA) Transitional Adjustment Assistance Program. <n>(Sec. 3) Revises requirements for the filing of petitions for TAA for a group of workers adversely affected by imports. Authorizes such petitions to be filed with the Governor of the State in which the workers' firm or subdivision is located by: (1) the group of workers (including workers in an agricultural firm or subdivision of any agricultural firm); (2) the certified or recognized union or other duly authorized representative of such workers; and (3) the employers of such workers, one-stop career centers, or State employment agencies, on behalf of such workers. <n>Requires the Governor to: (1) transmit the petition to the Secretary of Labor immediately; (2) ensure that rapid response assistance and basic readjustment services are made available to the workers; and (3) assist the Secretary in the review of the petition by verifying such information and providing such other assistance as the Secretary may request. Authorizes the Secretary to request the Governor to expedite the review of such petitions. <n>(

. Consumer Financial Protection Commission Act of 2013 [sic] - Amends the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010, title X of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, to replace the position of Director of the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection with a five-member Commission composed of the Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Federal Reserve System and four additional members appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, from among individuals who should want to protect service members and their families who are sacrificing their lives for this country from abusive financial practices. Prohibits Commission members from engaging in any other business, vocation, or employment. Requires one member of the Commission to have as their primary responsibility the oversight of the Bureau's activities pertaining to protecting consumers, with a focus on consumers who are older, minorities, youth, or veterans, from unfair, deceptive, and abusive lending practices. Makes the designated commissioner responsible for: (1) ensuring the Bureau conducts regular outreach to consumers regarding industry lending activities; (2) researching and reporting to the full Commission on the impact of new loan and credit products and services on consumers; and (3) ensuring the Bureau coordinates with state-level consumer protection agencies on enforcement measures that protect consumers from unfair, deceptive, and abusive lending practices.

Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness and Partnership Act of 1996 - Amends Federal law to: (1) revise management guidelines for the use of motorized boats in the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, Minnesota; and (2) establish the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Planning and Management Council to develop and monitor a comprehensive management plan for the Wilderness.

Opioid Addiction Treatment Modernization Act (Sec. 3) This bill amends the Controlled Substances Act to revise standards for determining whether a practitioner is qualified to engage in the treatment of opioid addiction. Currently, a practitioner must complete at least two years of training addressing: (1) opioid detoxification; (2) appropriate clinical use of all approved drugs for opioid addiction treatment; (3) the need for initial and periodic assessments of each patient; (4) the development of an individualized treatment plan for each patient; and (5) the importance of providing overdose reversal and relapse prevention and appropriate counseling and other services. Additionally, the bill requires that, with respect to patients to whom the practitioner will provide narcotic drugs for opioid addiction treatment, the practitioner has the capacity to provide directly or by referral all drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration for opioid addiction treatment and appropriate counseling and ancillary services. Additionally, the practitioner must maintain a diversion control plan containing specific measures to reduce the likelihood of the diversion of controlled substances prescribed for opioid addiction treatment.

Delaware Pensions Restoration Act of 2012 - Amends the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 (EESA) to revise the requirement that revenues from the sale of troubled assets purchased by the United States in connection with the bankruptcy of the General Motors Corporation be deposited into the general fund of the Treasury for reduction of the public debt. Declares that the proceeds from the sale of troubled assets shall: (1) be paid into the general fund of the Treasury for reduction of the public debt, and (2) be transferred after enactment of this Act to the Retired Employees Fund established by this Act for paying certain pension benefits of separated employees of the General Motors Corporation. Establishes in the Treasury the Retired Employees Fund.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced on March 16, 2006. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the federal government should take all necessary steps to stop the genocide in Darfur; (2) the President should work with the international community to impose targeted sanctions against those responsible for the genocide in Darfur; and (3) state and local governments and universities should divest from, and prohibit investments in, companies that conduct business operations in Sudan, unless the President certifies that Sudan is acting to demobilize the Janjaweed militia, protect civilians, and cooperate with aid workers and the African Union Mission in Sudan.<n><n>Prohibits the use of federal funds to acquire or acquire securities or any interest in companies that conduct business operations in Sudan unless the President certifies that Sudan is acting to demobilize the Janjaweed militia, protect civilians, and cooperate with the African Union Mission in Sudan.<n><n>Defines specified terms, including genocide."<n><n><n>Prohibits a state or local government from requiring, or restricting the investment of funds in, any company that conducts business operations in Sudan unless the President certifies that Sudan is acting to demobilize the Janjaweed militia, protect civilians, or"

Directs the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to establish a National Academy of Space for the instruction and preparation of selected individuals for service in a space-related capacity in the employ of the United States or a U.S. corporation. Requires the Academy to: (1) consist of a program of instruction leading to baccalaureate degrees in science, mathematics, and engineering at a specified number of State universities selected by a Board of the Academy (consisting of a broadly representative group of scientists, engineers, educators, and businessmen representing space-related industries); (2) develop an exam for secondary students testing knowledge in science, mathematics, and engineering, or select an exam from among existing national exams, and annually administer such exam; (3) provide for the placement at one of the Member Institutes of students awarded scholarships; and (4) establish a placement program to assist recipients of such awards in obtaining specified positions. <n>Requires the Board to: (1) establish a scholarship program for students to attend the Academy who are willing to commit themselves to service in a space-related capacity; and (2) annually certify the top ten scorers in each congressional district on the exam developed or selected, and award to the top two scorers in each State, and the top scorer in each district who is not one of the top two

Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to: (1) establish a program to screen veterans who are eligible for hospital care, medical services, and nursing home care for symptoms of traumatic brain injury; (2) develop and carry out a comprehensive program of long-term care for post-acute traumatic brain injury rehabilitation that includes residential, community, and home-based components utilizing interdisciplinary treatment teams; and (3) establish a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry. Requires the Secretary to notify individuals listed in the Registry.

Transfers administrative jurisdiction over specified Federal lands in Missouri over the Mingo Job Corps Civilian Conservation Center from the Secretary of the Interior to the Secretary of Agriculture, subject to the laws and regulations applicable to the National Forest System.

Office of Government Ethics Authorization Act of 1996 - Amends the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 to: (1) extend the authorization of appropriations for the Office of Government Ethics (OGE); and (2) authorize the OGE Director to accept gifts for OGE use. <n>Repeals a provision requiring an annual report from the Director of OGE to the Congress on gifts to be accepted by the Government. <n>Amends the Federal criminal code to revise postemployment restrictions on former Federal officers, employees, and elected officials of the executive and legislative branches, adding exceptions for communications or appearances made solely on behalf of a candidate in his or her capacity as a candidate, an authorized committee, a national committee, a national Federal campaign committee, a State committee, or a political party.

Hermosa Creek Watershed Protection Act of 2012 - Designates specified land in San Juan National Forest in Colorado as the Hermosa Creek Watershed Protection Area and the Hermosa Creek Special Management Area.

Energy Development Program Implementation Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Energy to: (1) develop strategic plans for the energy development program consistent with the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Act of 1978; and (2) implement such plans.

High School Data Transparency Act of 2011 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to collect, annually, from each coeducational secondary school that receives federal financial assistance for an interscholastic athletic program: (1) the total number of male and female students that attended the school, fully disaggregated and cross-tabulated by gender and race or ethnicity; (2) a listing of the teams that competed in athletic competition and for each such team the season in which the team competed, the total number of male and female participants as of the day of the first scheduled contest for the team, the total expenditures for the team, the equipment expenditures, the uniform expenditures, the expenditures for facilities, and the total numbers of trainers and medical personnel and their identifications; (3) the total number of competitive events scheduled, and for each indication of what day of the week and time the competitive event was scheduled; and (4) whether such team participated in postseason competition, and the success of such team in any postseason competition. Requires such schools to: (1) make such information available to students and potential students, upon request, and to the public; and (2) ensure that all students at the school are informed of their right to request such information.

Intermodal Equipment Safety and Responsibility Act of 2003 - Requires a controller of intermodal equipment that is interchanged or to be interchanged to be responsible and held liable for the systematic inspection, maintenance, and repair of the equipment. Prohibits a motor carrier from offering intermodal equipment to it unless such equipment has been interchanged.

Equitable Health Care for Severe Mental Illnesses Act of 1993 - Declares that it is the policy of the United States that: (1) persons with severe mental illnesses must not be discriminated against in the health care system; and (2) health care coverage, whether provided through public or private health insurance or any other means of financing, must provide for the treatment of severe mental illnesses in a manner that is equitable and commensurate with that provided for other major physical illnesses. Declares that this Act shall not be construed to preclude adoption of laws or policies requiring or providing for appropriate and equitable coverage for other mental health services. Declares that health care coverage shall cover services that are essential to the effective treatment of severe mental illnesses in a manner that: (1) is not more restrictive than coverage provided for other major physical illnesses; (2) provides adequate financial protection to the person requiring the medical treatment for a severe mental illness; and (3) is consistent with effective and common methods of controlling health care costs for other major physical illnesses.

Recapture Excess Profits and Invest in Roads (REPAIR) Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) impose on certain oil companies, for taxable years beginning in 2008 or 2009, an excise tax on 25% of their windfall profit from the sale of crude oil; (2) allow a tax deduction for the payment of such windfall profit tax; and (3) require that windfall tax proceeds be transferred to the Highway Trust Fund.

Transportation Efficiency Act - Requires the President to create a National Intermodal Transportation Planning Task Force to: (1) conduct a study on transportation needs; (2) sponsor a conference on National Transportation Planning; (3) use such study and the input of attendees to draft a National Intermodal Transportation Plan; and (4) transmit such Plan to Congress and the Department of Transportation's (DOT) Web site for public comment.

Bring Jobs Back to America: Strategic Manufacturing & Job Repatriation Act - Requires the Secretary of Commerce to: (1) create a comprehensive national manufacturing strategy designed to increase overall domestic production, create private sector jobs, and identify emerging technologies to strengthen American competitiveness and comparative advantages; (2) conduct an annual survey of American firms which maintain manufacturing, design or support service facilities outside the United States and for which products are manufactured at such facilities; and (3) establish Repatriation Task Forces to promote repatriation of production or services to the United States.<n><n>Establishes the American Economic Security Commission to study and make recommendations on policy relating to American competitiveness, particularly in the manufacturing, information technology, energy, and biotechnology.

National Drought Policy Act of 1997 - Establishes a National Drought Commission which shall: (1) determine what needs exist on the Federal, State, local, and tribal levels to prepare for and respond to drought emergencies; (2) review existing Federal laws and programs relating to drought; (3) review State, local, and tribal laws and programs relating to drought; (4) determine what differences exist between the needs of those affected by drought and the Federal laws and programs designed to mitigate their impacts; (5) collaborate with the Western Drought Coordination Council; (6) make recommendations on how Federal drought laws and programs can be better integrated with ongoing State, local, and tribal programs into a comprehensive national policy to mitigate the impacts of and respond to drought emergencies without diminishing the rights of States to control water through State law; and (7) include a recommendation on whether all Federal drought preparation and response programs should be consolidated under one existing Federal agency.

Military Eye Trauma Treatment Act of 2007 - Directs the Secretary of Defense to establish within the Department of Defense (DOD) the Center of Excellence in Prevention, Diagnosis, Mitigation, Treatment, and Rehabilitation of Military Eye Injuries to: (1) develop, implement, and oversee a registry for tracking the diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up for each case of significant eye injury incurred by a member of the Armed Forces while serving on active duty; (2) ensure the electronic exchange of registry information with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs; and (3) enable the Secretary to access the registry and add information pertaining to additional treatments or surgical procedures and eventual visual outcomes for veterans who were entered into the registry and subsequently received treatment through the Veterans Health Administration (VHA). Establishes the Military Eye Injury Registry.<n><n>Requires the Center to: (1) provide notice to the Blind Rehabilitation Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and to the eye care services of the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) on each member with an eye injury incurred while serving on active duty; and (2) ensure that registry information is available to the VA. Directs the Secretaries to jointly: (1) ensure that such information is available to appropriate VA personnel for purposes of encouraging and facilitating the conduct of research, and the development of best practices

Combat Veterans Back to Work Act of 2011 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt employers who hire in 2011 and 2012: (1) a current member of the National Guard or other reserve component of the Armed Forces or a veteran who returned from a deployment of at least 180 days in support of a contingency operation, (2) an individual who began employment with such an employer after June 30, 2011, and before January 1, 2013, and (3) such an individual who is not employed by such employer to replace another employee unless such other employee separated from employment voluntarily or for cause. Allows such employers to elect to have such exemption not apply.

Indian Trust Asset and Trust Fund Management and Reform Act of 2002 - Amends the American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act of 1994 to establish within the Department of the Interior the position of Deputy Secretary for Trust Management and Reform, who shall: (1) oversee all trust fund and trust asset matters of the Department; and (2) engage in government-to-government relations and consultations with Indian tribes and individual trust asset and trust fund account holders on matters involving trust asset and trust fund management and reform within the Department.

. The expanded summary of the House passed version is repeated here.) TITLE I--TRID IMPROVEMENT (Sec. 101) This bill amends the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974 to require that charges for any title insurance premium disclosed on settlement forms for residential mortgage loans be equal to the amount charged for each individual title insurance policy, subject to any discounts as required by state regulation or the title company rate filings. The Securities Act of 1933, the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 are amended to prohibit the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) from compelling a person to produce or furnish algorithmic trading source code or similar intellectual property that forms the basis for design of the code to the SEC unless the SEC first issues a subpoena. TITLE III--FOSTERING INNOVATION (Sec. 301) The bill amends the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 to prohibit the SEC from compelling an investment adviser to produce or furnish such code or such intellectual property unless the SEC first issues a subpoena. The SEC may not compel an investment company to produce or furnish such code or such intellectual property unless the SEC first issues a subpoena. TITLE IV--NATIONAL SECURITIES EXCHANGE REGULATORY PARITY (Sec

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on December 5, 2016. 400 Years of African-American History Commission Act (Sec. 3) This bill establishes the 400 Years of African-American History Commission to plan, develop, and carry out programs and activities appropriate for the commemoration of the 400th anniversary of the arrival of Africans in the English colonies, at Point Comfort, Virginia. The commission shall: plan and develop programs and activities that recognize and highlight the resilience and contributions of African-Americans since 1619, acknowledge the impact that slavery and laws that enforced racial discrimination had on the United States, and educate the public about the arrival of Africans in the United States and their contributions to the country; encourage civic, patriotic, historical, educational, artistic, religious, economic, and other organizations to organize and participate in anniversary activities; provide technical assistance to states, localities, and nonprofit organizations to further the commemoration; coordinate and facilitate for the public scholarly research on, publication about, and interpretation of the arrival of Africans in the United States and their contributions to the United States; ensure that the commemoration provides a lasting legacy and long-term public benefit by assisting in the development of appropriate programs; and help ensure that the observances of the commemoration are inclusive and appropriately

Preventive Medicine and Public Health Training Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to award grants to, or enter into contracts with, eligible entities to provide training to graduate medical residents in preventive medicine specialties. Directs that grant or contract funds be used to: (1) plan, develop, and operate residency programs for preventive medicine or public health; (2) provide financial assistance to resident physicians who plan to specialize in preventive medicine or public health; and (3) defray the costs associated with the planning, development, and operation of such programs.

Medicare Prevention and Osteoporosis Testing Act of 2007 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a national minimum payment amount for CPT codes 77080 and 77082 (relating to dual-energy x-ray absorpometry) and any successor to such codes as identified by the Institute of Medicine of the National Academies to provide: (1) 100% of the reimbursement rates in effect for such codes on December 31, 2008; and (2) a description of methods to increase use of bone mass measurement by beneficiaries and physicians.

Date Certain Tax Code Replacement Act - Terminates the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for taxable years beginning after 2005, except provisions of such Code relating to social security taxation (i.e., taxes on wage, self-employment, and railroad retirement income).Establishes within the legislative branch a National Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification. Directs the Commission to: (1) review the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and its impact on the economy, families, and the workforce: (2) determine whether the current income tax system can be replaced by more a more efficient and fair system of taxation; and (3) submit a report to Congress on the results of its review with recommendations for fundamental reform and simplification of the Code.Requires congressional approval of a new federal tax system no later than July 4, 2005, or a vote of Congress to reauthorize the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.

Equal Access to Medicare Options Act of 2009 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to phase in the implementation of amendments to the Medicare supplemental health insurance policies program made by this Act, in such manner as the Secretary determines appropriate, to minimize any adverse impact on individuals enrolled under such policies prior to the effective date of this Act. Limits the phase-in period to five years.<n><n>Requires any individual enrolled under a Medicare supplemental policy pursuant to the amendments made by this Act to be classified by the issuer as part of a separate premium class. Makes such provision applicable to individuals who enroll under a Medicare supplemental policy before January 1, 2015.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to establish a one-time enrollment period during which such an individual may enroll in any Medicare supplemental policy of the individual's choosing. Requires the Secretary to develop an outreach plan to notify such individuals of the one-time enrollment period.

Public School Emergency Relief Act - Directs the Secretary of Education to provide emergency impact aid for the 2014- 2015 school year to state educational agencies (SEAs) to make impact aid payments to local educational agencies (LEAs) and schools funded by the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) for instruction of unaccompanied alien students. Requires the amount of such impact aid to equal the product of: (1) the increase in the number of immigrant students enrolled in the LEA or school, over the number of such students enrolled in the corresponding quarter of the 2012-2013 school year; and (2) the insufficient funds available to pay the full amount of such impact aid.

Commission on Catastrophic Disaster Risk and Insurance Act of 2006 - Establishes a bipartisan Commission on Catastrophic Disaster Risk and Insurance. Requires the Commission to report to Congress on its findings and assessments regarding the risks posed to the United States by catastrophic disasters, and means for mitigating those risks and paying for losses caused by such disasters.

Requires the Secretary of Transportation to withhold from states allocations of transportation funding for FY2011-FY2015 if such states have not enacted and are not enforcing a law that prohibits a person from using a wireless communications device to compose, read, or send an electronic message when the vehicle is in motion or part of traffic. Exempts from such prohibition a wireless communications device used solely in a voice-activated or other hands-free mode, for making a cellular phone call, for obtaining emergency assistance, in the reasonable belief that a person's life or safety is in immediate danger, in an authorized emergency vehicle while in the performance of official duties, when the motor vehicle is stopped and the driver has the motor vehicle transmission in neutral or park, and in other circumstances where use of a wireless communications device does not adversely affect safety.

Stop Illegal Reentry Act or Kate's Law This bill amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide increased criminal and civil penalties for an alien who: (1) has been denied admission, excluded, deported, removed, or departed the United States while under an outstanding order of exclusion, deportation, or removal; and (2) thereafter enters, attempts to enter, or is at any time found in the United States, unless the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has expressly consented to the alien's reapplying for admission or the alien has established that he or she was not required to obtain such advance consent. With respect to an alien previously denied admission and removed, the bill: (1) requires the alien to establish that he or she was not required to obtain such advance consent; and (2) subjects an alien who enters the United States without permission or who has been removed without permission to specified criminal and civil penalties.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 26, 2015. GI Bill Processing Improvement Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to make changes and improvements to its information technology system to ensure that: (1) all original and supplemental educational assistance claims are adjudicated electronically, and (2) rules-based processing is used to make decisions with little human intervention. (Sec. 3) The Veterans Access, Choice, and Accountability Act of 2014 is amended to extend through July 1, 2016, the authority of the VA to enter into agreements with public institutions of higher education for the provision of higher education courses to veterans and members of the Armed Forces under the all-volunteer force educational assistance program and the post-9/11 educational assistance program. (Sec. 4) The bill permits individuals entitled to veterans' basic educational assistance to elect to receive educational assistance under the post-9/11 program.

Close the Revolving Door Act of 2010 - Amends the federal criminal code to impose a lifetime ban on any former Senator, Member of the House of Representatives, or elected officer of the Senate or House of Representatives lobbying any current Member, officer, or employee of Congress or any employee of any other legislative office (currently, the ban is for two years after a Senator leaves office and one year after a Member of the House of Representatives leaves office). Extends such ban from one to six years for officers and employees of the Senate, personal staff of Members, committee staff, leadership staff, and other legislative offices.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives to maintain a joint lobbyist disclosure Internet database for information required to be publicly disclosed by this Act, which shall be an easily searchable website called lobbyists.gov.<n><n>Prohibits a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal from being hired for a six-year period by a Member or congressional committee of either chamber with whom he or she has had a substantial lobbying contact. Authorizes waiver of such prohibition in the Senate or the House of Representatives by the Committee on Ethics or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct based on a compelling national need.<n><n>Amends the Federal
