Hydroelectric Licensing Process Improvement Act of 1998 - Amends the Federal Power Act to require a consulting agency (the Federal agency with administrative jurisdiction over a Federal reservation, or the Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of Commerce) in determining a condition to a license for a project on such reservation to take into consideration: (1) the impacts of such condition on economic and power values, electric generation capacity and system reliability, air quality, and drinking, flood control, irrigation, navigation, or recreation water supply; and (2) compatibility with other conditions to be included in the license, including mandatory conditions of other agencies. <n>Directs the consulting agency to create written documentation detailing all proposals made, comments received, facts considered, and analyses made regarding each of those factors sufficient to demonstrate that each of the factors was given full consideration in determining the condition to be submitted to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC). <n>Requires each condition determined by the consulting agency to be subjected to appropriately substantiated scientific review. Considers each condition to have been subjected to appropriately substantiated scientific review if the review: (1) was based on current empirical data or field-tested data; and (2) was subjected to peer review. <n>Directs the consulting agency: (1) before submitting to FERC a proposed condition and before filing

Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the United States Geological Survey, to: (1) establish a national biological data center to collect nonhuman biological data and make such data available for public use; and (2) seek to enter into a contract with a small business for the purpose of managing the center. Outlines contract requirements.

Securing America's Facilities, Equipment and Rail: Taking Responsibility for American National Security In Transit Act or the SAFER TRANSIT Act This bill directs the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), in coordination with the Office of Management and Budget, to report to Congress on the plan to expedite the implementation of the Implementing Recommendations of the 9/11 Commission Act of 2007 to: (1) assign rail carriers to high-risk tiers; and (2) establish a rail security training program. The bill reauthorizes through FY2020: (1) the surface transportation security inspector program, and (2) the public transportation security research and development program. DHS shall develop a "Local Transit Security Instructor Training Program" to provide training to local police officers regarding transportation security. The bill authorizes DHS to make grants to states, local governments, and Indian tribes to enhance security on public transportation systems and improve access to transportation facilities.

Good Samaritan Charitable Physicians' Services Act of 2018 This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax deduction for the unreimbursed Medicare-based value of qualified charity care furnished by certain physicians. The bill also amends the Public Health Service Act to provide that a physician shall not be liable under federal or state law for harm caused by an act or omission in the course of furnishing qualified charity care, if the act or omission occurred in the course of furnishing such care and was not grossly negligent.

Health Care Relief Act of 2007 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow: (1) individuals who had no health insurance coverage at any time during the six-month period before the earliest date that such individual has health insurance coverage a refundable tax credit for amounts paid for such coverage; and (2) certain small business employers a business tax credit for amounts paid for health insurance coverage for their employees.

Women in Trauma Act of 2002 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the National Institute of Mental Health, to award grants for: (1) building the evidence base for new treatment interventions that simultaneously address trauma, substance abuse, and psychiatric disorders, including depression and anxiety disorders; and (2) providing comprehensive community-based mental health and substance abuse services to women who have experienced a history of physical or sexual abuse, or other types of trauma. Requires the Secretary, acting through the Administrator of the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, to make such grants to public and nonprofit private entities.

Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the first-time homebuyer tax credit, to: (1) deny such credit to taxpayers under the age of 18; (2) require taxpayers claiming such credit to attach to their returns a properly executed copy of the settlement statement used to purchase their residence; (3) prohibit a credit for residences acquired from a spouse; and (4) treat certain errors relating to such credit as mathematical or clerical errors.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to require tax return preparers to file individual income tax returns on magnetic media if such returns are filed by such preparers and are for the calendar year during which such returns are filed.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on January 8, 2018. Fight Russian Corruption (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Department of State Office of Anti-Corruption to be headed by a Director who shall develop and report annually to Congress on: (1) opaque financial networks of the Russian Federation that operate in European countries relating to investments in real estate, energy, media, infrastructure, civil society, sports nongovernmental organization, and other sectors; and (2) illicit Russian financial activities in European countries to train U.S. diplomatic officers to cooperate with foreign partners uncovering such illicit Russian investments. The Office shall also: (1) analyze Russian financial networks that operate in European countries relating to investments in energy, media, infrastructure, civil society, sports nongovernmental organization, and other sectors; and (2) provide training to U.S diplomatic officers relating to such activities.

Citizens Right to Know Act of 2010 - Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to require an issuer that is registered under the Act and that makes or participates in an electioneering communication to disclose such activity in writing to each shareholder.<n><n>Prohibits an issuer from making or participating in any electioneering communication if 51% or more of the outstanding securities of such issuer are owned or controlled by any foreign principal or agent of a foreign principal. Requires an issuer to obtain prior shareholder approval before it makes or participates in any electioneering communication.<n><n>Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require: (1) the audio statement of any communication paid for by a corporation to be made by the president or chief executive officer; and (2) the president or chief executive officer of a corporation which pays for the largest portion of any such communication to be the president or chief executive officer of the corporation with the highest gross revenue for the calendar year prior to the date on which such communication is made.

Caribbean Amnesty and Relief Act - Provides for the adjustment to permanent resident status of certain Caribbean country nationals (and spouses, children, and certain unmarried sons or daughters) who have maintained continuous physical presence in the United States since at least September 30, 1996.Establishes in the Immigration and Naturalization Service the Visa Fairness Commission, which shall gather data on economic and racial profiling by embassy Consular Affairs offices and by Customs and immigration inspectors at U.S. ports of entry.Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to eliminate specified classification petition or labor certification requirements for certain aliens present in the United States who entered without inspection, accepted unauthorized employment, or are in unlawful status who wish to adjust to permanent resident status.

Fair International Labor Standards in Trade and Investment Act of 2001 - Authorizes the Secretary of Labor, through the International Labor Affairs Bureau, to promote fair international standards in trade and investment by: (1) representing the United States in the International Labor Organization (ILO); (2) providing bilateral and multilateral technical assistance to enable developing countries to implement core labor standards, strengthen governmental capacity to enforce national labor laws, and protect internationally recognized worker rights; (3) providing bilateral aid to foreign countries to eliminate abusive child labor and other trade and investment-related worker rights violations and to support workforce development programs to foster broad-based, equitable, and sustainable economic development in recipient countries; (4) compiling and reporting annually on the extent to which each foreign country that has a trade and investment agreement with the United States protects the free exercise of internationally recognized worker rights and promotes core labor standards as embodied in the ILO Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work; and (5) conducting research and analysis on the relationship between internationally recognized worker rights and core labor standards and the conduct of international, trade, commerce, and investment and related trends.

United States Army Commemorative Coin Act of 2008 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins in recognition and celebration of the founding of the United States Army in 1775.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2015. Patient Access to Disposable Medical Technology Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide Medicare coverage of certain substitute disposable medical technologies. "Substitute disposable medical technology" means medical equipment that: (1) is primarily and customarily used to serve a medical purpose; (2) would otherwise be covered as durable medical equipment but for the fact that such equipment is not durable; and (3) the Department of Health and Human Services determines substitutes for durable medical equipment. The bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services to determine a single payment amount, as specified by the bill, for such technologies and any services and supplies used in conjunction with them.

Farm-to-Fuel Investment Act of 2007 - Amends the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to: (1) designate bioenergy cropsheds, areas physically located within, as bioenergy cropsheds; (2) offer contracts to producers on a farm in a bioenergy cropshed to provide bioenergy crop transition assistance to encourage such producers to produce bioenergy crops for a biorefinery located in the cropshed; and (3) give priority to locations in which the establishment of bioenergy cropsheds is most likely to result in geographic diversity, diversity of feedstocks, net environmental benefit, and minimal environmental harm, and areas in which the existing or planned biorefinery is owned primarily by residents of a rural area.

Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to include in each lease authorizing drilling for oil and gas on the Outer Continental Shelf a provision that requires: (1) the lessee to certify annually to the Secretary that the person does not engage in any activity for which sanctions may be imposed under the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996; and (2) cancellation of the lease if such person fails to make such a certification or makes such a certification that is false. Directs the Secretary to also include in each lease a provision that: (1) requires the lessee to disclose to the Secretary any participation by the person in any energy-related joint venture, investment, or partnership located outside Iran that involves any person whose property and interests in property are blocked by certain Executive Orders relating to blocking property and prohibiting transacting with persons who commit, threaten to commit, or support terrorism, as well as any entity listed on appendix A to part 560 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations (relating to the Iranian Transactions Regulations); and (2) authorizes the Secretary to cancel the lease if the person fails to make such a disclosure or makes such a disclosure that is false. Authorizes the Secretary to waive such requirements and cancel the lease if it is in the national interest of the United States.

Encroachment on Military Bases Prevention Act - Amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to prohibit the Secretary of the Interior from designating as critical habitat any lands or other geographical areas owned or controlled by the Department of Defense (DOD), or designated for its use, that are subject to an integrated natural resources management plan prepared pursuant to the Sikes Act, if the plan addresses special management considerations or protection of endangered or threatened species.<n><n>Amends the National Park System General Authorities Act to require the Secretary of the Interior, if a study will include or the study will be expanded to include the consideration of any military lands, to provide written notice to the Secretary of Defense of the exact military lands to be covered by such study. Requires the Secretary, upon receipt of such notice, to evaluate the existing environmental protections for the military lands and the importance of such lands to military readiness and preparedness. Authorizes the Secretary to require the Secretary to exclude all or a portion of the military lands from the study if the environmental protections for such lands are sufficient and that inclusion of such lands in the National Park System could adversely impact military readiness and preparedness.<n><n>Amends the National Marine Sanctuary Act to prohibit the Secretary of the Interior from designating as a national marine sanctuary

Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Convention Act of 1995 - Provides for the implementation of the Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries, including regarding: (1) appointment of U.S. representatives and alternate representatives as Commissioners and on the Scientific Council; (2) handling of requests for scientific advice; (3) the authorities of the Secretary of State; and (4) cooperation between various agencies, private institutions, and organizations.

Statewide PTV Access Act of 2009 - Amends federal copyright law to allow satellite carriers to pay state-wide license fees for the secondary transmission of any noncommercial educational broadcast station within a state-wide network to any subscriber in any county within that state that is located outside that station\\'s local market and is not served by such a station located within that state. Defines state-wide network" as a network of three or more such stations that are licensed to a single state, political, educational, or special purpose subdivision of a state, or a single public agency.<n><n>Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to allow a satellite carrier to retransmission the signal of a television broadcast station outside the station\\'s local market by a satellite carrier directly to its subscribers, if the station is part of a network of three or more that are licensed to a single state, political, educational, or special purpose subdivision of a state, or a single public agency."

Equal Employment Opportunity Restoration Act of 2012 - Amends the federal judicial code to allow a group of at least one member, if the representative party shows by a reasonable inference that: (1) the members of the group are so numerous that their claims of the representative party are typical and the representative party's title counsel will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the group, and (2) members of the group are or have been, subject to an employment practice that has adversely affected the group's members, and the group's claims are adversely affecting a significant portion of the group's members. Authorizes a representative party, in seeking relief under specified provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, title V of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, title II of the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act of 2008, or title VII of the Social Security Act (SSA), to sue on behalf of all members of the group if the representative party shows that: (1) the members of the group are so numerous that their claims of the representative party are typical and the representative party's title counsel will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the group, and (2) members of the group are or have been, subject to an employment practice that has adversely affected their members.

Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a limited tax credit for amounts paid for health insurance coverage for the taxpayer, his spouse, and dependents.

Money Laundering Prevention Act of 1999- Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to report to specified congressional committees on private banking activities in the United States. <n>(Sec. 4) Amends Federal law governing anti-money laundering programs to direct the Secretary to prescribe regulations requiring financial institutions to maintain all accounts in such a way as to ensure that: (1) the name of all account holders in such a way as identified by the account holder are associated with money laundering activities; and (2) all such information is available for purposes of supervision and law enforcement. <n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) develop criteria for identifying areas outside the United States in which money laundering activities are concentrated; and (2) designate foreign high-intensity money laundering areas. <n>(Sec. 5) Amends the Money Laundering and Related Financial Crimes Strategy Act of 1998 to direct the Secretary to: (1) require insured depository institutions to include in their anti-money laundering programs the availability of certain account information; and (2) designate foreign high-intensity money laundering areas. <n>(Sec. 6) Directs the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to promulgate regulations requiring the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to take into account money laundering activities when considering certain applications for membership on the Board.

Highway Fairness and Reform Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Transportation, beginning with FY2011, to carry out a direct federal-aid highway program to permit a state governor or chief executive officer, at least 90 days before the beginning of the fiscal year, to elect to have the state waive its right to receive amounts apportioned or allocated to it under the federal-aid highway program for the fiscal year to which the election relates and to receive instead a prorated amount of taxes appropriated to the Highway Trust Fund (HTF).

Senior Citizens Against Marketing Scams Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal criminal code to establish enhanced penalties for telemarketing fraud. Directs the court, in sentencing an offender, to order the offender to pay restitution to any victims and may order the offender to pay restitution to others who sustained losses as a result of the offender's fraudulent activity. <n>Directs the United States Sentencing Commission to review and, if necessary, amend the Federal criminal code to provide for increased penalties for telemarketing fraud against older persons.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on September 22, 2007. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Third Higher Education Extension Act of 2007 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Higher Education Extension Act of 2005 to extend the programs under the Higher Education Act of 1965 through March 31, 2008. (Sec. 3) Declares that nothing in this Act, or in the Higher Education Extension Act of 2005, shall be construed to limit or otherwise alter the authorizations of appropriations for, or the durations of, programs contained in the amendments made by the Higher Education Reconciliation Act of 2005 (HEA) or by the College Cost Reduction and Access Act (CRA), or the Taxpayer-Teacher Protection Act of 2004. (Sec. 4) Amends HEA to revise the definition of eligible not-for-profit holder" to exclude from such definition a state, political subdivision, authority, agency, instrumentality, or other entity acting as a trustee on behalf of a state, political subdivision, authority, agency, instrumentality, or other entity that was the sole beneficial owner of a loan eligible for any special allowance payment under the HEA on the date of enactment of CRA. (Currently, such a state, political subdivision, authority, agency, instrumentality"

Energy Savings Through Public-Private Partnerships Act of 2014 - Amends the National Energy Conservation Policy Act to require a federal agency to implement, as part of its energy management certification system, any life-cycle cost-effective measures that have not been implemented. Requires each energy manager, as part of the certification system and using guidelines developed by the Secretary of Energy (DOE), to provide an explanation regarding any such life-cycle cost-effective measures that have not been implemented. Requires the status of each agency's energy savings performance contracts and utility energy service contracts, the investment value of such contracts, the guaranteed energy savings for the previous year as compared to the actual energy savings for the previous year, the plan for entering into such contracts in the coming year, and information explaining why any previously submitted plans for such contracts were not implemented. Allows agencies to enter into energy savings performance contracts, but requires them to limit the recognition of operation and maintenance savings associated with systems modernized or replaced with the implementation of energy conservation measures, water conservation measures, or any series of energy conservation measures and water conservation measures.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 6, 2003. The summary has been expanded because action occurred on the measure.) Childrens' Internet Protection Act - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to make any elementary or secondary school or library that fails to certify to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) that it has installed and uses a technology to filter or block material deemed to be harmful to minors on one or more of its computers with Internet access eligible for universal service assistance. Makes any library with only one computer with Internet access intended for use by the public eligible to receive universal service assistance even if it does not use a technology to filter or block material deemed to be harmful to minors on that computer if it certifies to the FCC that it employs a reasonably effective alternative means to keep minors from accessing material on the Internet that is deemed to be harmful to minors. Makes a school or library that fails to meet the requirements of this Act liable to repay immediately the full amount of all universal service assistance it received.(Sec. 3) Requires the FCC to adopt rules implementing this Act within four months of this Act's enactment.

Higher Education Affordability and Fairness Act This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an income tax deduction for the qualified tuition and related expenses of a student who is eligible for the Hope Scholarship tax credit and who is attending an institution of higher education. The bill limits the amount of such deduction to the lesser of: (1) $10,000 for each eligible student, or (2) $15,000 over the amount of such expenses taken into account in determining the Hope Scholarship tax credit. The deduction is allowed for four years of postsecondary education and is subject to an adjustment for certain scholarships and veterans benefits.

National Science Education Tax Incentive for Businesses Act of 2007- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow certain businesses engaged in the trade or business of providing STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) services a business tax credit for 100% of their contributions to schools providing such education, including for STEM school contributions, STEM teacher externship expenses, and STEM teacher training expenses.

Directs the Secretary of the military department concerned, in the case of a member of the Armed Forces with a combat-related disability who is entitled to monthly retired pay, to permit the member to elect to have used in that formula a retired pay base equal to $2,917, which represents the average monthly salary for high school graduates in the United States for 2006.

Administrative Simplification Compliance Act - Amends titles XVIII (Medicare) and XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to extend the deadline for certain covered entities to submit compliance plans to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 17, 2015. Autofill Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to require the Department of the Treasury to: (1) establish a program to allow taxpayers to download income tax forms that are populated with tax return information (e.g., wages, withholding, and self-employment income) previously reported to Treasury; (2) establish standards for data download to tax preparation software; and (3) provide on Treasury's website a secure function that allows a taxpayer to download, as both a printable document file and in a form suitable for input to automatic tax preparation software, the 1040, 1040A, and 1040EZ forms that are populated with tax return information previously reported to Treasury. Taxpayers must acknowledge that: (1) the taxpayer is responsible for the accuracy of his or her return, and (2) all tax return information provided under such program needs to be verified. The Social Security Act is amended to require the Commissioner of Social Security to provide Treasury with tax return information for 2015 and thereafter.

National Treatment in Banking Act of 1994 - Directs the Secretary of the Treas
ury to identify foreign countries that may be denying national treatment to U.S.
 banking organizations: (1) based on information relating to banking in a specif
ied report of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988; or (2) based on
 more recent information the Secretary considers appropriate. <n>Directs the Sec
retary to assess whether the possible denial of national treatment to U.S. banki
ng organizations by such a foreign country may be having a significant adverse e
ffect on them. Sets forth factors to be considered in making such assessment. <n
>Amends the International Banking Act of 1978 to direct the Federal Deposit Insu
rance Board to take into account whether the Secretary has published a notice th
at a foreign bank's home country may be denying national treatment to U.S. banki
ng organizations.

Notch Fairness Act of 1998 - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to revise the formula for the computation of minimum Old Age Insurance benefits for individuals who reached age 65 in or after 1979 and to whom applies the 15-year transition period for the changes in benefit computation rules enacted in the Social Security Amendments of 1977. <n>Sets forth a schedule of additional benefit increases for such beneficiaries (and related beneficiaries), with percentages declining from 55 percent to five percent and keyed to the year an individual became eligible for such benefits between 1979 and 1988. <n>Allows such beneficiaries, in the alternative, to receive lump sum payments over four years totaling $5,000. <n>Specifies offsetting nondefense and discretionary spending reductions the Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall make over a four-year period for the increase in direct spending estimated to result from enactment of this Act.

Intergovernmental Law Enforcement Information Sharing Act of 2001 - Directs the Attorney General to: (1) expeditiously carry out security clearance investigations for specified persons; and (2) grant appropriate security clearances to all such persons who qualify for clearances under applicable laws and executive orders.Authorizes the Attorney General to: (1) charge State, territorial, and local governments the costs of carrying out security clearance investigations and granting such clearances for Federal employees; and (2) waive any charges that would otherwise apply if such government agrees to promptly provide Federal officials, without charge, access to the criminal databases of such government for the purpose of conducting personnel security background investigations for military, civilian, and contract employees.Directs the Attorney General to: (1) conduct a study of methods to enhance the sharing of sensitive Federal law enforcement information with State, territorial, and local law enforcement officials; and (2) ensure that officials from State, territorial, and local law enforcement agencies participate in the study.

Promoting Human Rights by Ending Israeli Military Detention of Palestinian Children Act This bill amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to prohibit the United States from providing assistance to Israel or the Palestinian Authority unless the Department of State certifies that Israeli military detention of Palestinian children is in violation of the Convention on the Rights of the Child and other specified international standards.

Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act - Prohibits the wages or other remuneration earned by an employee who performs employment duties in more than one state from being subject to income tax in any state other than: (1) the state of the employee's residence; and (2) the state within which the employee is present and performing employment duties for more than 30 days during the calendar year. Exempts employers from withholding of tax and information return requirements for employees not subject to income tax under this Act.

Youth Protection From Tobacco Addiction Act of 1996 - Prohibits the advertising, promotion, and packaging of tobacco products. Declares that it shall be unlawful to: (1) distribute tobacco products as a free sample or to make such products available at no cost as the result of coupons or other method which allows products to be obtained for free or for reduced cost; (2) sponsor or cause to be sponsored any athletic, music, artistic, or other event in the name of a registered brand name, logo, or symbol of a tobacco product in a manner so that such product is publicly identified as a sponsor of or in any way associated with such an event; (3) market or cause to be marketed nontobacco products or services which bear the name of a registered brand name, logo, symbol of a tobacco product, except if the registered brand name is also the name of the corporation which manufactures the tobacco product and both the registered brand and the corporation were in existence prior to January 1, 1996; (4) pay or cause to be paid to have such product appear in any movie, television show, play, video game, or other form of entertainment, except if the registered brand name is also the name of the corporation which manufactures the tobacco product and both the registered brand and the corporation were in

Federal Financial Management Improvement Act of 1996 - Requires each agency to implement and maintain financial management systems that comply with Federal financial management systems requirements, applicable Federal accounting standards, and the United States Government Standard General Ledger at the transaction level. Directs a person performing an audit of an agency that reports noncompliance with such requirements to include in the report on the audit: (1) the name and position of any officer or employee responsible for the financial management systems that have been found not to comply; and (2) all facts pertaining to the noncompliance, including the primary reason or cause, any official responsible for the noncompliance, and any relevant comments from any responsible officer or employee. Specifies that no remedial actions shall be taken unless the person performing the audit certifies that: (1) the agency financial management systems are in compliance with applicable Federal accounting standards; and (2) a written determination is made that such systems are not in compliance.

American Health Security Partnership Act of 1995- Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make payments to States with comprehensive health insurance plans certified under this Act. <n>Directs the Secretary to certify State comprehensive health insurance plans which meet specified requirements. Sets forth a formula for the allocation of payments among the States. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Flu Protection Act of 2005 - Amends the Public Health Act to require: (1) the Secretary of Health and Human Services, through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, to conduct annual public awareness campaign and education and outreach (including Medicare outreach) efforts preceding the flu season; (2) the Director to contract with influenza vaccine manufacturers to ensure the availability of additional doses of flu vaccine; (3) the Director to support development of state adult immunization programs that place emphasis on improving vaccine delivery to high-risk populations and the general population; and (4) the Director to work with agencies to assess the efficacy of the influenza vaccine. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) allow a tax credit for investment in vaccine manufacturing facilities; and (2) define vaccine manufacturing facilities property.""

Opal Creek Forest Preserve Act of 1994 - Establishes the Opal Creek Forest Preserve, consisting of certain Federal lands in the Willamette and Mt. Hood National Forests, Oregon. <n>Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to prepare a comprehensive management plan for the Preserve to achieve the purposes of this Act. <n>Prohibits management of the Preserve by the Secretary or any responsible party except in accordance with the management plan. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) acquire non-Federal land within the Preserve; and (2) conduct environmental response actions or pursue liability. <n>Withdraws Federal lands within the Preserve from: (1) entry, appropriation, and disposal under the public land, mining, and mineral leasing laws; and (2) location, entry, and patent under the Federal mining laws. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to acquire lands and interests within the Preserve by donation, purchase with donated or appropriated funds, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency, except that such lands or interests owned by the State of Oregon or a political subdivision may be acquired only by donation or exchange.

Immigrant Labor Policy Review Act - Establishes the High Level Commission on Immigrant Labor Policy to study and report to the Congress on the interactions between Federal immigration policy and the U.S. labor markets.

Electric Reliability Act of 2004 - Amends the Federal Power Act to grant Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) jurisdiction over any Regional Transmission Organization (ERO), or any regional entities, and all users, owners, and operators of the United States' bulk-power system, for purposes of approving reliability standards and enforcing compliance with this Act.<n><n>Authorizes any person to submit an application to FERC for certification as an ERO if FERC determines that such ERO: (1) has the ability to develop and enforce reliability standards that provide for an adequate level of reliability of the bulk-power system; and (2) has established rules that assure: (1) its independence of the users and owners and operators of the bulk-power system; (2) equitable dues, fees, and other charges among end users for all activities under this Act; (3) fair and impartial procedures for enforcement of reliability standards through the imposition of penalties; and (4) reasonable notice and opportunity for public comment. Requires an ERO to file each reliability standard or modification to a reliability standard with FERC.<n><n>Authorizes FERC to approve a proposed reliability standard or modification if it determines that it is just, reasonable, not unduly discriminatory or preferential, and in the public interest. Requires FERC to give due weight to the technical expertise of the

Rail Passenger Disaster Family Assistance Act of 2001 - Amends Federal transportation law to direct the Chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, after being notified of a rail passenger accident within the United States involving a rail passenger carrier and resulting in a major loss of life, to: (1) designate and publicize the name and phone number of a director of family support services who shall be an employee of the Board and shall be responsible for acting as a point of contact within the Federal Government for the families of passengers involved in the accident and a liaison between the rail passenger carrier and the families; and (2) designate an independent nonprofit organization for coordinating the emotional care and support of such families. Grants the Board primary Federal responsibility for: (1) facilitating the recovery and identification of fatally injured passengers; and (2) communicating with such families as to the roles of the organization, the Government agencies, and the rail passenger carrier involved.Designates a designated organization with respect to the families of passengers involved in the accident to: (1) provide mental health and counseling services; (2) provide an environment in which the families may grieve in private; (3) meet with the families who have traveled to the location of the accident, to contact the families unable to travel to such location, and to contact all affected families periodically thereafter until such time as the organization

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 12, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Warren Hostage Rescue Act - Amends the National Security Act of 1947 to establish within the National Security Council the Committee on Hostage Recovery, which shall: (1) coordinate among the federal agencies and U.S. allies regarding retrieval of U.S. person hostages; (2) coordinate with the Interagency Fusion Cell on Hostage Recovery; (3) develop strategies and guidelines for hostage retrieval and analyzing all options and methods of rescue; (4) develop policies and procedures to effectively share information between federal agencies responsible for hostage rescue activities; and (5) develop a strategy to keep family members of U.S. person hostages informed of the status of such hostages and inform them of updates, procedures, and policies that do not compromise U.S. national security.<n><n>Requires the Committee to submit quarterly reports to specified congressional committees on its general activities and the Interagency Fusion Cell on Hostage Recovery with respect to U.S. person hostages.<n><n>Expresses the sense of Congress that the President should appoint a Special Advisor on Hostage Affairs who: (1) serves as the chair of the Committee; (2) has extensive experience in foreign policy, counterterrorism, and hostage

SIG TARP Small Business Awareness Act of 2009 - Amends the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 to require that the Special Inspector General (SIG) for the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) examine how smaller financial institutions are being affected by: (1) expenditures under the TARP program; and (2) the considerations and determinations of the Secretary of the Treasury and the regulators of such smaller financial institutions regarding capital adequacy and troubled assets. Directs the SIG to examine the effects of TARP on small businesses, including both positive and negative effects and the extent of such effects on small businesses generally and by type and region. Requires the SIG to include in each quarterly report to Congress information on the activities of the Secretary and any financial institutions receiving TARP assistance to include and utilize minorities and women- and minority-owned businesses.

International Tuberculosis Control Act of 2002 - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to direct the President, through the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), to provide assistance for the prevention, treatment and elimination of tuberculosis. States that Congress expects USAID to: (1) coordinate with specified organizations to develop a comprehensive tuberculosis control program; and (2) support the development and implementation of a comprehensive tuberculosis control program through the Global Tuberculosis Drug Facility.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 8, 2013. King Cove Road Land Exchange Act (Sec. 4) This bill directs the Department of the Interior to convey specified federal land within the Izembek National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to the state of Alaska in exchange for specified nonfederal land in the state for the purpose of: (1) designating a road corridor through the Refuge, and (2) constructing a single-lane gravel road along such corridor. The value of the federal and nonfederal lands exchanged shall be equal, as determined by appraisals. The value of such lands shall be equalized: if the final appraised value of such lands exceeds their final appraised value, by conveying additional nonfederal land in the state to Interior, subject to Interior's approval, or by using a combination of the methods described above; or if such value exceeds such value, by accepting a payment in excess of 25% of the value of the federal land conveyed.
Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) reduce estate and gift tax rates to 30 percent; (2) increase the unified credit to $10 million; and (3) increase the annual gift tax exclusion to $50,000.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on February 29, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.)Upper Housatonic Valley National Heritage Area Act - (Sec. 3) Establishes the Upper Housatonic Valley National Heritage Area in Massachusetts and Connecticut.(Sec. 4) Establishes the Upper Housatonic Valley National Heritage Area Management Entity (the Entity).(Sec. 5) Directs the Entity to submit to the Secretary of the Interior a management plan for the Area. Requires the Secretary to approve the Plan or to disapprove it, and to provide recommendations in the latter instance.Prohibits the Entity from using Federal funds received under this Act to acquire real property or any interest in real property.(Sec. 7) Authorizes the Secretary to provide technical and financial assistance to the Entity to develop and implement the management plan.Prohibits assistance under this Act after the expiration of the ten-year period beginning on the date the Secretary approves the plan.(Sec. 8) Authorizes appropriations. Limits Federal funding under this Act to 50 percent of the total cost of any assistance or grant under this Act.Prohibits the Secretary from making any grant or providing any assistance beyond 15 years after the date the Secretary approves the plan
Amends the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States to suspend, through six months after the enactment of this Act, the duty on certain drug substances.

Close Big Oil Tax Loopholes Act - Expresses the sense of the Senate with respect to high gas prices. Title I: Close Big Oil Tax Loopholes - (Sec. 101) Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) modify the foreign tax credit eligibility of major integrated oil companies (defined as companies with annual gross receipts over $1 billion and an average daily worldwide production of crude oil of at least 500,000 barrels or certain successors in interest of such companies); (2) deny such oil companies a tax deduction for the cost of oil, natural gas, or primary products thereof; (3) deny them a tax deduction for intangible drilling and development costs; (4) limit their percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells; and (5) deny them a tax deduction for tertiary injectants. (Sec. 201) Repeals provisions of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act that provide for royalty relief for deep water oil and gas production. Title II: Outer Continental Shelf Oil and Natural Gas - (Sec. 201) Repeals provisions of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act that provide for royalty relief for deep water oil and gas production. Title III: Miscellaneous - (Sec. 301) Expresses the sense of the Senate with respect to high gas prices.

Family Caregiver Support and Protection Act of 1996 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for coverage of respite care services under Medicare part A (Hospital Insurance). <n>Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to: (1) establish Medicare standards for individuals and entities providing such services; and (2) provide for payment of such services on an hour-by-hour basis, subject to specified limitations.

Veterans Serving Veterans Act of 2018 This bill amends the VA Choice and Quality Employment Act to require the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to maintain a single searchable database that includes the following information for each vacant VA position: the military occupational specialty or skill that corresponds to the position; and each qualified member of the Armed Forces who may be recruited to fill the position before the member has been discharged and released from active duty. The database shall include the following information with respect to each qualified member: the member's name and contact information; the date on which the member is expected to be discharged and released from active duty; and each military occupational specialty currently or previously assigned to the member. The VA shall hire qualified members of the Armed Forces who apply for listed positions without regard to civil service requirements. The VA may authorize a relocation bonus for qualified members who have accepted such a position. The VA shall implement a program to train and certify covered veterans to work as intermediate care technicians in VA medical facilities.

White House Quadrennial Small Business Summit Act of 2001 - Provides for a national White House Quadrennial Summit on Small Business once every four years, to be held during the second year following each presidential election, to: (1) increase public awareness of the contribution of small business to the national economy; (2) identify the problems of small business; (3) examine the status of minorities and women as small business owners; (4) assist small business in carrying out its role as the Nation's job creators; (5) assemble small businesses to develop recommendations for legislative and regulatory action for maintaining and encouraging the economic viability of small business and thereby, the Nation; and (6) review the status of recommendations adopted at the immediately preceding Small Business Summit.Directs the Small Business Commission to conduct Small Business Summits and State Summits to bring together individuals concerned with issues relating to small business. Requires the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration to assist in carrying out such summits.

Budget Surplus Dividend Act of 1998 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allocate credits to taxpayers for social security taxes, during any year in which there is a Federal budget surplus of more than $1 billion, so as to utilize 33 percent of such surplus. Requires that, during any such year, the remainder of such surplus shall be split and used to: (1) reduce the outstanding public debt; and (2) increase nondefense discretionary spending limits.

Dangerous Explosives Background Checks Requirement Act - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit a licensed importer, licensed manufacturer, or licensed dealer from transferring explosive materials to a permitee unless: (1) before the completion of the transfer, the licensee contacts the national instant criminal background check system and the system has not notified the licensee that the receipt of explosive materials by the permitee would violate the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act; (2) the system provides the licensee with a unique identification number or five days on which State offices are open have elapsed since the licensee contacted the system, and the system has not notified the licensee that the receipt of explosive materials by the permitee would violate such Act; (3) the transferor has verified the identity of the transferee by examining a valid identification document, and has examined the permit issued to the transferee and recorded the permit number on the record of the transfer; and (4) the system notifies the licensee that the information available to the system does not demonstrate that the receipt of explosive materials by the transferee would not violate such Act or State law. Specifies exceptions. Sets penalties for violations.

Immunization Now Act of 1993 - Entitles each U.S. infant who has not reached his or her second birthday, who is a citizen or national of the United States, an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence, or other alien permanently in the United States under color of law, and who is not entitled under a health insurance policy or other health benefit plan to receive without charge any immunizations against vaccine-preventable diseases. Declares that vouchers represent the obligation of the Federal Government to pay for such immunizations.

Amends the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 to direct the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to make recourse loans available to producers who elect to participate in the market-driven inventory system for corn, oats, barley, grain sorghum, wheat, and soybeans. States that: (1) enrollment in the system shall be voluntary and considered on a rolling basis; (2) enrollment restrictions shall end as soon as the Secretary determines that the one-month average of the market commodity is below the recourse loan rate for that commodity; (3) participation in the system for corn, wheat, and soybeans shall be limited to not more than specified amounts for corn, oats, barley, grain sorghum, wheat, and soybeans; and (4) as a condition of participation, producers shall store the commodity, maintain it in proper condition, and not sell or otherwise release it into the market.

Hire Just One Act of 2013- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow amounts from the Unemployment Fund to be withdrawn for the payment of allowances under an employment assistance voucher program. Defines "employment assistance voucher program" as a program under which an eligible individual is issued an employment assistance voucher, upon employment with an employer, which: (1) the eligible individual transfers the voucher to the employer, (2) the individual ceases to receive unemployment compensation and is paid wages by the employer, and (3) the employer receives payments upon presenting the voucher to the state. Sets forth rules relating to unemployed individuals.

Increases from 50 to 75 percent the amount of gain excluded from the sale of certain small business stock. Reduces from five to three years the holding period applicable to such a sale. Makes such exclusion available to corporations. Makes the stock of larger businesses eligible. Repeals the minimum tax preference for the exclusion for incentive stock options.

Medicare Telemedicine and Medical Informatics Demonstration Act of 1996 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services, through the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, to make a grant for a project to demonstrate the application of high- capacity computing and advanced networks to the provision of health care to both residents of medically underserved rural areas and residents of medically underserved inner city areas. Declares that the project shall focus on improvements in primary care for residents with diabetes and Medicare beneficiaries. Authorizes appropriations.

Highway Infrastructure Privatization Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for the treatment of qualified highway infrastructure project bonds as exempt facility bonds. Defines qualified highway infrastructure project" as a project for the construction or reconstruction of a highway, designated as an eligible pilot project. Directs the Secretary of Transportation to select up to 15 eligible pilot projects."

Spending Control Act of 2004 - Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 to extend discretionary spending limits through FY 2009 for the general purpose discretionary category in new budget authority and outlays. Counts discretionary advance appropriations provided in appropriation Acts in excess of $____ against the discretionary spending limits for the fiscal year for which the appropriation Act containing the advance appropriation is enacted. Sets forth the purpose of this Act: (1) to assure that any legislation enacted before October 1, 2009, that causes a net increase in direct spending will trigger an offsetting sequestration; and (2) to revise the definition of direct spending increase.

Keep Student Loans Affordable Act of 2013 - Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to extend until June 30, 2014, existing interest rates for loans made to undergraduate students under the Federal Direct Stafford Loan program. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to modify rules for required distributions from tax-exempt pension plans to an employee who dies before such employee's entire interest is distributed to require such interest to be distributed within five years after the death of such employee, subject to exceptions for an eligible designated beneficiary and surviving spouse of such employee. Defines "eligible designated beneficiary" to include a disabled or chronically-ill individual.

Directs the Secretary to ensure that the design developed includes recommendations for carrying out the proposed pilot program in: (1) the greater metropolitan region of the District of Columbia, including areas in Maryland and Virginia; (2) the greater metropolitan region of Los Angeles, California; and (3) three additional areas to be selected by the Secretary.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 27, 2016. Cyber Preparedness Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to revise the cybersecurity activities of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to: (1) include accessing timely technical assistance, risk management support, and incident response capabilities with respect to cyber threat indicators, defensive measures, cybersecurity risks, and incidents; (2) review information relating to cybersecurity risks that is gathered by state, local, and regional fusion centers and incorporate such information into DHS information relating to cybersecurity risks; (3) ensure the dissemination to state, local, and regional fusion centers of such information; and (4) enhance cybersecurity, including preparing for and responding to cybersecurity risks and incidents and developing state-wide cyber threat information analysis and dissemination activities. The bill expresses the sense of Congress that DHS should, to the greatest extent practicable, work to share actionable information related to cyber threats in an unclassified form. (Sec. 3) DHS may award grants to state and major urban area fusion centers for enhancing cybersecurity, including preparing for and responding to cybersecurity risks and incidents and developing state-wide cyber threat information analysis and dissemination activities.

Liquefied Natural Gas Act of 2005 - Amends the Natural Gas Act to prohibit any person from exporting any natural gas from the United States to a foreign country, or importing any natural gas from a foreign country without first having secured an order of the Secretary of Energy authorizing such person to do so, unless, after opportunity for hearing, the Secretary finds that the proposed exportation or importation will not be consistent with the public interest. Authorizes the Secretary to grant such order upon application, in whole or in part, with such modification and upon such terms and conditions as the Secretary may find necessary or appropriate. Declares that with respect to natural gas imported into the United States from a nation with which there is in effect a free trade agreement requiring national treatment for trade in natural gas: (1) such natural gas shall be treated as a first sale" within the meaning of the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978; and (2) the Secretary shall not, on the basis of national origin, treat any such imported natural gas on an unjust, unreasonable, unduly discriminatory, or preferential basis. Deems such importation or exportation to be consistent with the public interest. Prohibits any person from site, constructing, expanding, or operating a liquefied natural gas import terminal without first having"

Maritime Administration Authorization Act for Fiscal Years 2000 and 2001 - Authorizes appropriations for the Department of Transportation for the Maritime Administration for FY 2000 and 2001. Amends the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 to authorize the Secretary of Transportation (Secretary) to accept, hold, in escrow, the proceeds of a loan obligation guaranteed by the Secretary if such proceeds are to be used to finance the construction, reconstruction, or reconditioning of a vessel or vessels which will serve as security for the Secretary's guarantee. Prohibits the Secretary from releasing such funds from the escrow until the Secretary determines that the obligor has paid its portion of the actual cost of constructing, reconstructing, or reconditioning the vessel or vessels and that the funds to be released are needed to pay, or make reimbursements in connection with payments previously made to the shipyard or other contractors for work performed, or to pay for other approved costs, with respect to the vessel or vessels. Establishes in the Treasury a deposit fund into which the Secretary is authorized to deposit cash belonging to an obligor so long as the Secretary has a security interest in such cash.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) No Harm Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the federal criminal code to require a business entity and any responsible corporate officer, after acquiring actual knowledge of a serious danger associated with a product, service, or business practice of such entity: (1) within 24 hours, to inform an appropriate federal agency; (2) within 15 days, to inform an appropriate federal agency in writing; and (3) as soon as practicable, to warn affected employees in writing and to inform other individuals who may be exposed to the danger if such individuals can reasonably be identified. The bill defines: (1) serious danger" as a danger not readily informed to a reasonable person that exposed, or reasonably foreseeable use of, an individual to, a covered product, service, or business practice has an imminent risk of death or serious bodily injury; and (2) "warn affected employees" as taking reasonable steps to give each individual who may be exposed or exposed to the danger in the course of work a description of the danger and to inform other individuals who may be exposed."

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) International Fund for Israeli-Palestinian Peace Authorization Act of 2017 (Sec. 3) This bill urges the President to make every effort, in conjunction with the government of Israel, the Palestinian Authority, regional governments, and the international community to establish an International Fund for Israeli-Palestinian Peace. (Sec. 4) Authorizes appropriations for U.S. contributions to the Fund. Of the amounts made available for each of FY2017-FY2021, $50 million shall be authorized to be appropriated for U.S. contributions to the Fund following the committee of jurisdictions agreement to its structure and board.

E-Rate 2.0 Act of 2010 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to direct the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to implement a pilot program to extend broadband service to students who: (1) qualify for funding under the federally subsidized school lunch program; (2) attend secondary schools that receive support; and (3) possess a computer for use at home. Requires the pilot program to distribute funding to such secondary schools to dispense vouchers to eligible students to be used for monthly service fees for residential broadband service for such students.

Amends title XI of the Social Security Act (SSA) to require the Secretary of the Treasury to sell or redeem, for payment of cash benefits or administrative expenses during any debt limit default period, public debt obligations held by the applicable federal fund in order to obtain the amounts necessary for payment of such benefits or administrative expenses from the applicable federal fund, notwithstanding the public debt limit.<n><n>Amends Federal law to direct the Secretary, in the event that the Secretary of the Treasury is not able to issue obligations to make all payments authorized by law due to the public debt limitation, to give equal priority to: (1) payments of principal and interest on public debt; and (2) payments of amounts that the Secretary of Defense (and the Secretary of Homeland Security in the case of the Coast Guard) determines to be necessary to continue pay and allowances (without interruption) to the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, and Coast Guard, including reserve components thereof, who perform active service, payments determined by the President to be necessary to continue U.S. priorities of its vital national security interests, and payments for items and services under SSA title XVIII (Medicare).

Academic and CRNA Payment Improvement Act of 2006 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to revise the requirements and the formula for payments for services of certified registered nurse anesthetists under Medicare.

Establishes in the Treasury the HMO Guaranty Fund to make payments to a State to: (1) pay the outstanding health care provider claims for uncovered expenditures; and (2) provide for a temporary continuation of health care coverage for covered individuals. Requires the Fund to be administered by a Board of Directors appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury.

. Veterans' Access to Child Care Act (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to provide child care assistance to a veteran who is the primary caretaker of a child or children and who is receiving VA covered health care services, or who is in need of covered health care services, and but for lack of child care services, for any period that the veteran: (1) receives such services at a VA facility, and (2) is required travel to and return from such facility for the receipt of such services. The bill allows child care assistance to include any of the following: a stipend for the payment of child care offered by a licensed child care center (either directly or through a voucher program), direct provision of child care at an VA on-site facility, a payment made directly to a private child care agency, or a collaboration with a facility or program of another federal department or agency.

Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary of Defense (and the Secretary of Homeland Security with respect to the Coast Guard) should duly honor those members of the Armed Forces who are killed or wounded in terrorist attacks within the United States that are inspired by the ideology that gives rise to terrorism. Directs the Secretary concerned, for purposes of the award of the Purple Heart, to treat a member of the Armed Forces who is killed or wounded in a terrorist attack within the United States perpetrated by an individual or individuals expressing a political, religious, or ideological obligation to engage in unlawful violence directed against U.S military operations or foreign policy in the same manner as a member who is killed or wounded in action as the result of an act of the enemy.

Flint Hills Preservation Act - Amends the Clean Air Act to require a state and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), in determining whether an exceedance or violation of a national ambient air quality standard has occurred for purposes of such Act, to exclude data from a particular air quality monitoring location in the Flint Hills Region of Kansas and Oklahoma if emissions from one or more prescribed fires cause a concentration of the air pollutant at the monitoring facility in excess of the standard. Provides that if emissions from one or more prescribed fires in the Region are excluded, the Administrator shall not: (1) find that a state has failed to enforce, or has violated, a state implementation plan for national primary or secondary ambient air quality standards; and (2) find that a person has violated, or bring an enforcement action for violation of, a state implementation plan for such standards. Declares that no building, structure, or installation in connection with prescribed fires in the Region may be treated as a stationary source under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (NEPA).

Federal Agency Anti-Lobbying Act - Amends Federal law to prohibit the use of appropriated funds by any Federal agency for any activity that is intended to promote public support or opposition to any legislative proposal on which congressional action is not complete. Makes an exception for: (1) the President or Vice President; and (2) congressional communications. Declares that such prohibition shall not be construed to prevent any Federal agency official whose appointment is confirmed by the Senate, any official in the Executive Office of the President, or the head of any Federal agency, from communicating with the American public through radio, television, or other public communication media on the views of the President for or against any pending legislative proposal. Authorizes the Comptroller General, in exercising such authority, to obtain, without reimbursement from the Comptroller General, the assistance of the Inspector General within whose Federal agency activity prohibited by this Act is under review.

Public Good IRA Rollover Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income distributions from individual retirement accounts for certain charitable purposes. Requires such exclusions if no person holds an income interest in the amounts in the split-interest entity attributable to such distribution other than the individual for whose benefit the account is maintained, the spouse of such individual, or any such organization.

Mercury-Safe Seafood Act of 2001 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a tolerance for the presence of methylmercury in seafood. Deems any seafood bearing or containing methylmercury to be unsafe unless the quantity of methylmercury is within the limits of the tolerance.

Police and Fire Station Modernization Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for investment in qualified tax credit bonds of the police and fire department. Limits the amount of such bonds which may be issued.

Specifies that such a request shall: (1) specify an entity to gather responses to the request; (2) be from a private entity to a Federal entity; or (3) be deemed to have been made and to have specified such a private entity when the Federal entity has voluntarily been given cyber security information gathered by that private entity, including by means of a computer network or telecommunications system.<n>Provides that a cyber security information statement or other such information provided by a party in response to a request: (1) shall be exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act; (2) shall not be disclosed to or by any third party; and (3) may not be used by any Federal or State entity or by any third party in any civil action arising under Federal or State law. Makes exceptions regarding separately obtained information submitted in response to a request through the use of independent legal authorities and regarding information disclosed generally or broadly to the public with the express consent of the party.<n>(Sec. 5) Makes the antitrust laws inapplicable to conduct engaged in solely for facilitating or communicating about the correction or avoidance of a cyber security related problem. Makes an exception with respect to conduct that involves or results in an agreement to boycott any person, to allocate a market, or to fix prices or output.<n>(Sec.

Preserving Patient Access to Rehabilitation Hospitals Act of 2005 - Prohibits the Secretary of Health and Human Services from: (1) requiring a compliance rate under the 75 percent rule" used to determine whether a hospital or unit is an inpatient rehabilitation facility; (2) changing the designation of an inpatient rehabilitation facility that is in compliance with specified guidelines or conducting any necessity review; or (3) making any necessary adjustment to restore the status of a facility as an inpatient rehabilitation facility. Directs the Secretary to establish procedures for: (1) making any necessary adjustment to restore such status; and (2) developing and implementing an appeals process that provides for expedited review of any adjustment to such status. Establishes the National Advisory Council on Medical Rehabilitation."

Expresses the sense of the Senate that: (1) the United States government should take the lead in organizing a comprehensive diplomatic offensive to assist the government of Iraq in achieving national reconciliation and successfully meeting key security, political, and economic benchmarks; (2) it is in the U.S. interest that Iraq is not seen as a uniquely American" problem, but rather as of enduring importance to the security and prosperity of its neighbors, the entire Middle East region, and the broader international community; (3) the greater involvement in a constructive fashion of Iraq\\'s neighbors can help stabilize Iraq and end the outside flows of weapons, explosive materials, foreign fighters, and funding that contribute to the current sectarian warfare in Iraq; (4) the President and the Secretary of State should invest their personal time and energy in these diplomatic efforts to ensure that they receive the highest priority within the U.S. government and are viewed as a serious effort in the region; (5) the President, in order to demonstrate that a regional diplomacy strategy enjoys attention at the highest levels of the U.S. government, should appoint a seasoned, high-level Presidential envoy to the Middle East region to supplement the efforts of Ambassador Crocker and focus on the establishment of a regional framework to help stabilize Iraq; (6) the United States government should build"

Accelerating Biomedical Research Act Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 to require certain adjustments to discretionary spending limits in FY2015-FY2021 to accommodate increases in appropriations for the National Institutes of Health (NIH).

Technology Investment Incentive Act of 2003- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a deduction for the cost of qualified technological equipment and qualified computer software acquired between the enactment of this Act and September 11, 2004, for use in the active conduct of a trade or business and placed in service on or before September 11, 2004.Denies a deduction with respect to property used predominantly outside the United States or with respect to the portion of the cost of any property taken into account under this Act.Provides three-year depreciation for wireless telecommunications equipment, advanced services equipment, network or network system equipment, and research expenses for software development.

Directs the Secretary of Energy to establish and carry out a program to award grants, on a competitive basis, to each consortium of institutions of higher education (IHEs) operating in each of at least six regions established by the Secretary that, collectively, cover all states.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to use amounts made available under this Act to award such grants, on a competitive basis, to each consortium in equal amounts for each region of at least $50 million for each region.<n><n>Requires a consortium, as a condition for an initial grant, to submit to the Secretary for approval a plan that: (1) addresses the energy needs for the region; and (2) describes the manner in which the proposed activities will address those needs.<n><n>Makes a consortium that does not comply with such requirements ineligible to receive further grants.<n><n>Requires a consortium to use such a grant to conduct research, extension, and education programs relating to the region's energy needs, including: (1) the promotion of low-carbon clean and green energy and related jobs that are applicable to the region; (2) the development of low-carbon green fuels to reduce dependency on oil; (3) the development of energy storage and energy management innovations for intermittent renewable technologies; and (4) the accelerated deployment of efficient-energy

Solar Stimulus for Job Creation and Energy Independence Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) allow an increased refundable tax credit for investment in property used to manufacture solar energy property; (2) exempt solar energy property from private business use and subsidized energy financing rules; and (3) allow an election to take an increased depreciation allowance for solar energy property until 2011.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 7, 2016. Workforce Training Enhancement Act of 2016 (Sec. 3) This bill amends the Trade Act of 1974 to allow a state to use its allotment under the trade adjustment assistance (TAA) program to reimburse the costs of providing training to workers certified as eligible for TAA if the costs of providing the training are met as of the date: (1) the total or partial separations of the group of workers covered by the certification for eligibility began or threatened to begin, and (2) the state or local workforce development areas within the state or an eligible entity under the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act meet the requirements for approval of training. The bill applies only to costs paid before the date on which the total or partial separations of the group of workers covered by the certification for eligibility began or threatened to begin.

Military Survivor Benefits Improvement Act of 2003 - Adjusts the basic Survivor Benefit Plan annuity amount for surviving spouses, age 62 and older, of former military personnel to: (1) 35 percent of the retired pay of the decedent (current law), for a month before October 2004; (2) 40 percent for a month during FY 2005; (3) 45 percent for a month during FY 2006; (4) 50 percent for a month during FY 2007; and (5) 55 percent for a month after FY 2007. Adjusts similarly percentage amounts with respect to survivors of eligible persons dying on active duty. Provides a corresponding phased reduction in the annuity amount for months before and after FY 2004. Requires periodic recomputation of: (1) annuity amounts beginning in October 2004; and (2) retired pay reductions for supplemental survivor annuities.

Right of Passage Community Service Act - Amends the National and Community Service Act of 1990 to establish a Right of Passage Community Service Program.<n><n>Requires such program to be a community-based after-school and summer service corps for eligible young people who are between the ages of 12 and 16, inclusive at the time they begin such service. Requires such program to offer participants service-learning curricula linked to academic goals, as well as opportunities for: (1) service in their communities; (2) activities that train in certain critical skills; and (3) working with older members who can organize service projects and act as mentors.<n><n>Requires each individual program participant to: (1) agree to participate in such after-school or summer program for at least 160 hours during a period of at least two months and not more than one year; and (2) receive an education award of $500 upon completion of such required hours of service.

Market Based Manufacturing Incentives Act of 2011 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a retail tax credit for the purchase of certain domestic products consisting of at least 60% of components assembled or otherwise arising in the United States. Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to designate 10 products for designation as domestic products and to determine the applicable percentage of the credit based upon: (1) the number of jobs in the United States that the Secretary estimates will result from the designation of a product; and (2) the speed with which such jobs are likely to be created.

Classroom Safety Act of 1993 - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make grants to local educational agencies (LEAs) most directly affected by crime and violence. Requires the Secretary to develop a model for classroom safety written in English and Spanish and make such model available to LEAs that request it. <n>Directs that grants be used: (1) to fund anticrime and safety measures and to develop education and training programs for the prevention of crime, violence, and illegal use of drugs and alcohol; (2) for counseling programs for victims and witnesses of crime in schools; (3) for conflict resolution and peer mediation counseling for students, teachers, and other personnel in regular contact with students at school; (4) to purchase crime prevention equipment, including metal detectors and video-surveillance devices; and (5) for the prevention and reduction of the participation of students in organized crime and drug- and gang-related activities in schools. <n>Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) application requirements; (2) allocation of, and limitations on, grant funds; (3) selection of recipients; and (4) reporting requirements. <n>Authorizes appropriations.
