Unfair Foreign Competition Act of 2007- Amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to authorize a petitioning party, within 30 days after an antidumping or countervailing duty investigation is initiated, to elect to bring a civil action in a U.S. district court for a determination that: (1) an industry in the United States is materially injured, or is threatened with material injury, by reason of imports of the merchandise subject to the investigation and that imports of the subject merchandise are not negligible; or (2) the establishment of such an industry is materially retarded, by reason of imports, or sales, for importation, of the merchandise subject to the investigation, and that imports of the subject merchandise are not negligible. Provides for five-year reviews of such determinations.

Health Care Liability Reform Act - Allows punitive damages to be awarded against a manufacturer or product seller in a civil action if the claimant establishes by clear and convincing evidence that the harm suffered was the result of conduct manifesting actual malice.Prohibits the manufacturer of a prescription drug or device and a health care provider from being subject to punitive damages with respect to harm caused by a drug or device if the drug or device was approved under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act unless: (1) the manufacturer withholds from the Food and Drug Administration or the health care provider withholds from a patient, information relevant to the performance of the drug or device and causally related to the harm suffered by the plaintiff; and (2) the amount of punitive damages that may be awarded for a claim in any civil action shall not exceed three times the amount awarded to the claimant for the economic injury on which such claim is based, or $250,000, whichever is greater.Allows several liability for noneconomic damages. Limits such liability to the amount of noneconomic damages allocated to such manufacturer or seller in direct to such manufacturer or seller's percentage of responsibility as determined by the trier of fact.

Unshackling Students to Lead, Develop, and Serve Act of 2012 or the U.S. LEADS Act - Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to allow certain recent college students to defer payments on their Federal Family Education Loan or William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan loans for up to five years when the national unemployment rate exceeds 7%.

Biobased Energy Incentive Act of 2002 - Amends the Biomass Research and Development Act of 2000 to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a biobased energy incentive program under which the Secretary shall make payments to eligible producers to promote the use of specified commodities to produce biobased energy products.

Mayflower Commemorative Coin Act This bill directs the Department of the Treasury to mint and issue $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins emblematic of the arrival of the Pilgrims at Plymouth, Massachusetts, in 1620

Nuclear Non-Proliferation Policy Act of 1993 - Declares that it shall be U.S policy to: (1) encourage Ukraine, Belarus, and Kazakhstan to join Belarus in ratifying the START I Treaty and to accede to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty as non-nuclear weapon states in the shortest possible time; (2) encourage Belarus, Ukraine, and Kazakhstan to remove all nuclear weapons from their territory, accept IAEA safeguards over all of their nuclear facilities, and implement effective controls on nuclear and nuclear-related dual-use exports; (3) reach an agreement with the Russian Federation to deactivate and retire from field deployment all weapons to be withdrawn under the START I treaty and the START II treaty, on data exchanges and inspection arrangements to verify the elimination of all nuclear weapons scheduled to be withdrawn, and on data exchanges and inspection arrangements to place all fissile material from such weapons under bilateral or international controls, or both; (4) prepare for the ratification of the START II treaty by seeking the exchange of information on nuclear weapons stockpiles and fissile material facilities and inventories as a condition to its approval of the START I Treaty; and (5) prepare for a multilateral comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty by early 1995 before the conference to renew and extend the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Stem Cell Research Enhancement Act of 2008 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to conduct and support research that utilizes human embryonic stem cells, regardless of the date on which the stem cells were derived from a human embryo. Limits such research to stem cells that meet the following ethical requirements: (1) the stem cells were derived from human embryos donated from in vitro fertilization clinics for the purpose of fertility treatment and were in excess of the needs of the individuals seeking such treatment; (2) the embryos would never be implanted in a woman and would otherwise be discarded; and (3) such individuals donated the embryos with written informed consent and without receiving any financial or other inducements. Requires the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to issue guidelines on research involving human embryonic stem cells and may issue guidelines on research involving other human stem cells, as determined to be scientifically warranted by the Director. Requires the Director to: (1) review and update such guidelines when they are scientifically warranted; and (2) determine the extent to which such an update applies to ongoing NIH-conducted or supported research. Expresses the sense of Congress that the Director: (1) in developing, updating, and implementing the guidelines, should consult with the Commissioner of Food and Drugs; (2) any research using

Energy Price and Economic Stability Act of 2001 - Instructs the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to issue an order establishing cost-of-service-based rates for electric energy sold at wholesale subject to its jurisdiction under the Federal Power Act for use in that portion of the United States covered by the Western Systems Coordinating Council of the North American Electric Reliability Council.States that such rates shall not apply to sales of electric energy generated by any new generation facility.Authorizes a State to bring an action in the appropriate United States district court to enforce compliance with such order.Subjects violators to civil penalties equal to three times the value of the amount involved in such violation.

Work Force Enhancement for Technology Transfer Act - Requires the Secretary of Commerce, through the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology, to direct Regional Centers for the Transfer of Manufacturing Technology and, when established, Manufacturing Outreach Centers, to utilize their expertise and capability to assist managers and other workers in U.S. manufacturing firms in effectively utilizing and operating advanced and modern technologies. Directs the Secretary to assist managers and other workers in U.S. manufacturing firms in effectively utilizing and operating such technologies by: (1) establishing and managing a clearinghouse for information, to be available through the National Technology Transfer Center to the Regional Centers for the Transfer of Manufacturing Technology, to other technology training entities, or directly to U.S. manufacturing firms, on the best available training material and services for the effective utilization and operation of specific advanced and modern technologies; (2) encouraging U.S. providers of advanced and modern technologies for manufacturing firms to develop training material specifically designed for the managers and other workers responsible for utilizing and operating such technologies; and (3) establishing as an important criterion in the assessment of such availability the availability of training material specifically designed for such managers and other workers.

Cape Town Treaty Implementation Act of 2004 - Requires the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to establish a system for filing notices of prospective assignments and prospective international interests in, and prospective sales of, civil aircraft and aircraft engines. Designates the FAA Civil Aviation Registry as the United States Entry Point to the International Registry for the registration of aircraft and engines under the Cape Town Treaty. Declares that a registration with the International Registry is valid only if the person seeking the registration first files documents eligible for recording with the United States Entry Point and the United States Entry Point authorizes the registration.<n><n>Directs the Administrator to issue regulations necessary to carry out this Act, including any amendments made by this Act. Requires such regulations to specify, at a minimum, the requirements for: (1) the registration of aircraft previously registered in a country in which the Cape Town Treaty is in effect; and (2) the cancellation of registration of a civil aircraft of the United States based on a request made in accordance with the Treaty. Declares that the final rule shall not be effective before the date the Treaty enters into force with respect to the United States.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 14, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Securing Protections for the Injured from Limitations on Liability Act - Amends federal bankruptcy law regarding death on the High Seas Act, the Jones Act, and the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 to prohibit the trustee in bankruptcy from selling or leasing significant property of the estate, other than in the ordinary course of business, unless: (1) creditors holding at least two-thirds in amount and more than one-half in number of all such claims not paid by the debtor consent to such sale or lease; or (2) the court finds, after notice and a hearing, that sufficient property will remain in the estate, or that the debtor's anticipated future income will be sufficient, and all such claims will be paid in full. Prohibits the bankruptcy court from dismissing or converting a claim for wrongful death, personal injury, or property damage arising from an incident in which the debtor is liable under any law for such a claim if the holder of a claim: (1) is the spouse of the decedent; (2) is a lawful resident of the United States; or (3) was a lawful resident of the United States at the time of the incident. Requires a claim

Unemployment Assistance Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income amounts distributed from tax-exempt retirement plans, health savings accounts, Roth individual retirement accounts (IRAs), and qualified tuition programs to pay living expenses, health care expenses, or education or job training expenses during periods of unemployment up to two years.

1863 Gettysburg Campaign Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury, in recognition and commemoration of the 1863 invasion of Pennsylvania, the decisive Battle of Gettysburg, and President Abraham Lincoln's Gettysburg Address, to mint and issue $5 gold and $1 silver coins emblematic of the history and memory of the Battle of Gettysburg and the President's Gettysburg Address.

New England Wilderness Act of 2006 - Designates as wilderness areas and components of the National Wilderness Preservation System certain lands in New Hampshire which shall be known as the Wild River Wilderness and the Range Wilderness. Withdraws all federal land in such wilderness areas from: (1) entry, appropriation, or disposal under the public land laws; (2) location, entry, and patent under the mining laws; and (3) disposition under the mineral leasing laws, including geothermal leasing laws.<n><n> Designates specified lands in Vermont which shall be known as the Green Mountain National Forest Land and Resource Management Plan as wilderness areas and components of the National Wilderness Preservation System. Withdraws all federal land in such wilderness areas from: (1) entry, appropriation, or disposal under the public land laws; (2) location, entry, and patent under the mining laws; and (3) disposition under the mineral leasing laws, including geothermal leasing laws.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose an excise tax on imported crude oil and refined petroleum products if the average international price of crude oil for any four-week period is less than $24. (The tax is imposed on first sale of such petroleum product.)

Andrew Carnegie Public Libraries Act - Amends the Library Services and Technology Act to authorize the Director of the Institute of Museum and Library Services to make grants for the construction or modernization of public libraries. Authorizes appropriations.

(Sec. 4) Directs the Administrator to publish a list of 20 Environmental High Impact Areas (EHIAs) that are either counties or other appropriate geographic units in which high levels of chemicals are present and in which the population is exposed to such chemicals. Directs the Administrator, in selecting a methodology and compiling or revising the list, to: (1) use the most recent data available; (2) take into account the relative toxicity of the toxic chemicals; (3) determine, with the best available data, the actual and potential exposures, and toxicity of the toxic chemicals present in each impacted area; (4) consider and utilize all appropriate data compiled pursuant to any environmental regulatory authority and other sources, including but not limited to available data on lead-based paint and the existence of pollutants from mobile sources; (5) distinguish between toxic chemicals which are in a contained, controlled environment and released into the air, water, soil or groundwater of the area; and (6) take into account the impact of pollution in high population density areas.Title II: Enforcement Initiatives - Directs the Administrator to issue regulations to assure that facilities with the highest potential for release of toxic chemicals into the air, water, or soil or groundwater are: (1) reviewed and inspected at least every two years by an official of the State or local government

Psychological Kevlar Act of 2006 - Directs the Secretary of Defense to develop and implement a plan to incorporate evidence-based preventive and early-intervention measures, practices, or procedures that reduce the likelihood that personnel in combat will develop post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) or other stress-relatedologies into: (1) basic and pre-deployment training for enlisted members of the Armed Forces, noncommissioned officers, and officers; (2) combat theater operations; and (3) post-deployment service. Requires the Secretary to update such plan periodically to incorporate the results of relevant research.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) develop and implement a training program to educate and promote understanding and awareness among commissioned officers and non-commissioned officers about the risks of combat stress as well as the signs and risks of stress-relatedologies; (2) develop and implement a training program to educate front-line medical professionals and primary care providers about the signs and risks of combat stressology as well as signs and risks of substance use conditions; and (3) provide members of the Armed Forces and their families with pre-deployment combat stress management training and increase outreach and access to members and their families about programs and treatment options.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) establish a working group to research and develop post-traumatic stress disorder

Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006 - Deauthorizes the Blunt Reservoir feature of the Oahe Irrigation Project authorized as part of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Program.<n><n>Allows preferential leaseholders of parcels of the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features an option to purchase the land they lease from the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Commissioner of Reclamation, or the Commission of Schools and Public Lands of South Dakota. Prescribes terms for such purchases, the option exercise period, and the basis for parcel valuation.

Amends the Agricultural Act of 1949 (Act) to revise provisions concerning wheat and feed grain grazing. <n>(Sec. 1) Permits haying and grazing of reduced acreage, acreage devoted to a conservation use, and acreage diverted from production under a land diversion program during any consecutive five-month period established by a State committee established under the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act. Provides that during such period the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) may not exclude irrigated or irrigable acreage not planted to alfalfa when exercising the authority of the Secretary under the Act. <n>(Sec. 2) States that for haying and grazing of reduced acreage, acreage devoted to a conservation use, and acreage diverted from production under a land diversion program during such period: (1) the State committee for a State shall establish the five-month period beginning April 1, and ending October 31, of a year, in consultation with wildlife agencies of the State; and (2) the State committee for a State shall establish such period for any producer who elects to pay a fee equal to the grazing fee established by the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) or a haying fee established by the BLM that is comparable to the grazing fee. <n>Prohibits the Secretary from excluding irrigated or irrigable acreage not planted

Emigrant Wilderness Historical Use Preservation Act - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to ensure that, within the Emigrant Wilderness of Stanislaus National Forest in California, all pack and saddle stock use, including commercial pack and saddle stock services, are recognized as appropriate wilderness activities, along with their associated effect on soil, water, and vegetation. Requires the Secretary to complete an updated wilderness plan to incorporate management direction for the preservation of pack and saddle stock use and all legally acceptable recreational uses within the Emigrant Wilderness. Directs the Secretary to: (1) continue to authorize commercial pack and saddle stock services within the Wilderness consistent with commercial use within that area that existed as of the original designation of the Emigrant Wilderness on January 3, 1975; (2) specify the level of use, allotted user days, and activities by commercial outfitters and guides within that area in the Wilderness Plan; and (3) continue to issue authorizations to provide commercial stock operations within that area at historic levels consistent with this Act.

Artists' Contribution to American Heritage Act of 1999- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that, in the case of a qualified artistic charitable contribution, the amount of such contribution shall be the fair market value of the property contributed, and no reduction in the amount of such contribution shall be made. Defines such a contribution.

Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 - Provides for Federal-State agreements under which a State will make emergency extended unemployment compensation payments to individuals who: (1) have exhausted all rights to regular compensation under the State law; (2) have no rights to compensation (including both regular compensation and extended compensation) with respect to a week under such law or any other State unemployment compensation law or to compensation under any other Federal law (and are not paid or entitled to be paid any additional compensation under any State or Federal law); (3) are not receiving compensation for such week under the unemployment compensation law of Canada; and (4) were separated from employment on or after September 11, 2001.Requires a State to establish an emergency extended unemployment compensation account for an applicant's benefit year.

Superfund Research, Development, and Demonstration Act of 1999 - Amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) to authorize appropriations for FY 2000 through 2004 for the hazardous substance research, testing, evaluation, development, and demonstration program. Prohibits more than ten percent of such amounts from being used for training. <n>(Sec. 3) Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), in carrying out hazardous substances research, testing, evaluation, development, and demonstration projects, to: (1) strive to enter into agreements with the Departments of Defense, Energy, and other Federal agencies to ensure the effective transfer to those agencies and their contractors of technologies potentially applicable to remediation or containment of hazardous substances at sites owned or operated by such agencies; and (2) ensure that the hazardous substance research centers established under this Act include responsibilities relating to the conduct of research and training and the provision of technical assistance and technology transfer to local, State, and regional entities. <n>Repeals the requirement that the Administrator enter into agreements with persons, public entities, and nonprofit private entities to arrange for the use of hazardous substances research, testing, evaluation, development, and demonstration projects. Declares that each project appropriate for carrying out hazardous substances research,

Cancels the sequestration of budgetary resources for FY2013 ordered on March 1, 2013. States that the budget sequester for an account in the security and non-security categories required by the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 (Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act) for FY2013 shall be implemented within each account as determined by the head of an agency with spending authority over such account. Prohibits an agency head from exercising such authority unless he or she has submitted a notice of implementation describing the proposed exercise of authority to the Appropriations Committees of both chambers not later than 15 days before exercising such authority and each such committee approves the implementation. Requires the committees, after receiving an executive branch proposal for administering the sequester, to accept or reject the proposal. Allows the Secretary of Defense, in implementing the discretionary spending reductions required by such Act, to take appropriate actions in the management of current multiyear contracts of the Department of Defense (DOD) to minimize the effects of such reductions in the carrying out of such contracts. Authorizes the use of appropriations or funds made available or authority granted pursuant to the Continuing Appropriations Resolution, 2013 for specified DOD programs, projects, and activities in the 112th Congress or the funding tables in division D of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year

Trucking Industry Regulatory Reform Act of 1994 - Amends Federal transportation law to declare that the purpose of this Act is to enhance competition, safety, and efficiency in the motor carrier industry and to enhance efficiency in government. <n>(Sec. 4) Declares that it is the policy of this Act to: (1) encourage fair competition, and reasonable rates for transportation by motor carriers of property; and (2) promote Federal regulatory efficiency in the motor carrier transportation system and require fair and expeditious regulatory decisions when regulation is required. <n>(Sec. 5) Includes a motor carrier providing transportation of property other than household goods within the exemption from certain rail carrier transportation requirements. <n>(Sec. 6) Eliminates the authority of a motor contract carrier of property to establish rates, classifications, rules, and practices. <n>(Sec. 7) Prohibits a motor common carrier providing transportation of property other than household goods from being required to publish or file actual or minimum rates. Declares that nothing in this Act shall affect the application of the Negotiated Rates Act of 1993 (or the amendments made by it) to undercharge claims for transportation provided prior to the date of enactment of this Act. <n>(Sec. 8) Directs the Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC)

African Free Trade Initiative Act - Amends the African Growth and Opportunity Act to revise requirements for the President's plan to negotiate and enter into free trade agreements with sub-Saharan African countries. Requires such plan to identify: (1) the 15 countries or groups of countries that are most ready for such an agreement; (2) the steps such sub-Saharan African country needs to be equipped and ready to enter into such an agreement, including the development of a bilateral investment treaty; (3) milestones for accomplishing each step for each sub-Saharan African country, with the goal of establishing a free trade agreement with each country within 10 years; (4) a description of the resources required to assist each country in accomplishing such milestones; and (5) the extent to which steps and resources may be accomplished through regional or subregional organizations in sub-Saharan Africa.<n><n>Directs the United States Trade Representative (USTR) and the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) to coordinate with the Chief Executive Officer of the Millennium Challenge Corporation regarding countries that have entered into a Millennium Challenge Compact to develop and carry out the plan required by this Act.

Diamond-Blackfan Anemia Research and Care Act - Requires the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH), in coordination with other specified agencies, to expand and intensify research and related NIH activities with regard to Diamond-Blackfan anemia.Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Director of NIH to make grants to, or enter into contracts with, public or private entities to support a comprehensive research initiative to study, develop better treatments for, and ultimately find a cure for Diamond-Blackfan anemia.Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, to: (1) maintain and expand the Diamond-Blackfan Anemia Registry; and (2) establish a comprehensive clinical care center for Diamond-Blackfan anemia where a majority of the patients are examined, treated, and tracked through the Registry.

Prohibits the interment in National Cemetery or Military Cemetery of a person convicted of a capital offense unless a good faith effort has been made to determine whether such person is otherwise ineligible for such interment under Federal law. Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to prescribe regulations to ensure that such a person is not interred in any cemetery in the National Cemetery System unless a good faith effort has been made to determine whether such person is otherwise ineligible for such interment under Federal law. <n>Prohibits the Secretary of Defense from ensuring that funeral honors are provided for a person convicted of committing a capital offense unless a good faith effort has been made to determine whether such person is otherwise ineligible for such interment or honors under Federal law. Directs the Secretary of the Army to: (1) remove the remains of Russell Wayne Wagner from Arlington National Cemetery; and (2) notify the next of kin of Russell Wayne Wagner of the removal of his remains.

Amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act to prohibit, with exceptions, the importation, transport, or exportation of municipal solid waste (MSW) for final disposal or incineration in violation of the Agreement Between the Government of the United States of America and the Government of Canada Concerning the Transboundary Movement of Hazardous Waste, or any regulations issued to implement and enforce such agreement.Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to perform the functions of the Designated Authority of the United States with respect to the importation and exportation of MSW under such agreement. Requires the Administrator, in considering whether to consent to such importation, to: (1) give substantial weight to the views of the State or States into which the MSW is to be imported and to the views of the local government with jurisdiction over the location where the waste is to be disposed; and (2) consider the impact of such importation on, and the impact on, State and local recycling programs, landfill capacity as provided comprehensive waste management plans, air emissions from increased vehicular traffic, road deterioration from increased vehicular traffic, and the public health and the environment.Authorizes the Administrator to issue compliance orders, assess civil penalties, and commence civil action in U.S. district court for violations of this Act.

Economic Fairness for Seniors Act - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require the monthly premium for 2010 to be the monthly actuarial rate for 2009. Declares that the monthly actuarial rate for 2009 shall be such monthly actuarial rate for 2009. Amends the American Recovery and Reinvestment Tax Act of 2009 to extend: (1) through 2010 the economic recovery payments to Medicare beneficiaries; and (2) through 2010 the special credit for certain government retirees. Directs the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor to study and report to Congress on whether a consumer price index for elderly consumers (CPI-E) more accurately reflects the true costs of inflation for elderly Americans than the CPI-W in the determination of current benefit levels.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Assessment of Programs and Policies for Combatting the Proliferation <n> of Weapons of Mass Destruction <n> Title II: Report on Agency Role in Proliferation <n> of Weapons of Mass Destruction <n>Combatting Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction Act of 1996 - <n>Title I: Assessment of Programs and Policies for Combatting the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction <n> - Establishes the Commission on Programs and Policies for Combatting the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction. Requires the Commission to: (1) study and report to the Congress on the organization, policies, and programs of the Federal Government related to combatting the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (chemical, biological, and nuclear weapons); and (2) develop recommendations on means of improving the effectiveness of the organization, policies, programs of the intelligence community, and the programs and policies of other Federal agencies in meeting U.S. national security interests with respect to the proliferation of such weapons. <n>Authorizes appropriations. <n>Title II: Report on Agency Role in Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on June 24, 2015. Clarence Full Access to Justice Act or the Gage Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the federal judicial code to establish a Defender Office for Supreme Court Advocacy, as a private nonmembership nonprofit corporation, to: (1) advocate on behalf of individuals in noncapital cases involving federal criminal statutory or constitutional law and when resources permit, the highest court of a state; and (2) provide assistance to attorneys advocating on behalf of individuals in such cases. The office must maintain its principal office in the District of Columbia. The office must have a Board of Directors consisting of 18 voting members, including 6 of whom shall be Federal Public Defenders or Executive Directors of Community Defender Organizations, elected by the Federal Public Defenders and the Executive Directors of Community Defender Organizations in each district. The board must appoint a Director for the office. The office must: (1) grant grants for writs of certiorari in the Supreme Court of the United States in cases involving federal criminal statutory or constitutional law, and (2) conduct other specified activities.

Kids First Research Act of 2013 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to terminate: (1) the designation of income tax payments to the Presidential Election Campaign Fund, and (2) the Presidential Primary Matching Payment Account. Amends the Public Health Service Act to rename the Presidential Primary Matching Payment Account the 10 Year Pediatric Research Initiative Fund. Requires amounts in the Fund to be made available only for the purpose of: (1) identifying areas of emerging scientific opportunities, rising public health challenges, or knowledge gaps that deserve special emphasis and would benefit from conducting or supporting additional research that involves collaboration between two or more national research institutes or national centers, or would otherwise benefit from strategic coordination and planning; and (2) allocating such funds to the national research institutes and national centers for making grants for pediatric research.

(Sec. 2) Includes among permitted additional grant projects: (1) establishing school-based partnerships between local law enforcement agencies and local school systems, by using school resource officers who operate in and around elementary and secondary schools to serve as a law enforcement liaison with other Federal, State, and local law enforcement and regulatory agencies, combat school-related crime and disorder problems, gang membership and criminal activity, firearms and explosives-related incidents, illegal use and possession of alcohol, and the illegal possession, use, and distribution of drugs; and (2) developing and implementing innovative programs that bring together a community's sheriff, chief of police, and elderly residents to address the public safety concerns of older citizens. Authorizes the Attorney General to use up to five percent of appropriated funds for technical assistance and training to States, local governments, Indian tribal governments, and other public and private entities for those respective purposes. Authorizes the Attorney General to use up to five percent of appropriated funds for grants to States, local governments, Indian tribal governments, and other public and private entities for technical assistance and training to States, local governments, Indian tribal governments, and other public and private entities for those respective purposes. Authorizes the Attorney General to use up to five percent of appropriated funds for grants to States to assist

Amends title XII (School Facilities Improvement) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to make loans to local educational agencies (LEAs) for the construction, reconstruction, or renovation of schools in need of improvement: (1) of schools which are 50 years of age or older; or (2) of schools which are 50 years of age or older, but who are located on Indian reservations. <n>Requires the Secretary to consider: (1) the difficulty of the applicant in securing affordable financing from other sources; (2) the threat the condition of the physical plant poses to the safety and well-being of students; (3) the demonstrated need for the construction, reconstruction, or renovation as based on the condition of the facility; and (4) the age of the facility to be renovated or replaced. <n>Requires a loan to be in an amount not exceeding the total development cost of the facility, to be secured in such manner as may be determined by the Secretary, to be repaid within 30 years, and to bear interest at a rate that will cover the cost and the administrative cost to the Federal Government of the loan. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to guarantee and make commitments to guarantee eligible debt instruments issued by such LEAs for such school construction, reconstruction, or renovation

Citizenship Promotion Act of 1996 - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to establish within the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) the United States Citizenship Promotion Agency to: (1) carry out naturalization functions; and (2) assist in the implementation of a comprehensive program of encouraging and assisting eligible immigrants to become naturalized citizens as soon thereafter as they become eligible. Establishes the National Advisory Board on Citizenship to advise the Associate Commissioner for Citizenship, the Attorney General, the President, and the Congress regarding Agency objectives.

Columbian Temporary Protected Status Act of 2002 - Expresses the sense of Congress that Columbian nationals in the United States should be eligible for temporary protected status.Designates Columbia under the Immigration and Nationality Act as a country undergoing an ongoing armed conflict in order to make qualifying Columbians living in the United States eligible aliens for temporary protected status.

Authorizes the Chief of the National Guard Bureau to establish and operate not more than five schools for the provision by the National Guard of training in drug interdiction and counter-drug activities, and drug demand reduction activities, to the personnel of Federal agencies, State and local law enforcement agencies, community-based organizations, and other non-Federal governmental and private entities and organizations engaged in such activities. Allows National Guard personnel ordered to perform full-time National Guard duty in a State to provide training at such a school.Directs the Secretary of Defense to report annually to Congress on the activities of the schools.Authorizes appropriations for FY 2002 for the Department of Defense for the National Guard counterdrug schools.

Taxpayers Right to Know Act - Requires the head of each federal agency, by February 1 of each fiscal year, to publish on the agency website a report that: (1) identifies and describes every program administered by such agency; (2) determines the total administrative expenses and expenditures for services for each program; (3) estimates the number of clients served by each program and the beneficiaries who received assistance under each program; (4) estimates the number of full-time federal and contract employees who administer each program; and (5) identifies federal programs with duplicative or overlapping missions, services, and allowable uses of funds. Defines "program" as any organized set of activities directed toward a common purpose or goal undertaken by an agency that includes services, projects, processes, or financial or other forms of assistance, including grants, contracts, cooperative agreements, financial support (including grants and loans).

Amends the Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Technical Education Act of 1998 with respect to grants to tribally controlled postsecondary vocational and technical institutions that are not receiving federal support under the Tribally Controlled College or University Assistance Act of 1978 or the Navajo Community College Act to provide basic support for the education and training of Indian students.<n><n>Revises the definition of Indian student count" (essential to the formula for the determination of grant amounts).<n><n> Requires the Indian student count to be determined according to a specified formula, for each academic year, on the basis of the enrollments of Indian students as in effect at the conclusion of the third week of the fall term and the third week of the spring term. Allows the counting of students without secondary school degrees under certain circumstances."

College Construction Loan Insurance Association Privatization Act of 1995 - Provides that the College Construction Loan Insurance Association shall be a private, for-profit corporation and shall not be subject to Federal law.

Directs the Secretary of Commerce and the Oakdale Irrigation District and the South San Joaquin Irrigation District to jointly develop and conduct a nonnative predator fish removal pilot program to remove nonnative striped bass, smallmouth bass, largemouth bass, black bass, and other nonnative predator fish from the Stanislaus River, California. Requires the program to: (1) be scientifically based; (2) include methods to quantify the number and size of predator fish removed each year, the impact of such removal on the overall abundance of predator fish, and the impact of such removal on the populations of certain juvenile anadromous fish found in the Stanislaus River; and (3) be implemented for seven consecutive years.

Shirley A. Chisholm United States-Caribbean Educational Exchange Act of 2009 - Authorizes the Secretary of State to establish the Shirley A. Chisholm United States-Caribbean Educational Exchange Program under which: (1) secondary school students from Caribbean Community (CARICOM) countries will attend a public or private secondary school in the United States and participate in activities designed to promote a greater understanding of the values and culture of the United States; and (2) undergraduate students, graduate students, post-graduate students, and scholars from CARICOM countries will attend a public or private college or university, including a community college, in the United States and participate in activities designed to promote a greater understanding of the values and culture of the United States.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 16, 2015. Veterans TRICARE Choice Act (Sec. 2) This bill allows, as specified, an individual who is eligible to be a covered beneficiary entitled to health care benefits under the TRICARE program (a Department of Defense [DOD] managed health care program) and who is not serving on active duty in the uniformed services to: (1) elect to be ineligible to enroll in TRICARE, (2) make tax deductible contributions to a health savings account during the period such individual elects to be ineligible for TRICARE coverage, and (3) enroll in the TRICARE program at a later date during a special enrollment period. DOD shall submit to the Internal Revenue Service information on each TRICARE-eligible individual who makes such election for purposes of determining such individual's eligibility for a health savings account. DOD shall ensure that a TRICARE-eligible individual who makes such election is maintained on the Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System, or successor system, regardless of whether the individual is eligible for the TRICARE program during the period of such election.

SCHIP Enhancement Act of 2001 - Amends title XXI (State Children's Health Insurance Program) (SCHIP) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to give States the option to expand SCHIP eligibility to children whose family income does not exceed 300 percent of the Federal poverty line.Amends SSA title XIX to provide additional allotments to States that increase SCHIP income eligibility to a level of 250 percent of the poverty line.

American Worker Mobility Act of 2014 - Authorizes the Secretary of Labor to grant a relocation subsidy to an eligible individual who: (1) is totally unemployed and has been totally unemployed for at least 26 consecutive weeks; (2) has exhausted all rights to regular compensation under state or federal law with respect to a benefit year ending before July 1, 2008; (3) has not received such a subsidy in the 2-year period preceding the date of application; and (4) is able to work, available to work, and actively seeking work. Defines "eligible individual" as an individual who: (1) is totally unemployed and has been totally unemployed for at least 26 consecutive weeks; (2) has exhausted all rights to regular compensation under state or federal law with respect to a benefit year ending before July 1, 2008; (3) has not received such a subsidy in the 2-year period preceding the date of application; and (4) is able to work, available to work, and actively seeking work. Sets the amount of such subsidy at the lesser of $10,000 or the amount that any contribution by a potential employer of the individual to the individual's relocation expenses is exceeded by the sum of 90% of the reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in transporting the worker, the worker's family, and household effects, plus a lump sum equivalent to 3

Supporting Afterschool STEM Act This bill requires the National Science Foundation to award grants to afterschool or STEM network providers for the development and operation of afterschool and STEM (science, technology, engineering, or mathematics) programs for elementary, middle, or secondary school students when school is not in session, such as before or after school, on the weekend, or during the summer. A "afterschool or STEM network" is a coalition that fosters partnerships and provides support to afterschool program providers and STEM education providers to develop and sustain quality education programming for children and youth in afterschool programs.

Internet Freedom and Broadband Deployment Act of 1999- Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to provide that neither the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) nor any State shall have authority to regulate the rates, charges, terms, or conditions for, or entry into the provision of any high speed data service or Internet access service. Describes such service as one that consists of or includes the offering of a capability to transmit, using a packet-switched or successor technology, information at a rate that is generally not less than 384 kilobits per second in at least one direction. (Sec. 4) Prohibits the FCC or any State from regulating the transmission of Internet content and services, but does include the portion of such transmission from the user to the service provider. (Sec. 5) Declares that, except to the extent that such high speed data service and Internet access service are expressly referred to in this Act, neither the FCC, nor any State, shall have authority to regulate the rates, charges, terms, or conditions for, or entry into the provision of, any such service.

Universal Access to Affordable Insurance for all Americans Act of 2004 - Directs the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to administer a health insurance program for non-Federal employees and to prescribe regulations to apply to such program the provisions governing the Federal employee health benefits program to the greatest extent practicable.<n><n>Requires OPM, in each calendar year, to enter into a contract with one or more carriers to make health benefits plans available to eligible individuals. Allows any individual to enroll in such a plan unless the individual: (1) is 65 years of age or older; (2) is enrolled or eligible to enroll for coverage under a public health insurance program (including Medicaid or Medicare) or coverage under a State plan under title XIX of such Act; (3) is enrolled or eligible to enroll in such a plan; or (4) is a member of the uniformed services.<n><n>Allows rates and premiums for such a plan to differ among geographic regions. Makes such premiums tax deductible.<n><n>Provides that in the case of an individual, there shall be allowed as a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year an amount equal to the applicable percentage of the amount paid during such taxable year by the taxpayer for coverage of the taxpayer and family members under a health insurance plan established under this Act.

Native American Commercial Driving Training and Technical Assistance Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Labor to make competitive grants to support programs providing training and certificates leading to the licensing of Native Americans with respect to commercial vehicle driving. Authorizes appropriations.Requires grant priority to be given to entities that: (1) propose training that exceeds proposed minimum standards for training tractor-trailer drivers of the Department of Transportation; (2) propose training that exceeds the entry level truck driver certification standards set by the Professional Truck Driver Institute; and (3) propose an education partnership with a private trucking firm, trucking association, or similar entity.

In-Home Caregiver Assessment Resources and Education Act or the In-Home CARE Act This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Administration for Community Living to award competitive grants to eligible organizations to carry out home visiting programs for unpaid caregivers. An eligible organization is a local government agency, a health care entity, or any other nonprofit or community organization that has experience providing in-home monitoring, management, supervision, or treatment of a child or adult with a special need.

Liquefied Natural Gas Safety and Security Act of 2005 - Amends the Natural Gas Act to direct the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), before issuing an order authorizing an applicant to site, construct, expand, or operate a liquefied natural gas import facility, to require such applicant, in cooperation with the Commandant of the Coast Guard and state and local agencies that provide for the safety and security of the facility and any vessels that serve it, to develop a cost-sharing plan.

Prescription Drug Labeling Promotion Act of 2012 - Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish a working group to develop and promulgate guidance constituting best practices on access to prescription drug labeling for the visually impaired. Requires such guidance to be made available through publication in the Federal Register and posting on the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) website.

Religious Liberty and Charitable Donation Protection Act of 1997 - Amends Federal bankruptcy law to provide that a charitable contribution to a qualified religious or charitable entity or organization shall not be considered a transfer covered by bankruptcy provisions in any case in which: (1) the amount of that contribution does not exceed 15 percent of the gross annual income of the debtor for the year in which the transfer is made; or (2) the contribution made by a debtor exceeded the percentage amount of gross annual income specified in the preceding paragraph if the transfer was consistent with the debtor's practices in making charitable contributions. <n>Makes conforming amendments to the Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1994 and other Federal law.

Clean Air and Water Preservation Act of 2001 - Amends the Clean Air Act to prohibit the use of methyl tertiary butyl ether (MTBE) as a fuel additive. Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to amend regulations concerning MTBE to conform to this Act.Directs the Administrator to require: (1) persons selling gasoline that contains MTBE at retail to prominently label the fuel dispensing system with a notice that the gasoline contains MTBE; and (2) the States to assess MTBE in water sources.

Biennial Commission on Energy Policy Act of 2013 - Amends the Department of Energy Organization Act to establish the Biennial Commission on Energy Policy. Requires the Commission to be composed of 15 members from a diverse group of industries and political party affiliations with no federal, state, or local officers or employees. Directs the Commission to: (1) conduct a quarterly meeting of stakeholders to assist the Commission in carrying out its duties, and (2) submit a final report to Congress on its findings and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions to create an integrated and comprehensive national energy policy for the United States.

Home-Based Health Services Training and Employment Act of 2012 - Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to require the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to establish a pilot grant program to make grants to eligible entities for the training of public housing residents as home health aides and providers of home-based health services (including as personal and home care aides) to enable such residents to provide covered home-based health services to elderly and disabled public housing residents and elderly and disabled residents of federally-assisted rental housing.

Federal Credit Cost Reduction Act of 1994 - Amends the Federal Credit Reform Act of 1990 to provide for the treatment of administrative costs regarding direct and loan guarantees in the President's annual budget submission. <n>Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to prescribe maximum Federal credit subsidy rates for covered programs.

Prohibits treating any part of a physicians comparability allowance as basic pay for purposes of computing annuities under the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees Retirement System.

Amends the Trade Act of 1974 with respect to requirements for the United States Trade Representative (USTR) to determine whether a trade agreement is involved with respect to products subject to intellectual property protection and, if so, to determine whether rights under the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) or the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) 1994 are involved.<n><n>Amends the Andean Trade Preference Act (ATPA) and the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act (CBERA) to direct the USTR to ensure a timely review and disposition of requests received from an interested party that the President reconsider the status of a country as a beneficiary country under ATPA or CBI.<n><n>Requires the USTR to determine the extent to which a country provides adequate and effective protection of intellectual property rights notwithstanding the fact that the foreign country may be in compliance with the specific obligations of TRIPS or GATT 1994.<n><n>Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to require the USTR, in determining whether a country is in compliance with TRIPS or GATT 1994, to take into account: (1) the extent to which the country provides adequate and effective protection of intellectual property rights; and (2) the extent to which such country may be in compliance with the specific

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose an excise tax on: (1) acts of self-dealing between a disqualified person and an applicable tax-exempt organization; and (2) acts of private inurement between a disqualified person and an applicable tax-exempt organization.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on February 21, 2014. Syrian War Crimes Accountability Act of 2014 - (Sec. 3) Declares that Congress: condemns the ongoing violence using chemical weapons, targeting of civilian populations, and systematic gross human rights violations carried out by government of Syria and pro-government forces under the direction of President Bashar al-Assad, as well as abuses committed by violent extremist groups and other combatants involved in the civil war in Syria; supports the people of Syria seeking democratic change; urges all parties to the conflict to halt attacks on civilians; calls on the President to support efforts in Syria and on the part of the international community to ensure accountability for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed during the conflict; and calls for a United Nations Security Council investigation into gross violations of human rights and war crimes committed during the Syrian conflict. (Sec. 4) Directs the Secretary of State, within 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act and again within 180 days after the cessation of violence in Syria, to submit a report on war crimes and crimes against humanity in Syria, including: an account of the war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by the regime of President Bashar al-Assad, an account of the war crimes and

. DXM Abuse Prevention Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to prohibit the sale of a drug containing dextromethorphan (DXM, a cough suppressant and drug of abuse) to an individual under age 18 unless the individual has a prescription or is actively enrolled in the military. Retailers selling DXM must implement a verification system to ensure compliance. Civil monetary penalties that escalate upon repeated violation are imposed.

Railroad Infrastructure Financing Improvement Act - Amends the Railroad Revitalization and Regulatory Reform Act of 1976 to revise the requirements for railroad infrastructure financing. Authorizes the Secretary of Transportation to provide direct loans or loan guarantees for up to 80% of the cost of construction of a rail connection between a plant or facility and a rail carrier, limited option freight shippers that own or operate a plant or other facility, and any obligor, as designated by the Secretary, including a special purpose entity receiving user fees or other payments or revenues from dedicated sources for debt service and maintenance of the equipment or facilities to be acquired or improved. Directs the Secretary to revise certain application processing procedures.

Veterans Life Insurance Opportunity Act of 1998 - Makes certain veterans whose Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance (SGLI) was continued in force after termination of duty or discharge from service and whose coverage under SGLI terminated less than four years before the enactment of this Act eligible within one year from the effective date of the Veterans' Group Life Insurance (VGLI) program to apply for and be granted VGLI in an amount equal to the amount of the insured's SGLI which was not converted to an individual policy under prior law. Provides that VGLI shall be issued for a term of five years, less the time elapsing between the termination of the applicant's SGLI and the effective date of the VGLI program. <n>Allows any person who did not convert SGLI coverage to VGLI coverage within the period after separation, subject to specified conditions, to apply for and be granted VGLI coverage within the 20-month period beginning on the last day of such period of separation. Permits VGLI coverage to be granted for the same period under other Federal life insurance provisions. <n>Requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to provide notice to any member of the uniformed services who purchased a SGLI policy and who did not convert the policy to VGLI of the opportunities provided

Senior Executive Service Diversity Assurance Act of 2009 - Requires the Director of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to establish within OPM the Senior Executive Service Resource Office to: (1) improve the efficiency, effectiveness, and productivity of the Senior Executive Service (SES) through policy formulation and oversight; (2) advance the professionalism of the SES; and (3) ensure that, in seeking to achieve an SES reflective of the nation's diversity, recruitment is from qualified individuals from appropriate sources. Sets forth the functions of the Office.
Mortgage Insurance Fairness Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow the deduction of premiums for mortgage insurance. Provides for the phaseout of such deduction based on income.

Fitness Integrated with Teaching Kids Act or FIT Kids Act - Requires local educational agencies receiving funds under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to post on their websites and make available to parents and families information on healthful eating habits, physical education, and physical activity, including: (1) the importance of a healthy lifestyle; (2) how schools are promoting healthy lifestyles; (3) whether schools follow age-appropriate physical education curricula; (4) the most recent national recommendations for physical education and physical activity for elementary and secondary school students; and (5) the amount of time students are required to spend in physical education. Requires such agencies to assist schools in collecting and disseminating such information to parents and families of students enrolled in the school.

Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 1999- Amends the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 to authorize appropriations for grants to States to increase child care payment rates. <n>Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make such grants to States that: (1) have conducted a survey of the market rates for child care services in the State within the two years preceding the submission of an application; and (2) submit applications to the Secretary in accordance with specified requirements. Sets forth a formula for determining grant allotments. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Child Care Access and Refundability Expansion Act or the Child CARE Act Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the tax credit for expenses for household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment, to: (1) make such credit refundable; (2) increase the dollar limitation on such credit to $2,000, and (3) allow such credit for 50% of qualifying expenses up to $200,000 in a taxable year.

Air Cargo Security Act - Directs the Under Secretary of Transportation for Security (Under Secretary) to establish systems to screen, inspect, or otherwise ensure the security of all cargo that is to be transported in passenger aircraft operated by an air carrier or foreign air carrier in air transportation or intrastate air transportation. Directs the Under Secretary to develop a strategic plan to carry out such requirements.Directs the Under Secretary to: (1) establish a system for the regular inspection of shipping facilities for shipments of cargo transported in air transportation; (2) enter into arrangements with the civil aviation authorities of foreign countries to ensure that inspections are conducted on a regular basis at shipping facilities for cargo transported in air transportation; and (3) establish an industry-wide pilot program database of known shippers of cargo that is to be transported in passenger aircraft operated by an air carrier or foreign air carrier in air transportation.Directs the Under Secretary to: (1) conduct random audits, investigations, and inspections of indirect air carrier facilities to determine if such air carriers are meeting air cargo security requirements; (2) ensure compliance with such requirements; (3) notify the Secretary of Transportation of any indirect air carrier that fails to meet such requirements; and (4) assess the security aspects of the indirect air carrier program.

Simple Universal Healthcare Act of 2009 - Requires the Director of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to establish the Citizen's Congressional Health Benefits Program to provide comprehensive health insurance coverage to: (1) federal elected officials and their dependents; and (2) U.S. residents who are not covered under the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHBP). Requires such coverage to be provided in a manner similar to the manner in which coverage has been provided under FEHBP.<n><n>Requires the Director to enter into contracts with entities for the offering of qualified CCHBP health plans. Requires such contracts to be entered into in a manner similar to the process by which the Director is authorized to enter into contracts with entities offering health benefits plans under FEHBP.<n><n>Allows the Director to enter into a contract with an entity that is: (1) licensed as a health maintenance organization in the state in which the entity will offer the qualified CCHBP health plan; (2) meeting such requirements similar to those under FEHBP as the Director may establish relating to solvency, adequacy of plan benefits, organization, structure, governance, access, and quality; and (3) agreeing to participate in the high-risk reinsurance fund described in this Act.<n><n>Treats any health plan offered under FEHBP as

. People With Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014 - Requires each state to operate by January 1, 2015, a qualified state reinsurance program or a qualifying state high risk pool to provide health insurance coverage for individuals with pre-existing conditions. Defines "qualified state reinsurance program" as a program operated by a state program that provides reinsurance for health insurance coverage offered in the small group market that protects health insurance issuers against the annual aggregate spending of their enrollees as well as purchase protection against individual catastrophic costs. Defines "qualifying state high risk pool" as a current section 2745 qualified high risk pool that: (1) meets certain requirements, including providing coverage for preventive services and disease management for chronic diseases; and (2) does not eliminate any waiting lists so that all eligible residents who are seeking coverage should be allowed to receive coverage through the pool.

Medicare Part D Improvement Act of 2007 - Amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to count costs incurred in official enrollment or non-enrollment periods, as well as out-of-pocket costs, for purposes of determining eligibility for Medicare part D.

Restore Opportunity, Strengthen, and Improve the Economy Act - Declares that in the award of a contract for the acquisition of supplies or services, an executive agency may not award the contract to a source that is not a Good Jobs Model Employer, unless there is no offer from a source that is a Good Jobs Model Employer. Prohibits an executive agency from providing other forms of financial or nonfinancial assistance to entities that are not model employers when there is a similarly situated Good Jobs Model Employer that could receive the assistance, unless doing so would substantially undermine the value of the assistance to the public good. Requires executive agencies to incorporate into each new contract, contract-like instrument, or assistance agreement a clause requiring the contractor or recipient to conduct itself as a Good Jobs Model Employer for the duration of the contract.

Improved Consumer Access to Travel Information Act - Establishes the National Commission to Ensure Consumer Information and Choice in the Airline Industry to study and report to the President and Congress on: (1) consumer access to information about the products and services of the airline industry; (2) the effect on the marketplace of the emergence of new means of distributing such products and services; (3) the effect on consumers of the declining financial condition of travel agents in the United States; and (4) the impediments imposed by the airline industry on distributors of the industry's products and services, including travel agents and Internet-based distributors.Directs the Commission to recommend to the President and Congress policies necessary to: (1) ensure full consumer access to complete information concerning airline fares, routes, and other services; (2) ensure that the means of distributing the products and services of the airline industry, and of disseminating information about such products and services, is adequate to ensure that competitive information is available in the marketplace; (3) ensure that distributors of the products and services of the airline industry have adequate relief from illegal, anticompetitive practices that occur in the marketplace; and (4) foster healthy competition in the airline industry and the entry of new entrants.

IFQ Act of 2001 - Amends the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act to provide that a fishery management plan which establishes an individual quota system for a fishery after September 30, 2002, shall provide for administration of the system by the Secretary of Commerce. Mandates that such a plan include provisions that: (1) establish procedures and requirements for each Regional Fishery Management Council having authority over the fishery; (2) include provisions to promote sustainable management of the fishery, provide for fair and equitable allocation of quotas, minimize negative social and economic impacts of the system on local coastal communities, ensure adequate enforcement of the system, and take into account present participation and historical fishing practices; and (3) prevent any person or entity from acquiring an excessive share of individual quotas issued for a fishery.Authorizes a plan to permit the allocation of individual quotas among categories of vessels, and to provide a portion of the annual harvest in the fishery for entry-level fishermen, small vessel owners, or crewmembers who do not hold or qualify for individual quotas.

International Rule of Law and Antiterrorism Act of 2003 - Directs the President to direct: (1) the United States Permanent Representative to the United Nations to use U.S. influence to establish negotiations with the United Nations and United Nations member states to establish a professional United Nations civilian police corps (UNCPC); (2) the Secretary of State to request that the United Nations Secretariat prepare a report concerning such establishment; and (3) the Secretary of State to work with the UN Secretariat and other United Nations member states to establish standards and training programs for international civilian police. Expresses the sense of Congress that a UNCPC should be composed of the appropriate number of law enforcement professionals recruited and employed by the United Nations who are appropriately trained and equipped for civilian policing functions in international peace operations and available for rapid deployment to such operations as needed.

Rim of the Valley Corridor Study Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to study and report to specified congressional committees on the suitability and feasibility of establishing the Rim of the Valley Corridor in Southern California as a unit of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area.Establishes the Rim of the Valley Corridor and Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area Advisory Committee to advise the Secretary on the conduct of the study, and on the boundaries for, the Area.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) United States Grain Standards Act Reauthorization Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the United States Grain Standards Act to revise the requirements for official grain inspection and weighing at export elevators. If the Department of Agriculture (USDA) waives the requirement for official inspection due to an emergency, it shall: (1) immediately take such actions as are necessary to address the disruption and resume inspections or weighings, (2) submit a report to Congress describing the disruption and any actions necessary to address USDA concerns relating to the disruption so that inspections or weighings may resume, and (3) provide daily updates until official inspection or weighing services at the site of disruption have resumed. If USDA certifies that a state agency with a delegation of authority is meeting specified criteria, it shall establish a process for certification. The bill requires USDA, every five years, to certify that each state agency with a delegation of authority is meeting the criteria described under the Act. In the case of a state agency that intends to temporarily discontinue official inspection or weighing services for any reason, except in the case of a major disaster, it shall notify USDA in writing of the intention at least 72 hours in advance of the discontinuation date. USDA shall consider receipt of such notice

Authorizes additional appropriations for the U.S. Customs Service and the Immigration and Naturalization Service to enhance investigative resources on the Southwest border, enhance investigative resources for anticorruption efforts, intensify efforts against drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations, process cargo, reduce commercial and passenger traffic waiting times, and open all primary lanes during peak hours at certain ports on such border. Earmarks amounts for salaries, expenses, and equipment for such services.

Protecting Seniors' Medicare Choices from Obamacare Act of 2014 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act (SSA) with respect to the enhanced Federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP) under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) to exclude prisoners or individuals over whom a public institution maintains jurisdiction. Amends SSA title XVIII (Medicare) to establish a Medicare Advantage (MA) stabilization program under which the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) shall provide a PMPM stabilization funding amount to each eligible Medicare Advantage plan for plan year 2015 to address the beneficiary inadequacies described above.

Hygiene Assistance for Families of Infants and Toddlers Act of 2017 This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Administration for Children and Families within the Department of Health and Human Services to award grants to eligible entities to conduct demonstration projects that help families with eligible children to address the diapering needs of those children. Specifically, grants shall be used to: reduce the substantial cost of diapers and diapering supplies by making diapers and diapering supplies available available to low-income families; evaluate the effects of the projects on mitigating the health risks of diapering, urinary tract infections, and increased rates of parental and child anxiety and depression that can arise when low-income families do not have an adequate supply of diapers for infants and toddlers; and integrate the projects with other assistance programs serving families with eligible children.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on October 5, 2016. Block Access to North Korea Act of 2016 or theBANK Act of 2016 (Sec. 3) This bill expresses the sense of Congress that: providers of specialized financial messaging services are a critical link to the international financial system; directly providing specialized financial messaging services to, or enabling or facilitating access to such messaging services for, any financial institution is inconsistent with specified United Nations Security Council Resolution 2094; and the United States reaffirms its commitment to its allies in the region, including the Republic of Korea and Japan, which are directly threatened by North Korea. (Sec. 4) The President shall impose sanctions pursuant to the International Emergency Economic Powers Act with respect to a person who continues to knowingly and directly provide specialized financial messaging services to, or enable or facilitate access to, such messaging services for: the Central Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea; a financial institution that facilitates any transaction or transactions or provides significant financial services for nuclear development or proliferation for or on behalf of North Korea; or a person identified on the list of specially designated nationals and blocked persons maintained by the Office of Foreign Assets Control of the Department of the Treasury by reason of assisting the nuclear development or proliferation efforts of North

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Education Department Civil Rights Transparency Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Department of Education Organization Act to require the Department of Education's (ED) annual report on its Office for Civil Rights to include a list of educational institutions against which it has received, in the preceding year: each complaint alleging that the institution has violated a federal civil rights law; each educational institution against which ED has received, in the preceding year, more than one such complaint; each educational institution against which ED has received, in the preceding year, more than three such complaints; each educational institution that, during the preceding year, was under investigation by ED for such a complaint; each educational institution against which ED has received, in the preceding year, such a complaint for which ED has not commenced an investigation and which ED has dismissed without commencing an investigation; and each educational institution against which ED has received, in the preceding year, such a complaint for which ED has dismissed without commencing an investigation. The report shall include: the procedural or administrative reason for which a complaint was dismissed; any resolution agreement or letter between ED and an educational institution against which a complaint has been filed which settled ED's investigation of such complaint; any

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on December 7, 2016. Title I: Continuing Appropriations for Fiscal Year 2017 This bill provides FY2017 appropriations for continuing projects and activities for specified federal agencies that were conducted in FY2016 and for which appropriations, funds, or other authority were made available in specified appropriations Acts. The bill adjusts the rates for: security and nonsecurity operations in the revised security category; and expenditures in the revised nonsecurity category. No appropriations or funds made available or authority granted for the Department of Defense shall be used for: the new production of items not funded for production in FY2016 or prior years; the increase in production rates above those sustained with FY2016 funds; or the initiation, resumption, or continuation of any project, activity, budget activity, program element, and subprogram within a budget activity within an appropriation account and an R-1 line item that includes a program element and subprogram element within an appropriation account. Appropriations made and authority granted pursuant to this bill shall cover all obligations or expenditures incurred for any project or activity during the period for which funds or authority were not available during FY2016. Unless otherwise provided for in this bill or in the applicable appropriations Act for FY2017, appropriations and funds made available and authority granted pursuant

Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001 - Directs the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, the Secretary of the Treasury, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, and the Director of Central Intelligence to develop and implement a unified electronic data system to provide current and immediate access to information in databases of U.S. law enforcement agencies and the intelligence community that is relevant to determine whether to issue a visa or to determine the admissibility of an alien to the United States.Requires such system to: (1) be searchable based on linguistically sensitive algorithms that account for variations in name formats and accessibility of name elements, including varied spellings and varied separation or combination of name elements, within a particular language; (2) be implemented for at least four languages designated as high priorities by the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, and the Director of Central Intelligence; and (3) provide authoritative, easily accessed information about the nature, structure, and likely gender of names in different languages and a means for communication of questions to experts. Requires the Director of Central Intelligence to issue guidelines.Directs the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, the Secretary of the Treasury, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, and the Director of Central Intelligence to: (1) establish procedures to restrict access to intelligence information
