Reigniting Opportunity for Innovators Act This bill amends part D (Child Support and Establishment of Paternity) of title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to allow a qualifying small business startup borrower to defer periodic installments of principal need not be paid and interest during any period while the borrower is employed as a founder or full-time employee of a small business startup. A qualifying small business startup borrower shall not receive such deferment for any period: (1) in excess of three years, or (2) beginning more than five years, or ending more than eight years, after the small business startup was established. The Department of Education (ED) shall cancel the balance of interest principal due on any eligible Direct Loan not default for a borrower who: (1) at the time of such cancellation, is employed as a founder or full-time employee of a small business startup in a distressed area who has been approved for loan cancellation by a small business development center, and (2) began such employment during the five-year period beginning on the date that the small business startup was established (as determined by such center). Each of the 24 monthly payments required under such loan cancellation shall be made after the date of enactment of this bill. No borrower may, for the same service, receive a reduction of loan obligations under

After School Education and Anti- Crime Act of 1999 - Amends the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act to extend the maximum grant duration to five years. Revises grant application provisions to include, among others, students, parents, teachers, school administrators, local government, including law enforcement organizations such as Police Athletic and Activity Leagues.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 17, 2015. Jo Lawyer Spano Patient Registry Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry to develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma, including information on the incidence and prevalence of the disease in the United States. The registry must be used to: enhance and expand infrastructure and activities for tracking the epidemiology of mesothelioma patients; collect, consolidate, and report on health information on patients who have been diagnosed with mesothelioma, including their treatment outcomes and the number of patients receiving treatment for mesothelioma by hospital; better describe the incidence and prevalence of mesothelioma in the United States; examine factors, such as environmental and occupational factors, that may be associated with mesothelioma; better outline key demographic factors associated with mesothelioma; and make the information in the registry, other than individually identifiable information, available to the public to facilitate and enhance research on mesothelioma, and prevention and treatment purposes. The registry must also provide for collection and storage of information on mesothelioma when scientifically possible, such as information concerning the environmental risk factors, the natural history of the disease, the prevention of the disease, the detection, management, and treatment approaches for the disease, and the

Makes funds appropriated to the Department of Defense available for the payment of costs incurred by the National Guard in conducting international military-to-civilian contacts, civilian-to-civilian contacts, and comparable activities for purposes of: (1) supporting the objectives of the commander of the combatant command for the theater of operations in which such contacts and activities are conducted; (2) building international civil-military partnerships and capacity; (3) strengthening cooperation between the U.S. Government and agencies and foreign governments; (4) facilitating intergovernmental collaboration between the United States and foreign governments; and (5) facilitating and enhancing the exchange of information between the United States and foreign governments on matters relating to defense and security. Prohibits funds from being made available for the participation of a member of the National Guard in such activities in a foreign country unless the member is on active duty in the Armed Forces at the time of such participation. Requires the head of a Federal department or agency, in the event of the participation of personnel of such department or agency in such contacts and activities, to reimburse the Secretary of Defense for associated costs.

Handgun Trigger Safety Act of 2014 - Requires the Director of the National Institute of Justice to make grants to qualified entities (states or local governments, organizations, or institutions of higher education) to develop technology for personalized handguns (a handgun that enables only an authorized user to fire it). Requires a qualified entity that receives a grant to use not less than 70% of the amount of the grant to develop technology for personalized handguns. Allows such entity to use not more than: (1) 20% of the amount of the grant to develop technology for retrofitted personalized handguns, and (2) 10% of the amount of the grant for administrative costs. Provides for one-year grant awards, subject to renewal. Directs the Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) to promulgate a consumer product safety standard providing a specified timetable by which handguns manufactured, sold, offered for sale, traded, transferred, shipped, leased, or distributed in the United States must be personalized handguns or retrofitted personalized handguns, depending on the date of manufacture. Exempts antique firearms and firearms owned by the Department of Defense (DOD). Requires the cost of retrofitting a handgun to be borne by the manufacturer if the manufacturer is operational at the time the retrofit is required. Makes appropriations for the Department of Justice (DOJ) available to the Attorney

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 9, 2014. Family Farmer Bankruptcy Clarification Act of 2013 - (Sec. 2) Amends federal bankruptcy law governing a Chapter 12 debtor (adjustment of debts of an individual with regular income) with respect to a governmental claim arising from the disposition of property used in a farming operation as a result of the sale, transfer, exchange, or other disposition of such property before the filing of the bankruptcy petition, or before the debtor's discharge under Chapter 1228 (Adjustment of Debts of an Individual with Regular Income). Specifies that: (1) such unsecured claim shall be treated as an unsecured claim arising before the date on which the petition is filed, (2) the debtor shall not be entitled to priority under federal bankruptcy law for such claim, and (3) such claim shall be discharged in accordance with federal bankruptcy law. Provides that the amount that would be paid on such claim if the estate of the debtor were liquidated in a chapter 7 case shall be the amount that would be paid by the estate in a chapter 12 case if the claim were an unsecured claim arising before the date on which the petition was filed and were not entitled to priority. Requires the governmental unit to serve notice of such claim on the governmental unit charged

Amends the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 to revise exceptions to the requirement that federal agencies must lease space in buildings that have earned the Energy Star label. Requires a space leased by an agency in a building that has not earned the Energy Star label to be benchmarked under a nationally recognized, online, free benchmarking program, with public disclosure. Exempts from such requirement a space for which owners cannot access whole building utility consumption data. Requires an agency that is a tenant of a space that has not earned such label to provide to a building owner, or authorize the owner to obtain from the utility, the energy consumption information of the space for the benchmarking and disclosure requirements. Requires the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to study and report on: (1) the impact of state and local performance benchmarking and disclosure policies, and any associated building efficiency policies, for commercial and multifamily buildings and the programs and systems in which utilities provide aggregated information regarding whole building energy consumption and usage information to owners of multitenant commercial, residential, and mixed-use buildings; and (2) best practice policy approaches that have resulted in the greatest improvements in building energy efficiency. Requires the Secretary to maintain and make available public energy-related information on commercial and multifamily buildings.

Veterans Identity Protection Act or the Veterans Identity Protection Act Establishes the Office of Veterans Identity Protection Claims. Directs the President to appoint a Director of the Office. Defines an injured person" as an individual: (1) whose name or other personal identifying information is part of data of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) that was stolen from the home of a VA employee on or around May 3, 2006, that was reported missing from the Birmingham VA Medical Center or around January 22, 2007, or that is otherwise compromised as a result of a security breach; and (2) who suffered an injury as a result of such unauthorized use, disclosure, or dissemination of personal identifying information."

Western Hemisphere Traveler Improvement Act of 2007- Amends the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 to authorize a state, under a pilot program, to permit an individual to use his or her driver's license to meet certain documentation requirements for entry into the United States from Canada at the land and sea ports of entry.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of State to report to Congress: (1) an analysis of the impact of the pilot program on national security, recommendations on how to expand the program to other states, appropriate statutory changes to facilitate the expansion of the program to additional states, and a plan to scan individuals participating in the program against United States terrorist watch lists; (2) an evaluation of and recommendations for the type of machine-readable technology that should be used in enhanced driver's licenses; and (3) recommendations for improving the pilot program.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to permit an individual to enter the United States without providing any evidence of citizenship if the individual: (1) is less than 16 years old; (2) is accompanied by the individual's legal guardian; (3) is entering the United States from Canada or Mexico; (4) is a citizen of the United States or Canada; and (5) provides a birth certificate.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to establish a

Encouraging Mortgage Modifications Act of 2008- Amends the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974 to absolve a servicer of liability for entering into a qualified loan modification or workout plan in any action filed by or on behalf of any person: (1) based on the person's ownership of any interest in a residential mortgage, a pool of residential mortgage loans, or a securitization vehicle, that distributes payments out of the principal, interest, or other payment on loans in the pool; (2) based on the person's obligation to make payments determined in reference to any loan or interest; or (3) based on the person's obligation to insure any loan or any interest.

(Sec. 3) Prohibits the Secretary from making a loan to or for the benefit of a country which the Secretary has found falsified during the preceding five years to have: (1) falsified any item of information on any loan documentation submitted to the Fund; and (2) implemented, accounting controls and safeguards to curb potential misuse of loans, and to prevent such misuse, in the case of a country in which the controls and safeguards are insufficient to prevent such a misuse, the Fund is prohibited from making, and has exhausted, all opportunities to borrow from the private sector before instituting a quota increase for the member countries of the Fund. Prohibits the Secretary from making a loan to or for the benefit of a country which the Secretary has found falsified during the preceding five years to have failed to institute: (1) accounting controls and safeguards to curb potential misuse of loans by borrowers; and (2) in the case of a country in which the controls and safeguards are insufficient to prevent such a misuse, the Fund from making, and has exhausted, all opportunities to borrow from the private sector before instituting a quota increase for the member countries of the Fund. Reduces, for a fiscal year beginning in the first fiscal year after enactment of this Act, the U.S. reserve position to the lesser

District of Columbia College Access Improvement Act of 2002 - Amends the District of Columbia College Access Act of 1999 to revise the eligibility requirements for students under the public school program to attend eligible institutions of higher education in the District. Revises the eligibility requirements for students under the private school program to remove the requirement that any individual who graduates from a secondary school or receives the recognized equivalent of a secondary school diploma before January 1, 1998, be domiciled in the District for at least the 12 months preceding the commencement of the freshman year at an institution of higher education.Requires the Mayor of the District to establish a dedicated account for the administrative expenses of the public and private school programs.

American Heroes Act - Authorizes each State to provide one statue of an individual representing that State which shall be displayed in the Capitol Visitor Center. Requires the statues displayed in the Center to be depictions of individuals who participated in the life of the State they represent in ways that will inspire young Americans to embrace the ideals of the United States as reflected in the Constitution.Requires the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate to jointly assign to one of their employees the post of the American Hero Administrator, with such term agreed upon by the Clerk and the Secretary.Directs a State, in order for a statue to be provided, to establish an American Hero Commission to select the individual to represent it. Requires each Commission to: (1) choose, by a majority vote, the individual whose statue will represent the State; and (2) commission an artist to design and create the statue and arrange for its delivery.Requires each Commission to raise private or State funds to pay for the cost of commissioning the statue and delivering it to the Center.Directs the Architect of the Capitol to procure and install a statue honoring the passengers of United Airlines flight number 93 who died on September 11, 2001, for their heroic role in protecting Washington, DC from attack.

Workplace Fairness Act of 1996 - Prohibits employment discrimination on any basis other than job performance by covered entities, including entities covered under specified employment discrimination prohibitions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as well as employing authorities to which specified provisions of the Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 or the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 apply. Grants specified powers to administer and enforce this Act to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the Librarian of Congress, the Board of Directors of the Office of Compliance (for the Congress), the Attorney General, and Federal courts. Declares that this Act does not apply to religious organizations (except in their for-profit activities). Disallows State immunity. Makes the United States liable for all remedies (except punitive damages) to the same extent as a private person.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on November 14, 2016. Fair Wage Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 (FLSA) to increase the federal minimum wage for employees to: (1) $9.00 an hour beginning 30 days after enactment of this Act or January 1, 2017, whichever is earlier; (2) $9.00 an hour beginning 1 year after the date the wage specified in this Act takes effect; (3) $10.00 an hour beginning 2 years after such date; (4) $11.00 an hour beginning 3 years after such date; (5) $12.00 an hour beginning 4 years after such date; (6) $13.00 an hour beginning 5 years after such date; (7) $14.00 an hour beginning 6 years after such date; and (8) $15.00 an hour beginning 7 years after such date and annually thereafter. The Department of Labor shall determine the minimum wage for the subsequent one-year period: (1) not less than the amount in effect on the date of the increase, (2) increased from such amount by the annual percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers (United States city average, all items, not seasonally adjusted), or its successor publication, as determined by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS); and (3) rounded to the

Congressional Openness Act - Requires the Director of the Congressional Research Service (CRS) to make available through a centralized electronic database certain CRS information, including Issue Briefs, Reports, and Authorization of Appropriations Products and Appropriations Products, for access and retrieval by the public through the CRS website. Provides that such information shall not apply to: (1) any information that is confidential; or (2) any documents that are the product of an individual, office, or Committee research request. <n>Requires the Director to make such information available no earlier than 30 days and no later than 40 days after the date on which it is first made available to Members of Congress through the CRS website. Directs the Director to make such information available in a manner that: (1) is practical and reasonable; and (2) does not permit the submission of comments from the public. <n>Directs the Secretary of the Senate, through the Office of Public Records, to make available on the Internet for access and retrieval by the public: (1) Lobbyist disclosure reports required by the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 within 90 days after they are received; and (2) Senate gift rule disclosure reports within five days (Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays excepted) after they are received. <n>Requires the Superintendent of Documents, under the direction

Homeowners Empowerment and Protection Act of 1995 - Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to establish uniform Federal procedures applicable to all agencies. <n>Requires each agency to require any person required to file any application to conduct property impacting activity (an activity that generates pollutants or produces other adverse impacts with the potential to reduce the value of any private home) to provide notice under this Act. Requires the applicant to publish notice at least three times in the newspapers of general circulation in the affected community. <n>Requires such notice to describe the nature of the application to conduct activity, the potential impacts on homeowners and other members of the public, the name and telephone number of the applicant and an agency representative assigned to provide further information about the application, and any opportunities available for homeowners or other affected members of the public to comment on the proposed activity. <n>Requires each agency to establish a toll-free telephone number which homeowners may call to register concerns about potential effects on property values of any home identified by the agency as reasonably likely to suffer a reduction in value as a result of the proposed activity or to request additional information concerning an application filed with the agency and opportunities to submit public comment. <n>Requires the agency, if requested by an applicant or any homeowner whose property is reasonably

Eliminating Health Disparities Act of 2017 This bill allows a state to establish a Health Disparities Elimination Program for purposes of reducing health disparities among targeted populations in communities served by qualified community health systems under which the state provides incentive payments to such systems for initiatives approved by the Department of Health and Human Services. To be eligible for such a program, a state must require that a qualified community health system submit an action plan for an initiative to the state agency with responsibility for administering the state plan for approval that identifies: the target population or populations to be served by the initiative; specific, evidence-based projects that the system will undertake through the initiative to reduce health disparities for such population or populations; targets and benchmarks associated with such projects that must be met in order to receive incentive payments; measures for evaluating the effectiveness of the initiative in reducing health disparities; and the amount of any proposed initial incentive payments to be made to support startup costs of the initiative. The state may not approve an action plan for a period exceeding five years. At the end of any such period, the state shall require each participating qualified community health system to submit a report to the state describing the effectiveness of its initiative using specified measures.

Violent Juvenile Criminal Records Act of 1997 - Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to direct the Attorney General, acting through the Director of the Bureau of Justice Statistics, to make grants to States and local governments to: (1) establish programs to obtain fingerprints and photographs of juveniles arrested for specified violent offenses; (2) establish, develop, update, or upgrade the criminal history records systems of State and local governments to include arrest, detention, and disposition records, fingerprints, photographs, and DNA barcodes, for juveniles arrested or detained for certain violent offenses which, if committed by an adult, would be a felony or serious misdemeanor; (3) establish, develop, update, or upgrade the criminal information systems of State and local governments and regional intelligence sharing systems to include identification, and criminal investigative and intelligence information concerning adults who participate in the illegal activities of violent criminal gangs or other violent criminal organizations; (4) maintain the records described above at the State agency responsible for the operation of the adult criminal history record system of that State; (5) submit such information to the Federal Bureau of Investigation as is necessary to enable the records to be accessed in the same manner as are records for adult criminal histories; and (6) ensure that, each time an information on a criminal offense or activity is reported to a State repository

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a limited tax credit to a taxpayer who is a qualified mentor to each qualifying individual by the taxpayer an amount equal to $1,000. Defines qualified mentor" as an individual who: (1) has attained the age of 21 before the beginning of the taxable year; (2) with respect to whom any agency certified by the State in which the taxpayer has his or her principal place of abode to provide or facilitate mentoring services has placed a qualifying individual; and (3) is in compliance with the mentoring requirements of such agency or State."

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to declare that if the aviation tax rates prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury for any fiscal year are greater than or less than the otherwise applicable rates of the aviation taxes, the rates so prescribed shall apply for such year in lieu of the otherwise applicable rates. Specifies the method of determining such rates.

Implements of Torture Export Control Act of 2004 - Prohibits the Secretary of Commerce from approving the export of crime control and detection instruments and equipment (except pursuant to an individual export license) to any country that is a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) or is a major non-NATO ally unless the Secretary of State determines that the government of that country has repeatedly engaged in acts of torture. Makes such prohibition inapplicable to exports to any country that is a member of NATO or is a major non-NATO ally. Declares that such prohibition shall not apply to exports to any country that is a member of NATO or is a major non-NATO ally.

National Guard Investigations Transparency and Improvement Act of 2014 - Establishes in the Office of the Chief of the National Guard Bureau the Office of Complex Administrative Investigations to undertake complex administrative investigations of matters relating to members of the National Guard when in state status, including investigations of sexual assault involving a member of the National Guard in such status. Requires the Chief to ensure that such Office maintains the personnel and other capabilities necessary for the discharge of its duties.

Authorizes the Secretary of Defense to obligate and expend certain funds for proliferation threat reduction projects and activities outside the former Soviet Union if the Secretary determines that such projects and activities will: (1) assist the United States in the resolution of critical emerging proliferation threats; or (2) permit the United States to take advantage of opportunities to achieve long-standing U.S. nonproliferation goals. Limits the amount that may be obligated for such projects and activities to $50 million.

Television and Radio Program Violence Reduction Act of 1993 - Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to initiate a rulemaking proceeding to prescribe standards applicable to television and radio broadcast licensees and cable operators providing cable service under a franchise granted by a franchising authority, requiring such licensees and operators to reduce the broadcasting of all video and audio programming which contains violence. Directs the FCC to impose civil monetary penalties for: (1) intentional violations; and (2) repeated violations.

Directs the Customs Service to reliquidate, within 90 days after enactment of this Act, certain entries in accordance with the final decision of the International Trade Administration of the Department of Commerce, and the final results of the administrative reviews, for entries made on or after December 1, 1993, and before April 1, 2001.

Depository Institution Consumer Protection Act of 1997 - Amends the Federal Deposit Insurance Act to direct each Federal banking agency to prescribe and publish in final form consumer protection regulations which: (1) apply to sales, solicitations, advertising or offers of any nondeposit product (including shares issued by a registered investment company) by any retail depository institution, any affiliate or subsidiary of a retail depository institution, or any person engaged in such activities at the institution's office or on behalf of the institution; and (2) meet specified requirements and provide additional protections for consumers. <n>Directs the Federal banking agencies to consult with each other and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) regarding such regulations and to the greatest extent practicable to prescribe such regulations jointly. <n>Includes among such regulations: (1) anticoercion rules prohibiting depository institutions from making any extension of credit conditional upon the consumer's purchase of a nondeposit product from the same retail depository institution or an affiliate, subsidiary, or agent of that depository institution; and (2) specific rules prohibiting depository institutions, or their affiliates, subsidiaries, or agents from marketing nondeposit products to consumers while applications for extensions of credit from the depository institution are pending, unless marketing is done by mail, separate and distinct from any processing, discussion, or provision of information regarding

Chimney Rock National Monument Establishment Act - (Sec. 3) Establishes the Chimney Rock National Monument in Colorado in order to preserve, protect, and restore the cultural, historic, natural, educational, and scenic resources of Chimney Rock and adjacent land and to provide for public interpretation and recreation consistent with the protection of such resources. Allows the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to make minor adjustments to the boundaries of the Monument to reflect the inclusion of significant archaeological resources discovered on adjacent National Forest System land. (Sec. 4) Sets forth provisions for the administration of the Monument. Permits only such uses of the Monument that would further the purposes specified above. Allows for continued use of the Monument by Indian tribes for traditional ceremonies and as a source of traditional plants and other materials. Authorizes the Secretary to carry out vegetation management treatments within the Monument, except that harvesting of timber shall only be used when necessary for ecosystem restoration or the control of fire, insects, or diseases. Limits the use of motor vehicles and mountain bikes in the Monument to roads and trails identified as appropriate for their use. Directs the Secretary to permit grazing within the Monument where established before this Act's enactment. (Sec. 5) Directs the Secretary to: (1) develop a management plan for the Monument, in consultation with Indian

Home Health Care Planning Improvement Act of 2007 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to allow Medicare payment for home health services ordered by a nurse practitioner, a clinical nurse specialist, a certified nurse-midwife, or a physician assistant.

This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the tax credit for production of electricity from advanced nuclear power facilities, to require the Department of the Treasury to allocate any unutilized national megawatt capacity limitation as rapidly as is practicable after December 31, 2020, to facilities placed in service on or before such date to the extent that such facilities did not receive an allocation equal to their full nameplate capacity and then to facilities placed in service after such date in the order in which they are placed in service. The bill defines "unutilized national megawatt capacity limitation" as the excess (if any) of 6,000 megawatts, over the aggregate amount of national megawatt capacity limitation allocated by Treasury before January 1, 2021, reduced by any amount of such limitation which was allocated to a facility which was not placed in service before such date. In the case of any such limitation, such allocation shall be treated for purposes of the tax credit in the same manner as an allocation of national megawatt capacity limitation. If a taxpayer would be a qualified public entity, and such entity elects the application of this bill for such taxable year, the eligible project partner specified in the election shall be treated as the taxpayer for purposes of this bill. The bill sets forth rules for the transfer of the credit

Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Women's History Museum Act This bill establishes the Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Women's History Museum to submit to the President and Congress a plan of action for the establishment and maintenance of a National Women's History Museum in Washington, DC The commission shall be composed of eight members. The commission shall: (1) report on its recommendations with respect to such plan; (2) develop and submit to Congress a fundraising plan to support the establishment, operation, and maintenance of the museum through public contributions; and (3) obtain an independent review of such plan.

Graduation Really Achieves Dreams Act - GRAD Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award grants to states for innovative programs that increase the secondary school graduation and college attendance and completion rates of disadvantaged students.

Gender Advancement in Pay Act or theGAP Act This bill amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to revise the prohibition against sex discrimination in wages to include: (1) differentials based on expertise and shift differentials; and (2) a business-related factor other than sex, including but not limited to education, training, or experience. The bill applies the same prohibition to actions brought before the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) or by the Department of Justice under the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The statute of limitations for actions brought under the Portal-to-Portal Act of 1947 is tolled until the earlier of: (1) the date on which the EEOC or the Attorney General brings an action or provides notification to the employee with respect to the charge under the Civil Rights Act of 1964, or (2) 270 days after the date on which such charge is filed. The bill revises nonretaliation provisions to prohibit an employee from filing a charge or filing an action under the Act if: (1) the employee has made a charge or filed any complaint or instituted or caused to be instituted any investigation, proceeding, hearing, or action, including an investigation conducted by the employer; or (2) the employee has inquired about, discussed, or disclosed the wages of the employee or another employee, or has

Strengthening Community Safety Act of 2010 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to authorize the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to make grants to eligible first responder agencies for additional costs incurred as a direct result of one or more employees who are reservists being placed on active duty. Defines eligible first responder agency" as a law enforcement agency or fire service or a publicly or privately operated ambulance service that is: (1) authorized or licensed by a state to engage in rescue activity or to provide emergency medical services; and (2) designated by a state as a prehospital emergency medical response agency."

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 10, 2012. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Working Families Tax Protection Act of 2012 - Extends through 2013 provisions of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 (EGTRRA) relating to: (1) individual income tax rate reductions; (2) tax benefits related to children; (3) marriage penalty relief; and (4) affordable education provisions. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to reduce individual income tax rates for taxpayers whose adjusted gross income is less than $500,000 for the taxable year and to phase in such reduction by 2013.

Workers' Rights Principles for United States Businesses in China Act - Expresses the sense of Congress that any U.S. company doing business in China or Tibet shall: (1) prohibit the manufacture of goods or products by bonded labor or forced labor within prison camps or as part of reform-through-labor or reeducation-through-labor programs; (2) provide wages that meet workers' basic needs and provide fair and decent working hours; (3) use production methods that do not negatively affect the occupational safety and health of workers; (4) prohibit the use of corporal punishment, as well as any physical, sexual, or verbal abuse or harassment of workers; (5) refrain from seeking police or military intervention to prevent workers from exercising their rights; (6) promote freedoms among their employees and their suppliers; (7) prohibit discrimination in hiring, remuneration, or promotion based on age, gender, marital status, pregnancy, ethnicity, or region of origin; (8) prohibit discrimination in hiring, remuneration, or promotion based on labor, political, or religious activity, on involvement in demonstrations, past records of arrests or internal exile for peaceful protest, or on membership in organizations committed to nonviolent social or political change; and (9) prohibit child labor, including at a minimum, complying with guidelines on minimum age for employment under China's national labor

Combat Meth Act of 2005 - Authorizes additional appropriations for FY2006 to provide training to state and local prosecutors and law enforcement agents for the investigation and prosecution of methamphetamine offenses. Makes $3 million available only for prosecutors and law enforcement agents for rural communities.<n><n>Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to direct the Attorney General to allocate funds for the hiring and training of special assistant United States attorneys. Requires such funds to be used to: (1) train local prosecutors in techniques used to prosecute methamphetamine cases; (2) train local prosecutors in Federal and State laws involving methamphetamine manufacture or distribution; (3) cross-designate local prosecutors as special assistant United States attorneys; and (4) hire additional local prosecutors who are to be cross-designated to prosecute both Federal and State methamphetamine cases.

Recruit and Reward Future Math and Science Teachers of America Act of 1998 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to establish the National Math and Science Teacher Scholarships pilot program to recruit and train future secondary school mathematics and science teachers. <n>Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award National Math and Science Teacher Scholarships on a competitive basis to qualifying higher education institutions with graduate programs in teacher training. Sets forth eligibility criteria. <n>Requires scholarship recipients to agree to teach in an urban or rural public secondary school for at least three full academic years. <n>Sets forth repayment provisions.
Temporary IRA Distribution Suspension Act of 2008 - Suspends for calendar 2008 and 2009 the beginning date for required distributions from certain individual retirement (IRA) plans.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on February 11, 2016. Gas Pump Access Act of 2016 (Sec. 3) This bill declares that it shall be considered discrimination for purposes of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 if a gas station or convenience store fails to clearly display on each self-service gas pump a telephone number to call for assistance that: (1) is at least 15 square inches, (2) has a blue background, and (3) includes the International Symbol of Accessibility in printed white text. It shall be considered discrimination for such purposes if an attendant for a gas station or convenience store does not: (1) flash or otherwise signal to attract the attention of an attendant inside the facility if there is only one attendant on duty; or (2) notifies the individual of the availability of fueling assistance only during business hours if there is only one attendant on duty.

Decennial Census Improvement Act of 1997 - Requires the Bureau of the Census, in conducting the 2000 decennial census, to: (1) attempt to contact every household directly, whether by mail or in person (and allows the use of sampling as a substitute for direct contact in a particular census tract only after direct contact has been made with at least 90 percent of the households in such tract); and (2) seek to make more effective use of State and local government offices and appropriate local groups to reduce the undercount and include in a specified report a description of the measures it intends to carry out such requirement. <n>Prohibits the Bureau from using Federal funds to pay for temporary census employees except under specified circumstances.

Establishes a United States Delegation to meet jointly and at least annually with representative parliamentary groups from other countries in the Americas to: (1) discuss common problems and interests in intellectual and industrial property; and (2) initiate and promote national and multilateral measures that may further common interests in intellectual and industrial property. <n>Authorizes appropriations. <n>Amends the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 1961 to include in the annual appropriations report to the Congress a summary of the expenditures of the Delegation for each meeting of the Assembly.

Medicare Chronic Care Practice Research Network Act of 2007 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a Medicare Chronic Care Practice Research Network to develop and evaluate evidence-based chronic care management practices for Medicare beneficiaries with multiple, chronic illnesses, with a focus on beneficiaries under the Medicare fee-for-service program and whose care is most costly.

Federal Employees' Compensation Reform Act of 2011 - Terminates the payment of workers compensation for certain federal employees who have attained retirement age and are eligible for an annuity under the Civil Service Retirement System (CSRS) or the Federal Employees Retirement System (FERS).<n><n>Requires the Secretary of Labor to provide notice of this Act to: (1) such an employee; (2) the employing agency of such employee; and (3) the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). Requires the employing agency to file an application for an annuity with OPM within one year before such employee attains retirement age or subsequently becomes eligible for an annuity.

Caribbean National Forest Wild and Scenic Rivers Act of 2002 - Amends the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act to designate segments of the Rio Icacos, Rio Mameyes, and Rio de La Mameyes within the Caribbean National Forest/Luquillo Experimental Forest in Puerto Rico as components of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. States that nothing in this Act shall: (1) be construed to limit the authority of the Secretary of Agriculture to collect meteorological or atmospheric data with respect to the river segments when such facilities are essential to the scientific research purposes of the Forest; or (2) adversely affect the characteristics of such segments.

Imported Control and Safe Handling of Spent Nuclear Fuel Act of 1995 - Prohibits the importation of spent nuclear fuel into the United States unless: (1) the Congress has approved a repository or repositories with the capacity to store or dispose of all spent nuclear fuel generated by commercial nuclear reactors in the United States and from atomic energy defense activities; (2) the appropriate Federal agency or agencies have licensed such repositories; and (3) the repository or repositories are operating. Declares that such prohibition shall not apply to samples of spent nuclear fuel imported for testing and evaluation for national security purposes if the President determines that the country: (1) is not a country authorized to possess nuclear weapons under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons; and (2) is known or suspected to be producing or developing nuclear weapons and so notifies specified congressional committees at least 30 days in advance of the arrival of the imported fuel into the U.S. customs territory. <n>Authorizes any port authority to establish guidelines, through a public comment process, to ensure that the unloading, transfer, and shipment of spent nuclear fuel at or through a port under its jurisdiction is conducted in a manner that protects the public health and safety and the environment at, and in the vicinity, such marine port. Authorizes such authority to

Multilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2001 - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make competitive grants to local educational agencies to provide financial assistance to elementary and secondary schools for obtaining computer software for multilingual education. Requires the Secretary to give preference to schools in which: (1) a majority of the students are from families with incomes below the poverty line; or (2) there is a high concentration of students with low levels of English proficiency. Authorizes the Secretary to make competitive grants to local educational agencies to provide financial assistance to elementary and secondary schools for obtaining computers. Requires the Secretary to award such grants to any applicant LEA that serves elementary or secondary schools in which, cumulatively, a majority of the students are from families with incomes below the poverty line.Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to eligible partnerships to pay the Federal share of the cost of establishing and carrying out: (1) information technology training programs for former participants in such programs who have not received information technology certification, minorities, women, older individuals, veterans, Native Americans, and dislocated workers; and (2) multilingual education programs.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on September 6, 2017. Improving Support for Missing and Exploited Children Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Missing Children's Assistance Act to revise, reauthorize, and rename the program as the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC). The NCMEC must: (1) serve as a nonprofit, national resource center and clearinghouse for assisting victims, families, child-serving professionals, and the public; (2) work with various federal agencies and nongovernmental organizations to find missing and exploited children and to prevent child victimization; and (3) coordinate with missing children clearinghouses operated by the 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and international organizations to transmit images and information regarding missing and exploited children to law enforcement, nongovernmental organizations, and corporate partners across the United States and around the world instantly. The bill also specifies that the term "parent" includes a legal guardian or other individual standing in loco parentis (such as a grandparent or stepparent with whom the child lives, or an individual who is legally responsible for the child's welfare). (Sec. 4) The bill expands the duties of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention

Amends the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 to add to title I a new subtitle C, which may be cited as the Program for Investment in Microentrepreneurs Act of 1999. Directs the Administrator of the Community Development Financial Institutions Fund (Administrator) to establish a microenterprise technical assistance and capacity building program to provide Fund grants to qualified organizations to: (1) provide training and technical assistance to disadvantaged entrepreneurs; (2) provide training and capacity building services to microenterprise development organizations and programs to assist such organizations and programs in developing microenterprise training and services; (3) aid in researching and developing the best practices in the field of microenterprise and technical assistance programs for disadvantaged entrepreneurs; and (4) aid in researching and developing such best practices for Indian tribes. Sets forth an allocation formula for such assistance and for subgrants.

Construction Subcontractors Payment Protection Enhancement Act of 1998 - Amends the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act to require the Administrator of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy to establish appropriate Government-wide policies and assure Government-wide implementation through the Federal Acquisition Regulation of statutes and policies assuring the timely payment of contractors, subcontractors, and suppliers, including the Prompt Payment Act, the Miller Act, and section 2091 of the Federal Acquisition Streamlining Act of 1994. <n>Requires: (1) proposed revisions to the Government-wide Federal Acquisition Regulation to be published within 120 days after enactment of this Act and to provide at least 60 days for public comment; and (2) final regulations to be published within 180 days after enactment. <n>Amends the Miller Act to revise payment bond requirements, including to: (1) allow a payment bond to be equal to the amount of the performance bond; (2) cover progress payments under such Act as well as non-full progress payments; (3) require any person who institutes a payment bond suit to give notice to the contractor who furnished such bond; (4) make valid any waiver of protection afforded to a person by a payment bond; and (5) extend payment bond protection to all subcontractors and suppliers.

(Sec. 2) Makes such antitrust exemption inapplicable to a joint agreement: (1) by or among persons engaging in or conducting the sponsored telecasting of games of professional football, basketball, or hockey by which any league in that professional sport sells or otherwise transfers all or part of the rights of the member clubs in that league in the sponsored telecasting; (2) by which the member clubs of two or more professional football leagues combine their operations in an expanded single league that is exempt from taxation by reason of such exemption if that agreement: (1) increases the number of professional football clubs operating; and (2) contains provisions that are directly relevant to the operation of such league; or (3) denies a member club the right to transfer the location of the franchise right to that member club. Specifies conditions for such exemption. Provides that such exemption shall apply: (1) to a football league or major league baseball league in an expanded single league if the league agrees to meet specified conditions and to deposit an amount equal to ten percent of the amounts received under that agreement for the sale or transfer of rights in the sponsored telecasting of games of that league in the United States on the condition that any funds that are not obligated during the ten-year period for the sale or transfer of such rights are not obligated to the member

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 19, 2014. Colonias Improvement Act of 2014 - (Sec. 3) Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to issue a proposed rule containing a definition of the term "colonia" that: (1) is the same for each covered program (water and waste facility loans and grants under the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act, wastewater assistance to colonias under the Safe Drinking Water Act Amendments of 1996, drinking water assistance to colonias under the Public Health Service Act, housing assistance under the Housing Act of 1949, community development block grant assistance under the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act, and any other program of the EPA, the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), or the Department of Agriculture [USDA] that specifically includes assistance for colonias); (2) is limited to a community that is located within 75 miles of the border between the United States and Mexico or has applied for or received funding under a covered program before this Act's enactment; (3) reflects and preserves the historic, geographic, and cultural character of the communities served by such programs; and (4) may be used to determine whether an applicant qualifies for assistance under any such program. (Sec. 4)

Expresses the sense of the Congress that U.S. nationals conducting commercial cooperation projects in the Socialist Republic of Vietnam should adhere to specified principles, including to: (1) seek to ensure that political or religious views, sex, ethnic or national background, involvement in political activities or nonviolent demonstrations, or association with suspected or known dissidents will not prohibit hiring, lead to harassment, demotion, or dismissal of employees in the project; (2) ensure that methods of production used in the project do not pose unnecessary danger to workers and neighboring populations and property and that the project does not risk harm to the surrounding environment; (3) strive to use business enterprises that are not controlled by the Socialist Republic of Vietnam or its authorized agents and departments as potential partners in the project; and (4) promote freedom of association and assembly among the employees of the U.S. national, including the right of employees to form collective bargaining units. Requires the Secretary of State to forward a copy of such principles to the member nations of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and encourage them to promote principles similar to those described in this Act. Declares that no fee shall be required for registration under this Act.Requires each U.S. national conducting a commercial cooperation project in the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on September 6, 2017. Tribal Connect Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to establish a pilot program that provides E-rate support, through the Schools and Libraries Universal Service Support program, to tribal libraries and qualifying anchor institutions in order for such libraries to participate in the universal service program for schools and libraries. The bill defines "qualifying anchor institution" as a facility owned by an Indian tribe if: (1) the proposed qualifying anchor institution is exclusively owned by the Indian tribe, and (2) the proposed qualifying anchor institution intends to deliver publicly available Internet access to students, teachers, librarians, and members of the community for educational purposes. To be eligible to obtain E-rate support, a tribal government shall not have an existing tribal library eligible for the Schools and Libraries Universal Service Support program within the tribal community. E-rate support obtained under this bill shall only be available for an Indian tribe if the proposed qualifying anchor institution is exclusively owned by the Indian tribe and the proposed qualifying anchor institution intends to deliver publicly available Internet access to students, teachers, librarians, and members of the community for educational purposes. The FCC must report annually

Cure and Understanding Research for Alzheimer's Act of 2008 or the LaZH Act of 2008 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to ensure sufficient resources for activities relating to Alzheimer's disease and Hispanic communities, including by: (1) increasing efforts in Hispanic subgroups; (2) allocating resources to the National Institute on Aging Alzheimer's disease research centers and other academic centers involved in Alzheimer's disease research to increase participation of Hispanics and other under represented ethnic groups in research and clinical trials in sufficient numbers to draw valid conclusions; and (3) conducting social, behavioral, and health services research to understand more fully the disparities in Alzheimer's disease between Hispanic and other ethnic groups and to develop interventions to address such disparities.

Health Care Consumer Protection Act of 1995 - Requires insurers providing health insurance coverage under a health plan to provide: (1) annual notice to current enrollees regarding the extent of the plan's coverage; and (2) written notice, upon request, to each potential enrollee regarding the extent of the plan's coverage. Declares that, under a plan, the determination of what is medically necessary and appropriate for the health of a patient may not be made only by a licensed health care practitioner who is either directly involved in the care of such patient or licensed within the State in which the practitioner practices. Requires an insurer to pay for a service determined to be medically necessary and appropriate if the service is covered by the plan. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to promulgate regulations to ensure that an insurer not offer monetary rewards, penalties, or inducements to a licensed health care practitioner, or condition the continued participation of such practitioner in a plan, on the basis of the practitioner's decisions to limit the availability of appropriate medical tests, services, or treatments. Declares that any entity that offers a health plan that violates this Act shall be subject to a civil money penalty in an amount to be determined by the Secretary.

Faith-Based Drug Treatment Enhancement Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to allow religious organizations to provide services under designated programs for substance abuse prevention and treatment. States that the purpose of this Act is to allow religious organizations to be program participants on the same basis as any other nonprofit private provider without impairing the religious character of such organizations, and without diminishing the religious freedom of program beneficiaries.

Small Business Reform Act of 2010 or the Not Too Small to Succeed in Business Act of 2010- Amends the Small Business Act to increase from 9 to 11 years the period during which a small business that participated in the small business development program (program) prior to enactment of this Act may participate in such program. Authorizes a small business concern that previously participated in such program and that is otherwise eligible to participate in it except for having completed a nine-year period, and current net worth of $750,000 but still less than $2,250,000, to participate in such program during the two-year period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act. Limits the net worth and income requirements for such program.

Veterans' Education and Training Act of 1994 - Makes technical and conforming amendments to Federal provisions concerning: (1) active duty training; (2) the reserve program; (3) training and rehabilitation for veterans with service-connected disabilities; (4) alternative teacher certification programs; (5) education outside the United States; (6) correspondence courses; and (7) approval of programs of education.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code with respect to the tax deduction for fractional gifts to require that all interests in the property be held immediately before a contribution is made and that, in the case of an initial fractional contribution, such contribution is made pursuant to a written binding contract. Allows the Secretary of the Treasury to provide for exceptions to such requirement in cases where all persons who hold an interest in the property make proportional contributions of an undivided portion of the entire interest held by such persons. <n>Requires that the fair market value of any additional contribution be determined by multiplying the fair market value of all of the donor's interest in the property immediately before the additional contribution and the interest in the property (expressed as a percentage) contributed in such additional contribution. Declares that in the case of any additional contribution, the fair market value of such contribution shall be determined by multiplying: (1) the fair market value of all of the donor's interest in the property immediately before the additional contribution; and (2) the interest in the property (expressed as a percentage) contributed in such additional contribution. Declares that in the case of any recapture of the amount of any deduction allowed with respect to any contribution of an undivided portion of a taxpayer's entire interest in tangible personal property: (1)

Homeownership Vesting Plan Act of 2009 - Amends the National Housing Act to direct the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to insure and insure any mortgage covering a 1- to 4-family residence that is made to pay or prepay outstanding obligations under an existing mortgage or mortgages on the residence if such mortgage meets specified requirements. Requires the principal obligation amount of the mortgage to be insured to be equal to 97.5% of the current appraised value of the residence securing the mortgage.<n><n>Requires: (1) waiver of all penalties for prepayment or refinancing of the existing senior mortgage, and all fees and penalties related to default or delinquency on the existing senior mortgage; and (2) all holders of existing mortgages on the property to which the eligible mortgage relates to agree to accept the proceeds of the insured loan, and any payment pursuant to this Act, as payment in full of all indebtedness under the existing mortgage, and all encumbrances related to such existing mortgage.

Directs the Secretary of Defense (DOD), in order to continue and expand the study of urotrauma (injury to the urinary tract from a penetrating, blunt, blast, thermal, chemical, or biological cause) conducted in 2011, to establish the Commission on Urotrauma to: (1) conduct a study on urotrauma among members of the Armed Forces and veterans; and (2) provide an interim and final report to the congressional defense and veterans committees on such study.
Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from an individual's gross income up to $5,000 ($10,000 in the case of a joint return) of interest and dividends received from domestic corporations.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 16, 2015. Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Department of the Treasury to implement a voluntary prospective reporting system for employers to use after December 31, 2015. Such system shall be maintained by Treasury and shall include: a process for employers to voluntarily report information regarding health care coverage offered to full-time employees and dependents; a process to ensure that health care exchanges, the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub, and the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) can securely and confidentially access such information and to provide the Department of Health and Human Services additional information relating to eligibility determinations for advance payment of the premium tax credits and the cost-sharing subsidies under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act; a process to allow the appropriate agency to follow up with employers to obtain additional necessary information relating to an employee's eligibility for such advance payment or subsidies; and a process to allow employers using the system to provide timely updates to the Hub regarding any cancellation of coverage or significant change in availability of coverage for participating employees. If an employer provides prospective reporting for a calendar year in which the plan year ends and the employer furnishes a statement that the employee, or the spouse or dependent of the employee

Education in Vocational Technology Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make grants to the States to improve the quality of instruction or training in, or develop instruction and training in, manufacturing and other occupational technologies. <n>Authorizes the Secretary also to make grants to States to assist States in purchasing state-of-the-art equipment for technical vocational education. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Clarification of billing rights of certified nurse-midwives and certified midwives. Clarification regarding payments for certified nurse-midwife services and certified midwife services furnished in teaching hospitals.

Civil Justice Tax Fairness Act of 2013- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow: (1) an exclusion from gross income for amounts received (either backpay or frontpay or punitive damages) on account of an unlawful discrimination claim, and (2) income averaging for backpay and frontpay amounts received from such claims.

Justice and Understanding By International Loan Elimination and Equity (JUBILEE) Act of 2004 - Amends the International Financial Institutions Act to direct the Secretary of the Treasury to commence immediate efforts, within the Paris Club of Official Creditors, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank), and the other international financial institutions, to accomplish: (1) each institution to cancel all debts owed it by eligible poor countries; (2) any waiting period before receipt of debt cancellation to not exceed one month from the date of an eligible poor country's application for it; and (3) the government of each eligible poor country to be encouraged to allocate at least 20 percent of its national budget, including the savings from the cancellation of debt, for the provision of basic health care services, education services, and clean water services to individuals in the country. Specifies other requirements the Secretary must meet in order to ensure creditor transparency.

Foreign Service Overseas Pay Equity Act of 2008 - Amends the Foreign Service Act of 1980 to provide for an overseas comparability pay adjustment for members of the Foreign Service who are designated class 1 or below and whose official duty station is not in the continental United States or in a nonforeign area.

Brownfields Remediation Waste Act - Amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act to define remediation waste" as all solid and hazardous wastes, and all media and debris that contain listed hazardous wastes or that themselves exhibit a hazardous characteristic and are managed for implementing cleanup. Authorizes the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to provide alternative requirements for management of remediation waste in lieu of restrictions under such Act and to streamline regulation and achieve greater flexibility for State remediation programs. Prohibits the Administrator from using this Act to remove or diminish any existing waiver, variance, or exemption from otherwise applicable restrictions on the management of remediation waste. Declares that the rules promulgated by the Administrator on November 30, 1998, and on February 16, 1993, as modified on November 30, 1998, shall be deemed to satisfy the requirements of this Act and shall remain in effect unless the Administrator takes action. Prohibits the Administrator from publishing any proposal to modify such rules before submitting a Report to the Congress identifying problems associated with the implementation of such rules. Declares that placement of remediation waste in temporary units, staging piles, or corrective action management units designated under Federal or State authorities shall not be deemed to be engaging in land disposal and shall not be subject to requirements for land disposal under such Act. Provides for additional flexibility and clarification regarding"

Nuclear Policy and Posture Review Act of 2007 - Directs the President to conduct a nuclear policy review to consider a range of options on the role of nuclear weapons in United States security, which shall be coordinated by the National Security Advisor and include the Secretary of State, the Secretary of Energy, the Secretary of Defense, the Director of National Intelligence, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and the Director of the Office Science and Technology Policy.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of Defense to: (1) conduct a comprehensive review of the nuclear posture of the United States to clarify U.S. nuclear policy and deterrence strategy; and (2) report to Congress on the results of such review.<n><n>Directs the President to submit to Congress, by March 1, 2010, a report on the results of the nuclear policy review and the reasoning for the selection of the nuclear posture.<n><n>Expresses the sense of Congress that the nuclear policy review should be used as the basis for establishing future strategic deterrence objectives and negotiating positions of U.S. nuclear weapons.

Weekends Without Hunger Act - Amends the Richard B. Russell National Lunch Act to direct the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to establish a program providing competitive commodities to eligible public or private nonprofit institutions to provide nutritious food to at-risk school children on weekends and during extended school holidays during the school year. Authorizes appropriations.

Medicare Drug Card Guaranteed Savings Act - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for the offering of a Federal national prescription drug discount card program available for discount card eligible individuals throughout the United States, including the territories. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services, through direct negotiations with prescription drug manufacturers, to obtain discounted prices that are at least as low as the manufacturer's average foreign price for the drug involved.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Pharmaceutical Supply and Value Enhancement Act or the Pharmaceutical SAVE Act - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to authorize the temporary importation for up to three years of a prescription drug if there is, or is likely to be, a drug shortage. Sets forth conditions for such drug's importation, including that it: (1) is not a drug subject to shortage determinations; (2) is authorized to be lawfully marketed in one or more countries included in a specified list of countries; (3) has the same active ingredient as the drug for which there is a shortage; (4) the manufacturer certifies to the Secretary that it intends to seek approval of the drug; and (5) is filed with the Secretary information attesting that specified requirements are satisfied, identifying the drug the importer proposes to import and the manufacturer from whom the importer proposes to import such drug, and requesting authority to import the drug. Terminates such authority after three years, or when the drug shortage no longer applies, whichever occurs first.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to deny importation of a drug otherwise qualified for importation if the Secretary determines

Local School Board Governance and Flexibility Act This bill prohibits the Department of Education (ED) from issuing a federal regulation, rule, grant condition, guidance material, or other requirement pertaining to a state or local educational agency (LEA) that: (1) conflicts with the power and authority of the state delegated by the LEA regarding the operation of the schools; (2) results in additional costs to the LEA for reporting, grant administration, and general operations, unless fully funded from federal funds; (3) conflicts with the power and authority of the LEA to determine how to engage or act upon community participation and advice; (4) imposes requirements on an LEA that would limit or adversely affect the authority of the LEA to function as a legislative, executive, or quasi-judicial agency; (5) conflicts with the authority of the state to determine the appropriate governance structure of the state or the LEA to determine the appropriate governance and management of the schools that the state or LEA serves; (6) establishes reporting requirements for states or LEAs that duplicate existing federal requirements or that are issued without first conducting a fiscal impact statement related to the costs to states or LEAs; or (7) places conditions or requirements on a grant to a state or LEA that are not directly related to, or that do not directly support

Continuity of Electric Capacity Resources Act This bill amends the Federal Power Act to require a transmission organization to submit to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) a report that: (1) identifies electric capacity resources that are available to the organization, and describes the fuel sources and operational characteristics of each such resource; (2) evaluates the financial health, viability, and projected remaining years of service of such resources; (3) identifies the organization's future needs for such resources, the projected future needs of the organization for electric capacity resources, and the availability of transmission facilities and transmission support services necessary to provide for the organization reasonable assurances of reliability; (4) assesses the status of the reliability of the elements of the bulk-power system under the organization's control over the short- and long-term periods in the organization's planning cycle; and (5) is made available to members of the transmission organization and to the public for comment. The transmission organization must file with FERC a tariff amendment that would achieve specified objectives, including: (1) a diverse generation portfolio and the availability of transmission facilities and transmission support services necessary to provide reasonable assurances of a continuous supply of electricity for its customers at the proper voltage and frequency; (2) an enhanced opportunity for self-supply of electric capacity resources by electric cooperatives, federal power marketing agencies,

Streamlining Permitting of American Energy Act of 2012 - Amends the Mineral Leasing Act to require the Secretary of the Interior (or a designee) to decide whether to issue a permit to drill within 30 days after receiving an application. Requires the Secretary to provide an applicant whose application is denied written reasons why the application was not accepted and detailed information concerning any deficiencies and an opportunity to remedy any deficiencies. Deems an application approved if the Secretary has not made a decision on the application within 60 days. Requires the Secretary to: (1) provide a description of the reasons for the denial of a permit; (2) allow an applicant to resubmit an application within 10 days if the application is denied; and (3) issue or deny any resubmitted application within 10 days after the application is submitted. Directs the Secretary to collect a single $6,500 permit processing fee per application from each applicant at the time a final decision is made whether to issue a permit. Requires: (1) 50% of such fees to be transferred to the field office where they are collected and used to process protests, leases, and permits under this Act; and (2) the other 50% to be retained by the Secretary to be used to process permits, right-of-way applications, and other activities necessary for renewable development, at the discretion of

Historic Rehabilitation Tax Credit Expansion Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code with respect to the offset for rental real estate activities under passive activity rules to increase the rehabilitation tax credit under such rules.

Southern Nevada Higher Education Land Act of 2008- Directs the Secretary of the Interior to convey: (1) approximately 40 acres of Bureau of Land Management (BLM) land to the College of Southern Nevada; (2) approximately 2,869 acres of BLM land to be conveyed for the University of Nevada, Las Vegas; and (3) approximately 285 acres of BLM land to be conveyed for the Great Basin College.

Amends Federal law to prohibit funds appropriated or otherwise available to the Department of Defense (DOD) from being used for the procurement of any item (including food, clothing, tents, or natural fiber products, specialty metals, or hand or measuring tools) that is not grown, reprocessed, reused, or produced in the United States, except to the extent satisfactory quality and sufficient quantity of any such product cannot be procured at United States market prices and such Secretary has notified the congressional defense committees. <n>Makes additional exceptions for: (1) procurements outside the United States in support of combat operations, by vessels in foreign waters, and in emergency procurements or procurements of perishable foods by establishments located outside the United States for their personnel; (2) specialty metals or chemical warfare protective clothing; and (3) contracts and subcontracts for the procurement of commercial items. <n>Makes such prohibition applicable to contracts and subcontracts for the procurement of commercial items notwithstanding the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act. <n>Repeals specified provisions of Federal law relating to Buy American requirements.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on November 16, 2015. Department of Veterans Affairs Purchased Health Care Streamlining and Modernization Act (Sec. 2) This bill authorizes the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to enter into Veterans Care Agreements with certain health care providers to furnish hospital care, medical services, or extended care to veterans at VA facilities if the VA determines that furnishing such care and services at VA facilities or under contracts or sharing agreements is impracticable or inadvisable because of the medical condition of the veteran, the travel involved, or the nature of the care or services required. A veteran shall be eligible to enter into such an agreement if the VA determines that the provider: (1) meets certain criteria, including the gross annual revenue of the provider in the year preceding the year in which the provider enters into the Veterans Care Agreement does not exceed $11 million; (2) does not otherwise provide such care or services to patients pursuant to a contract entered into with a federal department or agency; (3) is a provider of services that has enrolled and entered into a provider agreement under title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act, a physician or supplier that has enrolled and entered into a participation agreement under Medicare part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance Benefits for the

Foreign Credit Reform Act of 2004 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to seek to negotiate an agreement among the member countries of the World Bank and the Global Fund for Reconstruction and Development under which, on approval by the Global Fund, the Bank and the Fund make a contribution to the Global Fund in an amount equal to the amount of the grant award for the year, except that the total amount of the contributions so made with respect to the country during a year shall not exceed the total amount of debt service payments made by the country to the Bank and the Fund during the year.

Educational Opportunity for All Act of 2005 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit up to $4,000 per student for qualified tuition expenses for education furnished during an academic period beginning in 2005.

Freedom From Restraint Act of 1999 - Amends part D (Peer Review) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require providers of services eligible to be paid under Medicare part A (Hospital Insurance) or enrolled under Medicare part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance) to: (1) protect and promote the right of each beneficiary to be free from physical or mental abuse, corporal punishment, involuntary seclusion, and any physical or chemical restraints imposed for purposes of discipline or convenience; and (2) impose restraints only to ensure the physical safety of the beneficiary or other individuals in the provider's care or custody and only upon the written order of a physician that specifies the duration and circumstances under which the restraints are to be used.
