Directs providers to report each sentinel event (an unexpected occurrence involving an individual in the care of a provider for treatment for a psychiatric or psychological illness that results in death or serious physical or psychological injury that is unrelated to the natural course of the individual's illness or underlying condition) to: (1) an agency or entity with oversight authority; and (2) the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

WTO Dispute Settlement Review Commission Act - Establishes the WTO Dispute Settlement Review Commission to review reports of dispute settlement panels or the Appellate Body of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in proceedings initiated by other WTO parties which are adverse to the United States and which are adopted by the Dispute Settlement Body. <n>Requires the Commission to determine whether the panel or the Appellate Body: (1) exceeded its authority; (2) added to the obligations of or diminished the rights of the United States; (3) acted arbitrarily or capriciously, engaged in misconduct, or demonstrably departed from proper procedures; and (4) deviated, in its report, from the applicable standard of review. Requires the Commission, upon an affirmative determination on one or more of these questions, to further determine whether the action of the panel or the Appellate Body materially affected the outcome of its report. <n>Requires the United States Trade Representative, upon enactment of a joint resolution directing such action, to negotiate to amend or modify the rules and procedures of the Understanding on Rules and Procedures Governing the Settlement of Disputes with respect to XX with respect to any affirmative determinations submitted to the Congress concerning the action of a panel or the Appellate Body. Provides for a joint resolution withdrawing congressional approval of the WTO agreement, ending U.S. participation

Preservation of Access to Osteoporosis Testing for Medicare Beneficiaries Act of 2011 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to extend through 2013 the reduction in the minimum Medicare payment for bone mass measurement.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for the product of a passenger automobile or light truck with a mile per gallon rating of 50 miles per gallon or more. Limits the amount of such credit based upon taxpayer adjusted gross income.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on September 6, 2017. Airline Consumer Protection Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Department of Transportation (DOT) to issue a final rule requiring an air carrier to seek, in the event of a delay exceeding three hours, cancellation, or misconnection as a result of circumstances or an event within the air carrier's control, alternative transportation for displaced passengers, including aboard another air carrier capable of transporting the passenger to his or her originally scheduled destination, and to accept, for a reasonable fee, the passengers of another air carrier who have been displaced by circumstances or an event within that air carrier's control, or if the passenger has been involuntarily denied boarding due to a lack of available seats. (Sec. 3) The Government Accountability Office shall report to Congress on: (1) the extent to which computer network architectures and software handle multiple critical functions; (2) the impact of consolidated systems and software that handle multiple critical functions; and (3) the most common causes of airline computer network disruptions. (Sec. 4) Any schedule change resulting from a computer network disruption, security breach, or other inoperability may be considered an event within an air carrier's control. DOT shall: (1) work closely with

Lorton Correctional Complex Closure Act - Provides for the closure of the Lorton Correctional Complex. <n>Prohibits the establishment of any District of Columbia prison, penitentiary, jail, correctional institution, or related facility after the enactment of this Act without the approval of the Governor of Virginia. <n>Requires: (1) any District of Columbia felon who is committed to the custody of the Attorney General for a term of imprisonment to be incarcerated in a facility designated by the Director of the Bureau of Prisons in accordance with rules established by the Attorney General to assure that the treatment of District of Columbia felons is similar to that of other individuals under the Director's control; and (2) in the case of an individual convicted of a felony in the Superior Court of the District of Columbia who is under the custody and control of the Director of the District of Corrections, to be transferred to the control of the Director of the Bureau of Prisons within five years after enactment of this Act. <n>Amends the Federal criminal code to require the Director of the Bureau of Prisons to provide suitable quarters and provide for the protection, instruction and discipline of all District of Columbia felons who are sentenced to death or committed to the custody of the Attorney General for a term of imprisonment. <n>Direct

Promoting Readiness through Early Pell Act of 2016 or the PREP Act of 2016 This bill amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to modify the determinations and eligibility requirements for the Federal Pell Grant program for students who are dually or concurrently enrolled at public institutions of higher education (IHEs) and secondary schools. Currently, an IHE may determine whether a student is eligible for the Pell Grant based on whether the student is attending an IHE and is carrying at least one-half the normal full-time work load for the course of study, as determined by the IHE, and is enrolled or accepted for enrollment in a postbaccalaureate program that does not lead to a graduate degree and courses required by a state to receive a professional certification or licensing credential that is required for employment as a teacher in an elementary or secondary school in that state. This bill requires an IHE to also determine whether a student is eligible for the Pell Grant based on whether the student: (1) is dually or concurrently enrolled at an IHE and a secondary school; or (2) demonstrates evidence of a credible disruption or redirection in course of study necessitating additional time to complete a postsecondary degree or a recognized postsecondary credential. Students who are dually or concurrently

Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005- Amends the Small Business Act to require Federal agencies and other entities authorized to recommend a qualifying termination or restructuring (any termination of the use of a facility or restructuring that will result in the net loss of at least 1,000 governmental and nongovernmental jobs in any State) to: (1) conduct a detailed analysis of the impact of such proposed termination or restructuring on small business concerns and small governmental jurisdictions; and (2) prepare a quantitative cost-benefit analysis of the economic impact upon such concerns and jurisdictions in any State where the agency or entity determines the economic impact of such termination or restructuring would exceed $100 million.

Medication Error Prevention Act of 2002 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to provide that any medication error information submitted by a health care provider pursuant to an agreement between the provider and the reporting program operated by the United States Pharmacopeial Convention, Incorporated, shall be privileged for purposes of Federal and State civil and administrative proceedings. Defines medication error" as any preventable event that may cause or lead to inappropriate events involving the provision of a health services."

Cameron Gulbransen Kids and Cars Safety Act of 2003 - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to evaluate: (1) devices and technologies intended to reduce the incidence of child injury and child death occurring outside of parked motor vehicles in nontraffic, noncrash events, including backing-over incidents, caused by such vehicles; and (2) currently available technology to prevent injury and death of children left unattended inside of parked motor vehicles, including injury or death due to hyperthermia, power windows, or power sunroofs.Directs the Secretary to: (1) establish and collect data on the numbers and types of injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles; and (2) evaluate technologies for detecting and preventing collisions with individuals and objects behind a motor vehicle, with respect to the accuracy, effectiveness, cost, and feasibility of installation in a wide variety motor vehicles.Directs the Secretary to prescribe certain motor vehicle safety standards that: (1) require the installation of devices for detecting and providing to operators a warning of individuals and objects behind the motor vehicle; and (2) establish requirements for the performance of such devices.

Beved Consumer's Bill of Rights Act of 2016 This bill directs the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to prescribe rules prohibiting unfair or deceptive acts or practices in the provision of funeral goods or funeral services. Such rules shall include requirements that: providers furnish accurate price information and disclose clearly and conspicuously the cost of each specific funeral goods or funeral services provided or offered for sale; providers provide clear and conspicuous disclosures of all fees and costs to be incurred in the future or at the time that funeral services or funeral goods are provided; cemeteries provide a clear explanation of all written rules and regulations of, and a clear option of, the right of a consumer to purchase any good or funeral service upon the purchase of any other good or funeral service; contracts for funeral services or funeral goods that are prepaid disclose clear and conspicuous disclosures of any penalties incurred if the consumer decides to cancel or transfer the contract to another provider; and cemeteries provide a timely explanation of all written rules and regulations of, and a clear option of, the right of a consumer to interment or entombment. The FTC must also prescribe rules prohibiting unfair or deceptive acts or practices in the provision of funeral services occurring in a cemetery, in interment, or entombment, as well as any acts or practices in the provision of

(Sec. 4) Amends the Federal judicial code to exclude from the definition of prison" any Federal, State, or local facility that incarcerates or detains prisoners, except with respect to a prisoner who has not attained the age of 18 years. <n>(Sec. 4) Amends the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act to exclude from such definitions any prisoner who has not attained the age of 18 years. <n>(Sec. 5) Extends to all prisoners, including child prisoners, the right to file a civil action against the United States for damages under specified provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. <n>(Sec. 6) Requires a court to stay an action if it determines that the prisoner is in danger of immediate harm, but allows the court not to stay the action if it determines that the prisoner is in danger of immediate harm. <n>(Sec. 7) Extends to all prisoners the right to file a civil action against the United States for damages under specified provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. <n>(Sec. 8) Provides that a prisoner who has not attained the age of 18 years may file a civil action against the United States for damages under specified provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. <n>(Sec"

Border Security and Enforcement Act of 1997 - Establishes in the Department of Justice (DOJ) the Office of Enforcement and Border Affairs, to be headed by a Director. Transfers from the Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) to the Director all functions, personnel, infrastructure, and funding of the following programs: (1) the Border Patrol program; (2) the detention and deportation program; (3) the intelligence program; (4) the investigations program; and (5) the inspections program. Specifies that all orders, determinations, rules, regulations, permits, grants, loans, contracts, agreements, certificates, licenses, and privileges that have been issued, made, granted, or allowed to become effective by the President, the Attorney General, or other Government official in the performance of any function transferred by this Act shall continue in effect until modified, terminated, superseded, set aside, or revoked in accordance with law by the President, any other authorized official, a court of competent jurisdiction, or operation of law.

Federal Employees Health Care Freedom of Choice Act - Directs the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to contract for a high deductible health plan with any qualified carrier that: (1) offers such a plan; and (2) offers a health benefits plan under title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act, as of the enactment of this Act. Authorizes OPM to contract for a high deductible health plan with any qualified carrier that offers such a plan but does not satisfy the requirement that plans provide benefits equal to those provided under Medicare or the Internal Revenue Code. Outlines provisions concerning the plan requirements and the requirements for contributions toward high deductible plans and medical savings accounts.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Tackling Excessive Standardized Testing Act of 2015 or the TEST Act of 2015 Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to alter the frequency with which students must take the tests used in determining whether they are making adequate yearly progress (AYP) toward state academic achievement standards in mathematics and reading or language arts. (Currently, students must take those tests in each of grades 3 through 8.) Authorizes a public school to administer the academic assessments in mathematics: (1) in each of grades 4, 6, and 8; or (2) in each of grades 3, 5, and 7 if the school is at the 15th percentile or above for mathematics in the state or its students are making appropriate progress, as determined by the Secretary of Education, toward state mathematics achievement standards. Authorizes a public school to administer the academic assessments in reading or language arts: (1) in each of grades 3, 5, and 7; or (2) in each of grades 3 and 7 if the school is at the 15th percentile or above for reading or language arts or its students are making appropriate progress toward state reading or language arts achievement standards. Excludes limited English proficient students who are in their first 12 months of enrollment in a public

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 21, 2015. DHS FOIA Efficiency Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Chief FOIA Officer of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to finalize and issue an updated regulation implementing the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) which shall include: public guidance on procedures to be followed when making FOIA requests; updated guidance to the components of DHS responsible for processing such requests, which may include information on how to adopt automated processing of such requests; detailed information on fees and costs associated with such requests; and detailed information on the appeals process for such requests. The Officer shall: (1) identify and eliminate unnecessary and duplicative actions taken by DHS in the course of processing FOIA requests; (2) develop a plan to automate the processing of such requests and address required and recommended technology capabilities and elements; and (3) update and issue guidance to DHS components regarding the goal of reducing the backlog in processing such requests by 50% between FY2015 and FY2018. The Officer shall include in each semiannual privacy report submitted under the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004: (1) the total costs to DHS for meeting FOIA requirements for the period covered by the report; (2) an assessment of progress made toward meeting the backlog goals;

Cocopah Lands Act - Requires the Secretary of the Interior to take certain land in Yuma County, Arizona, into trust for the Cocopah Indian Tribe, if the Tribe transfers title of the land to the Secretary and there are no adverse legal claims to such land. Declares that such land shall become part of the Tribe's reservation.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 8, 2015. National Traumatic Brain Injury Research and Treatment Improvement Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to: (1) evaluate existing surveillance and data collections systems that track the incidence and circumstances of traumatic brain injury, including concussion; (2) establish a statistically sound, scientifically credible, and integrated National Traumatic Brain Injury Surveillance System; and (3) ensure that the System is designed in a manner that facilitates further research on brain injury. The CDC shall: (1) provide for the collection and storage of information on the incidence and prevalence of traumatic brain injury, including concussion, in the United States across the lifespan; (2) provide for the collection and storage of other available information, including demographics and other information associated with the incidence of a traumatic brain injury; and (3) consult with individuals with appropriate expertise in disease surveillance or registries and co-occurring issues, such as substance abuse or post-traumatic stress disorder.

Amends the District of Columbia Code to make the Mayor of the District of Columbia (currently, the President of the United States) the Commander-in-Chief of the militia of the District. Makes conforming amendments to comply with this Act to: (1) Title 10 (Armed Forces); (2) Title 32 (National Guard); (3) the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1993; and (4) the District of Columbia Home Rule Act.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Family Leave Credit <n> Title II: Other Provisions <n>Flexible Family Leave Tax Credit Act of 1993 - <n>Title I: Family Leave Credit <n> - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a limited credit to employers for up to 20 percent of the qualified compensation of their employees who are on family leave. <n>Terminates such credit after 1996.

Saving and Investment Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a deduction for dividends paid by domestic corporations. Sets forth special rules for certain distributions of mutual savings banks.

Plan B for Plan B Act of 2005 - Requires the Commissioner of Food and Drugs to approve or disapprove the supplemental new drug application for Plan B ( leorgestrel tablets), as amended by the formal response to the non-approvable letter, within 30 days after enactment of this Act. Deems such approval to continue in effect unless the Commissioner publishes in the Federal Register a determination to approve or disapprove the application.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on September 6, 2017. Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act to revise the criteria used by the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) to identify which bank holding companies are global systemically important. (Currently, the FSOC is required to identify only large, interconnected bank holding companies.) The bill eliminates the requirement that these bank holding companies have total consolidated assets equal to or greater than $50 billion. (Sec. 3) The bill also revises the authority of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to issue rules that apply to certain acquisitions of bank holding companies. Currently, the Board is authorized to issue rules regarding acquisitions of bank holding companies with total consolidated assets equal to or greater than $50 billion. The bill eliminates this authority and instead requires that the bank holding companies be identified as global systemically important bank holding companies.

Safe Food Act of 1999 - Establishes in the executive branch an independent Food Safety Administration which shall administer and enforce the food safety laws for the protection of the public health. Transfers to the Administration all functions of specified Federal agencies that relate to administration or enforcement of the food safety laws.

Prohibits any such agreement, export license, or transfer of any such items unless Congress approves the President's report by enactment of a joint resolution.Subjects to the same prohibition and approval requirements any export license for, or transfer or retransfer to North Korea of, any nuclear material, facilities, goods, services, or technology controlled under the Export Trigger List of the International Security Assistance Act of 1976.

Uterine Fibroid Research and Education Act of 2003 - Requires the Director of the National Institutes of Health to expand, intensify, and coordinate programs for the conduct and support of research with respect to uterine fibroids.Requires the Office of Research on Women's Health to coordinate uterine fibroids research activities.Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services: (1) through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, to develop and disseminate to the public information regarding uterine fibroids, including information on the incidence and prevalence of uterine fibroids, the elevated risk for minority women, and the availability of a range of treatment options; and (2) through the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration, to develop and disseminate to health care providers information on uterine fibroids, including information on the elevated risk for minority women and the range of available options for the treatment of symptomatic uterine fibroids.

Directs each State to submit to the Attorney General a written report (and subsequent updates) that specifies each location at which any law enforcement agency operating under State law stores or keeps explosive materials that have been transported in interstate or foreign commerce and the types and amounts of such materials. Directs the Attorney General to prescribe final regulations governing the storage of such materials by State and local law enforcement agencies, including public safety and security standards and requirements for video surveillance and an alarm system.Authorizes the Attorney General to enter during business hours any place where a State or local law enforcement agency stores explosive materials that have been transported in interstate or foreign commerce, for the purpose of inspecting and determining whether they are stored in compliance with such regulations.Authorizes the Attorney General to reduce by 10% the funds that an agency would otherwise receive under any Department of Justice grant program if it fails to comply. Permits the Attorney General to make matching grants to State and local law enforcement agencies.

Gun Show Loophole Closing Act of 2017 This bill amends the federal criminal code to make it unlawful for any person to operate a gun show unless such person: has attained 21 years of age; is not prohibited from transporting, shipping, or receiving firearms or ammunition in interstate or foreign commerce; has not willfully violated any federal firearms requirements; has registered with the Department of Justice (DOJ) as a gun show operator and has certified that such person meets other requirements; has not willfully failed to disclose any material information required, and has not made any false statement as to any material fact, in connection with the registration; and has paid a registration fee. It shall be unlawful for a person to operate a gun show unless the person: not later than 30 days before the commencement of the gun show, notifies DOJ of the date, time, duration, and location of the gun show, and the identity of each person who will be a gun show vendor at the gun show; before commencement of the gun show, verifies the identity of each vendor at the gun show by examining a valid identification document containing a photograph of the vendor and enters such information into a ledger; and enters into the ledger the information concerning the vendor, the date, time, duration, and location of the gun

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 19, 2014. Bond Transparency Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to require brokers, dealers, and municipal securities dealers that effects a riskless principal transaction to disclose to the customer, in writing, at or before the time of completion of the transaction: (1) the amount of the difference between the customer\\'s purchase price and the broker\\'s, dealer\\'s, or municipal securities dealer\\'s purchase price; or (2) the customer\\'s sale price and the broker\\'s, dealer\\'s, or municipal securities dealer\\'s sale price. (Sec. 3) Defines a riskless principal transaction" as: (1) a transaction in which a broker, dealer, or municipal securities dealer receives a customer order to buy or sell any municipal securities and, after receiving the customer order, buys the municipal securities to, another person, while acting as principal for its own account, to complete the customer order; and (2) any other transaction the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) identifies as a riskless principal transaction."

Veterans Programs Improvement Act of 2003 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to increase, as of December 1, 2003, the rates of veterans' disability compensation, additional compensation for dependents, the clothing allowance for certain disabled adult children, and dependency and indemnity compensation for surviving spouses and children. Repeals a Federal provision requiring that, on the effective date of an award of death pension, the death compensation, dependency and indemnity compensation, or death pension be reduced by the lump-sum proceeds of any life insurance policy on a veteran.Excludes from annual income, for purposes of eligibility for veterans' disability compensation, the lump-sum proceeds of any life insurance policy on a veteran.Prohibits payment of disability compensation for substance abuse, even if the abuse is secondary to a service-connected disability.

Equity in Public Education Act of 1996 - Directs the Secretary of Education to reimburse States for certain educational costs incurred by local educational agencies (LEAs) in providing a free public education to certain illegal alien students. Declares that such payments shall be used only for reimbursable costs.

Anti-Fraudulent Intercountry Adoption Practices Act of 1996 - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit knowingly and willfully falsifying, concealing, or covering up by any trick, scheme, or device a material fact, or making any false, fictitious, or fraudulent statements or representations, or making or using any false writing or document in connection with the performance of such act or the rendition of such service or the offer to do so. Specifies that the material facts, documents, and representations shall include: (1) information about the political or legal conditions and circumstances prevalent and anticipated in any country in which the legal proceedings of the adoption are to take place that may affect the adoption process; and (2) information released by the United States Department of State in the form of travel notices and other advisories regarding the adoption process in any country in which the legal proceedings of the adoption are to take place. Specifies that: (1) it shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly and willfully solicit money or any thing of value, or the promise thereof, for placing or arranging for the placement of any child for adoption under circumstances that would require or result in such child being transported in interstate or foreign commerce; and (2) this prohibition shall not apply to any person who: (1) solicits or receives money or any

Dis crediting the Eternal Listing of Species or the Takings Act This bill declares that the United States Fish and Wildlife Service's five-year review of the Sands Flower-Las Vegas Fly must be construed to terminate the listing of such species as an endangered or threatened species under the Endangered Species Act.

. Targeting Child Predators Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the federal criminal code to modify the process for issuing a nondisclosure requirement in connection with administrative subpoenas in four categories of investigations: health care offenses, child sexual exploitation or abuse, unregistered sex offenders, and imminent threats to an individual protected by the United States Secret Service. It lengthens the period of time during which a recipient of an administrative subpoena is prohibited from disclosure. (Sec. 3) The bill subjects a nondisclosure requirement to judicial review, requires the administrative subpoena to include notice of the availability of judicial review, and establishes a process for judicial review.

Children's Environmental Health Protection Act - Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish the Task Force to Address Environmental Health and Safety Risks to Children. Requires the Task Force to recommend to the President and the Secretary of Health and Human Services that: (1) Federal agencies: (1) place a high priority on the identification and assessment of environmental health and safety risks that may disproportionately affect children; (2) ensure that agency policies, programs, activities, and standards address disproportionate risks to children that result from environmental health or safety risks; and (3) implement and comply with this Act.

Responsible Stem Research Act of 2001 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to contract establish a National Stem Cell Donor Bank to seek and preserve donations of qualifying human stem cells, and to make such donated cells available for biomedical research and for therapeutic purposes.Directs the Secretary, acting through the Director of the National Institutes of Health, to conduct and support qualifying stem cell research that uses qualifying human stem cells.

Provides criminal penalties for immigration consultants who handle immigration matters and do not meet specified requirements, including license and contract requirements. Exempts from such provisions: (1) attorneys; (2) certain law students and law graduates; (3) accredited representatives of qualifying organizations; (4) accredited foreign officials; and (5) persons authorized to practice before the Board of Immigration Appeals and the Immigration and Naturalization Service as of a certain date.Authorizes the Attorney General to provide State grants to educate persons respecting the requirements of this Act.Provides for confidentiality of information provided under this Act, and fines for knowing violation of such confidentiality.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to treat United States cruise industry income as effectively connected with the conduct of a trade or business within the United States. Defines United States cruise industry income" as income attributable to any covered passenger cruise, including income directly or indirectly attributable to the carriage of passengers and any on-board or off-board activities incidental to such cruise.Declares that no tax exemption or reduced tax rate shall be permitted under any treaty of the United States with respect to United States cruise industry income."

Cheyenne River Valley Conservation Act of 2010- Designates the Indian Creek East and Indian Creek West wilderness areas and the Red Shirt and Red Shirt East wilderness areas in South Dakota as wilderness areas and components of the National Wilderness Preservation System. (Defines wilderness area" as any of the areas designated as components of the National Wilderness Preservation System.)"

Incentives for our Nation's Veterans in Energy Sustainability Technologies or the INVEST Act This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a work opportunity tax credit for employers who hire veterans who are certified as having: (1) received a credential or certification from the Department of Defense of military occupational specialty or skill in a field of renewable energy or with respect to advanced manufacturing, machinist or welding, or engineering; (2) completed a vocational degree in a field of renewable energy during the one-year period ending on the hiring date; or (3) completed a LEED certification with the United States Green Building Council. The bill defines "renewable energy" as resources that rely on fuel sources that restore themselves over short periods of time and do not diminish, including the sun, wind, moving water, organic plant and waste material, and the earth's heat. The Department of the Treasury must pay to: (1) each possession of the United States with a mirror code tax system amounts equal to the loss to such possession due to this bill; and (2) each possession that does not have such a tax system the amount estimated by Treasury as being equal to the loss to such possession that would have occurred by reason of this bill if such a system had been in effect in such possession.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 2, 2017. Conflicts from Political Fundraising Act of 2017 (Sec. 3) This bill amends the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 to require the public disclosure of certain contributions to political organizations that promote or oppose changes in federal laws or regulations that are administered by the agency in which a covered individual has been nominated for appointment or is serving in a covered position. A "covered individual" is an individual who has been nominated for appointment to a covered position or is serving in a covered position. The bill defines "covered contribution" as a payment, advance, forbearance, rendering, or deposit of money, or any thing of value: (1) made by or on behalf of a covered individual; or (2) solicited in writing by or on behalf of a covered individual. The bill defines "covered contribution" as a payment, advance, forbearance, rendering, or deposit of money, or any thing of value: (1) made by or on behalf of a covered individual; or (2) solicited in writing by or on behalf of a covered individual.

Digital Coast Act of 2012- Directs the Secretary of Commerce, acting through the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), to establish and implement the Digital Coast, which shall: (1) collect specified priority supporting data and integrate such data with other available data for the benefit of the broadest measure of coastal resource management constituents and applications; (2) develop decision support tools that use and display resulting integrated data and provide training on use of such tools; (3) document such data to Federal Geographic Data Committee standards; and (4) archive all raw data acquired under this Act at the appropriate NOAA data center or other appropriate federal data center.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to: (1) recognize that remote sensing and other geospatial data acquisition for navigational and positioning purposes is carried out through other authorities and programs; and (2) focus on filling data needs and gaps for critical coastal management issues.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) make data and resulting integrated products developed under this Act readily accessible via the Digital Coast and other related Internet technologies; (2) develop decision support tools that use and display resulting integrated data; (3) document such data to Federal Geographic Data Committee standards; and (4) archive all raw data acquired under this Act at the appropriate NOAA data center or other appropriate federal data center.

Disaster Savings and Resilient Construction Act of 2012 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a business-related tax credit for a specified portion of the cost of commercial and residential buildings that comply with resilient construction requirements in a federally-declared major disaster area. Defines resilient construction requirements" as requirements that such buildings are designed and constructed to: (1) resist hazards brought on by a major disaster; (2) continue to provide their primary functions after a major disaster; (3) reduce the magnitude or duration of a disruptive event; and (4) have the absorptive capacity, adaptive capacity, and recoverability to withstand a potentially disruptive event."

Energy Conservation Opportunity Fund Act of 2008, or the ECO Fund Act of 2008- Establishes in the Treasury the Alternative Energy Sources State Revolving Fund to provide loans to states and Indian tribes to provide incentives to owners of single-family and multifamily housing, commercial properties, and public buildings to provide: (1) renewable energy sources for such structures; (2) energy efficiency and energy improvements and features for such structures; or (3) infrastructure related to the delivery of electricity and hot water for structures lacking such amenities.

Amends the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 to authorize the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) to carry out a Centennial Challenge Program to award prizes to stimulate innovation in basic and applied research, technology development, and prototype demonstration that have the potential for application to the performance of NASA's space and aeronautical activities. Requires: (1) recipients of prizes under the program to be selected through one or more competitions conducted by the Administrator; and (2) each potential recipient of a prize in a competition to register for the competition.Establishes the National Aeronautics and Space Foundation as a charitable, nonprofit corporation to: (1) encourage private gifts of real and personal property or any income therefrom or other interest therein for the benefit of, or in connection with, NASA; and (2) further the public's knowledge of and inspiration by the Earth, the Earth's atmosphere, space, and celestial bodies in space, for current and future generations of Americans.

Bankruptcy Fairness and Employee Benefits Protection Act of 2014 - Amends federal bankruptcy law governing a corporate debtor to prohibit any unfair reductions to: (1) employee health insurance benefits, and (2) any employee benefit other than health insurance benefits, including wages and pension benefits. Requires a debtor's proposal for modification of the health insurance benefits of employees to: (1) be comparable to, and not be more generous than, the modification of the debtor's health insurance benefits; and (2) entitle debtor employees to a claim for damages if the rejection of a collective bargaining agreement constitutes a breach of agreement. Requires the debtor's proposal for modification of the retiree health insurance benefits to be comparable to, and not more generous than, the modification of the debtor's health insurance benefits. Prohibits a claim for retiree benefits from being limited by, or otherwise denied on, the basis that the retiree's benefit was modified in violation of the collective bargaining agreement. Requires payment of the retiree health insurance benefits of officers and directors of the debtor in accordance with the terms of a collective bargaining agreement. Permits a bankruptcy court to award reasonable compensation out of the debtor's assets in connection with the liquidation of the debtor in certain circumstances. Requires a debtor's proposal for modification of the compensation of employees of the debtor

Global Nuclear Security Initiative Act of 2002 - Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary of Energy should develop a comprehensive program of activities to encourage all countries with nuclear materials to adhere to, or adopt International Atomic Energy Agency standards equivalent to, the standard on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material and Nuclear Facilities relating to the security of stockpiles of highly enriched uranium and plutonium.Directs the Secretary to study and report to Congress on: (1) the feasibility and advisability of developing a program to secure radiological materials outside the United States that pose a threat to U.S. national security; and (2) actions to reduce the risks associated with terrorist attacks on nuclear power plants outside the United States.Expresses the sense of Congress that the President should encourage amendment of the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Materials to: (1) apply it to both the domestic and international use and transport of nuclear materials; and (2) incorporate fundamental practices for the physical protection of such materials.

Authorizes the Secretary of Energy to expend specified amounts in the fund established under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 beginning October 1, 1999, for the decontamination and decommissioning program of the three gaseous diffusion plants in Portsmouth, Ohio, Paducah, Kentucky, and Oak Ridge, Tennessee, without further appropriation and without fiscal year limitation. Allocates such funds to each such program proportional to the total number of Separative Work Units processed at each site. Requires the Secretary, upon receiving advance notification that the United States Enrichment Corporation, or its affiliates, is terminating all or part of its lease with the Department of Energy (DOE) at the gaseous diffusion plant at Portsmouth, Ohio, or Paducah, Kentucky, to: (1) notify local and State officials, the congressional delegation, employee representatives, and community reuse organizations; and (2) determine within 60 days whether it will lease the facility involved in the lease to a successor entity, operate the facility as a government enterprise, operate it on standby, or close all or part of the facility. Requires DOE, within 30 days after determining that it will no longer operate or lease all or part of a gaseous diffusion plant, to initiate a decontamination and decommissioning program. Requires DOE to: (1) commence all required environmental reviews within 30 days after such decision; and (2) transmit to

Student Health Insurance Portability Protection Act of 1997 - Amends title XXVII (Assuring Portability, Availability, and Renewability of Health Insurance Coverage) of the Public Health Service Act, as amended by the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, to provide that the provisions of such Act in the same manner as they apply to health insurance coverage offered in connection with a group health plan shall apply to health insurance coverage offered in connection with a college-sponsored health plan in the same manner as they apply to health insurance coverage offered in connection with a group health plan. Applies such provision to coverage under college-sponsored health plans for students matriculating or enrolling for periods beginning on or after August 1, 1997, and the amendments made by this Act to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), the Internal Revenue Code, and the Public Health Service Act as if included in the enactment of such Act.

Amends the Indian Health Care Improvement Act to establish within the Public Health Service the Indian Health Service and the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Indian Health to administer such Service.

Federal Bureau of Investigation First Amendment Protection Act of 1993 - Prohibits the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) from initiating or conducting any investigation that may involve the collection of information about the exercise by a U.S. person of first amendment rights other than in accordance with the limitations and requirements established by this Act. Directs the Attorney General to issue publicly available guidelines for such investigations. <n>Prohibits the FBI from initiating an investigation unless the Director finds in writing that: (1) specific and articulable facts reasonably indicate that the subject of the investigation has engaged, is engaging, or is about to engage in a Federal criminal offense; and (2) that the investigation is warranted, taking into consideration the magnitude of the suspected criminal offense, the likelihood it would occur, and the danger to privacy and the exercise of first amendment rights. Requires such finding to include a citation of the specific section of law establishing the criminal offense. <n>Provides that, if such investigation is directed at an organization engaging in the exercise of rights under the first article of amendment to the Federal Constitution, such finding must also set forth specific and articulable facts reasonably indicating that all or most of the members of the organization have engaged, are engaging, or are about to engage in a Federal criminal offense

Taxpayer Savings and Employee Notification Act of 2003- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income nonqualified company-owned life insurance contract income. Provides for the disclosure of information to employees concerning nonqualified company-owned life insurance contracts.

Protecting Children from Sexual Exploitation Act of 2005 - Amends the federal criminal code to include within the definition of produces" a digital image, digitally- or computer-manipulated image of an actual human being, or an image of a visual depiction of sexually explicit conduct. Excludes from the definition of "produces" certain activities, including: (1) actually filming, videotaping, photographing, creating a picture, digital image, or digitally- or computer-manipulated image of an actual human being; (2) digitizing an image, of a visual depiction of sexually explicit conduct; or (3) assembling, manufacturing, publishing, duplicating, reproducing, or reissuing a book, magazine, periodical, film, video, digital image, or picture, or other matter intended for commercial distribution, that contains a visual depiction of sexually explicit conduct. Directs the Attorney General to promulgate regulations requiring persons who produce sexual depictions of simulated sexually explicit conduct to: (1) create and maintain individually identifiable records pertaining to every performer portrayed in such a visual depiction; (2) ascertain the identity of each performer and provide such other indicia of his or her identity; and (3) record and maintain such information."

Motor Donor Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish and maintain a national organ and tissue donor registry. Requires the registry to consist of a database of information listing individuals who have expressed an intent to be organ or tissue donors.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to: (1) coordinate activities with states that have organ and tissue donor registries operated through a state agency to share existing data and provide links between the registry and such state agencies; (2) coordinate activities with states to promote and encourage the establishment of such registries through the motor vehicle driver's license process; and (3) provide to each organ procurement organization within the United States a means by which it may promptly access the registry.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to states to establish organ and tissue donor registries through state motor vehicle driver's license application processes and linkages to the registry.

Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999- Amends the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act to declare that it is the policy of the Congress to provide for the establishment, use, and enforcement of a consistent and comprehensive system for labeling violent content in audio and visual media products (including labeling of such products in advertisements for such products) whereby: (1) the public may be adequately informed of the nature, context, and intensity of depictions of violence in such products and matters needed to judge the appropriateness of the purchase, viewing, listening to, use, or other consumption of such products by minors; and (2) the public may be assured of the accuracy and consistency of the system in labeling and of the accuracy and consistency of the system in providing information needed to judge the appropriateness of the purchase, viewing, listening to, use, or other consumption of such products containing violent content by minors. <n>Authorizes manufacturers and producers of interactive video game products and services, video program products, motion picture products, and sound recording products to submit to the Federal Trade Commission a joint proposal for a system for labeling the violent content in such products. Provides that such proposal should not apply to any joint discussion, consideration, review, action, or agreement between or among manufacturers and producers for purposes of developing a

Local Food for Healthy Families Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to establish the Local Food for Healthy Families Program to make grants to certain entities to carry out projects to provide incentives to low-income families receiving supplemental nutrition assistance program benefits to purchase fruits and vegetables. Requires the Secretary to convene an advisory committee to advise on the design of the Program.

Transparency and Honesty in Energy Regulations Act of 2017 This bill prohibits the Departments of Energy and the Interior from considering the social costs of carbon, methane, and nitrous oxide as part of any cost benefit analysis, unless a federal law is enacted authorizing such consideration.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Salton Sea Feasibility Study <n> Title II: Emergency Action to Improve Water Quality in the Alamo and New River <n> Salton Sea Reclamation Act of 1998 - <n>Title I: Salton Sea Feasibility Study - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, no later than January 1, 2000, to complete all feasibility studies and cost analyses for the following options that permit the continued use of the Salton Sea as a reservoir for irrigation drainage: (1) reduce and stabilize the overall salinity of the Salton Sea; (2) stabilize the surface elevation of the Salton Sea; (3) reclaim, in the long term, healthy fish and wildlife resources and their habitats; and (4) enhance the potential for recreational uses and economic development of the Salton Sea. Directs the Secretary to carry out the study in accordance with a memorandum of understanding entered into by the Secretary, the Salton Sea Authority, and the Governor of California. <n>(Sec. 102) Requires the Secretary, in evaluating options, to: (1) apply assumptions regarding water inflows into the Salton Sea Basin that encourage water conservation, account for transfers of water out of the Salton Sea Basin, and are based on a maximum likely reduction in inflows into the Salton Sea Basin which

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Preference for Contractors that Hire Welfare Recipients <n> Title II: Job Access and Work Incentives <n> Title III: Loan Guarantees of Loans Made by States to <n> Welfare Recipients <n> Title IV:SUBSTANCE ABUSE and Mental Health Services <n>Title I: Preference for Contractors that Hire Welfare Recipients <n> Title II: Job Access and Work Incentives <n> Title III: Loan Guarantees of Loans Made by States to Welfare Recipients <n>Title III: Loan Guarantees of Loans Made by States to Welfare Recipients <n>Title IV:SUBSTANCE ABUSE and Mental Health Services

Brownfields Housing and Community Renewal Development Act - Amends the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 to direct the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to establish a program to make grants to assist in carrying out redevelopment activities for brownfield sites and abandoned, idled, and underused industrial, commercial, or housing structures located in brownfield sites.

Delays from July to November 2000 the deadline for withdrawing the offer, or rescinding the withdrawal, of Medicare+Choice plans for 2001.<n>Amends SSA title XVIII part C to revise data collection requirements under the Medicare+Choice program with regard to: (1) establishment of a payment floor after applying risk-adjustment methodology; (2) the change in the application of the budget neutrality adjustment for 2001 and 2002; (3) an increase in the national per capita Medicare+Choice growth percentage in 2001 and 2002; (4) an increase in the minimum payment amount under Medicare for 2001 and 2002; (5) a movement to 50 percent blend in 2002; (6) an increased update for payment areas with only one or no Medicare+Choice contracts; (7) permitting higher negotiated rates in certain Medicare+Choice payment areas below national average; (8) a ten-year phase in of risk adjustment based on data from all settings; and (9) certain regulatory changes.

Land and National Park Deferred Maintenance Act or the LAND Act This bill reauthorizes through FY2024 the Land and Water Conservation Fund (LWCF). From amounts covered into the LWCF: (1) $450 million in each fiscal year shall be available for expenditure to carry out the purposes of this bill, without further appropriation or fiscal year limitation; and (2) the remainder of amounts covered into the LWCF shall be available subject to appropriations, which may be made without fiscal year limitation. The bill revises the allocation and uses of the LWCF. Not less than 1.5% of amounts appropriated or expended under the LWCF in each fiscal year shall be made available for the fiscal year for projects that secure recreational public access to existing federal public land for hunting, fishing, and other recreational purposes.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to deny a tax deduction for oil cleanup costs. Makes exceptions for: (1) small spills; (2) facilities closed and cleanup completed; (3) taxpayers with a complete liability defense; and (4) amounts deductible on account of the loss of the material discharged or released.

Stop Iran From Smuggling Weapons to Terrorists Act This bill authorizes the Department of Defense (DOD), with the concurrence of the Department of State, to: (1) provide training to the national military or other security forces of Israel, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Kuwait, and Qatar that have among their functional responsibilities maritime security missions; and (2) provide training to ministry, agency, and headquarters level organizations for such forces. The provision of such assistance and training may include the provision of de minimis equipment, supplies, and small-scale military construction. Training shall include elements that promote: observance of and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms; and respect for legitimate civilian authority within the country to which the assistance is provided. The bill makes $50 million available only for such assistance and training. DOD shall negotiate a cost-sharing agreement with a recipient country regarding the cost of any training provided.

Post-Prostate Cancer Treatment Equity Act of 2007 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) and the Public Health Service Act to require a group health plan, and a health insurance issuer providing health insurance coverage in connection with a group health plan, that provides medical and surgical benefits with respect to prostate cancer treatment to provide coverage for: (1) all stages of reconstructive prosthetic urology surgery; and (2) prostheses and physical complications of prostatectomy. Prohibits a plan or issuer from taking specified actions to avoid the requirements of this Act.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate with an amendment to the House passed version on January 16, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.)Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003- Amends Federal banking law governing interaccount transfers to provide that a depository institution may permit owners of certain interest- or dividend-paying accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month, for any purpose, to their other accounts in the same institution.Amends the Federal Reserve Act to authorize a Federal reserve bank to pay interest at least quarterly (at a rate not to exceed the general level of short term interest rates) to a depository institution on any balance it maintains at the reserve bank.Repeals a specified restriction in order to authorize pass-through reserves for member banks (as well as non-member banks).Reformulates the mandatory depository institution reserve ratio to: (1) one that is not greater than three percent, and may be zero, (currently, a flat ratio of three percent) for transaction accounts of $25 million or less; and (2) reduce from eight percent to zero the minimum ratio for transaction accounts exceeding $25 million.Requires the Federal reserve banks to transfer from their surplus funds up to: (1) $100 billion annually for deposit into the general fund of

State and Local Government Economic Empowerment Act - Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to have money available for purposes of this Act in an amount equal to the product of the population of the United States as determined by the Secretary of Commerce. <n>Requires that such money be created by having the Secretary and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System enter into a Loan Agreement in accordance with specified requirements. <n>Treats any amount made available pursuant to this Act as money created in the sovereign and exclusive capacity of the United States. Declares that no provision of this Act shall be construed as authorizing the expenditure of funds derived from revenues imposed and collected by the U.S. Government under any provision of law or from amounts borrowed by the U.S. Government pursuant to provisions of law, including the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974, the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985, and the Budget Enforcement Act of 1990. <n>States that money created under this Act shall not be treated as revenue when it is created or made available to the Administrator of General Services, nor shall it be treated as revenue by the Administrator or by the Secretary when the loans referred to in this Act are repaid. <n>Requires that the money created under this Act and the
Taiwan Airpower Modernization Act of 2011 - Directs the President to carry out the sale of no fewer than 66 F-16C/D multirole fighter aircraft to Taiwan.

Private Property Rights Act of 1997 - States that the policy of the Federal Government is to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public in a manner that, to the extent practicable, avoids takings of private property. <n>Directs each Federal agency to: (1) complete a private property taking impact analysis before taking any agency action (including the promulgation of a regulation) which is likely to result in a taking of private property, with specified exceptions, including for actions in which the power of eminent domain is formally exercised, in preparation for, or in connection with, treaty negotiations with foreign nations, a law enforcement action, a communication between an agency and a State or local land-use planning agency, the placement of a military facility or a military activity involving the use of solely Federal property, and any case in which there is an immediate threat to health or safety that constitutes an emergency requiring immediate response or the issuance of a regulation; and (2) provide such analysis as part of any submission otherwise required to be made to the Office of Management and Budget.

Mammogram Availability Act of 1999 - Amends the Public Health Service Act and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to require a group health plan, and a health insurance issuer offering group coverage, that provides coverage for diagnostic mammography for any woman who is 40 years of age or older to also provide coverage for annual screening mammography for such a woman under terms that are not less favorable. Prohibits: (1) denying screening coverage on the basis that it is not medically necessary or not pursuant to a referral or recommendation; (2) denying eligibility, enrollment, or renewal solely to avoid this requirement; (3) providing payments or rebates to women; or (4) penalizing or providing incentives to providers. Declares that this Act does not preempt State laws providing at least these protections.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 21, 2015. Citizen Empowerment Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill requires that any employee of an executive agency conducting an in-person or telephonic interview, audit, investigation, inspection, or other official in-person or telephonic interaction with an individual relating to a possible or alleged violation of any federal statute or regulation that could result in the imposition of a fine, forfeiture of property, civil monetary penalty, or criminal penalty against, or the collection of an unpaid tax, fine, or penalty from such individual or a business owned or operated by such individual to allow such individual to make an audio recording of such interaction at the individual's own expense and with the individual's own equipment. Any such employee: (1) may record such interaction if he or she informs the individual before or at the initiation of such recording and upon request provides the individual with a transcript or copy of such recording, but only if the individual provides reimbursement for the cost of the transcription and reproduction of such transcript or copy; and (2) shall, before or at an initial in-person or telephonic interview, audit, investigation, inspection, or other official in-person or telephonic interaction, provide the individual with a verbal or written notice of

Stand By Every Ad Act of 2010 - Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require certain campaign-related radio and television communications which expressly advocates the election or defeat of a clearly identified candidate or which consists of the functional equivalent of express advocacy to include: (1) an individual disclosure statement if the person paying for the communication is an individual; and (2) an organizational disclosure statement if the person paying for the communication is not an individual.

Electronic Books Opening Opportunity for Knowledge Act of 2014 or the E-BOOK Act of 2014 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to up to 10 institutions of higher education (IHEs) to reduce the cost of attendance for undergraduate students by providing them with expanded access to digital course materials. Directs the Secretary to give preference to grant applications that demonstrate a commitment to serving disadvantaged students. Requires each grant awarded to be used to support a pilot program for the IHE to make digital course materials available to undergraduate students in at least two different academic departments.

World Trade Center National Memorial Act - Authorizes establishment as a unit of the National Park System of the site of the World Trade Center (WTC) in New York City, New York.Requires: (1) the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to report to the Secretary of the Interior, the Governor of New York, and the Mayor of New York City on the recommended design and boundary for the Memorial; and (2) the final design and boundary to be approved by the Secretary, the Governor, and the Mayor.Requires the Memorial, upon transfer to the United States by willing sellers, to be administered by the Secretary through the National Park Service.

Tax Incentives Fuel Efficient Vehicles Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) increase the excise tax on automobiles at specified fuel economy standards; (2) increase the weight exemption for automobiles; and (3) allow a refundable tax credit for sales of highly fuel-efficient automobiles.

Special Olympics Sport and Empowerment Act of 2004 - Authorizes the Secretaries of Education, of State, and of Health and Human Services to award grants to, or enter into contracts or cooperative agreements with, Special Olympics for specified education, international, and health activities, including ones promoting Special Olympics and a greater understanding of contributions to society by individuals with intellectual disabilities outside the United States.

Embassy Employee Compensation Act - Establishes a program for providing compensation to individuals who were physically injured or killed as a result of the bombings of United States embassies in East Africa on August 7, 1998.Directs the Attorney General, acting through the Special Master, to: (1) administer the compensation program; (2) promulgate rules for the administration of such program; and (3) employ and supervise hearing officers and other administrative personnel to perform the duties of the Special Master under this Act.Authorizes appropriations.States that: (1) a claimant may file a claim for compensation under this Act with the Special Master; and (2) the claim shall be on the form developed and shall state the factual basis for eligibility for compensation and the amount of compensation sought.Requires the Special Master to develop a claim form that claimants shall use when submitting claims. Requires such form to request: (1) information from the claimant concerning the physical harm that the claimant suffered, or in the case of a claim filed on behalf of a decedent information confirming the decedent's death, as a result of such bombings; (2) information from the claimant concerning any possible economic and noneconomic losses that the claimant suffered as a result of such bombings; and (3) information regarding collateral sources of compensation the claimant has received or is entitled to receive as a result of such

Hunt Unrestricted on National Treasures Act or the HUNT Act Requires each head of a federal public land management agency to make available on the agency website: (1) a report that includes a list of the location and acreage of lands under the agency's jurisdiction on which the public is allowed to hunt, fish, or to use such lands for other recreational purposes, including a list of lands that have significant potential for use for hunting, fishing, and other recreational purposes; (2) a list of the lands that the agency determines have significant potential for such purposes; and (3) a plan that identifies how public access and egress could reasonably be provided to the legal boundaries of such lands in a manner that minimizes the impact on wildlife habitat and water quality, specifies the actions recommended to secure such access and egress, and is consistent with the travel management plan in effect on such lands. Requires each agency head to also make available to the public on the agency website a list of roads or trails that provide the primary public access and egress to the legal boundaries of contiguous parcels of land equal to more than 640 acres in size under the agency's jurisdiction on which the public is allowed to hunt, fish, or to use such lands for other recreational purposes. Amends the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965

SSI Outreach Act of 1993 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish within the Social Security Administration an Office of Outreach Coordination, to be administered by a Director of Outreach Coordination, to: (1) administer the grant program established under this Act and provide technical assistance to entities receiving grants; (2) formulate and provide information and technical assistance to Social Security Administration field offices regarding outreach policies and methods and local outreach activities and services; and (3) implement requirements of title XVI (Supplemental Security Income) (SSI) of the Social Security Act. <n>Directs the Secretary to provide grants to local governments and nonprofit organizations submitting applications to the Secretary to conduct outreach activities and services targeted at homeless individuals and other hard to reach populations, as determined appropriate by the Secretary.  Sets forth grant criteria.

Domestic Violence Courts Assistance Act - Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to include among the purposes for which grants may be used to establish and maintain a court system dedicated to the adjudication of domestic violence cases: (1) providing the resources to establish and maintain such a court system; and (2) providing technical assistance and counseling, training of attorneys, judges, and court personnel, technological improvements and data collection, and improvement of court facilities.Authorizes the Attorney General to make grants to States to implement and evaluate court-based approaches to adjudicating domestic violence cases in State courts and to provide technical assistance to State courts to facilitate the development and adoption of improved practices in the adjudication of domestic violence cases.Amends the State Justice Institute Act of 1984 to authorize appropriations for FY 2005 through 2008 for the State Justice Institute.

Student Loan Abuse Prevention Act of 2005 - Amends the Taxpayer-Teacher Protection Act of 2004 to eliminate special allowance payments made to lenders under the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) program. Replaces the current 9.5% rate of return on FFEL loans with a special allowance rate of 9.5% for loans: (1) originated, transferred, or purchased on or after the enactment of this Act; (2) financed by an obligation that has matured, been retired, or defeased on or after the enactment of this Act; (3) which the special allowance was determined on or after enactment of this Act; (4) for which the maturity date of the obligation from which funds were obtained for such loans was extended on or after enactment of this Act; or (5) sold or transferred to any other holder on or after enactment of this Act. Directs the Secretary of Education to encourage borrowers of FFEL loans to consolidate them under the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) program if one or more of such loans is a loan for which the holder is entitled to a special allowance payment of at least 9.5%. Prohibits the Secretary from offering an incentive to a borrower of a loan under FFEL that ensures the holder a minimum 9.5 percent rate of return on such loan by offering the borrower an incentive

Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to: (1) increase the amount of outside income which beneficiaries who have attained retirement age may earn without incurring a reduction in benefits; (2) increase for FY 1996 through 2002 the amount of outside income which beneficiaries who have attained retirement age may earn without incurring a reduction in benefits; and (3) require the Managing Trustee of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund to increase the rate of interest which is to be borne by obligations issued after September 30, 1995, and before October 1, 2002, by a specified percentage point.

Nuclear Safety and Promotion Act of 2001 - Amends the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 to extend from August 1, 2002 to August 1, 2012 the authorization of appropriations for Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) licensees.Amends the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 to eliminate: (1) foreign ownership restrictions on commercial and medical therapy and research licenses; and (2) certain antitrust review requirements with respect to combined construction and operating licenses.Amends the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 to prohibit the NRC, in conducting any environmental review in connection with an application for a license or a renewed license, from giving any consideration to the need for, or any alternative to, the facility to be licensed.Amends the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 to eliminate the duplicative antitrust review requirement with respect to NRC licenses for a combined construction and operating facility.Directs the NRC, in determining whether to approve an application for a combined construction and operating license, to take into account: (1) the impact on the environment of the proposed activity; and (2) specified factors, including the extent to which the proposed activity involves distribution of certain materials by the Department of Energy.Repeals the requirement that the NRC prepare an environmental impact statement pursuant to the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969.Requires the NRC, in granting a combined construction and operating

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: NTSB Amendments <n> Title II: Intermodal Safe Container Transportation <n> Title III: Aviation Safety Amendments <n> Title IV: Miscellaneous Provisions <n>National Transportation Safety Board Amendments of 1996 - <n>Title I: NTSB Amendments <n> - National Transportation Safety Board Amendments of 1996 (Sec. 102) Amends Federal transportation law to direct the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) to disclose records or information relating to its participation in foreign aircraft accident investigations, except that: (1) the Board shall release records pertaining to such an investigation when the country conducting the investigation issues its final report or two years following the date of the accident, whichever occurs first; and (2) the Board may disclose records and information when authorized to do so by the country conducting the investigation. Declares that nothing in this Act shall restrict the Board at any time from referring to foreign accident investigation information in making safety recommendations. <n>(Sec. 103) Prohibits the Board from disclosing voluntarily provided safety-related information if that information is not related to the exercise of the Board's accident or incident investigation authority and if the disclosure of the information would inhibit the voluntary provision of that type of information. <n>(Sec. 104

Environmental Protection Encouragement Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a taxpayer election to treat the cost of certain environmental improvement property as an expense which is not chargeable to capital account. Defines such property.

Amends the Federal criminal code to allow any person who is not prohibited from possessing, transporting, shipping, or receiving a firearm or ammunition to transport a firearm or ammunition for any lawful purpose from any place where such person may lawfully possess, carry, or transport such a firearm to any other place if certain conditions are met, including that the firearm is: (1) unloaded and in a locked container other than the glove compartment or console, or is secured by a secure gun storage or safety device; or (2) in a locked container or secured by a secure gun storage or safety device. Excludes from the meaning of transport" any activity incidental to the transport, but includes staying in temporary lodging overnight, stopping for food, fuel, vehicle maintenance, an emergency, medical treatment, and any other activity incidental to the transport, but does not include transportation: (1) with the intent to commit a crime punishable by imprisonment for a term exceeding one year that involves the use or threatened use of force against another; or (2) with knowledge, or reasonable cause to believe, that such a crime is to be committed in the course of, or arising from, the transportation. Prohibits a person who is transporting such a firearm, ammunition, magazine, or feeding device from being arrested or otherwise detained for violation"

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 9, 2013. Upper Mississippi Conservation and River Protection Act of 2013 or the Upper Mississippi CARP Act - Directs the Secretary of the Army, acting through the Chief of Engineers, to study the feasibility of temporary closure of the Upper St. Anthony Falls Lock and Dam to manage the threat of Asian carp traveling up the Mississippi River in Minnesota. Directs the Secretary to study the feasibility of implementing control measures at the Upper St. Anthony Falls and Dam and at Lock and Dam 1 to manage the threat of Asian carp traveling up the Mississippi River in Minnesota. Authorizes the Secretary to close the lock at the Upper St. Anthony Falls Lock and Dam if it is justified as a method to manage the threat of Asian carp traveling up the Mississippi River in Minnesota.

Natural Disaster Mitigation Act of 2011- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow individual taxpayers a tax credit for 25% of expenditures for qualified natural disaster mitigation property in connection with their principal residences. Limits the amount of such credit to $5,000 for any taxable year and the aggregate amounts allowed as a credit to the taxpayer (or the taxpayer's spouse) with respect to such residence for all prior taxable years.

Protecting Railroads against Enemy Efforts through Modernization, Planning, and Technology Act - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to develop a plan for the security of the Nation's railroads that includes: (1) identification and evaluation of critical railroad assets and infrastructures; (2) identification of threats to those assets and infrastructures; (3) identification of redundant and backup systems required to ensure the continued operation of critical elements of the railroad system in the event of an attack or other incident; (4) identification of security weaknesses in passenger and cargo security, transportation infrastructure, protection systems, procedural policies, communications systems, employee training, emergency response planning, and any other area identified by the plan; (5) a plan for the Federal Government to provide increased security support at high or severe threat levels of alert developed in consultation with the freight and intercity passenger railroads and State and local governments; (6) procedures for establishing and maintaining permanent and comprehensive consultative relations among the parties; and (7) a contingency plan developed in conjunction with freight and intercity and commuter railroads, to ensure the continued movement of freight and passengers in the event of an attack affecting the railroad system.Directs the Secretary to: (1) develop prioritized recommendations for improving railroad security, including recommendations for improving the security of rail tunnels, rail bridges, rail switching and car storage areas, other rail infrastructure and facilities
