National Policies Toward Gambling Review Act of 1995 - Establishes the Commission on the Review of National Policies Toward Gambling to conduct a comprehensive legal and factual study of: (1) gambling activities in the United States; (2) the social and economic impact of such gambling activities; and (3) existing practices in law enforcement, judicial administration, and corrections in the United States and in foreign legal jurisdictions for the enforcement of the prohibition and taxation of gambling activities. Directs the Commission to formulate and propose changes in such policies and practices as it may consider appropriate.

Essential Oral Health Care Act of 2009 - Amends title V (Maternal and Child Health Services) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to award grants to eligible entities to purchase portable or mobile dental equipment and pay for appropriate operational costs for the provision of free dental services to underserved populations, if such entities are tax-exempt community-based organizations that offer a free dental services program for underserved populations.<n><n>Amends SSA title XIX (Medicaid) to provide for an increase in the federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP) for states implementing approved equal access requirements to ensure that individuals covered by the state Medicaid plan have access to oral health care services to the same extent as such services are available to the population of the state.<n><n>Requires the state plan to provide assurances that: (1) individuals covered by the state plan have access to oral health care services to the same extent as such services are available to the population of the state; (2) payment for dental services for individuals covered by the state plan is made at levels consistent with market-based rates; (3) no fewer than 35% of the practicing dentists in the state participate (whether directly or through a plan providing dental services) under the state plan; (4) there

Veteran-Owned Small Business Promotion Act of 2009 - Reauthorizes the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) small business loan program (program) and increases: (1) the amount of loans that may be made to small businesses owned by disabled veterans; and (2) the maximum amount of such loans that can be made to businesses owned by veterans of the Vietnam era or disabled veterans. Repeals the provision requiring that at least 51% of a business concern be owned by disabled veterans in order for such concern to qualify for a direct loan. Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, under the program, to make only direct loans to small businesses owned and controlled by disabled veterans. Authorizes the Secretary to enter into a contract with an appropriate entity to carry out the program. Allows the Secretary to subsidize interest rates on guaranteed loans.

Harriet Tubman National Historical Parks Act - Establishes the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park in Caroline, Dorchester, and Talbot Counties, Maryland, as a unit of the National Park System. Requires the Secretary of the Interior to publish in the Federal Register notice of the establishment of the Park, including an official boundary map.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to acquire land and interests in land within the areas depicted on the map as Authorized Acquisition Areas" by purchase from willing sellers, donation, or exchange. Requires the boundary of the Park to be adjusted to reflect the acquisition.<n><n>Requires the Director of the National Park Service (NPS) and the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to enter into an agreement to allow the NPS to provide for public interpretation of historic resources located within the boundary of the Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge that are associated with the life of Harriet Tubman.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to provide interpretive tours to sites and resources located outside the boundary of the Park in Caroline, Dorchester, and Talbot Counties, Maryland, relating to the life of Harriet Tubman and the Underground Railroad.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to enter into a cooperative agreement with the state, political subdivisions of the state, colleges and universities, non-profit"

Amends the National Nuclear Security Administration Act to provide that, with respect to any vault containing Restricted Data at any national security laboratory, the procedures shall provide that an individual shall not have unrestricted access to any such vault except in accordance with the following requirements: (1) before each such access, the identity of the individual is verified by an attendant through direct visual observation, biometric technology, or other means providing a high confidence level in verifying the individual's identity; (2) for each such access, a permanent record of such access is maintained; and (3) the Administrator shall ensure, for each vault containing Restricted Data at each national security laboratory, that the combination of each lock to such vault is changed within one week after each removal of an individual from the list of individuals permitted access and 12 months after the date on which the combination was last changed. Directs the Administrator to ensure that, after October 1, 2002, each lock used by the Administration to secure any vault, safe, or other container used to store Restricted Data is an electronic lock that meets or exceeds the FF-L-2740A lock standard of the General Services Administration (GSA).

Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a demonstration project in not more than 40 local agencies in not fewer than two States under which costs of nutrition services and administration shall include the costs of identification of children eligible for benefits under, and enrollment of children in, State plans under titles XIX (Medicaid) or XXI (Children's Health Insurance Program) (CHIP) of the Social Security Act. Terminates the authority provided by this Act at the end of 2003. <n>Directs the Secretary to make grants to States to carry out State plans to involve eligible entities in the identification of children eligible for benefits and enrollment of children in: (1) a State plan under title XIX of the Social Security Act; and (2) a State child health plan under title XXI of the Social Security Act. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Hospital to Home- and Community-Care Linkage Development and Incentive Grant Program - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to compile, evaluate, publish, and disseminate to State and local officials, and to private organizations and agencies that provide services to individuals in need of long-term health care services, information and materials that may assist such entities in replicating successful programs that are aimed at offering care management to hospitalized individuals who are in need of long-term care so that services to meet individual needs and preferences can be arranged in home- and community-based settings as an alternative to long-term nursing home placement. <n>Directs the Secretary to establish a program under which incentive grants may be awarded to assist private and public agencies, including area agencies on aging, and organizations in developing and expanding programs and projects that facilitate the discharge of individuals in hospitals or other acute care facilities who are in need of long-term care services and placement of such individuals into home- and community-based settings. Authorizes appropriations.

Advancing Truth and Accountability in Campaign Communications Act of 2001 - Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require every person who makes a disbursement for electioneering communications in an aggregate amount in excess of $10,000 during any calendar year to file with the Federal Election Commission (FEC) a disclosure statement meeting specified requirements.Directs the Federal Communications Commission to compile and maintain any information the FEC may require to carry out this Act and to make it publicly available through its website.

FBI Counterintelligence Act of 1994 - Amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to require a consumer reporting agency (CRA) to furnish to the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) the names and addresses of all financial institutions at which a consumer maintains or has maintained an account, to the extent that information is in the FBI's files, when presented with a written request for that information, signed by the Director of the FBI, or the Director's designee, which certifies compliance with this Act. Permits the FBI to make such a certification only if it has determined in writing that: (1) such information is necessary for the conduct of an authorized foreign counterintelligence investigation; and (2) there are specific and articulable facts giving reason to believe that the consumer is an agent of a foreign power or a official of a foreign power, or is engaging or has engaged in international terrorism or clandestine intelligence activities that involve or may involve a violation of criminal statutes of the United States. <n>Requires a CRA to furnish identifying information respecting a consumer, limited to name, address, former addresses, places of employment, or former places of employment, to the FBI when presented with a written request, signed by the Director or the Director's designee, which certifies compliance. Permits the FBI to make such

This bill directs the Department of Transportation (DOT) to establish in the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration a Rural and Mountainous Advisory Council to undertake information gathering activities, develop technical advice, and present best practices or recommendations to DOT regarding the testing and deployment of highly automated vehicles and automated driving systems in areas that are rural, remote, mountainous, insular, or unclassified. A "highly automated vehicle" is defined as a motor vehicle (excluding a commercial motor vehicle) equipped with an automated driving system. An "automated driving system" is defined as the hardware and software that are collectively capable of performing the entire dynamic driving task on a sustained basis, regardless of whether such system is limited to a specific operational design domain.

Coastal Restoration Tax Credit Act of 2005 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for expenses incurred for an approved project to restore or protect coastal lands located in the United States. Limits the amount of such credit to $2 million for a taxable year.

Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 - Amends the National Dam Safety Program Act to require: (1) the Interagency Committee on Dam Safety to coordinate Federal and State programs concerning implementation of the Federal Guidelines for Dam Safety; and (2) the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency to prepare a strategic plan to establish goals, priorities, and target dates to improve the safety of dams in the United States and to establish cooperation and coordination with, and assistance to, interested governmental entities in all States.(Sec. 3) Requires the Director to develop technical assistance materials, seminars, and guidelines to improve security for dams in the United States.(Sec. 4) Requires the Chairman of the National Dam Safety Review Board to exercise by chairing the Board to coordinate national efforts to improve the safety of dams in the United States.(Sec. 5) Requires the Director to provide assistance to assist States in establishing, maintaining, and improving dam safety programs in accordance with specified criteria. Extends the authorization of appropriations.(Sec. 6) Authorizes the Secretary of the Army, acting through the Chief of Engineers and at the Board's request, to provide technical and financial assistance to States to improve dam safety. Repeals the mandate that the Secretary provide technical and financial assistance to States.(Sec.

(Sec. 2) Provides that an application for relief properly filed by a national of Guatemala or El Salvador under such Act, and on which a final administrative determination has not been made, shall, at the election of the applicant, be considered to be an application for adjustment of status under such Act, upon the payment of any fees, and in accordance with procedures, that the Attorney General shall prescribe. Prohibits the Attorney General from refunding any fees paid in connection with such an application.(Sec. 4) Authorizes the Attorney General to waive the grounds of inadmissibility for humanitarian purposes or when it is otherwise in the public interest. Authorizes an alien present in the United States who has been ordered excluded, deported, or removed, or ordered to depart voluntarily from the United States to apply for adjustment of status under such Act, notwithstanding such order, unless the alien is lawfully admitted for permanent residence or is subject to a final order of exclusion, deportation, or removal. Authorizes the Attorney General to grant a stay of removal or of removal if the Attorney General denies a stay of a final order of exclusion, deportation, or removal, or if the Attorney General renders a final administrative determination to deny the application for adjustment of status. Requires the Attorney General to

Iranian Nuclear Trade Prohibition Act of 2005 - Expresses the sense of Congress that the countries of the world should choose between trading with state sponsors of terrorism or maintaining good trade relations with the United States.<n><n>Amends the Iran and Libya Sanctions Act of 1996 to direct the President to prohibit the United States from purchasing nuclear fuel assemblies from any person or government entity, or any entity affiliated with such person or entity, that sells nuclear fuel assemblies to Iran. Authorizes a waiver of such prohibition in the national security interest of the United States.

Medicare Payment Improvement Act of 2009 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to determine a value index for each hospital referral area under the physician fee schedule. Requires the index to be the ratio of the quality component to the cost component for that hospital referral area.

Youth Opioid Use Treatment Help Act of 2017 or the YOUTH Act This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to revise and reauthorize through FY2022 grants for substance use treatment services for children and adolescents. The grant program is expanded to cover young adults. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) must award grants for demonstration programs to: (1) expand access to medication-assisted treatment for opioid use disorders among adolescents and young adults, or (2) create and distribute resources on medication-assisted treatment training and implementation for health care providers. AHRQ must report on the demonstration programs and the availability of medication-assisted treatment for adolescents and young adults.

Requires the Attorney General, if a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISA Court) issues a decision that determines that surveillance activities conducted by the government have violated the laws or Constitution of the United States, to publicly disclose the decision in a manner consistent with the protection of national security. Requires the Attorney General, for each disclosure required by this Act, to make available to the public documents sufficient to identify with particularity the statutory or constitutional provision that was determined to have been violated. Requires the Attorney General to release as much information regarding the facts and analysis contained in such a decision as is consistent with legitimate national security concerns. Requires the Director of National Intelligence to make specified disclosures to Congress and the public concerning: whether the National Security Agency (NSA) or any other element of the intelligence community has ever collected cell-site location information of a large number of U.S. persons with no known connection to suspicious activity, or made plans to collect such information; the type and amount of evidence the Director of National Intelligence believes is required to permit the collection of cell-site location information of U.S. persons for intelligence purposes; whether the NSA or any other element of the intelligence community has ever conducted a warrantless search of a collection of communications collected under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of

Declares that certain non-federal lands owned by the Quileute Indian Tribe are to be held in trust by the United States for the benefit of the Tribe without any further action by the Secretary of the Interior. Adjusts the boundaries of Olympic National Park and the Quileute Indian Reservation to reflect such change.

Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to carry out major medical facility projects (including construction of a Multi-Specialty Care Facility and a new medical facility at the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Louisville, Kentucky) in FY2010, in specified amounts. Authorizes the Secretary to carry out additional major medical facility projects in FY2010: (1) replacement of the existing Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Denver, Colorado; and (2) construction of Outpatient and Inpatient Improvements in Bay Pines, Florida.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to carry out the following FY2010 major medical facility leases (including leases of land) in specified amounts: (1) Anderson, South Carolina, Outpatient Clinic; (2) Atlanta, Georgia, Specialty Care Clinic; (3) Bakersfield, California, Community Based Outpatient Clinic; (4) Birmingham, Alabama, Annex Clinic and Parking; (5) Butler, Pennsylvania, Health Care Center; (6) Fayetteville, North Carolina, Health Care Center; (7) Huntsville, Alabama, Outpatient Clinic Expansion; (8) Kansas City, Kansas, Community Based Outpatient Clinic; (9) Loma Linda, California, Health Care Center; (10) Monterey, California, Health Care Center; (11) Montgomery, Alabama, Health Care Center; (12) Tallahassee, Florida, Outpatient Clinic; (13) Winston-Salem, North Carolina, Health Care Center; and (14) Winston-Salem

Lead Poisoning Reduction Act of 2006 - Amends the Toxic Substances Control Act to establish a Select Group on Lead Exposure to advise the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on actions necessary to reduce lead exposure in child-occupied facilities. Defines a child-occupied facility" as a childcare center, a pre-school or kindergarten classroom, or any other facility (including a facility used for a Head Start program or a similar program) at which a childcare provider receives compensation or a subsidy for services provided. Excludes a home-based childcare facility from the definition of "child-occupied facility.""

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 21, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Espionage Statutes Modernization Act of 2010 - Amends the federal criminal code to revise prohibitions against the unauthorized disclosure of classified information and related prohibitions with respect to persons working on behalf of foreign nations to: (1) apply such prohibitions to government employees, contractors, and consultants regardless of whether such employees, contractors, or consultants intend to aid foreign power or harm the United States; (2) apply such prohibitions to the unauthorized disclosure of information by government employees, contractors, or consultants regardless of whether such employees, contractors, or consultants intend to aid foreign power or harm the United States; and (3) include as predicate offenses to prosecutions under such prohibitions the unauthorized disclosure of classified information by such employees, contractors, or consultants regardless of whether such employees, contractors, or consultants intend to aid foreign power or harm the United States. Directs the Attorney General, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), to submit to Congress a report updating the laws applicable to persons working on behalf of foreign nations.

Cut Taxes for the Middle Class Act of 2014 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend through 2014: (1) the tax deduction for state and local sales taxes, (2) the tax deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses, and (3) the tax deduction for certain expenses of elementary and secondary school teachers. Amends the Housing Assistance Tax Act of 2008 to extend through 2014: (1) the exclusion from gross income for the low-income housing tax credit and the qualified residential rental project exempt facility bonds that determine area median gross income for such credit, (2) the employer wage tax credit for employees who are active duty members of the uniformed services, and (3) the new markets tax credit.

Establishes the terms and conditions under which the Secretary of the Interior shall convey to the highest bidder properties including 265 cabin sites and certain small contiguous parcels of the Bureau of Reclamation around Canyon Ferry Reservoir, Montana, to private parties.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on February 11, 2016. National Security Whistleblower Protection Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill extends the prohibition against Government Accountability Office (GAO) disclosures of classified information to Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and Department of Defense (DOD) employees. DOD's Inspector General, within one year after enactment of this bill and semiannually thereafter, shall submit to Congress a report containing specified information regarding: the number of allegations received by the Inspector General that an employee was suspended or revoked in retaliation for whistleblowing; the number of investigations of such allegations conducted by other DOD components, the number of such investigations that were returned as defective and a description of the remedial measures taken relating to such allegations; and the disciplinary actions taken against individuals who suspended or revoked an employee's access to classified information in retaliation for whistleblowing.

Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to direct the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to promulgate regulations to protect the privacy of customers of telecommunications service, including broadband Internet access service and interconnected VoIP service. Requires a telecommunications carrier to notify a customer about the collection, use, and sharing of customer proprietary information, including by: (1) notifying the customer about the types of customer proprietary information the carrier collects; (2) specifying how and for what purposes the carrier uses and shares customer proprietary information; and (3) identifying the types of entities with which the carrier shares customer proprietary information. Requires a telecommunications carrier to: (1) provide notification to a customer at the point of sale, before the purchase of service; and (2) update a customer when it makes a material change to a privacy policy. Directs the FCC to require a telecommunications carrier to: (1) obtain opt-in approval from a customer to use and share sensitive customer proprietary information; (2) implement strong protection for de-identified customary proprietary information; (3) prohibit a telecommunications carrier from refusing to serve a customer who doesn't consent to the use and sharing of his or her customer proprietary information for commercial purposes; and (4) develop reasonable data security practices and notify customers if a breach of security has occurred.

Authorizes the owner of a vessel eligible for a fishery endorsement under the American Fisheries Act to rebuild or replace such vessel in order to improve vessel safety and operational efficiencies (including fuel efficiency) and to be eligible for a fishery endorsement. Makes the rebuilt or replacement vessel eligible in the same manner and subject to the same restrictions and limitations as the vessel being rebuilt or replaced. Requires each fishing permit and license held by an owner of a vessel to be rebuilt or replaced to be transferred to the rebuilt or replacement vessel. Authorizes the North Pacific Council to recommend for approval by the Secretary of Commerce conservation and management measures, including size limits and measures to control fishing capacity, in accordance with the Magnuson-Stevens Act as it considers necessary to ensure that this Act does not diminish the effectiveness of fishery management plans of the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands Management Area or the Gulf of Alaska. Prohibits a replacement for a covered vessel which is validly documented with a fishery endorsement before the replacement vessel is documented with such an endorsement from harvesting fish in any fishery managed under the authority of any regional fishery management council (other than the North Pacific Council).

Conservation Security Act of 1999- Amends the Food Security Act of 1985 to establish a conservation security program through the use of contracts to assist owners and operators of farms and ranches to promote conservation of soil, water, and related resources, water quality protection and improvement, air quality protection and improvement, wetland restoration, protection, and creation, wildlife habitat development and protection, and any similar conservation purpose. <n>Makes an owner or operator ineligible to enter into a contract specifying compliance with a livestock nutrient management plan if the total number of animals raised by the owner or operator exceeds 1,000 animal units. <n>Requires a resource security plan to: (1) identify the resources to be secured by the plan; (2) describe the class of conservation practices to be implemented and maintained on the land subject to the contract period; (3) contain a schedule for the implementation and maintenance of the class of conservation practices described in the plan; (4) comply with the highly erodible land and wetland conservation requirements of subtitles B and C; and (5) contain such other terms as the Secretary may require. <n>Requires a livestock nutrient management plan to: (1) contain a plan for managing the manure and other organic byproducts produced on the farming or ranching operation in a manner that protects air, water, and soil quality; and (2) address the

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 23, 2016. Rural Housing Preservation Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Housing Act of 1949 to require the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to provide rural housing vouchers, in the amount provided under the low-income housing voucher program, to any low-income household (including those not receiving rental assistance) residing in a property financed with a loan made or insured under the low-income housing loan program which has been prepaid, or which has matured, after September 30, 2005. HUD shall: (1) administer and operate such vouchers with current regulations and administrative guidance applicable to enhanced voucher programs under the United States Housing Act of 1937, and (2) terminate such voucher assistance with respect to a property if a new loan is made or insured for the property and rental assistance is provided on behalf of the voucher holder in an amount comparable to the voucher holder's rental assistance. No owner of a property financed with a loan made or insured under the housing loan program may refuse to lease an available dwelling unit in the property to a household on behalf of whom voucher assistance is provided, and to enter into a voucher contract respecting such unit, a proximate cause of which is the status of such current or prospective tenant

Rocky Flats Environmental Technology Site Act of 2005 - Instructs the Secretary of Energy to use amounts made available under this Act to purchase essential mineral rights at Rocky Flats Environmental Technology Site, Colorado. Defines essential mineral right" as a right to a mineral identified as necessary to transition Rocky Flats to a National Wildlife Refuge by the Secretary of Energy and the Secretary of the Interior.<n><n>Prohibits the Secretary from purchasing such rights unless: (1) the owner of the essential mineral right is a willing seller; (2) the Secretary purchases the right at fair market value; and (3) the Trustees (federal and state officials designated as trustees under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980) enter into a natural resources damage settlement providing that the purchase satisfies any existing or potential natural resource damage liability claim arising from releases of hazardous substances identified in the administrative record for the site as of the enactment of this Act and includes a covenant not to sue.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to purchase essential mineral rights and satisfy any obligation of the Secretary under a settlement of a natural resource damage claim at Rocky Flats under such Act using only funds made available under this Act. Authorizes the Secretary, if an owner of an essential mineral right refuses to sell the right to the Secretary at fair market"

Mortgage and Rental Disaster Relief Act of 2007 - Amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to authorize the President to provide assistance on a temporary basis in the form of mortgage or rental payments to or on behalf of individuals and households who, as a result of financial hardship caused by a major disaster, have received written notice of dispossession or eviction from a residence by reason of a foreclosure of any mortgage or lien, cancellation of any contract of sale, or termination of any lease, entered into before such major disaster.<n><n>Allows assistance under this Act for a period of up to 18 months.<n><n>Applies this Act to any major disaster declared on or after October 21, 2007.

Sports Agent Responsibility and Trust Act This bill prohibits an athlete agent from: (1) recruiting or soliciting a student athlete to enter into an agency contract; (2) entering into an agency contract with a student athlete without providing the student athlete with specified disclosure documents; or (3) entering into an agency contract with a student athlete without providing the student athlete with specified disclosure documents. An athlete agent must provide a disclosure document to a student athlete or, if the student athlete is under age 18, to the student athlete's parent or legal guardian. Within 72 hours after entering into an agency contract or before the next athletic event in which the student athlete is eligible to participate, both the student athlete and the agent must notify the school's athletic director.

House Ethics Commission Establishment Act of 2007 - Establishes within the legislative branch an independent ethics commission within the House of Representatives. Limits membership of the Commission to former Members.

Common Sense Spending Act of 2005 - Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 (Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act) to extend the discretionary spending limits through FY 2010, with adjustments for inflation each year starting FY 2007.<n><n>Provides that if a bill or joint resolution is enacted that charges Federal agencies for the full cost of accrued Federal retirement and health benefits, and a bill or joint resolution making appropriations is enacted that provides new budget authority to carry out such legislation, the adjustment shall be equal to the reduction in mandatory budget authority and the outlays flowing therefrom estimated to result from the legislation.<n><n>Repeals the exemption of appropriations to cover agricultural crop disaster assistance from the application of mandatory adjustments in discretionary spending limits in a sequestration report and subsequent budgets for emergency appropriations for discretionary accounts. (Thus applies such mandatory adjustments in the total amount of emergency appropriations to appropriations covering agricultural crop disaster assistance.)<n><n>Revises PAYGO requirements to remove receipts from the requirement that any legislation enacted before FY 2010 affecting direct spending (currently, direct spending and receipts) that increases the deficit will trigger an offsetting sequestration. Revises the formula for calculating the amount of deficit increase or decrease by adding: (1) all Office of Management and Budget (OMB) estimates for the

Green Railcar Enhancement Act of 2010 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for 25% of the sum of: (1) the basis of any qualified freight railcar placed in service by the taxpayer during the taxable year; and (2) the qualified freight railcar rebuild expenditures of the taxpayer for such year.

Veterans Sexual Assault Prevention and Health Care Enhancement Act - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to develop and implement, by March 1, 2012, a centralized and comprehensive policy on reporting and tracking sexual assaults and other safety incidents at each medical facility of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), including: (1) risk-assessment tools; (2) mandatory security training; (3) physical security precautions (surveillance camera systems and panic alarm systems); (4) criteria and guidance for employees communicating and reporting incidents to specified supervisory personnel, VA law enforcement officials, and the Office of Inspector General; (4) an oversight system within the Veterans Health Administration; (5) procedures for VA law enforcement officials investigating, tracking, and closing reported incidents; and (6) clinical guidance for treating sexual assaults reported over 72 hours after assault.

Rocky Mountain National Park Wilderness and Indian Peaks Wilderness Expansion Act - Designates certain lands in Rocky Mountain National Park, Colorado, as wilderness and as a component of the National Wilderness Preservation System, which shall be known as the Rocky Mountain National Park Wilderness.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish an alignment line and identify the boundaries for the East Shore Trail within the East Shore Trail Area. Authorizes necessary adjustments in such boundaries, except any that would place any portion of the Trail in such Wilderness.

Directs the Attorney General to: (1) establish a program to identify from among the individuals incarcerated in local governmental incarceration facilities prior to arraignment on criminal charges those individuals who are within one or more of the following classes of deportable aliens; and (2) study and report to the Congress on the logistical and technological feasibility of implementing such program in a greater number of locations than those selected.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 13, 2011. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Veterans Education Equity Act of 2011 - (Sec. 2) Provides that, in the case of a program of education pursued at a public institution of higher learning, the lesser of the actual net cost for tuition and fees assessed by the institution for the program after the application of: (1) any waiver of, or reduction in, tuition and fees; and (2) any scholarship, or other federal, state, institutional, or employer-based aid or assistance (other than loans and any funds provided under the Higher Education Act of 1965) provided directly to the institution and specifically designated for the sole purpose of defraying tuition and fees, or the greater of any such waiver of, or reduction in, tuition and fees and any scholarship, or other federal, state, institutional, or employer-based aid or assistance (other than loans and any funds provided under the Higher Education Act of 1965) that is provided directly to the institution and specifically designated for the sole purpose of defraying tuition and fees. (Currently, the lesser of such actual net cost or any waiver of, or reduction in, tuition and fees is considered to be the cost of the program to

Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1998 - Amends the Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 to prohibit the sale, importation, and exportation of products intended for human consumption or application containing, or labeled or advertised as containing, any substance derived from any species of rhinoceros or tiger. Sets forth criminal and civil penalties for violations.

Wireless Users Interference Protection Act of 2013 - Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to: (1) expand the eligibility for part 74 licenses of the Communications Act of 1934 to the owners of, and operators of events performances at, specified sites, as well as the scope of service transmissions currently set forth in applicable regulations; and (2) establish two safe havens for exclusive use by wireless microphone users of specified spectrum frequencies. Directs the FCC to authorize the owners and operators of wireless microphones to have access to specified TV bands databases for the purpose protecting wireless microphone operations from interference interference.

Medical Device Safety Monitoring Act - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to initiate one or more pilot projects for voluntary participation by a manufacturer or manufacturers of medical device or device type, or continue existing projects, that: (1) are designed to generate reliable and timely safety and active surveillance data for use by the Secretary or manufacturers of the devices involved; (2) inform the development of methods, systems, data criteria, and programs that could be used to support safety and active surveillance activities for devices not included in the project; (3) are designed and conducted in coordination with a comprehensive system for evaluating medical device technology that operates under a governing board with appropriate representation of stakeholders, including consumer groups and device manufacturers; (4) use electronic health data including claims data, patient survey data, and any other data the Secretary determines appropriate; and (5) prioritize devices and device types for which the collection and analysis of real world evidence regarding a device's safety and effectiveness is likely to advance public health, devices and device types that are widely used, devices and device types that the failure of which has significant health consequences, and devices and device types for which the Secretary has received public recommendations and has determined to meet one of the criteria described above. Direct

Strong Forests Grow Strong Communities Act of 2014 - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to publish and submit to Congress the annual volume requirement for each unit of the National Forest System (NFS). Defines: (1) "annual volume requirement" as a volume of national forest materials no less than 50% of the sustained yield of the unit; and (2) "sustained yield" as the maximum annual growth potential of the forest calculated on the basis of the culmination of mean annual increment using cubic measurement. Prohibits the Secretary from reducing such requirement without the consent of Congress. Requires the Secretary to: (1) manage the sale of forest materials in each NFS unit in the manner necessary to meet the annual volume requirement; and (2) issue a determination explaining his or her view that a proposed sale is not likely to jeopardize the continued existence of an endangered or threatened species. Authorizes the Secretary to modify the standards and guidelines contained in the land and resource management plan for a NFS unit as necessary to meet the annual volume requirement. Requires the Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of Commerce, if the Secretary determines that a sale of forest materials may affect the continued existence of any endangered or threatened species, to issue a determination explaining his or her view that

Encouraging Work and Supporting Marriage Act of 2002 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to accelerate, from 2004 through 2009, the increase in the standard deduction for joint returns.Modifies the work opportunity credit and the welfare-to-work credit by: (1) determining eligibility of ex-felons without regard to family income; (2) increasing the maximum age for eligibility of food stamp recipients; (3) clarifying the treatment of individuals under individual work plans; and (4) providing for an increased credit for employment of long-term family assistance recipients.

Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit a telecommunications carrier or reseller from submitting or executing a change in a subscriber's selection of a provider of telephone exchange or toll service except pursuant to procedures prescribed by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). Requires the procedures prescribed by the FCC to verify a subscriber's selection of a provider to: (1) preclude the use of negative option marketing; (2) provide for verification of a change in service provider in oral, written, or electronic form; and (3) require the retention of such verification in appropriate form and for appropriate time as the FCC considers appropriate. Makes such prohibition inapplicable to a provider of commercial mobile service. <n>Requires a telecommunications carrier or reseller selected for a subscriber's selection of a provider of telephone exchange or toll service to notify the subscriber in writing, not more than 15 days after the change is processed, of: (1) the subscriber's new carrier; and (2) that the subscriber may request information regarding the date on which the change was agreed to and the name of the individual who authorized it. Directs the carrier or reseller, if it fails to resolve a complaint within specified time periods, to: (1) notify the subscriber in writing of the subscriber's right to file a complaint with the FCC concerning

Federal Employees Health Benefits Provider Integrity Amendments of 1997 - Amends Federal civil service law with respect to the debarment and other sanctions of providers providing health care services to Federal employees under the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHBP). Defines should know" to mean that a person acts in deliberate ignorance of, or in reckless disregard of, the truth or falsity of the information, and no proof of specific intent to defraud is required. <n>Directs the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to bar from FEHBP participation any provider: (1) whose license to provide health care services or supplies has been revoked, suspended, restricted, or not renewed by a State licensing authority for reasons relating to the provider\\'s professional competence, professional performance, or financial integrity; (2) that surrendered such a license while a formal disciplinary proceeding was pending before such authority, if the proceeding concerned the provider\\'s professional competence, professional performance, or financial integrity; (3) that is an entity directly or indirectly owned, or with a five percent or more controlling interest, by an individual who is convicted of any such offense, or who has been debarred; or (4) that an individual who directly or indirectly owns or has a controlling interest in the entity and who knows or"

Federal Employee Rights Act - Amends Federal law to prohibit Federal agencies from deducting labor organization fees from the salaries of their employees. Declares that dues collected by a labor organization may not be used for any purpose not directly related to the organization's collective bargaining activities on behalf of the employee unless, after a notice period of at least 35 days, the employee authorizes such use in writing. Declares that such authorization shall: (1) expire not later than one year after the date on which it is signed by the employee; and (2) not provide for an automatic renewal of any authorization. Amends the Postal Service Act to prohibit a labor organization from using dues collected by it for any purpose not directly related to the organization's collective bargaining activities on behalf of the employee unless, after a notice period of at least 35 days, the employee authorizes such use in writing.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to suspend excise taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene from May 26, 2008, until September 1, 2008. Provides for the reimbursement of the Highway Trust Fund and the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund for tax receipts lost during the period.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 5, 2006. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Puget Sound Regional Shellfish Settlement Act of 2006 - (Sec. 4) Approves and confirms the Settlement Agreement entered into by and among the Confederated Tribes of the Puget Sound Shellfish Settlement Fund, the Puget Sound Shellfish Growers, the state of Washington, and the United States regarding implementation of the Tribes' treaty right to take shellfish from covered tidelands owned, leased, or otherwise subject to harvest by commercial shellfish growers (agreement). Provides that the Agreement establishes a legally enforceable treaty right to take shellfish from covered tidelands described in the Agreement within 20 years after the deposit of funds in the Settlement Agreement, owned, leased, or otherwise subject to harvest by certain persons or entities that qualify as Growers. (Sec. 5) Establishes in the Treasury the Puget Sound Shellfish Settlement Trust Fund Account, the Special Holding Account, and the Puget Sound Shellfish Settlement Fund Account. Provides for the deposit of funds into such Accounts.

Enhancing America's Security Through Strategic Redeployment from Iraq Act - Declares that it is critical that a comprehensive security plan is developed for Iraq and the region that accepts the necessity for a deliberate redeployment of U.S. forces from Iraq.Requires the redeployment of U.S. Armed Forces serving in Iraq as part of Operation Iraqi Freedom to begin within three months after enactment of this Act.

Military Spouses Residency Relief Act - Amends the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act to provide that, for the purposes of voting for any Federal, State, or local office, a person who is absent from a State because the person is accompanying the person's spouse who is absent from that same State in compliance with military or naval orders shall not, solely by reason of that absence, be deemed to have: (1) lost a residence or domicile in that State, without regard to whether or not the person intends to return to that State; (2) acquired a residence or domicile in any other State; or (3) become a resident in or a resident of any other State.<n><n>Provides that a spouse of a servicemember shall neither lose nor acquire a residence or domicile for purposes of taxation with respect to the person, personal property, or income of the spouse by reason of being absent or present in any tax jurisdiction of the United States solely to be with the servicemember in compliance with the servicemember's military orders if the residence or domicile, as the case may be, is the same for the servicemember and the spouse.<n><n>Provides that income for services performed by the spouse of a servicemember shall not be deemed to be income for services performed or from sources within a tax

(Sec. 2) Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award grants to at least 50 local educational agencies (LEAs) for a fiscal year to enable the LEA to award bonuses to highly qualified individuals who agree to teach in elementary schools or secondary schools served by the LEA and located in high poverty areas, for a period of at least four years. <n>Makes an LEA eligible for such a grant if: (1) at least 20 percent of the children in the schools served by the LEA are eligible to be counted under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA); or (2) the LEA is eligible to be counted under ESEA 10952 of such Act. <n>Sets forth grant amounts for each LEA with an enrollment of: (1) 1,500 or fewer students; (2) 1,501 but less than 5,001 students; (3) 5,001 but less than 15,001 students; and (4) 15,001 students. <n>(Sec. 3) Requires each LEA receiving such a grant to use funds made available under this Act to: (1) award bonuses to highly qualified individuals who agree to teach in elementary schools or secondary schools in which at least 40 percent of the children are eligible to be counted under ESEA; (2) award the bonuses on a competitive basis taking

Makes appropriations for FY2009-FY2013 for Department of Defense (DOD) procurement of Army National Guard and Air National Guard equipment reset requirements, as well as other equipment procurement and resets, for the Army National Guard and Air National Guard.

Otay Mountain Wilderness Act of 1998 - Designates specified public lands in the California Desert District of the Bureau of Land Management as the Otay Mountain Wilderness. <n>Recognizes that the Congress does not intend for such designation to lead to the creation of protective perimeters or buffer zones around the Wilderness Area.

Freedom to Serve Without Fear Act of 2011 - Amends the federal criminal code to prohibit any person, in or affecting interstate or foreign commerce, from knowingly carrying a firearm: (1) in, or within 250 feet of an entrance to or exit from, a building or structure where the person knows that a Member of Congress is performing an official and representational duty, engaging in campaign activity as a candidate for election for federal office, or engaging in campaign activity as a candidate for election for state or local office; or (2) at, or within 500 feet of, any other place where the person knows that such Member is performing such a duty or engaging in such a campaign activity, if there is visible, at each place that is at the applicable distance from the building, structure, or other place, a sign which clearly and conspicuously states that such Member will be present at that place and so states the time interval during which the Member is scheduled to be so present. Provides exceptions.

Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2009 or the CARE for Kids Act of 2009- Amends the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 to require states that receive funds under such Act to require a state and national criminal background check for a child care staff member of a child care provider. Requires the background check to include searches of: (1) the National Sex Offender Registry established pursuant to the Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006; (2) the National Crime Information Center; (3) the state criminal registry or repository in the state in which the child care staff member resides and each state where such staff member previously resided; (4) state-based abuse and neglect registries and databases; (5) a search of state-based abuse and neglect registries and databases of each state where the child care staff member previously resided; and (6) the Federal Bureau of Investigation fingerprint check using the Integrated Automated Fingerprint Identification System. Defines child care provider" as a person that provides child care services or engages in the provision of child care services to children. Prohibits: (1) a child care provider from receiving a child care certificate as payment for child care services if any such background check reveals a felony conviction for child abuse or neglect, spousal abuse, a crime against children, violent crimes, or a drug-"

This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to implement a structured risk-benefit assessment framework in the new drug approval process to facilitate the balanced consideration of benefits and risks and to develop and implement a consistent and systematic approach to the discussion of, regulatory decisionmaking with respect to, and the communication of the benefits and risks of new drugs. Patients' experience data may be developed and used to enhance the framework. The FDA must establish and implement processes under which an entity seeking to develop patient experience data may submit to the FDA: (1) initial research concepts for feedback; and (2) draft guidance documents, completed data, and summaries and analyses of such data.

Small Business Employment and Education Enhancement Act of 2001 - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) locally-driven initiatives to improve education are crucial; (2) the views of small business should be taken into account in the debate over education; (3) in order to create jobs, our Nation must encourage small business expansion and foster small business entrepreneurship and job creation; (4) the Department of Education should facilitate the sharing of ideas and best practices at the State and local level, particularly with respect to partnerships between small businesses and school systems; and (5) when and where Department approval of a program or proposal is required, the Department should expedite approval of such programs or proposals.Directs the Secretary of Education to disseminate information and facilitate the sharing of information designed to assist small businesses in working with school systems to improve the education system through publication of guidance materials, best practices, checklists, and other formats on the World Wide Web.Directs the Secretary to establish a centralized database of materials to act as a clearinghouse for information on successful initiatives and best practices regarding the involvement of small businesses in education.Establishes in the Department an Office of Small Business Education, administered by the Director of Small Business Education.

Medicaid Fraud Recovery Act of 2008 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to provide that nothing in the Medicaid program shall be construed as preventing a county or other local government from establishing a local fraud investigative unit to investigate and prosecute provider and recipient fraud within its jurisdiction. Requires a state state plan for medical assistance payments to recognize and permit its operations in accordance with this Act.

Transfers administrative jurisdiction over specified lands in New Mexico and Washington (including the sand, gravel, or similar mineral material resources) from the Secretary of the Interior to the Secretary of the Air Force. Withdraws such lands from all forms of appropriation under the mining laws and the mineral and geothermal leasing laws. Authorizes the Secretary to use such resources, without application to the Secretary of the Interior, when required for construction needs on the Range.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2016. Low Volume Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Transportation (DOT) to exempt from federal motor vehicle safety standards up to 500 replica motor vehicles per year manufactured or imported by a low volume manufacturer (defined as a manufacturer whose annual worldwide production is not more than 5,000 motor vehicles). A low volume manufacturer is defined as a motor vehicle manufacturer, other than a person who is registered as an importer, whose annual worldwide production is not more than 5,000 motor vehicles. To qualify for an exemption, the manufacturer must register with DOT. DOT shall require a manufacturer to affix a permanent label to an exempt motor vehicle that identifies the specified standards and regulations for which such vehicle is exempt and designates the model year such vehicle replicates. DOT may require a manufacturer to deliver written notice of the exemption to: (1) the dealer; and (2) the first purchaser of the motor vehicle, if the first purchaser is not an individual that purchases the motor vehicle for resale. A low volume manufacturer shall annually submit a report on the number and description of the motor vehicles exempted and a list of the exemptions described on the label affixed to the exempt motor vehicle. Any motor vehicle exempted from

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 16, 2015. Service for Schools Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the National and Community Service Act of 1990 to direct the Corporation for National and Community Service to establish a Service Opportunity Registry of national service opportunities for which individuals may receive compensation of up to $10.00 per hour for completing 2000 qualifying hours of service, if the opportunity meets an unmet human, educational, environmental, or public safety need in a high-need community with an inadequate number of such professionals. The Registry must be made available to the public through a National Service for Schools website. A listed organization that offers an eligible service opportunity must re-apply at least every two years. A state must participate in the program carried out under this Act in order for students in the state to participate and receive credit.

Accuracy in Medicare Physician Payment Act of 2013 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish an expert outside advisory panel for purposes of providing oversight to the processes of identifying, reviewing, and adjusting valuations for physicians' services, including by: (1) establishing screens for identifying physicians' services for which there are potentially misvalued codes for review; (2) collecting data and developing supporting evidence relating to the valuation of physicians' services; (3) conducting surveys of suppliers of physicians' services; (4) transmitting codes for review and recommendations; and (5) evaluating recommendations submitted.

Head Start Assessment Act of 2005 - Prohibits the Secretary of Health and Human Services from proceeding with the full-scale implementation of the Head Start National Reporting System on Child Outcomes until the Secretary certifies to Congress that: (1) congressional oversight hearings have been concluded concerning such development and implementation; (2) public forums have been concluded concerning early childhood assessment proposals; and (3) the Secretary has submitted to Congress a study of early childhood assessments focusing on improving accountability, instruction, and the delivery of services. Requires the Secretary to request the National Academy of Sciences to prepare such study using a panel of nationally recognized experts in early childhood assessment, child development, and education.

Health Care OverUse Reform Today Act (HealthCOURT Act) of 2011 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to provide for the selection and issuance of best practice guidelines for treatment of medical conditions. Prohibits a court in a health care lawsuit from awarding noneconomic damages with respect to treatment that is consistent with such guidelines. Prohibits the award of punitive damages against a health care provider based on a claim that medical treatment caused the claimant harm if the treatment: (1) was subject to quality review by a qualified physician consensus-building organization and has been found to be safe, effective, and appropriate; (2) was approved in a guideline that underwent full review by such organization, public comment, the Secretary's approval, and dissemination as described in this Act; or (3) is generally recognized among qualified experts as safe, effective, and appropriate. Specifies that such guidelines may not be introduced as evidence of negligence or deviation in the standard of care unless they have previously been introduced by the defendant. Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary to award grants to states for the development, implementation, and evaluation of administrative health care tribunals that comply with such guidelines for the resolution of disputes concerning injuries allegedly caused by health care providers.

Drug Abuse Treatment on Demand Assistance Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make grants to increase the maximum number of individuals to whom public and nonprofit private entities are capable of providing effective treatment for substance abuse, with the goal of ensuring that substance abuse treatment is available for all substance abusers who seek it. Authorizes appropriations.Requires grants to be made to eligible States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico.

National September 11 Memorial & Museum Commemorative Medal Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury: (1) to strike and make available for sale not more than 2 million silver medals emblematic of the courage, sacrifice, and strength of those individuals who perished in the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, the bravery of those who risked their lives to save others that day, and the endurance, resilience, and hope of those who survived; and (2) in commemoration of the 10th anniversary of such attacks, to strike and make available for sale only two facilities of the United States Mint.<n><n>Expresses the sense of Congress that, to the extent possible, approximately one-half of the medals to be struck should be struck at the U.S. Mint at West Point, New York, and approximately one-half struck at the U.S. Mint at Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.<n><n>Terminates such authority after December 31, 2012.<n><n>Requires all sales of the medals to include a surcharge of $10 per medal, to be paid to the National September 11 Memorial & Museum at the World Trade Center to maintain maintenance operations of the National September 11 Memorial & Museum at the World Trade Center.

Debt Collection Act Amendments of 1993 - Amends Federal law to require a Federal agency to: (1) make debt collection available to executive or legislative agencies; (2) require collection of debt under salary offsets; (3) disclose to consumer reporting agencies information regarding debt amounts and the administrative offsets available to such agencies; and (4) report to the Internal Revenue Service of debt amounts paid in full. <n>Requires the Comptroller General to: (1) annually conduct audits of Federal agencies to determine the amount of debt owed to each agency, the amount of debt owed to the agency that is delinquent, and any action taken by the agency to recover the delinquent debt; and (2) report annually to the Congress on audits and agency actions to recover delinquent debt. <n>Repeals provisions allowing an extension of the pilot debt collection project. <n>Requires the head of an agency to prohibit loans to a loan applicant until the applicant has been prescreened to determine if the applicant is creditworthy. Requires recovered funds to be used to reduce U.S. budget deficit. <n>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require disclosure of debt address information by Internal Revenue Service personnel. <n>Prohibits the head of an agency from making a loan to a loan applicant until the applicant has been prescreened to determine if the applicant

Social Security Trust Funds Management Act of 1999 - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to authorize the Managing Trustee of the Board of Trustees of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund (social security trust funds) to invest such portion of such social security trust funds as is not required to meet current withdrawals only in interest-bearing obligations of the United States or obligations guaranteed by the United States on original issue or at the market price. Authorizes the Managing Trustee to purchase interest-bearing obligations of the United States or obligations guaranteed by the United States on original issue or at the market price if the Managing Trustee determines that the purchase is in the best interest of paying current and future benefits under OASDI and will not jeopardize the payment of such benefits. Declares that, in investing contributions made to the trust funds, the Managing Trustee may not invest such contributions in private financial markets. Prohibits the Managing Trustee or any other Federal officer or employee from directing private pension plans as to what type of investments to make or in which financial markets to invest. Specifies the purposes for which obligations of the United States may be issued under Federal law to authorize the issuance at

Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to establish a grant program for gifted and talented students. Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make competitive or formula grants to State educational agencies for development or expansion of gifted and talented education programs, and direct educational services and materials.

Provide for the Common Defense Act of 2013 - Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 (Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act) to eliminate for FY2014-FY2015 reductions in the discretionary spending limits for the revised security category. Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to: (1) increase the applicable percentage used to calculate Medicare part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance) premiums for high-income beneficiaries, and (2) increase the Medicare part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) deductible for new enrollees.

. Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) of the Department of Labor to prepare and publish a monthly Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers (CPIEC) that indicates changes over time in expenditures for consumption which are typical for individuals aged 62 years of age or older. This bill amends titles II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) and XVIII (Medicare) to use such new CPIEC in the computation of cost-of-living increases for Social Security and Medicare benefits, replacing the CPI for All Urban Consumers (U.S. city average).

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on December 10, 2014. United States Secret Service Accountability and Improvement Act of 2014 - (Sec. 3) Establishes in the legislative branch an independent advisory panel to: (1) examine the efficiency and effectiveness of the leadership structure, protocols, training tools, and capabilities of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS)'s mission to protect national leaders visiting heads of state and government, designated sites, and special events of significance; and (2) make recommendations to improve the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the United States Secret Service. (Sec. 4) Sets forth procedures for the appointment of panel members.

United States Employee Ownership Bank Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to establish the United States Employee Ownership Bank to foster increased employee ownership and greater employee participation in company decision-making throughout the United States.Requires the Bank to make: (1) loans, loan guarantees, and technical assistance to employees to purchase a business through an employee stock ownership plan or eligible worker-owned cooperative that are at least 51 percent employee owned; (2) grants to states and nonprofit and cooperative organizations with experience in developing employee-owned businesses and worker-owned cooperatives to provide education, outreach, and technical assistance to assist employee efforts to become business owners; (3) grants to states and nonprofit and cooperative organizations with experience in developing employee-owned businesses and worker-owned cooperatives to provide participation training to teach employees and employers methods of employee participation in company decision-making; and (4) grants to states and nonprofit and cooperative organizations with experience in developing employee-owned businesses and worker-owned cooperatives to conduct pre-feasibility and feasibility studies to determine if employees who would like to start-up employee stock ownership plans or worker cooperatives would be able to make a profit.Requires the Bank to insure such loans or loan guarantees against nonrepayment of the outstanding loan balance.

Empowerment of Iraqi Women Act of 2006 - Directs the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) to establish a fund to assist women and girls in Iraq in the areas of political, legal, and human rights, health care, education, training, security, and shelter. Requires that at least 15% of the aggregate amount of economic and humanitarian assistance authorized for Iraq for FY2007-FY2009 be made available for assistance directly to Iraqi-led local nongovernmental organizations, including Iraqi women-led organizations.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an individual a deduction for qualified postsecondary education expenses of the taxpayer, or an individual who is the spouse or a dependent of the taxpayer, for attendance at an eligible educational institution. Limits the per student deduction to $10,000 and the per taxpayer deduction to $20,000.

Border Health Security Act of 2015 This bill amends the United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act to revise the duties of the United States-Mexico Border Health Commission to include: cooperating with the Canada-United States Pan-Border Public Health Preparedness Council, and serving as an independent and objective body to both recommend and implement initiatives that solve border health issues. Members of the Commission and the Council may at any time provide advice or recommendations to the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) or any Member of Congress concerning issues that are considered by the Commission or Council. HHS shall award grants to states, local governments, Indian tribes, tribal organizations, urban Indian organizations, nonprofit health organizations, trauma centers, or community health centers located in the United States-Mexico or the United States-Canada border areas to improve the health of residents in such areas.

Directs the Secretary of Energy, at least every five years, to conduct a survey to determine the 10 highest-priority energy-related problems to resolve to ensure the goals of: (1) maximizing the energy security of the United States; (2) maximizing improvements in energy efficiency within the United States; and (3) minimizing damage to the economy and the environment. Requires each survey to contain a request that the respondent list, in descending order of priority, the ten highest-priority problems that require resolution as quickly as practicable to ensure the goals.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to: (1) announce the existence of each survey by publishing an announcement in the Federal Register and placing an announcement on the homepage of the Department of Energy (DOE) website; (2) ensure that each survey is made available in an electronic format only through a link on DOE's website; (3) require each respondent to provide information regarding age, occupational category, country of residence, and employer; and (4) ensure that each survey is conducted in a transparent, nonpolitical manner and without any political bias. Requires the Secretary to submit a report to Congress and make it available to the public including a list of the ten highest-priority problems based on all responses to the survey.

Financial Literacy and Education Coordinating Act of 2003 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to establish within the Office of Financial Education of the Department of the Treasury the Financial Literacy and Education Coordinating Committee to: (1) coordinate financial literacy and education efforts among Federal departments and agencies; (2) develop and implement a national strategy to promote basic financial literacy and education among all Americans; (3) reduce overlap and duplication in Federal financial literacy and education activities; (4) identify the most effective types of public sector financial literacy programs and techniques, as measured by improved consumer decision making; (5) coordinate and promote financial literacy efforts at the State and local level; and (6) carry out other appropriate duties consistent with this Act.

Purchase Card Waste Elimination Act of 2006 - Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to issue guidelines to assist executive agencies in improving the management of the use of the governmentwide commercial purchase card for making micropurchases, including guidelines on: (1) analysis of purchase card expenditures to identify opportunities for achieving savings through micropurchases made in economical volumes; (2) negotiation of discount agreements with major vendors accepting the card; (3) establishment of communication programs to ensure that purchase card holders receive information pertaining to the availability of discounts; (4) assessment of cardholder purchasing practices; (5) collection and dissemination of best practices and successful strategies for achieving savings in micropurchases; and (6) analysis of purchase card expenditures to identify opportunities for achieving and accurately measuring fair participation of small business concerns in micropurchases consistent with the national policy on small business participation in federal procurements.<n><n>Requires: (1) the Administrator of the General Services Administration (GSA) to continue efforts to improve reporting by financial institutions that issue the card so that the GSA has the data needed to identify opportunities for achieving savings; and (2) actively pursue point-of-sale discounts with major vendors accepting the card so that any federal purchaser using the card can benefit from such point-of-sale discounts.<n><n>Requires the Director to

Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Public Health Service Act to allow the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make grants to states which prohibit the sale or distribution of tobacco products to individuals under the age of 18 only if the state involved has in effect a law providing that: (1) it is unlawful for any manufacturer, retailer, or distributor of tobacco products to sell or distribute such product to any individual under 18 years of age; (2) it is unlawful for such an individual to purchase or receive, or attempt to receive, a tobacco product; (3) a law enforcement agency, upon determining that an individual under 18 allegedly purchased or received a tobacco product, or allegedly possessed a tobacco product in a public place, to notify the individual's parent or parents, custodian, or guardian; (4) any person engaged in the business of distributing tobacco products at retail to implement a program to notify each employee employed by that person who distributes tobacco products that state law prohibits the sale or distribution of tobacco products to any individual under 18 years of age and the purchase or receipt, or possession, in a public place, of tobacco products by any such individual; (5) an employer shall not be in violation of such prohibition if such employer relies upon proof of age that

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on September 6, 2017. Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Transportation (DOT) to establish a transformational infrastructure competitive grant program to award grants to state and local governments, transit agencies, and port authorities for certain public transportation projects (including water infrastructure projects) that will significantly impact a metropolitan area, a region, or all of the United States. The bill sets forth criteria for making such grants. None of the funds made available for a project under this bill may be used for it unless all of the iron, steel, and manufactured goods used in the project are produced in the United States. This prohibition shall not apply in cases where: applying it would be inconsistent with the public interest; iron, steel, or the relevant manufactured goods are not produced in the United States in sufficient and reasonably available quantities or to a satisfactory quality; or inclusion of such goods will increase the cost of the overall project by more than 25%.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 8, 2013. Humanitarian Assistance Facilitation Act of 2013 - Expresses the sense of Congress that humanitarian assistance should not be prohibited or restricted from being provided in al-controlled areas of Somalia (as defined by the International Emergency Economic Powers Act) while empowering terrorist organizations that became the sole conduit of accessing aid to the people of Somalia, while providing them with life-saving aid. Amends the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to authorize the President to restrict or prohibit transactions by a foreign person subject to U.S. jurisdiction with sanctions that are customary, necessary, and incidental to the donation or provision of goods or services by the person to prevent or alleviate the suffering of civilian populations, if the person subject to such sanctions has acted in good faith to achieve such purposes and has used its best efforts to minimize any such consequences. States that nothing in this Act shall be construed to prohibit the provision of humanitarian assistance by any person subject to sanctions under the Act.

Child Protection Compact Act of 2011 - Authorizes the Secretary of State to provide assistance to Tier 2 or Tier 2 Watch List countries (as defined by this Act) to improve child protection and prevent child exploitation within such countries. Defines severe forms of trafficking in persons" as sex trafficking in which a person induced to perform such act has not attained 18 years of age or the recruitment, harboring, transportation, provision, or obtaining of a person for labor or services through the use of force, fraud, or coercion for the purpose of subjection to involuntary, peonage, debt bondage, or slavery."

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 13, 2014. A's Law of 2014 - Directs the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) to withhold specified graduated percentages of a state's apportionment of certain federal-aid highway funds for FY2015-FY2017 if the state has not enacted and is not enforcing a law requiring the installation of an ignition interlock device for a minimum of 180 days on each motor vehicle operated by an individual convicted of driving while intoxicated or driving under the influence (having a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or greater).
