This bill directs the Department of Transportation (DOT) to make appropriate arrangements with the Transportation Research Board of the National Academies to study the cost and impact of rerouting freight rail traffic containing hazardous material to avoid transportation of such hazardous material through urban areas.

Prohibits the President from imposing a new unilateral agricultural sanction or a new unilateral sanction with respect to medicine, medical supplies, or medical equipment against a foreign country, unless: (1) at least 60 days before such sanction is proposed, the President submits a report to Congress that describes the activity proposed to be prohibited, restricted, or conditioned and describes the actions by the foreign country that justify the sanction; and (2) Congress enacts a joint resolution stating congressional approval of such report. Authorizes the President to impose such a sanction: (1) against a foreign country if Congress has enacted a declaration of war or proclaimed a state of national emergency; or (2) to the extent that the sanction would prohibit, restrict, or condition the provision or use of any commodity, product, medicine, supply, or equipment that is controlled on the United States Munitions List under the Arms Export Control Act or the Commerce Control List under the Export Administration Act of 1979.

Amends title IV (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) (TANF) of the Social Security Act to establish the Emergency Contingency Fund for State Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Programs for the purpose of grants to states by the Secretary of the Treasury related to: (1) increases in TANF caseloads, and (2) increased expenditures for non-recurrent short term benefits.

Directs the U.S. Customs and Border Protection to provide for the liquidation or reliquidation of certain entries of stainless steel cookingWARE entered from the Republic of Korea between January 1, 1999, and January 22, 2003.

Foreign Investment Transparency and Security Act of 2006 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to authorize a foreign government controlled entity to acquire, own, or otherwise control or manage any critical infrastructure of the United States only through the establishment or operation of a foreign owned general business corporation meeting specified requirements.

Authorizes each federal financial regulator to exercise oversight and carry out regulatory or oversight activity over: (1) any swap agreement entered into, purchased, or sold (or as to which the transaction, purchase, or sale is effected) by any financial institution, entity, or person subject to the regulator's jurisdiction; and (2) any swap agreement that is subject to such regulator's jurisdiction. Directs the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) to exercise such oversight and carry out regulatory or oversight activity over any: (1) exchange or clearing agency; and (2) trading facility or registered entity.

Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2015 This bill amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to require institutions of higher education (IHEs) to submit to the Department of Education (ED) data that the ED determines to be sufficient to complete all student components of reporting required for the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS). ED shall issue guidance outlining which data metrics IHEs are required to submit that are duplicative of title IV reporting requirements. An IHE shall, within five years after this bill's enactment: (1) not be required to make available such duplicative requirements, and (2) provide a prominently displayed link on its website to the IHE's IPEDS website. Each IHE shall submit to ED data sufficient to complete all student components of reporting required for IPEDS. ED shall: (1) establish common definitions for IHEs to follow in submitting the data required under this bill, and (2) determine collection and submission requirements. The ED shall require IHEs to submit student-level components of IPEDS to enable coding and reporting on: (1) students who participate in remedial education; (2) whether, and at what level, the student is seeking a degree; and (3)

Supporting America's Young Entrepreneurs Act of 2016 This bill amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to declare that a borrower of a loan under the William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan program shall be eligible for: (1) deferment, during which periodic installments of principal and interest need not be paid, during any period not in excess of three years during which the borrower is employed as a founder of a small business start-up; and (2) loan cancellation on any eligible Direct Loan not in default for a borrower who has made 24 monthly payments and is employed as such a founder in a distressed area during the period in which the borrower makes each of the 24 payments. The Department of Education (ED) shall cancel: (1) $20,000 of the balance of interest and principal due on such loans, and (2) $3,000 of the balance of interest and principal due on any eligible Direct Loan not in default for a borrower who has made 12 monthly payments after enactment of this bill pursuant to any one or a combination of payments under a repayment plan.

Catching Operational Vulnerabilities by Ensuring Random Testing Act of 2008 or the COVERT Act of 2008 - Amends the Aviation and Transportation Security Act to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to ensure that information concerning a covert test of a transportation security system to be conducted by a covert testing office, the Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), or the Government Accountability Office (GAO) is not provided to any individual prior to the completion of the test. Makes exceptions where: (1) an individual may provide information concerning such a test to federal employees, officers, and contractors, state and local government employees and officials, and law enforcement officials; and (2) for the purpose of ensuring the security of any individual in the vicinity of a test site, an individual conducting the test may disclose his or her status as an individual conducting the test to any appropriate individual if a security screener or other individual who is not a covered employee identifies the individual conducting the test as a potential threat. Requires: (1) the head of each covert testing office to ensure that a person or group of persons conducting a covert test of a transportation security system is accompanied at the test site by a cover team to monitor and confirm the identity of test personnel; and (2) a cover team to monitor and confirm the

Care Coordination for Older Americans Act of 2012 - Amends the Older Americans Act of 1965 to define care coordination" as a person- and family-centered, assessment-based, and interdisciplinary approach to meet the needs and preferences of an older individual and a family caregiver while enhancing the individual\\'s capabilities, including the ability to self-direct services. Directs the Assistant Secretary of Aging to: (1) encourage, provide technical assistance to, and share best practices with, states, area agencies on aging, Aging and Disability Resource Centers, and service providers to carry out outreach and coordinate activities with health care entities in order to assure better care coordination for individuals with multiple chronic illnesses; and (2) coordinate activities with other federal agencies that are working to improve care coordination and developing new models and best practices. Requires the state agency submitting a state plan for Older Americans to promote the development and implementation of a state system to address the care coordination needs of older individuals with multiple chronic illnesses and work with acute care providers, area agencies on aging, service providers, and federal agencies to ensure that the system uses best practices and is evaluated on its provision of care coordination. Requires area agencies on aging to provide assurances that they will identify existing care coordination programs and systems and work with acute care providers, area"

Bond Financing Renewal Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) increase the amount of qualified small issue bonds permitted for facilities to be used by related principal users from $10 million to $20 million, with an inflation adjustment beginning in 2004; and (2) include within the definition of manufacturing facility" certain software and biobased products. Defines "financial institution" for purposes of the exclusion from gross income of interest on qualified small issue bonds."

Freedom and Human Rights for the enclaved people of Cyprus Act - Directs the President to: (1) inform the United Nations, foreign governments, and the appropriate Federal departments and agencies of the Government of the restrictions on the enclaved people of Cyprus; (2) enlist the United Nations and foreign governments in efforts to end such restrictions; and (3) establish U.S. Government programs of assistance to such people, including programs to return ancestral homes and lands to them, in order to alleviate and eliminate restrictions on their freedom and human rights. <n>Directs the President to: (1) notify each fiscal year of any foreign country that is participating in restrictions on the freedom and human rights of the enclaved people of Cyprus of the opposition by the United States to such country's participation; and (2) urge such country's head of government to cease such participation and work to eliminate such restrictions. <n>Requires the President to direct the U.S. representative to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to: (1) urge the Commissioner to investigate the plight of those enclaved people on Cyprus and to implement appropriate and effective corrective action; and (2) call upon the U.N. Human Rights Commissioner to support such investigation. <n>Authorizes the President to waive the requirements of this Act if in the

Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to carry out an Early Federal Pell Grant Commitment Demonstration Program under which the Secretary: (1) awards grants to four state educational agencies (SEAs) to pay the administrative expenses incurred in participating in the program; and (2) awards Federal Pell Grants to participating students.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior to convey to Lake Gulch, Inc., a Colorado corporation, specified lands in Gilpin County, Colorado, in exchange for: (1) certain lands comprising approximately 40 acres located in Larimer County, Colorado, within the boundaries of Rocky Mountain National Park; (2) certain lands located along the Arkansas River in Lake County, Colorado; and (3) certain lands located within and adjacent to the United States Bureau of Land Management San Luis Resource Area in Conejos County, Colorado. <n>Directs the Secretary to notify and consult with the County and City and afford such units of local government the opportunity to acquire or reserve easements or rights-of-way parallel to North Clear Creek in Gilpin, Colorado, prior to transferring any lands which are contiguous to North Clear Creek out of public ownership. <n>Expresses that the exchange will be consummated if within 90 days after enactment of this Act.

Children\\'s Education Tax Credit Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish a tax credit (up to $450 per student) for the qualified educational expenses of a taxpayer, the taxpayer\\'s spouse, or any individual with respect to whom the taxpayer is allowed a deduction for qualified higher education expenses.Defines qualified education expenses" as amounts paid for tuition and fees required for the enrollment or attendance of a student at an eligible educational institution (including a vocational school, an elementary school, or a secondary school) and fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for courses of instruction at such an institution. Excludes meals, lodging, or similar expenses from the definition of "qualified education expenses.""

Marine Mammal Protection Act Amendments of 2002 - (Sec. 3) Amends the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 to replace references to the Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries with references to the Committee on Resources.(Sec. 4) Authorizes the export of a marine mammal product from the United States if it is: (1) legally possessed and exported as part of a cultural exchange by an Indian, Aleut, or Eskimo residing in Alaska; or (2) owned by a Native inhabitant of Russia, Canada, or Greenland and exported for noncommercial purposes in conjunction with travel within the United States or as part of a cultural exchange with such an Indian, Aleut, or Eskimo.(Sec. 5) Authorizes appropriations to the Department of Commerce for the purposes of carrying out obligations under such Act.Authorizes appropriations to the Department of the Interior for the purposes of carrying out obligations under such Act.(Sec. 6) Requires the Secretary of the Interior, before publishing any take reduction plan that is different from the draft plan proposed by a take reduction team, to reconvene the team and explain to it the differences between the published plan and the draft plan proposed. Requires such a team to include observer, research, and education and outreach programs.(Sec. 7) Authorizes appropriations to the Department

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Offense Victim Exoneration Act of 2017 (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Director General of the Foreign Service and the Director of Human Resources of the Department of State to review all employee terminations for perceived sexual orientation after January 1, 1950, to determine who was wrongfully terminated for their sexual orientation and their impact on U.S. lives and policies. The Director General and the Director of Human Resources must: (1) compile reviews of related complaints and report to Congress; (2) inform employees who experienced sexual orientation termination because of the actual testimony in order to receive an official record of their termination and the impact of such termination on U.S. lives and policies; and (3) establish within the Office of Civil Rights of the State Department a special measure of responsibility to inform and encourage congressional investigations into their employment of their sexual orientation or of their family members in light of such reports. The bill also requires the Department to report annually to Congress for two years on these findings.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for 50 percent of the cost of qualified advanced mine safety equipment property. Defines such property as any of the following: (1) an emergency communication technology or device for constant communication with individuals outside the mine; (2) an electronic identification and location device; (3) an emergency oxygen-generating device; (4) pre-positioned oxygen supplies; and (5) a comprehensive atmospheric monitoring system to monitor levels of carbon monoxide and other gases present in a mine.

Authorizes the Secretary of Education to waive or modify any statutory or regulatory provision applicable to the student financial assistance programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (HEA), or any student or institutional eligibility provisions, as the Secretary deems necessary in connection with a Gulf hurricane disaster, to ensure that: (1) the calculation of expected family contribution in the determination of need for student financial assistance under title IV is modified to reflect any changes in the financial condition of affected students and their families resulting from a Gulf hurricane disaster; and (2) institutions of higher education, systems of institutions, or consortia of such institutions located in an area affected by the disaster, or that are serving affected students, are eligible to apply for participation in the distance education demonstration program.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to cancel any obligation of an affected institution to return or repay any funds it received before the enactment of this Act for, or on behalf of, its students under the Federal Family Education Loan, Direct Loan, and Perkins Loan programs for any cancelled enrollment period.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to discharge all loan amounts under title IV of the HEA, and cancel any loan made under title IV, disbursed to, or on behalf of, an affected student for a cancelled enrollment period.

Legally Binding Budget Act of 2013 - Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 (CBA) to require joint budget resolutions signed by the President instead of the concurrent resolutions now required (which do not have to be signed by the President). Revises accordingly the congressional procedures for considering joint budget resolutions. Prohibits the consideration of budget-related legislation before the joint budget resolution becomes law. Requires the joint budget resolution to set forth appropriate levels for the fiscal year beginning on October 1 of such year and for at least each of the four ensuing fiscal years for the public debt limit for display purposes only. Permits revisions of joint budget resolutions already enacted. Makes a conforming amendment to the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. Makes it out of order in both chambers to consider any joint budget resolution, amendment, or conference report that contains certain matter prohibited by the CBA, particularly inclusion in the surplus or deficit totals of any outlays and revenue totals of the Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance (OASDI) program under title II of the Social Security Act. Considers the joint budget resolution as enforceable upon enactment or 15 days following presentment to the President, whichever occurs earlier. (Thus creates an automatic standing order upon a presidential veto of a joint budget

Meat Promotion Act of 2005 - Amends the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a voluntary country of origin labeling program for ground beef, ground pork, ground lamb, and fresh muscle cuts of beef, pork, and lamb. Sets forth limitations on the use of the United States as country of origin for covered meat products.

Building Energy Tax Credit Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a business-related tax credit for 35% of the cost of energy conservation commercial building property. Limits the amount of such credit to $4.00 per square footage of the building.

Agricultural Credit Act of 2001 - Amends the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act to exclude from the definition of debt forgiveness" any consolidation, rescheduling, reamortization, or deferral of a loan, any write-down during the borrower\\'s lifetime relating to a natural disaster or a medical condition of the borrower or an immediate family member, or any write-down provided as part of a resolution of a discrimination complaint against the Secretary of Agriculture.Prohibits the Secretary from making or guaranteeing a loan to a borrower who has received debt forgiveness on a loan made or guaranteed under the Act on more than two occasions. Authorizes the Secretary to make a direct or guaranteed farm operating loan for paying annual farm or ranch operating expenses of a borrower who: (1) was restructured with a write-down under this Act; or (2) is current on payments under a confirmed reorganization plan.(Sec. 4) Authorizes excess funds allocated for socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers to be pooled and rcated for use of such farmers and ranchers in other States in excess of the funds otherwise allocated.(Sec. 5) Revises loan recapture provisions to: (1) make a farmer or rancher eligible for a guaranteed operating loan if the borrower is operating in an area which the Secretary finds has been affected by a natural"

Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to require continued participation in defined benefit plans for certain individuals. Declares that such an election shall be deemed to include an election of continued participation on behalf of any other qualified beneficiary who would cease to be a beneficiary under the plan by reason of the qualifying event.

PTSD/TBI Guaranteed Review For Heroes Act This bill directs the Department of Defense (DOD) to establish within its Office of the Secretary a board of review to review the discharge or dismissal of a former member of the Armed Forces who: (1) was deployed in support of a contingency operation, (2) was discharged or dismissed from the Armed Forces under a general or other than honorable condition, and (3) has been diagnosed by a health care professional with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) or a traumatic brain injury. The board shall: (1) review such discharge or dismissal within 15 years after it is requested by the individual, Member of Congress, or the surviving spouse, next of kin, or legal representative of such individual; and (2) notify such Member of the decision and rationale for it. If the board denies such request or does not change the discharge or dismissal, it shall notify such Member of Congress of the decision and rationale. The bill requires the DOD Secretary to correct the military records of a covered individual in accordance with a change made by the board.

Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit any person from holding a gun show unless: (1) the person is licensed to do so; and (2) at least 30 days have elapsed since the person, using a form prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury, has notified the Secretary and the chief law enforcement officer of the postal address and the dates and times at which the gun show is to be held. <n>Requires: (1) the Secretary to approve or deny an application within 60 days after receiving it; and (2) the Secretary to establish to ensure that the fees collected are sufficient to cover the costs of issuing licenses. <n>Directs the Secretary to approve or deny such an application within 60 days after receiving it. <n>Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) application and transfer requirements; and (2) penalties for violations.

Obamacare Marriage Penalty Elimination Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the health insurance premium tax credit, to: (1) eliminate the marriage penalty, and (2) reduce the eligibility limit for such credit to a spouse whose income exceeds the poverty line.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 6, 2003. The summary has been expanded because action occurred on the measure.) Sales Crew Protection Act - Amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 (FLSA) to exclude from the definition of outside salesman" any individual employed in the position of a salesman if the individual travels with a group of salespeople, including a supervisor, team leader, or crew leader, and the employees in the group do not return to their permanent residences at the end of the work day. (Currently, such a definition includes only salespeople.)Prohibits an individual under 18 years of age from being employed in a position requiring the individual to engage in door-to-door sales or related support work in a manner that requires the individual to remain away from the individual\\'s permanent residence for more than 24 hours.(Sec. 3) Requires employers to provide their travelling sales crew workers with: (1) registration; (2) compensation insurance; (3) transportation safety; (4) housing safety; and (5) liability insurance. Prohibits an employer from requiring: (1) a deduction from wages for the actual cost of any lodging, sanitation, or other facilities provided by the employer; or (2) payment for any goods or services solely from the employer"

This bill directs the Department of the Interior to: (1) issue to the Gateway West Corporation a right-of-way for specified lands in Idaho to be used for the construction and maintenance of a high-voltage transmission line by the corporation; and (2) continue administering such lands as part of the National Landscape Conservation System. The conditions of such right-of-way shall include that: (1) the corporation shall pay all costs associated with the suppression of each respective line segment; and (2) during the time of construction of each segment, the corporation shall mitigate the impacts related to the construction of each segment and continue administering the lands as part of the Conservation Area.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 8, 2013. Cow Creek Land Conveyance Act of 2013 - (Sec. 3) Declares that 17,826 acres of federal land in Oregon shall be: (1) held in trust by the United States for the benefit of the Cow Creek Band of Umpqua Tribe of Indians, and (2) part of the Tribe's reservation. Prohibits on such land: (1) the export of unprocessed logs harvested from such land; and (2) the use of real property taken into trust for any gaming activity carried out on such land. (Sec. 7) Directs the Secretaries of Agriculture (USDA) and the Interior to identify any land owned by the Oregon and California Railroad that is conveyed under this Act and any public domain land that is taken into trust under this Act. Declares that nothing in this Act affects any right or claim of the Tribe existing on the date of enactment of this Act to any land or interest in land.

. Improving Treatment for Pregnant and Postpartum Women Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize through FY2021 and revise the grant program for substance abuse residential services for pregnant and postpartum women. (Sec. 3) The Center for Substance Abuse Treatment must carry out a pilot program to make grants to state substance abuse agencies to: (1) enhance flexibility in the use of funds designed to support family-based services for pregnant and postpartum women with a primary diagnosis of a substance use disorder, including opioid use disorders; (2) help state substance abuse agencies address identified gaps in services furnished to such women along the continuum of care; and (3) promote a coordinated, effective, and efficient state system managed by state substance abuse agencies by encouraging new approaches and models of service delivery. The Center must specify a minimum set of services required to be made available to eligible women through a grant awarded under the program.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on December 7, 2016. Economic Mobility for the Productive Mobility Act of 2016 (Sec. 3) This bill amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 and the Internal Revenue Code to require certain employers who provide wage subsidies to their employees in Puerto Rico to pay such employees a minimum wage of $5.50 an hour. The bill defines "eligible Puerto Rico employee" as an individual who: (1) is a U.S. citizen, (2) has a Social Security number issued to the individual by the Social Security Administration, and (3) certifies that such individual is a resident of Puerto Rico and intends to remain a resident for at least the next six months. Employers who elect to provide such wage subsidies must provide: (1) employees with certain information about the amount of payments and the number of such employees at the time such payments are made and by the case of employers who elect to receive an advance payment; and (2) employees with certain information about the aggregate amount of payments that will be paid to them and the hourly rate of pay for each such employee. Employers who fail to make such payments are subject to certain penalties.

Election Jamming Prevention Act of 2006 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit any person from annoy, abuse, threaten, or harass any person at the called number or who receives the communications with the intent to: (1) annoy, abuse, threaten, or harass any person at the called number or who receives the communications; (2) prevent or obstruct the broadcast or exchange of election-related information; or (3) impair or obstruct any other telecommunications device from being used to engage in communications containing election-related information. Defines election-related information" as information related to: (1) the endorsement, support, promotion, or opposition to any clearly identified candidate or slate of candidates for the office of President, Vice President, presidential elector, Member of the House of Representatives, Delegate, or Commissioner from a territory or possession; (2) the time, place, or manner for the election of such candidates or officers; and (3) facilitation of transport to or from polling places for any such election. Provides a private right of action for injunctive or declaration of relief against certain violations of such prohibition."

Health Care Assurance for Retired Employees Act of 1996 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) and the Internal Revenue Code to require that advance notice of material changes in benefits provided under group health plans be furnished to participants and beneficiaries not later than 180 days before such change takes effect. <n>Prohibits a change or modification in covered services or benefits provided in such a plan from taking effect until after the Secretary of Labor determines that such change or modification does not violate the plan. <n>Sets forth civil penalties for noncompliance with this Act.

(Sec. 3) Authorizes a court, at any time after the commencement of an adversary adjudication, to ask a party to declare whether such party intends to seek an award of fees and expenses against the agency should such party prevail.Provides that such fees and expenses may not be paid from the claims and judgments account of the Treasury from funds appropriated pursuant to the Equal Access to Justice Act (EAJA).(Sec. 4) Authorizes a Federal agency to offer a settlement of the claims made in an application for fees and other expenses. Provides that: (1) an offer not accepted shall be deemed withdrawn (but shall not preclude a subsequent offer); and (2) if any award for the merits of the proceeding finally obtained by the applicant is not more favorable than the offer, the applicant shall not be entitled to receive an award for attorneys' fees or other expenses incurred in relation to the application for fees and expenses after the date of the offer.Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) withdrawal of an offer; and (2) judicial proceedings.Repeals a provision prohibiting a fee award from being payable from the claims and judgments account of the Treasury from funds appropriated pursuant to the EAJA unless the adjudicative officer determines that the position of the United States was substantially justified (currently, unless the court finds

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) HIV/AIDS Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2007 - (Sec. 2) Amends the United States Leadership Against HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria Act of 2003 to authorize appropriations for FY2009-FY2013 for the United States Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR). (Current law authorizes appropriations for FY2008-FY2013.) States that not less than 50% of the amounts appropriated shall be dedicated to abstinence and fidelity as components of a comprehensive approach, including abstinence, fidelity, and the correct and consistent use of condoms, consistent with other provisions of law and the epidemiology of HIV infection in a given country. Prohibits programs and activities that implement or purchase new prevention technologies or modalities such as medical male prophylaxis, pre-exposure prophylaxis, or microbicides from being included in determining compliance with such provision. (Sec. 3) States that this Act shall not be construed to require preferential consideration" with respect to programs and activities that include a priority emphasis on public health measures to prevent the sexual transmission of HIV. (Current law requires "preferential consideration" only with respect to such programs and activities that include a priority emphasis on public health"

Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Act of 2011 - Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish a Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Program under which the Administrator shall award grants for each of FY2012-FY2016 to owners or operators of community water systems, treatment works, decentralized wastewater treatment systems, groundwater storage and replenishment systems, or natural or engineered systems that manage floodwater, in order to increase their resiliency or adaptability to changes to hydrologic conditions in a region.<n><n>Requires water systems to use grant funds exclusively for specified purposes, including: (1) conserving water or enhancing water use efficiency; (2) modifying or relocating existing water system infrastructure made or projected to be significantly impaired by changing conditions; (3) preserving or improving water quality; (4) enhancing water management by increasing watershed preservation and protection; (5) enhancing energy efficiency or the use and generation of renewable energy in the management, conveyance, or treatment of water, wastewater, or stormwater; (6) supporting the adoption and use of advanced water treatment, water supply management, or water demand management technologies; (7) modifying or replacing existing systems or constructing new systems for existing communities or land that is being used for agricultural production to improve water supply, reliability, storage, or conveyance in a manner that promotes conservation or improves the efficiency of use of available water

Healthy Maternity and Obstetric Medicine Act or the Healthy MOM Act This bill amends the Public Health Service Act and the Internal Revenue Code to require health plans to offer a special enrollment period to pregnant women. The special enrollment period offered by an insurer or group health plan must begin when the pregnancy is reported to the plan. Coverage offered by an insurer or group health plan that covers dependents must provide coverage for maternity care to all covered individuals.

(Sec. 102) Prohibits House of Representatives election candidates from accepting contributions from all sources outside their congressional district involved totaling in excess of the total of contributions accepted from individual residents of the congressional district involved.(Sec. 103) Limits to a national committee of a political party and the congressional campaign committees of a political party the acceptance of soft money by such committees in any calendar year.(Sec. 104) Requires operators of radio, television, and cable stations and systems to report to the Federal Election Commission (FEC) specified information about Federal political advertisements carried by such stations and systems.Title II: Worker Paycheck Fairness - Provides that workers who pay dues or fees to a labor organization shall not be required, as a matter of law, to pay any dues or fees supporting activities that are not necessary to performing the duties of the exclusive representative of the employees in dealing with the employer on labor-management issues.

Continuity of Congress Act of 2003 - Authorizes States to enact laws declaring who shall serve in the place of incapacitated members in the House of Representatives and Senate if one-fourth of the members of such chambers are killed or incapacitated. States that nothing in this Act shall limit the authority of any State under the Constitution to fill a vacancy in the House or Senate.

Regulatory Oversight Act of 1995 - Requires that a Federal agency promulgating a rule before it takes effect as a final rule submit to the Congress a report containing: (1) a copy of the rule; (2) a concise general statement relating to the rule; (3) the proposed effective date of the rule; and (4) a complete copy of the cost benefit analysis of the rule. Provides that a significant rule shall take effect as a final rule within 45 days after the Congress receives such report or the rule is published in the Federal Register, if the Congress passes a joint resolution of disapproval relating to the rule and the President signs the resolution, the earlier date: (1) on which either House of the Congress votes and fails to override the veto of the President; or (2) occurring 30 session days after the date on which the Congress received the veto and objections of the President. Declares that a rule shall not take effect as a final rule if the Congress passes a joint resolution of disapproval. Permits a rule that would not take effect by reason of this Act to take effect if the President: (1) determines that the rule is necessary because of an imminent threat to health or safety or other emergency, is necessary for the enforcement of criminal laws, or is necessary for national security; or (2) submits written notice

Earmark Reform and Federal Spending Transparency and Accountability Act of 2011 - Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to limit contributions by earmark beneficiary" (defined as any person who specifically requests and benefits from a congressionally directed spending item, a limited tax benefit, or a limited tariff benefit) during a calendar year to any requesting candidate. Applies such limitation to contributions made on and after January 1, 2011.<n><n>Prohibits an employee of the personal staff of a Member of Congress from attending a political fund raise on behalf of such Member, except in specified circumstances.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives to post on their websites links to the earmark database maintained by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). Requires the head of each federal department and agency to post on their websites links to a searchable database that lists each contract, grant, cooperative agreement, and other expenditure made by such department or agency with respect to the expenditure the amount, purpose, term, and office making such expenditure.<n><n>Requires a Government Accountability Office (GAO) report on each earmark funded through earmarks in the preceding fiscal year."

Private Wireless Spectrum Use Act - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to direct the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to initiate a rulemaking designed to identify and allocate at least 12 megahertz of electromagnetic spectrum located between 150 and 2,000 megahertz for use by private wireless licensees on a shared-use basis. Requires the new spectrum proposed to be reallocated to accommodate the need for paired allocations and for proximity to existing private wireless spectrum allocations. Requires the FCC to reserve at least 50 percent of the reallocated spectrum for the use of private wireless providers solely for the purpose described in this Act.

Unfunded Mandates Information and Transparency Act of 2008 - Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require the Director of the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) in preparing an assessment of the authorized level of funding to determine if the prospective costs of carrying out changes to a condition of federal assistance being imposed on participating state, local, or tribal governments and how these costs compare with the funds being authorized or, for reauthorizations, of the additional costs of changes in those conditions and how they compare with the changes in funding being authorized. Requires such assessment in cases where a bill or joint resolution provides such sums as are necessary.<n><n>Requires the Director to include in mandatory reports to Congress an identification and description of any reasonably foreseeable indirect costs to state, local, or tribal governments, or by the private sector, incurred as a result of implementing the federal mandate in the bill or joint resolution. Defines reasonably foreseeable indirect costs" as costs to the affected entities resulting from implementation of a federal mandate other than their own direct costs to carry out any such mandate.<n><n>Amends the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 to require the Director of the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) in preparing an assessment of the authorized level of funding to determine if the prospective costs of carrying"

Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2007 - Amends the federal criminal code to impose a fine and/or prison term of up to five years for knowingly communicating election-related information about a federal election with the intent to prevent another person from exercising the right to vote in such election. Extends the penalty for voter intimidation to five years.Directs the United States Sentencing Commission to review the federal sentencing guidelines and policy statements applicable to persons convicted of voter intimidation offenses.Authorizes any person to report a violation of this Act to the Attorney General. Directs the Attorney General to: (1) study the feasibility of providing corrective information through public service announcements, the emergency alert system, or other forms of public broadcast; and (2) refer the matter to the appropriate federal and state authorities for criminal prosecution or civil action after the election.

Supporting Emergency Responders Volunteer Efforts Act of 2009 or the SERVE Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow bona fide volunteer members of qualified volunteer emergency response organizations a refundable tax credit for $1,000 of their compensation for performing services for such organizations. Defines qualified services" as fire fighting and prevention services, emergency medical services, and ambulance services."

Fuel-Efficient Fleets Act of 2006 - Requires each passenger automobile purchased, or leased for at least 60 consecutive days, by an executive agency to achieve a minimum fuel economy of: (1) 15 miles per gallon for vans; (2) 20 miles per gallon for pickup trucks; (3) 24 miles per gallon for sport utility vehicles; and (4) 45 miles per gallon for passenger automobiles, not less than 45 miles per gallon for vans, pickup trucks, and sport utility vehicles. Requires: (1) 25% of such automobiles purchased during the one-year period beginning after enactment of this Act to achieve such minimum fuel economy; (2) 50% of such automobiles purchased during the one-year period beginning one year after enactment to achieve such minimum fuel economy; (3) 75% of such automobiles purchased during the one-year period beginning two years after enactment to achieve such minimum fuel economy; and (4) 100% of such automobiles purchased during the one-year period beginning three years after enactment to achieve such minimum fuel economy. (Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary of Energy to: (1) annually evaluate such fuel economy standards based on relevant technological advances during the previous year; and (2) increase such standards if significant technological improvements make it feasible to achieve higher fuel economy. (Sec. 4) Authorizes the Secretary of Transportation to award grants to assist states

Working Waterfront Preservation Act of 2005 - Amends the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act to authorize the Secretary of Commerce to award grants to the government of a Coastal State, a local government within a Coastal State, or a nonprofit organization or a fishing cooperative for projects to: (1) acquire real property or an interest in real property located in a Coastal State for the purpose of providing access to persons engaged in the commercial fishing or the aquaculture industry to coastal waters in working waterfront areas; or (2) make improvements to real property located in a Coastal State and owned by an eligible entity, including the construction or repair of wharfs or related facilities, to provide access to such persons to coastal waters in working waterfront areas. Defines working waterfront areas" as land that is used for or that supports commercial fishing or the aquaculture industry."

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Gold King Accountability and Compensation for Taxpayers or the Gold King ACT (Sec. 4) This bill requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to award or deny payment of claims brought under the Federal Tort Claims Act for injury resulting from the Gold King Mine spill on August 5, 2015, of approximately 3 million gallons of contaminated water from the Mine north of Cement Creek, Colorado, while EPA contractors were conducting an investigation of the Mine. An injured person may bring a claim arising out of, or relating to, any injury resulting from the spill under the Federal Tort Claims Act and the EPA shall receive, process, and pay those claims.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the Senate on February 20, 2000. The summary of that version is repeated here.) United Nations Rapid Deployment Police and Security Force Act of 2000 - Directs the Secretary of State to instruct the United Nations (UN) chief to establish a rapid deployment force consisting of: (1) at least 1,000 civilian police officers; and (2) at least 1,000 UN peacekeeping troops.Directs the President to instruct the United States Permanent Representative to the UN to: (1) seek to enter into an agreement with the UN Secretary General to provide for the deployment within within 90 days of enactment of this Act of at least 1,000 civilian police officers and UN peacekeeping troops; and (2) submit a report to Congress concerning such deployment.

Taxation of Minor Children Simplifcation Act of 2004 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to revise the tax treatment of minor children with respect to the application of the trust rate schedule to net unearned income and the election to claim income of child on parent's return.

Montgomery GI Bill Revitalization Act of 2003- Amends Federal basic educational assistance provisions (the Montgomery GI Bill) to authorize enhanced educational assistance to a member of the armed forces who, after September 30, 2003: (1) first enters on active duty; (2) reenlists or extends an enlistment; or (3) continues to serve on active duty. Requires such individual to serve a continuous period of active duty of at least four years.Declares that, in the case of such an individual who does not serve a continuous period of active duty of at least four years, the individual is entitled to one month of enhanced educational assistance benefits for each month of continuous active duty served. Limits the duration of such assistance to 36 months.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 19, 2014. Strengthening Child Welfare Response to Trafficking Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), in awarding grants to states under grants program for child welfare services, to give priority consideration to provisions and procedures for: (1) identifying and assessing reports involving children who are sex trafficking victims; (2) training state child protective services representatives about identifying and assessing children who are sex trafficking victims; and (3) identifying services and referral for appropriate referral to address the needs of children who are sex trafficking victims. Requires the Secretary to report on: (1) the specific type and prevalence of severe forms of trafficking in persons to which children identified for services or intervention under the placement, care, or supervision of state, Indian tribe, or tribal organization child welfare agencies have been subjected; (2) state practices and protocols to identify and serve children who are sex trafficking victims and children who are at risk of becoming victims; and (3) any barriers in federal laws or regulations that may prevent identification and assessment of children who are trafficking victims.

Promise for Antibiotics and Therapeutics for Health Act or the PATH Act This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to establish a limited population pathway, through which an antibacterial drug may be approved for use in a limited population of individuals who have no alternative treatment for a serious or life-threatening disease or infection. A drug is eligible for approval under the pathway only upon the request of its sponsor, who shall demonstrate its safety and effectiveness for the intended use. The FDA shall determine the benefit-risk profile of the drug in the limited population, taking into account the severity, rarity, or prevalence of the infection the drug is intended to treat and the availability or lack of alternative treatment. Approval of a drug under the pathway shall not be denied due to a lack of evidence to fully establish a favorable benefit-risk profile in a population that is broader than the intended limited population. In determining whether to approve a drug under the pathway, the FDA shall rely on sufficient evidence and may rely on supplemental data. The FDA shall require the labeling of an approved drug to indicate that it has been approved for use only in a limited population and to submit copies of related promotional materials at least 30 days prior to dissemination of the materials

Health Care COBRA OffSet Tax Savings Act of 2005 or the Health Care COSTS Act of 2005 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow certain individuals covered under the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA) a refundable tax credit for 50 percent of the cost of COBRA continuation coverage.

Education Flexibility Amendments of 1998 - Amends the Goals 2000: Educate America Act (Goals 2000) to expand the education flexibility demonstration program authorized under such Act. Authorizes the Secretary of Education to allow all States to participate in such program. <n>(Sec. 3) Requires that, in deciding whether to extend a State educational agency's (SEA) authority to issue waivers under the Goals 2000 program, the Secretary review the SEA's progress in: (1) developing a State improvement plan; (2) implementing challenging State content standards, challenging State student performance standards, and aligned assessments for which local educational agencies (LEAs) are producing the individual school performance profiles required by the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA); and (3) having LEAs and schools accountable for meeting the educational goals submitted in their local applications for waivers, and for taking corrective actions if they do not meet such goals. <n>Requires the Secretary to review such SEAs' progress in: (1) establishing procedures for increasing the percentage of elementary school and secondary school teachers who are highly qualified; and (2) ensuring that such LEAs and schools are held accountable for student performance. <n>Limits the duration of such waivers to three years, unless the Secretary extends such period upon determining that such waiver authority has

Enhanced Emergency and Enforcement Authority Act - Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to authorize the court, in any action or proceeding instituted by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) in a U.S. district court, to subpoena the attendance of witnesses or the production of documents or tangible things (or both) in any other district. Amends the Securities Act of 1933, the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, and the Investment Company Act of 1940 to authorize the court, in any SEC action or proceeding in a U.S. district court, to subpoena the attendance of witnesses or the production of documents or tangible things (or both) in any other district.

(Sec. 102) Authorizes a U.S. citizen parent to apply for naturalization on behalf of a child born outside the United States who has not acquired citizenship automatically. Directs the Attorney General to issue a certificate of citizenship to such parent upon proof that the following conditions have been fulfilled: (1) at least one parent is a U.S. citizen, whether by birth or naturalization; (2) the child is under the age of 18; (3) the child is residing in the United States in the legal and physical custody of the citizen parent pursuant to a lawful admission for permanent residence; and (4) the child is residing outside the United States in the legal and physical custody of the citizen parent, is temporarily present in the United States pursuant to a lawful admission, and is maintaining such lawful status. Applies such provisions to a child adopted by a U.S. citizen parent if the child satisfies such requirements.Title II: Provisions For Certain Aliens VOTING BASED on Reason of Citizenship (sic) - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide that, upon approval of an application for naturalization, a child shall become a U.S. citizen and shall be furnished with a certificate of citizenship.

Safe Medications for the Elderly Act - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for Medicare coverage of legally authorized pharmaceutical care services furnished by a pharmacist to an individual enrolled under Medicare part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance). <n>Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to: (1) identify and publish a list of outpatient prescription drugs used in the treatment of specified conditions prevalent in the elderly; and (2) develop a relative value scale and fee schedules for Medicare payment for such services.

. Reno, Nevada, Railroad Right-of-Way Validation Act (Sec. 2) This bill legalized, validated, and confirmed as far as any U.S. interest in specified lands in Washoe County, Nevada, concerning lands that form parts of the right-of-way granted by the United States to the Central Pacific Railway Company. (Sec. 3) The bill applies to all such lands except certain lands held in trust by the United States for the benefit of a grantee.

Baseball Fans and Communities Protection Act of 1994 - Amends the Clayton Act to apply the antitrust laws to any unilateral terms and conditions of employment in restraint of trade or commerce imposed by any party to an agreement between two or more major league baseball clubs and the labor organization representing the baseball players. <n>States that the antitrust laws shall not apply to a term or condition imposed solely with respect to a player party to a uniform player contract that is assigned, at the time such imposition occurs, to a non-major league professional baseball club.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 17, 2015. Stop Tampering of Prescription Pills Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to prescribe new drug application requirements for abuse-deterrent drugs: (1) containing as an active moiety (the part of the drug that makes it work the way it does) a controlled substance classified as opium, an opiate, or a derivative; (2) formulated for oral administration; (3) exhibiting physicochemical properties making them significantly more difficult or ineffective in altering the drug's characteristics for purposes of misuse or abuse; and (4) containing one or more additional ingredients intended to deter abuse through potential pharmacological effects. If the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) refuses a new drug application for any new (brand name) drug containing opium, an opiate, or a derivative as an active moiety that is not abuse-deterrent, the application must demonstrate that the new drug is not subject to such refusal. Additionally, the FDA may approve an application failing to contain the patent information prescribed by the bill, even if the application failed to contain the patent information required under the bill. The FDA may approve an application failing to meet these requirements: (1) to prevent or

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Defense of Environment and Property Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (commonly known as the Clean Water Act) to revise the definition of "navigable waters," the waters of the United States that are navigable-in-fact or permanent, standing, or continuously flowing bodies of water that form geographical features commonly known as streams, oceans, rivers, and lakes connected to waters that are navigable-in-fact. The definition does not include: (1) waters that do not physically abut or lack a continuous surface water connection to navigable waters; (2) man-made or natural structures or channels through which water flows intermittently or ephemerally, or that periodically provide drainage for rainfall; or (3) wetlands without a continuous surface connection to bodies of water that are waters of the United States. An activity carried out by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or the Corps of Engineers shall not, without explicit state authorization, impinge upon the traditional and primary power of states over land and water use.Aggregation of wetlands or waters shall not be used to determine or assert federal jurisdiction. Wetlands shall not be considered to be under federal jurisdiction. If a jurisdictional determination

Grow Research Opportunities with Taxcredits' Help Act or GROWTH Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) extend through 2010 the tax credit for increasing research activities; (2) increase the rate of the alternative simplified research tax credit; and (3) modify the tax credit for qualified research expenses after 2010.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 19, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Personal Privacy Act Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit the use of visual or auditory enhancement devices to capture or broadcast images or other reproductions of private lives for commercial purposes without the express, written, voluntary, informed consent of the individual involved. Provides for enforcement through the Federal Trade Commission, State attorneys general, or individual aggrieved by a violation of this Act.

This bill directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to arrange for the posthumous award of a Congressional Gold Medal to Private First Class Franklin Runyon, United States Marine Corps, and Private Troy Suribachi, American Veterans, in recognition of their dedicated service during World War II. The medal shall be displayed at the Smithsonian Institution, which is urged to make the medal available for display at other locations associated with such veterans or with World War II.

Low Income Community Development Tax Credit Act of 1995 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish a credit for nonresidential buildings located in distressed areas. Requires the rehabilitation expenditures for such buildings to be at least ten percent of the adjusted basis of the building.

Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Oversight and Resource Enhancement Act of 2006 - Amends the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 (FISA) to authorize the Chief Justice of the United States to designate additional judges of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (Court) to provide for the prompt and timely consideration of applications for orders approving electronic surveillance for foreign intelligence purposes. Requires any judge designated to be designated publicly.<n><n>Authorizes the: (1) Office of Intelligence Policy and Review of the Department of Justice to carry out the prompt and timely preparation, modification, and review of applications under FISA for orders approving electronic surveillance for foreign intelligence purposes; and (2) Attorney General to assign such personnel to and among appropriate offices of the National Security Agency (NSA) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).<n><n>Requires the Director of the FBI to assign personnel to and among the FBI field offices in order that such personnel may directly assist personnel in preparing applications.

El Stafford Mental Illness Information Disclosure Act of 2012 or El B's Law - Requires a health care professional, in the case of a minor child or an uninsured adult under 26 who is being treated for mental illness, to disclose information regarding the illness and treatment to a parent, if any, for appropriate involvement in the treatment. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to post information on the requirements of this Act on HHS websites.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) allow a tax credit for 50% of the cost of qualified hydrogen-powered vehicle refueling property; and (2) exclude from gross income income income attributable to the sale of hydrogen fuel sold at retail for use in a hydrogen fuel cell vehicle.

Energy Savings Through Public-Private Partnerships Act of 2013 - Amends the National Energy Conservation Policy Act to require each energy manager of a federal agency to consider: (1) implementing any energy-saving or conservation measure that is life cycle cost-effective, and (2) bundling individual measures of varying paybacks together into combined projects. Requires each agency to: (1) use the benchmarking systems selected or developed for it to track energy savings realized through the implementation of energy-saving or conservation measures; and (2) submit information regarding such savings to the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to be published on DOE's website. Makes it the goal of the federal government to enter into energy savings performance contracts or utility energy service contracts equal to $1 billion in each year during the five-year period beginning on January 1, 2014. Requires the Secretary, acting through the Federal Energy Management Program, to report to Congress on the government's progress in implementing energy-saving or conservation measures.

Fast Track to College Act of 2008 - Authorizes appropriations for FY2009-FY2014 to: (1) support early college high schools established pursuant to this Act; and (2) support other dual enrollment programs.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award six-year grants to eligible entities seeking to establish a new or support an existing early college high school or other dual enrollment program. Requires an eligible entity to contribute matching funds toward program costs. Requires grant priority to be given to applicants: (1) that propose to establish or support an early college high school or other dual enrollment program that will serve a student population of which 40% or more are counted under title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965; and (2) from states that provide assistance to early college high schools or other dual enrollment programs.

Appropriates specified amounts for the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for FY 1998. <n>(Sec. 101) Prohibits the obligation, transfer, or making available to the IMF until 30 days after the Secretary of the Treasury certifies that the Board of Executive Directors of the IMF have agreed by resolution that stand-by agreements or other arrangements regarding the use of IMF resources shall include provisions requiring the borrower to: (1) comply with the terms of all international trade obligations and agreements of which the borrower is a signatory; (2) eliminate the practice or policy of government directed lending or provision of subsidies to favored industries, enterprises, parties, or institutions; and (3) guarantee non-discriminatory treatment in debt resolution proceedings between domestic and foreign creditors, and for debtors and other concerned persons. <n>(Sec. 102) Directs the Secretary to certify to the appropriate congressional committees that the Board has agreed to provide timely access by the Comptroller General to information and documents relating to IMF operations, program and policy reviews and decisions regarding stand-by agreements and other uses of its resources. Directs the Secretary to: (1) develop and implement a plan to obtain timely public access to information and documents relating to IMF operations, programs, and policy reviews and decisions regarding stand-by agreements and other uses of its resources;

The Business Checking Fairness Act of 2007- Amends Federal law to authorize interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses, permitting up to 24 transfers per month to another account of the owner in the same institution (or any greater number the Federal Reserve Board may determine).<n><n>Amends the Federal Reserve Act, the Home Owners' Loan Act, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act to repeal the proscription on the payment of interest on demand deposits.<n><n>Declares that in the case of an escrow account maintained at a depository institution for the purpose of completing the settlement of a real estate transaction: (1) the absorption, by the depository institution, of expenses incidental to providing a normal banking service with respect to such account; (2) the forbearance, by the depository institution, from charging a fee for providing any such banking function; and (3) any benefit which may accrue to the holder or the beneficiary of such escrow account as a result of such action, including any benefits which have been so determined by the appropriate federal regulator.<n><n>Requires the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to obtain biennially a sample, representative by type and size of the institution (including small institutions) and geographic location, of the following retail banking services and products provided by insured depository institutions and insured credit

Promoting Wellness for Individuals with Disabilities Act of 2006 - Amends the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 to direct the Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board to issue standards setting forth the minimum technical criteria for medical diagnostic equipment used in, or in conjunction with, physician's offices, clinics, emergency rooms, hospitals, and other medical settings that ensure that such equipment is accessible to, and usable by, individuals with disabilities and allows independent entry to, use of, and exit from the equipment by such individuals to the maximum extent possible. Applies such standards to equipment that includes examination tables, examination chairs, weight scales, mammography equipment, x- ray machines, and other radiological equipment commonly used for diagnostic purposes by health professionals.<n><n>Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services, in collaboration with the National Advisory Committee on Wellness for Individuals With Disabilities, to make competitive grants to public and nonprofit private entities for programs for promoting good health, disease prevention, and wellness for individuals with disabilities, and preventing secondary conditions in such individuals. Authorizes the Secretary to make grants for programs or activities for: (1) smoking cessation; (2) preventive health screening programs for individuals with disabilities to reduce the incidence of secondary conditions; and (3) athletic, exercise, or sports programs that provide

True Reciprocity Investment Act of 2017 This bill amends the Defense Production Act of 1950 to direct the United States Trade Representative (USTR) to report annually to Congress assessing the extent to which governments of foreign countries allow investments by U.S. persons in those countries that are similar to investments in the United States made by entities organized under those countries' laws. The report shall assess: (1) the laws, policies, and practices of each major U.S. trading partner that allow investments by U.S. persons in those countries; (2) a comparison of such laws, policies, and practices with those of the United States; (3) an assessment of the laws, policies, and practices by a country that prohibit, restrict, or delay investment in the country by U.S. persons; (4) an identification of the industries in the United States that have been most severely affected by such laws, policies, and practices; (5) an assessment of the transparency of the process for making such laws, policies, and practices; and (6) if a bilateral investment treaty is in effect between the United States and the country, an assessment of the extent to which the government of the country has complied with its obligations under the treaty. The bill specifies whether each country that is a major U.S

Census Address List Improvement Act of 1994 - Amends Federal law to require the Secretary of Commerce to: (1) publish standards defining the content and structure of information which States and local governments may submit to the Secretary to be used in developing a national address list; (2) develop and publish a timetable for the Bureau of the Census to receive, review, and respond to such submissions before the decennial census date; and (3) be subject to the review process developed under this Act relating to responses. Specifies the Secretary's duties and obligations with respect to such information. Requires the Secretary to provide census liaisons designated by a local government with access to census address information for the purpose of verifying the accuracy of the address information of the Bureau for census and survey purposes. Limits such access to address information concerning addresses within a local unit of general purpose government represented by the census liaison or an adjacent local unit of general purpose government. Requires the Bureau to respond to each recommendation made by the census liaison concerning the accuracy of address information. Specifies confidentiality provisions.

Savings Enhancement for Education in College Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) allow a tax credit for contributions made by a taxpayer to a qualified tuition program (529 tuition program); and (2) exclude from the gross income of an employee amounts paid by an employer to a 529 tuition program.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on March 23, 2017. 50th Anniversary of the Texas Western College Men's Basketball Championship Commemorative Coin Act (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Department of the Treasury to mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins emblematic of the 1966 Texas Western College men's college basketball title. (Sec. 4) Treasury shall hold a competition to design the obverse of the coins. The design on the reverse side shall depict a basketball similar to those used by the Texas Western College Miners. The bill requires all sales of such coins to include a surcharge of $35 per coin for the $5 coin, $10 per coin for the $1 coin, and $5 per coin for the half-dollar coin, which shall be paid to the Texas Western College Men's Basketball Hall of Fame for the purpose of establishing a scholarship program.

Drunk Driving Repeat Offender Prevention Act of 2015 This bill directs the Department of Transportation to withhold specified graduated percentages of a state's apportionment of certain federal-aid highway funds for FY2018-FY2020 if the state has not enacted and is not enforcing a law requiring the installation of an ignition interlock device for a minimum of 180 days on each motor vehicle operated by an individual convicted of driving while intoxicated or driving under the influence (having a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or greater). The 180-day period may be reduced to 90 days if: (1) the driver's license is suspended for a minimum of 180 days as a result of the conviction, and (2) the period for installation of an ignition interlock device begins after the last day of the suspension.

Fulfilling the Potential of Women in Academic Science and Engineering Act of 2008 - Requires the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy in the Executive Office of the President, acting through the National Science and Technology Council (NSTC), to develop a policy for each federal science agency to carry out a program of workshops that educate program officers, members of grant review panels, institution of higher education department chairs, and other federally funded researchers about methods that minimize the effects of gender bias in evaluation, including of federal research grants, promotion, grant evaluation, award selection, and for selection for any other honor based on academic merit. Requires the Director to ensure that such agency programs are coordinated and supported jointly as appropriate. Authorizes federal science agencies to carry out the program of workshops by making grants to eligible organizations that have the primary mission of advancing the participation of women in science and engineering.

Aviation Security Stakeholder Participation Act of 2014 - Directs the Assistant Secretary of Homeland Security (Transportation Security Administration [TSA]) to establish within TSA an aviation security advisory committee. Requires the Assistant Secretary to consult the advisory committee on aviation security matters and to develop, upon request, recommendations for improvements to aviation security.

Recreational Hunting Safety and Preservation Act of 1993 - Makes it unlawful for a person knowingly and with the intent of obstructing, impeding, or interfering with the conduct of a lawful recreational hunt on Federal lands.

Declares that the Lower East Side Tenement at 97 Orchard Street, New York, New York, is a national historic site and shall be an affiliated site of the National Park System. Requires the Secretary of the Interior to coordinate the operation and interpretation of the site with the Statue of Liberty National Monument, Ellis Island National Monument, and Castle Clinton National Monument. Provides that the Lower East Side Tenement Museum shall continue to own, operate, and manage the site. <n>Directs the Secretary to develop a general management plan for the site. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) enter into a cooperative agreement with the Museum to ensure the marking, interpretation, and preservation of the site; and (2) provide technical and financial assistance to the Museum to mark, interpret, and preserve the site.

Modernizing Outdated and Vulnerable Equipment and Information Technology Act of 2016 or the MOVE IT Act This bill requires federal agencies to: (1) store or process government information on a federal information system with any cloud service provider unless the provider has an authorization to operate, or a provisional authorization to operate, covering the proposed scope of work; (2) issue an authorization to operate as soon as practicable and not rely on provisional authorization to operate for the duration of the scope of work; and (3) accept or rely upon certifications from other standards development organizations or third party assessment organizations as part of the authorization process. The Office of Management and Budget shall coordinate with the Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program Office to establish mandatory guidelines for the submission of an application for an authorization to operate and related materials.

Declares that all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to specified land in Rio Arriba County, New Mexico, and certain Bureau of Land Management land located in Santa Fe County, New Mexico, shall be held in trust for the Pueblo of Santa Clara, New Mexico, to be held in trust by the United States for the Pueblo of San Ildefonso, New Mexico. States that all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to specified land in Rio Arriba County and Santa Fe County, New Mexico, shall be held in trust for the Pueblo of San Ildefonso, New Mexico. States that the land referred to in this Act consists of approximately 2,000 acres of Bureau of Land Management land located in Rio Arriba County and Santa Fe County.

Small Business Expansion and Job Creation Act of 2010 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend through 2010: (1) the increased limitation on the expensing of depreciable business assets; (2) the special allowance for depreciable business property placed in service in 2010; and (3) the taxpayer election to accelerate alternative minimum tax and research tax credits in lieu of bonus depreciation. Sets forth special rules for taxpayers who previously elected acceleration of such credits and for those who did not.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on October 6, 2015. Homed Firearms Restriction Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Consumer Product Safety Act to prohibit the marketing or advertising of certain items, including a firearm receiver casting or blank that: (1) at the point of sale does not meet the definition of a firearm under federal law, and (2) after purchase by a consumer, can be completed by the consumer to the point at which such casting or blank functions as a firearm frame or receiver for a semiautomatic assault weapon or machine gun. This prohibition shall be treated as a ban under the Act. (Sec. 3) The bill makes it unlawful to market or advertise, on any medium of electronic communications, including over the Internet, for the sale of: a firearm receiver casting or blank that does not meet the definition of a firearm in federal law; an assault weapon parts kit; or a machinegun parts kit. Violations shall be treated as violations of a rule defining an unfair or deceptive act or practice under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Federal Trade Commission shall enforce this Act as though all applicable terms and provisions of the Federal Trade Commission Act were incorporated into and made part of this Act.
