Academic, Social, and Emotional Learning Act of 2011 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to require the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to local educational agencies (LEAs) to train and recruit teachers and principals who have demonstrated effectiveness in improving student achievement, attainment, and behavior through addressing the social and emotional development needs of students, such as through social and emotional learning programming.<n><n>Requires such grants to be used to: (1) train teachers and principals in practices that have demonstrated effectiveness in improving student achievement, attainment, and behavior through addressing such students\\' social and emotional development needs; and (2) address such students\\' social and emotional development needs to improve their student achievement and attainment.<n><n>Defines social and emotional learning" as the process through which children and adults acquire the knowledge, attitudes, and skills associated with the core areas of social and emotional competency, including: (1) self-awareness and self-management to achieve school and life success; (2) social awareness and interpersonal skills to promote others, communication, working cooperatively, conflict management, and helping others; and (3) decisionmaking skills and responsible behaviors in personal, academic, and community contexts, such as situational analysis, problem solving, reflection, and personal, and ethical responsibility."
Amends Federal civil service law to increase from one year to two years the probationary period for positions within the competitive service and for positions within the Senior Executive Service.

Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to make it out of order in the House of Representatives or in the Senate to consider any budget resolution for FY2006 or any ensuing fiscal year that is not consistent with the specified spending limitation in the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 (Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act).

Great Lakes Navigation System Sustainability Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretary of the Army, acting through the Chief of Engineers, to: (1) manage and allocate funding for all of the individually authorized commercial and recreational navigation projects in the Great Lakes Navigation System as components of a single, comprehensive system, recognizing the interdependence of the projects; and (2) establish a program to fund eligible operations and maintenance projects of the System with the objective of maintaining such projects to their authorized depths and widths. Authorizes appropriations for FY2014-FY2023 to fund eligible operations and maintenance of the System. Requires the Secretary, acting through the Chief, to give a higher priority to projects that: (1) are not subject to the harbor maintenance fee, (2) have not had commercial cargo loaded or unloaded from its harbor during the previous two fiscal years, and (3) for which the nonfederal sponsor provides a cost share of 50% of eligible operations and maintenance expenses is eligible for federal operations and maintenance funds.

Campus Fire Safety Education Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to institutions of higher education (IHEs) or nonprofit organizations for: (1) initiating, expanding, or improving fire safety education programs; and (2) increasing fire safety awareness among enrolled students, including students living in off-campus housing. Limits grants to $250,000 per fiscal year.

Strengthening Manufacturing and Rebuilding Transit Act of 2010 or the SMART Act - Directs the Secretary of Transportation (DOT), in awarding grants for projects that include the purchase of transit vehicle rolling stock, rail, and supporting equipment, to give preference to a project if the manufactured goods to be purchased have a domestic content percentage that: (1) exceeds otherwise applicable federal requirements; and (2) is consistent with industry-recognized standards, if available. Directs the Secretary to establish a centralized website that provides rules and guidance, waiver notices, and departmental and agency actions applicable to the domestic content standards of the federal-aid programs within DOT's jurisdiction.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on December 7, 2016. Investing in Neighborhood-focused, Vital, Evidence-based Strategies and Trust to Prevent Crime Act of 2016 or the INVEST to Prevent Crime Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize the Department of Justice (DOJ) to: (1) make grants to states, local governments, Indian tribes, tribal organizations, non-profit organizations, or institutions of higher education to prepare a comprehensive plan for and implement enhancement of the capacity of local and tribal communities to effectively target and address significant crime issues through collaborative cross-sector approaches; and (2) provide training and technical assistance to recipients of those grants. Projects funded under this bill shall: (1) identify a target neighborhood facing significant crime challenges; (2) use evidence-based practices or research-based practices; (3) encourage active involvement and leadership from neighborhood residents, business owners, organizations, and others who live, work, or conduct business in the target neighborhood; and (4) build cross-sector partnerships to address crime problems from multiple perspectives. To receive a planning or an implementation grant, an entity must identify a research partner and conduct a detailed crime analysis during the planning period and assist the grant recipient to select the most

Launch Services Corporation Act of 1994 - Authorizes the creation of a Launch Services Corporation to broaden and speed the economic use of space and to enhance the economic competitiveness of the U.S. launch services industry and all industrial, commercial, and financial businesses related thereto.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Foreign Adopted Children Equality Act or the FACE Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to revise the definition of "child adopted from outside the United States" to include a child adopted by a U.S. citizen if the Department of State is satisfied that: the child is adopted by a U.S. citizen; the child is younger than 18 years of age; each adopting parent is eligible and suitable to adopt the child; prior to the adoption, the child was an unmarried individual younger than 18 years of age whose biological parents have freely given their written irrevocable consent to the termination of their legal relationship and to the individual's emigration and adoption and that such consent has not been induced by payment or compensation and has not been given prior to the birth of the individual; the individual is unable to provide proper care for the individual or has voluntarily relinquished the individual to the competent authorities pursuant to the law of the individual's residence; or the individual has been abandoned or deserted by the individual's biological parents or legal guardian or has been orphaned due to the death or disappearance of the individual's biological parents or legal guardian. With respect to whom the

Northern Ireland Fair Employment Practices and Principles of Economic Justice Act of 1997 - Prohibits an article from being imported into the United States from Northern Ireland unless documentation is presented at the time of entry indicating that the enterprise which manufactured or assembled such article complied at the time of manufacture with certain fair employment principles (such as freedom from religious discrimination). Bases such principles on the MacBride Principles of Economic Justice, a nine-point set of guidelines for fair employment in Northern Ireland. <n>Requires any U.S. person who has a branch or office in Northern Ireland or who controls an enterprise in Northern Ireland in which more than ten people are employed to ensure implementation of such employment principles and compliance with this Act. <n>Authorizes the President to waive this Act in cases where compliance would harm U.S. national security. Requires the President to publish each waiver justification in the Federal Register. <n>Requires the Congress, within a specified period, to adopt a joint resolution disapproving the waiver.

Culture of Safety Hospital Accountability Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to study and report to Congress on existing activities and programs in hospitals for quality assurance, patient safety, and performance improvement and identify best practices that should be replicated in hospitals to improve patient safety and quality of care, consistent with the provisions included under the quality assessment and performance improvement program, as required under title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act. Directs the Secretary to establish the Culture of Safety Hospital Accountability demonstration program to support establishing partnerships and other cooperative approaches between hospitals, state health care agencies, and the Department of HHS to promote and implement such best practices with the goal of improving the safety and quality of care provided to Medicare beneficiaries and enhancing compliance with the conditions of participation for hospitals under Medicare.

Small Business Child Care Act - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a small business child care grant program to assist States in providing funds to encourage the establishment and operation of employer-operated child care programs. Authorizes appropriations.

Yankton Sioux Tribe and Santee Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act - Establishes in the Treasury the Yankton Sioux Tribe Development Trust Fund and the Santee Sioux Tribe Development Trust Fund. Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to deposit into such Funds specified amounts of interest that would have accrued if such amounts had been invested in interest-bearing obligations of the United States or in obligations guaranteed by the United States.
Repeal of Obamacare Act - Repeals the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, as amended by the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, effective as of the enactment of this Act.

Establishes the Sweetgrass Hills Natural Area within the Bureau of Land Management's Sweetgrass Hills Area of Critical Environmental Concern (ACEC) in Montana. <n>Directs the Secretary of the Interior to: (1) administer the Area in accordance with this Act and with the provisions of law generally applicable to Bureau units; (2) permit hunting and fishing on lands and waters within the Area; and (3) acquire necessary lands or interests in lands within the Area's boundaries by donation, purchase with donation or appropriated funds, or exchange. Permits lands within the Area owned by the State of Montana or any political subdivision thereof to only be acquired by donation or exchange. <n>Prohibits: (1) the Secretary from issuing any lease under the mineral leasing or geothermal leasing laws of the United States for lands within the Area; (2) the Secretary from issuing any patents under the Materials Act of 1947 for any location or claim made in reclamation to a United States subdivision; and (3) lands within the Area from being available for disposal of mineral materials under the Materials Act of 1947. Authorizes withdrawal of claims against the United States for locations or claims made in reclamation under this Act. <n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) undertake and complete within three years an expedited program to examine all unpatented mining claims

Hiring Heroes Tax Incentive Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow employers a business-related tax credit for 15% of wages paid to employees who are members of the Ready Reserve or National Guard and who are recently separated from the Armed Forces. Limits the amount of such credit to $10,000 per employee per year.

Prohibits the President from providing economic assistance, military assistance, or arms transfers to the Government of Sudan unless the President certifies to the Congress that: (1) such Government has taken appropriate action to eliminate chattel slavery in Sudan; and (2) the rigorous enforcement of such laws provides appropriate punishment for violators. Declares such prohibition inapplicable to the Government of any foreign country that participates in, or is otherwise involved in, the establishment or conduct of slavery originating from Sudan. <n>Directs the President to: (1) require the U.S. representative to each international financial institution to use the vote of the United States to oppose any assistance from that institution to Sudan until the Government of Sudan has taken actions to eliminate chattel slavery; and (2) designate an individual assigned to the diplomatic mission in Khartoum, Sudan, to be responsible for monitoring slavery in Sudan. <n>Requires the President to report periodically to the Congress on all forms of covert and over forms of slavery in Sudan, including the transfer of licensed and approved defense articles and services under the Arms Export Control Act. <n>Directs the President to: (1) instruct the U.S. representative to each international financial institution to use the vote of the United States to oppose any assistance from that institution to Sudan until the Government of

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude all gain on the sale or exchange of a principal residence if owned and used as the principal residence for periods aggregating two years or more during the five-year period prior to sale or exchange. Limits such exclusion to $250,000 ($500,000 in case of a joint return). Provides for an inflation adjustment.

Domestic Violence Victims Housing Act - Authorizes increased appropriations for housing assistance for victims of domestic violence under the United States Housing Act of 1937, the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, the National Housing Act, and the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1965. <n>Requires the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to: (1) make such amounts available to States and local governments, and to public housing agencies in such States and local governments, to provide housing assistance to victims of domestic violence; and (2) report to the Congress on the use of such funds.

Medicare Established Provider Act of 2015 Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop a system to designate service providers and suppliers who represent a low risk for submitting fraudulent Medicare claims as established providers afforded certain special treatment in the claim review process.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on March 23, 2016. California New River Restoration Act of 2016 (Sec. 4) This bill requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish a California New River restoration program for the New River that starts in Mexicali, Mexico, flows north into the United States through Calexico, passes through the Imperial Valley, and drains into the Salton Sea. Under the program, the EPA: (1) shall draw on existing and new management plans for the New River or portions of the New River and work in consultation with applicable management entities to identify, prioritize, and implement restoration and protection activities relating to the New River; (2) shall adopt a New River-wide strategy that supports the implementation of a shared set of science-based restoration and protection activities, such as those identified in the California-Mexico Border Relations Council strategic plan; and (3) shall establish a California New River advisory committee to advise the EPA on the implementation of the program.

Small Business Asset Investment and Modernization (AIM) Act of 2010 - Amends the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 to increase maximum amounts of loans under the section 504 program (local development business loans) of the Small Business Administration (SBA). Authorizes the SBA Administrator, through September 30, 2012, to approve the refinancing of indebtedness secured by a lien on commercial real estate or equipment of a small business, provided certain terms and conditions are met.
Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to strike and sell duplicates.Requires the medals to be given to the D-day Museum in New Orleans, Louisiana, for public display.

Crime Victims with Disabilities Act of 2006 - Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make grants to states, local governments, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations to implement a collaboration program to ensure coordination between and among criminal justice agencies, adult protective services agencies, victim assistance organizations, and organizations that provide services to individuals with disabilities to address crimes committed against such individuals and to provide services to crime victims. Requires the Secretary to give priority to applicants that demonstrate the greatest need for new or additional services or funding.

E-Mail User Protection Act - Prohibits any person, using any means or instrumentality of, or affecting, interstate or foreign commerce, from initiating the transmission of an unsolicited bulk electronic mail (e-mail) message that contains a false, fictitious, or misappropriated name of the sender, electronic mail return address, or name and phone number of a telephone contact person; (2) initiating the transmission of such a message to an interactive computer service with knowledge that such message falsifies an Internet domain, header information, date or time stamp, originating e-mail address or other identifier; (3) initiating the transmission of such a message and failing to comply with the request of the recipient, delivered to the sender's electronic mail address, that the recipient does not wish to receive such messages; (4) using, creating, selling, or distributing any computer software that is primarily designed to create such false Internet domain, header information, date or time stamp, originating e-mail address or other identifier; or (5) intentionally violating the requirements of this Act by misappropriated the name or electronic mail return address of another person or by initiating the transmission of unsolicited e-mail to an individual who has specifically communicated to the violator that individual's desire not to receive such mail.

Compassionate Pain Relief Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a program under which parenteral diacetylmorphine may be dispensed from for relief of pain due to terminal cancer. Declares that, for purposes of this Act, an individual is considered to have terminal cancer if there is evidence that the individual is generally recognized as a cancer with a high and predictable mortality.

Individual Income Tax Rate Reduction Act of 2001 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for a reduction in tax rates for individuals for calendar year 2001, as well as further reductions through calendar year 2006.Provides for a reduction in the alternative minimum tax for individuals.

Furthering Accountability and Individual Rights within the Military Act of 2014 or the Fair Military Act - Directs the Secretary of a military department to ensure that: (1) the written performance appraisals of each member of the Armed Forces (member) under that Secretary include an assessment of the extent to which such member supports the sexual assault prevention and response program of the Armed Force concerned; and (2) the performance appraisals of each commanding officer indicate the extent to which such officer has or has not established a command climate in which allegations of sexual assault are properly managed and fairly evaluated, and a victim can report criminal activity, including sexual assault, without fear of retaliation. Directs the Secretary of the military department concerned to modify Rule 404 of the Military Rules of Evidence to clarify that, except as provided by this Act, the general military character of an accused is not admissible for the purpose of showing the probability of innocence of the accused.

Directs the Office of Personnel Management to accept the certification of the Director of Central Intelligence or his designee concerning any such service. Applies the provisions of this Act to annuities commencing on or after the effective date of this Act.

Amends Federal highway provisions to require each State and its political subdivisions to extend the same parking privileges to qualified motor vehicles from other States as it grants to qualified motor vehicles designated under the laws of such State or political subdivision. <n>Directs the Secretary of Transportation to withhold five percent of the amount required to be apportioned to any State under Federal highway provisions in the first year after enactment of this Act and ten percent of such amount thereafter if the State or political subdivision is not in compliance. Provides that funds withheld from apportionment to any State on or before September 30, 1997, shall remain available for apportionment to the State as follows: (1) if the funds would have been apportioned but for this Act, the funds shall remain available until the end of the fiscal year for which the funds are authorized to be appropriated; and (2) if the funds would have been apportioned but for this Act, the funds shall remain available until the end of the third fiscal year following the fiscal year for which the funds are authorized to be appropriated. Provides that no funds withheld from apportionment to any State after September 30, 1997, shall be available for apportionment to the State.

Sound Science for Endangered Species Act Planning Act of 2002 - Amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to direct the Secretary of the Interior, when determining whether a species is endangered or threatened, to give greater weight to any scientific or commercial study or other information that is empirical or has been field-tested or peer-reviewed. Requires petitions regarding such species to contain clear and convincing evidence of: (1) the current known and historic ranges of the species; (2) the most recent population estimates and trends for the species, if available; (3) any change in the population that is alleged in the petition is beyond the natural range of fluctuations for the species; and (4) the reason that the petitioned action is warranted, including known or perceived threats to the species. Requires the evidence to include a bibliography of scientific literature on the species in support of the petition and a preponderance of the evidence if: (1) a preponderance of the evidence is based on reliable scientific and commercial information; and (2) the evidence is sufficient to support a firm belief by the Secretary that the petitioned action may be warranted.Directs the Secretary to promulgate regulations that establish criteria that must be met for scientific and commercial data, studies, and other information to be used as the basis of such a determination.Prohibits the Secretary from determining

Humanitarian Assistance to Combat HIV/AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean and National Security Act of 2003 - Authorizes the President to provide assistance, including through multilateral, nongovernmental, and faith-based organizations, to combat HIV/AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean and National Security Act of 2003.

Medicare Prescription Drug Cost Containment Act of 2004 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services, on the same date on which the President submits a budget to Congress, to submit to Congress a determination as to whether there is projected to be excess general revenue Medicare prescription drug funding for the fiscal year for which the budget is submitted. Treats such determination as a Medicare part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) funding warning for the fiscal year beginning on October 1 of the year in which it is submitted.<n><n>Amends SSA title XVIII, as amended by the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003, to direct the President to submit to Congress, within 15 days after the budget submission to Congress, a proposed legislation to respond to any Medicare part D funding warning made by the Secretary.

Permanent Families for All Children Act - Amends part E (Foster Care and Adoption Assistance) of title IV of the Social Security Act to provide that a foster care maintenance payment made on behalf of a child shall not be taken into account for purposes of determining the Federal matching rate for foster care maintenance payments unless the child is in a legal guardianship or kinship guardianship arrangement. Declares that a foster care maintenance payment made to a child-care institution on behalf of a child residing in the institution shall not be taken into account for purposes of determining the Federal matching rate for foster care maintenance payments after such a payment has been made to one or more such institutions on behalf of the child for 12 months (whether or not consecutive) ending after the effective date of this Act. Declares that a foster care maintenance payment made to a child-care institution on behalf of a child residing in the institution shall not be taken into account for purposes of determining the Federal matching rate for foster care maintenance payments if the payment has been made to one or more such institutions on behalf of the child for 12 months (whether or not consecutive) ending after the effective date of this Act. Eliminates the income eligibility requirement for foster care maintenance payments if the removal and foster care placement met, and the placement

Consortium on the Impact of Technology in Aging Health Services Act of 2006 - Establishes the Consortium on the Impact of Technology in Aging Health Services to evaluate the potential of new technologies to help the United States prepare for the unprecedented demographic changes that will occur during the next 10 years in the nation's health care system.

Save Our Students Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Defense to provide funds to the governor of a State who submits, and receives approval of, a plan for the National Guard to supplement State and local efforts to keep schools safe from violence, including: (1) the pay, allowances, and clothing of National Guard personnel; (2) the operation and maintenance of National Guard equipment and facilities; and (3) the procurement of related services and equipment. Authorizes National Guard personnel, under regulations prescribed by the Secretary, to perform full-time National Guard duty to supplement such efforts. Requires that the training required of such personnel be in addition to the duty performed.

Preserving Crime Victims' Restitution Act of 2006 - Amends the federal criminal code to establish guidelines for federal criminal cases in which a defendant dies before entry of a final judgment of guilt (deceased defendants).<n><n>Provides, as a general rule, that the death of a defendant who has been convicted of a federal criminal offense shall not be the basis for abating or otherwise invalidating a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, a verdict returned, a sentence announced, or a judgment entered prior to the death of such defendant, or for dismissing or invalidating the indictment, information, or complaint on which such a plea, verdict, sentence, or judgment is based, except as provided by this Act.<n><n>Requires a trial court, in a case in which a defendant admits guilt or is found guilty by a jury, but dies before final judgment, to: (1) enter a judgment with the notation that the defendant died before judgment was entered; and (2) commence a special restitution proceeding upon the motion of the government or any victim of the defendant's crime.<n><n>Permits the use of a guilty plea of a deceased defendant in subsequent civil proceedings.

National Ocean Exploration Program Act - Directs the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to: (1) conduct a coordinated national ocean exploration program within NOAA that promotes collaboration with other federal ocean and undersea research and exploration programs; (2) facilitate coordination of data and information management systems, outreach and education programs to improve public understanding of ocean and coastal resources, and development and transfer of technologies to facilitate ocean and undersea research and exploration; and (3) appoint an Ocean Exploration Advisory Board.<n><n>Title II: National Undersea Research Program - National Undersea Research Program Act of 2007 - Directs the Administrator to conduct an undersea research, exploration, education, and technology development program to increase scientific knowledge essential for the informed management, use, and preservation of oceanic, marine, coastal, and Great Lakes resources. Requires the Director to cooperate with institutions of higher education and other educational marine and ocean science organizations and to make available undersea research facilities, equipment, technologies, information, and expertise.

Stop Sweatshops Act - Amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to provide for the civil liability of manufacturers for sweatshop conditions in the garment industry. Sets forth civil penalties for violation of recordkeeping and payroll accounting requirements.

Directs the Secretary to report annually to specified congressional committees regarding the recovery of such marine areas from the effects of bottom trawling and use of other mobile fishing gear on the seabed.

Healthy America Commission Act of 2003 - Establishes the Healthy America Commission to study and report on: (1) the total predicted societal costs of preventable diseases in the United States, disagreggated by the incidence and societal costs of each such disease; (2) the Federal Government's share of paying for the total predicted societal costs of preventable diseases in the United States during, at a minimum, the next 20 years; (3) the impact of preventable disease on society relative to the quality and affordability of health care; (4) the estimated costs and likely long-term savings resulting from a long-term disease prevention program, taking into consideration a series of scenarios regarding the program's scope and effectiveness; (5) economic and other incentives throughout society for encouraging behavioral changes and personal responsibility; (6) cost-benefit ratios for a broad series of disease prevention initiatives; (7) target goals against which the Nation's progress under a long-term disease prevention program may be measured based on biannual achievement evaluations; (8) procedures for monitoring the Nation's progress under a long-term disease prevention program and changes that may need to be made as the program proceeds; (9) whether a series of pilot demonstration programs of various intensities should be undertaken before initiating a full-scale, comprehensive long-term disease prevention program for the Nation; and

Clean Up Earmarks Act of 2010 or the CUE Act of 2010- Directs the Comptroller General to submit an audit to Congress of 5% of Senate earmarks for the current fiscal year chosen at random.<n><n>Amends rule XLIV (Restrictions on Certain Bills) of the Standing Rules of the Senate to increase from three-fifths to two-thirds the number of points of order against AIRDROPPED items in conference reports.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives to take necessary steps to improve the earmarks.gov website: (1) to make earmarks more easily searchable by the requesting member of Congress and by any federally registered lobbyist who requested such earmark; and (2) ensure that the website is user friendly and does not include extraneous information.<n><n>Expresses the sense of the Senate that: (1) the subcommittees of the Senate Committee on Appropriations should hold hearings on earmark requests in excess of $5 million, during which Members who request them shall be invited to testify; and (2) such subcommittees shall hold hearings on earmark requests in excess of $5 million, during which Members who request them shall be invited to testify.<n><n>Requires all congressionally directed spending items to be included in the text of an appropriations or authorization

Balanced Economic and Environmental Priorities Act of 1994 - Amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to prohibit a Federal agency officer or employee from implementing or enforcing a designation, regulation, or recovery plan unless: (1) the Secretary of the Interior has prepared an economic impact analysis; (2) the Secretary determines that the benefits of that designation, regulation, or recovery plan outweigh its costs; and (3) the Secretary has published an economic impact statement describing the findings of such analysis. <n>Requires the Secretary to perform such an analysis with respect to each such designation, regulation, and recovery plan. <n>Requires such an analysis to include the economic consequences of implementing and enforcing the designation, regulation, or recovery plan, including: (1) identifiable and potential job losses or diminishments resulting from that implementation and enforcement; (2) identifiable losses or diminishments in the value of real property resulting from that implementation and enforcement; (3) losses or diminishments in the value of business enterprises resulting from that implementation and enforcement; (4) the effect that implementing and enforcing such designation, regulation, or recovery plan will have on tax revenues received by the Federal Government or by State and local governments; (5) the ecological and economic impacts of the extinction of any species that implementation and enforcement is intended to prevent; and (6) any other potential economic, budgetary, or

Securing the Cities Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to require the Department of Homeland Security (DHS)'s Domestic Nuclear Detection Division to establish the Securing the Cities (STC) program to enhance the ability of the United States to detect and prevent terrorist attacks and other high consequence events utilizing nuclear or other radiological materials that pose a high risk to homeland security in high-risk urban areas. Through the program, DHS shall: assist state, local, tribal, and territorial governments in designing and implementing, or enhancing existing, architectures for coordinated and integrated detection and interdiction of nuclear or other radiological materials that are out of regulatory control; support the development of a region-wide operating capability to detect and report on nuclear and other radioactive materials out of regulatory control; provide resources to enhance detection, analysis, communication, and coordination to better integrate state, local, tribal, and territorial assets into federal operations; facilitate alarm adjudication and provide subject matter expertise and technical assistance on concepts of operations, training, exercises, and alarm response protocols; communicate with, and promote sharing of information about, the presence or detection of nuclear or other radiological materials among appropriate federal, state, local, tribal, and territorial governments; provide augmenting resources enabling such governments

Building Security Act of 2003 - Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to establish a research and development program to: (1) provide the measurements and analysis for improved building and fire codes, standards, and practices; and (2) generate findings and recommendations that can be used to develop improved building and fire codes, and higher construction standards in the United States. Requires the Director to: (1) work with industry, trade associations, professional societies, and others to conduct experimentation, analysis, testing, verification, and demonstration of improved tools and practices that identify improved construction methods and materials relevant to structural fire safety, mitigation of vulnerability collapse, building and ventilation vulnerability reduction tools, equipment standards for first responders, and other ways to reduce the impact of extreme threats to the safety of buildings, their occupants, and emergency responders; and (2) submit to Congress a report containing recommendations on how to establish a private security review task force.Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to contract with the National Academy of Sciences to study and report to Congress on the feasibility and advisability of establishing Federal standards for the training and screening of private security officers.

Rural Aviation Improvement Act: (1) repeals the essential air service local participation program; and (2) prohibits the Secretary of Transportation from providing compensation to an air carrier to provide air transportation to certain eligible places in the 48 contiguous states if the eligible place: (1) is located fewer than 70 highway miles from the nearest large or medium hub airport; or (2) is fewer than 210 miles from the nearest large or medium hub airport and requires a per passenger subsidy in excess of $200 per year.

Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), at the request of the sponsor of a drug, to expedite the drug's development and review if: (1) it is intended, either alone or in combination, to treat a serious life-threatening disease or condition; and (2) preliminary clinical evidence indicates that the drug may demonstrate substantial improvement over existing therapies on one or more clinically significant endpoints. Authorizes the drug's sponsor to request the Secretary to designate the drug as a breakthrough therapy.

Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forests Land Exchange Act of 2007 - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture, if Grand Creek, LLC, offers to convey title acceptable to the United States in and to certain National Forest System land in Clear Creek County, Colorado, to convey to Grand Creek, LLC, all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to such federal land.<n><n>Requires the values of the non-federal and federal lands exchanged to be determined by the Secretary through appraisals performed in accordance with the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions (December 20, 2000) and the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice. Authorizes the Secretary, if the final appraised value of the non-federal lands exceeds the final appraised value of the federal land, to equalize the values by: (1) reducing the acreage of the non-federal land to be conveyed; (2) making a cash equalization payment to Grand Creek, LLC; or (3) a combination of an acreage reduction and a cash equalization payment. Authorizes the Secretary to accept a cash equalization payment from Grand Creek, LLC, in such amount as necessary to equalize the values of the land to be exchanged, including a cash equalization payment in excess of the amount authorized by the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of

Guaranteed Paid Vacation Act This bill entitles an employee who has been employed for not less than one year by an employer who provides paid vacation time to use during an absence of at least 1,250 hours, if the employee: (1) has provided at least 1,250 hours of service to such employer during the previous year; and (2) is, or was, an employee of the Government Accountability Office, a state employee, or an employee of the Library of Congress, except that such employee is also an employee of the Library of Congress. Paid vacation time is an increment of compensated leave to which an eligible employee is entitled under this bill.

Superfund Reinvestment Act Amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) to authorize the use of amounts in the Hazardous Substance Superfund for environmental cleanup costs authorized by such Act. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) extend the Hazardous Substance Superfund financing rate through December 31, 2024; and (2) increase the environmental excise tax on certain chemicals sold by their manufacturers, producers, and importers.

Directs the Great Lakes National Program Office to conduct: (1) five full scale demonstration projects of promising technologies to remedy contaminated sediments at appropriate sites; and (2) assessments and pilot scale demonstration projects of promising technologies at each area of concern.

World Trade Center Zone Tax Incentive Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to treat as conducted outside the United States any qualified headquarters activities of a foreign corporation conducted in the New York Liberty Zone if such corporation: (1) enters into a contract to acquire, lease, sublease, or otherwise occupy office space in the New York Liberty Zone for use in the conduct of relocation activities; and (2) before September 11, 2009, transfers qualified headquarters activities to the Zone and locates employees in the Zone.

Rights of the Child Act of 1997 - Expresses the sense of the Congress that the President should submit and seek the advice and consent of the Senate by December 31, 1998, to ratification of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, adopted by the United Nations with the support of the United States on November 29, 1989, and signed by Madeleine Albright as United States Delegate to the United Nations and on behalf of the United States. <n>(Sec. 3) Directs the Attorney General to meet with the attorneys general of the States and territories of the United States for the purpose of determining their recommendations concerning any limitations in the form of reservations, declarations, statements, and understandings that should accompany a proposed resolution of ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. <n>(Sec. 5) Establishes an advisory commission to be appointed by the President, the Speaker and minority leader of the House of Representatives, and the Secretary of Health and Human Services (or designee), with experience, expertise, and concerns pertaining to the economic, social, cultural, political, and civil rights of children as well as individuals who are parents or legal guardians of children. <n>Requires the commission to report to the Congress on any recommendations agreed to by a majority of its members for the United States contribution

Informed P2P User Act - Prohibits any commercial entity that develops a file sharing program from installing, making available for installation, or downloading a file sharing program without: (1) immediately before program installation or downloading, providing conspicuous notice that the program allows files to be searched and copied by one or more other computers and obtaining informed consent to the installation; and (2) immediately before initial activation of a file sharing function of the program, providing conspicuous notice of which files will be made available and obtaining informed consent.<n><n>Exempts: (1) modifications or upgrades of a program that was originally installed in compliance with this Act, provided certain requirements are met; and (2) pre-installed software.<n><n>Makes it unlawful for such an entity to prevent the reasonable efforts of an owner or authorized user to block the installation of such a program or to prevent such a user from having a reasonable way to disable or remove the program.<n><n>Requires violations of this Act to be treated as unfair or deceptive acts or practices under the Federal Trade Commission Act.

Guaranteed Health Coverage for Pre- Existing Conditions Act of 2014 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to prohibit a group health plan from imposing any preexisting condition exclusion. Defines "preexisting condition exclusion" as a limitation or exclusion of benefits relating to a condition based on the fact that the condition was present before the date of enrollment in such plan or for such coverage, whether or not any medical advice, diagnosis, care, or treatment was recommended or received before such date. Excludes genetic information from being treated as a preexisting condition in the absence of a diagnosis of the condition related to such information.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 6, 2017. Safe Drinking Water Assistance Act of 2017 (Sec. 4) This bill requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to: (1) review federal efforts to identify, monitor, and assist in the development of treatment methods for emerging contaminants and to assist states in responding to the human health challenges posed by those contaminants; (2) establish a strategic plan for improving those federal efforts; and (3) jointly establish a Working Group to coordinate federal activities to identify and analyze the public health effects of drinking water contaminants of emerging concern. The working group shall develop a strategic plan for improving federal efforts to identify, monitor, and assist in the development of treatment methods for emerging contaminants. The EPA must also submit to Congress a national research strategy on drinking water contaminants of emerging concern that includes: (1) research recommendations and recommendations for regulatory actions to address emerging contaminants as well as potential adverse effects on the health of individuals, a description of current federal efforts to address emerging contaminants as well as potential adverse effects on the health of individuals, and a description of research efforts supporting the development of treatment methods for emerging contaminants. The Government Accountability Office must report on the federal efforts to identify and analyze the public health effects of drinking water contaminants of emerging concern.

Workplace Integrity Act - (Sec. 2) Prohibits granting official time to any federal employee in connection with any matter covered by this Act, except: (1) to represent an exclusive representative in the negotiation of a collective bargaining agreement or in any activity relating to the internal business of a labor organization, including the solicitation of membership, elections, and collection of dues; or (2) to present a grievance on the employee's own behalf, under a negotiated grievance procedure, or in connection with any consultation or meeting with management officials officially requested or approved by the agency. Allows official time to be granted in any amount that the agency and the exclusive representative involved agree to be reasonable, necessary, and in the public interest, but only to the extent that it would not cause the ratio of the total amount of official time granted to such employee for use during any period over the total amount of time such employee would otherwise normally be in duty status to exceed 50%. Directs the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to report to the President and Congress annually on the use of official time.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow the issuance of tax-exempt bonds to finance alternative motor vehicle facilities. Limits the amount of such bonds which may be allocated by the Secretary of the Treasury to $12 billion, of which up to $4 billion may be allocated to any single taxpayer.

Military Families Act - Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) or the Attorney General to adjust the status of an eligible alien to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence if the alien: (1) applies for adjustment (with a time limit for an alien applying as a family member of a deceased Armed Forces member), (2) is admissible to the United States as an immigrant, and (3) pays a fee for processing the application and is physically present in the United States. Applies such provision to an alien who is: (1) a parent, spouse, child, son, or daughter (and their spouse, child, son, or daughter, if any) of a living Armed Forces member or of a deceased Armed Forces member who died as a result of service-incurred injury or disease; or (2) a son or daughter who has a Filipino parent who was naturalized as a U.S. citizen or lawfully admitted permanent resident if separated from service due to honorable conditions.

Preventing a Government Shutdown Act - Provides for automatic continuing appropriations if any regular appropriation for a fiscal year (or, if applicable, for each fiscal year in a biennium) does not become law before the beginning of such fiscal year, or a joint resolution making continuing appropriations is not in effect. Appropriates amounts necessary to continue any project or activity for which funds were provided in the preceding fiscal year: (1) in the corresponding regular appropriation Act for such preceding fiscal year; or (2) if such legislation did not become law, then in the joint resolution making continuing appropriations for such preceding fiscal year. Sets forth the terms and conditions relating to such continuing appropriations.

SMA Treatment Acceleration Act of 2009 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to: (1) provide for the upgrading and unification of spinal muscular atrophy clinical trial sites and the recruitment of new investigators and sites to establish a national clinical trials network for spinal muscular atrophy; and (2) establish a data coordinating center with respect to spinal muscular atrophy. Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to enhance and provide ongoing support to a spinal muscular atrophy patient registry to provide for expanded epidemiological research towards improving awareness, management, treatment, and prevention of spinal muscular atrophy. Requires the Secretary to: (1) ensure the collection and analysis of longitudinal data related to individuals with spinal muscular atrophy; and (2) establish the Interagency Spinal Muscular atrophy Research Coordinating Committee.

Amends the Small Business Act to designate one of the Associate Administrators as Associate Administrator for Telecommunications Finance, responsible for the supervision and management of financing in the area of telecommunications. Grants such Administrator authority to: (1) prescribe maximum amounts for loan guarantees in telecommunications; (2) approve all direct loans in telecommunications; and (3) approve loan guarantees with respect to Federal Communications Commission spectrum licenses acquired in the secondary market. <n>Directs the Associate Administrator, in the administration of the Telecommunications Spectrum Installment Loan Program and the Telecommunications Accelerated Certified Lender Program, to observe strict neutrality as to the choice that a potential applicant may make as to the appropriateness of a program for the applicant. Requires the choice to be solely that of the applicant and the Associate Administrator. <n>Establishes within the Small Business Administration (SBA) the Telecommunications Finance Office, to be headed by such Associate Administrator, to perform functions relating to SBA policies and programs with respect to financing in the area of telecommunications. Requires such Office to: (1) make direct loans to qualified telecommunications borrowers for acquisition of spectrum licenses through Federal Communications Commission auction; and (2) guarantee loans to qualified telecommunications borrowers for telecommunications equipment and working capital in connection with such acquisition. <n>Prohibits the Administrator from disburse any loan amount

Nuclear and Terrorism Threat Reduction Act of 2002 - Declares it to be U.S. policy to work cooperatively with the Russian Federation to prevent the diversion of weapons of mass destruction and materials relating thereto, including nuclear, biological, and chemical weapons, as well as the scientific and technical expertise necessary to design and build such weapons.Requires the President to report to Congress on how to enhance the implementation of U.S.-Russia non-proliferation and threat reduction programs, including recommendations on how to improve and streamline the contracting and procurement practices of those programs and a listing of impediments to their efficient and effective implementation.States that it is U.S. policy to establish jointly with the Russian Federation comprehensive inventories and data exchanges of Russian and U.S. weapons-grade material and assembled warheads, with particular attention to tactical, or nonstrategic," weapons a terrorist organization or terrorist state would attempt to acquire, and with particular attention focused on weapons that have been removed from deployment."

. Reducing Gun Violence in our Neighborhoods Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose an additional excise tax on the sale of firearms by manufacturers, producers, or importers. The tax is $100 per firearm, which shall not apply to any firearm purchased by the United States or by a state or local government for police or other law enforcement purposes. (Sec. 3) The bill establishes the Gun Violence Reduction and Mental Health Counseling Trust Fund into which appropriations shall be allocated for: (1) block grants for community mental health services, (2) block grants for community mental health services under the Public Health Service Act, and (3) expenditures to carry out specified provisions of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. (Sec. 4) The bill directs the Department of Justice (DOJ) to establish a national standard for the incorporation of a passive identification capability into all firearms sold in the United States. It shall be unlawful for a person, in or affecting interstate or foreign commerce, to manufacture a firearm that does not have a passive identification capability that does not emit or broadcast an electronic signal or other information that would enable the firearm or its owner to be monitored or tracked. DOJ shall give equal priority to the right of firearm owners to maintain their full right to privacy under

Mapping a New and Innovative Focus on Our Exploration Strategy for Human Spaceflight Act of 2016 or the MANIFEST for Human Spaceflight Act of 2016 This bill reaffirms that the long-term goal of the human space flight and exploration efforts of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) shall be to expand permanent human presence beyond low-Earth orbit and to do so, where practical, in a manner involving international partners. NASA shall submit an interim and final report setting forth a strategy to achieve human exploration of Mars, including the establishment of a capability to extend human presence to the surface of Mars.

Pathways to Prosperity Act of 2014 - Amends the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act to revise the requirements for the plan of a state seeking federal assistance for career and technical education programs. Requires the state plan to describe how the state will implement: (1) a coordinated, non-duplicative sequence of secondary and postsecondary academic and technical courses that contain rigorous, state-identified college and career readiness standards that align to local, regional, or state labor market needs; (2) support attainment of career readiness skills; (3) progress in content specificity; (4) incorporate multiple entry and exit points with portable demonstrations of technical competency, which may include postsecondary education credits as recognized by credit transfer or articulation agreements or industry-recognized credentials; and (5) culminate in the attainment of an industry-recognized credential, an apprenticeship or postsecondary certificate, or an associate or baccalaureate degree. Requires the Department of Education to: (1) collect information on the industry-recognized credentials awarded to participants in career and technical education programs of study, and (2) ensure that the necessary wage records are available to enable eligible agencies to collect data relating to the state performance measure.

Senior Nutrition Act of 2002 - Amends the Agriculture and Consumer Protection Act of 1973 to make elderly persons eligible for the commodity supplemental food program if they are at least 60 years old and have a household income less than or equal to 185 percent of the most recent Federal Poverty Income Guidelines. Authorizes appropriations for the program.

Financial Crisis Investigation Act of 2009 - Amends the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 (EESA) to expand the duties of the Oversight Panel of the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) to include investigating: (1) all causes, domestic and global, of the current financial and economic crisis in the United States, including the collapse of major financial and commercial firms and the deterioration of the credit and housing markets; (2) the role in the crisis of any financial or commercial corporation, partnership, hedge fund, private equity firm, or entity, including any of its employees; (3) the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), nationally recognized statistical rating organizations, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC), the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac), trading facilities for commodities, and self-regulatory organizations; (4) the federal banking agencies; and (5) any other governmental or nongovernmental entity, including any of its employees.<n><n>Requires the Panel to conduct a top-to-bottom review of the nation's existing financial regulatory structure and the contribution of the current structure to the stability or instability of financial markets, in order to develop a comprehensive framework for: (1) reforming the laws governing our nation's financial markets; (2) strengthening regulatory

Mortgage Disclosure Simplification Act of 2007- Amends the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974 to direct the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to develop standard written forms for statement of the essential terms of a federally related mortgage loan.

Authorizes appropriations.Directs the Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration to establish a select cadre of Special Agents with Spanish language capabilities who shall work with State and local law enforcement agencies across the United States on matters relating to the combating of methamphetamine-related drug trafficking.Authorizes appropriations.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 9, 2013. Organization of American States Revitalization and Reform Act of 2013 - (Sec. 4) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the Organization of American States (OAS) should be the primary multilateral diplomatic entity for regional dispute resolution and promotion of democratic governance and institutions; (2) the OAS should be the primary multilateral diplomatic entity for regional dispute resolution and promotion of democratic governance and institutions; (3) the Summit of the Americas institution and process should be formally and more effectively integrated into the work of the OAS, the Inter-American Development Bank, and other Members of the Joint Summit Working Group; (4) the OAS should be combined geographically and in conjunction with the Summit; (5) it should review its core functions at least annually and seek opportunities to reduce the number of mandates not directly related to its core functions; (6) it should remain central to the strategic planning process of the OAS; and (7) any new OAS mandate should be accepted by member states only after a financial analysis is conducted and formally presented to assure the organization's financial sustainability. (Sec. 5) Directs the Secretary of State to submit to specified congressional committees a multiyear strategy that: (1) identifies a path toward the adoption of necessary reforms that prioritize

High Performance Schools Act of 1999- Establishes in the Department of Education the High Performance Schools Program. Authorizes the Secretary of Education, through the Program, to make grants to: (1) school districts to implement the purpose of this Act; (2) administer the program of assistance to school districts; and (3) promote participation by school districts in the program. <n>Requires grants to be used to achieve energy efficiency performance not less than 30 percent beyond the levels prescribed in the 1998 International Energy Conservation Code as it is in effect for new construction and existing buildings. Requires grants to be made to school districts that: (1) have demonstrated a need for such grants in order to respond appropriately to increasing elementary and secondary school enrollments or to make major investments in renovation of school facilities; (2) have demonstrated that they do not have adequate funds to respond appropriately to such enrollments or achieve such investments without assistance; and (3) have made a commitment to use the grant funds to develop high performance school buildings in accordance with the plan developed and approved pursuant to this Act. <n>Requires grants to be used to evaluate compliance by school districts with requirements of this Act and in addition to be used for: (1) distributing information and materials to clearly define and promote the development of high performance school buildings for both new and existing facilities;

Commission on the Accountability and Review of Federal Agencies Act - Establishes the Commission on the Accountability and Review of Federal Agencies to: (1) evaluate executive agencies and their programs; and (2) submit to Congress a plan with recommendations of the agencies and programs that should be realigned or eliminated and proposed implementing legislation. Sets forth provisions governing congressional consideration of such legislation.

Directs that not fewer than 6,000 National Guard personnel shall continue to be deployed along the international border between the United States and Mexico under Operation Jump Start until the federal government has achieved operational control of such border. Exempts National Guard personnel deployed pursuant to this Act from the calculation to determine compliance with: (1) limits on end strength; or (2) limits on the number of National Guard personal that may be placed on active duty for operational support.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary of Defense to provide funds to a state governor who submits to the Secretary a state border control activities plan meeting specified requirements, including: (1) the pay, allowances, clothing, subsistence, gratuities, travel, and related expenses of National Guard personnel for border control activities; (2) the operation and maintenance of the equipment and facilities of the state's National Guard used for border control activities; and (3) the procurement of services and equipment, and the leasing of equipment, for such state's National Guard used for border control activities. Limits the use of such funds for the procurement of equipment to $5,000 per item, unless approval for procurement of equipment in excess of that amount is granted in advance by the Secretary.

Beved Consumer's Bill of Rights Act of 2010 - Directs the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to prescribe rules prohibiting unfair or deceptive acts or practices in the provision of funeral goods or services, including prohibitions on misrepresentations by providers and on conditioning the provision of any funeral good or funeral service upon the purchase of any other funeral good or funeral service from that provider, except as required by law. Requires future rules prescribed by the FTC prohibiting unfair or deceptive acts or practices in the provision of funeral goods or services to apply to cemeteries and religious organizations that are exempt from taxation under specified Internal Revenue Code provisions.

Select Agent Program and Biosafety Improvement Act of 2008 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to extend through 2013 the select agent program. Amends the Agricultural Bioterrorism Protection Act of 2002 to revise the list of the biological agents and toxins that are subject to the program. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to contract with the National Academy of Sciences to conduct a review of the program.

Curecanti National Recreation Area Boundary Establishment Act of 2010- Establishes the Curecanti National Recreation Area in Colorado, as a unit of the National Park System, and the Curecanti Conservation Opportunity Area, as a conservation opportunity area.

Transit Accessibility Innovation Act of 2014 - Directs the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) to carry out a transit accessibility innovation program to encourage public transit systems to take actions to address deficiencies in service for individuals with disabilities. Directs the Secretary to develop criteria to ensure that projects receiving funding under the program are innovative and replicable in other communities and will result in a substantive improvement in service for individuals with disabilities. Sets forth certain grant application requirements.

Suspends the application of Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) preferences to Brazil if the President determines that it is important to the national interests to: (1) attain the immediate return of Sean Goldman and all children wrongfully held in Brazil under the Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction; and (2) recognize the national interests of all children in Brazil who are being held in Brazil pursuant to such Convention and to the appropriate congressional committees that have objects to the suspension of this Act if the President so determines and reports to appropriate congressional committees that it is important to the national interests of all children in Brazil who are being held in Brazil pursuant to such Convention and to the appropriate congressional committees that have objects to the suspension of this Act.

Quadrennial Energy Review Act of 2011 - Amends the Department of Energy Organization Act to direct the President to establish an interagency working group to coordinate the Quadrennial Energy Review to provide an integrated view of national energy objectives and federal energy policy. Defines Quadrennial Energy Review" as a comprehensive multiyear examination of the energy programs and technologies of the federal government."

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Wood Regulatory Relief Act of 2014 (Sec. 2) This bill prohibits the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) from finalizing, issuing, implementing, or enforcing any rule under the Clean Air Act that applies to: a proposed rule entitled "Standards of Performance for New Residential Wood Heaters, New Residential Hydronic Heaters, and Forced-air Furnaces" or substantially similar rules; and any other rule under such Act that is applicable to any new source that is a residential heater, a forced-air furnace, or a residential heater that is certified as in compliance with any applicable emissions limit for particulate matter, except that such rule permits such a heater to be sold at retail for a specified period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act. During such period, the EPA may not establish: a particulate matter emissions limit for adjustable rate wood heaters or pellet heaters/stoves that were certified as being in compliance with any applicable standard of performance for particulate matter on or before the effective date of the rule; a particulate matter emissions limit for all other adjustable rate wood heaters, single rate wood heaters, or pellet heaters/stoves that are less than 4.5 grams of particulate matter per hour; a particulate

Authorizes appropriations for FY 2000 for specified Department of Agriculture and Department of Commerce programs relating to disaster relief for agricultural producers affected by Hurricane Floyd and other specified hurricanes.

Health Insurance Rate Review Act This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to declare that federal requirements that the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) review unreasonable premium increases in health care coverage do not prohibit a state from imposing additional rate requirements on health insurance issuers that are more protective of consumers. The review is expanded to include all rate increases, not only premium increases. HHS or the relevant state insurance commissioner or state regulator must ensure that any excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory rates are corrected before, or as soon as possible after, implementation, including through mechanisms such as denying rates, modifying rates, or requiring rebates to consumers. HHS may require a state to undertake corrective actions as a condition for receiving grant funds.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to suspend excise taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene from May 26, 2008, until September 1, 2008. Provides for the reimbursement of the Highway Trust Fund and the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund for tax receipts lost during the period.

Violence Against Children Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal criminal code to provide that whoever, whether or not acting under color of law, by force or threat of force willfully injures or attempts to injure any person under 18 years of age: (1) shall be imprisoned for not more than ten years and fined; and (2) shall be imprisoned for any term of years or for life, and fined if the death results from the offense or the offense includes kidnaping or an attempt to kidnap, aggravated sexual abuse, or an attempt to commit aggravated sexual abuse or an attempt to kill.Directs the United States Sentencing Commission to review and amend its guidelines and policy statements to provide enhanced penalties when a victim of a Federal crime is under 18 years of age.Requires the Comptroller General to review State laws and the sentencing practices of the States with respect to those crimes, including whether a State provides enhanced penalties when the victim is a child.Directs the Attorney General to provide technical, forensic, prosecutorial, or other assistance in the criminal investigation or prosecution of any crime that: (1) constitutes a crime of violence under Federal law; (2) constitutes a felony under State or Indian tribal law; and (3) is committed against a person under 18 years of age.

Birth Defects Prevention Act of 1993 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control, to award grants to, enter into cooperative agreements with, or provide direct technical assistance in lieu of cash to States, State health authorities, or health agencies of political subdivisions of a State for collection, analysis, and reporting of birth defects statistics and to collect and disaggregate such statistics by gender and racial and ethnic group. <n>Directs the Secretary to establish at least five regional birth defects monitoring and research programs for collecting and analyzing information on the number, incidence, correlates, and causes of birth defects, to include information regarding gender and different racial and ethnic groups, including Hispanics, non-Hispanic whites, African Americans, Native Americans, and Asian Americans. <n>Authorizes the Secretary, acting through the Director, to award grants or enter into cooperative agreements with State departments of health, universities, or other private, nonprofit entities engaged in research to enable such entities to serve as Centers of Excellence for Birth Defects Prevention Research. <n>Directs the Secretary, acting through the Director, to award grants to or enter into cooperative agreements with State departments of health, universities, or other private, nonprofit

Disaster Recovery Personal Protection Act of 2006 - Amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to prohibit any federal officer or employee, person operating pursuant to or under color of federal law, receiving federal funds, or providing services to such an officer, employee, or other person, while acting in support of relief from a major disaster or emergency, from: (1) temporarily or permanently seizing, or authorizing seizure, of any firearm the possession of which is not prohibited under federal or state law, other than for forfeiture in compliance with federal law or as evidence in a criminal investigation; (2) requiring the registration of any firearm for which registration is not required; or (3) prohibiting the possession of any firearm in any place or by any person where such possession is not otherwise prohibited by federal or state law. Authorizes an aggrieved individual to seek relief in an action at law, suit in equity, or other proper proceeding for redress against any person who subjects such individual, or causes such individual to be subjected to the deprivation of any of such rights, privileges, or immunities.

Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation Governance Improvement Act of 2009 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to expand the board of directors of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC) to include the Secretaries of the Treasury, Labor, and Commerce; a member representative of employers offering defined benefit plans; a member representative of organized labor and employees; and two other members. Requires board members to be appointed by the President, with the advice and consent of the Senate, at the beginning of the second year of the President's term of office and for four years thereafter. Prohibits more than two members from being affiliated with the same political party. Requires board members to designate in writing an official, not below the level of Assistant Secretary, to serve as the voting representative. Requires board members to serve without compensation and to be reimbursed for travel, subsistence, and other necessary expenses.

Calling for 2-1-1 Act of 2003 - Directs the Secretary of Commerce to award a grant to each State to carry out a program for making available throughout such State 2-1-1 telephone service for information and referral on human services. Requires the Secretary to develop a formula for allocating grant amounts among the States so that a grant may be awarded to each State seeking a grant.

Imported and Domestic Product Safety Act of 2009 - Establishes the Office of Imported and Domestic Product Safety in the Department of Commerce. Requires the Director of the Office to: (1) ensure coordination among federal agencies responsible for product safety that protects the health and safety of U.S. consumers and provides access to product safety information; (2) establish policies, objectives, and priorities to improve the management, coordination, promotion, and oversight of such agencies; (3) work with consumer groups, industry, and other interested parties to establish policies, objectives, and priorities; (4) improve the www.Recalls.gov Internet website that provides product safety information and recall information for products under different federal agencies; (5) develop a database that is centralized, user-friendly, and accessible to the public; (6) promote the development of risk assessment models to assist federal agencies responsible for the importation and safety of products to better identify and prevent the importation or introduction into commerce of unsafe products; (7) promote the development of tracing technology to provide consumers with access to the supply chain history of a product; (8) develop guidelines to facilitate information sharing relating to the importation and safety of U.S. products with respect to foreign countries; and (9) establish an advisory committee to assist in carrying out the Director's duties.

Energy and Science Research Investment of 2003 - Authorizes appropriations to the Office of Science of the Department of Energy for FY 2004 through 2007 to: (1) conduct a comprehensive program of fundamental research on chemical sciences, physics, materials sciences, biological and environmental sciences, geosciences, engineering sciences, plasma sciences, mathematics, and advanced scientific computing; (2) maintain, upgrade, and expand the scientific user facilities maintained by the Office and ensure that they are an integral part of the departmental mission for exploring the frontiers of fundamental science and nanotechnology; and (3) ensure that its fundamental science programs help inform the applied research and development programs of the Department.

Lebanon and Syria Liberation Act - Declares it to be U.S. policy to deny Syria the ability to: (1) finance, provide safe-haven or otherwise support terrorist organizations; (2) develop biological, chemical, or nuclear weapons and long-range ballistic missiles; (3) continue to occupy and otherwise interfere in the affairs of the government of Lebanon; (4) continue to oppress the people of Syria; (5) advocate for, and seek within the United Nations Security Council a mandatory international embargo against Syria; and (6) facilitate the development of Syria's nuclear, biological, or chemical weapons capabilities, or to help make operational any nuclear facility in Syria will have a detrimental impact on U.S. assistance to such country. States that such sanctions shall remain in effect until the President certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that: (1) a government exists in Syria that has ceased all support for terrorism, has permanently dismantled Syria's biological, chemical, or nuclear weapons programs, and has committed to combat the proliferation of such weapons; (2) has withdrawn from Lebanon and respects the boundaries and sovereignty of all neighboring countries; and (3) sovereignty has been restored to Lebanon and there exists a freely-elected, internationally recognized democratic government in Lebanon. Authorizes the President to provide development assistance to Syria and Lebanon to support a transition
