Atchafalaya National Heritage Area Act - (Sec. 5) Establishes the Atchafalaya National Heritage Area in Louisiana.(Sec. 6) Designates the Atchafalaya Trace Commission as the local coordinating entity (the entity) of the Heritage Area.(Sec. 7) Requires the Commission to develop and implement a management plan, subject to the Secretary of the Interior's approval, that recognizes important resource values within the Heritage Area, encourages sustainable economic development within the Heritage Area, and increases public awareness and appreciation for the natural, historic, and cultural resources of the Heritage Area.(Sec. 8) Prohibits the use of Federal funds to acquire real property or any interest in real property.(Sec. 9) Establishes a procedure for the voluntary inclusion of private property in the Heritage Area.(Sec. 10) Sets forth private property protections.(Sec. 11) Declares the effect of this Act with regard to certain authorities and powers.

Social Security Family Relief Act - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to continue an individual's entitlement to benefits through the month of his or her death with benefits for that month disregarded for purposes of determining maximum family benefits.

Protecting Neighborhoods from Oil Pollution Act of 2011 - Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (commonly known as the Clean Water Act) to direct the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to issue final regulations requiring an owner or operator of an oil storage or processing facility to permanently close such facility if: (1) the facility is located within one mile of 100 or more residential units and two or more covered discharges occur at such facility within any 10-year period; and (2) the facility is the source of groundwater contamination affecting 100 or more residential units.

Veteran Employment Through Technology Education Courses Act or the VET TEC Act Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out a five-year pilot program to provide eligible veterans with the opportunity to enroll in high technology programs of education, which are programs offered by entities other than institutions of higher learning, do not lead to a degree, and provide instruction in computer programming, computer software, media application, data processing, or information sciences. Requires the Secretary to: (1) enter into contracts with multiple qualified providers of such programs, under which the Secretary shall pay to such providers 25% of the cost of providing the program upon the enrollment of an eligible veteran, 25% of such cost upon the completion of the program, and 50% of such cost upon the employment of the veteran following completion; and (2) give preference to a qualified provider that offers tuition reimbursement for any student who completes a program of education offered by the provider and does not find full-time meaningful employment within the 180-day period beginning on the date the student completes the program. Directs the Secretary to pay a monthly housing stipend to each enrolled veteran who is enrolled in a high technology program of education on a full-time basis.

Lacey Implementation and Enforcement Fairness Act or RELIEF Act - Amends the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 to declare that the Act does not apply with respect to: (1) any plant imported into the United States before May 22, 2008; or (2) any finished plant or plant product the assembly and processing by such date. Declares that the Act is the sole authority for civil seizure or forfeiture actions alleging, or predicated upon, a violation of such Act. Exempts from such Act: (1) plant products derived from a tree; or (2) solid wood.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Frank and Jeanne Moore Wild Steelhead Management Area Designation Act (Sec. 3) This bill designates approximately 99,653 acres of Forest Service land in Oregon as the "Frank Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area." Nothing in this bill diminishes any treaty rights of an Indian tribe.

Directs the Secretary to establish such criteria as is required for payment with respect to the type of patient, patient condition, unusual variations, and home health service that qualifies for such waiver.

Veterans Education Flexibility Act - Amends Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) veterans' educational assistance provisions to allow an extension of the time limitation for using such benefits if the eligible individual is enrolled in an educational institution regularly operated on the quarter or semester system and the period of entitlement would expire during a quarter or semester, but if the individual is enrolled in an educational institution not regularly operated on the quarter or semester system and the period of entitlement would expire after a major portion of the course is completed. Requires such an extension to the end of the course or for 12 weeks, whichever is the lesser period of extension.

Inventory of Assets for Communications Facilities Act of 2018 This bill requires the General Services Administration (GSA) to ensure that the database established under Executive Order 13327 includes an inventory of federal real property or federal interest in real property on which a communications facility could be constructed or that is suitable for deployment of communications facilities or services. The GSA must make the inventory available to the Department of Commerce and any entity that constructs or operates communications facilities or provides communications services.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on January 30, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.)Veterans' Burial Benefits Enhancement Act of 2003 - (Sec. 2) Authorizes the burial allowance to be paid to any veteran who is eligible for burial benefits based on being a veteran of any war (currently limited to those who were discharged from the active military, naval, or air service for a disability incurred or aggravated in the line of duty and who are veterans of any war).(Sec. 3) Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to lease National Cemetery Administration land or facilities for up to three years in the public interest. Requires the Secretary, before entering into such a lease, to publish in a newspaper of general circulation in the community in which such land or facilities are located appropriate public notice of the Secretary's intention to enter into such lease.Requires proceeds from such a lease to be deposited in the National Cemetery Administration account.(Sec. 4) Directs the Secretary to establish a national cemetery in each geographic area in which: (1) the number of veterans who reside more than 50 miles from an open national cemetery or State cemetery for veterans exceeds 170,000; or (2) the number of veterans who reside more than 50 miles from an open

Iran Human Rights Act of 2007 (Sec. 3) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the President should designate Iran as a country of particular concern with respect to violations of internationally recognized human rights; (2) the President should designate Iran as a country of particular concern with respect to violations of internationally recognized human rights; and (3) the Secretary of State should designate Iran as a country of particular concern with respect to violations of internationally recognized human rights unless the Secretary certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that Iran has: (1) released all political prisoners; (2) ceased its practices of violence and abuse of Iranian citizens engaging in peaceful political activity; and (3) conducted a transparent investigation into the killings and abuse of peaceful political activists in Iran and prosecuted those responsible. (Sec. 4) Prohibits the importation into the United States of any textile or food article from Iran until the President certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that Iran has: (1) released all political prisoners; (2) ceased its practices of violence and abuse of Iranian citizens engaging in peaceful political activity; and (3) conducted a transparent investigation into the killings and abuse of peaceful political activists in Iran and prosecuted those responsible.

Directs the Secretary, in consideration of the Authority assuming from the United States all liability for administration, operation, maintenance, and replacement of the Griffith Project and subject to the Authority of the Federal repayment amount of $121,204,348, to: (1) convey and assign to the Authority all interest of the United States in and to improvements and facilities of the Project in existence as of this Act's effective date; (2) convey and assign to the Authority all interests reserved and developed in lands patented by the United States for the Project; and (3) convey and assign to the Authority all interests reserved and developed in lands patented by the United States for the Project. Declares that, from the effective date of such conveyance: (1) the Authority shall have a right-of-way at no cost across all Public Land and across any Federal lands as reasonably necessary for the prepayment of the Project, including existing access routes; and (2) rights-of-way established by this Act shall be valid for as long as they are needed for municipal water supply purposes and shall not require payment of rental or other fee.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service, to establish the Office for the Preservation of America's Main Street. <n>Directs the Office to: (1) support efforts of State and local public and private persons and entities in the States to preserve Route 66; (2) act as a clearinghouse for communication among Federal, State, and local agencies and private persons and entities interested in the preservation of Route 66; and (3) assist the States in determining the appropriate form of, and establishing and supporting a non-Federal entity or entities to perform the functions of the Office after it is terminated. <n>Authorizes the Office to: (1) enter into cooperative agreements; (2) accept donations; (3) provide cost-share grants; (4) provide technical assistance in historic preservation and fundraising; and (5) conduct research. Requires the Office to sponsor a road sign program on Route 66 to be implemented on a cost-sharing basis with State and local organizations. <n>Requires the Office to provide assistance in the preservation of Route 66 in a manner that is compatible with the nature of the highway and to cooperate with the States and local public and private persons and entities in developing local preservation plans to guide efforts to protect the most important or representative resources of Route 66. <n>Requires

Camera Accountability Maintenance and Transparency in Policing Act of 2017 or the CAM TIP Act of 2017 This bill amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize the Department of Justice's Bureau of Justice Assistance to make matching grants to states, local governments, and Indian tribes for the acquisition, operation, and maintenance of body-worn cameras for law enforcement officers. A grantee's body camera program must: establish policies and procedures for when law enforcement officers should wear, activate, and deactivate such cameras; ensure the protection of civil liberties of members of the general public; limit the use of recordings of such cameras to monitor the conduct of law enforcement officers outside of their official interactions with the public; develop standards regarding the effective body placement of such cameras; describe best practices for receiving an accurate narrative from recordings; establish procedures for collecting and storing recordings; establish policies governing the availability of such recordings to the general public, to victims of crimes, and for internal use by law enforcement; and have guidelines and training for law enforcement officers on the proper management and use of such cameras. The bill limits the federal share (with respect to the matching requirement) of program costs to 50%. The bill establishes in Justice a task force to study the cost to state and local law enforcement agencies of

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 5, 2017. Improving Corporate Governance Through Diversity Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill requires an executive agency to require a for-profit business with annual gross receipts in excess of $1 billion that is awarded a contract of $5 million or more to submit to the agency data on: the racial, ethnic, and gender composition of the board of directors and the C-level executives of the contractor; data on the affiliation of any member of the board of directors or any C-level executive to a historically underrepresented group; and any plan or strategy to improve the diversity of the board of directors or the C-level executives of the contractor. Each executive agency shall submit quarterly reports to the General Services Administration (GSA) that include such data. The GSA shall submit annual reports to Congress and each Office of Minority and Women Inclusion established under the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act that analyze the diversity of the board of directors and the C-level executives of each entity submitting data in comparison to the industry peers of such entity. Based on such analysis, the GSA shall list each entity submitting data that is significantly lagging behind the industry peers of such entity with respect to the diversity of the
Medicaid Mammography Coverage Act of 1993 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to provide for coverage of screening mammography under the Medicaid program.

. Smart Water Management Conservation and Efficiency Act of 2014 - Requires the Department of Energy (DOE) to establish and carry out a smart water management pilot program to award grants to three to five eligible entities (authorities that provide drinking water, wastewater treatment, or water reuse services) to demonstrate and deploy novel and innovative technology-based solutions that will: (1) increase the energy and water efficiency of drinking water, wastewater treatment, and water reuse systems; (2) improve such systems to help communities make significant progress in conserving water, saving energy, and reducing costs; and (3) support the implementation of innovative processes and the installation of advanced automated systems that provide real-time data on energy and water. Directs DOE, in selecting grant recipients, to consider: energy and cost savings; the novelty of the technology to be used; the degree to which the project integrates next-generation sensors, software, analytics, and management tools; the anticipated cost-effectiveness of the pilot project in terms of energy efficiency savings, water savings or reuse, and infrastructure costs averted; whether the technology can be deployed in a variety of geographic regions and the degree to which the technology can be implemented on a smaller or larger scale; and whether the project will be completed in five years or less. Requires DOE to annually

Medicare Incentive Access Act of 2002 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a demonstration project under which an incentive payment is provided to primary care physicians for each physician's service furnished in a Medicare health professional shortage area to an individual enrolled under Medicare part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance).Directs the Secretary to designate an area in a State as a Medicare health professional shortage area if the Secretary determines that individuals enrolled under Medicare part B and residing in the area have inadequate access to primary care physicians.Requires the Secretary to select one or more Federal rural health research centers within the Health Resources Services Administration to establish a methodology to assist the Secretary in designating such areas.

Keeping Salvadoran Families Together Act This bill amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to permit a qualifying Salvadoran national who was granted, or is eligible for, temporary protected status (TPS) to apply for legal permanent resident status if such alien: (1) applies for adjustment within three years, (2) is determined to be admissible to the United States for permanent residence, and (3) meets certain criteria. (TPS designations permit eligible nationals of designated counties affected by armed conflict or natural disasters to temporarily reside and work in the United States.) The bill: (1) removes certain grounds of inadmissibility; (2) authorizes the waiver of the continuous physical presence requirement if an alien's removal would cause extreme hardship to the alien and to the alien's spouse, children, parents, or domestic partner; and (3) authorizes an alien who has applied for status adjustment to work. The bill provides that the granting of status adjustment shall not reduce the number of available immigrant visas.

Beginning Farmers and Ranchers Tax Incentive Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income 100 percent of the gain, up to $500,000, from the sale of qualified farm property to: (1) a first-time farmer who certifies that the use of such property shall be as a farm for farming purposes for at least ten years; (2) any other person who certifies that the use of such property shall be as a farm for farming purposes for at least ten years; and (3) any other person for any other use. Sets forth related provisions respecting: (1) recapture events; and (2) joint filers.

Small Business Tax Relief Act of 2007- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to make permanent the work opportunity tax credit, the new markets tax credit, the increased expensing allowance for depreciable business assets, the tax deduction for environmental remediation costs, and the tax credit for increasing research activities.<n><n>Allows qualified small businesses to elect a taxable year, other than the required taxable year, which ends on the last day of any of the months of April through November (or at the end of an equivalent annual period).

College Research Education and Teacher Excellence (CREATE) Opportunity Act of 2012 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to make the tax credit for increasing research activities permanent. Increases the rate of such credit from 65% to 100% for amounts paid to colleges and universities. Allows such credit for research in social sciences, arts, and humanities. Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to award up to two Federal Pell Grants annually to students attending junior or community colleges in a single award year to accelerate their progress toward a degree or certificate. Treats a recipient of such a grant as a Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loan for purposes of student loan repayment.

Prescription Drug Price Monitoring Commission Act of 1998 - Establishes the Prescription Drug Price Monitoring Commission to study: (1) the impact of a pharmaceutical price review board on containing inflation on the cost of prescription pharmaceutical products in the United States; (2) how Federal tax credits and subsidies, as well as market exclusivity given to the pharmaceutical industry, can be used to modify an individual manufacturer's pricing behavior and research priorities; (3) drug prices in other industrialized nations; and (4) the feasibility of establishing in the United States a pharmaceutical products price review board. <n>Directs the Commission to report annually to the Congress on: (1) trends and changes in prices for prescription and nonprescription drugs in the United States and in other industrialized nations; (2) the scope of coverage, reimbursement, and financing under titles XVIII (Medicare) and XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act and other programs that directly provide or receive Federal funds to provide coverage for or reimbursement of prescription drugs; (3) the availability and affordability of prescription drugs for various population groups in the United States and the accessibility and affordability of public and private insurance programs for prescription drugs for such population groups; (4) changes in the level and nature of use of prescription drugs by recipients of benefits under Medicare and Medicaid; (5) recommendations to make prescription drugs more affordable and cost-

Secure Federal File Sharing Act - Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to issue guidance on the use of peer-to-peer file sharing software: (1) to prohibit the download, installation, or use by government employees and contractors of open-network peer-to-peer file sharing software on all federal computers, computer systems, and networks, unless approved in accordance with procedures under this Act; and (2) to address the download, installation, or use by government employees and contractors of such software on home or personal computers as it relates to telework and remotely accessing federal computers, computer systems, and networks. Defines peer-to-peer file sharing software" as a program, application, or software that is commercially marketed or distributed to the public and that enables: (1) a file or files to be designated as available for searching and copying to one or more other computers; (2) the searching of such files and the copying of any such file to another computer at the initiative of such other computer and without requiring any action by an owner or authorized user of the computer on which such program is installed; and (3) an owner or authorized user to search files on one or more other computers using the same or a compatible program, application, or software that enables such"

Medicare Commission Act of 1995 (sic) - Establishes the National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program to provide analyses of and recommendations with respect to the current and long-term financial condition of the Medicare trust funds for a report to the President, the Congress, and the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Requires the Commission to make its report to the President and the Congress by December 31, 1996.

Drug Trafficking Elimination Act of 2007- Amends the Controlled Substances Act to: (1) impose mandatory minimum prison terms for manufacturing, distributing, or possessing with intent to manufacture, distribute, or export large amounts of heroin, marihuana, and methamphetamine; (2) impose mandatory minimum prison terms for manufacturing or cultivating controlled substances on federal property; (3) impose mandatory minimum prison terms for using, or knowingly using, a poison, chemical, or other hazardous substance on federal land; (4) include murder and other violent crimes in the definition of drug trafficking crime" and increase criminal penalties for drug trafficking and related crimes."

Check the Box for Homeless Veterans Act of 2013 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) establish in the Treasury the Homeless Veterans Assistance Fund; (2) allow individual taxpayers to designate on their tax returns a specified portion (not less than $1) of any overpayment of tax, and to make a contribution of an additional amount, to be paid over to such Fund to provide services to homeless veterans; and (3) require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to submit a detailed expenditure plan for any amounts in the Fund to the congressional veterans committees within 60 days before any expenditure of such amounts is expended.

Speak Up to Protect Every Abused Kid Act - Amends the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act (CAPTA) to revise the definition of child abuse or neglect" to include: (1) any recent act or failure to act on the part of a parent or caretaker that results in death, serious physical or emotional harm, or sexual abuse or exploitation, or an act or failure to act that presents an imminent risk of serious harm to a child; and (2) any deliberate act on the part of an individual other than a parent or caretaker that results in death, serious physical or emotional harm, or sexual abuse or exploitation, or that presents an imminent risk of serious harm to a child. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to make grants to eligible entities to carry out educational campaigns and provide training regarding state laws for mandatory reporting of incidents of child abuse or neglect. Requires the Secretary to develop and disseminate guidance and information on best practices for: (1) educational campaigns to educate members of the public about the acts and omissions that constitute child abuse or neglect under state law, the responsibilities of adults to report suspected and known incidents of child abuse or neglect under state law, and the ways in which adults can respond to help children and families without such reporting in a case"

Prohibits funds available to the Department of State, the Agency for International Development, or any other Federal agency or entity from being obligated or expended for specified activities relating to the participation of any individual in any conference, exchange program, or activity relating to education, culture, training, or activities relating to Tibetan culture and human rights until the President certifies to specified congressional committees that the Chinese Government has: (1) released all individuals who were detained in connection with the selection of the Eleventh Pan Lama and others believed to have been appointed by Chinese authorities as that boy's successor; (2) ceased its practices of placing individuals as candidates for the position of Pan Lama and others in charge of all religious worship, activity, and funding in China; and (3) conducted a transparent investigation into the detention and abuse of such individuals and prosecuted those responsible.

Stop Turning Out Prisoners Act - Amends the federal judicial code with respect to remedies for prison crowding to require that prospective relief in a civil action for prison conditions extend no further than necessary to remove the conditions that are causing the deprivation of Federal rights of individual plaintiffs. Requires the court to: (1) find that such relief is narrowly drawn and the least intrusive means to remedy the violation of the Federal right; and (2) give substantial weight to any adverse impact on public safety or the operation of a criminal justice system caused by the relief. Prohibits the court from granting or approving any relief whose purpose or effect is to reduce or limit the prison population, unless the plaintiff proves that crowding is the primary cause of the deprivation of the Federal right and no other relief will remedy that deprivation. Provides that any prospective relief in any civil action for prison conditions shall terminate two years after the later of: (1) the date the court found the violation of a Federal right that was the basis for the relief; or (2) enactment of this Act. Entitles a defendant or intervenor to the immediate termination of any prospective relief, if such relief was approved or granted in the absence of a finding by the court that prison conditions violated a Federal right. Sets forth the procedure for motions affecting prospective relief.

Noncitizen Benefit Clarification and Other Technical Amendments Act of 1998 - Amends the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996, with respect to qualified noncitizens who were receiving benefits on the date of enactment of such Act, to provide that such provision shall not apply to eligibility for benefits under the following programs that are based on eligibility for benefits under the Act: (1) the supplemental security income program; or (2) any other program based on eligibility for benefits under the Act. <n>(Sec. 3) Amends the North American Trade Agreement Implementation Act to extend the authority of self-employment assistance programs. <n>(Sec. 4) Amends part D (Child Support and Establishment of Paternity) of title IV of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to reduce the percentage reduction for States not in compliance with specified child support data processing and retrieval requirements if the Secretary has made specified determinations under the Act. <n>(Sec. 5) Amends the Act to provide that a foreign national not physically present in the United States may be issued a professional license to, or the renewal of a professional license by, a foreign national not physically present in the United States. <n>(Sec. 6) Amends the Personal Responsibility and Work

Marine Navigation Safety Improvement Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish in the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund the Marine Navigation Safety Account. Directs the Secretary of Commerce to transfer to the Account for the benefit of marine navigational safety programs of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Makes amounts in the Account available to carry out programs and activities of NOAA related to commercial marine navigation in the Water Resources Development Act of 1986.

Library Education and Development Act of 2003- Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to provide for student loan forgiveness under the Federal Family Education Loan and the Direct Loan programs to individuals who have been employed as full-time librarians for five consecutive complete school years in certain elementary or secondary schools whose total student enrollments consist of at least 30 percent children.

(Sec. 2) Requires an abbreviated new drug application to include a certification (as under current law) of the active ingredient of the drug for which investigations were conducted, either alone or in combination with another active ingredient or which claims the first approved use for such drug. (Current law requires only a certification of an active ingredient.)Prohibits the Secretary of Health and Human Services from delaying review and approval of an application unless the petition demonstrates through substantial scientific proof that approval of such application would pose a threat to public health and safety.(Sec. 4) Requires that the effects of the drug and the listed drug do not show a significant difference based on tests (other than tests that assess rate and extent of absorption), including comparative pharmacodynamic studies, limited confirmation studies, or in vitro methods, that demonstrate that no significant differences in therapeutic effects of active or inactive ingredients are expected.(Sec. 5) Prohibits the Secretary from delaying review and approval of an application unless the petition demonstrates through substantial scientific proof that approval of such application would pose a threat to public health and safety.

North Korean Human Rights Reauthorization Act of 2008 (Sec. 3) Expresses the sense of Congress that the United States should: (1) make it a priority to seek permission by ally North Korea to process North Korean refugees overseas for U.S. resettlement; (2) ensure that its screening, processing, and resettlement of North Korean refugees is as efficient and expeditious as possible; (3) appoint a Special Envoy for North Korean Human Rights Issues as a full-time position within the Department of State; and (4) participate in policy planning and implementation with respect to refugee issues as intended by the North Korean Human Rights Act of 2004. (Sec. 4) Expresses the sense of Congress that China should: (1) halt its forcible repatriation of North Koreans; (2) fulfill its obligations pursuant to the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, the 1967 Protocol Relating to the Status of Refugees, and the 1995 Agreement on the Status of Refugees in the People's Republic of China; and (3) allow North Koreans who have expressed a wish to pursue refugee resettlement in the United States to consult with senior officials of the United States and the government of China in order to coordinate refugee screening, processing, and resettlement efforts.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on December 10, 2013. (Sec. 1) This bill extends through January 31, 2014, the temporary suspension of permanent price support and supplemental agricultural disaster assistance authorities under the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008. The bill does not apply to: the nutrition assistance program; the conservation stewardship program, farmland protection program, environmental quality incentives program, and wildlife habitat incentives program; the trade adjustment assistance program; the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 relating to the use of Commodity Credit Corporation funds to support local and regional food aid procurement projects; the McGovern-Dole International Food for Education and Child Nutrition Program; survey and report regarding foods purchased by school food authorities; rural development and market loss assistance for producers; the National Sheep Industry Improvement Center program; market loss assistance for rural microentrepreneur producers; funding of pending rural development loan and grant applications; the Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000 relating to funding of value-added agricultural market development program grants; the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act relating to the use of Commodity Credit Corporation funds for the National Sheep Industry Improvement Center; and the Food Security Act of 1985 relating to the conservation stewardship program, farmland protection program, environmental quality incentives program, and wildlife habitat incentives program.

Declares that it shall not be unlawful by reason of any provision of the antitrust laws for a professional sports league to enforce rules authorizing the league membership to decide that a member club shall not be relocated. Requires a league to take specified criteria into consideration before making a decision to approve or disapprove the relocation of a member team, including: (1) the extent to which fan loyalty and support for the team has been demonstrated during its tenure in the community; (2) the degree to which the team has engaged in good faith negotiations with appropriate persons concerning terms and conditions under which the team would continue to play its games in the community or elsewhere within its home territory; (3) the degree to which the ownership or management of the team has contributed to any circumstances that might demonstrate the need for the relocation; (4) the extent to which the team received public financial support by means of any publicly financed playing facility, special tax treatment, or any other form of public financial support; (5) the adequacy of the stadium in which the team played its home games in the previous season and the willingness of the stadium, arena authority, or local government to remedy any deficiencies in the facility; (6) whether the team has incurred net operating losses, exclusive of depreciation and amortization, sufficient to threaten the continued financial viability of the team;

Private Property Protection Act of 1995 - Declares that no law or agency action should limit the use of privately owned property so as to diminish its value. Requires the Federal Government to compensate an owner of property whose use of any portion of that property has been limited by an agency action under a specified regulatory law that diminishes the fair market value of that portion by 20 percent or more. Declares that the amount of the compensation shall equal the diminution in value that resulted from the agency action. Requires the Federal Government, if the diminution in value of a portion of that property is greater than 50 percent, at the owner's option, to buy that portion of the property for its fair market value. Declares that property with respect to which compensation has been paid shall not thereafter be used contrary to the limitation imposed by the agency action, even if that action is later rescinded or otherwise vitiated, and the owner elects to refund the amount of the compensation, adjusted for inflation, to the Treasury. Declares that if a use is a nuisance as defined by the law of a State or is already prohibited under a local zoning ordinance, no compensation shall be made under this Act with respect to a limitation on that use. Declares

Full-Service Schools Act - Establishes the Federal Interagency Work Group to facilitate collaboration between agencies and mobilize Federal policy to achieve systemic reform to meet the comprehensive needs of at-risk children and to provide grants to States and local entities to develop similar programs at the State and local levels. <n>Directs the Group to: (1) assist Federal, State, and local agencies in developing, implementing, and evaluating service integration programs under this Act; (2) coordinate agency resources and funding allowing for the consolidation of Federal categorical programs, when requests for such waivers are made; (3) establish and maintain a national data base that includes the collaborative efforts of the Government, the States, local entities, and private entities to serve at-risk children; (4) make grants to the States to develop an interagency work group and fund local efforts to integrate services for at-risk youth and their families; and (5) determine the amounts of each grant by considering how many local project sites the State interagency group can reasonably target with not more than $200,000 allocated to a site. <n>Sets forth provisions regarding State eligibility and local eligibility. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to issue a notice of proposed rule-making for a final regulation requiring compliance with such minimums as a condition for nursing facilities to receive payments under Medicare and Medicaid.

Tenth Amendment Enforcement Act of 1998 - Requires that, on or after January 1, 1999, any statute enacted by the Congress must include specified findings and declarations about the constitutional authority of the Congress in enacting such statute to preempt State and local laws. Makes it out of order for the Senate or House of Representatives to consider any bill, joint resolution, or amendment that does not include such declarations. <n>Amends Federal law to prohibit any agency from construing any statutory authorization to issue rules as authorizing preemption of State law or local ordinance by rulemaking or other agency action unless: (1) the statute expressly authorizes issuance of preemptive rules; and (2) the agency concludes that the exercise of State power directly conflicts with the exercise of Federal power under the Federal statute, such that the State statutes and the Federal rule promulgated under the Federal statute cannot be reconciled or consistently stand together. Specifies the contents of agency rulemaking notice and opportunity for comment. <n>Prohibits construing any regulatory preemption of State law to preempt any State or local government law, ordinance, or regulation unless a final agency rule contains an explicit provision declaring the Federal Government's intent to preempt and an explicit description of the extent and purpose of that preemption, the rule shall not be construed to preempt any State or local government law

Innovation Protection Act Amends federal patent law to replace the Patent and Trademark Office Appropriation Account with the United States Patent and Trademark Office Public Enterprise Fund. Establishes the United States Patent and Trademark Office Public Enterprise Fund as a revolving fund in the Treasury. Requires fees collected by the Office under federal patent law and the Trademark Act of 1946 to be deposited into the Fund and made available to the Director of the Patent and Trademark Office without fiscal year limitation. Requires the Director to: (1) report to Congress annually on Office operations, including costs for services, programs, activities, and duties relating to patents and trademarks; and (2) submit an annual spending plan to Congress.

(Sec. 2) Prohibits the Administrator from requiring any airport, air carrier, or screening company to participate in the program if the airport, air carrier, or screening company determines that it would not be cost effective for it to participate in the program and notifies the Administrator of that determination. Requires the Administrator to report to specified congressional committees on the status of the Administrator's efforts to utilize the program and, if the program is not sufficiently operational two years after enactment of this Act to permit its utilization, to notify such committees. <n>(Sec. 3) Amends Federal criminal law to require a criminal history record check for each individual applying for a position as a screener (currently, such check is required for applicants as a screener if the Administrator decides is necessary to ensure air transportation security). Provides that such check shall be conducted for each such individual during the first two years of such three-year period, for up to 30 days before the check is completed, if the request for the check has been submitted to the appropriate Federal agency and the employment investigation has been successfully completed, if such check has been completed before the individual begins employment, or if such check is completed before the individual begins employment. Exempts such individuals from employment investigation requirements (currently, an

Stop Tuberculosis (DOTS) Observed Treatment Short-course Now Act of 2007 - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to direct the President, through the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), to provide assistance for the prevention, treatment and control of tuberculosis (TB). Requires the President to: (1) coordinate with specified health agencies worldwide to develop and implement a comprehensive TB strategy; (2) set as a goal the detection of at least 75% of the cases of infectious TB, the cure of at least 90% of the cases detected, and the reduction of TB-related mortality by 50% by December 31, 2010; (3) give priority to activities that increase Directly Observed Treatment Short-course (DOTS) coverage (World Health Organization-supported prevention, treatment, and control programs) and reduce TB-related migration; (4) expend at least 10% of the allocated funds on antituberculosis drugs, supplies, direct patient service, and training in diagnosis and treatment of TB; (5) expend at least 10% of the allocated funds on a U.S. contribution to the Global Tuberculosis Drug Facility.

Tobacco Advertising and Promotion Studies Act of 1994 - Directs the Federal Trade Commission to conduct studies concerning: (1) current tobacco advertising to determine if and in what forms such advertising and promotion uses themes, graphics, and techniques which are likely to appeal specifically to girls and women and minorities in ways that make smoking attractive to them; (2) whether targeting girls, women, and minorities increases tobacco use; and (3) the extent to which advertising of alcoholic beverages targets girls and women and minorities.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal the requirement that property acquired from a corporation be subject to a liability test to determine the amount of liability assumed by the acquiring corporation. States that for purposes of determining the amount of liability assumed: (1) a recourse liability shall be treated as having been assumed if the transferee has agreed to, and is expected to satisfy, such liability (or a portion); and (2) a nonrecourse liability shall be treated as having been assumed by the transferee of any asset subject to such liability. Limits to the lesser of: (1) the amount of such liability which an owner of other assets not transferred to the transferee has agreed to, and is expected to satisfy, or the fair market value of such other assets; or (2) the amount of the nonrecourse liability which a transferee has agreed to, and is expected to satisfy, or the fair market value of such other assets.Prohibits an increase in the basis of any property above the fair market value by reason of any gain recognized to the transferor as a result of the assumption of a liability.

(Sec. 1) Defines such standards as: (1) a regulatory review period from application submission to application approval exceeding 60 months; (2) the owner of record of the patent or its agent has established by clear and convincing evidence that the patent owner acted with due diligence; and (3) granting the patent restoration would not be detrimental to the public interest and the interest of fairness. Requires subtraction from the total amount of the restoration term of any time during the regulatory review period during which the Commissioner finds that the patent owner did not act with due diligence.Provides that if the Commissioner determines that there is substantial evidence that the patent owner did not act with due diligence during a part of the regulatory review period, that part shall be deducted from the total amount of time in the applicable regulatory review period and the resulting period shall be the basis for calculating the patent restoration term.Requires the Commissioner, if there is a dispute concerning the underlying facts between the patent owner and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), to make the relevant records of the FDA available to the Commissioner.Provides that any application under this Act for restoration term shall be filed within two years after the enactment of this Act.

Hazardous Materials Cooperative Research Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to establish a hazardous materials cooperative research program and an independent governing board to select cooperative research projects and studies of hazardous materials transportation that are cross-cutting in nature and that consider issues not adequately addressed by existing federal or private sector research programs, with priority given to research studies that will yield results immediately applicable to risk analysis and mitigation or that will strengthen the ability of first responders to respond to accidents involving the transportation of hazardous materials.

Staffing for Adequate Fire and Emergency Response Firefighters Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 to require the establishment of a new office within the United States Fire Administration to administer the Staffing for Adequate Fire and Emergency Response (SAFER) Firefighter grant program under this Act.Authorizes the U.S. Fire Administrator to make grants directly to career, voluntary, and combination fire departments of a State for the purpose of substantially increasing the number of firefighters so that communities can meet industry minimum standards to provide adequate protection from acts of terrorism and hazards.Limits such grants to four years and their use for programs to hire new, additional career firefighters. Requires grantees to commit to retaining such career firefighters for at least one year beyond the termination of their grants.Authorizes the Administrator to give preferential consideration to applications for hiring and rehiring additional career firefighters that involve a non-Federal contribution exceeding specified minimums. Limits the portion of program costs that may be provided in the first year, second year, third year, and fourth year of such grants.

Establishes within the Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security the Special Office of the Inspector General for Natural Disaster Response and Reconstruction. Requires the Director of such Office to conduct, supervise, and coordinate audits and investigations of the treatment, handling, and expenditure of federal funds by any organization providing relief, assistance, or reconstruction related to Hurricane Katrina.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior, within 30 days after the enactment of this Act, to distribute to the Quinault Indian Nation certain funds appropriated on September 19, 1989, in satisfaction of an award granted to the Tribe under Dockets 772-71, 773-71, 774-71, and 775-71 before the United States Claims Court, less attorney fees and litigation expenses, and including all interest accrued to the date of disbursement, to be deposited into three separate accounts to be established and maintained by the Tribe. <n>Requires the Tribe to: (1) establish an account for the principal amount of the judgment funds and for all investment income earned on such funds between September 19, 1989, and the date of distribution of the funds to the Tribe; (2) carry out fisheries enhancement projects and pay expenses incurred in administering the Permanent Fisheries Fund established by such funds; and (3) establish an account for, and deposit in the account, all investment income earned on such funds between such dates and the date of distribution of the funds to the Tribe. <n>Requires the Tribe to make available to members of the Tribe a full accounting of the investment activities and expenditures of the Tribe with respect to each fund established. <n>Declares that on disbursement to the Tribe of such funds the United States shall bear no trust

Peopling of America Theme Study Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to prepare and submit to Congress a national historic landmark theme study on the peopling of America to identify regions, areas, trails, districts, communities, sites, buildings, structures, objects, organizations, societies, and cultures that: (1) best illustrate and commemorate key events or decisions affecting the peopling of America; and (2) can provide a basis for the preservation and interpretation of the peopling of America that has shaped U.S. culture and society.

Declares that the overall trade negotiating objectives of the United States with respect to a United States-Turkey Free Trade Agreement are to obtain: (1) more open, equitable, and reciprocal market access between the United States and Turkey; and (2) the reduction or elimination of barriers and other trade-distorting policies and practices that inhibit trade between the United States and Turkey.Authorizes the President to enter into a United States-Turkey Free Trade Agreement if such agreement is entered into on or before December 31, 2005.

Pathways to Self-Sufficiency Act of 2002 - Amends part A (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) (TANF) of title IV of the Social Security Act to authorize States to use State TANF grants to establish undergraduate post-secondary or vocational educational programs with respect to individuals who receive TANF assistance and: (1) are enrolled in postsecondary two- or four-year degree programs or in vocational educational training programs; (2) engage in a combination of educational activities in connection with a course of study, training, study time, employment, or work experience for an average of 24 hours per week; (3) work at least 15 hours per week (in addition to school and study time) or engage in a combination of educational activities in connection with a course of study, training, study time, employment, or work experience for an average of 30 hours per week; and (4) maintain satisfactory academic progress during the period of participation in the program.Requires such an individual to complete the requirements of a degree or vocational educational training program within the normal time frame for full time students seeking the particular degree or completing the vocational educational training program. Allows for good cause to allow an individual to complete their degree requirements or vocational educational training program within a period not to exceed one-half times the normal time frame

Housing Assistance for Veterans Act of 2012 or HAVEN Act - Directs the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to establish a pilot program to award grants to nonprofit organizations that primarily serve veterans or low-income individuals. Requires such grants to be used to rehabilitate and modify the primary residence of disabled or low-income veterans (at a specified limited or no cost to such veterans). Requires the Secretary to give grant preference to organizations that: (1) have experience in providing housing rehabilitation and modification services for disabled veterans, or (2) propose to provide such services for veterans who live in rural areas.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 16, 2015. American Manufacturing Competitiveness Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill expresses the sense of Congress that, to remove the competitive disadvantage to U.S. manufacturers and consumers resulting from an outdated Harmonized Tariff Schedule (HTS), Congress should consider a miscellaneous tariff bill not later than 180 days after the United States International Trade Commission (USITC) and the Department of Commerce issue reports on proposed duty suspensions and reductions. (Sec. 3) The bill establishes a process by which the appropriate congressional committees shall publish on their respective publicly available websites a process: (1) to provide for the submission and consideration of legislation containing proposed duty suspensions and reductions in a manner that is consistent with these requirements, and (2) to include in a miscellaneous tariff bill those duty suspensions and reductions that meet these requirements. The USITC shall publish in the Federal Register and on a publicly available website a notice requesting members of the public to submit to the USITC proposed duty suspensions and reductions. The USITC shall submit to the appropriate congressional committees: (1) within 15 days after the expiration of such 60-day period, the proposed duty suspensions and reductions; and (2) within 90 days after the end of the 90-day period beginning on the date of publication,

Enhancing Educational Opportunities for all Students Act - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA) to authorize a state educational agency (SEA) to allocate grant funds under part A (Flexibility and Accountability) of title I of the ESEA among the local educational agencies (LEAs) in the state based on the number of eligible children enrolled in the public and state-accredited private schools within each LEA's geographic jurisdiction. Defines "eligible child" as a child aged 5 to 17, inclusive, from a family with an income below the poverty level on the basis of the most recent satisfactory data published by the Department of Commerce. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) allow the allowance of home school expenses as qualified education expenses for purposes of a Coverdell Education Savings Account; and (2) remove the dollar limitation on contributions to a Coverdell Education Savings Account.

States that a presidential order neither constitutes nor has the force of law and is limited in its application and effect to the executive branch, except in cases of impeachment, for: (1) a reprieve or pardon for an offense against the United States, except in cases of impeachment; (2) military personnel pursuant to duties specifically related to actions taken as Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces; or (3) such an order not issued pursuant to a ratified or unratified treaty or bilateral or multilateral agreement which violates the ninth or tenth amendments to the Constitution or makes a delegation of power to a foreign government or international body when no such authority exists under the Constitution. Directs the President to provide for each presidential order a statement of the specific statutory or constitutional provision which in fact grants the President the authority claimed for such action. Makes this Act applicable to presidential orders in effect on or after 180 days after enactment of this Act. Authorizes persons, including Congress, State and local governments, and certain other governmental officials to challenge the validity of any such order which exceeds the power granted to the President by the relevant authorizing statute or the Constitution.

Trail of the Ancients National Heritage Area Study Act of 2005 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to study the feasibility and suitability of designating specified counties in Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah (the Four Corners region) as the Trail of the Ancients National Heritage Area.

Human Smuggling Prevention Act of 2014 - Prohibits, and sets penalties for, knowingly directing or participating in an effort or scheme to assist or cause five or more persons (other than a parent, spouse, or child of the offender) to: (1) enter, attempt to enter, or prepare to enter the United States by fraud, falsehood, or other corrupt means at any place other than a port or place of entry designated by the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS); (2) travel by air, land, or sea toward the United States knowing that such persons seek to enter the United States without lawful authority and with the intent to aid or further such entry or attempted entry; or (3) be transported or moved outside of the United States knowing that such persons are aliens in unlawful transit from one country to another or on the high seas and under circumstances in which the persons are in fact seeking to enter the United States without official permission or legal authority. Defines "lawful authority" to mean permission, authorization, or license that is expressly provided for in the immigration laws of the United States or accompanying regulations and that does not include authority secured by fraud or otherwise obtained in violation of law.

Work Force Diversity Partnership Act of 1993 - Authorizes the Secretary of Labor to award grants to eligible entities to pay the Federal share of the cost of programs established by such entities that are designed to: (1) target and develop issues relating to work force and cultural diversity; (2) develop public and private sector education and training materials that focus on such issues; (3) foster research, scholarship, innovative curriculum development, development of teaching materials, and other practicable supportive academic activities relating to such issues; (4) assist in the dissemination and transfer of such materials for use in private sector training efforts; and (5) develop and establish cooperative higher education-business training programs to assist public and private industry leaders and workers in addressing the issue of work force diversity. <n>Makes eligible for such a grant: (1) an institution of higher education in partnership with one or more organizations that are corporations, businesses, or partnerships and that have demonstrated interest or expertise in work force diversity issues; or (2) a labor organization, or an organization that has a demonstrated interest or expertise in work force diversity issues.  <n>Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) selection criteria; and (2) non-Federal share. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Public Housing Regulatory Relief Act - Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to authorize the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, upon the written request of a public housing agency or resident management corporation, to authorize the agency or corporation to establish policies for the operation, maintenance, management, and development of one or more public housing projects, but only with respect to the project or projects under provisions of law that the Secretary determines are not consistent with the policies proposed for the project or projects.Prohibits the Secretary fromwaiving or modifying: (1) any provision of the Act or other provision of law that limits occupancy of public housing dwelling units to low-income families; (2) section 18 of the Act that requires replacement of dwelling units in the case of demolition or disposition of public housing (except that the limitation on the use of tenant-based assistance to applications proposing demolition or disposition of 200 or more units may be waived); (3) the Uniform Relocation Assistance and Real Property Acquisition Policies Act of 1970; (4) any provision of law that relates to equal opportunity, nondiscrimination, or the environment; or (5) the Act or any other provision of law that relates to labor standards.Sets forth minimum criteria for approval of such requests.Authorizes the Secretary to renew such authority for a public housing agency or resident

Internet Gambling Prohibition Act of 1997- Amends the Federal criminal code to prescribe penalties to be imposed against any person who, while engaged in the business of betting or wagering, knowingly uses a communication facility for the transmission or receipt in interstate or foreign commerce of bets or wagers, information assisting in the placing of bets or wagers, or a communication that entitles the transmitter or receiver to receive money or credit as a result of bets or wagers. Provides that nothing in this Act shall be construed to prohibit the transmission or receipt in interstate or foreign commerce of any information: (1) for use in the news reporting of any activity, event, or contest upon which bets or wagers are based; (2) assisting in the placing of bets or wagers, if betting or wagering on such activity, event, or contest is not illegal in the State or foreign country in which the transmission originates; and (3) that entitles the transmitter or receiver to receive money or credit as a result of bets or wagers.

Requires the Administrator to transfer $1 million to the Governor of each State for use by an independent citizens' council established by this Act.Establishes in each State an independent citizens' council.Requires each council to review applications for and award SEARCH grants (for special environmental assistance for the regulation of communities and habitat) from funds transferred under this Act to small communities that meet specified eligibility criteria. Allows each council to award a SEARCH grant to a small community for an environmental project for which the small community: (1) is unable to secure funding or is underfunded; (2) has incurred unexpected expenses during construction of the environmental project; or (3) needs funds for initial feasibility or environmental studies before applying to traditional funding sources.Requires a small community, in order to apply for a SEARCH grant, to submit to the council an application that includes: (1) a description of the proposed environmental project; (2) an explanation of how the project would assist the community in complying with environmental regulations; (3) a description of all actions taken with respect to the project; and (4) a form provided by the council, completed and with all required supporting documentation. Requires each council to: (1) review all such applications; and (2) select a chairperson from among the members of the council, who shall not serve as chairperson.

Corinth Battlefield Preservation Act of 1999 - Establishes the Corinth Unit of the Shiloh National Military Park in the States of Mississippi and Tennessee to be administered as a unit of the National Park System.Requires the Secretary of the Interior to study and report to specified congressional committees on whether certain additional properties are appropriate for inclusion in the Unit.

Preventing Unemployment Act of 2010 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an employer participation in a short-time compensation program. Defines short-time compensation program" as a program under which: (1) an employer reduces the number of hours worked by employees in lieu of temporary layoffs; (2) such employees whose workweeks have been reduced by at least 10% are eligible for unemployment compensation; (3) the amount of unemployment compensation payable to any such employee is a pro rata portion of the unemployment compensation which would be payable to the employee if such employee were totally unemployed; (4) such employees are not expected to meet the availability for work or work search test requirements while collecting short-time compensation benefits, but are required to be available for their normal workweek; (5) eligible employees may participate in an employer-sponsored training program to enhance job skills if such program has been approved by the state agency; (6) the state agency shall require an employer to certify that the employer will continue to provide health benefits and retirement benefits under a defined benefit plan and contributions under a defined contribution plan to any employee whose workweek is reduced under the program under the same terms and conditions as though the workweek of such employee had not been reduced; (7) the state agency shall require an employer (or an employer\\'"

Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017 This bill amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the President from taking action against any person on the basis of viewpoints taken, or not taken, on issues of public importance in content that is broadcast or otherwise disseminated by such person or any person affiliated with such person. The bill prohibits the FCC from placing conditions on the approval of any person's approval regarding viewpoints in content broadcast or otherwise disseminated by the person seeking such approval, any successor of such person, or any person affiliated with such person. Nothing in this bill shall be construed to affect the FCC's or the President's authority to: (1) take action against any person on the basis of viewpoints taken, or not taken, on issues of public importance in content broadcast or otherwise disseminated by such person or any person affiliated with such person; or (2) execute the duties of the President under any provision of law.

Skilled Workforce Enhancement Act of 1998 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a highly skilled metalworking trades training credit for an employee's training expenses. Limits the credit to $100,000 per employee.

Department of National Homeland Security Act of 2001 - Establishes the Department of National Homeland Security. Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to: (1) plan, coordinate, and integrate those Federal activities relating to homeland security, including border security and emergency preparedness, and act as a focal point regarding natural and manmade crises and emergency planning; (2) work with State and local governments and executive agencies in protecting U.S. homeland security and support State officials through the use of regional offices around the Nation; (3) conduct exercise and training programs for Department employees and establish effective command and control procedures for the full range of potential contingencies regarding homeland security, including contingencies that require military assets; and (4) annually develop a Federal response plan for homeland security and emergency preparedness.Transfers to the Department the authorities, functions, personnel, and assets of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the United States Customs Service, the Border Patrol of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the United States Coast Guard, and the Critical Infrastructure Assurance Office and the Institute of Information Infrastructure Protection of the Department of Commerce.Establishes within the Department the Directorates of Prevention, Critical Infrastructure Protection, and Information Sharing and Analysis Centers.Establishes the National Infrastructure Protection Center and the National Domestic Preparedness Office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Voter Eligibility Verification Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to direct the Attorney General to establish a citizenship verification system to respond to inquiries made to verify an individual's citizenship by Federal, State, and local officials with responsibility for determining an individual's qualification to vote in a Federal, State, or local election.

Directs the Secretary to develop and publish criteria to determine which projects would qualify and have the highest priority for financing under this Act, including criteria to address: (1) how the project relates to the near- and long-term water demands and supplies in the study area; (2) the relative amount of water (acre feet) to be conserved pursuant to the project; (3) whether the project would provide operational efficiency improvements or achieve water, energy, or economic savings at a rate of acre feet of water or kilowatt energy saved per dollar expended on the construction of the project; and (4) if the project proponents have met the requirements specified in this Act. Requires a project sponsor seeking Federal funding under this Act to provide a report, prepared by the Bureau of Reclamation or prepared by any competent engineering entity and reviewed by the Bureau, that includes: (1) the total estimated project cost; (2) an analysis showing how the project would reduce, postpone, or eliminate development of new or expanded water supplies; (3) a description of conservation measures taken pursuant to the project plans; (4) the near- and long-term water demands and supplies in the study area; and (5) the engineering plans and designs that demonstrate that the project would provide operational efficiency improvements or achieve water, energy, or economic savings at a rate of acre feet

Amends the National School Lunch Act to make Head Start participants eligible for free or reduced price meals under the child and adult care food program. <n>Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to set enhanced reimbursement levels for the administrative expenses of sponsors serving providers in rural areas or areas in which poor economic conditions exist. Increases from two months to six months the period during which a sponsoring organization may receive expansion funds. Allows such funds to be used to conduct outreach to unlicensed day care homes to enable the day care homes to become licensed and to participate in the program. <n>Directs the Secretary to provide materials concerning the medical assistance program established under title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to State agencies for use in carrying out the Medicaid program. <n>Authorizes appropriations for FY 1998 through 2000.

Daniel Faulkner Law Enforcement Officers and Judges Protection Act of 2007 - Amends the federal criminal code to: (1) impose mandatory minimum terms of imprisonment for homicide or kidnapping crimes against a federal law enforcement officer or judge; (2) impose mandatory minimum terms of imprisonment for assault against a federal law enforcement officer or judge; and (3) increase penalties for assaulting or interfering with a federal law enforcement officer or judge while such officer or employee is engaged in, or on account of the performance of, official duties.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 8, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Over-Classification Reduction Act - (Sec. 3) Directs the Archivist of the United States to promulgate regulations to prevent the over-classification of information, including for determining when classified products should be prepared in a similar format government-wide and when classified products should also be prepared in an unclassified format, taking into consideration whether an unclassified product would reasonably be expected to be of any benefit to a State, local, tribal or territorial government, law enforcement agency, or other emergency response provider, the private sector, or the public. Requires such regulations to: (1) identify specific requirements to prevent the over-classification of information; (2) ensure that compliance with this Act protects national security and privacy rights; and (3) establish requirements for Federal agencies to implement, including for challenging classification decisions by another individual and being rewarded with specific incentives for successful challenges, informing individuals who repeated failure to comply with such regulations, and penalties for individuals who repeatedly fail to comply.(Sec. 4) Requires the Archivist to require that, at the time of classification of information, the name, personal identifier, or unique agency identifier of the individual applying classification markings to the

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 19, 2004. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act - Amends the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2004 to prohibit any person, or any officer, employee, contractor, subcontractor, or agent of such person, from discharging, demoting, suspending, threatening, harassing, or in any other manner discriminating against a whistleblower in the terms and conditions of employment because: (1) the whistleblower provided or caused to be provided information relating to any violation of the antitrust laws or a violation of another criminal law committed in conjunction with a potential violation of the antitrust laws or in conjunction with an investigation by the Department of Justice of a potential violation of the antitrust laws; or (2) the whistleblower filed, caused to be filed, testified, participated in, or otherwise assisted an investigation or a proceeding filed or about to be filed relating to such violations. Makes such prohibition inapplicable if: (1) the whistleblower planned and initiated a violation or attempted violation of the antitrust laws; or (2) the whistleblower planned and initiated an obstruction or attempted obstruction of an investigation by the Department of Justice of such a violation. Authorizes a whistleblower who alleges discharge or other discrimination by any person in violation

Oversight Workforce Improvement Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) to exclude from the definition of agency" for purposes of such Act the collection of information during the conduct of any evaluation, or other review conducted by the Federal Accountability and Spending Transparency Board, or during the conduct of any audit, investigation, inspection, evaluation, or any other review conducted by the Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency or any Office of Inspector General (Office). (Sec. 3) Declares that information relating to the agency\\'s information security program or practices shall be exempt from disclosure under FOIA if disclosure could reasonably be expected to lead to or result in unauthorized access, use, disclosure, disruption, modification, or destruction of such information system or the information such system controls, processes, stores, or transmits. Requires each agency that withholds information subject to such exemption to act in accordance with the obligation of the agency to reasonably segregate and disclose non-exempt information. (Sec. 4) Amends the Inspector General Act of 1978 to require the Inspector General of each designated federal entity to be classified at a grade, level, or rank designation, as the case may be, at or above those of a majority of the senior level executives"

Comprehensive TB Elimination Act of 2014 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to allow the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to award grants to state and local governments and federally qualified health centers to ensure timely and appropriate prevention, control, and elimination of tuberculosis (TB) in high-risk populations, including foreign-born, homeless, and uninsured populations. Amends the Public Health Service Act to allow the Secretary, acting through the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), to award grants to state and local governments and federally qualified health centers to ensure timely and appropriate prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of TB in high-risk populations.

Consumer Data Protection Act - Amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to require a consumer reporting agency to notify the Federal Trade Commission, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and appropriate law enforcement and intelligence agencies within two days of discovering a data breach involving an individual and as quickly and efficiently as is practicable, each affected individual. Requires the agency also, within three days after discovering such breach, to: (1) notify each affected individual of his or her rights under this Act; and (2) provide each affected individual with a copy of his or her consumer report, including a credit freeze, free of charge.<n><n>Prohibits a consumer reporting agency from releasing a consumer report upon request of: (1) a person or entity for the purpose of providing a credit monitoring or identity theft protection service to which the consumer has subscribed; (2) any person for the sole purpose of providing a credit monitoring or identity theft protection service to which the consumer has subscribed; (3) any person for the purpose of providing a copy of a consumer report, credit score, or educational credit score to a consumer upon request; and (4) any person acting under an authorization from a consumer to use a consumer report for employment purposes.<n><n>Defines a data breach" as the loss, theft, or other unauthorized access, other"

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on May 21, 2015. Cardiac Arrest Survival Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to provide immunity from civil liability for harm resulting from the use or attempted use of an automated external defibrillator device (AED) on a victim of a perceived medical emergency to the person who: (1) uses or attempts to use an AED on such a victim, and (2) is not the owner-acquirer of the AED. The bill grants an owner-acquirer of an AED immunity from civil liability for any harm resulting from the use or attempted use of such device unless the harm was proximately caused by the owner-acquirer's failure to properly maintain the device according to the manufacturer's guidelines. The immunity applies regardless of whether: the AED that is used or attempted to be used is marked with or accompanied by cautionary signage; the AED is registered with any government; the person who used or attempted to use the AED saw, read, understood, complied with, or attempted to comply with any cautionary signage present; the person who used or attempted to use the AED had received training relating to the use of AEDs in general or the particular AED; or the person who

Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to convey specified lands formerly part of the Fort Bayard Military Reservation, Grant County, New Mexico, to eligible buyers for business and community development.
