Declares that the Secretary shall sell the land in tracts of not less than 40 acres, require as consideration for the land's market price as agricultural grazing lands, protect valid existing rights, reserve easements for existing facilities, and reserve such easements for roads as the Secretary finds necessary to assure access to Federal lands or to meet public needs. Declares that the Secretary shall not make a conveyance to any one of the eligible buyers without written approval of two nonacquiring eligible buyers. Declares that, if historic or prehistoric cultural properties are located upon the conveyed lands, the Secretary shall be responsible for the costs and recovery of these sites and shall do so in a timely manner so as not to unduly restrict future use of the selected lands by the acquiring party. Authorizes the Secretary to use a deed reservation to retain historic or prehistoric properties in the ownership of the United States instead of site recovery. Declares that, upon application by the acquiring party, all undivided mineral interest of the United States in any parcel or tract sold pursuant to this Act shall be conveyed to the Secretary of the Interior

Great Lakes Pipeline Safety Act of 2016 This bill directs the Department of Transportation (DOT) to study the economic and environmental risks to the Great Lakes of oil or other hazardous liquids spills or leaks in the Straits of Mackinac from a rupture, breakage, or other failure of onshore, underwater pipeline facilities within the Straits. DOT shall conduct a supplemental study to evaluate the condition and structural integrity of onshore, underwater pipeline facilities in the Straits, taking into consideration the age, construction materials, external and internal corrosion, integrity, pressure, underwater currents, possible external damage caused by anchor strikes or dragging by recreational or cargo vessels, and the presence of in-line shutoff valves. The Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration shall terminate the operations of an onshore, underwater pipeline facility in the Straits if it determines that such facility poses a sufficient risk of hazard to life, property, or the environment.

Grand Jury Reform Act of 1998 - Amends Rule 6 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure to require the court, upon impaneling a grand jury, to instruct and charge the grand jury on the rights, responsibilities, and duties of the grand jury, including: (1) the duty to inquire into criminal offenses that are alleged to have been committed within the jurisdiction; (2) the right to call and interrogate witnesses; (3) the right to request production of a book, paper, document, or other object, including exculpatory evidence; (4) the necessity of finding credible evidence of each material element of the crime charged before returning a true bill; (5) the right to request that the attorney for the government draft indictments for charges other than those originally requested by that attorney; (6) the obligation of secrecy; and (7) such other rights, responsibilities, and duties as the court determines to be appropriate. Specifies that: (1) the court shall have the authority to investigate any violation of this section, including the authority to appoint counsel to investigate and report to the court regarding any such violation; and (2) upon service of any subpoena requiring any witness to testify or produce information at any proceeding before a grand jury before a district court, the witness shall be given adequate and reasonable notice of the witness'

Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to develop a plan for the purchase, storage, and rotation of a six-month supply of vaccines routinely recommended for children and adults and vaccines routinely recommended for adults by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. Requires the Secretary to: (1) fully implement the plan; and (2) require manufacturers of vaccines included in such supply to provide at least one year notice of a discontinuance of the manufacture of a vaccine.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to pay a specified amount of compensation to those members of the Armed Forces and U.S. civilian employees, or to the surviving spouses of such members and employees, who were captured by Japan and who were required to perform slave labor during World War II.

FAGER Lock Act of 1997 - Prohibits: (1) the transfer of a firearm in the United States, unless a locking device is attached to, or is an integral part of, the firearm; (2) the manufacture of a handgun in the United States, unless such a locking device is attached to, or is an integral part of, the firearm; and (3) the transfer of a handgun by a licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer without notice and warning. <n>Makes it unlawful for any licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer to transfer a handgun that is not accompanied by a locking device meeting minimum quality standards. <n>Makes it unlawful for an adult to leave a loaded firearm, or an unloaded firearm and ammunition for the firearm, with a minor, unless the possession by the minor is supervised by an adult who is not prohibited by Federal, State, or local law from possessing a firearm. <n>Sets forth civil and criminal penalties for violations of this Act.

General Services Administration Modernization Act - Establishes in the General Services Administration (GSA) a Federal Acquisition Service, headed by a Commissioner. Requires the Commissioner to carry out functions related to the uses for which the Acquisition Services Fund is authorized, including any functions that were carried out by the entities known as the Federal Supply Service and the Federal Technology Service. Authorizes the Administrator of GSA to appoint Regional Executives in the Service to carry out such functions. Abolishes the General Supply Fund and the Information Technology Fund and transfers their capital assets and balances to the Acquisition Services Fund.

Freedom and Mobility in Consumer Banking Act This bill amends the Truth in Savings Act to prohibit a depository institution from: (1) prohibiting a consumer from closing a covered account at the depository institution regardless of whether the balance in such account is positive, zero, or negative; (2) charging any fee to close such an account; or (3) reopening such an account that a consumer has requested to be closed in accordance with this bill to apply subsequent debits, whether preauthorized or otherwise, or for any other reason, unless the consumer expressly requests that the account be reopened. A depository institution must provide any consumer that opens such an account a description of its policies and procedures for closing such an account. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau must prescribe final regulations to: (1) require such an institution to close a covered account within five business days after a consumer requests it, (2) prescribe the methods by which a consumer may request to close such an account, and (3) establish procedures to require a depository institution to positively verify the identity of a consumer requesting to close such an account.

Authorizes school personnel to discipline (including expel or suspend), in the same manner in which such personnel may discipline a child without a disability, any child with a disability who commits specified school-related weapon or drug offenses. (Thus provides an exception to current IDEA procedural safeguards that require placement in an alternative educational setting.)Authorizes such personnel to modify the disciplinary action on a case-by-case basis. Permits assertion of a defense that the offense was committed unintentionally or innocently.Allows the local educational agency (LEA) responsible for providing educational services to a child with a disability who is expelled or suspended under this Act to choose to continue to provide educational services to such child; but specifies that an LEA that so chooses to continue to provide services: (1) is not required by this Act to provide such child with a free appropriate public education, or any particular level of service; and (2) has discretion as to the location where it provides the services.

Duty Suspension Facilitation Act of 2010 - Directs the International Trade Commission (ITC), by January 1, 2012, and every two years thereafter, to submit to the Senate Committee on Finance and the House Committee on Ways and Means proposed legislation which includes recommendations regarding: (1) Amendments to the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States extending existing temporary duty suspensions or existing duty reductions; (2) Amendments to such Schedule providing for new temporary duty suspensions or new duty reductions; and (3) technical corrections to such Schedule to make technical corrections with respect to headings, subheadings, or notes, errors in article descriptions, and other clerical errors.<n><n>Requires the ITC, in formulating recommendations and proposed legislation, to: (1) afford reasonable opportunity for interested parties to present their views in writing; and (2) provide for a public hearing.<n><n>Prohibits the ITC from recommending any suspension or reduction in duty if: (1) an interested federal agency determines such suspension or reduction is not in the interest of the United States and that determination is included in the record of the public hearing; (2) such suspension reduction is objected to by a domestic producer who demonstrates that there is domestic production of the article for which suspension or reduction of duty is recommended in commercially available quantities; (3) the loss in revenue to the United States from such suspension

National Park System New Area Studies Act - Amends the National Park System General Authorities Act to direct the Secretary of the Interior, at the beginning of each year, along with the annual budget submission, to submit to specified congressional committees a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System. Requires the Secretary, in developing such list, to give consideration to those areas that have the greatest potential to meet the established criteria of national significance, suitability, and feasibility. Prohibits any study of the potential of an area for inclusion in the System from being initiated after enactment of this Act, except as provided by specific authorization of an Act of Congress. Declares that nothing in this Act shall limit the authority of the National Park Service to conduct preliminary resource assessments, gather data on potential study areas, provide technical and planning assistance, prepare or process nominations for administrative designations, update previous studies, or complete reconnaissance surveys of individual areas requiring a total expenditure of less than $25,000. Requires the Secretary to complete the study for each area for potential inclusion in the System within three complete fiscal years following enactment of specific legislation providing for the study of such area. Requires each study to be prepared with appropriate opportunity for public involvement, including at least one public meeting in the vicinity of the

National Marine Scholarship Act of 2005 - Directs the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to establish a National Marine Scholarship Program to recruit and prepare students for careers in the fields of marine science. Directs the Administrator, as a condition for the award of each scholarship, to require the recipient to enter into a contractual agreement under which the individual is obligated to serve as a full-time employee of NOAA, for a period of time to be determined by the Administrator and stated in the contractual agreement.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 16, 2015. DHS Paid Administrative Leave Accountability Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to require each component of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to submit quarterly reports to the Chief Human Capital Officer of DHS: the number of DHS employees who had been on administrative leave, or any other type of paid non-duty status without charge to leave, for personnel matters for six consecutive months or longer; the total cost to each DHS component of such administrative leave and such paid non-duty status for such period; and the average duration that employees are placed on administrative leave, or any other type of paid non-duty status without charge to leave, for such personnel matters for such period. The Chief Human Capital Officer shall: maintain records of DHS employees who are placed on administrative leave or paid non-duty status without charge to leave for personnel matters and the costs associated with such leave or non-duty status; and determine, in consultation with each DHS component, any appropriate actions to be taken by DHS to resolve any personnel matter objectively, appropriately, and expeditiously or to reduce the use of administrative leave and paid non-duty status without charge to leave in addressing any personnel

(Sec. 3) Requires the Register of Copyrights to ensure that records of deposits, registrations, recordations, and other actions taken under Federal copyright law are maintained, and that indexes of such records are prepared.Revises copyright fee provisions to authorize the Register to adjust such fees for various services provided.

Tribal Colleges and Universities Faculty Loan Forgiveness Act - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to include, under the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) and Direct Loan (DL) programs, full-time faculty members at Tribal Colleges or Universities who are not in default on FFEL or DL loans.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of Education to carry out a program of assuming or canceling the obligation to repay FFEL or DL loans made, insured, or guaranteed after this Act's enactment for any new borrower on or after this Act's enactment who: (1) has been employed as a full-time faculty member at a Tribal College or University; and (2) is not in default on a loan for which the borrower seeks repayment or cancellation.<n><n>Limits the amount of such loans that may be forgiven or canceled to $15,000 in the aggregate for any student.<n><n>Amends the Public Health Service Act to include, under the Health Professions Education program, full-time faculty members at Tribal Colleges or Universities in the program that provides FFEL forgiveness or cancellation to physicians.

National Flood Insurance Program Commitment to Policyholders and Reform Act of 2005 - Directs the Comptroller General to study and report to Congress on the impact, effectiveness, and feasibility of amending the provisions of the Flood Disaster Protection Act of 1973 regarding the properties that are subject to the mandatory flood insurance coverage purchase requirements to extend such requirements to all properties located in the 500-year floodplain. Requires the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to report annually to Congress on the extent to which the updating and modernization of all floodplain areas and flood-risk zones has been completed.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on December 14, 2011. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Qualified Higher Education Retained, Train Act of 2011 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt employers who hire individuals for services performed under a trade or business from employment taxes during the period beginning on January 1, 2016, and ending on December 31, 2015, for wages paid to such individuals under a job training program. Defines qualified job training program" as a public or private institution of higher education providing specific training for available jobs to employers who partner with a public institution of higher education. Allows such employers to elect a work opportunity tax credit for the amount of wages paid to individuals under a job training program during the period beginning on January 1, 2016, and ending on December 31, 2015."

Taxpayers' Cancer Research Funding Act of 1996 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow certain individuals to designate that five dollars (ten dollars in the case of joint returns) be paid over to the Breast and Prostate Cancer Research Fund established by this Act.

MediFair Act of 2002 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a system for making adjustments to the amount of payment made to entities and individuals for items and services provided under the original Medicare fee-for-service program under parts A (Hospital Insurance) and B (Supplementary Medical Insurance). Requires such adjustments in order to make the State average per beneficiary amount equal to the national average per beneficiary amount.

Technology Transfer Improvements Act of 1993 - Amends the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 with respect to Government-owned or contractor-operated laboratories having a Cooperative Research and Development Agreement with another entity to: (1) ensure that title to any intellectual property arising from the agreement, except intellectual property developed in whole by a laboratory employee, is assigned to the collaborating party or parties to the agreement in exchange for reasonable compensation to the laboratory; (2) retain a nonexclusive, nontransferable, irrevocable, paid-up license from the collaborating party or parties for any intellectual property arising from the agreement and have such license practiced throughout the world by or on behalf of the Government, but not publicly disclose proprietary information related to the license; (3) retain the right to require a collaborating party to grant to a responsible applicant or applicants a nonexclusive, partially exclusive, or exclusive license to use the subject intellectual property in any field of use on terms that are reasonable under the circumstances, or if the collaborating party fails to grant such a license, to grant the license itself if the laboratory finds that the collaborating party has not taken, and is not expected to take within a reasonable time, effective steps to achieve practical application of the subject intellectual property in the field of use, such action is necessary to meet health

Terrorist Detainees Procedures Act of 2009 - Directs the President to ensure that no person alleged to be an unlawful enemy combatant is detained at Naval Station, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Requires a panel of military judges to determine the status of such a person.

Provides Access and Retain Continuity Act or the PARC Act Directs the Secretary of the Interior to enter into agreements with states to provide for those states to conduct certain activities at federal facilities that were conducted under a memorandum of understanding that: (1) was conducted during a time when the federal government was not conducting that activity due to the partial shutdown of the government; (2) was necessary to operate one or more facilities or programs that the Secretary and the state have agreed to have a direct economic impact on tourism, mining, timber, or general transportation in the state; (3) was conducted in a manner and at a level not substantially greater in scope or cost than how the activity would have been conducted by the federal government; and (4) is not a settlement of or defense against a claim of liability on the part of the state. Authorizes a state to petition the Secretary to enter into such an agreement if the Secretary determines that: (1) the petition is complete; (2) the proposed agreement submitted with the petition contains all of the terms required under this Act; or (3) the petition is from a state that had a previous agreement terminated and the reasons for that termination warrant denial of the new (or corrected) petition. Sets forth procedures for the approval or denial of petitions.

Innovation Competitiveness Act of 2004 - Directs the Secretary of Commerce to designate a Technology Transfer Director within the Technology Administration to perform oversight of and policy development for technology transfer activities at the Department of Commerce.

Community Coalitions for Access and Quality Improvement Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to assist in developing integrated health care delivery systems to serve defined communities to: (1) improve efficiency and coordination among providers; (2) assist local communities in developing programs targeted toward preventing and managing chronic diseases; and (3) expand and enhance services provided.<n><n>Requires eligible entities to be balanced consortia whose principal purpose is to ensure the sustainable capacity for the provision of a broad range of coordinated services for all residents, including at least one of each of the following providers that serve the community (with exceptions): (1) a federally qualified health center; (2) rural health clinics and rural health networks; (3) a hospital with a low-income utilization rate greater than 25% or a critical access hospital; (4) a public health department; and (5) an interested public or private sector health care provider or organization that has traditionally served medically uninsured and low-income individuals.

Sensible Estate Tax Act of 2008 - Repeals provisions of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 (EGTRRA) eliminating the tax on estates and generation-skipping transfers and the step-up in basis provisions for property acquired from a decedent for estates of decedents dying after 2008. Declares that the sunset provision (general terminating date of December 10, 2010) of EGTRRA shall not apply to title V of such Act (Estate, Gift, and Generation-Skipping Transfer Tax Provisions).<n><n>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) allow a permanent estate tax credit of $2 million ($7 million for married couples filing joint tax returns) and an annual inflation adjustment to such credit amount after 2008; (2) reduce estate tax rates; and (3) repeal the tax deduction for state death taxes.

Safe and Secure Border Infrastructure Act - Directs the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) to establish a grant program to construct transportation and supporting infrastructure improvements at existing and new international border crossings to facilitate the safe, secure, and efficient cross-border movement of motor vehicles, non-motor vehicles, cargo, and individuals, including pedestrians. Directs the Secretary to give grant priority to projects that: (1) improve the safety and security at United States facilities, including ports of entry; (2) facilitate safe, secure, and legal trade crossings of motor vehicles, non-motor vehicles, cargo, and individuals to alleviate border congestion and reduce the economic effect of border wait times and delays; (3) implement innovative technologies that enhance safety, security, or efficiency at the border; (4) coordinate a system of projects that improve security and systems efficiencies at ports of entry; (5) facilitate economic development strategies with respect to safety and security; and (6) implement congestion relief and air quality management strategies to improve the environment. Defines border state" as any state that has an international land border with Canada or Mexico."

Medicare Drug Savings Act of 2017 This bill requires drug manufacturers to pay the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) drug rebates for rebate eligible (low-income) individuals. Specifically, a rebate agreement shall require a drug or biological manufacturer to provide to the CMS a rebate, determined according to a specified formula, for each rebate period ending after December 31, 2017, for any covered Medicare part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) drug dispensed after that date to any rebate eligible individual for which payment was made by a prescription drug plan (PDP) sponsor or MedicareAdvantage (MA) organization for such period. The amount of the rebate shall be equal to the product of: (1) the total number of units of such dosage form and strength of the drug provided and dispensed for which payment was made by a PDP sponsor or an MA organization for the rebate period, including payments passed through the low-income and reinsurance subsidies; and (2) the amount by which the Medicaid rebate amount for such form, strength, and period exceeds the average Medicare drug program rebate eligible amount for such form, strength, and period.

Supporting Transparent Regulatory and Environmental Actions in Mining Act of 2015 or the STREAM Act of 2015 Amends the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 to direct the Department of the Interior to: (1) make publicly available on the date of the publication of any draft, final, emergency, or supplemental rule, each scientific product the Department relied upon in developing such a rule, environmental impact statement, environmental assessment, or economic assessment, and any background information used for those scientific products receiving federal funds; and (2) delay the effective date of any such rule by 60 days plus an additional day for each day of noncompliance.

Holocaust Survivors Assistance Act of 2011 - Amends the Older Americans Act of 1965 to include specifically within its purview older Americans who are Holocaust survivors. Authorizes the Administrator for Aging of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to make grants to nonprofit organizations to increase and improve transportation services for older individuals with preference to those older individuals who are Holocaust survivors.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose a five percent tax on the allocable amount of a covered passenger cruise. Defines covered passenger cruise" as a voyage of a commercial cruise vessel that extends over one or more nights and during which passengers embark or disembark the vessel in the United States. Declares that such tax shall not apply to voyages: (1) on any vessel owned or operated by the United States, a State, or any subdivision thereof, which occurs exclusively on U.S. inland waterways; (2) in which a vessel in the usual course of employment proceeds, without an intervening foreign port of call from one port or place in the United States to the same port or place or to another port or place in the United States; or (3) in which a vessel is used in the business of carrying passengers for hire. <n>Establishes the Intermodal Infrastructure Trust Fund consisting of such taxes. Appropriates to such Fund amounts equivalent to the taxes received under this Act."

Veterans Mental Health Treatment First Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out a program of mental health care and rehabilitation for veterans who: (1) have been discharged or released from service in the active military, naval, or air service under conditions other than dishonorable for a period of not more than two years; (2) are enrolled in the VA's annual patient enrollment system and have been so enrolled since before enactment of this Act; and (3) are diagnosed by a VA physician with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety disorder, or substance abuse that is either related to the PTSD or service-related. Requires each participant to agree to participation conditions, including compliance with a treatment regimen and rehabilitation plan prescribed by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs.

Quality Cancer Care Preservation Act - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require drug and biological manufacturers to report to the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) quarterly average sales prices for drugs and biologicals covered under Medicare. Directs the Secretary to publish such prices.

Small Business Lawsuit Abuse Protection Act of 1997 - Allows punitive damages, to the extent permitted by applicable State law, to be awarded against a small business only if the claimant establishes by clear and convincing evidence that conduct carried out by the defendant with a conscious, flagrant indifference to the rights or safety of others was the proximate cause of the harm that is the subject of the action. <n>States that in any civil action against a small business: (1) each defendant shall be liable only for the amount of noneconomic losses allocated to that defendant in direct proportion to the percentage of responsibility of that defendant for the harm caused to the plaintiff; and (2) the court shall render a separate judgment against each defendant describing such percentage of responsibility.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on October 16, 2011. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Country-of-Origin Labeling for Fuels Act (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Department of Energy (DOE) to study and report to Congress on the most feasible and cost-effective methods and standards for requiring that: (1) motor vehicle fuel suppliers disclose country-of-origin information regarding motor vehicle fuel to the next person in the fuel supply chain, and (2) motor vehicle retailers disclose such information to consumers. DOE must make recommendations with respect to the most feasible and cost-effective country-of-origin information disclosure requirements that can be imposed on motor vehicle fuel suppliers and motor vehicle fuel retailers. (Sec. 4) DOE shall prescribe regulations requiring disclosure of country-of-origin information by motor vehicle fuel suppliers and motor vehicle fuel retailers in accordance with DOE recommendations. The regulations shall not require the listing of more than one country-of-origin for a fuel blend containing fuel 70% or more of which originated in a single country. DOE may impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 on a person for knowingly violating such regulations.

. The expanded summary of the House passed version is repeated here.) Department of Homeland Security Morale, Recognition, Learning and Engagement Act of 2017 or the DHS MORALE Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to revise the responsibilities of the Chief Human Capital Officer of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). The bill requires the Chief Human Capital Officer to: inform DHS employees about leader development and employee engagement programs; maintain a catalogue of available employee development opportunities, including the Homeland Security Rotation Program; ensure that employee discipline and adverse action programs comply with the requirements of all pertinent laws, rules, regulations, and federal guidance; and serve as a Chief Learning and Engagement Officer to assist the Chief Human Capital Officer in carrying out such responsibilities. The Chief Human Capital Officer may designate an DHS employee to serve as such an Officer. The bill requires the Department to establish an employee engagement steering committee to: identify factors that have a negative impact on employee engagement, morale, and communications; develop and distribute initiatives and best practices to improve employee engagement, morale, and communications; monitor efforts of each component to address employee engagement, morale, and communications; advise the Department on efforts to improve employee engagement, morale, and communications; conduct regular meetings and report,

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 12, 2009. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Political Intelligence Disclosure Act - Amends the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 to define political intelligence activities" as political intelligence contacts and efforts in support of such contacts, including preparation and planning activities, research, and other background work intended, at the time it is performed, for use in contacts, and coordination with the political intelligence activities of others. Defines "political intelligence contact" as any oral or written communication (including an electronic communication) to or from a covered executive branch official or a covered legislative branch official, the information derived from which is intended for use in analyzing securities or commodities markets, or in informing investment decisions, that is made on behalf of a client with regard to: (1) the formulation, modification, or adoption of federal legislation (including legislative proposals); (2) the formulation, modification, or adoption of a federal rule, regulation, Executive order, or any other program, policy, or position of the United States Government; or (3) the administration or execution of a federal program or policy (including the negotiation, award, or administration of a federal contract, grant, loan, permit, or license). Excludes a communication that is"

Overseas Citizens Voting Rights Act of 1996 - Amends the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act (the Act) to provide for: (1) extension of the period for receipt of absentee ballots; (2) FederalRITE-IN Absentee Ballot provisions to special, primary, and runoff elections; (3) use of approved State absentee ballots in place of Federal write-in absentee ballots; (4) expeditious methods for the return of absentee ballots, including return by electronic transmittal; and (5) establishment of a system for electronic transmittal of balloting materials for overseas voters. Declares that no electronic transmittal or related procedure under the Act that is paid for with Federal funds may be carried out in any manner that permits any person other than the voter to view a completed ballot, or otherwise compromises ballot secrecy. Directs each State, in cooperation with the Presidential designee, to establish a system for electronic transmittal of balloting materials for overseas voters.

King Holiday and Service Act of 1993 - Amends the National and Community Service Act of 1990 to authorize the Martin Luther King, Jr. Federal Holiday Commission to provide service opportunities on the Federal legal holiday honoring Martin Luther King, Jr. <n>Authorizes the Commission to make grants to eligible entities for the Federal share of the cost of planning and carrying out service opportunities on such holiday. Makes the State and local share 30 percent and requires the Commission to make such grants.

Adoption Equality Act of 2007- Amends part E (Foster Care and Adoption Assistance) of title IV of the Social Security Act to revise requirements for children with special needs in the adoption assistance program. Requires that the child be in the care of a public or licensed private child placement agency or Indian tribal organization pursuant to a voluntary placement agreement, relinquishment, or involuntary removal of the child from the home, where the state has determined that continuation in the home would be contrary to the child's safety or welfare. Specifies related requirements.

Establishing Beneficiary Equity in the Hospital Readmission Program Act of 2015 Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) in determining a hospital's excess readmission ratio for purposes of making payments for discharges during FY2016-FY2017, and before the initial application of this Act, to provide for such risk adjustment as will take into account both a hospital's proportion of inpatients who are full-benefit dual eligible individuals and the socioeconomic status of the hospital's patients. Directs the Secretary to utilize the most recent data available from the Bureau of the Census in order to develop a quantitative method to adjust for socioeconomic status. Requires the Secretary, in developing such method, to use inputs that address at least income, education level, or poverty rate and may include inputs that address other socioeconomic and sociodemographic factors determined appropriate by the Secretary. Directs the Secretary to measure the socioeconomic status for all patients served by each hospital. Requires the Secretary to base such risk adjustment on specified reports submitted to the Secretary by the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission and the Administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. Directs the Commission to study the appropriateness of using a threshold of 30 days for readmissions during FY2016-FY2017

National Narcotics Leadership Act Amendments of 1993 - Amends the National Narcotics Leadership Act of 1988 to authorize the Director of National Drug Control Policy to require the inclusion, in the budget submission to the Office of Management and Budget by any National Drug Control Program agency, of funding requests for specific initiatives. Declares that: (1) the Director shall report to the Congress on a quarterly basis regarding the need for any reprogramming or transfer of appropriated funds in an amount greater than $5 million for Program activities; and (2) a Federal officer in the Office of National Drug Control Policy who is appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, may not participate in Federal election campaign activities. Declares that: (1) the Director shall include with each National Drug Control Strategy an evaluation of the effectiveness of Federal drug control during the preceding year, including assessments of Federal drug control efforts and drug use in the workplace and the productivity lost by such use; and (2) a Federal officer in the Office of National Drug Control Policy who is appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, may not participate in Federal election campaign activities. .

Streamlined and Improved Methods at Polling Locations and Early Voting Act or the SIMPLE Voting Act - Amends the Help America Vote Act of 2002 (HAVA) to require each state to allow individuals to vote in a federal election on each day during the 15-day period ending two days before the election date in the same manner as voting is allowed on election day. Requires a state to ensure that each polling place that allows early voting in a federal election is located within reasonable walking distance of a stop on a public transportation route. Requires the Election Assistance Commission to issue standards for the administration of early voting in a federal election. Requires each state to provide a sufficient number of voting systems, poll workers, and other election resources (including physical resources) at a polling place used in a federal election to ensure: (1) a fair and equitable waiting time for all voters in the state, and (2) that no individual will be required to wait longer than one hour to cast a ballot at the polling place. Requires each state to develop, and implement to the greatest extent practicable, a contingency plan under which it shall provide additional poll workers, machines, ballots, and other equipment and supplies on the date of a federal election.

Generic Drug Pricing Fairness Act - Amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to prohibit a prescription drug plan (PDP) from entering into a contract with any pharmacy benefits manager (PBM) to manage the prescription drug coverage under such plan, or to control the costs of such coverage, unless the PBM adheres to specified criteria when handling personally identifiable utilization and claims data or other sensitive patient data.

Code Talkers Recognition Act of 2008 - Directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to make appropriate arrangements for the award, on behalf of Congress, of gold medals of appropriate design in commemoration of the service of Native American code talkers during World War I and World War II. (Defines code talker" as a Native American who served in the Armed Forces during a foreign conflict in which the United States was involved and who transmitted secret coded messages for tactical operations during World War I and World War II using their native tribal language.) Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to strike: (1) silver duplicates of such medals; and (2) bronze duplicates with the same design."

Comprehensive Health Access District Act - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to require a State Medicaid plan to provide that each comprehensive health access district located within the State is served by a comprehensive community-based health access district plan. Defines comprehensive community-based health access plan" as an entity that provides health care services on a prepaid, capitated basis or any other risk basis and that the Secretary of Health and Human Services has certified meets all the requirements of this Act. <n>Directs each Health Alliance or other health insurance purchasing cooperative created as a result of the enactment of comprehensive health care reform legislation that receives premiums on behalf of persons formerly insured under title XIX of the Social Security Act to insure that a at least one comprehensive community-based health access plan is available to persons living in a comprehensive health access district. <n>Requires a health access plan to: (1) be a public or private organization organized under the laws of any State; (2) locate its primary place of business in the comprehensive health access district it serves; (3) give preference in hiring to otherwise qualified individuals who live within the comprehensive health access district; and (4) have made adequate provision against the risk of insolvency, which provision is satisfactory to the State and which assures that individuals enrolled"

So No Innocent Person Ever Repeats the Sniper Tragedy Act of 2003 or the SNIPER Act of 2003- Amends firearms provisions of the Federal criminal code to: (1) require a licensed importer, manufacturer, dealer, or collector, if found in violation of firearms requirements, to inspect or examine the importer, manufacturer, dealer, or collector's inventory and records at least once each year during the three years following such violation; (2) increase the penalty for willful violations; and (3) subject a licensed importer, manufacturer, dealer, or collector to license revocation, suspension, or a civil fine.Directs the Attorney General to issue a warning letter to alleged violators, and maintain a copy of such letter, along with any written report prepared by the inspector: (1) in the files of the appropriate Director of Industry Operations at the headquarters of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF); (2) at such headquarters; and (3) in the appropriate proceedings.Requires the Attorney General to require the Director of Industry Operations to issue a final decision within 120 days from the date on which a notice of revocation, suspension, or imposition of a civil fine is mailed to a licensee (currently, within 90 days from the date on which such decision is ordered by a U

Hass Quality Assurance Act of 2007 - Amends the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to issue final regulations to ensure that all Hass avocados sold to consumers in the United States meet minimum maturity standards, as measured by percentage of dry matter. Exempts from such standards: (1) intended for consumption by charitable institutions; (2) intended for distribution by relief agencies; (3) intended for commercial processing into products; and (4) that the Secretary determines should not be subject to such provisions or regulations. Sets forth civil penalties for violations.

Help Organ Procurement Expand Act of 2001 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a credit of $2,500 for qualified organ donations. Disqualifies for such credit any organ donation if the donor: (1) has been killed with assistance from a physician; (2) has authorized the withdrawal or denial of life sustaining medical treatment of the donor; (3) medically conducted or assisted in the operation to recover the organ; (4) the organs to be donated come from an unborn child or human fetus that was aborted; (5) the donor has committed suicide; (6) legal consent failed to be obtained from the donor or their family prior to the organ recovery; (7) the otherwise eligible individual has been indicted or convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor offense against the donor, or is actively under criminal investigation for the possible felony offense against the donor; or (8) in the case of living donors, the decision to donate the organ, in the judgment of the donor's attending physicians, would subject the donor to unacceptable levels of medical risk of death or permanent debilitation.

E-Mail User Protection Act of 1998 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to make it a violation of the Act to intentionally initiate the transmission of an unsolicited commercial e-mail message from an unregistered or fictitious electronic mail address for the purpose of: (1) preventing replies through the use of standard reply mechanisms in the recipient's electronic mail system or preventing receipt of standard notices of non-delivery; (2) using or distributing a computer program or other technical mechanism or procedure intending to disguise the source of unsolicited commercial e-mail messages or to disable or circumvent a mail filtering tool; (3) distributing a collection or list of electronic mail addresses knowing that such addresses have previously requested removal; (4) intentionally registering, creating, or causing to be created an Internet domain under false pretenses or to obtain the use of an Internet electronic mail account for the sole or primary purpose of disguising the source of unsolicited e-mail messages; (5) directing an unsolicited commercial e-mail message through the server of an interactive computer service provider to one or more subscribers knowing or having reason to know that such action is in contravention of service rules with respect to unsolicited commercial e-mail messages; (6) accessing the server of such computer service and using a computer program to collect electronic mail addresses of subscribers of such service for the

Unemployment Compensation, Reemployment, and Fairness Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code and title III (Unemployment Compensation) of the Social Security Act to provide that State unemployment compensation payments shall not be denied or reduced to any individual for any week because he or she is participating in a qualified self-employment program with the approval of the State agency. <n>Amends title III of the Social Security Act to require the State agency charged with administration of State unemployment law to: (1) provide an early review of an unemployed individual's reemployment prospects; (2) provide reemployment review information to other State employment and training program staff, including staff of State job services and service delivery areas; (3) provide job search and placement services, counseling, testing, occupational and labor market information, assessment, and referral to employers; (4) provide technical and training program staff to assist with reemployment services; and (5) provide followup evaluation and assistance to individuals participating in reemployment activities. <n>Requires the Secretary of Labor to prescribe regulations to carry out such requirements. <n>Amends title III of the Social Security Act to provide for hearings for employers on the use of computer technology to achieve the purposes of this Act. <n>Directs the Secretary to prescribe regulations to carry out such requirements.

Amends the Community Development Banking and Financial Institutions Act of 1994 to establish a CDFI Small Dollar Loan-Loss Guarantee Fund to defray the cost of losses on qualifying loans made by eligible financial institutions. Authorizes the Administrator of the Office of Thrift Supervision to provide reimbursement of a qualifying loan loss that is up to 60 percent of the loss on the qualifying loan to an eligible financial institution that has submitted an application.

Responsible Debt Relief and Democracy Reform Act - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to authorize the President to cancel or reduce amounts owed to the United States by foreign countries as a result of concessional or nonconcessional loans made, guarantees issued, or credits extended under any other provision of law only if certain additional requirements are satisfied, including that the government of the country: (1) ensures freedom of the press; (2) ensures freedom of association; (3) has established an independent and nondiscriminatory judiciary; (4) provides for the reduction or elimination of corruption relating to public officials; (5) is elected through free and fair elections; (6) does not engage in a consistent pattern of gross violations of internationally recognized human rights; and (7) does not repeatedly provide support for acts of international terrorism. <n>(Sec. 3) Expresses the sense of Congress that the President should instruct the U.S. Executive Director at each international financial institution to urge that the cancellation or reduction of debt owed to the institution by a country may be provided only if the country meets specified requirements. <n>(Sec. 4) Authorizes the President to cancel or reduce amounts owed to the United States by a foreign country under specified circumstances, including for emergency humanitarian relief purposes, if it is in the national security interests of the United States.

Protecting American Trade Secrets and Innovation Act of 2012 - Amends the federal judicial code to expand the civil jurisdiction of the district courts of the United States under provisions relating to the seizure of trade secrets to include actions related to the misappropriation of a trade secret that is related to or included in a product produced for or placed in interstate or foreign commerce. Authorizes a court, upon ex parte application and upon clear and convincing evidence that issuing the order is necessary to prevent irreparable harm, to issue an order providing for: (1) the seizure of any property used or intended to be used in the commission of the violation alleged in the civil action, and (2) the preservation of evidence in the civil action.

Adult Education Instructor Recruitment and Retention Act of 2002 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to provide student loan forgiveness in exchange for the borrower's commitment to three consecutive years of full-time employment as an adult education instructor at an adult education facility serving low-income communities.

Federal Prosecutors Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2001 - Includes Federal prosecutors (including assistants and attorneys employed by the Department of Justice (DOJ) and designated by the Attorney General) within the definition of a law enforcement officer for purposes of provisions governing the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees Retirement System.

Directs the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the Office of Federal Contract Compliance to provide counseling services regarding, and endeavor to address and resolve, claims of unlawful discrimination using certified contract mediators.Mandates that any Federal agency or court (or business enterprise receiving $20,000 or more in Federal funds, or having 20 or more employees): (1) establish an internal conflict management program or system providing the use of a certified mediator to resolve such disputes; and (2) participate in mediation in specified circumstances.

Federal Emergency Management Agency Restoration Act - (Sec. 2) Establishes the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) as a cabinet-level independent establishment in the executive branch responsible for emergency preparedness, response, recovery, and mitigation for all hazards, including major disasters, acts of terrorism, and other emergencies.<n><n>Requires the FEMA Director to be appointed, by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, from among persons who have extensive experience in emergency preparedness, response, recovery, and mitigation for all hazards, including major disasters, acts of terrorism, and other emergencies.<n><n>Extends the term of office of the Director from five to five years.<n><n>Requires FEMA to have one deputy director appointed in the competitive service by the Director, who shall serve as a liaison to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in the event of an act of terrorism.<n><n>Declares that the term emergency preparedness" does not include law enforcement efforts to prevent or deter acts of terrorism, protect critical infrastructure, and conduct intelligence activities.<n><n>(Sec. 3) Transfers to the Director FEMA the functions, personnel, assets, and liabilities of DHS, including functions relating to law enforcement efforts to prevent and deter acts of terrorism, protect critical infrastructure, and conduct"

21st Century Federal Pell Grant Plus Act - Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to develop, update, and publish in the Federal Register, at least once every two years, a list of engineering, mathematics, and science degrees, majors, certificates, or programs that may enable a student to receive an increased Federal Pell Grant amount.

Construction Consensus Procurement Improvement Act of 2016 This bill revises criteria for the use of design-build selection procedures for civilian and defense contracts for the design and construction of a public building, facility, or work. The Government Accountability Office shall report on the compliance of federal agencies with design-build contract requirements. The bill prohibits the use of reverse auctions for the award of design-build contracts.

Occupational Safety and Health Amendments of 1995- Amends the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to include as a purpose of such Act to encourage employers and employees in their efforts to reduce the number of occupational safety and health hazards, an employee participation committee. Declares that such committee does not constitute a labor organization" for purposes of the National Labor Relations Act or the Railway Labor Act. <n>Requires the Secretary of Labor, in determining the priority for establishing standards relating to toxic materials or harmful physical agents, to consider the number of workers exposed to such materials or agents, the nature and severity of potential impairment, and the likelihood of such impairment. <n>Requires the Secretary, in promulgating any final occupational safety and health regulation or standard, to publish in the Federal Register: (1) an estimate, calculated with as much specificity as practicable, of the risk to the health and safety of employees addressed by such regulation or standard, the affect of such regulation or standard on human health or the environment, and the costs associated with the implementation of, and compliance with, such regulation or standard; (2) a comparative analysis of such risk relative to other risks to which employees are exposed; and (3) a certification that such estimate and the analysis are: (1) based upon a scientific evaluation"

Veterans' Employment Transition Support Act of 2005 or the VETS Act of 2005 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow employers a business-related tax credit for 40 percent of the first-year wages paid to veterans who served in a combat zone or a hazardous duty area and for the same percentage of wages paid to disabled veterans.

United States Mariner and Vessel Protection Act of 2009 - Authorizes the Commandant of the Coast Guard to deploy a maritime safety and security team on a temporary basis, not to exceed six months, to deter, protect against, and rapidly respond to acts of piracy against vessels in international waters.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard is operating to: (1) issue regulations establishing standards and circumstances under which an individual is authorized to use force, including lethal force, against an individual in the defense of a vessel against piracy; and (2) work through the International Maritime Organization to establish agreements to promote coordinated action among flag and port states to deter, protect against, and rapidly respond to acts of piracy against the vessels of, and in the waters under the jurisdiction of, those nations.

Inspector General Act Amendments of 2001 - Amends the Inspector General Act of 1978 to: (1) prohibit an Inspector General from receiving any cash award or cash bonus, including any cash award under Federal law; (2) require an external review of the Office of Inspector General (Office) for at least every three years by the General Accounting Office or a private entity; (3) require an annual report from each Office to the head of the establishment and to appropriate congressional committees on Office activities and accomplishments during the immediately preceding 12-month period; and (4) revise required elements of such reports.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 5, 2016. Big Cat Public Safety Act of 2016 (Sec. 3) This bill amends the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 to prohibit any person from importing, exporting, transporting, selling, receiving, acquiring, purchasing in interstate or foreign commerce, breeding, or possessing any prohibited wildlife species (current law prohibits importing, exporting, transporting, selling, receiving, acquiring, or purchasing such a species in interstate or foreign commerce). The bill defines "breeding" as intentionally or negligently: (1) facilitating propagation or reproduction, or (2) failing to prevent propagation or reproduction. The bill removes from the list of persons authorized to import, export, transport, sell, receive, acquire, purchase, breed, or possess such species a person that is licensed or registered, and inspected, by the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) or any other federal agency with respect to such species. A person who knowingly violates such prohibition is subject to a fine, up to 10 years in prison, or both. (Sec. 4) The bill makes it unlawful for any person to import, export, transport, sell, receive, acquire, breed, or purchase any prohibited wildlife species in interstate or foreign

Resource Efficient Appliance Incentives Act of 2005- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a business tax credit for the production of certain energy efficient appliances ( dishwashers, clothes washers, and refrigerators). Sets the amount of the credit based upon certain energy and water savings amounts required by the Energy Star program for dishwashers and clothes washers. Terminates the credit after 2010.

Orphan Drug Act Amendments of 1994 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to extend from seven years to four years the period of market exclusivity for certain orphan drugs. <n>Authorizes the holder of the approved application, certification, or license of such a drug to apply to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for a three-year extension. Requires the Secretary to approve such an application if the applicant: (1) demonstrates that the drug has a limited commercial potential; and (2) makes such demonstration on the basis of regulations that were in effect on the date such drug received its designation or when the applicant applied for an exemption. <n>Declares that this Act shall not apply to a drug: (1) for which an application was submitted before March 1, 1994, for which human clinical trials were actively being conducted before such date, and for which an application for designation under the Act was submitted before this Act's enactment; or (2) for which an exemption under the Act was in effect before March 1, 1994, for which human clinical trials were actively being conducted before such date, and for which an application for designation was submitted before this Act's enactment. <n>Extends from six months to six months after enactment the period during which the Secretary may designate a drug as a orphan

Veterans Medicare Reimbursement Demonstration Act of 1997 - Directs the Secretaries of Veterans Affairs (VA) and Health and Human Services (HHS) to jointly carry out a three-year demonstration project under which the HHS Secretary provides the VA with reimbursement, determined under this Act, from the Medicare program for health care services provided to targeted Medicare-eligible veterans in or through facilities of the VA selected. Authorizes the HHS Secretary to waive any requirement of part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance) of title XI of the Social Security Act, or a related provision of law. Specifies that: (1) the Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall designate up to three geographic service areas from which facilities are selected to participate in the project; and (2) the Secretary shall establish a plan for the selection of facilities under the VA jurisdiction and located within such areas, with preference for facilities suited to serve Medicare-eligible veterans because of high potential demand, sufficient capability in billing and accounting to participate, favorable indicators of quality of care, and meeting other relevant factors. Specifies that participation of targeted Medicare-eligible veterans in the project shall be voluntary. Requires the Secretary to establish cost-sharing requirements for veterans participating in the project. Declares that payments received by the Secretary under the project shall be credited to the applicable VA

Low-Income Housing Preservation Act of 1995 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a 15-year recovery period for the depreciation deduction for new investments to rehabilitate qualified low-income housing projects. Exempts a specified amount of such rehabilitation costs from the passive loss limitations.

Small Business Assistance and Credit Crunch Relief Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal Deposit Insurance Act to require each appropriate Federal banking agency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) to take prompt corrective action to resolve the problems of an insured depository institution after taking into consideration: (1) the management expertise and recent earnings history of the directors, officers, and employees of such institution; (2) any recent earnings history that suggests an improvement in the institution's financial condition; (3) the quality of its assets held; and (4) the potential disruption to the local economy if such institution is closed or otherwise made subject to sanctions by Federal regulators. <n>Prohibits the promulgated of any new regulation until such agency has conducted a regulatory impact analysis and concluded that the benefits of the proposed regulation outweigh its costs. <n>Requires the appropriate Federal banking agency to consider including in a proposed regulation a provision that eases the regulatory burden on small banks. <n>Prohibits the promulgated of any new regulation until such agency has conducted a regulatory impact analysis and concluded that the benefits of the proposed regulation outweigh its costs. <n>Requires the appropriate Federal banking agency to: (1) conduct a review of certain statutory and regulatory provisions affecting small banks; and (2) report to the Congress on such review. <n>Directs

Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia Diagnosis and Treatment Act of 2011 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish and implement an HHT initiative to assist in coordinating activities to improve early detection, screening, and treatment of people who suffer from hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT), which shall focus on: (1) advancing research on the causes, diagnosis, and treatment of HHT; and (2) increasing physician and public awareness of HHT. Directs the Secretary to: (1) establish the HHT Coordinating Committee; (2) designate four HHT Treatment Centers of Excellence from among its members; and (3) award grants to, or enter into contracts or cooperative agreements with, public or private nonprofit entities for the establishment, operation, and maintenance of HHT Treatment Centers of Excellence.

(Sec. 101) Specifies that a claimed process of making or using a machine, manufacture, or composition of matter is not obvious if: (1) the machine, manufacture, or composition of matter is novel; (2) the claimed process is a biotechnological process; and (3) the machine, manufacture, or composition of matter and the claimed process invention at the time it was made were owned by the same person or subject to an obligation of assignment to the same person and claims to the process and to the machine, manufacture, or composition of matter are entitled to the same effective filing date and appear in the same patent application, different patent applications, or patent which is owned by the same person and which expires or is set to expire on the same date. <n>Title II: Biotechnological Material Patents <n>Amends Federal patent law to make persons who import, sell, or use a product which is made by using a biotechnological material patented in the United States liable as an infringer if the importation, sale, or use of the product occurs during the term of the patent. Specifies that the term biotechnological material" is defined as any material (including a host cell, DNA sequence, or vector) that is used in a biotechnological process."

Enhanced Savings Opportunities Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to modify the rules for defined contribution plans" to: (1) provide for the equitable treatment of employer contributions to such plans; (2) exclude amounts received by a former employee after the fiveth taxable year following the taxable year in which such employee was terminated from such plans; (3) permit contributions to an annuity contract or retirement income account of a participant who is an employee of a church, a convention or association of churches, and whose compensation is includible in such contract or retirement income account; and (4) set forth special rules for defined contribution plans and simplified employee pension plans."

Amends the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States to suspend, through December 31, 2005, the duty on: (1) certain shearing machines; (2) certain machine tools; (3) certain extruders; (4) certain sector press machines; (5) certain tires; and (6) certain tires designed for off-highway use.

Underage Drinking Prevention Act of 2007 - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) understanding which programs are effective in reducing underage drinking will maximize scarce federal resources and help the nation confront underage drinking in a more effective and cost-efficient manner; (2) the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration should explore ways to expand and improve evaluation efforts while preserving and continuing current programs and funding; and (3) the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration should continue to improve evaluation efforts and national outcome measures reporting in the Substance Abuse Prevention and Treatment Block Grant and other grant programs, when appropriate.<n><n>Requires the Director of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Programs to award grants to eligible entities to: (1) increase enforcement of underage drinking that occurs at house parties across the nation and instances of adults providing alcohol to people under age 21; (2) inform the public of the legal consequences of providing alcohol to people under the minimum drinking age of 21; (3) educate the public that the majority of people who drink underage are obtaining their alcohol from social sources, such as family and friends; and (4) enhance, not supplant, effective local community initiatives for enforcing underage drinking laws.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on October 1, 2015. Directing Dollars to Disaster Relief Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to: (1) develop and implement an integrated plan to control and reduce administrative costs for major disasters, which shall include steps to reduce administrative costs, milestones needed for accomplishing the reduction of administrative costs, strategic goals for the average annual percentage of administrative costs of major disasters for each fiscal year, the assignment of clear roles and responsibilities, and a timetable for implementation; (2) compare the costs and benefits of tracking the administrative cost data for major disasters by the public assistance, individual assistance, hazard mitigation, and mission assignment programs, and if feasible, track this information; and (3) clarify FEMA guidance and minimum documentation requirements for a direct administrative cost claimed by a grantee or subgrantee of a public assistance grant program. FEMA shall submit specified reports to Congress on the development and implementation of the plan.

Children First Act of 2010 - Amends part A (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) (TANF) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to: (1) exclude child care assistance from the determination of the five-year limit on assistance under TANF; (2) increase funding for child care; (3) require state certification of procedures to ensure that child care providers comply with applicable state or local health and safety standards; (4) increase from 6 to 13 the maximum age allowed of a child under the care of a single custodial parent or other individual with custody who will not be subject to a reduction or termination of TANF assistance as a result of a refusal of the individual to engage in work; and (5) subject to the individual and case data reporting requirements of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 any TANF funds expended for child care, whether or not transferred to that Act.

Office of Biometric Identity Management Authorization Act of 2018 or the OIDENT Authorization Act of 2018 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to establish within the Management Directorate of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) the Office of Biometric Identity Management, which shall be administered by a Director. The Director shall: have significant professional management experience as well as experience in the field of biometrics and identity management; lead DHS's biometric identity services to support anti-terrorism, counter-terrorism, border security, credentialing, national security, and public safety; enable operational missions across DHS by receiving, matching, storing, sharing, and analyzing biometric and associated biographic and encounter data; deliver biometric identity information and analysis capabilities to DHS and its components, appropriate federal, state, local, and tribal agencies, appropriate foreign governments, and appropriate private sector entities; support the law enforcement, public safety, national security, and homeland security missions of other federal, state, local, and tribal agencies; manage the operation of DHS's primary biometric repository and identification system; manage Biometric Support Centers to provide biometric identification and verification analysis and services to DHS, appropriate federal, state, local, and tribal agencies, appropriate foreign governments, and appropriate private sector entities; oversee the implementation

National Trails System Willing Seller Act - Amends the National Trails System Act to: (1) prohibit the federal acquisition of land and interest in land outside the exterior boundaries of any federally administered area, except with the owner's consent, for the Oregon, Mormon Pioneer, Lewis and Clark, Iditarod, and Nez Perce National Historic Trails and the Continental Divide, North Country, Ice Age, and Potomac Heritage National Scenic Trails; and (2) provide that federal authority to acquire fee title shall be limited to an average of not more than one-quarter mile on either side of the Oregon, Mormon Pioneer, Continental Divide, Lewis and Clark, and Iditarod trails.

Education for Retirement Security Act of 2002 - Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to eligible entities to provide financial education programs to mid-life and older individuals who reside in local communities in order to: (1) enhance financial and retirement knowledge; and (2) reduce financial abuse and fraud, including telemarketing, mortgage, and pension fraud, among such individuals.Authorizes the Secretary to award a grant to one or more eligible entities to: (1) create and make available instructional materials and information that promote financial education; and (2) provide training and other related assistance regarding the establishment of financial education programs awarded a grant under this Act.

Prohibits the payment of basic pay of certain federal employees, including prevailing rate employees, during the period beginning on January 1, 2014, and ending on the normal effective date of the applicable wage survey adjustment that is to take effect in FY2014, in an amount that exceeds the rate payable for the applicable grade and step of the applicable wage schedule in accordance with such Act. Prohibits the payment of such pay during the period beginning on the day after the end of such period and ending on September 30, 2014, in an amount that exceeds, as a result of such wage survey adjustment, the rate payable under such Act by more than the sum of: (1) the percentage adjustment taking effect in FY2014 in the rates of pay under the General Schedule; and (2) the difference between the overall average percentage of the locality-based comparability payments taking effect in FY2014 and the overall average percentage of such payments which was effective in the previous fiscal year.

Phone Bill Fairness Act - Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to jointly investigate and report to Congress on the billing practices of telecommunications carriers. Requires the FCC and FTC to determine: (1) the prevalence of confusion or confusing bills; (2) the most frequent causes for confusion; (3) whether or not telecommunications bills that impose fees through line-item charges characterize correctly the nature and basis of such fees, including whether or not such fees are required by the Federal Government or State governments; and (4) whether or not such fees are required by the Federal Government or State governments. Authorizes the FCC and FTC to: (1) obtain from any telecommunications carrier any record of such carrier that is relevant to the investigation; and (2) require the carrier to discontinue such characterization if it is incorrect.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Stop Tuberculosis Short [sic] Now Act of 2006 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to develop and implement a comprehensive strategy to: (1) control tuberculosis; (2) prevent the spread of tuberculosis; (3) reduce the incidence and mortality of tuberculosis; and (4) prevent and treat multi-drug resistant tuberculosis.

(Sec. 5) States that nothing in this Act shall limit the recovery by a claimant of the full amount of the available economic damages, notwithstanding the limitation contained in this Act. Allows the amount of noneconomic damages recovered, if otherwise available under applicable Federal or State law, to be as much as $250,000, regardless of the number of parties against whom the action is brought or the number of separate claims or actions brought. Prohibits: (1) discounting an award for future noneconomic damages; (2) the jury from being informed about the maximum award for noneconomic damages; (3) an award for noneconomic damages in excess of $250,000 to be reduced either before the entry of judgment or by amendment of the judgment after entry of judgment; and (4) the future noneconomic damages to be reduced first. Declares that each party shall be liable for that party's several share of any damages only and not for the share of any other person. Makes each party liable for the amount of damages allocated to such party in direct proportion to such party's percentage of responsibility. Declares that the total of all contingent fees for representing all claimants in a health care lawsuit shall not exceed specified limits. Declares that the court shall supervise the arrangements for payment of damages to protect against conflicts of

Alaska Adjacent Zone Safe Oil Transport and Revenue Sharing Act Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act (OCSLA) to direct the Secretary of the Interior to: (1) require oil produced from federal leases in certain Arctic waters, except in preproduction phases (including exploration), to be transported by pipeline to onshore facilities; and (2) issue appropriate permits for the transportation of oil from such leases in preproduction phases by means other than pipeline. Directs the Secretary to pay: (1) 25% of any allocable share of the state of Alaska directly to coastal political subdivisions within 300 miles of the geographical center of a leased tract; and (2) 25% of any allocable share of the state directly to certain Regional Corporations established under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act.

. National Sea Grant College Program Amendments Act of 2015 (Sec.3) This bill amends the National Sea Grant College Program Act to reauthorize through FY2021 the National Sea Grant College Program. The bill requires the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to award Dean John A. Knauss Marine Policy Fellowships. Currently, NOAA has discretion in awarding such fellowships. Those fellowships support the placement of graduate students in fields related to ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources in positions with the executive and legislative branches. (Sec.4)NOAA must establish priorities for the use of donations given for the National Sea Grant Program. (Sec.8)An agency may appoint a recipient of a Dean John A. Knauss Marine Policy Fellowship to a federal position within two years after such recipient successfully completes a fellowship. (Sec.9)The bill authorizes through FY2021 grants for university research on: (1) the biology, prevention, and control of aquatic nonnative species; (2) oyster diseases, oyster restoration, and oyster-related human health risks; (3) the biology, prevention, and forecasting of harmful algal blooms; and (4) sustainable aquaculture techniques and technologies. The bill also authorizes through FY2021 grants for: (1) fishery extension activities conducted by sea grant colleges or sea grant

Personal Exemption Fairness Act of 2010 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for regional cost-of-living adjustments in personal exemptions.
