Requires the Secretary of Labor to determine and publish a cost-of-living index for each statistical area for each calendar year beginning after 2009.

Biometric Enhancement for Airport- Risk Reduction Act of 2008 - Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security, acting through the Assistant Secretary of Homeland Security (Transportation Security Administration) (TSA), to study how airports can transition to uniform, standards-based, and interoperable biometric identifier systems for airport workers with unescorted access to secure or sterile areas of an airport. Requires: (1) the Secretary to conduct a risk-based analysis of selected Category X and I airports and other airports to identify where the implementation of biometric identifier systems could benefit airports; and (2) the Secretary to convene a working group of aviation industry stakeholders to assist the Secretary with issues pertaining to implementing and carrying out this Act.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 6, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Motor Carrier Safety Specialist Certification Act - (Sec. 3) Amends Federal transportation law to direct the Secretary of Transportation to establish a program for the training and certification of Federal, State, and local government, and nongovernmental motor carrier safety specialists. Declares that no safety compliance review shall be valid unless it is conducted by a certified motor carrier safety specialist.(Sec. 4) Directs the Secretary to ensure that: (1) at least 50 percent of the employees of the Department of Transportation who perform reviews to determine compliance of carriers in accordance with regulations promulgated by the Secretary are certified under this Act; and (2) all Federal, State, and local employees who perform such compliance reviews are so certified.(Sec. 5) Directs the Secretary to accept and include information, subject to verification by a clearinghouse designated by the Motor Carrier Safety Specialist Certification Board, obtained from nongovernmental motor carrier safety specialists certified under this Act.

Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for a prospective payment for inpatient rehabilitation hospital services based on discharges classified by functional-related groups.

Amends the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 to extend through: (1) May 16, 2007; and (2) September 8, 2007 (currently, September 8, 2005), the requirement that the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission report to the congressional defense committees on recommendations for the closure or realignment of military installations. Extends through: (1) June 30, 2007, the authority of the Secretary of Defense to close or realign any military installation; and (2) September 30, 2007, the authority of the President to require the closure or realignment of any military installation.

Transparency and Accountability in Congressional Travel Act of 2012 - Prohibits a Member or employee of Congress from undertaking any official foreign travel unless, not later than 14 days prior to the date on which the travel begins, such Member or employee prepares and submits to the Clerk of the House of Representatives or the Secretary of the Senate: (1) a statement of worthiness regarding the purpose of the travel, including a description of how the travel relates to the Member's or employee's official duties; (2) a tentative itinerary for each day of the travel, including a list of the foreign nations and the locations within each such nation the Member or employee intends to visit and any individuals with whom the Member or employee intends to meet; (3) the names of any other individuals who are accompanying the Member or employee during the travel, as well as the amount of per diem the Member or employee requested to be provided for the travel and whether the amount is greater than the standard per diem provided under federal law; (4) a statement as to whether the aircraft to be used for transportation for the travel is commercial, chartered, private, or military, and whether the seating is coach, business class, or first class; (5) the Member's or employee's best estimate of the costs of the

Family and Medical Leave Enhancement Act of 2009 - Amends the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 (FMLA) to cover employees at worksites that employ fewer than 50 employees, but not fewer than 25 employees. Continues to exempt from FMLA coverage employees at worksites that employ fewer than 25 employees (currently 50), if the total number of employees employed by that employer within 75 miles of that worksite is fewer than 25 (currently 50).<n><n>Allows an employee covered by FMLA to take up to 4 hours during any 30-day period, and up to 24 hours during any 12-month period, of parental involvement and family wellness leave to: (1) participate in or attend activities sponsored by a school or community organization and related to a program attended by the employee's child or grandchild; or (2) meet routine family medical care needs, including medical and dental appointments of the employee or a son or daughter, spouse, or grandchild of the employee, or to attend to the care needs of elderly individuals who are related to the employee, including visits to nursing homes and group homes.<n><n>Allows an employee to elect, or an employer to require the employee, to substitute any of the accrued paid vacation leave, personal leave, or family leave of the employee for any leave allowed under this

Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2017 This bill amends the federal judicial code to establish the Office of Inspector General for the Judicial Branch of the U.S. government, to be headed by an Inspector General appointed by the Chief Justice. The office shall: conduct investigations of alleged misconduct in the judicial branch, including misconduct in the United States Supreme Court; prevent and detect waste, fraud, and abuse; and recommend changes in laws or regulations governing the judicial branch. An inspector general may be removed from office by the Chief Justice.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 7, 2016. Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection Advisory Board Enhancement Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 to direct the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to establish a Small Business Advisory Board to: (1) advise and consult with the CFPB in the exercise of its functions under the federal consumer financial laws regarding eligible financial products or services, and (2) provide information on emerging practices of small business concerns that provide financial products or services for use by consumers primarily for personal, family, or household purposes. The CFPB shall establish a Credit Union Advisory Council, a Community Bank Advisory Council, and a Credit Union Advisory Council to advise and consult with the CFPB on consumer financial products or services that impact credit unions and community banks, respectively.

Preservation of Antibiotics for Human Treatment Act of 2002 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to deem unsafe animal feed containing a new animal drug which is a member of the fluoroquinolone class of antimicrobial drugs, unless the Secretary of Health and Human Services receives information from the drug's sponsor that there exists a reasonable certainty of no harm to human health due to the development of antimicrobial resistance attributable to the use of such drug in animal feed.Requires the Secretary to withdraw or rescind approval of previously approved drugs that are either critical antimicrobial drugs or in the same chemical class as critical antimicrobial drugs, unless the Secretary receives information from the drug's sponsor that there exists a reasonable certainty of no harm to human health due to the development of antimicrobial resistance attributable to the use of such drug in animal feed.

Declaration of Official Language Act of 1997 - Declares English to be the official language of the U.S. Government, and requires the U.S. Government to promote and support the use of English for communications among U.S. citizens. Requires all U.S. citizens to be encouraged to read, write, and speak English to the extent of their physical and mental abilities. Declares that it has been the long-standing national belief that full citizenship in the United States requires fluency in English. Directs the Immigration and Naturalization Service to: (1) enforce the established English language proficiency standard for all applicants for U.S. citizenship; and (2) conduct all naturalization ceremonies entirely in English. Makes this Act inapplicable to the use of a language other than English for: (1) religious purposes; (2) training in foreign languages for international communication; or (3) use of non-English terms of art in Government documents. Declares that this Act is not intended to affect programs in schools designed to encourage students to learn foreign languages. Authorizes anyone injured by a violation of this Act to obtain appropriate relief in a civil action. Allows the court to allow a prevailing party, other than the United States, a reasonable attorney's fee as part of costs.

Stop Legislative Automatic Spending Hikes (SLASH) Act of 2008- Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to report annually to Congress a list comprised of all agencies and programs that received ineffective ratings under the most recent program assessment rating tool pursuant to the Government Performance and Results Act of 1993 or three consecutive annual adequate ratings under such tool and the preceding two. Terminates any such agency or program 60 days after the OMB Director transmits such report to Congress, unless a statute has been enacted stating that all such agencies and programs shall not terminate.<n><n>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow individual taxpayers a rebate in each calendar year equal to the program elimination rebate amount determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. Defines program elimination rebate amount" as the amount that the Secretary estimates will result in a reduction in revenue equal to the dollar amount of estimated savings reported to the Secretary by the OMB in 2008 for the preceding calendar year."

Directs the Secretary of Defense to: (1) commence and complete the redeployment of units and members of the Armed Forces deployed in Iraq as part of Operation Iraqi Freedom and contractors operating in Iraq within 90 days after the enactment of this Act; and (2) complete such redeployment within 180 days.<n><n>Prohibits the obligation or expenditure of funds to increase the number of Armed Forces serving in Iraq in excess of the number serving as of January 1, 2007, unless the increase has been specifically authorized in advance by an Act of Congress.<n><n>Provides that nothing in this Act shall be construed to restrict the locations outside of Iraq to which units and members redeployed from Iraq may be transferred, including redeployment to an adjacent or nearby country at the invitation of the government of the country or redeployment to bolster military forces deployed in Afghanistan as part of Operation Enduring Freedom.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to retain in Iraq members of the Armed Forces for the purpose of providing security for the U.S. Embassy and other U.S. diplomatic missions in Iraq, protecting American citizens, and serving in roles consistent with customary diplomatic positions, engaging in targeted special actions limited in duration and scope to killing or capturing members of al-Qaeda and other terrorist organizations with global reach, and training and equipping

Child Immunization Incentive Act of 1993 - Amends the Social Security Act to require States to deny Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) benefits for children who have not attained the age of six years, unless the State has received from one or more physicians written verification that the child has been examined by a physician at least once every six months since the child was born and every year thereafter. <n>Amends the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act to require: (1) a requirement that child care providers require each child who receives child care services from them that certificates signed by a physician verify that the child has been immunized in accordance with recommendations issued by the Surgeon General to be submitted, at required intervals and in accordance with rules issued by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to the child care provider involved; and (2) such procedures to ensure that each such provider gives to parents of each child who receives child care services written notice of each immunization requirement applicable to such child, of an opportunity of at least 30 days to correct the failure to satisfy such requirement, and of the fact that child care services for such child will be terminated for failure to satisfy such requirement before the expiration of the 45-day period beginning on the date such notice is received. <n>Directs the Surgeon General

Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to: (1) develop and implement a fraud, waste, and abuse comprehensive pre-payment review prevention system for reviewing claims for reimbursement under title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act; and (2) carry out the System acting through the Center for Program Integrity of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services.

Home Energy Savings Incentives Act of 2005 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to replace the tax credit for nonbusiness energy property expenditures with a tax credit for certified natural gas savings and electricity savings.

Federal Computer Security Act - Requires the Inspector General of each of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Department of Defense (DOD), and the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) that operates a Federal computer system that provides access to classified information or personally identifiable information to submit a report to the Comptroller General and Congress regarding such system, including: (1) a description of the logical access standards used by the agency to access such system, including a list and description of logical access controls used and whether the agency is using multi-factor logical access controls to access such system; (2) if the agency does not use logical access controls or multi-factor logical access controls to access such system, a description of the reasons for not using such controls; (3) a description of the data security management practices used by the agency, including the policies and procedures followed to conduct inventories of the software present on such systems and the licenses associated with such software; (4) whether the agency has entered into a licensing agreement for the use of software security controls to monitor and detect exfiltration and other threats, including data loss prevention software and digital rights management software; and (5) how the agency is using such software. Requires the Comptroller General to report to Congress on: (1) any impediments to agency use of effective security software and security

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt employers, other than the United States, states, or political subdivisions, and public institutions of higher education, from employment tax for up to one year for wages paid to certain individuals hired in 2010 who: (1) begin employment with such employers after February 3, 2010, and before January 1, 2011; (2) certify, under penalties of perjury, that they have not been employed for more than 40 hours during the 60-day period ending on the date such individual begins employment; (3) are not employed by such employers to replace another employee unless such other employee separated from employment voluntarily or for cause; and (4) are not an individual described in the previous paragraph. Appropriates to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund amounts equal to the reduction in revenues resulting from the application of this Act. Allows an increased business-related tax credit for the retention of certain newly-hired workers for 52 consecutive weeks in 2010.

Small Business Start-up Savings Accounts Act of 2011- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for tax-exempt small business start-up savings accounts to pay for trade or business expenses, including the purchase of equipment or facilities, marketing, training, incorporation, and accounting fees. Allows annual contributions to such accounts up to the lesser of $10,000 or $150,000.

Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2011 - Directs the Secretary of Education to make grants to states to prevent teacher layoffs and support the creation of additional jobs in public early childhood, elementary, and secondary education in the 2011-2012 and 2012-2013 school years. Directs the Secretary to reserve funds for: (1) assistance to the outlying areas on the basis of their respective needs; and (2) activities in schools operated or funded by the Bureau of Indian Education.

Homeland Security Professional Development Act of 2006 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to establish the Homeland Security Mentoring Program for DHS employees. Requires the Program to: (1) be established in accordance with the DHS Human Capital Strategic Plan; (2) incorporate DHS human capital strategic plans and activities, and address critical human capital deficiencies, recruitment and retention efforts, and succession planning within the DHS workforce; (3) enable DHS employees to share expertise, values, skills, resources, perspectives, attitudes and proficiencies to develop and foster a cadre of qualified employees and future leaders; (4) incorporate clear learning goals, objectives, meeting schedules, and feedback processes that will help DHS employees, managers, and executives enhance skills and knowledge while reaching professional and personal goals; (5) enhance professional relationships, contacts, and networking opportunities among DHS employees; (6) complement and incorporate mentoring and training programs within DHS; and (7) promote cross-disciplinary mentoring and training opportunities that include provisions for intradepartmental rotational opportunities, in accordance with human capital goals and plans that foster a more diversified and effective DHS workforce.<n><n>Directs the Training Leaders Council established by the Chief Human Capital Officer to administer the Program.

Providing Retaliation Options against Those Engaging in Cyberattacks Targeting the United States Act or PROTECT US Act This bill authorizes the President to impose certain trade-related penalties on countries that are designated as state-sponsors of cyberattacks. The President shall submit to Congress a list of countries designated as state-sponsors of cyberattacks. If the President determines that the United States or a U.S. person has been targeted in a malicious cyber-enabled activity originating from, or directed by a person located, in a foreign country, and such activity is reasonably likely to result in, or have materially contributed to, a threat to the national security or foreign policy of the United States, or harmed the economic health or financial stability of the United States or a U.S. person, the President shall designate such country as a state-sponsor of cyberattacks. The President may impose a duty on any article or service imported directly or indirectly into the United States that is produced in whole or in part in a country listed as a state-sponsors of cyberattacks. The President may also impose specified actions with respect to a country that is included on the list, including: (1) a private demarche; (2) an official public condemnation; (3) a public condemnation within one or more multilateral fora; (4) the delay

Department of Homeland Security Data Framework Act of 2018 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to: (1) develop a data framework to integrate existing DHS datasets and systems for access by authorized personnel in a manner consistent with relevant legal authorities and privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties policies and protections; (2) ensure that such framework includes all information acquired, held, or obtained by an office or component of DHS that falls within the scope of the information sharing environment, including homeland security information, terrorism information, weapons of mass destruction information, and national intelligence; and (3) ensure that such framework is accessible to DHS employees who have an appropriate security clearance, are assigned to perform a function that requires access to information in such framework, and are trained in applicable standards for safeguarding and using such information. The bill sets forth provisions regarding the exclusion and security of information from the framework.

Veterans Health Care Budget Reform and Transparency Act of 2009 - Provides two-fiscal year budget authority for certain Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) medical care accounts, including the medical care accounts of the Veterans Health Administration. Requires the Comptroller General to study and report to Congress on the adequacy and accuracy of the budget projections made by the Enrollee Health Care Projection Model, its equivalent, or other methodologies for estimating and projecting VA health care expenditures.

Superfund Emergency Response Act of 2012 - Authorizes the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to carry out any assessment, monitoring, remediation, repair, or construction activity that the Administrator determines is necessary at a site that: (1) is proposed to be listed on, is listed on, or has been deleted from the National Priorities List (NPL); and (2) is located in an area that the President has declared a major disaster.<n><n>Authorizes the governor or Senator of a state to request that the Administrator: (1) carry out an assessment and report on the impacts, if any, of a major disaster on any site that is proposed to be listed on, is listed on, or has been deleted from the NPL and is located in an area that the President has declared a major disaster; and (2) determine whether to carry out such assessment and inform the governor or Senator of that determination within 15 days. Requires such assessment to include: (1) an evaluation of whether a major disaster resulted in the release of any contaminants into the ambient environment that threaten public health and the environment; (2) an assessment of any actions necessary to a toxic release, repair any damage, or provide monitoring in response to damage associated with the major disaster, along with an estimate of the cost to complete those actions;

Reach Every Mother and Child Act of 2017 This bill amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to direct the President to: establish a five-year strategy to achieve, with target countries and donors, the goal of ending preventable child and maternal deaths globally and ensure healthy and productive lives by 2030; and provide assistance to implement the strategy. The President shall designate a current U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) employee serving in the Senior Executive Service or at the level of a Deputy Assistant Administrator or higher to serve concurrently as the Child and Maternal Survival Coordinator, who shall be responsible for: overseeing such strategy, and all U.S. government funds appropriated or used for international maternal and child health and nutrition programs.

Native American Housing Enhancement Act of 2005 - Amends the Housing Act of 1949 to make Indian tribes eligible for certain housing assistance and youth build grants under such Act and the Cranston-Gonzales National Affordable Housing Act. (Current law makes Indian tribes ineligible for such assistance and YouthBuild grants.)

. Canine Members of the Armed Forces Act (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Department of Defense (DOD) to classify military working dogs as canine members of the Armed Forces and such dogs shall not be classified as equipment. If the Secretary of the military department concerned determines that a military working dog should be retired, and no suitable adoption is available at the military facility where the dog is located, DOD may transfer the dog to the 341st Training Squadron, or to another location for adoption. (Sec. 4) DOD shall establish and maintain a system to provide for the veterinary care of retired military working dogs. Requires the veterinary care provided to an eligible dog to be provided during the life of the dog beginning on the date on which the dog is adopted. Requires DOD to award a contract to a private non-profit entity to administer the system.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 23, 2011. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Nellis Dunes National Off-Highway Vehicle Recreation Area Act of 2011- (Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary of the Interior to convey to Clark County, Nevada, for no consideration, all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to approximately 1,211 acres of federal land in the county, to be used by the county: (1) for the establishment of a centralized off-road vehicle recreation park; (2) for the public with opportunities for off-road vehicle recreation, including a location for races, competitive events, training and other commercial services that directly support a centralized off-road vehicle recreation area and county park; and (3) for a designated area and facilities that would discourage unauthorized use of off-highway vehicles in areas identified by the federal government, state government, or county government as containing environmentally sensitive land. Provides that if the county ceases to use any such parcel for such purposes: (1) title to such parcel shall revert to the United States, at its option; and (2) the county shall be responsible for any reclamation necessary to revert such parcel to the United States. Authorizes the use of such land for the incidental purpose of

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Veterans' Disability Claims Efficiency Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in the case of a veteran who submits a disability claim for more than one condition and the Secretary determines that a disability rating can be assigned without further development for one or more conditions but not all conditions in the claim, to: (1) expeditiously review the claim; (2) assign an interim disability rating for each condition that the Secretary determines could be assigned without further development; and (3) continue development of the remaining conditions. Requires the Secretary, with respect to an interim disability rating assigned for a condition that is rated less than the maximum rate, to continue development. Provides that such rating shall remain in effect unless the Secretary later assigns an increased rating for such condition. Excludes such rating from application if: (1) the rating was based on fraud; or (2) such condition improves. Directs the Secretary to establish a process for the rapid identification of initial claims for disability compensation that should, in the order of review, receive priority.

Safe Schools Act of 1994 - Directs the Secretary of Education to make competitive grants to eligible local educational agencies to carry out projects designed to achieve Goal Six of the National Education Goals, which provides that by the year 2000, every school in America will be free of drugs and violence and will offer a disciplined environment conducive to learning, by helping to ensure that all schools are safe and free of violence. Directs the Secretary to develop a written safe schools model so all schools can develop models that enable all students to participate regardless of any language barriers. Authorizes appropriations. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to reserve up to five percent of funds to carry out national leadership activities under this Act. <n>Sets requirements for grant applications and plans. <n>Directs the Secretary, in awarding grants, to take into account the special needs of local educational agencies located in both rural and urban communities. <n>Authorizes appropriations. <n>Reserves up to five percent of funds to carry out national leadership activities under this Act.

Fair Elections Act of 1993 - Entitles an individual to be placed as a candidate on, and to have such individual's political party, body, or group affiliation in connection with such candidacy placed on, a ballot or similar voting materials to be used in a Federal election under specified conditions.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Black Hills National Forest and Rocky Mountain Research Station Improvement Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to convey certain lands in South Dakota and use the proceeds for acquisition, construction, or administrative improvements in the Black Hills National Forest or the Rocky Mountain Research Station.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 19, 2012. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Veterans Conservation Corps Authorization Act (Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish a veterans conservation corps to: (1) provide training and employment to unemployed veterans; (2) assist such veterans in the transition from service in the Armed Forces to civilian life; and (3) assist the federal government in maintaining federal land and water. Requires the Secretary to employ corps veterans for a one-year period to carry out work projects. Allows the Secretary to extend such employment for an additional one-year period. Limits the employment of corps veterans to 16 weeks in total. Requires each corps veteran to be assigned to a work project that falls within one or more of the following categories: transportation improvements, such as improving wilderness trails; Erosion control; landscape and recreation; habitat protection and restoration, including removal of invasive species; data collection; or any other specific project category. Directs the Secretary, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA), and the Secretary of Commerce to: (1) use existing facilities of the federal government to provide education and training necessary to enable corps veterans to carry out such work projects; and (2) develop and supervise such work projects that relate to the respective

National Center for Excellence in Research and Development Act of 1994 - Authorizes appropriations to the Secretary of Energy for FY 1995 and beyond to maintain the operational readiness of the underground nuclear testing facilities and infrastructure of the Nevada Test Site. <n>Establishes within the Department of Energy a National Test and Demonstration Center of Excellence at the Nevada Test Site, Nevada, to promote disarmament, demilitarization, alternative and renewable energy sources, the nonproliferation of nuclear weapons, sensor development, and environmentally sensitive technologies.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 16, 2015. Home Health Documentation and Program Improvement Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends part A (Hospital Insurance) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) to develop a single form or document to be used by a physician to satisfy the documentation requirements necessary to fulfill the face-to-face encounter and other criteria for home health eligibility. In developing the form or document, CMS shall seek input from stakeholders, including physicians and other non-physician providers, home health agencies, hospitals, patients or representatives of patients, and other entities the CMS determines appropriate. CMS shall set up a process to educate physicians and non-physicians on how to appropriately fulfill the documentation requirements related to the form or document prior to implementation. The CMS shall accept certain content as documentation of an individual's eligibility for home health services: with respect to the face-to-face encounter requirement, the date of the encounter; with respect to homebound status, a statement that provides the clinical basis for why the individual is determined to be confined to the home; and with respect to the need for skilled services, a selection, via

State Health Care Flexibility Act of 2011 - Allows a qualifying state to elect to opt out of the application of any or all of the provisions of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act with respect to health insurance coverage within such state.

School Desegregation Litigation Reform Act of 1996 - Amends the Equal Educational Opportunities Act of 1974 with respect to Federal jurisdiction over civil actions for the operation of public schools to require that prospective relief be narrowly drawn, extend no further than necessary, and be the least intrusive means necessary to remedy a violation of the Federal right. <n>Prohibits a Federal court from having jurisdiction to order prospective relief that: (1) requires or permits a government official to exceed authority under State or local law or otherwise violates State or local law unless Federal law requires such relief to be ordered in violation of State or local law; or (2) authorizes a Federal court in exercising its remedial powers to order the assignment of students to particular schools on the basis of race, color, or national origin, to order the raising of taxes, or to repeal, or make less restrictive from otherwise applicable limitations, the remedial powers of the courts. <n>Prohibits a Federal court from entering a student assignment order unless: (1) a Federal court has previously entered an order for less intrusive relief that has failed to remedy the violation of the Federal right sought to be remedied through the student assignment order; and (2) the defendant has had a reasonable time to comply with the previous court order. Specifies that a student assignment order

Helping Empower Low-income Parents (HELP) Scholarships Amendments of 1997 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to provide for allocation to local educational agencies (LEAs) of title VI funds for voluntary public and private parental choice programs that allow low-income parents to choose the appropriate school for their children. <n>Directs State educational agencies to distribute not less than 90 percent to LEAs within such State according to the relative enrollments in public and private, nonprofit schools within the school districts of such LEAs, adjusted, in accordance with criteria approved by the Secretary of Education, to provide higher per pupil allocations to LEAs which have the greatest numbers or percentages of children whose education imposes a higher than average cost per child. <n>Permits a State that has enacted or will enact a law that establishes such a program to reserve an additional 15 percent from the sums made available each year to carry out title VI if the additional amount reserved is used exclusively for such programs. <n>Requires such programs to: (1) be located in areas that have the greatest numbers or percentages of children living in high concentrations of low-income families, or living in sparsely populated areas; (2) ensure that participation is limited to families whose family income does not exceed 185 percent of the poverty

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Republic of the Marshall Islands Supplemental Nuclear Compensation Act of 2011 - Amends the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003 to direct the Secretary of Energy (DOE), as part of the Marshall Islands program, periodically (but not less frequently than every four years) to: (1) conduct a visual study of the concrete exterior of the Cactus Crater containment structure on Runit Island; and (2) conduct a radiochemical analysis of the groundwater surrounding and in the Cactus Crater containment structure on Runit Island.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to report to the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources and the House Committee on Natural Resources on the results of each visual survey, and the results of the radiochemical analysis, as well as a determination on whether the surveys and analyses indicate any significant change in the health risks to the people of Enewetak from the contaminants within the Cactus Crater containment structure.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to make available to the DOE, Marshall Islands Program, from funds available for the Technical Assistance Program of the Office of Insular Affairs, the amounts necessary to conduct the radiochemical analysis of groundwater.<n><n>Amends the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act

. Senior$afe Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill provides immunity from liability of: (1) a supervisor, compliance officer, or legal advisor for a covered financial institution who has received training regarding the identification and reporting of the suspected exploitation of a senior citizen (at least 65 years old) to a state financial regulatory agency, each of the federal financial institutions regulatory agencies, a law enforcement agency, or the adult protective services agency of a state, for disclosing such exploitation to such an agency; and (2) the financial institution for such a disclosure if the individual made the disclosure in good faith and with reasonable care. A "covered financial institution" is a bank, a credit union, an investment adviser, or a broker-dealer, as defined by the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The financial institution may provide the required training to each of its officers or employees.

Jumpstarting Our Business Sector Act of 2011 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to eliminate the corporate income tax and the alternative minimum tax (AMT) on corporations as of December 31, 2011. Establishes a 0% capital gains rate for individuals.

Men and Families Health Care Act of 2009 - Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish an Office of Men's Health to: (1) coordinate the collection and analysis of data on the health status of men in the United States; (2) oversee the development and implementation of a program to increase awareness among men of their health issues; and (3) work with federal, state, local, and tribal governments, institutions of higher education, and health care providers to carry out this Act.

Manufacturing Advisory Council Establishment Act of 2004 - Establishes the President's Council of Advisors on Manufacturing to: (1) advise the President on policy matters affecting the domestic manufacturing sector; (2) assist in the development of policies that will reduce production costs within the sector, promote the competitiveness of U.S. products in international markets, encourage innovation, investment, and productivity in the sector, and ensure an adequate supply of skilled workers in it; and (3) assist the Secretary of Commerce in securing private sector involvement for Department of Commerce activities.

Fair Trade in Grain Act of 1993 - Requires specified information to be included in the documentation covering the entry of foreign grain. Requires a consignee of imported foreign grain to submit quarterly reports to the Secretary of Agriculture certifying what percentage of the grain was used by the consignee and that the grain was used for the purpose stated in the end-use certificate. Applies civil penalties to violations of the requirements of this Act. <n>Amends the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 to direct the Secretary to provide agricultural commodities or cash payments to promote the export of wheat to Mexico. <n>Directs the administering authority to initiate a countervailing duty investigation and an antidumping duty investigation with respect to Canadian wheat subsidies.

Requires a life or disability insurer, as a condition for the sale of a covered insurance product, that an applicant submits to an examination or test by a physician, health professional, or medical laboratory to: (1) require the physician, professional, or laboratory to provide the results in a written report containing the findings of all tests, diagnoses, and conclusions made; and (2) mail the report to the applicant at an address provided by the applicant. <n>Requires the insurer, if it mails a report containing a finding of abnormality or irregularity with respect to the health or condition of the applicant, to include with the report a document that: (1) highlights the abnormal or irregular finding in language that is understandable to a person of average intelligence with no medical training; and (2) advises the applicant to consult with a suitable health professional for further explanation and appropriate follow-up. <n>Allows an applicant to elect to have the report and document mailed to him or her in lieu of having the report and document mailed. Specifies that the election shall be effective in any case where the applicant, before the date of the examination or test, declines to receive the results by submitting to the insurer a waiver form that includes: (1) a check-off box, marked by hand by the applicant, showing the

Medicare+Choice Improvement and Stabilization Act of 2001 - Amends part C (Medicare+Choice) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to: (1) provide for payment based on 100 percent of fee-for-service costs for 2003; (2) change Medicare+Choice reporting deadlines and annual, coordinated election period and delay in lock-in provisions; (3) provide for demonstration projects for preferred provider organizations, point-of-service plans, MSA plans, and disease management programs; (4) authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to carry out demonstration projects for preferred provider organizations, point-of-service plans, MSA plans, and disease management programs; and (5) provide for suspension of limitation for program reentry for 2003 and 2004.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 23, 2013. Up to STEM Act of 2013 - Amends the Department of Education Organization Act to establish the Office of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Education within the Department of Education to: (1) serve as the principal advisor to the Secretary of Education on matters affecting STEM education, and (2) administer STEM education programs administered by the Department of Education through the Office of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Education. Requires the Office to conduct an independent evaluation of STEM education programs. Authorizes appropriations for FY2014-FY2015 for the Advanced Research Projects for Education program. Establishes an Advanced Research Agency within the Department of Transportation to: (1) foster the use of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) curricula and instructional materials to improve student academic performance in mathematics and science; (2) devise, deploy, and support new STEM curricula, materials, and training; (3) train STEM teachers to incorporate STEM into their teaching; (4) develop STEM Career Awareness Programs; and (5) develop STEM-related workforce education and training programs.

Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 (Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act) to require that any document setting forth an agreement entered into under this Act and the President's report in support of such agreement be transmitted to each House of the Congress on the same day and be delivered to both Houses of the Congress if the House is not in session. <n>Requires any document setting forth such an agreement and the President's report to set forth a determination of the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration as to whether there is expected to be a net reduction in any positive actuarial balance for the 75-year period following the entry into force of the agreement, a net increase in any negative actuarial balance attributable to the operation of such agreement equal to at least 0.005 percent of the present value of the taxable payroll for such period.

Rural Health Quality Advisory Commission Act of 2007 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish the Rural Health Quality Advisory Commission to: (1) develop and implement a national plan for rural health quality improvement; and (2) design demonstration projects to test alternative models for rural health quality improvement.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to make grants to eligible entities for five demonstration projects to implement and evaluate methods for improving the quality of health care in rural communities.

Authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to administer a Biofuels Feedstocks Energy Reserve to: (1) provide feedstocks in furtherance of biofuel-based energy production; and (2) support the biofuels energy industry when production is at risk due to reductions in feedstocks or commodity prices. Sets forth related provisions respecting commercial commodity purchases, release of commodity stocks, and storage payments.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Southern Prairie Potholes Act of 2014 (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Department of the Interior to establish the Southern Prairie Potholes National Wildlife Refuge, located in Greene County, Iowa, and known as the Southern Prairie Potholes Trail.

Military Sexual Assault Victims Empowerment Act or the Military SAVE Act - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out a three-year pilot program to furnish hospital care and medical services to eligible veterans through non-VA health care providers to treat injuries or illnesses which, in the judgment of a VA professional employed by the VA, resulted from a physical assault of a sexual nature, battery of a sexual nature, or sexual harassment which occurred while the veteran was serving on active duty, active duty for training, or inactive duty training. Directs the Secretary to select no more than five sites and to ensure that: (1) each provider maintains at least the same or similar credentials and licenses as those required of VA health care providers, and (2) the provider is familiar with the conditions and concerns that affect members of the Armed Forces and veterans and is trained in evidence-based psychotherapy. Allows a veteran to elect to participate in the program at each site, but requires the Secretary to: (1) notify eligible veterans of the ability to make such election, and (2) provide to such veterans educational referral materials on the non-VA providers in the sites selected. Directs the Secretary to ensure that the VA authorizes and monitors the hospital care and medical services furnished under the program for appropriateness and necessity.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 2, 2016. Food Date Labeling Act of 2016 (Sec. 4) This bill requires the Departments of Agriculture and Health and Human Services to promulgate a uniform date label for ready-to-eat products that specifies: (1) the quality date on packaging, (2) the safety date on packaging, (3) the date that will be reasonably foreseeable without additional preparation or storage, and (4) the date that is immediately preceded by the uniform safety date label if the product may pose a health safety risk. The label must specify: (1) the quality date on packaging, (2) the safety date on packaging, (3) the date that will be reasonably foreseeable without additional preparation or storage, and (4) the date that is immediately preceded by the uniform safety date label if the product may pose a health safety risk.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on May 17, 2016. Empowering Teaching and Learning Through Education Portals Act (Sec. 3) This bill authorizes the Department of Education to award grants to states for the federal share of costs of implementing and maintaining education portal initiatives, which are initiatives that provide students, teachers, and administrators with access to education technology that improves their learning, training, and engagement. A state may receive a grant only if it submits an application that meets specified requirements, including: (1) a comprehensive plan for the initiative; (2) information describing how the state will provide the non-federal share of the cost and will continue to provide that share during the implementation of the initiative and the remainder of the grant period; (3) information explaining the protocol the state will use to ensure safe and legal access to the education portal; (4) information explaining the protocol the state has established or will establish an advisory panel to provide advice on the implementation and maintenance of the initiative, including representatives of leaders in school districts, leaders at institutions of higher education, state educational agencies, parents, and teachers; and (5) a plan to ensure sufficient statewide bandwidth capacity and systems access to implement and maintain the state education portal. The bill sets the federal share of such costs at 50%.

Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and the Internal Revenue Code to authorize the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC) to permit a pension plan sponsor to accept from an employer a ratified collective bargaining agreement providing for a reduction in contributions made by a contributing employer and appropriate reduction in level of future benefit accruals for any participants for a period of up to five years (or a shorter period as determined by the PBGC) provided that the employer: (1) will be unable to pay its debts when due and will be unable to continue business without a reduction in its contribution rates; (2) the aggregate withdrawal liability of the contributing employer with respect to all multiemployer pension plans exceeds $750 million or such lower amount as determined by the PBGC; (3) there is substantial doubt as to the collectability of the withdrawal liability if the contributing employer were to withdraw from the plan; (4) the reduced contributions are not reasonably expected to have an adverse effect on the deficit of the PBGC; (5) other creditors, stakeholders, and other parties to which the contributing employer is obligated have accepted reductions that are comparable to those of the pension plan; and (6) such other conditions are satisfied as may be imposed by the PBGC.

Freedom From Government Competition Act of 1997 - Requires Federal agencies to procure all goods and services necessary for or beneficial to the accomplishment of authorized functions from sources in the private sector, except if: (1) such goods or services are inherently governmental in nature; or (2) the head of the agency determines that the provision of such goods or services should be produced, provided, or manufactured by the Federal Government for reasons of national security. Prohibits agencies from beginning or carrying out activities to provide products or services that can be provided by the private sector.

Amends Federal law to limit appropriations to the Northern Mariana Islands for FY 1994 through 1998 to provisions set forth in the Agreement of the Special Representatives on Future Federal Financial Assistance of the Northern Mariana Islands executed on December 17, 1992. Declares that no amendment to such Agreement may take effect until approved by an Act of the Congress. Declares that no funds made available in accordance with such Agreement shall be obligated until 60 days after the Secretary of the Interior certifies, together with findings, after enactment of this Act, that specified conditions have been fulfilled, to the extent such condition is applicable in such fiscal year, and no such funds shall be obligated for additional projects thereafter if the Secretary determines that the Northern Mariana Islands are not in compliance with such conditions to the extent such condition is applicable at that time: (1) the number of aliens present in the Northern Mariana Islands for work or residency does not exceed the 1992 average daily number as determined by the Commissioner of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS); (2) the Northern Mariana Islands shall impose a numerical limitation on the total number of alien workers admitted for employment in the garment industry so that the percentage of alien workers compared to the total number of workers in the garment industry shall be 75 percent in 1994, 70 percent in 1995, and 65 percent in

Grant Reporting Efficiency and Agreements Transparency Act of 2018 or the REMOTE Act This bill requires the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to: (1) designate an executive department that issues the most federal awards in a calendar year as the standard-setting agency; and (2) establish government-wide data standards for information reported by recipients of federal awards. The standards must include core data elements (defined as data elements that are not program-specific in nature and are required by agencies for all or the vast majority of federal grant and cooperative assistance recipients for purposes of reporting) and unique identifiers for federal awards and entities receiving federal awards that can be consistently applied government-wide. The standards must: (1) render information reported by recipients of federal awards fully searchable and machine-readable, (2) be nonproprietary, (3) incorporate standards developed and maintained by voluntary consensus standards bodies, and (4) provide for data formats and types that conform with public-domain standards for electronic commerce. The OMB must: (1) provide guidance to agencies on applying data standards for grant reporting, and (2) study the feasibility and cost of developing an entirely electronic, web-based process for managing grant and cooperative agreement data.

Master Teacher Act of 2001 - Directs the Secretary of Education to conduct a demonstration project under which the Secretary shall award competitive grants to local educational agencies to increase teacher salaries and employee benefits for teachers who enter into contracts with such agencies to serve as master teachers.

Tax Reduction and Economic Growth Act of 1995 - Grants the President authority to declare temporary tax reductions based on economic growth and the rate of national unemployment. <n>Provides for a temporary surtax when the economic growth requirements subsequently satisfied.

Children's Products Safety Act of 2007- Amends the Consumer Product Safety Act to require every manufacturer (and any related private labeler) of an article for use by a child under 60 months of age which is subject to a consumer product safety standard or a rule under any Act administered by the Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) declaring a consumer product a banned hazardous product to certify, based on testing conducted by a nongovernmental independent third party, that the product conforms to such standard or is not a banned hazardous product. (Current law authorizes the CPSC to issue a certificate certifying that a product conforms to a standard or is not a banned hazardous product.) Requires any test or testing program on the basis of which a certificate is issued to be conducted by a nongovernmental independent third party qualified to perform such tests or testing programs.

Choice in Welfare Tax Credit Act of 1995 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to permit an individual income tax credit of up to $100 ($200 for a joint return) of the value of certain charitable contributions to any tax-exempt, United States organization that spends at least 70 percent of aggregate expenditures assisting the poor. Requires that: (1) taxpayers identify each such contribution and the recipient on the individual's tax return; and (2) such charities provide copies of their annual return to such individuals without charge.

Military Reserves Small Business Relief Act - Amends the Small Business Act to direct the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA), upon request, to defer repayment of principal and interest due on direct loans made to: (1) an individual who is a reserve member serving pursuant to a call or order to active duty, or an order to remain on active duty, during a period of military conflict (the period); and (2) a small business that received such loan before such individual was so called, ordered, or ordered, or before such individual was so called, ordered, or ordered to remain on active duty. Extends the loan deferral period from the date the individual is ordered to active duty until the later of 180 days after: (1) such reserve is discharged or released; or (2) enactment of this Act, with no accrual of interest during such period. Applies such provisions to any period of military conflict beginning on or after August 1, 1990. <n>(Sec. 3) Authorizes the SBA to make disaster loans to assist a small business that has suffered or is likely to suffer economic injury as the result of a call or order to active military duty, or an order to remain on active duty, of an owner, manager, or key employee of such small business during a period of military conflict

Human Cloning Prohibition Act of 1998 - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit: (1) any person or entity, public or private, in or affecting interstate commerce, from using human somatic cell nuclear transfer technology; and (2) any person or entity from importing an embryo produced through human somatic cell nuclear transfer technology. Sets forth criminal and civil penalties for violations. <n>Establishes within the Institute of Medicine the National Commission to Promote a National Dialogue on Bioethics to: (1) provide an independent forum for broad public participation and discourse concerning important bioethical issues including cloning; and (2) provide for a report to the Congress on its findings and recommendations concerning Federal policy and possible congressional action.

Crop Risk Options Plan Act of 2013 - Amends the Federal Crop Insurance Act to: (1) provide an agricultural producer with the option of purchasing additional crop insurance coverage (Supplementary Coverage Option) based on an individual yield and loss basis or an area yield and loss basis, supplemented with coverage based on an area yield and loss basis to cover a part of the deductible under the individual policy; (2) revise the level of coverage required to be purchased at any level to be dollar denominated; (3) require the Federal Crop Insurance Corporation (CCC) to provide producers with information on catastrophic risk and additional coverage in terms of dollar coverage; (4) direct the CCC to offer producers the opportunity to purchase coverage in combination with a policy or plan of insurance that would allow indemnities to be paid to a producer equal to a part of the deductible under the policy or plan of insurance at a county-wide level or in counties that lack sufficient data, on the basis of such larger geographical area as the CCC determines to provide sufficient data for purposes of providing the coverage; and (5) require the CCC to use data collected by the Risk Management Agency or the National Agricultural Statistics Service, or both, to determine yields.

Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 - Provides for the payment of temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who: (1) have exhausted all rights to regular compensation under State law; (2) have no rights to compensation (including both regular compensation and extended compensation) with respect to a week under such law or any other State unemployment compensation law or to compensation under any other Federal law (and are not paid or entitled to be paid any additional compensation under any State or Federal law); and (3) are not receiving compensation for such week under the unemployment compensation law of Canada.Requires Federal-State agreements to provide that the State agency of the State will make payments of temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who: (1) have exhausted all rights to regular compensation under State law; (2) have no rights to compensation (including both regular compensation and extended compensation) with respect to a week under such law or any other State unemployment compensation law or to compensation under any other Federal law (and are not paid or entitled to be paid any additional compensation under any State or Federal law); and (3) are not receiving compensation for such week under the unemployment compensation law of Canada.Sets forth provisions regarding the weekly benefit amount and the maximum amount of such compensation. Requires the Governor of a State to elect to trigger off an extended compensation period in order

Flat Alternative Individual Return Tax Act of 1997 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to permit an individual to elect a standard deduction and an additional deduction for each dependent in lieu of the tax imposed by sections 1 and 55 of the Code. Imposes a tax equal to 20 percent of such taxable income as defined by this Act.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to establish and submit to the congressional defense and appropriations committees procedures for complying with specified notification requirements concerning: (1) any sensitive military cyber operation conducted by the armed forces or by a foreign partner in coordination with the armed forces that is intended to cause effects outside a geographic location where U.S. armed forces are involved in hostilities; and (2) the use as a weapon of any cyber capability that has been approved for such use under international law by a military department within 48 hours after such use.

Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act of 2017 This bill amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to repeal the limitation on the amount of outside income which a beneficiary may earn (earnings test) without incurring a reduction in benefits.

John F. Kennedy Center Parking Improvement Act of 1997 (sic) - Amends the John F. Kennedy Center Act to authorize the Board of Trustees of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts to design and construct an addition to the parking garage at each of the north and south ends of the Center and site improvements and modifications. Declares that no appropriated funds may be used to pay the costs of: (1) the design and construction of such addition; (2) the design and construction of site improvements and modifications that the Board specifically designates will be financed using sources other than appropriated funds; or (3) any project to acquire large screen format equipment for an interpretive theater or to produce an interpretive film. Specifies that the Board shall ensure that safe and convenient access to the Center site is provided for pedestrians and vehicles. Directs the Board to develop plans and carry out projects to improve pedestrian and vehicular access to the Center site. Declares that certain findings and recommendations made pursuant to the Master Plan shall apply to the construction of the Center.

National Whale Conservation Fund Act of 1998 - Amends the National Fish and Wildlife Establishment Act to authorize the National Whale Conservation Foundation to establish a national whale conservation endowment fund to support research, management, or educational programs relating to the protection, conservation, or recovery of whale populations in U.S. waters. Authorizes the Foundation to: (1) accept, receive, solicit, hold, administer, and use any gift, devise, or bequest made to the Foundation for the express purpose of supporting whale conservation; and (2) deposit into such fund any amount received by the Secretary of Commerce or any portion thereof as a civil penalty assessed by the Secretary for damages in a civil action or other legal proceeding relating to natural resources.

Zimbabwe Democracy and Economic Recovery Act of 2001 - Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary of the Treasury should: (1) direct the U.S. executive director of each multilateral development bank to propose that the bank undertake a review of the feasibility of restructuring, rescheduling, or eliminating Zimbabwe's sovereign debt held by that bank; and (2) direct the U.S. executive director of each international financial institution to propose that the bank undertake financial and technical support for Zimbabwe, especially support intended to promote Zimbabwe's economic recovery and development, the stabilization of the Zimbabwean dollar, and the viability of Zimbabwe's democratic institutions.Directs the Secretary, upon receipt by specified congressional committees of a presidential certification that the rule of law has been restored, including respect for ownership and title to property, freedom of speech and association, and an end to the lawlessness, violence, and intimidation sponsored, condoned, or tolerated by the Government of Zimbabwe, the ruling party, and their supporters or entities, to oppose and vote against: (1) any extension by the respective institution of any loan, credit, or guarantee to the Government of Zimbabwe; or (2) any cancellation or reduction of indebtedness owed by the Government of Zimbabwe to the United States or any international financial institution.Prescribes conditions to be

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 21, 2013. Long Island Aviation History Act (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Department of the Interior to conduct a special resource study of the area commemorating the Long Island aviation history needed for the designation of the area as a unit of the National Park System, and to determine the suitability and feasibility of designating the area as a unit of the National Park System.

San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge Complex Establishment Act - Requires the Secretary of the Interior to establish the San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge Complex as an urban ecosystem wildlife refuge complex in San Francisco Bay, California.<n><n>Requires the Complex to be managed in accordance with all laws, regulations, executive orders, and comprehensive conservation plans that applied before this Act's enactment to the San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge Complex.<n><n>Sets forth as objectives to conserve, enhance, and restore the native aquatic and terrestrial communities and their characteristics found within the Complex and the San Francisco Bay ecosystem in partnership with governmental, nongovernmental, and private organizations and private individuals dedicated to fish and wildlife habitat preservation, protection, recovery, restoration, or enhancement.<n><n>Requires the Complex to be included within the boundaries of the existing Antioch, Slough, Farallon, Marin Islands, Salinas River, and San Pablo Bay National Wildlife Refuges as depicted on a specified map.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 19, 2014. Heroin and Prescription Opioid Abuse Prevention, Education, and Enforcement Act of 2014 - (Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), in cooperation with the Secretaries of Veterans Affairs (VA), Defense (DOD), and the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), to convene a Pain Management Best Practices Inter-Agency Task Force to develop and report on best practices for pain management and prescription of pain medication. Requires the task force to develop a strategy for disseminating information about such best practices to prescribers, pharmacists, state medical boards, and other parties. (Sec. 4) Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to state, local, or tribal governments, or the National Poison Data System working in cooperation with state, local, or tribal governments, to develop programs and activities to increase awareness of the risk of abuse of prescription opioids (drugs with effects similar to opium). Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to state, local, or tribal governments, or the National Poison Data System working in cooperation with state, local, or tribal governments, to develop programs and activities to increase awareness of the risk of abuse of prescription opioids. (Sec. 5) Amends the

Safe Treatment of Polluted Stormwater Runoff Act or STOPS Runoff Act (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Transportation (DOT) to establish a federal-aid highway runoff pollution avoidance and management program to ensure that covered federal-aid highway projects are sited, constructed, and maintained in accordance with design standards intended to protect surface and ground water quality and ensure the long-term management of stormwater originating from federal-aid highways. A "covered project" is a rehabilitation, reconfiguration, renovation, major resurfacing, or construction project carried out under federal-aid highway provisions that: (1) results in a 10% or greater increase in impervious surface of the aerial extent within the right-of-way of the project limit on a federal-aid highway or associated facility; or (2) results in an increase of one acre or more in impervious surface coverage. DOT may approve a covered project only if the state provides assurances satisfactory to DOT that the state will site, design, and construct the project in accordance with such design standards. The post-construction condition of a covered project shall maintain or restore the predevelopment hydrology of the project site with regard to the temperature, rate, chemical composition, volume, and duration of flow. Any covered project carried out within a watershed

Transition to Teaching Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements to institutions of higher education and public and private nonprofit agencies or organizations to carry out programs to recruit, train, place, and support career-changing professionals who have knowledge and experience that will help them become highly qualified teachers in high-poverty school districts, through: (1) continuing and enhancing the Troops to Teachers model for recruiting and supporting the placement of such teachers; and (2) recruiting, preparing, placing, and supporting such career-changing professionals through existing induction programs. Authorizes appropriations.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the Senate on March 19, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Justice for Public Safety Officers Act - Amends the Federal criminal code to provide penalties for killing, or attempting or conspiring to kill, a federally protected safety officer (an individual serving a public agency in an official capacity, as a law enforcement officer, as a firefighter, as a chaplain, or as a member of a rescue squad or ambulance crew) while that officer is engaged in official duties or on account of the performance of official duties, or killing a former such officer on account of the past performance of such duties.(Sec. 3) Defines federally protected safety officer" as a public safety officer for a public agency (including a court system, the National Guard or a State to the extent the personnel of that National Guard are not in Federal service) if: (1) the public agency receives, in any one year period, funding, equipment, or benefits in excess of $10,000 under a Federal program involving a grant, contract, subsidy, loan, guarantee, insurance, or other form of Federal assistance and the public agency is of an entity that is a State, the District of Columbia, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa"

Impaired Waters Improvement Act - Authorizes the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to make grants to the owner or operator of: (1) a publicly owned treatment works serving a total maximum daily load (TMDL) jurisdiction; (2) publicly owned storm water management practices serving such a jurisdiction; or (3) a privately owned farm implementing methods to reduce discharges of nitrogen, phosphorus, or sediment in such a jurisdiction. Defines covered TMDL jurisdiction" to mean a geographic area that is subject to a TMDL, including the geographic area subject to total maximum daily load for pollutants for the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries established by the Administrator on December 29, 2010, and noticed at 76 Fed. Reg 549 (January 5, 2011)."

Comprehensive Peace in Sudan Act - (Sec. 4) Condemns violations of human rights on all sides of the conflict in Sudan, the Government of Sudan, the Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLM), and the Janjaweed militia, and the Government of Sudan's continued support and assistance of the Janjaweed and their obstruction of the delivery of food, shelter, and medical care to the Darfur region, as well as the Government's continued support for the Janjaweed and their obstruction of the delivery of food, shelter, and medical care to the Darfur region: (1) every day that the Government of Sudan fails to comply with the terms of the Nairobi Declaration on the Final Phase of Peace in the Sudan signed June 5, 2004; (2) every day that the Government of Sudan fails to take actions necessary for such implementation; and (3) unless the President certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that the Government of Sudan is acting to demobilize the Janjaweed, protect civilians, and cooperate with aid workers and the African Union monitoring team. (Sec. 5) Authorizes the President to provide increased assistance to Sudan if the President determines and certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that: (1) the Government of Sudan is acting to demobilize the Janjaweed; (2) it is

Monuments Protection Act - Requires the Secretary of the Interior, with respect to land under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of the Interior, or the Secretary of Agriculture, with respect to land under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of Agriculture, to enter into an agreement with an entity to assume, in whole or in part, responsibility for resuming or continuing operations and public access to any public lands, units of the National Park System, the National Wildlife Refuge System, or units of the National Forest System during any period in which the federal government is unable to operate and manage such units at normal levels because of a failure to enact a regular appropriations bill or continuing resolution: (1) a lapse in available federal funds for all or part of the unit; or (2) insufficient federal funds to operate all or part of the unit as a result of a failure of the federal government to make sufficient funds available for this purpose.

Forest Resources Conservation and Shortage Relief Amendments Act of 1993 - Amends the Forest Resources Conservation and Shortage Relief Act of 1990 to direct the Secretary of Commerce to prohibit, through December 31, 1995, the export of unprocessed timber originating from public lands, with specified exceptions. <n>Prohibits the substitution of unprocessed timber originating from public lands in a State for exported unprocessed timber originating from private lands in that State. <n>Authorizes new State programs. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Secure Fence Act of 2006 - Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to take all actions determined necessary and appropriate to achieve and maintain operational control over the entire international land and maritime borders of the United States. Defines operational control" as the prevention of all unlawful entries into the United States, including entries by terrorists, other unlawful aliens, instruments of terrorism, narcotics, and other contraband.<n><n>Amends the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 to direct the Secretary to: (1) provide for at least two layers of reinforced fencing, the installation of additional physical barriers, roads, lighting, cameras, and sensors along specified border areas from Calexico, California, to Douglas, Arizona; (2) ensure that an interlocking surveillance camera system is installed along such area by May 30, 2007, and that fence construction is completed by December 31, 2008; and (3) ensure that fence construction is completed by December 31, 2008.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) conduct a study on the feasibility of a state-of-the-art infrastructure security system along the northern international land and maritime border of the United States; and (2) evaluate authority to stop vehicles that enter the United States through specified ports of entry in Texas."

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 22, 2016. Alabama Hills National Scenic Area Establishment Act (Sec. 3) This bill establishes the Alabama Hills National Scenic Area, comprised of approximately 18,610 acres in Inyo County, California. The purpose of the Area is the conservation, protection, and enhancement of its nationally significant scenic, cultural, geological, educational, biological, historical, recreational, cinematographic, and scientific resources. The Department of the Interior shall manage the Area: (1) as a component of the National Landscape Conservation System, (2) so as not to impact future continuing operations and maintenance of any activities associated with valid, existing rights; and (3) in a manner that conserves, protects, and enhances the Area's resources and values.

Wall Street Fair Share Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose an excise tax on the purchase of a security: (1) on a trading facility located in the United States, or (2) the purchaser or seller is a United States person. Defines security" to include: (1) stocks, partnership interests, notes, bonds, debentures, or other evidences of indebtedness issued by a nongovernmental entity; and (2) interests in a derivative financial instrument (i.e., any option, forward contract, short position, notional principal contract, credit default swap, or any similar financial instrument). Exempts from such tax: (1) initial issues of securities; (2) any note, bond, debenture, or other evidence of indebtedness issued by a nongovernmental entity; and (3) hedging transactions."

Police Creating Accountability by Making Effective Recording Available Act of 2015 or the Police CAMERA Act This bill amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize the Department of Justice's Office of Justice Programs to make grants to states, local governments, and Indian tribes to purchase or lease body-worn cameras and to implement body-worn camera programs. A state, local government, or Indian tribe that receives a grant must comply with certain requirements, including to establish policies and procedures for the use of body-worn cameras and to adopt data collection and retention protocols.
