Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Amendments Act - Amends the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act to: (1) redefine the terms employer," "plant closing," and "mass layoff" for purposes of the Act; and, among other things, (2) apply it to employers of 50 or more employees (currently, 100 or more employees).<n><n>Requires an employer to: (1) give 90-day (currently, 60-day) written notice to employees and appropriate State and local governments before ordering a plant closing or mass layoff; (2) notify the Secretary of Labor (currently, 60-day) of such closing or layoff; and (3) provide affected employees with information regarding benefits and services available to them, including unemployment compensation, trade adjustment assistance, COBRA benefits, onsite access to rapid response teams, and certain other services.<n><n>Makes an employer who violates such notice requirements liable to the employee for, among other things, two days pay (currently, back pay for each day of violation) multiplied by the number of days short of the required notice period that was not given, including interest on such pay."

Defense of Environment and Property Act of 2012 - Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (commonly known as the Clean Water Act) to redefine navigable waters" to mean waters of the United States, including the territorial seas, that are: (1) navigable-in-fact, or (2) permanent, standing, or continuously flowing bodies of water that form geographical features commonly known as streams, oceans, rivers, and lakes that are connected to waters that are navigable-in-fact. Excludes from the definition: (1) waters that do not physically abut or lack a continuous surface water connection to navigable waters; (2) man-made or natural structures or channels through which water flows intermittently or ephemerally, or that periodically provide drainage for rainfall; or (3) wetlands without a continuous surface connection to bodies of water that are waters of the United States.<n><n>Prohibits: (1) an activity carried out by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or the Corps of Engineers from impinge upon the traditional and primary power of states over land and water use; (2) aggregation of wetlands or waters other than those described in this Act from being used to determine or assert federal jurisdiction; or (3) a jurisdictional determination by the Administrator that would affect the ability of a state to plan the development and"

Directs the Under Secretary for Science and Technology in the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to provide for an independent study of the effects on human health caused by the use of backscatter x-ray machines at airline checkpoints operated by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA). Requires the Under Secretary to: (1) dismantle and evaluate one or more of such machines used at TSA checkpoints in order to determine the placement of testing equipment so that radiation emission readings are as accurate as possible, how best to measure the dose emitted per scan, determine the failure rates and effects of use of such machines, include the use of alternative testing methods in the determination of levels of radiation exposure, assess the fail-safe mechanisms of such machines in order to determine the optimal operating efficacy of such machines, ensure that any tests performed are replicable, obtain peer review of any tests performed, and meet such other requirements; and (2) provide for an independent panel to evaluate the data collected under the study to assess the health risks posed by such machines to individuals and groups of people screened or affected by them, including frequent air travelers, TSA employees, flight crews, other individuals who work at an airport, and individuals with greater sensitivity to radiation, such as children, pregnant women, the elderly, and cancer patients. Directs the

Servicemembers and Veterans Prescription Drug Safety Act of 2016 This bill requires the Department of Defense (DOD) and the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to jointly carry out a program under which a member of the Armed Forces, an individual receiving or entitled to military retired or retainer pay, a dependent-beneficiary of a member, or any person lawfully entitled to dispose of the property of any of such individuals may deliver a personal-use controlled substance (the prescription medication of a deceased individual) for disposal at a facility to be specified by DOD and the VA. The VA and DOD shall jointly develop appropriate guidelines and procedures to prevent the diversion, misuse, theft, or loss of such delivered substances.

E-Centives Act of 2009 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to make enhanced matching payments to states that provide incentive payments to physicians, hospitals, community health centers, rural health clinics, and community mental health centers that exhibit meaningful use of certified health information technology. Prohibits any payment to a state for incentive payments made by the state for meaningful use of health information technology that occurs before January 1, 2010.

Federal Railroad Safety Authorization Act of 1994 - Amends Federal rail safety law to authorize appropriations for FY 1995 through 1998. <n>Authorizes a railroad or railroads and all labor organizations representing any class or craft of directly affected covered service employees of the railroad or railroads to jointly petition the Secretary of Transportation for approval of a waiver of compliance with Federal rail safety law to enable the establishment of one or more pilot projects to demonstrate the possible benefits of implementing alternatives to the strict application of such law, including maximum on-duty and minimum off-duty periods. Authorizes such a waiver for up to a two-year period, with possible additional two-year extensions. Requires the Secretary to report to the Congress on the effectiveness of all pilot projects established pursuant to such waiver. <n>(Sec. 4) Amends Federal rail safety law to prohibit a person from violating any provision of a waiver applicable to that person that has been granted under this Act. Declares that this Act or any of the laws transferred to the Secretary's jurisdiction by the Department of Transportation Act shall apply to the person with respect to the hours of service requirement. <n>(Sec. 6) Requires the Secretary to report every two years, on or before July 1 of the year due, a comprehensive report on the

Emergency Unemployment Compensation Amendments of 1993 - Amends the Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 1991 to extend to October 2, 1993, the authorization for new claims for benefits under the emergency unemployment compensation (EUC) program and the final phase-out period for the program. Extends the final phase-out period through January 15, 1994. <n>Directs the Secretary of Labor to establish a program for encouraging the adoption and implementation by all States of a system of profiling all new claimants for regular unemployment compensation to determine which claimants may be likely to exhaust regular unemployment compensation and may need reemployment assistance services to make a successful transition to new employment. Requires the Secretary to report to the Congress on the operation and effectiveness of the profiling systems adopted by the States and the Secretary's recommendation for continuation of such systems and any appropriate legislation. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Presidential Trade Transparency Act of 2017 This bill requires the President to disclose income earned, assets held, and liabilities owed by the United States to countries for which the United States is negotiating a trade or investment agreement before initiating such negotiations and before taking specified trade enforcement actions with respect to such countries. "Covered action" means: a modification under a trade enforcement law of a duty imposed with respect to articles imported from a country; or an action under the Tariff Act of 1930, the Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015, or the Trade Act of 1974.

Amends the Small Business Act to prohibit the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) from collecting a guarantee fee in connection with a loan of up to $150,000 made through the SBA to a veteran or spouse of a veteran on or after October 1 of the first fiscal year beginning after enactment of this Act. Provides an exception if the President's budget for the upcoming fiscal year includes a cost for the veterans loan program that is above zero.

Drone Federalism Act of 2017 This bill directs the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), in prescribing regulations or standards related to civil unmanned aircraft systems, to: (1) define the scope of the preemptive effect of regulations or standards necessary to ensure the safety and efficiency of the national airspace system for interstate commerce; and (2) preserve, to the greatest extent practicable, legitimate interests of state, local, and tribal governments. The FAA must ensure that a state, local, or tribal government's authority to issue reasonable restrictions on the time, manner, and place of operation of a civil unmanned aircraft system that is operated below 200 feet above ground level or within 200 feet of a structure is not preempted. Reasonable restrictions on the time, manner, and place of operation of such a system include: limitations on speed; prohibitions or limitations on operations in the vicinity of schools, parks, roadways, bridges, or other public or private property; restrictions on operations in the vicinity of schools, parks, roadways, bridges, or other public or private property while the operator is under the influence of drugs or alcohol; and prohibitions on operations without the owner's permission or while the operator is under the influence of alcohol. The bill amends the FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 to prohibit the FAA from

Banous Additives Act of 2011 or the Ban of Bisphenol A (BPA) Act of 2011 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to deem a food to be adulterated if it is a food intended for children three years old or younger and the container of which is composed, in whole or in part, of bisphenol A (BPA). Defines baby bottle or cup" as a bottle or cup that: (1) is intended to aid in the feeding or providing of drink to children three years old or younger; and (2) does not contain a food when it is sold or distributed at retail.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to issue a revised safety assessment for food containers composed, in whole or in part, of BPA, taking into consideration: (1) potential adverse effects from low dose exposure, and (2) the effects of exposure on vulnerable populations, including pregnant women, infants, children, the elderly, and populations with high exposure to BPA. Requires the Secretary to determine whether there is a reasonable certainty that no harm will result from aggregate exposure to BPA through food containers or other items composed, in whole or in part, of BPA."

Burma Human Rights and Democracy Act of 2014 - Prohibits security assistance for Burma unless the Secretary of State certifies to Congress that: (1) Burma has taken steps toward establishing civilian oversight of the armed forces, addressing human rights abuses by the military, and terminating military relations with North Korea; (2) Burma has taken steps to establish a fair and inclusive process to amend the Constitution of Burma, including the full participation of the political opposition and ethnic minority groups; (3) Burma has amended its constitution and laws to ensure civilian control of the military; (4) Burma is promoting peace agreements or political reconciliation and is addressing the resettlement and humanitarian situation of displaced persons; and (5) the Burmese military is improving its human rights record, taking steps to withdraw forces from conflict zones, and signing and implementing a code of conduct.

Wekiva Wild and Scenic River Designation Act Amends the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act to designate specified segments of the Wekiva River, Rock Springs Run, and Black Water Creek in Florida as components of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

Young and Beginning Farmers Act This bill amends various agricultural laws to modify and establish programs to assist beginning farmers. The bill makes land trusts eligible for certain assistance under the Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Conservation Easement Program. In evaluating easement applications, USDA must give priority to purchasing an easement that: (1) maintains agricultural viability, (2) includes a requirement that any subsequent purchase of the easement be at agricultural value, or (3) achieves the objectives of both clauses. The bill amends the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act to require USDA to establish procedures to ensure that the Farm Service Agency (FSA) is prepared to respond to a request by a prospective loan applicant for a preliminary determination on: (1) whether the applicant would likely qualify for credit under any FSA program, or (2) the amount of credit for which the applicant would likely qualify under any such program. The bill increases the limit on the amount of USDA direct farm ownership loans that may be issued per borrower, subject to inflation indexation. (Under current law, the limit is set at the same amount as the amount authorized under the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002.) The FSA must establish procedures to ensure that prospective loan applicants are prequalified for credit under any FSA program. The General Services Administration may sell surplus farm equipment or property to socially

Trade Promotion Authority Extension and Enhancement Act of 2007- Amends the Bipartisan Trade Promotion Authority Act of 2002 to extend trade authorities procedures (fast track procedures) through July 1, 2016, and July 1 of each fifth calendar year thereafter (currently June 30, 2005).<n><n>Requires: (1) the President to report to Congress by April 1, 2011, and by April 1 of each fifth year thereafter, on the extension of trade authorities procedures; and (2) the Advisory Committee for Trade Policy and Negotiations to report to Congress by June 1, 2011, and by June 1 of each fifth year thereafter, on whether the trade authorities procedures should be extended for the succeeding five-year period.<n><n>Directs the International Trade Commission to report to Congress by June 1, 2011, and by June 1 of each fifth year thereafter, on the economic impact on the United States of all trade agreements implemented on or after July 1 of the fifth preceding calendar year.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 23, 2017. Family Farmer Bankruptcy Clarification Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the federal bankruptcy code to specify that a governmental unit shall not be entitled to claim an amount based on the disposition of property used in a farming operation as an unsecured claim arising before the filing of a bankruptcy petition, or before the debtor's discharge, as a result of the sale, transfer, exchange, or other disposition of such property. The governmental unit may file a proof of claim for such a claim that arises after the filing of the petition. If a debtor files a tax return after the filing of the petition for a period in which a claim arises, and the claim relates to the tax return, the debtor shall serve notice of the claim on the governmental unit charged with the responsibility for the collection of the tax at the address and in the manner designated. The governmental unit may file a proof of claim within 180 days after such notice was served. If the governmental unit has not filed a timely proof of the claim, the debtor or trustee may not file proof of the claim. A claim filed under this bill shall be determined and shall be allowed for the treatment of any claim by a governmental unit of a

Directs the Secretary to: (1) consult and coordinate with the Secretary of Agriculture, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and the Director of the Indian Health Service to develop criteria to ensure that the program does not duplicate, but instead complements, activities undertaken pursuant to such authorities; and (2) report to specified congressional committees on rural water projects within his or her jurisdiction and on authorized projects.Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) conduct appraisal investigations to identify opportunities for the construction of regional rural water supply systems and the enhancement of existing rural water supply systems for small communities and rural areas; and (2) prepare a feasibility study of a regional rural water supply system that includes a community with a population in excess of 40,000.

Directs the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection to provide for the liquidation or reliquidation of certain entries relating to high-density fiberboard-core laminate panels entered in June 2004 through October 2004.

Children's Smoking Prevention, Health, and Learning Trust Fund Act of 1999- Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to authorize waiver of the Federal share of recovery under the Medicaid program of tobacco-related funds if the Secretary of Health and Human Services finds that specified conditions are met, including that the State demonstrates that 50 percent of recovered amounts be expended on one or more specified tobacco use prevention programs.

Commit to Opioid Medical Prescriber Accountability and Safety for Seniors Act or the COMPASS Act This bill requires the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) to identify outlier opioid prescribers under the Medicare prescription drug benefit and Medicare Advantage prescription drug plans. Specifically, the CMS must: (1) establish a threshold for identifying whether a prescriber is an outlier compared to other prescribers, based on prescriber specialty and geographic area; (2) use valid prescriber National Provider Identifiers (unique provider identification numbers currently included on claims for covered drugs) to identify outlier prescribers; and (3) annually notify identified outlier prescribers of their status and provide them with resources on proper prescribing methods. The CMS may exclude from the analysis individuals receiving hospice services, individuals with a cancer diagnosis, and prescribers who are the subject of an investigation by the CMS or the Office of Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services.

Lead Exposure Reduction Amendments Act of 2012 - Amends the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) to exclude from the definition of abatement" any renovation, remodeling, landscaping, or other activity: (1) the primary purpose of which is to repair, restore, or remodel a structure or dwelling; and (2) that incidentally results in a reduction or elimination of lead-based paint hazards.<n><n>Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), prior to proposing any new regulation applicable to target housing or public or commercial buildings constructed before 1978, to study and report to Congress on the extent to which persons engaged in various types of renovation and remodeling activities in such housing or buildings are exposed to lead in the conduct of those activities or disturb lead and create a lead-based paint hazard on a regular or occasional basis. Requires the Administrator to complete each study within four years and publish the results.<n><n>Requires the Administrator to promulgate regulations requiring a resident owner of a dwelling that is target housing to certify to the Administrator that the owner has taken certain actions to reduce or eliminate lead-based paint hazards in such dwelling and to carry out a post-abatement clearance testing program for such dwellings. Requires the Administrator to promulgate regulations requiring a resident owner of a"

Public Health Coordinating Council Act - Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a National Public Health Coordinating Council to facilitate and strengthen sustained communication and coordination across Federal agencies and offices regarding public health and to review and make recommendations concerning adequate and needed socio-economic and environmental policies to reduce health disparities and improve the public's health.

Home Equity Protection Act of 1993 - Amends the Truth in Lending Act to define high cost mortgage" as a consumer credit transaction, other than a residential mortgage transaction, that is secured by a consumer\\'s principal dwelling and that satisfies at least one of the following conditions: (1) the annual percentage rate at consummation of the transaction will exceed by more than ten percentage points the rate of interest on obligations of the United States having a period of maturity of one year on the fifteenth day of the month before consummation; and (2) all points and fees payable by the consumer at or before closing will exceed the greater of eight percent of the amount financed, minus fees and points, or $400. Declares that any person who originates two or more high cost mortgages in any 12-month period, or any person who originates one or more high cost mortgages through a loan broker shall be considered to be a creditor for purposes of the Act. Specifies requirements for high cost mortgage disclosures and certain terms prohibited by the Act."

Fair and Speedy Treatment (FAST) of Medicare Prescription Drug Claims Act of 2007 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require prompt payment of clean claims to prescription drug plan (PDP) sponsors and Medicare Advantage prescription drug plans (MA-PD Plans). Defines prompt payment as within 14 days from submission for claims submitted electronically, and within 30 days for claims submitted otherwise. Requires payment of interest, also, if a payment is not issued, mailed, or otherwise transmitted within the applicable number of calendar days.

Prepare All Kids Act of 2009 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to establish a Prekindergarten Incentive Fund from which matching grants shall be awarded to states and, through them, subgrants to qualified prekindergarten providers to establish, expand, or enhance high quality prekindergarten programs serving children ages three through five.

Building Efforts for Wellness and Encouraging Longer Lives Act or the BE WELL Act Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt from the prohibitions against discrimination in group health plan benefits any wellness program designed to promote health or prevent disease, including a program designed to encourage individuals to adopt healthy behaviors.

Managed Care Integrity Act of 2001 - Requires each health benefits plan offered by a managed care entity to ensure that the actuarial value of the benefits provided is at least 85 percent of the aggregate amount of payments received from, or on behalf of, enrollees for such year. Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to waive such requirement under certain circumstances, including if the Secretary determines that the solvency of the entity or compliance with such requirement would cause the entity to fail to meet the solvency requirements required for licensure in the State.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on January 8, 2018. Desert Community Lands Act (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of the Interior, at the request of the town of Apple Valley, California, to convey certain land to the town in order to allow it to use the land for: (1) the establishment of a centralized off-road vehicle recreation park; (2) the public with opportunities for off-road vehicle recreation, including a location for races, competitive events, training and other commercial services that directly support a centralized off-road vehicle recreation area and town park; and (3) a designated area and facilities that would discourage unauthorized use of off-highway vehicles in areas identified by the federal government, the state of California, or San Bernardino County as containing environmentally sensitive land. (Sec. 3) Interior shall convey specified land to the city of Twentynine Palms, California, at the request of the city. (Sec. 4) Interior shall convey specified land to the city of Victorville, California, without consideration. Such land shall be known as the Valley of Victorville off-road vehicle recreation area.

Bay Area Regional Water Recycling Program Projects Authorization Act of 2006 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to participate in the design, planning, and construction of: (1) recycled water distribution systems in cooperation with the city of Palo Alto, California; and (2) recycled water system facilities in cooperation with the city of Pittsburg, California, and the Delta Diablo Sanitation District. Terminates the Secretary's authority to carry out these projects ten years after the enactment of this Act.

Alcohol Advertising Accountability Act of 1996 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to report annually to the Congress on alcohol advertising, its profile, and its effects. Requires the Secretary to establish a panel to review alcohol advertising. Specifies report contents.

Mortgage Cancellation Relief Act of 2004 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an individual taxpayer an exclusion from gross income up to $50,000 for a discharge of indebtedness incurred in connection with real property used by the taxpayer as a principal residence and secured by such real property. Limits to $50,000 the amount of such exclusion.

Reducing Special Education Through Prevention Act - Amends the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) to authorize the Secretary of Education to make grants to State and local educational agencies to develop and implement effective strategies to reduce the number of children who have, or are at risk of developing, emotional disturbances that require the provision of special education and related services under IDEA part D.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on May 2, 2017. Local Zoning Decisions Protection Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill nullifies: (1) the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) rule entitled "Affirmatively Furthering Fair Housing (AFFH)," published in the Federal Register on July 16, 2015; and (2) HUD's notice relating to the AFFH Assessment Tool, published in the Federal Register on December 31, 2015. (Sec. 3) No federal funds may be used to design, build, maintain, utilize, or provide access to a federal database of geospatial information on community racial disparities or disparities in access to affordable housing. (Sec. 4) HUD shall jointly consult with state, local government, and public housing agency officials to develop recommendations, consistent with applicable rulings of the U.S. Supreme Court, to further the Fair Housing Act's purposes and policies.

National Volcano Early Warning and Monitoring System Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the United States Geological Survey (USGS), to establish the National Volcano Early Warning and Monitoring System to monitor, issue warnings of, and protect U.S. citizens from undue and avoidable harm from, volcanic activity. Requires the System to include: (1) a national volcano watch office that is operational 24 hours a day and 7 days a week; (2) a national volcano data center; and (3) an external grants program to support research in volcano monitoring science and technology. Directs the Secretary to submit to Congress a five-year management plan for establishing and operating the System.

Honorable Stephanie Tubbs Jones College Fire Prevention Act - Directs the Secretary of Education to make competitive demonstration grants to institutions of higher education (IHEs), fraternities, and sororities for up to half the cost of installing fire sprinkler systems, or other fire suppression or prevention technologies, in student housing and dormitories owned or controlled by such entities. Gives grant priority to applicants that demonstrate the greatest financial need.

(Sec. 3) Amends the Bretton Woods Agreements Act to direct the Secretary of the Treasury to instruct the U.S. Executive Director at the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to urge the Fund to: (1) not provide any assistance to the government of the Russian Federation or of any political subdivision of the Russian Federation, or to any other entity in the Russian Federation, until there is in effect a Russian Federal law that implements specified economic reforms, including land reform, privatization, tax reform, and the development of effective commercial law and the ability of individuals to seek enforcement of contracts by an effective judicial system; and (2) provide assistance only to aid the implementation of such reforms.(Sec. 4) Directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate to seek to enter into negotiations with the Federation Council of the Russian Federation for the establishment of a commission to: (1) monitor expenditures from State and Federation funds to the government of the Russian Federation or a political subdivision of the Russian Federation for the purpose of evaluating the effectiveness of regional economic reform programs in the Russian Federation and the use of such criteria to assure that Western resources are provided to such political subdivisions on an equitable basis, taking into account the necessity to provide incentives for political subdivisions to implement viable economic reforms and to

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2013. Alternative Fueled Vehicles Competitiveness and Energy Security Act of 2013 - (Sec. 3) Amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to direct the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to make loan guarantees for the provision and distribution of alternative fuels. (Sec. 4) Amends the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 to revise the advanced technology vehicles manufacturing incentive program. Requires the Secretary, in determining whether to provide incentives for the manufacturing of advanced technology vehicles, to consider: (1) the average fuel economy for each vehicle type and class; (2) the alternative percentage for that vehicle type or class will result in substantial reductions in motor fuel consumption within the United States; and (3) will reduce consumption of conventional motor fuel by 25% or more, as compared to existing surface transportation technologies that perform a similar function. Redefines "advanced technology vehicle" to include a vehicle (such as a medium-duty or heavy-duty work truck, bus, or rail transit vehicle) that: (1) is used on a public street, road, highway, or transitway; (2) meets each applicable emission standard established as of the date of the application; and (3) will reduce consumption of conventional motor fuel by 25%

Equal Access to Quality Education Act of 2011 - Directs the Secretary of Education to award competitive matching grants to partnerships for the development and establishment of high-quality pathways for the teaching and education leadership professions, professional induction programs, and a stable and collaborative learning environment for educators and students.<n><n>Requires a partnership to use grant funds to establish or support: (1) a teacher preparation program that requires program participants to complete at least one year of residency at a high-need school in the local educational agency participating in the partnership; (2) a teacher induction and retention program that provides high-quality professional development to teachers and provides teachers with updated information on developments in curricula, assessments, and educational research; (3) a mentor teacher and other support for new teachers; and (4) leadership opportunities for teachers, including access to career ladders and roles as curriculum and instructional leaders, mentors, and coaches. Authorizes a partnership to use grant funds for: (1) providing support to each mentor teacher working with new teachers; (2) providing preparation in effective, evidence-based instructional assessment practices and classroom management strategies for general education teachers serving students with disabilities and students with limited English proficiency; (3) enabling teachers to engage in study groups, professional learning communities, and other collaborative activities and collegial interactions regarding instruction assessment; (4) paying for release time

Closing the Pre-Paid Mobile Device Security Gap Act of 2016 This bill requires pre-paid mobile device and SIM card purchasers to provide certain identifying information, including a photographic identification card or a form W-2 wage and tax statement, a Social Security benefit statement, or a document containing personal identifying information the Department of Justice finds acceptable. An authorized reseller making a sale in person must verify such information by requiring the purchaser to submit: (1) a valid credit or debit card account information, (2) Social Security number, and (3) driver's license number. Upon completion of a sale of a pre-paid mobile device or SIM card, an authorized reseller must record the sale in accordance with this bill. A purchaser who knowingly provides false or misleading information when providing such identifying information and documents may be fined and/or imprisoned for up to five years.

Environmental Export Promotion Act of 1994- Amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to direct the Secretary of Commerce to establish the Environmental Technologies Trade Advisory Committee to provide advice and guidance to the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee (TPCC) in the development and administration of programs to expand U.S. exports of environmental technologies, goods, and services. <n>Directs the TPCC to: (1) annually assess which foreign countries have markets with the greatest potential for the export of U.S. environmental technologies, goods, and services; and (2) select the five countries with the greatest potential for the application of Federal export promotion resources related to environmental exports as priority countries." <n>Requires the TPCC to annually create a plan for each priority country selected, setting forth in detail ways to increase U.S. environmental exports to such country. <n>Directs the Secretary to assign an environmental technologies specialist to the office of the United States and Foreign Commercial Service in each of the five priority countries. Requires such specialist to provide export promotion assistance to U.S. environmental businesses."

Abraham Lincoln Study Abroad Act of 2006 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants or contracts to institutions of higher education (IHEs) for the establishment or enhancement of study abroad programs for undergraduate students, with an emphasis on developing nations and study abroad destinations. Requires grant funds to be used by IHEs to establish or enhance study abroad programs, and by private nonprofit organizations for such purposes.

Job Preservation for Parents in Poverty Act - Amends part A (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) (TANF) of title IV of the Social Security Act to modify the TANF program by: (1) extending the availability of the Emergency Fund for FY2009 and FY2010; and (2) requiring that amounts appropriated to the Fund for the first quarter of FY2011 be used to make grants to states to cover expenditures to subsidize employment positions held by individuals placed in positions before FY2011. Limits expenditures for subsidized employment to those used to subsidize employment for a member of a needy family or an individual who has exhausted all rights to receive unemployment compensation.

Community Recreation and Conservation Endowment Act of 1997 - Amends the Land and Water Conservation Act of 1965 to provide for the establishment of the Community Recreation and Conservation Endowment Account in the Treasury. States that all escrowed oil and gas revenues and interest received pursuant to the June 19, 1997, Supreme Court decision in United States v. Alaska shall be deposited into such Account. Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to provide financial assistance to the States from interest earned on the Account. Requires States (other than an area treated as a State) to make available as grants to local governments and other qualified recipients at least one-half of the average annual State apportionment.

Open Fuel Standard Act of 2009 or the OFS Act - Requires each light-duty automobile manufacturer\\'s annual covered inventory to comprise at least: (1) 50% fuel choice-enabling automobiles in 2012, 2013, and 2014; and (2) 80% fuel choice-enabling automobiles in 2015, and in each subsequent year. Defines fuel choice-enabling automobile" as: (1) a flexible fuel automobile capable of operating on gasoline, E85, and M85; or (2) an automobile capable of operating on biodiesel fuel. Exempts manufacturers from such requirement on a temporary basis during the period beginning on this Act\\'s enactment and ending on December 31, 2015."

Children's Health Task Force Act of 2012 - Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), acting jointly, to establish and maintain a permanent Task Force on Environmental Health Risks and Safety Risks to Children. Requires the Task Force to recommend to the President and Congress federal strategies for addressing environmental health risks and safety risks to children in the United States, within projected budgetary limits.

Meat and Poultry Products Inspection Amendments of 1993 - Amends the Federal Meat Inspection Act and the Poultry Products Inspection Act with respect to Federal and State cooperation to: (1) eliminate the intrastate limitation; (2) increase State inspection authority, including use of State inspectors; and (3) prohibit additional or different State requirements.

Food Sharing Act of 2017 This bill amends the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 to reauthorize appropriations for the community food assistance program through FY2022 and authorize the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to make grants for projects to reduce food insecurity in low-income communities. The bill allows USDA to make grants to assist public food program service providers, tribal organizations, or private nonprofit entities that have experience in the area of providing food to individuals in low-income communities or engaging in efforts to reduce food insecurity in low-income communities, including food distribution, improving access to services, or coordinating services and programs. In selecting projects to receive grants, USDA must give preference to those that will: (1) collect and distribute surplus food resources; (2) coordinate food services with park recreation programs; and (3) reduce barriers to access to food.

Phone Scam Prevention Act of 2014 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require a provider of a voice service to offer each subscriber the option to designate, if technically feasible, a list of telephone numbers (whitelist) for which calls originating from those numbers to the subscriber are permitted to connect directly with the subscriber's voice service. Directs a provider that elects to designate a subscriber-designated telephone number to ensure that any call received for termination that is not associated with the subscriber's telephone number is processed according to the subscriber's preferences, including by limiting or disabling the ability of an incoming call to connect with the subscriber. Prohibits the processing of ten or more telephone numbers in accordance with a subscriber's preferences from being considered: (1) unjust or unreasonable, or (2) an unjust or unreasonable practice under the Act. Requires a provider of a voice service to allow subscribers to designate not less than 10 telephone numbers to be calculating the 10 telephone numbers to be on a free-of-charge basis. Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to develop authentication standards for providers of a voice service to validate a call originated through a voice service so that the subscriber receiving the call may obtain: (1) a secure assurance of the origin of the call, including the

Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to provide assisted living services to veterans eligible for medical care through the Department of Veterans Affairs. Prohibits the Secretary from providing such services to a veteran or his or her spouse unless the veteran or spouse agrees to pay the cost.

Social Security COLA Limitation Act of 1994 - Amends titles II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance), XVI (Supplemental Security Income), and XVIII (Medicare) part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance) of the Social Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code to provide for reduction in cost-of-living adjustments (COLAs) applied to: (1) higher primary insurance amounts; and (2) Supplemental Security Income for the aged, blind, and disabled.

Secure Miles with All Resources and Technology Act This bill amends the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 to direct the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to: (1) deploy the most practical and effective technology available along the U.S. border for achieving situational awareness and operational control, and (2) provide for the installation, operation, and maintenance of such technology in high-traffic areas. "High-traffic areas" means sectors along the northern, southern, or coastal border that: (1) are within the responsibility of U.S. Customs and Border Protection; and (2) have significant unlawful cross-border activity. DHS shall submit to Congress a comprehensive southern border strategy that includes: a list of known physical barriers, technologies, tools, and other devices that can be used to achieve and maintain situational awareness and operational control along the southern border; a projected per mile cost estimate for each physical barrier, technology, tool, and other device; a detailed account of which type of physical barrier, technology, tool, or other device is necessary to achieve and maintain situational awareness and operational control for each mile of the border; an explanation for why such physical barrier, technology, tool, or other device was chosen; and an examination of the methodology used to determine which type of

HOPE VI Green Building and Technical Assistance Act of 2007- Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to prohibit the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development from making a grant under the HOPE VI program, with respect to affordable housing and green communities, unless the revitalization plan of the applicant complies with the green communities criteria checklist of the national Green Communities program that provides criteria for the design, development, and operation of affordable housing.

State Temporary Economic Priority (STEP) Act - Authorizes a State to transfer or consolidate funds between and among certain transportation, education, and job training programs after the United States experiences economic growth at an annual rate of less than 1% for two calendar quarters and continuing until 18 months after the United States experiences economic growth at an annual rate of 1% or more for two calendar quarters.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 7, 2015. Alaska Outer Continental Shelf Lease Sale Act (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of the Interior to conduct annually under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act (OCSLA) one or more oil and gas lease sales in: (1) the Cook Inlet Planning Area, and (2) the portion of the Beaufort Planning Area located within three nautical miles of the seaward boundary of Alaska. (Sec. 3) The bill extends the initial term of certain Chukchi and Beaufort Planning Area oil and gas leases to 20 years. (Sec. 4) Interior must distribute to Alaska specified revenues derived from energy development in the Alaska outer Continental Shelf region. The term "qualified revenues" does not include revenues generated from leases subject to OCSLA.

Family and Medical Leave Enhancement Act - Amends the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 to extend coverage to employees at worksites where the employer employs at least 25 (currently 50) employees at the worksite and within 75 miles of that worksite. <n>Allows all employees covered by such Act to take up to four hours during any 30-day period, and up to 24 hours during any 12-month period, of parental involvement leave to participate in or attend their children's educational and extracurricular activities. <n>Amends Federal civil service law to apply the same parental involvement leave allowance to Federal employees.

Access for Afghan Women Act - Requires that activities carried out by the United States in Afghanistan relating to governance, post-conflict reconstruction and development, police and military training, and refugee and internally displaced person relief and assistance support the human rights of Afghan women and their full political, social, and economic participation.

Small Business Export Support Act of 2010 - Amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to direct the Secretary of Commerce to assign export licensing compliance specialists to at least 20 district offices (or, at any time when there are 20 or fewer such offices, to all such offices). Requires the Secretary, in determining whether to assign such a specialist to a district office, to take into account the need for such assistance of the small businesses and medium-sized businesses in the region served by the office.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) complete an annual review of the level of staffing at each district office of the United States and Foreign Commercial Service to determine the level of staffing that will enable such office to effectively serve small businesses and medium-sized businesses; and (2) report to the President of Commerce's budget for the fiscal year relating to such review.

Drunk Driving Repeat Offender Prevention Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to withhold specified graduated percentages of a state's apportionment of certain federal-aid highway funds for FY2013-FY2015 if the state has not enacted and is not enforcing a law requiring the installation of an ignition interlock device for a minimum of 180 days on each motor vehicle operated by an individual convicted of driving while intoxicated or driving under the influence (having an alcohol concentration of 0.08% or greater).

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on May 13, 2014. Opioid Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to award grants to states to carry out a one-year pilot project to develop a standardized peer review process and methodology to review and evaluate prescribing and pharmacy dispensing patterns through a review of prescription drug monitoring programs (PDMPs). Requires grant recipients to develop a systematic, standardized methodology to identify and investigate questionable or inappropriate prescribing and dispensing patterns of substances on schedule II or III under the Controlled Substances Act (CSA). Requires the methodology and prescribing and dispensing patterns to be shared with the appropriate state regulators and health profession boards. Authorizes states receiving such a grant to: (1) make the information with respect to controlled substances for which a prescriber is required to be registered with the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) available to state regulators and licensing boards, and (2) make the information with respect to such controlled substances available to state regulators and licensing boards. Authorizes a quality improvement organization with which the Secretary has entered into a contract under part B of title XI of the Social Security Act to develop peer review processes. (Sec. 3) Amends the Public Health Service Act to require

International Carbon Conservation Act - Establishes within the National Institute of Standards and Technology of the Department of Commerce an implementing panel to establish a carbon sequestration program to permit project sponsors to make carbon sequestration project proposals to the panel.

Congestion Relief Act of 2005 - Revises the apportionment of funds between urbanized areas of over 200,000 population for the surface transportation program and the congestion mitigation and air quality improvement program. Extends the period of obligation authority for the surface transportation program through FY 2009.<n><n>Revises the formula for the allocation of funds among states for the congestion mitigation and air quality improvement program.<n><n>Requires a state to make available to a metropolitan planning organization or other agency the amount of obligation authority distributed to it for federal-aid highways and highway safety construction programs for use in the area represented by the organization.
Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a taxpayer a 100 percent deduction of net capital gain from gross income. Allows such deduction in computing adjusted gross income.

Safe and Timely Interstate Placement of Foster Children Act of 2006 - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the states should expeditiously ratify the revised Interstate Compact for the Placement of Children recently promulgated by the American Public Human Services Association; (2) this Act and the revised Interstate Compact for the Placement of Children should not apply to those seeking placement in a licensed residential facility primarily to access clinical mental health services; (3) the states should recognize and implement the deadlines for the completion and approval of home studies under this Act to move children more quickly into safe, permanent homes; and (4) federal policy should encourage the safe and expedited placement of children into safe, permanent homes across state lines.<n><n>Amends part E (Foster Care and Adoption Assistance) of title IV of the Social Security Act to require the state receiving federal assistance for foster care and adoption assistance to have in effect procedures for the orderly and timely interstate placement of children. Requires such procedures to be implemented in accordance with an interstate compact if incorporating with the procedures prescribed by this Act.<n><n>Requires the state, within 60 days after receiving from another state a request to conduct a study of a home environment for purposes of assessing the safety and suitability of placing a child in the home, to conduct and complete the study and return to the other

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 21, 2015. World Press Freedom Protection Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) This bill authorizes the President to impose U.S. entry and admission sanctions against a foreign person who: is responsible for severe restrictions on the freedom of expression or freedom of the press, including the arrest, harassment, torture, mistreatment, threats, fines, or the pervasive surveillance of journalists, blockage of the Internet that hinders the free flow of information from journalists, or other serious violations of the international right to the freedom of expression; or has materially assisted, sponsored, or provided financial, material, or technological support for, or goods or services in support of, such an activity. The sanctions shall be ineligibly to receive a visa to enter the United States or to be admitted to the United States, or if the foreign person has been issued a visa or other documentation to be used to enter the United States, revocation of the visa or other documentation. The President shall consider: information provided by the chairperson and ranking member of each of appropriate congressional committees; and credible information obtained by other countries and nongovernmental organizations that monitor violations of human rights. The President may waive the application of such sanctions against a foreign person if in

Detergent Poisoning And Child Safety Act of 2015 or the Detergent PACS Act of 2015 This bill requires the Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) to promulgate a final rule that establishes safety standards for liquid detergent packets to protect children younger than five years of age from injury or illness caused by exposure to such packets. The final rule shall: require special packaging for liquid detergent packets; include standards to address the design and color of such packets to make them less attractive to children, reduce the likelihood of exposure to detergent, and otherwise reduce risks related to the ingestion or severe contact with, detergent and other potential injury risks of such packets; prescribe warning labels that adequately inform consumers of the potential risks of injury and death caused by such packets, are conspicuous and visible at the point of sale, and clarify hazard patterns; and identify actions needed to avoid injury. Such rule shall not apply if the CPSC determines that: (1) a voluntary standard pertaining to such packets manufactured or imported for use in the United States protects children, or (2) such standard is or will be in effect not later than one year after enactment of this Act.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to enter into an agreement with the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) under which certain persons are offered enrollment in a health benefits plan under the Federal Employees Health Benefits program in lieu of receiving care in treatment facilities of the armed forces or through the Civilian Health and Medical Program of the Uniformed Services or the TRICARE program (a Department of Defense managed health care program). Outlines provisions concerning: (1) required contributions for such coverage; and (2) the management of participants in the plan.

Directs the Boys and Girls Clubs of America to make subawards to local boys and girls clubs authorizing expenditures associated with providing technology programs, including the hiring of teachers and other personnel, procurement of goods and services, including computer equipment, or such other purposes as are approved by the Attorney General. Sets forth application requirements.Authorizes appropriations.

Misclassification of Employees Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that, for purposes of determining the liability of any taxpayer for employment taxes with respect to any individual for any period, such individual shall be deemed not to have been an employee of the taxpayer for such period if: (1) the taxpayer did not treat such individual as an employee for such period; (2) the taxpayer's treatment of such individual was based on a reasonable good faith misapplication of the common law rules used for determining the employer-employee relationship; (3) all Federal tax returns required to be filed by the taxpayer with respect to such individual for such period were filed on a basis consistent with the taxpayer's treatment of such individual as not being an employee; (4) the taxpayer (and any predecessor) did not treat any other individual holding a substantially similar position as an employee for purposes of the employment taxes for any period beginning after December 31, 1977; and (5) the taxpayer enters into a closing agreement with the Secretary of the Treasury, in the time and manner determined by the Secretary, agreeing to treat such individual, and any other individual holding a substantially similar position, as employees and to file all Federal employment tax returns with respect to such individuals on a basis consistent with the taxpayer's treatment of such individuals as employees.

Testaverde Adult Stem Cell Research Act of 2005 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to expand, intensify, and coordinate NIH activities regarding qualifying adult stem cell research. Requires the Director to award grants and contracts to public or nonprofit private entities to pay all or part of the cost of planning, establishing, improving, and providing basic operating support for centers of excellence regarding qualifying adult stem cell research. Requires each center to conduct basic and clinical research regarding qualifying adult stem cells. Allows a center to expend amounts provided to carry out a program to make individuals aware of opportunities to participate as subjects in research conducted by the centers.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 25, 2016. Solar Fuels Innovation Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to require the Department of Energy (DOE) to carry out the Solar Fuels Basic Research Initiative to expand science useful for the practical development of experimental systems to convert solar energy to chemical energy. The initiative must include multidisciplinary teams leveraging expertise from the National Laboratories, universities, and the private sector. DOE must support research needed to bridge scientific barriers and discover knowledge relevant to artificial systems.

Requires the Director of National Intelligence (DNI) to make publicly available on an Internet website all captured documents, including documents collected from Afghanistan or Iraq and from a private person or from the government of Iraq or from a private person during Operation Desert Storm, Operation Enduring Freedom, and Operation Iraqi Freedom. Provides that the DNI may review a captured document before making it publicly available, but shall not be required to do so if: (1) in the case of a captured document that is reviewed before enactment of this Act, the DNI submits to Congress a description of the criteria used to determine it is not appropriate to make such a document publicly available; or (2) in the case of a captured document that is reviewed after enactment of this Act, the DNI submits to Congress a description of the criteria used to determine if it is not appropriate to make such a document publicly available and the captured document meets such criteria.

Federal Lands Invasive Species Control, Prevention, and Management Act Directs the Department of the Interior, with respect to federal lands administered through the Bureau of Indian Affairs, the Bureau of Land Management, the Bureau of Reclamation, the National Park Service, or the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, and the Department of Agriculture, with respect to federal lands administered through the United States Forest Service, to plan and carry out activities on such lands to control and manage invasive species to inhibit or reduce their populations and to effectuate restoration or reclamation efforts. Requires such Departments to develop a strategic plan for the implementation of their invasive species programs to endeavor to achieve an annual five percent net reduction of invasive species populations on lands managed by them. Sets forth provisions concerning program funding allocations, administrative costs, and the use of funds for investigations, development activities, and outreach and public awareness efforts.

Iran Sanctions Enhancement Act of 2007 - Amends the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996 to direct the President to impose two or more of specified sanctions if a person has, with actual knowledge: (1) made an investment of $20 million or more (or any combination of investments of at least $5 million in any 12-month period) that directly and significantly contributed to the enhancement of Iran's ability to develop petroleum resources or engaged in an activity that could contribute to the enhancement of Iran's ability to import refined petroleum resources; or (2) on or after December 31, 2007, provided Iran with refined petroleum resources or engaged in an activity that could contribute to the enhancement of Iran's ability to import refined petroleum resources. (Current law imposes sanctions only if a person has made such an investment after the date of enactment of this Act.) Requires the President to report to the appropriate congressional committees on persons who have provided Iran with refined petroleum resources or who could contribute to the enhancement of Iran's ability to import refined petroleum resources.

Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2016 This bill directs the President to: (1) establish guidelines, according to best practices of monitoring and evaluation studies and analyses, for the establishment of measurable goals, performance metrics, and monitoring and evaluation plans for covered U.S. foreign assistance programs; and (2) report to Congress on specified aspects of the monitoring and evaluation processes of such programs.

Maritime Administration Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2001 - Authorizes appropriations for the Department of Transportation for the Maritime Administration for FY 2001.Amends the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 to exempt from certain requirements concerning documentation of vessels built in a foreign country a newly constructed drybulk or breakbulk vessel over 7,500 deadweight tons that has been delivered from a foreign shipyard or contracted for construction in a foreign shipyard before the earlier of: (1) one year after the enactment of this Act; or (2) the effective date of the OECD Shipbuilding Trade Agreement Act.Deems a vessel timely contracted for or delivered pursuant to this Act and documented under U.S. laws to have been U.S built for specified purposes if certain conditions are met, including that: (1) the vessel has any additional shipyard work necessary to receive its initial Coast Guard certificate of inspection performed in a U.S. shipyard; (2) the vessel is not documented in another country before being documented under U.S. laws; (3) the vessel complies with the same inspection standards set forth for ocean common carriers in the Coast Guard Authorization Act of 1996; and (4) actual delivery of a vessel contracted for construction takes place on or before the three-year anniversary of the date of the contract to construct the vessel.Instructs the Secretary of State to

Free to Fly Act - (Sec. 2) Amends federal aviation law to provide that a person who is not a U.S. citizen, and who is not a foreign air carrier to be issued and maintain a certificate for air transportation or intrastate air transportation, all employees and managing officers, other than the board of directors, must be citizens, nationals, or lawful permanent residents of the United States. (Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) to submit to the President each decision authorizing: (1) the provision of foreign air transportation; or (2) the provision of interstate air transportation or intrastate air transportation by a person who is not a U.S. citizen. (Sec. 4) Authorizes the Secretary to issue a certificate of public convenience and necessity to a person organized under federal or state law, the District of Columbia, or a U.S. territory or possession, of which more than 49 percent of the board of directors are not U.S. citizens, which is not under the actual control of U.S. citizens, or in which more than 49 percent of the voting interest is owned or controlled by persons that are not U.S. citizens. (Sec. 5) Directs the President to review each decision authorizing such air transportation

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the Senate on January 7, 2003. However, because action occurred on the measure, the summary has been expanded.)Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2003 - Title I: Antitrust Enforcement Provisions and Cooperation Incentives - (Sec. 101) Terminates, five years after enactment of this Act, certain antitrust enforcement provisions of the Department of Justice Antitrust Division's Corporate Leniency Policy. Provides that, with respect to an antitrust leniency applicant who has entered into an antitrust leniency agreement on or before the date on which such provisions cease to have effect, such provisions shall continue in effect.(Sec. 103) Limits the amount of damages recovered by or on behalf of a claimant in a civil action alleging a violation of the Sherman Act, or alleging a violation of any similar State law, based on conduct covered by a currently effective antitrust leniency agreement, together with the amounts so recovered from cooperating individuals who satisfy such requirements, to the portion of the actual damages sustained by such claimant which is attributable to the commerce done by the applicant in the goods or services affected by the violation. Permits an antitrust leniency applicant or cooperating individual, as the case may be, to satisfy such requirements with respect to a civil

Department of Veterans Affairs Claims Backlog Reduction Act of 2002 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to: (1) identify the backlog of veterans' claims and categorize them into types of specific claims; (2) refer those claims requiring development to a County Veterans Service Office for development; (3) choose an Office for development based upon the Office's geographical proximity to the claimant; and (4) transmit a claim referred to an Office for development to the Secretary when it is ready to rate.Allows claims for benefits under the laws administered by the Secretary to be submitted to County Veterans Service Officers. Requires an Officer receiving such a claim to: (1) make personal contact with the claimant, explain the situation, and develop the claim; and (2) have authority to fully develop and transmit the claim to the Secretary when it is ready to rate.

Title I: Nicodemus National Historic Site - Establishes the Nicodemus National Historic Site in Nicodemus, Kansas. <n>Title I: Nicodemus National Historic Site - Establishes the Nicodemus National Historic Site in Nicodemus, Kansas. <n>Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to: (1) provide technical assistance for the preservation of historic structures and the maintenance of the cultural landscape; and (2) acquire certain lands in connection with the Site. <n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) prepare a general management plan for the Site; and (2) submit a copy of the plan to specified congressional committees. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Crossroads of the American Revolution National Heritage Area Act of 2003 - Establishes in New Jersey the Crossroads of the American Revolution National Heritage Area.Requires the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service, to prepare a management plan for the Area.

International Clean Development Technology Fund Act of 2008 - Directs the President to establish an International Clean Development Technology Board, which shall administer the International Clean Development Technology Fund to provide assistance to qualified entities to support the purposes of this Act.

Asia-South Pacific Trade Preferences Act Authorizes the President to designate Asia or South Pacific countries as beneficiary Asia or South Pacific countries eligible for preferential treatment. Defines beneficiary Asia or South Pacific country" as an Asia or South Pacific country that is eligible for preferential treatment under this Act if the President determines that the country meets certain requirements under the African Growth and Opportunity Act, including a market-based economy and the rule of law, the protection of human rights and internationally-recognized worker rights, elimination of trade barriers to the United States, and non-engagement in activities that undermine U.S. national security or foreign policy interests or support acts of international terrorism. Applies the duty-free treatment provided under this Act to certain articles if: (1) the article is the growth, product, or manufacture of a beneficiary Asia or South Pacific country; and (2) the President determines, after receiving advice from the International Trade Commission (ITC), that the article is not import-sensitive in the context of imports from such country."

Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009 - Directs the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) (the enterprises) each to implement a program to purchase and securitize qualified refinancing mortgages and qualified new mortgages on single-family housing in accordance with policies and procedures established by the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA).<n><n>Directs the FHFA Director to require each enterprise to establish a procedure for approval of lenders to receive commitments, in advance of the origination of qualified mortgages, for purchase of such mortgages by the enterprise.<n><n>Defines qualified refinancing mortgage" as one that: (1) meets certain requirements for single-family housing; (2) requires the mortgagor to occupy the property subject to the mortgage as his or her principal residence; (3) satisfies all indebtedness under an existing first mortgage made for purchase of, or refinancing another first mortgage on, the same property that is subject to the qualified refinancing mortgage; and (4) has a term to maturity of not less than 30 years and not more than 40 years from the date of the beginning of the amortization of the mortgage.<n><n>Requires all penalties for prepayment or refinancing of the underlying mortgage refinanced by the mortgage, and all fees and"

Directs the President to enter into negotiations with specified foreign nations to conclude agreements that provide for such nations to pay at least 75 percent of the overseas basing costs incurred for the stationing of members of the armed forces and related Department of Defense civilian employees in that nation as a result of the implementation of a bilateral or multilateral defense agreement with that nation. Excludes from such provision any foreign nation that receives foreign military financing or provisions of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 relating to the foreign military financing program. Sets forth a maximum allowable percentage of such costs for FY 1994 through 1995. Authorizes the President to waive such limitations upon determining that it is in the national security interest of the United States. Directs the President to submit to the Congress a plan and schedule for concluding such agreements.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Cultural Resource Programs at the National Park Service, to facilitate the development of guidelines and a program of technical assistance and grants that will set priorities for the preservation of the Route 66 corridor. Defines Route 66 corridor" as the preservation or restoration of structures and other cultural resources of businesses, sites of interest, and other contributing resources located within the immediate vicinity of those portions of the highway formerly designated as United States Route 66 and private land within that immediate vicinity that is owned by persons or entities that are willing to participate in the programs authorized by this Act. Directs the Secretary to: (1) support efforts of State and local public and private persons, nonprofit Route 66 preservation entities, Indian tribes, State Historic Preservation Offices, and entities in the States for the preservation of the Route 66 corridor by providing technical assistance, participating in cost-sharing programs, and making grants; (2) act as a clearinghouse for communication among Federal, State, and local agencies, nonprofit Route 66 preservation entities, Indian tribes, State historic preservation offices, and private persons and entities interested in the preservation of the corridor; and (3) assist the States in determining the appropriate form of, and establishing and supporting, a non-Federal entity or entities to perform the functions of"

Deafy Glade Land Exchange Act - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to convey specified land in the Mendocino National Forest to Solano County, California, in exchange for four parcels of land consisting of a total of approximately 160 acres identified as the Fouts Springs Ranch. Requires the County to agree to continue to use the land it has acquired for purposes consistent with the purposes listed in the special use authorization for the Ranch in effect as of the enactment of this Act.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to grant an easement to provide continued access to, and maintenance and use of, the facilities covered by the special use authorization as necessary for the continued operation of the Ranch.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary of Commerce to sell or exchange to the city of Norfolk, Virginia, certain real property under the administrative jurisdiction of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).

Mental Health on Campus Improvement Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Administrator of the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, to award competitive grants to institutions of higher education (IHEs) or consortia of IHEs to improve mental and behavioral health services and outreach on college and university campuses. Requires grant funds to be used to: (1) target the particular mental and behavioral health needs of the students involved; (2) provide services and training to new and existing providers; (3) seek input from community mental health providers; and (4) meet the specific mental and behavioral health needs of veterans attending IHEs.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an investment tax credit for stage 3 aircraft modification property. Defines such property as tangible property which is: (1) an integral part of and modification of a nonstage 3 aircraft (an aircraft with a maximum gross takeoff weight in excess of 75,000 pounds which did not meet the stage 3 noise level requirements before the stage 3 aircraft modification property was installed); (2) certificated by the Federal Aviation Administration and made to qualify the aircraft for the stage 3 noise level requirements; and (3) the original use of which begins with the taxpayer.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 21, 2015. Taking Account of Institutions with Low Operation Risk Act of 2015 or the TAILOR Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill requires federal financial regulatory agencies to: (1) tailor any regulatory actions so as to limit burdens on the institutions involved, with consideration of the risk profiles and business models of those institutions; and (2) report to Congress on specific actions taken to do so, as well as on the extent to which such tailored actions result in differential regulation of similarly- situated institutions of diverse charter types. The bill requires these agencies to: (1) disclose in every notice of proposed rulemaking and in any final rulemaking how they have applied these requirements, and (2) review all regulations adopted within five years of this Act's enactment and apply them to any such regulations.

Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act with respect to the admission of temporary agricultural (H-2A visa) workers and related labor certification provisions.Directs the Attorney General, in considering an employer's petition for admission of H-2A aliens, to consider the certification decision of the Secretary of Labor and any countervailing evidence submitted by the employer with respect to the nonavailability of U.S. workers and the employer's compliance with related labor certification requirements.

No Ongoing Perks Enrichment Act or the NOPE Act This bill withholds the salaries of Members of a house of Congress that has not agreed to a budget resolution for FY2018 by April 15, 2017, as required by the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. Salaries are withheld from April 16, 2017, until the house of Congress agrees to a budget resolution or the last day of the 115th Congress, whichever is earlier. The bill prohibits funds from being made available for the pay of: (1) the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB); (2) the Deputy Director for Management of OMB; and (3) the Deputy Director for Management of OMB during any period of noncompliance determined by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) under this bill. The OPM Inspector General must annually determine whether OMB and the President are in compliance with requirements to submit budgets to Congress.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 5, 2003. However, because action occurred on the measure, the summary has been expanded.) Recyclable Material Roads Act of 2003 (sic) - Requires the Secretary of Transportation to establish a program to encourage States and Indian tribes to use recyclable material in Federal-aid highway construction. Defines recyclable material" to include certain waste materials such as plastic and reclaimed asphalt."

Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act of 1997 - Amends the Public Health Service Act and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to prohibit health insurance issuers in connection with group and individual coverage from requesting or requiring enrollees to disclose genetic information or to obtain genetic tests. Regulates genetic information disclosure by issuers. Sets forth exceptions to such prohibition.

(This measure has not been amended since it was amended by the Senate on December 13, 2011. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>United States Commission on International Religious Freedom Reform and Reauthorization Act of 2011 - (Sec. 2) Amends the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 to provide that each member serving on the U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom may be reappointed to not more than one additional consecutive term. Extends through May 14, 2013, the termination date of the Commission.<n><n>Prohibits: (1) a member attending less than 75% of the meetings during one of such member's terms from being eligible for reappointment, and (2) a member from being eligible to be elected as Chair of the Commission for a second, consecutive term.<n><n>Requires, for purposes of providing remedies and procedures to address alleged violations of rights and protections that pertain to employment discrimination, family and medical leave, fair labor standards, employee polygraph protection, worker adjustment and retraining, veterans' employment and reemployment, or reprisal, protections under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 occupational safety and health, labor-management relations, and rights and protections that apply to Commission employees whose pay is disbursed by the Secretary of the Senate or the Chief Administrative Officer of the House of
