Technological Resource to Assist Criminal Enforcement (TRACE) Act - Amends the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act to require a licensed manufacturer or importer of firearms to: (1) test fire manufactured or imported firearms as specified by the Attorney General; (2) prepare ballistics images of the fired bullet and cartridge casings; (3) make the records available to the Attorney General for entry in a computerized database; and (4) store the fired bullet and cartridge casings.Directs the Attorney General to assist firearm manufacturers and importers in complying with these requirements by: (1) acquiring, installing, and upgrading ballistics equipment and bullet and cartridge casing recovery equipment to be placed at or near the sites of licensed manufacturers and importers; (2) hiring or designating sufficient personnel to develop and maintain a database of ballistics images of fired bullets and cartridge casings, research, and evaluation; (3) providing education about the role of ballistics as part of a comprehensive firearm crime reduction strategy; (4) providing for the coordination among Federal, State, and local law enforcement and regulatory agencies and the firearm industry to curb firearm-related crime and illegal firearm trafficking; and (5) taking other necessary steps to make ballistics testing effective.Requires the Attorney General to: (1) establish a computer system through which State and local law enforcement agencies can promptly access the ballistics records stored under

This bill requires a state agency that has jurisdiction over the operation of a high occupancy vehicle (HOV) facility to establish the occupancy requirements of vehicles operating on the facility. No fewer than two occupants per vehicle may be required for use of an HOV facility. The agency may allow motorcycles and bicycles to use the HOV facility if it certifies to the Department of Transportation (DOT) that such use would create a safety hazard. DOT may accept a state agency certification if it publishes notice of the certification in the Federal Register and provides an opportunity for public comment. The state agency may allow public transportation vehicles to use the HOV facility if it establishes: (1) requirements for clearly identifying the vehicles, and (2) procedures for enforcing the restrictions on the use of the facility by such vehicles. The state agency may allow vehicles not otherwise exempt pursuant to this bill to use the HOV facility if the operators pay a toll charged by the agency for use of the facility. The state agency may allow vehicles not otherwise exempt pursuant to this bill to use the HOV facility if: (1) it establishes a program that addresses how motorists can enroll and participate in the toll program, (2) develops, manages, and maintains a system that will automatically collect the toll, and (3) establishes policies and procedures to

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 19, 2014. Expatriate Health Coverage Clarification Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) States that the provisions of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) and the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010 not to apply to: (1) expatriate health plans, (2) employers acting as plan sponsors, or (3) expatriate health insurance issuers with respect to coverage offered by such issuers. Deems coverage under an expatriate health plan to be minimum essential coverage under an eligible employer-sponsored plan under title XIX (Medicaid) of the Internal Revenue Code. Prohibits a qualified expatriate (and any dependent of such individual) enrolled in an expatriate health plan from being considered a U.S. health risk. Sets forth a special rule for 2014 regarding the fee under PPACA for expatriate health insurance issuers.

Buy America Update Act This bill revises the Buy America Act by requiring federal agencies to report on the cost of components and subcomponents produced in the United States of more than 60% of the cost of all components of a rolling stock and the final assembly of such rolling stock. The Department of Transportation (DOT) must review regulations to determine whether manufactured products other than those containing steel and iron should be considered for the purposes of domestic content preferences. DOT shall: (1) initiate a rulemaking to develop audit procedures for the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) to review offeror and recipient compliance with domestic content provisions; and (2) issue guidance on best practices for pre-award and post-delivery audits by recipients. In developing the guidance, DOT shall consider best practices for: (1) proper and sufficient documentation requests from bidders to support certification of compliance; (2) proper and sufficient documentation requests from recipients to support pre-award and post-delivery audits; (3) determining the timing and requirements for post-delivery audit; and (4) verifying the origin of supplier components and subcomponents. Amtrak shall contract with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to conduct a supplier scouting process for domestic suppliers that can provide the compliant products for which a waiver will be sought. DOT shall: (1) consult with NIST before

Amends federal copyright law to provide that a copyright owner shall not be liable in any criminal or civil action for disabling, interfering with, blocking, diverting, or otherwise impairing the unauthorized distribution, display, performance, or reproduction of his or her copyrighted work on a publicly accessible peer-to-peer file trading network, if such impairment does not, without authorization, alter, delete, or otherwise impair the integrity of any computer file or data residing on the computer of a file trader. Makes exceptions where: (1) the copyright owner impairs the availability within a publicly accessible peer-to-peer file trading network of a computer file or data that does not contain a work in which the copyright owner has an exclusive right granted; (2) the impairment causes economic loss to any person other than affected file traders; or (3) the copyright owner fails to comply with the notification requirements of this Act.

Health Research Act of 1994 - Establishes the National Fund for Health Research. Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to transfer to the Fund amounts designated by regional and corporate health alliances under this Act. Allows individuals to designate overpayments and contributions to the Fund.

Directs the Secretary of Education to discharge or cancel the federal student loan indebtedness of spouses, surviving debtors, and parents of individuals who died (or die) or who became (or become) permanently and totally disabled from injuries suffered in the terrorist attacks on September 11, 2001.

Eating Healthy at School Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to study and report to Congress on the effectiveness and efficiency of administrative review systems to ensure that local educational agencies (LEAs) participating in the school lunch and school breakfast programs comply with the provisions of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act and the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 regarding nutrition, eligibility, meal counts, and claims for reimbursement.

Asylum and Asylum Reform Amendments of 1993 - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to create grounds for exclusion of an alien who: (1) uses or attempts to use a fraudulent document to enter the United States, or to board a common carrier for such purpose; or (2) uses a document to board a common carrier and then fails to present such document to an immigration official upon arrival at a U.S. port of entry. <n>Prohibits the granting of asylum to an alien who is excludable or who has a credible fear of persecution if: (1) the exclusion is based upon direct departure from a country in which the alien has a credible fear of persecution; or (2) there is a significant danger that the alien would be returned to a country in which he or she would have a credible fear of persecution. <n>Requires: (1) an immigration officer to inspect each alien seeking entry into the United States who is excludable or who has a credible fear of persecution and who does not indicate an intention to apply for asylum; and (2) such alien to be specially excluded from entry without a hearing.
(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 2, 2017. Heavy Truck, and tires of type used on highway vehicles--the excise tax on such tires is repealed.

Reserve Employer Tax Credit Act of 2001- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide: (1) employers a business tax credit for a portion of compensation that was not paid with respect to members of the military reserves who were absent from work on qualified reserve duty; and (2) a comparable credit for participating self-employed individuals.

Promoting Life-Saving New Therapies for Neonates Act of 2015 Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to award to the sponsor of a neonatal drug application a voucher that entitles the holder to one year of extension of all existing patents and marketing exclusivity, including any extensions, for a single human drug with respect to an application submitted under the Public Health Service Act or for a single human biologic product with respect to an application submitted under the Act. Defines "neonatal drug application" to mean a human drug application submitted to the FDA for a drug or biological product that: (1) is for the prevention or treatment of a disease or condition listed on the Priority List of Critical Needs for Neonates; and (2) contains no active ingredient that has been previously approved in any other application. Requires the FDA to approve such an application upon determining that it: (1) is eligible for a neonatal drug exclusivity voucher, (2) relies on clinical data derived from studies examining a neonatal population and dosages of the drug intended for that population, and (3) is approved after this Act's enactment. Permits the sponsor of a neonatal drug application that receives such a voucher to transfer the voucher to a sponsor of a human drug for which

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on June 22, 2015. Veterans Entrepreneurship Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Small Business Act to prohibit the Small Business Administration (SBA) from collecting a guarantee fee, during FY2015, for a loan made under the SBA Express Program to a veteran or spouse of a veteran on or after October 1, 2015. (Sec. 3) The SBA must report to Congress on the level of outreach to and consultation with female veterans regarding access to capital by women's business centers and veterans business outreach centers. (Sec. 4) The bill increases funding for the SBA Express Program through FY2015. The SBA may not guarantee a loan on and after October 1, 2015, if: the lender determines that the borrower is unable to obtain credit elsewhere solely because the lender's liquidity depends upon the guaranteed portion of the loan being sold on the secondary market, or the sole purpose for requesting the guarantee is to allow the lender to exceed its legal lending limit.

Manufacturing Universities Act of 2014 - Authorizes the Director of the Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to establish a program to designate up to 25 institutions of higher education (IHEs) as United States manufacturing universities. Requires the Director to award designations no earlier than January 1, 2015, and no later than March 31, 2015. Directs the Secretary of Education to make a grant to each designated IHE for five fiscal years to carry out the goals and goals to be achieved by the IHEs.

Montgomery GI Bill Improvements Act of 2001- Repeals the authority of members of the armed forces who have completed at least 15 years of active duty service to elect not to enroll for basic educational assistance under the Montgomery GI Bill. Prohibits any reduction in the pay of such members for months beginning six months after enactment of this Act, with exceptions.Allows such members to transfer, in whole or in part, their entitlement to such assistance to certain dependents.

Wildlife Corridors Conservation Act of 2010 - Requires the Secretary of the Interior to establish a National Fish and Wildlife Habitat and Corridors Information Program to: (1) develop a Habitat and Corridors Information System; and (2) make recommendations to states and Indian tribes to support the development and implementation of the System.

Rape Survivor Child Custody Act - Directs the Attorney General to make grants to states that have in place a law that allows the mother of any child conceived through rape to seek court-ordered termination of the parental rights of her rapist with regard to that child, which the court shall grant upon clear and convincing evidence of rape. Requires the amount of such a grant to be in an amount not greater than 10% of the average of the three most recent awards that the state received under the following grant programs: (1) the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968, (2) the STOP Violence Against Women Formula Grant Program, and (3) the Sexual Assault Services Program.

Women and Alcohol Research Equity Act of 1996 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to increase the amount of appropriations authorized for the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism for FY 1997 and 1999 to carry out research on alcohol abuse and alcoholism among women.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) U.S. Merchant Marine Academy Board of Visitors Enhancement Act (Sec. 2) This bill establishes a U.S. Merchant Marine Academy Board of Visitors, which shall provide independent advice and recommendations on matters relating to the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy. The bill revises the process for appointment of Board members, terms of service, and terms of office.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 17, 2013. Veterans Accountability Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to submit semiannual reports to the congressional veterans committees on travel made by a VA employee on official business to any location outside of: (1) the several states, the District of Columbia, a territory, commonwealth, or possession of the United States; (2) Indian lands; or (3) the territorial waters of the United States. Directs the Secretary to report to the appropriate entity each case of a notifiable infectious disease or condition that is diagnosed at a VA medical facility in accordance with the laws of the state in which the facility is located. Requires the Secretary to report each such case that is classified as a health-care-associated infection event to the accrediting organization of such facility.

Airline Passenger Fairness Act - Amends Federal aviation law to revise provisions prohibiting unfair or deceptive practices in the airline industry. Extends such prohibition to certificated air carriers. Defines unfair or deceptive practice" to include, for purposes of this Act, an air carrier\\'s failure to: (1) inform a ticketed passenger, upon request, whether the flight on which the passenger is ticketed is oversold; (2) permit a passenger holding a confirmed reserved space on a flight to use portions of that passenger\\'s ticket for travel, rather than the entire ticket, regardless of the reason any other portion of the ticket is not used; (3) deliver a passenger\\'s checked baggage within 24 hours after arrival of the flight on which the passenger travelled, except for reasonable delays in delivery of such baggage; (4) provide a consumer full access to all fares for that air carrier, regardless of the technology the consumer uses to access the fares; (5) provide notice to each passenger holding a confirmed reserved space on a flight with reasonable prior notice when a scheduled flight will be delayed for any reason (other than reasons of national security); (6) inform passengers accurately and truthfully of the reason for the delay, cancellation, or diversion of a flight; (7) refund the full purchase price of a ticket if the passenger requests a refund"

HSA Accessibility and Portability Act of 2006 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to allow a health insurance issuer to elect to meet specified requirements for providing group health insurance coverage to eligible individuals instead of complying with the guaranteed issue requirement with respect to any small employer.

Benefit Rating Acceleration for Veteran Entitlements Act of 2007 - Amends titles II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) and XVI (Supplemental Security Income) (SSI) of the Social Security Act to treat service-connected disability rated and certified as total by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs as disability for purposes of the OASDI (including child's, widow's, and widower's benefits) and SSI programs.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on February 1, 2016. Greater Sage Grouse Protection and Recovery Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill prohibits the Department of the Interior and the Department of Agriculture (USDA), upon notification by a governor of a state with a state management plan, from making a finding that the greater sage grouse is not an endangered or threatened species under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 until September 30, 2026. Until such date, the conservation status of the greater sage grouse shall remain not warranted for listing it as an endangered or threatened species. Interior and USDA may not exercise authority under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to make, modify, or extend any withdrawal, nor amend or otherwise modify any federal resource management plan applicable to federal land in the state in a manner inconsistent with the state plan. In the case of any state that provides such notification, if any withdrawal was made, modified, or extended or if any amendment or modification of a federal resource management plan applicable to federal lands in the state was issued during the three-year period preceding the notification and the withdrawal, amendment, or modification shall be stayed to the extent that it is inconsistent with the state plan.

Tapping America's Energy Potential through Research and Development Act of 2012 - Requires the Secretary of Energy, acting through the Assistant Secretary for Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy, to carry out research, development, and demonstration activities to facilitate commercial application of energy technologies related to the exploration, development, and production of oil shale resources. Declares that the objectives of such activities shall be to: (1) address scientific and technological barriers to enable economically feasible production of oil shale; and (2) minimize potential associated environmental impacts. Directs the Assistant Secretary to transmit to Congress a program implementation plan that: (1) details constraints and opportunities affecting oil shale development; (2) identifies strategies to enable such development; and (3) identifies and prioritizes research, development, and demonstration activities necessary to advance program objectives.<n><n>Authorizes the Assistant Secretary to conduct research and make awards to eligible entities for research, development, and demonstration activities in areas that include: (1) oil shale resource characterization; (2) modeling and simulation of oil shale exploration and production technologies; (3) minimization and re-use of water; (4) efficient use of energy in exploration and production activities; and (5) utilization of exploration and production methods and materials that reduce the potential impact of such activities on the environment.

Authorizes up to ten initial grants during the demonstration project's first three years, and up to ten additional grants in the second year.Authorizes appropriations.Directs the Secretary to use specified funds to support research at a land-grant university into the effects of value-added projects on agricultural producers and the commodity markets.

Civil Rights Voting Restoration Act of 2014 - Declares that the right of a U.S. citizen to vote in any election for federal office shall not be denied or abridged because the individual has been convicted of a non-violent criminal offense, unless, at the time of the election, the individual: (1) is serving a sentence in a correctional institution or facility; or (2) is serving a term of probation. Provides that such an individual who is serving a term of probation shall have the right to vote restored in any election for federal office: (1) on the date on which the term of probation ends, if the term of probation is less than one year; or (2) on the date after one year after the individual begins serving the term of probation, if the term of probation is one year or longer. Requires each state to notify in writing any individual who has been convicted of a non-violent criminal offense under state law that the individual has the right to vote in any election for federal office.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2015. National Care Corps Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) This bill establishes in the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) the National Care Corps, through which Corps volunteers provide approved services to individuals in need via participation in local Care Corps programs. The duties of the Corps Director are to: design, develop, and administer Corps programs; manage the daily operations of the Corps; and report to the Administrator of the Administration for Community Living regarding the Corps' daily operations. (Sec. 4) To be eligible to serve as a Corps volunteer, an individual shall: be at least 18 years of age on or before December 31 of the calendar year in which the individual begins participation in the Corps; agree to participate in the Corps for up to 24 months, consisting of up to two terms of up to 12 months; submit an application to the Director at such time; pass a criminal background check; and agree to comply with such terms and conditions as the Director may require. The Director shall: request a criminal background check of any individual before selecting any individual to serve as a Corps volunteer; and provide for Corps volunteers to receive allowances, health insurance, and post-service educational awards. (Sec

Arlington National Cemetery Burial Eligibility Act - Allows the remains of the following persons to be interred at Arlington National Cemetery: (1) any member of the armed forces who dies while on active duty; (2) any retired member; (3) any former member who served on active duty, was honorably discharged, and who was under 60 years of age at the time of death; (4) any former member who was separated for physical disability before October 1, 1949, who served on active duty, and who would have been eligible for disability retirement if such provisions had been in effect on such date; (5) any former member whose last active military service was terminated honorably and who has been awarded one of a number of specified military decorations; (6) any former prisoner of war who dies on or after November 30, 1993; (7) the President or any former President; (8) the spouse, surviving spouse, minor child, and, in the discretion of the Cemetery's Superintendent, unmarried adult child of an interred member (but only if buried in the same gravesite); (9) the spouse, minor child, and unmarried adult child (discretionary) of a member on active duty if such person dies while the member is on active duty; (10) the individual whose spouse, minor child, and unmarried adult child (discretionary) is eligible under this Act

. Safe, Convenient, Reliable, Efficient, Effective, Next-Generation, Functional, and Secure TSA Act of 2016 or the SCREEN FAST Act (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) of the Department of Homeland Security to establish a pilot program at three airports to reconfigure and install security systems that increase efficiency and reduce vulnerabilities in airport terminals, particularly at airports that have large open areas where screening is conducted. The TSA shall establish a pilot program at three airports to develop and test prototypes of: (1) screening security systems and security checkpoint configurations to expedite the movement of passengers by deploying a range of technologies, including passive and active systems, new types of security baggage and personal screening systems, and new systems to review and address passenger and baggage anomalies; and (2) new airport security systems.

Microenterprise and Asset Development Act - Amends part A (Aid to Families with Dependent Children) (AFDC) of title IV of the Social Security Act to provide for the disregard of up to $10,000 in income and resources designed for education, training, and employability in determining eligibility for AFDC. <n>Provides for the treatment of earned or unearned income received in a month on a nonrecurring basis as income. <n>Defines qualified distributions" as distributions for expenses directly related to: (1) the attendance of a member of the family at any education or training program; (2) the improvement of the employability (including self-employment) of a member of the family (such as through the purchase of an automobile); (3) the purchase of a home for the family; or (4) a change of the family residence. <n>Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to study and report to the Congress on: (1) the need to revise the limitation on the value of a family automobile required to be disregarded by a State in determining the eligibility of the family for AFDC; and (2) the extent to which such a revision would increase the employability of recipients."

Safer Neighborhoods Gun Buyback Act of 2015 This bill authorizes the Department of Justice's Bureau of Justice Assistance to make two-year grants to states and local governments for subgrants to gun dealers, or to gun dealers directly, to conduct gun buyback programs under which gun dealers shall be issued smart prepaid cards to purchase specified guns (listed in this bill) from individuals wishing to dispose of them. A state or local government shall: (1) return any remaining smart prepaid cards and any unused portion of a grant it received; and (2) use not more than 10% of grant funds to recycle the guns and ammunition that it receives. In conducting such a grant program, the Bureau of Justice Assistance shall: distribute the smart prepaid cards without any funds loaded onto them; and determine the market value of each gun that the Bureau determines should be included in the program and make such information publicly available. A person may not use a smart prepaid card in the acquisition of a gun or ammunition and a person may not accept such a card in the transfer (including a loan) of a gun or ammunition. A person that violates such prohibition shall pay to the Bureau of Justice Assistance an amount equal to the value of the prohibited sale.

Independent Contractor Tax Simplification Act of 1996 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that, for purposes of determining the employment status of individuals as employees, a service provider shall not be treated as an employee, a service recipient shall not be treated as an employer, a payor shall not be treated as an employer, and compensation paid or received for such service shall not be treated as paid or received with respect to employment. Sets forth provisions concerning: (1) service provider requirements with regard to the service recipient; and (2) related entities.

. Iran Congressional Oversight Act of 2015 (Sec. 4) This bill requires the President to report to Congress at least every 90 days regarding Iran's compliance with the Joint Plan of Action or a successor arrangement between the United States, France, the Russian Federation, the People's Republic of China, the United Kingdom, and Germany. The President shall submit an unclassified certification to Congress whether Iran has complied with or violated the terms of such Joint Plan of Action or the successor arrangement.

Price Stability Act of 2008 - Declares it to be U.S. policy that: (1) the principal economic responsibilities of the government are to establish and ensure an environment that is conducive to both long-term economic growth and increases in living standards by establishing and maintaining free markets, low taxes, respect for private property, and the stable, long-term purchasing power of the U.S. currency; and (2) the primary long-term goal of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System should be to promote price stability.<n><n>Amends the Federal Reserve Act to declare that the Board and the Federal Open Market Committee shall: (1) establish an explicit numerical definition of price stability"; and (2) maintain a monetary policy that effectively promotes long-term price stability.<n><n>Declares that this Act shall not be construed as a limitation on the authority or responsibility of the Board to: (1) provide liquidity to markets in the event of a disruption that threatens the smooth functioning and stability of the financial sector; or (2) serve as a lender of last resort when necessary.<n><n>Requires the Board to consult with Congress at semiannual hearings about its objectives and plans with respect to achieving and maintaining price stability.<n><n>Requires the Board, concurrent with each semiannual hearing,"

Fort Stanton and Rio Bonito Corridor Vegetation Management Act - Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the Bureau of Land Management, to solicit competitive bids for and enter into vegetation sales contracts for the purpose of using livestock grazing as a vegetation management tool within Fort Stanton and the Rio Bonito Corridor in New Mexico. Declares that such contracts shall be consistent with any applicable land and resource management plan under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. Makes the proceeds from such contracts available to the Secretary for: (1) distribution to Lincoln County, New Mexico; (2) the general fund of the Treasury; and (3) 75 percent of such proceeds to a special Treasury account.

NSF Major Research Facility Reform Act of 2016 This bill requires the National Science Foundation (NSF) to maintain a Large Facilities Office to support the research directorates in the development, implementation, and assessment of major multi-user research facilities. The functions of the office shall include: providing oversight of the development, construction, and transfer to operations of major multi-user research facilities across NSF; ensuring that NSF's polices for developing and maintaining major multi-user research facility construction costs are consistent with the best practices described in the March 2009 Government Accountability Office Report GAO-09-3SP; ensuring that an external cost proposal analysis is conducted for any major multi-user research facility; ensuring that an incurred cost audit is conducted at least biennially on any major multi-user research facility; requiring that NSF provide oversight for contingency in accordance with Cost Principles Uniform Guidance in 2 CFR part 200.433, or any successor thereto, and the Federal Acquisition Regulation; not making any award which provides for contributions to a contingency reserve held or managed by the awardee; and updating its Large Facilities Manual and any other applicable guidance for contingencies on major multi-user research facilities with regard to estimating, monitoring, and accounting for contingency.

Healthcare Information Technology Enterprise Integration Act - Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to establish an initiative for advancing health care information enterprise integration within the United States. Requires the initiative to: (1) build upon ongoing efforts of NIST, the private sector, and other Federal agencies, and be designed to permit health care information enterprise integration; and (2) involve consortia that include government and industry and be designed to permit health care information enterprise integration. Authorizes the Director to assist health care representatives and organizations and Federal agencies in the development of technical roadmaps that identify the remaining steps needed to ensure that technical standards for application protocols, interoperability, data integrity, and security, as well as the conformance test protocols, will be in place. Requires the Director to report annually to specified congressional committees on NIST activities under this Act.

Pay Accountability Act - Requires the payroll administrator of a house of Congress, if a government shutdown is in effect or the public debt limit is reached, to withhold from compensation for each Member of Congress an amount equal to one day's worth of pay under the annual rate of pay applicable to the Member for the pay period and the number of 24-hour periods during which the government shutdown is in effect or the public debt limit is reached which occur during the pay period. Requires the payroll administrator of a house of Congress to transfer to the Secretary of the Treasury any amounts remaining in any escrow account under this Act on the last day of the Congress involved. Requires any such amounts transferred to the Secretary to be deposited in the Treasury and used for deficit reduction.

Agricultural Credit Expansion Act This bill amends the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act to modify the Department of Agriculture (USDA) farm credit program. The bill modifies the eligibility requirements for farm ownership, conservation, and operating loans and loan guarantees to specify that an entity shall be deemed to meet the owner-operator requirement if at least 75% of the ownership interests of the entity are owned directly or indirectly by the individual that owns the family farm. (Currently, the owner-operator or operator must own at least 50% of the entity to be eligible for the loans and loan guarantees.)

Rural Telemedicine Enhancing Community Health (TECH) Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish three-year telehealth pilot projects to analyze the clinical outcomes and cost effectiveness associated with telehealth services in a variety of geographic areas. Requires the Secretary to: (1) select entities to participate in the projects; and (2) evaluate the effective and economic delivery of care in treating behavioral health issues, the effectiveness of improving the capacity of non-medical providers and non-specialized medical providers to provide health services for chronic complex diseases, and the effectiveness of using telehealth to provide acute stroke evaluation and treatment, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and speech language pathology services to treat cerebrovascular disease in medically underserved and tribal areas. Authorizes appropriations for FY2011-FY2014.

Transparency in Reporting to Protect American Workers and Prevent Human Trafficking Act This bill amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to revise reporting requirements related to H-1B nonimmigrants (temporary nonagricultural workers). The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) must publish annually on a public website: (1) the number of aliens who were granted nonimmigrant visas or nonimmigrant status, (2) the number of aliens who had such visas or statuses expired, revoked, or otherwise terminated during each month of the preceding fiscal year, (3) the countries of origin of (including local region or state if available), age, gender, and occupations of, educational levels attained by, and compensation paid to aliens issued such visa or status; and (4) the names and addresses of employers and the number of aliens authorized per category and to work for each employer, including the country of origin, age, and gender of each alien authorized to work for each employer, the alien's primary work location, and secondary work location if one exists.

American Community Renewal Act of 2002- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to authorize the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to designate in the aggregate an additional 20 nominated areas as renewal communities. Permits a designation to be made and to take effect after the enactment of this Act and before January 1, 2004. Provides that such designations shall remain in effect from January 1, 2004, and ending on December 31, 2011.Amends the Code to provide for the nonrecognition of gain on proceedings of the sale of real property which is invested in a renewal community, business, or empowerment zone.

Community Protection and Preparedness Act of 2016 This bill requires the Department of Transportation (DOT), annually, to impose a $1,500 fee for each DOT-111 specification railroad tank car used to transport Class 3 flammable liquids during the previous fiscal year that did not meet DOT-117, DOT-117P, or DOT-117R specifications at the time it was used. Such fee shall be paid by each person who causes such liquids to be transported by such car in commerce and not by the railroad carrier that transports such liquids. Collected fees shall be deposited into a Rail Account established within the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund and shall be available only for: the payment of removal and remediation costs and other costs, expenses, claims, and damages related to an accident or incident involving the transportation of Class 3 flammable liquids by rail; and DOT grants to states and Indian tribes to develop emergency plans and to train regional hazardous material emergency response teams and public employees responding to such an accident or incident.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Women, Peace, and Security Act of 2016 (Sec. 3) This bill expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the United States should be a global leader in promoting the participation of women in conflict prevention, management, and resolution and post-conflict relief and recovery efforts; (2) the political participation and leadership of women in fragile environments, particularly during democratic transitions, is critical to sustaining democratic institutions; and (3) the United States should promote the participation of women in all aspects of conflict prevention, management, and resolution, and post-conflict relief and recovery efforts. (Sec. 4) The bill declares that it shall be U.S policy to promote the meaningful participation of women in all aspects of conflict prevention, management, and resolution, and post-conflict relief and recovery efforts. (Sec. 5) The President, by October 1, 2017, October 1, 2022, and October 1, 2027, shall submit to Congress and make public a Women, Peace, and Security Strategy, which shall: be aligned with other countries' plans to improve the participation of women in peace and security processes, conflict prevention, peace building, and decision-making institutions; include goals and evaluation plans to ensure strategy effectiveness; and include a specific implementation plan from

Requires the Interagency Group to: (1) locate, identify, inventory, recommend for declassification, and make available to the public at the National Archives and Records Administration, all classified Japanese Imperial Army records of the United States; (2) coordinate with agencies and take such actions as necessary to expedite the release of such records to the public; and (3) report to Congress, including the Committee on Government Reform and Oversight of the House of Representatives, describing all such records, their disposition, and the Interagency Group's activities. Authorizes appropriations.Requires the Interagency Group to release in their entirety Japanese Imperial Army records subject to specified exceptions for privacy and national security.

Juvenile Corrections Act of 1997 - Authorizes the Administrator of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention of the Department of Justice to make grants to assist States and local governments in planning, establishing, and operating secure detention facilities, secure correctional facilities, and other facilities and programs for violent juveniles and serious chronic juvenile offenders who are accused of, or who have been adjudicated as having committed, one or more offenses. <n>Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) application requirements; (2) minimum amounts allocated to qualifying States; (3) performance evaluations; and (4) technical assistance and training. Authorizes appropriations. <n>Amends the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 to make a compensating reduction of the authorization of appropriations from Violent Offender Incarceration and Truth in Sentencing Incentive Grants.

Foreign Counterfeit Merchandise Prevention Act Amends the federal criminal code to provide that it shall not be a violation for a U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) officer or employee, at the time that merchandise is presented for examination and thereafter, to: (1) provide to the owner of a copyright or a registered mark any information appearing on the merchandise, including its retail packaging, a sample of the merchandise and its retail packaging, or digital images of the merchandise and its packaging, as it was presented to the CBP, without redaction, whether imported into or exported from the United States, or attempted to be exported from the United States, for purposes of determining whether the merchandise or its retail packaging infringes the copyright, bears or consists of a counterfeit mark of the registered mark; or (2) provide to a person who may be injured by a violation of such provisions, after seizing merchandise pursuant to a determination that the merchandise is in violation, certain information with respect to the merchandise, including the date of importation, the port of entry, the description of the merchandise from the entry, the quantity involved, the country of origin of the merchandise, the name and address of the foreign manufacturer, the name and address of the importer, and photographic or digital images of the merchandise.

Guard and Reserve Readiness and Retention Act of 2004 - Makes an individual entitled to retired pay for non-regular (reserve) military service if such individual: (1) satisfies one of specified combinations of minimum age (between 53 and 60) and years of service (between 20 and 30); (2) performed the last six years of qualifying service in currently authorized categories of military service, but not while a member of a regular component, the Fleet Reserve, or the Fleet Marine Corps Reserve; and (3) is not entitled to any other retirement pay from an armed force or as a member of the Fleet Reserve or Fleet Marine Corps Reserve.<n><n>Authorizes a reserve member called or ordered to active duty to continue in force under the TRICARE program (a Department of Defense managed health care program).

Small Business Health Information Technology Financing Act of 2009 - Amends the Small Business Act to authorize the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) to guarantee up to 90% of a loan, up to specified loan amounts, to a small business health professional to acquire and install health information technology for the professional\\'s medical practice. Defines the term health information technology" to include computer hardware, software, and related technology that: (1) supports the requirements for being treated as a meaningful electronic health record (EHR) user; and (2) provides for enhancement of continuity of care for patients through electronic storage, transmission, and exchange of relevant personal health data and information. Excludes from such definition information technology the sole use of which is financial management, maintenance of inventory of basic supplies, or appointment scheduling. Sets loan limits at $350,000 for an individual professional and $2 million for a group of affiliated professionals. Authorizes the Administrator to impose a guarantee fee on such professionals, but prohibits any service, processing, or other fees."

Gulf Coast Back to Business Act of 2007 - Authorizes appropriations for the Economic Development Administration of the Department of Commerce to make grants to the appropriate state government agencies in Louisiana and Mississippi for assistance to small businesses located in a disaster area that was negatively affected by Hurricanes Katrina or Rita in 2005.

Breast Cancer Patient Education Act of 2012 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to provide for the planning and implementation of an education campaign to inform breast cancer patients anticipating surgery regarding the availability and coverage of breast reconstruction, prostheses, and other options. Requires such campaign to include dissemination of the following information: (1) breast reconstruction is possible at the time of breast cancer surgery, or in a delayed fashion; (2) prostheses or breast forms may be available; (3) federal law mandates both public and private health plans to include coverage of breast reconstruction and prostheses; (4) the patient has a right to choose their provider of reconstructive care; (5) the patient may opt to undergo breast reconstruction in a delayed fashion for personal reasons, or after completion of all other breast cancer treatments; and (6) such campaign may include dissemination of other information as the Secretary determines relevant. Prohibits such campaign from specifying, or being designed to serve as a tool to limit, the health care providers available to patients.

Independent Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Finance Reform Act of 1997 (sic) - Establishes the Independent Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Finance Reform to study the law relating to elections for Federal office and to report and recommend legislation to reform that law. Directs the Commission to submit a report to the President, the Speaker and minority leader of the House of Representatives, and the majority and minority leaders of the Senate on its activities. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Target Practice and Marksmanship Training Support Act - Amends the Pittman-Robertson Wildlife Restoration Act to limit the Federal share of the cost of any activity carried out with a grant for construction or expansion of public target ranges in States with population growth and reductions in the acreage of Federal lands where target practice and marksmanship training are permitted to 90 percent of such cost.Extends the availability of funds for such activity to States that have experienced population growth and reductions in the acreage of Federal lands where target practice and marksmanship training are permitted.

Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2006 - Amends the federal judicial code to establish the Office of Inspector General for the Judicial Branch of the U.S. government, to be headed by an Inspector General appointed by the Chief Justice. Sets forth the duties of such Office with respect to the Judicial Branch, other than the Supreme Court.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 6, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.)Cormorant Management and Natural Resources Protection Act - (Sec. 3) Amends the Migratory Bird Treaty Act to direct the Secretary of the Interior to delegate to the governor of a state authority over cormorants: (1) to manage cormorants in the state effective on the date the Secretary approves a state management plan that is submitted by the governor; and (2) to conduct informational and educational activities with respect to cormorants in that state. Directs the Secretary to approve or disapprove a management plan for a state within 60 days after it is submitted, subject to review and approval by the Secretary in accordance with treaties and federal law. Provides that a state governor's exercise of authority over cormorants found in accordance with treaties and federal law shall not limit state authority to prevent their proliferation, except upon request by the Secretary.

Tax Relief for Victims of Disasters Act of 2011- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide special tax rules for a federally declared disaster individual: (1) making applicable to federally declared disasters occurring after December 31, 2010, and before January 1, 2013; (2) allowing an income tax deduction for losses attributable to a federally declared disaster occurring after December 31, 2010, and before January 1, 2013; and (3) allowing an additional tax deduction, up to $2,000, for the housing of a qualified federally declared disaster displaced individual during 2011 or 2012.

Grants a Federal charter to the Association of American State Geologists, a nonprofit corporation organized under the laws of Delaware. Declares that the association shall promote, advance, and protect the common good, welfare, and security of the Nation through the application of geology and related earth sciences to: (1) foster wise and responsible stewardship of the Nation's natural resources; (2) foster the creation of national wealth, general prosperity, and a high quality of life in the United States; (3) foster appropriate and sustainable economic development; (4) foster prudent exploration, development, utilization, management and conservation of the Nation's land, seas, and seabeds including energy, mineral, water, environmental and ecological resources; (5) avoid, reduce and mitigate hazards related to geology, earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides and other natural hazards through public awareness and coordination with appropriate local, State, regional, and Federal agencies; and (6) educate the general public concerning the critical importance of geology to society, civilization, culture, economy, and national security.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on November 19, 2013. Hospice Care Reform Act of 2013 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to allow a physician, nurse practitioner, clinical nurse specialist, or physician assistant who has a face-to-face encounter with an eligible individual prior to the first 60-day period and each subsequent 60-day period or where exceptional circumstances may prevent such an encounter before the beginning of the hospice benefit period to attest that such visit took place. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), before implementing any revisions to the methodology for determining the payment rates for routine home care and other services included in hospice care, to establish a Hospice Payment Reform demonstration program to test such proposed revisions.

National Neurological Diseases Surveillance System Act of 2010 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to: (1) enhance and expand infrastructure and activities to track the epidemiology of neurological diseases, including multiple sclerosis and Parkinson's disease; and (2) incorporate information obtained through those activities into a National Neurological Diseases Surveillance System. Requires the Secretary to ensure that the System is designed in a manner that facilitates further research on neurological diseases. Provides for the collection and storage of information on neurological diseases, including the incidence, prevalence, and other information, to the extent practicable. Requires the Secretary to make information and analysis in the System available to the public, including researchers. Requires the Secretary to ensure that privacy and security protections applicable to the System are at least as stringent as the protections under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA).

Preserving Medicare Advantage for all Medicare Beneficiaries Act of 2015 This bill amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to delay termination of a contract with a Medicare Advantage (MA) organization solely because the MA plan has failed to achieve a minimum quality rating under the Medicare Advantage STARS rating system between enactment of this Act and the end of plan year 2018. The bill also directs the Department of Health and Human Services to establish a demonstration project to provide funds to MA organizations offering one or more qualified MA plans for use in developing or expanding programs or services to improve health care delivery and outcomes of care for enrollees with low socioeconomic status.

Provides that the display of the POW/MIA flag shall be in a manner designed to ensure visibility to the public. Grants a Federal charter to the Air Force Sergeants Association, a nonprofit corporation incorporated in the District of Columbia.

NSP Termination Act (Sec. 2) This bill rescinds and permanently cancels all unobligated balances remaining available from the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act. All such unobligated balances so rescinded and permanently canceled should be retained in the General Fund of the Treasury for reducing the budget deficit of the federal government. The Department of Housing and Urban Development has allocated funding to the states, including city, county, and municipal governments, under the third round of funding for the Neighborhood Stabilization Program, according to a specified allocation formula, which will be subject to possible rescission and cancellation.

Millennium Challenge Compact Improvement Act (MCIA) This bill amends the Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 to revise requirements for a Millennium Challenge Compact ( Compact). The duration of a Compact may not exceed five years if the International Development Board (Board): (1) determines that the Compact includes a project that cannot be completed in five years or less, and (2) approves a duration for the Compact of not more than ten years. The Board may enter into: (1) more than one Compact at any given time; and (2) subsequent Compacts with eligible countries after the expiration of existing Compacts if they are making considerable and demonstrable progress in implementing the terms of their existing Compacts and supplementary agreements. The United States may provide assistance for the development of a regional Compact with two or more countries in the same geographic region.

scaling up manufacturing Act of 2012 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an eligible business, including a start-up company, a business tax credit for 25% of qualified manufacturing facility construction expenditures in a taxable year. Defines eligible business" as any corporation or partnership that: (1) is engaged in an active trade or business, (2) is headquartered in the United States, (3) substantially all of the management or administrative activities of which are performed in the United States, (4) is a start-up company, and (5) with respect to which all debt obligations issued by, and equity interests in, have a rating of B minus (or its substantial equivalent) or higher from a credit rating agency registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)."

Promote Accountability and Government Efficiency Act Any new federal employee hired on or after one year after enactment of this Act shall be hired on an at-will basis. Such an employee may be removed or suspended, without notice or right to appeal, from service by the head of the agency at which such employee is employed for good cause, bad cause, or no cause at all. This Act shall not be construed to extinguish or lessen any effort to achieve equal employment opportunity through affirmative action or any right or remedy available to any employee or applicant for employment in the civil service who is hired subject to this Act under: the title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, prohibiting discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, or national origin; the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, prohibiting discrimination on the basis of age; the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex; the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, prohibiting discrimination on the basis of handicapping condition; the Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2012, prohibiting discrimination on the basis of marital status or political affiliation; the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995, in the case of employees of the legislative branch; the protections relating to prohibited personnel practices; or any law protecting the employment rights of veterans. Any employee or applicant for employment who

Adoption Promotion Act of 1996 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a credit for adoption expenses. Limits such expenses to $5,000 ($7,500 in the case of a child with special needs). Provides a limitation based upon modified adjusted gross income.

Federally Supported Health Centers Assistance Act of 1995 (sic) - Amends the Public Health Service Act to remove provisions ending, on a specified date, the application of provisions: (1) deeming certain entities (migrant and community health centers and grant recipients for health services to the homeless and to residents of public housing) and their contractors to be employees of the Public Health Service (PHS); and (2) making a malpractice claim against the United States the sole remedy against such entities and their contractors. Adds governing board members to the list of employees deemed to be PHS employees. <n>Allows the deeming of an entity to be an PHS employee only with respect to services provided to patients of, and individuals who are not patients of, the entity if the Secretary of Health and Human Services determines, after reviewing the application, that the provision of the services to such individuals: (1) benefits patients of, and general populations that could be served by, the entity through community-wide intervention efforts within the communities served by such entity; (2) facilitates the provision of services to such patients; or (3) are otherwise required under an employment contract or similar arrangement between the entity and an officer, governing board member, employee, or contractor of the entity. Sets forth an application process. <n>Directs

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 12, 2012. The summary of that version is repeated here.) United States-Israel Enhanced Security Cooperation Act of 2012 - Expresses the sense of Congress that the United States should: (1) seek to enhance the capabilities of the governments of the United States and Israel to address emerging common threats, increase security cooperation, and expand joint military exercises; (2) provide Israel with necessary support to increase development and production of joint missile defense systems, particularly systems that defend against the urgent threat posed to Israel and United States forces in the region; (3) provide Israel with assistance for the production and procurement of the Iron Dome defense system for purposes of intercepting short-range missiles, rockets, and projectiles launched against Israel; (4) provide Israel with additional excess defense articles, as appropriate, in the wake of the withdrawal of U.S. forces from Iraq; (5) examine ways to strengthen existing and ongoing efforts, including the Gaza Counter Arms Smuggling Initiative, aimed at preventing weapons smuggling into Gaza pursuant to the 2009 agreement following the Israeli withdrawal from Gaza, as well as measures to protect against weapons smuggling and terrorist threats from the Sinai Peninsula; (6) offer the Air Force of Israel additional training and exercise opportunities in the United States to compensate for

Interest on Business Checking Act of 2001- Amends the Federal Reserve Act, the Home Owners' Loan Act, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act to authorize a member bank, a Federal savings association, or an insured nonmember bank or insured State savings association to permit the owner of any deposit, any account which is a deposit, or any account on which interest or dividends are paid, to make not more than 24 transfers per month, or such greater number as the Federal Reserve Board may determine, for any purpose, to a demand deposit account of the owner in the same institution.Directs a lender or servicer to pay interest on an escrow account maintained in connection with a loan only if those payments are required by contract between the lender or servicer and the borrower, or a specific statutory provision of the law of the State in which the security property is located requires the lender or servicer to make such payments.Amends the Federal Reserve Act to repeal the proscription against interest payments on demand deposits.

Franked Mail Savings Act - Amends the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 1991 to revise the rules for the Official Mass Mailing Allowance for Members of the House of Representatives. Declares that such Allowance shall be available only for postage for any mass mailing sent by a Member as franked mail and shall be available, in a session of Congress, in an amount not to exceed the total amount allocated to such Member in such session. Prohibits transfers to or from such Allowance. <n>Provides that for purposes of such Allowance: (1) the Official Mass Mailing Allowance of any Member shall be treated separately from the Official Mail Allowance of any other official mail sent by such Member; and (2) otherwise applicable law relating to mass mailings sent by a Member shall continue to govern such mass mailings. <n>Prohibits a mass mailing from being sent during any session that begins in an even-numbered calendar year, and requires a Member to submit a sample of the mail matter involved to the House Commission on Congressional Mailing Standards for an advisory opinion as to whether such proposed mailing is in compliance with applicable provisions of law, rule, or regulation. <n>Requires the House Commission on Congressional Mailing Standards to establish procedures under which there shall be made available to the public for review and copying any matter submitted to

Rural Law Enforcement Assistance Act of 1997- Authorizes a private, nonprofit corporation, to be known as the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement, for the purpose of assisting rural law enforcement agencies with management education and training, maintaining a clearinghouse, evaluation, technical assistance, research, computer and forensic education and training, and providing such other support as may be necessary or useful. Authorizes appropriations.

Amends the Food Security Act of 1985 to direct the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to deny, for a period not to exceed five crop years, or permanently, payments under the special supplemental nutrition assistance program (SNAP, formerly the food stamp program) to any person or legal entity who is determined to be ineligible for such benefits and payments. Provides for repayment of any such benefits or payments already received by such person or entity.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) request the Administrator of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to verify the average adjusted gross income, average adjusted gross farm income, and average adjusted gross nonfarm income of a person or legal entity applying for SNAP benefits; and (2) deny such benefits if the Administrator determines that such person or entity does not comply with such limitations.<n><n>Authorizes a person or legal entity subject to denial of benefits to request a reconsideration of the denial by the Farm Service Agency office serving the location in which the person or legal entity resides or operates. Prohibits such person or entity from applying for more than one redetermination, as described in this Act, a calendar year.

Pipeline Improvement and Preventing Spills Act of 2015 Directs the Department of Transportation (DOT) to prescribe minimum standards to require: (1) a pipeline facility owner or operator to notify all property owners and residents located within 2,000 feet of a pipeline transmission line of the property's proximity to the line, including its specific location if located on private residential property; and (2) the notice to include a method for electronic access to such information through the Geospatial Platform or other federal data archive and information on how to obtain a map of the pipeline system through the National Pipeline Mapping System. Directs DOT to prescribe minimum standards requiring: (1) an operator of a pipeline facility to maintain information related to facility operation (including updates and changes) to DOT, state regulatory officials, state and local emergency responders, and other appropriate entities; and (2) the operator to provide such information to the extent applicable to the local district. Directs DOT to prescribe such standards requiring the availability of industry standards and procedures adopted by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) for pipeline facilities in high-consequence areas. Directs DOT, in the case of a local emergency responder, to file the information submitted to DOT only to the extent applicable to the local district. Prohibits DOT from approving a pipeline facility operation information standard

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for family caregivers of individuals with long-term care needs who are at least six years old and unable to perform at least three activities of daily living due to a loss of functional capacity or who require substantial supervision to protect such individuals from threats to health and safety due to severe cognitive impairment.

Chickasaw National Recreation Area Land Exchange Act of 2004 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to convey specified Federal land in Oklahoma to the Chickasaw Nation in exchange for certain non-Federal land in Oklahoma located adjacent to the Chickasaw National Recreation Area.<n><n>Requires the fair market values of the Federal and non-Federal lands to be determined by an appraisal acceptable to the Secretary and the Chickasaw Nation.

Immigration Anti- Discrimination Improvement Act of 1993 - Approves the findings of the General Accounting Office (GAO) report entitled Immigration Reform: Employer Sanctions and the Question of Discrimination." Declares that the Congress approves such report. <n>Authorizes appropriations for: (1) the use of civil penalties collected under the Immigration and Nationality Act for enforcement of such Act; and (2) regional offices of the Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices within the Department of Justice. <n>Directs the Comptroller General to report annually to the Congress on: (1) the pervasiveness of unfair immigration-related employment practices (including enforcement actions); and (2) the Attorney General on such practices. <n>Requires the Special Counsel to: (1) provide for agreements with Federal and State agencies involved in enforcement of laws prohibiting discrimination on the basis of national origin to forward charges respecting unfair immigration-related employment practices to the Special Counsel; (2) establish a national, toll-free telephone service to receive such charges; and (3) provide outreach efforts to educate the public. <n>Directs the Attorney General to: (1) provide technical assistance to States and local governments concerning such provisions and the roles provided for receipt of charges; and (2) establish a monitoring panel to monitor the application of such provisions. <n>Authorizes an"

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2016. Grow Our Own Directive: Physician Assistant Employment and Education Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out a five-year Grow Our Own Directive or G.O.O.D. pilot program to provide educational assistance to certain former members of the Armed Forces for education and training as VA physician assistants. The VA shall provide eligible individuals with program information about application requirements and partner entities. An individual is eligible to participate in the pilot program who: has medical or military health experience; has received a certificate, associate degree, baccalaureate degree, master's degree, or postbaccalaureate training in a science relating to health care; has participated in the delivery of health care services or related medical services, including military training regarding identification, treatment, and prevention of diseases and disorders; and does not have a degree of doctor of medicine, doctor of osteopathy, or dentistry. The VA shall select at least 250 pilot program participants and give priority to persons who: participated in the Intermediate Care Technician Pilot Program between January 2011 and February 2015, and agree to be employed as a Veterans Health Administration (VHA) physician assistant in a community

Satellite Home Viewer Protection Act of 1996 - Amends copyright law with respect to satellite carrier service of network stations to require a satellite carrier that makes secondary transmissions of a primary transmission made by a network station to provide a subscriber with a written statement describing the network territorial restrictions on such service and the subscriber's rights. <n>Requires a satellite carrier, upon a challenge by a network station regarding whether a subscriber is an unserved household within the predicted grade B contour of the station, to: (1) inform the subscriber who is the subject of the challenge in writing that the network station has challenged the subscriber's receipt of the same network signal; and (2) offer the subscriber the option of conducting a measurement of the subscriber's household to determine whether the household is an unserved household. Requires the satellite carrier to terminate service to the household of the signal that is the subject of the challenge and notify the network station that made the challenge that service has been terminated. Provides that if the subscriber requests the satellite carrier to conduct a signal intensity measurement, the satellite carrier shall give reasonable notice to the network station issuing the challenge to the subscriber that the satellite carrier will be conducting such measurement. <n>Allows satellite carriers and network broadcasters to negotiate the terms and conditions, including technical standards and costs,

Amends part E (Foster Care and Adoption Assistance) of title IV of the Social Security Act to provide that a State shall not require any parent or legal guardian to transfer custody of a child in order to have the child placed outside the parent's or legal guardian's home, if the sole reason for the placement is the need to obtain services provided under the State plan for the child's emotional, behavioral, or mental disorder or developmental or physical disability. Requires that: (1) the State be responsible for the placement of any child subject to a voluntary placement agreement and for the care of any child so placed; and (2) the State apply procedural safeguards to assure each child so placed of dispositional hearings of the type.

ogen Reduction and Testing Reform Act of 2014 - Amends the Federal Meat Inspection Act to prohibit the sale or distribution of meat and meat food products that contain a strain of a microbial pathogen associated with serious illness or death that is resistant to not less than two critically important antibiotics for human medicine. Amends the Poultry Products Inspection Act to require the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to establish sampling protocols and testing procedures for meat and meat food products.

Developing Standards for Electronic Shipping Papers Act of 2014 - Directs the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) to establish a Hazardous Materials Information Advisory Committee to: (1) develop a voluntary standard for the use of electronic shipping papers until a rulemaking has been completed, (2) establish a standardized curriculum for training first responders and enforcement officials in the use of such papers and other alternative means of communicating hazardous materials information, (3) provide recommendations and best practices for the use of electronic shipping papers by first responders in varying circumstances and locations, and (4) assess potential methods during deployment phases involving electronic shipping papers.

Secondary Payer Advancement, Rationalization, and Clarification Act or the Clarification Act This bill amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to specify that a prescription drug plan shall be secondary payor to any valid and collectible payment from a primary drug plan until the plan pays a final settlement, judgment, or award to an individual enrolled under the plan with regard to an injury or illness involved or otherwise terminates the plan's ongoing responsibility for medical payments with respect to the individual. A primary drug plan is defined as a group health plan, a group health plan or large group health plan (other than a group health plan or multiemployer or multiple employer plan of, or contributed to by, an employer with 20 or fewer employees for each working day in each of 20 or more calendar weeks in the calendar year involved or the preceding calendar year), a self-insured plan, a service benefit plan, a managed care organization, a pharmacy benefit manager, or other party that, by statute, contract, or agreement, is legally responsible for payment of a claim for a covered outpatient drug, in enrolling an individual or in making payments for benefits to the individual or on the individual's behalf, may not take into account that the individual is enrolled under a prescription drug plan

(Sec. 4) Establishes the Ronald Reagan Memorial Commission to: (1) prepare a recommendation to the Congress for a permanent location for the memorial; (2) select a design for the memorial; and (3) report to the Congress and the President on its activities every six months.(Sec. 5) Directs the Commission to: (1) begin the process of recommending a location and selecting a design for the memorial no later than six months after enactment of this Act; (2) erect a suitable marker at the site approved by the Congress for the memorial, which shall be installed by the Secretary within three months after enactment of a law approving the location; (3) select a design for the memorial from proposals solicited and accepted from qualified American architects; and (4) report to the Congress and the President on its activities every six months.(Sec. 6) Authorizes appropriations.

(Sec. 1) This bill directs the Department of the Interior, within 180 days after enactment of this bill and subject to valid existing rights held by third parties and any mining claims, millsites, or tunnel sites of a qualified entity, to offer for sale to such an entity, for fair market value, the remaining right, title, and interest of the United States in and to certain federal land in Mohave County, Arizona (covered land). The qualified entity shall be required to pay all costs related to the conveyance of the covered land. The authority of Interior to sell covered land shall terminate 10 years after this bill's enactment.

Americans Want to Work Act - Amends the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008 with respect to the state-established individual emergency unemployment compensation account (EUCA). Replaces the current three-tiered emergency unemployment compensation (EUC) system with a fifth-tier EUC system. Requires a further augmentation of an individual's EUCA, using the current formula, by an amount equal to the lesser of: (1) 80% of the total amount of regular compensation (including dependents' allowances) payable to the individual during the individual's benefit year under the state law; or (2) 20 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount for the benefit year.

Professional Sports Antitrust Clarification Act of 1996 - Authorizes a professional sports league or its member franchises to establish and enforce rules and procedures for the purpose of deciding whether a member franchise may change its home territory. Declares that nothing in this Act shall be construed to exempt from the antitrust laws any conduct which would be unlawful under any antitrust law if engaged in by a single entity. Declares that this Act applies to a professional sports league and its member franchises if such league: (1) establishes rules and procedures to govern whether a member franchise may change its home territory that are available upon request to any interested party; (2) affords due process, including 180 days notice and an opportunity to be heard, to interested parties prior to deciding whether a member franchise may change its home territory; and (3) promotes comparable economic opportunities by sharing revenue among member franchises to account for disparities in revenue received or costs saved due to direct or indirect public benefits and subsidies, including publicly financed facilities, rent abatement, special tax treatment, favorable arrangements for parking, concessions, and other amenities, and other public benefits not generally available to businesses as a whole within the jurisdiction. Declares that the standard of judicial review shall be de novo in any action challenging the establishment and enforcement of rules and procedures for deciding whether

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on November 14, 2016. Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to increase the federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP) for jurisdictions affected by the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003 by the number of percentage points estimated by the chief executive official of the affected jurisdiction for a calendar quarter. For calendar quarters beginning on or after January 1 of the first year beginning after the enactment of this bill: (1) HHS shall increase the FMAP for each affected jurisdiction by the number of percentage points estimated by the chief executive official; and (2) the Department of the Interior shall review the estimation submitted by the chief executive official, make any appropriate adjustments, and submit a final estimated amount of compact migrant expenditures for such quarter. HHS shall estimate the number of percentage points that the FMAP for each affected jurisdiction would need to be increased for a calendar quarter to result in an increase in the amount of total federal payments to the affected jurisdiction under title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act equivalent to the final estimated amount of compact migrant expenditures submitted for such quarter. In no case shall an increase in the FMAP applicable to an affected jurisdiction that exceeds

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on December 10, 2015.
