Department of Veterans Affairs Construction, Accountability, and Reform Act (Sec. 2) This bill authorizes the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out the major medical facility project to replace the VA medical center in Aurora, Colorado, in an amount not to exceed $1,730 million. (Sec. 3) The VA may not pay any bonus during FY2015-FY2016 until the project is completed by September 30, 2016, unless it is certified to Congress that it is fully operational. During the fiscal year in which the VA may begin to pay a bonus, and each fiscal year thereafter through FY 2024, the VA shall ensure that the aggregate amount of bonuses paid does not exceed $360 million. (Sec. 4) The VA shall enter into an agreement with the Army Corps of Engineers for the Army Corps to carry out, on a reimbursable basis, the design, contract, construction management, and other similar services for the Aurora medical facility project.

Real Estate Mortgage Investment Conduit Improvement Act of 2009 - Provides that if a real estate mortgage investment Conduit (REMIC) modifies or disposes of a troubled asset under the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) established by the Secretary of the Treasury under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 (EESA): (1) such modification or disposition shall not be treated as a prohibited transaction; (2) an interest in the REMIC shall not fail to be treated as a regular interest solely because of such modification or disposition; and (3) any proceeds resulting from such modification or disposition shall be treated as amounts received under qualified mortgages. Terminates a REMIC when the instruments governing the conduct of servicers or trustees with respect to qualified mortgages or foreclosure property prohibit or restrict such servicers or trustees from reasonably modifying or disposing of such qualified mortgages or foreclosure property in order to participate in TARP or under rules established by the Secretary under this Act.

National Education Technology Corps Act (NET Corps Act) - Amends the Domestic Volunteer Service Act of 1973 to direct the Director of the Corporation for National and Community Service to establish a National Education Technology Corps as part of the Volunteers in Service to America program.Requires the Director to assign Corps volunteers to projects and programs that utilize such volunteers to perform the following activities: (1) improving the ability of teachers, staff, students, and other persons to use information technology in schools, libraries, and community centers; (2) providing information technology training for teachers so that teachers can incorporate the use of computers and other information technologies in classroom instruction; and (3) providing technical support to administrators of school, library, and community center information technology networks.Allows such programs and projects to be administered by public or private nonprofit agencies and organizations, community-based nonprofit organizations, local and State education agencies, local and State agencies administering information technology programs, educational institutions, libraries, and local, municipal, and State governmental entities. Requires a volunteer serving in the Corps to be assigned to a school to perform services unless the school, or a local educational agency on behalf of the school, submits to the Director a technology plan that: (1) outlines the goals for the school's education technology; and (2) complies with such guidelines as

NWR's Home Protection Act - Amends the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974 to require a manufacturer to provide with each manufactured home (other than a manufactured home affixed to a permanent foundation) instructions for the installation of a weather radio. Requires model installation standards to require each manufactured home to be installed with a radio inside that broadcasting conditions is capable of: (1) broadcasting emergency conditions; and (2) complying with the Consumer Electronics Association (CEA) Standard 2009-A Specific Performance Specification for Public Alert Receivers (or its current revision). Requires installers to ensure that manufactured homes are supplied and installed with such a radio. Provides immunity from common law civil liability for specified aspects of the installation, furnishing, function, operation, performance, capabilities, or utilization of the weather radio.

odegas as Catalysts for Healthy Living Act - Directs the Administrator of the Small Business Administration to make grants to small businesses and community organizations to: (1) provide assistance in expanding the inventory of fresh fruits and vegetables and healthy alternatives; and (2) provide assistance in carrying out consumer education and outreach activities to encourage the purchase of such products.Amends title XVIII (Medicare) and title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to cover additional primary and preventive services relating to obesity treatment and prevention, supervised exercise sessions, stress testing, lifestyle modification education, and nutrition education.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 9, 2014.leanor Smith Inclusive Home Design Act of 2013 - (Sec. 3) Requires applicants for federal financial assistance to assure the federal agency responsible for such assistance that all of its programs and activities will be conducted in compliance with this Act. Defines a "federal financial assistance" as: (1) any assistance provided or otherwise made available by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) or the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA), through any grant, loan, contract, or any other arrangement, after the expiration of the one-year period beginning on the date of the enactment of this Act, including grants, subsidies, or other funds; (2) services of federal personnel; (3) real or personal property or any interest in or use of such property, including transfers or leases of the property for less than fair market value or for reduced consideration and proceeds from a subsequent transfer or lease of the property if the federal share of its fair market value is not returned to the federal government; (4) tax credits, mortgage or loan guarantee or insurance; and (5) community development funds in the form of obligations guaranteed under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 or the Housing Act of 1949. (Sec.

Settlement Trust Improvement Act of 2017 This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to modify the tax treatment of Settlement Trusts established under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (ANCSA). (Settlement Trusts are corporations that receive payments under the ANCSA and then transfer the payments to the trusts.) The bill excludes from gross income the value of any payments that would otherwise be made to a Native Corporation pursuant to, or as required by, any provision of the ANCSA, including any payments that would otherwise be made to a Village Corporation pursuant to the same provision. The payments must be assigned in writing to a Settlement Trust and be not received by the Native Corporation before the assignment. The bill also: (1) allows a tax deduction for certain contributions made by a Native Corporation to an Settlement Trust, and (2) establishes a 15-year carryover period for any excess contributions by a Native Corporation to a Settlement Trust.

Montana Fish and Wildlife Conservation Act of 1998 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, subject to specified provisions of law, to sell at fair market value: (1) all interest of the United States in and to 265 cabin sites and certain small contiguous parcels of the Bureau of Reclamation at Canyon Ferry Reservoir, Montana; and (2) easements for vehicular access to each leasehold, access to and the use of one dock per leasehold, and access to and the use of all boathouses, ramps, retaining walls, and other improvements for which access is provided in the leases. Directs the Secretary to solicit sealed bids for all of the leaseholds and, subject to specified minimum bids, sell the leaseholds to the bidder that submits the highest bid above the minimum bid. Establishes in the Treasury the Canyon Ferry- Missouri River Trust Fund, to be funded by proceeds from the sale of the leaseholds.

Establishes the Emergency Trade Deficit Commission to examine the nature, causes, and consequences of the U.S. trade deficit, and make recommendations on how to address and reduce structural trade imbalances, including with respect to the U.S. merchandise trade deficit, in order to promote sustainable economic growth that provides broad-based income and employment gains.

Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997 - Amends Federal criminal law to require an employer of private security officers, at the request of an employer of private security officers, an association of such employers, designated by the Attorney General, to submit to the Attorney General fingerprints or other methods of positive identification of an employee for a background check. Authorizes an employer to seek authorization from its employees to submit their fingerprints for such a background check. Requires the Attorney General, upon receipt of fingerprints from such an association, to search the records of the Interstate Information Index of the National Crime Information Center and the Identification Division of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and to provide any identification and criminal history records corresponding to the fingerprints to the requesting association within 30 business days. Directs the Attorney General to: (1) encourage the use of the best technology available in compiling criminal history information and in responding to requests under this Act; and (2) submit employee fingerprints to the Attorney General for identification and appropriate processing within one business day of receiving them. Requires an association to also transfer a copy of such identification and criminal history records to the requesting employer within one business day of receiving them. Sets penalties for the knowing and intentional use of any such information other than for the purpose of determining the suitability of an individual for employment as

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 6, 2017. Border Enforcement Security Task Force Reauthorization Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to revise the requirement that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) consider threats posed by transnational criminal organizations when establishing a unit to assist in border security and counter-terrorism activities. Such unit shall be composed of at least one member from the Coast Guard Investigative Service and the geographically responsible Coast Guard Sector Intelligence Office. Port security best units shall be composed of at least one member from each of the following: the Coast Guard Investigative Service, and the geographically responsible Coast Guard Sector Intelligence Office. (Sec. 3) The bill expresses the sense of Congress that providing danger pay to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents assigned to dangerous overseas posts will: (1) help ICE modernize its overseas workforce compensation system, and (2) place ICE on equal footing with the law enforcement agencies of the Department of Justice. The Department of State may not deny a request by the Drug Enforcement Administration, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, or U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to authorize a danger pay allowance for any employee of any such agency.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior to manage such segment as a recreational river in accordance with the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1996. Prohibits any privately owned land from being included in such segment.

Veteran Employment Transition Act of 2010- Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the work opportunity tax credit, to expand the definition of recently discharged veteran" to include: (1) any individual who has served on active duty in the Armed Forces or the National Guard for more than 180 total days (whether consecutive or not); (2) any individual who has been discharged or released from active duty for a service-connected disability; and (3) any member of the National Guard who has served for more than 180 total days."

Clean Energy Technology Manufacturing and Export Assistance Act of 2011 - Directs the Secretary of Commerce to establish a Clean Energy Technology Manufacturing and Export Assistance Program, to be carried out by the Under Secretary for International Trade of the Department of Commerce, to: (1) promote policies to reduce production costs and encourage innovation, investment, and productivity among businesses in the United States that produce or export clean energy technologies or related services; (2) implement a national strategy with respect to the exportation of such technologies and services from the United States; and (3) ensure that businesses in the United States that produce or export clean energy technologies or related services have the information and assistance necessary to be competitive and to create and maintain clean energy technology jobs in the United States.

Fair And Immediate Release of Generic Drugs Act or the FAIR Generics Act This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FFDCA) to disqualify from being a “first applicant” an applicant submitting an abbreviated new drug application (for a generic drug) to the Food and Drug Administration that has entered into a specified agreement. Currently, any generic drug applicant submitting an application on the first day an application is submitted for that drug is a “first applicant” and is granted a 180-day marketing exclusivity period. An agreement that disqualifies a generic drug applicant from being a first applicant is an agreement between the applicant and the holder of the application or a patent for the brand name drug whereby the applicant agrees not to seek approval or begin marketing the generic drug until the expiration of the exclusivity period awarded to another applicant. “First applicant” is expanded to include applicants that did not submit an application on the first day an application was submitted. These first applicants must not have a patent infringement action pending against them and must not have been found to have infringed a patent. If an applicant that submitted an application on the first day an application was submitted has begun marketing the drug,

Public Health Equity Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to ensure that no person shall be excluded from participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subject to discrimination under, any program or activity on the ground of race, color, or national origin. <n>Directs the President to ensure that no person shall be excluded from participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subject to discrimination under, any program or activity on the ground of race, color, or national origin. <n>Directs the Secretary of Labor, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and any other head of a Federal agency with responsibility for providing Federal financial assistance to a program or activity to issue regulations implementing such nondiscrimination requirements in accordance with applicable law. Requires such regulations to: (1) bar acts with discriminatory effects as well as intentionally discriminatory acts; and (2) address actions of programs or activities that result in disproportionate exposure to a covered substance on the basis of race, color, or national origin.

Brownfield Cleanup and Redevelopment Revolving Loan Fund Pilot Project Act of 1996 - Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to establish a pilot project to provide a capitalization loan to one or more States that submit applications to the Administrator to establish or expand a State revolving loan fund for purposes of providing loans for voluntary environmental cleanups of eligible facilities. <n>Requires the Administrator to ensure that the State voluntary program provides adequate opportunities for public participation, sufficient technical assistance, and oversight to ensure that cleanups comply with Federal and State laws, and certification to the owner and prospective purchaser that the cleanup is complete. <n>Requires the application to include: (1) evidence that the State is carrying out a voluntary cleanup program for eligible facilities; (2) evidence that the State will provide a matching share of at least 20 percent of the costs of such cleanup from either new or existing sources of State funding; and (3) a description of the State's proposed revolving loan program and capability to manage the program. <n>Directs the State's revolving loan program to: (1) provide loans to both public and private parties conducting voluntary cleanups who are unable to secure loans from private lending institutions or other means of financing; (2) require borrowers to demonstrate credit worthiness and the ability to carry out the cleanup; and

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 12, 2012. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Smith-Mundt Modernization Act of 2012 - (Sec. 2) Amends the United States Information and Educational Exchange Act of 1948 to direct the Secretary of State and the Broadcasting Board of Governors (Board) to use funds appropriated or otherwise made available for public diplomacy information programs to provide for the preparation, dissemination, and use of information intended for foreign audiences abroad about the United States, its people, and its policies, through press, publications, radio, motion pictures, the Internet, and other information media, including social media, and through information centers, instructors, and other direct or indirect means of communication. Authorizes the Secretary and the Board, upon request and reimbursement of the reasonable costs incurred in fulfilling such a request, to make available in the United States motion pictures, films, video, audio, and other materials prepared for dissemination abroad or disseminated abroad pursuant to specified Acts, the United States International Broadcasting Act of 1994, the Radio Broadcasting to Cuba Act, and the Television Broadcasting to Cuba Act. Directs the Secretary and the Board to issue regulations to: (1) establish procedures to maintain such material, (2) reimburse reasonable costs incurred in fulfilling requests

Access Obstetric Care Act of 1993 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to provide for demonstration projects by States that seek to reduce infant mortality by improving access in urban and rural underserved areas to obstetric services for eligible pregnant women under title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act. Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to increase the Federal medical assistance percentage with respect to additional expenditures for medical assistance made under the State Medicaid plan to carry out such a project.

. Student Disciplinary Fairness Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) This bill amends the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 to establish an Office of School and Discipline Policy for the purpose of reducing the number of juveniles who are incarcerated and develop a criminal record based on activity that occurs while the juvenile is at school. The office must: collect and publish data relating to the arrest and incarceration of juveniles for violations of school policies or rules; work with states, local governments, and nongovernmental organizations to expand the use of alternatives to detention and incarceration programming in schools; and collect and publish data on the relationship between the presence of a school resource officer at a school and the rate of juveniles who are arrested and incarcerated for violations of school rules or policies. The office may award grants to states, local governments, and local educational agencies to reduce the number of juveniles who are incarcerated and develop a criminal record based on activity that occurs while the juvenile is at school. (Sec. 4) The bill amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to modify the conditions under which states are allowed to receive Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grants by requiring them to give priority to applicants that demonstrate an commitment to reducing the number of juveniles who are incarcerated and develop a criminal record based

Medicare Certified Registered Nurse First Assistant Direct Reimbursement Act of 2001 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act, as amended by the Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000, to provide for Medicare coverage of surgical first assisting services furnished by a certified registered nurse first assistant.

Generating Antibiotic Incentives Now Act of 2011- Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to extend by five years the exclusivity period for the first approved drug or biological product qualified infectious disease product, which is an antibiotic drug for treating, detecting, preventing, or identifying certain resistant or multi-drug resistant pathogens. Defines qualified infectious disease product" as an antibiotic drug for treating, detecting, preventing, or identifying a qualifying pathogen. Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, to review the guidelines of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the conduct of clinical trials for antibiotic drugs and revise such guidelines to reflect developments in medical information and technology. Allows the sponsor of a drug intended to be used to treat, detect, prevent, or identify a qualifying pathogen, as defined by this Act, to request the Secretary to designate the drug as a qualified infectious disease product."

Amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) the Social Security Act (SSA) to: (1) extend Medicare prescription drug initial enrollment periods for 2006 and 2007; (2) suspend the late enrollment penalty through December 31, 2007; and (3) allow open enrollment and disenrollment in prescription drug plans during the first 12 months of enrollment.

CTR Modernization Act - Revises Federal money and finance law to specify that, when a depository institution is involved in a transaction for the payment, receipt, or transfer of United States coins or currency (or other monetary instruments the Secretary of the Treasury prescribes), in an amount, denomination, or amount and denomination of not less than $30,000, the depository institution and any other participant in the transaction shall file a report on the transaction at the time and in the way the Secretary prescribes. Prohibits the Secretary from requiring a depository institution to file a currency transaction report when the transaction involves the transfer of currency of an amount and denomination of less than $30,000. Requires the Secretary to: (1) solicit and review comments about the appropriateness and utility of the then current threshold amount or denomination; (2) review the continuing appropriateness, relevance, and utility of each threshold amount or denomination; and (3) adjust such amount, at appropriate time and in no case later than 365 days following the expiration of the public comment period, for any inflation that the Secretary determines has occurred since the date any such amount was established or last adjusted, except that the Secretary shall not reduce such amount to an amount and denomination of less than $30,000. Directs the Secretary to: (1) prescribe regulations to permit a qualified customer exemption from the

Waco Mammoth National Monument Establishment Act of 2011- Establishes the Waco Mammoth National Monument in Texas as a unit of the National Park System.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with Baylor University and the city of Waco, Texas (the city), to complete a general management plan for the Monument.<n><n>Terminates the designation of the Monument as a unit of the National Park System if federal funds are required to operate and maintain it.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2016. Methane Hydrate Research and Development Amendments Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Methane Hydrate Research and Development Act of 2000 to revise and reauthorize through FY2020 the methane hydrate research and development program. The Department of Energy (DOE) may award grants or enter into contracts or cooperative agreements with institutions that: conduct basic and applied research to identify, explore, assess, and develop methane hydrate as a commercially viable source of energy; identify and characterize methane hydrate resources using remote sensing and seismic data; develop technologies required for efficient and environmentally sound development of methane hydrate resources; conduct basic and applied research to assess and mitigate the environmental impact of hydrate degassing; develop technologies to reduce the risks of drilling methane hydrates through drilling and degassing with drilling operations on permafrost and nonperma gas; conduct exploratory drilling, well testing, and production testing on permafrost and nonperma gas in support of specified test operations; perform long-term hydrate production test on land in the United States Arctic region within 4 years after enactment of this Act; perform a long-term hydrate production test in a marine environment within 10 years after enactment of this Act; or expand education training

Comprehensive Fentanyl Control Act This bill expresses the sense of Congress regarding the trafficking in, and use of, illicit fentanyl. The bill amends the Controlled Substances Act to: (1) set the threshold for determining whether a controlled substance analogue is a “substantially similar” to a controlled substance; (2) impose enhanced penalties for manufacturing, distributing, or possessing with intent to distribute a controlled substance; (3) exclude from the definition of “controlled substance analogue” a substance that is intended for human consumption; and (4) expand the definition of “controlled substance analogue” to include Tableting machines, encapsulating machines, and controlled substance counterfeiting materials.

Commission on Probabilistic Methods Act - Directs the Administrator of the Research and Special Programs Administration of the Department of Transportation to establish the Commission on Probabilistic Methods to: (1) identify where and how probabilistic methods can help the Department; (2) assess the extent to which such methods can help the Department maximize return on investment and increase public safety; (3) evaluate the state of probabilistic methods technology; (4) identify the probabilistic techniques that are ready for practical use and recommend guidelines that can help a user decide what technique to use; (5) establish models for quantifying uncertainties in major Department programs that affect cost, operation, and performance; (6) identify key technology areas that must be further developed; (7) recommend guidelines for implementation of probabilistic technology; (8) recommend probabilistic-based guidelines for safety tests; (9) recommend guidelines for creating required database; (10) determine appropriate means of expediting technology transfer and ensuring that the principles of probabilistic methods are used appropriately in decisions involving funds under the control of the Department; (11) identify legal and cultural barriers to the effective use of probabilistic methods at the Department; (12) identify legal and cultural barriers to the effective use of probabilistic methods at the Department; (13) make recommendations for the use of probabilistic methods in Department programs; (14) make recommendations for institutionalizing probabilistic methods values at the Department; and (15) recommend

Plymouth 400th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act This bill directs the Department of the Treasury to mint and issue up to 100,000 $5 coins, 500,000 $1 coins, and 750,000 half-dollar clad coins emblematic of the landing and settlement of Plymouth Colony, Massachusetts, the signing of the Mayflower Compact, and the interaction of the indigenous Wampanoag people with the settlers. These coins may be issued only during a two-year period beginning January 1, 2020. Sales of such coins shall include specified surcharges, which shall be paid by Treasury as follows: 50% to Plymouth 400th Anniversary, Inc., to support the its work to develop, implement, and provide oversight for the commemorations surrounding the events of 2020-2021 and to be distributed, at the organization's discretion, to local historical preservation and cultural organizations to support their work in educating the public about the settlement of 1620 and their continued existence for the benefit of future generations; 15% to Wampanoag Tribes to support their work in educating the public about the life of the Wampanoag people prior to the Plymouth settlement and their interactions with the settlers; 15% to a Wampanoag tribal organization to continue programs to educate people about the life of the Wampanoag people prior to the Plymouth settlement and their interactions with the

Trade and Environment Reporting Act of 1994 - Directs the United States Trade Representative (USTR), before entering into negotiations for any free trade agreement or other major trade action, to consult with the Congress, appropriate advisory committees established under the Trade Act of 1974, and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in identifying environmental resources that may be affected by the agreement or any major trade action, determining the scope of the environmental assessment required under this Act, and issuing regulations which establish procedures for consultations and for public comment. <n>Requires the USTR to submit to the Congress an environmental assessment for each agreement, including: (1) identification of the potential effects of the agreement on environmental resources; (2) the environmental resources protection laws that may be affected; (3) measures to supplement the agreement that would minimize adverse effects; and (4) a detailed summary of the manner in which the results of consultations were taken into consideration with respect to the agreement. <n>Requires the USTR to submit to the Congress: (1) such an assessment after the free trade agreement is signed by the President; and (2) at least 60 days before the President transmits legislation to implement the agreement to the Congress. <n>Directs the USTR to report to the Congress on the effects of a free trade agreement on environmental resources, including

Local Emergency Health Services Reimbursement Act of 2002 - Amends the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 to appropriate $200 million for each of FY 2003 through 2007 for allotments to States for reimbursement of emergency health services furnished to undocumented aliens (presently such appropriations end after FY 2001). Sets forth formulas for the disbursement of funds by the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

Student Credit Card Transparency Act of 2009 - Amends the Truth in Lending Act to require creditors to report annually to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System on the terms and conditions of all business, marketing, and promotional agreements and college affinity card agreements with an institution of higher education, or an alumni organization or foundation affiliated with or related to such institution, with respect to any college student credit card issued to a college student at such institution. Requires such information to be aggregated with respect to each institution of higher education, alumni organization, or foundation affiliated with or related to such institution.<n><n>Directs the Comptroller General to periodically review such reports and report to Congress on the impact that college affinity card agreements and college student card agreements have on credit card debt.

Small Business Jobs Act of 2015 Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an employer with not less than 2 or more than 100 employees in a calendar year a business-related tax credit for the cost of up to 5 newly-hired employees who are employed, on average, at least 30 hours per week. Makes such credit available to tax-exempt eligible small employers.

Revolving Door Sunshine Act of 1993 - Amends the Government in the Sunshine Act to require a senior member of the Federal Government, after his or her service or employment as a senior member of the Government terminates, to file a five-year public disclosure report containing: (1) the name of any Member of Congress, and the name and title of any congressional staff member or of any officer or employee of any agency, to whom he or she makes an oral or written communication on behalf of anyone other than himself or herself or the United States during the five-year period beginning on the date on which his or her service or employment as a senior member of the Federal Government terminates, regarding an official action of the Congress or that agency; (2) a former senior appointee to report only a communication regarding an official action by an agency of which he or she was an officer or employee, an official action by the Congress that directly affects such an agency, or an official action relating to a matter in which he or she participated personally and substantially as such senior appointee; (3) the name, address, and telephone number of any person on whose behalf he or she makes such a communication; and (4) the name, address, and telephone number of any foreign government, foreign political party, or foreign business entity

Requires the independent analysis of such a regulatory action to include: (1) an analysis by the Comptroller General of the potential benefits, costs, and effects of the regulatory action, including any beneficial effects that cannot be quantified in monetary terms and the identification of those likely to receive the benefits; (2) an analysis by the Comptroller General of any alternative regulatory approaches that could achieve the same goal in a more cost-effective manner or that could provide greater net benefits, and, if applicable, a brief explanation of any statutory reasons why such alternatives could not be adopted; (3) an analysis of the extent to which the regulatory action would affect State or local governments; and (4) a summary of how the results of the Comptroller General's analysis differ, if at all, from the results of the agency's analyses in promulgating the regulatory action.Requires the Comptroller General to develop procedures for determining the priority and number of those requests for review that will be reported.Provides that Federal agencies shall cooperate with the Comptroller General by promptly providing necessary records and information.

New Jersey Ecosystem Protection Act of 1996 - Prohibits, as of September 1, 1997, the transport of dredged material (other than Category I or Category II material) for disposal at the Dump Site, New York Bight, New Jersey, other than for remediation purposes. <n>Prohibits dumping any Category II dredged material into ocean waters at the Dump Site, unless the applicant for a permit for transport under the Marine Protection Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972 has certified that the affected States or ports were requested to provide alternative sites and that such sites did not provide a reasonable alternative. <n>Prohibits dumping any dredged material in ocean waters outside of the New York-New Jersey Harbor, or into waters of the Port of New York-New Jersey, after September 1, 1997. <n>Authorizes the Secretary of the Army, in cooperation with the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, the Secretary of Transportation, State and local governments, and environmental and port interests, to designate, operate, and maintain a confined dredged material disposal facility or facilities within the New York Bight of the Port of New York and New Jersey Harbor.

Amends the Food Security Act of 1985 to reduce maximum annual direct and counter-cyclical commodity payments to $20,000 and $30,000, respectively. Revises limitation provisions for marketing loan gains, loan deficiency payments, and commodity certificate transactions, and establishes an annual combined limitation of $87,500 for such payments. Doubles payment limitations for single farming operations. Limits an individual to $275,000, with an exception for spouse equity.

Amends Federal provisions relating to the Court of Veterans Appeals to authorize the Court to provide funds for financial assistance to legal assistance entities for programs to ensure that financially needy veterans receive, without charge, legal assistance in connection with Court proceedings. Directs the Court to seek to provide funds for such purpose through a nonprofit organization selected by it. Authorizes appropriations.

Investing in Our Future Act of 2011 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) impose an excise tax on currency transactions, to be paid by or on behalf of a U.S. person; and (2) allow an exception from such tax for low-value currency transactions.

Gas Price and Refinery Capacity Relief Act of 2013 - Amends the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 to require the owner or operator of a refinery to submit to the Administrator of the Energy Information Administration (EIA) information describing: (1) the schedule of the refinery for any planned refinery outage, including the dates for the outage at least one year in advance of the date of the expected outage or the date the outage is scheduled; and (2) the estimated inventories and production of refined petroleum products during the period. Directs the Administrator, on an ongoing basis, to: (1) review information on planned refinery outages and unplanned refinery outages reported by refineries and that are available from commercial reporting services; (2) analyze that information to determine whether the scheduling of a planned refinery outage or an unplanned refinery outage may nationally or regionally substantially affect the price or supply of any refined petroleum product by decreasing the production of the refined petroleum product and causing or contributing to a retail or wholesale supply shortage or disruption; and (3) alert the Secretary of any refinery outage that the Administrator determines may nationally or regionally substantially affect the price or supply of a refined petroleum product. Directs the Secretary, upon a determination by the Secretary that a refinery outage may affect the price or supply of a refined petroleum product, to make available to refinery operators information

School-Based Respiratory Health Management Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to allow the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to give additional preference to states that require public elementary and secondary schools to certify that they have in place a plan for having on the premises of the school a school nurse or other trained individuals who are trained personnel of the school administer rescue medications for allergies and reversible lower airway disorders. Requires such a plan to include a comprehensive school-based allergies and reversible lower airway disorders management program that includes: (1) a method to identify all students with a diagnosis of allergies and reversible lower airway disorders; (2) an individual student allergies and reversible lower airway disorders action plan for each student; (3) allergies and reversible lower airway disorders education for school staff who are directly responsible for students who have been identified as having allergies or reversible lower airway disorders; (4) rescue medications for allergies or reversible lower airway disorders and emergency policies that are specific to the school; (5) efforts to reduce the presence of environmental triggers of allergies and reversible lower airway disorders; and (6) a system to support students with a diagnosis of allergies or reversible lower airway disorders through coordination with family members, primary care providers, and others as necessary.

Authorizes a complainant who seeks a determination by the Department of Agriculture on the merits of an eligible complaint and the complaint is not resolved by the Department within 270 days after it has been investigated to petition the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice to review the complaint and make recommendations to the Department of Agriculture to resolve it. Requires the Civil Rights Division to conduct the review, and make recommendations to resolve the complaint, within 30 days after the complainant files a petition.Allows access to review by the Department of Justice under this Act to any complainant with a complaint that: (1) is not considered an eligible complaint; and (2) is pending at the Office of Civil Rights of the Department on the date of enactment of this Act.

Freedom of Choice Act - Declares that it is the policy of the United States that every woman has the fundamental right to choose to: (1) bear a child; (2) terminate a pregnancy before fetal viability; or (3) terminate a pregnancy after fetal viability when necessary to protect her life or her health.<n><n>Prohibits a federal, state, or local government entity from: (1) denying or interfering with a woman's right to exercise such choices; or (2) discriminating against the exercise of those rights in the regulation or provision of benefits, facilities, services, or information. Provides that such prohibition shall apply retroactively.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 21, 2015. Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish and implement a Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Program to award grants to owners or operators of water systems for increasing the resiliency or adaptability of such systems to any ongoing or forecasted changes to the hydrologic conditions of a region of the United States. As a condition on receipt of a grant, an owner or operator of a water system shall agree to use the grant funds exclusively to assist in the planning, design, construction, implementation, operation, or maintenance of a program or project that meets specified purposes, including: conserving water or enhancing water use efficiency; modifying or relocating existing water system infrastructure made or projected to be significantly impaired by changing conditions; preserving or improving water quality; enhancing water management by increasing watershed preservation and protection; enhancing energy efficiency or the use and generation of renewable energy in the management, conveyance, or treatment of water, wastewater, or stormwater; supporting the adoption and use of advanced water treatment, water supply management, or water demand management technologies, projects, or processes; modifying or replacing existing systems or constructing new systems for existing communities or land that is being used for

Amends the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 to repeal the goal of achieving a zero mortality rate for a species or population stock of marine mammals that is equal to or less than ten percent of the potential biological removal of a given marine mammal species or population stock.

National Security Readiness Act of 2003 - Amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to prohibit the Secretary of the Interior from designating as critical habitat any lands or other geographical areas owned or controlled by the Department of Defense (DOD), or designated for its use, that are subject to an integrated natural resources management plan that addresses special management considerations or protection. Prohibits anything in this Act from affecting the obligation of DOD to comply with the Act, including the prohibition preventing extinction and taking of endangered species and threatened species.Amends the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 to define harassment" as: (1) any act that injures or has the significant potential to injure a marine mammal or marine mammal stock in the wild; or (2) any act that disturbs or is likely to disturb such a stock in the wild by causing disruption of natural behavioral patterns, including, but not limited to, migration, surfacing, nursing, breeding, feeding, or sheltering to a point where such behavioral patterns are abandoned or significantly altered.Authorizes the Secretary of Defense to exempt from compliance with such Act any action or category of actions undertaken by DOD or its components from compliance with any requirement of such Act if the Secretary determines that it is necessary for national defense. Makes such an exemption effective"

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2014. Rapid DNA Act of 2014 - (Sec. 3) Amends the DNA Identification Act of 1994 to require the Attorney General to establish separate standards: (1) for testing the proficiency of qualified agencies (i.e., booking stations, jails, prisons, detention centers, other law enforcement organizations, and facilities outside of forensic laboratories that can perform DNA analysis using sample-to-answer DNA systems on subjects meeting current legislative guidelines) and for testing the proficiency of operators of such systems; and (2) for DNA analyses of samples using such systems, as well as quality assurance guidelines recommended by the scientific working group on DNA analysis methods. Defines "qualified agencies" as those engaged in the intake, processing, booking, detention, or incarceration of individuals charged or convicted of qualifying offenses and the analysis of DNA samples is conducted on a sample-to-answer DNA analysis system. (Sec. 4) Defines: (1) "blind external proficiency test" as a test that is presented to qualified agencies through a second agency and appears to the operator to involve routine DNA samples for sample-to-answer DNA analysis systems, and (2) "qualified operator&quot

Child Nutrition Protection Act of 1994 - Amends the National School Lunch Act to direct the Secretary of Agriculture (Secretary) to establish procedures for nonprocurement debarment under certain child nutrition programs. <n>Directs the Secretary to establish procedures for nonprocurement debarment relating to specified food programs, including the school lunch, school breakfast, special milk, special nutrition, summer food service, and child and adult care food programs.

Rocky Mountain Front Heritage Act of 2013- Establishes the Rocky Mountain Front Conservation Management Area in Montana. Designates specified land within the Lewis and Clark National Forest in Montana as wilderness and as additions to existing components of the National Wilderness Preservation System (NWPS).

New Economy Workforce Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide that an immigrant visa may be made available to an alien who: (1) does not have a bachelor's degree (or higher degree) only if there is no qualified individual to whom such a visa may be made available who has such a degree; or (2) is not a high school graduate only if there is no qualified individual to whom such a visa may be made available who has such a degree or who is a high school graduate.<n><n>Prohibits an alien from being eligible for an employment-based immigrant visa unless he or she has a bachelor's degree (or higher degree).<n><n>Requires the Secretary of State to: (1) verify the authenticity of any foreign educational credential proffered by an alien; and (2) allocate family-sponsored immigrant visas to such individuals. Establishes the Foreign Degree Equivalence Account for the deposit of fees collected pursuant to this Act.

Federal Protective Service Reform and Enhancement Act of 2010 - Authorizes appropriations in FY2011 for the Federal Protective Service (FPS) to carry out counterterrorism functions, including law enforcement on federally controlled property, incident investigations, suspect capture and detention, 24-hour security alarm monitoring, nationwide dispatch services, and terrorism prevention. Authorizes full-time equivalent positions in the FPS inspector force that monitor performance of security personal services procured by contract. (Sec. 3) Grants the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS), acting through the FPS, the lead authority in the executive branch to carry out counterterrorism functions on federal property managed by the General Services Administration (GSA), including: (1) law enforcement on federally controlled property; (2) incident investigations; (3) suspect capture and detention; (4) 24-hour security alarm monitoring; (5) nationwide dispatch services; (6) facility security assessments; and (7) terrorism prevention. Authorizes the FPS to enter into agreements with other law enforcement authorities to provide security or respond to incidents on property under the jurisdiction and control of the Administrator of GSA. (Sec. 4) Directs the Secretary to submit to Congress a five-year budget outlook and strategic plan for FPS that includes: (1) estimates of staffing and associated costs the FPS requires to provide basic security functions, (2) estimates of staffing and associated costs the FPS

Cosmetology Tax Fairness and Compliance Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the credit for the portion of social security taxes paid with respect to employee tips, to make such credit applicable to employers of cosmetologists.Establishes provisions concerning returns relating to cosmetology services employers and information to be provided to cosmetologists.

Community Access to Emergency Defibrillation Act of 2001 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to States, political subdivisions, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations to develop and implement public access defibrillation programs by: (1) training and equipping local emergency medical services personnel to administer immediate care, including cardiopulmonary resuscitation and automated external defibrillation, to cardiac arrest victims; (2) purchasing automated external defibrillators, placing them in public places where cardiac arrests are likely to occur, and training personnel to administer cardiopulmonary resuscitation and automated external defibrillation to cardiac arrest victims; (3) setting procedures for proper maintenance and testing of such devices; (4) providing training to members of the public in cardiopulmonary resuscitation and automated external defibrillation; (5) integrating the emergency medical services system with the public access defibrillation programs so that emergency medical services personnel, including dispatchers, are informed about the location of such defibrillators in their community; and (6) encouraging private companies, including small businesses, to purchase such defibrillators and provide training for their employees to administer cardiopulmonary resuscitation and automated external defibrillation to cardiac arrest victims in their community.Directs the Secretary to give a preference to applicants that: (1) have a particularly low local survival rate for cardiac arrests, or

Preserving Access to Manufactured Housing Act of 2013 - Amends the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Dodd-Frank) to make it an unlawful employment practice for a retailer of manufactured or modular homes (or its employees) to engage in activities in excess of any compensation or gain received in a comparable cash transaction, unless such retailer or its employees receive compensation or gain for engaging in such activities in excess of any compensation or gain received in a comparable cash transaction. Amends the Truth in Lending Act to revise the definition of "high cost mortgage." Deems a consumer credit transaction by a first mortgage on a consumer's principal dwelling that is considered personal property (or is a consumer credit transaction that does not include the purchase of real property on which a dwelling is to be placed), at consummation, to exceed the average prime offer rate by specified percentages.

Fallen Timbers Battlefield and Fort Miamis National Historical Site Act - Establishes the Fallen Timbers Battlefield and Fort Miamis National Historical Site in Ohio.Withdraws the Site from such designation if the Secretary of the Interior determines and notifies the Governor of Ohio that: (1) its use, condition, or development is incompatible with the purposes of this Act; or (2) its management entity has not made reasonable and appropriate progress in preparing or implementing a management plan for the Site.

Deter Cyber Theft Act Requires the Director of National Intelligence (DNI) to report annually to Congress on foreign countries that engage in economic and industrial espionage in cyberspace with respect to U.S. trade secrets or proprietary information, including countries that engage in the most egregious forms of such espionage. Requires each report to: (1) identify countries that engage in such espionage, including countries that facilitate, support, fail to prosecute, or otherwise permit such espionage; (2) specify the countries that engage in the most egregious forms of such espionage; and (3) describe actions taken and progress made by federal agencies to decrease the prevalence of such espionage. Directs the President to: (1) direct the DNI to make it a priority to collect and analyze information to identify countries that engage in such espionage, and (2) direct U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to exclude certain articles from entry into the United States if the President determines that such exclusion is warranted for the enforcement of intellectual property rights or to protect the integrity of the Department of Defense (DOD) supply chain.

Office of Surgeon General Sunset Act - Terminates the Office of the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service and the position of such Surgeon General. Transfers all functions which the Surgeon General exercised before the enactment of this Act to the Office of the Assistance Secretary for Health.

Infrastructure Reinvestment and Economic Revitalization Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require the Secretary of Transportation to pay from time to time into the Infrastructure Reinvestment Fund amounts equivalent to 2.5 cents per gallon of excise taxes imposed between September 30, 1994, and before October 1, 2024. Establishes the Fund. Authorizes appropriations. Specifies that the maximum amount which the Secretary estimates may be fully amortized before October 1, 2024: (1) based on an amortization schedule comparable to a 30-year bond issued as part of the public debt; and (2) using only amounts appropriated to the Fund before such date. Requires repayment of advances made to the Fund after September 30, 2024, and requires interest on such advances to be paid under such terms and conditions as the Secretary shall prescribe. Specifies that no advance shall be made to the Fund after September 30, 2024, and all advances made to it shall be repaid on or before such date.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish an advisory committee under the Federal Advisory Committee Act to advise the Federal agencies with respect to any memorandum of understanding concerning the manner in which any authority of a Federal agency under any law is to be exercised within the Columbia/Snake River Basin and for the purpose of formulating recommendations concerning the manner in which such authority should be exercised. Conditions any such memorandum of understanding on the establishment of the advisory committee by the Secretary.

Establishes in the Department of Energy an Office of Global Climate Change which shall serve as a focal point for coordinating for the Secretary and Congress all departmental issues and policies regarding climate change and related matters.

Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Act of 1999- Amends the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 to direct the Secretary of Commerce to conduct a grant program to be known as the John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Grant Program to provide grants to eligible stranding network participants for the recovery or treatment of marine mammals, the collection of data from living or dead marine mammals for scientific research regarding marine mammal health, and facility operation costs directly related to those purposes. <n>Directs the Secretary to establish an advisory group to advise on implementation of this Act, including the award of grants. <n>Limits the amount of a grant to $100,000. <n>Requires the non-Federal share of the costs of an activity conducted with a grant to be 25 percent of such costs. Authorizes the Secretary to apply to the non-Federal share of an activity conducted with a grant the amount of funds, and the fair market value of property and services, provided by non-Federal sources and used for the activity. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Clear Creek National Recreation Area and Conservation Act of 2012 - Establishes the Clear Creek National Recreation Area in California, to promote environmentally responsible high-quality motorized and non-motorized trail based recreation, including off-highway vehicle use, scenic touring, access for hunting and collecting, while protecting ecological, geological, scenic, cultural, and historic resources, fish and wildlife values, and other resources of the landscape. Requires the development of a comprehensive management plan for such Area.

. Construction Reform, Authorization, and Choice Improvement Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to: (1) enter into an agreement with an appropriate non-VA entity to provide full project management services for a super construction project (expenditures exceeding $100 million) involving the construction, alteration, or acquisition of a medical facility, and (2) use industry standards, standard designs, and best practices in carrying out medical facility construction. The VA may not obligate or expend funds for advance planning or design for any super construction project until 60 days after it submits notice of such obligation or expenditure to the congressional veterans committees. A super construction project means one for the construction, alteration, or acquisition of a medical facility involving a total expenditure of more than $100 million (but does not include an acquisition by exchange). The VA may not obligate funds for a major medical facility project or a super construction project approved by a law that would cause the total amount obligated for that project to exceed the amount specified in the law for that project (or would add to total obligations exceeding such specified amount) by more than 10% unless the veterans committees each approve in writing the obligation of those funds. The VA may not obligate any funds for such a project unless each of

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that dividends received from domestic corporations shall be taxed as net capital gain.Provides for the treatment of dividends received from regulated investment companies and real estate investment trusts.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 8, 2014. Hurricane Sand Dunes National Recreation Area Act of 2014 - (Sec. 3) Establishes the Hurricane Sand Dunes National Recreation Area in Utah to provide for: (1) the enhancement of recreational uses, and (2) the use of off-highway vehicles. Excludes a proposed exchange parcel from the Recreation Area. (Sec. 4) Requires the Secretary of the Interior to convey to Utah all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to specified federal land in Washington County, Utah, in exchange for specified nonfederal land in the state. Requires the value of the federal and nonfederal lands exchanged to be equal or to be made equal.

Public Land Management Participation Act of 1997 - Amends the Antiquities Act to require the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to establish procedures to give Federal, State, and local governments and the public adequate notice and opportunity to comment upon and participate in the formulation of plans relating to the declaration of national monuments upon Federal lands pursuant to the authority of the Antiquities Act. <n>Requires the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture, prior to any recommendations for declaration of an area, to: (1) ensure compliance with all applicable Federal land management and environmental statutes, including the National Environmental Policy Act; (2) cause mineral surveys to be conducted by the Geological Survey to determine the mineral values, if any, present in such areas; (3) identify all existing rights held on Federal lands contained within such areas by type and acreage; and (4) identify all State lands contained within such areas. <n>Requires the President to advise the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives of his recommendations with respect to declaration as national monuments of each such area, together with a map thereof and a definition of its boundaries. Makes a recommendation of the President for declaration of a national monument effective only if so provided by an Act of the Congress. <n>Amends the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980

International and Foreign Language Studies Act of 2004 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 (HEA) to revise requirements for foreign language and area centers and programs, including by requiring such programs to support instructors of less commonly taught languages. (Current law requires such programs to support instructors of more commonly taught languages.) Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make grants to institutions of higher education for: (1) foreign language and area centers and programs; (2) stipends for undergraduate and graduate students in instructional programs with stated performance goals for functional foreign language use or in programs developing such goals, in combination with area studies, international studies, or the international aspects of a professional studies program; and (3) funds to promote foreign language and cultural knowledge. Requires a recipient of an undergraduate stipend to be engaged in an instructional program with stated performance goals for functional foreign language use or in a program developing such goals in combination with area studies, international studies, or the international aspects of a professional studies program. Authorizes the use of funds for undergraduate or graduate international studies and foreign language programs.

Long Island Sound Protection Act This bill amends the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972 to prohibit the dumping or transportation for purposes of dumping of dredged material from any federal or nonfederal dredging project that results in the production of more than 25,000 cubic yards of dredged material, unless the material is determined to have, or to cause (including through bioaccumulation) concentrations of chemical constituents that are not greater than those present in the water column, sediments, and biota of areas proximate to, but unaffected by, the proposed disposal site. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) must develop a dredged material management plan for the management of all dredged sediment in Long Island Sound, Fisher's Island Sound, Block Island Sound, Peconic Bay, and any harbor or tributary of such bodies of water.

Lending Enhancement Through Necessary Due Process Act - Amends the Federal Deposit Insurance Act and the Federal Credit Union Act to provide that directors, officers, or institution-affiliated parties of insured depository institutions shall not be deemed to have committed any violation or breach of duty in the making of: (1) any business judgment if the director disclosed an interest at or before the time the judgment was made or abstained from any vote taken in connection with such business judgment or from otherwise participating in the judgment; (2) any regulatory approval upon full and accurate disclosure of the relevant facts, approved the good faith practice, action, or omission which is alleged to be the violation or breach; or (3) unforeseeable economic conditions which develop after the occurrence of the practice, action, or omission and were the proximate cause of any loss experienced by the institution. Declares that directors, officers, or institution-affiliated parties shall not be deemed to have committed any violation or breach of duty if any examiner or other representative of an appropriate Federal banking agency or State bank supervisor, upon full and accurate disclosure of the relevant facts, approved the good faith practice, action, or omission which is alleged to be the violation or breach, whether or not such approval was communicated to the director, officer, or institution-affiliated party or any other

Rural Health Care Protection Act of 1997 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act with respect to the reclassification of hospitals as rural referral centers. Prohibits the Medicare Geographic Classification Review Board from rejecting an application for reclassification on the basis of any comparison between the average hourly wage of the hospital and the average hourly wage of hospitals in the area in which it is located. Declares that any hospital classified as a rural referral center by the Secretary of Health and Human Services for FY 1991 shall be classified as such a center for FY 1998 and each subsequent fiscal year. Declares that the provisions of such Act regarding budget neutrality and geographic reclassification shall apply to such reclassifications. Declares that for a requirement that the Secretary make a proportional adjustment in Medicare standardized payment amounts for inpatient hospital services to assure that geographic reclassifications of hospitals resulting from this Act do not result in an increase in aggregate payments under Medicare. Declares that a hospital may submit an application to the Board requesting a change in its classification for purposes of determining the disproportionate share hospital payment for FY 1998 if the hospital would be eligible for such a change in its classification but for its failure to meet the deadline for applications. Deems such an application approved for

Balanced Trade Restoration Act of 2006 - Directs the Secretary of Commerce to establish within the International Trade Administration a Balanced Trade Certificate Program to create gradually balance between the dollar value of goods imported into the United States and goods exported from the United States. Defines Balanced Trade Certificate" as a certificate that provides the holder of the certificate with a license to import into the United States a good with an appraised value that is equal to or less than the face value of the certificate."

Individual Investment Account Act of 1999 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a deduction for amounts contributed to individual investment accounts. Allows tax-free distributions, limited to $15,000 for all taxable years, from such accounts for use in the purchase of a principal residence by a first-time homebuyer. Makes such accounts tax-exempt unless the individual engages in prohibited transactions.

United States-Commonwealth of the Northern Marianas Human Dignity Act of 1996 - Amends Federal law to prohibit the affixation of the Made in the USA" label to a textile fiber product from the Northern Mariana Islands unless: (1) each worker producing such product was paid a minimum wage equal to or greater than a specified amount; and (2) the product was manufactured in compliance with all Federal labor laws, including, but not limited to, the National Labor Relations Act, the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, and the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. <n>(Sec. 3) Applies to the Northern Mariana Islands the minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, except that: (1) through December 31, 1997, the minimum wage applicable to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands shall be $3.55 per hour; (2) on January 1, 1998, and on July 1 and January 1 of each year thereafter, the minimum wage applicable to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands shall be $0.50 per hour more than the minimum wage that was applicable to it for the preceding six-month period until it is equal to the minimum wage rate set forth in the Act; and (3) after such minimum wage, the minimum wage shall increase as necessary to remain equal. <n>(Sec. 4)"

Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis Management Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to develop guidelines to be used on a voluntary basis to develop plans for individuals to manage the risk of food allergy and anaphylaxis in schools and early childhood education programs. Requires such guidelines to be considered an education record for purposes of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974.

Drug Price Competition Act of 2009 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to disqualify from being a first applicant" an applicant submitting an abbreviated new drug application (for a generic drug) to the Secretary of Health and Human Services on the first day an application is submitted for that drug or an applicant submitting an application for another generic drug. Defines "first applicant" as an applicant that submits an application on the first day an application is submitted for that drug or an applicant submitting an application for another generic drug that satisfies certain requirements but does not forfeit the 180-day exclusivity period (for a generic drug) provided for by current law. Requires an applicant that forfeits such exclusivity period to be eligible to receive immediately effective approval at a time before any other applicant has begun commercial marketing."

Veterans' Compensation Rate Amendments of 2001 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to increase, as of December 1, 2001, the rates of veterans' disability compensation, additional compensation for dependents, the clothing allowance for certain disabled adult children, and dependency and indemnity compensation for surviving spouses and children.

(Sec. 2) Sets forth criminal and civil penalties for violations of this Act, including manufacturer noncompliance and false reports to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.<n>(Sec. 3) Directs the Attorney General to determine the amount of a civil penalty that may be imposed for each day of violation by a manufacturer under this Act.

Hibben Center for Archaeological Research Act of 2002 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to construct and occupy a portion of theen Center for Archaeological Research at the University of New Mexico.Authorizes the Secretary to provide grants to the University for the Federal share of construction and related costs.Requires the University to offer to pay the Federal share of costs for the: (1) finishing the interior portion of the Center leased by the National Park Service; and (2) tenant improvement costs.Requires the University to provide to the Secretary for the long-term lease of the Center a portion of the Center for storage, research, and offices.Authorizes the Secretary to enter into cooperative agreements with the University, other National Park System units, and Indian tribes to: (1) curation and conduct research on artifacts in the museum collection; (2) develop, use, manage, and operate the Center; and (3) pay costs related to carrying out this Act.

Discretionary Spending Control Act of 2004 - Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 to extend discretionary spending limits through FY 2009, with adjustments for FY 2007 and 2008.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 5, 2003. The summary has been expanded because action occurred on the measure.) Occupational Safety and Health- Fairness Act of 2003 - Amends the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to revise requirements relating to enforcing, contesting, reviewing, and adjudicating citations, failures to correct, and willful violations.(Sec. 4) Requires that, in determining the appropriate penalty for a violation, the Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission (OSHRC) consider specified factors, including: (1) the size and financial condition of the employer; (2) the gravity of the violation; (3) the good faith of the employer; (4) the history and recentness of substantially similar previous violations at the same nonconstruction worksite and at construction worksites within the same State; and (5) the degree of responsibility or culpability for the violation of the employer, the employees, and/or other persons.(Sec. 5) Authorizes the President to extend the term of a OSHRC member to allow a continuation in service at the pleasure of the President after the expiration of that member's term until a successor nominated by the President has been confirmed to serve.(Sec. 6) Revises requirements for the award of attorney's fees

Homeland Security Volunteerism Enhancement Act of 2005 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish, as a component of the USA Freedom Corps, the Citizen Corps to coordinate homeland security volunteer activities.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to establish a Border Corps, to be administered by the Commissioner of the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection, under the Citizen Corps. States that members of the Border Corps shall be volunteers who agree to contribute services without compensation.<n><n>Requires the Border Corps to assist the United States Border Patrol. States that all citizens and legal permanent residents of the United States over 18 years of age shall be eligible to serve in the Border Corps.<n><n>Allows members of the Border Corps to assist the Border Patrol in: (1) line watch operations to prevent illegal entry and smuggling; (2) signcutting operations to detect and interpret disturbances in natural terrain conditions that indicate the presence or passage of people, animals, or vehicles; (3) traffic checkpoints to detect aliens unlawfully traveling into the interior of the United States and to detect illegal narcotics; (4) air operations; (5) horse and bike patrol; and (6) marine patrol.

Superfund Recycling Equity Act of 1995 - Amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to absolve persons (other than persons who arrange for the recycling of recyclable material) from liability for environmental response actions arising out of transactions involving such material. Declares that transactions deemed to be recycling of a recyclable material are considered to be such transactions if the person arranging for the transaction can demonstrate that: (1) the recyclable material met a commercial specification grade, was made available for use as a feedstock for the manufacture of a new salable product, and could have been a replacement for a virgin raw material or product made from a virgin raw material; (2) in the case of a transaction occurring not later than 90 days after enactment of this Act, the person exercises reasonable care to determine that the consuming facility was in compliance with Federal, State, or local environmental laws or regulations and any compliance order or decree issued pursuant to such laws or regulations; (3) in the case of a transaction involving scrap metal, the recyclable material could have been a replacement or substitute for a virgin raw material, or the product to be made from the recyclable material could have been a replacement or substitute for a product made from a virgin raw material; and (4) in the case of a transaction occurring after the effective date

Armed Forces Education Benefits Improvement Act - Increases the monthly rates of educational assistance under the Montgomery GI Bill for active duty members of the Armed Forces and Selected Reserve. Directs the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to study and report to specified congressional committees on the effect of all Montgomery GI bill educational benefits upon: (1) recruitment and retention; and (2) readjustment of veterans eligible for such benefits.

No Electronic Theft (NET) Act - Amends Federal copyright law to define financial gain" to include the receipt of, or expectation of receipt of anything of value, including the receipt of other copyrighted works. Amends the Federal criminal code to impose criminal penalties on persons who willfully infringe a copyright by reproducing or distributing, including by electronic means, during any 180-day period, one or more copies or phonorecords of one or more copyrighted works which have a total retail value of more than $1,000. Extends the statute of limitations for criminal copyright infringement from three to five years.Revises Federal criminal code provisions regarding criminal copyright infringement to provide for a fine and up to five years\\' imprisonment for infringing a copyright: (1) for purposes of commercial advantage or private financial gain, by reproducing or distributing, including by electronic means, during any 180-day period, at least ten copies or phonorecords of one or more copyrighted works which have a total retail value of more than $2,500; or (2) otherwise by reproducing or distributing one or more copyrighted works which have a total retail value of more than $1,000.Provides for: (1) up to three years\\' imprisonment and fines in any other such infringement case (without commercial gain intent), based on the retail value of the works; and (2) up"

Economic Modernization Act This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an employer a business-related tax credit equal to the sum of payroll taxes paid by an employer during the three-year period beginning with the day an employee begins work and the payroll taxes imposed by an employer for the period during which such employee was employed in a declining field. The bill also provides for an enhanced education tax credit for professionals in a short supply field.
