Workplace Religious Freedom Act of 1999- Amends the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to modify the definition of religion" to include all aspects of religious observance, practice, and belief unless, after initiating and engaging in an affirmative and bona fide effort, an employer demonstrates that it is unable to reasonably accommodate a religious observance or practice without undue hardship (action requiring significant difficulty or expense) on the conduct of the employer\\'s business. <n>Prohibits deeming an accommodation by the employer reasonable if the accommodation does not remove the conflict between employment requirements and the religious observance or practice. Excludes, in certain circumstances, a defense that the accommodation would be in violation of a bona fide seniority system. Prohibits requiring payment of premium wages for work performed during hours to which premium wages would ordinarily be applicable, if work is performed during such hours only to accommodate religious requirements of an employee."

Medicare Nonprofit Hospital Protection Act of 1997 - Amends part A (Hospital Insurance) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to prohibit payment with respect to inpatient hospital services of a hospital if the hospital, on or after January 7, 1997, was owned or controlled by a nonprofit entity and there is an impermissible transfer (as defined in this Act) with respect to the hospital or the entity.

Guidance, Understanding, and Information for Dual Eligibles (GUIDE) Act - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a three-year demonstration program under which the Secretary awards grants and contracts to appropriate, qualified community programs and clinics for individuals with intellectual or developmental disabilities or such programs described under the Public Health Services Act to employ qualified social workers and case managers to provide Medicare prescription drug assistance to target full-benefit dual eligible individuals.<n><n>Requires a program or clinic, as a condition of receiving a grant or contract, to collect and maintain data identified by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services as critical for the final evaluation and report to Congress.

Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to: (1) establish a process for the enrollment of Medicare Prescription Drug Plan eligible individuals under the Rx Option that is based upon the process for enrollment in Medicare+Choice plans under Medicare part C; and (2) provide a benefit for outpatient prescription drugs through private entities under the Rx Option equal to 50 percent of the lesser of the cost of such drugs for a year or $5,000. Provides a cost-of-living adjustment for such amount.

National Fish and Wildlife Policy Fellowship Program Act of 2004 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to award fellowships to qualified graduate and post-graduate level students engaged in advanced degree programs concerning freshwater and anadromous fish, wildlife, conservation management, or biology. Declares fellowship objectives to provide: (1) qualified graduate and postgraduate level individuals opportunities for participation in the policy process within the executive and legislative branches of the Federal Government; and (2) Federal agencies and Congress with specific expertise in fish and wildlife management and conservation biology to aid in the effective management of the Nation's natural living resources. Requires the Secretary to strive to ensure equal access for minority and economically disadvantaged students.

. Public Infrastructure Modernization Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretary of the Army to approve or disapprove a covered permit application for a public safety project on or before the last day of the two-year period beginning on the date of submission of the application, unless the Secretary does not approve or disapprove it on or before the last day specified in this Act: (1) the application shall be considered under the expedited process established under this Act, unless the governor of the state in which the project is to be located issues a declaration of emergency with respect to it; and (2) the Secretary may not require mitigation costs in an amount that exceeds 20% of the total cost of the project. Directs the Secretary to establish a process to expedite the consideration of such an application.

Worker Protection Against Combustible Dust Explosions and Fires Act of 2011 - Directs the Secretary of Labor, within one year after enactment of this Act, to promulgate an interim final standard regulating occupational exposure to combustible dust hazards, which shall apply to manufacturing, processing, blending, conveying, repackaging, and handling of combustible particulate solids and their dusts, including organic dusts, plastics, sulfur, wood, rubber, furniture, textiles, pesticides, pharmaceuticals, fibers, dyes, coal, metals, and fossil fuels. (Requires such standard to be based on National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) dust explosion standards and shall not apply to processes already covered by the occupational safety and health standard on grain facilities.)

Health Care Coverage Assistance for the Unemployed Act of 2001 - Directs the Secretary of Labor to establish a program under which premium assistance for COBRA continuation coverage shall be provided for qualified individuals. Limits the period of premium assistance to an individual on the earlier of: (1) the date the individual is no longer covered under COBRA continuation coverage; or (2) 18 months after the individual is first enrolled in the premium assistance program.

Amends Federal law to provide that the National Park Foundation (NPF) shall have exclusive authority to license or authorize persons to use specified trademarks and logos that are or may be in the future adopted and owned by the Foundation for the purposes of representing, promoting, or advertising for commercial purposes or pecuniary gain that an individual company or particular good or service is an official sponsor or official supporter of the National Park System or National Park Service. Subjects such authority to the prior written approval of the Secretary of the Interior and certain other conditions.

Two-Midnight Rule Coordination and Improvement Act of 2014 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to develop appropriate criteria for payment under title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act for payment for short inpatient hospital stays. Requires the criteria to: (1) account for medical necessity and the appropriateness of an inpatient stay that is less than the two-midnight benchmark, and (2) be developed in consultation with interested stakeholders. Directs the Secretary to develop a payment methodology under Medicare for hospitals for short inpatient hospital stays that: (1) is implemented in a budget-neutral manner, (2) may be a reduced payment amount for such inpatient hospital services than would otherwise apply if paid pursuant to a certain alternative payment methodology, and (3) takes into consideration the criteria developed under this Act. Directs the Secretary to develop general equivalency maps (crosswalks) to link the relevant ICD- 10 codes to relevant CPT codes, and the relevant CPT codes to relevant ICD-10 codes, in order to permit comparisons of inpatient hospital services, for which payment is made under Medicare, and hospital outpatient department services, for which payment is made under Medicaid. Directs the Secretary to develop: (1) a proposed ICD-10-to-CPT crosswalk; and (2) a second crosswalk between diagnosis-related group (DR

Voluntary Protection Program Act - Directs the Secretary of Labor to establish a program of entering into cooperative agreements with employers to encourage the establishment of comprehensive safety and health management systems that include: (1) requirements for systematic assessment of hazards; (2) comprehensive hazard prevention, mitigation, and control programs; (3) active and meaningful management and employee participation in the voluntary program; and (4) employee safety and health training. Sets forth requirements for such programs.

Bullying and Gang Prevention for School Safety and Crime Reduction Act of 2005 - Amends: (1) the Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act to cover bullying and gangs; and (2) the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize (with respect to juvenile accountability block grants) establishing and maintaining accountability-based programs that are designed to enhance school safety, which may include research-based bullying and gang prevention programs.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 5, 2016. Scotchman Peaks Wilderness Act of 2016 (Sec. 3) This bill designates certain National Forest System land in Idaho as the Scotchman Peaks Wilderness and as a component of the National Wilderness Preservation System. (Sec. 4) The wilderness area shall be administered by the Department of Agriculture (USDA). The bill withdraws the wilderness area from: (1) entry, appropriation, and disposal under the public land laws; (2) location, entry, and patent under the mining laws; and (3) disposition under the mineral leasing, mineral materials, and geothermal leasing laws. (Sec. 5) USDA may carry out management activities to maintain or restore fish and wildlife populations and habitats to support fish and wildlife populations within the wilderness area if such activities: (1) are consistent with relevant wilderness management plans; (2) are conducted in accordance with policies that create a protective perimeter or buffer zone around the wilderness area; and (3) would promote healthy, viable, and more naturally distributed wildlife populations that would enhance wilderness values. (Sec. 6) The bill requires USDA to ensure that Indian tribes have access to the wilderness area for traditional cultural and religious purposes and for the purpose of exercising any right reserved by treaty. (Sec. 7) The bill

Federal Land Exchange Improvement Act of 1995- Amends the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to require lands acquired by the Secretary concerned under specified land exchanges to be eligible for estimated equal value treatment based on the Consumer Price Index. <n>Directs that amounts received by the Secretary concerned from land exchanges be deposited in a special fund in the Treasury, subject to the availability of appropriations, which shall be available to the Secretary concerned for processing land exchanges. Limits amounts received by the Secretary concerned which would be added to such fund to such amount as miscellaneous receipts. <n>Requires: (1) an environmental assessment to be prepared for any exchange pursuant to the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (NEPA); (2) any conferencing or consultation required for an exchange pursuant to the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to be completed within 45 days after the date on which such conferencing is initiated; and (3) after completion of an exchange, no action may be taken on the non-Federal land acquired until the Secretary concerned has complied with NEPA and Endangered Species Act of 1973 concerning such action, and any necessary amendment to the land management plan applicable to such land. Declares that the non-Federal land to be included in any exchange shall be valued without the application of any Federal or State restriction concerning an environmental

Baseball Fans and Communities Protection Act of 1994 - Amends the Clayton Act to apply the antitrust laws to any unilateral terms and conditions of employment in restraint of trade or commerce imposed by any party to an agreement between two or more major league baseball clubs and the labor organization representing the baseball players. <n>States that the antitrust laws shall not apply to a term or condition imposed solely with respect to a player party to a uniform player contract that is assigned, at the time such imposition occurs, to a non-major league professional baseball club.

Wild Sky Wilderness Wilderness Management Act of 2004 - Designates certain Federal lands in the State of Washington (Wild Sky Wilderness) as wilderness and as a component of the National Wilderness Preservation System. Designates the Wild Sky Wilderness as a comprehensive part of the larger complex of adjacent and nearby wilderness areas. Authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to use helicopter access to construct and maintain a joint Forest Service and Snohomish County repeater site, in compliance with a Forest Service approved communications site plan, for the purposes of improving communication for safety, health, and emergency services. Prohibits the designation of the Wild Sky Wilderness from precludeing the operation and maintenance of the Evergreen Mountain Lookout in the same manner and degree in which it was occurring as of enactment of this Act. Directs the Secretary to assure adequate access to private inholdings in the Wild Sky Wilderness. Authorizes the use of floatplanes on Lake Isabel in the Wild Sky Wilderness, where such use was established before enactment of this Act, where such use shall be permitted to continue subject to such reasonable restrictions as the Secretary determines desirable. Designates specified Federal lands in the Skykomish Valley, Washington, as the Skykomish Backcountry Wilderness Management Area.

Identify Theft and Tax Fraud Prevention Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose a fine and/or prison term of up to five years on any person who knowingly or willfully misappropriates another person's tax identification number in connection with any document submitted to the Secretary of the Treasury. Increases the civil and criminal penalties for improper disclosure or use of tax information by tax return preparers. Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to implement a tax fraud prevention program under which: (1) a person who has filed an identity theft affidavit with the Secretary may elect to be provided with a unique personal identification number to be included on any federal tax return filed by such person or to prevent the processing of any federal tax return submitted in an electronic format by a person purporting to be such person; and (2) the Secretary will provide additional identity verification safeguards for the processing of any federal tax return filed by such person in cases where a unique personal identification number is not included on the return. Authorizes the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to transfer funds to the Enforcement account of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) for purposes of preventing and resolving potential cases of tax fraud. Directs the Commissioner to: (1) establish within the Criminal Investigation Division of the IRS the position of Local Law Enforcement Liaison; and (2) report

Reciprocity and Fairness in Foreign Investment Act - Prohibits a foreign person that is owned or controlled by the government of a foreign country from acquiring or holding an equity interest, or other evidence of ownership, in a business entity organized under the laws of the United States or in real property in the United States only to the same extent as that foreign country allows U.S. persons to acquire or hold such equity interests or other evidences of ownership in comparable business concerns in that country. Allows a foreign person to acquire or hold a property interest in, or control operations, management, or security operations of, critical infrastructure in the United States only to the same extent as the foreign country allows U.S. persons to acquire or hold equivalent property interests or other evidences of ownership in, or to control operations, management, or security operations of, comparable critical infrastructure in that country.

Amends the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity (LIBERTAD) Act of 1996 to direct the Secretary of State to deny a visa to, and the Secretary of Homeland Security to exclude from the United States, any alien who the Secretary determines is: (1) an officer or principal of an entity, or a shareholder who owns a controlling interest in an entity, that on or after May 2, 2006, makes an investment that equals or exceeds $1 million (or any combination of investments that in the aggregate equals or exceeds $1 million in any 12-month period), that contributes to the enhancement of Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources of its submerged lands; or (2) is a spouse, minor child, or agent of such person.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to waive such exclusion if the Secretary certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that: (1) admission is necessary for critical medical reasons or for purposes of litigation of an action under title III of the Social Security Act; or (2) such requirements have been satisfied.<n><n>Directs the President to impose certain economic sanctions against Cuba if a person has made an investment that equals or exceeds $1 million (or any combination of investments that equals or exceeds $1 million in any 12-month period) that contributes to the enhancement of Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources

(Sec. 2) Amends the Internal Revenue Code to make the two-percent floor on miscellaneous itemized deductions inapplicable to qualified professional development expenses paid or incurred by eligible kindergarten, elementary, and secondary school teachers. Defines such expenses as expenses: (1) for tuition, fees, books, supplies, equipment, and transportation required for the enrollment or attendance of an individual in a qualified course of instruction; and (2) for which a deduction is allowable under provisions relating to employer-provided educational assistance.(Sec. 3) Allows a limited tax credit to elementary and secondary school teachers who provide classroom materials.

Preserving and Reforming SSDI (PAR- SSDI) Act of 2016 This bill amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act (SSAct) to: require the Social Security Administration (SSA), in determining whether an individual is under a disability, to make such determination without regard to the individual's ability to communicate in English; prohibit the SSA from considering the individual's vocational background unless the individual had at least 16 quarters of coverage during the 24-quarter period ending with the quarter in which such month occurs; and require the SSA to prepare and implement a complete update of the vocational and educational factors considered in making disability determinations within five years. If for any week in whole or in part within a month an individual is paid or determined to be eligible for unemployment compensation, such individual shall be deemed to have engaged in substantial gainful activity for such month. The bill also revises the entitlement period for disability insurance benefits.

(Sec. 9) Authorizes the Board to impose conditions to encourage and expand competition between and among rail carriers in the affected region or the national rail system, if such conditions do not cause substantial harm to the benefits of the transaction to the affected carriers or the public.(Sec. 10) Authorizes the Board to grant temporary relief to remedy inadequate service.Declares that the Board's authority to grant such temporary relief does not extend to agreements affecting only the transportation of household goods.(Sec. 12) Authorizes appropriations to the Board for FY 1999 through 2002.(Sec. 13) Amends Federal transportation law to require the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, to designate the Chairman of the Board as the Chairman of the Surface Transportation Board.

Authorizes funds appropriated to the Architect of the Capitol (AOC) in any fiscal year to construct, operate, and maintain on a reimbursable basis battery recharging stations in parking areas under the jurisdiction of the House of Representatives for use by privately owned vehicles used by Members of Congress or covered employees. Defines covered employee" as: (1) an employee whose pay is disbursed by the Chief Administrative Officer (CAO) of the House; or (2) any other individual who is authorized to park in any parking area under the jurisdiction of the House on Capitol Grounds.<n><n>Directs the AOC to charge fees or charges for electricity provided to Members and covered employees sufficient to cover the costs to the AOC to carry out this Act, including costs to any vendors or other costs associated with maintaining the recharging stations. Requires: (1) the AOC to report on the financial administration and cost recovery of activities under this Act after each fiscal year to the House Committee on House Administration; and (2) the AOC to report to such Committee every three years determining whether Members, including any Delegate or Resident Commissioner, and covered employees using battery recharging stations authorized by this Act are receiving a subsidy from the taxpayers."

Traumatic Brain Injury Act of 2008 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to expand the national program for traumatic brain injury registries to include grants for a traumatic brain injury surveillance system.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to conduct a study to: (1) determine the incidence and prevalence of traumatic brain injury and related disability; (2) report national trends in traumatic brain injury; (3) identify common therapeutic interventions used for the rehabilitation of individuals with such injuries; and (4) develop practice guidelines for such rehabilitation.

Alternatives Opoids (ALTO) in the Emergency Department Act This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services to award grants to hospitals and emergency departments to develop, implement, enhance, or study alternative pain management protocols and treatments that promote the appropriate limited use of opioids in emergency departments.

Minority Business Development Improvements Act of 2009 - Directs the Director of the Minority Business Development Agency to establish the Minority Business Development Program to assist qualified minority businesses. Requires the Director to certify any entity as a qualified minority business any entity that: (1) not less than 51% of the entity is directly and unconditionally owned or controlled by historically disadvantaged individuals; (2) each officer or other individual who exercises control over the regular operations of the entity is a historically disadvantaged individual; (3) the net worth of each principal of the entity is not greater than $2 million; (4) the principal place of business of the entity is in the United States; (5) each principal maintains good character; (6) the entity engages in competitive and bona fide commercial business operations in not less than one sector of industry that has a North American Industry Classification System code; and (7) submits reports to the Director at such time. Prohibits this Act from being renewed.<n><n>Authorizes the Director to: (1) provide technical assistance to qualified minority businesses in writing business plans, marketing, management, and securing sufficient financing for business operations; (2) make loan guarantees of up to 90% for qualified minority businesses; and (3) enter into agreements with persons to provide technical assistance under this Act.<n><n>Authorizes appropriations.<n><n>Authorizes the Director to make

Individual Social Security Retirement Account Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to reduce the Old-Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance (OASDI) tax rates on employees and on employers. Applies the same reduction to the self-employed. Amends title II (Old-Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to establish an individual social security retirement account program through a payroll deduction plan.

Amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 regarding the innovative technologies loan guarantee program to require any guarantee to be made unless: (1) an appropriation for the cost has been made; (2) the Secretary of Energy has received from the borrower a payment in full for the cost of the guarantee and deposited such payment into the Treasury; or (3) a combination of appropriations under such Act or payments from the borrower has been made that is sufficient to cover the cost of the guarantee.<n><n>Prohibits the source of payments received from a borrower from being a loan or other debt obligation that is made or guaranteed by the federal government.<n><n>Authorizes the head of the loan guarantee program, upon a determination that there is a severe shortage of candidates or a severe hiring need for particular positions, to recruit and directly appoint highly qualified critical personnel with specialized knowledge important to the function of the programs under this Act into the competitive service. Makes such authority inapplicable to positions in the excepted service or the Senior Executive Service.<n><n>Terminates such authority on September 30, 2011.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 2, 2014. Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) Directs the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to establish a Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing program to guarantee the repayment of principal and interest on loans made by lenders to local governments, local redevelopment agencies, or BRAC redevelopment projects for the purposes of carrying out projects for redeveloping brownfields and promoting urban renewal. Requires a local government, agency, or project to be eligible to receive such a loan guarantee only if it submits: a master plan that meets specified requirements; a certification from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), or an entity designated by EPA, that the brownfield to be contaminated and expected to result from the remediation; and any other information the Secretary may require. Permits a loan to be guaranteed only if it meets specified requirements, including: the original principal amount of the loan shall not be less than $25 million and the total cost of the redevelopment project for which the loan is to be used shall not exceed the lesser of $150 million or 20% of the maturity of such loan. Prohibits a local government, agency, or BRAC redevelopment project from receiving such a

Medicare Fraud Enforcement and Prevention Act of 2010 - Amends title XI of the Social Security Act (SSA) to increase criminal penalties for both felony and misdemeanor fraud under SSA titles XVIII (Medicare) and XIX (Medicaid).<n><n>Adds a new offense of distribution of two or more Medicare or Medicaid beneficiary identification numbers or billing privileges with the intent to defraud.<n><n>Applies civil monetary penalties to: (1) conspiracy to make false statements or commit other specified offenses with respect to Medicare or Medicaid claims; and (2) knowing creation or use of false records or statements with respect to the transmission of money or property to a federal health care program. Extends the statute of limitations from six to 10 years after presentation of a claim.<n><n>Amends SSA title XI, as amended by the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, with respect to the access to claims and payment data granted to the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). Requires the Inspector General to implement mechanisms for the sharing of information about suspected fraud relating to the federal health care programs under Medicare, Medicaid, and SSA title XXI (Children's Health Insurance Program) (CHIP) with other appropriate law enforcement officials.

Television Viewer Privacy Act of 2003 - Prohibits, with limited exceptions, an interactive video-related service provider from collecting, maintaining, or disclosing any personally identifiable personal viewing information regarding a subscriber without the prior written or electronic consent of such subscriber, except: (1) to render, or conduct a legitimate business activity related to, the service provided; or (2) as provided by this Act.Provides that subscriber consent shall not be considered to be made unless the subscriber is provided a separate statement that clearly and conspicuously informs the subscriber of: (1) the nature of personally identifiable information collected or to be collected with respect to the subscriber and the nature and use of such information; (2) the nature, frequency, and purpose of any disclosure that may be made of such information; (3) the period during which such information will be maintained by the provider; (4) the limitations provided with respect to the collection, maintenance, and disclosure of such information; and (5) the methods by which such limitations may be enforced.Allows a provider to disclose such personally identifiable personal viewing information to the extent necessary to comply with a court order authorizing such disclosure to a governmental entity, but only if the subscriber is notified of such order by the person to whom the order is directed and that the subject of the information is reasonably suspected of engaging in

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to make the tax on prohibited transactions inapplicable to a qualified home equity participation arrangement (one in which up to $10,000 in an individual retirement plan is used to acquire an ownership interest in a dwelling unit that is to be used as the principal residence for a first-time homebuyer). Requires such ownership interest to be a fee interest requiring full repayment. Prohibits the use of loans used to purchase a principal residence for first-time homebuyers.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow individual taxpayers a tax deduction from gross income for premiums paid for coverage under a high deductible health care plan. Exempts from such deduction: (1) group health plan coverage; (2) medical and health savings accounts; and (3) employer contributions to a health savings account.

Motor Vehicle Owners' Right to Repair Act of 2005 - Requires the manufacturer of a motor vehicle sold or introduced into commerce in the United States to promptly provide to the vehicle owner, or to a repair facility of the vehicle owner's choosing, the information necessary to diagnose, service, or repair the vehicle. Requires such manufacturer to make available all non-emission-related service information, training information, and diagnostic tools on a non-discriminatory basis to any repair facility of the owner's choosing, and not limit such information to those repair facilities within the manufacturers' approved network. Directs that such information include: (1) the same service and training information related to vehicle repair that is made available to franchised dealerships; and (2) the same diagnostic tools and capabilities related to vehicle repair that are made available to franchised dealerships.

(Sec. 102) Requires any grant or contract entered into under the Act that involves the provision of health care items or services to individuals to include provisions to ensure that, to the extent feasible, any prescriptions provided for under such grant or contract are filled by providing the generic form of the drug involved, unless the nongeneric form of the drug is: (1) specifically ordered by the prescribing provider; or (2) requested by the individual for whom the drug is prescribed.(Sec. 103) Makes this Act applicable to grants or contracts entered into under the Medicare program, title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act, the Medicaid program, and programs affecting Indians, veterans, the uniformed services, and prisoners.(Sec. 105) Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to provide for coverage of generic drugs under Medicare part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program).Title II: Therapeutic equivalence requirements for generic drugs (sic) - Amends Federal law to require the Secretary, acting through the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, if a drug is approved as a generic form of a listed drug and the Secretary determines that such drug is therapeutic equivalent to the brand-name drug, to prescribe for nongeneric form of the drug the therapeutic equivalent of that drug, unless the non

Bank On Our Communities Act of 2009 - Amends the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 (EESA) to establish within the Treasury the Community Credit Renewal Fund to provide assistance to community banking institutions in an amount not to exceed $15 billion. Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to transfer $15 billion to the Fund for such purposes.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to provide assistance to any community banking institution, and a community banking institution to establish its long-term viability, by demonstrating its receipt of capital from investors other than the Secretary if: (1) the amount of capital to be received from the Secretary is equal to or greater than the amount to be received from the Secretary; (2) the aggregate amount of capital to be received from the Secretary and from investors other than the Secretary is determined, on the basis of a forward-looking assessment by the institution's management, to enable the community banking institution to remain well-capitalized even under a reasonably adverse economic scenario during the two-year period following receipt of such capital, and to increase the outstanding loans of the community banking institution, by December 31, 2010, such that the total amount of commercial and industrial loans is at least 5% greater than the smallest amount of such loans held by the community banking institution, as of any quarter-end in calendar year

No Qualified Teacher Left Behind Act of 2004 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA) to revise requirements for highly qualified teachers," for purposes of certain ESEA grants relating to teacher recruitment, retention, and professional development, to require that teachers be highly qualified by the end of the 2008-2009 school year if they: (1) have successful completion in each of their academic subjects of an academic major or minor, a graduate degree, State certification of sufficient college-level coursework, or advanced certification; or (2) pass a high objective uniform State standard of evaluation in each of their academic subjects. Requires that the consideration of any professional development being pursued be taken into consideration when determining whether teachers are highly qualified. Requires that a plan developed by a State or local educational agency ensure that all teachers who are meeting such eligibility criteria but are teaching in a rural school district are highly qualified by the end of such school year. Provides additional funding for such teachers in rural districts. Prohibits an entity from receiving any ESEA funds unless it ensures that all elementary school and secondary school teachers employed by the entity and teaching in core academic subjects are highly qualified by the end of the 2005-2006 school year."

Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2013 - Directs the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) (government sponsored enterprises or GSEs) each to carry out a program to provide for the refinancing of qualified mortgages on single-family housing they own or guarantee through a refinancing mortgage and for the purchase of and securitization of such refinancing mortgages. Requires such refinancing of a qualified mortgage upon the request of the mortgagor made to the applicable GSE and a determination by the GSE that it is a qualified mortgage. Defines "qualified mortgage" as one that: (1) is an existing first mortgage made for purchase of, or refinancing another first mortgage on, a one- to four-family dwelling that is occupied by the mortgagor as the principal residence of the mortgagor; (2) is owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac; and (3) was originated on or before this Act's enactment.

Student Loan Simplification and Opportunity Act of 2011 - Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to repeal the authority of the Secretary of Education to convert Direct Loans to Federal Family Education Loans (FFELs) upon the request of an eligible borrower.<n><n>Provides for a FFEL Debt Conversion Loan to be repayable by the borrower under the same terms and conditions as were applicable to the FFELs being repaid by the Secretary.

Information Classification Act of 1994 - Amends the National Security Act of 1947 to provide that information may be classified only if the interest of the public in knowing such information is outweighed by the damage to U.S. national security which demonstrably could be expected to result from the public release of such information. Specifies information that may be considered for classification as information that includes but is not limited to any of the following concerns: (1) the ability of the U.S. military to defend the Nation from armed aggression, engage in armed conflict, or participate in peacekeeping or multinational operations abroad; (2) the vulnerability of U.S. Government personnel, facilities, weapons technology, or related systems to armed attack, loss or compromise, or measures that would weaken their effectiveness or counter their capabilities; (3) diplomatic relations between the United States and another country or international organization of governments; (4) intelligence sources and methods, including those related to covert actions and cryptologic activities; and (5) the ability of the United States to apply critical research or technology to the national defense or foreign relations of the United States. Declares that information may be classified if at the time the original classification decision is made either of the following is identified or described: (1) Exceptionally grave damage to the national security of the United States which

Provides for the adjustment to permanent resident status of certain Haitian nationals (and spouses and children) who were physically present in the United States on December 1, 1995, and who are present in the United States on the date of application for such status adjustment.

Cancer Drug Coverage Parity Act of 2011 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), the Public Health Service Act, and the Internal Revenue Code to require a group health plan providing benefits for intravenously administered or injected anticancer medications to provide no less favorable coverage for prescribed, orally administered anticancer medication used to kill or slow the growth of cancerous cells and that has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Defines  anticancer medication" as a medication prescribed based on a finding by the treating physician that: (1) is medically necessary for the purpose of killing or slowing the growth of cancerous cells in a manner that is in accordance with nationally accepted standards of medical practice; (2) is clinically appropriate in terms of type, frequency, extent site, and duration; and (3) is not primarily for the convenience of the patient, physician, or other health care provider."

National Nurse Act of 2011 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to establish within the Office of the Surgeon General a full-time position to be known as the National Nurse for Public Health. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to: (1) initially appoint the individual serving as the Chief Nurse Officer of the Public Health Service as of this Act's enactment as the first National Nurse for Public Health, and (2) thereafter appoint the National Nurse for Public Health in accordance with Commissioned Corps Instruction CC23.4.6 (relating to Chief Professional Officer Nominations), as in effect on February 13, 2008. Grants the National Nurse the same rank and grade as the Deputy Surgeon General.<n><n>Lists duties of the National Nurse, including to provide leadership and coordination of Public Health Service nursing professional affairs for the Office of the Surgeon General and other agencies of the Service, to represent the Surgeon General and agencies of the Service in communications with groups and societies concerned with nursing issues at the local, state, national, and international levels, to conduct media campaigns, and to provide guidance and leadership for activities to promote the public health. Requires the National Nurse to: (1) participate in the identification of national health priorities; (2) encourage volunteerism and strengthen the relationship between government agencies and health-related national organizations

White House Inspector General Act of 1996 (sic) - Amends the Inspector General Act of 1978 to: (1) establish an Office of Inspector General (IG) in the Executive Office of the President; (2) require the IG to serve under the President's authority, direction, and control with respect to audits or investigations, or the issuance of subpoenas, which require access to information concerning ongoing criminal investigations, policy making, and national security (unless the President notifies the IG that disclosure of pertinent information would interfere with the core functions of his or her constitutional responsibilities); and (3) require the IG to comply with the same semiannual reporting requirements that all other IGs are subject to, plus, at a minimum, supply additional specified information as well. <n>Authorizes the President to prohibit the IG from carrying out or completing any audit or investigation, or issuing any subpoena, after the IG has decided to initiate, carry out, or complete such audit or investigation or to issue such subpoena if the President determines that: (1) the disclosure of that information would interfere with the core functions of his or her constitutional responsibilities; and (2) the prohibition is necessary to prevent such disclosure. Requires the President to notify the IG within 30 days after deciding that such prohibition is necessary. Requires the IG

Medicare, Medicaid, and MCH Tobacco Cessation Promotion Act of 2004 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to provide for coverage of counseling for cessation of tobacco use.

Competitive and Open Markets That Protect and Enhance the Treatment of Entrepreneurs Act of 2007 or the Compete Act of 2007- Amends the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 to revise requirements for attestation and reports by a registered public accounting firm on an issuer's internal control assessment. Requires such attestation and report to focus on the process and system management used to identify and manage risks, identify and implement key controls, and come to a conclusion on the effectiveness of internal controls over financial reporting. Excludes a separate opinion on the outcome of the assessment, including any pass or fail opinion by the auditor on the effectiveness of such controls.<n><n>Directs the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to develop: (1) standards for attestation and evaluations; and (2) a materiality standard.

Fair Justice Act of 2001- Establishes the Fair Justice Agency as an independent agency in the executive branch.Requires the Director of the Agency to be appointed, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, from among persons who are specially qualified to manage the full range of responsibilities of the Director.Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) pay; (2) travel expenses; and (3) investigative and prosecutorial authority.Authorizes the Director to investigate and prosecute any alleged misconduct, criminal activity, corruption, or fraud by a Department of Justice officer or employee.

Ensuring Quality in the Unemployment Insurance Program (EQUIP) Act - Amends title III (Grants to States for Unemployment Compensation Administration) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to require state unemployment compensation laws to require high-risk applicants for unemployment compensation to test negative for controlled substances within one week after receipt of compensation. Prohibits regular compensation from being paid to high-risk applicants: (1) for 30 days if they test positive for controlled substances; or (2) during the remainder of a benefit year if they test positive for controlled substances. Requires high-risk applicants to be responsible for the cost of any drug testing.

Commission on Homeland Security Act - Establishes the Commission on Homeland Security to study procedures to protect the security of the United States, including, but not limited to: (1) the efficiency and effectiveness with which Federal departments and agencies perform their security missions; (2) the adequacy of Federal personnel resources to perform security missions; (3) the adequacy and effectiveness of Federal controls over financial and information systems; (4) the accuracy, reliability, and security of personal identification information and systems used by the Federal Government under existing law; (5) how effectively Federal departments and agencies are organized to perform security missions; and (6) the effectiveness of relationships among the Federal Government, the States, and municipalities to protect security.

Indian Youth Telemental Health Demonstration Project Act of 2006 - Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants for the provision of telemental health services to Indian youth who: (1) have expressed suicidal ideas; (2) have attempted suicide; or (3) have mental health conditions that increase or increase the risk of suicide. Requires such grants to be awarded to Indian tribes and tribal organizations that operate facilities in Alaska and part of the Alaska Federal Health Care Access Network, reporting active clinical capabilities, or offering school-based telemental health services relating to Indian youth.

Nuclear Facility and Material Security Act of 2008 - Directs the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to issue a final rule requiring all commercial nuclear power reactors approved for construction after enactment of this Act to be designed to withstand a large commercial aircraft impact. Requires such rule to: (1) address the structural response, shock and vibration effects, and fire effects of the impact; and (2) ensure that important safety functions will operate for a sufficient period after the impact and the consequences will not result in a release of radioactive materials to the environment. Directs the NRC to issue a final rule: (1) requiring the configuration of spent fuel assemblies stored in spent fuel pools to minimize the risk of fire in the event they are drained during an accident or terrorist attack; (2) requiring spent nuclear fuel to be transferred from a spent fuel pool into dry cask storage at the earliest possible time that the heat load of the spent fuel material allows for such transfer to occur safely; and (3) providing for the incorporation of Independent Spent Fuel Storage Installations into the design basis threat rule issued under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954.<n><n>Directs the NRC to: (1) consider the likely consequences of a potential terrorist attack in any review it is required to undertake under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969; and (2) issue an Independent Spent Fuel Storage Installation

Olympic Commemorative Coins Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury, beginning in 1997, in each six-month period prior to the date upon which the Summer or Winter Olympic Games are held in a nation other than the United States, to issue commemorative one-dollar coins containing 90 percent silver and ten percent alloy. Requires the Secretary to develop an expanded multi-coin commemorative coins program in each year prior to such games in the United States. Prohibits the Secretary from issuing other coins in the first two months of each period. Requires all sales of such coins to include a surcharge of ten dollars per coin. Requires all surcharges received from such coin sales to be paid to the Corporation of the United States Olympic Committee to carry out the Amateur Sports Act of 1978. Declares that funds received by the Corporation under this Act shall be used to carry out such Act.

Bridge Ice and Snow Prevention Pilot Program Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to establish and implement a pilot program to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of the use of technologies to prevent ice, snow, and other adverse weather effects associated with freezing temperatures on bridges on the National Highway System. Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to not more than five states to conduct projects under the program. Limits to 20 the number of highway bridges that the Secretary may select for participation in the program.

Weather and Oceans Resources Realignment Act - Transfers the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to the Department of the Interior. Maintains NOAA as a distinct entity in the Department of the Interior.

Inflammatory Bowel Disease Research and Awareness Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to: (1) conduct, support, and expand existing epidemiology research on inflammatory bowel disease in pediatric and adult populations; and (2) award grants to, and enter into contracts and cooperative agreements with, patients or medical organizations with expertise in conducting such research to develop and administer the epidemiology program. Requires the Secretary, acting through the Director, to award grants to, and enter into contracts and cooperative agreements with, patients or medical organizations to increase awareness of inflammatory bowel disease among the general public and health care providers.

Public School Redefinition Act of 1993 - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make grants to State educational agencies to plan and implement charter public schools. <n>Sets forth program requirements, including that: (1) each State educational agency receive a grant to award grants to one or more charter public schools in the State to plan and implement a charter public school in accordance with this Act; and (2) each receiving a grant shall use such grant funds to plan and implement a charter public school in accordance with this Act. <n>Requires a charter public school, to receive a grant under this Act, to provide matching funds in the amount of: (1) ten percent of the grant payment received in the first year; and (2) five percent of such grant funds for the second and third years. <n>Requires each school, to receive a grant, to: (1) meet all State and local health and safety requirements; and (2) participate in an eligible partnership, which is a partnership between a sponsor and a charter public school. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Regulatory Capture Prevention Act of 2011 - Establishes in the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) the Office of Regulatory Integrity and the head of such Office shall be appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate.<n><n>Requires the Administrator of such Office, in order to defeat regulatory capture and related threats to the integrity of federal agencies, to investigate and report on the influence of concentrated economic interests on federal agencies and components that results in: (1) agency action or inaction that fails to advance the congressionally assigned mission of the agency or is otherwise inimical to the public interest; (2) regulation, licensing, adjudication, grants, or other agency action that favors a limited number of economic interests at the expense of the agency's congressionally assigned mission or is otherwise inimical to the public interest; (3) enforcement priorities that are not reasonably calculated to accomplish the goals of the regulatory program in question; or (4) a loss of confidence in the integrity of the regulatory process. Sets forth reporting requirements.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary has been expanded because action occurred on the measure.) Opportunities for Success Act - Directs the Secretary of Education to establish a grant program to support educational institutions in allocating funds to support eligible students attending internship activities. Directs that a qualifying educational institution receive the following grants for FY2013: (1) a grant to make professional internship awards to eligible students enrolled at the institution; (2) other federal financial aid office awards to full financial assistance to such students; and (3) a student development career center grant to eligible students. Prohibits the use of such grants to supplant federal financial aid received by non-qualifying educational institutions.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 21, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Middle East and North Africa Transition and Development Act - Declares that it is U.S policy to: (1) support a successful and sustainable transition to democracy in the Middle East and North Africa, including Egypt and Tunisia; and (2) increase economic prosperity in that region through financial investment and technical assistance and by utilizing the resources of appropriate multilateral development banks. Declares that the Secretary of the Treasury should instruct the U.S. Executive Director of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (the Bank) to promote such policies. Declares that the negotiating objectives of the United States with respect to an agreement to expand the use of the Bank's resources for countries located in the Middle East or North Africa should be to seek: (1) criteria that are consistent with the criteria described in this Act for the approval of loans or other assistance by the Bank to countries that become country of activity as a result of the implementation of the agreement; and (2) the establishment by the Bank of a credible mechanism to ensure that countries of activity that are not committed to the fundamental principles of multiparty democracy, pluralism, and market economics do not continue to benefit from

Housing Authority Funding Fairness Act of 2007- Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to authorize appropriations for FY2008-FY2012 for tenant-based rental assistance (vouchers) in public housing.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to provide renewal funding for each public housing agency: (1) based on leasing and costs from the prior year; (2) by making any adjustments necessary to provide for the first-time renewal of vouchers; and (3) by making other adjustments as the Secretary considers appropriate.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to provide amounts to any public housing agency, at its request, in an amount up to 2% of the allocation for the agency for the calendar year.

Youth Smoking Prevention Act of 1995- Denies the Secretary of Health and Human Services any authority under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act, or the Comprehensive Smokeless Tobacco Health Education Act of 1986 to regulate the manufacture, labeling, sale, distribution, and advertising and promotion of tobacco and other tobacco products containing nicotine. Declares that the Federal authority to regulate such products is established as a condition to the receipt by States of the Federal preventive health and health services block grant. <n>(Sec. 3) Amends the Public Health Service Act to require States to enact laws which: (1) prohibit the sale or purchase of tobacco and other tobacco products containing nicotine to an individual under the age of 18; (2) prohibit the presentation of such products with a document containing the individual's photograph and date of birth; (3) prohibit the sale of such products to individuals under age 18 to purchase them; (4) prohibit the operation of vending machines which dispense tobacco or smokeless tobacco products unless in plain view and under the direct supervision and control of the individual in charge of the location or such individual's designated agent or employee, except in the case of a vending machine located at a private club, in a bar or bar area of a food service

Alerting Lives through Effective and Reliable Technological Systems Act of 2008 or the ALERTS Act of 2008 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to: (1) establish a national integrated public alert and warning system; and (2) designate an agency within the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to receive, aggregate, validate, and authenticate homeland security and other information originated by authorized federal, state, local, and tribal governments to facilitate the transmission of the Commercial Mobile Alert System.

Medicare and Medicaid Provider Review Act of 1997 - Amends title XI of the Social Security Act, as amended by the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, to require certain health care providers to fund annual financial and compliance audits as a condition of participation under the Medicare and Medicaid programs.
Directs the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection to provide for the liquidation or reliquidation of certain entries relating to polyester lubricant RESIN from Canada and Mexico.

Directs the Secretary of State, at least annually, to provide detailed briefings to Congress on: (1) any discussions conducted between any executive branch agency and the government of Taiwan during the covered period (as defined by this Act); and (2) any potential transfer of defense articles or defense services to Taiwan.

Financial Crimes Resources Act of 2009 - Authorizes appropriations for FY2010-FY2012 to the Director of the United States Secret Service, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the Civil Division of the Department of Justice (DOJ), the Tax Division of DOJ, the offices of the United States Attorneys, the Inspector General of the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), the Chief Postal Inspector of the United States Postal Inspection Service, and the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts. Provides that such funds shall be used: (1) by the recipients to provide resources to investigate and prosecute criminal activity involving computers, crimes of fraud involving federal economic assistance and relief programs, and financial crimes, including mortgage fraud, securities fraud, and financial institution fraud; and (2) by the recipient for costs associated with providing defense services in cases in which a defendant is charged with such criminal activity.<n><n>Authorizes the Assistant Attorney General for the Office of Justice Programs of the Department of Justice to award grants to states to establish and develop programs to increase and enhance enforcement against criminal activity involving computers and financial crimes.

Student Medical Access Raising Test Scores Health Act, or the SMARTS Health Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make demonstration grants to eligible entities for the expansion of school-based health programs that are operated by such entities. Makes eligible for such grants: (1) entities that are public or nonprofit private institutions of higher education or local educational agencies; (2) programs of the National Institutes of Health; and (3) the National Center on Minority Health and Health Disparities.

Strategic Deterrent Sustainment Act of 2007 - Directs the Secretary of Defense to report to the congressional defense and appropriations committees on the capability of the U.S. industrial base to: (1) maintain, modernize, and sustain the Minuteman III intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) system until at least 2030; (2) replace such system with a follow-on land-based strategic deterrent system after 2030; and (3) extend the Minuteman III intercontinental ballistic missile system after 2020 and include in such report plans for extending such system after 2030. Requires the Comptroller General to submit a related report.

9/11 Commission Civil Liberties Board Act - Amends the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 to: (1) revise requirements for the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board; and (2) require the Board to be independent.

inal Well Production Preservation and Enhancement Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) increase the percentage depletion allowance for oil and natural gas produced from marginal properties; (2) modify the definition of depletable oil quantity" to include 1,000 barrels of heavy oil; and (3) extend the suspension of the taxable income limit on marginal production through 2011.<n><n>Amends the Clean Air Act to modify the definition of "wastewater treatment facility" to include produced water from an oil production facility.<n><n>Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to define "heavy oil" as domestic crude oil produced from any property if such crude oil had a weighted average gravity of 20 degrees or less (corrected to 60 degrees Fahrenheit)."

Authorizes the Merit Systems Protection Board to: (1) establish a three-year program to provide Federal employees and agencies with alternative dispute resolution processes to apply to workplace disputes and disagreements involving removals, suspensions for more than 14 days, and other adverse actions; and (2) test and evaluate a variety of alternative dispute resolution techniques.

Television Violence Reduction Through Parental Empowerment Act of 1993 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require television sets to be equipped with circuitry designed to enable viewers to block the display of channels, time slots, and programs. Prohibits any person from shipping, manufacturing, assembling, or importing any television not so equipped.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Distributions from Leaking Underground Storage Tank <n> Trust Fund <n> Title II: Compensation Programs <n>Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund Amendments Act of 1997 - <n>Title I: Distributions from Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund <n> Act of 1997 - Amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act to require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to distribute to States at least 85 percent of the funds appropriated to EPA from the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund each fiscal year for the reasonable costs under cooperative agreements of: (1) State actions under the EPA program for petroleum release responses; (2) necessary administrative expenses directly related to corrective action and compensation programs under State financial responsibility requirements; (3) other costs of such programs in any instance, as determined by the State, in which an owner's or operator's financial resources (excluding resources provided by such programs) are inadequate to pay the costs of a corrective action without significantly impairing the ability to continue in business; and (4) enforcement of an approved State or local underground storage tank (UST) program or similar provisions. Prohibits use of such funds to provide financial assistance to an owner or operator in meeting regulatory requirements for upgrading of existing UST systems.

. (Sec. 102) Authorizes appropriations for the U.S. Information Agency (USIA) to carry out international information activities, and educational and cultural exchange programs, as amended, the Mutual Educational and Cultural Exchange Act of 1961, as amended, Reorganization Plan No. 2 of 1977, the Radio Broadcasting to Cuba Act, the Inspector General Act of 1978, the Center for Cultural and Technical Interchange Between North and South Act, the National Endowment for Democracy Act, and for other purposes authorized by law. <n>(Sec. 103) Authorizes the USIA to carry out projects involving security construction and related improvements for Agency facilities not collocated with Department of State facilities abroad. <n>(Sec. 104) Declares that individuals contracted for personal service abroad shall not be regarded as U.S. Government employees for purposes of any law administered by the Office of Personnel Management. <n>(Sec. 105) Amends the Foreign Relations Authorization Act, Fiscal Years 1992 and 1993 to repeal a provision requiring that certain information disseminated abroad by the USIA be disseminated within the United States, its territories, or possessions, but on request, be made available following its release as information abroad to representatives of U.S. press associations, newspapers, magazines, radio and television systems

Jobs Now Act of 2017 This bill amends the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act to require the Department of Labor to carry out a two-year pilot program to award grants, on a competitive basis, to general local government units or community-based organizations to retain, employ, or train employees who provide them a public service. Priority in awarding grants shall be given to: units of general local government with high unemployment, foreclosure, and poverty rates; and community-based organizations located in units of general local government with high unemployment, foreclosure, and poverty rates.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for the coordination of the collection of domestic service employment taxes with the collection of income taxes. Applies such tax coordination to employers. Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to prepare and make available information on Federal tax obligations of employers with respect to employees performing domestic service in a private home.

Line Veto/Expedited Rescissions Act of 1993 - Amends the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 to allow the President an additional method of rescinding budget authority by the transmittal to the Congress, for expedited consideration, of one or more special messages proposing to rescind all or part of any item of budget authority provided in an appropriation bill. Limits the amount subject to rescission to 25 percent of the amount appropriated. Sets forth House and Senate procedures for the expedited consideration of such a proposal.

Helping Individuals Return to Employment Act or the HIRE Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Labor to award competitive grants for the hiring of unemployed individuals to perform work to benefit communities, under terms and conditions set forth in this Act.<n><n>Authorizes such grants to be awarded to any of the following entities in areas where the unemployment rate is higher than 7% during the three-month period preceding the award of the grant: (1) local government; (2) workforce investment boards; and (3) nonprofit organizations.<n><n>Limits the use of such grants to hiring unemployed individuals, including individuals age 16 and older, with priority going to individuals who have been unemployed for more than a year.<n><n>Prohibits an individual whose employment is funded under this Act from working for an employer at which a collective bargaining agreement is in effect covering the same or similar work, unless: (1) the consent of the labor organization at such employer is obtained; and (2) negotiations have taken place between such labor organization and the employer as to the terms and conditions of such employment.

Drug Trafficking Vessel Interdiction Act of 2008 - Amends the federal criminal code to impose a fine and/or prison term of up to 15 years for knowingly operating or attempting or conspiring to operate by any means, or for embarking in, any submersible vessel or semi-submersible vessel that is without nationality and that is navigating or has navigated into, through, or from waters beyond the outer limit of the territorial sea of a single country or a lateral limit of that country's territorial sea with an adjacent country, with the intent to avoid detection. Imposes an additional civil fine of up to $1 million for violations.

Directs the Customs Service, upon request, to liquidate or reliquidate certain entries of television sets and refund any amounts owed.<n><n>Provides that any amounts owed by the United States pursuant to the liquidation or reliquidation of an entry under this Act shall be paid not later than 180 days after the date of such liquidation or reliquidation.

Congressional Medal of Honor Memorial Coin Act of 2003 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue not more than 50,000 $5 gold coins and 250,000 $1 silver coins emblematic of the values and abilities necessary to earn the Congressional Medal of Honor.Directs that all surcharges received from coin sales be promptly paid by the Secretary to the Riverside National Cemetery Congressional Medal of Honor Memorial Committee to help finance the construction of a National Medal of Honor Memorial at Riverside National Cemetery.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Public Housing and Section 8 Rental Assistance <n> Title II: Federal Multifamily Housing <n> Program <n> Title III: Housing and Community Development <n> Title IV: Miscellaneous Provisions <n>Temporary Extension of Public Housing Reform Provisions Act of 1997 - <n>Title I: Public Housing and Section 8 Rental Assistance <n> Title II: Federal Multifamily Housing Program <n> Title III: Housing and Community Development <n> Title IV: Miscellaneous Provisions <n>Temporary Extension of Public Housing Reform Provisions Act of 1997 - Amends the Balanced Budget Downpayment Act, I, the Departments of Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development, and Independent Agencies Appropriations Act, 1996, and the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations for Additional Disaster Assistance, for Anti-terrorism Initiatives, for Assistance in the Recovery from the Tragedy that Occurred at Oklahoma City, and Rescissions Act, 1995 to extend through March 31, 1998, the public housing ceiling rent adjustments and income adjustments, and rental assistance provisions, of: (1) the Departments of Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development, and Independent Agencies Appropriations Act, 1996; (2) the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations for Additional Disaster Assistance, for Anti-terrorism Initiatives, for Assistance in the Recovery from the Tragedy that Occurred at Oklahoma City, and

Small Business Partners in Reconstruction Act of 2006 - (Sec. 3) Amends the Small Business Act to direct the Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy, in order to enable the federal government to purchase goods and service quickly and efficiently in times of disaster, contingency, or other emergency, while promoting small business utilization, to: (1) ensure that the Emergency Procurement Flexibilities Guidelines (A Framework for Responsive Contracting & Guidelines for Using Simplified Acquisition Procedures) continue to encourage the federal government to utilize the small business procurement flexibilities in this Act; (2) ensure that the Guidelines fully address all available small business procurement flexibilities, including those authorized for small businesses owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals, HUBZone (historically underutilized business zone) small businesses, and small businesses owned and controlled by service-disabled veterans; (3) periodically revise, update, or modify the Guidelines; (4) publish the Guidelines, as updated to comply with this Act, in the Federal Register; and (5) consult with the Administrator on any changes to the Guidelines.<n><n>Directs the Administrator to: (1) develop and conduct ongoing government-wide training on small business emergency procurement flexibilities; (2) designate at least one official to provide advice and assistance to the Office and other federal agencies on the use of such flexibil

Congressional Budget Office Improvement Act of 1998 - Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to establish a Congressional Budget Board and Economic Advisory Council. Directs the Office of Management and Budget to establish an Economic Advisory Council to: (1) review and make recommendations to the Board on activities undertaken by the Office; (2) evaluate the quality and objectivity of research performed by the Office and the reports that result from that research; and (3) undertake additional related tasks as the Board may direct.

Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to disburse a cash payment of $250 each non-cost-of-living adjustment to recipients of Social Security, Supplemental Security Income (SSI) under title XVI of the Social Security Act, railroad retirement benefits, and veterans disability compensation or pension benefits.

Endangered Species Criminal and Civil Penalties Liability Reform Act - Amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to provide that a person shall not be liable for any criminal or civil penalty for a violation of such Act committed while conducting an otherwise lawful activity and not for the purpose of a taking prohibited by such Act unless: (1) the Secretary of the Interior provides the person notice of the violation and the person fails to terminate and otherwise correct the activity constituting the violation within 30 days after such notice; and (2) a person may correct an activity by mitigation, entering into a binding commitment to carry out mitigation or other method determined by the Secretary to be reasonably calculated to restore the species to its status immediately before the activity.Directs that each conservation plan developed under such Act include provisions under which a person who has entered into, and is in compliance with, the plan may not be required to undertake any additional mitigation measures for species covered by the plan if the measures would require payment of money, or compliance with use, development, or management restrictions on any land, waters, or water-related rights, in addition to payments or compliance with such plan terms.Makes it an affirmative defense to the allegation that a defendant could not reasonably have known that the fish or wildlife or plant concerned is a member of

Reserve Component Tax Assistance Act of 2001- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) allow a deduction from gross income for the expenses paid or incurred by a member of a reserve component of the Armed Forces in connection with services performed; and (2) allow a reserve component employment credit and a qualified self-employment credit.

Amends Federal bankruptcy law to give priority in the payment of claims for retiree health benefits to holders of claims payable under chapter 7 (Liquidation) of the bankruptcy code. Gives a priority under chapter 11 (Reorganization) to a class of claims for retiree health benefits if liquidation is proposed in the plan. Declares that the plan provides: (1) for the continuation after its effective date of payment of all retiree benefits at the level established pursuant to the amendments made by this Act, at any time prior to confirmation of the plan, for the duration of the period the debtor has obligated itself to provide such benefits; and (2) if the plan provides for liquidation, for the payment of allowed unsecured claims for retiree health benefits, but only to the extent of the aggregate amount that represents $10,000 multiplied by the number of former employees with respect to whom a retiree health benefit accrues.

. (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Hoopa-Yurok Settlement Act to direct the Department of the Interior and the Department of Agriculture: (1) in consultation with the Yurok Tribe, to identify and private land available from willing sellers within and adjacent to or in close proximity to the Yurok Reservation in the aboriginal territory of the Yurok Tribe (excluding any land within the Hoopa Valley Reservation) as land that may be considered for inclusion in the Reservation; (2) to negotiate with the Tribe to determine, from such land, a land base for an expanded Yurok Reservation that will be adequate for economic self-sufficiency and the maintenance of religious and cultural practices; (3) to provide for consultation with local governments and other parties whose interests are directly affected concerning the potential sale or other transfer of land to the Tribe; (4) to report to Congress identifying any parcels of land within their respective jurisdictions that are determined to be within the land base negotiated; and (5) within 60 days after such report is submitted, convey to Interior in trust for the Yurok Tribe the parcels of land within their respective jurisdictions that are within that land base. Interior shall: (1) accept in trust for the Yurok Tribe the conveyance of such private land as the Yurok Tribe, or the United States on behalf of

Student Loan Evaluation and Stabilization Act of 1995 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 with respect to the Federal Direct Student Loan Program (FDSL Program) to limit the number of loans made under the Program in each academic year to five percent of the new loan volume for that year. Limits the total number of loans made and funded under the Program for any succeeding fiscal year to loans to students and parents of students attending eligible institutions that have applied and been accepted for participation in the Program on or before December 31, 1994. Declares that administrative expenses under the Program shall include the costs of annually assessing the Program. Authorizes appropriations.

Unemployment Insurance Modernization Act - Amends the Social Security Act to require the Secretary of Labor to make unemployment compensation modernization incentive payments in FY2008-FY2012 by certain transfers from the federal unemployment account to the accounts of the states in the Unemployment Trust Fund.

This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the tax exemption for charitable organizations, to require an organization applying for such exemption to disclose: (1) the names and addresses of any officer, director, trustee, or highly compensated employee of the organization who, at any time before the date of the application: (1) was a member or employee of an organization described in the bill, (2) was an unindicted coconspirator with respect to a terror finance scheme of an organization, or (3) was an employee of any charity found liable in the federal criminal code for a terror finance scheme. The bill also requires an organization to disclose in its annual tax return a statement that no officer, director, trustee, or highly compensated employee of the organization is described in the bill or in the statement.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2015. Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill increases the per diem payment under the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) comprehensive service program for homeless veterans who are placed in housing that will become permanent upon the termination of such services to a maximum of 150% of the per diem rate authorized for veterans receiving domiciliary care in state homes.
