(Sec. 3) The VA may provide per diem payments for furnishing care for a dependent under the care of a homeless veteran while the veteran receives VA services. (Sec. 4) The VA may enter into partnerships with public or private entities to fund a portion of the legal services such entities provide to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness related to housing, income support, and criminal defense.

Transfers administrative jurisdiction over specified lands in the State of Washington from the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the Bureau of Land Management (BLM), to the Secretary of Energy. Withdraws such lands from all forms of appropriation under the public land laws, including the mining and mineral leasing laws, and reserved for the use of the Hanford project of the Department of Energy.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 26, 2013. Small Business Tax Certainty and Growth Act of 2013 - Expresses the sense of the Senate that Congress should undertake comprehensive tax reform legislation to: (1) make our system fairer and simpler; and (2) promote economic growth. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) make permanent the reduction in the tax deduction for start-up expenses and organizational expenses, (2) allow individual taxpayers whose gross receipts do not exceed $10 million (currently, $5 million) to use a cash accounting method, (3) expand the definition of qualified small business entity" for purposes of the tax deduction for business start-up expenses, and (4) allow an annual inflation adjustment to the dollar amounts of the tax deduction for start-up expenses."

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 26, 2013. Flood Control Credit Act of 2013 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Army to apply credit for in-kind contributions provided by a non-federal interest that is in excess of the required non-federal cost-share for a water resources study or project, including credit for in-kind contributions provided to accelerate completion of a water resources study or project, toward the required non-federal cost-share for a different water resources study or project. Permits such credit only if the non-federal interest submits a comprehensive plan to the Secretary that identifies: (1) the studies and projects for which the non-federal interest intends to provide in-kind contributions for credit in excess of the non-federal cost share for the study or project, and (2) the studies and projects to which that excess credit would be applied. Directs the Secretary, in evaluating a request to apply credit in excess of the non-federal cost-share for a study or project toward a different study or project, to consider whether applying that credit will: (1) help to expedite the completion of a project or group of projects, (2) reduce costs to the federal government, and (3) aid the completion of a project that provides significant flood risk

Tax Relief for Long-Term Care Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow individual taxpayers an income-based tax credit for: (1) long-term care insurance premiums; and (2) expenses incurred for the care of family members or dependents with long-term care needs.

SCORE for Small Business Act of 2012 - Amends the Small Business Act to reauthorize the SCORE program (Service Corps of Retired Executives) for FY2013-FY2015.<n><n>Renames such program the SCORE program. Directs a volunteer participating in the program to: (1) provide at no cost to individuals who own, or aspire to own, small business concerns personal counseling, mentoring, and coaching relating to the process of starting, expanding, managing, buying, and selling a business; and (2) facilitate low-cost education workshops for individuals who own, or aspire to own, small business concerns.<n><n>Directs the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) to: (1) ensure that each volunteer participating in the program is adequately oriented and trained in the areas and disciplines necessary to ensure successful, outcome-oriented client interactions relating to the services provided; (2) ensure that the program and each of its chapters develop and implement plans and goals for outreach to individuals in rural, ethnically diverse, minority, and underserved communities, including a plan to recruit more diverse counselors; and (3) ensure that the program and each of its chapters develop and implement plans and goals to more effectively and efficiently provide services to individuals in rural areas, economically disadvantaged communities, and other traditionally underserved communities, including plans

Federal Air Marshals and Safe Sky Act of 2001 - Directs the Attorney General to establish a Federal Air Marshals program consisting of Federal Air Marshals, including those participating in the Federal Air Marshals Program being administered by the Federal Aviation Administration, and Deputy Federal Air Marshals in order to provide maximum security at airports and on board commercial aircraft.

Exempt Organization Simplification and Taxpayer Protection Act of 2013 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require a tax-exempt organization to notify the Secretary of the Treasury that it is operating as a tax-exempt organization within 60 days of its establishment. Requires such notice to include: (1) the organization's name, address, and taxpayer identification number; (2) the date on which, and the state under which, the organization was organized; (3) a statement of the purpose of the organization; and (4) an acknowledgment of receipt of such notice by the Secretary. Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) extend the 60-day period for reasonable cause; and (2) impose a user fee for submission of such notice. Requires the Secretary to require an organization to include on its first tax return filed that information required in support of its treatment as a tax-exempt organization. Establishes tax penalties for organizations that fail to notify the Secretary of intent to operate as a tax-exempt organization.

Eating Disorders Awareness, Prevention, and Education Act of 2003 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to authorize appropriations for programs to improve the identification of, training on, and educational awareness of eating disorders.Directs the Secretary of Education to carry out a program to develop, distribute, and promote the broadcasting of public service announcements to improve public awareness, and to promote the identification and prevention, of eating disorders.Requires the National Center for Education Statistics and the National Center for Health Statistics to study the impact of eating disorders on educational advancement and achievement.

Border Protection and Infrastructure Act of 1998 - Amends the Federal criminal code to set penalties for: (1) violence while eluding or committing a crime of violence during and in relation to attempting to elude or eluding customs, immigration, or agriculture inspection or failing to stop at the command of an officer of such agencies; or (2) an intentional violation of such requirements as set forth in specified provisions of the Federal Plant Pest Act, the Federal Noxious Weed Act of 1974, the Act of August 30, 1890, the Immigration and Nationality Act, and other Federal law. <n>(Sec. 3) Increases from two to five years the maximum term of imprisonment for a false statement offense. <n>(Sec. 4) Prohibits the master, operator, or person in charge of a vessel of the United States or a vessel subject to U.S. jurisdiction from failing to obey an order to heave to that vessel on being ordered by a Federal law enforcement officer. Prohibits any person on board a vessel of the United States or a vessel subject to U.S. jurisdiction from knowingly or willfully failing to: (1) comply with an order of a Federal law enforcement officer in connection with the boarding of the vessel; (2) impede or obstruct a boarding or arrest, or other law enforcement action authorized

. Women's Health Protection Act of 2015 (Sec. 4) This bill prohibits a federal, state, or local government agency or individual acting under color of law from: (1) denying or interfering with a woman's right to access an abortion, or (2) discriminating against an abortion provider based on the race, color, or national origin of the woman, the race of the child, or the disability of the woman. The bill defines "abortion" as any medical treatment, including the prescription of medication, intended to cause the termination of a pregnancy except for the purpose of increasing the probability of a live birth, to remove an ectopic pregnancy, or to remove a dead fetus. It defines "government" as a branch, department, agency, instrumentality, or individual acting under color of law of the United States, a state, or a subdivision of a state.

Provides for an extension of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 through July 31, 2009, for: (1) crop programs; (2) direct spending programs and authorities; and (3) specified appropriations and program terminations.

Outer Continental Shelf Permit Processing Coordination Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish a regional joint outer Continental Shelf (OCS) lease and permit processing coordination office for the Alaska region of the OCS and a regional joint OCS lease and permit processing coordination office for the Pacific region of the OCS. Directs the Secretary to enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Secretary of Commerce, the Chief of Engineers, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the head of any other federal agency that may have a role in permitting activities, and the head of each borough government located adjacent to any active lease area to carry out this Act.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 14, 2009. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Metro Accountability and Investment Act - Amends the Passenger Rail Investment and Improvement Act of 2008 to authorize appropriations to the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) for grants to the Metropolitan Washington Transit Authority (WMATA) for FY2009-FY2020 for capital and preventive maintenance projects, but only if the Secretary certifies that the WMATA Board of Directors has passed a resolution that: (1) establishes an independent budget authority for the Office of Inspector General of WMATA; (2) establishes an independent procurement authority for such Office; (3) ensures that such inspector general can obtain legal advice from a counsel reporting directly to the director; (4) requires the inspector general to submit recommendations for corrective action to the General Manager, the Board of Directors, and the appropriate congressional committees; and (5) requires the inspector general to publish on the Office of Inspector General website any recommendation that would pose a security risk to WMATA systems. Prohibits the use of specified amounts for grants to the WMATA under such Act unless the Secretary certifies that the Board of Directors has passed a resolution that: (1) establishes an independent budget authority for the Office of Inspector General; (2) establishes an independent procurement authority for the Office

Seniors Real Property Tax Relief Act of 1998 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a deduction for State and local real property taxes to certain low-income senior taxpayers. <n>Allows a deduction, of up to $2,000, for cash contributions to a senior citizen real property tax account.

Voluntary Opportunities for Increasing Contributions to Education Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to permit a tax credit for 75 percent of certain cash contributions by a taxpayer to a school tuition organization, for the improvement, renovation, or construction of a school facility used primarily for elementary or secondary education, or for the acquisition of computer technology or equipment, or for training related to the use of such technology or equipment, for use in a school facility. Sets a maximum credit of $100,000 for corporations and $500 for other taxpayers ($1,000 for a joint return).

Breast Cancer and Environmental Research Act of 2001 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Director of the National Institute of Environmental Health Services, based on recommendations from the Breast Cancer and Environmental Research Panel (established by this Act), to make grants, after a process of peer review and programmatic review, to public or nonprofit private entities for the development and operation of not more than eight centers for the purpose of conducting multidisciplinary and multi-institutional research on environmental factors that may be related to the etiology of breast cancer. Requires each such center to be known as a Breast Cancer and Environmental Research Center of Excellence.

Consumer Protection Home Inspection Counseling Act of 2012 - Amends the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Dodd-Frank) concerning home inspection counseling to direct the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to publish a Mortgagee Letter informing mortgagees of their obligation to provide such counseling.<n><n>Requires each person providing counseling for a housing counseling entity authorized, certified, or funded under the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968 to be trained through a voluntary home inspection training module and to distribute the counseling aids to be developed under this Act.<n><n>Requires any homeownership counseling program required under, or provided in connection with, any HUD-administered program to be provided only by organizations or counselors certified by the Secretary as competent to provide voluntary home inspection counseling.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to establish a comprehensive program to train HUD staff, contractors, individuals, and entities that provide housing counseling under the HUD-administered programs also to provide counseling to consumers on voluntary home inspections.<n><n>Requires the training program to include development of a training module to train counselors as well as counseling aids to be used by housing counselors and suitable for distribution to consumers.<n><n>Requires the training provided under the program to include: (1) Internet website references and information sufficient for counselors and homebuyers to

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the Senate on March 5, 2002. However, because action occurred on the measure, the summary has been expanded.)Permits the Secretary of Transportation to enter into contracts with, and enter into cooperative agreements with, State highway offices and other experienced driving safety organizations to obtain and distribute educational materials on rumble strip installation on Pennsylvania roads to prevent drift-off crashes.Directs that certain funds under this Act be used to assess the effectiveness of continuous rumble strips to reduce drift-off crashes.

Teachers For Tomorrow Act of 2001- Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to establish new programs for teacher student loan forgiveness, under the guaranteed loan program and the direct loan program.Makes eligible for such student loan forgiveness any new borrower on or after October 1, 1998, who is employed as a full-time teacher in a public elementary or secondary school and who: (1) is teaching a subject area relevant to the borrower's academic major as certified by the chief administrative officer of the public secondary school in which the borrower is employed; and (2) has a State certification or license to teach, and has not failed to comply with State or local accountability standards.Directs the Secretary to establish a formula that ensures fairness and equality for applicants in the selection of borrowers for such loan repayment under this section, based on the amount available.Limits the portion of the outstanding loan obligation which the Secretary may repay to 25 percent for the first or second year of such service, and 50 percent for the third year.

Assistance for Orphans and Other Vulnerable Children in Developing Countries Act of 2004 - Amends the United States Leadership Against HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria Act of 2003 to require that not less than ten percent of amounts appropriated for HIV/AIDS assistance for FY 2006 through 2008 be expended for assistance for orphans and other vulnerable children affected by HIV/AIDS.
Authorizes appropriations. Requires the Comptroller General to report to Congress before the conclusion of the three-year project recommending whether or not Congress should permanently authorize it.

Department of Veterans Affairs Health Professionals Education Debt Reduction Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to carry out a Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Education Debt Reduction Program to assist VA personnel serving in health care positions in reducing the amount of education debt incurred in completing educational programs that qualify such personnel for such service. Makes eligible for such Program any individual (other than a physician or dentist) who owes: (1) any amount of principal or interest under a loan used by or on behalf of the individual to pay costs relating to a course of education or training at a qualifying educational institution which course led to a degree that qualified the individual for the position; or (2) any amount of principal or interest under a loan the proceeds of which are being used by or on behalf of the individual to pay costs relating to a course of education or training at a qualifying educational institution which course leads to a degree that qualifies the individual for such a position. Directs the Secretary, in selecting individuals for such Program, to give preference to: (1) individuals who have completed or are engaged in, as the case may be, a two-year or four-year course of education or training at an undergraduate institution leading to a degree that qualified or qualifies, as the case may be; or (2) individuals who serve

Promoting Regional Energy Partnerships for Advancing Resilient Energy Systems Act or the PREPARE Act (Sec. 4) This bill requires the Department of Energy (DOE) and the Department of the Interior to provide technical assistance for developing energy strategies and plans that help harmonize and promote national, regional, and state energy goals, including goals for advancing resilient energy systems to mitigate risks and prepare for emerging energy challenges. DOE and Interior may enter into cooperative agreements with states and Indian tribes to develop and implement energy strategies and plans to address the energy challenges of states, Indian tribes, and regions. A cooperative agreement must provide: (1) the purpose and goals of the agreement; (2) the roles and responsibilities of the states or Indian tribes and DOE in implementing the agreement; (3) a comprehensive framework for the development of energy strategies and plans for states, Indian tribes, or regions; (4) timeframes with associated metrics and objectives; (5) a governance structure to resolve conflicts and facilitate decisionmaking consistent with underlying authorities; and (6) other provisions determined necessary by DOE and Interior. DOE must assign or employ individuals who have expertise in the technical and regulatory issues relating to the cooperative agreement.

Community Hazard Assessment and Mitigation Program Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Homeland Security, acting through the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Administration (FEMA), to provide grants to certain areas to prepare for a tsunami. Requires the Director to give priority to areas in which the likelihood of a tsunami striking in the next 50 years is 10% or greater. Declares that, in addition to the priority given, the Director shall award a grant on a competitive basis to emergency management departments on a financial need, benefit to the community, and a demonstrated ability to cooperate with other providers of emergency services.Authorizes emergency management departments to use grant funds to: (1) establish or improve warning systems; (2) purchase public safety agency communications gear and reverse 911 systems; (3) reinforce buildings and facilities in maintaining continuity of critical services; (4) purchase public safety agency rescue equipment; and (5) develop outreach programs to educate residents and tourists of different types of tsunami.Requires emergency management departments with populations between 20,001 and 50,000 to provide: (1) 20% of the total cost of a project established with a grant under this Act; and (2) 10% of the total cost of a project established with a grant for a project serving an area with a population under 20,000.

Corporate Tax Dodging Prevention Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that, for taxable years beginning after 2013, the income of a controlled foreign corporation derived from any foreign country shall be considered "subpart F income" (income of a controlled foreign corporation earned outside the United States that is not tax deferred). Amends the Internal Revenue Code to limit or repeal the foreign tax credit for large integrated oil companies which have gross receipts in excess of $1 billion and an average daily worldwide production of crude oil of at least 500,000 barrels for a taxable year. Defines a "large integrated oil company" as one which had gross receipts in excess of $1 billion and an average daily worldwide production of crude oil of at least 500,000 barrels for the taxable year.

Digital Television Transition Extension Act of 2009 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to extend the transition of television broadcasting from analog to digital to June 13, 2009. Requires the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to extend for a 116-day period the licenses for recovered spectrum, including the license period and construction requirements associated with those licenses. Extends to July 31, 2009, the deadline for requesting digital-to-analog converter box coupons. Requires the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information to issue such coupons for each household that expired without being redeemed.

Veterinary Workforce Expansion Act of 2005 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award competitive grants to eligible entities for the purpose of improving public health preparedness through increasing the number of veterinarians in the workforce. Authorizes appropriations.

Cooperative Agricultural Programs Extended Retirement Credit Act of 1993 - Provides for creditable service under the Civil Service Retirement System for periods performed before January 1, 1984, as an employee of a State, or an instrumentality of a State, in which capacity such individual performed duties relating to specified Department of Agriculture cooperative programs.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on September 19, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Verifying Official Totals for Elections Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to prohibit a voting system used in a state in a federal election from containing or using any election-dedicated voting system technology which is not deposited by the state (or, at the state's option, by the vendor) with the National Software Reference Library of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) prior to the date of the election, to be held in escrow and subject to disclosure in accordance with this bill. If the chief state election official certifies to the NIST Director before the election that, because of a revision to the technology made less than 30 days before the election, the state or vendor is unable to deposit it in accordance with this bill, the voting system used in the election may contain or use it if: (1) the chief state election official approves its use; and (2) the state or vendor deposits it in accordance with this bill within one week after the election. The Department of Justice may bring a civil action against a vendor in appropriate district court if the vendor fails to deposit the technology according to this bill

National Hurricane Research Initiative Act of 2006 - Requires the Under Secretary for Oceans and Atmosphere of the Department of Commerce and the Director of the National Science Foundation (NSF) to establish a National Hurricane Research Initiative and to cooperate with other federal agencies to carry it out. Sets forth reporting requirements.

Employment Non-Discrimination Act of 1994 - Prohibits employment discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation by covered entities, including entities receiving Federal financial assistance. Declares that this Act does not apply to the provision of employee benefits to an individual for the benefit of his or her partner. Exempts religious organizations from this Act. Declares that this Act does not apply to the relationship between the United States and members of the Armed Forces. Declares that this Act does not repeal or modify any Federal, State, territorial, or local law creating special rights or preferences for veterans. Grants enforcement powers to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the Librarian of Congress, and the Attorney General. Declares that a State shall not be immune from an action in a Federal court of competent jurisdiction for a violation of this Act. Provides for State immunity. Makes the United States liable for all remedies under this Act to the same extent as a private person and liable to the same extent as a nonpublic party for interest to compensate for delay in payment. Declares that attorneys' fees shall not be immune from suit under this Act.

Second Chance Voting Rights Act of 2006 - Declares that the right of a U.S. citizen to vote in any election for federal office shall not be denied or abridged because that individual has been convicted of a criminal offense. Applies this Act to an individual convicted of a criminal offense upon the unconditional release of that individual from incarceration for that offense and the completion of sentence for that offense, including parole. Authorizes the Attorney General, in a civil action, to obtain such declaratory or injunctive relief as is necessary to remedy a violation of this Act. Allows a private right of action.

Filipino Veterans Fairness Act - Amends federal veterans' benefits provisions to: (1) revise the eligibility requirements for veterans of World War II, Commonwealth Army veterans, and new Philippine Scouts for disability compensation; (2) provide $100 per month for disability compensation for veterans who reside in the Philippines and have a service-connected disability or are new Philippine Scouts; and (3) direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to furnish outpatient health care and other services to such veterans and scouts on an outpatient basis at the Manila VA Outpatient Clinic.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an individual a deduction from gross income for up to $5,000 of the interest paid on medical education loans for the taxpayer to perform full-time services in a rural community for a period of 24 consecutive months after completion of education. Defines a rural community" as any political subdivision of a State which has a population of 5,000 or less and a per capita income of $15,000 or less."

Clean Water Infrastructure Financing Act of 2005- Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to remove certain requirements for States with respect to construction of treatment works under capitalization grant agreements.Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to assist States in establishing simplified procedures for small water systems to obtain assistance under the Act.Requires revolving funds to be used only for providing assistance for activities that have as a principal benefit the improvement or protection of water quality of navigable waters.Provides for an extended repayment period and loan guarantees for financially distressed communities.Reauthorizes appropriations for FY2006-FY2010 for the revolving fund program.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on December 7, 2015. Protecting Workplace Advancement and Opportunity Act (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Department of Labor to publish the final rule entitled "Defining and Delimiting the Exemptions for Executive, Administrative, Professional, Outside Sales and Computer Employees" (July 6, 2015) in the Federal Register not later than 60 days after the enactment of this Act. The final rule shall: (1) set the federal minimum salary threshold 20 percent higher than the minimum salary threshold under any state law effective on the date of enactment of this Act, and (2) deny exemptions for Medicare or Medicaid dependent health care providers.

Eastern Sierra Rural Heritage and Economic Enhancement Act - Designates the following areas in California as wilderness areas and as components of the National Wilderness Preservation System: (1) certain land in the Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest, which shall be deemed to be a part of the Hoover Wilderness; and (2) certain land in the Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest, which shall be deemed to be a part of the Emigrant Wilderness.

Cocopah Lands Act - Requires the Secretary of the Interior to take certain land in Yuma County, Arizona, into trust for the Cocopah Indian Tribe, if the Tribe transfers title of the land to the Secretary and there are no recognized environmental problems with, or adverse legal claims to, the land. Declares that such land shall become part of the Tribe's reservation.

National Ice Fund Act of 2015 Establishes the National Ice Fund in the Treasury to be used only for: (1) construction, alteration, and renovation of icebreakers for the Coast Guard, including design work related to such construction, alteration, and renovation; and (2) lease or charter of icebreakers for the Coast Guard. Requires all funds appropriated to the Department of Defense (DOD) or any other federal agency for such purposes to be used for such purpose. Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to accept from any person, foreign government, or international organization any contribution of money, personal property, or assistance in-kind for support of icebreakers in accordance with procedures prescribed by the Secretary. Prohibits the use of Fund amounts: (1) to lease, construct, alter or acquire a vessel capable of ice-breaking, in any way, located in a foreign country; or (2) for missions related to research and resupply in the Antarctic department.

United States Marshals Service 225th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury, in commemoration of the 225th anniversary of the establishment of the United States Marshals Service, to mint and issue $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins emblematic of the 225 years of exemplary and unparalleled achievements of the U.S. Marshals Service.

Authorizes the President to conclude an agreement with Mexico to establish a binational commission to be known as the United States-Mexico Border Health Commission. Declares that it should be the duty of the Commission to: (1) conduct a needs assessment in the United States-Mexico border area to identify and resolve health problems that affect the general population of the area; and (2) formulate recommendations for a fair method by which the government of one country would reimburse a public or private person in the other country for the cost of a health care service furnished to a citizen or resident alien of the first country who is unable to pay for the service. Permits the Commission to perform additional functions as it determines appropriate, including to: (1) conduct or sponsor investigations, research, or studies designed to identify, study, and monitor health problems that affect the general population in the border area; and (2) provide financial, technical, or administrative assistance to public or private persons who act to prevent, resolve, or educate such population concerning such health problems.

Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award a grant to Teach For America, Inc., to implement and expand its program of recruiting, selecting, training, and supporting new teachers. Requires that such grant funds be used to: (1) provide highly qualified teachers to high need local educational agencies in urban and rural communities; (2) pay the cost of recruiting, selecting, training, and supporting new teachers; and (3) serve a substantial number and percentage of underserved students.

EQIP Improvement Act of 2018 This bill amends the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) to modify the conservation quality incentives program. (EQIP provides financial and technical assistance for agricultural producers and land owners to implement certain conservation practices.) The bill modifies EQIP to: establish a cap on payments for certain practices and expand the definition of "high-priority practice" to include certain aquaculture facilities; require the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to coordinate with states regarding conservation effects assessments and to provide guidance that states should use as a primary factor in allocating program funds for high-priority practices; modify eligibility requirements for rural water districts and associations to qualify for EQIP assistance; require USDA to provide technical assistance and best practices guidance to participants; and increase funding for the program.

Directs the Secretary of Transportation to investigate and hold a public hearing on a petition submitted by the sponsor of a commercial service airport claiming that fares for scheduled air transportation at the airport are unreasonably high, or that competition between air carriers at the airport is inadequate. Requires an air carrier providing air transportation at the airport to provide such information as the Secretary considers necessary to making findings in response to the petition.

Declares that specified provisions of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act respecting family offices shall apply to any family office that: (1) has no clients other than family clients; (2) is owned, controlled, or operated primarily for the benefit of family clients; and (3) does not hold itself out to the public as an investment adviser.

Immigrant Children's Educational Advancement and Dropout Prevention Act of 2001 - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to direct the Attorney General to cancel the removal of, and adjust to permanent resident status, certain (inadmissible or deportable) alien secondary or higher education students under the age of 21 with qualifying years of U.S. residency.

Authorizes the issuance of a special nonimmigrant visa to an alien who: (1) on May 8, 2008, was a resident of the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and was a permanent resident, an immediate relative of a citizen, or the parent of a citizen under 21 years old; and (2) on the transition program effective date, was lawfully present in the Commonwealth or only temporarily absent from the Commonwealth pursuant to immigration laws of the Commonwealth. Allows such visa-eligible parents to apply for a special nonimmigrant visa. Requires such visa to be valid until the earlier of: (1) the date the alien's child petitions for adjustment to permanent resident status to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence; or (2) November 28, 2014.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Trucking's Law - Directs the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) to implement a pilot program to address the shortage of long-term parking for commercial motor vehicles on the National Highway System (NHS).<n><n>Directs the Secretary to allocate such funds among states, metropolitan planning organizations, and local governments, with priority to applicants that: (1) demonstrate a severe shortage of commercial motor vehicle parking capacity in the corridor to be addressed; (2) have consulted with affected state and local governments, community groups, private providers of commercial motor vehicle parking, motorist and trucking organizations; and (3) demonstrate that the proposed projects are likely to have positive effects on highway safety, traffic congestion, or air quality.<n><n>Authorizes appropriations for FY2010-FY2015.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on February 15, 2016. Intermodal Shipping Container Security Act (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Under Secretary of Homeland Security for Border and Transportation Security (DHS) to take into account the National Maritime Transportation Security Plan. The plan incorporates relevant aspects of the National Maritime Transportation Security Plan and addresses all modes of commercial transportation to, from, and within the United States. (Sec. 3) DHS shall submit to specified congressional committees a strategic plan for integrating security for all modes of transportation by which intermodal shipping containers arrive, depart, or move in interstate commerce that: (1) takes into account the security-related authorities and missions of all federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies that relate to the movement of intermodal shipping containers via air, rail, maritime, or highway transportation in the United States; and (2) establishes a goal to create a comprehensive, integrated strategy for intermodal shipping container security that encompasses the authorities and missions of all those agencies and sets forth specific objectives, mechanisms, and a schedule for achieving that goal. DHS shall: (1) consult with all federal, state, and local government agencies responsible for security matters that affect or relate to the movement of intermodal shipping containers via air, rail, maritime, or highway transportation in the

Amends the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 to direct the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to develop an independent safety assessment procedure and, at the request of a Governor of a State in which a nuclear facility is located, conduct an assessment if the licensee of such facility has: (1) applied to the NRC for an extension of the operating license of the licensee, or for approval of an extended power uprate for the licensee; or (2) during any five-year period, received, under the reactor oversight process, two or more greater-than-green inspection findings. Prescribes inspection requirements.

Older Driver and Pedestrian Safety and Roadway Enhancement Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to establish and implement a roadway safety enhancement program for older drivers and pedestrians to improve roadway safety infrastructure in all states in a manner consistent with the recommendations included in the publication of the Federal Highway Administration entitled Highway Design Handbook for Older Drivers and Pedestrians" (FHWA-RD-01-103), dated May 2001 or as subsequently revised and updated.<n><n>States that the purpose of the program is to achieve a significant reduction in roadway fatalities and serious injuries among drivers and pedestrians 65 years of age or older on all public roads.<n><n>Authorizes states to obligate funds for the planning, design, and construction of infrastructure-related projects that employ safety enhancement recommendations set forth in the Handbook to: (1) improve safety at intersections, interchanges, rail grade crossings, and roadway segments; (2) make systemic roadway safety improvements on public roads; and (3) improve roadway safety on other sections or elements of public roads that a state transportation department identifies as hazardous for older drivers and pedestrians."

Real Estate Transparency Act of 2007- Amends the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974 to require a mortgage originator, not later than three days after an applicant applies for a federally related mortgage loan, to provide to such applicant a written agreement itemizing all of the fees that such applicant may be charged by the mortgage originator, including origination fees, underwriting fees, broker fees, and any other fees to be charged at or before the settlement of such loan to be paid to the mortgage originator.<n><n>Requires each originator fee agreement to set out three methods for the payment of such fees: (1) payment in cash before or at settlement; (2) adding such fees into the total loan amount to be borrowed; and (3) increasing the interest rate of the loan. Requires: (1) each applicant for such a loan to choose one of such payment methods; and (2) each mortgage originator of a federally related mortgage loan to explain each of the payment options to each applicant before accepting any payment.<n><n>Requires: (1) each applicant for such a loan to have agreed to and signed such originator fees agreement; and (2) such agreement to include all fees to be charged to such applicant by independent third parties, including government agencies at or before settlement of the loan, plus all escrows reserves which may be required of that

Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to carry out a program of training to provide eligible veterans with skills relevant to the job market. Defines such veterans as those: (1) whose military occupational specialty at the time of discharge is determined by the Secretary to have limited transferability to the civilian job market; (2) who are not otherwise eligible for education or training services; (3) who have not acquired a marketable skill since leaving military service; and (4) who was discharged under conditions not less than general under honorable conditions. Requires the program to provide payments to employers who provide for eligible veterans a program of apprenticeship or on-the-job training if: (1) such program is approved; (2) the rate of pay for veterans participating in the program is not less than that for nonveterans in similar jobs; and (3) the Secretary reasonably expects that the veteran will be qualified for employment in that field upon completion of training and the employer will hire the veteran at the completion of training.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the expensing allowance for Gulf Opportunity Zone property placed in service after August 28, 2005, and placed in service before December 31, 2007. Defines Gulf Opportunity Zone" as that portion of the Hurricane Katrina disaster area determined by the President to warrant individual or individual and public assistance from the federal government under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act by reason of Hurricane Katrina."

Enhanced Veteran Healthcare Experience Act of 2011 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to provide certain eligible veterans with hospital care, medical service, rehabilitative or preventative health services (covered services) that are provided by a non-VA provider whom the Secretary enters into a contract with if the Secretary determines that VA facilities are not capable of furnishing such services: (1) economically because of geographical inaccessibility; or (2) because such facilities lack the required personnel, resources, or ability. Revises the requirements for providers of covered services under such contract.

Federal Probation System Reform Act - Amends the Federal criminal code to require the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts to ensure that an appropriate probation officer or pretrial services officer supervises a person who is required to wear an electronic monitoring device as a condition of probation or release. Requires the Director to ensure that such an officer: (1) conducts a daily review of any data produced by the device; and (2) conducts an investigation immediately following an alert produced by such device that requires an investigation, including contacting the person, inspecting such device, and documenting the alert and the response taken.Establishes within the Office of the Inspector General for Probation and Pretrial Services the Office of the Inspector General for Probation and Pretrial Services.

National Fab Lab Network Act of 2013 - Establishes the National Fab Lab Network (NFLN), as a federally nonprofit corporation, to facilitate the creation of a national network of local labs, and serve as a resource to assist stakeholders with the effective operation of labs. Defines a " lab" as a facility equipped with an integrated suite of fabrication tools to convert digital designs into functional physical things and scanning tools to convert physical things into digital designs and available for a range of individual and collaborative educational, commercial, creative, and social purposes.

Post-Deployment Health Assessment Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Defense to issue guidance for the provision of an in-person mental health screening for each member deployed in connection with a contingency operation: (1) at a time during the period beginning 180 days before the deployment in connection with the operation and ending 90 days before the deployment in connection with such operation, (2) at a time during the period beginning 90 days after the date of redeployment from such operation and ending 180 days after the date of redeployment from such operation, and (3) not later than each of six months, 12 months, and 18 months after such screening. Provides screening exceptions. Terminates such screening requirements after the individual's discharge or release.

Reliable Farm Safety Net Act - Amends the Federal Crop Insurance Act to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to provide emergency financial assistance to agricultural producers who incur qualifying weather-caused crop losses in a federally-declared disaster area. Makes producers ineligible for crop disaster assistance if they did not: (1) get Federal crop insurance for insurable commodities; and (2) file required paperwork and pay related fees for noninsurable commodities. Directs the Secretary to provide assistance for livestock losses located in a federally-declared disaster area.

Green River National Wildlife Refuge Act of 2002 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish the Green River National Wildlife Refuge which shall consist of specified land and water in Kentucky.Requires the Secretary to revise the boundaries of the Refuge to carry out its purposes or to facilitate the acquisition of land, water, and interests in land or water within the Refuge.

Access to High Standards Act - Directs the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to State educational agencies or local educational agencies to increase access for low-income students to advanced placement courses and advanced placement tests to earn advanced placement and credits at institutions of higher education.

Continued Dumping or Subsidy Offset Act of 1999 - Amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to declare that, whenever continued dumping or subsidization is found to exist by the administering authority or by operation of law, any duties assessed shall be distributed as continued dumping or subsidy offsets to the affected domestic producers for qualifying expenditures on an annual basis. <n>Limits qualifying expenditures to expenditures incurred after the issuance of the antidumping duty finding or order or countervailing duty order in any or all of the categories of plant, equipment, research and development, personnel training, acquisition of technology, employer-paid employee health care and pension benefits, and environmental equipment, training, or technology. <n>Directs the Commissioner of the United States Customs Service to prescribe offset disbursement procedures. Sets forth general procedures for notification of eligible parties. <n>Requires the Commissioner to establish a special account in the Treasury to receive all antidumping or countervailing duties, including interest, for distribution according to this Act, within 14 days after an antidumping or countervailing duty order takes effect.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on June 19, 2014. National Care Corps Act of 2014 - (Sec. 3) Establishes in the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) the National Care Corps, through which National Care Corps members provide approved services to individuals in need via participation in local Care Corps programs. Requires the Secretary of HHS, acting through the Administrator for Community Living, to appoint a Director of the Corps. Sets forth the Director's duties with respect to Corps membership and eligibility. (Sec. 4) Requires an individual, to be eligible for membership in the Corps, to: be at least 18 years of age on or before December 31 of the calendar year in which the individual begins participation in the Corps; agree to participate in the Corps for a period of up to 24 months; submit an application to the Director at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Director may require; pass a criminal background check; and agree to comply with such terms and conditions as the Director may require. Directs the Director to request a criminal background check before selecting any individual for membership in the Corps. Makes an individual ineligible to be a Corps member if: (1) such individual refuses to consent to the criminal background check, or

Criminal Gang Activity Act of 2004 - Amends the Federal criminal code to include within the definition of criminal street gang" a formal or informal group, club, organization, or association of three or more individuals, who act in concert, or agree to act in concert, with a purpose that any of these persons alone, or in any combination, commit or will commit: (1) two or more predicate gang crimes after this Act\\'s enactment and the last of which occurs not later than ten years after the commission of a prior predicate gang crime; or (2) any act or threat which is chargeable under Federal or State law and punishable by imprisonment for more than one year involving murder, attempted murder, manslaughter, gambling, kidnapping, robbery, extortion, arson, obstruction of justice, tampering with or retaliating against a witness, victim, or informant, burglary, sexual assault, carjacking, or manufacturing, importing, distributing, possessing with intent to distribute, or otherwise dealing in a controlled substance or listed chemicals. Defines: (1) "predicate gang crime" as any act or threat which is chargeable under Federal or State law and punishable by imprisonment for more than one year involving murder, attempted murder, manslaughter, gambling, kidnapping, robbery, extortion, arson, obstruction of justice"

Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017 This bill amends the federal criminal code to prohibit and punish the straw purchasing of firearms. A straw purchase occurs when: (1) a person buys a firearm from an unlicensed seller on behalf of a person prohibited by law from possessing one, or (2) a person buys a firearm from a licensed dealer on behalf of another person. Any person that commits, attempts, or conspires to commit a straw purchasing offense is subject to a fine and/or prison term of up to 15 years (25 years if the firearm is used to commit a crime of violence). The bill expands the penalty for committing a firearms trafficking offense.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 7, 2016. Drinking Water Affordability Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Safe Drinking Water Act to revise requirements concerning national primary drinking water regulations, including by: removing a requirement that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) maintain, or provide greater, protection of human health when revising those regulations; extending the repayment schedule for loans from the drinking water state revolving funds (SRFs); authorizing states to protect public drinking water source areas; removing federal reporting requirements if state or local requirements are not as stringent as federal requirements; and requiring the EPA to conduct a review on best practices for streamlining the application process for public water systems to receive loans or loan guarantees from an SRF as well as best practices for administering SRFs efficiently. The bill directs the EPA to exempt public water systems from federal cross-cutting requirements if the state in which the systems are located has a requirement that is as stringent as the federal requirement. The Government Accountability Office must report on federal cross-cutting requirements and public water systems that receive loans or loan guarantees under the Act.

Justice for Sergei Magnitsky Act of 2010 - Makes an alien ineligible for entry or admission to the United States when the Secretary of State determines such alien to be: (1) an individual who engaged in any act that was instrumental in causing the death of Sergei Magnitsky; (2) an individual who conspired to defraud the Russian Federation of taxes on corporate profits because of fraudulent transactions and lawsuits against the Hermitage foreign investment company; or (3) the spouse, son, daughter, or parent of such alien.<n><n> Revokes any visa issued for such person. Authorizes the Secretary to waive such prohibition if in the United States national security interest.<n><n>States that such provisions shall cease to be effective when the Secretary certifies to Congress that: (1) the government of the Russian Federation has conducted a thorough and impartial investigation into Mr. Magnitsky's detention and death, and the responsible individuals have been brought to justice according to the Russian Federation's laws and pursuant to its international legal obligations; (2) the government of the Russian Federation has taken steps to bring its criminal justice and penal systems into compliance with international legal standards; and (3) the United States is confident that the investigation was properly conducted.

Marketplace Fairness Act (Sec. 2) This bill expresses the sense of Congress that states should have the ability to enforce their existing sales and use tax laws and to treat similar sales transactions equally, without regard to the manner in which the sale is transacted, and the right to collect-or decide not to collect-or decide not to collect: taxes that are already owed under state law. (Sec. 3) Each member state under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement (the multistate agreement for the administration and collection of sales and use taxes adopted on November 12, 2002) is authorized to require all sellers not qualifying for a small-seller exception to collect and remit sales and use taxes with respect to remote sales under the provisions of the Agreement, beginning no earlier than the first day of the calendar quarter that is at least 90 days after the enactment of this Act. A state that is not a member state under the Agreement is authorized to require all sellers not qualifying for the small-seller exception to collect and remit sales and use taxes (but only if the state adopts and implements minimum simplification requirements). Such authority shall commence no earlier than the first day of the calendar quarter that is at least six months after the state enacts legislation to implement each of the following minimum simplification requirements: a

Consumer Credit Card Protection Act of 2005- Amends the Truth in Lending Act to prohibit a credit card issuer from using any adverse information concerning any consumer (including information in any consumer report, or any change in the consumer's credit score) as the basis for increasing any annual percentage rate of interest (APR) applicable to a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan, or from removing or increasing any introductory APR for reasons other than actions or omissions of the consumer directly related to such account. Declares that such prohibition shall not apply to the use of any adverse information by a credit card issuer in any disclosure or statement required by the Act, including: (1) the required minimum monthly payment on the account, represented as both a dollar figure and a percentage of the outstanding balance; and (2) the number of months it would take the consumer to pay the entire amount of the current outstanding balance if the consumer pays only the required minimum monthly payments and no further advances or extensions of credit are made with respect to such account. Sets forth guidelines governing disclosure of payment terms. Prohibits a creditor from increasing an APR before the beginning of the billing cycle, unless the obligor provides specified advance notice of the increase to the consumer.

Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to coordinate and oversee the confidentiality and disclosure policies established by this Act. Requires the Director to review and approve any rules proposed by an agency before they become effective.Authorizes appropriations.

Reclamation Title Transfer Act of 2008 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish a program to: (1) identify and analyze the potential for public benefits from the transfer of eligible facilities out of federal ownership, which may include an analysis of the financial, operational, water supply, and environmental characteristics of the properties proposed for transfer; and (2) facilitate the transfer of title of eligible facilities out of federal ownership to promote more efficient management of water and water-related facilities. Defines: (1) eligible facilities" as a reclamation project or facility, or a portion of such a project or facility, that may include dams and appurtenant works, water rights, infrastructure, recreational facilities, buildings, distribution and drainage works, and associated lands or interests in lands or water; and (2) "qualifying entity" as an agency of a state or local government or an Indian tribe, a municipal corporation, public agency, or other entity such as a water district, that held or holds a water service contract, repayment contract, water rights settlement contract or exchange contract providing for water service from the eligible facility to be transferred and that has the capacity to continue to manage the conveyed property for the same purposes that the property has been managed under reclamation law.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary, without further authorization from"

American Textile Technology Innovation and Research for Exportation (ATTIRE) Act - Directs the Secretary of Commerce to establish a competitive grant program to fund textile research and innovation and to promote increased textile exports. Limits grant recipients to institutions of higher education (IHEs), including not-for-profit industry associations whose core mission is to support textile research and innovation.

Communist China Subsidy Reduction Act of 1997 - Amends the International Financial Institutions Act to direct the Secretary of the Treasury to instruct the United States Executive Directors at each international financial institution to use the vote of the United States to oppose the provision by the institution of concessional loans to the People's Republic of China, any citizen or national of China, or any entity established in China. <n>Expresses the sense of the Congress that U.S. nationals conducting industrial cooperation projects in China should: (1) suspend the use of goods, wares, articles, or merchandise that they have reason to believe were mined, produced, or manufactured by convict or forced labor; (2) seek to ensure that political or religious views, sex ethnic national background, involvement in political activities or nonviolent demonstrations, or association with suspected or known dissidents will not prohibit hiring, lead to harassment, demotion, or dismissal of employees in the industrial cooperation project; (3) ensure that methods of production used in the project do not pose unnecessary danger to workers and the surrounding environment; and (4) consult with community leaders regarding environmental protection with respect to the project. <n>Urges the Secretary to instruct the U.S. Executive Directors at each international financial institution to oppose the provision by such institution of concessional loans to

Asthma Act - Authorizes appropriations to the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute to carry out the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program for FY2010-FY2014. Requires the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program Coordinating Committee to report to Congress on the scope of asthma in the United States, all federal programs that carry out asthma-related activities, and recommendations for strengthening and better coordinating such activities.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to collaborate with the states to expand the scope of: (1) activities to determine the incidence and prevalence of asthma; and (2) activities to prevent the health consequences of asthma, including through the provision of information and education to the public regarding asthma.<n><n>Requires the Secretary, acting through the Director, to: (1) conduct local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on the prevalence and severity of asthma and the quality of asthma management; (2) compile and annually publish data on the prevalence of children suffering from asthma in each state and the childhood mortality rate associated with asthma nationally and in each state; and (3) make grants to nonprofit private entities for projects to carry out, in communities identified by the Secretary as having a high incidence of asthma, certain community outreach activities regarding asthma

National Discovery Trails Act of 1997 - Amends the National Trails System Act (the Act) to provide that national discovery trails established under the Act shall be components of the National Trails System. Provides that a trail shall not be considered feasible and desirable for designation as a national discovery trail unless it: (1) links to one or more areas within the boundaries of a metropolitan area and joins with other trails, tying the National Trails System to significant recreation and resources areas; (2) is supported by a competent trailwide nonprofit organization; and (3) is extended and passes through more than one State. Requires the appropriate Secretary for each national discovery trail to administer the trail in cooperation with a competent trailwide nonprofit organization. <n>Designates the 6,000-mile American Discovery Trail (established by this Act) as a national discovery trail. Provides that the Trail shall extend from Cape Henlopen State Park in Delaware to Point Reyes National Seashore in California, extending westward through Delaware, Maryland, the District of Columbia, West Virginia, Ohio, and Kentucky, where near Cincinnati, Ohio.

FISA Court Reform Act of 2013 - Establishes in the executive branch an Office of the Special Advocate, headed by a Special Advocate who shall: (1) review each application to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 (FISA) Court by the Attorney General; (2) review each decision of the FISA Court or the FISA Court of Review issued after enactment of this Act and all documents and other material relevant to such decision in a complete, unredacted form; (3) participate in a proceeding before the FISA Court if appointed to participate by the FISA Court; (4) request to participate in such a proceeding if granted; (5) participate in such a proceeding if granted; and (6) participate in such appeal or review. Requires the Special Advocate to: (1) protect individual rights by vigorously advocating before the FISA Court or the FISA Court of Review; and (2) have access to all relevant evidence as well as the authority to petition the Court for access to such evidence.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on November 16, 2016. Veterans Benefits Network Act (Sec. 2) This bill authorizes the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to make grants, during FY2017-FY2021, to a state or local government, a regional council of governments, or a private entity to establish or expand a regional technology system to provide an active database and enrollment system that can be used by a coordinated network of private, public, and nonprofit entities to assist veterans and their family members in applying for benefits and services offered by those entities that participate in the network. The services and resources included in the networks may include: education, employment, family support and recreation, health care, mental health and behavioral counseling, substance abuse counseling, housing, financial assistance, legal assistance, and benefits under VA laws; and other appropriate services and resources as the VA determines appropriate. To be eligible for inclusion in the networks, service providers must: demonstrate the capacity, experience, and expertise required to participate; and enter into an agreement with the entity receiving the grant that ensures that the provider will not input the personal information of a veteran or veteran's family member into the network without receiving the informed consent and authorization of the veteran or family member. The VA

Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to pay the holder of a mortgage obligation, before suit or foreclosure, the unpaid balance of the obligation plus accrued interest and reimburse the holder for advances, costs, and attorney fees incurred in connection with the default, as found properly and reasonably incurred. <n>Requires the Secretary, within ten days after receiving a notice of default, to notify the mortgagor that the Secretary may purchase the loan from the holder. Requires the mortgagor to submit a written request to the Secretary within 20 days after receiving notification that: (1) the mortgagor wants the Secretary to purchase the loan; and (2) the consequences to the mortgagor if the Secretary purchases the loan. <n>Authorizes the Secretary, upon receiving a request from the mortgagor to purchase the loan, for the purpose of avoiding foreclosure, to purchase the loan from the holder if: (1) the default was caused by circumstances beyond the mortgagor's control and rendered the mortgagor temporarily unable to correct a mortgage delinquency and resume full mortgage payments; and (2) it is determined that the holder is unwilling to grant further forbearance, the mortgagor desires to retain and occupy the property, the mortgagor has maintained the property in good condition or, if major

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on September 27, 2016. Ending Homelessness Act of 2016 (Sec. 3) This bill amends the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act to make FY2017-FY2021 appropriations for emergency relief grants to address the unmet needs of homeless populations in jurisdictions with the highest need. The bill directs the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to establish a formula for allocating the grant amounts among collaborative applicants, which shall include data providing accurate counts of: the poverty rate in the geographic area represented by the collaborative applicant; shortages of affordable housing for low-, very low-, and extremely low-income households in the geographic area represented by the collaborative applicant; the number of overcrowded housing units in the geographic area represented by the collaborative applicant; the number of unsheltered homeless individuals and the number of chronically homeless individuals; and any other factors that HUD considers appropriate. Each collaborative applicant that receives a grant shall use at least 75% of the grant amount for permanent supportive housing, including capital costs, rental subsidies, and services. HUD shall exempt a collaborative applicant from the requirement that: (1) chronic homelessness has been functionally eliminated in the geographic area served by the applicant, or (2) the applicant has demonstrated that it has or will address a significant

National Immunization Improvement Act of 1993 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a program under which the Secretary may award grants to States to develop and operate computerized State registries to collect, track, and monitor immunization data with respect to children residing within such States. Requires the Secretary to develop a minimum uniform data set and data standards applicable to State registries. Specifies that such a registry shall be designed to collect immunization information on each child residing within the State from the time that each such child is born, and track the immunization records of each such child as they grow older. Specifies that such a registry shall contain at least the following information with respect to each child residing within the State: (1) the name, address and date of birth of the child; (2) the complete immunization history of the child; (3) the type and lot numbers of each vaccine provided to the child; (4) the name and address of each health care provider providing a vaccination to the child; and (5) identifying data sufficient to enable the registry to locate the child for purposes of conducting immunization notification activities. Specifies that the Secretary shall: (1) provide technical assistance to States for the development of State registries; and (2) report annually to the Congress on State progress in operating such a

Southern Sea Otter Recovery and Research Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) and the United States Geological Survey (USGS), to carry out a recovery and research program for southern sea otter populations along the coast of California, informed by the prioritized research recommendations of the Final Revised Recovery Plan for the southern sea otter (Enhydra lutris nereis) published by USFWS and dated February 24, 2003, the Research Plan for California Sea Otter Recovery issued by USFWS and dated March 2, 2007, and any other recovery, research, or conservation plan adopted by USFWS after this Act's enactment. Directs the Secretary to: (1) appoint persons to a southern sea otter recovery implementation team as authorized under the Endangered Species Act of 1973; and (2) establish a peer review panel to provide scientific advice and guidance to prioritize proposals for grants for research regarding southern sea otters and for projects assisting the recovery of southern sea otter populations.

Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to allocate national limitations on the maximum aggregate face amount of qualified school construction bonds issued during any calendar year among the States in proportion to the respective amounts each State received for basic grants under part A of title I of the Act for the most recent fiscal year ending before such calendar year. Establishes the allocation formula.

Parent and Teacher Achievement Act of 2001 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to establish a new part E (State Incentives for Teacher Testing and Merit Pay). Directs the Secretary of Education to make an award to each State that: (1) administers a test to each elementary school and secondary school teacher in the State, with respect to the subjects taught by the teacher, every three to five years; (2) has an elementary school and secondary school teacher compensation system based on merit; and (3) requires elementary school and secondary school teachers to earn continuing education credits as part of a State recertification process. Defines a State" as each of the 50 States and the District of Columbia.Authorizes States to use Federal education funds to: (1) carry out such tests and merit pay programs; or (2) establish tax credits for qualified elementary and secondary school expenses, up to $1000 per qualifying student."

National Foundation on Physical Fitness and Sports Establishment Act - Establishes the National Foundation on Physical Fitness and Sports as a charitable, nonprofit corporation: (1) to develop, in conjunction with the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, a list and description of activities which would further the goals outlined in Executive Order 12345 and with respect to which combined private and governmental efforts would be beneficial; and (2) to promote private organization participation in, and private gifts to support, those activities.

National Climate Service Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Commerce to establish within the Climate Program Office of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) a National Climate Service, including a national center and a network of regional and local facilities for operational climate observation, modeling, and research.<n><n>Requires the Service to: (1) inform the public through the sustained production and delivery of authoritative, timely, useful information about impacts on local, State, regional, tribal, national, and global scales; (2) be user-centric; and (3) provide such usable information through a sustained network of observations, modeling, and research activities.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to submit to specified congressional committees a plan of action for the Service.

Biotechnology Future Investment Expansion Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that, in the case of a biomedical research corporation, any owner shift involving a five-percent shareholder which occurs as the result of a qualified investment during the testing period shall be treated for purposes of the current income tax incentive carryforwards as occurring before the testing period.

Counseling in Shelters Act of 2002 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Assistant Secretary for the Administration on Children, Youth, and Families, to make grants to eligible entities for the purpose of providing on-site mental health and substance abuse counseling and referral services.Requires such grant recipients to: (1) hire licensed professionals to provide counseling to women and children who have been subjected to domestic or sexual violence; (2) hire dedicated staff qualified to coordinate mental health and substance abuse services for victims of domestic and sexual violence and their children; and (3) provide training in the dynamics of domestic violence and sexual assault.

Aggregate Risk and Revenue Management Act of 2011 or ARRM Act of 2011 - Amends the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 to direct the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to give an operator, tenant, or sharecropper, as appropriate, on a farm an opportunity to make an annual election for all producers on the farm to receive aggregate risk and revenue management (ARRM) payments for the crop year for which the election is made. States that the total number of acres planted to all covered commodities and peanuts on the farm may receive ARRM payments shall equal the total number of acres planted to all covered commodities and peanuts on the farm. Declares that native sod that is tilled for the purpose of producing annual crop after the enactment of this Act shall not be considered acreage planted to the covered commodity or peanuts for harvest on a farm in a crop year for purposes of making ARRM payments. Limits ARRM payments to the actual acreage of native sod that was converted to crop production during the first five crop years of planting.

Amends the Federal criminal code to provide for the criminal and civil forfeiture of the proceeds of mail and wire fraud. Makes the forfeiture procedures of the Controlled Substances Act applicable to forfeitures under this Act.

School Anti-Violence Empowerment Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to local educational agencies (LEAs) for: (1) crisis intervention programs, including school counselors; and (2) school safety programs for students, staff, and school facilities. <n>Directs the Secretary, in awarding such grants, to ensure an equitable geographic distribution among the regions and among urban, suburban, and rural areas. <n>Requires LEA grant applications to include: (1) a description of any existing violence prevention, safety, and crisis intervention programs; (2) proposed changes to such programs and a description of any new programs; and (3) documentation regarding financial need. <n>Requires LEA grantees to provide annual reports to the Secretary describing how they used funds provided and including the number of school counselors hired with such funds.  <n>Authorizes appropriations for FY 2000 through 2004. <n>Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to increase funding for Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS).

Social Security Protection and Tax Relief Act of 2001- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose a tax equal to 12 percent of an individual\\'s social security taxable income for the taxable year. Defines social security taxable income" as adjusted gross income reduced by the greater of: (1) the sum of the standard deduction applicable to the taxpayer (or which would be applicable if the taxpayer did not elect to itemize deductions for the taxable year); and (2) the deduction for personal exemptions.Excludes from gross income: (1) amounts received as a pension or annuity from a qualified plan; (2) amounts received as a social security benefit; and (3) amounts received as earned income.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for a decrease in the rate of the Old-Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance tax on employees."

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow penalty-free withdrawals from individual retirement plans if used within 60 days for the acquisition of a principal residence for a first-time homebuyer or for the payment of qualified higher education expenses.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) World War II Memorial Completion Act - Establishes in the Treasury a fund to be created by the American Battle Monuments Commission for the World War II memorial to be established by the Commission on Federal land in the District of Columbia or its environs to honor members of the Armed Forces who served in World War II and to commemorate the participation of the United States in that war.Requires the Commission to solicit and accept contributions for the memorial.Authorizes the Commission to borrow up to $65 million from the Treasury to assure that groundbreaking, construction, and dedication of the memorial are completed on a timely basis.
