Campus Sexual Violence Elimination Act or the Campus SaVE Act - Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to require each institution of higher education (IHE), other than a foreign IHE, that is participating in any program under title IV to include in its annual security report a statement of policy regarding: (1) its sexual assault and other intimate partner violence programs; (2) the procedures followed once a sex offense or other intimate partner violence has occurred; and (3) the institution honoring any order of protection, no contact order, restraining order, or similar lawful order issued by any criminal or civil court.

Family Education Reimbursement Act of 2005 - Directs the Secretary of Education to establish a Family Education Reimbursement Account program to provide reimbursement to parents of displaced students for enabling their children to attend their school or preschool programs during the 2005-2006 school year.<n><n>Requires that such reimbursement be provided: (1) at the direction of the parent; (2) on a quarterly basis; and (3) to the appropriate local fiscal agent for the school.<n><n>Allows the Secretary to provide reimbursement on behalf of a displaced student only if the school or preschool program involved agrees to use such reimbursement for providing educational and other services to the student and not for the construction or renovation of facilities.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) develop and implement a web-based system to support the registration in the program of displaced students by means of an Internet site, toll-free telephone number, or paper form; and (2) facilitate the timely payment of funds from the accounts of families participating in the program.

Lamprey Wild and Scenic River Act - Amends the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act (the Act) to designate a segment of the Lamprey River in New Hampshire as a component of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. <n>Requires the segment to be: (1) administered by the Secretary of the Interior through cooperative agreements between the Secretary and the State of New Hampshire and the towns of Durham, Lee, and Newmarket, New Hampshire; and (2) managed in accordance with the Lamprey River Management Plan. <n>Directs the Secretary to coordinate the management responsibilities of the Secretary with respect to the segment with the Lamprey River Advisory Committee established under the New Hampshire Revised Statutes, upon request by the town of Epping, New Hampshire, which abuts an additional 12 miles of river found eligible for designation as a recreational river under the study. <n>Requires the Secretary, upon request by the town, to offer assistance concerning continued involvement of Epping in the implementation of the Plan and in consideration of potential future addition of the portion of the river within Epping as a component of the System. Authorizes appropriations.

Veterans Emergency Treatment Act or the VET Act (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), when a veteran requests examination or treatment for a medical condition, to ensure that the veteran is provided an appropriate medical screening examination within the VA hospital emergency department, including ancillary services routinely available to such department. If the VA determines that the veteran has an emergency medical condition, it shall provide: (1) such further medical examination and such treatment as may be required to stabilize the medical condition, or (2) for the transfer of the veteran to another VA or a non-VA medical facility. The VA shall take all reasonable steps to secure the written informed consent of such veteran to refuse such examination and treatment. The VA may not transfer a veteran with an emergency medical condition that has not been stabilized until: (1) the veteran, or a legally responsible individual acting on his or her behalf, requests such transfer in writing; (2) a physician has signed a certification that the medical benefits reasonably expected from the provision of appropriate medical treatment at another facility outweigh the increased risks to the veteran and, in the case of labor, to the unborn child; or (3) if a physician is not physically present in the emergency department at the time a veteran is transferred, a qualified medical person has signed a certification

Meat and Poultry Products Inspection Amendments of 1994- Amends the Federal Meat Inspection Act and the Poultry Products Inspection Act with respect to Federal and State cooperation to: (1) eliminate the intrastate limitation; (2) increase State inspection authority, including use of State inspectors; and (3) prohibit additional or different State requirements.

Help Emergency Responders Operate Act- Authorizes appropriations to the Secretary of Agriculture for FY 2001 through 2002 for the Cooperative Forestry Assistance Program.Amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to authorize the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency to guarantee loans to volunteer fire and rescue agencies for specified purposes, including: (1) purchasing equipment necessary for proper performance of agency duties; (2) repairing, rehabilitating, or otherwise improving agency facilities; (3) carrying out public education programs regarding fire prevention, life safety, and arson; (4) enforcement of fire codes; (5) carrying out and improving training programs regarding arson investigation, hazardous materials, and anti-terrorism; or (6) developing or enhancing safety programs for firefighters and rescue personnel.Sets forth loan terms, including a fee at the time of issuance.

Restitution and Responsibility Act - Authorizes the Attorney General to provide grants to enable States to: (1) collect data on victim restitution over a specified period of time; (2) create or expand automated data systems to track restitution payments; (3) make improvements in the manner in which restitution is ordered and collected; and (4) enhance and expand methods of enforcement of restitution orders. Sets forth provisions regarding eligibility requirements for grant recipients and reporting requirements.Authorizes appropriations.

Worldwide Tobacco Disclosure Act of 1997 - Prohibits the use of funds appropriated by law to: (1) seek the removal or reduction by any foreign country of any nondiscriminatory law or regulation, or any proposed nondiscriminatory law or regulation, in that country that restricts the advertising, manufacture, packaging, taxation, sale, importation, labeling, or distribution of tobacco products (tobacco products); or (2) encourage or promote the export, advertising, manufacture, sale, or distribution of tobacco products. <n>Makes it unlawful for any domestic concern to export from the United States, or to sell or distribute in, or export from, any other country, any cigarettes whose package does not contain a warning label that: (1) complies with Federal labeling requirements for cigarettes manufactured, imported, or packaged for sale or distribution within the United States; and (2) is in the primary language of the country in which the cigarettes are intended for consumption. Applies Federal labeling format requirements to such cigarettes. Authorizes the President to waive such requirements for reasons of national security.

Directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President Pro Tempore of the Senate to make arrangements for the presentation of a congressional gold medal to Muhammad Ali in recognition of his contributions to the nation.

Sportsmen's Heritage And Recreational Enhancement Act or the SHARE Act Amends the Fish and Wildlife Coordination Act to establish the Wildlife and Hunting Heritage Conservation Council Advisory Committee to advise the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture on wildlife and habitat conservation, hunting, and recreational shooting. Requires the Advisory Committee to advise the Secretaries on: implementation of Executive Order 13443: Facilitation of Hunting Heritage and Wildlife Conservation, which directs federal agencies to facilitate the expansion and enhancement of hunting opportunities and the management of game species and their habitat; policies or programs to conserve and restore wetlands, agricultural lands, grasslands, forest, and rangeland habitats; policies or programs to promote opportunities and access to hunting and shooting sports on federal lands; policies or programs to recruit and retain new hunters and shooters; policies or programs that increase public awareness of the importance of wildlife conservation and the social and economic benefits of recreational hunting and shooting; and policies or programs that encourage coordination among the public, the hunting and shooting sports community, wildlife conservation groups, and states, tribes, and the federal government.

Police Gun Buyback Assistance Act - Authorizes the Attorney General to make grants to States or local governments to: (1) assist States and local governments in purchasing new firearms without transferring decommissioned firearms to any person; and (2) destroy decommissioned firearms. Permits a State or local government to: (1) transfer a decommissioned firearm to a law enforcement agency; and (2) use grant funds only to purchase new firearms.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2015. Protecting Honest Fishermen Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to ensure that its seafood inspection activities are coordinated with the national sea grant college program to provide outreach to states, local health agencies, consumers, and the seafood industry on seafood safety. The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) must develop, maintain, and post on its website a list that: (1) includes each exporter whose seafood is imported or offered for import into the United States; and (2) tracks the timing, type, and frequency of violations of federal law relating to seafood safety. The Department of Commerce and HHS must ensure that inspections and tests for seafood safety also collect information for seafood fraud detection and prevention. Beginning in calendar year 2017, Commerce must implement requirements for seafood imported into the United States or otherwise distributed or offered for sale in interstate commerce that include disclosure of: (1) the acceptable market name and scientific name for the seafood species, the method of harvest of the seafood, and the date of the catch; (2) if seafood has been previously frozen, treated with any substance that may affect the true weight of the seafood, or processed in a country other than that in which

Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2001 - Amends the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) Implementation Act to permit a party or person to file with the U.S. Court of International Trade an appeal of a determination of a binational panel, alleging that a panel determination was based on a misinterpretation of U.S. law, a member of a binational panel is guilty of gross misconduct, bias, or serious conflict of interest, or that the panel seriously departed from a fundamental rule of procedure or exceeded its own authority, and such actions have materially affected panel determinations with respect to antidumping and countervailing duty cases and threaten the integrity of the panel review process. Authorizes a party or person requesting a panel review that is not convened within 315 days to file an appeal with the U.S. Court of International Trade if such request has been made and a panel is not convened within the same period.

Death Tax Repeal Act of 2015 This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) repeal the estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes, and (2) make permanent the maximum 35% gift tax rate and a $5 million lifetime gift tax exemption.

Responsible Education Achieves Care and Healthy Outcomes for Users' Treatment Act of 2018 or the REACH OUT Act of 2018 This bill requires the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services to award grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements to support eligible entities in providing technical assistance to: (1) outlier prescribers of opioids about best practices for prescribing opioids; (2) outlier prescribers of opioids about non-opioid pain management therapies; and (3) outlier prescribers of opioids about non-opioid pain management therapies. In awarding such grants, the CMS shall prioritize establishing technical assistance resources in each state.

Amends the Bretton Woods Agreements Act to require the Secretary of the Treasury to instruct the U.S. Governor of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria to: (1) accept the amendments to the Articles of Agreement of the Fund approved in resolution 52-4 of the Board of Governors of the Fund; and (2) seek to enter into negotiations for the purpose of inducing other Fund members to contribute to the Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. Requires the Secretary to provide for the contribution to the Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria in each of FY 2004 through 2006.

Shaken Baby Syndrome Prevention Act of 2007 - Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through specified federal officials, to develop a national Shaken Baby Syndrome public health campaign which shall inform the general public, and new parents, child care providers and other caregivers of young children, health care providers, and social workers, about brain injuries and other harmful effects that may result from shaking, or abusive impact to the head, of infants and children under age five, and healthy strategies to cope with a crying infant and related frustrations. Requires the Secretary to: (1) develop a National Action Plan for prevention of Shaken Baby Syndrome; and (2) carry out communication, education, and training about Shaken Baby Syndrome prevention.

Directs the Assistant Attorney General for the Office of Justice Programs of the Department of Justice to award such grants to PAL chapters for: (1) establishing chapters to serve public housing projects and other distressed areas; and (2) expanding existing chapters to serve additional youths. Requires PAL to submit grant applications to the Assistant Attorney General, which shall include: (1) a long-term strategy to establish 250 additional PAL chapters and detailed summary of those areas in which new PAL chapters will be established or in which existing chapters will be expanded to serve additional youths during the next fiscal year; (2) a plan to ensure that there are a total of not less than 570 PAL chapters in operation before January 1, 2003; (3) a certification that there will be appropriate coordination with those communities where new PAL chapters will be located; and (4) an explanation of the manner in which new PAL chapters will operate without additional, direct Federal financial assistance.

(Sec. 3) Requires the Federal reserve banks to transfer from their surplus funds, in addition to the amounts required to be transferred from their surplus funds to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System for deposit into the general fund of the Treasury, such sums as are necessary to equal the net cost of this Act in each of FY 2001 through 2005. Directs the Board to determine the amount each such bank shall pay in such fiscal year. Declares that no Federal reserve bank may replenish such bank\\'s surplus fund by the amount of any transfer during the fiscal year for which such transfer is made.(Sec. 4) Requires each insured depository institution to make available to consumers an affordable transaction account," with specified features, by regulation: (1) as an initial deposit; and (2) as a minimum balance, if any, to maintain such account. Allows an insured depository institution to require as an initial deposit: (1) up to ten percent of the total amount of advances on the account; and (2) up to 20 percent of the total amount of deposits placed into such account during any 30-day period. Allows an insured depository institution to have up to ten percent of the total amount of deposits placed into such account as an initial deposit, and up to 20 percent of the total amount of deposits"

United States-Israel Homeland Security Foundation Act - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to authorize the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish a United States-Israel Homeland Security Foundation, for the purpose of awarding conditional grants to joint business ventures between United States and Israeli private corporate entities to develop, manufacture, sell, or otherwise provide products and services with applications related to homeland security.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) STEM Network Act (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Education (ED) to make matching grants to state-based science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) networks or similar organizations of STEM stakeholders to expand STEM education. (Sec. 3) The grants must be used for: testing, validating, sharing, and scaling up STEM education research, promising practices, and exemplary programs; identifying state STEM education weaknesses and prioritizing strategies to address them; assisting in the implementation of rigorous common content standards in STEM education that reflect common elements between such disciplines and take into consideration the Next Generation Science Standards and the Common Core State Standards Initiative, the needs of English language learners and special education students, and the need to increase scientific literacy of prekindergarten through grade 12 students; promoting and developing undergraduate pre-service teacher programs in institutions of higher education that emphasize STEM content; developing STEM career pathways that reflect 21st century workforce needs; developing STEM-related workforce education and training programs in secondary schools and institutions of higher education to enhance the skills of workers to meet the needs of business and industry; and developing systems for the implementation of extended learning times on school sites to enhance STEM education inside and outside of the classroom

Supporting Education for Returning Veterans Act of 2008 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to award three-year grants to institutions of higher education to establish programs that support students who are veterans by providing and coordinating services that address their academic, financial, physical, and social needs. Requires grantees to establish a campus Center of Excellence for Veteran Student Success that provides a single point of contact to coordinate comprehensive support services for students who are veterans.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 6, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Consumer Checking Account Fairness Act - Amends the Expedited Funds Availability Act to direct the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to prescribe regulations to: (1) reduce certain check hold periods; and (2) eliminate certain distinctions if they no longer have any significance for any category of checks under the Checking Clearing for the 21st Century Act or regulations implementing such Act.Prohibits a depository institution from assessing any fee for an overdraft when it has received a provisional or final settlement with respect to a deposited check. Requires the depository institution to credit all deposits to an account before debiting any check drawn on the account.Treats Saturdays as business days for purposes of determining check hold periods.Requires a depository institution to post credits and debits against a checking account used primarily for personal, family, or household purposes after the close of any business day.

Home Construction Lending Regulatory Improvement Act of 2011 - Directs each of the appropriate federal banking agencies to initiate a coordinated rulemaking regarding financial institutions under their respective jurisdictions that make real estate loans to home builders. Requires such rulemaking to provide for: (1) elimination of the 100% of bank capital measurement requirement if any qualified financial institution is holding real estate loans in its lending portfolio that in the aggregate represent 100% or more of its total capital; (2) prohibitions by the appropriate federal banking agency against a qualified financial institution from making a real estate loan to a home builder that has a viable project; (3) requirements that entities used by financial institutions assess the value of collateral with respect to a real estate loan associated with any viable project in such institution's lending portfolio utilize an as completed valuation to make such assessment; and (4) requirements that entities used by financial institutions assess or review underwriting standards and collateral values for real estate loans made by such institutions use comparable sales involving arms length transactions.

National Sea Grant College Program Amendments Act of 2008- (Sec. 4) Amends the National Sea Grant College Program Act to substitute extension services" for "advisory services" in the definition of "project." (Sec. 5) Adds regional research and information plans as elements of the national sea grant college program. Removes a reference to the sea grant review panel from provisions relating to the administration of the program. Refers to regional or national strategic investments being developed in consultation with the board and with the approval of sea grant colleges and the sea grant institutes. (Current law refers to the approval of the sea grant review panel as well as the colleges and institutes.) Revises the program director\\'s duties. (Sec. 6) Excludes amounts appropriated under provisions relating to graduate ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources fellowships (the Dean John A. Knauss Marine Policy Fellowship Program) from provisions restricting contributions by the Secretary of Commerce to two-thirds of the total cost of sea grant programs and projects. (Sec. 7) Requires that sea grant colleges provide extension services (currently, advisory services). (Sec. 8) Requires that amounts available for fellowships (under provisions relating to graduate and post-graduate fellowships related to ocean, coastal, and Great"

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on October 16, 2016. Security Assessment Feasibility for Equipment Testing and Evaluation of Capabilities for our Homeland Act or the SAFE TECH Act (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to develop a program to enable a vendor of transportation security screening technology to obtain testing, including as an alternative to the TSA's testing process, by an appropriate third party before procurement or development of such technology. The third party testing program shall include detection testing to evaluate the performance of a security screening technology relating to the probability of detection, the probability of false alarm, and other indicators that such technology is able to meet the TSA's mission needs for detection of explosives and prohibited items. The TSA shall: (1) coordinate such testing with any associated subsequent final DHS testing, (2) share detection testing information and standards with appropriate international partners, and (3) prioritize field testing of security screening technology and equipment by third parties. Such testing may include as an alternative to the TSA's testing process at the TSA Systems Integration Facility, including testing for health and safety factors, operator interface, human factors, environmental factors, throughput, reliability, maintainability, and availability factors. The TSA shall:

(Sec. 3) Prohibits the Board of Directors of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) from voting in favor of any action proposed to be taken by OPIC that is likely to have significant adverse environmental impacts unless: (1) an environmental impact assessment or initial environmental audit, analyzing the environmental impacts of the proposed action and of alternatives to the proposed action has been completed by the project applicant and made available to the Board; and (2) such assessment or audit has been made available to the public of the United States, locally affected groups in the host country, and host country nongovernmental organizations.(Sec. 4) Requires the Board to hold a public hearing to afford an opportunity for any person to present views regarding OPIC activities. (Sec. 5) Authorizes the United States Trade Representative (USTR) to designate a Deputy USTR to serve on the Board in place of the U.S. Trade Representative.(Sec. 6) Directs the Agency for International Development (AID) to require corporations and other entities to: (1) share the costs of feasibility studies and other project planning services funded under this Act; and (2) reimburse AID if the corporation or entity concerned succeeds in project implementation.(Sec. 7) Increases the amount authorized to be appropriated for FY 2000 and

Unemployment Compensation Amendments of 1999 - Amends the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970 to: (1) repeal certain State law requirements under the extended unemployment compensation benefit program; (2) establish certain mandatory triggers based on total unemployment; (3) revise requirements for supplemental benefits during high unemployment periods; and (4) modify provisions for alternative triggers that States may establish.

Great Falls Preservation and Redevelopment Act of 1993 - Establishes the Great Falls Historic District in Paterson, New Jersey, to be administered through cooperative agreements. <n>Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to make grants to, and enter into cooperative agreements with, nonprofit entities for: (1) the purchase of property or easements; (2) emergency stabilization; and (3) the establishment of a coordinated fund. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Authorizes the Commandant of the Coast Guard to transfer to Presque Isle Township, Michigan, possession of the Lens from the Presque Isle Light Station Lighthouse, Michigan. Conditions such transfer on the Township installing and operating the Lens as a Class I private aid to navigation. Declares that, upon the making of such certification, all active Federal aids to navigation located at the Lighthouse shall cease to be operated and maintained by the United States. <n>Requires the Township: (1) if it does not comply with such condition within the time specified, to return the Lens to the United States; (2) to retain possession of the Lens for installation as an artifact in, at, or near the Lighthouse upon approval of the Commandant; and (3) if the Lens is returned to the Township no later than two years after such transfer, to return the Lens to the Coast Guard at no cost to the United States and under such conditions as the Commandant may require. <n>Authorizes the Commandant to transfer to the Township any additional personal property of the United States related to the Lens that the Commandant considers appropriate for conveyance under this Act, if the Lens is returned to the Township: (1) to operate the Lens as a Class I private aid to navigation; and (2) to hold the United States harmless for any claim arising with

Katie Sepich Enhanced DNA Collection Act of 2010 - Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to increase by 5% the amount of funds a state receives under the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant Program for a fiscal year if such state has implemented a minimum DNA collection process and has implemented an enhanced DNA collection process. Defines minimum DNA collection process" as a process under which the Combined DNA Index System of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) is searched at least one time against samples from individuals who are at least 18 years of age who are arrested for, charged with, or indicted for a murder or voluntary manslaughter or a criminal offense that is punishable by imprisonment for more than five years, or for a kidnaping or abduction for five years or more. Defines "enhanced DNA collection process" as a process under which a state provides for the collection, for purposes of inclusion in the CODIS, of DNA samples from such individuals who are at least 18 years of age."

Hardship Outlays to protect Mortgagee Equity (HOME) Act- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt from the tax on early distributions from tax-exempt retirement plans any principal residence mortgage payment distributions received by an individual before the close of the 120th day after the day on which such payment or distribution is received to pay qualified mortgage costs with respect to a principal residence of such individual or the spouse of such individual.

Small Watershed Rehabilitation Amendments of 1998 - Amends the Watershed Protection and Flood Prevention Act to authorize the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Natural Resources Conservation Service, to provide financial assistance to an eligible local organization (or appropriate State agency) for the rehabilitation of structural measures originally constructed as part of a covered water resource project. Limits the amount of such assistance to 65 percent of the total rehabilitation costs. Authorizes technical assistance in planning, designing, and implementing such projects, which may consist of specialists in such fields as engineering, geology, soils, agronomy, biology, hydraulics, hydrology, economics, water quality, and contract administration. Prohibits the use of such assistance to perform operation and maintenance activities specified in the agreement for the project entered into between the Secretary and the eligible local organization. Requires such operation and maintenance activities to remain the responsibility of the local organization so that the completed rehabilitation project is not quickly rendered inadequate by additional development and that society can realize the full benefits of the rehabilitation investment. Authorizes the Secretary, as part of such assistance, to renegotiate the original agreement for the project entered into between the Secretary and the eligible local organization regarding responsibility for the operation and maintenance of the project.

Sikes Act Amendments Act of 2011 - Amends the Sikes Act relating to the use and maintenance of military installations and facilities owned and operated by a state to authorize the Secretary of a military department to develop and implement an integrated natural resources management plan for a state-owned National Guard installation. Requires such plan to be implemented in coordination with the chief executive officer of the state in which the installation is located. Defines state-owned National Guard installation" as land owned and operated by a state when such land is used for training the National Guard, with funds provided by the Secretary of Defense (DOD) or the Secretary of a military department, even though such land is not under DOD jurisdiction.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of a military department to carry out a cooperative program for the conservation and rehabilitation of resources on such installations. Requires such program to be carried out in coordination with the chief executive officer of the state in which the installation is located."

Student Aid Streamlined Disclosure Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow the Secretary of the Treasury to disclose to the Department of Education certain tax return information for purposes other than tax administration, including taxpayer identity information, the filing status of a taxpayer, the adjusted gross income of such taxpayer, the total earnings from employment, the Federal income tax liability of such taxpayer, and the type of tax return filed by such taxpayer.Authorizes the Department of Education to disclose to applicants for grants, loans, benefits, or work assistance under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965: (1) the fact that a material discrepancy between certain tax return information and information reported to the Department would result in an over or under award of grants or loans; and (2) whether such items are greater than or less than such items reported to the Department.

Community Restoration and Revitalization Act of 2004 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) revise rules for determining the applicable percentage for certain buildings eligible for the low-income housing tax credit; (2) increase the rehabilitation tax credit for certain smaller projects; (3) exclude from the definition of certified historic structure" for purposes of the rehabilitation tax credit any building eligible for the investment tax credit; and (4) revise the date by which a building must be first placed in service for purposes of the rehabilitation tax credit."

Golden Spike/Crossroads of the West National Heritage Area Act of 1999 - Establishes the Golden Spike/Crossroads of the West National Heritage Area in Utah. <n>Designates the city of Ogden, Utah, as the management entity for the Area. Requires the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a management plan for the Area. <n>Directs the Secretary, in cooperation with the city, to study and report to specified congressional committees on the feasibility of establishing a national heritage corridor from the city to the Crossroads of the West. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

National Quality Commitment Award Act of 1993 - Amends the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 to direct the Secretary of Commerce to carry out a National Commitment to Quality Award Program. <n>Directs the Secretary to periodically conduct a competition and make specified monetary awards to institutions of higher education. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to award a specialized award to any institution of higher education that: (1) in teaching or practicing either total quality management or process manufacturing engineering services productivity improvement a specialized award; and (2) demonstrates continuous improvement in its education program through application of total quality management principles within the institution. <n>Requires the presentation of such awards by the President or the Secretary, based on recommendations received from the Secretary, or the Secretary, to institutions of higher education which have substantially benefited the economic and social well-being of the United States through activities that: (1) teach effective total quality management techniques and approaches; (2) demonstrate continuous improvement in the institution's total quality management curriculum; (3) emphasize the value and prestige of pursuing careers in process manufacturing engineering; (4) demonstrate continuous improvement in the institution's education program through application of total quality management principles that the institution maintains with private industry; and (5) demonstrate commitment and application of total quality management principles that the institution maintains with private industry.

American Opportunity Tax Credit Extension Act of 2010 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) make permanent the increase in the Hope Scholarship tax credit and the lifetime learning tax credit; (2) allow an increased tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses for the first four years of a post-secondary education; (3) allow an exclusion, up to $2,000, from the gross income of an employee for qualified tuition and related expenses and for course materials; and (4) allow certain additional expenses for the Hope Scholarship and Lifetime Learning tax credits, including job skills courses.

HIV Nondiscrimination in Travel and Immigration Act of 2007- Authorizes the Secretary of Homeland Security to issue a waiver to the HIV prohibition, on a case-by-case basis, only to any HIV-positive individual who: (1) applies for permanent admission as an immigrant; (2) is the parent, spouse, unmarried son or daughter, or minor adopted child of a U.S. citizen or a permanent resident, or a refugee or asylee adjusting to immigrant status; and (3) can establish that the danger to public health of the United States created by the applicant's admission would be minimal, the possibility of the spread of the infection would be minimal, and there would be no cost incurred by any level of government agency without the prior consent of that agency.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior to complete a study on the eligibility and results of designating a specified segment of the Everglades River in Florida as a component of the National Wild and Scenic River program.

Small Company Capital Formation Act of 2011 - Amends the Securities Act of 1933 to direct the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to add a class of securities to the small issue exemption from its registration requirements, including equity securities, debt securities, and debt securities convertible or exchangeable equity interests, which may be offered and sold publicly. Limits the aggregate offering amount of all such securities within the prior 12-month period in reliance on the small issue exemption to $50 million. Declares that the securities shall: (1) not be restricted securities within the meaning of federal securities laws, (2) apply to any person offering or selling such securities, (3) be subject to civil liability, and (4) be required to file audited financial statements with the SEC annually.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Iran and Western Hemisphere Prevention Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill declares that it shall be U.S. policy to continue policy to prevent further Iranian-related terrorist activities in the Western Hemisphere, including partnerships with Iranian-based terrorist organizations, and to disrupt illicit drug trafficking there. (Sec. 3) The President may waive the requirements of this bill under certain circumstances. The bill requires the President to report to Congress annually regarding U.S. efforts to prevent Iranian-related terrorist activities in the Western Hemisphere.

. Small Business Mergers, Acquisitions, Sales, and Brokerage Simplification Act of 2014 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to exempt from its registration requirements certain merger and acquisition brokers and associated persons. A merger and acquisition broker shall not be exempt from registration, however, if the broker: (1) receives, holds, transmits, or has custody of any funds or securities to be exchanged by parties to a transfer of ownership of an eligible privately held company; or (2) engages on behalf of an issuer in a public offering of securities that are either subject to mandatory registration, or with respect to which the issuer must file periodic information, documents, and reports. Nothing in this Act shall be construed to limit any other authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to exempt any person, or any class of persons, from any provision of this Act, or from any provision of any rule or regulation.

Amends the Food Stamp Act of 1977 to authorize the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to issue regulations establishing specific time periods during which the authorization to accept and redeem food stamp coupons shall be valid for retail stores and wholesale food concerns (stores) based on lack of business integrity. Requires such regulations to: (1) reflect the severity of business integrity infractions that are the basis of the denials or withdrawals of store authorization; and (2) require such stores and concerns to provide written authorization for the Secretary to verify all relevant tax filings with appropriate agencies, and to obtain corroborating documentation from other sources in order that the accuracy of information provided by such stores and concerns may be verified. Directs the Secretary to prohibit a store that initially fails to meet authorization criteria from submitting a new application for six months after such denial. Authorizes the Secretary to suspend a store pending administrative and judicial review for program violations.

(Sec. 2) Makes it an unfair or deceptive practice and an unfair method of competition for an air carrier or foreign air carrier to: (1) fail to provide a consumer full access to all fares for air transportation provided by them, regardless of the technology or other method the consumer uses to access the fares; (2) fail to provide an air carrier passenger with an accurate explanation of the reasons for a flight delay, cancellation, or diversion from a ticketed itinerary; or (3) prohibit a person (including a governmental entity) that purchases air transportation from only using a portion of the air transportation purchased (including using air transportation purchased only for one-way travel instead of round-trip travel), or assess an additional fee on or charge to such a person or any ticket agent that sold the air transportation to such person. Makes it an unfair or deceptive practice and an unfair method of competition for an air carrier or foreign air carrier, in the case of a termination, cancellation, nonrenewal, or substantial change in the competitive circumstances of the appointment of a ticket agent by an air carrier or foreign air carrier, to fail: (1) to provide the ticket agent with written notice, and a full statement of reasons for the action, on or before the 90th day preceding the action; and (2) to provide the

Idaho Land Enhancement Act - Requires the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture, upon Idaho's offer, to convey certain state land to the United States in exchange for certain federal land in the Idaho Panhandle and Clearwater National Forests.

Custodial Interrogation Recording Act of 2009 - Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to direct the Attorney General to make grants to states and local governments to take whatever steps the Attorney General determines to be necessary to achieve the complete and accurate recording, by both audio and video means, of every custodial interrogation occurring within the state or local government. Limits the portion of the costs of a program funded by a grant that may not exceed 75%.

Worker-Executive Parity Act of 2009 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) and the Internal Revenue Code to prohibit accrual of deferred compensation under certain deferred executive compensation arrangements which are comparable to certain funding-based limits on benefits and benefit accruals imposed on defined benefit pension plans.

Amends the District of Columbia Code to make the Mayor of the District of Columbia (currently, the President of the United States) the Commander-in-Chief of the militia of the District. Makes conforming amendments to comply with this Act to: (1) Title 10 (Armed Forces); (2) Title 32 (National Guard); (3) the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1993; and (4) the District of Columbia Home Rule Act.

Social Security Totalization Agreement Reform Act of 2007 - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to provide that any agreement to establish a totalization arrangement which is entered into with another country shall enter into force with respect to the United States if (and only if): (1) the President, at least 90 calendar days before the date on which he enters into the agreement, notifies each House of the Congress of his intention to enter into it, and promply thereafter publishes notice of such intention in the Federal Register; (2) he transmits the text of such agreement to each House of the Congress; and (3) a joint resolution regarding such agreement has passed both Houses of Congress and been enacted into federal law.<n><n>Sets forth procedures for the consideration of such a joint resolution.

Improving Medical Device Innovation Act This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to recognize all or part of a standard established by a nationally or internationally recognized standard organization within 60 days after receiving a request for recognition. The FDA must: (1) issue a response in writing to the requester within 60 days and make the rationale for recognizing or withdrawing a standard publicly available within such time frame; and (2) provide Food and Drug Administration employees who review premarket submissions for devices periodic training on the concept and use of recognized standards. The FDA must review and update, if necessary, previously published guidance and standard operating procedures identifying the principles for recognizing standards and for withdrawing recognition of standards, taking into account the experience with and reliance on a standard by foreign regulatory authorities and the device industry, and whether recognition of a standard will promote harmonization among regulatory authorities in the regulation of devices. The FDA must identify within 120 days and at least once every five years any type of class I and class II devices that it determines no longer requires a report to provide reasonable assurance of safety and effectiveness. Upon such publication: (1) each type of class I device shall be exempt from the requirement for a report, and (2) the classification regulation applicable to each such type of

Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a community-based overweight and obesity prevention program awarding grants and contracts to, or entering into contracts with, eligible entities to: (1) plan evidence-based programs for the prevention of overweight and obesity among children and their families through improved nutrition and increased physical activity; or (2) implement such programs.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to give preference to eligible entities that: (1) will serve communities with high levels of overweight and obesity and related chronic diseases; or (2) will plan or implement activities for the prevention of overweight and obesity in school or workplace settings.

Temporary Duty Suspension Process Act of 2012 - Directs the United States International Trade Commission (USITC) to complete all actions necessary to establish a process pursuant to which it will: (1) review each article with respect to which a duty suspension or reduction may be made; or (2) submit a draft bill to the appropriate congressional committees. Defines duty suspension or reduction" as an amendment to the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States (HTS) that: (1) extends an existing temporary suspension or reduction of duty on an article, or (2) provides for a new temporary suspension or reduction of duty on an article.<n><n>Requires the USITC to establish procedures under which a petition requesting it to review a duty suspension or reduction may be submitted to the USITC by a member of the public or referred to the USITC by a Member of Congress. Requires such petitions to receive treatment no more favorable than that received by a petition submitted to the USITC by a member of the public.<n><n>Directs the USITC to establish procedures for: (1) notifying the public when it initiates the process of reviewing articles regarding which duty suspensions or reductions may be made and distributing information about the process, (2) notifying the public of the duty suspensions and reductions it is considering, and (3) providing the public with"

Tax Equity Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates. Directs the Secretary of Labor to determine and publish a regional cost-of-living index for each statistical area.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 18, 2014. Ebola Emergency Response Act - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the current outbreak of the Ebola virus disease in West Africa poses severe health, economic, and security threats to the countries affected by the outbreak, the United States, and the broader international community; and (2) the whole-of-government response taken by the United States provides unique capabilities that are critical to effectively helping contain the Ebola virus disease, yet the United States alone will not succeed in containing it. Directs the President to: (1) support a robust international response to the Ebola virus disease in West Africa by undertaking a range of activities to help detect, contain, treat, and deter the further spread of the disease; (2) support the efforts of governments of affected countries and of local, regional, and international nongovernmental organizations and civil society organizations working on the front lines of the response; and (3) work with appropriate security personnel engaged in the response to the Ebola virus disease in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone, as well as with civil society, regional organizations, and the United Nations to enhance border security and create a secure operating environment for health workers and other responders serving in such countries. Directs the President to: (1)

Marine Renewable Energy Research and Development Act of 2007- Directs the Secretary of Energy to: (1) support research, development, demonstration, and commercial application to expand marine renewable energy production; (2) award grants for the establishment of National Marine Renewable Energy Research, Development, and Demonstration Centers; and (3) develop siting criteria for marine renewable energy generation demonstration and commercial application projects.

Veterans' Compensation Cost-of-Living Adjustment Act of 2008 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to increase, as of November 30, 2008, the amounts for the payment of veterans' disability compensation, additional compensation for dependents, the clothing allowance for certain disabled adult children, and dependency and indemnity compensation for surviving spouses and children. Requires each such increase to be the same percentage as the increase provided under title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act, on the same effective date, and to be published at the same time the latter increases are published.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to adjust administratively the rates of disability compensation payable to persons receiving benefits pursuant to public laws administered by the Secretary. Directs the Secretary to publish such increased amounts in the Federal Register.

Prohibits treating any such service as an intensive residential service unless the facility: (1) is legally authorized to provide such service under State law or is certified to provide such service by an appropriate accreditation entity approved by the State; and (2) meets other requirements as the Secretary may impose to assure the quality of the intensive residential services provided.

Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to: (1) develop and publish in the Federal Register standards for evaluating dredged materials to be used solely for remediation purposes at the Site; and (2) provide notice and an opportunity for public comment before issuing final standards.

Government Reform Act of 2003 - Establishes a Government Reform Commission which shall: (1) examine the current configuration of executive agencies and investigate their duties and responsibilities; (2) review the operational jurisdictions of executive agencies to determine whether areas of overlap exist and whether the mission of any agency has become obsolete; (3) identify and address opportunities for increasing efficiency and reducing costs in executive agencies as a result of executive action or legislation, areas within executive agencies where managerial accountability can be enhanced and administrative control can be improved, any Federal programs that have accomplished their original objectives and should be terminated, any Federal services that could be provided at lower cost by the private sector, budget process reforms that could yield savings, increase accountability and efficiency, and enhance public confidence in the budget process, and areas for further study based on likelihood for potential savings; and (4) review existing Government Accounting Office, Congressional Budget Office, and Office of Management and Budget prior reform efforts and identify and address areas for further study which could yield savings, increase accountability and efficiency, and enhance public confidence in the budget process.

Emergency Mortgage Loan Modification Act of 2008- Establishes a standard for loan modifications or workout plans for pools of certain residential mortgage loans.<n><n>States that a servicer of such pooled loans owes a duty to the securitization vehicle to maximize, or not adversely affect, the recovery of total proceeds from such loans for the benefit of all investors and holders of beneficial interests in the pooled loans, in the aggregate, and not to any individual party or group of parties.<n><n>Deems the loan servicer, if a loan is in payment default under the loan agreement or for which payment default is imminent or reasonably foreseeable, to be acting on behalf of the securitization vehicle in the best interest of all such investors and holders if the servicer: (1) makes reasonable, documented efforts to implement a modification or workout plan; or (2) engages in other loss mitigation efforts, if unsuccessful or the plan would be infeasible.<n><n>Declares, furthermore, that a servicer that acts in a manner consistent with such duty shall not be liable for entering into a qualified loan modification or workout plan.<n><n>Applies this Act only to plans initiated before January 1, 2011.

Unfunded Mandates Accountability Act of 2011 - Amends the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 (UMRA) to require federal agencies, before promulgating any proposed or final rule that may have an annual effect on the economy of $100 million or more (adjusted for inflation), or that may result in the expenditure by state, local, and tribal governments, in the aggregate, of $100 million or more in any one year, to prepare and publish in the Federal Register an initial and final regulatory impact analysis. Requires such analysis to include: (1) an analysis of the anticipated benefits and costs of the rule, (2) an analysis of the benefits and costs of a reasonable number of regulatory alternatives within the range of the agency's discretion under the statute authorizing the rule, (3) estimates of any disproportionate budgetary effects of the rule upon any particular region of the nation or particular state, local, or tribal governments, urban or rural or other types of communities, or particular segments of the private sector, and (4) a description of the agency's prior consultation with affected state, local, and tribal governments. Requires: (1) the agency, before promulgating any proposed or final rule for which a regulatory impact analysis is required, to identify and consider a reasonable number of regulatory alternatives within

Foreign Debt Transparency and Threat Assessment Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to publish annually in the Federal Register and online a list of: (1) all debt instruments of the United States, including bonds, notes, and other obligations issued or guaranteed by the United States or by an entity of the United States government, including any government-sponsored enterprise; and (2) the foreign holders of such securities.

William H. Gray, III, College Completion Challenge Grant Program of 1999 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to establish the William H. Gray, III, College Completion Challenge Grant Program to assist institutions of higher education to help students who are at risk of ending their postsecondary education prior to obtaining baccalaureate degrees, particularly those who are economically disadvantaged, to stay in school until they obtain those degrees. <n>Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award competitive three-year grants to eligible institutions to pay the Federal share of costs of carrying out such programs. Allows such institutions to apply for such grants only as part of a consortium that includes one or more institutions that award baccalaureate degrees. <n>Requires the Federal share of such program costs to not be more than 50 percent, and the matching funds to not be more than 50 percent, of the total cost of such programs. <n>Limits an institution that receives such a grant to three years of such assistance, subject to satisfactory progress. <n>Makes the following institutions eligible for such grants: (1) an institution of higher education; (2) a historically Black college or university; (3) a Hispanic-, Alaska Native-, or Native Hawaiian-serving institution; or (4) a tribally controlled college or university. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Land Disposal Program Flexibility Act of 1996 - Amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act to provide that solid waste identified as hazardous based solely on one or more characteristics shall not be subject to Federal laws relating to land-based solid waste management if the waste: (1) is treated in a treatment system that subsequently discharges to waters of the United States pursuant to a permit issued under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (commonly known as the Clean Water Act); and (2) no longer exhibits a hazardous characteristic prior to management in any land-based solid waste management unit. <n>Exempts from the requirements of this Act an owner or operator of a new municipal solid waste landfill unit, an existing municipal solid waste landfill unit, or a lateral expansion of a municipal solid waste landfill unit, that disposes of less than 20 tons of municipal solid waste daily, based on an annual average, if: (1) there is no evidence of ground water contamination from the landfill unit or expansion; and (2) the landfill unit or expansion serves a community that experiences an annual interruption of at least three consecutive months of surface transportation that prevents access to a regional waste management facility, or one that has no practicable waste management alternative and the landfill unit is located in an area that annually receives less than or equal to 25 inches of precipitation.

International Commerce Enhancement Act - Amends the Arms Export Control Act to increase the value of certain defense articles and services that may be transferred to foreign countries without the President's prior consent from: (1) $4 million to $25 million; and (2) $50 million to $75 million. Decreases from 15 to 30 days the period during which the President must submit to Congress a certification regarding any proposed transfer of defense articles or services to a country other than a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), Japan, Australia, or New Zealand. Decreases from $15 to 30 days the period during which the President must submit a certification regarding any proposed sale of defense articles or services to a country other than a member of NATO, Japan, Australia, or New Zealand. Declares that transfers of defense articles and services to non-NATO countries shall not be subject to the same requirements as transfers to NATO countries.

Congestion Relief Act of 2004 - Amends Federal highway law to direct the Secretary of Transportation to establish and implement a traffic incident management program to assist States and localities in planning and carrying out projects to mitigate the effects of traffic delays resulting from accidents, breakdowns, and other non-recurring incidents on highways. Makes funds available for: (1) regional collaboration and coordination activities that lead to regional traffic incident management policies, programs, plans, procedures, and agreements; (2) purchase or lease of telecommunications equipment for first responders as part of the development of a regional traffic incident management program; (3) payments to contractors for towing and recovery services as part of a regional traffic incident management program; (4) rental of vehicle storage or staging areas immediately adjacent to roadways as part of a regional traffic incident management program; (5) traffic service patrols as part of a regional traffic incident management program; (6) enhanced hazardous materials incident response; (7) traffic management systems in support of traffic incident management; (8) traffic incident management training; (9) crash investigation equipment; (10) statewide incident reporting systems; and (11) other activities under a regional traffic incident management plan. Prohibits funds apportioned to a State from being obligated for an urbanized area with a population greater than 300,000 until such time as a regional traffic incident management plan is developed for the

Securing Department of Homeland Security Firearms Act of 2017 or the Securing DHS Firearms Act of 2017 (Sec. 3) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to include firearms and other sensitive assets in the responsibilities of the Under Secretary for Management of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). (Sec. 4) The Under Secretary shall develop and disseminate a DHS-wide directive, meeting specified criteria, for achieving adequate security over firearms and other sensitive assets across DHS. Such directive shall include: descriptions of what equipment is classified as a sensitive asset for the purpose of carrying out this bill, requirements for securing DHS-issued firearms and other sensitive assets, a classification system for all categories of DHS-issued badges, and reporting requirements for lost firearms and other sensitive assets. The directive shall also require: components to develop procedures to safeguard firearms and other sensitive assets during on- and off-duty time, the issuance of safety locking devices and policies on the use of such assets, initial, recurrent, and remedial training on safeguarding such assets, and recordkeeping requirements for lost firearms and other sensitive assets in inventory systems. DHS component heads shall: comply with federal law, federal regulations, executive branch guidance, and DHS policy, including directives required by this bill, relating to the management and oversight of securing

Firefighter Cancer Registry Act of 2016 This bill requires the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to develop and maintain a voluntary patient registry to collect data on cancer incidence among firefighters. The registry must be used to: (1) establish and improve collection infrastructure and activities related to the nationwide monitoring of cancer among firefighters, and (2) collect, consolidate, store, and make publicly available epidemiological information related to cancer incidence and trends among firefighters. The CDC should seek to include in the registry de-identified information on: cancer diagnoses and treatment of firefighters; individual patient history relating to the incidence of cancer among firefighters; basic demographic information on the firefighter involved and age of onset of cancer; a listing of status of the firefighter as either volunteer, paid-on-call, or career firefighter; the number of years on the job and a detailing of additional employment experience that was either performed concurrently alongside firefighting service or thereafter; a measure of the number of fire incidents attended as well as the type of fire incidents (such as residential house fire or commercial fire); or in the case of a firefighter who is unable to provide information on such number and type, an estimate of such number and type based on the method developed; and a list of additional risk factors, including smoking or drug use. The CDC must

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on October 1, 2015. Safer Trucks and Buses Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Transportation (DOT) to ensure that certain motor carrier data, including crash data, is not made available to the public. DOT shall enter into an agreement with the National Academy of Public Administration to study how to improve the Compliance, Safety, Accountability initiative of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration, including how to ensure that the initiative: utilizes only safety data determined to be predictive of motor carrier crashes; addresses concerns relating to the age of utilized safety data, including violations; does not unfairly harm small motor carriers as a result of limited safety data availability; addresses differences between motor carriers transporting passengers and motor carriers transporting freight; allows individual motor carriers to be effectively compared; and utilizes accurate safety data, including by appropriately addressing variations between state- and self-reported data, by accounting for geographic differences with respect to enforcement, and by not utilizing crash data from crashes with respect to which a motor carrier was free from fault. A motor carrier is free from fault with respect to a crash if: the vehicle of the carrier was struck by another vehicle that crossed the center line or median of a roadway, was driving the wrong

Ottawa National Wildlife Refuge Complex Expansion and Detroit River International Wildlife Refuge Expansion Act - Expands the Ottawa National Wildlife Refuge Complex to include specified land and water in the State of Ohio. Permits the Secretary of the Interior to acquire by donation, purchase, or exchange the land and water and interests in land and water within the boundaries of the Complex.Expands the southern boundary of the Detroit River International Wildlife Refuge (the Refuge) to include additional land and water located in the State of Michigan east of Interstate Route 75.Prescribes requirements for administration of the Complex.Directs the Secretary to ensure that hunting, trapping, fishing, wildlife observation and photography, and environmental education and interpretation shall be the priority public uses of the Complex.Requires the Secretary to encourage the State of Ohio to use authority under the recreational trails program under Federal law to provide funding for the acquisition and development of trails within the boundaries of the Complex.

Requires the Centers to be affiliated with any U.S.-based nonprofit institution or organization, or group thereof, that applies for and is awarded financial assistance under this Act. Declares that the objective of the Centers is to enhance productivity and technological performance in U.S. electronic commerce through the transfer of electronic commerce technology and techniques developed at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to companies throughout the United States, the participation of individuals from industry, institutions of higher education, State governments, other Federal agencies, and, when appropriate, NIST in cooperative technology transfer activities.Requires the Secretary of Commerce, under specified conditions, to provide financial support to any Center created under this Act. Allows any nonprofit institution, or group thereof, or consortia of nonprofit institutions to submit to the Secretary an application for financial support for the creation and operation of a Center.

Voter Outreach and Turnout Expansion Act of 2003- Amends the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to permit an individual to register to vote and vote at the polling place in an election for Federal office on the date of the election if such individual: (1) completes an application for voter registration in accordance with this Act and other applicable law; and (2) executes a written affirmation before an election official at the polling place stating that the individual is eligible to register to vote in the jurisdiction in which the individual desires to vote and has not already voted in the election.Requires an appropriate official at a polling place to transmit any voter registration application accepted to the appropriate State election official at the time the official at the polling place transmits the ballots cast at the polling place to the official.Provides that, if an individual's application for voter registration is received by the appropriate election official after the deadline for receipt of applications with respect to the election under State law, the official shall transmit a notice to the individual stating that the application was received after the deadline and that the individual may register to vote at the polling place on the date of the election.Amends the Voting Information Act of 1965 to require each jurisdiction in a State which administers an election for Federal office to designate early voting sites within the jurisdiction

Commission on Chemical and Biological Warfare Agent Exposure Act - Establishes the Commission on Chemical and Biological Warfare Agent Exposure to investigate: (1) the presence of chemical and biological warfare agents in the Persian Gulf theater during the Persian Gulf conflict; (2) the location and nature of all releases, detections, or reports of such agents and the proximity of military personnel to such locations; (3) the preparedness of military personnel to recognize and respond to possible exposure to such agents; and (4) the adequacy of Department of Defense recordkeeping and reporting procedures with respect to such exposure.

Internet Drug Sales Accountability Act - Amends the Controlled Substances Act to make it unlawful for a person who controls a third-party Internet sales site to: (1) accept for posting on the site an offer to sell an item that the person knows is a controlled substance; or (2) fail to promptly remove from the site an offer to sell an item when a Federal or State official notifies the person that the item is a controlled substance. Defines third-party Internet sales site" as an Internet site that permits users to post an offer to sell an item directly to a consumer. Exempts from such prohibition a licensed pharmacy.Requires a person who controls a third-party Internet sales site to create a system for receipt of notice regarding controlled substance sales by the Federal or State official who sent it.Provides criminal and civil penalties for violations.Declares that a third-party Internet sales site that in good faith monitors and removes any posting of an offer to sell an item that the site believes violates Federal or State law shall not be liable under any Federal or State law."

Colorectal Cancer Detection Act of 2018 This bill amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for Medicare coverage and payment, subject to specified frequency limits, of certain colorectal cancer screening blood-based tests.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Conquer Childhood Cancer Reauthorization Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH), to make an award to build upon existing initiatives to collect biospecimens and clinical and demographic information for at least 90% of all children and adolescents with cancer in one or more Comprehensive Children's Cancer Biorepositories to achieve a better understanding of the cause of such cancers and the effects of treatments for such cancers. Permits funds to be used to: (1) prospectively acquire, preserve, and store high quality, donated biospecimens and associated clinical and demographic information on children, adolescents, and young adults diagnosed with cancer in the United States; (2) maintain a secure searchable database on stored biospecimens and associated clinical and demographic data from such individuals for the conduct research by scientists and qualified health care professionals; and (3) establish procedures for evaluating applications for access to such data for use by researchers and other qualified health care professionals. Directs the Secretary to: (1) require all recipients to make a standard dataset available in electronic format to researchers and qualified health care professionals for peer

College and University Rural Education (CURE) Act of 2007- Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to make grants to partnerships to improve: (1) enrollment rates for graduates and former attendees of rural high schools at rural institutions of higher education; and (2) access and exposure to campuses, classes, programs, and facilities of rural institutions of higher education by rural students.

Foster Children Opportunity Act Amends part E (Foster Care and Adoption Assistance) of title IV of the Social Security Act to require a state plan for foster care and adoption assistance to include procedures to help alien children in the child welfare system achieve special immigrant juvenile status and lawful permanent resident status, so that the child can reasonably be expected to achieve such relief before exiting foster care, if doing so would be in the child's best interests. Requires state child welfare agencies to document for each alien child who is determined to be a child who may qualify for special immigrant juvenile status, lawful permanent resident status, or other forms of relief under immigration law the documentation of: (1) the steps the agency is taking in assisting the child to obtain such status before exiting foster care; and (2) the requisite petitions have been filed on the child's behalf, and whether assistance has been provided to secure immigration legal counsel for the child. Directs the court to determine whether a petition for special immigrant juvenile status or lawful permanent resident status has been filed on the child's behalf and, if so, whether it is in the child's best interests to have such a petition filed. Authorizes the use of court improvement program grant funds to educate and train child welfare and court staff to assist alien children

Older Americans Act Technical Amendments of 1993 - Makes technical amendments to the Older Americans Act of 1965. <n>(Sec. 3) Renames the Assistant Secretary for Aging as the Assistant Secretary for Aging. <n>(Sec. 4) Eliminates the position of Commissioner on Aging from the Administration on Aging of the Department of Health and Human Services. <n>(Sec. 5) Makes technical amendments to the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 and to the Older Americans Act of 1965. <n>(Sec. 6) Repeals the requirement that the Secretary of Health and Human Services designate a Deputy Assistant Secretary for Aging. <n>(Sec. 7) Amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to make technical amendments to the Act. <n>(Sec. 8) Renames the position of Commissioner on Aging as the Commissioner on Aging. <n>(Sec. 9) Eliminates the position of Deputy Commissioner for Aging from the Administration on Aging of the Department of Health and Human Services. <n>(Sec. 10) Renames the position of Director of the Office for Aging as the Director of the Office for Aging. <n>(Sec. 11) Amends the Older Americans Act of 1965 to extend the authorization of appropriations through FY

Employee Free Choice Act of 2016 This bill amends the National Labor Relations Act to require the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) to certify a bargaining representative without directing an election if a majority of the bargaining unit employees have authorized designation of the representative (card-check) and there is no other individual or labor organization currently certified or recognized as the exclusive representative of any of the employees in the unit. The NLRB shall develop guidelines and procedures for the designation by employees of a bargaining representative.

Infertility Research Centers Act of 2002 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development to make grants to, or enter into contracts with, public or nonprofit private entities for the development and operation of centers to conduct activities for the purpose of improving methods of preventing infertility. Requires each center to: (1) conduct clinical and other applied research; (2) develop protocols for training physicians, scientists, nurses, and other health and allied health professionals; (3) conduct training programs for such individuals; (4) develop model continuing education programs for such professionals; and (5) disseminate information to such professionals and the public.Allows a center to use funds to provide: (1) stipends for health and allied health professionals enrolled in specified programs; and (2) fees to individuals serving as subjects in clinical trials.Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a program of agreements with health professionals to conduct infertility prevention research in return for the Government repaying the professionals' educational loans.

Amends Federal law to direct the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to establish a pre-decisional administrative review process for Forest Service actions implementing land and resource management plans that will serve as the sole means by which a person can seek administrative review. Exempts a proposed action from such process if the Chief of the Forest Service determines that an emergency situation exists for which immediate implementation of the action is necessary. Requires the Forest Service to provide notice of, and distribute, a proposed decision along with the final environmental assessment or environmental impact statement. Provides that a proposed action shall not be subject to such process if the Chief determines that an emergency situation exists for which immediate implementation of the action is necessary. Requires the Forest Service to provide notice of the final decision and a process for an expedited post-decisional review. Makes this Act inapplicable to: (1) an authorized hazardous fuel reduction project under the Healthy Forests Restoration Act of 2003, and (2) a proposed action for which a categorically exclusion is provided.

Handgun Control Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit the importation, manufacture, sale, purchase, transfer, receipt, or transportation (use) of a handgun, with exceptions. Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury, consistent with public safety and necessity, to exempt such activities by licensed importers, manufacturers, or dealers, and by licensed pistol clubs, as may be required for the operation of such clubs. <n>Requires a pistol club desiring to be licensed to file an application for a license with the Secretary. Establishes a $25 per year license fee.
