Requires approval of any such application if: (1) all club members are age 21 or older; (2) no member of the club is prohibited from transporting, shipping, or receiving firearms or ammunition in interstate or foreign commerce; (3) no member of the club has willfully violated any Federal firearms law or regulations; (4) the club has not willfully failed to disclose any material information required, or has not made any false statement as to any material fact, in connection with the application; and (5) the club has premises from which it operates and has procedures and facilities for keeping such handguns in a secure place, under the control of the club's chief officer, at all times when they are not being used for target shooting or other

A Better Chance to Learn Act of 1993 - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make grants to local educational agencies and community-based organizations for home-based parent and early childhood education programs. <n>Directs the Secretary to give priority in awarding grants to applicants that are: (1) establishing new programs; and (2) operating or expanding existing programs. <n>Requires grantees to conduct programs that target: (1) working poor families or near poor families that do not qualify for assistance under the early childhood programs under the Head Start Act; (2) families that qualify for assistance under the Federal programs but that are not served by such programs; or (3) parents who have limited or unsuccessful formal schooling. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

NAFTA Worker Adjustment Assistance Act - Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to require the Secretary of Labor to certify a group of workers affected by the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) as eligible for trade adjustment assistance if the Secretary determines that: (1) increases in imports of articles like or directly competitive with articles produced by the workers\\' firm or appropriate subdivision contributed importantly to such total or partial separation, or threat thereof, and to such decline in sales; (2) the Agreement contributed importantly to a shift in production to Mexico of articles like or directly competitive with articles produced by such workers\\' firm or appropriate subdivision thereof; or (3) the group is employed in the manufacture of motor vehicles in the United States. <n>(Sec. 2) Defines North American Free Trade Agreement" as an agreement between the United States and Mexico which provides for the establishment of a free trade area between the United States and Mexico through the reduction and elimination of barriers to trade. <n>(Sec. 3) Requires the Secretary to ensure that adversely affected workers covered by a certification are provided early and effective reemployment assistance. <n>(Sec. 4) Increases the amount authorized to be appropriated for training of adversely affected workers under the Act. <n>(Sec. 5) Requires the Secretary to ensure that adversely affected workers"

Essential Access Community Hospital (EACH) Amendments of 1993 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act with respect to the essential access community hospital program (EACH) to: (1) increase the number of participating States from seven to nine; (2) prohibit the provision of any inpatient hospital services to any patient whose attending physician does not certify that such patient may reasonably be expected to be discharged or transferred to a hospital within 72 hours of admission to the facility, unless the attending physician certifies that the risk associated with transferring the patient to a hospital outweighs the benefits of transferring the patient to a hospital; and (3) limit the average length of inpatient stays for designated rural primary care hospitals. <n>Permits designation of hospitals (currently, only urban hospitals) located in urban areas.

Veterans Sexual Trauma Treatment Act (Sec. 2) This bill revises provisions relating to sexual trauma counseling for veterans to: (1) make the program mandatory; (2) require the provision of treatment for sexual trauma; (3) require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to determine that a mental health professional employed by the Department of Veterans Affairs determines that a veteran is eligible for counseling and treatment; and (4) require that information about the counseling and treatment available to veterans be made available at each Department facility and that it be advertised through public service announcements, pamphlets, billboards, and other appropriate means of communication. Makes eligible for such counseling and treatment: (1) a veteran; (2) a member of a reserve component; and (3) an individual who is a former member of a reserve component and who was discharged or released from service under conditions other than dishonorable.

Federal Accountability for Nuclear Waste Storage Act of 2007 - Amends the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 to require that: (1) a contractor shall transfer spent nuclear fuel from spent nuclear fuel pools to spent nuclear fuel dry casks at an independent spent fuel storage installation licensed by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) and located at the power reactor site; (2) a contractor shall complete the transfer of all spent nuclear fuel that is stored in spent nuclear fuel pools within six years after enactment of this Act; and (3) a contractor shall complete the transfer of any spent nuclear fuel stored in a spent nuclear fuel pool within six years after enactment of this Act. Sets forth requirements for adequate funds or availability, including expedited review.

Volunteer Protection Act of 1995 - Prescribes circumstances under which volunteers working for nonprofit organizations or government entities shall be immune from personal financial liability for acts on behalf of the organization or entity, provided harm was not caused by willful and wanton misconduct, or that the volunteer was acting within the scope of his or her responsibilities. Sets forth exceptions and conditions that a State may impose on the granting of such immunity.

Establishes the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area in Arizona. Requires the Secretary of the Interior, through the Bureau of Land Management, to administer such lands and develop a management plan for the Area.

State Fiscal Relief Act of 2004 - Amends the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003 to extend the temporary freeze of the Federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP) under title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act (SSA) for certain States (continuing the FY 2003 FMAP through each calendar quarter of FY 2004, and the FY 2004 FMAP for each calendar quarter of FY 2005 if the FY 2005 FMAP would otherwise be less than the FY 2004 FMAP).<n><n>Amends the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003 to increase the FMAP: (1) by 2.95 percentage points for the last two calendar quarters of FY 2003 and the first three calendar quarters of FY 2004; and (2) by 1.26 percentage points for the last calendar quarter of FY 2004 and each calendar quarter of FY 2005.<n><n>Increases by 5.9 percent the ceiling on Medicaid payments to territories for the last two calendar quarters of FY 2003 and the first three calendar quarters of FY 2004. Increases such ceiling by 2.52 percent for the last calendar quarter of FY 2004 and each calendar quarter of FY 2005.

Federal Reserve Accountability Act of 2009 - Authorizes the Comptroller General to conduct reviews, including onsite examinations, of the accounting, financial reporting, and internal controls of certain credit facilities established by the Federal Reserve Board or any federal reserve bank, including when such activities are carried out by or on behalf of the Board or any official of a federal reserve bank. Requires: (1) a report on each review conducted to be submitted to Congress within 90 days; and (2) the Comptroller General to release a nonredacted version of any reports on specific credit facilities, one year after the termination of the relevant credit facility. Declares that the Comptroller General shall not disclose to any person or entity, including to Congress, the names or identifying details of specific participants in any of the audited facilities, or identifying details regarding assets or collateral held by, under, or in connection with any of the audited facilities. Prohibits the Comptroller General from disclosing to any person or entity, including to Congress, the names or identifying details of specific participants in any of the audited facilities or identifying details regarding assets or collateral held by, under, or in connection with any of the audited facilities. Declares that the nondisclosure obligation shall expire, and the Comptroller General shall release a nonredacted version of any reports on specific

Requires the Architect of the Capitol to fix the rate of basic pay and benefits for the Director of Fire Safety and Protection at such rate as the Architect considers appropriate, except that such rate may not be less than the rate of pay and benefits for the Director of Engineering under the Architect of the Capitol.Requires the Director, working under the direction and control of the Architect, to: (1) be responsible for all fire safety and protection activities of the Architect of the Capitol; (2) ensure that Architect properties meet the applicable codes and standards established by the National Fire Protection Association, except that the Architect may modify the application of such codes to the properties to take into account the historic and architecturally significant features of such properties so long as a reasonable degree of safety and protection is maintained; and (3) carry out the following duties: (1) the routine periodic testing and maintenance of all fire alarm, fire suppression, and fire protection systems in all Architect properties; (2) the conduct of comprehensive inspections and risk assessments of all Architect properties to identify conditions which constitute fire hazards and to develop plans for the prompt abatement of such conditions; (3) the development and implementation of programs to train employees of the Architect and others in the proper use and maintenance of fire alarm, fire suppression, and fire protection systems and in the proper use and storage

Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2005 - Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to require brokers to disclose in writing to purchasers of mutual funds the amount of any compensation received or to be received by the broker in connection with the transaction. Defines compensation" to include any payment made by an investment adviser to a broker or dealer for promoting the sales of securities of an open-end company.<n><n>Prohibits such disclosure from appearing exclusively in either a registration statement or prospectus of an open-end company, or any other filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).<n><n>Amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 to direct the SEC to require, by rule, that brokerage commissions paid by an open-end company be included in any disclosure of fees and expenses payable by a holder of company securities in a registration statement or other filing with the SEC, including the calculation of expense ratios.<n><n>Reduces from 60 percent to 25 percent the number of interested persons who may serve on the board of directors of a registered investment company. Prohibits any action by such board of directors against any interested person, unless the director has been: (1) approved or elected by the shareholders at least once every five years; and (2) found, on an annual basis,"

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 9, 2014. Liquidity Pricing Act of 2013 - Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to allow the board of directors of an issuer with a public float of $500 million or less (based on a rolling average over the course of the preceding 3-month period) and an average daily trading volume of less than 500,000 shares to select to have its securities quoted and traded using an increment of either $0.05 or $0.10. Prohibits the issuer, with respect to the average trading price in the most recent one-month period for its securities: (1) if such average price is less than $1, it may not make the selection; and (2) if such average price is $1 or more, but less than $2, it may only select to have its securities quoted and traded using an increment of $0.05. Authorizes an issuer that has made such selection to choose to opt out at any time after the 6-month period beginning on the date such selection was made. Requires such issuer to do so by informing the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and each exchange on which its securities are traded. Allows an issuer that opts out to make the selection again at any time after the one-year period beginning on the date

Africa's Call Act) States that Congress supports implementing the Commission for Africa's recommendations to increase foreign assistance to Africa for rich nations to eliminate trade barriers that impede economic opportunity in sub-Saharan Africa.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require an individual taxpayer whose adjusted gross income exceeds $1 million to pay an additional income tax equal to  0.8 percent of so much of such taxpayer's adjusted gross income as exceeds the threshold amount ($1 million in the case of a joint return and $500,000 in the case of any other return). Terminates such tax after 2011.

Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2010 - Requires each state educational agency (SEA) to issue regulations establishing the following minimum requirements: (1) each local educational agency (LEA) in the state shall develop and implement a standard plan for concussion safety and management that includes the education of students, parents, and school personnel about concussions and specified best practices designed to ensure the uniformity of safety standards, treatment, and management; and (2) each public elementary and secondary school shall post on school grounds and make publicly available on the school website specified information on concussions.

TSA Office of Inspection Accountability Act of 2014 - Directs the Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to analyze the data and methods that the Assistant Secretary of Homeland Security (Transportation Security Administration [TSA]) uses to identify TSA employees who meet certain criminal investigative duties. Prohibits the TSA from hiring any new employee to work in the Office of Inspection until: (1) the Assistant Secretary certifies to Congress that the TSA utilized adequate and valid data and methods to make such certification, and (2) the Inspector General submits a finding that such data and methods are inadequate or invalid. Requires the Assistant Secretary to: (1) reclassify criminal investigator positions in the Office as noncriminal investigator positions or non-law enforcement positions if the individuals in those positions do not, or are not expected to, spend an average of at least 50% of their time performing criminal investigative duties; and (2) estimate the total long-term cost savings to the federal government resulting from such implementation and provide such estimate to Congress. Directs the Assistant Secretary to: (1) document and certify to Congress that only those TSA employees who meet the criminal investigative requirements are classified as criminal investigators and are receiving premium pay and other benefits associated with such classification, and (2) reclassify criminal investigator positions as noncriminal investigator positions or non

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Commemorative Coins <n> Title II: Marian Anderson Centennial Commission <n>Marian Anderson Centennial Commemorative Coin Act - <n>Title I: Commemorative Coins <n> Title II: Marian Anderson Centennial Commission <n>Marian Anderson Centennial Commemorative Coin Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to mint one-dollar silver coins emblematic of the accomplishments of Marian Anderson in commemoration of the centennial of her birth. <n>Directs the Secretary to conduct an open design competition for the design of the obverse and reverse of the coins. <n>States that only one facility of the U.S. Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of the coins. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to issue such coins only after July 31, 1997. <n>Requires specified surcharges in sales of the coin, including a surcharge of ten dollars per coin for the half-dollar coin. <n>Mandates prompt payment of all surcharges received from coin sales to the Marian Anderson Commission.

Coordinated Recovery Initiative for Babies Act of 2014 or the CRIB Act of 2014 - Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to study neonatal abstinence syndrome, including by identifying: (1) the most effective and beneficial methods currently available to identify the need for treating and best treatment methods for, infants diagnosed with neonatal abstinence syndrome; (2) barriers that may hinder the clinical use of best practices by medical professionals and other health care providers for such identification and treatment; (3) circumstances that may require particularized best practices; (4) existing surveillance measures within HHS and in state health agencies relating to neonatal abstinence syndrome; and (5) areas in which information on neonatal abstinence syndrome and its surrounding circumstances is insufficient, incomplete, or requires further study or analysis. Directs the Secretary to convene an advisory panel to identify and compile the best practices for identifying and treating neonatal abstinence syndrome. Requires the Secretary to: (1) identify and compile the best practices for medical professionals and other health care providers for identifying and treating neonatal abstinence syndrome; (2) develop and implement a plan for the coordination and, if necessary, expansion and enhancement of public health surveillance of neonatal abstinence syndrome; and (3) post such best practices on HHS' public Internet site.

Cures Can Be Found Act of 2005 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow tax credits for: (1) qualified stem cell research and storage contributions; and (2) qualified umbilical cord blood donation.

American 5-Cent Coin Design Continuity Act of 2003 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to change the design on the obverse and the reverse of the 5-cent coin for coins issued in 2003, 2004, and 2005 in recognition of the bicentennial of the Louisiana Purchase and the expedition of Meriwether Lewis and William Clark.Amends Federal law governing coins and currency to mandate that: (1) the obverse of any 5-cent coin issued after December 31, 2005, bear the likeness of Thomas Jefferson; and (2) the reverse of any such coin bear an image of the home of Thomas Jefferson at Monticello.Establishes the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee to advise the Secretary on the selection of themes and designs for coins (including circulating and bullion coinage) and for congressional and national medals.

Growing Our Manufacturing Employment Act or the GoMe Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow through 2009: (1) a manufacturer's jobs tax credit for wages paid to employees in the United States with a W-2 wage level; and (2) an extension through 2012 of the tax credit for increasing research activities.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 7, 2016. Regulatory Integrity Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill requires each executive agency to make publicly available on its website or in the rule making docket on Regulations.gov a list of each pending agency regulatory action and with regard to each such action: the date on which the agency first began to develop or consider the action, the status of the action, an estimate of the date of upon which the action will be final and in effect, a brief description of the action, and a list of agency regulatory actions issued by the agency that duplicate or overlap with the action. For each pending agency regulatory action, the agency must publish a list of each public communication about the action and with regard to each such communication: the date of the communication, the intended audience of the communication, the method of communication, and a copy of the original communication. The agency must publish such information within 24 hours after its issuance and maintain its public availability at least five years after the date on which the action is finalized. Any public communication issued by an executive agency that refers to a pending agency regulatory action must: specify whether the agency is considering alternatives, specify whether it will be accepting comments, expressly disclose that the agency

Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop and issue public service announcements that advertise and promote the pharmacist profession, highlight the advantages and rewards of being a pharmacist, and encourage individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds to enter the pharmacist profession. Requires such announcements to be: (1) broadcast through appropriate media outlets, including television or radio; and (2) placed in newspapers, on billboards, or on the Internet.Directs the Secretary to: (1) award grants to entities to support State and local advertising campaigns to promote the pharmacist profession, highlight the advantages and rewards of being a pharmacist, and encourage individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds to enter the pharmacist profession; and (2) establish a demonstration project to enhance the participation of individuals who are pharmacists in the National Health Service Corps Loan Repayment Program.Authorizes the Secretary to make grants or contracts to qualifying schools of pharmacy for the purpose of assisting such schools in acquiring and installing computer-based systems to provide pharmaceutical education.

Energy Tax Prevention Act of 2011 - Amends the Clean Air Act to prohibit the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) from promulgating any regulation concerning, taking action relating to, or taking into consideration the emission of a greenhouse gas (GHG) to address climate change. Excludes GHGs from the definition of air pollutant" for purposes of addressing climate change.<n><n>Exempts from such prohibition: (1) implementation and enforcement of the rule, "Light-Duty Vehicle Greenhouse Gas Emission Standards and Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards" and finalization, implementation, enforcement, and revision of the proposed rule, "Greenhouse Gas Emissions Standards and Fuel Efficiency Standards for Medium- and Heavy-Duty Engines and Vehicles"; (2) implementation of the renewable fuel program; (3) statutorily authorized federal research, development, and demonstration programs addressing climate change; (4) implementation and enforcement of stratospheric ozone protection to the extent that such implementation or enforcement only involves class I or class II substances; and (5) implementation and enforcement of renewable fuel program requirements under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990."

Medicare Improvements for Special Needs Beneficiaries Act of 2002 - Amends part C (Medicare+Choice) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for the establishment of specialized Medicare+Choice plans for special needs beneficiaries as any type of coordinated care plan.Permits enrollment restrictions by such plans.Requires plans to establish a clinical delivery system and a data collection system.Requires plans to develop outcome measures.

Knife Owners' Protection Act of 2017 This bill entitles any person who is not otherwise prohibited by federal law from possessing, transporting, shipping, or receiving a knife or knives to transport a knife or knives from any place where such person may lawfully possess, carry, or transport such a knife or knives to any other place where such person may lawfully do so: (1) by motor vehicle if the knife or knives are not directly accessible from the passenger compartment or are contained in a locked container, glove compartment, or console; or (2) by other means if the knife or knives are contained in a locked container. Emergency Knives may be carried in the passenger compartment and need not be secured in a locked container. The bill prohibits the arrest or detention of a person for violation of this requirement unless probable cause exists.

Child Modeling Exploitation Prevention Act This bill amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 and federal criminal law to prohibit employment of exploitive child modeling. It defines exploitive child modeling" as marketing himself or herself in lascivious positions and acts, rather than actually marketing products to consumers, because of financial gain or contractual relationship. An employer who violates this prohibition is subject to criminal penalties—a fine, up to 10 years in prison, or both."

Helping Our Professionals Educationally (HOPE) Act of 2001 - Authorizes each Secretary of the military department concerned to permit a member of the Armed Forces with a critical military skill, at the member's request, to transfer up to one-half of the member's entitlement to basic educational assistance to the member's spouse, children, or combination of such individuals. Limits the total number of months of such transferred to 18 months.Requires the member to designate the dependent(s) to whom such assistance is being transferred and the percentage of such entitlement to be transferred.Allows such members to make, revoke, or modify such transfers at any time after approval. Requires a pro rata repayment of transferred assistance for any of the four-year service period not successfully served by the member (with exceptions in the case of member death or release or discharge for a service-connected disability, for hardship, or for a physical or mental condition).

(Sec. 3) Directs the Office of Government Ethics to conduct a study and report to specified congressional committees on improvements to the financial disclosure process for presidential nominees required under the Ethics in Government Act of 1978. Authorizes appropriations.

Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to continue an individual's entitlement to benefits through the month of his or her death, without affecting any other person's entitlement to benefits for that month.Disregards monthly benefits received for the month in which the individual dies for purposes of the maximum benefit cap.

Amends the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 to establish a National Electric System Public Benefits Fund, administered by the National Electric System Public Benefits Board, to provide matching funds to States for the support of eligible public purpose programs, including conservation and energy efficiency and renewable energy, universal and affordable service, or research and development to support such purposes.Requires owners and operators of electric power generation facilities to contribute funds to the Fund as a condition of transmitting power to any transmitting utility.Permits any State to establish and apply for matching funding for a public purpose program.

Directs the Secretary of the Army to transfer certain land acquired by the United States for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project and located above the top of the exclusive flood pool of such Project to the Secretary of the Interior to be held in trust for the benefit of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe of North and South Dakota. Prohibits such transfer from interfering with any authorized purposes of such Project, or any applicable law.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Gold King Spill Recovery Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) This bill: (1) defines "Gold King Mine spill" as the discharge on August 5, 2015, of approximately 3 million gallons of contaminated water from the Gold King Mine north of Colorado, into Cement Creek that occurred while contractors of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) were conducting an investigation of the mine; and (2) entitles each injured person to receive from the United States compensation for a claim filed or civil action brought under the Federal Tort Claims Act arising out of, or relating to, such spill. The Office of Gold King Mine Spill Claims shall: (1) process such claims as expeditiously as practicable, and (2) determine the amount of compensation appropriate for each claimant.

Energy and Water Integration Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Energy to enter into an arrangement with the National Academy of Sciences to conduct an in-depth analysis of the impact of energy development and production on the water resources of the United States. Requires such analysis to include: (1) a lifecycle assessment of the quantity of water withdrawn and consumed in the production of transportation fuels, or electricity; (2) an assessment of the quantity of water used and consumed in the production of electricity; and (3) an identification and analysis of any unique water impact associated with a specific fuel source.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to enter into an agreement with the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to conduct a demonstration project under which certain eligible covered beneficiaries residing in the area covered by the project will be eligible to enroll in health benefits plans offered through the Federal Employees Health Benefits program. Includes as an eligible covered beneficiary a member or former member of the armed forces, or a dependent of such member, who is or becomes entitled to hospital insurance benefits under part A of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act. <n>Directs the Secretary to carry out the project in two geographic areas, including the catchment area of one or more military medical treatment facilities, within which no more than 25,000 eligible covered beneficiaries reside. Prohibits the other area from including the catchment area of any military medical treatment facility. <n>Directs OPM to require participating health benefits plans to maintain a separate risk pool for purposes of establishing premium rates for covered beneficiaries. Requires the Secretary to make the Government contribution for an eligible covered beneficiary who enrolls in such a plan irrevocable.

Financial Information Privacy Act - Amends the Consumer Credit Protection Act to prohibit obtaining or causing the disclosure of customer information of a financial institution relating to another person by knowingly: (1) making a false statement to an institution with intent to deceive; (2) making a fraudulent statement to an institution with intent to deceive; or (3) knowingly providing any document to an institution knowing that it is counterfeit, that it was fraudulently obtained, or that it contains a false statement.Prohibits: (1) requesting a person to obtain customer information of a financial institution under false pretenses; and (2) law enforcement agencies from obtaining customer information of a financial institution under false pretenses.Provides for: (1) administrative enforcement by the Office of Thrift Supervision; (2) civil and criminal penalties; and (3) related agency guidance.

PLO Accountability Act of 2017 This bill prohibits the President from certifying to Congress that the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) or the Palestinian Authority (PA) are in compliance with certain commitments made with Israel regarding the status of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The Anti-Terrorism Act of 1987 is amended to authorize the President to waive for up to six months the prohibition against establishment or maintenance of a PLO office, headquarters, premises, or other facilities within U.S. jurisdiction, if the President certifies to Congress that the PLO or the PA are in compliance with their commitments and that such waiver is in the national security interests of the United States.

Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act - Amends the federal criminal code to prohibit transporting a minor child across a state line to obtain an abortion (deems such transporting to be a de facto abridgment of the right of a parent under any law in the minors state of residence that requires parental involvement in the minors abortion decision). Makes an exception for an abortion necessary to safe the life of the minor.Makes it an affirmative defense to a prosecution for, or to a civil action based on, such a violation that the defendant: (1) reasonably believed that before the minor obtained the abortion, the required parental consent or notification or judicial authorization took place; or (2) was presented with documentation showing that a court waived parental notification requirements or authorized the minor's abortion.Authorizes any parent who suffers harm from a violation to obtain appropriate relief in a civil action unless such parent committed an act of incest with the minor.

High-End Computing Revitalization Act of 2004 - (Sec. 4) Directs the Secretary of Energy, acting through the Director of the Office of Science of the Department of Energy (DOE), to carry out a program of research and development (involving software and hardware) to advance high-end computing systems. Requires the Secretary to: (1) support individual investigators and multidisciplinary teams of investigators; (2) conduct research in multiple architectures, including vector, reconfigurable logic, streaming, processor-in-memory, and multithreading architectures; (3) conduct research in software development on optimal algorithms, programming environments, tools, languages, and operating systems for high-end computing systems; (4) acquire, or operate from large computing power equipment or facilities for the use of investigators conducting research and development on an ultrascale scientific computing capability; (5) support technology transfer to the private sector and others in accordance with applicable law; and (6) ensure that the program is coordinated with relevant activities in industry and other Federal agencies, including the National Nuclear Security Administration, the National Science Foundation, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, and the National Security Agency.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to develop, plan, construct, acquire, or operate at least one High-End Software Development Center which shall concentrate efforts to: (1) support individual

Amends the Homeland Security Act to repeal the transfer of agricultural import and entry inspection functions from the Department of Agriculture to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). Directs the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of DHS to enter into an agreement to effectuate the return of such functions to the Department.

International Remittance Services Enhancement and Protection Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal Credit Union Act to authorize the National Credit Union Administration to prescribe regulations requiring financial institutions or money transmitting businesses initiating an international money transfer on behalf of a consumer to disclose in English and in any other language: (1) any fees to be charged to the recipient, including any exchange rate or currency conversion fees; (2) a final itemization of all costs to the consumer, which would include all fees charged, for the remittance; and (3) the exact amount of foreign currency to be received by the recipient in the foreign country.Directs the appropriate Federal banking agencies and the Federal Trade Commission to jointly prescribe such regulations.

Animal Agriculture Environmental Incentives Act of 1998 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish an animal feeding operation equipment credit for eligible nutrient management costs." Defines such costs as amounts paid by a taxpayer to purchase animal manure or eligible processing equipment for use at an animal feeding operation owned by the taxpayer."

Prescription and Responsible Drug Disposal Act of 2010 - Amends the Controlled Substances Act to authorize an ultimate user (defined as a person lawfully entitled to dispose of a controlled substance under the same conditions as provided for under this Act) to dispose of a controlled substance to another person for the purpose of disposal under the same conditions in accordance with regulations issued by the Attorney General to prevent diversion.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 17, 2015. Social Security Identity Defense Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to require the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), if it has reason to believe that there has been a fraudulent use of a Social Security account number in an individual's employment context, to disclose to the individual: (1) the account number; (2) the taxpayer identity information of the individual who was assigned such account number; and (3) the employer who made the statement including the account number. The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the Attorney General may disclose information received from the IRS to federal, state, and local law enforcement officials, but may not use such information for criminal investigations or prosecutions. Any return information disclosed may not be provided to state or local law enforcement officials until an official has entered into a memorandum of understanding with the IRS that includes: (1) confidentiality of returns and return information and prohibitions on disclosure; (2) safeguards, restrictions on access, and recordkeeping requirements; and (3) application of penalties for the unauthorized disclosure of returns and return information. The IRS must notify an employee who has reason to believe that his or her social security number is not the correct number. (Sec. 3) The bill

Windstorm Hazard Reduction Research and Technology Transfer Act - Requires the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy to establish an Interagency Group, to be cochaired by the Director or the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) or that Director's designee, consisting of representatives of appropriate Federal agencies, including the National Science Foundation, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the National Institute of Standards and Technology, the Department of Energy, and other agencies with jurisdiction over housing, construction, and natural disaster mitigation and relief, to be responsible for the development and implementation of a coordinated Federal windstorm hazard reduction research, development, and technology transfer program. Declares that the objective of the windstorm hazard reduction program is to achieve major measurable reductions in losses that would otherwise have occurred to life and property from windstorms. States that such program shall include: (1) pertinent basic and applied research which takes into account locality-specific weather, susceptibility to other hazards, and design and construction practices; (2) better understanding of impediments and disincentives to wind hazard reduction; (3) inventorying of existing buildings and related data for use in developing and deploying wind hazard mitigation measures; (4) dissemination of information on cost-effective and affordable wind hazard reduction research results, technology, and techniques to industry

Establishes the San Juan Islands National Conservation Area, consisting of approximately 1,000 acres of public land in the Washington state. Directs the Secretary of the Interior to develop a comprehensive plan for the long-term management of the Conservation Area. Requires the Secretary to: (1) manage the Conservation Area in a manner to conserve, protect, and enhance its resources; and (2) develop a comprehensive plan for the long-term management of the Conservation Area.

Flagship Species Conservation Act of 2004 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to use amounts in the Flagship Species Conservation Fund established by this Act to provide financial assistance for projects for the conservation of flagship species throughout the world for which project proposals are approved by the Secretary. Defines a flagship species" as any mammal, fish, bird, or reptile that is listed as an endangered or threatened species under the Endangered Species Act of 1973, whose range is wholly outside of the United States, and that appeals to the public and has other features that make it suitable for communicating conservation concerns. Allows proposals for projects for the conservation of a flagship species to be submitted to the Secretary by: (1) a country\\'s wildlife management authority that has within its boundaries any part of the range of a flagship species, if the agency has authority over fish or wildlife and the agency\\'s activities affect the species; (2) the CITES Secretariat; or (3) any person with demonstrated expertise in the conservation of such species."

Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act and the Code of Federal Regulations to extend until October 16, 2003, the deadline for certain covered entities (health care providers, health plans, and health care clearinghouses) to comply with electronic transaction and privacy standards established under such Acts and the Privacy Act of 1974.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on March 23, 2012. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Autism Spectrum Disorders Implementing Training Act of 2012 - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award grants to local educational agencies (LEAs), partnerships between states and LEAs, nonprofit organizations, or consortia of such entities to implement a demonstration program to provide effective teaching, communication, and related staff methods in classroom settings for students with autism spectrum disorders. Requires the Secretary to conduct an evaluation of such program.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the Senate on March 6, 2003. However, because action occurred on the measure, the summary has been expanded.)Smaller Schools, Stronger Communities Act - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA) to allow States to use certain ESEA funds for grants to local educational agencies for the development or renovation of small learning communities. Defines a small learning community as one involving an enrollment of no more than 1,000 students, but no more than 600 students in secondary schools.

Video Choice Act of 2005 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit a competitive video services provider (CVSP) from being required to obtain a franchise in order to provide any video programming, interactive on-demand services, other programming services, or any other video services in any geographic area if the CVSP has any right, permission, or authority to establish lines in or across public rights-of-way in such area which right, permission, or authority does not rely on, and is independent of any cable franchise obtained pursuant to this Act. Allows the CVSP to be subject to the payment of fees to a local franchising authority, based on the provider's gross revenues. Limits the rate at which fees are imposed to: (1) the rate at which franchise fees are imposed on any cable operator providing cable service in the authority's jurisdiction; or (2) the rate at which franchise fees could be imposed on a cable operator in any jurisdiction in which no cable operator provides service.

After June 1, 2001, a vessel subject to this Act may not operate on the navigable waters of the United States unless a response plan for that operation has been approved by the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard is operating and implemented. Defines a response plan" as a plan for the prevention of oil spills and the containment and cleanup of oil spills from the navigable waters of the United States and for the protection of fisheries and wildlife, natural resources, and public and private property from such a spill.Directs the Secretary to issue regulations establishing the minimum requirements for approval of response plans, including requiring that each plan: (1) include complete details concerning the response to oil spills of various sizes from vessels to which the plan applies; (2) be designed in terms of personnel, materials, and equipment necessary to remove oil and minimize any damage to the environment resulting from a maximum probable spill and a worse case spill; (3) provide procedures for early detection of an oil spill and timely notification of appropriate Federal, State, and local authorities about the spill; (4) demonstrate ownership of or access to an emergency response communications network that covers all locations of operation or transit by the vessel to which the plan applies and provides for immediate notification and continual emergency communications during cleanup response; (5) state the number, training preparedness"

Protection from Sexual Predators Act of 1997 - Expresses the sense of the Congress that States should: (1) more seriously consider the relatively high recidivism rate of sexual offenders when deciding whether to plea bargain with first-time sexual offenders and whether to grant parole to sexual offenders; and (2) review their treatment and parole supervision programs for sexual offenders to assure that such programs are fulfilling their goals. <n>Amends the Federal criminal code to provide that whoever violates provisions regarding aggravated sexual abuse (or engages in conduct that would violate such provisions if the conduct had occurred in the special maritime and territorial jurisdiction of the United States) after having previously been convicted of another State or Federal sexual abuse offense (or conduct that would have been such an offense if the offense had occurred in such jurisdiction) shall be imprisoned for life. <n>Amends the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 to require a State, to be eligible for a grant under such Act, to provide assurances to the Attorney General that it has in effect laws which allow the court to impose a sentence of life in prison without parole on a defendant in a criminal case who is convicted of a State offense for conduct that is either an aggravated sexual abuse offense or one which would have been such an offense if the offense had occurred in such jurisdiction

Meat and Poultry Products Traceability and Safety Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal Meat Inspection Act and the Poultry Products Inspection Act to direct that cattle, sheep, swine, goats, horses, mules and other equines presented for slaughter for human consumption, and the carcasses or parts of carcasses and the meat and food products of those animals, shipped in interstate commerce be identified in a manner that enables the Secretary of Agriculture to trace: (1) each animal to any location at which the animal was held at any time before slaughter; and (2) each carcass or part of a carcass and food product forward from slaughter through processing and distribution to the ultimate consumer.Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) prohibit or restrict entry to a slaughtering establishment of such an animal not so identified; and (2) require that each person, firm, or corporation required to identify livestock maintain accurate records.Directs the Secretary to establish a traceability system for all stages of production, processing, and distribution of poultry and poultry food products produced through the slaughter of such animals.

Presidential Historical Records Preservation Act of 2008 - Directs the National Archives and Records Commission to make grants on a competitive basis to eligible entities to promote the historical preservation of, and public access to, historical records and documents relating to any President who does not have a Presidential archival depository currently managed and maintained by the federal government pursuant to the Presidential Libraries Act of 1955. Defines eligible entity" as: (1) a tax-exempt organization or federal, state, or local government; or (2) a state or local government. Prohibits the use of grant funds for the maintenance, operating costs, or construction of any facility to house such records or documents."

Local Zoning Preservation Act of 1999 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to declare that a State or local government decision to deny a request to place, construct, or modify personal wireless service facilities shall be in writing and supported by substantial evidence. (Current law requires such a decision to be in writing and supported by substantial evidence.)

Antitrust Video Competition Improvement Act of 1998 - States that, in any civil action based on an antitrust claim under the Sherman Act, evidence that a multichannel video programming distributor (MVPD) has acted exclusive with respect to a market in which it has market power to prevent another MVPD from obtaining particular video programming from any person shall be sufficient to establish a presumption of a violation of such section. <n>(Sec. 3) States that evidence that an MVPD has obtained particular video programming from any person on terms more favorable than those offered by another MVPD in the same market shall be sufficient to establish a presumption of a violation of such section. <n>(Sec. 4) Defines multichannel video programming distributor" as a person, including a cable operator, a multichannel multipoint distribution service, a direct broadcast satellite service, an open video system, a multichannel television broadcaster, or a television receive-only satellite program distributor, that makes available for purchase, by subscribers or customers, multiple channels of video programming. <n>(Sec. 5) Makes this Act effective on the date of enactment, but shall not apply to conduct occurring before such date."

Veterans Timely Access to Health Care Act - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to prescribe an appropriate standard for access to health care for a veteran seeking primary care from the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) that is determined from the date that the veteran contacts the VA seeking an appointment until a visit with a primary-care provider is completed, 30 days. Directs the Secretary to periodically review the performance of VA health-care facilities compared to such standard. Authorizes the Secretary to furnish health care and services for a veteran in a non-VA facility when the Secretary is unable to meet such access standards. Prohibits the non-VA facility from billing the veteran for any difference between its billed charges and the amount paid by the Secretary. Makes such provisions inapplicable to a veteran enrolled or seeking care at a VA facility within a VA geographic service area that has a compliance rate of 90% or more. Directs the Secretary to submit quarterly reports to the congressional veterans committees on the experience of the VA during the quarter covered by the reports with respect to waiting times for VA health-care appointments.

Team B Act This bill amends the National Security Act of 1947 to establish the Counterterrorism Competitive Analysis Council to: advise the National Intelligence Director (NID) on matters of policy relating to the threats of international terrorism and domestic radicalization based on all-source information; prepare a competitive analysis of each national intelligence estimate concerning al-Qaeda and other foreign terrorist organizations and submit such analysis to the NID and the Council; and annually submit to Congress a report on trends in counterterrorism and domestic radicalization. The NID shall transmit to the Council each national intelligence estimate concerning al-Qaeda and other foreign terrorist organizations.

Afghanistan Suspension and Debarment Reform Act - Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 to authorize the Inspector General (IG) of the Department of Defense (DOD) to refer to the lead agency for suspension or debarment a case involving an Afghan national or foreign national or foreign company operating in Afghanistan that has received, or may receive in the future, funds from a covered prime contract or a subcontract. Requires: (1) the lead agency to accept or decline the case; and (2) the Interagency Committee on Debarment and Suspension to make a determination regarding whether the IG shall act as lead agency in the case.

Adoption Equality Act of 1998 - Amends title IV part E (Federal Payments for Foster Care and Adoption Assistance) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to revise adoption assistance eligibility guidelines for children with special needs. <n>Makes eligible for such assistance only children who before termination of parental rights and the initiation of adoption proceedings were: (1) in the care of a public or licensed private child care agency or Indian tribal organization, either pursuant to a voluntary placement agreement or as a result of a judicial determination to the effect that continuation in the home would be contrary to the child's safety and welfare; or (2) residing in a foster family home or child care institution with the child's minor parent. <n>Requires a State to consider such special needs, together with the circumstances of the adopting parents, in determining the amount of Federal adoption subsidies paid to them. <n>Prohibits assistance with respect to any child who is not a U.S. citizen or resident and who was adopted outside the United States or was brought into it for adoption purposes. <n>Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to reduce Federal adoption subsidies by specified amounts for FY 1999 through 2002 to each State.

Historically Women's Public Colleges or Universities Historic Building Restoration and Preservation Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to award grants to historically women's public colleges or universities for the preservation and restoration of historic buildings and structures on their campuses. Specifies eight institutions to receive such grants in FY 2001.

(Sec. 2) Provides that, in any case, the maximum aggregate outstanding amount of notes and obligations of a single issuer guaranteed shall be based upon the amount of the grant approval for the issuer, the fiscal condition of the issuer, and the potential return on investment of the projects to be undertaken with the proceeds of such notes and obligations, but may not exceed the discounted present value of the grants that the issuer would receive over a period not to exceed 20 years if the issuer's annual grant amount over such period were equal to 80 percent of the current grant approval for the issuer.(Sec. 3) Amends the Federal Home Loan Bank Act to repeal the requirement that a Federal home loan bank make advances to a nonmember mortgagee, except that such advances may be used only for community lending (currently, only for community lending).(Sec. 4) Repeals the requirement that a Federal home loan bank make advances to a State or local housing finance agency or Indian housing authority approved under title II of the National Housing Act, which is subject to the inspection and supervision of a governmental agency, is not an insured depository institution or a subsidiary of an insured depository institution, and is certified as a community development financial institution under the Community Development Banking and Financial Institutions Act of 1994.(

Judicial Administration and Technical Amendments Act of 2008 - Amends the federal judicial code to: (1) change the composition of divisions of the Western District of Tennessee; (2) require a supplemental attendance fee for petit jurors serving on lengthy trials; (3) authorize district courts as to a jury summons; (4) require the clerk of court or jury commission to post a general notice for public review on the court's website explaining the process by which names are periodically and randomly drawn; (5) require public drawing specifications for jury wheels; (6) direct the Comptroller General to assess the cost of using court technology in federal criminal cases; and (7) repeal a provision in the federal bankruptcy code that terminates the authority of certain magistrate judges.

Global Investments in America's Cities Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to direct that at least 3,000 of the visas made available each fiscal year be reserved for qualified immigrants seeking to invest in a new commercial enterprise which will create employment in an economically distressed urban area. Defines "economically distressed urban area" as a city that has an average unemployment rate of at least 150% of the national average rate for the preceding year. Directs that the petitioner for classification under this Act be guaranteed of a decision on the petition in 60 days or less. Directs the Comptroller General (GAO) to report to Congress on the EB-5 Visa Program.

Restoring the 10th Amendment Act - Authorizes a designated state official to submit to the head of a federal agency proposing a rule, during the period during which the proposed rule is open for public comment, a legal brief challenging the constitutionality of the rule under the Tenth Amendment. Requires the agency head: (1) to notify the designated official of each state within 15 days after such a brief is submitted; (2) to post prominently on the front page of the agency's website a link to the brief; and (3) within 15 days after posting such link, to certify in writing that the rule does not violate the Tenth Amendment and post the certification prominently on the front page of the agency's website, unless the agency determines not to finalize the proposed rule.

Small Business Expansion and Hiring Act of 2011- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow employers a business-related tax credit for the retention of certain employees who were employed for not less than 52 consecutive weeks between December 31, 2010, and January 1, 2014, or whose wages equaled at least 80% of them during the last 26 weeks of such period. Limits the amount of such credit to $400,000 in any taxable year.

End Tax  uncertainty Act of 2010 - Makes permanent: (1) the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001; and (2) provisions of the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003 that reduce income tax rates on dividend and capital gains income.<n><n>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) provide for annual increases, between 2010 and 2020, in the amount of the alternative minimum tax (AMT) exemption amount for single and married taxpayers; and (2) allow a permanent offset against the AMT for certain nonrefundable tax credits.

Shields an air carrier, contractor, or subcontractor employee from liability for refusing to violate or assist in the violation of any law, including any rule or regulation, in the course of employment if the refusal is based on a reasonable belief that the law would be violated. Prohibits air carriers, contractors, and subcontractors from discriminating against an employee alleging discrimination in violation of this Act. Sets forth procedures and penalties for violations.

Making Education Affordable Act This bill amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to: (1) extend the authorization of appropriations for the Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education through FY2018, and (2) authorize the Department of Education (ED) to award grants to institutions of higher education to carry out credit-based academic transition programs established through partnerships between high schools and such institutions that utilize dual or concurrent enrollment programs or early college high school programs that enable students to earn college credits while in high school. ED shall give priority in awarding grants to institutions that serve students from low-income families, students from rural communities, or students who are the first in their family to receive postsecondary education. ED shall: (1) conduct an independent evaluation of the effectiveness of grantees' activities, and (2) report to Congress on the evaluation.

Helping Responsible Homeowners Act - Requires the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) (government sponsored enterprises or GSEs) to provide for the refinancing of qualified mortgages on single-family housing they own and guarantee. Requires the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) to establish policies and procedures requiring the GSEs to: (1) purchase or guarantee the refinancing mortgage used to refinance a qualified mortgage upon the request of the mortgagee; and (2) not charge the mortgagee any up-front fee beyond the standard guarantee fee for such refinancing. Prohibits: (1) charging the mortgagee any up-front fee beyond the standard guarantee fee for such refinancing; and (2) resubordination of second liens by any servicer or creditor holding a second lien on a qualified mortgage who refuses to resubordinate that lien.

(Sec. 3) Prohibits a depository institution or branch of a foreign bank (other than an affiliate of a foreign bank) from opening or maintaining any account in the United States for a foreign entity or a representative of a foreign entity, unless: (1) for each such account, the institution completes and maintains in the United States a form or record identifying each person having a direct or beneficial ownership interest in the account; or (2) some or all of the shares of the foreign entity are publicly traded. Prohibits such an institution from opening or maintaining a correspondent account in the United States for or on behalf of a foreign banking institution, or a correspondent bank relationship with a foreign bank, that: (1) is organized under the laws of a jurisdiction outside of the United States; and (2) is not subject to comprehensive supervision or regulation on a consolidated basis by the appropriate authorities in such jurisdiction. Directs the appropriate Federal banking agency, within 48 hours after receiving a request by the appropriate Federal banking agency for information related to anti-money laundering compliance by a financial institution or correspondent bank, to issue a cease and desist order: (1) prohibiting the opening or maintaining of any correspondent account in the United States for or on behalf of a foreign banking institution or a correspondent bank relationship with a foreign bank

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Federal Airports Security Enhancement Act <n> Title II: Miscellaneous Amendments <n> Title III: Effective Dates <n>Title I: Federal Airports Security Enhancement Act (Sec. 102) Amends the Federal Airports Security Enhancement Act to provide for the establishment of Airport Security Committees at each airport location. Requires the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to establish such Committees at each airport location to be composed of representatives of the air carriers, airport operators, other interested parties, and at least one representative from the Federal Protective Service, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the FAA, and one member from each local jurisdiction that the airport may be located in or that may have jurisdictional authority for the airport facility. <n>(Sec. 103) Directs the Administrator to prescribe regulations requiring the screening of all passengers and property that will be carried in a cabin of an aircraft in air transportation or intrastate air transportation. Requires the Administrator to: (1) require that sufficient Federal Police Officers are posted at airport facilities to provide patrol duties during all hours of operations as well as supervise screening personnel; (2) maintain sufficient numbers of Special Agents to provide necessary investigative and supervisory capability; and (3) obtain all necessary personnel and authorization from the Administrator of the General Services Administration

Comprehensive Strategy to Destroy ISIS Act of 2017 This bill requires the Department of Defense and the Department of State to submit jointly to Congress a strategy to destroy the Islamic State Iraq and al-Sham (ISIS) and its affiliates. Such strategy shall include: an update on the status and progress of the Global Coalition to Counter ISIS and specific actions being taken in conjunction with such Coalition to destroy and eliminate ISIS; a strategy for the deployment of U.S. military assets, including ground combat forces, to train and equip allies, as well as potential direct confrontation with ISIS fighters and affiliates; a strategy for the use of drone strikes in Iraq and Syria against ISIS senior leaders and infrastructure; a plan to strengthen the capacity of the Iraqi Security Forces, the Kurdish Peshmerga, the Jordanian Armed Forces, the Afghanistan Security Forces, and others to counter gains by ISIS and its affiliates; a plan to provide humanitarian assistance and relief, governance, and rule of law to regions previously impacted by ISIS and its affiliates; and a plan to deny financial resources to ISIS and its affiliates. The State Department shall submit at least once every two years an update of such strategy.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to set forth rules for the tax deduction for charitable contributions of computer software or equipment to elementary and secondary schools and to qualified organizations providing assistance to individuals with disabilities.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 23, 2016. Contact Lens Consumer Health Protection Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act to revise the process for contact lens sellers and prescribers to verify prescriptions. If a prescriber communicates a question or concern about the accuracy of a prescription, or any other matter relating to the verification of the prescription, to a seller through a toll-free telephone service or dedicated email address before the eight-business-hour period ending before the seller obtains affirmative confirmation of the prescription's accuracy, the prescription shall be unverified until the seller obtains affirmative confirmation from the prescriber. If a prescriber informs a seller that the contact lens prescription is inaccurate, expired, or otherwise invalid: (1) the seller shall not fill the prescription, and (2) the prescriber shall specify the basis for the inaccuracy or invalidity of the prescription. If a prescriber communicates a question or concern about the accuracy of a prescription before the deadline, the seller shall not fill the prescription and the prescriber shall provide the seller with an accurate prescription. The bill allows a prescriber to provide written notification to a seller requesting that all requests for verification from that seller be communicated to that prescribe

Women's Human Rights Protection Act of 1993 - Requires the Secretary of State to submit to the Congress a report on the steps taken to create the position of women's human rights advocate within the Department of State.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) expand the definition of qualifying income" for purposes of determining publicly traded partnerships to include income and gains from the use, sale, or exchange of infrastructure property; (2) make infrastructure property eligible for the domestic production deduction; and (3) treat infrastructure property as five-year property for purposes of the deduction."

Independent Pharmacy Protection Act of 2006 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require each contract entered into with a prescription drug plan (PDP) sponsor with respect to a prescription drug plan offered by such sponsor to provide for: (1) the availability of direct deposit payments; (2) increased dispensing fees for generic drugs; and (3) payments within ten days for certain pharmacies. Applies such requirements to contracts with a Medicare Advantage organization in the same manner as they apply to contracts with a PDP sponsor offering a prescription drug plan under Medicare part D.

Natural Disaster Tax Relief Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to prohibit an additional tax on distributions from certain retirement plans to pay qualified acquisition costs for the principal residence of a taxpayer: (1) who receives such a distribution or is the spouse, child, or grandchild of such individual and whose principal residence was destroyed or substantially damaged by Hurricane Andrew, Hurricane Iniki, or Omar; or (2) whose principal residence was destroyed or substantially damaged by such hurricane. <n>Authorizes a taxpayer who has income derived from the sale or exchange of crops grown in an area designated by the President as a disaster area to include such income in the year following the taxable year in which such sale or exchange occurs. Declares that if the taxpayer's principal residence or any of its contents is compulsorily or involuntarily converted as a result of a presidentially declared disaster, then the applicable contribution base for purposes of the self-employment tax shall be increased by the lesser of: (1) the applicable contribution base for the preceding taxable year, reduced by the self-employment income of the taxpayer for the preceding taxable year; or (2) the amounts so included in gross income for the taxable year of inclusion. <n>Amends provisions concerning involuntary conversions to provide that a taxpayer shall

Return of Talent Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) to establish the Return of Talent Program to permit eligible aliens to temporarily return to their country of citizenship in order to make a material contribution if the country is engaged in post-conflict or natural disaster reconstruction activities. Directs that an alien is eligible to participate in the Program if he or she meets the following special immigrant description: (1) a citizen of a country where authorization for United Nations peacekeeping operations was initiated by the United Nations Security Council during the 10 years preceding such determination; or (2) a citizen of a country which received funding from the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) in response to a declared disaster in such country that is beyond the country's response capacity and warrants a response by the U.S. government. Allows the spouse, parents, siblings, and any minor children of an alien who participates in the Program to return to the alien's country of citizenship with the alien and reenter the United States with them.

Lifelong Improvements in Food and Exercise Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to carry out a national program to reduce obesity and chronic obesity among individuals.<n><n>Requires the Secretary, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to support activities to: (1) train health professionals to recognize that patients are overweight and to recommend prevention activities regarding such condition; (2) educate the public with respect to the condition being overweight; (3) develop and demonstrate intervention strategies for use at hospitals and community health centers; and (4) conduct and support research to determine ways to prevent obesity and chronic disease among individuals who are overweight.

SOAR to Health and Wellness Act of 2016 This bill directs the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish a pilot program, to be known as Stop, Observe, Ask, and Respond to Health and Wellness Training (or SOAR to Health and Wellness Training), to provide training to health care providers and other related providers on human trafficking. The pilot program shall train health care providers and other related providers to: (1) identify potential human trafficking victims; (2) work with law enforcement to report and facilitate communication with such victims; (3) refer victims to social or victims service agencies or organizations; and (4) provide such victims care that is coordinated, victim centered, culturally relevant, comprehensive, evidence based, gender responsive, age appropriate, and trauma informed. HHS shall report on the number of human trafficking victims identified and served in health care settings or other related provider settings.

Applies the rights and protections of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 to any individual who occupies an employment position or who is an applicant for an employment position, as well as to any employing authority of the House of Representatives. Applies the rights and protections of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to any individual who is employed by an instrumentality of the Congress. Declares that the provisions of this Act are enacted by the House as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the House, with full recognition of the right of the House to change its rules, in the same manner, and to the same extent as in any other rule of the House. <n>Makes such provisions applicable to any individual who is an employee of, or an applicant for employment with, an instrumentality of the Congress. <n>Requires the chief official of each instrumentality of the Congress to establish remedies and procedures to be utilized with respect to such rights and protections. <n>Requires the Architect of the Capitol to report to the Congress describing steps taken to implement provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 regarding age discrimination in the legislative branch. <n>Expresses the sense of the House of Representatives that the Committee on House Administration should review the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 and make

Expanding International Education for All Act - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to revise provisions for international education programs at the undergraduate level, including to: (1) authorize the Secretary of Education to make grants to higher education institutions, community and junior colleges, or consortia of such institutions (which may include graduate schools as part of a consortia that serves undergraduates) to pay the Federal share of the cost of planning and establishing a foreign language program, an international studies program, or a business and international education program at the undergraduate level; (2) require such grants to be used in conjunction with institutional resources and private sector funds for specified activities, including teaching, research, curriculum planning and development, training of faculty members in foreign countries, acquisition of research and instructional materials, establishing and maintaining a network with other institutions of higher education and resource centers focused on strengthening foreign language study and international studies programs, expansion of existing and development of new opportunities for learning foreign languages, international education programs designed to develop or enhance linkages between two- to four-year institutions of higher education, or baccalaureate and postbaccalaureate programs or institutions, the development or expansion of undergraduate study abroad in which study abroad opportunities are not otherwise available or which serve students for whom such opportunities are not otherwise available and which provide courses closely related

Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Tax Treatment Act - Provides that if a qualified taxpayer receives qualified settlement income during a taxable year the tax imposed by chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code for such taxable year shall be equal to the sum of the tax which would be imposed if no amount of elected qualified settlement income were included in gross income and no deduction were allowed for such year for expenses attributable to such elected qualified settlement income plus the increase in tax under such chapter which would result if taxable income for each of the years in the applicable period were increased by an amount equal to the applicable fraction of the elected qualified settlement income reduced by any expenses attributable to such elected qualified settlement income. Specifies that if a qualified taxpayer makes an election with respect to any qualified settlement income for any taxable year the taxpayer may not elect to treat such amount as elected farm income under the Code.

Employee Right to Choose Act of 2003- Amends the National Labor Relations Act to require that, when the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) certifies the results of an election of a collective bargaining unit, the results shall be made available to the public and on the Board's website.Repeals the requirement that, when the NLRB certifies an election of a collective bargaining unit, the results shall be made available to the public and on the Board's website.Repeals the requirement that, when the NLRB certifies an election of a collective bargaining unit, the results shall be made available to the public and on the Board's website.Requires collective bargaining to be the performance of the mutual obligation of the employer and the representative of the employees to meet at reasonable times and confer in good faith with respect to wages, hours, and other terms and conditions of employment, or the negotiation of an agreement, or any question arising thereunder, and the execution of a written contract incorporating any agreement reached if requested by either party, but does not compel either party to agree to a proposal or require the making of a concession.Provides that, where there is in effect a collective-bargaining contract covering employees in an industry affecting commerce, the duty to bargain collectively shall also

Highway Runoff Management Act This bill requires a state to develop a process for analyzing the erosive force of highway runoff generated from federal-aid highway projects and apply management measures to maintain or restore impacted hydrology associated with such runoff. The Department of Transportation (DOT) must publish guidance to assist states in carrying out this bill.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on September 22, 2013. Forces for Military Mental Health Act (Sec. 2) This bill authorizes the Department of Defense (DOD) to carry out a three-year pilot program to assess the feasibility and advisability of enhancing DOD efforts in research, treatment, education, and outreach on mental health and substance use disorders and Traumatic Brain Injury in members of the National Guard and reserves, their family members, and their caregivers through specified community partners.
