DOD may award up to five grants to such community partners, which shall be used to: (1) engage in research on the causes, development, and innovative treatment of mental health and substance use disorders and Traumatic Brain Injury in such members and family members and their caregivers; (2) provide treatment to such members and family members; (3) identify and disseminate evidence-based treatments of mental health and substance use disorders and Traumatic Brain Injury; and (4) provide outreach and education to such members, their families, and caregivers and the public about such mental health and substance use disorders and Traumatic Brain Injury. DOD may award a grant to an organization or institution only if the awardee agrees to make contributions toward the costs of activities carried out with the grant, from non-federal sources, an amount equal to

Graduate Opportunities in Higher Education Act of 2005 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 (HEA) to revise requirements for Graduate and Postsecondary Improvement Programs (title VII), and to reauthorize appropriations for some of such programs through FY2010.<n><n>(Sec. 2) Revises the Jacob K. Javits fellowship program. Directs the Secretary of Education to give grant priority to institutions of higher education (IHEs) for fellowships to students in advanced linguistic studies and courses that prepare teachers to teach students with limited English proficiency. Permits IHEs to allow fellowship recipients an interruption of study due to active duty military service or a personal or family member illness. Revises requirements for allocation of fellowships. Directs the Secretary to ensure that one member of the fellowship board will be from a minority-serving institution. Reauthorizes appropriations through FY2010.<n><n>(Sec. 3) Revises the program of graduate assistance in areas of national need. Directs the Secretary to give grant priority to IHEs to prepare mathematics, science and special education faculty who can train highly qualified mathematics, science, or special education teachers for service in elementary and secondary schools. Revises requirements relating to collaboration with other programs. Reauthorizes appropriations through FY2010.

Gasoline Tax Relief Act of 2006 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to suspend the excise tax on highway motor fuels, for a specified 60-day period, when the retail price for gasoline is greater than the benchmark price ( $2.75 per gallon). Provides for adjustments to such excise tax for inflation beginning in 2007.

National Cancer Act of 2003 - Expresses the sense of the Senate that it is at a point in history in which we must take the proper steps to reach the goal of making cancer survivorship deaths rare by the year 2015.Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop a plan for which the State cancer registries funded with grants under the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results program of the National Cancer Institute shall outline strategies by which the State cancer registries funded with such grants shall: (1) expand, intensify, and coordinate efforts to collect and analyze data on cancer incidence and mortality in the United States; (2) ensure that such data are made available to the public at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; (3) make it available to the public through the Internet at no cost; and (4) ensure that it is affordable.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 19, 2014. Tick-Borne Disease Research Accountability and Transparency Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to: (1) conduct or support epidemiological, basic, translational, and clinical research regarding Lyme disease and other tick-borne diseases; and (2) ensure that each biennial report on NIH's activities regarding Lyme disease and other tick-borne diseases includes information on actions undertaken by NIH to carry out such provisions. Directs the Secretary to establish a permanent Interagency Lyme and Tick-Borne Disease Working Group to review all efforts within HHS concerning Lyme disease and other tick-borne diseases to ensure interagency coordination, minimize overlap, and examine research priorities. Requires the Working Group to: (1) develop and periodically update a summary of ongoing Lyme disease and other tick-borne disease research related to causes, prevention, treatment, surveillance, diagnosis, diagnostics, duration of illness, intervention, and access to services and supports for individuals with Lyme disease or other tick-borne diseases; (2) ensure that a broad spectrum of scientific viewpoints is represented in each summary; (3) monitor federal activities regarding Lyme disease and other tick-borne diseases; (4) make recommendations

Seniors Financial Fraud Prevention Act of 2010 - Requires the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to establish a separate office within its office to monitor the market for mail, telemarketing, television, and Internet fraud targeting seniors and to assist it with: (1) consumer education; (2) complaints; and (3) law enforcement action.

Hope through Principled, Ethically-Sound Stem Cell Research Act or the HOPE Act This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services to develop techniques for the isolation, derivation, production, or testing of pluripotent stem cells that have the flexibility of embryonic stem cells (whether or not they have an embryonic source), which may result in improved understanding of or treatments for diseases and other adverse health conditions.

Community Health Center Volunteer Provider Protection Act of 2005 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to deem volunteer practitioners who provide medical services to patients at certain community health centers in underserved areas as employees of the Public Health Service (thus extending the liability protections of the Act to such practitioners). Defines volunteer practitioner" as a licensed physician or licensed clinical psychologist who provides services to patients of a health center without compensation or reimbursement at a health center site or a site designated by the health center. Directs the Comptroller General to study and report to Congress on the adequacy of funding for the liability coverage provided under the Act for public or nonprofit private entities receiving federal funds for health centers and volunteer practitioners serving such health centers."

Consultation and Coordination With Indian Tribal Governments Act - Requires the Department of the Interior, the Indian Health Service, and the National Indian Gaming Commission to have an accountable consultation process with Indian tribal governments when formulating, amending, implementing, or recinding one or more policies that have tribal implications. Requires an agency head to designate an official with principal responsibility for the agency's implementation of this Act.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Medication Research <n> Title II: Protections for Drugs <n> Title III: Treatment of Addictions <n>New Medications to Treat Addiction Act of 1998 - <n>Title I: Medication Research <n> Title II: Protections for Drugs <n> Title III: Treatment of Addictions <n>New Medications to Treat Addiction Act of 1998 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize appropriations for medication research. <n>Title II: Protections for Drugs <n>Title III: Treatment of Addictions<n> - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to add references to treatment of addiction to illegal drugs to provisions relating to drugs for rare diseases or conditions, allowing exclusive approval, certification, or licensure, subject to exception. Requires that the sponsor of such a treatment drug be encouraged to design open protocols. <n>Title III: Treatment of Addictions<n> - Requires that the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences establish criteria for an acceptable drug for treatment of addiction to illegal drugs.

Fix United States Government Contracting Deficit with China Act - Directs the Secretary of Commerce to certify annually to Congress whether or not the Chinese government has prohibited the procurement of U.S. goods during the preceding calendar year and, if so, the total value of U.S. goods procured by the Chinese government that year. Limits the total value of Chinese goods that may be procured by the U.S. government during a calendar year to not more than the total value of U.S. goods procured by the Chinese government if any during the preceding calendar year.

Preventing Waste, Fraud, and Abuse Act of 2010 - Requires that for every $1 invested in the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Department of Justice (DOJ) for program integrity efforts to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse of the Medicare, Medicaid, and the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) to determine whether a recipient of disability insurance benefits under title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act will continue to be eligible for such benefits, specified amounts will be saved. Requires that for every $1 invested in the Social Security Administration (SSA) for program integrity efforts to increase the volume of continuing disability reviews to determine whether a recipient of supplemental security income benefits under SSA title XVI will continue to be eligible for such benefits, specified amounts will be saved.

Dru Sjodin National Sex Offender Public Database Act of 2004 or Dru's Law - Directs the Attorney General to: (1) make publicly available in a registry, via the Internet, information about sexually violent predators and persons convicted of a sexually violent offense or a criminal offense against a minor; and (2) allow users to determine which registered sex offenders are currently residing within a specified area.Requires any person convicted of such an offense or a sexually violent offense to register with a minimally sufficient sexual offender registration program within a State, including a program established under the Jacob Wetterling Crimes Against Children and Sexually Violent Offender Registration Act.Directs any State that provides for a civil commitment proceeding to issue timely notice to the attorney general of that State of the impending release of any person incarcerated by the State who: (1) is a sexually violent predator; or (2) has been deemed by the State to be at high-risk for recommitting specified sexually violent or criminal offenses against a minor. Requires: (1) the State attorney general to consider whether or not to institute a civil commitment proceeding; and (2) each State to intensively monitor, for at least one year, any such person who has been unconditionally released by the State and not been civilly committed pursuant to a civil commitment proceeding

Amends Federal highway law to direct the Secretary of Transportation to carry out a grant program to provide financial assistance to States for up to 90 percent of the cost of local rail line relocation projects.

Indian Gaming Regulatory Act Amendments of 1994 - Amends the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act to revise the definition of: (1) class II gaming to exclude electronic or technological aids used in connection with card games; and (2) electronic facsimile" to mean a copy of some or all of the fundamental elements of a game, where the electronic or electromechanical device alters the game rather than simply electronically replicating the fundamental elements of a game. <n>(Sec. 3) Requires the Chairman of the National Indian Gaming Commission (the Commission) to consult with an Indian tribe which has jurisdiction over a class II or class III gaming activity in dispute and attempt to resolve the dispute in a manner that avoids such actions, only after the Commission has concluded that cooperative resolution has been adequately pursued and that further consultation would be futile.  <n>(Sec. 4) Repeals the requirement that a tribal ordinance or resolution provide for the licensing or regulation of Indian charitable class II gaming activities on Indian lands up to the same level and scope as permitted by a Compact so provides, where class II gaming is. <n>(Sec. 5) Authorizes the Commission to regulate class II gaming activities on Indian lands up to the same level and scope as permitted by a Compact so provides, where class II gaming is. <n>"

Sugar Competitiveness Act of 1995- Amends the Agricultural Act of 1949 to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to make market-orIENTED sugar program recourse loans available to processors of sugarcane on raw cane sugar processed from the 1995 and succeeding crops of sugarcane and sugar beets on refined sugar processed from the 1995 and succeeding crops of sugar beets. Sets forth loan rates: (1) per pound of raw cane sugar for the 1995 crop; (2) per pound of refined sugar for the 1996 and 1997 crops; and (3) per pound of sugarcane for the 1998 and succeeding crops. Specifies the length of such loans, which may be extended for additional three-month terms. <n>Prohibits the Secretary from making sugar price supports, whether in the form of nonrecourse loans, payments, purchases, or other operations, for the 1995 or subsequent crops of sugarcane or sugar beets by using the funds of the Commodity Credit Corporation. <n>Directs the Secretary to make such loans available to processors of sugar beets on refined sugar processed from the 1995 and succeeding crops of sugar beets. Sets forth loan rates: (1) per pound of refined sugar for the 1995 crop; (2) per pound of refined sugar for the 1996 and 1997 crops; and (3) per pound of sugarcane for the 1998 and succeeding crops.

Directs the Attorney General, acting through the Director of the National Institute of Justice, to: (1) evaluate potential problem officer early warning programs being or have been utilized by local governments; (2) develop a model early warning system that is effective and affordable to local governments with populations of 50,000 or more; and (3) report to the Congress on the evaluation and developing of such programs. <n>Expresses the sense of the Congress that: (1) the Attorney General should make program grant grants to eligible entities; (2) a local government should be eligible if its police department adopts and enforces a written policy prohibiting the use of unreasonable or unnecessary physical force by law enforcement officers and procedures for receiving and investigating citizen complaints alleging misconduct by police officers; and (3) the grant recipient demonstrates a commitment to the long-term continuance of the program and the reduction of the incidence of police brutality. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to authorize the Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to submit a request to the President for a declaration that a major disaster for wildfire on federal lands exists. Sets forth requirements for such a declaration, including that: (1) the request shall be made in writing; and (2) the amount appropriated in the current fiscal year for wildfire suppression operations of the federal land management agencies shall increase the total unobligated balance of amounts available for suppression by an amount equal to or greater than the average total costs incurred by such agencies per year for wildfire suppression operations. Authorizes the President to transfer funds to conduct wildfire suppression operations on federal lands (and nonfederal lands pursuant to a fire protection agreement or cooperative agreement) when a major disaster for wildfire on federal lands exists.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on July 22, 2014. Gerardo Hernandez Airport Security Act of 2014 - (Sec. 3) Directs the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) of the Department of Homeland Security to: (1) conduct outreach to all U.S. airports at which the TSA performs, or oversees the implementation and performance of, security measures; and (2) give necessary technical assistance to verify that such airports have in place individualized working plans for responding to security incidents inside the airport perimeter, including active shooters, acts of terrorism, and incidents that target passenger-screening checkpoints. Requires the TSA to report to Congress on the findings from its outreach and on the level of preparedness such airports have to respond to such incidents. (Sec. 4) Requires the TSA to: (1) identify best practices that exist across airports for security incident planning, management, and training; and (2) establish a mechanism through which to share those best practices with other airport operators nationwide. (Sec. 5) Requires the TSA to certify annually to specified congressional committees that all screening personnel have participated in practical training exercises for active shooter scenarios. (Sec. 6) Requires the TSA to report to Congress on: (1) an analysis of how the TSA can use cost savings achieved through efficiencies to increase over the next five

Declares that it is U.S. policy that the residents of Puerto Rico periodically should be afforded an opportunity freely to express their wishes regarding their political status. Requires a referendum on the option of continuing the current Commonwealth arrangements and Puerto Rico's current political status, or entering on a process leading to permanent full self-government through separate sovereignty or statehood. Requires the referendum to be held by December 31, 1998.

Stock Option Accounting Reform Act - (Sec. 2) Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to require an issuer of registered securities to show as an expense in its annual report the fair value of all stock purchase options granted after December 31, 2004, to: (1) all individuals serving as the chief executive officer of an issuer, or acting in a similar capacity, during the most recent fiscal year, regardless of compensation level; and (2) the four most highly compensated executive officers (other than a chief executive officer) that were serving as executive officers of an issuer at the end of the most recent fiscal year (other than such chief executive officer).<n><n>Defines the fair value of an option to purchase such stock.<n><n>Exempts small business issuers from the Act\\'s requirement.<n><n>(Sec. 3) Amends the Securities Act of 1933 to prohibit the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) from recognizing as generally accepted" any accounting principle established by a standard setting body relating to the expensing of stock options unless: (1) it complies with the requirements of this Act; and (2) the economic impact study required by this Act has been completed.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of Labor to conduct and complete a joint study on the economic impact of the"

Space to Schools Act of 2010 - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to carry out a program to: (1) encourage highly skilled retiring or displaced aerospace professionals with backgrounds in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) to pursue careers as elementary, secondary, or vocational school teachers; and (2) promote STEM education in kindergarten through grade 12 by encouraging aerospace professionals to pursue careers in teaching. Defines an eligible individual" as an individual who is a former employee of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), its suppliers, or a related contractor and who has relevant work experience in the aerospace industry. Directs the Secretary to prescribe criteria to select Program participants."

USDA Debarment Act of 1993 - Requires the Secretary of Agriculture, if he or she obtains notice of an alleged material violation of a Department of Agriculture program or activity and determines that there is sufficient reason to initiate a nonprocurement debarment proceeding, to initiate such proceeding within 180 days after such determination, with an exception if the Secretary determines that the proceeding cannot be made within the 180-day period because of the need to further investigate the actions of a person relating to the alleged material violation. Specifies provisions concerning the period of debarment.

Department of Defense Overseas Educators Act - Provides that, in filling a vacant position for which a qualified displaced employee has applied in timely fashion, an agency shall, in filling such position before selecting any candidate from outside the agency, give full consideration to such application before selecting any candidate from outside the agency for the position. Declares that a displaced employee shall remain entitled to such consideration until the end of the 12-month period beginning on the date such employee receives the specific notice that such individual is to be separated due to a reduction in force and the effective date of such separation. Applies such Act to any individual who: (1) becomes a displaced employee during the 12-month period ending on the day before the enactment of this Act; or (2) becomes a displaced employee on or after such enactment and before October 1, 1997. Applies the Act to teachers recruited outside the United States for service in a teaching position, after such individual completes one full school year of service in a teaching position, to the extent that such benefits are based on service in a teaching position.

Livestock Concentration Report Act - Establishes a Commission on Concentration in the Livestock Industry to: (1) determine whether the study of concentration in the red meat packing industry adequately examined and identified procurement markets for slaughter cattle in the continental United States, effects of slaughter cattle procurement practices and concentration in the procurement of slaughter cattle, the use of captive cattle supply arrangements by beef packers, and the effects of such arrangements on slaughter cattle markets; (2) request the Attorney General to report on the application of Federal antitrust laws with respect to concentration and vertical integration in the procurement and pricing of slaughter cattle and of slaughter hogs by meat packers; (3) review related laws and regulations; (4) review the farm-to-retail price spread for livestock during the period beginning on January 1, 1993, and ending the date the report is submitted; (5) review Department of Agriculture price data and the adequacy of price discovery in the livestock industry for animals held for market; and (6) review the lamb industry study completed by the Department of Justice during 1993.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from the gross income of a U.S. shareholder of a controlled foreign corporation the amount of any distribution received from such corporation which is invested in certain property located in the United States or used to hire new employees in the United States. Requires a taxpayer who fails to meet the investment in property or job creation requirements of this Act to pay a recapture amount in the year in which such reinvestment period ends.

Law Enforcement Protection Act of 1997 - Amends the Federal criminal code to exempt qualified current and former law enforcement officers carrying appropriate written identification from State and local laws prohibiting the carrying of concealed firearms. Declares that nothing in this Act shall be construed to exempt such officers from Federal or State laws prohibiting or restricting the possession of a firearm on Federal property, installation, building, base, or park. Specifies that nothing in this Act shall be construed to supersede or limit: (1) any Federal law or regulation prohibiting or restricting the possession of a firearm on any Federal property, installation, building, base, or park; or (2) State laws that grant rights to carry a concealed firearm that are broader than those granted under this Act, permit private persons or entities to prohibit or restrict the possession of concealed firearms on their property, or prohibit or restrict the possession of firearms on any State or local government property, installation, building, base, or park. <n>Authorizes the consent of the Congress to: (1) enter into compacts or agreements for cooperative effort in enabling individuals to carry concealed weapons as dictated by State laws within which the owner resides and is authorized to carry a concealed weapon; and (2) establish agencies or guidelines to make effective such agreements and compacts.

Clean Vehicles Incentive Act of 2015 Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow certain businesses located in areas designated as nonattainment areas under the Clean Air Act a general business tax credit for the cost of certain clean-fuel vehicle property and clean-burning fuel. Allows the credit to be taken against regular and alternative minimum tax liabilities. Allows a tax deduction for any unused clean fuel credit amounts.

National Strategy for Homeland Security Act of 2004 - Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security: (1) to develop and submit to Congress the National Strategy for Homeland Security for the detection, prevention, protection, response, and recovery with regard to terrorist threats to the United States; (2) in collaboration with the Assistant to the President for Homeland Security and the Homeland Security Council, to establish the Homeland Security Strategy Commission; and (3) to provide an assessment of progress on implementing the Strategy, including the adequacy of resources, and recommendations to improve and implement it.

Amends Federal law to allow lands held in trust for the Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde Community of Oregon and the Cabazon Indian Reservation in California to be held in trust for the Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde Community of Oregon and the Cabazon Indian Reservation, respectively (currently, such lands are held in trust for the Cahuilla Band of Indians of California and such lands are held in trust for the Navajo Reservation). <n>(Sec. 2) Amends the Grand Ronde Reservation Act to increase the acreage authorized to be held in trust for the Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde Community of Oregon. <n>(Sec. 3) Amends the San Carlos Apache Tribe Water Rights Settlement Act of 1992 to remove a provision limiting to ten percent the amount of funds which may be distributed to any individual Indian in any year. <n>(Sec. 4) Amends the Indian Health Care Improvement Act to direct the Secretary of the Interior to extend the terms of certain self-determination contracts with Indian tribes that were retained by the Ponca Tribe of Nebraska to carry out health care programs. <n>(Sec. 6) Amends the Navajo-Hopi Land Dispute Settlement Act to allow any funds provided to the Navajo Tribe of Nebraska for any of FY 1992 through 1998

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 6, 1993. However, because action occurred on the measure, the summary has been expanded.) Art Maintenance-in-Federal Maintenance Act of 1993 - Requires the Administrator of the General Services Administration (GSA) to make at least one percent of the funds made available for new construction, building purchase, acquisition, or repair and alteration projects available for art projects for Federal buildings. Allows the Administrator to increase such percentage for projects warranting more artwork, such as a building with exceptional public vitality whose architectural character and scale would be significantly enhanced by large-scale artists. <n>Requires the preliminary planning and design of each new Federal building to include planning for art reproductions by previously acquired artist works of art. Directs the Administrator, in commissioning works of art, to select artists based upon the artistic merit of the proposed work of artist, the estimated value of the proposed work of art, and the scope of each regional community of artists. <n>Prohibits the Administrator from being subject to title III of the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 or any other provision of law with regard to the commissioning of works of art under this Act.

Promoting Self-Reliance for the World's Poorest Act of 2002 - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to reauthorize appropriations for FY 2003 through 2006 for: (1) micro- and small enterprise development credits; and (2) microenterprise development grant assistance.Directs the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development to develop methods to measure the level of poverty of clients of sustainable poverty-focused microenterpise programs.Requires the Administrator to implement interim poverty measurement methods with respect to: (1) not less than 25 sustainable poverty-focused programs by September 30, 2002; and (2) not less than 40 sustainable poverty-focused programs by September 30, 2003.

Prohibits the President from directing DOD to deploy a system unless and until: (1) the President certifies to Congress that the above deployment conditions have been met; and (2) a joint resolution is enacted concurring in the President's certification.(Sec. 4) Prohibits DOD procurement funds from being obligated for a system unless: (1) the President certifies to Congress that adequate system tests have been undertaken to meet identified threats against countermeasures; and (2) a joint resolution is enacted concurring in the President's certification. Outlines procedures for the consideration of each joint resolution.

Establishes the Northern Yukon-Arctic International Wildlife Refuge, which shall include the entire Arctic National Wildlife Refuge administered under the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1966.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 6, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Homeless Children's Immunization Assistance Act - Amends the Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act to provide for child immunization within the following activities of assistance provided under the emergency shelter grants program: (1) providing transportation for children occupying facilities assisted under such Act to locations where such immunization is available; (2) providing information and counseling to families occupying such facilities regarding the benefits and availability of such immunization; and (3) providing child immunization for children occupying such facilities at the facility, or coordinating and arranging for such immunization at the facility. Requires that, for any child who has not attained the age of six and is occupying a facility assisted under such Act, the recipient of such assistance: (1) make reasonable efforts to obtain from the child's family or the appropriate State or local health agency information sufficient to determine whether the child has been immunized in accordance with recommendations issued by the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service; and (2) for any child that has not been so immunized, provide the family with information regarding the benefits and availability of child immunization. Requires that, for any child occupying a project that is transitional housing, the recipient of such assistance: (1) make reasonable efforts to

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on March 12, 2007. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>Directs the Secretary of Energy to: (1) initiate a project to establish technical standards for general service lamps; (2) report periodically to specified congressional committees on the development and promulgation of such standards; and (3) carry out a lighting technology research and development program to support the research, development, demonstration, and commercial application of lamps and related technologies sold, offered for sale, or otherwise made available in the United States.<n><n>Requires the Secretary, in cooperation with the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), to report to Congress on: (1) recommendations relating to the means by which the federal government may reduce or prevent the release of mercury during the manufacture, transportation, storage, or disposal of mercury bulbs; and (2) current lamp labeling practices by lamp manufacturers and recommendations for a national labeling standard.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 22, 2017. Traveler Redress Improvement Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to ensure the availability of the DHS Traveler Redress Inquiry Program to adjudicate inquiries for individuals who: are U.S. citizens or aliens lawfully admitted for permanent residence; have filed an inquiry with DHS TRIP after receiving enhanced screening at an airport passenger security checkpoint more than three times in any 60-day period; and believe they have been wrongly identified as a threat to aviation security. The TSA shall: (1) review and update the Privacy Impact Assessment for the Secure Flight programs to ensure that it accurately reflects the operation of such programs, (2) conduct a comprehensive review of TSA intelligence-based screening rules, and (3) notify specified entities within DHS of any such change, update, implementation, or suspension. The Government Accountability Office shall report to Congress on: (1) how TSA's intelligence-based screening rules are incorporated in the risk analysis conducted during the Federal Air Marshal mission scheduling process, and (2) the effectiveness of such rules in identifying and mitigating potential threats to aviation security.
Amends the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States to suspend, through December 31, 2007, the duty on certain chemicals used in the formulation of an HIV protease inhibitor.

Teacher Tax Credit Act of 2007- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow certain kindergarten, elementary, and secondary school teachers, instructors, counselors, aides, and principals a refundable tax credit for 50% of their qualified elementary and secondary education expenses up to $300 and for their qualified professional development expenses up to $300.

Pension Protection and Diversification Act of 2001 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to prohibit treating an applicable individual account plan as an eligible individual account plan unless it meets specified Diversification requirements, including: (1) acquisition and holding requirements; and (2) the opportunity for employee divestiture of employer securities.

Agricultural Bioterrorism Technologies Countermeasures Act of 2001 (sic) - Authorizes appropriations to: (1) the Secretary of Agriculture for Agricultural Research Service biosecurity activities; (2) the Secretary for renovation, update, and expansion of Biosafety Level 3 laboratory and animal research facilities at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center, New York; (3) the Secretary for expansion of Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service facilities in Georgia and Iowa; (4) the Secretary for collaborative research in defending food supply partners to maximize the impact of research and development; (5) the Secretary for the purchase of rapid detection test kits; and (6) State and local agencies engaged in defending against agroterrorism and the training of appropriate authorities.Directs the Secretary to establish a Consortium for Countermeasures against Agricultural Bioterrorism which shall include the following entities: (1) the National Academy of Sciences; (2) the Institute of Medicine; (3) the Food and Drug Administration; (4) the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; and (5) private sector organizations. Authorizes the Secretary to make competitive research grants for the development of countermeasures against agricultural bioterrorism.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 19, 2013. (Sec. 1) States that it shall be U.S. policy to: (1) take all necessary and appropriate steps in accordance with international agreements to support U.S. commitments to ensure the security protection of Camp Liberty/Hur residents, members of the opposition and the Embassy Mujahedeen e-Khalq (MEK), in accordance with the United States Embassy Statement on Transfer of Security Responsibility for Camp Liberty/Hur of December 28, 2008; (2) assist the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in ensuring the rapid orderly resettlement of all Camp Liberty/Hur residents outside Iraq; and (3) permit the admission as refugees of the residents of Camp Liberty/Hur to the United States, who express a desire for such resettlement. (Sec. 3) Directs the United States to: (1) take all necessary and appropriate steps to ensure the safety of such residents outside the Camp IPPC compound, secure refugee resettlement in the United States for any such residents who express a desire, and timely admit as refugees residents of Camp Liberty/Hur stationed in the United States; (2) take all necessary and appropriate steps to ensure the safety of such residents outside the Camp IPPC compound, secure refugee resettlement in the United States for

Administrative Law Judges Retirement Act of 2003 - Sets forth separate provisions governing Government and employee contributions, annuity eligibility requirements (ten years of service and age 55), immediate retirement, and computation of annuities for administrative law judges under the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System.

(Sec. 102) Directs the Secretary to prescribe uniform guidelines for conducting such elections for members and alternates of county and area committees, members and alternates of community committees so established, and delegates to local administrative area conventions and county conventions. Prohibits members elected pursuant to such an election from commencing their term of service unless and until the Secretary determines that: (1) the election fully complied with the laws, regulations, and guidelines applicable to the conduct of the election; and (2) the members-elect satisfy the eligibility requirements for committee membership. States that: (1) a county committee employee who has completed three years of service shall be given a career civil service appointment; and (2) the period of permanent service as a county committee employee shall be counted when calculating the three years of service necessary for conversion to career civil service status.

Loan Interest Forgiveness for Education Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an individual a deduction for interest paid on any qualified education loan. Limits such deduction based on modified adjusted gross income.

Prescribes guidelines under which the Secretary of the Interior shall undertake a program to determine the validity of specified mining claims located within a specified area of California, and to withdraw Federal lands from all forms of entry and patent; and (2) if a claim is determined to be invalid, declare the validity of any claim to be null and void and recommended protection for existing rights. <n>Prohibits, after the enactment of this Act: (1) a claim on Patent Issuance of each claim referred to in this Act from being open to location, entry, or extraction under the general mining laws; (2) a claim on a lease of a specified mill site from being open to location, entry, or extraction under the general mining laws; and (3) the Secretary from authorizing any mining activity on Federal lands within the area, except for reclamation activities. <n>Requires the Secretary to: (1) consult with the State of California before approving any mining activity under this Act and within two years after enactment of this Act to do so on specified Federal lands; and (2) determine the validity of specified mining claims located within the area, and withdraw Federal lands from all forms of entry and patent. <n>Instructs the Secretary, if necessary to protect the area, to withdraw from all forms of entry

Basic Pilot Program Extension and Expansion Act of 2003 - Amends the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 to extend the basic pilot immigrant investor pilot program from six years to 11 years. Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to expand such program to all 50 States by December 1, 2004.Amends the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State, the Judiciary, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1993 to authorize the Secretary to give priority to petitions filed by aliens seeking admission under the basic pilot program. Extends pilot program authority through FY 2004.Directs the General Accounting Office to report to Congress on the immigrant investor program.

Clean for Marijuana Offenses Act of 2015 This bill amends the federal criminal code to establish a process to expunge an individual's records related to a marijuana-related criminal offense. A marijuana-related criminal offense is one in which the conduct constituting the offense: (1) was legal under state law at the time; or (2) was the possession of marijuana in a quantity not greater than one ounce. To be eligible for expungement, an individual must fulfill all requirements of the sentence for the conviction, including completion of any term of imprisonment or period of probation, meeting all conditions of supervised release, and paying all fines.

Enhancing Nutrition in Medical Education Act of 2004 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to accredited schools of medicine to integrate innovative curricula on nutrition into medical education. Requires the Secretary to ensure that such curricula focus on preventive health measures, including: (1) education on the causes, treatment, and prevention of obesity; (2) office education and counseling to ensure appropriate diet for mostly healthy people; (3) prevention and treatment of common nutritional deficiencies; (4) appropriate and inappropriate use of herbs and supplements; (5) office recognition and treatment of common eating disorders; and (6) identification of special dietary needs, eating disorders, and appropriate routes of referral for medical nutrition therapy. Requires the Secretary to establish a multidisciplinary planning committee to develop such curricula. Limits grants to $100,000 per fiscal year.

. Dismemberment Abortion Ban Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill prohibits any physician from knowingly performing a dismemberment abortion and thereby killing an unborn child, unless the pregnancy is necessary to save the life of a mother whose life is endangered by a physical disorder, physical illness, or child physical injury, including a life- endangering physical condition caused by or arising from the pregnancy itself. This prohibition does not apply to a dismemberment abortion that is necessary to save the life of a mother whose life is endangered by a physical disorder, physical illness, or child physical injury, including a life- endangering physical condition caused by or arising from the pregnancy itself. Nothing in this Act shall be construed to limit abortions performed for any reason, including when the pregnancy is a result of rape or incest, if performed by a method other than dismemberment abortion. A woman upon whom an abortion has been performed in violation of this Act may, in a civil action against any person who committed the violation, obtain appropriate relief. A parent of a minor on whom an abortion has been performed may, in a civil action against any person who committed the violation, obtain appropriate relief. No damages, attorney's fee, or other monetary relief may be assessed against the

Electronic Device Recycling Research and Development Act - Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to award competitive grants to consortia to conduct research to create innovative and practical approaches to manage the environmental impacts of electronic devices and, through such research, to contribute to the professional development of scientists, engineers, and technicians in the fields of electronic device manufacturing, design, refurbishing, and recycling.

No Entry for Supporters of the Iranian Regime Act of 2010 - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to prohibit the United States from admitting an alien who engages in certain sanctionable activities with respect to Iran, including: (1) an activity relating to the proliferation by Iran of weapons of mass destruction or the means of delivery of such weapons; (2) an activity relating to support for international terrorism by the government of Iran; (3) any other activity with respect to Iran for which sanctions may be imposed; or (4) the spouse or minor child of an alien who engages in such an activity or the chief executive officer, president, or other individual in charge of overall management of, or a shareholder with a controlling interest in, an entity that engages in such an activity.

Amends the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 (PURPA) to require each state regulatory authority to: (1) establish proceedings to examine the degree to which distributed resources contribute ancillary services (defined as supply, regulation, frequency response, energy imbalance, operating reserves, and flexibility and services) so that grid interconnection for distributed resources is safe, reliable, and efficient; and (2) prescribe measures to ensure adequate ancillary services so that grid interconnection for distributed resources is safe, reliable, and efficient.<n><n>Requires each state regulatory authority to establish proceedings to: (1) examine the effects of net metering and customer-owned distributed generation on resource planning of each electric utility; and (2) determine whether electricity rates established for net metering service are just and reasonable and not unduly preferential or discriminatory.<n><n>Sets deadlines for such proceedings.

Making Home Affordable Improvements Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to provide assistance to the National Foreclosure Mitigation Counseling Program for foreclosure mitigation counseling activities in connection with the Home Affordable Modification Program of the Making Home Affordable initiative of the Secretary. Sets forth a formula for the funding of such Program.

Synthetics Trafficking and Overdose Prevention Act of 2016 or the STOP Act of 2016 This bill amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to require: (1) the filing of required documentation or information regarding merchandise entering the United States through the U.S. Postal Service (USPS) by either the owner or purchaser, or by a person holding a valid license as designated by the owner, purchaser, or consignee, in the case of non-letter class mail; and (2) U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to accept a consignee's declaration that he or she is the owner or purchaser of such merchandise without liability when the consignee declares on entry that he or she is the owner or purchaser. The bill defines "non-letter class mail" as any product of the USPS or a Universal Postal Union designated operator that is provided pursuant to specified regulations. The Department of the Treasury shall issue regulations to require the USPS Postmaster General or a designee of the Postmaster General to file informal customs entries for all non-letter class mail that meets the informal entry requirements and subpart C of part 143 of title 19, Code of Federal Regulations. The bill amends the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 to provide for: (1) the reduction or modification of

Trade Normalization With Cuba Act Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 (including other specified laws) to repeal the embargo placed upon all trade with Cuba. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to declare the denial of foreign tax credit inapplicable to Cuba.Permits: (1) installation and maintenance of telecommunications equipment and facilities in Cuba, including telecommunications services between the United States and Cuba; and (2) travel to and from Cuba by U.S. citizens or residents.

National Beverage Container Recycling Initiative Act - Amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act to prohibit the sale of certain beverages unless the containers carry a refund value of ten cents.Makes unclaimed refunds (the amount by which the total refund value of all containers sold by distributors exceeds the amount paid by distributors to persons in a State) available to a State for carrying out pollution prevention and recycling programs.Prohibits distributors and retailers from: (1) selling beverages in metal beverage containers with detachable openings; and (2) disposing of containers subject to this Act or any metal, plastic, or glass from such containers (other than the top or seal) in landfills or solid waste disposal facilities.Makes this Act inapplicable to States that have adopted requirements similar to those under this Act or that have demonstrated a recycling or reuse rate for beverage containers of at least 35 percent.Prohibits States or political subdivisions that impose taxes on the sale of beverage containers from imposing any tax on the amount attributable to the refund value.

Ports-to-Forts Act of 2012 - Authorizes the Administrator of the Maritime Administration to make grants to assist states or port authorities in conducting repair or construction activities relating to a commercial strategic seaport. Defines commercial strategic seaport" as a port that the Secretary of Defense has determined to be vital to the readiness and cargo throughput capacity of the Department of Defense (DOD)."

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on December 10, 2015. Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) Authorizes the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out the following leases at the VA West Los Angeles Campus in Los Angeles, California: an enhanced-use lease of real property for supportive housing purposes; a lease of real property for not to exceed 50 years to a third party for services that principally benefit veterans and their families and that are related to health and wellness, education, vocational training and employment, peer activities, socialization, or physical recreation, legal and federal benefits assistance, volunteerism, family support services, and transportation; and a lease of real property for not to exceed 10 years to an institution of California that has had a medical affiliation with the VA for more than 20 years if the lease is consistent with the VA master plan and the provision of veterans services is the predominant focus. Prohibits the VA from entering into any land-sharing agreement unless it provides additional health care resources and benefits veterans and their families other than from the generation of revenue for the VA. Prohibits the VA from selling or otherwise conveying to a third party fee simple title to any real property or improvements to real property made at

Medicare Mental Health Improvement Act - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for coverage of inpatient psychiatric hospital services under Medicare part A (Hospital Insurance). <n>Provides for coverage of intensive residential services under Medicare part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance).

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on August 5, 2015. Head Start Improvement Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Head Start Act to revise and reauthorize the program through FY2020. The bill makes appropriations for the program, which provides financial assistance to local educational agencies to promote the school readiness of low-income children, beginning on October 1 of the first fiscal year following enactment of this Act. The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) must award grants to states and Indian tribes, according to a formula that takes into account the number of children, age 5 and younger, from families with incomes below 100% of the poverty line for the most recent fiscal year for which satisfactory data are available. allotments are based on the number of such children from families with incomes below 100% of the poverty line: (1) in the state, the District of Columbia, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Northern Mariana Islands; and (2) in each of the other states, the District of Columbia, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Republic of Palau. HHS must give priority to states that demonstrate the greatest need for financial assistance, based on the number of children from families with incomes below 100% of the

Commission On Reforming Entitlement Spending Act or the CORE Spending Act Establishes the Commission On Reforming Entitlement Spending to develop legislation designed to address: (1) the unsustainable imbalance between long-term federal spending commitments and projected revenues; (2) increases in net national savings to provide for domestic investment and economic growth; (3) the implications of foreign ownership of debt instruments issued by the federal government; and (4) revision of the budget process to place greater emphasis on long-term fiscal issues. Requires the Commission to: (1) hold at least one town-hall style public hearing within each federal reserve district; and (2) submit a legislative proposal to Congress and the President.

District of Tax Revenue Nondiscrimination Act of 1997 - Amends the District of Columbia Code to repeal the provisions of specified Acts that provide for the tax exemption of certain entities in the District of Columbia.

Accessing Medicare Therapies Act of 2013 - Amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to count the negotiated price of drugs furnished free or at nominal charge under compassionate treatment programs toWARDS incurred out-of-pocket costs.

Criminal Improvements Act of 2006 - Amends the federal criminal code to apply the death penalty or life imprisonment for a terrorist offense that results in the death of a person. Makes the death penalty available for: (1) participation in nuclear and weapons of mass destruction threats to the United States; (2) missile systems to destroy aircraft; (3) atomic weapons; (4) radiological dispersal devices; (5) the variola virus; and (6) receiving military-type training from a foreign terrorist organization. Increases penalties for providing material support to terrorists and for receiving military-type training from a foreign terrorist organization. Denies federal benefits to any individual convicted of a federal terrorism offense.

International Protecting Girls by Preventing Child Marriage Act of 2010 - Defines child marriage" as the marriage of a girl or boy not yet the minimum age for marriage stipulated in law in the country in which the girl or boy is a resident, or where there is no such law, under the age of 18. (Defines "child marriage" as the marriage of a girl or boy not yet the minimum age for marriage stipulated in law in the country in which the girl or boy is a resident, or where there is no such law, under the age of 18.) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) child marriage is a violation of human rights; (2) the practice of child marriage undermines U.S. investments in foreign assistance to promote education and skills building for girls, reduce maternal and child mortality, reduce maternal illness, halt the transmission of HIV/AIDS, and reduce poverty; and (3) expanding educational opportunities for girls, economic opportunities for women, and reducing maternal and child mortality are critical to achieving the Millennium Development Goals and the global health and development objectives of the United States, including efforts to prevent HIV/AIDS. Authorizes the President to provide assistance to prevent child marriage in developing countries through the promotion of educational, health, economic, social, and"

Arches National Park Expansion Act of 1998 - Modifies the boundary of the Arches National Park, Utah, to include the area known as the Lost Spring Canyon Addition. Directs the Secretary of the Interior to transfer jurisdiction over the Federal land contained in the area from the Bureau of Land Management to the National Park Service. Specifies provisions regarding the continuation and sale of grazing leases, permits, and licenses for the area.

First Responders Support Act of 2002 - Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to appoint a Chief Homeland Security Liaison Officer to coordinate the activities of the Homeland Security Liaison Officers.Requires the Chief Homeland Security Liaison Officer to prepare an annual report that contains: (1) a description of the State and local priorities in each of the 50 States based on discovered needs of first responder organizations; (2) a needs assessment that identifies homeland security functions in which the Federal role is duplicative of the State or local role and recommendations to decrease or eliminate inefficiencies between the Federal Government and State and local entities; (3) recommendations to Congress regarding the creation, expansion, or elimination of any program to assist State and local entities to carry out their respective functions under the Department of Homeland Security; and (4) proposals to increase the coordination of Department of Homeland Security priorities within each State and between the States.Directs the Secretary to designate at least one employee in each State to: (1) serve as the Homeland Security Liaison Officer in that State; and (2) provide coordination between the Department and State and local first responders.Establishes an Interagency Committee on First Responders that shall: (1) ensure coordination among the Federal agencies involved with State, local, and community-based law enforcement, fire and rescue operations, and medical and emergency relief

Agricultural Water Conservation Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for 30 percent of the water conservation system expenses for the purchase and installation of an agricultural water conservation system. Limits the amount of such credit to $500 and the number of acres served.

Dollar Bill Act of 2013 - Directs the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to: (1) designate a specific week, the Target Week, starting no earlier than 90 days from enactment of this Act and ending no later than 120 days after enactment; and (2) employ a random process to select a specific day, hour, minute, and second during the Target Week which shall not be publicly disclosed. Requires the Board, at the Target Week, to make the value of the U.S. dollar equal to the price of gold on the exchange operated by the Commodities Exchange, Inc. (COMEX) of the New York Mercantile Exchange, Inc. (COMEX) as of the Target Range. Requires the Board to maintain the value of the U.S. dollar within the Target Range directly, via open market operations, and not indirectly, as in the current practice of targeting the federal funds rate. Requires the Board to use its banking and bank regulatory powers to maintain and promote stable and effective financial markets during and after the transition to a defined value for the U.S. dollar. Entitles all entities that depreciate capital assets for tax purposes to 100% expensing of all capital investment for tax purposes in the year that the investment is made. Amends the Federal

Incentives to Educate American Children (I Teach) Act of 2002 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide refundable tax credits for: (1) teachers in schools in rural areas or schools with high poverty; and (2) certified teachers in public kindergartens or public elementary or secondary schools in rural areas or schools with high poverty.

Dairy Promotion Fairness Act - Amends the Dairy Production Stabilization Act of 1983 to include dairy products imported into the United States as products" for purposes of the National Dairy Promotion and Research Board (the Board). Defines "importer" as a person that imports an imported dairy product into the United States. Directs the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to: (1) appoint up to two Board members who represent dairy product importers; and (2) impose assessments on dairy product importers to reflect the proportion of domestic production and imports supplying the United States market."

Airport and Airway Trust Fund Financing Act of 2007- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the rate of tax on aviation-grade kerosene and aviation gasoline. Extends through FY2011 the excise taxes on: (1) aviation-grade kerosene and aviation gasoline; and (2) transportation of persons and property.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Authorizes the President to provide defense articles, defense services, and related training directly to the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) in Iraq to counter the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), as well as related training directly to the KRG military. (Sec. 2) Expresses the sense of Congress that: the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant, ISIL's sanctuary in Iraq, and the KRG's continued growth present an imminent threat to Iraqi Kurdistan, the rest of Iraq and the international security interests of the United States, and the KRG government should be resolved expeditiously to allow for a resumption of normal relations; and the longer ISIL remains largely unchallenged, the more effectively it will partner with the United States and other international coalition members to defeat ISIL. (Sec. 4) States that it shall be the sense of Congress that: the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant, ISIL's sanctuary in Iraq and the Levant, and the KRG government should be resolved expeditiously to allow for a resumption of normal relations; and the longer ISIL remains largely unchallenged, the more effectively it will partner with the United States and other international coalition members to defeat ISIL. Authorizes the President

FHA Multifamily Housing Loan Limit Improvement Act - Amends the National Housing Act to direct the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to adjust annually the multifamily mortgage loan limit for: (1) rental housing; (2) cooperative housing; (3) rehabilitation and neighborhood conservation housing; (4) housing for moderate income and displaced families; (5) housing for the elderly; and (6) condominiums.

Pesticide Maintenance Fees Reauthorization Act - Amends the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act to increase and extend through FY 2006 the fees for registrant and non- registrants, the total amount of fees, and the definition of small business.Repeals the requirement that the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency ensure the expedited processing and review of pesticide application applications.Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Administrator to ensure the expedited processing and review of any application that includes an inert ingredient.

Consumer Identity Protection and Security Act - Amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to require a consumer reporting agency to place a security freeze upon a private information file requested by the consumer: (1) by certified mail, (2) by telephone, or (3) through a secure electronic mail connection if such connection is made available by the agency.<n><n>Requires the agency to: (1) place the requested freeze no later than two business days after receiving a written or telephone request from the consumer, or 24 hours after receiving a secure electronic mail request; and (2) send a written confirmation of the freeze and provide the consumer a unique personal identification number or password to authorize access or removal of the freeze.<n><n>Prohibits a consumer reporting agency from granting access to a private information file on which a security freeze has been placed, or releasing information contained in such file, except in accordance with this Act or other Federal law.<n><n>Requires a consumer reporting agency: (1) within three business days after receiving a request from a consumer upon whose private information file a security freeze has been placed to allow access to that file to a third party, or for a period of time, specified by the consumer, to make such file available in accordance with the request notwithstanding the security freeze; and (2) to develop procedures involving the use of

Family Foreclosure Rescue Corporation Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to establish the Family Foreclosure Rescue Corporation to: (1) refinance certain home mortgages held by the Treasury; and (2) make bond payments of accrued interest plus principal.

Endangered Law Act of 2014 - Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize the Attorney General to make grants to law enforcement agencies to: (1) reduce the risk of injury and death relating to some individuals with autism and other disabilities, and (2) safeguard the well-being of such individuals during interactions with law enforcement. Authorizes the use of such grants to provide: (1) education and resources to law enforcement agencies first responders, schools, clinicians, and the public in order to reduce the risk of autism or other disabilities, help identify signs of abuse, increase personal safety and survival skills for individuals with autism or other disabilities, and facilitate effective communication with individuals who have communication-related disabilities; (2) training and emergency protocols for school administrators, staff, and families; (3) response tools and training for law enforcement and search-and-rescue agencies, including tracking technology; and (4) standards and best practices for the use of tracking technology to monitor children with autism and other disabilities.

Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to authorize an Indian tribe to coordinate its federally funded alcohol and substance abuse and mental health programs in a manner that integrates services involved into a single, coordinated, comprehensive program and reduces administrative costs by consolidating administrative functions. Specifies that the programs that may be integrated in a demonstration project shall include: (1) any program under which an Indian tribe is eligible for the receipt of funds under a statutory or administrative formula for the purposes of prevention, diagnosis or treatment of alcohol and other substance abuse problems and disorders, or mental health problems and disorders; (2) any program under which an Indian tribe is eligible for receipt of funds though a competitive or other grant program for such purposes; and (3) any program under which an Indian tribe is eligible for receipt of funds under any other funding scheme for such purposes.

No Child Left Behind Reform Act - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA) to allow States to include measures of individual or cohort growth over time in determining whether students are making adequate yearly progress (AYP) toward State academic performance standards. Eliminates the consideration of student attendance rates.Allows schools to be given credit for performing well on measures other than test scores when calculating student achievement.Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award competitive: (1) grants to State educational agencies to develop or increase the capacity of data systems for accountability purposes; and (2) subgrants to increase the capacity of local educational agencies to upgrade, create, or manage information databases for the purpose of measuring AYP.Revises the definition of highly qualified teacher to authorize States to: (1) use a generalist exam for middle school teachers; and (2) issue certificates that qualify teachers to teach a number of subjects in social studies or in science.

cratic Oath and Patient Protection Act of 1996 - Prohibits health carriers from: (1) preventing or limiting a health care provider's protected communication to a patient or the public or operating an improper incentive plan; or (2) including indemnification clauses in contracts or agreements. Declares that such a protected communication does not include a trade secret or a knowing misrepresentation by a provider. Declares improper a health care provider incentive plan unless it meets requirements under title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act for physician incentive plans in contracts with eligible organizations. Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to impose fines on health carriers who violate this Act. Allows a private cause of action for violations of this Act.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 5, 2017. SuperPAC Elimination Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 (FECA) to allow direct contributions by citizens and lawful permanent residents of the United States to candidates for federal office without regard to whether the contributions are made through an authorized political committee of the candidate or an authorized political committee of the candidate. Current law limits direct contributions by lawful permanent residents to those made through an authorized political committee of the candidate or an authorized political committee of the candidate. (Sec. 3) The bill revises reporting requirements to require a candidate's principal campaign committee to notify the Federal Election Commission (FEC), the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Secretary of State, as appropriate, in writing, within 24 hours after a contributor receives an aggregate amount of contributions in excess of $200 from any contributor during a calendar year.

Honoring Promises to Service-Disabled Veterans Act of 2011 - Amends the Small Business Act to require the head of each executive department to submit quarterly reports to the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) that contain: (1) the percentage of the total value of all prime contracts awarded by such department to small business concerns owned and controlled by service-disabled veterans; (2) the name of each contractor to which such department awards a contract; (3) for each contract awarded to a contractor, the percentage goal for the utilization as subcontractors of such small business and the weighted average percentage goal negotiated by each contractor for all contracts awarded; and (4) for all contracts awarded to such contractors, the percentage of the total value of all subcontracts awarded. Requires: (1) such reports to be published on a website accessible to the public, and (2) the Administrator to publish on such website the information submitted to the Administrator, except if such publication would be detrimental to national security.

Children's Environmental Protection Act of 1996 - Amends the Toxic Substances Control Act to declare it U.S. policy that: (1) all environmental and public health standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) must be adequate to protect children and other vulnerable subpopulations that are at greater risk from exposure to environmental pollutants; (2) adequate hazard data should be developed with respect to the special vulnerability and exposure to environmental pollutants of children and other vulnerable subpopulations to better assess where, and at what levels, children and other vulnerable subpopulations are being exposed; (3) scientific research opportunities should be identified by EPA to study the health effects of cumulative and simultaneous exposures of children and other vulnerable subpopulations to environmental pollutants; (4) information should be made readily available by EPA to the general public to advance the public's right-to-know, and allow the public to avoid unnecessary and involuntary exposure; and (5) a family right-to-know initiative should be developed by EPA to provide parents with basic information so they can make informed choices to protect their children from environmental health threats in their homes, schools, and communities. <n>Directs the Administrator of EPA to: (1) work with each State to develop and carry out a family right-to-know initiative; and (2)

Accountability in Foster Care Act - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish an Advisory Panel on the Adoption and Foster Care Analysis and Reporting System (AFCARS) to revise and monitor the data collection, analysis, and reporting system designed to be used to assess and improve State performance in operating child protection and child welfare programs pursuant to parts B and E of title IV of the Social Security Act. Directs the Panel to: (1) make written recommendations for changes in law or data collection procedures necessary to revise AFCARS to enable the revised System to track child-specific outcomes longitudinally, analyze entry and exit cohort data, be integrated with the National Youth in Transition Database, and monitor implementation of these AFCARS improvements; and (2) monitor implementation and propose improvements to other State performance measures related to provision of services to children and families.

Buy America 2.0 Act This bill prohibits funds made available to carry out a transportation or infrastructure project using federal funds from being obligated for a project unless the steel, iron, and manufactured goods used for the project are produced in the United States. The bill makes an exception where: (1) applying such prohibition would be inconsistent with the public interest, (2) iron, steel, and the relevant manufactured goods are not produced in the United States in sufficient and reasonably available quantities and of a satisfactory quality, or (3) inclusion of such goods will increase the cost of the overall project by more than 25%. If a federal agency receives a request for a waiver from such prohibition, it shall make available to the public a copy of the request and information concerning the request and allow for public input on the request at least 15 days prior to making a finding based on the request.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 19, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Central American and USA Initiatives Act or the CAUSA Initiatives Act (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to work with the government of Canada and the government of Mexico to establish a program to: (1) assess the specific needs of Central American countries to maintain the security of their international borders, (2) determine the support needed by such countries from the United States, Canada, and Mexico to meet such needs, and (3) assess the current structure for handling displaced minors and other vulnerable individuals in Central American countries and recommendations to improve such structure. Any actions taken pursuant to such program shall be taken in accordance with the goals of advancing human rights and economic opportunities, as well as programming and support for the rule of law, good governance, and civil society. (Sec. 3) DHS shall work with the government of the Caribbean to establish a program to assess the specific needs of such countries to address the unique challenges of maritime border security. (Sec. 4) DHS shall work with the government of Mexico to establish a program to assess: (1) the specific needs of Mexico to help secure its southern border from undocumented aliens, drugs, weapons,

First Time Property Owners Tax Credit Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow individual taxpayers who purchase a real property a refundable tax credit for 5% of the purchase price of such property. Limits the amount of such credit to $1,500, adjusted for inflation after 2008.

Primary Care Physician Reentry Act This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services to establish a demonstration program to assist the development of innovative programs that facilitate physician reentry into clinical practice to provide primary health services. Under such program, HHS must: (1) award one grant, on a competitive basis, to an eligible entity in each of the 10 regions served by a HHS regional office to carry out physician reentry projects to assist reentering physicians participating in such projects; and (2) carry out specified administrative activities, including conducting a national needs assessment with regard to the supply of physicians who provide primary health services, developing a database that contains a directory of programs that help physicians reenter clinical practice, disseminating evidence-based assessments and evaluation tools as such tools become available to measure the basic core competencies of physicians reentering clinical practice, and assisting state regulatory authorities and hospital credentialing committees to structure requirements for physicians to return to clinical practice in a manner that ensures patient safety while addressing the burdens on such physicians.

Terrorism Elimination Act of 2001 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish the Counter-Terrorism Trust Fund from which amounts shall be available for expenditures for counter-terrorism efforts by the United States.Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to issue Freedom Bonds" in response to the September 11, 2001, terrorist acts and to raise funds to assist in recovery operations and for efforts to combat terrorism.Amends the Code to allow taxpayers to designate overpayments and contributions for counter-terrorism efforts. Treats such overpayments and contributions as refunds."

Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to disburse a one-time payment to recipients of Social Security, SSI (Supplemental Security Income under title XVI of the Social Security Act), railroad retirement benefits, and veterans disability compensation or pension benefits if no cost-of-living adjustment is payable in 2011.

National Election Standards Act of 2001- Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to direct the Federal Election Commission (FEC) to provide required uniform national standards regarding procedures for Federal elections that: (1) minimize delay, error, or confusion in voting and in voter registration; (2) eliminate fraud in the voting process; (3) increase the accuracy and reliability of vote counts and counting procedure; (4) reduce the number of uncounted and discarded ballots; (5) encourage voter registration and voter turnout; (6) ensure accessibility to registration facilities and polling places for all voters; and (7) promote public confidence in the accuracy and reliability of the election process.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 9, 2014.
