Federal Facility Accountability Act of 2013 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) to subject each federal department, agency, and instrumentality to state requirements regarding response relating to hazardous substances or pollutants or contaminants (current law refers only to remedial actions) at facilities owned or operated by such department, agency, or instrumentality in the same manner and to the same extent as any nongovernmental entity. Waives any U.S. immunity otherwise applicable with respect to any state substantive or procedural requirement. Makes neither the United States, nor any agent, employee, or officer thereof, immune or exempt from any process or sanction of any state or federal court with respect to the enforcement of injunctive relief. Declares that no agent, employee, or officer of the United States shall be personally liable for any civil penalty under any state substantive or procedural requirement, or this Act, with respect to any act or omission within the scope of official duties of such agent, employee, or officer. Waives immunity of the United States with respect to any such requirement. Makes the reasonable service charges or oversight costs of such an entity

Ensuring Full Use of Federal Health Care Funding Act of 2014 - Amends the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to recoup from states any PPACA grant funds that are not obligated for expenditure before April 1, 2014. Directs the Secretary to use all such funds to make grants to qualified entities in a state to carry out activities before the beginning of the open enrollment period for 2015, including outreach, education, and enrollment activities.

New War on Cancer Act - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to authorize the sponsor of a drug intended for use for cancer to request the Secretary of Health and Human Services to provide written recommendations for nonclinical and clinical investigations which must be conducted with the drug before: (1) it may be approved for cancer; or (2) if the drug is a biological product, it may be licensed for cancer. Requires the Secretary, if the Secretary has reason to believe that a drug for which such a request is made is a cancer drug, to provide the person making the request written recommendations for the nonclinical and clinical investigations which the Secretary believes would be necessary for either approval of such drug for cancer or licensing of such drug for cancer under the Public Health Service Act. <n>Authorizes the sponsor of a drug to request the Secretary to designate the drug as a cancer drug. Requires such designation to be subject to the condition that: (1) the manufacturer of the drug will notify the Secretary of any discontinuance of the production of the drug at least one year before discontinuance; and (2) before an application is approved for the drug or a license is issued for it, the sponsor of the drug will notify the Secretary of any decision to discontinue active pursuit of approval

Department of Homeland Security Component Privacy Officer Act of 2008 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to designate a full-time privacy official for each DHS component, who shall have primary responsibility for implementing the component's privacy policy.

Securing Opioids and Unused Narcotics with Deliberate Disposal and Packaging Act of 2018 or the SOUND Disposal and Packaging Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to authorize the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to require an applicant for a new drug or new animal drug to implement or modify technologies, controls, or measures regarding the packaging or disposal of the drug, including by reducing the availability of unused drugs. The technologies, controls, or measures must: be commensurate with the specific risk of abuse or misuse of the drug; consider the risk not to be unduly burdensome on patient access; and reduce the risk of abuse or misuse. The FDA may issue an order providing for a range of options and incorporating by reference standards established by a nationally or internationally recognized standard development organization. An order may also require the applicant to submit a supplement containing proposed changes to comply with the order.

Federal Surface Transportation Policy and Planning Act of 2009 - (Sec. 2) Declares that it is U.S. policy to develop a comprehensive national surface transportation system that advances the national interest and defense, interstate and foreign commerce, the efficient and safe interstate mobility of people and goods, and the protection of the environment. Requires that such system be built, maintained, managed, and operated as a partnership between the federal, state, and local governments and the private sector and be coordinated with the overall U.S. transportation system, including the nation's air, rail, pipeline, and water transportation systems.<n><n>Sets forth as the objectives of the policy to facilitate and advance: (1) the efficient connectivity of persons and goods within and between nations, regions, states, and metropolitan areas; (2) the safety and health of the public; (3) the security of the nation and the public; (4) environmental protection and enhancement, including the reduction of carbon-related emissions; (5) energy conservation and security, including reducing transportation-related energy use; (6) international and interstate freight movement, trade enhancement, job creation, and economic development; (7) responsible land use and sustainable development; (8) the preservation and adequate performance of system-critical transportation assets; (9) reasonable access to the national surface transportation system for

Enhancing Renewable Energy Investment Act Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) increase the energy tax credit for equipment used to generate electricity by geothermal power and (2) extend the tax credit for qualified energy property grants in lieu of tax credits, including grants for investment in renewable energy property.

(Sec. 2) Allows the Secretary to add any parcel of real property to the System if the parcel owner requests that the Secretary add the parcel to the System and the parcel is a depositional geologic feature.(Sec. 3) Requires the Secretary to: (1) publish in the Federal Register a notice of any addition of property to the System, including notice of the availability of a map showing the property's location; (2) provide a copy of that map to the State and local government in which the property is located and the Committee on Resources of the House of Representatives; and (3) revise the maps to reflect the addition of the property.(Sec. 4) Reauthorizes appropriations.(Sec. 5) Directs the Secretary to undertake a pilot project to determine the feasibility and cost of creating digital versions of System maps. Requires the Secretary to report to specified congressional committees on the project.(Sec. 6) Authorizes appropriations.

Good Neighbor Social Security Office and Community Protection Act of 2012 - Directs the Commissioner of Social Security to develop: (1) financial guidelines that may be used to identify Social Security Administration (SSA) field offices for possible closure, and (2) standardized closure procedures that meet specified requirements. Defines closure" as any realignment, consolidation, or merger of an SSA field office."

Authorizes the President to extend nondiscriminatory treatment (normal trade relations treatment) to the products of the Russian Federation under the Trade Act of 1974. Declares it is U.S policy to remain fully committed to a multifaceted engagement with the Russian Federation, including by: (1) urging the Russian Federation to ensure that its national, regional, and local laws, regulations, practices, and policies fully comply with the standards of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), including by ensuring that the registration of religious groups, visa and immigration requirements, and other laws, regulations, and practices are not used to interfere with the activities or internal affairs of minority religious communities; and (2) enforcing and enhancing existing Russian laws at their legal regime and enforcement record; and (3) providing constitutional guarantees of freedom of the press.

Medicare Prescription Drug Lifeline Act of 2006 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a process under which an applicable individual may terminate enrollment in a prescription drug plan or a Medicare Advantage-Prescription Drug (MA-PD) plan in which they are enrolled and enroll in any plan that provides some coverage of covered Medicare part D drugs after the individual has reached the initial coverage limit but has not reached the annual out-of-pocket threshold, and that serves the area in which the individual resides.<n><n>Directs the Comptroller General to study and report to Congress on: (1) the costs to the Medicare program of eliminating the initial coverage limit; and (2) the adjustment to the coinsurance amount that would be necessary to eliminate such initial coverage limit and provide that standard prescription drug coverage included such adjusted coinsurance amount until the individual reached such annual out-of-pocket threshold.

Fighting Fraud in Bankruptcy Act of 2011 - Amends federal bankruptcy law to deem a person to have asserted a claim by, without limitation, preparing, signing, filing, submitting, or later advocating a proof of claim, a motion seeking relief from the stay imposed under chapter 7 (Liquidation) or chapter 13 (Adjustment of Debts of an Individual with Regular Income) of the bankruptcy code, or other paper, representing to the court that a claim is owed or that it is owed in a specific amount. Deems any officer, director, employee, or agent of the person asserting a claim and any attorney, accountant, or other professional person who is employed by or is assisting such person to have asserted such a claim, as well as under a court's inherent powers: (1) an order or judgment imposing a civil penalty of up to $5,000 for each claim asserted by the person in violation of this Act; (2) an order or judgment requiring a person in one or more cases to pay actual damages to an injured debtor, or trustee; and (3) an order or judgment imposing upon a person in one or more cases, wherever situated, in which the person has asserted, or could assert, a claim in violation of this Act, other prospective or retrospective relief, including de

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 16, 2016. (Sec. 1) This bill authorizes the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to direct a VA employee to repay a portion of any bonus or award paid to the employee, provided that: (1) the VA Secretary determines such repayment appropriate pursuant to VA regulations, and (2) the employee is afforded notice and an opportunity for a hearing conducted by the Secretary. The decision of the Secretary regarding such a repayment is final and may not be reviewed by any other agency or any court. The bill makes conforming amendments to Federal law regarding the Senior Executive Service (SES). (Sec. 2) The requirements applicable to a covered small business under the Small Business Act shall apply with respect to a small business owned and controlled by a veteran with a service-connected disability or by such a small business awarded a contract that is counted for purposes of meeting the goals of the Small Business Act for small business utilization in the VA. Such requirements shall also apply to a small business if the Secretary determines that such small business did not act in good faith with respect to such requirements. The Director of Small and Disadvantaged Business Utilization for the VA and the Chief Acquisition Officer of the VA shall jointly implement a process using specified systems to monitor compliance

Community Services Block Grant Amendments of 1994 - Amends the Community Services Block Grant Act (CSBGA) to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make grants to local, private, nonprofit community development corporations, or to enter into contracts or cooperative agreements with such corporations, to plan and carry out economic development activities in economically distressed communities. Specifies that such economic development activities shall be designed to address the economic needs of low-income individuals and families by creating employment and business development opportunities and by providing support services designed to enhance the ability of low-income individuals and families to successfully avail themselves of such opportunities. Allows such activities to include the development of facilities through means such as the establishment of partnerships with Head Start agencies, agencies or organizations providing child care or otherwise engaged in the field of child care or child development, and agencies or organizations serving children, youth, and families. Declares that each community development corporation receiving funds shall be governed by a board that shall consist of residents of the community and business and civic leaders. Specifies that the Secretary shall annually publish a statement of the types of projects or activities for which funding under this Act will be a priority, such as projects or activities designed to strengthen or enhance activities funded by other Federal programs. Directs the

Political Broadcasting Access Act of 1993 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require each license for a broadcasting station and each cable operator to make available free broadcast or cable time for political advertising. Provides standards for time allotment, including total time to be allotted, the length of each unit of such free time, the hours of the day and the time of the year in which such free time must be allowed, a limitation on such free time, and the use of such free time.

Enhancing Employment and Training Through Education Act of 2013 - Amends the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 to direct the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to carry out pilot projects to identify best practices for employment and training programs to raise the number of work registrants who obtain unsubsidized employment, increase their earned income, and reduce their reliance on public assistance, including but not limited to the supplemental nutrition assistance program (SNAP, formerly the food stamp program). Requires the Secretary to provide an independent evaluation of the pilot projects to measure the impact of their impact on the ability of each pilot project target population to find and retain employment that leads to increased household income and reduced dependency, compared to what would have occurred in the absence of the pilot projects.

Drive Away From Ethanol Welfare Act of 1996 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to deny the credit for alcohol used to produce ether. Limits the credit to alcohol produced after December 31, 1996, only if such alcohol is designated by a producer who is registered under the Code. Makes such alcohol eligible for the credit only if it is: (1) produced by a producer other than an eligible small ethanol producer as of December 31, 1996; and (2) sold or used by such producer for any purpose specified under this Act.

Dine College Act of 2016 This bill directs the Department of the Interior to: (1) conduct a survey and study of all capital projects and facility needs of Dine College on the Navajo Nation, and (2) report to Congress on the results. Interior shall make grants to the college for: (1) construction activities, including the renovation and repair or construction of buildings, water and sewer facilities, roads, information technology and telecommunications infrastructure, classrooms, and external structures; and (2) operation and maintenance activities, including basic, special, developmental, vocational, technical, and special handicapped education costs, annual capital expenditures, and summer and special interest programs.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 6, 2016. Veterans Access to Care Accountability Act (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to conduct random, periodic audits of Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) medical facilities and Veterans Integrated Service Networks (VISNs) to assess whether they are complying with all standards imposed by law or by the VA Secretary with respect to the timely access of veterans to VA hospital care, medical services, and other health care. (Sec. 3) The VA Secretary shall: (1) notify a veteran who has been subjected to a wait time of more than 30 days for an appointment for VA hospital care, medical services, or other health care upon receipt of such report; and (2) make every effort possible to schedule such an appointment through a non-VA health care provider by a specified date. (Sec. 4) The VA Inspector General shall notify the Secretary within 30 days after determining that the director of a VA medical facility has purposefully misrepresented patient records or other data to conceal a failure to comply with VA patient access or care standards or for the purpose of qualifying for a performance award. The Secretary shall ensure that any performance review or consideration for promotion of a director or other VA official with respect to which

Bounty Hunter Accountability and Quality Assistance Act of 1998 - Directs the Attorney General to develop model guidelines for the State control and regulation of persons employed or applying for employment as bounty hunters, including recommendations regarding whether: (1) a person seeking such employment should be required to submit to a fingerprint-based criminal background check prior to entering into such employment or not be allowed to obtain such employment if that person has been convicted of a felony offense under Federal or State law; (2) bounty hunters and employers should be required to obtain adequate liability insurance for actions taken in the course of performing duties; and (3) State laws should provide official recognition of bounty hunters from other States, first on the front door and announcing the presence of one or more bounty hunters from other States, unless such person also is self-employed to obtain the recovery of any fugitive from justice who has been released on bail. <n>Directs the Attorney General to publish model guidelines for State control and regulation of persons employed or applying for employment as bounty hunters, including recommendations regarding whether: (1) a person seeking such employment should be required to obtain adequate liability insurance for actions taken in the course of performing duties; and (2) State laws should provide official recognition of bounty hunters from other States, first on the front door and announcing the presence of one or

Reinstatement of Enrollment for Medicaid Eligibility of Disadvantaged Youth (REMEDY) Act - Amends titles XIX (Medicaid) and XXI (State Children's Health Insurance) (SCHIP) of the Social Security Act to require state Medicaid and SCHIP plans to reinstate Medicaid and SCHIP enrollment for certain youth upon release from public institutions, unless they are no longer eligible.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish, in the case of an eligible enterprise zone business, a zone clean fuels credit equal to the sum of the zone clean-fuel property credit and the zone clean-burning fuel use credit. Defines eligible enterprise zone business" as: (1) an enterprise zone business located within an empowerment zone or enterprise community; and (2) a trade or business located outside of an empowerment zone or enterprise community, but only with respect to qualified clean-fuel vehicle property used substantially within an empowerment zone or enterprise community."

21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001- Amends the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act to declare that it is the policy of Congress to provide for the establishment, use, and enforcement of a consistent and comprehensive system for labeling violent content in audio and visual media products (including labeling of such products in advertisements) whereby: (1) the public may be adequately informed of the nature, context, and intensity of depictions of violence in such products; and (2) matters needed to judge the appropriateness of the purchase, viewing, listening to, use, or other consumption of such products containing violent content by minors of various ages. Authorizes manufacturers and producers of interactive video game products and services, video program products, motion picture products, and sound recording products to submit to the Federal Trade Commission a joint proposal for a system for labeling the violent content in such products. Outlines labeling system requirements, including a minimum age for purchase and viewing.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 9, 2016. Amateur Radio Parity Act of 2016 (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to amend its regulations concerning amateur radio services to prohibit an application to amateur stations of any private land use restriction, including a restrictive covenant, that: (1) precludes communications in an amateur radio service; (2) fails to permit a licensee in an amateur radio service to install and maintain an effective outdoor antenna on property under the licensee's exclusive use or control; or (3) does not constitute the minimum practicable restriction on such communications to accomplish the lawful purposes of a community association seeking to enforce such restriction. The FCC shall require: (1) any licensee in an amateur radio service to notify and obtain prior approval from a community association concerning installation of an outdoor antenna; and (2) such association to prohibit installation of any antenna or antenna support structure by a licensee in an amateur radio service on common property not under the exclusive use or control of the licensee. The FCC shall permit a community association to establish reasonable written rules concerning height, location, size, and aesthetic impact of, and installation requirements for, outdoor antennas and support structures for the purpose of conducting communications in the amateur radio services.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on January 8, 2006. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>Title I: Dorothyll Memorial Visitor Center Lease Act - Dorothyll Memorial Visitor Center Lease Act - Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Porter County Convention, Recreation and Visitor Commission to establish a joint partnership for the management of the Dorothyll Memorial Visitor Center located south of the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore. Authorizes the Secretary to lease space in the Center for use as a visitor center. Authorizes the Secretary to use Lakeshore Center employees to provide visitor information and education at the Center. Authorizes appropriations.<n><n>Title II: Public Land Technical Amendments Act of 2006 - Gay Nelson Wilderness Redesignation Act - Amends the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2005 to modify the boundary of the Gay Nelson Wilderness to include the Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee Memorial, and Cumberland Island Wilderness.<n><n>Modifies the boundary of the Petr Forest National Park Expansion Act to include the Arlington House, the George Washington Parkway, and the Robert E. Lee Memorial.

Achieving a Better Life Experience Act of 2011 or the ABLE Act of 2011- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish tax-exempt ABLE accounts and allow contributions to such accounts for the purpose of meeting the qualified disability expenses of a designated beneficiary with a disability. Defines qualified disability expenses" as expenses for the benefit of an individual with a disability who is a designated beneficiary, including expenses for education, housing, transportation, health and wellness, financial management and administrative services, and assistive technology and personal support services."

Reserve Account for Administrative Savings Act of 1993 - Amends Federal law to require all appropriations for salaries and expenses to be apportioned as necessary to carry out this Act, except that, in apportioning any appropriation for salaries and expenses for a fiscal year, a reserve shall be established in an amount equal to five percent of the actual amount incurred for those salaries and expenses in the immediately preceding fiscal year. Specifies the size of each reserve to be established for a fiscal year. <n>Requires the head of each agency that has an appropriation for salaries and expenses for a fiscal year to: (1) within 60 days after the beginning of that fiscal year or within 60 days after the date of enactment of the law by which the appropriation for that fiscal year is made available, whichever occurs later; and (2) make recommendations to the President of changes in laws or regulations or other changes that should be made to bring about a more efficient and cost-effective operation and thereby reduce salaries and expenditures without jeopardizing any programs that agency administers. <n>Requires the President's annual budget submission for a budget year to include a special message which sets forth on an agency-by-agency basis a recommendation for the current fiscal year of whether: (1) for the programs that agency administers to be maintained at a proper administrative

Governors Island Preservation and Development Act of 1998 - Amends the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 to establish the Governors Island Commission. <n>Requires the Commission to: (1) conduct meetings and hold hearings; (2) consider each plan for the disposition of Governors Island, New York; and (3) submit to the President a recommendation for the disposition of Governors Island. Requires the recommendation of the Commission to be made to the President by the Governor of New York, the mayor of New York, or the speaker of the city council of New York, New York. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Title II: Delivery of Services Regarding Lupus<n> - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make grants for projects for the establishment, operation, and coordination of effective and cost-efficient systems for the delivery of essential services to individuals with lupus and their families. Authorizes appropriations.

Amends the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 to authorize a qualified State or personal funds issuer of a debenture purchased by the Federal Financing Bank (Bank) and guaranteed by the Small Business Administration (SBA), if the debenture is outstanding and neither the loan securing the debenture nor the debenture is in default, to prepay the debenture to the Bank by paying the unpaid principal balance and the amount of the repurchase premium (determined under this Act). Specifies the amounts of such prepayments.

(Sec. 3) Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), after consultation with appropriate Federal, State, and local officials, to conduct studies for use in developing: (1) a more complete list of potential human health risks from inhalation, ingestion, or body contact with coastal recreation waters; (2) appropriate and effective indicators for improving direct detection of the presence of pathogens that are harmful to human health in such waters; (3) appropriate, accurate, and expeditious methods for detecting the presence of pathogens, harmful to human health, found in such waters; and (4) guidance for the State-to-State application of such criteria to account for the diversity of geographic and aquatic conditions nationwide. Directs the Administrator, based on the results of such studies, to: (1) conduct, in cooperation with the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere, studies to provide additional information to the current base of knowledge for use in developing such criteria; and (2) publish the water quality criteria for coastal recreation waters that are consistent with such criteria. Deems the water quality criteria for coastal recreational waters for the State to have been promulgated if the State has not complied with such requirement within a specified time period.(Sec. 4) Requires the Administrator to issue guidance for States to incorporate other water quality criteria into appropriate programs

Prescription Coverage Now Act of 2006 - Amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to provide for an expedited process for the qualification for low-income assistance through a request by the Secretary to the Secretary of the Treasury for information sufficient to identify whether the individual involved is likely eligible for subsidies based on such information and the amount of premium and cost-sharing subsidies for which they would qualify based on such information. Requires the Secretary to ensure that, as part of the Medicare enrollment process, enrolling individuals: (1) receive information describing the low-income subsidy provided; and (2) are provided the opportunity to opt-in to the expedited process by giving consent for the Secretary to screen the beneficiary for eligibility for such subsidy through a request to the Secretary of the Treasury under the Internal Revenue Code.

U.S. Agricultural Sector Relief Act of 2012 - Amends the Clean Air Act to direct the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), for each year beginning 2013, to take all appropriate actions within the authority of EPA to seek a critical use exemption under the Montreal Protocol to allow the production, importation, and consumption of methyl bromide: (1) for any use of methyl bromide that is an approved critical use; and (2) in the amount necessary for the use described in this Act. Requires the Administrator, when evaluating the technical and economic feasibility of any alternative, to consider: (1) cost and commercial availability of the alternative to the applicant; (2) demonstrated effectiveness of the alternative for the applicant's specific intended use; (3) demonstrated effectiveness of the alternative in the geographic region of the applicant's intended use; and (4) state or local regulations that may restrict use of the alternative for the applicant's intended use.<n><n>Requires the Administrator to allow the production, importation, and consumption in the United States of methyl bromide: (1) for any use described in this Act in response to an emergency event, and (2) in an amount necessary for such use. Limits the amount of methyl bromide allowed for use per emergency event at a specific location to 20 metric tons. Limits the aggregate amount of methyl bromide

Repeals provisions of the following Acts: the National Space Grant College and Fellowship Act; the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Authorization Act, 1978; the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Authorization Act, 1983; the Departments of Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development, and Independent Agencies Administrative Appropriations Act, 1992; the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Authorization Act, 1992; the Land Remote Sensing Policy Act of 1992; the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Authorization Act, 1993; the Science, Space, and Technology Education Trust Fund Act of 1989; the Departments of Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development, and Independent Agencies Administrative Appropriations Act, 1990; the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Authorization Act, 1996; and the Technology Education Trust Fund Act of 1997.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) increase by 50 percent the tax imposed on a corporate insider for any taxable year the amount realized from the disqualified disposition of stock acquired by such insider upon the exercise of a stock option granted by the corporation; (2) increase by 50 percent the tax imposed on the net cost of personal perks provided to a retired executive of the corporation; and (3) include in the gross income of certain corporate insiders amounts received as funded deferred compensation.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 9, 2014. Working Families' Access to Health Innovations Act of 2013 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Small Business Act to authorize the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) to guarantee up to 90% of the amount of a loan, up to specified loan amounts, to a small business concern whose practice is a small business concern and is in a medically underserved community for the acquisition of health information technology for use in the professional's medical practice and for the costs associated with the installation of such technology. Defines the term "health information technology" to mean computer hardware, software, and related technology (including electronic medical record technology) that: (1) supports the compliance with the meaningful electronic health record use requirements of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act; (2) is purchased by an eligible professional to aid in the provision of health care in a health care setting; and (3) provides for enhancement of continuity of care for patients through electronic storage, transmission, and exchange of relevant personal health data and information, enhancement of communication between patients and health care providers, improvement of quality measurement by eligible professionals enabling them to collect, store, measure, and report on the processes and outcomes of

Superfund Site Public Health Improvement Act - Amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) with respect to requirements for health assessments at National Priorities List facilities owned by the Federal Government. Requires such assessments to be commenced as soon as practicable after each facility is proposed for inclusion on such List and completed by the date of the issuance of a remedial investigation and feasibility study to allow full consideration in selecting the remedial action of the public health implications of any release.Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency and the Administrator of the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry to develop strategies to obtain relevant on-site and off-site characterization data for use in a health assessment. Requires the Administrator, to the maximum extent practicable, to provide the Administrator with the data and information necessary to make such assessments sufficiently prior to the initiation of remedial actions.Requires the Administrator, in order to improve community involvement in health assessments, to: (1) actively collect data from residents of affected communities and from other sources in communities affected or potentially affected by releases of hazardous substances, pollutants, or contaminants; and (2) design health assessments that take into account the needs and conditions of the affected community.Requires the Administrator to: (1) conduct a human health study of exposure or other health effects for

Community Mental Health and Addiction Safety Net Equity Act of 2010 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require services under the community mental health services plan for FY2011-FY2015 to be provided only through appropriate, qualified community programs, including federally qualified behavioral health centers, child mental health programs, psychosocial rehabilitation programs, mental health peer-support programs, and mental health primary consumer-directed programs. Requires the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) to certify, and recertify at least every five years, federally qualified behavioral health centers meeting specified criteria.

Declares that: (1) the parties agree that disputes between the parties regarding interpretation, application, and implementation of the Compact shall be settled by alternative dispute resolution; and (2) the Council, in consultation with the Provinces, shall provide by rule procedures for the resolution of disputes pursuant to this Act.Entitles any person aggrieved by any action taken by the Council under this Act to a hearing before the Council. Entitles any person aggrieved by a Party action to a hearing pursuant to the relevant Party's administrative procedures and laws. Provides for exhaustion of such administrative remedies, and provides for judicial review of a Council action in the District Court for the District of Columbia or the Court in which the Council maintains offices, provided such action is commenced within 90 days.Authorizes the Council, or any Party or the Council to initiate actions to compel compliance with the provisions of this Compact, and the rules and regulations promulgated under this Act. Grants jurisdiction over such actions to the court of the relevant Party, as well as the U.S. District Courts for the District of Columbia and the District Court in which the Council maintains offices. Permits each Party to issue orders within its respective jurisdiction and to initiate actions to compel compliance with the provisions of its respective statutes and regulations adopted to implement

EMTALA Regulatory Improvement Act of 2003 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act with respect to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA) to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to: (1) establish a procedure to notify hospitals and physicians when an EMTALA investigation is closed; and (2) request prior review by peer review organizations in EMTALA cases involving termination of a hospital's participation in EMTALA.Directs the Secretary to establish a Technical Advisory Group to review issues related to EMTALA and its implementation.

Military Injury Surgical Systems Integrated Operationally Nationwide to Achieve ZERO Preventable Deaths Act or the MISSION ZERO Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to award grants to up to 20 eligible high-acuity trauma centers to enable military trauma teams to provide trauma care and related acute care at such trauma centers. Limits grants to $1 million per year and their duration to between three and five years. Requires the Secretary to award grants to eligible trauma centers to enable military trauma care providers to provide trauma care and related acute care. Requires a grant recipient to agree to allow military trauma care providers providing care pursuant to such grant to be deployed by the Secretary for military operations, for training, or for response to a mass casualty incident. Allows grants to be used to train and incorporate military trauma care providers into such trauma center.

Super Pollutants Act of 2014 - Requires the President to establish the Interagency Task Force on Short-Lived Climate Pollutant Mitigation. Defines "short-lived climate pollutant" as black carbon, methane, or hydrofluorocarbons with high global warming potential (high-GWP HFC). Directs the Task Force to: (1) review the policy or recommendations made by the Interagency Climate Change Adaptation Task Force, the Interagency Strategy to Reduce Methane Emissions, the March 2012 report to Congress on Black Carbon, and the Council on Climate Preparedness and Resilience; (2) incorporate any appropriate proposals or recommendations made by entities or reports relevant to short-lived climate pollutants into the Task Force's action plan; (3) identify federal programs that are or could be addressing the reduction of short-lived climate pollutants; (4) identify overlapping and duplicative programs that would benefit from consolidation and streamlining; (5) identify gaps and serious deficiencies in U.S. programs targeted at short-lived climate pollutants; (6) report to Congress on findings and recommendations resulting from those activities; and (7) in developing recommendations, consult with affected stakeholders in private industry. Requires each federal agency to submit a report that includes: (1) agency plans for reducing hydrofluorocarbon emissions, and (2) plans to

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on March 23, 2017. Vision Zero Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill authorizes the Secretary of Transportation to award grants to a city, town, township, borough, county, parish, district, village, or other political subdivision of a state to develop a Vision Zero plan to eliminate transportation-related fatalities and serious injuries in its jurisdiction within a specified timeframe, not to exceed 20 years. The total number of grants awarded is limited to 5. At least 25% of funds made available for this Act shall be used to make grants to eligible entities serving a jurisdiction with a population of under 200,000. The federal share of projects costs shall not exceed 80%.

Soil and Water Protection Act of 1992 - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a Federal energy conservation program to target and promote more efficient energy use in, and the conservation of energy with respect to, tillage practices, chemical and fertilizer management, irrigation management, livestock facility management, horticulture, and wood utilization. <n>Directs the Secretary, acting through the Soil Conservation Service, to make grants to individuals or institutions that present within eligible States for projects for energy conservation, including: (1) demonstrating the advantages of conservation tillage practices that promote energy conservation; (2) training horticultural pest scouting and soil sampling to promote education concerning prescription application of manure systems; (3) reducing energy consumption; (4) managing livestock irrigation facilities for energy conservation; (5) managing facilities for energy conservation; and (6) improving efficiency in utilization of wood, including milling of forest products and the use of wood for production of energy. <n>Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) Federal grant limits and limitations; (2) allocation among eligible States; (3) State agriculture energy conservation review panels; and (4) State participation and assistance. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Small Business Hardship Relief Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to treat a small business as experiencing a hardship for any calendar year if such business: (1) missed two or more consecutive loan payments; (2) is a debtor in a title 11 case; (3) received a notice from a utility that it is preparing to stop providing services to such business because of nonpayment of amounts owed for utility service; (4) received a notice of eviction of foreclosure; or (5) experienced a fire, flood, other natural or human-caused disaster that resulted in substantial damage to the business property. Limits the duration of such exemptions to five years.

(Sec. 1) Amends the Omnibus Consolidated and Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act, 1999 to revise requirements for the appraisal of the Canyon Ferry Cabin Site, Montana, to provide that the appraisal shall use the Canyon Ferry Cabin Site appraisal with a completion date of March 29, 1999, and amended June 11, 1999, with an effective date of valuation of October 15, 1998, for the Bureau of Reclamation, on the conditions that: (1) the contract appraisers that conducted the original appraisal having an effective date of valuation of October 15, 1998, for the Bureau shall make appropriate modifications to permit recalculation of the lot values established in the original appraisal into an updated appraisal; and (2) any changes in the characteristic of a property that form part of the basis of the updated appraisal shall be made appropriate adjustment to the updated appraisal. Declares that the October 15, 1998, Canyon Ferry Cabin Site original appraisal shall remain valid for use by the Bureau in the sale process for at least three years from the date of completion of the updated appraisal. States that the October 15, 1998, appraisal shall remain valid for use by the Bureau in the sale process for a period of no less than three years from the date of completion of the updated appraisal. Specifies that: (1) the remaining lessees shall have a right to continue leasing through August 31, 2014; and (2)

Amends Federal law to require the Director of the National Weather Service to notify the Secretary of Health and Human Services whenever any State, county, municipality, or other jurisdiction is subject to a heat emergency which threatens the health of its residents. Declares that such notification shall be delivered to the Secretary within one hour of the declaration being determined. Declares that there is authorized a pool of monies that shall be added to the appropriations of the Department of Health and Human Services for the expressed purpose of providing assistance to low income recipients and seniors for the duration of a declared heat emergency. Directs the Secretary, prior to such authorization, to research and report to the Congress on the amount of funds needed to fully compensate public utilities for the delivery of energy necessary to sufficiently cool the residencies of a Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) recipient in a manner that will alleviate the likelihood of heat-related illness and prevent the worsening of preexisting acute conditions. Requires the Secretary to take into account: (1) the number of current LIHEAP recipients; (2) the amount of energy needed to cool the homes of LIHEAP recipients; and (3) the number of days in the previous calendar year in which the National Weather Service declared a heat emergency in areas served by LIHEAP. Declares that

Telework Tax Incentive Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a limited tax credit for qualified teleworking expenses. Defines telework" as performing work functions, using electronic information and communication technologies, thereby reducing or eliminating the physical commute to and from the traditional worksite."

Rail-Highway Grade Crossing Safety Act of 1994 - Amends Federal highway law to authorize States to use increased Federal surface transportation program funds for incentive payments to local jurisdictions for permanent closings of public at-grade crossings. <n>Directs the Secretary of Transportation: (1) to establish guidelines to enable States to determine the public benefits and costs resulting from any new rail-highway grade crossings; (2) before making an apportionment of Federal surface transportation program funds, to set aside $500,000 for a public information and education program to help prevent and reduce motor vehicle accidents, injuries, and fatalities, to improve driver performance at railway-highway crossings, and to help prevent trespassing on rail rights-of-way; and (3) to carry out a program to provide an additional financial incentive to States that review and implement grade crossing safety improvements on a corridor basis. <n>Directs the Secretary to set aside $15 million for a fiscal year to carry out a program to provide a financial incentive to States that review and implement grade crossing safety improvements on a corridor basis.

Taxpayer Responsibility, Accountability, and Consistency Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) require reporting to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) of payments to corporations (other than for tax-exempt hospitals and extended care facilities); (2) set forth safe harbor criteria and rules relating to the treatment of workers as employees or independent contractors; and (3) increase penalties for failure to file correct tax return information or comply with other information reporting requirements.

Fairness and Accountability in Reorganizations Act of 2006 - Amends federal bankruptcy law regarding executive compensation to require the court to approve or disapprove an executive's compensation disclosed in writing, without deference to the debtor's request, as reasonable.<n><n>Prohibits the bankruptcy court from finding that specified transfers or obligations of a debtor, in the absence of a finding by the court that such transfers or obligations are essential to the survival of the business or to the orderly liquidation and maximization of value of debtor's assets, are reasonable under the circumstances of the bankruptcy case.<n><n>Requires the court to take into account the ongoing impact on the debtor's relationship with all subsidiaries and affiliates, regardless of whether a subsidiary or affiliate is domestic or nondomestic, or whether any such subsidiary or affiliate is a debtor entity.<n><n>Requires the court to assure that: (1) all creditors, the debtor, and affected parties are treated fairly and equitably; and (2) in determining whether the proposal for a collective bargaining agreement provides for those necessary modifications in employee benefits and protections, the court takes into account the ongoing impact on the debtor's relationship with all subsidiaries and affiliates.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 2, 2014. Frank Buckles World War I Memorial Act (Sec. 3) This bill authorizes the World War I Memorial Foundation to establish a commemorative work rededicating the District of Columbia War Memorial as a national and District of Columbia World War I Memorial, including: (1) full restoration of the existing Memorial; and (2) the addition of an appropriate sculptural or other commemorative element, which shall complement and preserve the existing Memorial and its landscape, at the site of the existing Memorial to make it a national memorial. The rededication of the District of Columbia War Memorial shall be in accordance with the Commemorative Works Act, except it shall not apply to this Act. (Sec. 5) The Foundation shall solicit and accept private contributions for the Memorial. If, upon payment of all expenses of the rededication, there remains a balance of funds received for the establishment of the commemorative work, the Foundation shall transmit the amount of such balance to the Secretary of the Treasury for deposit in an account provided for in the Commemorative Works Act.

Pension Right to Know Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require notice to participants and employee organizations of large defined benefit plan amendments which have the effect of significantly reducing future benefit accruals.

Manufacturing Modernization and Diversification Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to certify special purpose vehicles (SPVs) to take part in a program to carry out Collateral Support Programs and Loan Participation Programs for the benefit of qualified manufacturers. Defines a qualified manufacturer" as a business engaged in manufacturing that has less than $50 million in annual revenue and less than $50 million in assets.<n><n>Requires each SPV wishing to participate in the loan program to submit an application to the Secretary, which shall include a detailed proposal for the structure of the Collateral Support Program the SPV proposes to carry out, including what criteria it intends to use to determine which qualified manufacturers will be eligible to participate.<n><n>Requires: (1) loans made to SPVs under the loan program to be made with an interest rate of 0.5%; and (2) the amount of all fees and interest payments paid by qualified manufacturers to an SPV to be retained by the SPV."

Antitrust Modernization Commission Act of 2001 - Establishes the Antitrust Modernization Commission to: (1) investigate and study issues and problems relating to the modernization of the antitrust laws; (2) solicit divergent views of all parties concerned with the operation of such laws; (3) evaluate the advisability of proposals and current arrangements with respect to such issues and problems; and (4) prepare and submit a report to Congress and the President on such issues and problems.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 17, 2015. Gabriella Miller Kids First Research Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to terminate the funding of political party conventions and transfer the amounts in each account maintained for the national committee of a major party or minor party to a fund in the Treasury established by the Public Health Service Act (PHSA) for the 10-year Pediatric Research Initiative Fund. The PHSA is amended to require the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Division of Program Coordination, Planning, and Strategic Initiatives to identify research that represents important areas of emerging scientific opportunities, or knowledge gaps that deserve special emphasis and would benefit rising public health challenges, and to allocate funds for such research to the national research institutes and national centers for conducting and supporting research that is identified.

Department of Defense Anthrax Vaccination Moratorium Act - Expresses the sense of the Congress that: (1) a single force protection measure such as the mandatory anthrax vaccine immunization program should not be implemented by the Department of Defense (DOD) without regard for its own effects on morale, retention, recruiting, and budget; and (2) an insufficiently proven vaccine should not be advocated as a substitute for research, development, and production of truly effective vaccines and essential antibiotics, adequate personal protective equipment, detection devices, and nonproliferation measures. Requires the Secretary of Defense to suspend implementation of the anthrax vaccination program of DOD and prohibits further vaccination of any member of the Armed Forces under such program. Requires the Director of the National Institutes of Health to require an independent study of the effectiveness and safety of the vaccine used in the DOD anthrax vaccination program, including determinations of: (1) types and severity of adverse reactions; and (2) long-term health implications, including interactions with other vaccines and medications. Prohibits the Director from using for purposes of the study any data arising from the experience of inoculating members of the Armed Forces with the vaccine studied because of the lack of informed consent and inadequate recordkeeping associated with such inoculations. Requires the Director, upon completion of the study, to

Independent Counsel Reauthorization Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal judicial code to reauthorize the independent counsel program for five years. <n>Requires an independent counsel to: (1) conduct all activities with due regard for expense; (2) authorize only reasonable and lawful expenditures; and (3) promptly, upon taking office, assign to a specific employee the duty of certifying that such expenditures are reasonable and made in accordance with law. <n>Requires the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts to provide administrative support and guidance to each independent counsel. <n>Directs the Administrator of General Services to provide appropriate office space for each independent counsel. Requires such office space to be within a Federal building unless the Administrator determines that other arrangements would cost less. <n>Entitles an independent counsel and persons appointed to be entitled to the payment of travel expenses as provided under the Federal judicial code, including travel or transportation expenses in accordance with requirements for travel reimbursement. Declares that an independent counsel and any person appointed shall not be entitled to the payment of travel and subsistence expenses with respect to duties performed in the city in which the primary office of that independent counsel or person is located after one year of service by that independent counsel or person unless the employee assigned duties certify that the payment is in the

Postresearch Chimpanzee Care Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a system to provide for the lifetime care of chimpanzees that have been used, or were bred or purchased for use, in research conducted or supported by the National Institutes of Health, the Food and Drug Administration, or other Federal agencies and with respect to which it has been determined that the chimpanzees are not needed for such research. Requires all surplus chimpanzees owned by the Federal Government to be accepted into the sanctuary system and requires any surplus chimpanzee that is not owned by the Federal Government to be accepted into the system if the owner transfers to the Federal Government title to the chimpanzee. Sets forth standards for operating the sanctuary system to provide for the permanent retirement of surplus chimpanzees.

Clearwater Basin Project Act - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to establish the Clearwater Advisory Panel to improve collaborative relationships and provide advice and recommendations to the Forest Service regarding the Clearwater Basin pilot project and activities under the project, as authorized by this Act. Requires the Panel to: (1) review and make recommendations to the Forest Service regarding activities proposed for high priority implementation as part of the project; (2) provide early and continuous coordination with appropriate Forest Service and other agency officials in reviewing and recommending activities for high priority implementation; and (3) provide frequent opportunities for citizens, organizations, tribes, agencies, and other interested parties to participate in all stages of the activity schedule development process.

. Satisfying Energy Needs and Saving the Environment Act or the SENSE Act (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to authorize an operator of a coal refuse electric utility steam generating unit to elect to comply with either: (1) an emissions standard for emissions of hydrogen chloride that meets specified requirements; or (2) an emission standard for emissions of sulfur dioxide that meets the requirements of this bill, but may not require that the unit comply with both an emission standard for emissions of hydrogen chloride and an emission standard for sulfur dioxide. The EPA shall require the operator to comply, at the election of the operator, with no more than one of the following emission standards: (1) an emission standard for emissions of hydrogen chloride from the unit that is no more stringent than an emission rate of 0.002 pounds per million British thermal units of heat input; (2) an emission standard for emissions of sulfur dioxide from the unit that is no more stringent than an emission rate of 0.20 pounds per million British thermal units of heat input; (3) an emission standard for emissions of sulfur dioxide from the unit that is no more stringent than an emission rate of 1.5 pounds per megawatt-hour; or (4) an emission standard for emissions of sulfur dioxide across the generating unit or group of generating units that is

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on September 6, 2017. NIST Cybersecurity Framework, Assessment, and Auditing Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to require the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to emphasize the principle that expanding cybersecurity threats require engineering security from the beginning of an information system's life cycle, building more trustworthy and secure components and systems from the start, and applying well-defined security design principles throughout. (Sec. 3) The bill requires NIST to: promote the implementation by federal agencies of the Framework for Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity by providing to the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), the Office of Science and Technology Policy, and all other federal agencies six months after enactment of this bill guidance that federal agencies may use to incorporate the Framework into their information security risk management efforts, describe how the Framework aligns with or augments existing agency practices related to compliance with federal cybersecurity requirements, identify any areas of conflict or overlap between the Framework and existing cybersecurity requirements, include a template for federal agencies on how to use the Framework, recommend procedures for streamlining and harmonizing existing and future cybersecurity-related requirements, recommend other procedures for compliance with cybersecurity reporting, oversight, and policy review and creation requirements

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 25, 2017. Strengthening State and Local Cyber Crime Fighting Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to authorize for FY2017-FY2022 within the United States Secret Service a National Computer Forensics Institute to: disseminate information related to the investigation and prevention of cyber and electronic crime and related threats, and educate, train, and equip state, local, tribal, and territorial law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and judges; and train and equip such law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and judges on methods to obtain, process, store, and admit digital evidence in court. The institute must ensure that timely, actionable, and relevant expertise and information related to cyber and electronic crime and related threats is shared with state, local, tribal, and territorial law enforcement officers and prosecutors. The institute may provide law enforcement officers with computer equipment, hardware, software, manuals, and tools necessary to conduct cyber and electronic crime and related threat investigations and computer and mobile device forensic examinations. The institute must facilitate the expansion of the network of Electronic Crime Task Forces of the Secret Service through the addition of state, local, tribal, and territorial law enforcement officers educated and trained at the institute. (Sec

Nutria Eradication and Control Act of 2009 - Establishes a nutria eradication program under which the Secretary of the Interior may provide financial assistance to Maryland, Louisiana, Delaware, Oregon, Virginia, and Washington to eradicate or control nutria and restore nutria-damaged wetland.<n><n>Requires that the Maryland program consist of management, research, and public education activities carried out in accordance with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service\\'s document Eradication Strategies for Nutria in the Chesapeake and Delaware Bay Watersheds." Limits the federal share of the program\\'s cost to 75%. Prohibits more than 5% of such assistance from being used for administrative expenses."

(Sec. 3) Authorizes the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to require cable operators that provide interconnection, using cable system facilities, with the Internet to offer such interconnection on terms that are fair, reasonable, and nondiscriminatory. Requires such requirements to include the obligation to provide direct or indirect interconnection with the facilities and equipment of any Internet service provider on terms and conditions that are functionally and economically equivalent to the terms and conditions of such interconnection with the facilities and equipment of any Internet service provider affiliated with the cable operator. Authorizes the FCC, if it determines that such cable operator is not complying with such obligation, to establish the terms and conditions of such interconnection.(Sec. 4) States that until the FCC establishes open access or interconnection standards and obligations and that seeks to obtain channel capacity for federally-restricted video programming, a service that provides high-speed data service shall be treated as seeking channel capacity for a franchising authority and shall not be subject to regulation as a common carrier service.(Sec. 5) Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to declare that a telecommunications service provided by a cable system is subject to regulation as a common carrier service. Declares that nothing in this Act shall be construed to affect any civil action that is pending in State or Federal court on the

Bramwell National Historical Park Act of 1993 - Establishes the Bramwell National Historical Park, West Virginia, to be administered as a unit of the national park system. <n>Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to: (1) accept and retain donations of funds, property, or services to provide services and facilities consistent with this Act; (2) enter into cooperative agreements with the State of West Virginia, or any political subdivision thereof, for carrying out this Act; and (3) acquire land or interests in land within Park boundaries only by donation, exchange, or purchase from willing sellers with donated or appropriated funds. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to enter into cooperative agreements with the owners of properties of historical or cultural significance within the Park pursuant to which the Secretary may mark, interpret, restore, and provide technical assistance for the preservation and interpretation of such properties. <n>Specifies that nothing in this Act may be construed as authorizing the Secretary to have access to private residential property within the Park for the purpose of conducting visitors through such property, or for any other purpose, without the advice and consent of the owner. <n>Directs the Secretary to prepare a plan for the restoration, preservation, interpretation, and development of the historical, cultural, and architectural resources of the Park. Requires such plan to

Expresses the sense of Congress that the Department of Defense (DOD) should undertake appropriate actions to ensure that family members of members of the National Guard and reserves who are deployed have full access to mental health care during the periods of mobilization, deployment, and demobilization. Directs the Secretary of Defense to undertake a nationwide initiative to increase access to mental health care for family members of such members who are mobilized.

Children's Health Equity Act of 1998 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to allow use of State children's health insurance program (SCHIP) funds for enhanced matching rates for coverage of additional children under the Medicaid program.

Congressional Foreign Travel Reform Act of 2010 - Authorizes the House of Representatives and the Senate to obtain local currencies for use on official foreign travel by Members, officers, or employees of Congress. Limits the amount of such currency to the equivalent of $75 per day per person or the maximum per diem allowance established under federal law for federal employees while traveling in a foreign country, whichever is greater, exclusive of the actual cost of transportation.

Strengthening Local Transportation Security Capabilities Act of 2018 (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to prioritize the assignment of officers and intelligence analysts: (1) from the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to locations with participating state, local, and regional fusion centers in jurisdictions with a high-risk surface transportation asset; and (2) from the Office of Intelligence and Analysis to locations with such centers in order to enhance the security of such assets, including by improving timely sharing of classified information regarding terrorist and other threats. Officers and intelligence analysts assigned to locations with participating centers shall participate in the generation and dissemination of transportation security intelligence products. DHS shall: (1) make available to appropriate owners and operators of such assets, and any other person determined appropriate to foster greater sharing of classified information relating to such assets, the process of application for security clearances relating to a classified national security information program, or any successor executive order; and (2) develop, through the Federal Law Enforcement Training Centers, a training program to enhance the protection, preparedness, and response capabilities of law enforcement agencies with respect to terrorism and other serious incidents at a surface transportation asset.

Energy Conservation Through Trees Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to provide financial, technical, and related assistance to retail power providers to assist with the establishment of new, or continued operation of existing, targeted residential tree-planting programs. Directs the Secretary, in carrying out such authority, to create a national public recognition initiative to encourage such provider participation. Sets forth requirements that a tree-planting program must meet to qualify for assistance, including that the program provide free or discounted shade-providing or wind-reducing trees to residential consumers interested in lowering their home energy costs.

Home Safety Tax Credit Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for 50 percent of the abatement cost for each eligible dwelling unit. Allows the amount of the credit for any eligible dwelling unit to not exceed $1,500, over the aggregate cost for such unit for all preceding taxable years.

International Space Station Independent Safety Commission Act of 2004 - Directs the President to establish an independent, nonpartisan Commission within the executive branch to discover and assess any vulnerabilities of the International Space Station (ISS) that could lead to its destruction, compromise the health of its crew, or necessitate its premature abandonment. Requires the President to issue an executive order establishing such a Commission within 30 days after the enactment of this Act. Sets forth provisions regarding the membership and powers of the Commission.

Amends the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 to terminate on September 30, 2010. <n>(Sec. 2) Amends the Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act of 1999 to terminate on September 30, 2010, the authority of the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to collect base market Hogs and packer reporting information. <n>(Sec. 3) Revises reporting requirements for: (1) swine processing plants; and (2) packers and packer representatives. <n>(Sec. 4) Requires that certain information collected by the Secretary be made available to the public on the Internet and in printed form.

American Family Business Preservation Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to reduce the estate tax rate on qualified family-owned business interests from 15 percent to 20 percent. Allows a recapture of such tax benefit if such interests are not held for ten years after the decedent's death.

Amtrak Reauthorization Act of 2002 - Amends Federal transportation law to reauthorize Amtrak for FY 2003.Directs the Secretary of Transportation to make payments to Amtrak of amounts authorized under this Act for capital expenditures only if the Secretary has received, either in an annual work plan or a supplement thereto, a description of the work to be funded, a work timetable, cost estimates, and a list of other funding sources if the project is not entirely funded by the Federal Government. Requires the Secretary to determine, within 30 days after receiving such a description, whether each of the capital projects proposed is sufficiently justified.Directs the Secretary to make payments to Amtrak of amounts authorized under this Act for operating expenditures only if the Secretary has received, either in an annual work plan or a supplement thereto, a description of the work funded, a work timetable, cost estimates, and a list of other funding sources if the project is not entirely funded by the Federal Government.Requires the Secretary to make payments to Amtrak of amounts authorized under this Act as follows: (1) 50 percent on October 1; (2) 25 percent on January 1; and (3) 25 percent on April 1.Authorizes appropriations for FY 2003 for grants to finance the cost of enhancements to the security and safety of Amtrak intercity rail passenger service,

Joseph Moakley Memorial Fire Safe Cigarette Act of 2002 - Directs the Consumer Product Safety Commission to prescribe one or more fire safety standards for cigarettes to reduce the risk of ignition presented by cigarettes.Prescribes testing methodology. Requires the Commission to accept a testing methodology and acceptance criterion proposed by the manufacturer or manufacturers of the cigarette if it determines that the cigarette has an ignition propensity equivalent to or less than cigarettes that pass the acceptance criterion.Authorizes the Commission to regulate the ignition propensity of cigarette paper for roll-your-own tobacco products.Directs the Commission to prohibit the stockpiling of cigarettes to which a fire safety standard will apply.

NEPA Reciprocity Act - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to establish a program to eliminate duplicative environmental reviews and approvals under State and Federal law of projects for rail and highway projects. Defines Federal environmental laws" to include laws governing the review of environmental impacts of, and issuance of permits and other approvals for, the construction and operation of projects, including the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969, the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, the National Historic Preservation Act, and the Endangered Species Act of 1973."

Military Commissions Act of 2004 - Amends the Uniform Code of Military Justice to authorize the use of military commissions for offenses against the law of war or in furtherance of terrorism. Provides that a military commission: (1) may try any person, not a U.S. citizen, for one or more offenses against the law of war or in furtherance of terrorism; and (2) shall consist of not less than three members and not more than seven members, with exceptions.

Freedom from Unfair Energy Levy Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to suspend for six months (the period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act) motor fuel taxes. Repeals certain tax increases enacted in 1993.

Witness Security and Protection Grant Program Act of 2011 - Directs the Attorney General to make competitive matching grants to state, local, and tribal governments to establish or maintain witness protection programs in court proceedings involving homicide, or involving a serious violent felony or serious drug offense, and court proceedings involving gangs or organized crime. Sets forth criteria for making grants.

Establishes in the Treasury the Emergency Watershed Protection Disaster Assistance Fund to carry out activities under the emergency watershed protection program. Requires amounts in the Fund to be available to the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to provide additional amounts for authorized activities in areas affected by a natural disaster. Defines natural disaster" as a natural disaster declared by the Secretary under the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act, or a major disaster or emergency designated by the President under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act."

Oil Industry Merger Antitrust Enforcement Act - Amends the Clayton Act to place the burden of proof, in any civil action brought against a person for violating this Act, on the defendant or defendants to establish by a preponderance of the evidence that the merger, acquisition, or transaction at issue will not substantially lessen competition or tend to create a monopoly. <n>Directs the Federal Trade Commission and the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice to jointly review and revise all enforcement guidelines and policies, including the Merger Guidelines issued April 2, 1992, and revised April 8, 1997, and the Non-elastic Merger Guidelines issued June 14, 1984, and to ensure that their application will prevent any merger and acquisition in the oil industry when the effect of such a merger or acquisition may be to substantially lessen competition, or to tend to create a monopoly, and reflect specified special conditions prevailing in the oil industry.

Trade Enforcement and Trade Deficit Reduction Act This bill directs the United States Trade Representative (USTR), if the Department of Commerce determines that a foreign government has imposed or discovered a tariff or nontariff barrier or policy or practice with respect to U.S. exports of any product that has not been reduced or eliminated in accordance with the terms of a trade agreement entered into between the United States and the foreign country, to withdraw any modification of the duty on any product that has the same physical characteristics and uses as a product for which a modification of an existing duty is sought until Commerce certifies to Congress that the foreign government has reduced or eliminated the tariff or nontariff barrier or policy or practice. The bill defines "interested party" as: a manufacturer, producer, or wholesaler in the United States of a domestic product that has the same physical characteristics and uses as the product for which a modification of an existing duty is sought; a certified union or recognized union or group of workers engaged in the manufacture, production, or wholesale in the United States of a domestic product that has the same physical characteristics and uses as the product for which a modification of an existing duty is sought; a trade or business association a majority of whose members manufacture, produce, or wholesale in the United

Children's Act for Responsible Employment of 2001 or the CARE Act- Amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to repeal certain exemptions from child labor prohibitions for agricultural employment.Applies the same age restrictions to agricultural employment as to other forms of employment. Limits exemptions to agricultural labor outside of school hours, if the individual is employed by his or her parent, grandparent, uncle, first cousin, or legal guardian, on a farm owned or operated by such parent, grandparent, aunt, uncle, first cousin, or legal guardian. Raises from 16 to 18 years old the minimum age for engaging in hazardous agricultural employment.Increases civil and criminal penalties for child labor violations.Directs the Secretary of Labor and the Director of the Bureau of the Census to compile data biannually from State employment security agencies and from other sources in all the States concerning: (1) the types of industries and occupations in which children under 18 are employed; and (2) cases in which children were employed in violation of Federal or State law.Requires each employer who employs an individual in a State under the age of 18 to report to the State employment security agency in the State on any injury to such individual that results in lost employment time or any illness that contributes to lost employment time.Directs the Secretary to
