(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2015. Veterans Homebuyer Accessibility Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the tax credit for first-time homebuyers, to allow veterans of the Armed Forces a tax credit for 10% of the purchase price of a principal residence purchased prior to January 1, 2017. The credit is increased for residences with special fixtures or movable facilities made necessary by the nature of the veteran's disability, if such fixtures and facilities are provided pursuant to specially adapted housing assistance or similar facilities. If a veteran sells such residence within 36 months after purchasing it, the credit is increased by the lesser of $8,000 or the portion of the purchase price of the residence attributable such fixtures or movable facilities. The bill defines "first-time homebuyer" as an individual who: (1) has served on official extended duty service in the Armed Forces, or (2) is a member of the uniformed services, the Foreign Service, or the National Guard.

Amends the Clean Air Act to revise the definition of renewable biomass." Defines "renewable biomass" as: (1) materials, pre-commercial thinnings, or invasive species from National Forest System land and public lands that are byproducts of preventive treatments that are removed to reduce hazardous fuels, to reduce or contain disease or insect infestation, or to restore ecosystem health, that would not otherwise be used for higher-value products, and that are harvested in accordance with specified law and land management plans; and (2) any organic matter that is available on a renewable or recurring basis from non-federal land or land belonging to an Indian or Indian tribe that is held in trust by the United States or subject to a restriction against alienation imposed by the United States, including renewable plant material and waste material."

Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 and Federal armed forces provisions to require local educational agencies (LEAs) receiving assistance under such Act to provide, upon a request made by a military recruiter or institution of higher education, access to the name, address, and telephone listing of each secondary school student served by such LEA, unless the student's parent has submitted a prior written consent request to release the student's name, address, and telephone listing for such purposes. Permits a parent to submit a written request, to the LEA, that such student's name, address, and telephone listing not be released for such purposes without the parent's prior written consent. Requires the LEA to notify the parents of such students of the option to make such request. Declares that, whenever a student has attained 18 years of age, the permission or consent required of and the rights accorded to the student shall only be required of and accorded to the student.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 21, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Air Force Work Force Renewal Act - Amends Federal provisions concerning voluntary separation pay and retirement under the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System to entitle to retirement an employee of the Department of the Air Force who is separated from service voluntarily after completing 25 years of service or after becoming 50 years of age and completing 20 years of service, as long as such separation is determined to be necessary for maintaining continuity of skills among Air Force employees and adapting such skills to emerging technologies critical to the needs and goals of the Department.) Authorizes the Secretary of the Air Force, during a five-year period, to carry out a program of experimental use of the special personnel management authority provided in this Act to facilitate recruitment of civilian personnel to perform: (1) research and exploratory or advanced development; or (2) acquisition of major weapons systems, excluding sustainment activities.

NOAA Corps Disestablishment Act - Requires each conversion-eligible officer who has signed a conversion agreement and the position to which such officer is assigned as of the disestablishment date to be converted into the civilian service. Makes such officers eligible for health insurance. <n>Directs the Secretary of Commerce to provide a conversion benefit to each such officer. Requires any officer leaving NOAA within 180 days after conversion to the civilian service to refund to the Treasury a specified amount of the product of the member's years of active service and 12 times the monthly basic pay to which the member is entitled on such date. Requires such officers to be eligible immediately to make contributions to the Thrift Savings Fund. <n>Provides for crediting to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund an amount equal to the Federal Employee Retirement System supplemental liability created by this Act to those NOAA Corps officers converted into the civilian service. <n>Directs the Under Secretary of Commerce for Personnel and Management to establish additional civilian positions in NOAA as determined to be appropriate.

American Freedom Agenda Act of 2007 - Repeals the Military Commissions Act of 2006.<n><n>Authorizes the President to establish military commissions for the trial of war crimes only in places of active hostilities against the United States where an immediate trial is necessary to preserve fresh evidence or to prevent local harm.<n><n>Prohibits the President from detaining any individual indefinitely as an unlawful enemy combatant unless there is substantial evidence that such individual has directly engaged in active hostilities against the United States. Entitles any individual detained as an enemy combatant to petition for a writ of habeas corpus.<n><n>Prohibits civilian or military tribunals from admitting as evidence statements from the defendant by torture or coercion.<n><n>Prohibits federal agencies from gathering foreign intelligence in contravention of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act unless they are irreparable to the President's constitutional power to gather foreign intelligence.<n><n>Requires the House and Senate to enjoy standing to file a declaratory judgment action in federal district court challenging the constitutionality of a presidential signing statement that declares they are irreparable to the national security of the United States.<n><n>Prohibits the use of secret evidence to designate an individual or organization with a U.S. presence as a foreign terrorist or foreign terrorist organization for purposes of the criminal

Creating Opportunities for Military Members to Use Transportation Efficiently Act of 2014 or the COMUTE Act of 2014 - Directs the Secretary of Defense (DOD) to establish a Military Community Infrastructure Program to authorize the Secretary to provide grants to eligible entities (state or political subdivisions, owners or operators of public transportation, local governmental authorities, or regional transportation planning organizations) for transportation infrastructure improvement projects in military communities. Authorizes the use of grant funds for projects that: (1) improve access to a military installation; and (2) are in a location that is within or abutting an urbanized area and designated as a growth community by the Office of Economic Adjustment. Directs the Secretary to conduct a traffic impact study for any urbanized area that expects a significant increase in traffic related to a military installation within or abutting the urbanized area.

Amends the San Luis Rey Indian Water Rights Settlement Act to require the Secretary of the Interior, in order to provide supplemental water supply for the benefit of the Bands and certain local entities outside the service area of the Central Valley Project, California, to: (1) arrange for the development of not more than 16,000 acre-feet per year of supplemental water from public lands within the boundaries of that Project; (2) obtain not more than 16,000 acre-feet per year either from water conserved by the authorized works or through contract with the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California; or (3) construct that portion of such works necessary to conserve 16,000 acre-feet of water per year and arrange to deliver such water to the Bands and the local entities by exchange or through contract with such District and other parties with conveyance facilities. Declares that the right to continue 16,000 acre-feet of water per year shall be held in trust for the San Luis Rey Indian Water Authority and shall not be subject to the provisions of such Act and the settlement agreement governing the use and disposition of supplemental water. Authorizes appropriations to construct such portion of authorized works that is necessary to conserve 16,000 acre-feet of water per year, but prohibits the use of such funds to construct any new dams, reservoirs, or surface water storage facilities.

Enhanced Rescission/Receipts Act of 1993 - Grants the President legislative line item veto rescission authority. Authorizes the President to rescind all or part of any discretionary budget authority or veto any targeted tax benefit within any revenue bill if the President determines that such rescission: (1) would help reduce the Federal budget deficit; (2) will not impair any essential Government functions; and (3) will not harm the national interest. Requires the President to notify the Congress of such a rescission or veto by special message after enactment of appropriations legislation providing such budget authority or a revenue bill containing a targeted tax benefit. Makes such a rescission effective unless the Congress enacts a rescission disapproval bill. Describes: (1) information to be included in the President's message; and (2) procedures to govern consideration of rescission disapproval legislation in the Senate and the House of Representatives.

(Sec. 3) Increases from: (1) eight percent to six percent the percentage of a transaction secured by a first-lien security interest that must be refinanced within one year; and (2) nine percent to nine percent the percentage of a transaction secured by a subordinate-lien security interest that must be refinanced within three years. Sets penalties for prepayments that occur during the one-year period after the mortgage is consummated. Decreases from five percent to three percent the percentage of a transaction that must be refinanced within one year. Sets penalties for prepayments that occur during the one-year period after the mortgage is consummated.

Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 1999- Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit an incumbent local exchange carrier (LEC) from being subject to regulations regarding: (1) facilities and equipment used exclusively to provide advanced service; and (2) the provision of such service in any State in which 70 percent of the LEC's territory are DSL-capable. Declares that the prices, terms, and conditions of any advanced service by an LEC shall not be subject to regulation if the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) determines that advanced service is being offered by an unaffiliated advanced service provider in competition with the LEC within a geographic area served by a central office. Authorizes an LEC to file a petition with the FCC for such relief if the FCC does not act on it within 30 days after it is filed. Deems such a petition to have been approved if the FCC does not act on it within 30 days after it is filed. Declares that the rates, terms, and conditions of advanced service offered by an LEC or its affiliate are not subject to regulation in any geographic area in which such carrier, its successor, or assigns was not the LEC on February 8, 1996.

Madera Water Supply Enhancement Act - Prohibits further studies or reports to the Secretary of the Interior and the Bureau of Reclamation regarding the Madera Water Supply Enhancement Project, California, owned, operated, maintained, and managed by the Madera Irrigation District.Requires all planning, design, and engineering related to the Project to be undertaken in accordance with a cooperative agreement between the Secretary and the District.Limits the Federal share of the capital costs of the Project to 25 percent.Requires the District, before obligating funds for design or construction of the Project, to work cooperatively with the Bureau to complete the Project.

Homeowners' Emergency Mortgage Assistance Act- Directs the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to establish a mortgage emergency assistance program for qualifying homeowners with one- to four-unit residences who are temporarily unable to meet their obligations due to financial hardship beyond their control. Requires homeowner repayment of such assistance and interest.

National Center for Social Work Research Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to establish the National Center for Social Work Research as an agency of the National Institutes of Health. Authorizes the Center to conduct, support, and disseminate information with respect to basic, clinical, and services social work research, training, and other programs in patient care, including child and family care. <n>Authorizes the Director of the Center to: (1) provide research training and instruction and establish research traineeships and fellowships in the study and investigation of the prevention of disease, health promotion, and the social work care of persons with and families of individuals with acute and chronic illnesses, including child abuse and neglect and child and family care; and (2) provide stipends and allowances for such individuals. <n>Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish an advisory council for the Center that shall advise, assist, consult with, and make recommendations to the Secretary and the Director of the Center on matters related to the activities carried out by and through the Center and the policies with respect to such activities. Authorizes the advisory council to recommend to the Secretary the acceptance of conditional gifts for study, investigations, and research and for the acquisition of grounds or construction, equipment, or maintenance of facilities for the Center

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 19, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.) National Capital Area Physician Emergency Assistance Act - Provides that if the President declares that a public health emergency is in effect in the National Capital Area, then any physician who holds a valid medical license issued by an Area State government may provide health services to victims of the emergency to the same extent as the physician is authorized to provide health services within the jurisdiction of the Area State government that issued the license, notwithstanding the law of the other Area State governments, and is not liable for any harm caused by any act or omission in providing such services, notwithstanding the law of any of the Area State governments, unless the harm is caused by willful or criminal misconduct, gross negligence, reckless misconduct, or a conscious, flagrant indifference to the rights or safety of others. Applies such provision to any period during which a public health emergency is in effect in an Area portion of Maryland, Virginia, or the District of Columbia pursuant to a declaration by the Governor of Maryland, the Governor of Virginia, or the Mayor of the District. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish and maintain a system for verifying the credentials, licenses, and hospital privileges

Judgment Evading Foreign States Accountability Act of 2008 - (Sec. 3) States that the purpose of this Act is to protect U.S. economic interests and its citizens from the irresponsible conduct of certain states, and agencies and instrumentalities of such states, that willfully refuse to satisfy United States court judgments. (Sec. 4) Defines judgment evading foreign state" as any state that: (1) has one or more judgments entered against it by any U.S. district court or the court of any state, the combined amount of which exceeds $1 billion; and (2) fails to satisfy in full any such judgment for more than six months after it becomes a final judgment. (Sec. 5) Declares it shall be U.S. policy to prevent judgment evading foreign states and their corporations from raising capital in the United States until those states demonstrate that such measures are no longer necessary by satisfying all outstanding judgments of the U.S. courts. (Sec. 6) Authorizes the President to waive the requirements of this Act if it is in the national security interest of the United States."

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 19, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Protecting Domestic Violence and Stalking Victims Act - Amends the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act to expand the definition of victim" for purposes of provisions prohibiting the sale or other disposition of a firearm or ammunition to an individual who has been convicted in any court of a misdemeanor crime of stalking or a crime that involves conduct which would be prohibited under federal, state, territorial, or tribal law if committed within the special maritime and territorial jurisdiction of the United States. (Currently, such provisions prohibit the sale or other disposition of a firearm or ammunition to an individual who has been convicted in any court of a misdemeanor crime of stalking or a crime that involves conduct which would be prohibited under federal, state, territorial, or tribal law if committed within such jurisdiction.) Subjects to a court order restrains such person from: (1) harassing, stalking, threatening, or engaging in other conduct that would put an individual in reasonable fear of bodily injury to such individual, including an order issued at the request of an employer on behalf of its employee or at the request of an institution of higher education on behalf of its student; or (2) intimidating or dissuading a"

Gas Price Relief Act of 2005 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose upon integrated oil companies an excise tax of 50 percent of their net windfall profit from the sale of all barrels of taxable crude oil for each taxable year. Defines windfall profit" as the excess of the removal price (sales price) of a barrel of taxable crude oil over the base price of such barrel ($40 per barrel). Terminates such tax three years after the enactment of this Act."

Data Broker Accountability and Transparency Act - Prohibits a data broker from obtaining, causing the disclosure of, or requesting another person to obtain personal information or other information relating to any person by making a false statement or representation. Requires a data broker to establish procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of personal information it collects, assembles, or maintains, and any other information it collects, assembles, or maintains that specifically identifies an individual, unless the information only identifies an individual\\'s name or address. Allows a data broker to collect information that may be inaccurate for the purpose of: (1) indicating whether there may be a discrepancy or irregularity in the personal information associated with an individual; (2) helping to identify, or to authenticate the identity of, an individual; or (3) helping to protect against or investigate fraud or other unlawful conduct. Requires a data broker to provide an individual with a means to review any personal information or other information that specifically identifies that individual, unless an exception applies. Defines data broker" as a commercial entity that collects, assembles, or maintains personal information concerning an individual who is not a customer or an employee of that entity in order to sell the information or provide third party access to the information."

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 2, 2014. Investing in Student Success Act of 2014 - (Sec. 101) Authorizes individuals to enter into income share agreements for the purposes of obtaining funds in exchange for agreeing to pay to the holder of the contract a specified percentage of the individual's future income. (An income share agreement is an agreement between an individual and any other person under which the individual commits to pay a specified percentage of the individual's future income, for a specified period of time, in exchange for payments to or on behalf of such individual for postsecondary education, workforce development, or other purposes.) Requires an income share agreement to specify: the percentage of future income which the individual will be obligated to pay, except that the contract shall exempt, at a minimum, the first $10,000 (adjusted each year to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor for the most recent 12-month period for which such data are available) of such individual's income when determining such individual's obligation for a given year. Requires an income share agreement to specify: the definition of income to be used for purposes of calculating such individual's obligation;

Gang Prevention and Youth Recreation Act of 1993 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make grants to assist up to ten selected cities in establishing and operating teen resource and education centers in such cities to provide education, employment, recreation, social, and cultural awareness assistance to at-risk youth. Limits the duration of such grants to three years.

Declares that it shall not be necessary that the person trading while in possession of such information, or making such communication, know the specific means by which the information was obtained or communicated, or whether any personal benefit was paid or promised by or to any person in the chain of communication so long as the person trading while in possession of such information or making the communication was aware, or recklessly disregarded that such information was wrongfully obtained or communicated. Exempts from such prohibitions any person who: (1) acts at the direction of, and solely for the account of, a person whose own securities trading, or communications of material, nonpublic information, would be lawful under this Act; and (2) controls or employs a person who has violated this Act, if such controlling person or employer did not participate in, profit from, or directly or indirectly induce the acts constituting the violation.

Desalination Energy Consumption Reduction Act of 2006 - Requires the Secretary of Energy to make incentive payments to the owners or operators of qualified desalination facilities (facilities first used to produce commercial desalinated water after enactment of this Act), including facilities owned or operated by Indian tribes, for up to ten years to encourage the utilization of the best available technology to reduce the consumption of electrical energy in the desalination process. Specifies a formula for determining the amount of payments.

Water Desalination Act of 1996 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to award grants and enter into contracts to conduct, encourage, and assist in the financing of research to develop processes for converting saline water into water suitable for beneficial uses. <n>Directs the Secretary to recommend desalination demonstration projects to the Congress and to conduct a demonstration and development program for water desalination and related activities. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Customs Training Enhancement Act - Directs the Commissioner of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to establish and carry out educational seminars at U.S. ports of entry to improve the ability of CBP personnel to: (1) classify and appraise articles imported into the United States in accordance with U.S. customs laws, including to improve their ability to identify and prevent the mislabeling and transshipment of articles; and (2) identify and prevent the mislabeling and transshipment of articles. Requires the Commissioner to establish and carry out at least 15 seminars each year.

Emergency Steel Loan Guarantee Program - Establishes the Emergency Steel Guaranteed Loan Program to guarantee loans provided by private banking and investment institutions to qualified steel companies. Sets forth loan guarantee limits.

United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 - Amends Federal shipping law to revise certain requirements for the coastwise transportation of passengers on vessels with a coastwise endorsement. <n>Makes exceptions with respect to: (1) cruise vessels operating under a demise charter that has a term of at least 18 months and is to a person described in this Act; (2) vessels that are not documented on the date of enactment of this Act and that are not less than five years old and not more than 15 years old on the first date that the vessel is documented; and (3) vessels that the owner or charterer of has entered into a contract for the construction in the United States of another cruise vessel that has a total berth or stateroom capacity at least 80 percent of the capacity of the cruise vessel. <n>Prohibits a person from operating any vessel between: (1) any two ports served by another cruise vessel that transports passengers in coastwise trade after the date on which a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement is first issued for the vessel after enactment of this Act if, before the end of that 18-month period, the demise of another vessel has not been laid, or another vessel is not at a similar stage of construction, under a contract required for the vessel; or (2) any of the

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 9, 2014. Reinvesting In Vital Economic Rivers and Waterways Act of 2013 or the RIVER Act - (Sec. 5) Directs the Secretary of the Army, acting through the Chief of Engineers, to promulgate regulations that require for each qualifying construction and major rehabilitation project for navigation infrastructure of inland and intracoastal waterways that is: (1) risk-based and has a confidence level of at least 80%; (2) an independent external peer review and submission to Congress for any qualifying project that has an estimated total project cost greater than $45 million, is subject to public safety concerns, involves a high level of complexity or novel or precedent-setting approaches, or is identified by the Secretary as a matter of significant interagency interest; (3) the appointment to a project development team for the qualifying project of a member of the Inland Waterways Users Board; (4) a quarterly update submitted to the Board on the status of a qualifying project that is under construction; (5) the inclusion of the Chairman of the Board and the project development team as signatories of the project management plan for a qualifying project; (6) the establishment of a system to identify and apply on a continuing basis lessons learned from prior or ongoing projects so as to improve the likelihood

. Death Gratuity Equity Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill requires a federal agency to pay a death gratuity to a civilian employee who dies on or after enactment of this bill if the death resulted from an injury sustained in the line of duty and did not result from: (1) natural causes; or (2) serious and willful misconduct by the civilian employee. The bill sets the amount of such a gratuity at $100,000 per civilian employee and adjusted annually by the amount determined by the Department of Labor to represent the percentage difference between the Consumer Price Index and that price index published for December of the preceding year (adjusted to the nearest 10% of 1%). The amount of such a gratuity shall be paid upon the establishment of a valid claim for it. The payment shall be made to the surviving spouse, child, or descendants of the civilian employee.

Iran Human Rights Sanctions Act - Directs the President to: (1) impose visa entry and financial sanctions on a person determined to be complicit in human rights abuses committed against Iranian citizens or their family members on or after June 12, 2009, regardless of whether such abuses occurred in Iran; and (2) submit to Congress a list of persons who are complicit in such human rights abuses.

National Park Centennial Fund Act - (Sec. 3) Establishes in the Treasury the National Park Centennial Fund.<n><n>(Sec. 4) Directs the President, each fiscal year, to include a list of National Park Centennial Proposals.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of the Interior to establish a standard process for developing the list that shall encourage input from both the public and a broad cross-section of employees at every level of the National Park Service (NPS).<n><n>(Sec. 5) Requires proposals for the Education in Parks Centennial Initiative" to meet specified requirements, including that: (1) priority be given to proposals designed to increase National Park-based educational opportunities for elementary, secondary, and college students particularly those from populations historically under represented among visitors to the NPS; (2) priority be given to proposals designed to bring students into the NPS in person; (3) proposals be developed in consultation with the leadership of educational and youth organizations expected to participate in the initiative; and (4) proposals be designed to provide specific opportunities for NPS employees to participate in professional career development. Authorizes proposals for the "Supporting Park Professionals Centennial Initiative" to include NPS-designed, internal professional development programs.<n><n>Requires proposals for the "Environmental Leadership Centennial Initiative" to meet specified requirements, including that: (1) each proposal be"

Home Energy Loss Prevention Act - Prohibits a seller of single-family or multifamily housing that will be purchased with the assistance of a federally related housing loan from selling such housing unless: (1) at least five years before sale, an energy audit is conducted; (2) the seller provides a copy of the audit results to the purchaser; and (3) the results are submitted to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). Defines "energy audit" as: (1) an audit conducted by a home energy auditor or equivalent; (2) the results of the audit are recorded using energy audit and disclosure forms prescribed by the Secretary for single-family or multifamily housing; and (3) the results include a standardized ratings score that allows the housing's energy efficiency to be compared to similar housing, and a prioritized list of potential energy efficiency improvements. Exempts from such requirements new energy efficient housing constructed not more than five years before sale. Directs the Secretary to: (1) coordinate with local deeds offices responsible for maintaining records of residential real property interests and transactions to maintain copies of the results of energy audits on-file in conjunction with the deeds to such housing; and (2) establish and maintain a database containing copies of the results of such audits on an Internet website. Sets forth civil penalties for violations

Seeds for the Future Act This bill amends the Competitive, Special, and Facilities Research Grant Act to require the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to award at least $50 million per fiscal year in competitive research grants to support the development of public cultivar. The bill also requires USDA to appoint a public research activities coordinator within the Research, Education, and Extension Office to coordinate public breeding research activities within USDA.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on December 21, 2016. (Sec. 1) This bill states that the President shall instruct the United States Executive Director at each international financial institution to use U.S. influence to oppose any loan for the government of Honduras's benefit, other than for basic human needs or to promote democracy, unless the Department of State certifies that Honduras is taking effective steps to: (1) promote democracy and an independent judicial system and electoral council; (2) strengthen the rule of law; (3) promote democracy and an independent judicial system and electoral council; (4) strengthen the rule of law; and (5) respect the right to freedom of association and expression. The Department of the Treasury shall submit a report assessing: (1) the effectiveness of the international financial institutions in enforcing applicable program safeguards in Honduras, and (2) the effects of specified constitutional and election concerns in Honduras on long-term prospects for positive development outcomes there.

Higher Education Investment Act of 1995 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for interest paid or incurred on any qualified education loan during the first 60 months (whether or not consecutive) for which interest payments are required to be made. Limits such credit to $500 ($1,000 in the case of two or more individuals with qualified higher education expenses paid by any qualified education loan). Provides for a limitation based on modified adjusted gross income.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 5, 2016. Patient Access to Durable Medical Equipment Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) to extend from June 30, 2016, through June 30, 2017, the transition to new payment rates for durable medical equipment (DME) under the Medicare program. (DME includes certain medically necessary equipment such as walkers, wheelchairs, and hospital beds.) The bill also amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require the CMS to establish a floor on the bid ceiling for competitive acquisitions for DME furnished on or after January 1, 2019. (Sec. 4) The bill requires the CMS, in adjusting payment rates for DME furnished on or after January 1, 2019, to take into account stakeholder input and compare certain information from competitive acquisition programs. (Sec. 5) The CMS must publish on its website: (1) results of the monitoring of Medicare beneficiaries' access to durable medical equipment and of health outcomes, and (2) specified information regarding the effective date of provisions establishing a prospective payment system (PPS) for DME furnished on or after January 1, 2017.

Opioids and STOP Pain Initiative Act This bill establishes the Opioids and STOP Pain Initiative, which shall include efforts to support research on: the understanding of pain, the development of therapies for chronic pain, and the development of alternatives to opioids for effective pain treatments; developing improved options and evidence for medication-assisted treatment; the Federal Pain Research Strategy; and the pain therapy screening program established by this bill. The Department of Health and Human Services may designate elements of the initiative.

Establishes the U.S. Office for Native Hawaiian Relations (Office) within the Office of the Secretary of the Interior.Recognizes the right of the Native Hawaiian people to adopt organic governing documents. Provides that following the organization and election of a Native Hawaiian government and the adoption of such documents, the duly elected Native Hawaiian government shall submit those documents to the Secretary and to the State of Hawaii for purposes of advising the State that such government has been reorganized. Extends Federal recognition to the Native Hawaiian government as the representative governing body of the Native Hawaiian people upon election of officers and certification by the Secretary.Permits the United States, upon Federal recognition of the Native Hawaiian government, to enter into an agreement with Hawaii and such government regarding the transfer of lands, resources, and assets dedicated to Native Hawaiian use.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 25, 2017. Organic Farmer and Consumer Protection Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Organic Foods Production Act of 1990 to authorize appropriations for the national organic program through FY2023. (Sec. 3) The bill directs the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to modernize: (1) international trade tracking and data collection systems of the national organic program, and (2) trade and transaction certificates to ensure full traceability without unduly hindering trade. Of the funds of the Commodity Credit Corporation, USDA shall make available: (1) $5 million for FY2019 to carry out this bill, and (2) previously carried out database and technology upgrades. The bill permits all parties to an active investigation (including certifying agents, state organic certification programs, and the national organic program) to share confidential business information with federal and state government officers and employees and certifying agents involved in the investigation as necessary to fully investigate and enforce potential violations of the Act. USDA shall have access to available data from cross-border documentation systems administered by other federal agencies. USDA shall: (1) have oversight and approval authority over any certifying agent operating in a foreign country, and (2) require an annual authorization for each certifying agent that intends to operate in any foreign country. (Sec. 5) The

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 9, 2014. Survivor Benefits Improvement Act of 2013 - (Sec. 2) Amends federal veterans' benefits provisions to extend from two to five years the period during which a veteran's disability compensation shall be payable to his or her surviving spouse due to a service-connected disability. (Sec. 3) Makes a remarriage after age 55 after such age bars a veteran's remarriage from barring the furnishing of such benefits to the surviving spouse. (Sec. 4) Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to provide to a child of a veteran of active duty in Thailand who is suffering from spina bifida the health care, vocational training and rehabilitation, and monetary allowance required to be paid to a child of a Vietnam veteran who is suffering from spina bifida as if such child were a child of a Vietnam veteran who is suffering from spina bifida. (Sec. 5) Directs the Secretary to carry out a pilot program through the Readjustment Counseling Service of the Veterans Health Administration to assess the feasibility and advisability of providing grief counseling services to surviving spouses of veterans who die while serving on active duty in the Armed Forces. Requires participation at election of a surviving spouse.

Veterans Tobacco Trust Fund Act of 1998 - Establishes in the Treasury the Veterans Tobacco Trust Fund which shall be available, without fiscal year limitation, to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for: (1) furnishing medical care and services for the prevention and treatment of, and rehabilitation from, tobacco addiction and diseases associated with tobacco use; and (2) conducting such research, with particular emphasis on research relating to prevention and treatment of, and rehabilitation from, tobacco addiction and diseases associated with tobacco use.

Medicaid Directory of Caregivers Act or the Medicaid DOC Act Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to require a state plan that provides medical assistance on a fee-for-service basis or through a primary care case-management system to provide that the state agency administering the plan publishes on its public website, at least annually, a directory of certain providers that includes their names, specialties, addresses, and telephone numbers.

United States Specialty Crop Export Opportunities Act of 2007 - Amends the Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000 to authorize the Secretary of Agriculture to regulate plants, plant products, biological control organisms, and noxious weeds for export purposes.<n><n>Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to repeal the transfer of agricultural import and entry inspection functions from the Department of Agriculture to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).<n><n>Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to establish within the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) the International Agricultural Inspection Program to carry out import and entry agricultural inspections. Requires the Administrator of APHIS to establish: (1) an import and entry agriculture inspector career track program; and (2) an advisory committee to assist in developing such program.

Quality of Life for Women Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to carry out a program to provide education to health professionals and the public on bladder and bowel dysfunction and other pelvic floor disorders.Requires the Secretary to ensure that such education: (1) includes information describing the prevalence of such disorders in women and information regarding treatment options; and (2) is provided through the posting of information on the CDC website.Directs the Director of the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases to provide for continuing consultation with each treating center and a single biostatistical treatment network under the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary has been expanded because action occurred on the measure.) Summer Fishery Management Plan Modification - Amends the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act to direct the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council to submit to the Secretary of Commerce a modified summer fishery management plan that does not reflect the best available modern fishery management techniques. Authorizes the Secretary to approve such plan if the Council fails to submit the plan.

Employee Benefit Plan Security and Protection Act of 1994- Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and the Internal Revenue Code with regard to fiduciary duties under employee benefit plans.

Child Opportunity Zone Family Center Act of 2001 - Amends title X (Programs of National Significance) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA) to authorize the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to eligible partnerships for the Federal share of cost of establishing and expanding child opportunity zone family centers.Includes among required activities: (1) providing or linking children and their families with information, support, activities, or services in core areas such as education, child care, before- and after-school care and enrichment programs, health services, mental health services, family support, nutrition, literacy services, parenting skills, and drop-out prevention; (2) providing intensive, high-quality, research-based programs that provide violence prevention education for families and developmentally appropriate instructional services to children; and (3) providing training, information, and support to families to enable them to participate effectively in their children's education and to help their children meet challenging standards.

Public Health Pesticides Protection Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) to require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to consider the risks and benefits of public health pesticides separate from the risks and benefits of other pesticides. <n>Defines: (1) public health pesticide" as any minor use pesticide product registered for use and used predominantly in public health programs for vector control or for other recognized health protection uses that pose a threat to public health; and (2) "vector" as any animal capable of transmitting the causative agent of human disease or capable of producing human discomfort or injury, including mosquitoes, flies, cockroaches, or other insects and ticks. <n>Revises provisions concerning: (1) the public health and agricultural need for such minor use; and (2) registration fees. Declares that any pesticide defined as a public health pesticide more than 50 percent of its usage is devoted to the promotion of public health and that an end use product that is registered for a public health pesticide of which at least 50 percent of its usage is devoted to the promotion of public health shall be exempt from fees. <n>Requires that a registrant of a public health pesticide send to the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) a report"

Border Crossing Deterrence Act of 2008- Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security, in Cooperation with the Attorney General, to expand Operation Streamline (the zero-tolerance prosecution policy for illegal entry and reentry) to all 20 border sectors.<n><n>Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to revise criminal penalties for illegal entry into the United States by aliens who have been denied admission, excluded, deported, or removed, or who have departed the United States while under an outstanding order of exclusion, deportation, or removal, and who subsequently cross the border into the United States or are at any time found in the United States. Provides enhanced penalties for reentry of criminal offenders and aliens convicted of murder, rape, kidnapping, for a felony offense relating to peonage and slavery, or terrorism.<n><n>Makes it an affirmative defense to a violation of this Act that: (1) the alien had sought and received, before the alleged violation, affirmative defenses relating to prior convictions; and (2) proven beyond a reasonable doubt at trial or admitted by the defendant that the violation was committed with intent to unlawfully enter the United States.

Medicare Patient Safeguards Act of 2009 - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) efforts to make the Medicare program financially sustainable, including the application of comparative effectiveness research, should not deprive patients of medically necessary care solely due to the cost of such care or limit access to needed health care services due to a patient's age, gender, ethnicity, or disability status; and (2) Congress should protect patients' access to needed care by ensuring that the Administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services relies on adequate clinical expertise when proposing to narrow coverage for a product or service under the Medicare program under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. Sets forth conditions under which the Administrator may not issue a final national coverage determination (NCD) restricting local or national coverage for an item or service that: (1) was routinely covered under the Medicare program before its issuance; (2) would result in significant cost savings for the Medicare program; (3) is supported by current clinical practice guidelines or is endorsed by the National Quality Forum or by another national organization that evaluates consensus-based evidence; and (4) limits access to needed health care services due to a patient's age, gender, ethnicity, or disability status.

Ending Maternal Mortality Act of 2018 This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to develop and submit a national plan to reduce the rate of maternal mortality, with the goals of: (1) cutting the rate in half over the next 10 years, and (2) eliminating preventable maternal deaths by the date that is 20 years after this bill's enactment. In each biennial plan, HHS must address: (1) increasing public understanding of maternal mortality and severe maternal morbidity; (2) improving understanding of the root causes of maternal mortality and severe maternal morbidity; (3) improving data collection; (4) identifying at-risk populations and eliminating disparities that persist based on a mother's race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, and geographic location; (5) supporting and expanding maternal mortality review committees that bring together public and private relevant stakeholders to review cases of pregnancy-related and pregnancy-associated complications and deaths; (6) assessing hospital culture of safety in maternity care and how best to provide resources to improve outcomes; (7) improving health and treatment services for expectant mothers struggling with substance use and mental health disorders; and (8) studying and supporting local and targeted responses to maternal death.

Backcountry Landing Strip Access Act - Prohibits the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture from taking any action that would permanently close, restrict, or render or declare as unserviceable any aircraft landing strip located on land under their respective jurisdiction, unless: (1) the action has been approved by the head of the aviation department of the State in which the aircraft landing strip is located; (2) the Secretary publishes notice of the proposed action in the Federal Register, including notice that the action would permanently close, restrict, or render or declare as unserviceable; (3) the Secretary provides a 90-day public comment period beginning on the date on which the notice is published; and (4) the Secretaries and the head of the aviation department of the State in which the affected aircraft landing strip is located have taken into consideration any comments received during the comment period.Directs the Secretaries to jointly: (1) establish a national policy for governing backcountry aviation issues relating to the management of Federal land under their jurisdiction; and (2) require officials with such jurisdiction to adhere to it. Declares that any policy affecting air access to an aircraft landing strip, including such policy, shall not take effect unless certain conditions are met, including its acknowledgment that the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has the sole authority

This bill requires the Department of Energy (DOE) to carry out a program to enhance the nation's economic, environmental, and energy security by making awards to consortia for establishing and operating Energy Innovation Hubs to conduct and support multidisciplinary, collaborative research, development, demonstration, and commercial application of advanced energy technologies. Each Hub shall: (1) designate for each Hub a unique advanced energy technology focus; (2) ensure the coordination of, and avoid unnecessary duplication of, the activities of Hubs with those of other DOE research entities; and (3) encourage collaboration and communication among the consortium and awardees by conducting activities whenever practicable at one centralized location. A Hub shall: (1) conduct or provide for multidisciplinary, collaborative research, development, demonstration, and, where appropriate, commercial application of advanced energy technologies within its technology development focus; and (2) maintain conflict of interest procedures to ensure that employees and consortia designees for Hub activities who are in decisionmaking capacities disclose all material conflicts of interest and avoid such conflicts.

National Center for Pain Research Act of 1996 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish within the National Institutes of Health the National Center for Pain Research. Authorizes appropriations.

Economic Recovery Adjustment Act of 2009 - Establishes within the Department of Justice an Office of the Taxpayer Advocate, which shall: (1) conduct ongoing audits and oversight of the recipients of Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) funds with respect to the compensation of the officers and directors; and (2) have access, upon request, to any information, data, schedules, books, accounts, financial records, reports, files, electronic communications, or other papers, things, or property belonging to or in use by the assisted entity and to the officers, directors, employees, independent public accountants, financial advisors, and other agents and representatives thereof.

Native American Challenge Demonstration Project Act of 2007- Directs the Secretary of Commerce to establish and implement a Native American Challenge Demonstration Project in the Department of Commerce, under which the Secretary may provide economic development assistance to eligible entities that enter into Native American Challenge Compacts.

Civic Justice Corps Act of 2011- Directs the Secretary of Labor to award a grant to a national intermediary or one or more local subgrantees to implement a Civic Justice Corps program that provides educational, career, and work experience opportunities to court-involved, previously incarcerated, and otherwise disadvantaged youth and young adults between the ages of 16 and 25 through service and conservation corps and other community-based service organizations.

Educational Flexibility Act - Amends the General Education Provisions Act to direct the Secretary of Education to assist elementary and secondary schools and other service providers to improve the achievement of all students and other participants, but particularly disadvantaged individuals, by authorizing waivers for States to conduct projects to improve the performance of schools and programs by increasing their flexibility in the use of their resources while holding them accountable for achieving educational gains. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to waive any statutory or regulatory requirement applicable to a program under specified Federal laws relating to elementary, secondary, and youth vocational training that may impede the ability of a school or other service provider to meet the special needs of such students and other individuals in the most effective manner possible. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to only waive a statutory or regulatory requirement applicable to a program under: (1) title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965; (2) the Dwight D. Eisenhower Mathematics and Science Education Act; (3) the Follow Through Act; (4) the Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Applied Technology Education Act; (5) the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 1988; (6) the Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act of 1986; and (7) the Alcohol and Drug Abuse Education Act. <n>Limits projects assisted under this Act to three years, with

Green Communities Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Commerce, acting through the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Development, to award grants to eligible municipalities to carry out community greening initiatives (a program that increases economic development by improving the environment). Defines community greening initiative" as a program that increases economic development by improving the environment, including by: (1) revitalizing municipal parks and public spaces; (2) landscaping community gateways and key corridors; (3) tree plantings and urban forestry projects; (4) comprehensive planning for open space preservation; (5) education, training, and volunteer management concerning community green initiatives; (6) green roof construction; (7) green stormwater infrastructure; and (8) vacant lot management."

Medicare and Medicaid Hospital Self- Referral Amendments of 1996 - Amends titles XVIII (Medicare) and XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to require hospitals participating in the Medicare or Medicaid programs to: (1) give notice of availability of providers as part of the discharge planning process; and (2) maintain and disclose information on certain providers and the types of services provided.

Defined Benefit Pension Plan Reform Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to provide that for multiemployer pension plans, the alternative to the current amortizing net experience loss method shall be to use an emergency investment loss method. Defines emergency investment loss as the amount by which the fair market value of the plan's assets as of the last day of a plan year is less than the fair market value which would have been determined if the plan's earnings for the plan year had been equal to the projected investment return based on the actuarial interest rate.

Acquiring Community Care Expect Safe Services Act of 2017 or the Veterans ACCESS Act (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to deny or revoke the eligibility of a health care provider to provide non-VA health care services to veterans if the provider: was removed from employment with the VA due to conduct that violated a VA policy relating to the delivery of safe and appropriate health care; violated the requirements of a medical license; had a VA credential revoked and the grounds for such revocation impacts the ability the provider to deliver safe and appropriate health care; or violated a law for which a term of imprisonment of more than one year may be imposed. The VA may deny, revoke, or suspend such eligibility if necessary to immediately protect the health, safety, or welfare of veterans and if such action is necessary to harmonizing the eligibility criteria between VA and health care providers eligible to provide non-VA health care services.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on September 6, 2017. Scenic Columbia Gorge Restoration Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Forest Service to: (1) begin proposing response activities for lands within the National Scenic Area adversely impacted by a catastrophic event within 30 days after the conclusion of such an event; (2) allow 30 days for public scoping and comment regarding a response activity, 15 days for filing an objection, and 15 days for the agency response to the filing of an objection; and (3) complete an environmental assessment for a response activity within 60 days after the conclusion of such an event. A categorical exclusion is available for any response activity that: (1) does not exceed 10,000 acres within the Area, and (2) includes lands that are visible from key viewing areas, are part of a municipal watershed, or contain utility or power transmission right-of-ways. No consultation shall be required under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 with respect to a response activity that is not likely to adversely affect a listed species or designated critical habitat. No restraining order, preliminary injunction, or injunction pending appeal shall be issued with respect to any decision to prepare or conduct a response activity.

Treatment of Indian Tribal Natural Resource Income Act of 2001 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt income and self-employment taxes and employment taxes from taxation on income derived from a natural resources-related activity conducted by a member of an Indian tribe or a qualified Indian entity. Defines natural resources-related activity" as any activity directly related to cultivating, harvesting, processing, extracting, or transporting natural resources held in trust by the United States for the benefit of an Indian tribe if substantially all of the selling activity is performed by tribe members. Excludes activities directly related to extracting minerals, ores, oil, or gas."

Green Affordable Housing Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to carry out a program to make grants and loans to owners of eligible federally assisted housing projects for making eligible green retrofit improvements to such projects. Defines eligible green retrofit improvements" as improvements to an eligible federally assisted housing project that are approved by the Secretary as having one or more of the following attributes, as compared with the comparable component that would normally be used by owners of similar properties in the same market area: (1) materially lower electric, heating fuel, or water consumption; (2) materially lower emissions of chemicals thought to be harmful to humans; (3) materially longer useful life; (4) materially more easily recycled; (5) materially lower use of raw materials or use of materially more recycled content; and (6) materially lower transportation costs of products delivered to the project."

Cape Fox Land Entitlement Adjustment Act - Provides that Cape Fox Corporation shall not be required under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to select or receive conveyance of 160 acres of Federal unconveyed land. Permits Cape Fox to select 99 acres of the surface estate of Tongass National Forest land outside Cape Fox's current exterior selection boundary. Directs the Secretary of the Interior, upon conveyance to Cape Fox of the surface estate, to convey to Sealaska the subsurface estate to that land.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish a Selection Commission to recommend individuals to the President for appointment to the vacant office of Commissioner of Internal Revenue. Requires the Commission to make its recommendations for the Commissioner within 60 days after its establishment. Declares that the Commission shall: (1) be elected by the members; and (2) be paid at a rate equal to the daily equivalent of the minimum annual rate of basic pay payable for level IV of the Executive Schedule.

Expand and Rebuild America's Schools Act of 1997- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a limited credit to taxpayers holding school construction bonds. Defines such bonds. Sets a national school construction bond limit.

Veterans Benefits and Economic Welfare Improvement Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) and the Assistant Secretary of Labor for Veterans' Employment and Training to jointly carry out a program of training to provide certain veterans with skills relevant to the job market. Allows such program payments to employers who provide a program of apprenticeship or on-the-job training.

Shareholder Protection Act of 2010 - Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to require any solicitation of a proxy or consent or authorization with respect to any security of an issuer to: (1) describe the specific nature and total amount of political expenditures proposed to be made by the issuer for the forthcoming fiscal year not previously approved, including the total amount of such proposed expenditures; and (2) provide for a separate shareholder vote to authorize such proposed expenditures in such amount. Prohibits an issuer from making any political expenditure for such activities in any fiscal year unless: (1) such expenditure is of the nature of those proposed; and (2) authorization for such expenditures has been granted by votes representing a majority of outstanding shares. Declares a violation of this requirement a breach of a fiduciary duty of the officers and directors who authorized such expenditure without first obtaining such authorization of shareholders. Makes the officers and directors who authorize such an expenditure jointly and severally liable in any action brought in any court of competent jurisdiction to any individual or class of individuals who held shares at the time such expenditure was made for an amount equal to three times the amount of such expenditure.

Government Audit Reform Act of 2010 - Expresses the sense of Congress that the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) should follow the Government Accountability Office (GAO) report Single Audit: Opportunities Exist to Improve the Single Audit Process and Oversight." Amends the Single Audit Act to direct the Director to: (1) monitor the risk, cost-benefit, efficiency, and effectiveness of the implementation by federal agencies of the Act by evaluating such implementation government-wide and identifying additional guidance and resources necessary to improve such implementation; (2) report to Congress and the Comptroller General on the findings of such evaluation; and (3) evaluate the process for the single audit and the program-specific audit to identify simplified alternatives for achieving the purposes of the Act and the Single Audit Act Amendments of 1996 for the audits of small and large recipients that also achieve the proper balance between risk and cost-effective accountability for small and large recipients."

Andrew Prior Act or Andrew's Law This bill amends the Truth in Lending Act to allow a private educational loan to be discharged in the event the borrower dies or is totally and permanently disabled. Under the bill, neither the borrower's estate nor any cosigner of a private educational loan shall be obligated to repay the outstanding principal or interest on the loan.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 14, 2013. Critical Infrastructure Protection Act or CIPA (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to require the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), in furtherance of domestic preparedness and response, to: (1) include in national planning scenarios the threat of electromagnetic pulse (EMP) events and conduct outreach to educate owners and operators of critical infrastructure, emergency planners, and emergency responders at all levels of government of such threat; and (2) conduct research and development to mitigate the consequences of such events. The scope of such research and development shall include: an objective scientific analysis of the risks to critical infrastructures from a range of EMP events; the determination of the critical national security assets and vital civic utilities and infrastructures that are at risk from EMP events; an evaluation of emergency planning and response technologies that would address the findings and recommendations of experts, including those of the Commission to Assess the Threat to the United States from Electromagnetic Pulse Attack; an analysis of technology options that are available to improve the resiliency of critical infrastructure to EMP; and the restoration and recovery capabilities of critical infrastructure under differing levels of damage and disruption from various EMP events. DHS must submit: (1) a recommended strategy to protect and prepare the critical

Clean Water Affordability Act of 2014 - Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (commonly known as the Clean Water Act) to require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish a comprehensive and integrated planning approach to the obligations under the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) program of a publicly owned treatment works (POTW) or a municipal separate storm sewer system. Requires such approach to account for: (1) the financial capability of the POTW or storm sewer system; (2) preexisting maintenance, operational, and regulatory obligations of the POTW; and (3) new innovative treatment approaches, new regulatory requirements, and changes in financial capability. Permits approval of a NPDES permit with a term of more than 5 years but not more than 25 years if the permittee has an approved integrated plan. Directs the Administrator to update guidance entitled "Combined Sewer Overflows--Guidance for Financial Capability Assessment and Schedule Development," dated February 1997, to ensure that the evaluations by the Administrator of financial capability assessment and schedule development meet specified criteria.

Professional's Access To Health Workforce Integration Act of 2015 This bill authorizes the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to award grants to eligible entities to: provide services to assist unemployed and underemployed skilled immigrants residing in the United States who have legal, permanent work authorization and who are internationally educated health professionals, enter into the American health workforce with employment matching their health professional skills and education, and advance in employment to positions that better match their skills and education; provide training opportunities to reduce entry barriers for internationally educated health professionals; educate employers regarding the abilities and capacities of such professionals; facilitate access to contextualized and accelerated courses on English as a second language; and assist in the evaluation of foreign credentials.

National Monument Creation and Protection Act or the National Monument CAP Act Prohibits the designation of a national monument under this Act in a configuration that would create a monument: (1) exceeding 640 acres; and (2) whose exterior boundary is less than 50 miles from the closest exterior boundary of another declared monument. Sets forth exceptions for a monument of less than 5,000 acres, up to 10,000 acres, and up to 85,000 acres.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 21, 2005. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Native American Veteran Home Loan Act - Makes permanent (currently terminates in 2006) the authority of the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to establish and implement a pilot program making direct housing loans to Native American veterans. Establishes a maximum amount of such loans and revises the limitation on the amount that may be made available to such veterans. Extends direct loan authority to a Native American veteran who is the spouse of a Native American veteran.

Amends Internal Revenue Code provisions relating to the first-time homebuyer tax credit to: (1) extend such credit to all purchasers of a principal residence (currently, limited to first-time homebuyers); (2) extend such credit and its waiver of recapture provisions (for sales of principal residences before the required holding period) through November 30, 2010; (3) allow taxpayers to treat, for tax purposes, a purchase of a principal residence made in 2009 as made on December 31, 2008; and (4) allow a deduction from gross income for loss from the sale or exchange of a principal residence.

Veterans Benefits Administration Improvement Act of 2001 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to submit to specified congressional committees and the Speaker of the House of Representatives a comprehensive plan for the improvement of the processing of claims for veterans compensation and pension.

Healthy Schools Partnerships Act of 2010 - Amends the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a demonstration project under which grants are awarded to school food authorities to fund collaborations with local partner organizations to test and evaluate innovative models to improve nutrition education, student decisionmaking, and healthy school environments.

Young Child Tax Credit Act Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an refundable tax credit for each qualifying child under the age of three. Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to establish a program to make advance payments of such credit.

Small Business Investment Improvement Act of 1999- Amends the Small Business Act (the Act) to increase the maximum amounts of loans that a small business investment company may make to small businesses. <n>Provides that, in determining whether a small business satisfies net income standards established pursuant to the Act, if the business concern is not required by law to pay Federal income taxes at the enterprise level, but is required to pass income through to the shareholders, partners, beneficiaries, or other equitable owners of the business concern, the net income of the business concern shall be determined by allowing a deduction in an amount equal to the sum of: (1) if the business concern is not required by law to pay Federal income taxes at the enterprise level, the net income (determined without regard to this subparagraph), multiplied by the marginal State and local income tax rate that would have applied if the business concern were a corporation; and (2) the net income (determined without regard to this subparagraph), multiplied by the marginal State and local income tax rate that would have applied if the business concern were a corporation. <n>Repeals provisions concerning: (1) the issuance of guarantees and trust certificates; and (2) the authority of the Secretary of the Treasury to guarantee loans made by a small business investment company to small businesses

Safe Transit and Rail Awareness and Investments for National Security Act of 2004 or the Safe TRAINS Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Homeland Security to make grants, through the Under Secretary for Border and Transportation Security, to improve the security of public transportation systems against acts of terrorism. Sets forth considerations for awarding grants, including: (1) risk of terrorism; and (2) merit of the proposed projects to increase national security. Authorizes the use of grant funds for: (1) support for increased capital investments in surveillance systems, command, control, and communications systems and for improved situational awareness; (2) increased training and technical support for public transportation employees; (3) expanded deployment of equipment and other measures, including canine detection teams, for the detection of explosives and chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear agents; (4) capital improvements and operating activities to increase the physical security of stations, vehicles, bridges, and tunnels; (5) capital improvements and operating activities to improve passenger survivability in the event of an attack; and (6) acquisition of emergency response and support equipment, including fire suppression and decontamination equipment. Makes owners, operators, and providers of public transportation systems eligible for grants at the Secretary's discretion.

Pro-Growth Budgeting Act of 2012 - Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) to prepare for each major bill or resolution reported by any congressional committee a macroeconomic impact analysis of the budgetary effects of such measure for the next 10 fiscal-year periods. Requires the analysis to describe the potential economic impact of the measure on major economic variables, including real gross domestic product (GDP), business investment, the capital stock, employment, interest rates, and labor supply.<n><n>Requires the CBO to submit to the congressional budget committees an additional supplemental projection with a supplemental projection for the fiscal year beginning on October 1 of that year with a supplemental projection for the 10 fiscal-year periods assuming: (1) the budgetary effects of measures extending the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001, (2) the budgetary effects of measures extending the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003, and (3) the continued application of the alternative minimum tax (AMT) as in effect for taxable years beginning after 2011.

Ballistic Missile Defense Act of 1996 - States as the priority of the United States with respect to theater ballistic missile defense programs based upon the following agreements: (1) the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty (ABM); (2) the START I Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty; and (3) the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty with Russia. <n>Directs the Secretary of Defense to: (1) review and report annually to the Congress on the readiness of the National Missile Defense System; (2) ensure that the system is improved by the end of 2000 by incorporation of evolving technology; and (3) ensure that a national missile defense system is improved by the end of 2003 if the treaty establishes the means for the parties to amend the treaty.

Federal Land Freedom Act of 2015 This bill authorizes any state that has established a state leasing, permitting, and regulatory program to: (1) submit to the Department of the Interior, Agriculture, and Energy a declaration that such program has been established or amended; and (2) seek to transfer responsibility for leasing, permitting, and regulating oil, natural gas, and other forms of energy development from the federal government to the state. Any action by a state to lease, permit, or regulate the exploration and development of oil, natural gas, and other forms of energy on federal land located in the state in lieu of the federal government shall not be subject to, or considered a federal action, federal permit, or federal license under specified federal law.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 6, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Repeals the Federal Trade Commission Act to prohibit: (1) selling or offering for sale any two consumer products from the same manufacturer that are substantially similar if such products are priced differently based on the gender of the individuals for whose use the products are intended or marketed; and (2) selling or offering for sale any services that are substantially similar if such services are priced differently based on the gender of the individuals for which the services are performed, offered, or marketed. Provides for enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and State attorneys general.

Check Cashing Act of 1995 - Prohibits a person, other than a depository institution, from engaging in business in a State as a check cashing business unless: (1) the State has established a system for licensing or registering check cashing businesses that is approved by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in accordance with this Act; (2) the person is licensed by or registered with such system; and (3) the person engages in that business in accordance with the requirements under that system for licensing or registration. Specifies that any person that violates such prohibition shall be subject to a civil penalty of up to $5,000, which may be assessed by the Commission. Declares that this Act does not apply to engagement by a person in business in a State as a check cashing business in the one-year period beginning on the date of approval of such a system. Declares that any State may apply to the Commission for approval of a State check cashing business licensing or registration system if the system consists of State laws that: (1) prohibit any person from engaging in business in the State as a check cashing business unless the person holds a license issued under the system or is registered with the State under the system; (2) prohibit the issuance of a check cashing business license to a person or the registration of
