Neighborhood Integrity and Responsibility Act - Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to require each public housing agency administering assistance under the housing certificate program to ensure that the rent charged for each dwelling unit assisted by the agency is reasonable in comparison with rents charged for comparable unassisted units available in the private residential rental market by: (1) reviewing all rents for units under consideration by families assisted under the program; and (2) reviewing all rent increases for units under lease by families assisted under the program if the rent (or rent increase) is not reasonable. Directs the agency to disapprove a lease for such a unit if the rent (or rent increase) is not reasonable. Specifies rent comparisons to be conducted by comparing the rent of the assisted dwelling unit with the rent of comparable unassisted units that are located in a geographical area, determined by the agency and approved by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development that: (1) is geographically smaller than the applicable housing area used for the establishment of fair market rentals; (2) has a continuous boundary; and (3) exhibits a commonality of geographic, demographic, housing, or other characteristics that make it appropriate for use under the program, including characteristics such as consisting of a recognized or identifiable neighborhood or geographic area, proximity to or identification with a particular location, structure, or feature,

Land Management Workforce Flexibility Act This bill allows an employee of a land management agency serving under a time-limited appointment in the competitive service to compete for a permanent appointment in the competitive service under that agency\\'s merit promotion procedures if: (1) the employee was appointed initially under open, competitive examination to the time-limited appointment; (2) the employee has served under one or more time-limited appointments by such agency for a period or periods totaling at least 24 months without an intervening break of two or more years; and (3) the employee\\'s performance has been at an acceptable level of performance throughout the period or periods. The bill defines successor permanent position" to mean a permanent position in the competitive service with the same or substantially similar major duties and qualification requirements in the same major subdivision of the same agency as the time-limited position. An agency shall be deemed to have met its obligation under this bill if notice is sent to the last known address of such individual 21 or more days before a successor permanent position for which he or she is eligible is filled."

Amends the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act of 1986 to revise requirements for notifying owners or operators of facilities of hazardous substances releases.Requires the owner or operator of a facility to notify: (1) the community emergency coordinator for the local emergency planning committees for any area likely to be affected by the release and to the State emergency planning commission of any State likely to be affected by the release; or (2) a State agency authorized by State law to receive such notification. Allows notification later than one hour if the owner or operator is unable to notify because of unusual, extenuating circumstances, including remote location, power outages, incapacity of owner or operator, and disruption of telephone service.Amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to revise requirements for notifying persons in charge of vessels or facilities of hazardous substances releases.Requires the National Response Center and the State emergency response commission to convey notification within two hours to the Governor of any affected State, the National Response Center, the State emergency response commission, or the appropriate State agency as designated by State law.

(Sec. 3) Grants Federal district courts original jurisdiction over any civil action brought as a class action in which: (1) any member of a proposed plaintiff class is a citizen of a State different from any defendant; (2) any member of a proposed plaintiff class is a foreign state and any defendant is a citizen of a State; or (3) any member of a proposed plaintiff class is a citizen of a State and any defendant is a citizen or subject of a foreign state. Specifies that the district courts shall not exercise jurisdiction over such an action if it is: (1) an intrastate case; (2) a limited scope case; or (3) a State action case. Defines an intrastate case" as a class action in which the record indicates that: (1) the claims asserted therein will be governed primarily by the laws of the State in which the action was originally filed; and (2) the substantial majority of the members of all proposed plaintiff classes, and the primary defendants, are citizens of the State in which the action was originally filed. Defines a "limited scope case" as a class action in which the record indicates that all matters in controversy asserted by all members of all proposed plaintiff classes do not in the aggregate exceed the sum or value of $1 million, exclusive of interest and costs, or"

United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) Funding Act of 1999 - Authorizes appropriations for FY 2000 and 2001 for U.S. voluntary contributions to the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA). Directs that such funds be withheld from obligation and expenditure unless the President certifies to appropriate congressional committees that the UNFPA country program in China: (1) focuses on improving the delivery of voluntary family planning information and services; (2) is designed in conformity with the human rights principles affirmed at the International Conference on Population and Development with the support of 180 nations including the United States; (3) is implemented only in counties of China where all quotas and targets for the recruitment of program participants have been abolished and the use of coercive measures has been eliminated; (4) is carried out in consultation with and under the oversight and approval of the UNFPA executive board, including the United States representative; (5) is subject to regular, independent monitoring to ensure compliance with the principles of informed consent and voluntary participation; and (6) suspends operations in project counties found to be in violation of program guidelines.

Resolution of the Ethiopia-Eritrea Border Dispute Act of 2004 - States that it is U.S. policy to support: (1) the implementation of the Comprehensive Peace Agreement between Ethiopia and Eritrea; and (2) the creation of a neutral border between the two countries.<n><n>Prohibits certain economic assistance and military assistance to Ethiopia and Eritrea unless the President certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that: (1) the governments of the two countries have taken actions to implement the Comprehensive Peace Agreement and the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement; (2) the border between the two countries has been delimiting and demarcate; (3) the neutral Boundary Commission has been established; and (4) U.N. Peacekeeping Mission personnel have been stationed at the border between the two countries.<n><n>Authorizes the President to: (1) provide assistance to Ethiopia and Eritrea to support their implementation of the Comprehensive Peace Agreement and the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement; and (2) provide military assistance and arms transfers to support the implementation of such Agreements.
Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide (temporarily) for the nonrecognition of gain or loss from transfers by common trust funds to regulated investment companies.

Nuclear Power Plant Safety Act of 2011 - Amends the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 to direct the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to initiate a rulemaking proceeding to revise its regulations to ensure that each licensed utilization facility can withstand and adequately respond to: (1) an earthquake, tsunami, strong storm, or other event that threatens a major impact to the facility; (2) a loss of the primary operating power source for at least 14 days; and (3) a loss of the primary backup operating power source for at least 72 hours. Specifies that the revision of such regulations shall provide for a requirement that each licensed utilization facility, including any onsite spent nuclear fuel facilities, be equipped with resilient containment, safety, and diagnostic systems sufficient to withstand such circumstances.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Hurricane Katrina Financial Services Relief Act of 2005 - Expresses the sense of Congress that it is vital that insured depository institutions and insured credit unions continue to provide financial services to consumers displaced or otherwise affected by Hurricane Katrina, which includes the cashing of federal government assistance and benefit checks. Expresses the sense of the Congress that the Secretary of the Treasury and federal financial regulators should seek to educate insured depository institutions and insured credit unions on the proper application of the published guidance on the cashing of such checks.Urges the federal financial regulators to continue to work with such institutions and credit unions operating under extraordinary circumstances to facilitate the cashing of such checks.Requires a federal reserve bank to waive or rebate any transaction fee for wire transfer services that otherwise would be imposed on any insured depository institution or insured credit union that, as of August 28, 2005, was headquartered in a qualified disaster area.Authorizes a federal financial regulator to forbear from taking any required action, on a case-by-case basis, with respect to any undercapitalized insured depository institution or credit union that is not significantly or critically undercapitalized if the entity meets specified prerequisites, and would be consistent with safe and sound practices

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 6, 2018. Peer Support Communities of Recovery Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), when awarding grants under the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration's Building Communities of Recovery program, to award grants to independent nonprofit organizations that serve: (1) substance use disorder treatment and recovery initiatives; and (2) prevention, treatment, recovery, payor, faith-based, and criminal justice stakeholders in the implementation of local addiction and recovery initiatives. The bill defines "recovery community organization" to mean: (1) a national nonprofit entity focused on substance use disorder with a network of local affiliates and partners that are geographically and organizationally diverse; or (2) a nonprofit organization focused on substance use disorder, established by individuals in personal or family recovery, and serving prevention, treatment, recovery, payor, faith-based, and criminal justice stakeholders in the implementation of local addiction and recovery initiatives. HHS may award grants to eligible entities for establishing regional technical assistance centers. In the case of a grant awarded to a recovery community organization, the grant must be used to provide for the establishment of regional technical assistance centers to provide regional technical assistance for
Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose taxes on: (1) coal; (2) petroleum with respect to which there is a taxable event; and (3) natural gas.

Amends the United States Grain Standards Act to reauthorize through FY2010: (1) inspection and supervisory fees; (2) weighing and supervisory fees; and (3) the Secretary of Agriculture's (USDA) Advisory Committee on Grain Standards.<n><n>Revises the use of official inspection authority and funding to authorize the Secretary to use private entities for all or specified functions involved in official inspection (other than appeal inspection) at export port locations. States that official inspection shall continue to be the direct responsibility of the Secretary.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to report annually to Congress on the use of authority to contract with persons or private entities to perform official inspections at export port locations.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on May 21, 2015. Combat Human Trafficking Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the federal criminal code, with respect to sex trafficking of children, to: (1) subject to criminal prosecution buyers, as well as sellers, of commercial sex involving sex trafficking victims; (2) provide that in prosecutions of sex trafficking crimes, the government is not required to prove that a sex trafficking defendant knew or recklessly disregarded the fact that a victim was under age 18; (3) equalize the period of supervised release for sex trafficking offenders convicted of conspiracy; (4) expand wiretap authority for investigating crimes related to sex trafficking, including slavery, involuntary servitude, and forced labor; (5) grant crime victims the right to be informed in a timely manner of any plea agreement or deferred prosecution agreement; and (6) require an appellate court to apply ordinary standards of review in reviewing appeals filed by crime victims. (Sec. 3) The Bureau of Justice Statistics of the Department of Justice (DOJ) must prepare and report annually on: (1) the rates of arrests by state law enforcement officers for sex trafficking crimes involving buyers of commercial sex involving sex trafficking victims, prosecutions for such crimes in state courts, and convictions for such crimes in state courts; and (2) sentences

(Sec. 101) Reauthorizes appropriations to the Secretary of Transportation for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration for FY 2005 and 2007.(Sec. 102) Authorizes the Secretary to participate in international activities to enhance motor vehicle and traffic safety through exchanging information, conducting safety research, examining safety needs, best practices, new technology, and improvements in motor vehicle safety standards, and participating in the implementation of existing international agreements concerning motor vehicle safety to which the United States is a contracting partner.(Sec. 103) Prohibits a person from affixing a certification label to a motor vehicle or item of motor vehicle equipment unless the person has either performed tests or otherwise documented the basis for certifying compliance with all applicable safety standards. Allows a manufacturer that completes a vehicle after receiving compliance documentation from the manufacturer of the earlier stage of the vehicle to rely on such documentation in accordance with regulations issued by the Secretary.(Sec. 105) Prohibits a dealer from selling or leasing a used motor vehicle until the dealer informs the purchaser or lessee of any notification of a defect or noncompliance with respect to a vehicle that has not been remedied, and either: (1) offers to have the defects or noncompliances remedied; or (2) gives the purchaser or lessee a written description of the defects or noncompliances

Child Care Criminal Background Check Act of 2009 - Amends the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 to require a state child care services plan to certify that the state will require child care providers that are licensed by the state or that receive funds under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Program to obtain a comprehensive criminal background check of each employee who provides child care services, each applicant for employment, and each family child care provider who provides or applies to provide such services and to refuse to employ, or continue to employ, an individual to provide such services: (1) if such individual was convicted of a crime of violence or a crime against children; (2) to an eligible child without the supervision of an employee whose criminal background check satisfies requirements, pending receipt of such individual's background check; and (3) to an eligible child with the supervision of an employee whose criminal background check satisfies requirements and for a period exceeding 90 days, pending receipt of such individual's background check. Requires a state child care services plan to also certify that the state will carry out a comprehensive criminal background check of each employee of, and each applicant for employment by, a child care provider that is licensed by the state or receives funds under the Program and make the results available to such provider, employee, and applicant

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 6, 2003. The summary has been expanded because action occurred on the measure.)Architect of the Capitol Human Resources Act - Directs the Architect of the Capitol (AOC) to establish and maintain a personnel management system.Requires such system to include, at a minimum: (1) a system which ensures that applicants for employment and employees of the AOC are appointed, promoted, and assigned on the basis of merit and fitness after fair and equitable consideration of all applicants and employees through open competition; (2) an equal employment opportunity program which includes an affirmative employment program for employees and applicants for employment, and procedures for monitoring progress by the AOC in ensuring a workforce reflective of the diverse labor force; (3) a system for the classification of positions which takes into account the difficulty, responsibility, and qualification requirements of the work performed and which conforms to the principle of equal pay for substantially equal work; (4) a program for the training of AOC employees which has among its goals improved employee performance and opportunities for employee advancement; (5) a formal performance appraisal system which will permit the accurate evaluation of job performance on the basis of objective criteria for all AOC employees; (6) a fair and equitable system to address unacceptable conduct and performance by AOC employees, including a

Fair, Accurate, Secure, and Timely Voting Act of 2012 or the FAST Voting Act of 2012 - Directs the Attorney General to award grants, on a competitive basis, to enable states to: (1) invest in practices and technology designed to expedite voting at the polls, and (2) simplify voter registration. Limits each grant to four years.

Global Climate Change Security Oversight Act - Requires the Director of National Intelligence to submit to Congress a National Intelligence Estimate on the anticipated effects of global climate change and the implications of such effects on the national security of the United States.
Debt Relief Reconciliation Act for Fiscal Year 2001 - Establishes in the Treasury the Public Debt Reduction Payment Account. Appropriates funds to the Account for FY 2001 and 2002.

Volunteer Emergency Services Recruitment and Retention Act of 2006 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to permit election of length of service award plans as eligible deferred compensation plans. Defines length of service award plan" as any plan paying solely length of service awards to bona fide volunteers (or their beneficiaries) on account of qualified fire fighting and prevention, emergency medical, ambulance, and emergency rescue services."

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 2, 2017. Medicaid Reform and Personal Responsibility Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to require states to apply a work requirement to able-bodied adults without dependents, generally defined as individuals under age 18 who are not physically or mentally unfit for employment or who are enrolled in a training program or regular participant in a drug addiction or treatment and rehabilitation program. An "able-bodied adult without dependents" is an individual who is not: under 18 or over 55 years of age; medically certified as physically or mentally unfit for employment; a parent or other member of a household with responsibility for a dependent child; a bona fide student enrolled at least half time in any recognized school, training program, or institution of higher education; or a regular participant in a drug addiction or treatment and rehabilitation program. The bill also prohibits able-bodied adults without dependents from receiving Medicaid assistance if they: refuse, at the time of application and every 12 months thereafter, to register as employed or as unemployed or looking for employment for less than 12 consecutive months in a manner prescribed by the state; refuse without good cause to accept an offer of employment

Our Nation's Trade, Infrastructure, Mobility, and Efficiency Act of 2007 or the ON TIME Act of 2007- Directs the Secretary of Transportation to issue regulations establishing a national trade gateway corridor fee on each article imported into the United States in commerce and on each article exported from the United States in commerce. Sets the fee amount at .075 percent of the value of the article or $500, whichever is less. Terminates the fee after FY2017.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Commerce, to develop and implement a comprehensive program for fish screens, fish passage devices, and other measures agreed to by local interests and relevant Federal agencies for water diversions by local governmental entities in Oregon, Washington, Montana, and Idaho that provide water supplies. Specifies that the goals of the program shall be to: (1) decrease the incidence of juvenile and adult fish entering water supply systems; and (2) decrease fish mortality associated with the withdrawal of water for irrigation and other purposes without impairing the continued withdrawal of water for that purpose. Requires non-Federal participation in the program to be voluntary.Makes the non-Federal interests responsible for all costs associated with operating, maintaining, repairing, rehabilitating, and replacing all projects carried out under this Act.Requires the owner of land on which a project is constructed to grant appropriate Federal personnel reasonable access to the project for installation, maintenance, repair, rehabilitation, or replacement of fish screens and passage devices.

Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to award grants to State and local educational agencies to assist local educational agencies in providing: (1) signing bonuses to middle or secondary school math or science teachers who agree to teach in a school in a high-need area during the four-school-year period that begins on the date on which the teacher is hired; and (2) mastery bonuses to supplement the salaries of middle or secondary school math or science teachers who pass an advanced competency exam in math and science that is approved by the National Academy of Sciences and agree to teach during the five-school-year period that begins during or after the date on which the State educational agency determines that the teacher has passed the advanced competency exam.

Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis Management Act of 2008 - Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop and make available to local educational agencies a voluntary policy to manage the risk of food allergy and anaphylaxis in schools. Directs that such policy address: (1) a parental obligation to provide the school with information regarding a student's food allergy and risk for anaphylaxis; (2) communication strategies between schools and emergency medical services; (3) strategies to reduce the risk of exposure in classrooms and common areas; (4) food allergy management training of school personnel; (5) authorization of school personnel to administer epinephrine when the school nurse is not immediately available; and (6) creation of an individual health care plan tailored to each student's risk for anaphylaxis.

Community College Teacher Preparation Enhancement Act of 2004 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to award grants to eligible entities to enable them to pay the Federal share of the costs of carrying out teacher training or preparation programs. Includes among such eligible entities: (1) a statewide governing or coordinating board with jurisdiction over community colleges and four-year institutions of higher education; (2) a partnership between a statewide governing or coordinating board with jurisdiction over community colleges and a statewide governing or coordinating board with jurisdiction over four-year institutions of higher education; or (3) a community college offering a teacher preparation program that provides all, or a significant portion, of teacher training, postbaccalaureate certification, and professional development.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Little Traverse Bay Bands of Odawa Indians and the Little Traverse River Band of Ottawa Indians Act - Reaffirms Federal recognition and the rights and privileges of the Little Traverse Bay Bands of Odawa Indians and the Little Traverse River Band of Ottawa Indians (in the State of Michigan). Entitles such Bands to the Federal services and benefits provided to recognized Indians.

Housing Affordability for Teachers and Public Safety Officers Act of 2005 - Amends the National Housing Act to provide for one percent downpayments (and deferral and reduction of up-front payments) for Federal Housing Administration (FHA) mortgage loans for qualified elementary and secondary school teachers and administrators and non-Federal public safety officers to purchase homes within the jurisdictions of their employing agencies. Limits the aggregate number of insured mortgages in any fiscal year to ten percent of the aggregate number of mortgages and loans insured during the preceding fiscal year.

Access to Health Care for Individuals with Disabilities Act of 2010 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to award formula grants to states to develop and maintain accessible health care provider directories for individuals with disabilities.

Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award scholarships to students who have demonstrated outstanding academic achievement in the physical, life, or computer sciences, mathematics, or engineering and show promise of continued outstanding academic performance in such field of study. <n>Requires the Director of the National Science Foundation to develop and submit to the Secretary proposed criteria for the selection of National Science Scholars for initial year scholarships. <n>Requires the Secretary and the Director to agree to and jointly publish in the Federal Register appropriate selection criteria. <n>Requires each State to establish a nominating committee to qualify its students for selection as National Science Scholars. <n>Requires the Director to submit to the President nominations of at least four individuals from each congressional district in the State, at least half of whom shall be female. <n>Requires the President to select two National Science Scholars for each academic year from each congressional district. <n>Requires the Secretary to notify each Member of the Congress of selections made from each State.

Caregiver Corps Act of 2014 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to contract with a nonprofit entity for the development of an online toolkit and guidance providing for the establishment and implementation of Caregiver Corps volunteer programs in local communities. Authorizes the Secretary to award grants to public and private nonprofit entities for the operation of local Corps programs. Requires a local Corps program to: (1) conduct screening and criminal history background checks of Corps volunteers; (2) provide in-person orientation and training for Corps volunteers; (3) develop and monitor volunteer assignments; (4) assist in the provision of appropriate volunteer recognition; (5) maintain records and prepare reports as required by the Secretary; and (6) carry out any other activities determined appropriate by the Secretary.

Directs the Commissioner of Social Security to waive the application of the five-month waiting period for entitlement to benefits under title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) of the Social Security Act in cases in which a terminally ill individual is not entitled to benefits based on disability.

Update, Promote, and Develop America's Transportation Act of 2013 - Expresses the sense of Congress that by 2024 the gas tax should be repealed and replaced with a more sustainable, stable funding source. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the rate of tax on motor fuels, including gasoline other than aviation gasoline, diesel fuel or kerosene, and diesel-water fuel emulsion.

Korean War Veterans Recognition Act of 2006 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service, to place a plaque at the Korean War Veterans Memorial in Washington, D.C., to commemorate the Korean War.

Cigarette Fire Safety Act of 2004 - Directs the Consumer Product Safety Commission to prescribe one or more fire safety standards for cigarettes, except as provided in this Act. Prohibits the application of specified Federal laws to the promulgation of such rule or the modification of such rule.

District of Columbia Full Self- Government Act - States that all of the territory constituting the permanent seat of the Federal Government in the District of Columbia shall continue to be designated as the District. States that all of such territory shall remain and continue a body corporate.Provides that: (1) all of the territory shall continue to be designated as the District; and (2) the District's legislative power shall extend to all rightful subjects of legislation within the District consistent with the Constitution.Establishes a Council of the District, elected by the registered qualified electors of the District, which shall have no authority to pass any act contrary to this Act, or to impose any tax on property of the United States or any of the several States, lend the public credit for support of any private undertaking, enact any act, or enact any act to amend or repeal any Act of Congress which concerns the functions or property of the United States or which is not restricted in its application exclusively in or to the District, impose any tax on the whole or any portion of the personal income of any individual not a resident of the District, enact any act, resolution, or rule which permits the building of any structure within the District in excess of the height limitations contained in the Act of June 1, 1910, and in effect

Hydrographic Services Improvement Act Amendments of 2008- Amends the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 to revise the definitions of: (1) hydrographic data" to include lidar, radar, remote sensing, shoreline and other ocean- and coastal-related surveying, and water level observations; and (2) "hydrographic services" to include references to shoreline and water level information.<n><n>Authorizes the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to acquire hydrographic data and provide hydrographic services if it does not detract from the promotion of safe and efficient navigation.<n><n>Authorizes the Administrator to: (1) create, support, and maintain a Joint Hydrographic Institute; and (2) acquire hydrographic data and provide hydrographic services to support the conservation and management of coastal and ocean resources, save and protect life and property, support the resumption of commerce in response to emergencies, natural disasters, and man-made disasters, and meet homeland security and maritime domain awareness needs.<n><n>Requires the Administrator, except for conducting hydrographic surveys, to contract for hydrographic surveys, including the leasing or time chartering of vessels.<n><n>Extends funding for the Hydrographic Services Review Panel through FY2012."

Migratory Bird Treaty Reform Act of 2004 - Amends the Migratory Bird Treaty Act to exclude from its application non-native, human introduced bird species that are native to the United States and whose occurrence in the United States is entirely the result of natural biological or ecological conditions. Provides that a bird species shall not be treated as native to the United States if it occurs in the United States solely as a result of intentional or unintentional human-assisted introduction and shall be treated as native to the United States if it was native to the United States and extant in 1918, was extirpated after 1918 throughout its range in the United States, and was reintroduced in the United States as a part of a program carried out by a Federal agency. Directs the Secretary of the Interior to publish a list of all non-native, human introduced bird species to which the Migratory Bird Treaty Act does not apply that belong to biological families of migratory birds covered under any of the migratory bird conventions with Great Britain (for Canada), Mexico, Russia, or Japan. Declares that nothing in this Act shall delay implementation of other provisions of this Act that exclude non-native, human introduced bird species from the application of the Treaty Act.Title II: Conservation of Neotropical

Civil Rights Commission Amendments Act of 1994 - Amends the United States Commission on Civil Rights Act of 1983 to reestablish the United States Commission on Civil Rights. Declares that the Commission shall: (1) investigate allegations relating to deprivations because of color, race, religion, sex, age, disability, or national origin; (2) collect information relating to Federal civil rights enforcement efforts; (3) serve as a national clearinghouse for information relating to such efforts; and (4) prepare public service announcements and advertising campaigns to discourage discrimination or denials of equal protection of the laws under the Constitution or in the administration of justice. Declares that nothing in this Act shall be construed as authorizing the Commission, its advisory committees, or any person under its supervision or control, to inquire into or investigate any membership practices or internal operations of any fraternal organization, any college or university fraternity, or any private club, or any religious organization.

English Language Unity Act of 2015 Declares English to be the official language of the United States. Establishes the affirmative obligation of the representatives of the federal government to preserve and enhance the role of the English language as the government's official language. Requires the official functions of the government to be conducted in English. Requires: (1) a uniform English language testing standard for U.S. naturalization, and (2) all naturalization ceremonies to be conducted in English. Sets forth exceptions to and rules of construction for such requirements. Requires, as a general rule of construction, that English language requirements and workplace policies, whether in the public or private sector, shall be presumptively consistent with the laws of the United States. Sets forth exceptions to and rules of construction for such requirements. Requires the Department of Justice to issue for public notice and comment a proposed rule for uniform testing of English language ability of candidates for naturalization based upon the principles that: (1) all citizens of the United States should be able to read and understand generally the English language text of the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution, and the laws of the United States; and (2) any exceptions to this standard should be limited to extraordinary circumstances, such as asylum.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 19, 2014. Community Gardening and Nutrition Act of 2014 - (Sec. 3) Amends the Domestic Volunteer Service Act of 1973 to include among the purposes of the community garden volunteer program: establishing initiatives that address the health and nutrition of individuals in low-income and underserved communities; and developing initiatives that increase access to healthy, locally grown foods for the community at large. (Sec. 110) Requires the Director of the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to establish a Community Garden Pilot Program to carry out at least 40 projects, of which at least 40% shall be located in varied geographic regions. Requires the Director to give priority to volunteers with experience in health, nutrition, and gardening. (Sec. 194) Authorizes appropriations for the program for FY2014-FY2015.

Federal Internship Improvement Act - Directs the head of each executive agency operating an internship program to: (1) appoint an internship coordinator within the agency; and (2) make publicly available on the Internet such coordinator's name and contact information and information regarding application procedures and deadlines for each internship program. Directs the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to: (1) make publicly available on the Internet links to the websites where such information is displayed; and (2) establish and maintain a centralized electronic database that contains the names, contact information, and relevant skills of individuals who have completed or are nearing completion of an internship program and are currently seeking full-time federal employment. Directs each agency operating an internship program to conduct an exit interview and administer a survey with each intern who completes such program.

Concussion Treatment and Care Tools Act of 2010 or the ConTACT Act of 2010 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to: (1) establish concussion management guidelines that address the prevention, identification, treatment, and management of concussions in school-aged children, including standards for such children to return to play after experiencing such a concussion; and (2) convene a conference of medical, athletic, and educational stakeholders to assist in the establishment of such guidelines. Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to states for: (1) providing for the collection by target entities of information on the incidence and prevalence of concussions among school-aged children attending or participating in such entities; (2) adopting, disseminating, and ensuring the implementation by target entities of the guidelines; (3) funding implementation by target entities of pre-season baseline and post-injury testing, including computerized testing, for school-aged children; and (4) any other activity or purpose specified by the Secretary. Directs the Secretary to require states receiving grants to utilize, to the extent practicable, applicable expertise and services offered by high school sports associations, youth sports associations, athletic trainer associations, and local chapters of national brain injury organizations.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Migratory Bird Treaty Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Migratory Bird Treaty Act to prohibit persons from placing, exposing, depositing, distributing, or scattering salt, grain, or other feed that could lure or attract migratory birds to, on, or over areas on which a hunter is attempting to take migratory birds, unless the area has been treated with a normal agricultural practice or has standing crops that have not been manipulated, or has standing crops that have been or are flooded. The bill defines: "baiting" as the direct or indirect placing, exposing, depositing, distributing, or scattering of salt, grain, or other feed that could lure or attract migratory birds to, on, or over any areas on which a hunter is attempting to take migratory birds; and "normal agricultural practice" as any practice in one annual growing season that is carried out in order to produce a marketable crop and is recommended for the successful destruction of a given crop by the applicable state office of the Cooperative Extension System of the Department of Agriculture, in consultation with, and if requested, the concurrence of, the head of the applicable state department of fish and wildlife.

International Money Transfer Disclosure Act - Directs the appropriate Federal agencies to jointly prescribe regulations requiring any financial institution or money transmitting business initiating an international money transfer on behalf of a consumer to make a good faith effort to make disclosures in English and in the same language, if other than English, to the consumer before the consummation of the transaction, including: (1) any fees to be charged to the recipient, including any exchange rate or currency conversion fees; (2) a final itemization of all costs to the consumer, which would include all fees charged; and (3) the exact amount of foreign currency to be received by the recipient in the foreign country.

Mental Health First Act of 2013 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to replace provisions requiring the Administrator of the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration to award grants to states, local governments, Indian tribes and organizations, and nonprofit private entities to initiate and sustain mental health first aid training programs with provisions requiring the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through the Administrator, to award grants to states, local governments, Indian tribes and organizations, and nonprofit private entities to initiate and sustain mental health first aid training programs. Requires a program to be designed to train specified categories of individuals, including: emergency services personnel and other first responders; police officers and other law enforcement personnel; teachers and school administrators; human resources professionals; faith community leaders; nurses and other primary care personnel; students enrolled in an elementary school, a secondary school, or an institution of higher education; the parents of students; and veterans. Requires a program to be designed to train individuals to: (1) safe de-escalation of crisis situations; (2) recognize the signs and symptoms of mental illness, including common psychiatric conditions as schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, major clinical depression, and anxiety disorders; and (3) timely referral to mental health services in the early stages of developing mental disorders in order to avoid more costly subsequent behavioral

Mandate Prevention Act of 2010 - Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to make it out of order in both chambers to consider any bill, joint resolution, amendment, motion, or conference report that would increase the direct costs of federal private sector mandates by an amount that causes specified thresholds to be exceeded, unless: (1) the bill provides new budget authority or new entitlement authority in the House of Representatives or direct spending authority in the Senate for each fiscal year for such mandates included in the bill, joint resolution, amendment, motion, or conference report in an amount equal to or exceeding the direct costs of such mandate; or (2) the bill includes an authorization for appropriations in an amount equal to or exceeding such mandate's direct costs. Requires the responsible federal agency, within 30 days after the beginning of the fiscal year, to notify the appropriate authorizing committees of the determination that the amount appropriated is sufficient to pay for the direct costs of such mandate, or that legislative recommendations for either implementing a less costly mandate or making such mandate ineffective for the fiscal year. Requires such mandate to: (1) cease to be effective 60 days after the statement submitted by the agency is submitted unless Congress has approved it by joint resolution; (2) continue not to be effective 60 days after the date the legislative recommendations of the responsible

Federal Trade Commission Reauthorization Act of 2008 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTCA) to authorize appropriations for the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) for FY2009-FY2015.<n><n>(Sec. 3) Authorizes the FTC to: (1) commence, defend, or intervene in the litigation of any civil action involving the FTC Act (including an action to collect a civil penalty) and any appeal of such action in its own name by any of its attorneys designated by it; and (2) consult with the Attorney General of any such action or request the Attorney General to commence, defend, or intervene in any such action.<n><n>Authorizes the FTC, in appointing administrative law judges, to give preference to judges who have experience with antitrust or trade regulation litigation and who are familiar with the kinds of economic analysis associated with such litigation.<n><n>(Sec. 4) Allows the FTC to: (1) represent itself before the Supreme Court in any civil action in which it represented itself before the Court in which it represented itself before the Court in any such action; and (2) request the Attorney General to represent it before the Supreme Court in any such action.<n><n>(Sec. 5) Revises civil penalties for violations of the FTC Act to: (1) make a violation

Immigration Enforcement Review Commission Act - Establishes the Immigration Enforcement Review Commission which shall be responsible for investigating complaints of civil rights abuses against the Immigration and Naturalization Service, its employees, or any facilities where detainees are held in Service custody.

Securities Law Technical Corrections Act of 2007- Makes technical corrections to the Securities Act of 1933, the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, the Trust Indenture Act of 1939, the Commodity Futures Modernization Act of 2000, the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and the Investment Company Act of 1940.

Free File Act of 2016 This bill directs the Department of the Treasury to continue to operate the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) Free File Program, which provides free commercial-type online individual income tax preparation and electronic filing services to the lowest 70% of taxpayers. The IRS Free File Program shall continue to work cooperatively with the private sector to provide the free income tax preparation and electronic filing services while reducing the cost of processing returns. The IRS shall work cooperatively with state and local agencies to enhance and expand the use of the program while reducing the cost of processing returns. The IRS shall work with the private sector to implement innovative program features to: (1) simplify taxpayer compliance with the internal revenue laws, (2) reduce taxpayer compliance burdens, (3) increase individual income tax return accuracy through financial data authentication, (4) strengthen the tax system against fraud and threats of fraud through cybersecurity collaboration, (5) avoid duplication of effort in the tax system, (6) simplify the tax system, and (7) maximize the use of electronic technology.

Medicare Patient IVIG Access Act of 2009 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to collect and review data and review complexity codes for the physician administration of intravenous immune globulins (IVIGs).<n><n>Directs the Secretary, after completion of the review, to provide, if appropriate, an additional payment to such physicians for all items related to the furnishing of IVIG in the home.<n><n>Provides for coverage of IVIG administered in the home.<n><n>Makes disposable drug delivery systems, including elastomeric infusion pumps, for the treatment of colorectal cancer durable medical equipment for Medicare purposes.

Securely Expediting Clearances Through Reporting Transparency Act of 2018 or the SECRET Act of 2018 (Sec. 3) This bill requires the National Background Investigations Bureau (NBI) of the Office of Personnel Management to report to Congress within 90 days and quarterly thereafter for five years on the backlog of personnel security clearance investigations at the NBI. (Sec. 4) The Office of Administration of the Executive Office of the President must report to Congress within 90 days and quarterly thereafter for five years on the process for conducting and adjudicating security clearance investigations for personnel of the Executive Office, including personnel of the White House Office. (Sec. 5) The Office of Personnel Management must report to Congress within 120 days and quarterly thereafter for five years on the cost of maintaining comprehensive background investigations capability within the NBI and a background investigations capability for Department of Defense personnel under the control or direction of the Department of Defense for implementation of the plan referenced in the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2018. (Sec. 6) The NBI must report to Congress regarding: (1) the status of implementing continuous evaluation programs, and (2) barriers to implementing such programs, including requirements for reciprocal recognition to access classified information.

. Presidential Library Donation Reform Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends federal law regarding presidential archival depositories to require any presidential library fundraising organization to submit quarterly reports to the National Archives and Records Administration (National Archives) on every contributor who gave the organization a contribution or contributions (whether monetary or in-kind) totaling $200 or more for the quarterly period. The Archivist of the United States must publish such information on the website of the National Archives within 30 days after each quarterly filing. The bill makes it unlawful for contributors or fundraising organizations to knowingly and willfully submit false information or omit material information. Violators are subject to criminal penalties under the federal criminal code.

Confederated Oji Tribes of Michigan Act - Reaffirms Federal recognition and the rights and privileges of the Confederated Oji Tribes of Michigan (the Tribe). Entitles such Tribe to the Federal services and benefits provided to recognized Indians and restores all member rights and privileges which may have been abrogated or diminished before this Act's enactment.

Wastewater Treatment Operator Training and Certification Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to direct the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to develop and implement a national program to train individuals in the operation of municipal and industrial wastewater treatment works and other facilities with a water pollution control purpose. <n>Authorizes the Administrator to make grants to, or enter into contracts with, institutions of higher education, or combinations of such institutions and State agencies to support the development and implementation of such training programs. <n>Directs the Administrator to: (1) publish guidance that specifies the minimum elements of such training programs; (2) solicit proposals from institutions of higher education, or combinations of such institutions, and State agencies to provide training services; and (3) award training grants to such institutions and agencies for each fiscal year. <n>Directs the Administrator to: (1) provide for the review and evaluation of each training program that receives funding not later than three years after it initially receives the funding and every three years thereafter; and (2) develop and maintain a system for forecasting the supply of, and demand for, various professional and other occupational categories needed for the prevention, reduction, and elimination of water pollution in each region, State, or area of the United States. <n>Requires the Chief Operator of a publicly owned

Migratory Bird Hunting and Conservation Stamp Promotion Act of 1998 - Amends Federal law to authorize the Secretary of the Interior to use from receipts from the sale of migratory bird hunting and conservation stamps an amount not to exceed $1 million for each of FY 1999 through 2003 for the promotion of additional stamp sales. Requires the Secretary to: (1) include in each required report a statement of all expenditures; and (2) provide a copy of such report to the Migratory Bird Conservation Commission, the Committee on Environment and Public Works of the Senate, and the Committee on Resources of the House of Representatives.

Promoting American Agricultural and Medical Exports to Cuba Act of 2009 - Prohibits the President from restricting direct transfers from a Cuban depository institution to a U.S. depository institution in payment for an agricultural commodity or product authorized for sale under the Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to provide information and technical assistance to U.S. agricultural producers, cooperative organizations, and state agencies to promote U.S. agricultural commodities or products exports to Cuba.<n><n>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the airport ticket tax for transportation between the United States and Cuba.<n><n>Establishes in the Treasury the Agricultural Export Promotion Trust Fund.

Middle Class Tax Relief Act of 2010 - Makes permanent provisions of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 relating to: (1) individual income tax rate reductions; (2) tax benefits related to children; (3) marriage penalty relief; (4) the increased expensing allowance for depreciable business assets; (5) the offset against the alternative minimum tax (AMT) of nonrefundable personal tax credits; and (6) the increased exemption amount for the alternative minimum tax (AMT).<n><n>Excludes from the meaning of high income individual taxpayer provisions relating to: (1) reductions in individual income tax rates; (2) tax benefits related to children; (3) marriage penalty relief; (4) the increased expensing allowance for depreciable business assets; and (5) the offset against the AMT of nonrefundable personal tax credits.

Renewable Energy Investment Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend through 2014: (1) the tax credit for renewable electricity production; (2) the tax credit for new clean renewable energy bonds; (3) the tax credit for investment in advanced energy facilities; (4) the tax credit for alcohol fuels; (5) the tax credit for biodiesel and renewable diesel; and (6) the tax credit for research in and development of fungible biofuels.

Visa Waiver Program Security Enhancement Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to require a visa for an alien who has recently traveled to Iraq or Syria at any time during the most recent five-year period. Authorizes the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) to prohibit a national of a participating visa waiver country from traveling to the United States under the program if such national has traveled during the past five years to a country in which: (1) a designated foreign terrorist organization has a significant presence; and (2) prohibiting such national from traveling to the United States under the program is in the U.S. national security interests.<n><n>Requires electronic passports for visa waiver program countries.<n><n>Amends the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act of 2002 to require a participating visa waiver country to certify that its citizens use machine-readable, electronic passports.<n><n>Requires a country, for purposes of information sharing with the United States under the visa waiver program, to: (1) enter into an agreement with the United States to assist in the operation of an effective Air Marshal Program; and (2) comply with U.S. aviation and airport security standards.

Stop Taking Our Health Privacy (STOHP) Act of 2002 - Declares that modifications made by the August 2002 rules concerning the December 2000 medical privacy rule have no force or effect with respect to provisions concerning patient consent for the use or disclosure of health information for treatment, payment, or health care operations. Requires that, in addition to the circumstances described in such rules, such modifications ensure that activities typically considered marketing: (1) fall under the rule\\'s privacy protections relating to the use of patient health information for marketing activities; and (2) eliminate the broad public health" exemption created by the August 2002 rule."

National Reconstruction Study Area Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service, to complete a study of the suitability and feasibility of designating specified historical sites in the historic district of Beaufort, South Carolina, relating to the Reconstruction Era (the period when Congress adopted the 13th amendment ending slavery, the 14th amendment guaranteeing civil rights, and the 15th amendment guaranteeing voting rights to all citizens of the United States) as a unit of the National Park System.

Directs the Attorney General to provide for the granting of posthumous citizenship as of September 10, 2001, to a person who died as a result of the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, as a result of an injury incurred in the crash of American Airlines Flight 11 into the World Trade Center in New York, New York, and the crash of United Airlines Flight 175 into the World Trade Center in New York, New York, and the hijacking of American Airlines Flight 77 into the Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia, and the crash of United Airlines Flight 93 in Stony Creek Township, Pennsylvania.

Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to ensure that the Women Veterans Bill of Rights is printed on signs in accessible formats and displayed prominently and conspicuously in each VA facility and distributed widely to such veterans. States that such Bill of Rights is a sign stating that women veterans should have the following rights: (1) coordinated, comprehensive, primary women's health care at every VA medical facility; (2) treatment with dignity and respect at all VA facilities; (3) innovation in care delivery promoted and incentivized by the Veterans Health Administration to support local best practices fitted to the particular configuration and women veteran population; (4) enhanced capabilities of medical providers, clinical support, non-clinical, and administrative to meet the comprehensive health care needs of women veterans; (5) gender equity in provision of clinical health care services; (6) parity to their male veteran counterpart regarding the outcome of performance measures of VA health care services; (7) notification, through outreach campaigns, of benefits under VA laws and inclusion in VA outreach materials, of all VA benefits and services; (8) proportionately featured in VA outreach materials; (9) equal consideration in hiring and employment; (10) equal consideration in securing federal contracts; (11) the right to have their claims adjudicated equally, fairly, and accurately without bias or disparate treatment; (12) training to be aware of and sensitive to

Common Sense Prison Work and Victim Restitution Act of 1998 - Amends the Crime Control Act of 1990 to require convicted inmates confined in Federal prisons, jails, and other detention facilities to engage in: (1) work for no fewer than 50 hours weekly; and (2) job-training and educational and life skills preparation study. Allows nonprofit entities to utilize the services of prisoners if opportunities otherwise provided by law for inmates to work are insufficient to meet such requirements. <n>Directs the Attorney General to: (1) submit legislative recommendations to the Congress for permitting Federal prisoners to perform work for private employers while minimizing the economic impact on the private sector of this expansion of the use of prison labor; and (2) establish in the Treasury a Fund into which shall be placed all proceeds and wages from prison labor performed by inmates under the supervision of the Attorney General. Directs that such Fund be used: (1) to offset the costs of prisoner incarceration (one third); (2) for victim restitution (one third); (3) for payment into the individual prisoner's account to be paid upon his or her release (one tenth); and (4) to States and local jurisdictions that operate correctional facilities to benefit the dependents of prisoners, but only to those States that have substantially the same prison work requirements and prison conditions as established for Federal prisoners

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 9, 2013. Strengthening Background Checks Act of 2013 - Amends the NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007 to require the Attorney General to withhold 10% of a state's allocation of a grant program under the National Criminal History Improvement Program if the state fails to provide 90% of its criminal background check records to the Attorney General. Authorizes the Attorney General to waive such penalty if the state provides substantial evidence that the state is making a reasonable effort to comply with criminal background check records requirements. Requires a state to have in effect throughout the fiscal year a law that: (1) requires the state to provide to the Attorney General at least 90% of its criminal background check records, and (2) requires the state to provide the Attorney General with the records in the same manner, or in a manner substantially similar, to the manner in which such records are required to be provided. Authorizes appropriations for the grant program through FY2015.

Freedom to Fish Act - Amends the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act to prohibit any fishery management plan prepared by a Regional Fishery Management Council or the Secretary of Commerce from establishing areas closed to recreational fishing unless: (1) there is a clear indication that recreational fishermen are the cause of a specific conservation problem and that less severe conservation measures will not adequately provide for conservation and management of the affected stocks of fish; (2) the closed area regulation includes specific measurable criteria to determine the conservation benefit of the closed area on such fish and provides a timetable for periodic review of the continued need for the closed area; (3) the closed area is no larger than that which is supported by the best available scientific information; or (4) provision is made to reopen the closed area to recreational fishing whenever any such condition that was the basis of the closure no longer exists.Amends the National Marine Sanctuaries Act to direct the Secretary to provide such a Council with the opportunity to propose and revise all regulations applicable to fishing within designated marine sanctuaries according to the standards and procedures of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. Requires such regulations, upon approval by the Secretary, to apply within the exclusive economic zone and may be applied within the boundaries of a State, with the approval of the Governor

All Economic Regulations are Transparent Act of 2015 or the ALERT Act of 2015 Requires federal agency heads to submit to the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (OIRA) specified information on each rule that the agency expects to propose or finalize during the following year, including: a summary of the nature and objectives of, and the legal basis for, the rule; the stage of the rule making as of the date of submission; whether the rule is subject to review; and for any rule for which the agency expects to finalize during the following year and has issued a general notice of proposed rule making, an estimate of whether the rule will cost, the economic effects of the rule, and a statement affirming that no information on the economic effects, including the effect on the number of jobs, of the rule has been considered. Requires: (1) the OIRA to publish annually in the Federal Register, and (2) the OIRA to make such information publicly available on the Internet.

State Court Interpreter Grant Program Act - Directs the Administrator of the Office of Justice Programs of the Department of Justice to make grants to States to develop and implement programs to assist individuals with limited English proficiency to access and understand State court proceedings in which they are a party. Requires the Administrator to allocate grant funds: (1) to establish a court interpreter technical assistance program; and (2) from amounts appropriated under this Act to States that have extraordinary needs in order to develop, implement, or expand a State court interpreter program.

Prostate Cancer Diagnosis and Treatment Act of 1997 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for coverage of services for the early detection of prostate cancer and certain drug treatments for such cancer. Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish fee schedules for such services.

Medical Device User Fee Stabilization Act of 2005 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to set annual fees for premarket approval of medical devices, based on a premarket application fee of $281,600.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to use unobligated carryover balances from fees collected in previous fiscal years to ensure that sufficient fee revenues are available in that fiscal year, so long as the Secretary maintains unobligated carryover balances of not less than one month of operating reserves for the first month of FY2008.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to provide notice to specified congressional committees not later than 14 days before anticipating the use of such funds.<n><n>Authorizes appropriations in amounts equal to or greater than $205,720,000 multiplied by the adjustment factor applicable to the fiscal year.

Outer Continental Shelf Royalty Reform and Enhancement Act of 2006 - Instructs the Secretary of the Interior to place limitations based on market price on the royalty relief granted under any lease for the production of oil or natural gas entered into on or after enactment of this Act.<n><n>States that Congress reaffirms the authority of the Secretary of the Interior to vary, based on the price of production from a lease, the suspension of royalties under any lease subject to the Outer Continental Shelf Deep Water Royalty Relief Act.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to offer to enter into written agreements to amend the payment responsibilities under each lease entered into by the Secretary that: (1) authorizes the production of oil or natural gas on the Outer Continental Shelf; (2) provides for relief from the payment of royalties; and (3) does not provide for the suspension of the relief based on an increase in the price of oil or natural gas, respectively, above specified thresholds.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to provide each lessee that has entered into such a lease with a separate written offer to amend the payment responsibilities of the lessee under the lease. Requires the offer to propose imposing price thresholds beginning in the calendar year in which the offer is accepted at a level consistent with the price thresholds contained in outer Continental Shelf leases that contained price

Water Quality Conservation Act of 2017 This bill amends the Food Security Act of 1985 to authorize the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to carry out a precision conservation pilot program to provide grants to not more than 10 states to assist agricultural producers with projects that increase nutrient retention in soil, reduce soil erosion, reduce nutrient loss from soil, improve soil health, and improve water quality. To be eligible to receive a grant, a state must: collaborate with a partnership of entities, including state agencies, local governments, institutions of higher education, soil and water conservation districts, producers, Indian tribes, agricultural associations, nonprofit entities, and other relevant entities; and give priority to assisting producers with projects within critical areas. A state awarded a grant may use grant funds only to: educate and recruit agricultural producers to participate in the pilot program, provide technical and financial assistance to producers that elect to participate in a precision conservation pilot program for which the state received a grant, monitor and analyze the effectiveness of such plans, and encourage the use of precision agriculture technology to achieve conservation benefits. In the case of information furnished by a producer or state in order to facilitate the creation and implementation of a precision conservation plan, USDA, any other USDA officer or employee, or any other person may not: (1) use such information

Social Security Caregiver Credit Act of 2018 This bill amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act with respect to determining entitlement to and the amount of any monthly benefit, including any lump-sum death payment, payable under OASDI on the basis of the wages and self-employment income of any individual. Deems such an individual to have been paid a wage (according to a specified formula) during each month during which the individual was engaged for at least 80 hours in providing care to a dependent relative without monetary compensation for up to five years of such service.

Sexual Assault Prosecution Act of 2002 - Amends the Federal criminal code to provide that an indictment for certain sexual offenses may be found at any time without limitation.Requires the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to develop a plan to grant voluntary awards to States to facilitate DNA analysis of all casework evidence of unsolved crimes.Sets forth award conditions, including that: (1) each laboratory performing DNA analysis satisfies quality assurance standards and utilizes state-of-the-art DNA testing methods; and (2) each DNA sample collected and analyzed be made available only to criminal justice agencies for law enforcement purposes, in judicial proceedings if otherwise admissible, to a criminal defendant who shall have access to samples and analyses performed in connection with any case in which such defendant is charged, or to a criminal defendant who is convicted of a crime punishable by imprisonment for a term exceeding one year.

Global Autism Assistance Act of 2008 - Directs the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) to establish and administer a Global Autism Assistance Program to: (1) support activities by nongovernmental organizations and other service providers focused on treating autism in developing countries; and (2) establish the teachers' program to train health and education professionals working with children with autism in developing countries.<n><n>Requires the Administrator to: (1) designate at least two regions in developing countries that require assistance in dealing with autism and have resources for families of autism; and (2) award grants to local service providers and advocacy groups to implement the Program.

Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act of 2017 This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to categorize certain hearing aids as over-the-counter hearing aids and issue regulations regarding those hearing aids. The regulations for over-the-counter hearing aids must provide reasonable assurances of safety and efficacy and establish output limits for the hearing aids. State and local governments may not establish or continue in effect requirements for over-the-counter hearing aids that would restrict or interfere with the servicing, marketing, sale, dispensing, use, customer support, or distribution of hearing products that are not identical to FDA requirements.

Worker Ownership, Readiness and Knowledge Act or the WORK Act This bill requires the Department of Labor to establish an Office of Employee Ownership and Participation to promote employee ownership and participation in business decisionmaking. The office must head a program that encourages new and existing state programs designed to foster employee ownership and participation in business decisionmaking.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Red Cliffs Desert Reserve Completion Act (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Department of the Treasury to pay James Doyle, representing the amount to which he may be entitled, a sum of money in an amount to be determined by the U.S. Court of Federal Claims, representing the amount to which James Doyle may be entitled to compensation for any damages and losses sustained by James Doyle by reason of the federal government's acquisition of approximately 2,000 acres of his land located in the St. George area of Utah, now designated as the Red Cliffs Desert Reserve, and set aside as habitat for the Mojave desert tortoise.

Estate Tax Repeal Acceleration (ExTRA) for Family-Owned Businesses and Farms Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from a decedent's gross estate, for estate tax purposes, the adjusted value of the carryover business interests of the decedent.

Teaching Children to Save Lives Act of 2011 - Directs the Secretary of Education to award grants to local educational agencies (LEAs) or targeted schools for implementing nationally recognized cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) training courses. Authorizes grant funds to be used for: (1) training individuals in CPR and AED skills and instruction; (2) obtaining printed informational or instructional materials; (3) obtaining manikins; (4) obtaining AED training devices; and (5) obtaining other appropriate equipment. Requires a LEA or targeted school, to be eligible to use the grant to obtain an AED training device, to demonstrate to the Secretary that it has implemented or intends to implement an AED training program in conjunction with a CPR training program. Defines a targeted school" as a public elementary or secondary school that provides education to students in any of grades 6 through 12."

Amends part A (Teacher and Principal Training and Recruiting Fund) of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to require that: (1) innovative school improvement projects include training of teachers, librarians, counselors, and other instructional and pupil services personnel in gender-equitable education methods, techniques, and practices; and (2) local educational agencies (LEAs) that demonstrate a substantial difference in the participation or achievement of students by sex include descriptions of planned efforts to implement gender equity training for chapter 1 personnel.(Sec. 3) Requires such LEA grants to include the training of parents, teachers, and other instructional pupil services personnel regarding the impact of gender-role socialization on the educational needs of eligible children and the use of gender-equitable educational practices.(Sec. 4) Requires LEAs receiving chapter 1 grants to include in their applications for schoolwide programs: (1) a description of planned efforts to implement gender equity training for chapter 1 personnel; and (2) the methods used to ensure gender-equitable instruction in such programs.(Sec. 7) Requires such LEA grants to demonstrate the greatest degree of effort to promote gender equity and to incorporate gender-equitable instruction into the program.(Sec. 8) Requires such LEA grants to be used: (1) to eliminate gender bias in instruction

Renewable Energy Assistance Act of 2007 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) extend through 2016 the tax credit for residential energy efficient property; (2) repeal the dollar limitation on such credit; and (3) allow such credit against the alternative minimum tax.

Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1996 - Amends the Federal judicial code with respect to the authority of an independent counsel. <n>Directs the division of the court that appoints an independent counsel to: (1) define with specificity the independent counsel's prosecutorial jurisdiction; and (2) assure that such counsel has adequate authority to fully investigate and prosecute the alleged violations of criminal law with respect to which the Attorney General has requested the appointment and matters directly related to such criminal violations. <n>Revises provisions regarding: (1) the fees of attorneys; and (2) office space. <n>Requires the Administrator of General Services to provide appropriate office space for each independent counsel. Requires such office space to be within a Federal building unless the Administrator determines that other arrangements would cost less. <n>Directs the Comptroller General of the United States to report to the Congress with recommendations of ways to improve controls on costs of offices of independent counsel.

. The expanded summary of the Senate passed version is repeated here.) (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to make appropriate arrangements for the posthumous award, on behalf of Congress, of a gold medal to Lyndones Johnson in recognition of his contributions to the nation, including the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1965, the Social Security Amendments Act of 1965, the Higher Education Act of 1965, and the Immigration and Naturalization Act of 1965, which transformed the nation's immigration system by abolishing the racially based quota system and replacing it with a policy whose central purpose was family reunification. (Sec. 3) The medals struck pursuant to this Act shall be given to the Lyndones Johnson Library and Museum. It is the sense of Congress that the medals awarded pursuant to this Act should be made available for display elsewhere, associated with duplicates of the bronze medal struck pursuant to this Act, and sufficient to cover the cost of the gold medal.

Comprehensive Problem Gambling Act of 2011 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through the Administrator of the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, to: (1) establish and implement programs for the prevention, treatment, and research of pathological and other problem gambling; (2) carry out a national campaign to increase knowledge and raise awareness of problem gambling; (3) establish and implement a national program of research on problem gambling; (4) develop a treatment improvement protocol specific to problem gambling; and (5) integrate problem gambling into existing alcohol, tobacco, and other drug prevention programs.

Clean Distributed Energy Grid Integration Act - Directs the Secretary of Energy to: (1) carry out efforts for advancing the integration of clean distributed energy into electric grids; and (2) study and report to Congress on the status of such integration.
