Defines clean distributed energy" as energy technologies that are located on the customer site operating on the customer side of the electric meter and are interconnected with the electric grid."

Pima County Land Adjustment Act - Requires the Secretary of the Interior (the Secretary) to convey to Las Cienegas Conservation, LLC, the Sahuarita property, which consists of approximately 1,280 acres, in exchange for the Ironwood-Simonson property, which consists of approximately 2,490 acres. Requires the Secretary to modify the boundaries of the Las Cienegas National Conservation to include the Empirita-Simonson property, which consists of approximately 2,490 acres. Instructs the Secretary to convey the Tumamoc Hill property, which consists of approximately 290 acres, to Pima County, Arizona, upon the County paying the value of such property to the State of Arizona, State Land Department.

Transportation Security Technology Innovation Reform Act of 2018 (Sec. 3) This bill establishes in the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) a Transportation Security Administration Systems Integration Facility (TSIF) to test and evaluate advanced transportation security screening technologies related to the TSA's mission and development. The facility shall: evaluate such technologies to enhance the security of transportation systems through screening and threat mitigation and detection; conduct testing of such technologies to support identified TSA mission needs and to meet requirements for acquisitions and procurement; provide original equipment manufacturers with test plans to minimize requirement interpretation disputes and adhere to provided test plans; collaborate with other technical laboratories and facilities for purposes of augmentingF's capabilities; deliver advanced transportation security screening technologies that enhance the overall security of domestic transportation systems; and provide funding and promote efforts to enable participation by a small business that has an advanced technology or capability but does not have adequate resources to participate in testing and evaluation processes. The TSA shall: ensure adequate staffing and resource allocations for authorities or responsibilities in a manner that prevents unnecessary delays in testing and evaluating advanced transportation security screening technologies for acquisitions and procurement determinations; ensure the issuance of final paperwork certification does not exceed 45 days after the conclusion of such testing and evaluation; and collaborate with technology stakeholders to close capabilities gaps in transportation security. (Sec

Defense of Freedom Education Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make grants to eligible institutions to develop post-secondary education programs emphasizing the nature, history, and philosophy of free institutions and Western civilization and the nature of the threats to freedom from totalitarianism in all its forms.

Hospital Readmissions Program Accuracy and Accountability Act of 2014 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act with respect to the program for reducing avoidable hospital readmissions. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), in determining a hospital's excess readmission ratio for purposes of making payments for discharges occurring on or after October 1, 2016, to risk adjust readmissions to account for the socioeconomic status of the patients served by the hospital. Requires the Secretary to use the most recent data available from the Bureau of the Census in order to develop a quantitative method to adjust for socioeconomic status. Directs the Secretary, prior to applying an alternative adjustment method, to conduct a comparative analysis of such method and the method described in this Act and seek public comment.

Grand Jury Reform Act of 2017 This bill requires a state or local government that is eligible to receive federal funding under the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant Program to: (1) report the death of a person to the chief officer of the law enforcement agency of the locality in which the death occurs within 24 hours after such death, and (2) report the death to the state governor within 24 hours after receiving such notice. The elected prosecutor of such locality shall report the death to the governor within 24 hours after receiving such notice. The governor: (1) within three days after receiving such report, shall appoint a special prosecutor to present evidence on the state's behalf at a hearing before a judge to determine whether probable cause exists to bring criminal charges against the law enforcement officer; (2) shall use a random process to select the special prosecutor from among all of the elected prosecutors in the state, excluding the elected prosecutor of the locality in which the death occurred; and (3) shall assume exclusive control of the investigation of the death during the pendency of the probable cause hearing. The chief officer of the law enforcement agency of the locality in which the death occurred shall cooperate with the special prosecutor and the chief officer of the state law enforcement agency by responding promptly to requests for information related to the death. The hearing shall

Amends the Federal criminal code to revise provisions regarding the arrest of material witnesses. Authorizes a judicial officer to order the arrest of a person as a material witness, if it appears from an affidavit filed by a party in a criminal case before a court or by an attorney for the Government in a matter occurring before a Federal grand jury that there is probable cause to believe that: (1) the testimony of such person is material in such case or matter; and (2) the person has been served with a summons or subpoena and failed or refused to appear as required. Permits a judicial officer to waive the summons or subpoena requirement if the officer finds by clear and convincing evidence that the service of a summons or subpoena: (1) is likely to result in the person fleeing; or (2) cannot adequately secure the appearance of the person as required. Specifies the requirements for a warrant. Requires the warrant to: (1) contain the name of the material witness or, if the name of such witness is unknown, a name or description by which the witness can be identified with reasonable certainty; (2) specify that the testimony of the witness is sought in a criminal case or grand jury proceeding; (3) command that the witness be arrested and brought without unnecessary delay before a judicial officer; (4) inform the witness of the witness's

Welfare Improvement Act of 1997 - Amends title IV, part A (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) (TANF) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to prohibit States from providing additional cash benefits for children born to families receiving assistance. Declares that such prohibition shall not apply to a child born to a family receiving assistance if the family does not include any other children. Exempts from such prohibition: (1) children born to families with no other children; and (2) children born as a result of rape or incest. Makes such prohibition inapplicable to a State if State law specifically exempts the State TANF program from such prohibition. Declares that nothing in SSA title shall be construed to authorize recruitment activities, including outreach programs or demonstration projects. Declares that if an individual in a family receiving assistance under TANF refuses to engage in work required in accordance with such title, the State shall: (1) reduce the amount of assistance otherwise payable to the family pro rata (or more, at the State's option) for any period during a month in which the individual so refuses; or (2) terminate such assistance, subject to such good cause and other exceptions as the State may establish. Decreases from 50 percent to 75 percent the work participation rate

Job Creation and Affordable Housing Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to make grants to each state in an amount equal to its low-income bond-subsidized housing election amount.<n><n>Requires a state receiving such a grant to use the grant to make subawards to finance the construction or acquisition and rehabilitation of qualified low-income buildings which have received the corresponding allocation of qualified residential rental project bonds under this Act.

Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to submit to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget a strategic plan outlining the use of such incentive payments and a proposed organizational chart for the Department of Veterans Affairs once they have been completed. Authorizes the Secretary to pay a voluntary separation incentive payment to an employee only to the extent necessary to reduce or eliminate the positions and functions identified by the strategic plan. Provides for the treatment of payments. <n>Requires the Director to approve or disapprove each plan submitted and to make appropriate modifications to it with respect to the time period in which voluntary separation incentives may be paid, with respect to the number and amounts of incentive payments, or with respect to the coverage of incentives on the basis of specified factors. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to pay a voluntary separation incentive payment to an employee only to the extent necessary to reduce or eliminate the positions and functions identified by the strategic plan. Provides for the treatment of payments. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

. Cyber Supply Chain Management and Transparency Act of 2014 - Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to issue guidelines for each federal agency that require including in any contract for the acquisition of software, firmware, or product that contains a binary component: a clause that requires the inclusion of a comprehensive and confidentially supplied list, or a bill of materials, of each binary component of the software, firmware, or product that is used in it; a clause that requires the contractor providing such software, firmware, or product to verify that it does not contain any known security vulnerabilities or defects listed in the National Institute of Standards and Technology National Vulnerability Database and any additional database selected by the OMB that tracks security vulnerabilities and defects in a binary component, and that is necessary to capture a wider list of binary components with known security vulnerabilities or defects and for which a less vulnerable alternative is available; a clause that requires a contractor to submit a written application, and obtain a waiver from the agency head, for each binary component that is known to be vulnerable; such software, firmware, or product to be written or designed in a manner that allows for any future security vulnerability or defect in any part of it to be easily, updated, or replaced to fix the vulnerability or defect

Makes technical amendments to provisions concerning: (1) the rights and responsibilities of specified veterans' organizations; (2) the authority of the President to award grants and enter into cooperative agreements with such organizations; and (3) the authority of the Secretary of the Interior to provide technical assistance to such organizations.

Hazard Reporting Protection Act of 1999- Amends the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to prohibit employer reprisals against employees based on certain employee conduct concerning safe and healthy working conditions. Sets forth procedures for filing, investigating, issuing temporary and final orders providing relief, conducting hearings, obtaining judicial review of final orders, and enforcing final orders with regard to an employee's complaint of such a reprisal.

Start Healthy, Stay Healthy Act of 2005 - Amends titles XIX (Medicaid) and XXI (State Children's Health Insurance) (SCHIP) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to give States the option to expand or add coverage of certain pregnant women under Medicaid and SCHIP.

Oklahoma City Victims Compensation Act - (Sec. 4) Declares that it is the purpose of this Act to provide compensation to any individual (or relatives of a deceased individual) who was physically injured or killed as a result of the bombing of the Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, on April 19, 1995.(Sec. 5) Directs the Attorney General, acting through the Special Master, to: (1) administer the compensation program; (2) promulgate all procedural and substantive rules for the administration of this Act; and (3) employ and supervise hearing officers and other administrative personnel to perform the duties of the Special Master under this Act.(Sec. 6) Authorizes a claimant to file a claim for compensation under this Act with the Special Master. Requires the Special Master to: (1) develop a claim form that claimants shall use when submitting claims; and (2) ensure that such form can be filed electronically. Requires the Special Master to ensure that such form can be filed electronically.Requires claims to be filed within 14 days after the date on which the claim was filed or the date on which the Special Master has determined that: (1) the claimant was physically injured or killed as a result of the bombing; (2) the claimant suffered economic and noneconomic losses which are allowed as recovery under applicable State

School Security Improvement Act of 1997 - Amends the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) to require State and local educational agencies and intermediate educational units to include in the educational record of a child with a disability or a child without a disability a statement of any disciplinary measure taken against such child that results in an out-of-school suspension of more than ten days or an expulsion from school and in a case in which such child is transferred from an elementary school or secondary school to another such school, to transmit the statement with the educational record to other educational entities involved with such a transfer. <n>Authorizes the use of a long-term disciplinary measure to address the behavior of a child with a disability that is a violation of the rules or code of conduct of an educational entity, if: (1) the behavior was not a manifestation of the disability of the child; and (2) such measure applies to the child without a disability to the same extent it applies to a child without a disability who engages in the same behavior. Requires such child to continue to receive educational services in accordance with IDEA provisions unless: (1) the behavior of the child was not a manifestation of the disability; and (2) the policy of the educational entity is to cease educational services to any child determined to be engaged in

National Laboratory Technology Mat Act of 2014 - Directs the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to establish the National Laboratory technology maturation program under which the Secretary shall make grants to National Laboratories (national laboratories) for the purpose of increasing the successful transfer of technologies licensed from such laboratories to small businesses by providing a link between an innovative process or technology and a practical application with potential to be successful in commercial markets. Requires a national laboratory receiving such a grant to use the grant funds to provide vouchers to small businesses that hold a technology license from a national laboratory to pay the cost of providing assistance from scientists and engineers at the national laboratory to assist in the development of the licensed technology and further develop related products and services until the products and services are market-ready or sufficiently developed to attract private investment.

End Oil Speculation Now Act of 2011- Directs the Chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) to unilaterally establish one or more speculative position limits in any registered entity on or through which crude oil, gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, or heating oil futures or swaps are traded that: (1) are traded on a swap market, (2) are executed opposite a counterparty for which the transaction would qualify as a bona-fide hedge transaction, or (3) reduce risks attendant to the conduct and management of a commercial enterprise.

Directs the Director to establish and maintain a national clearinghouse for information on incidents of crime and terrorism committed against or directed at any animal enterprise, against or directed at any commercial activity because of the perceived impact or effect of such commercial activity on the environment, or against any person because of such person's perceived connection with or support of any such enterprise or activity.

American Democracy Index Act of 2009 - Amends the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to direct the Election Assistance Commission to: (1) develop an American Democracy Index for the evaluation of elections for federal office occurring in 2010 and thereafter; (2) establish and operate a data collection system to collect and measure election data required for the Index; and (3) make the Index available to the public, including through the Internet.

Corporate Welfare Reduction and Job Preservation Act of 2006 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code and the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to require reductions in tax benefits for profitable large corporations which reduce workforce.

Gun Victim Compensation Act - Amends the Federal criminal code to make any person who sells, delivers, or otherwise transfers a firearm or a handgun to a person who the transferor knows or has reasonable cause to believe is a juvenile liable for damages caused by a discharge of the transferred firearm. Declares that an action may be brought in a U.S. district court by, or on behalf of, any person who suffers damages resulting from bodily injury to or the death of any person caused by a discharge of the transferred firearm. Declares that there shall be no liability under this Act if it is established by a preponderance of the evidence that: (1) the damages were suffered by a person who was engaged in a criminal act against another at the time of the injury; or (2) the injury was self-inflicted, unless the plaintiff establishes that the transferor knew or had reasonable cause to believe that the transferee had not attained the age of 18 years or had been adjudicated as a mental defective or committed to a mental institution. Prohibits an action from being brought for damages that are caused more than five years after the date of the transfer of a firearm upon which an action could otherwise be based. Declares that a prevailing plaintiff shall be awarded reasonable attorney's

National Guard and Reserve Education Act of 2004 - Increases, as of October 1, 2004, the rate of basic educational assistance payable to members of the Selected Reserve: (1) who, on or after September 11, 2001, serve a period of active duty of at least 180 days of active duty pursuant to an order to serve on active duty during a five-year period (or, in the case of a member of the Army National Guard or Air National Guard, who performed full time National Guard duty for at least 180 days during a five-year period when authorized by the President or Secretary of Defense for the purpose of responding to a national emergency declared by the President and supported by Federal funds); and (2) who are entitled to retired pay. Provides a similar increase for such members who serve on or after September 11, 2001, for at least 180 days of active duty pursuant to an order to serve on active duty during a five-year period (or, in the case of a member of the Army National Guard or Air National Guard, who performed full time National Guard duty for at least 180 days during a five-year period when authorized by the President or Secretary of Defense for the purpose of responding to a national emergency declared by the President and supported by Federal funds). Authorizes, as of October 1, 2004, a

Small Business Relief and Job Creation Act This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow small business employers whose gross receipts in the preceding taxable year did not exceed $20 million or who did not employ more than 100 full-time employees a work opportunity tax credit for hiring unemployed individuals as full-time employees during 2018 or 2019. The bill defines "eligible small business" as any person if: (1) the gross receipts of such person for the preceding taxable year did not exceed $20 million, or (2) in the case of a person who does not apply, such person employed not more than 100 full-time employees during the preceding taxable year. The bill defines "eligible unemployed individual" as any individual who is certified as being eligible to receive unemployment compensation during the one-year period ending on the hiring date, or whose employment with the employer was terminated before January 1, 2018. The bill reduces the rate of such credit for employers located in counties with high unemployment rates.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 9, 2014. Stop the Sale of Murderabilia Act of 2013 - Amends the federal criminal code to prohibit: (1) an inmate of a state or federal prison convicted of a crime of violence from mailing or delivering any property, article, or object with intent that it be placed in interstate or foreign commerce; and (2) the Bureau of Prisons and the head of any state department of corrections from promulgating uniform guidelines to restrict the privileges of any inmate who violates this Act. Authorizes an inmate to mail or deliver mail to real property, title to motor vehicles, or a security if such mailing or delivery is to satisfy debt that is: (1) imposed by law or a court order, including support obligations and property taxes, income taxes, back taxes, a legal judgment, fine, or restitution, fees to cover the cost of incarceration, and other financial obligations mandated by law or a court order; or (2) incurred through a contract for legal services, a mortgage on the primary residence of the inmate's immediate family, the inmate's education or medical care, or life, health, home, or car insurance.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to implement a process to provide eligible organizations and individuals expedited access to federal lands to conduct good Samaritan search-and-recovery missions, which are searches for one or more missing individuals believed to be deceased at the time that the search is initiated. Requires such process to include provisions that clarify that: (1) an eligible organization or eligible individual granted access shall be acting for private purposes and shall not be considered a federal volunteer, (2) an eligible organization or eligible individual shall not be considered a volunteer under the Volunteers in the Parks Act of 1969, and (3) neither the Federal Torts Claim Act nor the Federal Employee Compensation Act shall apply to an eligible organization or eligible individual. Bars the Secretaries from requiring an eligible organization or eligible individual to have liability insurance as a condition of accessing federal lands under this Act if it: (1) acknowledges and consents, in writing, to these clarifying provisions; and (2) signs a waiver releasing the federal government from all liability related to the access granted.

Expresses the sense of the Congress that the abuse of Federal bankruptcy law by certain coal industry employers is damaging to the economic health of the United States, as well as to the employees who are directly harmed by such legal abuses. Declares that a covered facility of a coal industry employer that is sold by the trustee shall remain subject to the labor rights of the current and former employees of the debtor. Defines labor rights" as: (1) if the employees at a covered facility of a coal industry employer to be sold are covered under the terms of a current collective bargaining agreement or under the National Labor Relations Act; or (2) if the employees at a covered facility of a coal industry employer to be sold are represented by a labor organization but are not covered under the terms of an current collective bargaining agreement, the obligations of the debtor arising under the National Labor Relations Act. Directs the Secretary of Labor to submit a list of five disinterested individuals who are qualified and willing to serve as trustees in the case."

MMA Territorial Equity for Low-Income Individuals Act of 2004 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) with respect to the Medicare prescription drug transitional assistance program (Medigap) to: (1) apply the poverty line to residents of Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, or the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands; (2) eliminate the exclusion of such residents from premium and cost-sharing subsidies under such program; and (3) require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to request the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences to study and report on Medicare beneficiaries in the U.S. territories access to prescription drugs during each of three periods: (1) before the enactment of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003; (2) during the implementation of the discount card and transitional assistance program; and (3) after such enactment.

Volunteer First Responder Housing Act This bill makes qualified volunteer first responders eligible for: (1) the Department of Agriculture single family housing guaranteed loan program; and (2) the Department of Housing and Urban Development\\'s Good Neighbor Next Door Sales Program. A qualified volunteer first responder" is any individual who: is a bona fide volunteer performing qualified services for an eligible employer; has volunteered for not less than two continuous years for an eligible employer; during each of the two years described, met the minimum requirements for active membership established by the employer or, if the employer did not establish such requirements, volunteered for not less than 200 hours; and is certified as a firefighter or other responder in the state, local government, or Indian tribe in which the individual is serving as volunteer."

Sexual Harassment Prevention Act of 1993 - Directs employers (including Federal and congressional agencies) to keep posted in conspicuous places a notice prepared or approved by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) that sets forth: (1) the definition of sexual harassment found in the Code of Federal Regulations; (2) the fact that sexual harassment is a violation of title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964; (3) information describing how to file a complaint with the EEOC alleging such harassment; and (4) the address and toll-free number to be used to contact the EEOC. <n>Requires employers to provide annually to each employee separately a written notice that includes: (1) the matters specified in this Act to resolve allegations of sexual harassment; (2) a description of the procedures established by the employer to resolve such allegations; and (3) information specifying the responsibilities of, and the methods to be used by, such employee to ensure that immediate and corrective action is taken to address such allegations. <n>Requires employers to provide to each supervisory employee information specifying the responsibilities of, and the methods to be used by, such employee to ensure that immediate and corrective action is taken to address such allegations. <n>Prescribes civil penalties for willful violations of this Act. <n>Directs the EEOC to

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 23, 2007. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>(Sec. 2) Designates a specified portion of the project for navigation, Saco River, Maine, as an anchorage area.<n><n>(Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary of the Army to publish a supplement to the major rehabilitation report for the Herbert Hoover Dike system, approved by the Chief of Engineers in November 2000. Requires the supplemental report to include: (1) an evaluation of existing conditions at the system that are equal or greater than standard projected flood risks; (2) an identification of additional risks associated with flood events at the system that are equal or greater than standard projected flood risks; (3) an evaluation of the potential integrate at the point of beginnings of South Branch (commonly known as the Turning of Everglades) into the enhanced flood protection system for Lake Everglades (commonly known as the potential for additional water storage north of Lake Everglades); and (4) a review of the report prepared for the Comprehensive Restoration Plan dated April 2006.<n><n>Authorizes appropriations to carry out this section.<n><n>(Sec. 4) Prohibits the authorization of appropriations for a specified portion of the project known as the South Branch of the Illinois River, Illinois, which

Forest Roads-Community Right-To-Know Act - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture, with respect to National Forest System lands, and the Secretary of the Interior, with respect to Federal lands, to: (1) meet with appropriate State and local government officials at least once each fiscal year to describe all agency plans or proposals that, within the next two fiscal years, will or may result in the permanent closure of forest roads on Federal lands; (2) provide information on all forest roads that have been subject to permanent closure in that State during the previous five years, including a map and a description of the location of such roads; and (3) publish an announcement describing the proposed closure in the local newspaper of record for the area likely to be affected by such closure. Prohibits the permanent closure of a forest road until after 90 days have elapsed after such announcement was published so as to permit the public to submit comments regarding the decision to select or propose the road for permanent closure.

Declares that a specified portion of the Texas City Ship Channel, Texas City, Texas, shall not be subject to servitude beginning on the date of enactment of this Act.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of the Army to convey to the City of Texas City, Texas, all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to a specified tract of land in the City.

Medicare Common Access Card Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) to establish a pilot program that demonstrates the feasibility of using smart card technology to address Medicare fraud. Under the program, smart card technology must be issued free-of-charge to selected Medicare beneficiaries, suppliers, and providers; such technology must support the secure, electronic authentication of beneficiary identity at points of service. In selecting program participants, the CMS must consider the risk of fraud, waste, or abuse among categories of suppliers and providers. The program must be conducted for a three-year period and be conducted in at least three geographic areas.

Juvenile Justice Reform Act of 2008- Amends the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 to: (1) revise the definition of contact" with respect to the Act to include any sight or sound interaction between a juvenile in a secure custody status with an adult inmate; (2) define "juvenile justice stakeholders" to include individuals and representatives of agencies, institutions, and organizations with interest in the activities and outcomes of the juvenile justice system; (3) require state plans under such Act to include plans for providing easily accessible, community-based and operated, culturally and linguistically appropriate services to youth at-risk or in contact with the juvenile justice system; (4) require the inclusion of individuals with special experience or competence in addressing the needs of girls or implementing gender responsive services in such plans; and (5) prohibit the placement of juveniles who are awaiting trial or any other legal process in secure detention facilities."
Estate and Gift Tax Phase-Out Act of 1997 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the unified estate and gift tax credit. Repeals Federal transfer taxes.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 21, 2012. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Establishes the World War I Centennial Commission to: (1) plan, develop, and execute programs, projects, and activities to commemorate the centennial of World War I; (2) encourage private organizations and state and local governments to organize and participate in such activities; (3) facilitate and coordinate such activities throughout the United States; (4) serve as a clearinghouse for the collection and dissemination of information about centennial events and plans; and (5) develop recommendations for Congress and the President for commemorating the centennial of World War I.

Rural Law Enforcement Act of 1996 - Amends the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 to establish: (1) the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement at the University of Arkansas, at Little Rock; and (2) the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement Advisory Board. <n>Directs the Attorney General to appoint the Executive Director of the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement in consultation with the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Chancellor of the University of Arkansas at Little Rock. <n>Requires the Director to provide for the training of supervisory and executive managers of rural law enforcement in a systematic manner and through distance learning. Authorizes the Director to make grants and provide technical assistance to State and local law enforcement agencies for the training of supervisory and executive managers of such agencies through distance learning. Authorizes appropriations.

Rocky Mountain National Park Wilderness Act - Designates certain lands in Rocky Mountain National Park, Colorado, as wilderness and as a component of the National Wilderness Preservation System, to be known as the Rocky Mountain National Park Wilderness.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require that the adjusted basis of certain assets (corporate stock and tangible property that is a capital asset of property used in a trade or business) be indexed for inflation for the purpose of determining gain on the sale or other disposition by an individual of an indexed asset which has been held for more than one year. Excludes from the definition of indexed asset" any interest in property which is in the nature of a creditor\\'s interest, any collectible, any option or other right to acquire an interest in property, net lease property, and certain preferred stock."

Russian Democracy Act of 2002 - Expresses the sense of Congress that the United States should: (1) recognize that a democratic and economically stable Russian Federation is inherently less confrontational and destabilizing in its foreign policy than in its foreign interest; and (2) continue and increase assistance to the democratic forces in the Russian Federation, including the independent media, regional administrations, democratic political parties, and nongovernmental organizations.Declares it shall be U.S. policy to: (1) facilitate Russia's integration into the Western community of nations, including supporting the establishment of a stable democracy and a market economy within the framework of the rule of law and respect for individual rights; and (2) focus U.S. foreign assistance programs on using local expertise and to give local organizations a greater role in designing and implementing such programs, while maintaining appropriate oversight and monitoring.Authorizes the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development to provide assistance to the Russian Federation to strengthen and advance institutions of democratic government, of free and independent media, and of civil society, including the independent media.

Muhammad Ali Expansion Act - Amends the Professional Boxing Safety Act of 1996 to include mixed martial arts fighters within its coverage. Defines combat sport competition" as a professional fight that allows fighters to use one or more forms of martial arts, including mixed martial arts. Excludes from such definition a combat sport that allows the use of a weapon or foreign object or a competition that is regulated by an amateur sports organization."

Buy American Motor Vehicles Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a refundable tax credit for 15 percent of the purchase price of a new domestic passenger vehicle purchased in 1993 or 1994. Limits such credit to $2,000 for taxable years ending on or before December 31, 1993, and $1,000 for taxable years ending after such date.

Common Sense Campaign Reform Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for congressional campaign contributions. <n>Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to reduce the congressional campaign contribution limit and to increase the limit on contributions by persons other than multicandidate political committees. <n>Prohibits a candidate for Federal office from establishing, maintaining, financing, or controlling a political committee other than the principal campaign committee.

Provides that, except as otherwise provided in this Act, the Tribe shall: (1) be eligible to apply for and administer the special programs and services provided by the United States to Indians because of their status as Indians; and (2) be recognized as an independent tribal entity, separate from the Cherokee Nation or any other Indian tribe.

Spyware Control and Privacy Protection Act of 2000 - Requires any computer software made available to the public that includes the capability to collect information about the user of such software, the hardware on which such software is used, or the manner in which such software is used, and the capability to disclose such information to any person other than the software user, with specified exceptions, to include: (1) a clear notice that such software contains such capability; (2) a description of the information subject to collection; and (3) clear electronic instructions on how to disable such capability without affecting software performance or operation.Prohibits such capability from being enabled unless the user provides affirmative consent in advance.Treats each violations of such requirements and prohibition as an unfair or deceptive act or practice under the Federal Trade Commission Act.Authorizes a software provider to disclose such information to law enforcement officials or a court under a warrant or court order. Requires a court issuing such an order to impose appropriate safeguards on the use of such information.

This bill amends the AIDS Housing Opportunity Act to revise the formula and terms for allocations of grants to public housing agencies for housing programs for persons with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) (as under current law), as well as those with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

Medicare Advantage Participant Bill of Rights Act of 2014 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to establish limits on the removal of Medicare Advantage (MA) providers by MA organizations.

Federal Emergency Management Agency Sunset Act of 1993 - Transfers all functions, powers, and duties of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to the Secretary of Defense. <n>Provides for the transfer of FEMA personnel and assets, liabilities, contracts, property, records, and unexpended balances to the Secretary of Defense.

Developing Resources Immediately and Long-Term through Leases on Our Nation's Offshore Waters Act of 2009 or the DRILL NOW Act of 2009 - Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act (OCSLA) to revoke the President's authority to withdraw lands from disposition for exploration, development, or production of oil and gas, except as determined necessary for national security purposes. Declares that this Act shall not affect any withdrawal in effect immediately before the enactment of the DRILL NOW Act of 2009.<n><n>Authorizes the governor of a state to petition the Secretary of the Interior for authorization to conduct oil and natural gas exploration and extraction activities in any area within 50 miles of the state's coastline and within the lateral seaward boundaries of the state extended. Prohibits the Secretary from approving such a petition unless the state enacts a statute authorizing the issuance of leases for oil and natural gas in the coastal zone of the state.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to deposit into a separate account in the Treasury 30 percent of all rentals, royalties, bonus bids, and other sums due and payable to the United States from leases entered into on or after the date of enactment of this Act for natural gas exploration and extraction activities. Requires the remainder of such revenues to be

Federal Reserve Board Civil Rights Compliance Act of 1999 - Directs the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to report to Congress on its compliance with the Civil Rights Act of 1964. <n>Authorizes the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to determine that a notice to be prepared or approved by the Board setting forth the pertinent provisions of title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and information pertinent to the rights and procedures applicable under such Acts to employees of, and applicants for employment, the Board.

Neighborhood Security Act of 2003 - Authorizes the Attorney General, through the Office of Justice Programs, to award one or more grants eligible entities to develop and improve Neighborhood Watch throughout the Nation.Requires such grants to be used to: (1) complete a survey of Neighborhood that identifies such programs by ZIP code; (2) establish a national registry of Neighborhood Watch leaders, with appropriate contact information; (3) identify best practices and model programs among Neighborhood Watch for educating community members about the prevention of terrorism and crime, preventing or assisting with the prevention of terrorism and crime, and achieving broad community involvement activities; (4) create a manual for communities seeking to establish, establish, or improve an existing Neighborhood Watch; and (5) engage in outreach and respond to inquiries about, and disseminate information about, effective Neighborhood Watch.Requires a grantee to provide a Neighborhood start-up kit (a material useful for a Neighborhood Watch) which includes material useful for a Neighborhood Watch.

Heart Disease Education, Analysis, Research, and Treatment for Women Act or the HEART for Women Act - (Sec. 2) Directs to the Comptroller General to study and report to specified congressional committees on the extent to which sponsors of clinical studies of investigational drugs, biologics, and devices and sponsors of applications for approval or licensure of new drugs, biologics, and devices comply with Food and Drug Administration (FDA) requirements and follow guidance for presentation of clinical study safety and effectiveness data by sex, age, and racial subgroups. Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to submit to such committees a response to the the Comptroller General's report, including a corrective action plan as needed to respond to the recommendations in such report. Requires biennial reports by: (1) the Office of Women's Health of the FDA to such committees, and (2) the FDA Director of the Office of Minority Health of the FDA to such committees, with respect to women's health. (Sec. 3) Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary to report to Congress on the quality of, and access to, care for women with heart disease, stroke, and other cardiovascular diseases, including recommendations for eliminating disparities in, and improving the treatment of, heart disease, stroke, and

United States Buffalo Nickel Act of 1997 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to issue five-cent coins based on the original five-cent coin designed by James Earle Fraser in 1913 to 1938. Declares that the design for the coins shall be: (1) selected by the Secretary after consultation with specified congressional committees; and (2) reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. Declares that only one facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular combination of denomination and quality of the coins. Terminates the authority to mint such coins after December 31, 2000. Provides for coin sale surcharges, which shall be paid to the National Museum of the American Indian for the tenth anniversary of its establishment.

National Women's Rights History Project Act of 2005- Amends the Act that established the Women's Rights National Historical Park in Seneca Falls and Waterloo, New York, to direct the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of National Park Service, to designate a vehicular tour route, privately known as the Votes for Women History Trail Route, to link properties in New York that are historically and exhibits associated with the struggle for women's suffrage in the United States.

Education Savings Account and School Excellence Act of 1999- Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to education individual retirement accounts (IRAs), to: (1) permit distributions for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses; (2) increase the annual contribution limit from $500 to $2,000; (3) waive the beneficiary age limitation (18) for contributions on behalf of special needs beneficiaries; (4) permit corporations to contribute to education IRAs; (5) permit annual contributions to be made until the filing date (not including extensions) for a tax year; (6) extend the time for return of excess contributions; and (7) provide for coordination with Hope and lifetime learning credit and qualified tuition program provisions.

Restoring the Partnership for County Health Care Costs Act of 2015 This bill amends titles XVIII (Medicare), XIX (Medicaid), and XXI (Children's Health Insurance Program) (CHIP) of the Social Security Act to allow benefits under those titles for persons in custody in a public institution pending disposition of charges. Benefits under these titles shall be withheld until the individual is no longer either in custody pending disposition of charges or an inmate of a public institution, or shall be paid to the individual's estate if the individual dies before the pending charges are disposed of or while the individual is an inmate of a public institution.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on November 14, 2016. Patient Access and Medicare Protection Act (Sec. 2) This bill prohibits the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) from using information on the payment determined under the competitive acquisition programs under title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to adjust the payment amount that would otherwise be recognized for wheelchair accessories (including seating systems) and seat and back episodic when furnished in connection with Group 3 complex rehabilitative power wheelchairs. The Government Accountability Office must study such accessories and seat and back and report on: (1) the item descriptions and associated HCPCS codes for such accessories and seat and back; (2) a breakdown of utilization and expenditures for such accessories and seat and back under Medicare; (3) a comparison of the payment amount under the competitive acquisition program with the payment amount that would otherwise be recognized; and (4) the aggregate distribution of such accessories and seat and back furnished within specified groups of providers. The bill also requires the CMS to report on an alternative payment model for Medicare payment of radiation therapy services furnished in nonfacation settings. (Sec. 4) The bill postpones from January 1, 2017, to January 1, 2018, the requirement that: (1) the fee schedule for radiation therapy services furnished in 2016 include

Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require a telecommunications carrier that receives or obtains customer proprietary network information by virtue of its provision of a telecommunications service to use, disclose, or permit access to such information that identifies a customer as: (1) in the provision of the telecommunications service from which such information is derived and services necessary to, or used in, the provision of such telecommunications service, including the publishing of directories; and (2) in the case of the use of such information by the telecommunications carrier for the provision of another of its products or services to the customer, only if such carrier provides the customer a clear and conspicuous notice, meeting specified requirements, of such use and permits the customer to review such information for accuracy and to correct and supplement such information and does not receive such notice within 15 days. Requires the same requirements in the case of the use, disclosure, or access of or to such information by another party only if the carrier that originally receives or obtains such information: (1) meets such requirements with respect to such information; and (2) receives from the customer written notice approving such use, disclosure, or access of or to such information for the provision of the product or service to the customer. Requires a telecommunications carrier to terminate the use, disclosure

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on September 6, 2017. Internet of Things Consumer Tips to Improve Personal Security Act of 2017 or the IOT Consumer TIPS Act of 2017 (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to coordinate with the National Institute of Standards and Technology and relevant private sector stakeholders and experts to develop, submit to the FTC, and make publicly available voluntary educational resources for consumers relating to the protection and use of Internet of Things (IoT) devices, including best practices and advice to protect against cybersecurity threats or security vulnerabilities. The resources shall be technology-neutral, and shall include best practices and advice for consumers to protect against, mitigate against, and recover from cybersecurity threats or security vulnerabilities. The resources shall be available for voluntary use by consumers. The FTC may not base an enforcement action on the failure to promote or use the resources, unless the practice allegedly violates a consent order. The Department of Justice may bring a civil action to enforce the requirements of this bill.

Railroad Right-of-Way Conveyance Validation Act - Authorizes the conveyance of certain lands in Nevada County, California, by the Southern Pacific Transportation Company to the Central Pacific Railway Company.

Brownfields Use Invigoration Land Development Act - Amends the Small Business Act to authorize the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) to make grants to eligible entities to enable them to participate in the redevelopment of remediated sites. Defines remediated site" as any real property with respect to which requirements under federal or state law for remediation of hazardous substances, pollutants, and contaminants have been completed. Authorizes such grants to be used only: (1) for the development of plans for the reuse of a remediated site; or (2) to perform marketing analyses with respect to such a site. Sets forth selection criteria, including consideration of the ability of the entity to develop plans for the reuse of the remediated site and to perform marketing analyses."

Infant and Care Improvement Act - Amends the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award high-quality infant and toddler care program grants to states and, through them, subgrants to family child care providers who provide care to infants or toddlers. Defines "high-quality infant and toddler care program" as providing care to an infant or toddler with a developmental delay or disability more than one infant or toddler with a developmental delay or disability and to limited English proficient.

Border Health Security Act of 2013 - Amends the United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act to revise the duties of the United States-Mexico Border Health Commission to include: (1) cooperating with the Canada-United States Pan Border Public Health Preparedness Council, and (2) serving as an independent and objective body to both recommend and implement initiatives that solve border health issues. Authorizes members of the Commission and the Council to provide advice or recommendations to the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), Congress, or any Member of Congress concerning issues that are considered by the Commission or Council. Directs the Secretary to award grants to eligible entities to improve the health of the United States-Mexico and the United States-Canada border areas.

Give Judge Venckiene the Court Act This bill directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to arrange for the return to the United States of Judge Venckiene from Lithuania.

Indian Tribal Development Corporation Feasibility Study Act of 2004 - Amends the Native American Business Development, Trade Promotion, and Tourism Act of 2000 to direct the Secretary of the Interior to establish the Tribal Development Corporation Feasibility Study Group to determine the feasibility of establishing an Indian Tribal Development Corporation.

Servicemembers Access to Justice Act of 2012 - Waives a state's sovereign immunity with respect to the enforcement of the employment and reemployment rights of members of the Armed Forces under the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 (USERRA). Declares that a state's receipt or use of federal financial assistance for any program or activity of a state shall constitute a waiver of sovereign immunity, under the 11th amendment to the Constitution or otherwise, to a suit brought by: (1) a person who is or was an employee in that program or activity for the rights or benefits authorized the person by USERRA; (2) a person applying to be such an employee in that program or activity for such rights or benefits; or (3) a person seeking reemployment as an employee in that program or activity for such rights or benefits.<n><n>Makes unenforceable agreements between an employer and employee requiring arbitration of disputes arising under USERRA. Provides an exception when the parties involved knowingly and voluntarily agree to arbitration. Requires the validity and enforceability of such an agreement to be determined by a court rather than an arbitrator.

Lake Erie Western Basin International Wildlife Refuge Establishment Act - Establishes the Lake Erie Western Basin International Wildlife Refuge (Refuge) which shall consist of specified lands and waters in Ohio and Michigan.Requires the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, to: (1) conduct a study of fish and wildlife habitat and aquatic and terrestrial communities in and around two specified dredge spoil disposal sites in Toledo Harbor; and (2) submit a report containing the results to Congress.Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) use available authority for the conservation of fish and wildlife and for provision of fish and wildlife dependent recreational opportunities in the Refuge; and (2) ensure that compatible hunting, fishing, wildlife observation and photography, and environmental education and interpretation are the priority public uses of the Refuge.

Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to make a group health plan, or a health insurance issuer offering health insurance coverage in connection with the plan, jointly and severally liable for damages to any participant or beneficiary aggrieved by the plan's or issuer's failure to provide benefits under managed care as a result of clinically or medically inappropriate decisions or determinations resulting from: (1) the application of any cost containment technique, any utilization review directed at cost containment, or any other medical care delivery policy decision which restricts the ability of providers of medical care from utilizing their full discretion for treatment of patients; or (2) any other medical care delivery policy decision which restricts the ability of such providers to utilize their full discretion for treatment of patients. Allows punitive damages to be awarded in such cases.

Railroad Hours of Service Act of 2010 - (Sec. 2) Amends Federal transportation law to revise the definition of railroad employee" to include: (1) yardmaster employee; and (2) train employee. Declares the purpose of railroad employees covered by this Act to be to be provided predictable and defined work and rest periods. (Sec. 4) Defines "yardmaster employee" as an employee who supervises and coordinates the activities of workers engaged in railroad traffic operations, including making up or breaking up trains and switching inbound or outbound traffic. (Sec. 5) Revises the definition of "train employee" to include: (1) employees operating motor vehicles requiring a commercial driver\\'s license while on duty; and (2) all work where there is a potential to interact or otherwise come into contact with safety-critical devices or circuits. (Sec. 7) Requires: (1) a train employee to be notified before going off duty whether such period off duty is an interim release; and (2) time on duty to include all work where there is a potential to interact or otherwise come into contact with safety-critical devices or circuits. Directs the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) to prescribe regulations to require all deadhead transportation in excess of a specific number of hours to be counted as time on duty and"

Uranium Mining Modernization Act - Amends Federal law to permanently withdraw all Federal lands from location and entry for uranium mining. <n>Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to: (1) divide any Federal lands that are not withdrawn from mineral leasing and that are otherwise available for uranium leasing under applicable law into leasing tracts of such size as the Secretary finds appropriate and in the public interest; and (2) offer such lands for uranium leasing and award uranium leases thereon by competitive bidding. <n>Prohibits any bid for a uranium lease from being accepted that is less than the fair market value of the uranium subject to the lease. <n>Directs the Secretary, before issuing any uranium lease, to consider effects that mining under the proposed lease might have on an impacted community or area, including impacts on the environment, on agricultural, on cultural resources, and other economic activities, and on public services. <n>Prohibits lease sales from being held for lands until after a notice of the proposed offering for lease has been given once a week for three consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the county in which the lands are situated, or in electronic format, in accordance with regulations prescribed by the Secretary. <n>Requires all lands to be leased to the highest responsible qualified bidder under

Veterans Back and Spinal Therapy Act - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to establish a pilot program to provide veterans with non-invasive techniques to treat spinal, back, and musculoskeletal injuries and pain. Requires such program to assess the effectiveness of such techniques.

Amends the Federal criminal code to authorize Federal Prison Industries (FPI) to sell excess property on the open market at the best available price and to deposit the proceeds in the Treasury to the credit of the Prison Industries Fund. <n>(Sec. 2) Requires FPI to determine the character of and necessity for its obligations and expenditures and the manner in which they shall be incurred, allowed, and paid, subject to laws specifically applicable to government corporations. <n>(Sec. 3) Requires FPI to determine in what manner and to what extent industrial operations shall be carried on in Federal penal and correctional institutions for the production of commodities and services and to conform to design, quality, and testing standards of the Federal Government and the relevant private industry. <n>(Sec. 4) Authorizes FPI to: (1) produce or provide for sale on the open market processes, products, and services that would otherwise be produced by foreign labor at offshore locations; (2) enter into agreements with private industry to carry out this section; (3) certify that processes, products, or services undertaken are labor-intensive and limited to levels that replace goods and services produced by offshore labor; and (4) provide to FPI the maximum practicable opportunity to participate as a subcontractor in labor-intensive, light manufacturing segments of contracts

Authorizes the Court of Veterans Appeals to provide funds to nonprofit organizations for programs to ensure that financially needy veterans: (1) receive legal assistance without charge; (2) have case screening and referral services; (3) train attorneys and legal personnel; and (4) encourage and facilitate pro bono representation by attorneys and such programs and organizations.

Federal Entrepreneur-in-Residence Act of 2012 - Directs the Director of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to establish an entrepreneur-in-residence program to appoint in-house entrepreneurs who have demonstrated success in working with small businesses and entrepreneurs to: (1) assist federal agencies in improving outreach to small businesses and entrepreneurs, (2) provide recommendations on inefficient or duplicative agency programs and on methods to improve agency efficiency, (3) facilitate meetings and forums to educate small businesses and entrepreneurs on agency programs and initiatives, and (4) provide technical assistance or mentorship. Limits to 10 the number of entrepreneurs-in-residence that the Director may appoint in any year.<n><n>Authorizes the Director to establish an informal working group to allow entrepreneurs-in-residence to meet to discuss best practices, experiences, and recommendations in order to create an informal knowledge base for current and future entrepreneurs-in-residence.<n><n>Terminates such program after September 30, 2016.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on June 17, 2015. School-Based Asthma Management Program Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), when awarding grants to states under the children's asthma treatment grants program, to give additional preference to states that require public elementary and secondary schools to: (1) permit trained personnel of the school to administer epinephrine to any student reasonably believed to be having an anaphylactic reaction, (2) maintain a supply of epinephrine in a secure location that is easily accessible to trained personnel for administration to any student reasonably believed to have an anaphylactic reaction, (3) permit trained personnel of the school to administer asthma-related rescue medication to any student reasonably believed to have an asthma diagnosis, (4) maintain a supply of asthma-related rescue medication and modes of delivery, such as spacers or nebulizers, in a secure location that is easily accessible to trained personnel for administration to any student reasonably believed to have an asthma diagnosis, and (5) have in place a program that includes a comprehensive school-based asthma management program and a system to support students with a diagnosis of asthma through coordination with family members, primary care providers, and others.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for the production and use of renewable liquid fuels. Defines renewable liquid fuel" as liquid hydrocarbons derived from waste and byproduct streams, including agricultural byproducts and wastes, aqua-culture products produced from waste streams, food processing plant byproducts, municipal solid and semi-solid waste streams, industrial waste streams, automotive scrap waste streams, and as further provided by regulations. Terminates such credit after 2010."

Diesel Tax Fairness Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to reduce the excise tax on diesel fuel and kerosene from the date of enactment of this Act until December 31, 2010. Provides for adjustments to such tax for floor stocks.

Amends the International Development Association Act to authorize the U.S. Governor of the Association to contribute on behalf of the United States an amount equal to the amount appropriated pursuant to the resolution entitled Additions to IDA Resources: Thirteenth Replenishment."Amends the International Financial Institutions Act to direct the Secretary of the Treasury to instruct the U.S. Executive Director at each multilateral development institution to inform such institution of certain U.S. policy goals and to work toward achieving such goals before June 30, 2005.Amends the Asian Development Bank Act to authorize the Secretary to make specified contributions to the Asian Development Fund.Amends the International Financial Institutions Act to direct the Secretary to instruct the U.S. Executive Director at each multilateral development institution to publish on the website of the Department of the Treasury any written statement presented at a meeting of the Board of Directors of the institution concerning: (1) a project on which a claim has been made to the inspection mechanism of the institution; or (2) a pending inspection mechanism case."

Environmental Risk Evaluation Act of 1995 - Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to identify, take into account, and report on the sources of pollution with respect to the relative degree of risk of adverse effects on human health, the environment, and public welfare, and to rank sources of pollution considering the extent and duration of the risk, taking into account broad societal values and the role of natural resources in sustaining economic activity into the future. Requires the Administrator, in evaluating such risks and costs, to: (1) identify the major uncertainties associated with the risks; and (2) determine the type and nature of research that would likely reduce the uncertainties and the cost of conducting research.

Metropolitan Washington Airports Act Amendments of 1995 - Amends the Metropolitan Washington Airports Act of 1986 to revise requirements with respect to the appointment of members of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority. <n>(Sec. 3) Increases the number of board members. Requires seven votes to approve bond issues and the annual budget. <n>Prohibits the board from taking a proposed action which could result in a change in the impact of aircraft noise in the vicinity of a Metropolitan Washington Airport unless the board notifies, in writing, the Committee on Noise Abatement at National and Dulles Airports of the Washington Council of Governments of the action and submits: (1) the opportunity to review and submit comments on the action; and (2) a response to any comment of such committee within 30 days after receipt of such comment. <n>Directs the Governors of Virginia and Maryland to appoint to the board members, with the Mayor of the District of Columbia appointed by the Governor. <n>Sets forth requirements for initial and initial appointments.

Directs the Assistant Secretary for Educational Research and Improvement to submit to the Senate Committee on Appropriations a spending plan for activities funded through the Office of Educational Research and Improvement for each fiscal year, prior to the obligation of any funds for the fiscal year.<n><n>Grants the National Assessment Governing Board (Board) exclusive authority over all policies, direction, and guidelines for establishing and implementing voluntary national tests for fourth grade English reading and eightth grade mathematics. Provides that such tests shall be made available to a State, local educational agency, or private or parochial school, upon request of the State, agency, or school, and their use shall not be a condition for receiving any Federal funds.<n><n>Sets forth Board duties.<n><n>Prohibits a State or local educational agency from requiring any private or parochial school student, or home-schooled individual, to take any test developed under this Act without the student's written consent.<n><n>Amends the National Education Statistics Act of 1994 to revise requirements for Board membership and terms of office.

National Strategic and Critical Minerals Production Act of 2012- Defines strategic and critical minerals" as minerals that are necessary: (1) for national defense and national security requirements; (2) for the nation\\'s energy infrastructure, including pipelines, refining capacity, electrical power generation and transmission, and renewable energy production; (3) to support domestic manufacturing, agriculture, housing, telecommunications, health care, and transportation infrastructure; and (4) for the nation\\'s economic security and balance of trade.<n><n>Considers domestic mines that will provide strategic and critical minerals to be an "infrastructure project" as described in Presidential Order "Improving Performance of Federal Permitting and Review of Infrastructure Projects" dated March 22, 2012.<n><n>Requires the lead agency with responsibility for issuing a mineral exploration or mine permit to appoint a project lead who shall coordinate and consult with other agencies, cooperating agencies, project proponents, and contractors to ensure that agencies minimize delays, set and adhere to timelines and schedules for completion of reviews, set clear permitting goals, and track progress against those goals. Directs the lead agency to determine any such action would not constitute a major federal action significantly affecting the quality of the human environment within the meaning of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 if the procedural and substantive safeguards of the lead agency\\'s permitting process"

Aviation Industry Stabilization Act of 2003 - Amends Federal aviation law to direct the Secretary of Transportation to insure domestic and foreign air carriers through December 31, 2007.Extends through December 31, 2003, the authority of the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Board to issue loan guarantees and lines of credit to air carriers for aviation fuel costs in the event of an extraordinary increase in jet fuel prices.Authorizes application for Federal credit instruments authorized under the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act to be filed for a period of 30 days following the date on which the President authorizes the military to use force against the Republic of Iraq in 2003.States that a Federal credit instrument issued by the Board shall: (1) be for the purpose of allowing an air carrier to secure financial obligations to pay for its aviation fuel purchases for a period of six months or the period that begins on the date the Board determines that an extraordinary increase in jet fuel prices has occurred and ends on the date the Secretary determines that the average price for jet fuel in calendar year 2003 is equal to or less than the average price reported by major air carriers for calendar year 2002; and (2) be for the actual increased aviation fuel cost incurred by the air carrier or a reasonable estimate of such cost over the average price of commercial aviation fuel reported to the Secretary of Transportation by

Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out a program under which the Secretary may enter into not more than five partnership agreements with specified entities to conduct one or more major construction projects: (1) super construction projects; (2) major medical facility projects; or (3) major construction projects to construct new cemeteries or to develop additional gravesites or columbarium niches at existing cemeteries. Prohibits such authority from being carried out notwithstanding any other provision of law, except for: (1) federal laws relating to environmental and historic preservation; and (2) the Davis-Bacon Act. Specifies the projects that the Secretary may select for the program, including one for which Congress has appropriated partial funding or the VA has identified a need through its long-range capital planning process by listing the project on the Major Construction Strategic Capital Investment Planning priority list included in the budget submitted by the President. Sets forth the requirements for partnership agreements, including requiring the entity to: (1) conduct any necessary environmental and historic preservation due diligence; (2) conduct any necessary environmental and historic preservation due diligence, comply with local zoning requirements (except for studies and consultations required of the VA under federal law), and obtain any permits required before beginning construction; (3) establish a Board of Directors to oversee the conduct of the project; and (4) contribute funds

Tobacco Program Administrative Reform Act of 1998 - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to estimate annually the costs to be incurred by the Department of Agriculture during the next fiscal year to: (1) administer the tobacco quota program under the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938; (2) administer the tobacco price support program; (3) carry out tobacco crop insurance programs; and (4) extend services related to tobacco production and marketing. Identifies the costs to be incurred by each tobacco product manufacturer and tobacco product importer. Establishes in the Treasury the Tobacco Assessment Fund.

Amends the Delaware and Lehigh National Heritage Corridor Act of 1988 to rename the Delaware and Lehigh National Heritage Corridor as the Delaware and Lehigh Conservation and Natural Resources Corridor. Designates the Delaware and Lehigh Heritage Corporation as the local management entity for the Corridor.Directs the Secretary of the Interior to conduct a special resource study of sites and associated landscape features within the boundaries of the Corridor that contribute to the understanding of the Corridor's national significance. Requires the study to review the resources of the greater anthracite region of Pennsylvania covered by other designated national heritage areas.Directs the Secretary to enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Corporation to assure appropriate transition of the local management to the Corporation and coordination with the Corporation regarding the implementation of the management action plan.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 16, 2015. Hurricane Sand Dunes National Recreation Area Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) Establishes the Hurricane Sand Dunes National Recreation Area in Utah to provide for: (1) the enhancement of recreational uses, and (2) the use of off-highway vehicles. (Sec. 4) Directs the Department of the Interior to convey to Utah all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to specified Bureau of Land Management land in Washington County, Utah, in exchange for specified nonfederal land in the state. Requires the value of the federal and nonfederal lands exchanged to be equal or to be made equal.

Arsenic-Treated Wood Mandatory Labeling Act - Amends the Agricultural Marketing of 1946 to require each piece of arsenic-treated wood offered for sale in the United States to have affixed to it a consumer warning label that displays the following statements: (1) This piece of wood has been treated with arsenic; (2) this wood mishandling can cause cancer; (3) doing so will release arsenic into the air; (4) producers must wear coveralls and face masks when working with arsenic; and (5) coveralls and face masks when working with arsenic.Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to report to Congress on: (1) the status of any ongoing review by EPA of the health risks associated with exposure to arsenic; and (2) recommendations for interim guidelines.

Meat and Poultry Products Safety Improvement Act of 2002- Amends the Federal Meat Inspection Act and the Poultry Products Inspection Act to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to prescribe performance standards for the reduction of microbiological pathogens in meat and meat products and poultry and poultry products, respectively. Grants the Secretary authority to enforce such standards in effect on January 1, 2000.(Sec. 3) Amends the Federal Meat Inspection Act to direct the Secretary to prescribe regulations to require that cattle, sheep, swine, goats, horses, mules and other equines presented for slaughter for human food be identified in the manner prescribed by the Secretary to enable the Secretary to trace each animal to any premises at which the animal has been held for such period prior to slaughter. Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) prohibit or restrict entry to a slaughtering establishment of any cattle, sheep, swine, goats, horses, mules or other equines not identified; and (2) require that each person, firm, or corporation required to identify livestock maintain accurate records regarding the purchase, sale, and identification of such livestock. Prohibits the alteration, destruction, or misrepresentation of such records.(Sec. 4) Establishes civil penalties for violations of this Act.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2016. Broadband Conduit Deployment Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Department of Transportation (DOT) to require states to evaluate the need to install broadband conduit in any project to construct a new highway or additional lane or paved shoulder for an existing highway that is begun after the enactment of this Act and that receives funding under the federal-aid highway program. "broadband conduit" means a conduit for fiber optic cables that support broadband or, where appropriate, wireless facilities for broadband service. DOT shall: (1) ensure that such conduit is installed to accommodate multiple broadband providers along the highway; and (2) ensure that each conduit includes a pull tape and is capable of supporting fiber optic cable placement techniques. DOT shall ensure that each conduit is placed at a depth consistent with industry best practices and that, in determining the depth of placement, consideration is given to the location of existing utilities and the cable separation requirements of state and local electrical codes. DOT shall ensure that any requesting broadband provider has access to each conduit installed, on a competitively neutral and nondiscriminatory basis, for a charge not to exceed a cost-based rate.
