National Forest Good Neighbor Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Cooperative Forestry Assistance Act of 1978 to authorize the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to enter into a good neighbor agreement with a state governor to carry out forest, rangeland, and watershed restoration services on National Forest System (NFS) land. A good neighbor agreement" is a cooperative agreement or contract entered into between USDA and a state governor to carry out authorized restoration services. Such services may be carried out on NFS land except: (1) a component of the National Wilderness Preservation System, (2) federal land on which the removal of vegetation is prohibited or restricted by a law or presidential proclamation, or (3) a wilderness study area. A "forest, rangeland, and watershed restoration services" is an activity to treat insect- or disease-infected trees, reduce hazardous fuels, and restore or improve forest, rangeland, and watershed health, including fish and wildlife habitat. Such services shall not include the construction, reconstruction, repair, or restoration of a paved or permanent road or parking area or the construction, alteration, repair, or replacement of a public building or work."

Housing Assistance Authorization Act of 2007- Authorizes the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to provide financial assistance to the Housing Assistance Council (the Council) to develop the ability and capacity of community-based housing development organizations to undertake community development and affordable housing projects and programs in rural areas. Includes among such activities: (1) technical assistance, training, support, and advice to develop the business and administrative capabilities of rural community-based housing development organizations; and (2) loans, grants, or other financial assistance to such organizations to carry out such activities for low- and moderate-income families.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to make a grant to the Raza Development Fund (the Fund) to provide technical and financial assistance to local nonprofit organizations to undertake community development and affordable housing projects and programs serving low- and moderate-income households, particularly through organizations located in neighborhoods with substantial populations of income-disadvantaged households of Hispanic origin.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to make a grant to the Housing Partnership Network (the Network) to create, sustain, and improve access to affordable housing and community facilities that benefit very low- and moderate-income households and communities. Includes among such activities: (1) making investments, loans, and grants to its member nonprofits that demonstrate expertise in using such

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 10, 2012. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Strengthening and Focusing Enforcement to Deter Organized Stealing and Enhance Safety Act of 2012 or the SAFE DOSES Act - Amends the federal criminal code to prohibit: (1) the embezzlement, stealing, or by fraud or deception obtains, or knowingly and unlawfully takes, carries away, or conceals, a pre-retail medical product; (2) knowingly and falsely makes, alters, forges, or counterfeits the labeling or documentation of such a product; (3) knowingly possesses, transports, or traffics in such a product that was involved in a violation of this Act; (4) with intent to defraud, buy, or otherwise obtains, a product that has expired or been stolen; or (5) attempting or conspiring to violate this Act. Imposes criminal and civil penalties for violations.<n><n>Defines a pre-retail medical product" as a drug, biological product, device, medical food, or infant formula that has not yet been made available for retail purchase by a consumer."

IP-Enabled Voice Communications and Public Safety Act of 2007 - Amends the IP-Enabled Voice Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999 to require IP-enabled voice service providers to provide 9-1-1 service, including enhanced 9-1-1 service, to their subscribers. Requires the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to issue regulations granting such providers access to 9-1-1 components that are necessary to provide 9-1-1 service, on the same rates, terms, and conditions that are provided to commercial mobile service providers. Requires the FCC to require such providers to register with it and establish a point of contact for public safety and government officials relative to 9-1-1 service and access. Allows the FCC to delegate enforcement authority to state commissions or other state agencies or programs with jurisdiction over emergency communications.<n><n>Provides that nothing in this Act shall be construed as repealing or otherwise altering, modifying, affecting, or superseding federal regulations obligating an IP-enabled voice service provider to provide 9-1-1 service or enhanced 9-1-1 service. Authorizes the FCC to require any provider of a voice service that is a substitute for telephone exchange service (as defined in the Communications Act of 1934) to provide 9-1-1 service, including enhanced 9-1-1 service, to its subscribers.

Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2003- Amends the Temporary Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2002 (TEUCA, which is title II of the Job Creation and Worker Assistance Act of 2002, PL107-147) to: (1) provide for additional weeks of TEUC and TEUC-X benefits; (2) repeal certain restrictions on transfers from the general fund of the Treasury to individual TEUC accounts; (3) extend the TEUC-X transition period; and (4) extend the TEUC-X benefit period through December 31, 2003.

Commission on Retirement Income Policy Act of 1993 - Establishes the Commission on Retirement Income Policy to review and study: (1) trends in retirement savings in the United States; (2) existing Federal incentives and programs established to encourage and protect such savings; and (3) new Federal incentives and programs needed to encourage and protect such savings. Declares that a Commission recommendation for a new Federal incentive or program that would result in an increase in the Federal budget deficit shall not appear in the report required under this Act unless it is accompanied by a recommendation for offsetting the increase.

Personal Health Investment Today Act of 2009 or the PHIT Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a medical care tax deduction for up to $1,000 ($2,000 for a joint return or a head of household) of qualified sports and fitness expenses. Defines qualified sports and fitness expenses" as amounts paid for fitness center memberships, physical exercise programs, and exercise equipment."

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 16, 2011. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Trade Secrets Protection Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to prohibit the issuance of a summons and the Secretary of the Treasury from beginning any action to enforce any summons to enforce any summons, to produce or examine any computer software source code or related customer communications, and training materials. Excepts where information not otherwise available to verify correctness of an item on a return is unable to otherwise ascertain with reasonable accuracy the correctness of any item on a return after employing auditing procedures and practices otherwise used pursuant to the Code, the Secretary identifies with reasonable specificity a portion, item, or component of such code needed to verify the correctness of such item on the return, and the Secretary demonstrates that with respect to the issue under examination need for the portion, item, or component of the software source code requested outweighs the burdens of production imposed on the summoned person and the risks of disclosure of trade secrets. Exempts: (1) inquiry into the administration or enforcement of internal revenue laws and computer software for internal use not for commercial purposes; and (2) any computer software developed by the taxpayer or a related person for internal use not for commercial purposes. Requires any person to whom

Southern New Mexico and El Paso, Texas, Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Care Improvement Act of 2011 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to report on the feasibility and advisability of establishing a polytrauma rehabilitation center or polytrauma network site of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) in the southern New Mexico and El Paso, Texas, region, which shall be within a reasonable driving distance of Fort Bliss, White Sands Missile Range, and Holloman Air Force Base.

Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture Act This bill establishes the Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture. The commission shall report to the President and Congress on: its recommendations for a plan of action for the establishment and maintenance of a National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture in Washington, DC; the availability and cost of collections to be acquired and housed in the museum; the impact of the museum on regional Asian Pacific American history-related museums; potential locations for the museum in Washington, DC, and its environs; the governance and organizational structure from which the museum should operate; and best practices for engaging Asian Pacific Americans in the development and design of the museum. The commission shall: (1) develop and submit to Congress a fundraising plan to support the museum through public contributions, and (2) obtain an independent review of the viability of such plan. The commission may host a national conference on the museum for individuals who are committed to the advancement of Asian Pacific American history, art, political or economic status, or culture.

Enhancing Safety in Medicine Utilizing Leading Advanced Simulation Technologies to Improve Outcomes Now Act of 2007 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to: (1) conduct and support research, evaluations, initiatives, and demonstration projects, and provide grants or enter into contracts or cooperative agreements, to enhance the deployment of medical simulation technologies and the incorporation of such technologies and equipment into medical, nursing, allied health, podiatric, osteopathic, and dental education and training protocols; and (2) establish medical simulation centers of excellence to provide leadership and conduct research with respect to enhancing and expanding the utilization of medical simulation technologies and simulation-based skills training for physicians, nurses, allied health professionals, and qualified students. Requires each center to: (1) provide leadership in a specific area of medical simulation technology or knowledge; (2) enhance and expand the knowledge base within the specific area of medical simulation technology or knowledge in line with the program requirements and the long-term interests of the medical simulation community; and (3) serve as a resource center to interested health professional schools and individuals who want to learn about medical simulation. Requires the Director to: (1) promote innovation in medical simulation technologies and encourage development and deployment of challenging and complex medical simulation technologies and applications; (2) award grants

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) increase the rate of the tax deduction for certain dividends received by a U.S. corporation from a controlled foreign corporation; and (2) make the tax deduction for such dividends permanent.Establishes in the Treasury the Emergency Transportation Safety Fund to make priority expenditures from the Fund for federal transportation safety projects.

Service Dogs for Veterans Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to commence a three-year pilot program to assess the benefits, feasibility, and advisability of using service dogs for the treatment or rehabilitation of veterans with physical or mental injuries or disabilities, including post-traumatic stress disorder. Requires the Secretary to: (1) carry out the pilot program by partnering with nonprofit organizations that have experience providing service dogs to individuals with injuries or disabilities and that do not charge fees for the dogs, services, or lodging that they provide; and (2) reimburse partners for costs relating to the provision of such dogs.

Upper Mississippi Conservation and River Protection Act of 2012 or the Upper Mississippi CARP Act - Directs the Secretary of the Army, acting through the Chief of Engineers, to study: (1) the feasibility of temporarily closing the lock at the Upper St. Anthony Falls Lock and Dam to manage the threat of Asian carp traveling up the Mississippi River in Minnesota; and (2) the feasibility of implementing control measures at the Upper St. Anthony Falls Lock and Dam to manage the threat of Asian carp traveling up the Mississippi River in Minnesota.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to close the lock at the Upper St. Anthony Falls Lock and Dam if: (1) silver carp has been captured above Lock and Dam 2, or (2) juvenile Asian carp has been captured above Lock and Dam 4.

Coordinating Assistance for TANF Recipients Act Amends part A (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) (TANF) of title IV of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to make grants to states to conduct demonstration projects designed to implement and evaluate strategies to provide coordinated case management to help TANF recipients increase their employment and self-sufficiency. Requires the Secretary to submit recommendations to Congress on ways to improve case management and better coordinate benefits and services across programs.

Veterans Comprehensive Hepatitis C Health Care Act - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, during the first year after the enactment of this Act, to provide a blood test for the Hepatitis C virus to: (1) each veteran who served on active military duty during the Vietnam era and is enrolled to receive veterans' medical care and requests such care or is otherwise receiving a physical examination or any other care or treatment from the Secretary; and (2) any other veteran who requests such test. Requires the Secretary, after such one-year period, to provide such test to any veteran who presents one or more risk factors for such virus and who requests such test. Requires the Secretary, in the case of any veteran who tests positive, to: (1) provide an appropriate treatment protocol; (2) perform a liver biopsy on any veteran who tests positive; and (3) provide a Hepatitis C virus genotype test before beginning treatment of such veteran.Directs the Secretary to: (1) require each Department medical center to employ at least one full-time gastroenterologist or hepatologist to conduct such tests; (2) ensure that each Department medical center has at least one staff member assigned to work in coordination with Hepatitis C medical personnel to coordinate treatment options for Hepatitis C patients and provide information for those patients; and (3) provide increased training options to Department health

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: WithDRAWAL of ACKNOWLEDGEMENT or RECOGNITION <n> Title II: Central Council of Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska <n>Title I: WithDRAWAL of ACKNOWLEDGEMENT or RECOGNITION - Federally Recognized Indian Tribe List Act of 1994 <n>Title I: WithDRAWAL of ACKNOWLEDGEMENT or RECOGNITION - Federally Recognized Indian Tribe List Act of 1994 <n>Title II: Central Council of Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska - Tlingit and Haida Status Clarification Act <n>Title II: Central Council of Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska - Central Council of Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska Reaffirms and acknowledges that the Central Council of Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska is a federally recognized Indian tribe. Declares that nothing in this title shall be construed to diminish or interfere with the government-to-government relationship between the United States and other federally recognized Alaska Native tribes, nor to vest any power, authority, or jurisdiction in the Central Council of Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska over other federally recognized Alaska Native tribes.

Social Security Protection Act of 2011 - Makes it out of order in the Senate or the House of Representatives to consider any legislation that: (1) increases the retirement age or the early retirement age for individuals receiving benefits under title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act on or after enactment of this Act, or (2) reduces the cost-of-living adjustment (COLA) for individuals receiving benefits under OASDI on or after enactment of this Act.
Americans Giving care to Elders (AGE) Act of 2007 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for a portion of a taxpayer's expenses for eldercare, up to $6,000.

Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a program to encourage and assist producers, processors, and other handlers of agricultural commodities to donate such commodities to selected food banks, soup kitchens, and homeless shelters in the United States to assist the homeless and needy. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to enter into agreements with producers, processors, and other handlers who offer to make such commodities available for donation. Authorizes the Secretary to agree to make such donation if: (1) the commodity would likely not be harvested, handled, packaged, or processed in the absence of payment; and (2) volunteer harvesters or packaging or processing services are unavailable or unfeasible. <n>Provides for: (1) nomination by local governments of food banks, soup kitchens, and homeless shelters for selection to receive such commodities; and (2) selection by the Secretary. <n>Directs the Secretary to enter into contracts with persons to collect, store, distribute agricultural commodities under the program.

Savings for Seniors Act of 2017 This bill amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to: (1) establish in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund a Social Security Surplus Protection Account to hold the Social Security surplus; (2) require the Managing Trustee of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund to transfer the Social Security surplus to the Account; and (3) establish in the executive branch a Social Security Investment Commission to study and recommend the most effective vehicles for investment of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund, other than investment in the form of obligations of the United States resulting in the transfer of Trust Fund assets to the general fund of the Treasury.

Flight 93 National Memorial Act - Establishes as a unit of the National Park System a memorial at the site in Stonycreek Township, Somerset County, Pennsylvania, to honor the passengers and crewmembers of United Airlines Flight 93.

Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt employers who hire unemployed individuals in 2010 from employment taxes. Allows an employer to elect not to apply such exemption.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Continuing Education for Law Enforcement Officers <n> Title II: Grants to States for Law Enforcement Training Programs <n>Law Enforcement Responsibility and Improvement Act of 1993 - <n>Title I: Continuing Education for Law Enforcement Officers <n> Title II: Grants to States for Law Enforcement Training Programs <n>Law Enforcement Responsibility and Improvement Act of 1993 - <n>Title I: Continuing Education for Law Enforcement Officers <n> - Directs the Assistant Attorney General for Postsecondary Education to allocate funds to States for scholarship programs to enhance the educational status of law enforcement personnel and to provide continuing education assistance to such personnel. <n>Provides that each State receiving such funds shall pay the Federal share of the cost of awarding scholarships to law enforcement personnel to enable such personnel during nonworking hours to enroll in courses, not to exceed a total of 18 credit hours, at an institution of higher education. <n>Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) State application requirements; (2) scholarship eligibility; (3) restrictions on the use of scholarships for educational expenses at an accredited institution of higher education; and (4) reporting requirements.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a business-related tax credit for investment in a livestock-derived renewable energy facility. The credit applies to a facility that is owned by the taxpayer, placed in service before January 1, 2018, and the livestock-derived renewable energy output of which is marketed through an interconnection with a gas distribution or transmission pipeline or used on-site with a gas distribution or transmission pipeline.

Assisted Living Pilot Program for Veterans with Traumatic Brain Injury Extension Act - Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 to extend and modify the pilot program on assisted living services for veterans with traumatic brain injuries (TBI). Requires the pilot program to be carried out at locations selected by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) for purposes of the program, including at at least one location in each VA health care region that contains a polytrauma center. Revises and extends reporting requirements for the pilot program.

Quit Smoking Incentive and Opportunity Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a refundable credit for qualified tobacco use cessation expenses paid by the taxpayer. Defines such expenses as expenses: (1) for products determined by the Food and Drug Administration to be safe and effective in promoting a reduction in tobacco use; and (2) for counseling for cessation of tobacco use.

Transit in Parks Act This bill requires the Departments of the Interior and Transportation to enter into a memorandum of understanding to establish a transit in parks program to encourage and promote the development of transportation systems within National Park System (NPS) units to improve visitor mobility and enjoyment, reduce pollution and congestion, and enhance resource protection through the use of transit. The program shall be administered by Interior, in conjunction with Transportation.

Community Pharmacy Fairness Act of 2007- Entitles independent pharmacies negotiating contract terms with a health plan for the provision of health care items or services to the same treatment under the antitrust laws as the treatment to which bargaining units recognized under the National Labor Relations Act are entitled. Treats such a pharmacy as an employee engaged in concerted activities in connection with such negotiations. Exempts actions taken in good faith reliance on this Act from being subject to criminal sanctions or civil penalties beyond actual damages incurred.

Amends the Commodity Exchange Act to direct the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) to maintain a liaison with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC).Subjects specified agreements, contracts, or transactions in exempt energy commodities and exempt metals commodities to: (1) CFTC enforcement requirements; and (2) CFTC prohibitions against manipulation of commodity market prices.Subjects to CFTC enforcement requirements a person or group of persons that constitutes, maintains, administers, or provides a physical or electronic facility or system in which a person has the ability to offer, execute, trade, or confirm the execution of an agreement, contract, or transaction (other than an agreement, contract, or transaction in an excluded commodity) by making or accepting the bids and offers of one or more participants on the facility or system.Authorizes a person or group to offer to enter into, enter into, or confirm the execution of any agreement, contract, or transaction (other than an agreement, contract, or transaction in an excluded commodity) on a bilateral dealer market if the bilateral dealer market meets specified requirements. Requires: (1) CFTC notice to the Commission in such form as the CFTC may specify; (2) filing with the CFTC any reports (including large trader position reports) that the CFTC requires by rule or regulation; (3) maintenance of

Copper Valley Native Allotment Resolution Act of 2007- Grants the Copper Valley Electric Association rights-of-way across specified Native allotments for an electric transmission line owned by the Association.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on May 10, 2016. Stop Trafficking of Pills Act or the STOP Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to require state Medicaid programs to establish a restricted recipient program for high-risk prescription drug users. A “high-risk prescription drug user” is an individual who: (1) may be dispensed on the prescription of a physician to an individual eligible to receive medical assistance under the state Medicaid program, and (2) presents a high risk of misuse or overutilization. The state must implement a program to: (1) identify any prescription drug that may be dispensed on the prescription of a physician to such an individual and present a high risk of misuse or overutilization; (2) establish a dosage level for each identified prescription drug that would be deemed excessive in the absence of evidence of medical necessity; (3) identify individuals who are eligible for medical assistance under the state Medicaid program and are receiving a prescription drug identified as excessive or who have been convicted of a drug-related offense; and (4) ensure that such individuals are assigned to the restricted recipient program. The state must also establish a Medicaid lock-in program to ensure that any identified high-risk prescription

Prohibits the use of funds authorized to be appropriated under this Act to pay the cost of administration of the activities assisted under this Act.Requires the Secretary of Education to: (1) use 45 percent of such funds to award grants under this Act; (2) make available to the Secretary of Defense 45 percent of such funds for grants to local educational agencies for which the number of children determined under this Act constitutes at least 25 percent of the number of children who were in average daily attendance in the schools of such local educational agency during the school year preceding the school year for which the determination is made; and (3) use ten percent of such funds for grants under this Act.

Congressional Pension Forfeiture Act of 1997 - Amends Federal law to provide that any service as a Member of Congress of an individual convicted of specified offenses committed while a Member during the 105th Congress or later, if the conduct on which the offense is based is directly related to the individual's service as a Member, shall not be taken into account as creditable service for purposes of annuity or retirement provisions. Entitles such individual (or his or her beneficiary or estate, if applicable) to be paid so much of such individual's lump-sum credit as is attributable to such service.

Influenza Vaccine Emergency Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require manufacturers or distributors of influenza vaccine to include in written contracts for the sale of such vaccine a provision stating that if the Secretary of Health and Human Services publishes in the Federal Register an emergency declaration of a shortage of such vaccine, the Secretary has authority to: (1) take title to any quantities of such vaccine necessary for the public health; and (2) provide a refund if the purchaser does not receive, or loses possession of, a quantity of such vaccine.Requires the Secretary to: (1) determine the extent of compliance with guidelines for the distribution of such vaccine; and (2) determine within 30 days after making such emergency declaration that the extent of such compliance has not been sufficient to constitute an adequate response to the emergency. Authorizes the Secretary, in lieu of such authority, to order any manufacturer or distributor of influenza vaccine to honor its contracts with States or political subdivisions for the sale of such vaccine. Requires any such vaccine to be provided to States and political subdivisions in accordance with the State's immunization program and other public or private entities as the Secretary determines to be appropriate as a response to the emergency involved.Authorizes the Secretary to make such an emergency declaration: (1) if the delivery waiting time for States or political subdivisions to

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on February 27, 2003. However, because action occurred on the measure, the summary has been expanded.) Upper Mississippi River Basin Protection Act - Requires federal investments in the Upper Mississippi River Basin to be guided by accepted and documented scientific methods, taking into account the results of studies using such methods to identify and quantify the sources, transport, and fate of nutrients and sediment and to quantify the effect of various treatment methods or conservation measures on nutrient and sediment management.Title I: Sediment and Nutrient Monitoring Network - (Sec. 101) Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the United States Geological Survey (USGS), to establish a nutrient and sediment monitoring network for the River Basin as part of the Upper Mississippi River Stewardship Initiative.(Sec. 102) Directs the Secretary to: (1) establish guidelines for related data collection and storage activities; (2) inventory the sediment and nutrient monitoring efforts in existence as of this Act's enactment; (3) integrate existing monitoring efforts into the network; (4) develop a baseline understanding of the overlap, data gaps and redundancies; and (5) collaborate with other public and private monitoring programs in establishing the network.(Sec. 106) Directs the National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences to

Employee Changing Room Privacy Act - Prohibits employers from engaging in video or audio monitoring of employees in restroom facilities, dressing rooms, or other areas in which it is reasonable to expect employees to change clothing. Prohibits employers from: (1) using the results of such monitoring for any purpose, including employee discipline; and (2) discharging, disciplining, or discriminating in any manner against an employee because the employee has filed a complaint or instituted a proceeding under this Act, or testified or is about to testify in any such proceeding. Provides for enforcement of this Act by the Secretary of Labor.

Super-Efficient Appliance Incentives and Market Transformation Act of 2007- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to modify the tax credit for production of energy efficient appliances (i.e. dishwashers, clothes washers, refrigerators, and ice makers) by: (1) increasing the dollar limits on such credit; (2) making such credit available to manufacturers of appliances that consume a specified percentage of energy; (3) allowing the credit to be transferred from the general business tax credit to the energy tax credit; and (4) making the credit refundable.

Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to establish a grants program for Resource Staff for Students. Direct the Secretary of Education to award such grants to States and local educational agencies to recruit, train, and hire 100,000 individuals to serve as school-based resource staff who have documented competence and training in mental health to provide services to children and adolescents in a school setting.Requires such resource staff to: (1) reduce the student-to-counseling ratios nationally, in grades 6-12, to an average of one such staff member for every 250 students; (2) help address the mental, emotional, and developmental needs of public school students; and (3) support other school staff and teachers in reaching students early before problems arise, conducting behavioral interventions to improve school discipline, and developing the awareness and skills to identify early warning signs of violence and the need for mental health services.

Dairy Farmer Viability Act - Establishes the Dairy Farmer Viability Commission to study matters relating to improving the viability of dairy farming. <n>Directs the Commission to develop recommendations to improve the viability of dairy farming after considering, with respect to dairy industry, farm prices, competition, leverage, stability, and concentration in the marketplace. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Water System Adaptation Partnerships Act of 2009 - Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to make grants to water systems to assist in planning, designing, constructing, implementing, or maintaining any program, strategy, or infrastructure improvement to: (1) conserve water or increase water use efficiency; (2) carry out water metering to measure water efficiency effectiveness of a water efficiency program; (3) preserve or improve water quality; (4) enhance water management by increasing source water preservation and protection, or natural or engineered green infrastructure in the management, conveyance, or treatment of water, wastewater, or stormwater; (5) increase energy efficiency or the use and generation of renewable energy in the management, conveyance, or treatment of water, wastewater, or stormwater; (6) support the adoption and use of advanced water treatment, water supply management, or water demand management technologies or processes that maintain or increase water supply or improve water quality; (7) complete studies or assessments to project how climate change may impact the future operations and sustainability of the water system; or (8) carry out any other activity or project to address any ongoing or forecasted, based on the best available research and data, climate-related impact on the water quality or quantity of a region of the United States that increases the resiliency of a water system to the impacts of climate change.

Health Empowerment Zone Act of 2003 - Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to: (1) designate health empowerment zones; (2) make grants to community partnerships of private and public entities to establish such zones; and (3) provide technical assistance and evidence-based strategies to communities of color that experience disproportionate disparities in health status and health care.

International Hydrocephalus Treatment and Training Act This bill amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to declare that hydrocephalus is an important priority of U.S bilateral foreign assistance, including through promotion of innovative treatments and training of medical practitioners from the developing world in the latest treatment protocols and best practices for the treatment of hydrocephalus.

(Sec. 3) Prohibits employers from discriminating between employees on the basis of employment status by paying temporary employees at a rate less than the rate for full-time employees, where such payment is made pursuant to: (1) a seniority system, a merit system, a system that measures earning by quantity or quality of production, or a differential based on any other factor other than employment status; or (2) a differential based on any other factor other than employment status. Prohibits employers who are paying a wage rate differential in violation of this Act from reducing the wage rate of any employee in order to comply with such provisions. Prohibits a labor organization, or its agents, representing the employees of an employer having employees subject to such provisions from causing or attempting to cause such an employer to discriminate against an employee in violation of this Act. Deems any amounts owing to any employee that have been withheld in violation of this Act to be unpaid minimum wages or unpaid overtime compensation for purposes of administration and enforcement.(Sec. 4) Amends the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to require, at the place of employment of the employer, furnish to each person at such place a place which is free from recognized hazards that are causing or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm

Charitable Pension Flexibility Act of 2013 - Amends the Pension Protection Act of 2006, as amended by the Preservation of Access to Care for Medicare Beneficiaries and Pension Relief Act of 2010, to authorize a plan sponsor to elect to cease to be treated as an eligible charity plan for plan years beginning after 2013. Defines "eligible charity plan" as a defined benefit plan under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) that has: (1) an 11-year shortfall amortization base, (2) a 12-year shortfall amortization base, and (3) a 7-year shortfall amortization base. Authorizes a plan sponsor that makes such election to also elect to apply the rules described in this Act for plan years beginning after 2013.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 5, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Health Care for Veterans of Project 112/Project SHAD Act of 2003 - (Sec. 2) Makes any veteran who participated in a test conducted by the Department of Defense Deseret Test Center as part of a program for chemical and biological warfare testing from 1962 through 1973 (including the program designated as Project Shipboard Hazard and Defense" and related land-based tests) eligible for hospital care, medical services, and nursing home care, notwithstanding insufficient medical evidence to conclude that the illness is attributable to such testing, after December 31, 2005.(Sec. 3) Provides that, in a case in which a registered nurse has accomplished the performance elements required for promotion to the next grade, the lack of a baccalaureate degree in nursing shall not be a bar to promotion to that grade, and in such a case the registered nurse shall not be denied a promotion on that basis.(Sec. 4) Entitles Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) health care employees who are appointed to the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) to additional pay on the same basis as provided for nurses.(Sec. 5) Requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to provide for"

Expedited CARD Reform for Consumers Act of 2009 - Amends the Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure Act of 2009 to delay until February 22, 2010, the effective date of certain requirements governing credit card disclosures, including: (1) the review of past consumer interest rate increases; and (2) the requirement that penalty fees be reasonable and proportional to the violation of credit card law. Amends the Truth in Lending Act to delay until August 22, 2010, the effective date of provisions: (1) prohibiting a creditor from imposing adverse consequences for past consumer interest rates and fees; and (2) requiring that penalty fees be reasonable and proportional to the violation of credit card law.

Authorizes the Secretary to make minor adjustments in the boundaries of the Park consistent with the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965.Authorizes the Secretary to acquire lands, waters, and interests in lands within the boundaries of the Park from willing landowners by donation, purchase with donated or appropriated funds, or exchange. Requires the Secretary, in acquiring lands and interests in lands under this Act, to acquire the minimum interest necessary to achieve the purposes for which the battlefield is established. Permits the Secretary to acquire an easement on property outside the boundaries of the Park and around the city of Richmond, with the owner's consent, if the easement is necessary to protect core Civil War resources.

Safe, Efficient, Coordinated, Unified, Revitalized, Enhanced Visa Waiver Act - Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish, as part of the integrated entry and exit data system required under the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996, an electronic system through which an alien seeking to enter the United States without a visa under the visa waiver program is required to submit biographical information prior to embarkation.<n><n>Requires the system to include a method for an electronic determination of eligibility to be made, and an electronic response to be provided, in 30 minutes or less, as to whether or not an alien submitting such information is eligible to be admitted to the United States as a nonimmigrant visitor.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to establish a fee to be charged to aliens described in this Act that is set at a level that will ensure the recovery of the full costs of establishing and operating the system.<n><n>Amends the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act to direct the Secretary: (1) by October 26, 2004, to install at all ports of entry equipment and software to allow biometric comparison and authentication of all U.S. visas and other travel and entry documents issued to aliens; and (2) by October 26, 2005, to install at all ports of entry equipment and software to allow

. Pro-Growth Budgeting Act of 2014 - Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) to prepare for each major bill or resolution reported by any congressional committee a macroeconomic impact analysis of the budgetary effects of such legislation for the next 10 fiscal-year periods. Requires the analysis to describe the potential economic impact of the legislation on major economic variables, including real gross domestic product (GDP), business investment, the capital stock, employment, interest rates, and labor supply. Requires CBO to report on the accuracy of the original macroeconomic impact analysis of such enacted legislation and submit these reports to the congressional budget committees.

Made in America Act of 2016 This bill requires the Federal Trade Commission to establish America Star labels as a voluntary means of indicating to consumers the extent to which products introduced, delivered, sold, advertises, or offers for sale in commerce are of United States origin. Such labels shall be known as America Star labels. The regulations required by this bill shall establish four such labels: a label that satisfies the standard for an unqualified U.S. origin claim set forth by the FTC in its Enforcement Policy Statement; a label that may be used for a product for which not less than 90% of the total cost of manufacturing the product is attributable to United States costs; a label that may be used for a product for which not less than 80% of the total cost of manufacturing the product is attributable to United States costs; and a label that may be used for a product for which not less than 70% of the total cost of manufacturing the product is attributable to United States costs. The bill prohibits the FTC from requiring a person who makes a qualified or unqualified claim that a product is of U.S. origin to use an America Star label.

Common Sense Superfund Liability Relief Act of 1997 - Amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) to extend liability for response costs to persons who cause a hazardous substance release or threatened release from a Superfund facility. Declares that a person who does not impede the performance of a response action or natural resource restoration at a facility shall not be liable to the extent liability at such facility is based solely on this Act and the person arranged for disposal, treatment, or transport for disposal or treatment of only municipal solid waste or sewage owned or possessed by such person, with exceptions. Declares that this Act shall have no effect on the liability of any other person. Declares that a person who has acquired real property shall have made all appropriate inquiry if he establishes that, within 180 days prior to the time of acquisition, an environmental site assessment of the real property was conducted which meets certain requirements.

Helping Homeless Heroes Act of 2011- Prohibits the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) from denying an application from an entity that seeks a grant under the comprehensive service programs for homeless veterans solely on the basis that the entity proposes to use funding from other private or public sources, if the entity demonstrates that a private nonprofit organization will provide oversight and site control for the project. Defines private nonprofit organization" to mean: (1) an incorporated private institution, organization, or foundation that has received, or has temporary clearance to receive, tax-exempt status for which no part of the institution, organization, or foundation inures to the benefit of any member, founder, or contributor of the institution, organization, or foundation and that the Secretary determines is financially responsible; and (2) a for-profit limited partnership or limited liability company, the sole general partner or manager of which is an organization meeting specified criteria.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to study and develop: (1) the method used to make per diem payments under such programs; and (2) an improved method for adequately reimbursing recipients of grants for services furnished to homeless veterans. Authorizes the Secretary, in developing the method, to consider payments and grants received by recipients of such grants from other federal and local governments and"

National Geologic Mapping Reauthorization Act of 1996 (sic) - Amends the National Geologic Mapping Act of 1992 to declare that: (1) there is established a national cooperative geologic mapping program between the United States Geological Survey and the State geological surveys, acting through the Association of American State Geologists (Association); and (2) the cooperative geologic mapping program shall be designed and administered to achieve specified objectives developed in consultation with the advisory committee (created by this Act) and administered through the Survey. <n>Extends the authorization of appropriations for the geologic mapping program through FY 2000. Adds the Association as a lead agency for the development and administration of the program. <n>Requires the Secretary of the Interior to: (1) prepare and transmit to specified congressional committees a five-year program plan for the cooperative geologic mapping program; and (2) establish an advisory committee to advise the Survey and the Association on the development and implementation of the program. <n>Directs the Secretary, in consultation with the Association and the State geological surveys, to provide for the coordination of geologic mapping activities between Federal and State agencies. <n>Authorizes appropriations to carry out the Act.

roop Talent Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretaries of the military departments (the Secretaries) to make information on civilian credentialing opportunities available to members of the Armed Forces beginning with, and at every stage of, military occupational training in order to permit members to: (1) evaluate the extent to which such training correlates with the skills and training required in connection with various civilian certifications and licenses; and (2) assess the suitability of such training for obtaining or pursuing such civilian certifications and licenses. Requires such information to be made available in a manner consistent with the Transition Goals Plans Success (GPS) program. Allows the Secretaries, in coordination with the Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness, to make available to accredited civilian credentialing agencies that issue certifications or licenses, upon request, information such as military course training curricula, syllabi, and materials, levels of military advancement, and professional skills developed. Includes within such information the availability and use of educational benefits available to members of the Armed Forces. Authorizes the Secretaries to use and adapt appropriate portions of the Credentialing Resources and Educational Research Tooling Agencies programs of the Army and Navy to meet requests for such information.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Biofuels Research and Development Enhancement Act - (Sec. 2) Directs the Secretary of Energy, in cooperation with the Secretary of Agriculture, to establish a biofuels and biorefinery information center to make available to interested parties information on research, development, and commercial application of technologies related to biofuels and biorefineries, including: (1) biochemical and thermochemical conversion technologies capable of making fuels from lignocellulosic feedstocks; (2) biotechnology processes capable of making biofuels with an emphasis on development of biorefinery technologies using enzyme-based processing systems; and (3) other advanced processes and technologies that will enable the development of biofuels. In administering the center, the Secretary shall: (1) continually update information provided by the center; (2) make information available to interested parties on the process for establishing a biorefinery; and (3) make information and assistance provided by the center available through a toll-free telephone number and website. (Sec. 3) Amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to direct the Secretary to: (1) carry out a research, development, and demonstration program as it relates existing transportation fuel distribution infrastructure and new alternative distribution infrastructure; and (2) report to

Department of Veterans Affairs Nurse Recruitment and Retention Act of 2004 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to: (1) designate a Department of Veterans Affairs health-care service region or section in which health-care facilities are adversely affected by a shortage of qualified nurses; and (2) conduct a pilot program to determine the effectiveness of the use of innovative human-capital tools and techniques in the recruitment of qualified nurses and for the retention of nurses at such facilities. Requires the Secretary to enter into a contract with a private-sector entity for services under such program for recruitment of qualified nurses. Requires the Secretary to identify and use recruitment practices that have proven effective for placing qualified individuals in positions that are difficult to fill due to shortages of qualified individuals or other factors. Requires the Secretary, in carrying out such program, to revise procedures and systems for selecting and hiring qualified nurses to reduce the length of the hiring process. Directs the Secretary to report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs on the extent to which the pilot program achieved its goal of improving the recruitment and retention of nurses in Department health-care facilities.<n><n>Provides that if the Secretary determines it to be necessary in order to obtain or retain the services of registered nurses at a Department health-care facility, the Secretary may provide that such nurse

Arsenic-Treated Wood Prohibition Act - Amends the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act and the Solid Waste Disposal Act to direct the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to promulgate regulations prohibiting the use of arsenic-treated wood to manufacture: (1) any product or structure that may be used for or by children; (2) mulch, compost, or soil-amendment products; (3) railroad ties, marine pilings, or utility poles; and (4) such additional uses of arsenic-treated wood to manufacture products or structures as the Administrator determines to be appropriate, whether such products or structures are intended for residential or commercial use. Requires the Administrator to: (1) publish in the Federal Register an assessment of the risks posed by the production, cutting, milling, sanding, mulching, and use of arsenic-treated wood; and (2) follow the methodology recommended by the Scientific Advisory Panels that were organized by the EPA and that met in October 2001. Prohibits the use of arsenic-treated wood to manufacture lumber.Amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act to require: (1) the Administrator to establish minimum requirements for training of maintenance applicators and service technicians; (2) the Department of Agriculture to establish a minor use pesticide data revolving fund; and (3) the Administrator to promulgate

SMA Treatment Acceleration Act - Requires the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to provide for upgrading and unification of existing clinical trials network for treatment of spinal muscular atrophy despite the need of the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS) and the National Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to establish a national clinical trials network for treatment of spinal muscular atrophy. Requires the Director of CDC to ensure that such network: (1) conducts, publishes, and disseminates trial findings; and (2) provides support for multi-site clinical trials of treatment for spinal muscular atrophy.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 19, 2012. The summary of that version is repeated here.) International Food Assistance Improvement Act of 2012 - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) even in this time of fiscal austerity, the American people support the U.S. government's historic commitment to providing life-saving food assistance to the world's most vulnerable populations; (2) high food prices require the United States to focus on creating efficiencies, improving quality controls, and maximizing cost-effectiveness and nutritional impact of U.S. food assistance programs; (3) improving maternal and child health with supplemental nutrition products is a central objective of international food assistance programs; and (4) the United States has shown considerable leadership in meeting the nutrition needs of pregnant women and small children through the 1,000 Days Partnership to support the  scaling up nutrition movement.<n><n>Amends the Food for Peace Act to direct the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) to use funds made available in FY2012 and subsequent fiscal years to improve the nutritional quality of U.S food assistance, particularly for vulnerable groups such as pregnant and lactating mothers, children under the age of 5, and beneficiaries under the President's Emergency Fund for AIDS Relief in Africa (

Budget Control Act of 2002 - Amends the concurrent resolution on the budget for FY 2002 to increase the amount of new budget authority, total budget outlays, the surplus or deficit, public debt, and net interest, as well as reduce the amount of sequestration required.Requires the chairs of the congressional budget committees to make necessary conforming changes for FY 2003 through 2011 in total new budget authority, total budget outlays, the surplus or deficit, public debt, and debt held by the public, net interest, and allowances (920) as set forth in the concurrent resolution on the budget for FY 2002.Increases allocations to the Committee on Appropriations of each House for FY 2002 in new budget authority and outlays. Repeals provisions of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 (Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act) pertaining to sequestration in the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) reports and in the President's budget.Amends the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 to provide for technical corrections to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 (Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act).

Unrecognized Southeast Alaska Native Communities Recognition and Compensation Act Amends the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to permit the Native residents of each of the Native Villages of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell, Alaska, to organize as Urban Corporations and to receive certain settlement land and other compensation pursuant to this Act. Directs the Secretary of the Interior to enroll to each of the Urban Corporations for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell those individual Natives who enrolled under the Act to the Native Villages of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell.

Keep Our Homes Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow: (1) taxpayers a deduction from gross income for up to $500 of mortgage counseling costs; (2) a tax deduction up to $5,000 for the acquisition of a principal residence with a downpayment of 20% of the value of such residence; and (3) an income-based tax credit up to $5,000 for the acquisition of a principal residence with a downpayment of 20% of the value of such residence.

North Korea Nonproliferation Act of 1999 - Directs the President to report periodically to specified congressional committees on: (1) whether North Korea has taken an action inconsistent with its obligations under the agreement between North Korea and the United States of September 12, 1999, to suspend launches of long-range missiles, or any other international agreement in which North Korea agreed to limit such testing, deployment, or transfer to other countries of missiles or missile technology; and (2) if there is such credible information, describing the nature of that information and of the action or actions taken by North Korea. <n>Requires the President to report periodically to the same committees on whether North Korea, on or after the enactment of this Act, transferred to a destination outside of North Korea specified goods, services, or technology, or goods, services, or technology not included on either list, but which nevertheless would be, if they were U.S. goods, services, or technology, prohibited for export to that destination because of their potential to make a material contribution to the development of nuclear, biological, or chemical weapons, or of ballistic or cruise missile systems. <n>Authorizes the President to reinstate specified restrictions on commerce with North Korea if there is credible information that North Korea has transferred such goods, services, or technology to a

International Infectious Diseases Control Act of 2001 - Directs the President to establish a comprehensive strategy to combat HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria, which shall: (1) ensure that prevention, care, and treatment are provided to all people affected by such diseases; (2) integrate prevention, care, and treatment into all health systems; and (3) maximize U.S. capabilities to support comprehensive health systems in developing countries.Directs the President to establish within the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development a global fund to fight HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria. Authorizes appropriations.

Coordinate to Educate Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make grants to local educational agencies to develop and implement coordinated service programs. <n>Requires special consideration to be given to: (1) geographic distribution of awards, including urban, suburban, and rural districts; (2) districts with concentrated pockets of educationally at-risk students; (3) local educational agencies with high proportions of educationally at-risk students; and (4) areas with a large number of single parent or two-parent, working families. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Preserving Data in Government Act of 2017 This bill requires a federal agency to preserve open government data that is made available to the public for at least 90 consecutive days: (1) remain machine-readable, available in an open format, and part of the worldwide public domain or, if necessary, published with an open license; and (2) not be altered in such a way as to decrease the machine-readable nature of the data. The bill declares that it shall not be a violation to alter: (1) the digital location or format of open government data for the purpose of routine asset maintenance or long-term archiving if the alteration does not decrease the open public accessibility or the machine-readable nature of the data, or (2) the contents of open government data for purposes of updating or correcting an error in the data. Any substantial alteration of the contents of open government data shall be recorded in a log that is made available to the public in an open format along with the open government data. An agency may remove open government data from public availability if: (1) it is too costly to maintain, or (2) does not provide sufficient value to the public.

National Environmental Technologies Agency Act - Establishes the National Environmental Technologies Agency. <n>Directs the Agency to: (1) coordinate Federal environmental restoration and protection planning; (2) identify areas that need technical solutions to maintain environmental security, are not receiving product-oriented research necessary to meet those needs, and exhibit the greatest promise for the development of solutions; (3) support the development of technology having future application in environmental restoration and protection; (4) coordinate the exchange of technological information relating to environmental restoration and protection between Federal agencies and the private sector; (5) support continuing research and development of advanced technologies; (6) monitor research and development being conducted on advanced technologies by private industry; and (7) promote continuing development of a technological industrial base in the United States. <n>Establishes the Industry and Academia Advisory Council to advise and provide information to the Agency on the needs and concerns of their agencies in the field of environmental technologies. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Small Business Review Panel Technical Amendments Act of 1999 - Amends Federal provisions concerning the promulgation of Federal rules to allow representatives of small entities that may be affected to make an oral presentation to a review panel for a proposed rule. Requires the head of an agency covered by the rule to print the report of the review panel in the Federal Register within 120 days after receiving it or as part of the publication of the notice of proposed rulemaking for the rule.

Small Business Interest Checking Act of 2001- Amends the Federal Reserve Act, the Home Owners' Loan Act, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act to repeal the proscription against the payment of interest on demand deposits. Exempts from such proscription any depository institution which is prohibited by State law from offering demand deposits and which either: (1) does not engage in any lending activities; or (2) is not an affiliate of any company or companies with assets that, in the aggregate, represent more than ten percent of the depository institution's total assets.Allows any depository institution to permit the owner of any deposit or account on which interest or dividends are paid and is not a deposit or account, for any purpose, to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account of the owner in the same institution.Amends the Federal Reserve Act to: (1) authorize a Federal reserve bank to pay interest on reserves at least once each calendar quarter at a rate not to exceed the general level of short term interest rates; and (2) authorize a depository institution to receive earnings to be paid by a Federal reserve bank at least once each calendar quarter at a rate not to exceed the general level of short term interest rates.Requires the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to: (1) obtain and report to Congress

Unintended Pregnancy Reduction Act of 2006 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to prohibit a state from providing for medical assistance through enrollment of an individual with benchmark coverage or benchmark- equivalent coverage unless that coverage includes family planning services and supplies. Expands coverage of family planning services and supplies to include individuals who meet the income standards for pregnant women.

International Anti-Corruption Act of 1999 - Directs the President to certify annually to the appropriate congressional committees as to whether each country receiving foreign assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is: (1) conducive to U.S. business; (2) not conducive to U.S. business; or (3) hostile to U.S. business. Prescribes foreign assistance limitations for countries hostile or not conducive to U.S. business. <n>Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to instruct the U.S. Executive Director of each multilateral development bank to vote against any loan or other utilization of the institution's funds with respect to a country: (1) certified as hostile to U.S. business; or (2) not conducive to U.S. business until the President certifies to such committees that the country is making significant progress in implementing the economic indicators described above and is no longer hostile to U.S. business. <n>Exempts a country from such assistance limitations if the President determines that its continuation is important to the national security interest of the United States. <n>Requires the President to certify annually to the appropriate congressional committees as to whether each country receiving foreign assistance under the Act is: (1) conducive to U.S. business; or (2) not conducive to U.S

Cut Energy Bills Home Act Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a new tax credit for a qualified whole home energy efficiency retrofit. Defines qualified whole home energy efficiency retrofit" as the implementation of measures placed in service during the taxable year intended to reduce the energy use of the principal residence of the taxpayer which is located in the United States."

Asset Forfeiture Responsibility Act of 2011 - Establishes in the Treasury the Fisheries Investment Fund. States that all sums received by the United States as fines, penalties, and forfeitures of property for violations of any provision of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act or any other marine resource law enforced by the Secretary of Commerce shall be deposited into such Fund to be used to: (1) reimburse reasonable attorneys' fees to any person that has sought remittance of a fisheries enforcement penalty or that submitted a complaint to the Special Master prior to May 7, 2011; and (2) conduct specified enforcement activities and monitoring activities under such Act.

Electric Reliability Improvement Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal Power Act to grant Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) jurisdiction over any regional entity, and all users, owners, and operators of the bulk-power system, for purposes of approving reliability standards and enforcing compliance with this Act.Prescribes procedural guidelines for: (1) certification as the Electric Reliability Organization (ERO) by FERC; and (2) filing of reliability standards.

Land Management Agency Housing Improvement Act of 1994 - Authorizes the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture (the Secretaries) to make employee housing available on or off public lands and to rent or lease such housing to employees of the respective Departments at a reasonable value. Specifies that: (1) housing made available on public lands shall be limited to those areas designated for administrative use; and (2) no private lands or interests therein outside of the boundaries of federally administered areas may be acquired for such purposes except with the consent of the owner. Specifies that the base rental rate comparable to private rental rates for comparable housing facilities and associated amenities shall not exceed the most recent Census Bureau American Housing Survey median monthly housing cost for renters inclusive of utilities, as a percentage of current income, whether paid as part of rent or paid directly to a third party. <n>Authorizes the Secretaries to: (1) enter into contracts and agreements with public and private entities to provide employee housing on or off public lands; and (2) enter into cooperative agreements or joint ventures with local governmental and private entities to provide appropriate and necessary utility and other infrastructure facilities in support of such housing facilities. <n>Requires the Secretaries to: (1) conduct a survey of the availability of quarters at field units under each Secretary's jurisdiction at least every five

Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to: (1) develop methods for conducting evaluations of lead detection products and techniques; (2) make available to the public the results of such evaluations; and (3) establish protocols, criteria, and minimum performance standards to be used in such evaluations and to ensure reliable, accurate, and effective lead detection technologies. <n>Requires the Administrator to conduct a long-term research study to establish the sources of lead exposure for children under the age of seven years. <n>Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to: (1) carry out research studies to evaluate which practices and techniques are most effective in reducing human exposure to lead; and (2) establish performance criteria and standards for lead removal and containment products. <n>Directs the Administrator to: (1) sponsor public education and outreach efforts to increase awareness of the scope, severity, and sources of lead exposure; and (2) focus such education and efforts in a manner which provides information to the children for whom profiles are established about the particular kind and route of lead exposure. <n>Requires the Administrator to: (1) ensure that any information which is made available to the public pursuant to this Act is made available through the clearinghouse and hotline established pursuant to the Toxic Control Substances Act; and (2) establish performance criteria and standards for

American Farm Protection Act of 1995 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from the gross estate, if the executor so elects, the value of land subject to a qualified conservation easement (reduced by the amount of any indebtedness secured by such land). Includes in the gross estate the value of any development right retained by the donor in the conveyance of the easement. Provides for the treatment of such retained right.

Medicaid and CHIP Quality Improvement Act of 2016 This bill amends titles XIX (Medicaid) and XXI (Children's Health Insurance Program [CHIP]) of the Social Security Act to: (1) require comparable primary care case management services providers as well as health care services furnished in fee-for-service settings or other delivery systems to be used for reporting on comparable quality measures for Medicaid eligible adults, (2) require states to use such measures and approaches for reporting on the initial core set of quality measures for Medicaid eligible adults, and (3) expand reporting requirements to include pediatric health care measures.

National Materials Corridor Partnership Act of 1999 - Directs the Secretary of Energy to establish a comprehensive program to promote energy efficient, environmentally sound economic development along the United States-Mexico border through the research, development, and use of new materials technology. <n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) give due consideration to the proposal made to the United States-Mexico Binational Commission for the Materials Corridor Partnership Initiative; and (2) organize and conduct the program jointly with the Departments of State, Environmental Protection Agency, National Science Foundation, and National Institute of Standards and Technology. Requires funds made available under this Act to be made available for research and development or education and training activities that are conducted with the participation and support of private sector organizations in the United States and, subject to specified requirements, Mexico. <n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) encourage public, academic, and private sector participation; and (2) initiate and manage an advisory committee to advise the Secretary regarding the implementation of the program. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on January 7, 2003. However, because action occurred on the measure, the summary has been expanded.)Country of Origin Labeling Amendment Act of 2003 - Amends the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 to revise the country of origin requirements for country of origin labeling for meat, lamb, pork, farm-raised fish, and perishable agricultural commodities (as defined in this Act). States that a retailer may designate a commodity as having a country of origin only if the commodity: (1) is exclusively from an animal born, raised, and slaughtered in the United States (including from an animal born, raised, and slaughtered in Canada and Hawaii for purposes of transportation and storage); (2) is exclusively born, raised, and slaughtered in the United States (including from an animal born, raised, and slaughtered in Canada and Hawaii for purposes of transportation and storage); (3) is exclusively born, raised, and slaughtered in the United States (including from an animal born, raised, and slaughtered in Canada and Hawaii for purposes of transportation and storage); or (4) is exclusively born, raised, and slaughtered in the United States (including from an animal born, raised, and slaughtered in Canada and Hawaii for purposes of transportation and storage).Requires that: (1)

Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017 This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose an excise tax on certain corporations that employ low-wage employees during the year. The tax is equal to a percentage of the aggregate wages paid to such employees during the year, determined according to a specified formula. The tax also applies to employers who do not offer their full-time employees the opportunity to enroll for all months in minimum essential health coverage.

Trade and Environment Enforcement Act or Green 301 Act - Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to require the United States Trade Representative (USTR) to identify trade practices of foreign countries that cause negative impacts on the protection of human, animal, or plant life or health, or the conservation of exhaustible natural resources in the United States, the foreign country, a third country, or internationally.

Volunteer Protection Act of 1993 - States that nothing in this Act shall be construed to preempt the laws of any State governing tort liability actions. Declares that any volunteer of a nonprofit organization or governmental entity shall incur no personal financial liability for any tort claim alleging damage or injury from any act or omission on behalf of the organization or entity if the individual was acting in good faith and within the scope of such individual's official functions and duties with the organization or entity and such damage or injury was not caused by willful and wanton misconduct by such individual. Declares that this Act shall not be construed to affect civil actions brought by any nonprofit organization or governmental entity against any volunteer of such organization or entity. Sets forth conditions on and exceptions to the granting of such liability, including that the organization or entity shall: (1) adhere to risk management procedures, including mandatory training of volunteers; and (2) be liable for the acts or omissions of its volunteers to the same extent as an employer is liable for the acts or omissions of its employees. Declares that this Act shall not apply if the volunteer was operating a motor vehicle or was operating a vessel, aircraft, or other vehicle for which a pilot's license is required. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Native American Language Student Achievement Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Department of Education to award grants to schools or private or tribal, nonprofit organizations that have plans to develop and maintain, or to improve and expand, programs that support schools using Native American languages as the primary language of instruction of all curriculum taught at the schools. The bill defines "eligible entity" as a school or a private or tribal, nonprofit organization that has a plan to develop and maintain, or to improve and expand, programs that support schools using Native American languages as the primary language of instruction of all curriculum taught at the schools. The bill sets forth requirements for grant applications and for awarding grants.

Presidential Sites Improvement Act of 1999 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to: (1) award grants for major maintenance and improvement projects at Presidential sites to owners or operators; and (2) establish the Presidential Site Grant Commission to review applications for grants and to make recommendations for the awarding of grants under this Act. Authorizes appropriations.

No Subsidies Without Verification Act of 2014 - Prohibits the health plan premium assistance tax credit or cost-sharing reduction under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act before an individual's eligibility and the accurate amount of the credit or reduction is verified.

Pueblo of Isleta Settlement and Natural Resources Restoration Act of 2006 - Establishes: (1) the Pueblo of Isleta Natural Resources Restoration Fund in the Treasury; and (2) the Pueblo of Isleta Settlement Fund in the Treasury. Directs the Secretary of the Interior, upon the request of the Pueblo, to distribute amounts from the Restoration Fund to the Pueblo for: (1) the drainage and remediation of approximately 1,081 acres of agricultural land; and (2) the rehabilitation of forest and range land of the Pueblo.

Improving Security for Investors and Providing Closure Act of 2013 or the Improving SIPC Act of 2013 - Amends the Securities Investor Protection Act of 1970 to authorize the Securities Investor Protection Corporation (SIPC) (a nonprofit, nongovernment, membership corporation funded by its broker-dealer customers) to allow all customers of a debtor in pending actions to elect to receive a one-time payment from the SIPC Fund. Requires a customer election to be made within 180 days after the SIPC chooses to allow it. Limits the amount paid to a customer to the lesser of: (1) the customer's net equity claim against the debtor, and (2) the cap set at $500,000. Requires SIPC to set a cap on the amount of one-time payments that can be made under this Act and such cap to: (1) not exceed $500,000, and (2) apply equally to all SIPC customers. Makes a customer who receives a one-time payment subrogated to all rights of such customer against the debtor once the customer recovers an amount equal to the customer's net equity claim against the debtor.
