Civil Rights Amendments Act of 1993 - Amends the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and other civil rights laws to include affectional or sexual orientation among the prohibited categories of discrimination.

Amends the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States to reduce, through December 31, 2008 or 2009 (as appropriate), the duty on certain cotton shirting fabrics. Limits the quantity of imported woven fabrics of cotton containing 85 percent or more by weight of cotton used by a U.S. manufacturer in cutting and sewing men's and boy's shirts. Provides for the issuance of import licenses subject to such limitation.Establishes the Pima Cotton Trust Fund in the Treasury.

Esther Martinez Native American Languages Preservation Act of 2006 - Amends the Native American Programs Act of 1974 to authorize the Secretary of the Interior to make grants for a Native American language survival school, a Native American language nest, or any other educational program in which instruction is conducted in a Native American language. Requires grant applicants to have at least three years of experience in operating and administering such a school, nest, or program.

Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that for purposes of the general business credit, for either an eligible taxpayer or a farmer-owned entity, the value-added agricultural property investment credit for any taxable year is 50 percent of the basis of any qualified value-added agricultural property placed in service during the taxable year. Provides that, in the case of a farmer-owned entity, such credit shall be allocated on a pro rata basis among eligible persons holding qualified interests in such entity as of the last day of such taxable year. Limits such credit.

Regional Innovation and Entrepreneurship Enhancement Act of 2014 - Amends the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 to direct the Secretary of Commerce to establish an Office of Innovation and Entrepreneurship to foster innovation and the commercialization of new technologies, products, processes, and services with the goal of promoting productivity and economic growth in the United States. Requires the Office to: (1) develop policies to accelerate innovation and advance the commercialization of research and development; (2) identify existing barriers to innovation and commercialization; (3) provide access to relevant data, research, and technical assistance on innovation and commercialization; (4) oversee the implementation of the loan guarantee programs and the Regional Innovation Program; and (5) develop and update every five years a strategic plan to guide its activities. Directs the Secretary to establish or designate an advisory committee to provide advice to the Secretary on carrying out the duties and responsibilities of the Office. Requires the first report from the advisory committee to be submitted within one year after enactment of this Act. Authorizes the Secretary to award grants on a competitive basis to eligible recipients for activities relating to the formation and development of regional innovation clusters.

Home Health Documentation and Program Improvement Act of 2017 This bill amends titles XVIII (Medicare) and XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to specify how the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) will document the Medicare eligibility of home health services furnished by a home health agency. Under current law, the CMS must use the medical records of the physician who certifies or the medical record of the acute or post-acute care facility when documenting Medicare eligibility for home health services. The bill allows the CMS to use the home health agency medical records as well. The CMS must establish a settlement process under which a home health agency entitled to an eligible administrative appeal has the option to enter into a settlement with the CMS that is reached in a manner consistent with this bill.

Promoting Affordable Childcare for Everyone Act or the PACE Act This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the tax credit for employment-related expenses incurred for household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment, to: (1) make the credit refundable, (2) increase the rate of such credit from 35% to 50%, (3) increase the exclusion from gross income for employer-provided dependent care assistance, and (4) allow an inflation adjustment to the dollar amounts of such credit beginning after 2016.

Absentee Ballot Track, Receive, and Confirm Act - Amends the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to direct the Election Assistance Commission to reimburse a state for the costs incurred in establishing, if it so chooses, an absentee ballot tracking program for federal elections.
Homeowner Empowerment Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income up to $5,000 of distributions from qualified retirement plans used for mortgage payments.
Civil Rights Amendments Act of 2003 - Amends the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and other civil rights laws to include affectional or sexual orientation among the prohibited categories of discrimination.

Counter Terrorism Financing Coordination Act - Directs the Secretary of State and the Secretary of the Treasury to negotiate and enter into a Memorandum of Agreement specifying the role of each agency within the Terrorist Financing Working Group regarding the delivery of counterterrorism financing training and technical assistance to countries vulnerable to terrorist financing.

Birthparent Assistance Act of 2008 - Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to provide certain services for birthparents who have placed a child for adoption, either directly or by grant to or contract with state or local governmental entities or public or private agencies or organizations, including licensed child welfare or adoption agencies or adoptive family groups and faith-based organizations. Includes among such services: (1) post-legal adoption services; (2) individual, group, and family counseling; (3) establishment and operation of a nationally-available hotline; and (4) training of staff at hospitals and other appropriate birth care facilities relating to their interaction with birthparents and adoptive families.

Animal Drug Amendments of 1994 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to allow, on order of a veterinarian: (1) a new animal drug approved for one use to be used for a different purpose other than a use in or on animal feed; and (2) a new drug approved for human use to be used in animals. <n>Specifies that regulations may prohibit particular uses of an animal drug and shall not permit such different use if the labeling of another animal drug contains the same active ingredient and that is in the same dosage form and concentration provides for such different use. <n>Permits the Secretary of Health and Human Services, upon finding that there is a reasonable probability that an animal drug use may present a risk to the public health, to establish a safe level for residue of an animal drug for such different authorized use and require the development of a practical, analytical method for the detection of residues of the drug above the safe level established. Directs that the use of an animal drug which results in residues exceeding a safe level so established be considered an unsafe use of such drug. Allows safe levels to be established either by regulation or order. <n>Authorizes the Secretary by general regulation to provide access to the records of veterinarians to ascertain any use or intended use

Models' Academy Demonstration Act - Directs the Secretary of Education to carry out a demonstration program under which the Secretary establishes a four-year, residential, military style academy that: (1) offers at-risk youth secondary school coursework and vocational training, and that may offer precollegiate coursework; (2) focuses on the education and vocational training of youth at risk of delinquency or dropping out of secondary school; (3) whose teachers are primarily composed of former members of the Armed Forces or participants in a specified program assisted under the Troops to Teachers Program; (4) operates a mentoring program that provides one- to-one mentoring relationships between mentors and Academy students; (5) may contain Reserve Officers Training Corps role models; and (6) is housed on the site of any military installation closed pursuant to a base closure law.

Information Technology Partnerships Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make competitive grants to institutions of higher education to establish, oversee the operation of, and provide technical assistance to projects implemented by community-based organizations to provide postsecondary information technology education and employment procurement assistance to eligible individuals.Makes institutions eligible only to receive one grant, but may use such grant to enter into contracts with more than one community-based organization.Requires the provision of payments under a grant to not exceed five fiscal years and shall be subject to the annual approval of the Secretary and subject to the availability of appropriations for each fiscal year involved.Prohibits an entity from being considered a community-based organization unless, at the time it enters into a contract with an institution of higher education for such a project, it has demonstrated to the Secretary that: (1) it has the capacity successfully to recruit eligible individuals for project participation; (2) it is providing an educational service, social service, or employment procurement service; and (3) in the case of an entity that independently manages its own finances, it has been in existence two years or more.

Amends the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to allow a state authorized public entity health benefits pool to apply to the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) for a pass through of funding with respect to health care benefits provided through that pool for coverage years beginning on or after January 1, 2014.

Prostate Testing Full Information Act - Requires physicians, if they examine the prostate gland of a patient during a physical examination, to provide information concerning the availability of appropriate diagnostic procedures, including the prostate antigen test, if any of the following conditions are present: (1) the patient is over 50 years of age; (2) the patient manifests clinical symptomatology; (3) the patient is at an increased risk of prostate cancer; or (4) the provision of such information is medically necessary. Declares that nothing in this Act shall be construed as requiring a group health plan or a health insurance issuer providing health insurance coverage in connection with a group health plan to provide coverage for prostate specific antigen tests. Amends the Public Health Service Act, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, and the Mental Health Parity Act of 1996 to require those same physicians to provide information concerning the availability of appropriate diagnostic procedures, including the prostate antigen test, if any of the following conditions are present: (1) the patient is over 50 years of age; (2) the patient manifests clinical symptomatology; (3) the patient is at an increased risk of prostate cancer; or (4) the provision of such information is medically necessary.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on January 8, 2013. Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2012 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act to revise the nutritional information that chain restaurants and retail food establishments must disclose, including: (1) the number of calories contained in the whole product; (2) the number of servings and number of calories per serving; or (3) the number of calories per common unit of the product, such as for a multi-serving item that is typically divided before presentation to the consumer. Allows such information to be provided by a remote-access menu, such as one available on the Internet, instead of on a premises menu. Defines reasonable basis" for nutrient disclosure purposes to mean that the disclosure is within acceptable allowances for variation in nutrient content.<n><n>Authorizes restaurants or retail food establishments to determine and disclose nutritional information by using: (1) ranges, averages, individual labeling of flavors or components, or labeling of one preset standard build."

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2009. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Troubled Assets Stabilization Act of 2009 - (Sec. 2) Amends the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 to redefine  troubled asset" to include: (1) any residential mortgage that is in pre-foreclosure or in forbearance; or (2) any other financial instrument that the Secretary of the Treasury determines is necessary to promote financial market stability, but only upon transmittal to the appropriate congressional committees. Defines "rebilitated mortgage" as a mortgage that has been restructured, refinanced, or otherwise modified to lower the borrower\\'s monthly payment.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to establish a Troubled Asset Restoration Program (TARAP) to allow the Treasury to purchase lenders or rehabilitated mortgage lenders on terms and conditions determined by the Secretary, subject to specified conditions.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to write off certain conditions between the original asset and the rehabilitated asset portion of the lender or lender that is not paid for all of the mortgage debt on which the lender was not paid for in 2008.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary, in TARAP, to purchase troubled assets as well as rehabilitated assets, if an independent appraiser determines that an asset"

Requires the petitioner, to seek acknowledgment or recognition as an Indian tribe under Federal law, to first submit to the Secretary of the Interior a letter of intent to seek such status. (Sec. 2) Requires the Secretary to notify the Governor and attorney general of each State in which the petitioner states that it is located of: (1) the letter of intent; and (2) the name and contact information for the Indian tribe. Requires the Secretary to consult with the Governor and attorney general of the affected State or States to identify municipalities located within the vicinity of the place that the petitioner states on the application.(Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary to notify the petitioner and all interested parties, and publish notice in the Federal Register, of the date that a petition comes under active review. Requires the Secretary to provide a reasonable period for comment by interested parties and the public on each petition for Federal acknowledgment or recognition. Requires the Secretary to publish in the Federal Register detailed findings on each of those criteria.Requires any petition under review on the date of the enactment of this Act not subject to such comment to be reconsidered by the Secretary to provide a comment period.(Sec. 6) Prohibits the Director from granting Federal acknowledgment or recognition to any Indian tribe unless such petitioner has met all of the criteria

Employment Non-Discrimination Act of 1995 Prohibits employment discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation by covered entities, including entities covered under specified employment discrimination prohibitions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as well as employing authorities to which specified provisions of the Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 or the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 apply. Prohibits such entities from: (1) adopting or implementing a quota on such basis; or (2) giving preferential treatment to an individual on such basis. Exempts religious organizations from such prohibitions.

EPSCoR Research and Competitiveness Act of 2006 - Authorizes appropriations to the National Science Foundation (NSF) for FY2007-FY2011 for the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).<n><n>Requires the Director of NSF, in administration of EPSCoR grants, to authorize states participating in the grant program to include partnerships with out-of-state research institutions if the amount of funding transferred to another state does not exceed 5% of the amount of the grant in any fiscal year.<n><n>Requires the Director to obligate and expend at least 20% of the amount available for EPSCoR on co-funding projects ranked by a peer-review process in the top 20% of all proposals submitted in response to an announced competition.<n><n>Requires the Director, through the Office of Major Research Instrumentation, to develop and publish a plan enabling states participating in EPSCoR to develop partnerships and participate fully in the NSF's major research instrumentation program.

Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to direct the Attorney General to ensure that all numerical limitations applicable to the issuance of visas or the provision of nonimmigrant status are applied in a manner that: (1) accurately reflects the actual number of aliens who commence employment in the United States as H-1B (specialty occupations) nonimmigrants in each fiscal year; and (2) does not count against any such numerical limitation any visa issued to an alien based on a petition filed by an employer that is not used by the alien as the basis for admission into the United States and commencement of employment with such employer within a reasonable period of time subsequent to its issuance any visa, including any visa in excess of one, in cases in which multiple visas are issued to a single alien based on petitions filed by multiple prospective employers and the alien accepts employment with only one of those employers.

Amends Federal civil service law to include as Federal law enforcement officers eligible under the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System revenue officers in the Internal Revenue Service, customs inspectors and canine enforcement officers in the Customs Service, and inspectors and diversion investigators in the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

Support for Democracy and Human Rights in Zimbabwe Act of 2007 (Sec. 3) States that it is U.S policy to: (1) support the people of Zimbabwe in their efforts to promote democracy and respect for human rights; and (2) call on President Mugabe to immediately restore democracy and human rights in Zimbabwe. (Sec. 4) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the United States welcomes the announcement by the Southern African Development Community that the President of South Africa, Thaboeki, will lead negotiations between the ruling and opposition parties in Zimbabwe to resolve the political and humanitarian crisis in a way that reflects the will of the people of Zimbabwe and respects international standards; (2) the creation of a level playing field for those who want to participate in the political process should be priority objectives in the negotiations; (3) all preparations should be made to hold free and peaceful elections in accordance with international standards; and (4) cooperation between the United States, regional players in the Parliamentary Forum Election Norms and Guidelines and the wider international community is an important component of a proactive strategy to support democratic rule and respect for human rights in Zimbabwe. (Sec. 5) States that until the government of Zimbabwe promotes democracy and the rule of law, the United States will continue to isolate the government of Zimbabwe and work with regional and international

Cell Phone Theft Prevention Act of 2012 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit a provider of commercial mobile or commercial mobile data service from providing service on a mobile electronic device that has been reported to such provider as stolen: (1) if the account holder submits a copy of a report made to a law enforcement agency regarding the theft to the service provider, or (2) by another service provider receiving a copy of the report. Requires service providers receiving a report that a device has been stolen to inform all other providers.<n><n>Prohibits the manufacturing of a mobile electronic device, or the importation of such a device into the United States for sale or resale to the public, unless the device is: (1) equipped with a unique identifier (such as a Mobile Equipment Identifier) that allows the service provider to identify the device; and (2) configured with remote deletion capability. Requires service providers to make available to account holders the capability of deleting, from a remote location, all information that was placed on a mobile electronic device after its manufacture.

Vote By Mail Act of 2016 This bill directs the Election Assistance Commission to award grants to eligible states to implement a vote-by-mail election system. A "eligible state" is a state that has received a grant under the Voting Rights Act of 1965 or the National Voter Registration Act of 1993.

Local Control of Broadcast Towers Act - Prohibits the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) from adopting as a final rule the proposed rule set forth in Preemption of State and Local Zoning and Land Use Restrictions on Siting, Placement and Construction of Broadcast Station Transmission Facilities." Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to authorize States or local governments to: (1) deny an application to place, construct, or modify broadcast transmission facilities on the basis that alternative technologies, delivery systems, or structures are capable of delivering broadcast signals comparable to those proposed to be delivered by such facilities in a manner that is less intrusive to the community concerned; (2) consider the aesthetics, environmental impact, and radio frequency interference or radiation emitted by such technologies, systems, or structures when determining such eligibility; and (3) regulate the location, height, or modification of such facilities in order to address the effects of radio frequency interference caused by such facilities on local communities and the public. Prohibits the FCC from requiring studies and documentation regarding the intrusiveness, environmental impact, and radio frequency interference or radiation emitted by such technologies, systems, or structures."

Mandates Information Act of 1998 - Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 (the Act) to require the Director of the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) in preparing estimates of the direct costs of a Federal private sector mandate to estimate, when applicable, the impact of such mandate on consumers, workers, and small businesses, including any disproportionate impact in particular regions or industries. Requires a point of order against legislation that would increase the direct costs of Federal private sector mandates (excluding direct costs attributable to revenue resulting from tax or tariff provisions of any such measure if it does not raise net tax and tariff revenues over the five-fiscal-year period beginning with the first fiscal year such measure affects such revenues) by an amount that causes the stated threshold of $100 million per fiscal year to be exceeded.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on September 24, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) American Elections Act of 2010 - Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to prohibit any corporation (other than a foreign principal) under foreign control or substantial foreign influence from making contributions, donations, or expenditures in connection with a federal, state, or local election, unless the corporation: (1) provided the corporation a majority of its gross receipts for the immediately preceding fiscal year, or the current pro-rated fiscal year if the corporation was established during the current fiscal year; (2) controls 20% or more of the voting shares of the corporation; (3) controls a majority of the Board of Directors of the corporation; or (4) has the power to direct, dictate, control, or directly or indirectly participate in the decisionmaking process of the corporation with respect to activities in connection with such an election, such as a decision concerning making a contribution, donation, expenditure, or disbursement in connection with such an election or the administration of a political committee. Requires a corporation to certify to the Federal Election Commission (FEC) that it is in compliance with such Act.<n><n>Requires communications to include the percentage of voting shares of the corporation that are controlled by a

Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through one or more officers or employees duly designated by the Secretary, to inspect establishments engaged in the manufacture, propagation, compounding, or processing of a device or devices in accordance with one risk-based inspection schedule established by the Secretary, applied consistently across regional offices. Requires the Secretary to: (1) apply the factors identified in this Act to the extent applicable for device establishments, and (2) consider the participation of such establishment in international device audit programs in which the United States participates or the United States recognizes for purposes of inspecting. Directs the Secretary to adopt a uniform process and uniform standards applicable to inspections of domestic and foreign device establishments. Requires the Secretary to provide nonbinding feedback regarding proposed actions within 45 days of receipt of such request. Sets forth exceptions to the requirements of this Act for inspections other than for-cause inspections.

Small Business Health Relief Act of 2011 - Amends the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) to repeal provisions that: (1) limit the annual deductible on health plans offered in the small group market, (2) deem catastrophic plans to meet essential health benefits coverage requirements, and (3) impose an annual fee on health insurance entities. Requires such provisions to be applied and administered as if they had never been enacted.<n><n>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to treat a health plan that meets certain requirements for a high deductible health plan as meeting such requirements if the enrollee has established a health savings account.<n><n>Repeals the prohibitions on payments for over-the-counter medications from health savings accounts, medical savings accounts, and health flexible spending arrangements. Repeals the $2,500 annual limit on employee contributions by salary reduction to a health flexible spending arrangement under a cafeteria plan.

Acid Rain Mercury Control Act - Amends the Clean Air Act to require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to reduce aggregate sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide emissions from powerplants by 75% from the levels allowed under full implementation of the Phase II sulfur dioxide requirements under the Act. Requires mercury emissions from power plants to reduce by 75% from the levels allowed under the Mercury Rule under the Clean Air Act.

Healthy Kids for Healthy Futures Act of 2009 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), the Public Health Service Act, and the Internal Revenue Code to require a group health plan and a health insurance issuer providing coverage in connection with a group health plan to provide coverage for appropriate preventive care for each qualified dependent child of the participant. Defines appropriate preventive care" as medical care that meets the most recent Bright Futures Guidelines for Health Supervision of Infants, Children, and Adolescents. Prohibits a plan from: (1) denying eligibility, enrollment, or renewal solely to avoid this Act\\'s requirements; (2) penalizing or providing incentives to providers; or (3) imposing cost-sharing."

. The expanded summary of the House passed version is repeated here.) Sport Fish Restoration and Recreational Boating Safety Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act to reauthorize through FY2020 the grant program for state recreational boating safety programs and the Sportfishing and Boating Safety Act of 1998. The bill sets the amount of grants that may be used for boating infrastructure improvement under the Clean Vessel Act of 1992 and the Sportfishing and Boating Safety Act of 1998 at 4% of the amounts authorized to be appropriated to the Department of the Interior for each fiscal year through FY2020. Not more than 75% of the amounts authorized through FY2020 shall be available for projects under either Act. The bill sets the amount of grants that may be used by the Coast Guard for each fiscal year from FY2016-FY2020 at no more than the amount specified in the bill for the fiscal year for the purposes of the grant program.

Officer Daniel Faulkner Children of Fallen Heroes Scholarship Act of 2010 - Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to eliminate the expected family contribution (EFC) used to determine financial need in the case of a Pell Grant-eligible student whose parent or guardian died in the line of duty as a police officer, firefighter, or ambulance member. (Such student is eligible to receive an automatic zero EFC and qualify for the maximum Pell Grant award if the student was less than 24 years old or enrolled at an institution of higher education at the time of the parent or guardian's death.)

Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act of 1993 - Amends the Consumer Credit Protection Act to prohibit a seller in a rent-to-own transaction from receiving or assessing any interest, finance charge, or other fee for the transaction that exceeds the interest, fees, or finance charges permissible under the laws of the State in which the seller is located which establish: (1) a maximum rate or amount of interest, finance charge, or time-price differential that may be charged in connection with a credit sale or retail installment sale for the same or a similar item; (2) the types of fees and the maximum amount of fees that a seller may so charge; or (3) the types of credit insurance and the maximum amount of premiums that can be charged for credit insurance in such a connection. <n>Sets forth required disclosures, prohibitions, and enforcement, as well as civil liability for failure to properly disclose the terms of a rent-to-own transaction. <n>Declares this Act inapplicable to certain motor vehicles sales and leases otherwise subject to the Truth in Lending Act.

Office of Domestic Product Promotion Act - Establishes within the Department of Commerce an Office of Domestic Product Promotion to: (1) work with U.S. businesses to promote domestic products; (2) provide information and advice to such businesses on benefits and incentives available to them for producing such products, including federal procurement contracts and federal and state tax benefits; (3) establish a comprehensive database of businesses that use, sell, or would prefer to use or sell domestic products and make such information available to the public; and (4) develop tools and ideas on how to promote domestic products.<n><n>Requires the Office to have six regional offices, each headed by a regional director, and one regional office.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on February 29, 2016. Executive Cyberspace Coordination Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the head of each federal agency to submit to the National Office for Cyberspace a budget for the following fiscal year relating to the protection of information infrastructure for such agency, which shall include: a review of any threats to information technology for such agency; a plan to secure the information infrastructure for such agency based on threats to information technology, using the National Institute of Standards and Technology guidelines and recommendations; a review of compliance by such agency with any previous year plan; and a report on the development of the credentialing process to enable secure authentication of identity and authorization for access to the information infrastructure of such agency. The office shall be headed by a Director who shall make recommendations to the President regarding changes in the organization, management, and budget of each agency relating to the protection of information infrastructure and changes in the allocation of personnel to and within such agency, including monetary penalties or incentives necessary to encourage and maintain accountability of any agency or senior agency official for efforts to secure the information infrastructure of such agency. The President's annual budget submission to Congress shall include recommendations for: (1) specific initiatives consistent with the priorities of the President relating to

Paul Wellstone Mental Health Equitable Treatment Act of 2005 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) and the Internal Revenue Code to prohibit a group health plan that provides both medical-surgical and health benefits from imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements with respect to the coverage of benefits for mental illnesses unless comparable treatment limitations or financial requirements are imposed on medical and surgical benefits.

Establishes the Trade Agreement Enforcement Commission to monitor, investigate, and report to Congress and the President on the enforcement by each trading partner of worker rights in the territory of the trading partner.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax deduction for the value of securities transferred from a decedent to an employee stock ownership plan in a qualified gratuitous transfer. Defines qualified gratuitous transfer" as a transfer of qualified employer securities to an employee stock ownership plan in which the remainder interest is in securities issued by a domestic corporation which has no outstanding stock which is readily tradable on an established securities market."

Genetic Fairness Act of 1996 - Prohibits insurers offering a health plan from: (1) terminating, restricting, limiting, or otherwise applying conditions to coverage of an individual or family member or the sale of the plan to an individual or family member; (2) canceling or refusing to renew the coverage of an individual or family member; (3) denying coverage or excluding coverage for certain benefits and services; (4) imposing a rider that excludes coverage for certain benefits and services; (5) establishing differentials in premium rates or cost sharing for coverage; or (6) discriminating against an individual or family member in the provision of health care on the basis of any genetic information concerning an individual or family member, or on the basis of an individual's or family member's request for or receipt of genetic services. Declares that an insurer offering a health plan may not require an applicant for coverage, or an individual or family member who is presently covered under the plan, to be the subject of a genetic test or to be subjected to questions relating to genetic information. Specifies that an insurer offering a health plan shall, in the enrollment information provided by it, provide an enrollee with a written statement disclosing the rights of the enrollee under this Act. Specifies that such requirements shall be enforced by the State insurance commissioner

This bill declares it shall be U.S policy to condemn Iranian activities in Yemen in violation of United Nations Security Council Resolution 2216 (2015) and call on all responsible countries to take appropriate and necessary measures against the government of Iran, including the interdiction of Iranian weapons to the Houthis, and the bilateral and multilateral application of sanctions against Iran for its violations of such Resolution. United States sanctions with respect to Yemen provided for in Executive Order 13611 shall remain in effect. The President shall determine whether specified Iranian persons are responsible for engaging in such activities and, if so, impose such sanctions.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on December 7, 2011. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Microenterprise and Youth Entrepreneurship Development Act of 2011 - Amends the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 to include entrepreneurs operating businesses or intending to operate businesses in an investment area among those eligible for microenterprise technical assistance and capacity building grants. Authorizes the use of such assistance to advertise in print, electronic, and other media the training and technical assistance provided under such program. Reduces from 50% to 60% the matching funds required of grant recipients. Directs the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA), in determining whether to reduce or eliminate such matching requirements, to consider the impact of the economic crisis of 2007 through 2009 on the geographic area in which an applicant operates.<n><n>Requires the Administrator to report to the congressional small business committees recommendations for improving the application and grant making process of such program.<n><n>Directs the Administrator to establish in the SBA the position of Microenterprise Coordinator to: (1) ensure that the contributions of microenterprises to the economy are maximized; (2) enhance, support, and coordinate federal programs providing assistance to microenterprises; (3) ensure that underserved entrepreneurs are included; (4) make available to the

Defend America Against Weapons of Mass Destruction Act of 1996 - Directs the Secretary of Defense to carry out a research and development program to enhance U.S. capabilities relating to the threat to the United States by unconventional means involving weapons of mass destruction.

Cancer Survivorship Research and Quality of Life Act of 2002 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to: (1) expand and coordinate NIH activities with respect to cancer survivorship research; and (2) establish an Office on Survivorship within the National Institute on Child Health and Human Development.Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, to study the unique health challenges associated with cancer survivorship and carry out projects and interventions to improve the long-term health status of cancer survivors.

Fair Pay Act of 1997 - Amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to prohibit discrimination in the payment of wages on account of sex, race, or national origin. <n>Directs courts, in any action brought under this section for violation of such prohibition, to allow expert fees as part of the costs awarded to prevailing plaintiffs. Allows any such action to be maintained as a class action. <n>Requires employers subject to such prohibition to preserve records which document and support the method, system, calculations, and other bases used by the employer in establishing, adjusting, and determining the wages paid to their employees, for periods of time prescribed by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), and make reports to the EEOC. <n>Directs the EEOC to: (1) undertake studies and provide information and technical assistance to employers, labor organizations, and the general public concerning effective means available to implement the provisions of this Act; (2) carry on a continuing program of research, education, and technical assistance with specified components related to the purposes of this Act; and (3) include a separate evaluation and appraisal regarding the implementation of this Act in its annual report to the Congress.

Military Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2013 - Expands the covered communications of a member of the Armed Forces with respect to prohibited retaliatory personnel actions to include: (1) testimony or otherwise participating in an investigation or proceeding related to such a communication, or filing, causing to be filed, participating in, or otherwise assisting in an action brought; and (2) any favorable action or a significant change in a member's duties, responsibilities, or working conditions to include any violation of any law, rule, or regulation, including a law or regulation prohibiting rape, sexual assault, or other sexual misconduct. Prohibits the exclusion from such protections of a communication made to a person who participated in an activity that the member reasonably believed to be covered by such protection because: (1) the communication was made to a person who participated in such an activity; (2) the communication revealed information that had previously been communicated; (3) the member's motive for making the communication was not made in writing; (4) the communication was made while the member was off duty; (5) the communication was made during the normal course of duties of the member; and (6) the member's consent. Requires: (1) a report from the Inspector General (IG) of a military department to the Secretary of Defense (DOD)

Charles August Longdiagnosed Diseases Research and Collaboration Network Act of 2011 or the CAL Undiagnosed Diseases Research and Collaboration Network Act of 2011 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH), to establish and maintain an undiagnosed undiagnosed diseases network (the CAL Network) to: (1) provide physicians who are handling cases of undiagnosed diseases with a means to search for similar cases and to network and collaborate with physicians handling such cases in order to find a diagnosis and to improve patient care and outcomes; (2) better enable and examine cross-disease research whereby cases of undiagnosed diseases can be cross-diagnosed against attributes of common diseases and rare diseases to assist in the rendering of a diagnosis and to identify potential treatments; (3) better describe the types and prevalence of cases of undiagnosed diseases in the United States; (4) make necessary data available to elucidate appropriate factors that may be associated with the various types of cases of undiagnosed diseases reported by individuals specified by the Director of NIH; (5) outline key demographic factors of individuals who are undiagnosed; (6) provide such data necessary to better understand the length of time for a diagnoses to be rendered in cases of undiagnosed diseases and to identify barriers to diagnoses and reasons for restricted access; and (7)

Empowering Financial Institutions to Fight Human Trafficking Act of 2018 This bill requires the Department of the Treasury to issue regulations to allow qualified nonprofit organizations to share information with financial institutions, associations of financial institutions, their regulatory authorities, and law enforcement agencies regarding individuals, entities, organizations, and countries suspected of possible human trafficking or related money laundering activities.

Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to establish a program of grants to local educational agencies (LEAs) that have taken steps to improve teacher quality and raise student achievement. Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award such grants if the applicant LEAs: (1) have a percentage of children eligible for free or reduced priced lunches under the National School Lunch Act that exceeds 65 percent; (2) have taken significant steps to ensure that all students are taught by fully-qualified teachers; (3) do not use teachers certified on an emergency basis; (4) do not use social promotion; (5) all students in grades kindergarten through grade 12 under their jurisdiction are subject to State achievement standards in the core curriculum at key transition points; and (6) use tests and other indicators, such as grades and teacher evaluations, to assess student performance in meeting State achievement standards. Requires LEA grant applications to include plans for ensuring that all students are taught by fully-qualified teachers and for quantifying progress toward achieving that end.

Teacher Protection Act of 2001 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA) to establish a new title XV, Teacher Liability Protection.Preempts State laws to the extent that such laws are inconsistent with ESEA, except that ESEA shall not preempt any State law that provides additional protection from liability relating to teachers. Makes ESEA title XV inapplicable to any civil action in a State court against a teacher in which all parties are citizens of the State if such State enacts a statute in accordance with State requirements for enacting legislation: (1) citing the authority of this Act; (2) declaring the election of such State that ESEA shall not apply, as of a date certain, to such civil action in the State; and (3) containing no other provisions.Declares that no teacher in a school shall be liable for harm caused by an act or omission on behalf of the school if the teacher was acting within the scope of employment or responsibilities related to providing educational services, actions were carried out in conformity with local, State, or Federal laws, rules or regulations in furtherance of efforts to control, discipline, expel, or suspend a student or maintain order or control in the classroom or school, the teacher was properly licensed, certified, or authorized by the

Education Modernization Fund Act - Directs the Secretary of Education to make loans to States for the purpose of constructing and modernizing elementary schools and secondary schools.Establishes in the Treasury the Education Modernization Fund.

Pregnant Workers Fairness Act - Prohibits employment discrimination based on pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions against job applicants or employees by covered entities, including entities covered under specified provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995, and the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993.

Electronic Funds Transfer Equal Consumer Protection Act - Amends the Electronic Fund Transfer Act to define  Error" as an electronic fund transfer affecting a consumer\\'s account in connection with a transaction not accepted by the customer or a designee or not delivered to the customer, or that is not in accordance with an agreement made at the time of a transaction. Excludes from such definition transactions initiated through an electronic terminal, telephonic instrument, or computer, including transactions initiated through a card commonly referred to as a debit card, without regard to the manner in which the third party conveys the order, instruction, or authorization to credit or debit the consumer\\'s account at the financial institution.<n><n>Requires a financial institution to provisionally recredit a consumer\\'s account for an amount alleged to be in error within one business day after receiving notice of such error from the consumer. Requires the financial institution to investigate the alleged error, determine whether an error has occurred, and report or mail the results to the consumer within one business day.<n><n>Revises prompt error resolution requirements to require a financial institution to investigate and determine within one business day whether an error has occurred.<n><n>Allows a financial institution to require written confirmation from a consumer of an error provided the consumer: (1) advises the consumer of such requirement at"

Energy Savings Performance Contracts Amendments Act of 2003 - Amends the National Energy Conservation Policy Act to: (1) repeal the termination date (thus extending the programs under such Act indefinitely); and (2) allow benefits ancillary to an energy savings contract or energy savings performance contract providing for energy savings through the construction and operation of one or more buildings or facilities to replace one or more existing buildings or facilities to include savings resulting from reduced costs of operation and maintenance at such replacement buildings or facilities when compared with costs of operation and maintenance at the buildings or facilities being replaced.(Sec. 3) Allows aggregate annual payments by an agency under an energy savings contract or energy savings performance contract to take into account savings resulting from reduced costs of operation and maintenance.(Sec. 4) Redefines energy savings" to include a reduction in the cost of energy or water, from a base cost established through a methodology set forth in the contract, used in an existing federally owned building or facilities as a result of: (1) the lease or purchase of operating equipment, improvements, altered operation and maintenance, or technical services; (2) the increased efficient use of existing energy sources by cogeneration or heat recovery, excluding any cogeneration process for other than a federally owned building or facilities; or (3) the increased efficient use of existing"

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Joint Resolution making further continuing appropriations for FY 1986 <n> Title II: General Provisions <n>Title I: Joint Resolution making further continuing appropriations for FY 1986 <n> Title II: General Provisions <n>Repeals the authority of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation to make new obligations with respect to clean coal technology projects selected by the Secretary of Energy pursuant to the fifth general request for proposals issued by the Secretary. <n>Rescinds any unobligated funds previously appropriated for the Clean Coal Technology program. <n>Title IV: Foreign Operations Programs <n> - Repeals title IV of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, but continues to apply with respect to functions performed by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget.

Cattle Industry Improvement Act of 1996- Amends the Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996 to provide for the expedited implementation of the Fund for Rural America. <n>(Sec. 3) Amends the Packers and Stockyards Act, 1921 to prohibit noncompetitive livestock or meat procurement practices. <n>(Sec. 4) Amends the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 to direct persons in the slaughtering business to report to the Secretary of Agriculture certain price and sale information. Provides for fines and/or imprisonment for failure to comply. <n>(Sec. 5) Amends the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 to require the Secretary to: (1) eliminate obsolete reports; and (2) streamline collection and reporting of data related to livestock and meat and livestock products, using modern data communications technology, to provide information to the public on as close to a real-time basis as practicable. <n>(Sec. 6) Amends the Packers and Stockyards Act, 1921 to provide for protection of livestock producers against retaliation by packers. <n>(Sec. 7) Amends the Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996 to direct the Secretary to conduct a review of certain Federal agriculture credit policies. <n>(Sec. 9) Amends the Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996 to direct the

Cancer Research Fund Act of 1997 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to establish in the Treasury the Cancer Research Trust Fund. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to designate the Fund as a tax-exempt organization.

Derivatives and Hedge Fund Regulatory Improvement Act of 2008 - Directs the appropriate federal banking agencies and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to initiate a coordinated rulemaking to regulate entities that engage in transactions involving unregistered hedge funds or over-the-counter derivatives. Requires such regulations to: (1) extend the requirements of regulations relating to the safety and soundness of the financial system applicable to mutual funds under the Investment Company Act of 1940 to unregistered hedge funds; (2) provide for the regulation of over-the-counter derivatives, including credit default swaps, interest rate swaps, currency swaps, mortgage-backed securities, asset-backed securities, collateralized debt obligations, and other derivatives that are not traded on a national securities exchange or by a registered securities association, in the public interest and for the protection of investors, the stability of the financial markets, and the well-being of the economy; and (3) prohibit insured depository institutions from trading derivatives for their own accounts.

Border Security Enforcement Act of 2010 - Authorizes the Governor of Arizona to: (1) order 3,000 members of the Arizona National Guard and other National Guard units to perform Active Guard and Reserve duty, by immediately deploying along the Tucson Sector border and the Yuma Sector border; and (2) construct and maintain surveillance platforms to facilitate such deployment. Requires such deployment to continue until the Governor certifies that the federal government has achieved operational control of such border.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) to: (1) increase the number of trained Border Patrol agents stationed along such border by 3,000, compared to the number as of this Act's enactment date; (2) make progress in increasing such number during each of FY2010-FY2015; and (3) assign Border Patrol agents who are assigned to rural, high-trafficked areas to receive hardship duty pay, in an amount determined by the Commissioner, Customs and Border Protection, which may not exceed the rate of special pay to which members of a uniformed service are entitled.<n><n>Authorizes appropriations to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) for FY2010-FY2020 for enhancing law enforcement preparedness and operational readiness along U.S. borders through Operation Stonegarden. Requires at least 90% of such appropriations to be allocated for grants and reimbursement to law enforcement

Deadly Driver Reduction Act - Amends Federal transportation law to direct the Secretary of Transportation to withhold five percent of a State's Federal-aid highway funds for FY 2003 if such State has not enacted and is not enforcing a law that provides certain minimum sentences for driving a motor vehicle while under the influence (having a blood alcohol concentration of .16 or greater) of alcohol, including revocation of the individual's driver's license, payment of a $500 fine, and assessment of the individual's degree of alcohol abuse. Authorizes the Secretary to withhold ten percent of a State's Federal-aid highway funds for FY 2003 if the State has not enacted and is not enforcing such a law.

Kosova Peace and Democracy Act of 1994 - Expresses the sense of the Congress that: (1) the elected government of Kosova should be allowed to assemble and exercise its mandate as elected representatives of the people of Kosova; (2) all individuals in Kosova whose employment was terminated on the basis of Albanian ethnicity should be allowed to be reinstated to all residents of Kosovar territory whose employment was terminated on the basis of Serbian ethnicity; (3) all ethnic Albanians in Kosovar areas and their replacement by Serbs should be allowed to be outside Kosovar territory and their replacement by U.S. federal positions should be reinstated; (4) the United Nations Special Rapporteur on Human Rights in Kosova should be allowed to assemble and exercise his or her mandate as elected representatives of the people of Kosova; (5) all individuals in Kosovar territory and their replacement by Serbian ethnicity should be allowed to be outside Kosovar territory and their replacement by U.S. federal positions should be reinstated; (6) all forms of Albanian language relating to freedom of expression should be respected; (7) Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe should be readmitted to Kosova and their numbers expanded; (8) the United Nations should dispatch observers to Kosova to monitor human rights and cultural character of the people of Kosova

Amends the Agricultural Act of 1949 to repeal the tobacco price support and marketing quota provisions. Amends the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 to repeal the tobacco marketing quota provisions. <n>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to disallow the deduction for certain advertising expenses for tobacco products.

Marriage Penalty Relief Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to accelerate, from 2003 through 2004, the elimination of the marriage penalty on the standard deduction and on the 15 percent tax bracket for married couples filing joint tax returns.Provides for an inflation adjustment to the $3,000 earned income credit amount for married couples filing joint tax returns.

Repatriate Our Patriots Act - Prohibits an alien special veteran" (defined as an alien who was discharged or released from the Armed Forces under honorable conditions and who does not include individuals who have been convicted of voluntary manslaughter, murder, rape, sexual abuse of a minor, or offenses relating to terrorism) from being removed from the United States. Requires a special veteran, notwithstanding any other provision of law, to be naturalized as a U.S. citizen upon the filing of the appropriate application, paying the appropriate fees, and, except with respect to naturalization taking and subscribing before an officer of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) within the United States, taking and subscribing before an DHS officer. Directs the Secretary of DHS to take steps to ensure that the period in which an application for naturalization is pending does not exceed 90 days. Directs the Secretary to furnish each special veteran naturalized with a certificate of citizenship. Authorizes in the case of a special veteran residing abroad, the application for naturalization to be filed from abroad and the oath of allegiance to be subscribed to abroad at U.S. embassies, consulates, and military installations overseas for members of the Armed Forces and their spouses and children. Authorizes the Secretary to waive the taking of the oath"

Revised Statutes 2477 Rights-of-Way Settlement Act - Requires a State, political subdivision, or other holder of a right-of-way across public lands which was granted under the Revised Statutes before the enactment of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (the Act) or any person who uses or could use such right for passage across such lands to access property in which such person has an interest to file with the appropriate Secretary of the Department of the Interior a notice of such right-of-way. Requires the notice to be filed within ten years after the enactment of this Act, to identify the State or political subdivision through which the right-of-way passes, and to contain a map and a general description of the route, termini, and scope of such right-of-way. <n>Requires the Secretary to: (1) notify the holder, or other party giving notice, of the recognition or objections of the Secretary of the right-of-way or any portion thereof; and (2) recognize any right-of-way which was accepted or established in accordance with the laws of the State where it is located or by an affirmative act of a State or political subdivision indicating acceptance of the grant. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to bring an action based

Mowa Band of Choctaw Indians Recognition Act - Extends Federal recognition and associated services and benefits to the Mowa Band of Choctaw Indians of Alabama. Restores Federal rights and privileges abrogated by earlier statutes. <n>Approves and ratifies the cession to the United States of all historical tribal lands of the Tribe. <n>States that, by virtue of such cession, all claims against the United States, a State or local government, or any other person or entity, by the Tribe, including but not limited to claims for trespass damages or claims for use and occupancy, arising subsequent to such cession and based upon any interest in or right involving the land, shall be regarded as extinguished as of the date of the cession. <n>Prohibits the Tribe from using its Federal recognition to assert any historical land claim. <n>Transfers all legal rights, title, and interests in lands held by the Tribe to the United States in trust for the use and benefit of the Tribe.

Congressional Accountability Now Act or CAN Act - Prohibits the use of funds appropriated or otherwise made available for the official travel expenses of a Member of Congress or other officer or employee of any office in the legislative branch for airline accommodations which are not coach-class accommodations. Amends the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 1991 to prohibit the use of funds appropriated or otherwise made available during a fiscal year for the operations of a House of Representatives, including the official and representational expenses of a Member, or the expenses of a committee or leadership office of a House, for the long-term leasing of a vehicle. Amends the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946 to reduce by 10% the annual rate of pay for each Senator, Member of the House, and Delegate to the House, and the Resident Commissioner from Puerto Rico, effective after the first regularly scheduled general election for federal office which is held after enactment of this Act. Amends Federal law to eliminate further retirement coverage of Members of Congress.

Flood-Affected States Assistance Act of 1993 - Establishes the Federal medical assistance percentage for services furnished during the two-year period beginning July 1, 1993, to any designated individual: (1) under title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act; and (2) in a designated State or a designated political subdivision. <n>Excludes from a determination of income or resources made by a State under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act as a result of the widespread flooding in the Midwest in 1993 the donation or temporary financial assistance provided by the Federal Government, a State, a political subdivision, or a private person to a designated individual or designated family as disaster assistance. <n>Provides for: (1) the Federal share of any grant made under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to a designated individual or a designated family for the two-year period beginning April 1, 1993; and (2) a waiver of the five percent limitation on administrative expenses under such Act. <n>Extends through December 31, 1993, the deadline for certain reporting requirements under the Act.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 12, 2014. Johnson Valley National Off-Highway Vehicle Recreation Area Establishment Act - (Sec. 2) Designates specified public land and interests administered by the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) in San Bernardino County, California, as the "Johnson Valley National Off-Highway Vehicle Recreation Area." Withdraws the public land and interests in the Recreation Area from all forms of appropriation under the public land laws, including the mining laws and the mineral leasing and geothermal leasing laws. (Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary of the Navy to authorize the Secretary of the Navy to utilize portions of the Recreation Area twice in each year for up to a total of 60 days per year for: sustained, combined arms, live-fire, and maneuver field training for large-scale Marine air-ground task forces; individual and unit live-fire training ranges; equipment and tactics development; and other defense-related purposes. Requires the Secretary of the Navy to: (1) consult with the Secretary of the Interior regarding the best times for military use to reduce interference with or interruption of nonmilitary activities, and (2) provide for public awareness of and participation in the selection process. Requires the Secretary of the Navy to:

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 12, 2016. Know Before You Fly Act (Sec. 2) This bill makes it an unfair or deceptive practice for any air carrier, foreign air carrier, or ticket agent to fail to include, in an internet fare quotation for a specific itinerary in air transportation selected by a consumer, a clear statement that additional fees for checked baggage and carry-on baggage may apply, along with a prominent link from that internet website page directly to a list of all such fees. (Sec. 3) A "covered air carrier" (an air carrier that provides scheduled or public charter passenger air transportation by operating an aircraft that as originally designed has a passenger capacity of 30 or more seats) shall publish on its public internet website, via a prominent link on its website, a clear statement indicating whether or not it will: (1) provide for hotel accommodations, (2) arrange for ground transportation, (3) provide meal vouchers, (4) arrange for air transportation on another air carrier or foreign air carrier to the passenger's destination, and (5) provide for sleeping facilities, food, and water inside the airport terminal. The information provided by a covered air carrier shall identify each air carrier and foreign air carrier with which it will arrange air transportation

Sport Fish Restoration and Recreational Boating Safety Act of 2011 - Amends the Federal Aid in Fish Restoration Act to reauthorize through FY2017 the Sport Fish Restoration and Boating Trust Fund. Extends the distributions of appropriations to: (1) the Department of the Interior for coastal wetlands distributions, the Clean Vessel Act of 1992, boating infrastructure, and national outreach and communications; and (2) the Department of Homeland Security (the department in which the Coast Guard is operating) for state recreational boating safety programs. Sets forth a formula that determines the maximum amount Interior may use for FY2013 and each fiscal year thereafter for national recreational boating safety activities. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend through FY2017 the exception from a limitation on transfers to fund state recreational boating safety programs.

Pain at the Pump Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal certain tax incentives for oil and gas companies, including: (1) the tax credit for enhanced oil recovery, (2) the tax credit for producing oil and gas from marginal wells, (3) the expensing allowance for intangible drilling and development costs, (4) the tax deduction for tertiary injectant expenses, (5) the percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells, and (6) the exception to passive loss limitations for working interests in oil and gas properties.

Stand with the Iranian People Act - Expresses the sense of Congress that the United States: (1) respects the sovereignty, history, and rich culture of the Iranian people; (2) respects and admires the Iranian people as they take steps to peacefully express their voices, opinions, and aspirations; (3) deplores the use of coerced confessions and  show trials" as tools of political repression in Iran; (4) urges the government of Iran to intensify cooperation on the case of Robert with the Embassy of Switzerland in Tehran and to share the results of its investigation into the disappearance of Robert with the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI); and (5) recognizes the importance of diplomacy with Iran in order to advance U.S. national security interests, but such diplomacy should not be construed as official recognition of the declared results from the June 12, 2009, Iranian presidential election.<n><n>States that it is U.S. policy to: (1) work to ensure that sanctions are clearly targeted at the government of Iran and individuals within the government of Iran, rather than the Iranian society as a whole; (2) encourage U.S. allies to freeze bank accounts held or controlled by Iranian government officials who have carried out human rights abuses against the Iranian people; (3) encourage U.S. allies to deny entrance to the United States visas for"

Patients' Formulary Rights Act of 1999- Amends the Public Health Service Act and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to prohibit a group health plan and a health insurance issuer offering group coverage from using a formulary unless the plan or issuer: (1) notifies participants, beneficiaries, and enrollees, prior to initial enrollment or coverage, and makes available at any time to health care professionals who prescribe prescription drugs under the plan or coverage; (2) notifies participants, beneficiaries, enrollees, and health care providers who prescribe covered prescription drugs under the plan or coverage on a routine and annual basis of any changes in the formulary; and (3) permits a participant, beneficiary, or enrollee who is provided coverage for a prescription drug at the time it is removed from the formulary to continue to have the drug prescribed for treatment of the same condition for which it was previously prescribed. <n>Directs that such provisions apply to coverage offered in the individual market.
Revolutionary War Historic Preservation Study Act of 1994 - Establishes the Revolutionary War Sites Advisory Commission to prepare a study of Revolutionary War sites. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Lymphedema Diagnosis and Treatment CostSaving Act of 2011 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for coverage of lymphedema diagnosis and treatment services and lymphedema compression treatment items.

Disaster-Affected Homeowners Notification Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac), with respect to any major disaster declared pursuant to the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act, to: (1) notify each mortgagor under a covered mortgage of the forbearance relief made available, required, or recommended; and (2) provide community-wide notification of such relief in accordance with the guidelines issued under this Act. Defines a "covered mortgage" as one that: (1) is secured by a one- to four-family dwelling that is the principal residence of the mortgagor, and (2) is located within an area for which such major disaster was declared.

HUD Programs Information Verification Act - Amends part D (Child Support and Establishment of Paternity) of title IV of the Social Act to direct the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to furnish to the Secretary of Health and Human Services information in HUD's custody for comparison with information in the National Directory of New Hires, in order to obtain information in the Directory with respect to individuals who are participating in: (1) any public housing or assisted housing program under specified Federal laws; and (2) the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act or the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1965. <n>Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to compare information in the National Directory with information provided by HUD about such individuals. Directs HUD to make such disclosures only to the extent necessary to verify their employment and income. Authorizes the Secretary to use the information resulting from a data match to: (1) verify the employment and income of such individuals; and (2) analyze such information after the removal of personal identifiers. Sets forth rules for the types of disclosures permitted and conditions on disclosure.

Help Extend Auditory Relief (HEAR) Act of 2013 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to cover aural rehabilitation services and hearing aids as durable medical equipment. Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to prescribe requirements for such services, which are furnished by a physician or qualified audiologist, and for hearing aids.

Forest Service Financial Accountability Restoration Act of 1999 - States that specified limitations on Forest Service appropriations or obligations shall terminate on the earlier of: (1) the date on which the Forest Service is no longer an agency at high risk of waste, fraud, abuse, and mismanagement due to weaknesses in its accounting and financial reporting systems; and (2) the end of the fifth fiscal year subject to such limitations. <n>Declares that the Forest Service shall no longer be at high risk if the Comptroller General certifies in writing to the Congress that Forest Service financial management is no longer at high risk. Authorizes the Comptroller General to make such certification only if: (1) the Forest Service receives two consecutive unqualified audit opinions from the Inspector General of the Department of Agriculture; and (2) the Forest Service corrects the material weaknesses identified in the audit reports of the Inspector General regarding the Forest Service's FY 1995 financial statements and all subsequent audit reports of the Inspector General regarding such statements published before the date of the enactment of this Act. <n>Requires the Forest Service, during each fiscal year, to maintain or increase output, relative to the levels achieved during FY 1999, from programs that directly reduce the natural resources restoration and maintenance backlog within the National Forest System, including: (1) acres of forested land treated for reduction of wildfire risk

Amends the Department of Education Organization Act to establish in the Department an Office of Women's Equity, to be administered by a Director of Women's Equity. Declares that such Office shall be considered an organizational entity and shall not be subject to the reorganization authority of the Secretary of Education. <n>Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to repeal provisions for a women's educational equity program. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to, and enter into contracts with, public agencies, private nonprofit agencies, organizations, and institutions, including students and community groups, for activities designed to achieve educational equity for women and girls at all levels of education, including preschool, elementary and secondary education, higher education, adult education and vocational and technical education, and local implementation grants. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Distributed Power Hybrid Energy Act - Directs the Secretary of Energy to develop and transmit to Congress a distributed power hybrid systems strategy showing: (1) opportunities and priorities that might best be met with the use of distributed power hybrid systems; (2) what barriers exist to the use of such systems; (3) what technology gaps need to be closed; and (4) what system integration tools are needed to plan, design, build, and operate such systems for maximum benefits. Authorizes the strategy to provide for development of: (1) system integration tools for planning, designing, building, and operating economical, safe, and clean distributed power hybrid systems; (2) tests of such systems to validate integrated performance and to give consumers, policymakers, and industry the confidence that such systems work reliably, safely, and cleanly; (3) special design tools that can characterize the benefits and values of such systems for consumers and enable virtual prototyping; (4) data to characterize grid operations; and (5) precise resource assessment tools to map local resources for such systems.

Cuba Transition Act of 2003 - Directs the Secretary of State to designate within the Department of State a coordinator who shall be responsible for: (1) designing an overall strategy to coordinate preparations for, and a response to, a transition in Cuba; (2) coordinating assistance provided to the Cuban people in preparation for such transition; (3) coordinating strategic support for the consolidation of a political and economic transition in Cuba; (4) ensuring program and policy coordination among Federal agencies; and (5) pursuing coordination with other countries and international organizations, including international financial institutions.Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the President should begin consultations with governments of other Western countries regarding a transition in Cuba; and (2) the President should begin consultations with appropriate international partners and governments regarding a multilateral diplomatic and financial support program for response to a transition in Cuba.Authorizes the Secretary to designate up to $5 million of total amounts made available for contributions to international organizations to be provided to: (1) the Organization of American States (OAS) for guidance and mechanisms for response by OAS members to the governmental transition in Cuba and that country's eventual reintegration into the inter-American system; (2) the OAS emergency fund for Cuban human rights activities; (3) scholarships for Cuban students attending colleges, universities, or other educational programs in member states of the OAS;

Federal Workforce Reduction and Reform Act of 2011 - Amends the Continuing Appropriations Act, 2011 to extend through December 31, 2014, the freeze on the pay of federal employees, including bonuses and cash awards. Prohibits agencies during FY2012-FY2014 from paying any bonus (including any recruitment or retention bonus) or any cash award (including any performance-based cash award) to any employee.<n><n>Directs the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to: (1) ensure that the total number of federal employees, beginning in FY2022, does not exceed 85% of the total number of federal employees on September 30, 2011; (2) continuously monitor all agencies and make a determination on whether the total number of federal employees exceeds the maximum number allowable; and (3) provide written notice to the President and Congress, within 14 days after the last day of the quarter to which such determination relates, of any determination that the total number of federal employees exceeds the maximum number allowable. Prohibits any agency, until OMB provides written notice, from appointing any employee to fill any vacancy within such agency until OMB provides such notice. Allows a waiver of such limitation by the President for national security reasons or in the case of an extraordinary emergency threatening life, health, public safety, property, or the environment.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to permit an individual a tax credit equal to the energy conservation expenditures made by the taxpayer for qualified energy property which is certified to equal or exceed energy conservation standards and which is installed on or in connection with a dwelling unit which is located in the United States and which is used by the taxpayer as a residence. Limits such credit to $2,000 for each dwelling unit for the taxable year.

Authorizes the Administrator to set aside amounts for grants to local community groups and nonprofit organizations to foster community involvement in the decision making process, environmental educational goals, and restoration strategies.
