Requires the Administrator, in carrying out the program, to work in coordination with other Federal agencies, particularly the Army Corps of Engineers. Authorizes appropriations.

Social Security Disability Amendments Act of 1994 - Amends title XVI (Supplemental Security Income) (SSI) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to: (1) disregard the deemed income and resources of an ineligible spouse when determining continued eligibility for SSI; (2) deem a completed plan for achieving self-support not disapproved within 60 days to be approved; (3) allow the inclusion of housing goals in a plan; (4) treat certain grant, scholarship, or fellowship income as earned income for SSI purposes; and (5) extend SSI eligibility for students temporarily abroad.

Gold King Mine Spill Accountability Act of 2016 This bill directs the Department of Justice (DOJ) to appoint a special investigator, dedicated full time, to conduct an investigation of the Gold King Mine spill in Colorado and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)'s failure to take action after the spill. The investigator: (1) shall be compensated for expenses incurred in the course of the investigation; and (2) may appoint and fix the pay of additional personnel.

E-911 Implementation Act of 2003 - Amends the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to direct the Assistant Secretary for Communications and Information at the Department of Commerce and the Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to: (1) establish a joint program to facilitate coordination and communication between Federal, State, and local emergency communications systems, emergency personnel, public safety organizations, telecommunications carriers, and telecommunications equipment manufacturers and vendors involved in the implementation of E-911 (emergency communications service) services; and (2) create an E-911 Implementation Coordination Office to implement such provisions.Directs the Assistant Secretary and the Administrator to jointly develop a management plan for the program, which shall include the organizational structure and funding profiles for the five-year duration of the program.Requires the Office to: (1) take actions to improve coordination and communication; (2) develop, collect, and disseminate information concerning practices, procedures, and technology used in the implementation of E-911 services; (3) advise and assist eligible entities in the preparation of implementation plans; (4) receive, review, and recommend the approval or disapproval of applications for grants; and (5) oversee the use of funds provided by such grants in fulfilling implementation plans.Directs the Assistant Secretary and the Administrator to provide annual reports to Congress on Office activities.Direct

8 Investigation Team Act - Establishes the 8 Investigation Team, which shall examine: (1) the events beginning on August 29, 2005; and (2) each flood control and restoration project that has been carried out in the Gulf Coast since August 29, 2005.

Wall Street Compensation Reform Act of 2010 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income compensation paid by systemically significant financial institutions to employees whose actions have a material impact on the risk exposure of the taxpayer. Defines systemically significant financial institution" as an entity that: (1) engages primarily in activities which are financial in nature; (2) owns or controls assets greater than $25 billion and maintains a ratio of debt to equity of greater than 20 to 1."

Truth in Video Game Rating Act - Directs the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to prescribe rules to prohibit any rating organization from assigning a content rating to any video or computer game that is to bear a label containing such rating unless the organization has reviewed its entire playable content.Requires such rules to prohibit: (1) any person who produces, sells, or otherwise distributes video or computer games in interstate commerce from withholding or hiding any playable content from, or in any other manner failing to disclose such content to, a rating organization; and (2) any rating organization from providing a content rating that grossly mischaracterizes the game content.Directs the Comptroller General to study and report to Congress on the efficacy of the Entertainment Software Ratings Board ratings system in assigning appropriate content ratings to video and computer games, including ratings for online or Internet-based games.

Directs the Secretary of Energy, acting through the Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy, to: (1) coordinate and disseminate information on existing federal programs and assistance that may be used to help initiate, develop, and finance energy efficiency, renewable energy, and energy retrofitting projects for schools; (2) establish a federal cross-departmental collaborative coordination, education, and outreach effort to streamline communication and promote such opportunities more effectively; (3) provide technical assistance for states, local educational agencies, and schools to help develop and finance such projects; (4) develop and maintain a single online resource website with contact information for relevant technical assistance and support staff in the Office; and (5) establish a process for recognition of schools that have successfully implemented such projects and are willing to serve as resources for other local educational agencies and schools to assist initiation of similar efforts.

Bill Emerson English Language Empowerment Act of 1997 - Amends Federal law to declare English as the official language of the Federal Government. Declares that representatives of the Federal Government shall have an affirmative obligation to preserve and enhance the role of English as the official language. Requires the Federal Government to: (1) conduct its official business in English; and (2) conduct all naturalization ceremonies entirely in English. Declares that this Act shall supersede any existing Federal law that contravenes such provisions (such as by requiring the use of a language other than English for official business of the Federal Government). Declares that this Act may be construed to: (1) prohibit a Member of Congress or an employee or official of the Federal Government, while performing official business, from communicating orally with another person in a language other than English; (2) limit the preservation or use of Native Alaskan or Native American languages (as defined in the Native American Languages Act); (3) discriminate against or restrict the rights of any individual in the United States; and (4) discourage or prevent the use of languages other than English in any nonofficial capacity.

Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act This bill requires the Director of the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) for a state (respecting certain public lands) or the Regional Forester with jurisdiction over the National Forest System (NFS) land of a specific Forest Service Region (respecting certain NFS lands) to: (1) select an eligible federal lands parcel for conveyance in response to a request submitted by an owner of nonfederal land that shares one or more boundaries with such parcel, or (2) upon the recommendation of the District Office of the BLM or the NFS unit exercising administration over such parcel. The BLM or the Forest Service, when a landowner submits a request for conveyance of an eligible federal lands parcel, shall review such parcel and determine, within 30 days after receipt of the request, whether it satisfies the definition of such a parcel for conveyance. If they determine that all or a portion of such a parcel fails to satisfy the definition of such a parcel, they shall give the landowner a written explanation of the reasons for the rejection and how and why the parcel fails to satisfy that element and how continued administration by the BLM or the Forest Service would impact the parcel and surrounding economy.

scaling up manufacturing Act of 2013 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an eligible business a business-related tax credit for 25% of qualified facility construction expenditures. Defines "qualified facility construction expenditures" as amounts paid or incurred by the taxpayer: (1) for the construction of a facility in the United States to manufacture a qualified product (including amounts for professional services necessary for the planning of such construction), and (2) for the purchase of specialized equipment for use at such facility and required for the manufacture of such product. Terminates such credit after 2016.

Nonprofit Energy Efficiency Act - Directs the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to establish a pilot program to award grants, through FY2016, to nonprofit organizations for retrofitting their buildings with energy-efficiency improvements. Defines "energy-efficiency improvement" as an installed measure that results in a reduction in demand by a nonprofit organization for energy or fuel supplied from outside the nonprofit building. Amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to reauthorize appropriations for FY2013-FY2016.

Reconnecting Congress with America Act of 2011- Reduces the annual salary of a Member of Congress (including a Delegate or Resident Commissioner) for pay periods occurring in a calendar year by 80% of the base rate if, with respect to the most recent fiscal year ending before that calendar year, the federal deficit was equal to or greater than 3% of the gross domestic product, 80% of the base rate if the deficit was less than 3% and 100% of the base rate if there was no federal deficit.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of the Treasury, within 30 days after the end of each fiscal year, to: (1) make a determination of the gross domestic product for that fiscal year, (2) make a determination of whether a federal deficit existed with respect to that fiscal year, and (3) report such determinations to Congress.<n><n>Applies this Act to pay periods occurring on or after January 1, 2013.<n><n>Expresses the sense of Congress that each Member of Congress should voluntarily adjust the amount of his or her salary to reflect the annual rates of pay that will take effect on such date.<n><n>Reduces the member contribution to the Civil Service Retirement System (CSRS) and the government contribution to the Federal Employees Retirement System (FERS).<n><n>Amends the Commodity Exchange Act to prohibit

Empowerment Zone Enhancement Act of 1998 - Amends title XX (Block Grants to States for Social Services) of the Social Security Act to provide for: (1) additional State entitlements to grants for empowerment zones; (2) additional empowerment zone grant amounts; and (3) responsibility for environmental review for empowerment zones and enterprise communities.

Mentor Schools Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award grants to up to 100 local educational agencies for the planning and operation of one or more mentor schools which are to: (1) provide access to same gender schools for low-income students; (2) develop a plan for, and provide access to, a school for boys and a school for girls; (3) give parents the option of choosing to send their child to one such school; (4) admit students on the basis of a lottery, if more students apply for admission to that school; (5) operate as part of the educational program of a school receiving funds under this Act; and (6) involve parents in the educational options and choices of their children. <n>Requires such grants to be awarded to eligible LEAs that: (1) receive school improvement funds under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA); and (2) are among the 20 percent of LEAs receiving ESEA funds that do not have a mentor school program. <n>Sets forth requirements for: (1) mentors and schools; (2) educational evaluation; (3) advisory boards; and (4) local plans and applications. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 5, 2016. Overtime Reform and Review Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to require the Department of Labor, in promulgating regulations for defining and delimiting the terms "exempt employees" under the Act, to require that any such employee is compensated at a rate that is not less than the applicable salary threshold (currently $35,984 per year, or $692 per week), which shall be increased beginning on December 1, 2016, to a rate equal to: (1) $39,780 per year or $765 per week on December 1, 2018, (2) $43,628 per year or $839 per week on December 1, 2019, (3) $47,476 per year or $913 per week on December 1, 2021, and (4) any rate of compensation provided by Labor in accordance with such requirements for nonprofit organizations (including nonprofit institutions of higher education), Medicare or Medicaid dependent health care providers, and state and local governments. Such increases shall occur only if: the Government Accountability Office (GAO) conducts and submits a study in accordance with this bill; and the GAO certifies that the increase in the salary threshold from the threshold in effect prior to December 1, 2016, has not:

Judicial Administration and Improvement Act of 2016 This bill divides the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit into: (1) a new Ninth Circuit that consists of only California and Hawaii; and (2) a newly established Twelfth Circuit to be composed of Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Montana, and Nevada. The Twelfth Circuit must hold regular sessions in Las Vegas, Phoenix, Anchorage, and Missoula, Montana. Each circuit judge of the former Ninth Circuit who is in regular active service and whose official duty station is currently in Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Montana, or Nevada may elect to be assigned to: (1) the new Ninth Circuit; or (2) the new Twelfth Circuit.

Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to require individual account plans which consist of employer securities and employer real property to include with account statements a notice that the account may be over invested in employer securities and employer real property. Authorizes the Secretary of Labor to assess a civil penalty against a plan administrator for failure or refusal to provide notice to participants and beneficiaries.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a limited exclusion from gross income for qualified retirement planning services provided by a qualified investment advisor.

Know Before You Owe Private Education Loan Act of 2016 This bill amends the Truth in Lending Act to require a creditor, before issuing funds for an extension of credit for a private student loan, to obtain from a higher education institution the student's enrollment status, cost of attendance, and estimated financial assistance. A creditor may issue funds for such an extension without obtaining such a certification if the institution fails to provide within 15 business days of the creditor's request for it: (1) the requested certification, or (2) notification that the institution has received the request and will need additional time to comply. The bill requires a creditor to: (1) send loan statements to borrowers at an institution of higher education at least once every three months during the time that such student is enrolled there; and (2) notify the institution of higher education, in writing, of the amount of the extension of credit and the student on whose behalf credit is extended.

End Trafficking in Government Contracting Act of 2012 - Amends the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 to require the head of an executive agency to take any of the other remedial actions authorized in such Act if the grantee or any subgrantee, or the contractor or any subcontractor, engages in, or uses labor recruiters, brokers, or other agents who engage in severe forms of human trafficking in persons, the procurement of a commercial sex act during the period that the grant, contract, or cooperative agreement is in effect, the use of forced labor in the performance of such grant, contract, or cooperative agreement, or acts that directly support or advance trafficking in persons, including: (1) destroying, concealing, removing, or confiscating an employee's immigration documents without the employee's consent; (2) failing to repatriate an employee upon the end of employment, unless exempted from the duty to the employee by the federal agency providing or entering into the grant, contract, or cooperative agreement or the employee is a victim of human trafficking seeking victim services or legal redress in the country of employment or a witness in a human trafficking enforcement action; (3) soliciting a person for the purpose of employment, or offering employment, by means of materially false or fraudulent pretenses, representations, or promises regarding that employment;

Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998 - Amends part C (Medicare+Choice) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act with regard to authority to delay and alternative termination decisions by Medicare+Choice organizations. Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to end such a delay early upon determining that an adequate provider network has been established which will provide at least an equal level of insurance coverage as existed in the area affected by the termination on the date the Medicare+Choice organization informed the Secretary of its intention to terminate the contract. Authorizes the Secretary and the Medicare+Choice organization terminating coverage to negotiate during the period of delay for a new contract which will enable the organization to continue coverage. Extends the initial Medicare+Choice contract period from one year to three years. Revises requirements for notice of termination. Requires any Medicare+Choice organization contract to provide and pay for a written notice to enrollees at least 120 days before termination, together with a description of alternatives for obtaining benefits.

APHIS Transfer Act - Transfers to the Secretary of Homeland Security the functions of the Secretary of Agriculture relating to agricultural import and entry inspection activities under specified federal agricultural laws.

Focus on Children Act Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require the Congressional Budget Office (CBO), at the request of a congressional committee, to conduct a study of a bill, joint resolution, amendment, amendment between the chambers, or conference report containing changes in spending on children. Requires the CBO to submit annual reports on spending on children to Congress, including: (1) a summary of the total amount of appropriations or new obligational authority and outlays requested for spending on children; (2) an estimate of the level of spending on children; (3) an estimate of the share of federal spending that constitutes spending on children; and (4) an estimate of the date on which federal spending on children will be less than outlays for interest on the public debt. Authorizes the CBO to: (1) provide a warning report to Congress regarding a fiscal year in which outlays for interest on the public debt will exceed spending on children; and (2) include in such a report a list of possible budgetary options to prevent such an imbalance between outlays for interest on the public debt and spending on children. Requires the CBO to publish all of the reports and studies required under this Act in a publicly accessible format, including through a dashboard tool (commonly referred to as a "dashboard")

Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to nondiscrimination requirements for tax-exempt employee pension, profit-sharing, and stock bonus plans, to include protections for older, longer service participants in such plans, including the grandfathering of such participants under defined benefit plans.

English Language Empowerment Act of 1996 - Declares English to be the official language of the Federal Government. States that the Federal Government shall have an affirmative obligation to preserve and enhance the role of English as the official language. Requires the Federal Government to conduct its official business in English. Prohibits denial of Federal services because a person communicates in English. Entitles every person in the United States to: (1) communicate with the Federal Government in English; (2) receive information from or contribute information to the Federal Government in English; and (3) be informed of or be subject to official orders in English. Authorizes persons injured by violations of this Act to obtain appropriate relief in civil actions. Declares English to be the language of opportunity for all immigrants to take their rightful place in society in the United States. Requires all authorized officials to conduct all naturalization ceremonies entirely in English. States that nothing in this Act shall be construed to: (1) prohibit a Member of Congress, an employee or official of the Federal Government, while performing official business, from communicating orally in a foreign language with another person; (2) discriminate against or restrict the rights of any individual in the country; (3) discourage or prevent the use of languages other than English in any nonofficial capacity; or (4) repeal existing Federal laws,

Health Care Continuation Coverage Act of 2002 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to establish a program under which premium assistance for COBRA continuation coverage shall be provided for qualified individuals.Requires that such assistance be provided through the establishment of direct payment arrangements with the administrator of the group health plan that provides or administers the COBRA continuation coverage.

Intercity Passenger Rail Trust Fund Act of 1997 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish the Intercity Passenger Rail Trust Fund which shall finance qualified expenses of: (1) the National Railroad Passenger Corporation; and (2) non-Amtrak States.

Coastal and Estuarine Land Protection Act - Directs the Secretary of Commerce to establish a Coastal and Estuarine Land Protection Program to protect the environmental integrity of important coastal and estuarine areas, including wetlands and forests, that have significant conservation, recreation, ecological, historical, aesthetic, or watershed protection values and that are threatened by conversion from their natural, undeveloped, or recreational state to other uses.Requires the program to be administered by the National Ocean Service of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) through the head of the Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management.Directs the Secretary to make program grants to coastal states with approved coastal zone management plans or National Estuarine Research Reserve units for the purpose of acquiring property that will further the goals of such plans or units, or a regional or state watershed protection plan involving coastal states with approved coastal zone management plans.

Home-Based Business Fairness Act of 1997 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow, for self-employed individuals, a deduction for health insurance costs. <n>Declares that a home office shall qualify as the principal place of business for purposes of determining whether an individual is not an employee if: (1) the office is the location where the taxpayer's essential administrative or management activities are conducted on a regular and systematic basis; and (2) the office is necessary because the taxpayer has no other location for the performance of the essential administrative or management activities of the business. <n>Provides a safe harbor rule for determining that certain individuals are not employees for purposes of employment taxes.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 3, 2014. American Indian Trust Responsibility Review Act of 2014 - (Sec. 3) Declares that it is timely and essential to conduct a review of the current state of the United States unique trust relationship with federally recognized Indian tribes and their members in order to better administer constitutional trust responsibilities and make necessary revisions in relevant trust statutes, regulations, and policies for the benefit of American Indian people. (Sec. 4) Establishes the American Indian Trust Review Commission to conduct a comprehensive review of the unique trust relationship between the United States and federally recognized Indian tribes, including: (1) a study and analysis of the Constitution, and relevant treaties, compacts, statutes, judicial interpretations, and Executive Orders to determine the attributes of such relationship; (2) a review of the policies, practices, and structure of the federal agencies charged with protecting Indian tribal trust resources and providing services to Indians; (3) a management study of the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) and its ability to discharge its trust responsibilities without conflicting with the duties of other federal agencies and departments; (4) a review of relevant statutes, regulations, and policies to determine the feasibility of authorizing Indian tribes, in their discretion, to assume some or all of the functions

Business Checking Freedom Act of 2002 - Amends the Federal Reserve Act, the Home Owners' Loan Act, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act to repeal the proscription against the payment of interest on demand deposits.Authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses, permitting up to 24 transfers per month to another account of the owner in the same institution (or any greater number the Federal Reserve Board may determine).Amends the Federal Reserve Act to authorize a Federal reserve bank to pay interest at least quarterly (at a rate not to exceed the general level of short term interest rates) to a depository institution on any balance it maintains at the reserve bank.Repeals a specified restriction in order to authorize pass-through reserves for member banks (as well as non-member banks).Amends the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 to require the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to: (1) obtain and report to Congress annually on a representative sample of bank fees and services offered by insured depository institutions; and (2) prescribe regulations governing the payment, distribution, and crediting of earnings attributable to balances maintained by any such entity on behalf of depository institutions.Repeals a specified restriction in order to authorize the payment of interest at least quarterly (at a rate

Poison Center Support, Enhancement, and Awareness Act of 2008 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to provide coordination and assistance for the maintenance of the nationwide toll-free phone number to access poison control centers. Authorizes appropriations.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to carry out and expand upon a national media campaign to educate the public and health care providers about poison prevention and the availability of local poison control center resources, and to conduct advertising campaigns concerning the nationwide toll-free number. Authorizes the Secretary to enter into contracts with one or more public or private entities to conduct such campaigns.

Guam War Claims Review Commission Act - Establishes the Guam War Claims Review Commission to: (1) review the facts and circumstances surrounding the implementation and administration of the Guam Meritorious Claims Act (the Act) and the effectiveness of such Act in addressing the war claims of American nationals residing on Guam between December 8, 1941, and July 21, 1944; (2) review all relevant Federal and Guam territorial laws, records of oral testimony previously taken, and documents in Guam and the Archives of the Federal Government regarding Federal payments of war claims in Guam; (3) receive oral testimony of persons who personally experienced the taking and occupation of Guam by Japanese military forces, noting especially the effects of infliction of death, personal injury, forced labor, forced march, and internment; (4) determine whether there was parity of war claims paid to the residents of Guam under the Act as compared with awards made to other similarly affected United States citizens or nationals in territory occupied by the Imperial Japanese military forces during World War II; (5) advise on any additional compensation that may be necessary to compensate the people of Guam for death, personal injury, forced labor, forced march, and internment; and (6) report to the Secretary of the Interior, the House Committee on Resources and the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, and the Senate Committee on the

Protect Our Recovery Through Oversight of Proprietary Trading Act of 2010 or the PROP Trading Act - Amends the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 to prohibit a banking entity from: (1) engaging in proprietary trading; or (2) taking or retaining any equity, partnership, or other ownership interest in or sponsor a hedge fund or a private equity fund. Subjects any specified nonbank financial company that engages in proprietary trading and taking or retaining any equity, partnership, or other ownership interest in or sponsors a hedge fund or a private equity fund to additional capital requirements for and additional quantitative limits on such proprietary trading. Directs the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) to jointly adopt rules to effectuate the provisions of this Act.

Concussion Awareness and Education Act of 2015 This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to: (1) establish and oversee a national system to accurately determine the incidence of sports-related concussions among youth, and (2) begin implementation of such system within one year of this Act's enactment. The data collected shall include: the incidence of sports related concussions in individuals 5 through 21 years of age; demographic information of the injured individuals; pre-existing conditions of the injured individuals; the concussion history of the injured individuals; the use of protective equipment and impact monitoring devices; the qualifications of personnel diagnosing the concussions; the cause, nature, and extent of the concussive injury; and the methods used to diagnose and treat the injured individuals. The National Institutes of Health must: (1) conduct or support research designed to establish metrics and markers of concussion diagnosis, prognosis, and recovery in youth and to inform the creation of guidelines for the management of short- and long-term sequelae of concussion in youth; (2) establish a Concussion Research Commission to conduct, support, and coordinate research designed to establish metrics and markers of concussion diagnosis, prognosis, and recovery in elementary and secondary schools and to inform the creation of guidelines for the management of short- and

Accountability and Responsibility in Contracting Act - (Sec. 2) Makes an acquiring corporation, or any subsidiary thereof, that enters into a corporate expatriation transaction ineligible for a Federal contract for three years, beginning on the date of completion of such transaction. Defines corporate expatriation transaction" as, with certain exceptions, one in which a foreign corporation acquires substantially all of the properties held by a domestic corporation and in which, immediately after the transaction, more than 80% of the stock of the acquiring corporation is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation. Makes such provision inapplicable if an acquiring corporation reorganizes as a domestic corporation within one year after enactment of this Act under the applicable incorporation laws of a State. (Sec. 3) Prohibits this Act from applying with respect to a corporate expatriation transaction occurring before, on, or after enactment of this Act: (1) if the President certifies to Congress that a waiver is required in the interest of national security; or (2) if an entity with a foreign subsidiary doing business with a state sponsor of terrorism or foreign terrorist organization is eligible to be awarded a Federal contract. Provides a period of ineligibility of: (1) three years for a first offense; (2) 10 years for a second offense; and (3) 15 years for any"

Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to establish a Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program.Authorizes the Secretary of Education to contract with, or make a grant to, the Council on Legal Education Opportunity to provide: (1) assistance to low-income, minority, or disadvantaged college students to gain access to and complete law school study; and (2) support services to first-year law students to improve retention and success in law school studies and to motivate and prepare such students with respect to law school studies and practice in low-income communities.

Federal Public Safety Officer Surviving Spouse Protection Act of 2005 - Amends Federal retirement provisions with respect to the Civil Service Retirement System (CSRS) and the Federal Employees Retirement System (FERS) to provide that, if the widow, widower, or former spouse was married for at least 30 years to the individual on whose service the survivor annuity is based or in the case of a widow or widower the individual on whose service the survivor annuity is based was a Federal public safety officer who was killed in the line of duty, then provisions providing for termination of a survivor annuity because of a remarriage before the age of 55 years shall not apply if: (1) the widow, widower, or former spouse was married for at least 30 years to the individual on whose service the survivor annuity is based; or (2) in the case of a widow or widower the individual on whose service the survivor annuity is based was a Federal public safety officer who was killed in the line of duty.

Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 - Repeals the death penalty under specified Federal laws for: (1) murder related to the smuggling of aliens; (2) destruction of aircraft, motor vehicles, or related facilities resulting in death; (3) murder committed during a drug-related drive-by shooting; (4) murder committed at an airport serving international civil aviation; (5) civil rights offenses resulting in death; (6) murder of a member of Congress, an important executive official, or a supreme court justice; (7) death resulting from offenses involving transportation of explosives, destruction of government property, or destruction of property related to foreign or interstate commerce; (8) murder committed by use of a firearm during commission of a crime of violence or a drug trafficking crime; (9) genocide; (10) first degree murder; (11) murder by a Federal prisoner; (12) murder with intent to prevent testimony by a witness, victim, or informant; (13) murder of a State or local law enforcement official or other person aiding in a Federal investigation; (14) murder of a State correctional officer; and (15) mailing of injurious articles with intent to kill or resulting in death.

Education and Training for Health Act of 2017 or the EAT for Health Act of 2017 This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services to issue guidelines to federal agencies for developing procedures and requirements to ensure that every primary care health professional employed full-time for such agencies have continuing education courses relating to nutrition. These courses must include at least courses on the role of nutrition in the prevention, management, and, as possible, reversal of weight-related health problems.

Drug Rebate Equalization Act of 2009 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to provide that a contract between a state and a Medicaid managed care organization shall provide that payment for covered outpatient drugs dispensed to individuals eligible for medical assistance who are enrolled with the organization shall be subject to the same rebate required by the agreement entered into under the Act as the state is subject to, and capitation rates paid to the entity shall be based on actual cost experience related to rebates and subject to the federal regulations requiring actuarially sound rates. (Currently, such a contract provides that payment for covered outpatient drugs dispensed to individuals eligible for medical assistance who are enrolled with the organization shall be subject to the same rebate required by the agreement entered into under the Act as the state is subject to, and capitation rates paid to the entity shall be based on actual cost experience related to rebates and subject to the federal regulations requiring actuarially sound rates.)<n><n>Allows a Medicaid managed care organization with a contract to exclude or otherwise restrict coverage of a covered outpatient drug on the basis of its policies or practices, such as those affecting utilization management, formulary adherence, and cost sharing or dispute resolution, in lieu of any state policies or practices relating to the exclusion or restriction of coverage

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) (Sec. 13) Declares that there is a wide range of national and multilateral tools, including the re-imposition of sanctions, available to the United States and United States partners, including European allies, should Iran fail to meet its JCPOA commitments. (Sec. 14) Directs the President to designate within the Department of State a special coordinator for implementation of and compliance with the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action regarding Iran's nuclear program. (Sec. 15) Expresses the sense of Congress that the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) must have sufficient funding, manpower, and authority to undertake its verification responsibilities under the JCPOA or any other related agreement and the President should engage with international partners to ensure that the IAEA receives the full additional $10 million per year necessary to fulfill its verification responsibilities. Authorizes appropriations for FY2016-FY2026 as necessary to meet U.S. annual funding commitments to the IAEA. Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) Iran should continue to be prohibited from undertaking any activity related to ballistic or cruise missiles capable of delivering nuclear weapons, and (2) United Nations member states should take measures to prevent the transfer of technology or

Respirator Access Assurance Act of 2005 - States that manufacturers or sellers of respirators shall not be subject to claims for defective design or warning relating to a respirator or any claim based on such allegation if such respirator has received National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) approval and such respirator is manufactured in compliance with NIOSH-approved design and labeling in effect on the date of manufacture. Makes this provision inapplicable to a manufacturer or seller of a respirator if NIOSH withdraws its approval for the respirator that is the subject of the claim involved based on a finding by NIOSH that the manufacturer or seller: (1) withheld from or misrepresented to NIOSH material information about the respirator's design or labeling and the respirator otherwise would not have been approved; or (2) made an illegal payment to a NIOSH official or employee for the purpose of securing or maintaining approval of the respirator's design or labeling.

(Sec. 2) Amends the Truth in Lending Act to make unlawful the use of an instrumentality of interstate or foreign commerce to: (1) notify a creditor that a statement of account contains a billing error with regard to a transaction, knowing the statement to be correct with regard to such transaction; or (2) notify a card issuer of an unauthorized use of a credit card with regard to a transaction knowing the use of the credit card in connection with such transaction to have been authorized.(Sec. 3) Amends Federal criminal law to subject to a fine and/or imprisonment for up to ten years any person who: (1) submits an application for a credit card to a credit card issuer knowing the application to be forged, fictitious, altered, or fraudulent; (2) submits false or misleading information to a credit card issuer; or (3) applies for two or more credit cards from one or more credit cards within any one-year period, for up to ten years, or both.(Sec. 4) Amends the Federal Reserve Act to repeal the requirement that depository institutions file quarterly reports with the Secretary of the Treasury regarding transactions deemed suspicious. Allows such depository institutions to file such reports on a quarterly basis if the number of such reports averages less than 50 per month. Declares that such

Small Cap Liquidity Reform Act of 2014 - Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to revise the formula for the Liquidity Pilot Program for securities of certain emerging growth companies. Requires a covered emerging growth company's securities to be quoted using: (1) a minimum increment of $0.05; or (2) if the company so elects, a minimum increment of $0.10. Allows a covered emerging growth company to elect at any time after enactment of this Act to change the minimum increment from $0.05 to $0.10 or from $0.10 to $0.05. Prohibits a covered emerging growth company from making more than one election. Requires the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), upon being informed of such an election, to notify each exchange or other trading venue where the securities of the covered emerging growth company are quoted or traded. Requires, if an issuer ceases to be a covered emerging growth company: (1) its securities to be quoted at the increment at which it would be quoted without regard to the minimum increments established under this Act, and (2) its first share of securities offered to the public at a price below $1 to continue to meet the requirements of this Act.

Public Safety Officers' Defense Act - Amends the Federal judicial code to prohibit a court, justice, or judge from having jurisdiction to consider any claim relating to the judgment or sentence in an application for a writ of habeas corpus on behalf of a person in custody pursuant to the judgment of a State court for a crime that involved the killing of a public safety officer while such public safety officer was engaged in the performance of official duties or on account of such officer's performance of official duties, unless the applicant shows that the claim qualifies for consideration on the grounds described above.Sets forth time limits in the district court for any motion by either party for an evidentiary hearing and for any motion for an evidentiary hearing. Requires a district court to enter a final order, granting or denying the application for a writ of habeas corpus, not later than 15 months after the date on which the State files its answer or, if no timely answer is filed, the date on which such answer is due. Authorizes the State to petition the court of appeals for a writ of mandamus to enforce the requirements of this Act if the district court fails to comply.

Consumer Affordable Transaction Account Act of 2001 - Requires each insured depository institution to make available to consumers an affordable transaction account" with specified features, to be prescribed jointly by the Federal banking agencies, including: (1) the maximum amount which an insured depository institution may require as an initial deposit; (2) the maximum amount any institution may require as a minimum balance; (3) a minimum number of eight withdrawal transactions, including withdrawals by negotiable or transferable instruments for the purpose of making payments to third parties and electronic fund transfers, during any periodic cycle at no additional charge; and (4) the maximum amount the institution may charge per periodic cycle for the use of such account.Authorizes a depository institution to: (1) impose a reasonable per-transaction charge for any withdrawal transaction other than a transaction required to be provided free; or (2) impose the fees and charges normally applied to other consumer transaction accounts available at that institution."

Grants a Federal charter to the 29th Division Association, Incorporated (a nonprofit corporation organized under the laws of New Jersey). (Sec. 2) Sets forth the objects and purposes of the corporation, including: (1) promotion of fellowship among its members; (2) the perpetuation of the record of the 29th Division, United States Army, in the World Wars; (3) the promotion of the welfare of its members, their families, and the families of the members who lost their lives in the service of Our Country; (4) the consideration of questions concerning the military policy of the United States of America; and (5) upholding and defending the Constitution of the United States. (Sec. 4) Requires the corporation to comply with the laws of the State or States in which it is incorporated and the laws of such State or States in furtherance of its corporate purposes. (Sec. 5) Prohibits eligibility for membership in the corporation and the rights and privileges of members from being discriminated on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, religion, or handicapped status. Requires the composition of the board of directors of the corporation and the responsibilities of such board to be as provided in the articles of incorporation of the corporation. (Sec. 7) Prohibits any part of the income or

Educators in Military Service Act of 2005 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA) to extend the deadline for states and local educational agencies (LEAs) to ensure that all teachers teaching in core academic subjects within their states are highly qualified, and for LEAs to ensure that all teachers teaching within their school districts are highly qualified, with respect to certain teachers who are serving in the Armed Forces or the National Guard on or after January 8, 2002.

Rural Alaska Access Rights Act of 1999- Amends the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act (ANILCA) to require all Federal public land managers in Alaska, or a region that includes Alaska, to participate in an ANILCA training class within 120 days after enactment of this Act. Requires all future appointed Federal public land managers in Alaska, or a region containing Alaska, to complete ANILCA training within 60 days of assuming their position. <n>(Sec. 2) Requires all future appointed Federal public land managers in Alaska, or a region containing Alaska, to complete ANILCA training within 120 days after enactment of this Act. <n>(Sec. 3) Revises requirements regarding: (1) access to, and the right-of-way of, Federal lands within an area established under ANILCA to provide for the demonstration of pre-existing use; and (2) prohibitions to the smallest area and to the shortest practicable period prior to formal consultation with and consideration of the views of the State of Alaska. Directs the Secretary of the Interior to limit any prohibitions to the smallest area and to the shortest practicable period prior to formal consultation with and consideration of the views of the State of Alaska. <n>(Sec. 4) Revises requirements regarding permits, leases, and permits

University Transit Rider Innovation Program Act of 2015 or the UTRIP Act This bill authorizes the Department of Transportation to make grants to eligible entities to increase the use of public transportation by undergraduate or graduate students attending institutions of higher education. An "eligible entity" is: a recipient or subrecipient that provides covered students a discounted fare for public transportation that meets specified requirements; or a recipient that allocates amounts provided to the recipient under the grant to subrecipients that are eligible entities to increase the use of public transportation by covered students. A "subrecipient" is a state or local governmental authority, a private nonprofit organization, or an operator of public transportation services, including a private operator of public transportation services. An eligible entity may use grant funds to: offset decreased revenue resulting from providing discounted fares to covered students; provide general operating assistance to public transportation services and routes designed to better serve institutions of higher education; or pay for capital costs associated with expanding and maintaining public transportation services and routes designed to serve institutions of higher education.

Telemarketer Identification Act of 2001 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit any person or entity from interfering with or circumventing the ability of a caller identification service to access or provide information about the call to the recipient.Directs the Federal Communications Commission to prescribe regulations implementing such prohibition. Provides a private right of action for violations of such prohibition and regulations.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 17, 2015. Improving Department of State Oversight Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill requires any employee of the Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction who completes at least 12 months of service at any time prior to the termination of the Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction, October 5, 2013, and was not terminated for cause to acquire competitive status for appointment to any position in the competitive service for which the employee possesses the required qualifications. (Sec. 3) The Secretary of State shall certify to Congress that the Department of State has made reasonable efforts to ensure the integrity and independence of the Office of the Inspector General Information Technology systems. (Sec. 4) The Foreign Service Act of 1980 is amended to require each Department of State bureau, post, or other office to report to the Department's Inspector General any allegations of: waste, fraud, or abuse in a State Department program or operation; criminal or serious misconduct on the part of a State Department employee at the FS-1, GS-15, GM-15 level or higher; criminal misconduct on the part of any State Department employee; and serious, noncriminal misconduct on the part of any individual authorized to carry a weapon, make arrests, or conduct searches. The Inspector General

. Detect and Defeat Tunnels Act (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Department of Defense (DOD), in coordination with the Department of State and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), to seek to enter into an agreement with Israel to partner and coordinate in developing and deploying technologies to detect and counter tunnels. DOD may seek to enter into similar agreements with U.S. allies to develop technologies to detect and counter tunnels. DOD shall designate a military department or other element of DOD to: (1) carry out such technology development as the lead agency of the federal government; and (2) designate a senior intelligence officer to manage the collection and analysis of intelligence regarding the tactical use of tunnels by state and non-state actors. The Director of National Intelligence shall designate a senior intelligence officer to manage the collection and analysis of intelligence regarding tunnel attacks throughout the world.

Securing Tomorrow by Saving Today Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income up to $500 ($1,000 in the case of a joint return) of interest income annually. Provides for an inflation adjustment to such amount.

Healthy Kids from Day One Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to award competitive grants to five state health departments to support child care collaboratives designed to reduce the prevalence of overweight or obesity among children from birth to age 5 in child care settings through dissemination of available tools and curricula and implementation of emerging best practices. Requires the Secretary to award grants to Prevention Research Centers or universities to evaluate the effectiveness of the child care collaboratives.

Public Pension Parity Act of 1995 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide an exclusion from gross income for that portion of a governmental pension which does not exceed the maximum benefits payable under title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act which could have been excluded from income for the taxable year.

Enhancing Military and Police Operations through Women's Engagement and Recruitment Act of 2016 This bill requires the Department of State to report to Congress annually regarding the number of female participants in each program and activity funded by the State Department for military forces, police, and peacekeeping operations.

Spirit of America Commemorative Coin Act of 2001 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue: (1) 50 dollar gold coins; (2) one dollar silver coins; and (3) half dollar coins emblematic of the tragic events that occurred at the Pentagon, in New York City, and in Pennsylvania, on September 11, 2001.

Reducing Over-Classification Act of 2008 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to develop and administer policies, procedures, and programs within DHS to prevent the over-classification of homeland security information, terrorism information, weapons of mass destruction information, and other information within the scope of the information sharing environment established under the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004. Requires such policies, procedures, and programs to prevent such over-classification that must be disseminated to prevent and to collectively respond to acts of terrorism.

. Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians Land Affirmation Act of 2017 (Sec. 3) This bill ratifies and confirms: the action taken by the Department of the Interior on January 20, 2017, to place approximately 1,427.28 acres of land located in Santa Barbara County, California, into trust for the benefit of the Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians, the actions taken to assume jurisdiction over the appeals relating to the fee-to-trust acquisition of such land on January 30, 2015, and the actions taken by Interior on January 19, 2017, to dismiss the appeals relating to such land acquisition. The land placed into trust shall be a part of the Santa Ynez Indian Reservation and administered in accordance with the laws and regulations generally applicable to land held in trust by the United States for an Indian tribe. For purposes of certain California state laws, placing such land into trust shall remove any restrictions on the property pursuant to California Government Code Section 51295 or any other provision of this bill.

National Guard and Reservists Education Benefits Act - Directs the Secretary of Education to carry out a program of block grants to States to provide for the payment of tuition and fees for undergraduate studies at public institutions of higher learning otherwise payable by a member of the Selected Reserve attending those institutions for such studies. Limits such assistance to a member who participates in the educational assistance program of the Armed Forces. Requires the chief executive officer of each State desiring to receive such an allotment to certify to the Secretary that the State will: (1) use such funds to defray the costs of tuition and fees for undergraduate studies of members of the Selected Reserve attending public institutions of higher learning in the States; (2) return any unused funds to the Secretary in accordance with the reconciliation process under this Act; and (3) comply with the reporting requirements of this Act.

Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2001 - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make grants to State educational agencies to award grants to local educational agencies for developing or expanding gifted and talented education programs, and providing direct educational services and materials through one or more of the following activities: (1) developing and implementing programs for general educators, specialists in gifted and talented education, administrators, school counselors, or other personnel at the elementary and secondary levels; (2) making materials and services available through State regional education service centers, universities, colleges, or other entities; (3) providing direct educational services and materials to gifted and talented students, which may include curriculum compacting, modified or adapted curriculum, acceleration, independent study, and dual enrollment; and (4) supporting innovative approaches and curricula used by local educational agencies, individual schools, or consortia of schools or local educational agencies.

Bank Insurance Regulation Act of 1995 - Amends the Revised Statutes of the United States to prohibit a State from imposing: (1) any insurance regulatory requirement relating to providing insurance as an agent or broker that treats a national bank differently than all other persons who are authorized to provide insurance as agents or brokers in such State, unless there is a legitimate and reasonable State regulatory purpose for the requirement for which there is no less restrictive alternative; or (2) on a national bank any insurance regulatory requirement relating to providing insurance as principal, agent, or broker that treats the bank more restrictively than any other depository institution operating in the State. Declares that nothing in this Act shall: (1) affect the validity of a State law that prevents a national bank from engaging in insurance activities within the State to as great an extent as a savings association under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act and that was in effect on June 1, 1995; or (2) affect the authority, pursuant to the Federal Reserve Act, of a national bank to act as insurance agent or broker consistent with State law.

Directs the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to: (1) assess and collect charges for utilization of radio and television communications sites located on Federal lands administered by the Forest Service or the Bureau of Land Management; (2) review such charges annually and adjust them to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index; and (3) establish a broad-based advisory group to review and report to the Congress on criteria for determining fair market value for such uses.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 2, 2017. Recall Unsafe Drugs Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require a registered producer of a drug or device to notify the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as soon as practicable if such person has reason to believe: (1) that such drug is adulterated or misbranded, and (2) there is a reasonable probability that the use or consumption of, or exposure to, the drug will cause a threat of serious adverse health consequences or death to humans or animals. The FDA may: (1) request that any person who distributes a drug that the FDA has reason to believe is adulterated, misbranded, or otherwise in violation of the FFDCA voluntarily recall such drug; and (2) issue an order requiring any person who distributes a drug that may cause serious adverse health consequences or death to humans or animals to immediately cease distribution of such drug and to provide notice, including to affected persons. A person who is subject to such an order may appeal within 24 hours of issuance. After affording an opportunity for an informal hearing, the FDA shall determine: (1) whether the order should be amended to require a recall, or (2) inadequate grounds exist to support

Directs the President to impose quotas, tariff surcharges, negotiated voluntary enforceable export restraint agreements, or otherwise to ensure that the volume of steel products imported into the United States during any month does not exceed the average volume of steel products that was imported monthly into the United States during the 36-month period preceding July 1997. Directs: (1) the Secretary of the Treasury, through the United States Customs Service, to implement a program for administering and enforcing such restraints; and (2) the Secretary of Commerce, in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury, to establish a steel import notification and monitoring program, including a requirement that any person importing a product classified under the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States obtain a steel import notification certificate before such products are entered into the United States.

Business Supply Chain Transparency on Trafficking and Slavery Act of 2014 - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) business enterprises have a responsibility to respect human rights, and (2) legislation is necessary to provide consumers information on products that are free of child labor, forced labor, slavery, and human trafficking. Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to direct the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to promulgate regulations requiring mandatory annual reports to disclose whether a covered issuer has taken measures during the year to identify and address conditions of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and the worst forms of child labor within the covered supply chain. Defines a "covered issuer" as any publicly traded company that is required to file annual financial statements with the SEC, and is also required under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to disclose annually whether it has taken measures during the year to identify and address conditions of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and the worst forms of child labor within its supply chain.

Freedom Consolidation Act of 2001 - Supports enlargement of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).Designates Albania, Croatia, Georgia, and Macedonia as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994.States that such designation: (1) is in addition to the designation of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia pursuant to the NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996, the designation of Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria pursuant to the European Security Act of 1998, and the designation of Slovakia pursuant to the NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994; and (2) shall not preclude the designation by the President of other countries as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994.

America's Youth Commission Act of 2001- Establishes the National Commission on the Impact of United States Culture on America's Youth to investigate and report findings and recommendations with respect to: (1) the condition and status of contemporary youth in America compared to prior generations, with particular attention to family, neighborhood, schools, scholastic attainment, work, and community involvement; (2) the nature, origins, and trends of antisocial and violent behavior among American youth, including the influence of organizations, other cultural elements, and individuals contributing to the incitement or encouragement of violent behaviors; (3) identification of successful initiatives that involve youth in positive development and experiences that curb antisocial behavior among youth; and (4) recommendations for averting and reducing violence among American youth.

Line-Item Rescission Act of 1993 - Amends the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 to allow the President to transmit to both Houses of the Congress, for consideration, one or more special messages proposing to rescind all or part of any item of budget authority provided in an appropriation bill. Specifies the contents of such a message. <n>Requires each special message to be accompanied by a draft bill or joint resolution that would, if enacted, rescind the budget authority proposed to be rescinded.  Sets forth House and Senate procedures for the expedited consideration of such a proposal.

Setting New Priorities in Education Spending Act - Repeals specified provisions of the: (1) Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965; (2) Early Reading First program; (3) William F. Goodling Even Start Family Literacy program; (4) Improving Literacy through School Libraries program; (5) Close Up Fellowship program; (6) comprehensive school reform; (7) part H of title I; (8) school dropout prevention; (9) special education teacher training; (10) advanced certification or advanced credentialing; (11) early childhood educator professional development; (12) teacher mobility; (13) National Writing Project; (14) part D of title II; (15) Improving Language Instruction Educational Programs for Academic Achievement Act; (16) Improving Language Instruction Educational Programs for Academic Achievement Act; (17) Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act; (18) Foreign Language Assistance Act of 2001; (19) Carol M. White Physical Education Program; (20) Star Schools Act; (21) Ready to Teach program; and (20) Foreign Language Assistance Act of 2001.

National Renewable Energy Lands Act of 2002 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Bureau of Reclamation and the Bureau of Land Management, to: (1) evaluate all Federal hydroelectric facilities on Federal lands and identify facilities that are candidates for interconnection with potential renewable energy generation facilities; and (2) evaluate and identify potential renewable energy production sites on Federal lands.Directs the Secretary to: (1) complete an engineering feasibility analysis for sites identified as candidates for interconnection; and (2) make the most promising of such sites available for long-term lease pursuant to a competitive bidding process to qualified renewable energy development firms.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 19, 2014. Protecting Employees and Retirees in Municipal Bankruptcies Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) Amends federal bankruptcy law governing a municipality's eligibility for municipal bankruptcy to require the debtor, with respect to creditors who are municipal employees or retirees, to establish by clear and convincing evidence that it satisfies the requirements of chapter 9 (Adjustment of Debts of a Municipality) of the federal criminal code (thus qualifying the municipality for municipal bankruptcy). (Sec. 3) Requires the appropriate court of appeals to have jurisdiction of an appeal of a determination made by a bankruptcy court that an entity is eligible to be a debtor under chapter 9 on an expedited basis and to consider and determine such appeal on an expedited basis. Provides that such appeal shall be a direct appeal to be reviewed and heard de novo on the merits. (Sec. 4) Amends the federal judicial code to declare that, in a case in which the plan modifies a collective bargaining agreement or modifies a retiree benefit, the authorized representative of the employees covered by such agreement, or the authorized representative of individuals receiving the retiree benefits, agrees to the plan. Declares that the authorized representative of individuals receiving a retiree benefit covered by a collective

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) exempt State and local committees of candidates and of political parties from specified notification requirements; and (2) exempt State and local political committees from specified reporting and annual income tax return requirements.Amends related penalty provisions.

Strengthening the Health Care Safety Net Act of 2009 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to establish a DSH redistribution pool from portion of unexpended Medicaid DSH allotments to fund increase in allotments for low DSH states and for health network access grants.

Strengthening Public Health Protections in Major Disasters and Emergencies Act - Amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to authorize the President to carry out a program for the protection, assessment, monitoring, and study of the health and safety of individuals if chemicals or substances associated with potential acute or chronic human health effects (substances of concern) are being or have been released in a major disaster area.<n><n>Makes participation in any registry or study that is part of such a program voluntary. Requires the President to take appropriate measures to protect the privacy of registry or study participants.

Paleontological Resources Preservation Act - (Sec. 3) Directs the the Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of Agriculture, as appropriate, to: (1) manage and protect paleontological resources on federal land, using scientific principles and expertise; and (2) develop plans for inventory, monitoring, and the scientific and educational use of such resources.<n><n>(Sec. 4) Directs the Secretary to establish a program to increase public awareness about the significance of such resources.<n><n>(Sec. 5) Prohibits a person from collecting a paleontological resource from federal land without a permit issued under this Act by the Secretary. Authorizes the Secretary to allow casual collecting of a resource on certain federal lands without a permit where such collection is consistent with the laws governing the management of those federal lands and this Act. Recognizes as valid permits issued before enactment of this Act. Sets forth criteria by which the Secretary may issue permits for paleontological resources. Requires that each permit include requirements that: (1) the paleontological resource that is collected from federal land under the permit will remain the property of the United States; (2) such resource and copies of associated records will be preserved for the public in an approved repository, to be made available for scientific research and public education; and (3) specific

Health Care Fraud and Abuse Advisory Opinion Act of 1994 - Amends titles XI (General Provisions) and XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to issue advisory opinions concerning: (1) prohibited remuneration; (2) whether an arrangement or proposed arrangement satisfies criteria for activities which do not result in prohibited remuneration; (3) whether an arrangement or proposed arrangement satisfies the criteria the Secretary has established, or shall establish by regulation, for activities which do not result in prohibited remuneration; (4) what constitutes an inducement to reduce or limit services to individuals entitled to benefits under parts A (Hospital Insurance) or part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance) of title XVIII or XIX (Medicaid) of the Act; and (5) whether an arrangement, activity, or proposed arrangement or proposed activity violates any other provision of the Act. Specifies matters not subject to advisory opinions, including whether the fair market value of any goods, services, or property was paid or received for any such goods, services, or property.

Alternative Minimum Tax Repeal Act of 2001 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal the alternative minimum tax on individuals as of 2011.Provides for an increase in certain individual exemption amounts and a phase-out of the phase-out of exemption amounts for corporations.Provides that the aggregate amount of nonrefundable personal tax credits fully allowed against regular tax liability shall not exceed the sum of the taxpayer's regular tax liability for the taxable year reduced by the foreign tax credit allowable under the Code, and the tax imposed by the alternative minimum tax. Sets forth credit limitation provisions.

Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to define sterilization" as the treatment of sediments in ballast water tanks to remove or destroy all living biological organisms through filtration, thermal methods, or other treatment techniques approved by the Secretary. Requires the Secretary to maximize public participation in the issuance of such regulations."

Critical Minerals and Materials Promotion Act of 2011 - Defines critical minerals and materials" as naturally occurring, nonliving, nonfuel substances with a definite chemical composition that perform an essential function for which no satisfactory substitutes exist and that the supply of which has a high probability of becoming restricted, leading to physical unavailability or excessive costs for the applicable minerals and materials in key applications. Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the United States Geological Survey (USGS), to establish a research and development program to: (1) provide data and scientific analyses for research on, and assessments of the potential for, undiscovered and discovered resources of critical minerals and materials in the United States and other countries; and (2) analyze and assess current and future critical minerals and materials supply chains with advice from the Energy Information Administration on future energy technology market penetration and using the Mineral Commodity Summaries produced by the USGS. Directs the Secretary to cooperate with international partners to ensure that such program provides analyses of the global supply chain of critical minerals and materials.<n><n>Requires the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to conduct a program of research, development, and demonstration to strengthen the domestic critical minerals and materials supply chain for clean energy technologies and to ensure the long-term, secure, and sustainable supply of critical minerals and materials"

Military Sexual Assault Crimes Revision Act of 2004 - Amends the Uniform Code of Military Justice to rewrite current provisions concerning the military crime of rape and carnal knowledge to conform with Federal sexual assault crimes. Makes it a crime (aggravated sexual abuse) not only to use force to engage in a sexual act, but to obtain a sexual act by threatening or placing a person in fear that any person will otherwise be subjected to death, grievous bodily harm, or kidnapping. Includes within the act of aggravated sexual abuse: (1) engaging in a sexual act with a person under 12 years of age; and (2) knowingly engaging in a sexual act with a person over 12 but under 16, or with a person's spouse. States that, in the prosecution of either type of sexual abuse, it need not be proven that a person knew the age of the other person engaging in the sexual act. States that, in the prosecution of either type of sexual abuse, it is an affirmative defense that the accused reasonably believed that the other person had attained age 16.<n><n>Defines as the military crime of aggravated sexual abuse when a person: (1) causes another person to engage in a sexual act by using force; (2) causes another person to engage in a sexual act by threatening or placing that other person

Ethanol Stimulus Act of 2006 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a small ethanol producer tax credit for the production of ethanol in two-two states, which are either: (1) consumed more than 2% of the aggregate amount of gasoline consumed in all states during a period; and (2) produced less than 2% of the aggregate amount of ethanol produced in all states during such period.

Asbestos Management Incentive Act - Exempts a lending institution that makes a loan or other extension of credit secured by a mortgage or other lien on a commercial building from liability until it is renegotiated or a superseding loan or other extension of credit is made under any Federal, State, or local law to any person for injuries, costs, damages, expenses, loss, or other obligation which results from the presence of asbestos-containing material in the building in any case in which: (1) the building was constructed during the five-year period ending on the date that the loan or other extension of credit is made; and (2) the building's construction manager certifies that the building contains no asbestos-containing material.

Stop Tobacco Sales to Youth Act of 2015 This bill amends the Jenkins Act to prohibit the sale of electronic cigarettes to individuals under the age of 18. The bill excludes from the definition of "electronic cigarette" an electronic device that delivers nicotine, flavor, or other substance via an aerosolized solution (including an electronic cigarette, cigar, pipe, or other tobacco product sold in Indian country) but excludes product that: is approved by the Food and Drug Administration for sale as a tobacco cessation product or for another therapeutic purpose; and is marketed and sold solely for such a purpose. The bill amends the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act to prohibit any agreement, compact, or other arrangement between any Indian tribe and any state or local government relating to the collection of taxes on cigarettes or smokeless tobacco sold in Indian country from affecting: (1) any state law that authorizes or otherwise pertain to the collection of state, local, or tribal taxes on cigarettes or smokeless tobacco sold in Indian country; or (2) any limitations under federal or state law, including federal common law and treaties, and any regulatory authority with respect to the sale, use, or distribution of cigarettes and smokeless tobacco by or to Indian tribes, tribal members, tribal enterprises, or tribal organizations.

Amends the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) to require that certain information made available in electronic format and indexation of records under such Act be: (1) made available by computer telecommunications or, if computer telecommunications means have not been established by the agency, by other electronic means; and (2) made available to the public through a computer network or, if computer network means have not been established by the agency, by other electronic means.

Financial Derivatives Supervisory Improvement Act of 1998 - Establishes the Working Group on Financial Derivatives, which shall study and report to the Congress on: (1) the regulation of the derivatives markets, including over-the-counter derivatives and exchange-traded derivatives, in which depository institutions, brokers or dealers registered under the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, foreign banks, or affiliates of a depository institution or a foreign bank, participate; and (2) modernizing and harmonizing the statutes, regulations, and policies to: (1) reflect changes in such markets; (2) improve their operations; (3) enhance legal certainty for all types of instruments related to such markets; and (4) promote interagency harmonization. <n>Directs the Secretary of the Treasury and the Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to submit to the Congress legislation authorizing appropriations for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for any fiscal year after FY 2000. <n>Terminates the Working Group upon enactment of legislation authorizing appropriations for such Commission.
