Intermodal Equipment Safety and Responsibility Act of 2003 - Requires an equipment controller, notwithstanding any provision in an equipment interchange agreement to the contrary, to be responsible and held liable for the systematic inspection, maintenance, and repair of equipment interchanged or intended for interchange. Requires an equipment controller, each time before offering a motor carrier agent the equipment for interchange, to inspect and make repairs to, the equipment to ensure it complies with Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations at all times. Prohibits a motor carrier agent from offering equipment that has not been inspected and repaired as necessary to comply with such regulations.

Shareholder Protection Act of 2010 - Amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to prohibit any issuer from making any expenditure for political activities in excess of $10,000 in any fiscal year without first obtaining the written affirmative authorization for such expenditure by a majority of all shareholders. Deems a violation of this requirement a breach of a fiduciary duty of the officers and directors who authorized such expenditure. Makes the officers and directors who authorize such an expenditure jointly and severally liable in any action brought in court for the amount of such expenditure. Exempts from this requirement an issuer whose sole business is the publication or broadcasting of news, commentary, literature, music, entertainment, artistic expression, scientific, historical or academic works, or other forms of information.

Sunset Wasteful Executive Expenditures and Programs Act of 2013 - Directs the Comptroller General (GAO), beginning with 2014, to review three Executive departments, in the order of their creation, to identify agencies and programs within their jurisdiction that perform similar or related functions and that no longer serve a public need. Requires the Comptroller General to review every department at least once every five years using specified criteria, including: (1) the effectiveness and efficiency of the programs carried out by each such executive department; (2) whether such programs are cost-effective; (3) whether the executive department has acted outside the scope of its original authority and whether its original objectives have been achieved; (4) whether less restrictive or alternative methods exist to carry out the functions of the executive department; (5) the extent to which the jurisdiction of, and the programs administered by, the executive department duplicate or conflict with the jurisdiction and programs of other executive departments; (6) the potential benefits of consolidating programs administered by the executive department with similar or duplicative programs of other executive departments and the potential for consolidating such programs; (7) the number and types of beneficiaries or persons served by programs carried out by each executive department; (8) any trends, developments, and emerging conditions that are likely to affect the future nature and extent of the problems or needs that the

Makes eligible for veterans' disability compensation for service-connected disabilities those individuals who were discharged or released from the Selected Reserve before completing six years of service because of a service-connected disability (currently, those who were discharged or released before completing four years of such service). Repeals the requirement that a veteran, while serving on active duty in the Selected Reserve or in the National Guard, notify the Secretary (currently, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs) of his or her eligibility for veterans' disability compensation.Authorizes the refinance of a veteran's loan guaranteed, insured, or made through the Department of Veterans Affairs to improve the dwelling securing such loan properly through energy efficiency improvements.Authorizes the Secretary to charge a fee for refinancing a veteran's loan being refinanced under a Federal Housing Administration mortgagee loan.Provides that manufactured homes manufactured under the National Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974 shall not be deemed to conform to veteran housing construction and safety standards pursuant to the Act, except to the extent permitted by state law.

Federal Mandate Relief Act of 1993 - Prohibits an intergovernmental regulation from being enforced against a State or local government unless there has been made an appropriation of Federal funds and such funds have been made available to all State and local governments for the fiscal year in an amount sufficient to reimburse all State and local governments for the total amount of additional costs that will be incurred by those governments in complying with the regulation during the fiscal year. <n>Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to report to the President and the Congress, with an estimate, for that fiscal year and the following fiscal year, of the total amount of additional costs that have been incurred by each State government and by each local government within each State in complying with that intergovernmental regulation. Specifies that the total amount of such costs shall be the total amount estimated for compliance with the regulation for the fiscal year in the report. <n>Makes appropriations available to reimburse State and local governments for additional costs estimated for compliance with an intergovernmental regulation.

Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure Act of 2006 or the Credit CARD Act of 2006- Amends the Truth in Lending Act to prohibit any increase in any annual percentage rate (APR) of interest (other than an increase due to the expiration of any introductory percentage rate of interest, or due solely to a change in another rate of interest to which such rate is indexed) with respect to a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan before the beginning of the billing cycle beginning not less than 15 days after the obligor receives notice of such increase, and before the effective date of the increase. Requires such notice to be made in a clear and conspicuous manner, and to contain a brief statement of the right of the obligor to cancel the account before the effective date of the increase.<n><n>Prohibits: (1) the imposition of finance or interest charges with regard to any amount of a new extension of credit that was paid on or before the date on which it was due; and (2) cancellation or additional fees for on-time payments or payment in full.<n><n>Prohibits a creditor from: (1) imposing any fees on the obligor for any extension of credit in excess of the amount authorized to be extended with respect to such account, if such

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on May 15, 2008. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Naval Vessel Transfer Act of 2008 - Authorizes the President to transfer certain naval vessels to foreign recipients on a grant basis under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. Declares that the value of such a transfer shall not be counted against the aggregate value of excess defense articles transferred to Israel in any fiscal year under such Act. Requires transfer recipients to have necessary repair or refurbishment performed in the United States before the vessel joins its naval forces. Terminates such authority at the end of the two-year period beginning on the date of the enactment of this Act.<n><n>Directs the President to: (1) assess on an ongoing basis the extent to which Israel possesses a qualitative military edge over military threats to Israel; and (2) ensure that such assessment is used to inform the review by the United States of applications to sell defense articles and defense services under the Arms Export Control Act to countries in the Middle East.<n><n>Amends the Arms Export Control Act to require the President to: (1) transmit to the appropriate congressional committees a report on the initial and most recent assessment on the extent to which Israel possesses a qualitative military edge over military threats to Israel;

Joint Committee on Agency Rule Review Act of 2003 (JCARR Act) - Establishes a Joint Committee on Agency Rule Review in the Congress to: (1) review Federal agency regulations; and (2) report to the Congress on its recommendations for legislative and administrative action.Sets forth procedures for consideration of a joint resolution of review in both chambers.

Amends the Export-Import Bank Act of 1945 to prohibit the Export-Import Bank of the United States from providing assistance for exports to China unless the Board of Directors determines that an entity is adhering to a code of conduct set forth in this Act.

Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to convey specified real property to the State of Colorado for use as a correctional facility, including improvements thereon other than Kit Carson Chapel, comprising the location of the Ft. Lyon Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center. Prohibits the Secretary from making such conveyance unless: (1) Colorado agrees to provide public access to Kit Carson Chapel and the cemetery located on such property; and (2) the Secretary opens not less than three health care facilities, and a nursing home care facility, in Veterans Integrated Service Network 19 as replacement facilities for the Center until the Secretary completes the evaluation and performance of any environmental restoration activities required by the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. Declares that as part of such conveyance the Secretary may convey to Colorado any furniture, fixtures, equipment, and other personal property associated with the property that the Secretary determines is not required for purposes of Department of Veterans Affairs health care facilities to be established in southern Colorado or for purposes of Ft. Lyon National Cemetery. Declares that the exact acreage and legal description of the real property to be conveyed, and of any fixtures and other personal property conveyed, shall be determined by a survey, and by such other methods, as are satisfactory to the Secretary. Authorizes the Secretary

Department of Defense Privatization and Outsourcing Moratorium Act - Prohibits, for a five-year moratorium period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act and continuing until the end of the five-year period beginning on the date the Secretary of Defense certifies to Congress that all actions necessary to carry out the 1995 round of base closures and realignments have been completed, any conversion of a commercial or industrial type function of the Department of Defense (DOD) to contractor performance, except under a Strategic Sourcing or Business Process and Re-engineering plan of DOD.

Commission on Effective Regulation and Assessment Systems for Public Schools Act Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to establish the Commission on Effective Regulation and Assessment Systems for Public Schools. Requires the Commission to: (1) examine federal, state, and local regulatory requirements on elementary and secondary education; (2) make recommendations on how to align and improve such requirements to improve performance and innovation; (3) examine the quality and purpose of current federal, state, and local assessment requirements; and (4) make recommendations to improve and align assessment systems to provide quality and meaningful information for parents, teachers, and students to improve student achievement, teacher performance, and innovation.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 12, 2012. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Congressional Accountability and Oversight in Syria Act - Expresses the sense of Congress that: the government of Syria should immediately cease the use of heavy weapons in population centers, all parties within Syria should bring about a cessation of armed violence in all forms, the Secretary of State should introduce a list of state-sponsored terrorist organizations within Syria, and the President should adhere to the War Powers Resolution and obtain specific statutory authorization for U.S. military operations in Syria; and the President should adhere to the War Powers Resolution and obtain specific statutory authorization for U.S. Armed Forces military operations in Syria, unless and until Congress expressly authorizes such assistance by law enacted after enactment of this Act. Prohibits federal assistance for paramilitary operations in Syria, unless and until Congress expressly authorizes such assistance by law enacted after enactment of this Act.

Genetic Privacy and Nondiscrimination Act of 2003 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to prohibit health discrimination in group health insurance coverage on the basis of genetic information in the group market, including information about a request for or receipt of genetic services.Prohibits a group health plan from adjusting premiums or contribution amounts for a group on the basis of predictive genetic information concerning any individual (including a dependent) or family member of the individual, including information about a request for or receipt of genetic services.Prohibits health discrimination on the basis of predictive genetic information as a condition of coverage in the individual market. Excludes from such prohibitions information: (1) from which individual identifiers are removed, encoded, or encrypted to prevent disclosure of the individual's identity; (2) for research conducted in compliance with Federal regulations; or (3) related to a manifested disease, disorder, impairment, or condition which could be reasonably detected by a health care professional with appropriate training and expertise in the field of medicine involved.

Victims of Abuse Access to Health Insurance Act - Prohibits insurers from denying, canceling, limiting, or increasing health insurance coverage or health benefits, or establishing, increasing, or varying the premium charged for coverage, to or for an individual on the basis that the individual is, has been, or may be the victim of domestic violence or to or for a group or employer on the basis that the group includes or the employer employs, or provides or subsidizes insurance for, such an individual.Prohibits a health benefit plan from considering a condition or injury that occurred as a result of domestic violence as a pre-existing condition.Subjects violators to: (1) a fine for a class A misdemeanor not resulting in death; (2) a civil monetary penalty; and (3) commencement of a civil action.

Health Care Fraud Enforcement Act of 2009 - (Sec. 2) Directs the United States Sentencing Commission to: (1) review the Federal Sentencing Guidelines and policy statements applicable to persons convicted of federal health care offenses; (2) amend such Guidelines and policy statements to provide that the aggregate dollar amount of fraudulent bills submitted to a government health care program shall constitute prima facie evidence of the intended loss by the defendant; and (3) amend such Guidelines to provide specified increases in the offense level for any defendant convicted of a federal health care offense relating to a government health care program which involves a loss of not less than $1 million and less than $7 million and a four-level increase in the offense level for any defendant convicted of such an offense relating to a government health care program which involves a loss of not less than $20 million. Requires the Commission to: (1) ensure that such Guidelines reflect the serious harms associated with health care fraud and the need for aggressive and appropriate law enforcement action to prevent such fraud; (2) provide increased penalties for persons convicted of health care fraud offenses in appropriate circumstances; (3) consult with individuals or groups representing health care fraud victims, law enforcement officials, the health care industry, and the federal judiciary as part of such review; (4) ensure reasonable consistency with other relevant directives and with other guidelines under such Guidelines

Benjamin Franklin Patriot Act - States that certain provisions of the USA PATRIOT Act, including provisions relating to: mandatory detention, searches, pen registers, foreign intelligence purposes, and national security letters, shall cease to have effect 90 days after enactment of this Act and shall not apply to residents of the United States other than for intelligence purposes. Declares that Congress may, at the request of the President, hold hearings to determine whether a particular section should be removed from such list.Applies provisions of: (1) the federal criminal code relating to wire and electronic communications and their interception as well as the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 2002 (FISA) to the use of pen registers for foreign intelligence purposes; (2) the USA PATRIOT Act to which such provisions apply; (3) the Immigration and Nationality Act to which such provisions apply; and (4) the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 (FISA) to the use of pen registers for foreign intelligence purposes.

Makes appropriations to the Secretary of Energy for the purchase of essential mineral rights at Rocky Flats Environmental Technology Site, Colorado.<n><n>Prohibits the Secretary from purchasing an essential mineral right unless: (1) the owner of the essential mineral right is a willing seller; and (2) the Secretary purchases the essential mineral right for a amount that does not exceed fair market value.<n><n>Requires that only those funds authorized to be appropriated by this Act be available for the Secretary to purchase such rights.<n><n>States that any natural resource damage liability claim shall be considered to be satisfied by: (1) the purchase by the Secretary of essential mineral rights for consideration in an amount equal to $10 million; (2) the payment by the Secretary to the trustees of $10 million; or (3) the purchase by the Secretary of any portion of the mineral rights for consideration in an amount less than $10 million and a payment by the Secretary to the trustees of an amount equal to the difference between.<n><n>Exempts any purchases of mineral rights under this Act from the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (NEPA).<n><n>Requires that any amounts received under this Act be used by the Trustees for specified purposes, including: (1) the purchase of additional mineral rights at Rocky Flats; and (2) the development of habitat restoration projects at Rocky

Blueprint for Health Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to create a Blueprint for Health that provides a national infrastructure for disease prevention, health promotion, and education about and better management of chronic conditions through the use of a nationwide integrated medical home model of care in a manner that is designed to initiate, coordinate, and evaluate measures for promoting health and preventing disease in the United States.<n><n>Requires the Blueprint for Health to include: (1) a strategic plan for designing the integrated medical home model of care; (2) a strategic plan for designing the integrated coordinated chronic care management model of care; (3) a plan for the formation of community care teams and the use of specialists and other patient support personnel; (4) a plan for integrating recommended prevention programs and a strategy for integrating them into the integrated medical home model of care; (5) a plan to ensure that chronically ill patients have a low level of cost sharing under the integrated medical home model of care; (6) development and use of outcome and reporting measures designed to track the progress of patients meeting clinically recommended treatment goals; (7) a strategy for ensuring the broad support of the integrated medical home model of care by health insurers, hospitals, and health care professionals; (8) recommendations for better integrating specialty care services into primary care practices to

Job Opportunity and Welfare Reduction Act of 1997 - Directs the Attorney General to conduct a pilot program under which the Attorney General shall provide a written notice to a State of one or more potential employment opportunities for an adult who is receiving assistance under the State program funded under part A (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) of title IV of the Social Security Act, where such opportunity arises from: (1) the removal of one or more unauthorized aliens from a work site in the State by an officer or employee of the Immigration and Naturalization Service performing duties relating to the enforcement of the immigration laws; or (2) the issuance of an unauthorized work letter by the Attorney General to an employer.

Army Arsenal Strategic Workload Enhancement Act of 2012 - Directs the Secretary of Defense (DOD) to develop and promulgate measurable and enforceable guidelines for DOD, defense agencies, and the military services to have supplies, components, end items, parts, assemblies, and sub-assemblies made in factories or arsenals owned by the United States to the extent those factories or arsenals can make those supplies, components, end items, parts, assemblies, and sub-assemblies on an economical basis while preserving the ability to provide an effective and timely response to mobilizations, national defense contingency situations, and other emergency requirements. Requires the Secretary, for purposes of determining whether supplies, components, end items, parts, assemblies, and sub-assemblies can be made on an economical basis," to analyze the direct costs associated with the manufacture of such supplies, components, end items, parts, assemblies, and sub-assemblies."

Supply Our Soldiers Act of 2005 - Directs the Postal Service and the Secretary of Defense to provide for a program under which postal benefits are made available to the designated representative of each qualified individual who is: (1) a member of the Armed Forces on active duty; or (2) a civilian who is authorized to use postal services at Armed Forces installations and holds a position or performs one or more functions in support of military operations. Defines qualified individual" as an individual who is: (1) serving in an overseas area designated by the President where the Armed Forces are engaged in action against an enemy of the United States, engaged in military operations involving armed conflict with a hostile foreign force, engaged in temporary military operations under arduous circumstances, serving with a friendly foreign force in an armed conflict in which the United States is not a belligerent, or temporarily deployed overseas for an operational contingency in arduous circumstances, or hospitalized in a Armed Forces facility as a result of disease or injury incurred as a result of such service; or (2) serving under such conditions as designated by the President."

United States Mint Bicentennial Coin Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to issue five-dollar gold coins, one-dollar silver coins, and half-dollar silver coins in commemoration of the bicentennial of the founding of the United States Mint. <n>Mandates that all surcharges received from coin sales be paid to the National Numismatic Collection at the National Museum of American History to assist its mission of preserving and interpreting the history of the United States.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 5, 2016. Janey Ensminger Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry to: (1) review the scientific literature relevant to the relationship between the employment or residence of individuals at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, for at least 30 days between August 1, 1953, and December 21, 1987 and specific illnesses or conditions incurred by those individuals; (2) determine each illness or condition for which there is evidence that exposure to a toxic substance at Camp Lejeune may be a cause of the illness or condition; and (3) categorize the evidence of the connection of the illness or condition to exposure as sufficient to conclude with reasonable confidence that the exposure is a cause of the illness or condition, modest supporting causation but not sufficient to conclude with reasonable confidence that exposure is a cause of the illness or condition, or no more than limited supporting causation. The Registry must publish and update the list of illnesses or conditions for which such a determination has been made and the citations for all literature reviewed. An individual who has been furnished hospital care or medical services under this bill for an illness or condition shall remain eligible for such care notwithstanding that the evidence

Veterans Equal Treatment Act - Terminates the Department of Veterans Affairs medical care funding allocation system known as the Veterans Equitable Resource Allocation system. Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to develop a new formula for the allocation of funds appropriated to the Department for Medical Care to its national service regions, known as Veterans Integrated Service Networks (VISNs).

. National Purple Heart Hall of Honor Commemorative Coin Act (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Department of the Treasury to mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins emblematic of the National Purple Heart Hall of Honor. (Sec. 4) The bill requires all sales of such coins to include a surcharge of $35 per coin, which shall be paid by Treasury to the National Purple Heart Hall of Honor, Inc., to help finance the construction and operation of this Hall. (Sec. 5) Treasury shall ensure that: (1) minting and issuing such coins will not result in any net cost to the federal government; and (2) no funds, including applicable surcharges, shall be disbursed to the Hall until the total cost of designing and issuing all authorized coins is recovered by the Treasury.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on October 6, 2015. Safe and Affordable Drugs from Canada Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to promulgate regulations permitting individuals to safely import into the United States, with exceptions, a prescription drug purchased from an approved Canadian pharmacy that: is dispensed by a pharmacist licensed in Canada; is purchased for personal use in quantities not greater than a 90-day supply; is filled using a valid prescription issued by a physician licensed to practice in the United States; and has the same active ingredient or ingredients, route of administration, dosage form, and strength as a prescription drug approved under the Act. The bill excludes controlled substances, biological products, infused drugs, intravenously injected drugs, drugs that are inhaled during surgery, parenteral drugs, and drugs manufactured through biotechnology processes. The FDA must publish a list of approved Canadian pharmacies, including their website address, from which individuals may purchase prescription drugs in accordance with this Act. To be an approved Canadian pharmacy, the FDA must certify that the pharmacy: has been in existence for at least five years preceding the date of certification; operates in accordance with pharmacy standards enacted in

Michelle's Law - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), the Internal Revenue Code, and the Public Health Service Act to prohibit a group health plan from terminating coverage of a dependent child due to a medically necessary leave of absence from a postsecondary education institution that: (1) is due to a severe illness or injury as certified by the child's attending physician; and (2) causes the child involved to lose full-time student status.

Sudden Oak Death Syndrome Control Act of 2004 - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to conduct sudden oak death syndrome programs of: (1) research, monitoring, and regulation; (2) management and treatment; and (3) fire prevention.

Financial Security Credit Act of 2015 Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an income-based tax credit equal to the lesser of $500 or 50% of the amount deposited or contributed into designated savings products in a taxable year. Defines "designated savings products" as a qualified retirement plan, a qualified tuition plan, a Coverdell education savings account, a certificate of deposit with a duration of at least 8 months, a savings account, or other savings product considered appropriate by the Secretary of the Treasury. Directs the Internal Revenue Service to notify individual taxpayers who may qualify for a savings product tax credit that they have the option of an electronic direct deposit of any portion of their tax refund into a designated savings product.

Maternal Motor Vehicle Crash Safety Act of 2006 - Expresses the sense of Congress that the Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) should: (1) continue to include in the National Automotive Sampling System Crashworthiness Data System data related to motor vehicle crashes that involved pregnant women; and (2) identify other means to advance the current level of understanding regarding the number, nature, and impact of motor vehicle crashes involving pregnant women and their unborn children through data collection, data linkage systems, and analysis systems. Directs the Administrator to carry out a program to provide grants and other incentives to promote the development of data linkage systems to track adverse health effects and birth outcomes for pregnant women who are occupants of a motor vehicle that is involved in a crash and the unborn children of such women, through the connection and analysis of multiple data sources.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on November 16, 2013. Title I: Veterans Health-Care Improvements - (Sec. 101) Authorizes the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to provide care for a newborn child of an enrolled woman veteran. Allows such care to be provided until the mother is discharged from the hospital or for 14 days after delivery, whichever is shorter, and only if the VA contracted for the delivery of the child.)(Sec. 102) Provides pay comparability for the Director, Nursing Service of the VA.(Sec. 103) States that outpatient dental care for all former prisoners of war may be provided only during a period of at least 90 days after delivery.(Sec. 102) Prohibits the furnishing of certain benefits under the veterans' benefit program on behalf of a deceased veteran: (1) who died as the result of a service-connected disability, (2) who was under 60 years of age at the time of death, or (3) who died while in receipt of veterans' disability compensation.(Sec. 202) Specifies that: (1) a certificate shall not be furnished under the veterans' benefit program on behalf of a deceased veteran; (2) a flag shall not be furnished on behalf of such a veteran; and (3)

FHA Seller-Financed Downpayment Reform and Risk-Based Pricing Authorization Act of 2008 - Amends the National Housing Act to make exceptions to the prohibition against mortgage insurance for mortgages involving a downpayment using funds furnished by: (1) the seller or any party that benefits financially from the transaction (seller-financed downpayment); or (2) any third party that is reimbursed by the seller or any such party. Makes eligible for mortgage insurance, in spite of a seller-financed downpayment, any mortagors with credit scores equivalent to a FICO score of: (1) 680 or more; (2) at least 620 but less than 680; or (3) 619 or less. Prescribes conditions for mortgage insurance in FY2010 and thereafter.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on March 14, 2016. Off-Reservation Land Acquisition Guidance Act (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Department of the Interior, before determining whether to take certain off-reservation land into trust for the benefit of an Indian tribe under the Indian Reorganization Act, to evaluate: (1) the anticipated benefits to the tribe associated with taking such land into trust; and (2) any concerns raised by applicable state and local governments relating to the acquisition of such land. In evaluating the anticipated benefits to the tribe, Interior shall prepare a report that includes an assessment of: the impacts of taking the applicable off-reservation land into trust on the on-reservation unemployment rate; the impacts of taking such land into trust on reservation life and tribal membership if the members, dependents, and descendants of the Indian tribe relocate to the off-reservation land or adjacent communities; the specific on-reservation benefits of taking such land into trust, including whether on-reservation jobs will be created and the quantity of jobs expected to be created; and whether the tribal government can efficiently exercise its governmental and regulatory responsibilities if a gaming facility is constructed on the off-reservation land. In evaluating any concerns raised by applicable state and local governments, Interior shall prepare a report

SSI Disability Benefits Reform Act of 1995 - Amends title XVI (Supplemental Security Income) (SSI) of the Social Security Act to provide that, in the case of an individual who has attained 18 years of age and for whom a determination has been made of eligibility for an SSI benefit by reason of disability, the determination of eligibility is effective for the three-year period beginning on the date of the determination, and the eligibility of the individual lapses unless a determination of continuing eligibility is made before the end of such period, and before the end of each subsequent three-year period. Exempts such an individual upon attaining 65 years of age if the individual has an impairment that is not expected to improve (or a combination of impairments that are not expected to improve). <n>Prohibits the Commissioner of Social Security from making the redetermination of whether the individual continues to be eligible for the benefit unless the individual submits an application requesting the redetermination. Requires the Commissioner to make the redetermination only after making redeterminations for individuals for whom eligibility has not lapsed.

Medicare Dual Eligible Prescription Drug Coverage Act of 2005 - States that, for prescriptions filled between January 1, 2006, and June 30, 2006, Medicare part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) coverage of prescription drugs under title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act shall not apply and a state shall continue to provide medical assistance with respect to prescription drugs as if such provision had not been enacted.

National Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government Act of 2001 - Establishes the National Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government to: (1) conduct a private sector survey on management and cost control in the Federal Government; (2) conduct in-depth reviews of the operations of the executive agencies; (3) review existing reports from the Government Accounting Office, the Congressional Budget Office, and the various Inspector General offices within executive agencies, reports and other existing governmental and nongovernmental recommendations for reducing waste, including recommendations from the President's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control; and (4) submit to the President and the Congress recommendations for improving the budget process, management, and reducing waste and costs in the Federal Government.

Child Abuse and Neglect Enforcement Act - Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to reduce by ten percent the funds available to a State under the drug control and system improvement grant program unless such State has in effect a law requiring that a law enforcement agency designated by such State make available to child protective workers and child welfare workers criminal conviction record information and orders of protection based on a claim of domestic or child abuse to the same extent as such information is made available to law enforcement officers in such State. Requires the Attorney General to issue regulations to ensure compliance. <n>Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make a grant under the substance abuse prevention and treatment block grant program to a State that requires that: (1) each newborn infant born in the State be tested for physical dependence on any drug, fetal alcohol syndrome, fetal alcohol effects, the presence of alcohol, and the presence of drugs associated with substance abuse; and (2) if the newborn tests positive, the principal State or local agency with responsibility for the protection of children be notified. Provides for withheld funds for certain States.

Servicemembers Credit Protection Act - Amends the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act to require the Secretary of the military department concerned to notify each consumer reporting agency that compiles and maintains files on consumers on a nationwide basis of the deployment of a servicemember away from his or her usual duty station to duty for which special pay is entitled within 30 days after such deployment. Requires such agency to notify each such consumer when the required notice ceases to apply within 30 days after the end of the deployment.<n><n>Amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to require a consumer reporting agency that receives a notice from the Secretary concerning a servicemember to: (1) include a combat zone duty alert in the consumer's file, and (2) exclude the consumer from any list of consumers prepared by the agency and provided to any third party to offer credit or insurance to the consumer as part of a transaction that was not initiated by the consumer. Requires the consumer reporting agency also to provide the consumer with a summary of consumer rights and the duties of creditors and other persons under the Act.<n><n>Increases penalties for certain violations of the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act involving servicemembers deployed to an overseas combat zone.

Wildlife Without Borders Authorization Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to carry out the Wildlife Without Borders Program within the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to provide international wildlife conservation assistance through the initiation, facilitation, and promotion of locally adapted wildlife management and conservation programs in coordination with non-governmental organizations, governments, private businesses, and community leaders. Provides that such program shall include, but shall not be limited to, partnership programs for grass roots capacity building, applied scientific conservation research, and wildlife management training.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on June 17, 1996. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Justice for Victims of State Sponsored Terrorism Act - Amends the Federal judicial code to deny a foreign state immunity from the jurisdiction of U.S. or State courts in any case in which money damages are sought against a foreign state for personal injury or death that was caused by an act of torture, extrajudicial killing, aircraft sabotage, hostage taking, or the provision of material support or resources for such an act if such act or provision is engaged in by an official, employee, or agent of such foreign state while acting within the scope of his or her office, employment, or agency. Directs the court to hear a claim if: (1) the foreign state was designated as a state sponsor of terrorism under specified laws at the time the act occurred; (2) the claimant or the victim was a U.S. national, a member of the armed forces, or an employee of the U.S. government or its contractors acting within the scope of employment when the act upon which the claim is based occurred; or (3) where the act occurred in the foreign state against which the claim has been brought, the claimant has afforded the foreign state a

Government Excess Prevention Act of 2011 - Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to coordinate with the heads of federal departments and independent agencies to: (1) determine which government publications could be available on government websites and no longer printed, and devise a strategy to reduce overall government printing costs over the 10-year period beginning with FY2012; (2) establish government-wide guidelines on employee printing; (3) issue on OMB's public website the results of a cost-benefit analysis on implementing a digital signature system and on establishing employee printing identification systems; (4) ensure that federal employee printing costs unrelated to national defense, homeland security, border security, national disasters, and other emergencies do not exceed $860 million annually; and (5) issue guidelines requiring every federal agency to list on each publication distributed to the public and paid for by the government the name of the issuing agency, the total number of copies of the document printed, the collective cost of producing and printing all of the copies of the document, and the name of the firm publishing the document. Prohibits the total amount paid or reimbursed by a federal agency for travel and subsistence expenses, mileage allowances for official travel by federal employees, or other related expenses from exceeding 50% of the total amount paid or reimbursed by such agency for the

Employers Financial Literacy Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow small business employers (employers with between two and 50 employees) a business tax credit for 35% of continuing financial education expenses provided to their employees. Defines qualified continuing financial education program" as a program that: (1) is provided by a community-based budget and counseling agency; (2) promotes consumer understanding of consumer, economic, and personal finance issues and concepts, including saving for retirement, managing credit, long-term care, estate planning, and education on predatory lending, identity theft, and financial abuse schemes; and (3) is offered to all employees of the taxpayer who have at least two weeks of service with the employer."

Poverty Trap Study Act of 2001 - Establishes the National Commission on Marginal Tax Rates for the Working Poor to: (1) determine the total effective marginal rate of tax from all taxes and benefit program phaseouts that persons are subject to (both as individuals and as married couples) at all earnings levels between $7,000 and $30,000 per year for at least five States, including Wisconsin and California; and (2) submit a report to Congress on its findings.

Fairness for America's Servicemen and Women in Higher Education Act of 2003- Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 (HEA) to provide that a student who withdraws from an institution of higher education to serve on active duty during a war or national emergency shall not be required to repay any grant assistance that is otherwise required to be repayed under such Act.Amends the HEA to provide that during which a borrower is a member of a regular component on active duty during a war or during a national emergency: (1) the Federal Family Education Loan, Direct Loan, and Consolidation Loan programs may be treated as if the borrower were a member of a regular component on active duty during such war or emergency; and (2) members of the National Guard may be treated as members of a regular component on active duty during such emergency.

Assured Food Safety Act of 2007 - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture and the Commissioner of Food and Drugs to jointly establish a program requiring all food items imported into the United States to bear a certificate of assured safety issued by the government of the country from which the item is imported. In conducting such program, the Secretary and the Commissioner shall: (1) establish requirements for a food item to be issued a certificate of assured safety by the government of the country from which the food item is to be imported; and (2) prohibit a food item that does not bear a certificate of assured safety from being imported into the United States. Allows the Secretary and the Commissioner to exempt from such requirements a food item that is imported: (1) from a country that has not been the source of a contaminated food item resulting in a significant health or safety recall in the preceding five years; or (2) in a de minimis volume. Prohibits the importation of any food item that fails to provide the level of safety assured in the certificate, that is produced by the same person, and that is produced in the same country until the Secretary or the Commissioner: (1) is given an opportunity to inspect the place of production to determine whether appropriate corrections have been made and determines that such country has taken sufficient steps to identify and correct

Authorizes the President, on behalf of Congress, to award a gold medal collectively to the Tuskegee Airmen in recognition of their unique military record, which inspired revolutionary reform in the Armed Forces.

Planning Actively for Cancer Treatment (PACT) Act of 2013 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for Medicare coverage of cancer care planning and coordination services.

Save Our Seas Act of 2017 or the SOS Act of 2017 This bill amends the Marine Debris Act to require the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to work with other federal agencies to develop outreach and education strategies to address both land- and sea-based sources of marine debris and to promote international action to reduce the incidence of marine debris. The NOAA may determine whether there is a severe marine debris event and make sums available to an affected state or the state's governor for activities to assist in the cleanup and response required by such an event. In providing assistance, the NOAA shall prioritize assistance for activities to respond to a severe marine debris event in a rural or remote community or in a habitat of national concern. The federal share of costs for such activities shall be 100% if the activity is funded wholly by funds made available by an entity to the federal government from foreign countries for the purpose of responding to such an event. The bill expresses the sense of Congress that the President should: support federal funding for research and development of bio-based and other alternatives or environmentally feasible improvements to materials that reduce municipal solid waste and its consequences in the ocean; work with representatives of foreign countries that contribute the most to the global marine debris problem to learn about, and find solutions to, their contributions

Interstate Transportation of Municipal Waste Act of 1995 - Amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act to authorize a State Governor, if requested by an affected local government, to prohibit the disposal of out-of-State municipal waste in: (1) any landfill or incinerator subject to the jurisdiction of the Governor or the affected local government; and (2) landfill cells that do not meet the design and location standards and leachate collection and groundwater monitoring requirements of State law in effect on January 1, 1993, for new landfills. <n>Authorizes such Governors, without the request of such local governments, to: (1) limit the quantity of out-of-State municipal waste received for disposal at each landfill in the State to an annual quantity equal to the quantity received for disposal at the landfill during 1993 or 1994 whichever is less; and (2) limit the disposal of out-of-State municipal waste at landfills that received documented shipments of more than 50,000 tons of such waste in 1993 and to 20 percent of all municipal waste received at such landfill in each of 1998 and 1999. <n>Authorizes a State Governor, if requested by such local governments, to: (1) ban imports from large exporting States if the volumes of municipal solid waste exported by those States did not meet reduction targets; and (2) limit the quantity of out-of-

Protecting Consumers from Unreasonable Credit Rates Act of 2009 - Amends the Truth in Lending Act to prohibit a creditor from extending credit to a consumer under an open end consumer credit plan (credit card) for which the fee and interest rate exceeds 36%.

. The expanded summary of the Senate reported version is repeated here.) Brownfields Reauthorization Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill modifies the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) to specify if a state or local government takes title to a brownfield site as a result of law enforcement activity, that government is not an owner or operator for the purposes of CERCLA. (Brownfields are certain commercial properties that are hindered from reuse or redevelopment due to the presence of a hazardous substance, pollutant, or contaminant.) (Sec. 3) The bill modifies brownfield program eligibility with respect to petroleum sites where no viable responsible party exists. Specifically, it eliminates the requirement that sites be of relatively low risk. (Sec. 4) The bill revises leaseholder status regarding bona fide prospective purchasers. (Sec. 5) The bill expands CERCLA eligibility for nonprofit organizations and qualified community development entities. (Sec. 6) The brownfield site characterization and assessment grant program and the brownfield remediation grant and loan program are revised by authorizing eligible governmental entities to receive grants and loans for property that was acquired before January 11, 2002, even if the entities do not qualify as bona fide prospective purchasers. (Sec. 7) The bill increases the cap on the amount that may

Long-Term Care Advancement Act of 1998 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for an exception from the penalty tax and the exclusion from gross income for amounts withdrawn from certain retirement plans to pay long-term care insurance premiums.

Access for All America Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize appropriations for grants to federally-qualified health centers (FQHCs) for FY2010-FY2016. Allows FQHCs to provide required primary health services and additional health services at facilities directly operated by the FQHC or at any other inpatient or outpatient settings determined appropriate by the FQHC to meet the needs of its patents. Declares that a FQHC shall not be required to locate its service facility or facilities within a designated medically underserved area in order to serve either the residents of its catchment area or a special medically underserved population comprised of migratory and seasonal agricultural workers, the homeless, or residents of public housing, if such location is determined to be reasonably accessible to and appropriate to meet the needs of the medically underserved residents of the center's catchment area or the special medically underserved population.

Great Lakes Federal Effectiveness Act - Establishes a Great Lakes Research Council to: (1) advise and promote the coordination of Federal research activities to avoid unnecessary duplication and ensure greater effectiveness in achieving ecosystem protection of the Great Lakes through the goals of the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement; (2) prepare and provide to interested parties a document which includes an assessment of the research activities needed to fulfill such Agreement goals and of existing Federal expertise and capabilities in those activities needed to fulfill such goals; (3) identify topics for and participate in meetings, workshops, symposia, and conferences on Great Lakes research issues; (4) make recommendations for the uniform collection of data for enhancing research and management protocols relating to the Great Lakes ecosystem; (5) advise and cooperate in the establishment of a comprehensive, multi-media data base for the ecosystem; and (6) ensure that findings and information regarding such research programs conducted or sponsored by the Federal Government are disseminated in a timely manner and in useful forms to interested persons.

Summer Relief for Leaking Underground Storage Tank Act of 2006 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to suspend excise taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene from May 29, 2006, until September 4, 2006. Provides for the reimbursement of the Highway Trust Fund and the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund for tax receipts lost during the suspension period.

Meeting Our Responsibility to Medicare Beneficiaries Act of 2005- Amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to grant the Secretary of Health and Human Services authority to negotiate contracts with manufacturers of covered Medicare part D drugs in bulk, consistent with the requirements and in furtherance of the goals of providing quality care and containing costs under Medicare.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to exercise such authority with respect to covered Medicare part D drugs offered under: (1) each fallback prescription drug plan; and (2) Medicare Advantage prescription drug plans (MA-PD plans).<n><n>Eliminates the Medicare Regional Plan Stabilization Fund (Slush Fund).<n><n>Requires the Secretary to ensure that payments to Medicare Advantage organizations are adjusted based on such factors to ensure that the health status of the enrollee is reflected in such adjusted payments, including adjusting for the difference between the health status of the enrollee and individuals enrolled under the original Medicare fee-for-service program under parts A and B.<n><n>Amends SSA title XVIII part D to require two prescription drug plans to avoid Federal fallback.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to waive the late enrollment penalty under Medicare part D for full-benefit dual eligible individuals for the

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an individual a deduction for political contributions made by the individual. Limits such deduction to $100 ($200) for a joint return. Disallows such deduction to estates and trusts.

Cuba Sanctions Reform Act of 2004 - Terminates, one year after enactment of this Act, certain sanctions against Cuba, including prohibitions under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 against assistance to Cuba and certain authorities conferred by the Trading with the Enemy Act on July 1, 1977. Authorizes the renewal of such restrictions.

Fox- Wisconsin Heritage Parkway National Heritage Area Act of 2010- Establishes the Fox- Wisconsin Heritage Parkway National Heritage Area in Wisconsin. Designates the Fox- Wisconsin Heritage Parkway, a nonprofit, as the local coordinating entity for the Heritage Area. Requires the coordinating entity to prepare and submit a management plan for the Heritage Area.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code and the Employee Retirement and Income Security Act to provide that small employer benefit arrangements shall be treated as employers for purposes of administering and allocating items of income, credits, deductions, or exclusions associated with the provision of employee benefits.

Mexican Agricultural Trade Compliance Act - Directs the United States Trade Representative to enforce the provisions of the Trade Act of 1974 with respect to any trade agreement that has the effect of denying the rights of the United States under the Uruguay Round Agreements.

Mortgage Broker Transparency and Accountability Act of 2007- Amends the Truth in Lending Act to deem a mortgage broker, who provides mortgage brokerage services to any consumer, to have an agency relationship with the consumer. Subjects such broker to all federal and state requirements for agents of consumers.<n><n>Requires a mortgage broker to: (1) act in providing such services to the consumer and provide the consumer with a reasonable choice among available home mortgage loan products that meet the consumer's stated needs for mortgage financing; (2) disclose to the consumer the risks and benefits of each home mortgage loan product offered to the borrower, including any possibility of a payment increase at the time of any agreement of prepayment penalties, balloon payments, and the consumer's responsibilities to pay taxes and insurance; (3) disclose to the consumer all fees or other payments the mortgage broker may receive from a creditor in connection with each home mortgage loan product offered to the consumer; (4) meet all applicable licensing requirements; and (5) obtain and permanently maintain a bond-mortgage bond for an amount equal to 1% of the aggregate value of all direct and indirect fees received by the mortgage broker in connection with providing mortgage brokerage services in the calendar year preceding the date of the transaction executed first, to the benefit of any consumer who has any claim against the mortgage broker

Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) should be structured to promote and protect human rights around the world, working with other like-minded countries; and (2) the United States should retain the chance to participate in the UNHRC more efficient and more effective than the first group of nine countries elected to the first group.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require that an inflation indexed basis rather than an adjusted basis be used to determine the gain or loss of a taxpayer (other than a corporation) of an indexed asset which has been held for more than three years. Defines such asset as common stock in a C corporation (other than a foreign corporation) and tangible property which is a capital asset or property used in a trade or business.

Fair Debt Collection Practices Amendments Act of 1995- Amends the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act to prohibit a debt collector from: (1) collecting a debt owed to the Federal Government or to any State; and (2) communicating with persons other than the consumer's attorney for the purpose of acquiring location information or information relating to the consumer's income, assets, or credit if the attorney refuses to provide such information to the debt collector. <n>Authorizes a debt collector to: (1) communicate with persons other than the consumer's attorney for the purpose of acquiring location information or information relating to the consumer's income, assets, or credit if the attorney refuses to provide such information to the debt collector; and (2) require that certain validation statements appear in type at least as large as 12-point type. <n>Makes legal actions by debt collectors mandatory. <n>Revises civil liability limitations relating to damages and costs of action.

Paskenta Band Restoration Act - Extends Federal recognition and associated rights, privileges, and benefits to the Paskenta Band of Nomlaki Indians of the Paskenta Rancheria of California (the Tribe). <n>Makes the provisions of the Indian Reorganization Act applicable to the Tribe and its members. <n>Declares that, without regard to the existence of a reservation, the Tribe and its members shall be eligible for all Federal services and benefits furnished to federally recognized Indian tribes or their members. <n>Deems members of the Tribe residing in the Tribe's service area to be residing on a reservation. <n>Prohibits this Act from expanding, reducing, or affecting any hunting, fishing, trapping, gathering, or water right of the Tribe or its members.

Veterans' Employment Transition Support Act of 2007 or the VETS Act of 2007- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow employers a business-related tax credit for hiring veterans who are certified as being veterans by a designated local agency and who have a service-connected disability rating of 10% or more. Limits the amount of such credit to the applicable percentage of such veterans' first-year wages, as determined by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs.

Students Learning in Safe Schools Act of 1999- Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize the Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance to make grants to States, local governments, Indian tribes, and local educational agencies to purchase school safety equipment for use in and near elementary and secondary schools. <n>Authorizes the Director to give preferential consideration to an application from a jurisdiction that: (1) has the greatest need for school safety equipment, based on the percentage of elementary and secondary schools in the applicant\\'s jurisdiction that do not have access to such equipment, has a violent crime rate at or above the national average as determined by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, or has not received a block grant under the Local Law Enforcement Block Grant program described under the heading Violent Crime Reduction Programs, State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance" of the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State, the Judiciary, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1998; or (2) has not received a block grant under such program. <n>Limits: (1) a qualifying State, unit of local government, Indian tribe, or local educational agency to five percent of the total amount appropriated in each fiscal year for such grants; and (2) the portion of the costs of a program provided by such a grant"

Provides that the sentence imposed by a magistrate judge for any criminal contempt shall not exceed the penalties for a class C misdemeanor.Sets forth provisions regarding certification of other contempts to the district judge.Requires the magistrate judge, upon the commission of any act described in this section, to certify the facts to a district judge and to serve or cause to be served upon any person whose behavior is brought into question an order requiring such person to appear before a district judge upon a day certain to show cause why such person should not be adjudged in contempt by reason of the facts so certified.Requires the district judge to hear the evidence as to the act or conduct complained of and, if it is such as to warrant punishment, punish such person in the same manner and to the same extent as for a contempt committed before a district judge.Authorizes a magistrate judge to issue an order requiring any person accused of contempt to appear before the district court upon a day certain to show cause why such person should not be adjudged in contempt by reason of the facts so certified.

Harold Hughes- Bill Emerson Commission on Alcoholism Act - Establishes the Harold Hughes- Bill Emerson Commission on Alcoholism to: (1) hold public hearings on selected areas of interest related to alcoholism; (2) promote the development of a national consensus on policy issues related to alcoholism; (3) evaluate the interest of the provider and medical communities in new medications related to alcoholism and the barriers to the communities in obtaining such medications; (4) in conjunction with the National Institute on Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse and the advisory council of such Institute, conduct a study to identify the current state-of-the-art alcohol research, unmet alcohol research needs, and appropriate research funding in view of the size and scope of the alcoholism problem; (5) evaluate and make recommendations regarding the education of physicians in American medical schools concerning alcoholism and the certification of other individuals trained to provide alcoholism prevention and treatment services; (6) evaluate and make recommendations regarding the availability, timing, and dissemination of research information to alcoholism prevention and treatment services administrators and providers, and the application of current research findings by these administrators and providers; and (7) make recommendations designed to reduce and prevent alcoholism which include recommendations concerning appropriate roles for the Federal, State, and local governments and the private sector, and concerning specific changes needed to Federal laws and Federal programs. <n>Author

Taxpayer Choice Act of 2007 [sic] - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) repeal the alternative minimum tax for noncorporate taxpayers; and (2) allow taxpayers an election to elect a simplified individual income tax system in lieu of the existing tax systems.

Community Investment and Empowerment Act - Amends the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 to direct the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) to make competitive grants to economically underserved communities for: (1) the creation of a grant and/or revolving loan fund program that helps develop financing packages for Class 1 commercial investment; (2) lowering real estate property tax rates; (3) conducting community-wide market analysis to help recruit and/or retain Class 1 commercial investment; (4) creating employment training programs for Class 1 business customer service, sales, and managerial positions; (5) retail marketing strategies to solicit new Class 1 commercial investment starts in the community; (6) program allowances for activities such as the publication of marketing materials, development of economic development web pages, and educational outreach activities with retail trade associations; and (7) hiring business recruitment specialists. Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) eligibility requirements; and (2) matching funds and limitations.

Directs the Secretary of Commerce to: (1) assess the United States economy to determine what goods the United States currently produces, where such goods are produced, in which U.S. manufacturing sector the United States is most competitive in the global economy, and what policies are necessary to maintain or increase the competitiveness of U.S. manufacturing in the global economy; and (2) develop a comprehensive national manufacturing strategy. Sets forth the goals of such strategy, including to: (1) increase the aggregate number of manufacturing jobs in the United States; (2) identify emerging technologies to strengthen the competitiveness of the United States in the global marketplace; and (3) strengthen manufacturing sectors in which the United States is most competitive in the global economy. Requires the Secretary to: (1) establish targets for the growth of U.S manufacturing, including targets for job creation, for each of FY2012-FY2016; (2) conduct a survey of federal agencies that provide support to U.S manufacturers and report on such survey and to Congress on how such agencies can best support the comprehensive national manufacturing strategy required by this Act; (3) conduct a survey of all persons with headquarters in the United States that maintain manufacturing facilities outside of the United States to identify the categories of products manufactured at such facilities, the number of manufacturing jobs located at such facilities,

Local Farm Vehicle Flexibility Act - Amends the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act to prohibit the Secretary of Agriculture from terminating, reducing, limiting, or otherwise interfering with the amount or timing of grants that a state is otherwise eligible to receive as a result of any minimum standard or exemption provided by the state for a covered farm vehicle or the driver of such vehicle that is less stringent than the requirements for commercial motor vehicles and drivers established under federal regulations.

Economic Growth and Tax Relief Act of 2001 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code, as of tax year 2000, to reduce the 15 percent tax rate to 12 percent for: (1) joint filers with taxable income below $12,000; (2) heads of household with taxable income below $10,000; and (3) single or married persons filing separately with taxable income below $5,000. Provides an inflation adjustment to the initial bracket amount for taxable years beginning before January 1, 2007.

Choice in Health Options Insures Care for Everyone (CHOICE) Act of 2009 - Establishes the American Trust Health Plan, or the Plan, to provide for the offering to eligible individuals of health benefits coverage throughout the United States. Requires the Plan to comply with all requirements applicable to other health benefits plans to be offered through a National Health Insurance Exchange, including minimum benefit and cost-sharing requirements and premium rating requirements. Exempts health benefits plans offered through the Exchange from state insurance regulations.<n><n>Establishes within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) the Office of American Trust Health Administration, headed by an Administrator appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate.<n><n>Prohibits the Administrator and the Office from participating in the administration of any regulation regarding the health insurance market or in the administration of the Exchange.<n><n>Requires the Administrator to establish an Advisory Board, composed of seven individuals appointed by the President, to advise the Administrator regarding the operation of the Plan and the establishment of standards for benefits and cost-sharing and for premiums for such health benefits coverage.

Air Line Pension Act of 2003 - Sets forth funding requirements (including a moratorium on deficit reduction contributions) for defined benefit pension plans established and maintained by commercial passenger air carriers with funded percentages of less than 80 percent as of January 1, 2003.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 19, 2014. TRUE Safety Act (Sec. 1) This bill requires the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to assess the methodology used by the Department of Transportation (DOT) in carrying out the new commercial motor vehicle restart rule on December 27, 2013, as required by the Federal Motor Safety Administration (FMCSA). The assessment shall assess the extent to which the methodology meets the requirement of the rule of the applicable rule to develop the proposed applicable rule and service support used under the FMCSA's new commercial motor vehicle restart methodology. (Sec. 2) The GAO shall submit a final report to Congress on the conclusions of the operational study completed pursuant to this Act not later than six months after the date of enactment of this Act, including scientific conclusions not concurring with the conclusions of the operational study published in the Federal Register on December 27, 2011. The FMCSA's 34-hour restart rule issued on April 28, 2003, shall apply without force or effect until later than six months after this Act's enactment, if the GAO submits a final report to Congress not later than that date.

Motor Vehicle Safety Whistleblower Act - Amends federal transportation law to authorize the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) to pay an award or awards to one or more whistleblowers in an aggregate amount of up to 30% of collected monetary sanctions for voluntarily providing to the Secretary original information relating to any motor vehicle defect, noncompliance, or any violation or alleged violation of any notification or reporting requirement which is likely to cause unreasonable risk of death or serious physical injury. Defines a whistleblower" as any employee or contractor of a motor vehicle manufacturer, part supplier, or dealership who voluntarily provides to the Secretary original information relating to any motor vehicle defect, noncompliance, or any violation or alleged violation of any notification or reporting requirement which is likely to cause unreasonable risk of death or serious physical injury. Directs the Secretary, in determining an award, to take into consideration: (1) whether a whistleblower reported or attempted to report the information internally to an applicable motor vehicle manufacturer, part supplier, or dealership; (2) the significance of the original information provided by the whistleblower to the successful resolution of the covered action; (3) the degree of assistance provided by the whistleblower and any legal representative of the whistleblower in the covered action; and (4) such additional factors as the Secretary considers relevant. Prohibits an award from being made: (1)"

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Women's Autoimmune Diseases Research and Prevention Act - Requires the Director of the Department of Health and Human Services' Office on Women-Autoimmune Diseases to expand and coordinate the Office's research and related activities with respect to autoimmune diseases affecting women.

Redundant Remapping Reform Act of 2011 - Prohibits the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) from updating or publishing a National Flood Insurance Program rate map during a specified 48-month period with respect to: (1) a levee for which the Army Corps of Engineers has entered into a cost-sharing agreement, the 48-month period beginning on the date on which the Army Corps makes available any funds required to be made available by the Corps under the agreement, and (2) any levee for which a community or other party has sought recognition or which the Administrator has not issued a Letter of Final Determination. Defines a qualified levee" as one being constructed or modified if its owner enters into an agreement with the Administrator that construction or modification will be completed before the end of a covered period relating to the qualified levee.<n><n>Prohibits the Administrator, except in certain circumstances, from updating or publishing a map during such period with respect to an area protected by a qualified levee: (1) for which a community or other party has sought recognition, and (2) with respect to which the Administrator has not issued a Letter of Final Determination.<n><n>Requires the Administrator to publish a notice to be used by owners of qualified levees to disclose to persons affected by such levees: (1)"

Year of Freedom and Community Protection Act of 1995 - Prescribes conditions, in a case in which a league approves the relocation of a professional sports team from a community to another community, that: (1) the registered mark that identifies the team becomes only the property of the community; (2) the league reserve the registered mark and any portion of the registered mark for use only by the community; and (3) the registered mark may not be used by another professional sports team in the same community. <n>Requires that notice of a relocation be provided to: (1) the local government for the stadium or arena located in the community; (2) the owner or operator of the stadium or arena; and (3) each professional sports team that is a member of the league concerned. Specifies additional requirements. <n>Directs the league to grant to the investor an expansion fee of no greater than 85 percent of the capital required for the last expansion professional sports team franchise granted by the league. <n>Makes additional requirements of this Act effective when the league grants an expansion fee of no greater than 85 percent of the capital required for the last expansion professional sports team franchise to the owner or operator of the stadium or arena located in the community which the relocation is to occur. <n>Amends the Public Health Service Act to

Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2006 to provide special immigrant status for certain aliens, including translators and interpreters, who are serving with federal agencies in Iraq and Afghanistan. (Currently, such aliens are provided status as translators and interpreters for such purposes.) Makes aliens eligible for such status if they: (1) were paroled or admitted as nonimmigrants into the United States; and (2) are otherwise eligible for special immigrant status and refugee assistance under the Immigration and Nationality Act.

Cargo Theft Deterrence Act of 1997 - Amends the Federal criminal code to: (1) expand the definition of interstate or foreign shipment" to include air cargo containers and trailers; and (2) authorize the court, upon motion of the Attorney General, to reduce any penalty imposed with respect to any defendant who provides information leading to the arrest and conviction of any dealer or wholesaler of stolen goods or chattels moving as or which are a part of or which constitute an interstate or foreign shipment. Specifies that goods and chattel shall be construed to be moving as an interstate or foreign shipment at all points between the point of origin and the final destination, regardless of any temporary stop while awaiting transshipment or otherwise. Specifies that it shall be an affirmative defense (on which the defendant bears the burden of persuasion by a preponderance of the evidence) to an offense under this Act that the defendant bought, received, or possessed the goods, chattels, money, or baggage at issue with the sole intent to report the matter to an appropriate law enforcement officer or to the owner of the goods, chattels, money, or baggage. Directs the United States Sentencing Commission to amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to provide a sentencing enhancement of not less than two levels for any offense"

Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to: (1) develop procedures for the use and acceptance of electronic signatures by executive agencies; (2) ensure the implementation by executive agencies of procedures for the use and acceptance of electronic signatures; and (3) conduct an ongoing study of the use of electronic signatures under this Act.

Transparency in Energy Production Act of 2016 This bill requires the Department of the Interior to make available to the public through the Internet certain information regarding fossil fuel operations on federal lands, including: (1) the aggregate amount of each fossil fuel, by type and by state, produced under federal leases; (2) the portion and source of such amount that was released by each venting, flaring, and fugitive release; (3) the estimated amounts of existing fossil fuel resources on federal lands and lands that have potential for such leasing; and (4) the amount and sources of energy, in megawatts, produced from operating solar, wind, and geothermal projects on federal lands under lease for the production of renewable energy. Interior must initiate a process under the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982, the Mineral Leasing Act, or other applicable law to require accurate measuring and reporting to Interior by each holder of a lease for the production of fossil fuels on federal land of the actual amount of methane gas produced under such lease, including all such gas not sold by or on behalf of the lessee.

Authorizes the award of a single Congressional Gold Medal to collectively honor the American soldiers who were prisoners of war in Bataan, Philippines, and Corregidor, Philippines, during World War II, in recognition of their personal sacrifice and service to their country. Provides for the Medal's display at the Smithsonian Institution.
