Government Shutdown Accountability and Economic Report Act of 2017 This bill prohibits the payroll administrators of each house of Congress from paying compensation to Members of Congress on any day during a government shutdown. The payroll administrators must exclude from pay the product of: (1) one day's worth of pay under the annual rate of pay applicable to the Member of Congress under the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946, and (2) the number of 24-hour periods during which the government shutdown is in effect which occur during the pay period. If a government shutdown is in effect during the 115th Congress, the payroll administrator of each house must: (1) withhold from compensation for each Member of Congress an amount equal to the product of one day's worth of pay under the annual rate of pay applicable to the Member under that Act and the number of 24-hour periods during which the government shutdown is in effect which occur during the pay period, and (2) deposit in an escrow account all amounts withheld. The bill also requires the Congressional Budget Office, within 24 hours after each day on which a government shutdown is in effect, to submit a report to Congress containing information on: (1) an estimate of the economic output lost on that day as the result of the shutdown, (2) an estimate of any decrease in gross domestic product for the quarter that will

(Sec. 2) Allows any depository institution to permit: (1) the owner of any interest-bearing or dividend-earning account to make up to 24 transfers per month, for any purpose, to another account of the owner in the same institution; and (2) the owner of any deposit or account (negotiable order of withdrawal, or NOW, account) to make withdrawals by negotiable or transferable instruments for the purpose of making payments to third parties. Requires, with respect to an escrow account, a lender or servicer to pay interest only if such payments are required by: (1) a contract between the lender or servicer and the borrower; or (2) a specific statutory provision of the law in effect in the State in which the property which is secured by the loan is located requires the lender or servicer to make such payments.Repeals the prohibition under the Federal Reserve Act against interest payments on demand deposits.Amends the Federal Reserve Act, the Home Owners' Loan Act, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act to mandate that balances maintained at Federal reserve banks by or on behalf of a depository institution receive earnings to be paid by the Federal reserve bank at least once each calendar quarter at a rate not to exceed the rate earned on the securities portfolio of the Federal Reserve System during the preceding quarter.
Detention of Enemy Combatants Act - Requires the President, every six months, to report to Congress with respect to the detention of any U.S. citizen or lawful resident who is an enemy combatant.

. Marijuana Businesses Access to Banking Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill prohibits a federal banking regulator from: (1) terminating or limiting the deposit insurance or share insurance of a depository institution solely because it either provides or has provided financial services to a marijuana-related legitimate business; or (2) prohibiting, penalizing, or otherwise discouraging a depository institution from providing financial services to a marijuana-related legitimate business. It prohibits a federal banking regulator, in addition, from recommending, motivating, providing incentives, or encouraging a depository institution not to offer financial services to an individual, or to downgrade or cancel financial services offered to an individual, solely because the individual: is or later becomes a manufacturer, producer, owner or operator of a marijuana-related legitimate business; or the depository institution was not aware that the individual is the owner or operator of a marijuana-related legitimate business. The bill prohibits a federal banking regulator from taking any adverse or corrective supervisory action on a loan made to an owner or operator of: (1) a marijuana-related legitimate business solely because the owner or operator owns or operates it, or (2) real estate or equipment that is leased to a marijuana-related legitimate business solely because the owner or operator of the real estate or equipment leased the equipment or real estate to a marijuana-

Border Security and Elimination of Sanctuary for Illegal Aliens Act of 2007- Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to: (1) increase border patrol recruitment incentives by offering a ($40,000 maximum) repayment of higher education loans; and (2) develop border patrol retention incentives through the establishment of a retention program.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary to deploy newly-developed technologies to secure the U.S. international land and maritime borders.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) prioritize border fence construction; and (2) report to Congress regarding such construction's progress.<n><n>Requires that if an alien who is unlawfully present in the United States is arrested for any offense by a state or local law enforcement agency the head of such agency shall immediately notify United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) of the arrest and the alien's identity.<n><n>Requires that such an arrested alien be detained by ICE and presented before an immigration judge for expedited U.S removal without release from detention and without further hearing or review. Provides for criminal penalties and expedited removal for such a removed alien who subsequently returns unlawfully to the United States.<n><n>Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) to make inadmissible an alien who has been unlawfully present in the United States for any period of time and who is subsequently determined

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on September 6, 2017. Cyber Scholarship Opportunities Act of 2017 (Sec. 3) This bill amends the Cybersecurity Enhancement Act of 2014 to revise the National Science Foundation (NSF) CyberCorps: Scholarship-for-Service program. The bill expands the program to include students who are pursuing an associate's degree in a cybersecurity field without the intent of transferring to a bachelor's degree program and either have a bachelor's degree already or are veterans of the Armed Forces. Scholarship recipients shall include students who: have demonstrated a high level of competency in relevant knowledge, skills, and abilities, as described in the national cybersecurity awareness and education program; are full-time students or enrolled for study leading to a degree on a less than full-time basis but not less than half-time; and meet other specified requirements. The NSF shall evaluate and make public, in a manner that protects the personally identifiable information of scholarship recipients, information on the success of recruiting individuals for scholarships and on hiring and retaining those individuals in the public sector workforce. The NSF shall: work with the Office of Personnel Management to establish an online resource center for the CyberCorps community that consolidates or eliminates other relevant websites; present up-to-date

Campus Sexual Violence Elimination Act - Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to require each institution of higher education (IHE) participating in any title IV program (except foreign schools) to include in its annual security report a statement of policy regarding: (1) its programs to prevent domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking; and (2) the procedures it will follow once an incident of such violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking has been reported. Requires such policy to address the following areas: (1) education programs to promote the awareness of rape, acquaintance rape, domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking; and (2) ongoing prevention and awareness campaigns for students and faculty.

Safe Building Code Incentive Act of 2012 - Amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to authorize the President to increase the maximum total of contributions for a major disaster by an amount equal to 4% of the estimated aggregate amount of grants to be made under such Act if, at the time of a declaration of a major disaster, the affected state has in effect and is actively enforcing a state building code that satisfies specified conditions, including that it: (1) is consistent with the most recent version of a nationally recognized model building code; (2) has been adopted by the state within six years of the most recent version of such nationally recognized code; and (3) uses the nationally recognized code as a minimum standard.

Drug- Rape Prevention and Punishment Act of 1996 - Amends the Controlled Substances Act (CSA) to provide penalties for: (1) distributing a controlled substance with intent to commit a crime of violence against an individual; and (2) importing and exporting such controlled substances. <n>Directs the United States Sentencing Commission to: (1) review and amend its sentencing guidelines for offenses involving flunitrazepam (a cough suppressant) to ensure that the guidelines reflect the serious nature of such offenses; and (2) disseminate those guidelines to police departments throughout the United States. <n>Directs the Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration to study and report to the Congress on the appropriateness and rescheduling of flunitrazepam as a Schedule I controlled substance. <n>Authorizes the Attorney General to: (1) create educational materials regarding the use of controlled substances in the furtherance of rapes and sexual assaults; and (2) disseminate those materials to police departments throughout the United States.

Equal Employment Opportunity Commission Amendments of 1993 - Amends the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to grant the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) increased enforcement powers. <n>Requires any agency, department, or unit which fails to submit an employment opportunity plan to: (1) appear before the EEOC to explain the reasons for the failure; and (2) present any objections to any requirement of the plan. <n>Directs the EEOC, after investigation and consideration of the evidence submitted, to submit its findings and recommendations to the administrative head of the agency, department, or unit in which such officer or employee is employed and to send copies of the findings to such officer or employee. Requires the administrative head to take any action recommended by the EEOC. <n>Authorizes the EEOC, in enforcing compliance with such an order, to issue an order that: (1) any officer or employee of the agency, department, or unit charged with complying with the order shall be responsible for the failure of such agency, department, or unit to comply; or (2) any officer or employee of the United States determined to be responsible for the failure to comply shall not be entitled to receive payment for service as an officer or employee for the period during which the order has not been complied with. <n>Directs the EEOC

America Gives More Act of 2014 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the tax deduction for charitable contributions of food inventory, to: (1) make permanent the deduction allowed for such contributions; (2) increase the maximum amount of such deduction to 15% of a taxpayer's aggregate net income from all trades or businesses from which such contributions were made; (3) allow individual taxpayers a tax-free distribution from an individual retirement account (IRA) of amounts contributed to a tax-exempt organization; and (4) allow corporate taxpayers a tax deduction for contributions to a tax-exempt organization.

Southwest Forest Health and Wildfire Prevention Act of 2004 - Directs the Secretary of Agriculture, through the Chief of the Forest Service, to establish three Institutes (one each in Arizona at Northern Arizona University, New Mexico, and Colorado) to promote the use of adaptive ecosystem management to reduce the risk of wildfires, and improve the health of forest and woodland ecosystems in the interior West.

Distilled Spirits Tax Payment Simplification Act of 1997 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to modify or impose requirements regarding: (1) the transfer of distilled spirits between bonded premises and between importation and bonded premises; (2) operations as a bonded dealer conducted on the bonded premises of a distilled spirits plant; (3) establishment and operation of such a plant by a bonded dealer; (4) election to be treated as a bonded dealer; (5) the time at which the tax on distilled spirits is determined; (6) distilled spirits lost or destroyed in bond or returned to bonded premises; (7) the time for tax payment and payment by electronic transfer; and (8) application to a plant used by a bonded dealer of provisions relating to sales by proprietors of controlled premises.

Supporting America's Charities Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the tax deduction for charitable contributions, to: (1) make permanent the special rule for qualified conservation contributions; (2) allow a 15-year carryover of amounts received from Native Corporations which are contributions of property which was land conveyed under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act; (3) extend the deduction for charitable contributions of food away from home to all taxpayers, including C corporations and taxpayers without children; and (4) increase the limit on the amount of such deduction for charitable contributions of food away from home.

Securing Consumers' Assurance in Moving Act of 2003 - Amends Federal transportation law to authorize an individual or a State or political subdivision to enforce consumer protection provisions with respect to interstate household goods carriers. Requires the Secretary of Transportation to establish a working group of State attorneys general, State consumer protection officials, and State and local law enforcement officials to develop practices and procedures to enhance State enforcement efforts with respect to interstate transportation of household goods.

Servicemembers Educational Opportunity Act of 1999- Amends Federal basic educational assistance provisions (the Montgomery GI Bill) to authorize enhanced educational assistance to a member of the armed forces who, after September 30, 1999: (1) first enters on active duty; (2) reenlists or continues to serve on active duty; (3) serves a continuous period of active duty of at least four years; or (4) serves and is discharged or released for a period of not less than 42 months of such active duty, at the convenience of the Government. <n>Allows such member to meet the service requirement by having been granted credit for the equivalent of 12 semester hours in a program leading to a standard college degree before the end of the individual's period of active duty. <n>Allows an eligible individual to elect (in a form and manner prescribed by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs) to receive basic educational assistance in lieu of such enhanced educational assistance for an enrollment period. Requires such election to be made by not later than 30 days before the beginning of the enrollment period. Allows a revocation of an election made pursuant to the above requirements at any time before the beginning of the enrollment period. <n>Entitles each eligible individual to a monthly enhanced educational assistance allowance for a period or periods not to exceed a total of

Bipartisan Panel to Design Long-Range Social Security Reform Act of 1998 - Establishes the Bipartisan Panel to Design Long-Range Social Security Reform to design a single set of legislative and administrative recommendations for long-range reforms for: (1) restoring the solvency of the Social Security system; and (2) maintaining retirement income security in the United States.

Fairness in Immigration Litigation Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) to bar inadmissible arriving aliens from seeking judicial review of removal orders through habeas corpus, mandamus, or other extraordinary petitions.<n><n>Imposes a similar bar on denials of discretionary relief and orders against criminal aliens with an exception for petitions for review concerning constitutional claims or pure questions of law.<n><n>Establishes the INA's judicial review provisions as the sole avenue for challenging removal orders and reviewing claims arising under the United Nations Convention Against Torture and Other Forms of Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment or Punishment.

Metropolitan Medical Response System Program Act of 2009 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to conduct a Metropolitan Medical Response System Program to assist state and local governments in preparing for and responding to mass casualty incidents resulting from natural disasters, acts of terrorism, and other man-made disasters. Authorizes the Secretary, through the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), to make grants to assist in preparing for and responding to such incidents. Authorizes the use of such grants to support the integration of emergency management, health, and medical systems into a coordinated response to such incidents, including to strengthen: (1) medical surge capacity; (2) mass prophylaxis capabilities including development and maintenance of an initial pharmaceutical stockpile sufficient to protect first responders, their families, and immediate victims from a chemical or biological event; (3) chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear, and explosive detection, response, and decontamination capabilities; (4) mass triage and pre-hospital treatment plans and capabilities; (5) information sharing and collaboration capabilities of regional, state, and urban areas; (6) medical supplies management and distribution; (7) training and exercises; and (8) integration and coordination of the activities and capabilities of public health personnel and medical care providers with those of other emergency response providers as well as federal agencies, the private

Chacoan Outliers Protection Act of 1993 - Designates nine new outlying areas as Chaco Culture Archaeological Protection Sites associated with Chacoan Anasazi Indian culture in the San Juan Basin and surrounding areas of New Mexico and Colorado. Expands the boundaries and removes or reduces the acreage of certain existing Sites. Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to assist the Navajo Nation in the: (1) protection and management of such Sites located on lands of the Navajos through a grant, contract, or cooperative agreement entered into pursuant to the Indian Self-Determination and Education Act; and (2) planning, resource protection, interpretation, resource management actions, and such other purposes as may be identified in such grant, contract, or cooperative agreement.

Consumer Assurance of Radiologic Excellence Act of 2003 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish standards to assure the safety and accuracy of medical imaging or radiation therapy, including licensure or certification, accreditation, and other requirements determined by the Secretary to be appropriate. Exempts physicians, nurse practitioners, and physician assistants.Directs the Secretary to certify private nonprofit organizations or State agencies as approved bodies for the accreditation of educational programs or the administration of examinations. Requires the Secretary to establish minimum standards for such certification, including standards for recordkeeping, the approval of curricula and instructors, the charging of reasonable fees for accreditation or for undertaking examinations, and other additional additional requirements.

This bill directs the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to convey to the Tanana Tribal Council in Tanana, Alaska, all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to certain property (including all land, improvements, and appurtenances) containing 11.25 acres, in the village of Tanana for use in connection with health and social services programs. HHS shall convey to the Bristol Bay Area Health Corporation in Dillingham, Alaska, all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to certain property included in Dental Annex Subdivision, creating tract 1, containing 1.474 acres more or less. Neither the Tanana Tribal Council nor the Corporation shall be liable for soil, surface water, groundwater, or other contamination resulting from the disposal, release, or presence of environmental contamination, including oil or petroleum products, or hazardous substances on any of the properties.

Dental and Optometric Care Access Act or the DOC Access Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require a health plan or individual or health insurance coverage to provide: (1) payment amounts from covered persons for items and services furnished by a doctor of optometry, doctor of dental surgery, or doctor of dental medicine that has an agreement to participate in the plan or coverage and that furnishes items or services that are not covered by the plan or coverage; and (2) the negotiated rate for providers that participate in the provider network of such plan or coverage to be changed only pursuant to a subsequent agreement signed by the doctor that documents the acknowledgment and acceptance of the doctor. Prohibits the agreement from being for a period greater than two years.Prohibits the plan or coverage from: (1) denying a doctor participation because of the doctor's failure to accept terms and conditions under the agreement for ancillary services or procedures; or (2) requiring such a doctor to participate with, or be credentialed by, any specific plan or coverage offering limited scope dental or vision benefits as a condition to participate in the provider network. Allows a private right of action for violations of this Act.

Amends the Clean Air Act to require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), upon petition by a State governor, to waive any oxygen content requirement for that State.<n><n>Authorizes the Administrator to control or prohibit the use of any oxygenate (including methyl tertiary butyl ether) as a fuel, or fuel additive for fuel, for use in a motor vehicle, motor vehicle engine, or nonroad engine or nonroad vehicle if in the Administrator's judgment such oxygenate causes or contributes to contamination of drinking water which may reasonably be anticipated to endanger public health, welfare, or the environment in the United States.<n><n>Requires the Administrator, if the Administrator seeks to control or prohibit the use of any oxygenate, to take into account information as to whether such control or prohibition will affect the use of any other oxygenate in a manner which may reasonably be anticipated to endanger public health, welfare, or the environment in the United States.<n><n>Directs the Administrator to promulgate regulations to require that, for the calendar year beginning January 1, 2005, and for each calendar year thereafter, the annual volume of methyl tertiary butyl ether (MTBE) manufactured or introduced into commerce in the United States for use as a fuel, or fuel additive for fuel

Amends title XII (School Facilities Improvement) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to establish a program for public school repair and renovation. <n>Directs the Secretary of Education to award grants to local educational agencies (LEAs) with high percentages of students living on Indian lands, for repairs, renovations, or construction of new schools if the LEA will replace an existing school that is in such poor condition that renovating the school will not be cost-effective.

Federal Employees Health Benefits Access Act - Amends Federal civil service law to require any contract or plan approved under the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHBP) to offer health benefits to the general public throughout each term for which the contract or approval remains effective, the same benefits as would be offered under such contract or plan to Federal employees and annuitants and their family members. Declares that premiums for coverage under FEHBP shall be established in conformance with such requirements as the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) shall by regulation prescribe. Prohibits enactment of this Act from resulting in: (1) any increase in the level of individual or Government contributions required under FEHBP or any other provision of Federal law; (2) any decrease in the types of benefits offered under FEHBP; or (3) any other change that would adversely affect such coverage to Federal employees and annuitants and their family members. Requires benefits under FEHBP, with respect to an individual entitled to benefits under part A of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act, to be offered (for use in coordination with those Social Security benefits) to the same extent and in the same manner as if coverage were under the preceding provisions of Federal law. Allows a carrier to file

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to make permanent the exclusion from gross income for employer-provided educational assistance. Restores the exclusion for graduate education expenses. <n>Allows a deduction for interest paid on education loans. Limits such deduction based on modified adjusted gross income.

Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999 - Directs each Federal agency to develop and implement a plan that, among other things, streamlines and simplifies the application, administrative, and reporting procedures for Federal financial assistance programs administered by the agency. Requires each agency to report to specified congressional committees on the reasons for any noncompliance with such requirement. <n>Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to consult with specified congressional committees on plan development and implementation.

Repeals subtitles A (Repeal of Estate and Generation-Skipping Transfer Taxes) and E (Carryover Basis at Death; Other Changes Taking Effect With Repeal) of title V (Estate, Gift, and Generation-Skipping Transfer Tax Provisions) of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Makes the sunset provisions (sunset provisions) of such Act inapplicable to the remainder of title V.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) provide for an increase to $3.5 million of the estate tax exclusion ($3 million in the case of a decedent dying, and gifts made, after December 31, 2002) and for a phaseout of graduated estate tax rates and the unified credit against the estate tax; (2) set forth estate valuation rules for certain transfers of nonbusiness assets; and (3) limit estate tax discounts for certain individuals with minority interests in a business acquired from a decedent.

Energy Tax Rebate Act of 2005 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow individual taxpayers a rebate of up to $500 for energy taxes paid in 2005.<n><n>Expresses the sense of the Senate that Congress should appropriate full funding for the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program for FY 2006 and each subsequent fiscal year.<n><n>Prohibits the sale of crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates at a price that: (1) is unconscionably excessive; or (2) indicates the seller is taking unfair advantage of circumstances to increase prices unreasonably.

Earmark Transparency Act of 2010 - Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate to jointly establish a searchable website, available to the public at no cost, listing all requests by Members of Congress for congressionally directed spending items.

Insurance Disclosure Act of 1997 - Requires insurers to ensure that an individual's medical examination is provided at the time it is conducted and to make it available to the individual's own physician. <n>Amends the Public Health Service Act to provide for enforcement of this Act.

Deficit Reduction Check-Off Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow every individual to designate on his or her income tax return that an amount (not less than $1 and not more than $10) be paid over for the purpose of reducing the deficit of the United States. Requires the designation to be accompanied by a statement stating that the federal budget will be reduced by an amount equal to ten times the amount you elect in the box.<n><n>Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 (Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act) to require a sequestration of the deficit equivalent to the amount designated under this Act within 15 days after Congress adjourns for the year. Requires the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to: (1) calculate the total amount designated under this Act; (2) apply an across-the-board reduction in federal spending in an amount equal to the product of the designated amount and 10% of the preceding fiscal year's spending reduction; and (3) apply any amounts not calculated by the October 1st deadline to the following fiscal year federal spending reduction.

National Children's Island Act of 1995 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, in order to facilitate the construction, development, and operation of National Children's Island (the Island), to transfer by quitclaim deed all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to the Islands to the District of Columbia. Requires the District to pay unbudgeted actual costs incurred by the Secretary for such transfer. <n>Directs the Secretary to grant permanent easements across the waterways and bed of the Anacostia River to the District for the purpose of providing the necessary informational and safety requirements for vehicular and pedestrian egress and ingress to and from the Island, as well as for the construction, reconstruction, maintenance, operating, and otherwise providing the necessary informational and security for the Islands. <n>Requires the development of National Children's Island to proceed as specified in the legend on the plat or as otherwise authorized by the District by agreement, lease, resolution, appropriate executive action, or otherwise. <n>Requires the Secretary to transfer, and the District to revert, to the United States all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to the Islands after the date that one of the following has occurred: (1) failure to commence improvements for the recreational park within

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on December 10, 2013. Uphold Our Promise to Veterans Act - (Sec. 2) Repeals the provision of the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2013 that requires an annual adjustment in the retired pay and veteran pay amounts of members of the Armed Forces under age 62. (Sec. 3) Prohibits the U.S. government, including the Department of State, from providing assistance under the Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs Act, 2012 to the government of Egypt until the President certifies to Congress that democratic national elections have taken place in Egypt followed by a peaceful transfer of power. Suspends the provision of: (1) defense articles currently slated for transfer to Egyptian Ministry of Defense (MOD) and Ministry of Interior (MOI) until the President certifies to Congress that democratic national elections have taken place in Egypt followed by a peaceful transfer of power; and (2) defense services to Egyptian MOD and MOI until the President certifies to Congress that democratic national elections have taken place in Egypt followed by a peaceful transfer of power. Suspends the processing of draft Letters of Offer and Acceptance (LOAs) for future arms sales to Egyptian MOD and MOI entities until the President certifies to Congress that democratic

Winter Readiness Act of 2005 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax deduction in 2006 and 2007 for the cost of qualified oil and gas production property and repairs to such property on account of hurricane-related damage arising from any Presidentially declared disaster during 2005.

Farm Relief Act of 2008 - Amends the U.S. Troop Readiness, Veterans' Care, Katrina Recovery, and Iraq Accountability Appropriations Act, 2007 to make emergency financial assistance available to agricultural producers who incurred qualifying 2008 crop losses due to a natural disaster or any related condition.<n><n>Makes appropriations to the Secretary of Agriculture to make payments to sugar and sugarcane processors in Florida to compensate first processors and producers for losses due a natural disaster or any related condition, and to assist sugarcane growers in Texas for costs of demurrage, storage, and transportation resulting from natural disaster or any related condition during calendar year 2008.

Helping Enhance the Globe Commission Act - Establishes the Helping Enhance the People (HELP) Around the Globe Commission to: (1) identify the past and present objectives of United States development assistance; (2) identify cases in which such assistance has been most successful and analyze why such successes have not been transferable to other countries or areas; (3) study ways to expand educational opportunities and investments in people, and assess infrastructure needs; (4) because of the difficulty in measuring results in lesser developed countries, study whether additional resources should be dedicated in order to bring about tangible results; (5) analyze how the United States could place conditions on governments in countries receiving United States development assistance, in light of and notwithstanding the objectives of the Millennium Challenge Account; (6) analyze ways in which the United States can coordinate its development assistance programs with those of other donor countries and international organizations; (7) analyze ways in which the safety of development assistance workers can be ensured, particularly in the midst of conflicts; (8) compare the effectiveness of increased and open trade with development assistance, and analyze the advantages and disadvantages of such trade and whether such trade could be a more effective alternative to United States development assistance; (9) analyze ways in which the United States can strengthen the capacity of indigenous nongovernmental organizations to be more effective in grassroots development; (10) analyze how political pressures affect

Mine Safety and Health Act of 2006 - Amends the Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 to establish mandatory health and safety standards that apply to all coal or other mines: (1) strategically locate not less than one oxygen station within each area of an underground coal or other mine where miners are working; (2) make available to each miner a wireless emergency tracking device that will enable rescuers to locate the miner in the event of an accident or emergency; (3) require each miner working in an underground coal or other mine to carry a wireless text messaging or other wireless communications device that will enable rescuers or mine operators to communicate with the miner; and (4) require the operator of a coal or other mine to ensure that communications relating to the rescue are transmitted only to the individuals participating in the rescue operation. Requires an operator to provide secondary telephone service, or equivalent two-way communication facilities, between the surface and the underground mine at an entry separate from the location of existing telephone service or equivalent facilities, in order to increase the likelihood of maintaining communications between the miner and surface or rescue personnel in the event of an accident or emergency. (Sec. 3) Requires the Secretary of Labor to: (1) conduct interviews of the miners regarding an accident or other occurrence relating to health or safety in a coal or other mine without

Oil Subsidy Elimination Act of 2006 - Requires certain large integrated oil companies to: (1) increase the value of their LIFO inventories of crude oil, natural gas, or other petroleum products by a specified amount; and (2) decrease their cost of goods sold for such taxable year by the aggregate amount of such increases. Defines large integrated oil companies" as companies with average daily worldwide production of crude oil of at least 500,000 barrels and gross receipts in excess of $1 billion in a calendar year."

Grants to members of the Army, Navy, Air Force, or Marine Corps, or civilian employees of the Department of Defense (DOD), as well as to faculty members of certain military and DOD professional schools, limited authority to secure copyrights for certain scholarly works that are prepared as part of a person's official duties and that meet specified criteria for consideration for publication in a scholarly journal, publication, or other edited work for which such a copyright is a requirement for consideration.

Less Imprecision in Species Treatment Act of 2018 or the LIST Act of 2018 This bill amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to require the Department of the Interior to initiate the procedures to remove a species from a list of endangered or threatened species if: (1) the goals of a recovery plan for the species have been met; or (2) the goals for recovery of the species have not been developed and Interior determines that the species has recovered sufficiently to no longer require the protection of the Act. Interior shall remove a species from any list if the Department has produced or received substantial scientific or commercial information demonstrating that the species is recovered or that recovery goals set for the species have been met. " substantial scientific or commercial information" is any information demonstrating that the listing was determined on the basis of scientific or commercial information available to, or received or produced by, Interior that at the time the information was available to or received or produced by Interior it was: inaccurate beyond scientifically reasonable margins of error; fraudulent; or misrepresentative. Interior shall: (1) find whether the inclusion of a species in such a list was less than likely to have occurred in the absence of such scientific or commercial information, and (2) remove such species from such list and promptly publish notice of such finding in the Federal

National MS and Parkinson's Disease Registry Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, to establish and operate a multiple national surveillance system for multiple sclerosis (MS) and Parkinson's disease ( Parkinson's disease). Requires the Secretary, acting through the Director, to: (1) identify, build upon, expand, and coordinate existing data and surveillance systems, surveys, registries, and other federal public health and environmental infrastructure wherever possible; and (2) provide for research access to MS and Parkinson's disease data.

Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award such competitive grants to local educational agencies (LEAs) to establish master teacher programs that provide funding assistance and salary incentives to: (1) teachers to become board certified by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards; and (2) teachers who become board certified. Requires such grants to be distributed among school districts with the highest concentration of teachers who are not certified or licensed or are provisionally certified or licensed.

Patient Right to Know Act - Prohibits provisions of any contract or agreement between an entity operating a health plan and a health care provider (or group of health care providers) that restrict or restrict the provider from engaging in medical communications with his or her patient. Nullifies any such provision. States that nothing in this Act shall be construed to prohibit: (1) the enforcement, as part of a contract or agreement to which a health care provider is a party, of any mutually agreed upon terms and conditions, including terms and conditions requiring a health care provider to participate in, and cooperate with, all programs, policies, and procedures developed or operated by a health plan to assure, review, or improve the quality and effective utilization of health care services (if such utilization is according to guidelines or protocols based on clinical or scientific evidence and the professional judgment of the provider) but only if such guidelines or protocols do not prohibit or restrict medical communications between providers and their patients; or (2) a health care provider to misrepresent the scope of benefits covered under a health plan or to otherwise require the plan to reimburse providers for benefits not covered under the plan. Directs the Secretary of Labor to enforce this Act in States that have failed to substantially enforce it.

Urban Entrepreneurial Opportunities Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax deduction for the equity contributions made by a domestic corporation to an urban entrepreneurial opportunity financing subsidiary which makes enterprise zone business loans. Directs the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to allocate the program limitation among the qualified contributing corporations.

Makes a national of the United States eligible for advanced training in, or financial assistance as a member of, the Senior Reserve Officers' Training Corps if he will: (1) become a resident of a State before commencing such training; and (2) file an application for naturalization within 60 days after the later of the date that he meets naturalization requirements or the date that he is accepted into the training program.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on September 25, 2007. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Veterans' Housing Benefits Enhancement Act of 2007 - Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to furnish improvements and structural alterations for a total disability incurred or aggravated during active-duty service by a member of the Armed Forces who is hospitalized or receiving outpatient medical care, services, or treatment for such disability if the Secretary determines that such member is likely to be discharged or released from the Armed Forces for such disability. (Sec. 2) Directs the Secretary to report to the congressional veterans committees on an assessment of the adequacy of the authorities available to the Secretary to assist disabled veterans in acquiring: (1) suitable housing units with special fixtures or movable facilities required for their disabilities; (2) such adaptations to their residences as are reasonably necessary because of their disabilities; or (3) residences already adapted with special features determined by the Secretary to be reasonably necessary as a result of their disabilities. (Sec. 5) Makes veterans and members of the Armed Forces with severe burn injuries eligible for Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) housing assistance. (Sec. 6) Permits a family member of a veteran who is hospitalized or receiving outpatient medical care, services, or treatment for a service-connected disability

Amends Federal veterans' benefits provisions to extend through December 31, 1998, the authority of the Department of Veterans Affairs to provide sexual trauma counseling to veterans. Repeals a provision of the Veterans Health Care Act of 1992 which limits the period of receipt of such counseling to one year after discharge from active duty. Provides for increased priority of care for those veterans eligible for such counseling. Requires information on counseling to be provided through the Department's telephone system. Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to report to the Congress on the operation of such system.

Safety and Fuel Economy (SAFE) Act - Amends Federal transportation law to direct the Secretary of Transportation to issue a notice of proposed rulemaking to prescribe a new Federal motor vehicle safety standard that includes a Crash Aggressivity index (CRAGG index) that: (1) measures the aggressivity of a motor vehicle; (2) takes into account the stiffness, structure height, and mass of a vehicle; and (3) substantially improves the present crash safety of automobiles and light trucks by reducing the aggressivity.Directs the Secretary to: (1) complete a rulemaking to prescribe such a standard by issuing a final rule by June 1, 2003; (2) issue an advanced notice of proposed rulemaking to determine if substantial improvement has been made in the crash safety of automobiles and light trucks that are subject to the standard; and (3) post on the Department of Transportation's Internet website, beginning September 1, 2005, comparative CRAGG index ratings by make and model, and an identification of the ten motor vehicles with the greatest aggressivity.Requires the Secretary to annually report to Congress on the progress made in improving the crash safety of automobiles and light trucks in collisions.Directs the Secretary to issue regulations that require motor vehicle manufacturers to: (1) report CRAGG index ratings for each model year after model year; (2)

Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals Reorganization Act of 1999 - Divides the current U.S. Court of Appeals for the ninth circuit into the following two circuits: (1) the ninth circuit composed of Arizona, California, and Nevada, consisting of 20 judges, and holding regular sessions in San Francisco and Los Angeles; and (2) the twelfth circuit, composed of Alaska, Guam, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Northern Mariana Islands, Oregon, and Washington, consisting of eight judges, and holding regular sessions in Portland and Seattle. <n>Assigns circuit judges of the former ninth circuit to either of the two new circuits based upon their official station, with senior judges permitted election of assignment.

Gulf Coast College Revitalization Act - Expresses the sense of Congress that this Act is a first step toward revitalizing and restoring the economic, social, and cultural prosperity of the entire Gulf Coast region.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of Education to award five-year grants to institutions of higher education (IHEs) adversely affected by a Gulf hurricane disaster to assist them in recruiting and retaining students and retaining faculty.<n><n>Requires not less than 50% of grant funds to be used for need-based aid to students attending the affected IHE for academic year 2005-2006, and each of the four succeeding academic years, for purposes of attracting new and returning students to enroll in such IHE.<n><n>Requires not more than 5% of grant funds to be used for incentives for faculty at the affected IHE to remain in the Gulf Coast region or, if the IHE is unable to continue to employ such faculty, at another affected IHE.<n><n>Requires prevailing wages to be paid to students or faculty in whole or in part with grant funds received for employment as laborers, mechanics, or service employees for purposes of rebuilding an affected IHE's facilities.

Home Energy Conservation Act of 2010 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish a national limit on the amount of home energy conservation bonds that may be designated by any issuer. Imposes certain limitations on the amount of such bonds.

Federal Wetlands Jurisdiction Act of 2005 - Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (FWPCA) to clarify that waters of the United States, including the territorial seas, are subject to the jurisdiction of the permitting program for the discharge of dredged or fill material if such waters are: (1) navigable; (2) connected to navigable waters through a continuous, naturally occurring surface water connection; or (3) wetlands adjacent to such navigable or connected waters. Declares that waters are considered connected to navigable waters for purposes of this Act if connected by perennial or intermittent streams that contribute flow to navigable waters. Excludes from the definition those waters connected by: (1) sheet flow; (2) ephemeral waters, ground water, manmade ditches, or pipelines; or (3) a municipal separate storm sewer system or any other regulated point source. States that connecting waters shall not be subject to the jurisdiction of the permitting program. Provides that fastlands (areas located behind legally constituted manmade structures) shall not be subject to the jurisdiction of the permitting program. Authorizes a person who holds an ownership interest in property, or who has written authorization from such person, to submit to the Secretary of the Army a request identifying such property and requesting that the Secretary determine the presence or absence of U.S. waters subject to the jurisdiction of the

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on July 1, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) West Nile Virus and Aviral Disease Act - (Sec. 2) Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to make grants to States for the prevention and control of West Nile Virus and related aviral diseases. Encourages States that receive grants to work with local health entities to develop prevention and control programs. Allows the Secretary to give preference to States that: (1) have an incidence or prevalence of West Nile Virus or related aviral diseases, or a population of infected mosquitoes that is substantial relative to other States; or (2) have an increased risk of West Nile Virus or related aviral diseases. Requires funds to be used for: (1) the development, implementation, and evaluation by States and localities of community-based, comprehensive mosquito control plans; and (2) the development and implementation of programs on medical entomology, avirology, and other vector-borne diseases that would support longer term prevention and control efforts, including training to assist in developing a competent workforce to direct and manage local mosquito and vector-borne disease control programs.

. Consumer Review Freedom Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill prohibits a provision of a form contract from being void from the inception if it: (1) prohibits or restricts an individual who is a party to the contract from engaging in a written, oral, or pictorial review, performance assessment, or other similar analysis of, including by electronic means, the goods, services, or conduct of a person with respect to which such person is also a party (covered communication); (2) imposes a penalty or fee against such an individual for engaging in such a communication; or (3) transfers or requires such an individual to transfer to any person any intellectual property rights in review or feedback content, with the exception of a non-exclusive license to use the content, that the individual may have in any otherwise lawful covered communication about such person or the goods or services provided by such person. A violation of such prohibition shall be treated as an unfair or deceptive act or practice under the Federal Trade Commission Act.

Nurturing And Supporting Healthy Babies Act or the NAS Healthy Babies Act This bill requires the Government Accountability Office to report on neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS), including information on: the prevalence of NAS; the services for which coverage is available under state Medicaid programs for treatment of infants with NAS; settings for such treatment; the prevalence of utilization of various care settings under state Medicaid programs for such treatment; and best practices for treating infants with NAS. The bill amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to exclude abuse-deterrent formulations of prescription drugs from the requirement that manufacturers of single-source or innovator drugs pay additional rebates to states. Under current law, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services must use predictive modeling and other analytics technologies to identify and prevent waste, fraud, and abuse with respect to the Medicare, Medicaid, and Children's Health Insurance Programs. The bill prohibits a state agency from using or disclosing such technologies except for purposes of administering a state plan under Medicaid or the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP).

Captain James A. Lovell Federal Health Care Center Act of 2008 - Authorizes the Secretary of Defense to transfer, without reimbursement, to the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) the Navy ambulatory care center located in Great Lakes, Illinois, parking structure, and supporting facilities, and related medical personal property and equipment under a resource-sharing agreement between the Secretaries of Defense and Veterans Affairs. Designates such facility and supporting facilities as the Captain James A. Lovell Federal Health Care Center." Requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, if any of the real and related personal property transferred is subsequently used for purposes other than the purposes specified in the resource-sharing agreement or otherwise determined by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to be excess to the VA\\'s needs, to offer to transfer such property to the Secretary of Defense. Requires the transfer to be completed within one year after the acceptance of such offer.<n><n>Authorizes the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to transfer to the VA functions necessary for the effective operation of the Center."

Main Street Survival Act - Expresses the sense of Congress that the President, acting through the Secretary of the Treasury, should encourage financial institutions that have received federal financial support to maintain historic levels of lending to small and medium-sized businesses. Directs the Secretary to establish the Main Street Revolving Loan Fund Program to provide temporary loans to businesses that have less than 1,000 full-time equivalent employees, meeting specified eligibility criteria.

FCC Modernization Act of 1996 (sic)- Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to prepare a plan to: (1) adjust the allocation of agency personnel to reflect open-entry and pro-competitive policies; (2) propose the automation or privatization of routine agency functions, including the use of advisory committees for coordinating frequency assignments and automating frequency assignment databases; (3) propose the termination of agency functions that are no longer necessary to the protection of the public interest; (4) reduce the levels of agency's expenses for management and overhead; and (5) prepare the agency for rapid response to changes in technologies and markets. <n>(Sec. 3) Authorizes the FCC, when necessary to the prompt and orderly conduct of its business, to delegate to advisory coordinating committees its authority to grant licenses and permits for stations in the private mobile services to certain advisory coordinating committees. <n>(Sec. 4) Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to authorize the FCC to require the filing by any carrier of any contract, agreement, or arrangement with the FCC. Delays the effective date of such authority to six months after enactment of this Act. <n>(Sec. 5) Repeals requirements that the FCC develop and publish in the Federal Register a plan for the control of interlocking directorates (currently, only the

Dairy Promotion Equity Act - Amends the Dairy Production Stabilization Act of 1983 to increase the minimum membership of, and include dairy products importers on, the National Dairy Promotion and Research Board.Requires dairy product importers to pay an assessment to the Board.Prescribes guidelines under which the Secretary of Agriculture shall conduct a referendum in connection with this Act.

National Park Service Entrepreneurial Management Reform Act of 1994 - Amends the Land and Water Conservation Act of 1965 to increase the admission fees for National Park System areas. <n>Requires receipts from such fees to be made available for authorized resource protection, rehabilitation, and conservation projects, including projects to be carried out by the Public Land Corps or any other conservation corps pursuant to the Youth Conservation Corps Act of 1970. <n>Increases the annual permit fee for the National Park System to $15 and requires that any amount by which such fee exceeds $15 be credited to the appropriation account of the unit of the National Park System that collected the fee, which shall be available to the unit without further appropriation. <n>Requires the Secretary of the Interior to establish a pilot project at Yosemite National Park that utilizes incentives, including waiving or reducing admission fees, to encourage use of public transit which serves the purpose of reducing vehicular traffic within Yosemite National Park. <n>Prohibits the issuance of free permits to any person, except as otherwise provided by this Act. <n>Requires the fee for a single-visit permit at any designated area to be not more than $6 per person for persons entering by any means, except that the fee shall not exceed $20 for all persons entering a designated area in a single noncommercial vehicle

Balanced Trade Act of 2006 - Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to require the President, whenever there is a U.S. current account deficit that exceeds 2% of the gross domestic product (GDP), to: (1) determine that fundamental international payments problems do exist that require special import measures to imports; and (2) proclaim a temporary import surcharge in the form of duties on articles imported into the United States. Sets forth a minimum amount and maximum amount of such surcharge.

Iran Intelligence Oversight Act - Requires the Director of National Intelligence (DNI) to submit to Congress an updated National Intelligence Estimate on Iran. Requires the Estimate to address: (1) the foreign policy and regime objectives of Iran; (2) the current status of Iran's nuclear programs; (3) the military and defense capabilities of Iran; (4) the relationship of Iran with terrorist organizations; (5) the prospects for support from the international community for various potential courses of action with respect to Iran; (6) the anticipated reaction of Iran to such courses; (7) the level of popular and elite support within Iran for the Iran regime, and for its civil nuclear program, nuclear weapons ambitions, and other policies, and the prospects for reform and political change within Iran; and (8) the views among the populace and populace of Iran regarding the United States and Iran with respect to other key countries involved in nuclear diplomacy with Iran, the likely effects and consequences of any military action against the nuclear programs or other regime interests of Iran, and the confidence level of key judgments in the Estimate. Directs the President to report to Congress on: (1) the objectives of U.S. policy on Iran; and (2) the process for vetting and clearing statements of Administration officials that are drawn from or rely upon intelligence.

American Dream Tax Fairness Equity Act of 1997- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) reduce the maximum capital gains rate for individuals to 15 percent with respect to assets held for more than three years; and (2) replace the estate and gift tax rate schedules with a 15 and 28 percent rate.

National Invasive Species Council Act - Prohibits any federal agency from authorizing, funding, or carrying out any action that would likely cause or promote the introduction or spread of an invasive species in the United States or any other location unless the head of the federal agency, at his or her sole discretion and pursuant to guidelines developed under this Act, determines that: (1) the benefits of the action clearly outweigh the potential harm to the environment, economy, or human health caused by the introduction or spread of the invasive species; and (2) all feasible and prudent measures to minimize risk of harm to the environment, economy, or human health will be taken in carrying out the actions. Establishes as an independent entity within the executive branch the National Invasive Species Council to provide leadership and coordination among federal agencies and between the federal government and state and local governments regarding effort to minimize the economic, ecological, and human health impacts that invasive species cause and reduce the threat of further invasions.

Establishes the Commission on Financial Accounting for Intangibles to: (1) consider the general usefulness of financial statements prepared under generally accepted accounting principles in light of recent trends in the securities markets; (2) consider the impact that shortcomings in generally accepted accounting principles have on securities market volatility, capital allocation, and the investment of retirement fund assets, both individual and institutional; (3) consider methods to better identify, value, and account for purchased and internally generated intangible assets; (4) examine the general questions surrounding the role of intangible assets in financial reporting in the economy; and (5) consider the economic impact that would result if the pooling of interests method of accounting for business combinations were eliminated.

Immigration Backlog Reduction Act of 2011 - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to revise the expedited removal provisions to: (1) apply such provisions to an alien who has not been admitted or paroled into the United States and has not been physically present in the United States continuously for the four-year period immediately prior to the date of determination of inadmissibility; and (2) expand the expedited removal provisions to include an alien who has been convicted of a criminal offense and who was not lawfully admitted for permanent residence or had permanent resident status on a conditional basis.

Mortgage E-Verify Act of 2010 - Amends the Federal National Mortgage Association Charter Act, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation Act, and the National Housing Act to prohibit the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) from refinancing, restructuring, or modifying any single-family housing mortgage held by or that backs any security issued by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, or purchasing or issuing any security backed by any single-family housing mortgage made for such refinancing, restructuring, or modification, unless the mortgagor's identity and work eligibility has been confirmed by an inquiry made through the E-Verify program under the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996.

United States Life-Saving Service Heritage Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, through the National Maritime Initiative of the National Park Service, to establish a program to inventory, evaluate, document, and assist efforts to restore and preserve surviving United States Life-Saving Service stations.Requires the Secretary to: (1) serve as a clearinghouse of information for persons interested in restoring and preserving historic lifesaving and lifeboat stations, their boats, and related lifesaving equipment; and (2) make information regarding the Service, Revenue Service, and predecessor private and State lifesaving organizations that provided humanitarian assistance to mariners and their passengers, including information on historic lifesaving stations, historic lifesaving boats, and other significant lifesaving artifacts.Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to coordinate and assist in the restoration and preservation of such stations and to employ such individuals and organizations.

swine waste infrastructure and environment Act or the SWINE Act This bill requires the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to establish a program to certify environmentally sustainable swine waste disposal technologies. The bill defines swine waste disposal technologies" as technologies that manage animal waste in a manner that: (1) eliminates nutrient and heavy metal pathogens from swine waste; (2) substantially eliminates the release of disease transmitting vectors and airborne pathogens from swine waste; (3) substantially eliminates soil and groundwater contamination from swine waste; and (4) is cost-effective and produces significant environmental and public health benefits. USDA must establish standards that require swine waste disposal technologies to meet or exceed certain minimum standards for environmental protection. USDA must also establish a grant program to provide technical assistance to nonfederal entities for developing and implementing swine waste disposal technologies."

Cure for AIDS Act of 2012 - Expresses the sense of Congress in support of finding a cure for HIV/AIDS. Directs the Secretary of Defense, acting through the Congressionally Directed Medical Research Program, to establish and support an accelerated research program dedicated to the discovery of a cure for HIV/AIDS.

Acid Deposition and Ozone Control Act of 1997 - Amends the Clean Air Act to direct the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to add any State to the single ozone transport region that contributed or more to ozone aerial transport to the ozone level any noncompliant area of the single ozone transport region for any one of the second through the worst days that occurred during the previous ten years. <n>Directs the Administrator to promulgate regulations requiring reductions in the emissions of nitrogen oxide and sulfur dioxide to a specified level by the year 2003. Applies such regulations to the single ozone transport region as if the Administrator had adopted them before enactment of this Act. <n>Authorizes the Administrator to establish an allowance of nitrogen oxide or sulfur dioxide to be transferred to a noncompliant State under specified circumstances. <n>Requires the Administrator to promulgate regulations requiring reductions in the emissions of nitrogen oxide and sulfur dioxide to a specified level by the year 2003.

Readjustment Counseling Service Amendments of 1993 - Includes a Readjustment Counseling Service (RCS) as part of the Veterans Health Administration of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Prohibits the Secretary of Veterans Affairs from altering or revising the organizational structure of RCS until the Secretary has notified specified congressional committees and 60 days have elapsed since such notification. Requires RCS budget information to be included annually in the President's budget submitted to the Congress. <n>Outlines eligibility requirements for one of the Assistant Under Secretaries for Health in the Department, including at least three years of clinical experience and two years of administrative experience in RCS or other comparable mental health care counseling service. Makes such a qualified person the director of RCS. <n>Increases from one to two the authorized number of Assistant Under Secretaries for Health. <n>Authorizes the Secretary, upon request of a veteran, to furnish readjustment counseling to assist such veteran in readjusting to civilian life. Requires such counseling to include a general mental and psychological assessment to ascertain whether such veteran has mental or psychological problems associated with readjustment to civilian life. <n>Authorizes the Secretary to provide counseling services to the surviving parents, spouse, and children of any member of the armed forces who dies while serving on active duty or from a condition incurred

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 9, 2013.uity Safety and Security Under Reasonable Enforcement Act of 2013 or theASSURE Act of 2013 - Amends the Truth in Lending Act to direct the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to issue regulations requiring any payment to a benefit recipient, whether or not such payment is an extension of credit, that diminishes the recipient's ability to control the payments from his or her federal or military pension in any way, to be treated as an extension of credit for purposes of required disclosures under such Act. Prohibits a creditor from imposing an annual percentage rate (APR) greater than the federal funds rate plus 6% if such payment is not an extension of consumer credit. Directs the CFPB to issue regulations requiring that the aggregate amount of cash and property paid in exchange for such payment may not exceed a maximum APR equivalent to that imposed by this Act. Allows a benefit recipient to bring a private right of action against a pension assignee in federal or state court and recover three times the damages suffered due to the assignment of pension benefits, court costs, and reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses. Prohibits a member of the armed forces who is entitled to retired pay and enters into an agreement with another person

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on October 16, 2013. (Sec. 1) This bill repeals the requirement under the Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge Act of 2012 (STOCK Act) that the Secretary of the Senate, the Sergeant at Arms of the Senate, and the Clerk of the House of Representatives ensure that financial disclosure forms filed by Members of Congress and candidates for Congress, as well as notices of extensions, amendments, and blind trusts, are made available to the public through databases maintained on the official websites of the House and Senate. The President, Vice President, Members of Congress, candidates for Congress, and any officer occupying a position listed under Level I and Level II of the Executive Schedule having been nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate are exempt from such requirement. The requirement that such financial disclosure forms be made available to the public through databases maintained on the official website of the Office of Government Ethics (OGE) is extended through January 1, 2014. Such databases shall provide public access to: (1) financial disclosure reports filed by Members of Congress and candidates for Congress, (2) reports filed by Members of Congress and candidates for Congress of a transaction disclosure required by the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, and (3) notices of extensions, amendments, and blind trusts,

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to revise the tax deduction for depreciation of heating, ventilation, air conditioning, or commercial refrigeration equipment that is installed in nonresidential real property and residential rental property to: (1) establish a 20-year recovery period for such equipment; and (2) establish a 25-year recovery period for such equipment.

Local Government Landfill Compliance Deadline Act - Provides that, during the one-year period beginning on October 9, 1993, each municipal solid waste landfill that is in existence on October 8, 1993, and that meets specified requirements of the Solid Waste Disposal Act as in effect on January 1, 1993, shall not be required to meet any revised criteria that take effect after such date. <n>Authorizes the owner or operator of such a landfill to submit an application to the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or an appropriate State official for a 180-day extension of such exemption if the Administrator determines that the owner or operator cannot achieve compliance with the revised criteria by the end of such period because of one or more factors beyond his or her control, including: (1) litigation; (2) adverse weather conditions that slow or bring to a temporary halt the construction of a landfill; (3) a breakdown in negotiations for the construction or use of a regional landfill that requires any local government participating in the negotiations to pursue other arrangements for waste disposal; or (4) any delay in siting, permitting, or patenting a landfill or transfer station, including any delay attributable to the unavailability of, or inaccessibility to, technical assistance or procedures for purchasing, leasing, permitting, or patenting a site on Federal land. <n>Prohibit

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 3, 2014. Financial Institution Customer Protection Act of 2014 - (Sec. 2) Prohibits a federal banking agency (or the National Credit Union Administration [NCUA] in the case of an insured credit union) from suggesting, requesting, or ordering a depository institution to terminate a specific customer account, or otherwise restrict or discourage it from entering into or maintaining a banking relationship with a specific customer, unless: (1) the agency has a material reason to do so, and (2) the reason is not based solely on reputation risk. Directs each federal banking agency, within 60 days after enactment of this Act, to issue regulations defining the term "reputation risk." Requires the appropriate federal banking agencies also to accompany any such suggestion, request, or order with a justification for why it is needed, including any specific laws or regulations the agency believes are being violated by the customer. Prohibits this Act from being construed as requiring a depository institution or a federal banking agency to inform a customer of the justification for the customer's account termination. Requires each appropriate federal banking agency to issue an annual report to Congress stating: (1) the aggregate number of specific customer accounts that the agency suggested

Wildlife and Hunting Heritage Conservation Council Advisory Committee Act - Amends the Fish and Wildlife Coordination Act to establish the Wildlife and Hunting Heritage Conservation Council Advisory Committee to advise the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture on wildlife and habitat conservation, hunting, and recreational shooting.

Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to prohibit the admission of an alien who is convicted of an aggravated felony or who is convicted under any law of purchasing, selling, offering for sale, exchanging, using, owning, possessing, or carrying, or attempting or conspiring to purchase, sell, offer for sale, exchange, use, own, possess, or carry, any weapon, part, or accessory which is a firearm or destructive device in violation of any law.<n><n>Prohibits the waiver of such prohibition if the alien subsequent to such conviction has been granted a full and unconditional pardon by the President of the United States or by the Governor of any of the several States.<n><n>Prohibits the waiver of such prohibition if an alien: (1) is present in the United States after the expiration of the period of stay authorized by the Attorney General or is present in the United States without being admitted or paroled if either such alien has been convicted of an aggravated felony committed in the United States or has not resided continuously in the United States for at least seven years immediately preceding the date of initiation of proceedings to remove such alien from the United States; or (2) has sought to procure or has procured a visa, other documentation, or admission into the United States or other benefit provided

Amends the Federal Reserve Act to: (1) revise the guidelines under which the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System (the Board) calls subscription to stock of Federal reserve banks; and (2) authorize a member bank with total consolidated assets of $10 billion or less to elect to pay one-half of the subscription in lieu of the currently required one-half.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary has been expanded because action occurred on the measure.) Amends the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 to: (1) replace provisions establishing the Office of Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons within the Department of State with provisions establishing the Bureau to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons within the Department of State; and (2) repeal provisions terminating the Office of Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons.

Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve Boundary Adjustment Act of 2004 - Amends the National Parks and Recreation Act of 1978 to: (1) adjust the boundary of the Barataria Preserve Unit of the Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve in Louisiana by increasing the acreage limitation; and (2) authorize the Secretary of the Interior (the Secretary) to acquire any such additional land, water, and interests in land and water by donation, purchase with donated or appropriated funds, transfer from any other Federal agency, or exchange.<n><n>Requires, with respect to the areas identified as Bayou aux Carpes Addition" and "CIT Tract Addition," that: (1) any Federal land acquired in such areas be transferred without consideration to the administrative jurisdiction of the National Park Service; and (2) any private land in such areas be acquired by the Secretary only with the owner\\'s consent. Requires any Federal land in the area identified as the CIT Tract Addition that is transferred to be subject to any easements that have been agreed to by the Secretary and the Secretary of the Army.<n><n>Modifies and/or eliminates certain provisions related to the acquisition of property within the Unit.<n><n>Requires the Secretary, with respect to the land, water, and interests in land and water of the Unit, to"

Child Support Assurance Act of 1994 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make grants to up to six States to conduct demonstration projects to establish or improve a system of assured minimum child support payments. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Motor Vehicle Owners Right to Repair Act of 2010 - Requires the manufacturer of a motor vehicle sold, leased, or otherwise introduced into commerce in the United States to provide to the owner of the motor vehicle and the service provider of the motor vehicle, using reasonable business means and on a non-discriminatory basis, all information to diagnose, service, maintain, or repair the motor vehicle, including all safety alerts, recalls, service bulletins, and the adjustments needed to maintain the efficiency, safety, and convenience of the vehicle. Requires such information to include: (1) information about all safety alerts, recalls, service bulletins, and the adjustments needed to maintain the efficiency, safety, and convenience of the vehicle; and (2) all information of any kind provided directly, indirectly, or wirelessly to new car dealers or any repair facility to diagnose, service, maintain, repair, activate, certify, or install any motor vehicle equipment.

Collaborating for Economic Reintegration of Troops Act or the CERT Act This bill establishes the Commission on Veteran Certification Standards, which shall: (1) identify where there are gaps between military training and civilian credentials' training requirements; and (2) identify opportunities for military training to be reformed to address such gaps and for transition to be improved by increased recognition of military training as equivalent through a Blue Star certification.
