Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to use amounts from the Reclamation Rural Water Construction Fund to complete construction of rural water projects: (1) authorized to be carried out by the Secretary on or before this Act's enactment date; or (2) for which the Secretary has completed a feasibility report by September 30, 2012, that recommends the construction of a rural water project and an Act of Congress after this Act's enactment has authorized the construction of such project. Prohibits the Secretary from using amounts from the Fund to pay for any operation and maintenance costs of an authorized rural water project until the Secretary develops programmatic goals that: (1) would enable the completion of construction of the authorized rural water projects as expeditiously as possible; and (2) reflect the goals and priorities identified in the laws authorizing such projects and the goals of the Reclamation Rural Water Supply Act of 2006.

Federal-Utah State Trust Lands Consolidation Act - (Sec. 3) Establishes that the State of Utah, the Department of the Interior, and the Department of Agriculture have agreed to exchange certain Federal lands in the State of Utah for certain Utah State lands of approximately equal value. Ratifies, confirms, and incorporates all provisions set forth in the Agreement for Exchange of Lands 2002 Federal-Utah State Trust Lands Consolidation."(Sec. 4) Directs that all conveyances in the Agreement shall be completed within 70 days after enactment of this Act. Declares that, in the approximately 4,000 acres of Federal lands being conveyed, the United States will retain the coal estate and the right to develop such estate.Directs the Secretary of the Interior to identify Federal lands being conveyed that contain wildlife species, or habitat of wildlife species, that are listed as threatened or endangered or as candidates for either classification under the Endangered Species Act of 1973."

Iran Nuclear Nonproliferation Act - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) full diplomatic, political, and economic relations between the United States and Iran cannot be normalized unless and until the government of Iran suffers from the absence of constitutional and statutory authorization for any diplomatic dialogue to prevent weaponization of Iran or for any covert military action to prevent such weaponization; (2) no congressional authorization for use of military force against Iran constitutes either or an authorization for preemptive war against Iran in accordance with international law and statutory requirements for congressional authorization; and (3) only an authorization for military use of force in accordance with such international law and statutory requirements for congressional authorization may be used to cause or prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon.

Radiation Experimentation Compensation Act of 1994 - Declares that it is the purpose of this Act to establish a procedure to make partial restitution to the individuals used in certain Federal radiation experiments for the burdens they have borne for the Nation as a whole, although monetary compensation can never fully compensate them. Declares that the Congress apologizes on behalf of the Nation to such individuals and their families for the hardships they have endured because of the experiments. Establishes the Radiation Experimentation Compensation Trust Fund in the Treasury. Authorizes appropriations. Declares that any individual who, without the individual's informed consent, was intentionally exposed to radiation as a subject in an experiment of the Federal Government between January 1, 1940, and December 31, 1974, shall receive $50,000 if a claim for such payment is filed with the Attorney General by or on behalf of such individual and the Attorney General determines that the claim meets specified requirements.

Equal Opportunity for Residential Representation Act This bill requires the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to make grants through the Office of Community Planning and Development to eligible organizations to provide legal and other supportive services on behalf of low-income families who: (1) reside in a rental dwelling unit; and (2) have an income that does not exceed 80% of the median income for the area in which the family resides. Grants may be used only to provide eligible services in connection with: an eviction of a family; the prevention of an eviction of such a family; a dispute between the landlord and a tenant who is facing eviction; and housing-related legal services or needs.

Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act of 1995 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a program to improve the prevention, detection, and control of Medicare fraud and abuse. Requires the Secretary to pay a portion of any civil monetary penalty assessed under the Medicare program to any individual or entity who provided information which served as the basis for the assessment of the penalty, under the same terms and conditions applicable to awards to qui tam plaintiffs under Federal law. <n>Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require the Secretary, with each explanation of Medicare benefits provided to an individual, and with each notice of payment provided to such individual, to include a statement soliciting information on fraud and abuse committed against the Medicare program, together with a toll-free telephone number through which the individual or entity may report such information. <n>Increases civil and criminal monetary penalties under Medicare. <n>Requires the Secretary to: (1) provide advance notice of a survey to nursing facilities by suppliers of medical equipment of medical necessity forms; (2) include diagnosis code on unassigned claims; (3) assess a civil penalty for each failure to include such code on unassigned claims; (4) assess a civil penalty for each failure to provide information on referring physician on unassigned claims; (5)

Voter Registration Modernization Act - Amends the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 (NVRA) to direct states to ensure the availability of the Internet for online voter registration. Requires a state to accept an online voter registration application provided by an individual and ensure that the individual is registered to vote if the individual: (1) meets the same voter registration requirements applicable to individuals who register to vote by mail in accordance with the mail voter registration application form prescribed by the Election Assistance Commission; and (2) in the case of an individual who has a signature on file with the state motor vehicle authority, the information provided in the application matches the records of such state motor vehicle authority; and (3) provides a signature in electronic form.

Child Safety Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to, and enter into contracts and cooperative agreements with, public or nonprofit private entities to assist such entities in the establishment and operation of supervised visitation centers. Declares that grantees shall target the economically disadvantaged and those individuals who could otherwise afford such visitation services. Authorizes appropriations.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that: (1) the filing period for a tax interest abatement claim shall be at any time after the earlier of the mailing of the Secretary of the Treasury's final determination not to abate such interest or 180 days after the filing with the Secretary of a claim for abatement; and (2) a small tax case shall have its filing period extended from the date of filing to 180 days after the Secretary's final determination not to abate such interest. <n>(Sec. 102) Provides that a tax interest abatement claim shall have its filing period extended from the date of filing to 180 days after the Secretary's final determination not to abate such interest. <n>(Sec. 103) Provides that a tax interest abatement petition shall have its filing period extended from the date of filing to 180 days after the Secretary's final determination not to abate such interest. <n>(Sec. 104) Provides that a spousal relief petition shall have its filing period extended from the date of filing to 180 days after the Secretary's final determination not to abate such interest if the petitioner is either an individual or an entity other than an individual. <n>Title II: United States Tax Court Administration <n> - Amends the Internal Revenue Code

Amends the Small Business Act to authorize the Small Business Administration (SBA) to award a grant, on a competitive basis, to one or more eligible associations to assist small businesses in successfully completing the Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Program and the Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Program. Defines an eligible association" as a national, regional, organization, coalition, or other entity that represents small businesses participating in SBIR or STTR programs.<n><n>Requires amounts made available under such a grant to be used to establish and carry out a program under which one or more qualified mentoring organizations provide technical assistance (which may include marketing, proposal writing, government accounting, government audits, facilities and equipment, project management, human resources, phase III partners, commercialization, and venture capital networking) to small businesses located in low participation areas in order to advise and guide them through the SBIR and STTR program processes from application to award and successful completion of each phase of the program. Authorizes the use of such amounts to reimburse qualified mentoring organizations participating in the program for necessary out-of-pocket expenses incident to the provision of services by employees under the program and while employees of such organizations are providing such services away from their homes or regular places of business for travel expenses"

United States Airlift Requirements Act - Directs the Secretary of Defense to study and report to Congress on various alternatives for the size and mix of assets for the Air Force intertheater airlift force, with a particular focus on current and planned capabilities and costs of the C-5 aircraft and C-17 aircraft fleets. Requires the Secretary to select a federally funded research and development center (FFRDC) that has experience and expertise in conducting similar studies. Directs the FFRDC to: (1) develop the methodology for the study; and (2) submit the methodology to the Comptroller General for review. Requires the Comptroller General to: (1) review the methodology for identifying any flaws or weaknesses; and (2) report to the FFRDC that sets forth any flaws or weaknesses in the methodology, and makes any recommendations the Comptroller General considers advisable for improvements to the methodology. Directs the FFRDC to: (1) modify the methodology in order to address flaws identified by the Comptroller General in the report, and to improve it in accordance with any recommendations made by the Comptroller General; and (2) report to the congressional defense committees if it does not improve the methodology according to the Comptroller General's recommendation. Requires the study to: (1) build upon the results of the recent Mobility Capabilities Studies of the Department of Defense (DOD), the on

Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to prohibit the admission of an alien who remains in the United States for any period of time after the expiration of his or her visa or status unless the Secretary of Homeland Security determines on an individual case-by-case basis that because of a medical necessity, public safety, or national security the alien violated such provision. Prohibits: (1) such an alien convicted of visa overstay from being admitted to the United States for five years, beginning on the date of the conviction; and (2) such an alien convicted of subsequent violation from being admitted to the United States for ten years, beginning on the date of the conviction. Requires the Secretary of State or the Secretary of Homeland Security to disclose such penalties in any application or petition for admission. Provides that a revocation of visa shall automatically cancel any other valid visa in an alien's possession. Declares that: (1) in any removal proceedings before an immigration judge and in any appeal proceedings before the Attorney General from any such removal proceedings, the Secretary may provide to a foreign government copies of Department of State and diplomatic and consular office records pertaining to the issuance or refusal of visas or permits to enter the United States, or information contained in such records, if the Secretary determines that it is in the national

United States-Pakistan Security and Stability Act - Directs the President to develop and transmit to the appropriate congressional committees, with intelligence support from the Director of National Intelligence, a comprehensive interagency strategy and implementation plan for long-term security and stability in Pakistan.

Outer Continental Shelf Enhanced Exploration and Deep Water Incentives Act - Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to direct the Secretary of the Interior to reduce, suspend, or eliminate any royalty or net profit share set forth in leases, if any, to: (1) promote development and new production on producing or nonproducing leases, through primary, secondary, or tertiary recovery means; or (2) encourage production of marginal or uneconomic resources on producing or nonproducing leases, which may include the use of such means. Declares that no royalty payment shall be due on new production from any lease located in water depths of 200 meters or greater until the capital costs directly related to such new production have been recovered by the lessee out of the proceeds from such new production. Declares that, in any month during which the arithmetic average of the closing prices for the earliest delivery month on the New York Mercantile Exchange for Light Sweet crude oil exceeds $28.00 per barrel, any production of oil described in this Act shall be subject to royalties at the lease stipulated rate. Requires that, in any month during which the arithmetic average of the closing prices for the earliest delivery month on the New York Mercantile Exchange for natural gas exceeds $3.50 per million British thermal units, any production of natural gas described in this Act shall be

Combating Climate Change Through Individual Action Act of 2008- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a business-related tax credit for 30% of qualified carbon sequestration and soil conservation expenditures paid or incurred for land used in farming.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 7, 2016. TPS Reform Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to revise the process for designating a foreign state as a temporary protected status (TPS) state. To be designated a foreign state, a state must: (1) have an ongoing armed conflict within its boundaries that would require the return of TPS-eligible aliens; (2) be affected by an earthquake, flood, drought, epidemic, or other immediately life-threatening environmental disaster; (3) be unable, temporarily, to handle adequately the return of TPS-eligible aliens; and (4) have requested designation. The bill provides for: (1) an extension of such designation up to 18 months, and (2) a termination of such designation upon enactment of an Act that contains a finding that the foreign state (or part of it) no longer meets the conditions for designation. Aliens lack a lawful immigration status.

Military Call-Up Relief Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to waive the ten percent penalty on early distributions from qualified retirement plans to individuals called to active duty during the national emergency declared by the President on September 14, 2001.

Timely Payment for Veterans' Medical Care Act (Sec. 2) This bill authorizes the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to enter into contracts with eligible entities (agency, organization, or other person with a contract) to serve as administrative contractors for the performance of certain functions relating to the furnishing of medical care and hospital services in non-VA facilities, including: determining the amount of required payments to a non-VA facility; making such payments; providing education and outreach to enrollees in the VA patient enrollment system and assistance to them with specific issues, concerns, or problems; providing consultative services to institutions, agencies, and other persons to enable them to establish and maintain fiscal records necessary for VA purposes; communicating to non-VA facilities any information or instructions furnished to such contractor by the VA; and performing the functions relating to non-VA facility education, training, and technical assistance. The VA: (1) shall use competitive procedures when entering into such contracts, taking into account performance quality as well as price and other factors; and (2) may renew a contract from term to term without regard to law requiring competition, if the administrative contractor has met or exceeded contract performance requirements, and the VA shall provide for the application of competitive procedures at least once every five years. The VA: (1) may

National Defense Energy Savings Act of 2003 - Authorizes the Secretary of Defense to: (1) enter into an energy savings performance contract in order to achieve energy savings and ancillary benefits; (2) incur obligations under the contract to finance energy conservation measures so long as guaranteed savings exceed the debt service requirements; and (3) implement a pilot program to enter into up to ten energy savings performance contracts for the purpose of achieving energy savings, secondary savings, and incidental benefits, in nonbuilding applications.Sets forth implementation guidelines, including contract terms and conditions.

Improved Passenger Automobile Fuel Economy Act of 2007 - Amends federal transportation law to direct the Secretary of Transportation to prescribe minimum corporate average fuel economy (CAFE) standards for passenger automobiles, including standards that are based on one or more vehicle attributes that relate to fuel economy. Requires the Secretary of Transportation, when deciding maximum feasible average fuel economy for passenger automobiles, to consider (in addition to current considerations) motor vehicle safety, emissions, and the need of the United States to reduce its dependence on oil for transportation. Prohibits the Secretary from prescribing an CAFE standard that imposes marginal costs that exceed marginal benefits. Requires the Secretary, before taking final action on a standard or an exemption from a standard, to notify the Secretary of Energy and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and provide them a reasonable time to comment on the standard or exemption.

Specifies that any account placed for collection or charged to profit and loss in which the amount placed to collection or charged to profit and loss did not exceed $100 and which antedates the report by more than three years, if: (1) the consumer to whom the report relates completed a credit and financial management class during such three-year period; and (2) the consumer has not previously had such an account excluded. Requires the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Federal Trade Commission to monitor and report to Congress on the extent to which: (1) consumer disputes with consumer reporting agencies over the accuracy or completeness of information in a consumer's file are promptly and fully investigated and any incorrect, incomplete, or unverifiable information is immediately corrected or deleted; (2) furnishers of information to such agencies maintain full and prompt compliance with the duties and responsibilities established under the Act; and (3) such agencies establish and maintain appropriate internal controls and management review procedures for maintaining such compliance.

Rural Energy Communities Development Act of 2010 - Authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to make loans to eligible communities for essential community facilities for purposes including: (1) conservation, development, use, and control of water; (2) installation or improvement of drainage or waste disposal facilities; (3) transportation facilities; and (4) affordable housing.<n><n>Makes a community eligible for such a loan if it is a city, town, or incorporated area that has a population of less than 20,000 and has experienced net job growth in the energy sector of not less than 20% between January 1999 through December 2009.<n><n>Sets forth loan application requirements.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) make permanent the increased expensing allowance for depreciable small business assets and the expensing allowance for computer software; and (2) allow a tax deduction for the purchase of domestically manufactured automobiles.

Advancing Innovation and Reinvigorating Widespread Access to Viable Electromagnetic Spectrum Act or the AIRWAVES Act This bill requires the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to: complete by December 31, 2018, a system of competitive bidding to grant priority licenses for the use of certain electromagnetic spectrum between 3550 megahertz and 8400 megahertz; complete a system of competitive bidding to complete a system of competitive bidding for the use of spectrum in specified frequencies between December 31, 2018, and December 31, 2020; and complete a system of competitive bidding for the use of spectrum frequencies between specified frequencies between April 17, 2015, and the date of enactment of this bill. The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) must: identify, within one year after enactment of this bill, any frequency between 7125 megahertz and 8400 megahertz that is being considered for unlicensed use; and submit to the FCC a report identifying any other frequency between 7125 megahertz and 8400 megahertz that is being considered for licensed use. The FCC and NTIA must: complete by December 31, 2017, a system of competitive bidding to grant priority licenses for the use of certain electromagnetic spectrum between 3550 megahertz and 40000 megahertz; and complete by December 31, 2020, a system of competitive bidding for the use of spectrum between

State Veterans Home Nurse Recruitment Act of 2004 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to make payments to States for the purpose of assisting State homes in the hiring and retention of nurses and the reduction of nursing shortages at State homes. Requires a State to receive such payments to have in effect an employee incentive scholarship program or other incentive program at a State home designed to promote the hiring and retention of nursing staff and to reduce nursing shortages at the State home. Limits a program to 50 percent of the costs for a fiscal year of such program.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow small manufacturers a business-related tax credit for the lesser of 50% of the amount paid for qualified computer hardware and software property or $35,000. Terminates such credit after 2011.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on February 13, 2016. Strengthening American Transportation Security Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the personnel system utilized by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) provides insufficient workplace protections for the TSA's Transportation Security Officer workforce, and (2) such personnel should be entitled to the rights provided to most other federal workers. (Sec. 4) The TSA shall not establish a personnel system that denies TSA employees the rights provided to most other federal workers, including: (1) the right to appeal adverse personnel decisions to the Merit Systems Protection Board; (2) fair pay and raises under the General Services wage system, including overtime guidelines, access to earned leave, the application of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, and fair performance appraisals; and (3) direct protections against employment discrimination. The TSA shall consult with: (1) the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Government Accountability Office (GAO); and (2) the labor organization certified by the Federal Labor Relations Authority to carry out the conversion of TSA functions into a collective bargaining unit. The bill prescribes transition rules that: (1) apply to the majority of TSA employees performing screening functions, and (2) prohibit a strike by such employees. The TSA may not

Video Competition and Consumer Choice Act of 1998 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to declare that the authority to regulate cable programming rates shall not apply to such services provided after March 31, 1999, unless the franchising authority for such cable system, after notice and opportunity for a public hearing, certifies to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) that the operator is not providing subscribers an acceptable range of programming choices to the extent technically feasible and economically reasonable. <n>Sets forth factors for the franchising authority to base its determination on, including: (1) delivery of the packages is technically feasible based on the current and expected capability of the system; (2) delivery of the packages is economically reasonable based on the technical requirements for delivery of the packages; (3) delivery of the packages can be performed without jeopardizing security of multichannel video programming and other services offered over the system, or the legal rights of the system operator to prevent theft of service; (4) any revenues received by the cable operator and cable programming providers from advertising, including the economic effect of offering additional programming choices on advertising revenues and subscriber rates; (5) the packages permit subscribers to subscribe to significantly less than the majority of upper tier programing services available; and (6) the packages are related to the program category interests of groups as demonstrated by polling, referenda, statistics, or

Central American Deportation Relief Act - Amends the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 with respect to the computation of the period of continuous physical presence with respect to the suspension of deportation. Provides that, in any case in which the Attorney General elects to terminate and reinitiate proceedings in accordance with such provision, such provision shall not apply to an order to show cause issued before April 1, 1997. Declares that, for purposes of calculating the period of continuous physical presence, such period is deemed to terminate on April 1, 1997, in the case of an alien who demonstrates that he or she has not been convicted at any time of an aggravated felony and has not been apprehended while attempting to enter the United States unlawfully after December 12, 1990. Declares that: (1) any alien found ineligible for suspension of deportation prior to July 10, 1997, solely on the basis of this Act, and who claims eligibility for suspension of deportation as a result of the amendments made by this Act, may, notwithstanding any other limitations imposed by law on motions to reopen, file one motion to reopen deportation proceedings; and (2) the Attorney General shall designate a specific time period in which all such motions to reopen are required to be filed.

Arctic Marine Shipping Assessment Implementation Act of 2009 - Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary of State, acting through the Commandant of the Coast Guard, should work to establish agreements to promote coordinated action among the United States, Russia, Canada, Iceland, Norway, and Denmark and other seafaring and Arctic nations with respect to: (1) placement and maintenance of aids to navigation in waters of the Arctic; (2) improved navigational charts; (3) monitoring of ocean conditions, wind, waves, and currents and the timely reporting of information about ice and weather conditions; and (4) maritime search and rescue in the Arctic.

Energy Security and Foreign Policy Integration Act of 2007 - Amends the National Security Act of 1947 to establish a Directorate of Energy within the National Security Council, which shall be the lead U.S. government entity in charge of formulating and coordinating U.S. national energy security policy.<n><n>Directs the President, every four years, to conduct a quadrennial national energy security review (QESR) which shall set forth the national energy security strategy of the United States and establish goals to achieve energy security.

Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee Act - Establishes the Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee to: (1) study and report on programs established and carried out to achieve restoration goals for the Great Lakes prepared by the Governors of Great Lakes States; and (2) make recommendations for prioritization of such goals, legislation and funding to achieve such goals, and improvement of coordination among programs and governments with respect to such goals.

Civic Participation and Rehabilitation Act of 1999 - States that the right of a U.S. citizen to vote in any election for Federal office shall not be denied or abridged because that individual has been convicted of a criminal offense unless such individual is serving a felony sentence in a correctional institution or facility at the time of the election. Authorizes the Attorney General, in a civil action, to obtain declaratory or injunctive relief as is necessary to remedy a violation of this Act. Authorizes a person aggrieved by a violation of this Act to provide written notice of the violation to the chief election official of the State involved and, if the violation is not corrected within 90 days after receipt, to obtain declaratory or injunctive relief with respect to the violation if it occurred within 120 days before the date of an election for Federal office.

San Francisco Old Mint Commemorative Coin Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue not more than 100,000 $5 coins and 500,000 $1 coins emblematic of the San Francisco Old Mint Building, its importance to California and U.S. history, and its role in rebuilding San Francisco after the 1906 earthquake and fire.Requires that all sales of coins minted under this Act include a surcharge of: (1) $35 per coin for the $5 coin; and (2) $10 per coin for the $1 coin, which shall be paid to the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society for the design and construction of appropriate exhibitions in the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society.

Residential and Commuter Toll Fairness Act of 2009 - Authorizes states, counties, municipalities, and multi-jurisdictional transportation authorities to establish programs that offer discounted transportation tolls, user fees, and fares for residents of specific geographic areas who live in areas that are only accessible through a means that requires them to pay a toll, user fee, or fare.

edible Military Option to Counter Iran Act - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) military exercises conducted in the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman emphasize the United States resolve and the policy of the United States by enhancing the readiness of the U.S. military and allied forces, as well as signaling to the government of Iran the commitment of the United States to defend its vital national security interests; and (2) the President, as Commander in Chief, should require the U.S. military to develop a plan to augment the presence of the U.S. Fifth Fleet in the Middle East and conduct military deployments, exercises, or other visible, concrete military readiness activities to underscore such policy. Directs the Secretary of Defense (DOD) to prepare such plan.

(Sec. 102) Requires the Administrator, as soon as practicable after being informed of a serious threat to the safety or security of children enrolled in a childcare facility in a public building under the Administrator's control, to notify the parents or guardians: (1) of the current tenants in the public building; and (2) of the designation of the level of security of the building. Requires the Administrator, after providing such notification, to notify the parents or guardians if any new Federal tenant is scheduled to take occupancy in the building. Directs the Administrator, not later than one year after the enactment of this Act, to transmit to Congress a comprehensive report on childcare facilities in public buildings under the Administrator's control, including: (1) an identification and description of each such facility; and (2) an assessment of the level of safety and security of children enrolled in the facility and recommendations on methods for enhancing that safety and security. Requires the Administrator, in conducting such assessment, to examine the windows and interior furnishings of the facility to determine whether adequate protective measures have been implemented to protect children in the facility against the dangers associated with windows and interior furnishings in the event of a natural disaster or terrorist attack, including the deadly effect of flying glass.Title II: Federal Protective Service Reform Act of 2000 - Amend

Service Members Student Loan Relief Act - Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to allow members of the Armed Forces and National Guard to defer payments of principal on their Federal Family Education Loans, William D. Ford Federal Direct Loans, and Federal Perkins Loans for the period (up to 180 days) beginning on the date they receive a call or order to duty in connection with a war, military operation, or national emergency and ending on their first day of service. (Currently, the payment of principal on those loans is also deferred during their period of service and for the 180-day period after their demobilization date.)

Taxpayer's Right To View Act of 1993 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit a cable operator from assessing or collecting any separate charges for any video programming of a sporting, theatrical, or other entertainment event performed at a facility constructed, renovated, or maintained with tax revenues or by an organization that receives public financial support. Authorizes the Federal Communications Commission and local authorities to make determinations concerning the applicability of such prohibition.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose a tax equal to 20 percent of the excess (if any) of: (1) the taxable earned income received or accrued during the taxable year; over (2) the standard deduction for such taxable year. Increases the basic standard deduction and provides an additional standard deduction for each dependent. <n>Allows a tax deduction for charitable contributions and gifts up to $2,500 ($1,250 for a married individual filing a separate return). <n>Repeals provisions relating to a limitation on the tax deduction for home mortgage interest.

Mississippi Gulf Coast National Heritage Area Act - Establishes the Mississippi Gulf Coast National Heritage Area in Mississippi. Designates the Mississippi Department of Marine Resources as the coordinating entity for the Area, which shall develop and submit a management plan for the Area.

Consumer Learning through Electronically-Accessible and Reasonable Cost Information Act of 2013 or CLEAR Cost Information Act of 2013 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require certain hospitals to report to the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) payment data on the actual amounts collected by the hospital from uninsured and insured patients over the preceding two years for each of the 50 most common diagnosis-related groups and ambulatory payment classification groups for which Medicare payment is made. Requires the Secretary to post such data on a publicly accessible and searchable Internet website in a form and manner that: (1) allows for meaningful comparisons of hospital collections and related policies by zip code; and (2) is readily understandable by a typical consumer. Amends the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to require the Secretary to post data in the annual report from the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (MEDPAC) to Congress on the percentage that charity care makes up of the total care furnished by hospitals and critical access hospitals.

Coral Reef Resource Conservation and Management Act of 1999 - Requires the Secretary of the Interior to establish a Coral Reef Task Force to coordinate Federal coral reef conservation and management efforts. Defines coral reef" to mean any species of the phylum Cnidaria, including: (1) any species of the order Antipatharia (black corals), Scleractinia (stony corals), Gorgonacea (horny corals), Stolonifera (organpipe corals and others), Alcyanacea (soft corals), or Coenothecalia (blue corals), of the class Anthozoa; and (2) any species of the order Hydrocorallina (fire corals and hydrocorals) of the class Hydrozoa.Establishes in the Department of the Interior the Coral Reef Foundation."
Communities Committed to College Tax Credit Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for 50% of charitable contributions made to a need-based college scholarship trust.

Alaska Peninsula Subsurface Consolidation Act of 1993 - Provides for the acquisition of Koniag, Incorporated's selection rights to the oil and gas rights and other interests in the subsurface estate of specified public lands in Alaska.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2016. Clinical Trials Modernization Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), in order to promote the efficiency of the development and regulatory review and approval, licensure, or clearance of drugs, biological products, and devices and the timely availability of innovative treatments, to establish and implement a framework through which sponsors of drugs, biological products, or devices may submit to the FDA a proposal for the incorporation of adaptive trial designs, Bayesian methods, or other alternative statistical methods into proposed clinical protocols and marketing applications for those products. The FDA shall: (1) update and finalize the draft guidance addressing the use of adaptive trial design for drugs and biological products, and (2) issue draft guidance on the use of Bayesian methods in the development and regulatory review and approval, licensure, or clearance of those products. The guidances shall: (1) establish or clarify standards for using adaptive trial designs and Bayesian methods in clinical trials, (2) establish a mechanism for sponsors to obtain feedback on technical issues related to modeling and simulations prior to the completion of such modeling or simulations, (3) specify the types of quantitative and qualitative information required for review, and (4) specify

Medicare Home Health Equity Act of 1998 - Amends part D (Miscellaneous Provisions) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA), as amended by the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (BBA '97), with respect to the computation formula of the interim system of limited payments for services provided by home health agencies, in order to: (1) restore the cost limits; and (2) provide for a change in additions to cost limits. <n>Directs the Director of the Congressional Budget Office to estimate annually, until the prospective payment system (PPS) for home health agencies is in effect, the amount of savings to the Medicare program resulting from the interim payment system for home health services.

Open Fuel Standard Act of 2009 or the OFS Act - Requires each light-duty automobile manufacturer\\'s annual covered inventory to comprise at least: (1) 50% fuel choice-enabling automobiles in 2012, 2013, and 2014; and (2) 80% fuel choice-enabling automobiles in 2015, and in each subsequent year. Defines fuel choice-enabling automobile" as: (1) a flexible fuel automobile capable of operating on gasoline, E85, and M85; or (2) an automobile capable of operating on biodiesel fuel. Exempts manufacturers from such requirement on a temporary basis during the period beginning on this Act\\'s enactment and ending on December 31, 2015."

Drive America on Natural Gas Act of 2008 - Amends the Clean Air Act to redefine renewable fuel" as fuel that: (1) is produced from renewable biomass; and (2) is used to replace or reduce the quantity of fossil fuel present in a transportation fuel. Defines "renewable fuel" to include compressed natural and liquefied natural gas when used as transportation fuel.<n><n>Allows a new qualified alternative fuel motor vehicle tax credit for dual fuel motor vehicles which are only capable of operating on an alternative fuel or on an alternative fuel and gasoline or diesel fuel.<n><n>Directs the Secretary of Energy to conduct a natural gas vehicle research, development, and demonstration program."

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 17, 2015. Ensuring the Taxpayer a Fair Return for Federal Onshore Oil and Gas Resources Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Mineral Leasing Act to direct the Department of the Interior to adjust by regulation, at least once every four years, the minimum bid and annual rental amounts for oil and gas leases on public lands (including submerged lands) to reflect the cost-of-living adjustment. This adjustment shall be provided by the cost-of-living adjustment percentage for a dollar amount by which: the Consumer Price Index for the month of June of the calendar year preceding the adjustment exceeds the Consumer Price Index for the month of June of the calendar year in which the dollar amount was last set or adjusted pursuant to law; and the index for all urban consumers published by the Department of Labor exceeds 12.5%. (Sec. 3) The bill revises the statutory formula for the royalty rates payable to Interior to prescribe a minimum rate of royalty for: new oil and gas leases on federal lands (including submerged lands) of 18.75 cents per barrel, and new oil and gas leases on federal lands of 28.75 cents per barrel. The bill also revises and expands royalty sharing requirements for oil and gas

Kake Tribal Corporation Land Exchange Act - Amends the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to direct the Secretary of the Interior to convey to the Kake Tribal Corporation specified Federal land in the Copper River Meridian, subject to: (1) the corporation having an option to select up to 388 acres in the Lakes area; and (2) Sealaska Corporation title to the subsurface estate in that land.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the rate of the tax credit for increasing research activities by increasing the medical research base amount. Defines qualified medical research expenses" as expenses incurred for research in, or reasonably expected to lead to, the development of any medical product for the prevention, cure, or alleviation of human disease, sickness, or injury incurred before the earliest of: (1) the date on which an application with respect to such product is approved under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act; (2) the date on which a license for such product is approved under the Public Health Service Act; or (3) the later of the date classification of such product as intended for human use is made under such Act or the date of approval of such product as intended for human use is granted."

Noxious Weed Control and Eradication Act of 2004 - Amends the Plant Protection Act to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a program to provide financial and technical assistance to control or eradicate noxious weeds. Directs the Secretary to make grants to recognized weed management entities for the control or eradication of noxious weeds. Directs the Secretary to enter into agreements with weed management entities to provide financial and technical assistance for the control or eradication of noxious weeds. Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) grant considerations; and (2) project selection.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate with an amendment to the Homeland Security Act of 2002.)United States Fire Administration Authorization Act of 2003 - (Sec. 2) States that the Administrator of the United States Fire Administration (Director) shall continue to be appointed and compensated as provided under the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974.(Sec. 3) Directs the Administrator to develop and implement a strategy for promoting the installation and use of residential fire sprinklers. Requires the strategy to include: (1) advocacy and informational support to relevant stakeholders; (2) promotion of residential sprinklers in residences supported by the Federal Government; (3) a particular focus on residences at high risk to fire hazards, such as senior citizens and persons with disabilities; and (4) a particular focus on localized fire suppression in high-risk areas of residences.(Sec. 4) Requires the Administrator to provide grant-writing assistance to applicants under the firefighter assistance program (currently, the Director is required to establish specific criteria for the selection of recipients and provide grant-writing assistance to applicants).(Sec. 5) Extends through FY 2006 the authorization of appropriations for the firefighter assistance program.(Sec. 6) Directs the Administrator to offer courses and training assistance as necessary to accommodate all geographic regions and needs of career and volunteer

Ute-Moab Land Restoration Act - Amends the Strom Thurmond National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1999 to provide that the United States conveys to the Ute Indian Tribe of the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation all Federal land within the exterior boundaries of Oil Shale Reserve Numbered 2 (NOSR-2) in fee simple (including surface and mineral rights). Excludes from such conveyance specified reservations of the United States: (1) a nine percent royalty interest in the value of any oil, gas, other hydrocarbons, and all other minerals from the conveyed land that are produced, saved, and sold, the payments for which shall be made by the Tribe or its designee to the Secretary of Energy during the period that the oil, gas, hydrocarbons, or minerals are being produced, saved, sold, or extracted; (2) the portion of the bed of Green River contained entirely within NOSR-2, as depicted on the map; and (3) a 1/4 mile scenic easement on the east side of the Green River within NOSR-2. Declares that such land conveyed to the Tribe shall: (1) not revert to the United States for management in trust status; and (2) not affect the Tribe's right to obtain, use, and maintain access to the Green River through the use of the road within

Job Creation and Economic Growth Act - Amends the Budget Control Act of 2011 to include job creation and economic growth among the goals of the Joint Select Committee on Deficit Reduction. Requires the Committee to report to the Congress on proposals to spur economic growth and restore the nation's workforce to full employment over the period of FY2012-FY2013.

. (Sec. 1) This bill directs the Governor of the Virgin Islands to appoint a Chief Financial Officer, with the advice and consent of the Legislature of the Virgin Islands, from a list required by this bill. If the Legislature has not confirmed a nominee within 90 days, the Governor shall appoint an Acting Chief Financial Officer until the Legislature consents to a Chief Financial Officer. The Virgin Islands Chief Financial Officer Search Commission shall appoint an Acting Chief Financial Officer from the list, until a Chief Financial Officer is appointed, if one has not been appointed within 180 days. If the Acting Chief Financial Officer serves in an acting capacity for 180 consecutive days, without further action the Acting Chief Financial Officer shall become the Chief Financial Officer. The functions of the Director of the Office of Management and Budget established under the laws of the Virgin Islands shall be transferred to the Chief Financial Officer. All employees of the Office of Management and Budget become employees of the Office of the Chief Financial Officer. The duties of the Chief Financial Officer shall include: Assume the functions and authority of the Office of Management and Budget established under this bill; develop a report on the financial status of the government of the Virgin Islands within six months after appointment and quarterly thereafter; certify the annual budget and whether or not the budget is balanced

Technology and Research Accelerating National Security and Future Economic Resiliency Act of 2014 or the TRANSFER Act - Amends the Small Business Act to replace provisions requiring the Director of the National Institutes of Health to use funds for a Proof of Concept Partnership pilot program to accelerate the creation of small businesses and the commercialization of research innovations made by certain institutions with provisions directing the head of each federal agency required to establish a small business technology transfer (STTR) program to establish an Innovative Approaches to Technology Transfer Grant Program to make grants to eligible institutions to improve or accelerate the commercialization of high quality and commercially viable federally funded research and technology by small businesses. Defines "eligible institution" to mean an institution of higher education, a technology transfer organization that facilitates the commercialization of technologies developed by one or more institutions of higher education, a federal laboratory, a public or private nonprofit entity, or a consortium of any such entities. Revises and expands the grant program to require its uses to include: providing early-stage proof of concept funding for translational research; identifying research and technology that have the potential for accelerated commercialization; supporting technology maturation activities; providing funding for technical validations, market research, clarifying intellectual property rights position and strategy, and investigating commercial and business opportunities; providing

Enhancing Teaching Standards and License Portability Act of 2007 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to states and, through them, subgrants to state educational agencies to carry out specified activities related to: (1) the development or updating of core teaching standards and content-specific kindergarten through grade 12 teaching standards that are rigorous and incorporate 21st century learning skills and recent research and expert knowledge on teaching practices; (2) the development of teacher assessments linked to such standards that can be used for licensing, are valid and reliable, and are performance-based; (3) the provision of technical assistance to states in the adoption, pilot testing, and implementation of such standards and teacher assessments; and (4) the provision of technical assistance to states to facilitate teacher license portability across states through changes in relevant state policies or the creation of new policies.

Directs the President to designate at least three closed military installations, or portions thereof, for siting a refinery. Requires the President, in considering any site for possible designation, to conduct an analysis of: (1) the availability of crude oil supplies to the site; (2) the distribution of the nation's refined petroleum product demand; (3) whether such site is in close proximity to substantial pipeline infrastructure; (4) the need to diversify the geographical location of the domestic refining capacity; (5) the effect that increased refined petroleum products from a refinery on that site may have on the price and supply of gasoline to consumers; and (6) the impact of locating a refinery on the site on the readiness and operations of the Armed Forces. Prohibits the federal government from selling or otherwise disposing of the military installations designated pursuant to this Act until two years after enactment of this Act. Requires the redevelopment authority for such installation, with respect to a closed military installation designated by the President as a potentially suitable refinery site, to consider the feasibility and practicability of siting a refinery on the installation and the Secretary of Defense, in managing and disposing of real property at the installation pursuant to the base closure law applicable to the installation, to give substantial deference to the recommendations of such authority regarding the siting of a refinery on

Teacher Victims' Family Assistance Act of 2017 This bill directs the Department of Education (ED) to provide assistance to the surviving spouse, dependent child, or other next of kin of a teacher, administrator, employee, or paid or unpaid staff member of a public or private elementary or secondary school who was killed as a result of an act of violence committed by another person while performing school duties. The bill includes among such assistance: funeral assistance; a death benefit payment to the surviving spouse, dependent child, or other next of kin; monthly living assistance for the surviving spouse until death or remarriage and for each dependent child until age18; and undergraduate education assistance for each dependent child for five years or until age 25. The bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from income: (1) a teacher who is a victim of an act of violence while performing school duties, and (2) assistance provided under this bill.

Jamestown 400th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act of 2003 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to issue $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins emblematic of the settlement of Jamestown, Virginia, the first permanent English settlement in America. Prohibits such coins from being issued until December 31, 2007.

Senior Safe Corridor Act - Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize the Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance to make grants to States and local governments with populations of 100,000 or more to fund programs that create corridors for senior citizens in high-density senior citizen areas to reduce violent crimes against senior citizens. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 16, 2016. Executive Appointee Ethics Improvement Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the federal criminal code to revise post-employment lobbying restrictions on certain former government employees to: extend the ban to two years, subject to a waiver, for individuals who were employed in a position specified under the Executive Schedule, a limited term appointee, limited emergency appointee, or noncareer appointee in the Senior Executive Service, or in a position of a confidential or policy-determining character; repeal the ban on representation of foreign entities for certain high-level former employees; and prohibit former employees who were registered lobbyists under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 from participating in any particular matter on which they made a lobbying contact, or who seek or accept employment with any agency with respect to which they made such a lobbying contact, during the two-year period preceding their appointment. The bill prohibits former employees who have not received a waiver from participating in any particular matter involving specific parties that is directly and substantially related to their former employer or former clients during such two-year period. The Office of Government Ethics must certify to the President and specified congressional committees that it is in the public interest to grant such a waiver.
Caring Family Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for additional exemptions, between 2003 and 2012, for dependents with long-term care needs in the taxpayer's home.

Rare Earths Supply Technology and Resources Transformation Act of 2010 or the RESTART Act - Declares it to be U.S. policy that each federal agency take appropriate actions to expedite permitting and projects that will increase exploration for, and development of, domestic rare earths. Establishes the Rare Earth Policy Task Force within the Department of the Interior.

Iran Nonproliferation Amendments Act of 2005 - Amends the Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000 to prohibit the importation into the United States of goods, services, and technology that could contribute to the development of weapons of mass destruction or their means of delivery (including missiles capable of delivering such weapons). (Current law prohibits the importation into the United States of goods, services, and technology that could contribute to the development of such weapons.)

Union Integrity Act This bill amends the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 to prohibit a labor organization from terminating or discriminating against an employee as to whether at the employee's initiative or in the ordinary course of his or her duties, the employee has: (1) provided information to the labor organization, the Department of Labor, or any other state, local, or federal government authority or law enforcement agency relating to any violation of federal labor-management relations law or other provision of law that the employee reasonably believes to be a violation; (2) testified or will testify in a proceeding resulting from the administration or enforcement of any provision of federal labor-management relations law or other provision of law that is subject to the jurisdiction of the Department of Labor or the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB); (3) filed, instituted, or caused to be filed or instituted any proceeding under the Act; or (4) objected to, or refused to participate in, any activity, policy, practice, or assigned task that the employee reasonably believed to be in violation of federal labor-management relations law or other provision of law. A person who believes that he or she has been discharged or discriminated against by any person in violation of this bill may file a complaint with the Department of Labor alleging such discharge or discrimination and

. Independent Outside Audit of the Indian Health Service Act of 2017 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to contract with a reputable private entity to conduct an independent assessment of the health care delivery systems and financial management processes of the Indian Health Service (the Service). The assessments shall address: current and projected demographics and unique health care needs of the patient population served by the Service; and projected health care capabilities resources of the Service, including hospital care, medical services, and other health care furnished by non-Service facilities under contract with the Service, to provide timely and accessible care to eligible patients. HHS shall designate one such entity that is predominantly a health care organization as the program integrator responsible for coordinating the outcomes of the assessments.

Iraq Strategic Agreement Review Act of 2008 - Directs the Secretary of State, the Secretary of Defense, and any other necessary executive branch officer, employee, or representative to commence consultations with specified congressional committees and leadership on any potential long-term security, economic, or political agreement with the government of Iraq. Requires that such consultations include full and complete transparency of all security, economic, political, and other arrangements under consideration for the agreement.

Serving Everyone with Reliable, Vital Internet, Communications, and Education Act of 2007 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to direct the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to: (1) continue in effect the Lifeline Assistance Program and the Link Up Program; and (2) expand such programs by allowing low-income consumers participating in such programs to choose to use such assistance for any one of the following: (1) wire or wireless telephone service; (2) Internet access service; (3) wire or wireless broadband service.<n><n>Requires the FCC to study and report to Congress on: (1) the necessary benefit level for a household participating in the Lifeline Assistance Program or the Link Up Program which will encourage low-income consumers to seek broadband service; (2) projections on the potential of new broadband service consumers who would seek this service if economically accessible; (3) industry requirements to provide broadband service access in underserved areas; (4) data that accurately illustrates the extent of current deployment of broadband service to residential users; and (5) policy proposals to address gaps in broadband service availability.

Business Relief and Incentives for Small Entrepreneurs Act of 2007 or the Business RAISE Act- Amends Internal Revenue Code provisions relating to the business tax credit to: (1) provide for a 15-year recovery period for the depreciation of certain improvements to retail space and for qualified new restaurant improvements; (2) expand the eligibility for the work opportunity tax credit to include individuals with a disability rating of at least 10%; (3) authorize appropriations for FY2008-FY2012 to carry out the work opportunity tax credit; and (4) extend permanently the tax credit for increasing research activities.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) increase from $4.375 to $3.00 the tax credit amount for the production of refined coal from certain renewable resources; and (2) include refined coal produced from a qualified coal waste sludge recycling process as a renewable resource for purposes of such tax credit. Defines qualified coal waste sludge recycling process" as a process using a facility to liquefy coal waste sludge and distribute the liquefied coal waste sludge on the coal to create a feedstock for the manufacture of coke."

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on September 25, 2017. Community Coordination And Resource Empowerment Act or the Community CARE Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to extend funding through 2019 for community health centers (community health centers). The Public Health Service Act is amended to allow the Department of Health and Human Services to award supplemental grant funds to health centers to implement evidence-based models for increasing access to high-quality primary care services. Supplemental funding may be used for models related to: improvement of the delivery of care for individuals with multiple chronic conditions; workforce configuration; reduction of the cost of care; enhancing care coordination; expanding the use of telehealth and technology-enabled collaborative learning and capacity building models; care integration, including integration of behavioral health, mental health, or substance use disorder services; and addressing emerging public health or substance use disorder issues to meet the health needs of the population served by the health center. The bill reduces from two years to one year the period during which a health center shall be required to submit a plan for continuing funded activities.

Urban Sprawl and Smart Growth Study Act - Directs the Council on Environmental Quality to conduct a study of urban sprawl and smart growth that updates and builds on the Council\\'s 1974 study entitled The Costs of Sprawl" and its 1981 study entitled "National Agricultural Lands Study." Requires the Council to select and examine a variety of environmental impact statements and environmental assessments by a minimum of 15 Federal agencies that were completed after 1995 for land and facility management, transportation and infrastructure, and regulatory and development assistance programs, including rural, urban, and tribal assistance. <n>Directs the Council to provide opportunities for public participation in the study, including by: (1) conducting public meetings in at least five cities that are each located in a different region of the United States and in an area experiencing an increase in urban sprawl; (2) making electronically accessible to the public information on the study and related documents; (3) holding discussions with Federal, State, and local government personnel and representatives of Indian tribes involved in the process of formulating environmental impact statements and environmental assessments; and (4) holding discussions with such personnel and representatives of Indian tribes involved in the process of formulating such statements and assessments. Urges the Council to seek the participation of other Federal agencies. <n>Authorizes appropriations. <n>Requires the Administrator"

Training for Realtime Writers Act of 2003 - Directs the Secretary of Education to make competitive grants to eligible entities to promote training and placement of individuals, including individuals who have completed a court reporting training program, as realtime writers providing closed captioning in video programming. Sets forth priorities in awarding grants. Limits grants to $1.5 million for a two-year period. Repeals this Act five years after funds are appropriated to carry it out.

Directs the Secretary of Agriculture: (1) to study the economic and trade impact of agricultural exports of food products from cloned animals; (2) with the Government Accountability Office (GAO) and with the National Academy of Sciences, to study the health effects and costs attributable to milk from cloned animals in the food supply; and (3) with the GAO, to study the public health effects and associated health care costs that result from any decrease in milk consumption, attributable to the commercialization of milk from cloned animals and their progeny.

Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2017 This bill amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to require states to direct their local educational agencies to establish policies that prevent and prohibit conduct, including bullying and harassment, that is sufficiently severe, persistent, or pervasive to: (1) limit students' ability to participate in, or benefit from school programs; or (2) create a hostile or abusive educational environment that adversely affects their education.

Federal Asset Management Improvement Act of 2001- Directs the Administrator of General Services to: (1) establish performance measures to determine the effectiveness of Federal property management; and (2) submit to Congress a program management plan describing how the program will be implemented, individuals who will exercise operational authority over the program, the qualifications of such individuals, and a timeline for implementation.Amends the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 to authorize the Administrator to enter into agreements for the creation of one or more public-private partnerships to: (1) lease Federal real property; and (2) develop, rehabilitate, or renovate facilities on such leased property for use by executive agencies.

Enhanced Dental Care for Veterans Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out a three-year pilot program to assess the feasibility and advisability of furnishing dental care to all enrolled veterans who are not eligible for dental services and treatment, and related dental appliances, under current authorities. Requires the Secretary to carry out the pilot program at not fewer than 16 locations, including four VA medical centers with an established dental clinic and four VA medical centers with a current contract for the furnishing of dental care. Requires the dental services and treatment furnished to veterans under the pilot program to be consistent with the dental services and treatment furnished by the Secretary to veterans with service-connected disabilities rated 100% disabling. Allows the total amount the Secretary may expend furnishing dental services and treatment to any participating veteran during any one-year period to not exceed $1,000.

On-the-Job Training Tax Credit Act of 2015 This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow employers who employ not more than 500 full-time employees during the taxable year a business-related tax credit equal to the lesser of: (1) 50% of the job training program expenditures for a full-time employee participating in a qualified training program, or (2) $5,000. The bill defines qualified training program" as any of the following written plans of study and training: an apprenticeship program registered and certified with the Secretary of Labor; a program licensed, registered, or certified by the workforce investment board or apprenticeship agency or council of a state or administered in compliance with apprenticeship laws; a program conducted by a vocational or technical education school, community college, industrial or trade training organization, or labor organization; a program which conforms to apprentice training programs developed or administered by an employer trade group or committee; or an industry sponsored or administered program which is clearly identified and commonly recognized. The bill defines "eligible employee" as any employee of an employer, who while participating in the job skills training program is employed on average at least 40 hours of service per week. The bill requires that the credit be increased by an amount equal to the"

Directs the Secretary of Defense (DOD) to: (1) assess and develop a uniform definition of hazing applicable to members of the Armed Forces for inclusion in the Uniform Code of Military Justice; and (2) develop and implement a comprehensive policy on the prevention of and response to hazing involving such members. Directs the Secretaries of Defense and Homeland Security (DHS) to develop and implement a centralized, case-level database for the collection and maintenance of information regarding hazing involving members of the Armed Forces, including incidents occurring at officer candidate schools, military academies, military academy preparatory schools, and basic training and professional schools for enlisted members. Requires the Secretaries to: (1) submit to the congressional defense and judiciary committees a plan for the implementation of such database; and (2) report annually to such committees on hazing incidents involving members.

Patient Health and Real Medication Access Cost Savings Act of 2009 or the PHARMACY Bill (Sec. 2) This bill grants a consumer the right to choose to purchase prescription drugs from any domestic pharmacy that meets all applicable federal and state license and permit requirements. (Sec. 3) A pharmacy benefit manager (PBM) may not: (1) provide incentives to enrollees of pharmacy benefit plans administered by such a PBM to encourage them to use certain pharmacies unless the PBM offers the same incentives for all pharmacies in the network for such plan; or (2) refer, coerce, or mandate that an enrollee use a specific mail order pharmacy, specialty drug pharmacy, or other entity if the PBM has an ownership interest in such pharmacy or entity or if the pharmacy or entity has an ownership interest in such PBM. A PBM or pharmacy benefit plan sponsor may not exclude a pharmacy from a pharmacy network if: (1) the pharmacy agrees to the terms of the network contract; (2) the pharmacy meets all applicable federal and state license and permit requirements; and (3) the owners of the pharmacy have not been convicted of a federal crime related to owning or managing a pharmacy. A PBM shall ensure that enrollees pay a copayment of 20% for brand name drugs not to exceed a maximum amount of $150 per prescription.

National Parks Capital Improvements Act of 1996 - Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to enter into a memorandum of agreement with an entity to act as an authorized fundraising organization for the benefit of the Grand Canyon National Park and any other national park designated by the Secretary that has an approved general management plan with capital needs in excess of $5 million. Requires the organization to issue taxable bonds in return for a park surcharge. Declares that the United States shall not be liable for the security of such bonds, except that if such surcharge is not imposed for any reason or if it is reduced or eliminated, the full faith and credit of the United States is pledged to the payment of such bonds and the interest accruing on them. <n>(Sec. 4) Requires the organization to enter into a memorandum of agreement that specifies: (1) the amount of the bond issue; (2) the maturity of the bonds, not to exceed 20 years; (3) the per capita amount required to amortize the bond issue, provide for the reasonable costs of administration, and maintain a sufficient reserve consistent with industry standards; (4) any project that will be funded with the bond proceeds and the specific responsibilities of the Secretary and the organization with respect to the project; and (5) procedures for modifications of the agreement with the consent of both

Campaign Information Improvement Act - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to: (1) reduce the lowest unit charge of a broadcasting station for advertising to 30 percent of the lowest charge of the station for the same amount of time for the same time of day and day-of-week; and (2) prohibit a broadcasting station licensee from preempting the use of its broadcast time by a legally qualified candidate for public office who has purchased and paid for such use. <n>Requires each license for a broadcasting station to annually make available free broadcast time for policy debates. Directs a licensee to allot free broadcast time for each even-numbered year to: (1) the candidates for the House of Representatives of each qualified political party for any congressional district that falls within the grade B contour of such stations signal; and (2) the candidates for the Senate of each qualified political party of the State within which the station's audience resides. <n>Requires a licensee to allot free broadcast time for each joint appearance by: (1) the candidates for the House of Representatives of each qualified political party for any congressional district that falls within the grade B contour of such stations signal; and (2) the candidates for the Senate of each qualified political party of the State within which the station's audience resides.

Railroad Safety Improvement Act of 2005 - Requires the Secretary of Transportation to: (1) establish a pilot program in the five States with the highest rates of collisions, injuries, and fatalities at highway-rail grade crossings that uses automated video image analysis technology to record violations by motorists at crossings equipped with automatic warning devices; (2) submit to specified congressional committees a plan for annually eliminating highway-rail grade crossings that includes guidelines for establishing new crossings and an estimate of the cost; and (3) update and reissue A Guide to Crossing Consolidation and Closure." Requires the Secretary to: (1) conduct a comprehensive review of the safety of all public railway-highway grade crossings in the United States; and (2) compile, maintain, and submit to Congress a list of the 5,000 railway-highway grade crossings most in need of safety improvements. Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to States to improve the safety of railway-highway crossings. Sets forth a formula for the apportioning of such grants."

SAFE Transitional License Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 (Act) to state that, upon employment by a state-licensed mortgage company, an individual who is a registered loan originator shall be deemed to have temporary authority to act as one in an application state for a specified period if the individual: has not had an application for a loan originator license denied, or had such a license revoked or suspended in any governmental jurisdiction; has not been subject to or served with a cease and desist order in any governmental jurisdiction; has not been convicted of a felony that would preclude licensure under the law of the application state; has applied to be a state-licensed originator in the application state; and was registered in the Nationwide Mortgage Licensing System and Registry as a loan originator during the 12-month period preceding the date of the required information. A state-licensed loan originator shall also be deemed to have temporary authority to act as a loan originator in an application state for a specified period if the loan originator: (1) meets certain requirements; (2) is employed by a state-licensed mortgage company in the application state; and (3) was licensed in another state during the 30-day period before submitting the information required in connection with the application to the

National Hate Crimes Hotline Act of 2016 This bill authorizes the Department of Justice (DOJ) to award grants to private, nonprofit entities for: (1) the establishment and operation of a national, toll-free telephone hotline to provide information and assistance to victims of hate crimes; and (2) the establishment and operation of a highly secure Internet website to provide that information and assistance to such victims.

Dietary Supplement Full Implementation and Enforcement Act of 2010 - Amends the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994 (DSHEA) to direct the Administrator of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to: (1) fully implement and enforce DSHEA and other laws governing the regulation of dietary supplements; and (2) establish a system for the reporting and enforcement of violations involving dietary supplements.

Amends the Social Security Act to provide that if the taxpayer treats an individual as not being an employee for any period after December 31, 2000, and the taxpayer meets certain consistency requirements, the taxpayer shall be treated as an employee for purposes of employment taxes and may elect to be treated as one instead of the other under current law.

Higher Education Affordability and Availability Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code (as revised by the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997) to exclude from income distributions from qualified tuition programs used for qualifying higher education expenses. Includes within the definition of qualified State tuition program" programs maintained by eligible educational institutions. Requires such non-State programs to limit annual contributions on behalf of a designated beneficiary to $5,000."

Puerto Rico Economic Activity Credit Improvement Act of 1999 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to modify the requirements for corporations to be eligible for the Puerto Rico economic activity credit. Requires that, in determining the credit amount, the credit provisions be applied separately to each substantial line of business of the corporation.
