Removes provisions limiting, in taxable years beginning after 2001, the aggregate taxable income taken into account in determining the amount of the credit. Terminates the credit four years after Puerto Rico has, for three consecutive years, unemployment under and per capita income over specified percentages of the United States rates.

National Defense Science and Technology Investment Act of 1998 - States that the purpose of this Act is to create a ten-year budget plan to support the disciplines, research, and concept of operations experimentation that will transform our military and reduce the threat from weapons of mass destruction early in the next century. Declares that it shall be an objective of the Secretary of Defense to increase the Defense Science and Technology Program budget by no less than 2.0 percent over inflation greater than the previous fiscal year's budget request. Requires that funds made available to the Program be used to benefit the Department of Defense, which includes: (1) the development of defense technology; (2) the development of military useful, commercial viable technology; or (3) the adaption of commercial technology, products, or processes for military purposes.

Amends the Victims of Crime Act of 1984 to require: (1) the court, at the request of a victim, to address personally any victim of the offense for which sentence is to be imposed and afford such victim the opportunity to make a statement and present information in relation to the sentence; and (2) a State to provide an effective system of notice to crime victims of the existence of compensation and other programs to assist such victims in which those victims might be eligible to participate. <n>Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to: (1) allow programs that allow for the physical and visual separation of a victim of crime from an alleged perpetrator of such crime while waiting in a judicial facility for a courtroom appearance; and (2) provide for a reduction of formula grants for noncompliance by States with such rights. <n>Directs the Attorney General to assure that Federal prosecutors and law enforcement officials provide an effective system of notice to crime victims of the existence of compensation and other programs to assist crime victims in which those victims might be eligible to participate.

Middle Class Tax Relief Act of 2006 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) allow a 10% tax reduction for taxpayers with adjusted gross incomes over $75,000 ($150,000 in the case of a joint return); (2) allow an additional $1,000 tax credit for each qualifying child; (3) eliminate the middle class tax surcharge for taxpayers with incomes over $1 million; and (4) increase and make permanent the tax deduction for certain expenses of elementary and secondary school teachers.

(Sec. 3) Includes an operator of an Internet Web site (including an agent of such operator) or other third party as a provider of secure on-line communications only if the disclosure is: (1) necessary to initiate, provide, bill, or collect for such service or for access to or use of such Internet Web site; (2) necessary to protect the rights or property of the provider; (3) made at the request of the subscriber or customer; (4) made with the affirmative consent of the subscriber or customer; or (5) required by law. Prohibits termination of the provision of service or access to or use of an Internet Web site to an individual who refuses to consent to such disclosure. Permits a provider of electronic communication service or remote computing service, operator of an Internet Web site, or third party from using, disclosing, or permitting access to aggregate customer or subscriber information from which individual customer or subscriber information and characteristics have been removed. Declares that nothing in this Act may be construed to prohibit a provider of electronic communication service or remote computing service, operator of an Internet Web site, or third party from using, disclosing, or permitting access to aggregate customer or subscriber information from which individual customer or subscriber information and characteristics have been removed.

Israel Anti- Boycott Act This bill opposes politically motivated boycotts against Israel and views such policies as actions to boycott, divest from, or sanction Israel. The bill amends the Export Administration Act of 1979 to declare that it shall be U.S. policy to oppose: requests by foreign countries to impose restrictive practices or boycotts against other countries friendly to the United States or against U.S. persons; and restrictive trade practices or boycotts fostered or imposed by an international governmental organization against Israel, or requests to impose such practices or boycotts, against Israel. The bill prohibits U.S. persons engaged in interstate or foreign commerce from: requesting the imposition of any boycott by a foreign country against Israel; or supporting any boycott fostered or imposed by an international organization against Israel, or requesting imposition of any such boycott, against Israel. The bill amends the Export-Import Bank Act of 1945 to include as a reason for the Export-Import Bank to deny credit applications for the export of goods and services between the United States and foreign countries, opposition to policies and actions that are politically motivated and are intended to penalize or otherwise limit commercial relations specifically with citizens or residents of Israel, entities organized under the laws of Israel, or the Government of Israel.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Flat Tax <n> Title II: Miscellaneous <n> Title III: Effective Dates <n>Flat Tax Act of 1995 - <n>Title I: Flat Tax <n> - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to revise the individual income tax. Establishes a 15 percent tax on the excess of the earned income of every individual over a basic standard exemption amount. Includes as earned income: (1) wages, salaries, and other employee compensation; (2) net earnings from self-employment; and (3) dividends from a personal service corporation or which are otherwise directly or indirectly compensation for services. Excludes tips and amounts received as a pension or annuity. <n>(Sec. 102) Repeals the tax deduction for home mortgage interest. <n>Title II: Miscellaneous <n>Title III: Effective Dates.

Strengthening Homeland Security, Intelligence, and Essential Law Enforcement Departments Act of 2011 or SHIELD Act of 2011- Requires the payment of the following obligations incurred by the United States if the total public debt reaches the public debt limit: (1) the pay and allowances of members of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, and Coast Guard who perform active service; and (2) the pay and allowances of critical law enforcement officers who are employed by federal agencies.

Specifies that if the interest rate in effect on the date on which the disclosure is made is a temporary rate that will change under a contractual provision applying an index or formula for subsequent interest rate adjustment, the creditor shall apply the interest rate in effect on the date on which the disclosure is made for as long as that interest rate will apply under that contractual provision, and then apply an interest rate based on the index or formula in effect on the applicable billing date.Directs the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to publish model disclosure forms in accordance with this Act.Amends the Truth in Lending Act to require a creditor, during the period of an open end consumer credit plan, if the creditor obtains a security interest in personal property purchased using that plan, to provide to the consumer, at the time of purchase, a written statement setting forth in a clear, conspicuous, and easy to read format: (1) the property in which the creditor will receive a security interest; (2) the nature and method of the security interest available to the creditor in the event of nonpayment; (3) the method in which payments made on the credit plan balance will be credited against the security interest taken; and (4) the following statement.Provides that any creditor making advances under an open end credit plan

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on July 9, 2014. Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act of 2013 - Amends the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2004 to prohibit an employer from discharging, demoting, suspending, harassing, or in any other manner discriminating against an employee, contractor, subcontractor, or agent of such employer (covered individual) who by a specified act: (1) provided information to the employer or the federal government relating to any violation of antitrust law or of another criminal law committed in conjunction with a potential violation of antitrust law or in conjunction with an antitrust investigation by the Department of Justice; or (2) filed, caused to be filed, testified, participated in, or otherwise assisted in an investigation or proceeding relating to such a violation. Makes such prohibition inapplicable if the covered individual planned and initiated: (1) a violation or attempted violation of antitrust law in conjunction with a violation or attempted violation of another criminal law, or (2) an obstruction to an investigation by the Department of Justice of such a violation. Authorizes a covered individual who alleges discharge or other discrimination by an employer in violation of such prohibition to seek relief: (1) by filing a complaint with the Secretary of Labor, or (2) if the Secretary has not issued a final decision

Title I: Antitrust and Criminal Provisions - Internet Freedom Act - (Sec. 101) States that evidence that an incumbent local exchange carrier that has market power in the broadband service provider market has willfully and knowingly failed to provide conditioned unbundled local when economically reasonable and technically feasible, or restrains unreasonably the ability of a carrier to compete in its provision of broadband services over a local loop, shall be sufficient to establish a presumption of such a violation. (Sec. 102) States that evidence that a broadband access transport provider that has market power in the broadband service provider market has offered access to a service provider on terms and conditions that are less favorable than those offered by such operator to itself, to an affiliated service provider, or to another service provider, or that restrains unreasonably the ability of a service provider from competing in its provision of broadband services, shall be sufficient to establish such a violation. (Sec. 103) Makes it unlawful for a broadband access transport provider to engage in unfair methods of competition, unfair or deceptive acts or practices, the purpose or effect of which is to discriminate in favor of a service provider that is affiliated with a broadband access transport provider or to restrain unreasonably the ability of a service provider that is not affiliated with such provider from competing in its provision of

Prohibits any product from bearing a label which states or suggests that it was made in America unless: (1) the product has been registered with the Department of Commerce; and (2) the Secretary of Commerce has determined that not less than 60 percent of the product was manufactured in the United States and final assembly of the product took place in the United States. Sets forth penalties for the fraudulent use of labels. <n>Amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to require additional foreign content marking on imported articles if such articles are assembled from parts that are not the product of one or more foreign countries that are not the country of origin. Sets forth civil penalties for the fraudulent use of labels. <n>Requires any product manufactured in the United States and assembled from any part that is the product of a foreign country to disclose in its labeling: (1) the country of origin of such part; and (2) the proportion of the cost of such product which is accounted for by such part.

District of Columbia Land Use Notification Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 to require the Administrator of the General Services Administration (GSA), not later than 60 days before carrying out any activity that affects real property in the District, to provide a notice describing such activity and the property affected to the Mayor of the District, the Chair of the Council of the District, and the Chair of the Advisory Neighborhood Commission in whose neighborhood such property is located and to provide such individuals with the opportunity to present oral or written comments before the Administrator carries out such activity. Authorizes the Administrator to waive such requirements if compliance would jeopardize the public safety or national security interests of the United States, but only if the Administrator: (1) certifies such finding and the reasons for such finding to the individuals and to the Congress; and (2) at the earliest time practicable, provides such individuals with the notice and the opportunity to present comments. <n>Prohibits any event at the William H. G. Fitzgerald Tennis Center at Rock Creek Park without the prior approval of the Director of the National Park Service and the Mayor.

Oil Subsidy Elimination for New Strategies on Energy Act or the Oil SENSE Act - Amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to repeal provisions relating to: (1) marginal property production incentives; (2) incentives for natural gas production from deep wells in the shallow waters of the Gulf of Mexico; (3) royalty relief for deep water production; (4) the inventory of Outer Continental Shelf oil and natural gas resources; (5) the management of federal oil and gas leasing programs; (6) ultra-deepwater and unconventional natural gas and other petroleum resources; and (7) Alaska offshore royalty suspension.<n><n>Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to direct the Secretary of the Interior to suspend the application of any provision of federal law under which a person would otherwise be provided relief from a requirement to pay a royalty for the production of oil or natural gas from federal land (including submerged land) occurring after enactment of this Act during any period in which: (1) for the production of oil, the average price of crude oil in the United States during the four weeks preceding the date of enactment of this Act is over $55 per barrel; or (2) for natural gas production from deep wells in the shallow waters of the Gulf of Mexico, the average price of natural gas during such period is over $10 per 1,000 cubic feet.<n><n>

Fair Gift Card Act of 2009 - Prohibits imposition of a dormancy fee, inactivity charge or fee, or a service fee with respect to a gift certificate, store gift card, or general-use prepaid card. Makes an exception with respect to a certificate or card that has a remaining value of $5 or less at the time the charge or fee is assessed.

Stop Any TARP Extension Act of 2009 - Amends the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 (EESA) to repeal the authority of the Secretary of the Treasury to purchase troubled assets through the Troubled Assets Relief Program (TARP).<n><n>Requires the Secretary to deposit in a Public Debt Reduction Payment Account all remaining funds available under TARP, as well as any amounts received by the Secretary for repayment of financial assistance, for payment of any interest on the receipt of such assistance by an entity that has received such financial assistance, including the Capital Purchase Program.<n><n>Requires the Secretary to use amounts in the Account to pay at maturity, or to redeem or buy before maturity, any obligation of the government held by the public and included in the public debt. Prohibits the reissuance of any obligation which is paid, redeemed, or bought with amounts from the Account.

Directs the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to commence actions to improve the TSA's process for vetting individuals with access to secure areas of vessels and maritime facilities, including: (1) conducting a comprehensive risk analysis of security threat assessment procedures, and (2) implementing identified best practices for quality assurance at every stage of such assessments and improving fraud detection techniques. Requires the Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to report to Congress on such actions and the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) to commission an assessment of the effectiveness of the transportation security card program at enhancing security and reducing security risks for maritime facilities.

Security Enhancement and Jobs Act of 2011 - (Sec. 2) Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) to approve within 120 days an airport operator's application for the provision of private screening services at an airport, unless the Secretary determines that such approval would compromise security, detrimentally affect the efficiency or effectiveness of the screening of passengers or property at the airport, or otherwise adversely affect the mission of the Transportation Security Administration (TSA). Requires the Secretary to: (1) provide an airport operator with a list of qualified private screening companies, within 60 days after approval of such application, except in a case in which the airport operator is competing to provide screening services; and (2) take into consideration an airport operator's recommendation as to which company would best serve the security screening and passenger needs of the airport. Requires the Secretary to reconsider any pending application for the screening of passengers and property that was submitted by an airport operator as of January 1, 2011, and has not been approved by the Secretary on or before this Act's enactment. Deems such an application approved.

Electronic Freedom of Information Act Amendments of 1996 - Amends the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) to require Federal agencies to include in their electronic format any information that would be an agency record subject to such Act, including information maintained in any format, including an electronic format. Specifies that: (1) the extent of any deletion of records which is made available or published shall be indicated on the portion of the record which is made available or published, unless including that indication would harm an interest protected by the exemption in which the deletion is made; (2) if technically feasible, the extent of the deletion shall be indicated at the place in the record where the deletion was made; and (3) copies of all records, regardless of form or format, which have been released to any person under FOIA and which the agency determines have become or are likely to become the subject of subsequent requests for substantially the same records, shall be made available by computer telecommunications by December 31, 1999. Specifies that, for records created on or after November 1, 1996, within one year after such date, each agency shall make such records available, including by computer telecommunications or, if computer telecommunications means have not been established by the agency, by other electronic means. Specifies that an agency shall: (1) provide the

Healthy Employees, Healthy Small Businesses Act of 2004 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow certain small employers (with between nine and 50 employees) a refundable tax credit for a specified percentage of the health insurance costs of their employees.

Fair American Corporate Tax Act or FACT Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) reduce the maximum corporate income tax rate to 28%; and (2) limit tax withholding benefits for certain deductible payments made between persons who are members of the same foreign controlled group of entities.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on December 16, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Protect Our Health Privacy Act - Amends the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to include in the report to Congress regarding any case of a breach of protected health information involving an entity that transmits health information in electronic form: (1) the number and nature of all such breaches; (2) the identity of the covered entity involved; (3) the kind of covered entity involved (such as a health plan, health care clearinghouse, or a health care provider who transmits any health information in electronic form in connection with a transaction covered by this Act); and (4) actions taken in response to such breaches. Requires information about complaints resolved informally to include: (1) the number of such complaints resolved informally; (2) a summary of the types of complaints so resolved; (3) the average amount of time between receipt of a complaint to resolution; (4) examples of complaints resolved informally and the Secretary's rationale for resolving them; and (5) the number of covered entities that received technical assistance to achieve compliance. Requires: (1) the number of state attorney general actions pursued pursuant to the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) and the

Alaska Natural Gas Pipeline Improvement Act of 2011 - Amends the Alaska Natural Gas Pipeline Act of 2004 to redefine Alaska Natural Gas Transportation Project" to include any natural gas pipeline system that carries Alaska natural gas to the border between Alaska and Canada, and any pipeline segment that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) finds could be incorporated into and serve as an integrated segment of such system."

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Expansion of Certain Wilderness Areas <n> Title II: Red Table Mountain Wilderness <n> Title III: Other Matters <n>Title I: Expansion of Certain Wilderness Areas <n> Title II: Red Table Mountain Wilderness <n>Title I: Expansion of Certain Wilderness Areas <n> - Amends the Colorado Wilderness Act of 1993 to designate specified lands in Summit and Gunnison Counties, Colorado, as wilderness and as components of the National Wilderness Preservation System. <n>Title II: Red Table Mountain Wilderness <n> - Designates specified lands in Eagle County, Colorado, as wilderness and as a component of the National Wilderness Preservation System, to be known as the Red Table Mountain Wilderness. <n>Directs the Secretary of the Interior to allow maintenance of rights-of-way and access roads located within the Red Table Mountain Wilderness Area to the extent necessary to operate a transmission line or electrical power line in a manner that avoids negative impacts on public safety and allows for compliance with State and Federal safety requirements. Directs the Colorado Army National Guard, through the High Independence Aviation Training Site, to continue to be allowed to conduct aerial navigation training exercises over and upon the lands within the Red Table Mountain Wilderness Area in a manner consistent with a specified memorandum of understanding entered into

Internet Tax Freedom Act - Prohibits any State or local government from imposing any tax or fee directly or indirectly on: (1) the Internet or interactive computer services; or (2) the use of such services. Declares that such prohibition does not apply to taxes imposed on and measured by net income derived from the Internet or interactive computer services, to apportioned business license taxes applied to businesses that have a business location in the taxing jurisdiction, and to impose a sales or use tax on sales or other transactions effected by use of the Internet or interactive computer services if: (1) the tax is the same as the tax imposed and collected by that State or political subdivision on sales or interstate transactions effected by mail order, telephone, or other remote means within its taxing jurisdiction; and (2) the obligation to collect the tax from sales or other transactions is imposed on the same person or entity as in the case of sales or transactions effected by mail order, telephone, or other remote means. Declares that the Secretaries of the Treasury, Commerce, or State, and the President, in consultation with appropriate committees of the Congress, consumer and business groups, and other appropriate groups, shall: (1) undertake an examination of U.S. domestic and international taxation of the Internet and interactive computer services, if any

Railroad Infrastructure Financing Improvement Act of 1997- Amends Federal transportation law to authorize the Secretary of Transportation to provide direct loans and loan guarantees to State and local governments, government sponsored authorities and corporations, and railroad carriers. Declares that such loans and loan guarantees shall be used to: (1) acquire, improve, or rehabilitate rail equipment or facilities; (2) refinance outstanding debt incurred for such purposes; or (3) develop or establish new railroad facilities. Prohibits the use of such loans and loan guarantees for railroad operating expenses. Directs the Secretary, in granting applications for such loans or loan guarantees, to give priority to projects that: (1) enhance public safety; (2) enhance the environment; (3) promote economic development; (4) enable U.S. companies to be more competitive in international markets; (5) are endorsed by State or State approved plans; or (6) preserve rail service to small communities or rural areas.

Preparing Teachers for Digital Age Learners Act of 2008 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to award grants to, or enter into agreements with, eligible consortia to pay the federal share of costs of projects to: (1) graduate teacher candidates who are prepared to use modern information, communication, and learning tools to improve student learning, assessment, and learning management; and (2) help students develop skills to succeed in higher education and enter the workforce. Defines eligible consortium" to mean a consortium of members that includes: (1) at least one institution of higher education that awards baccalaureate or masters degrees and prepares teachers for initial entry into teaching; (2) at least one state educational agency or local educational agency; (3) a department, school, or college of arts and sciences at an institution of higher education; (4) a department, school, or college of arts and sciences at an institution of higher education; or (5) at least one entity with the capacity to contribute to the technology-related reform of teacher preparation programs.<n><n>Requires an eligible consortium to use funds made available under this Act to carry out a project that: (1) develops long-term partnerships among members that are focused on effective teaching with modern digital tools and content that substantially connect pre-service preparation of teacher candidates with"

District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act - Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to issue during 2009 redesigned quarter dollars commemorating the District of Columbia and the U.S. Territories, including the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands.

FEMA Common Sense and Cost Effectiveness Act of 2011 - Amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act and the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 to authorize the President, if financial assistance is used to acquire or accept property for open space purposes, to permit the construction or maintenance on the property of: (1) a levee that is federally owned and operated; (2) a permanent levee that is federally constructed and non-federally operated and maintained; (3) a levee that is a nonpermanent levee that a non-federal entity desires to operate and maintain as a permanent levee; and (4) the owners of which are participating in the emergency response to natural disasters program or who are participating in the flood mitigation assistance program, if the levee poses a significant threat of harm to downstream communities.

Directs the Attorney General to establish a National Task Force on Violence against Women to: (1) develop a uniform Federal, State, and local law enforcement strategy aimed at protecting women against violent crime, punishing persons who commit such crimes, and enhancing the rights of victims; and (2) report to the Attorney General on such strategy.

Path to Success: Gang Prevention through Community Partnerships Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award grants to community colleges to enter into and maintain partnerships with juvenile detention centers and secure juvenile justice residential facilities to provide assistance, services, and education to eligible individuals who reenter the community and pursue, in accordance with this Act, at least one of the following: (1) a certificate of graduation from a school providing secondary education, a general equivalency diploma (GED), or another recognized equivalent of such a certificate or diploma; (2) a certificate of completion for a specialized area of study, such as vocational training and other alternative post-secondary educational programs; and (3) an associate's degree.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: Labor Provisions <n> Title II: Other Provisions <n>Small Business Emancipation Act of 1996 - <n>Title I: Labor Provisions <n> Title II: Other Provisions <n>Small Business Emancipation Act of 1996 - <n>Title I: Labor Provisions <n> - Provides that the regular rate" at which an employee of a small business concern is employed shall not be deemed to include sums paid in recognition of services performed during a given period if the payments are made to reward an employee or group of employees for meeting or exceeding the productivity, quality, efficiency, or sales goals as specified in a gainsharing, incentive bonus, commission, or performance contingent bonus plan. <n>(Sec. 102) Provides that: (1) an employee of a small business concern may receive compensatory time off at a rate not less than one-half hours for each hour of employment for which overtime compensation is required; (2) an employer may provide such compensatory time only pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement, memorandum of understanding, or any other agreement between the employer and employee; (3) an employee may accrue not more than 240 hours of compensatory time; (4) an employee shall be provided monetary compensation for any compensatory time off accrued during the preceding calendar year which was not used prior"

21st Century Veterans Equitable Treatment Act - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to establish a maximum specialist referral period of 30 days between the date that a veteran is referred to a specialty clinic of the Department of Veterans Affairs health care system and the date for which the veteran is scheduled for an appointment with a Department specialist. Directs the Secretary to: (1) reimburse the provider for the reasonable value of such care or services; and (2) ensure that the Department is able to provide appropriate transportation services for qualified veterans within a reasonable time period of a scheduled appointment.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2016. Moving to Work Reform Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill prohibits the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) from entering into or extending any Moving to Work agreement for any public housing agency (PHA) for participation in the demonstration established under the Departments of Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development, and Independent Agencies Appropriations Act, 1996 unless such agreement is subject to specified terms and conditions, including that: the policy change will be subject to a detailed evaluation using a rigorous research methodology which includes, at least in part, random assignment to treatment and control groups to compare the impact on assisted families (including families that cease to receive assistance during the term of the evaluation) to similar families not subject to such policy change; and HUD determines that adequate federal or other resources are available to undertake the required evaluation. A PHA may use funds appropriated for renewal of tenant-based rental assistance only for payments to or on behalf of eligible families that assist them with housing costs, except that up to 10% of such funds may be used for other eligible purposes. A PHA shall receive funding for renewal of tenant-based rental assistance determined using the same formula applied to public housing agencies that do

Reward Innovation in America Act This bill establishes in the Department of Commerce a National Innovation Prizes Board to develop and administer a program of competitions to award innovation prizes to eligible individuals and entities to advance the research, development, and commercial application of innovative technologies. The board shall: (1) determine the research topics for competitions, (2) select the research topics for competitions, (3) determine the amount of the innovation prize for each competition, and (4) determine the annual funding requirement for each competition.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 10, 2015. Seniors' Health Care Plan Protection Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to delay until the end of 2018 the authority of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services to terminate a Medicare Advantage (MA) plan contract solely on the basis of its performance under the five-star rating system. (Sec. 3) The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) must revise the Medicare Advantage risk adjustment system, including by taking into account the number of chronic conditions with which an individual has been diagnosed, and by evaluating the impact of: including two years of data to compare the models used to determine risk scores for 2013 and 2014, removing the diagnosis codes related to chronic kidney disease in the 2014 risk adjustment model, and including 10% of encounter data in computing payment for 2016 and CMS readiness to incorporate encounter data in risk scores. In conducting such evaluations and analyses, CMS must: (1) use data collected as encounter data on or after January 1, 2012, to analyze such data for accuracy and completeness, and (2) ensure that the data reflects the degree and cost of care coordination under MA plans.

Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to transfer certain naval vessels to: (1) Brazil, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, and Egypt; (2) Greece, Mexico, and Poland; (3) the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office of the United States in Taiwan; and (4) Turkey. Declares that such transfers shall not be counted for purposes of the limitation on the aggregate value of excess defense articles transferred to countries under this Act in any fiscal year.

Volunteer Firefighter and EMS Support Act of 2008 - Amends the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish a program to provide funds to a state or local government, non-profit firefighter association, or governmental or nongovernmental emergency medical services organization that carries out a volunteer firefighter incentive program. Defines volunteer firefighter" as an individual who provides firefighting service or emergency medical service to a state or local government or a governmental or nongovernmental organization without pay. Permits a volunteer firefighter to receive benefits or incentives for firefighting service or emergency medical service, including retirement benefits, reimbursement for travel and training, health insurance or other health benefits, life insurance, tuition or school loan forgiveness, a tax reduction, and any other approved benefit or incentive approved by the Administrator of the United States Fire Administration."

Roosevelt Lake Recreation Area Fee Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to collect recreation use fees and sell recreation use passes at designated recreation sites within the Roosevelt Lake Recreation Area in the Tonto National Forest, Arizona.

Preventing Illegal Radio Abuse Through Enforcement Act or the PIRATE Act Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prescribe increased fines for: (1) willfully and knowingly doing or causing or suffering to be done pirate radio broadcasting; and (2) knowingly and intentionally facilitating such broadcasting. Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to: (1) assign appropriate enforcement personnel to focus specific and sustained attention on the elimination of pirate radio broadcasting within the top five radio markets identified as prevalent for such broadcasts; and (2) conduct monitoring sweeps to ascertain whether the pirate radio broadcasting identified by such sweeps is continuing to broadcast and whether additional pirate radio broadcasting is occurring. Prohibits the FCC from decreasing or diminishing regular enforcement efforts targeted to pirate radio broadcast stations for other times of the year. Requires the FCC to revise its rules to require that it proceed directly to issue a Notice of Apparent Liability" without first issuing a "Notice of Unlicensed Operations." Directs the FCC to publish semiannually a database of all licensed radio stations operating in the AM and FM bands."

Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the United States should raise at the United Nations (U.N.) the issue of Israel's blockade of Gaza and support international efforts to end such blockade; (2) the United States should support the efforts of Israel's allies in Europe and Asia to end the Israeli blockade; and (3) the United States should support a comprehensive and independent U.N. investigation into the May 2010 Israeli raid on the vessels of the IHH and other specified organizations.<n><n>Prohibits FY2012 appropriations for any U.S. department or agency from being used to purchase any vessel that, during the period beginning on May 31, 2010, or before the date of enactment of this Act, participated in a flotilla organized by IHH or other specified organizations, or any of its agents or affiliates, in order to breach the Israeli blockade.

Prohibits the Department of Energy (DOE) from having any regulatory or enforcement authority with respect to nuclear safety and occupational safety and health responsibilities assumed by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) or the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at any nonmilitary DOE energy laboratory. Declares that a contractor operating a DOE nonmilitary energy laboratory shall not be responsible for the costs of decommissioning that facility. Prohibits any enforcement action against such contractor for any violation of NRC decommissioning requirements, if such violation is the result of DOE failure to authorize or fund decommissioning activities. Directs DOE and the NRC, within one year after enactment of this Act, to enter into a memorandum of understanding establishing decommissioning procedures and requirements for such laboratories. Grants the NRC exclusive regulatory authority over accelerators, other electronic sources of radiation not assigned to the NRC, accelerator-produced radioisotopes, and naturally occurring radioactive materials at such laboratories.

Tax Relief and Fulfilling Our Obligation to Patriotic Soldiers Act of 2007 [sic] - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income: (1) enlistment, accession, reenlistment, retention, incentive, or other bonus paid by the Secretary concerned to a member of the Armed Forces in exchange for the member's agreement to accept a commission as an officer, extend an active service commitment as an officer, enlist, reenlist, or extend an enlistment as an enlisted member in an active or reserve component; or (2) certain combat-related disabilities for members retired or separated due to a combat-related injury. Directs the Secretary of Defense to require the continued payment of any such bonus or disability payment to a member who: (1) was entitled to immediately before the retirement or separation; and (2) would continue to be entitled to if the member was not retired or separated.

Establishes a Board of Inquiry into the September 11, 2001 Terrorist Attacks. Directs the Board to: (1) study matters relating to the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Centers in New York and the Pentagon, and the hijackings which proceeded the attacks; and (2) report to Congress on its work and its recommendations for legislation and administrative actions.

GI Bill Processing Improvement Act Directs the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), for each veteran or other individual pursuing a course of education using veterans' educational assistance, to make available to the educational institution offering the course information about the amount of such assistance. Extends through December 31, 2022, the authority of the VA Advisory Committee on Education. Revises requirements regarding the use of reporting fees paid to educational institutions and joint apprenticeship training committees by the VA. Requires such fees to be used solely for the making of certifications required for such institutions or committees. Directs the VA to set forth requirements relating to training for school certifying officials employed by such institutions offering approved veterans educational assistance courses. Authorizes appropriations for VA readjustment benefit programs.

Skills Connection Act This bill requires the Department of Labor to create a publicly available, easily navigable, and searchable database containing: (1) a registry of credentials, (2) a skills database, and (3) a jobs bank to enable programs that lead to such a credential to receive priority under specified covered provisions of the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 and the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006.

Santa Cruz Valley National Heritage Area Act - Establishes the Santa Cruz Valley National Heritage Area in Arizona. Designates the Santa Cruz Valley Heritage Alliance, Inc., as the management entity for the Area. Requires the Alliance to prepare and submit a management plan for the Area.

Supporting America's Protective Security Advisor Act of 2007 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to establish within the Protective Security Coordination Division of the Office of Infrastructure Protection a Protective Security Advisor Program Office. Grants the Office primary responsibility and authority for: (1) encouraging state, local, and tribal governments and private sector owners and operators of critical infrastructure and key resources to participate and collaborate within the risk management framework of the National Infrastructure Protection Plan; (2) coordinating national and intergovernmental critical infrastructure and key resource activities with state, local, and tribal governments and owners and operators of critical infrastructure or key resources; (3) facilitating and conducting requirements, capabilities, and risk assessment analyses that enhance critical infrastructure and key resources preparedness; (4) promoting information sharing and security awareness, particularly with state homeland security advisors and private sector security officials; (5) assisting state, local, and tribal governments in developing multi-jurisdictional security plans; (6) helping to ensure ongoing coordination between federal, state, and tribal governments, owners and operators of critical infrastructure or key resources, emergency response providers, and related agencies; (7) serving as infrastructure liaison officials to advise the designated Principal Federal Official on issues dealing with nationally critical infrastructure when a joint field office is activated in response to a natural disaster or terrorist event; and (8) facilitating and coordinating interaction with international security
Medicare Home Infusion Site of Care Act of 2014 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for Medicare coverage of home infusion therapy.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 6, 2017. Wi-Fi Innovation Act (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to modify regulations regarding the allocation and use of electromagnetic spectrum used by dedicated short-range communications services to provide additional unlicensed spectrum in the 5850-5925 MHz band, under technical rules suitable for the widespread commercial development of unlicensed operations in the band, by cooperating with the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA). The NTIA shall facilitate such modification by cooperating with the FCC to identify the spectrum management actions necessary to accommodate such regulatory changes. The FCC's Office of Engineering and Technology must issue a public notice seeking comment on proposals for: interference-mitigation techniques and technologies, and potential rechannelization, that would accommodate both incumbent licensees, including Dedicated Short Range Communications Services licensees, and widespread commercial unlicensed operations in the band; and deployment timelines for the technologies. The NTIA must submit to the FCC a description of any current and anticipated further federal uses of the band. The FCC must: (1) develop and publish a test plan for the use of unlicensed devices in the band, including a timeline to migrate safety or shared spectrum technologies, and (2) evaluate whether non-exclusive licensing or other

Climate Resiliency, Security, and Source Water Protection Act This bill amends the Safe Drinking Water Act to revise requirements for source water and distribution system vulnerability assessments and source water and distribution system protection plans. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) must establish a Drinking Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Program to award grants to owners or operators of community water systems to increase their resiliency or adaptability to threats to their source water and distribution systems.

Civil Rights Commission Act of 1998 - Amends the Civil Rights Commission Act of 1983 (the Act) to reauthorize the Civil Rights Commission through FY 2001. <n>(Sec. 3) Provides a four-year term of office for the Commission's Staff Director. Requires the Commission to annually review the performance of the Staff Director. <n>(Sec. 4) Requires the Commission to: (1) apply the Freedom of Information Act and the Privacy Act of 1974 as if it were a Federal agency; and (2) have an independent external auditor audit. <n>(Sec. 6) Extends from six to five years the terms of Commission members. <n>(Sec. 7) Requires the Commission to report annually to the Congress on: (1) the policies and practices of public schools to determine whether laws are being effectively enforced to prevent discrimination or the denial of equal protection of the law based on religion, and whether such laws need to be changed in order to protect more fully the constitutional and civil rights of students and of teachers and other school employees; (2) review the enforcement activities of Federal agencies, including the Departments of Justice and Education, to determine if those agencies are properly protecting the religious freedom in schools; and (3) report regarding the enforcement of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA

Spending Reduction Act This bill requires the head of each executive agency to submit to the President and Congress a report on the implementation of recommendations made by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) reports entitled "Opportunities to Reduce Potential Duplication in Government Programs, Save Tax Dollars, and Enhance Revenue" in March 2011, "Opportunities to Reduce Duplication, Overlap and Fragmentation, Achieve Savings, and Enhance Revenue" in February 2012, and "Actions Needed to Reduce Fragmentation, Overlap, and Duplication and Enhance Revenue" in April 2013. Each report shall include: a discussion by the head of the executive agency of matters on which the agency agrees, disagrees, or partially agrees with GAO, and recommendations by the agency head for actions that should be taken in the agency as a result of such reports; an opinion by the Comptroller General on whether each such recommendation is consistent with the GAO reports; a proposal for legislative changes, if any, necessary to implement such recommendations; a statement of the annual impact on costs to the federal government, including cost savings, expected to occur as a result of implementation of such recommendations; and other appropriate information. The head of each executive agency shall begin to implement the recommendations submitted in such report

Aviation Safety Enhancement Act of 2008 - Establishes in the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) an Aviation Safety Whistleblower Investigation Office to receive and assess complaints and information relating to possible violations of aviation safety laws and regulations. Directs the Secretary of Transportation to appoint the Director of such Office, who shall make recommendations for further investigation or corrective actions.

Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor Act of 1998 - Authorizes the President to award, and present in the name of the Congress, a Medal of Valor to a public safety officer cited by the Attorney General, on the advice of the Medal of Valor Review Board, for extraordinary valor above and beyond the call of duty. <n>Establishes a permanent Medal of Valor Review Board to: (1) select candidates to receive the Medal from among applications received by the National Medal Office; and (2) present the name or names of those it recommends as Medal of Valor recipients to the Attorney General. Requires the Board to set an annual timetable for fulfilling its duties. <n>(Sec. 4) Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) compensation; and (2) confidentiality.

Antiboycott Act - Provides that it is U.S policy to: (1) oppose restrictive trade practices or boycotts fostered or imposed by foreign countries against other countries friendly to the United States or against any U.S. person; (2) encourage and require U.S. persons engaged in the export of goods or technology or other information to refuse to take actions which have the effect of furthering or supporting such boycotts; and (3) foster international cooperation and the development of international rules and institutions to assure reasonable access to world supplies. Directs the Secretary of Commerce to issue regulations prohibiting any U.S. person from taking or knowingly agreeing to take specified actions with intent to comply with, further, or support any boycott fostered or imposed by a foreign country against a country that is friendly to the United States and is not itself the object of any form of boycott pursuant to U.S. law or regulation.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 6, 2003. The summary has been expanded because action occurred on the measure.)Workers\\' Political Rights Act - Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 (FECA) to exclude from the definition of contribution or expenditure" (as defined for the purposes of such Act) any contributions or expenditures by a labor organization in connection with any political committee, unless the labor organization provides, at least once annually, a written notification to all its employees within its bargaining unit or units that: (1) an employee cannot be obligated to pay for labor organization political activities, including the maintenance and operation of, or solicitation of contributions to, a political committee, political communications to members, and voter registration and get-out-the-vote campaigns; (2) no employee may be required actually to join any labor organization, but if a collective bargaining agreement covering an employee purports to require membership or payment of dues or other fees to a labor organization as a condition of employment, the employee may elect instead to pay an agency fee to the labor organization; (3) the amount of the agency fee shall be limited to the employee\\'s pro rata share of the cost of the labor organization\\'s exclusive representation services"

Nazi Benefits Termination Act of 2001 - Denies Federal public benefits to individuals who have been participants in Nazi persecution. Authorizes the Attorney General, if an individual who has applied for or is receiving a Federal public benefit may have been such a participant, to provide an opportunity for a hearing on the record with respect to the matter. Allows the Attorney General to delegate the conduct of the hearing to an immigration judge.Describes hearing procedures under this Act. Requires an immigration judge who finds that the respondent has been a participant in Nazi persecution to: (1) promptly issue an order declaring the respondent to be ineligible for any Federal public benefit and prohibiting any person from providing such a benefit to the respondent; and (2) transmit a copy of such order to any governmental entity or person known to be so providing such a benefit.

Telecommunications Trust Act of 1998 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to terminate the contributions of providers of interstate telecommunications services to the Advanced Telecommunications Trust Fund (established by this Act). Directs that such funds constitute the exclusive source of funds for the provision of any type of Federal universal service support, including rural, high-cost, lifeline, programs or any other program of Federal universal service support. <n>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish the Telecommunications Trust Fund. Appropriates to such Fund amounts equivalent to 100 percent of the taxes received in the Treasury after December 31, 1998.

Internet Freedom Preservation Act - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require each broadband service provider (provider) to: (1) not block, interfere with, discriminate against, impair, or degrade the ability of any person to use a broadband service to access, use, send, post, receive, or offer any lawful content, application, or service made available via the Internet; (2) prevent or obstruct a user from attaching or using any device to the provider's network only if such device does not physically damage or substantially degrade the use of such network by other subscribers; (3) provide and make available to each user information about the user's access to the Internet and the speed, nature, and limitations of such user's broadband service; (4) enable any content, application, or service made available via the Internet to be offered, provided, or posted on a basis that is reasonable and nondiscriminatory, including with respect to quality of service, access, speed, and bandwidth; (5) not impose a charge on the basis of the type of content, applications, or services made available via the Internet into the provider's network; (6) only prioritize content, applications, or services accessed by a user that is made available via the Internet within the provider's network based on the type of

Great Lakes Water Protection Act This bill amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (commonly known as the Clean Water Act) to prohibit a publicly owned treatment works (POTW) from intentionally diverting waste streams to bypass any portion of a treatment facility if the diversion is: (1) unavoidable to prevent loss of life, personal injury, or severe property damage; (2) there is no feasible alternative; and (3) the treatment works provides notice of the bypass, or the bypass does not cause effluent limitations to be exceeded and is for essential maintenance to ensure efficient operation of the treatment facility. The requirement that the bypass be unavoidable is not satisfied if adequate back-up equipment should have been installed in the exercise of reasonable engineering judgment to prevent the bypass and it occurred during normal periods of equipment downtime or preventive maintenance. A POTW must provide: (1) prior notice of an anticipated bypass and notice of an unanticipated bypass within 24 hours following the time the treatment works first becomes aware of the bypass; and (2) follow-up notices within 5 days following the date on which the treatment works first becomes aware of the bypass. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or a state with an approved permit program must post all such notices provided or received in a searchable database accessible on the Internet. The maximum civil penalty for a violation of

Caregiver Assistance and Resource Enhancement Act - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to develop and carry out a program for caregivers and family caregivers that includes: (1) educational sessions, stipends, and access to support services; (2) counseling and other services; (3) respite care; and (4) medical care. Defines caregiver" as an individual who: (1) provides caregiver services to a disabled veteran who is enrolled in the VA health care system; and (2) is not a member of the veteran\\'s family.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to make available educational sessions for caregivers, family caregivers, and individuals who provide them with support through an aging network. Requires such educational sessions to: (1) be made available both in person and on an Internet website; (2) incorporate available technology; and (3) teach techniques, strategies, and skills for caring for a disabled veteran, including a veteran who was deployed in support of Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom and who has post-traumatic stress disorder, a traumatic brain injury, or other severe injury or illness."

Permit Reassurances Enabling Direct Improvements for Conservation, Tenants, and Species Act of 2018 or the PREDICTS Act of 2018 This bill amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to prohibit the Department of the Interior from revoking a permit issued under the Act or any candidate conservation agreement (conserved habitat areas) unless it finds that continuation of the permitted activity would be inconsistent with specified criteria or the inconsistency has not been remedied in a timely fashion. Each permit issued by Interior and each candidate conservation agreement shall contain assurances addressing changed circumstances and unforeseen circumstances that: (1) are deemed necessary to respond to changed circumstances, and (2) are specified in the operating conservation program of the plan for the permit or in the agreement.

Directs the Institute to establish a pilot program to provide such manufacturers and businesses with the information they need to make informed decisions in utilizing electronic commerce-related goods and services.

Mining Claim Maintenance Act of 2001 - Directs holders of certain unpatented mining claims, mill or tunnel sites, to pay to the Secretary of the Interior, on or before August 31 of each year, a claim maintenance fee of $100 per claim, in lieu of the assessment work requirement contained in the general mining laws and the related filing requirements of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. Makes this Act inapplicable to any oil shale claims for which a fee is required to be paid under the Energy Policy Act of 1992.Authorizes the Secretary to waive the claim maintenance fee for a claimant who certifies in writing that on the date the payment was due, the claimant and all related parties: (1) had filed a patent application with the Secretary on or before September 30, 1994; and (2) had fully complied with certain Revised Statutes requirements for vein or lode claims, placer claims, and mill site claims.Allows a claimant to elect to perform the assessment work required under the general mining laws in lieu of paying the maintenance fee if the claimant and all related parties: (1) are producing hard rock minerals under a valid notice or plan of operation which production results in not less than $1,500 and not more than $800,000 in gross revenues per year from a total of ten or fewer claims; (2) are performing

Federal Employee Short-Term Disability Insurance Act of 2011- Requires the Director of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to establish and administer a program to make insurance coverage available for: (1) an injury or disability not covered under federal employee worker's compensation provisions; (2) leave to care for, or leave to make arrangements to care for, a member of family, including the birth of a son or daughter; and (3) leave to make arrangements to adopt a child or to become a foster parent. Prohibits such insurance if the injury or disability is: (1) caused by willful misconduct; (2) caused by the employee's intention to bring about such injury or disability to himself or to another individual; or (3) proximately caused by the intoxication of such employee. Requires the Director to contract with one or more carriers for such disability insurance policies.

Cesar Chavez National Historical Park Act This bill establishes the Cesar Chavez National Historical Park within the National Park System in California and Arizona as a unit of the system. The Department of the Interior may acquire lands and interests within the park's boundary and may enter into cooperative agreements with the states, local governments, public and private organizations, and individuals to mark, interpret, preserve, and nationally restore historic or cultural resources relating to the life of Cesar Chavez or the history of the farm worker movement.

Directs the Secretary of Education to pay Fort Lewis College in Colorado an amount equal to the charges for tuition for students who are not residents of that state but are enrolled in Fort Lewis College for the academic year ending before the beginning of such fiscal year. Limits that payment each fiscal year to the amount by which the college exceeds the amount paid to Colorado for the same academic year.

Positive Train Control Safety Act This bill extends the deadline for submission to the Department of Transportation (DOT) by a Class I railroad carrier and each entity providing regularly scheduled intercity or commuter rail passenger transportation of a plan for implementing positive train control (PTC) systems. (A PTC system is a communications and signaling system designed to prevent train-to-train collisions, over-speed derailments, incursions into established work zone limits, and the movement of a train through a switch left in the wrong position. Railroads which carry passengers or have high-volume freight traffic with certain hazardous materials are required to implement a PTC system.) DOT may extend the implementation deadline for an applicant whose application is under review, but may not extend the deadline beyond June 30, 2016. Each Class I railroad carrier and each entity providing regularly scheduled intercity or commuter rail passenger transportation must submit annually to DOT a plan on the status of PTC implementation. DOT must: (1) publish on its website a summary of each progress report, and (2) approve or disapprove each plan submitted.

Rebuilding Equity Act of 2013 - Directs the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) (government sponsored enterprises or GSEs) each to establish a voluntary program under which they shall pay $1,000 toward the closing costs associated with applying for and receiving the refinancing of a mortgage with a term of not longer than 20 years for borrowers who: (1) qualify for the Home Affordable Refinance Program carried out by the GSEs, whose subject property has a loan-to-value ratio of not less than 105 percent; and (2) refinances from a loan with an original term of 30 years to a loan with a term of 20 years or less.

Protecting Pregnant Women and Children From Perchlorate Act of 2011 - Amends the Safe Drinking Water Act to require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to publish a health advisory for perchlorate that: (1) is fully protective of the body weight and exposure patterns of pregnant women, infants, and children; (2) provides an adequate margin of safety; and (3) takes into account all routes of exposure to perchlorate. Requires the Administrator also to establish a national primary drinking water regulation for perchlorate that fully protects such vulnerable persons, taking into consideration body weight, exposure patterns, and all routes of exposure to perchlorate.

National Childhood Brain Prevention Network Act of 2008 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to establish the National Childhood Brain Prevention Network to: (1) coordinate national research efforts regarding childhood brain tumors; (2) provide grants to eligible consortia to conduct research with respect to the causes of and risk factors associated with childhood brain tumors; and (3) designate a central laboratory to collect, analyze, and aggregate data with respect to such research.

Rural Broadband Access Enhancement Act - Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to revise the definition of eligible rural community" to include any area of the United States: (1) not included within the boundaries of any city, town, borough, or village with a population of more than 20,000 inhabitants, (2) not in the urbanized area contiguous and adjacent to such a city, town, borough, or village, and (3) the average median household income of which is not more than 80% of the national average median household income.<n><n>Prohibits the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) from approving an application submitted for a loan or loan guarantee for the provision of new broadband service to: (1) an area in which at least 40% of the population does not have access to broadband service, unless the value of the applicant\\'s assets not pledged or hypothecated for any other purpose equals at least 10% of the principal amount of the loan; or (2) any other area, unless the value of such assets equals at least 15% of the principal amount of the loan involved.<n><n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) take such steps as are necessary to reduce the paperwork required of applicants; and (2) conduct outreach to inform the population of areas in which there is no or limited broadband service of"

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 2, 2017. Security Clearance Family Review Act (Sec. 3) This bill requires the President to establish within the Office of White House Executive Office the process for reviewing security clearances for relatives of the President. The bill prohibits federal agencies from granting security clearance access to a relative of the President unless a favorable determination is submitted to the head of the agency. The bill specifies the process for determining whether a relative is ineligible for access to security clearances because of: (1) ongoing and privately owned foreign enterprises or substantial commercial relationships with state-owned or foreign financial institutions; or (2) financial institutions with which the relative has a financial relationship. The Department of Defense must submit a determination of whether a relative is ineligible for access to security clearances because of such relationships to the President, agency head, and specified congressional committees.

Declares that Cape Fox Corporation shall not be required under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to select or receive conveyance of specified land. Permits Cape Fox to select and the Secretary of the Interior to convey specified additional Tongass National Forest land outside the exterior selection boundary of Cape Fox.Directs the Secretary to convey to Sealaska Corporation the subsurface estate to specified National Forest land to be conveyed to Cape Fox.

Designates the structure of the Gateway Arch and the Old St. Louis Courthouse as National Historic Landmarks and the grounds of the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial as National Register of Historic Places. Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to enter into agreements with the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial Trust to: plan and develop the St. Louis riverfront between Eads and Poplar Street bridges, the Memorial grounds including the interstate highway and roadways now traversing them, Luther Ely Smith Square, and the Old Courthouse as a single project area, and facilitate the planning, construction, and operation of a cultural facility on federal land within the boundary of the Memorial to enhance the visitor experience and for exhibitions, learning and interpretation associated with American migration, and other terms and conditions the Secretary determines necessary.

Department of Defense Office of the Victim Advocate Act of 2004 - Establishes in the Office of the Secretary of Defense an Office of the Victim Advocate which shall have responsibility for coordination of programs and activities of the military departments to the extent that they relate to victims of interpersonal violence among members of the armed forces or between members of the armed forces and family members and partners (including former spouses, children, significant others, children-in-common, girl friends, and boy friends). Defines victim" as a person who is the victim of sexual misconduct or interpersonal violence which: (1) is carried out by another member of the armed forces or a family member or intimate partner; and (2) is carried out by a family member or intimate partner of that person. Requires the Director of the Office to carry out coordination functions, including: (1) coordinating programs and activities of the military departments relative to care, services, and treatment for victims; (2) serving as headquarters program manager for the victim advocates and the victim service specialists in the Department of Defense; and (3) coordinating services for victims among military and civilian communities and providing guidance to victims in obtaining those services. Requires the Director to: (1) evaluate the prevalence of interpersonal violence associated with members of the armed forces; (2) evaluate the programs established by the military departments"

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on December 7, 2016. San Juan County Settlement Implementation Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill authorizes the Department of the Interior to retire any coal preference right lease application for which it has made an affirmative commercial quantities determination: (1) by issuing bidding rights in exchange for relinquishment of such application; and (2) by making a payment to the relevant state in an amount equal to 50% of the dollar amount of any bidding right subsequently used in lieu of any monetary payment of a bonus in a coal lease sale or of rental or royalty under a federal coal lease. Interior shall make such payments from amounts that would otherwise be deposited in the Treasury. A payment to a state shall be treated as a payment under the Mineral Leasing Act. A bidding right issued under this bill shall be fully transferable to any other person. Such bidding right shall terminate five years after it is issued. The tolling of such period shall be tolled during any period in which exercise of such bidding right is precluded by temporary injunctive relief granted under, or administrative, legislative, or judicial suspension of, the federal coal leasing program. (Sec. 3) The Navajo Nation may make new land selections under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act Selected

Port Threat and Security Act - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to report annually to specified congressional committees on all nations whose flag vessels have entered United States ports in the previous year, including a separate list of those nations whose registered flag vessels appear as Priority III or higher on the Priority Matrix maintained by the Coast Guard.Directs the Secretary to establish a program to place sea marshals on vessels entering United States ports identified as requiring: (1) the presence of port facilities that handle hazardous or flammable materials that make them potential targets of attack; (2) the proximity of such facilities to residential or other densely populated areas; and (3) the proximity of sea lanes or navigational channels to hazardous areas that would pose a danger to citizens in the event of a loss of navigational control by the ship's master.Directs the Secretary to report to such committees on: (1) the effectiveness of the security measures maintained at each foreign seaport served by U.S. vessels, from which foreign vessels serve the United States, or that pose a high risk of the danger to international sea travel; and (2) the potential for increasing the capabilities of sea pilots to provide information on maritime domain awareness.Authorizes appropriations.

(Sec. 102) Directs the Secretaries of Commerce and the Interior to study and report to Congress on: (1) if the distribution success classes in the Atlantic striped bass population appropriate for maintaining adequate recruitment and sustainable fishing opportunities; and (2) the results of peer-reviewed research funded under the Act.Authorizes appropriations for FY 2001 through 2005 under the Atlantic Coastal Fisheries Cooperative Management Act to carry out a report that includes information regarding: (1) the structure of the Atlantic striped bass population required to maintain adequate recruitment and sustainable fishing opportunities; and (2) measures necessary to achieve such population structure.(Sec. 202) Amends the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 to rename the John H.Stevens Fishery Assistance Grant Program the John H.Stevens Mammal Rescue Grant Program, requiring annual reports from the Secretary of Commerce to specified congressional committees on the use of assistance under such Act. Authorizes appropriations for FY 2001 through 2005.

Amends the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act to repeal provisions prohibiting an Indian tribe or Native Hawaiian organization from owning or controlling a cultural item discovered or excavated on Aboriginal lands after November 16, 1990, unless such item was reasonably recorded according to generally accepted scientific standards and remains under the control of the Federal agency having primary management authority for the land on which it was excavated or discovered until 90 days after publication in the Federal Register of a notice setting out a general description of the item, its estimated age, and the general area of discovery. Declares that any person or entity that disposes of or controls a cultural item described above shall comply with applicable requirements concerning the recording and status of items excavated or discovered on Federal lands after November 16, 1990, except those items whose ownership or control is established after such date. <n>Requires that studies of cultural items for which no lineal descendants have been identified and in cases of all other cultural items be conducted in an attempt to establish an affiliation or to obtain scientific, historical, or cultural information if the Federal agency or museum having custody of the item has agreed upon by the culturally affiliated tribe or Native Hawaiian organization their affiliation. Requires the Federal agency or museum to: (1) notify any such tribe or Native Hawaiian organization of its affiliation; and (2)

Transparency and Accountability of Failed Exchanges Act - Amends the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to require a state that is awarded a grant to establish an American Health Benefit Exchange (a health insurance exchange created under such Act) that terminates the operation of such Exchange or otherwise transfers the operation of it to an entity other than such state to: (1) submit to Congress and the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) a report containing the results of an audit of how amounts awarded to it pursuant to the grant were used; and (2) within 30 days after such termination or transfer, rescind any unobligated amounts awarded to it pursuant to the grant and require the state to provide to the Administrator of General Services any property acquired with such amounts, as well as submit to Congress and the Secretary a record of the provision of such property to the Administrator. Requires funds rescinded to be retained in the general fund of the Treasury for federal budget deficit reduction and allows the Administrator to dispose of any property obtained through a public auction for cash and for not less than its fair market value, as determined by the Administrator. Provides that such property shall not be subject to certain property disposal requirements.

Secondary Payer Advancement, Rationalization, and Clarification Act or the Cites Act This bill amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to specify that a prescription drug plan shall be secondary payor to any valid and collectible payment from a primary drug plan until such plan pays a final settlement, judgment, or award to an individual enrolled under the plan with regard to an injury or illness involved or otherwise terminates its ongoing responsibility for medical payments with respect to the individual. A primary drug plan is defined as a primary drug plan, other than a group health plan or multiemployer or multiple employer plan of, or contributed to by, an employer that has 20 or fewer employees for each working day in each of 20 or more calendar weeks in the calendar year involved or the preceding calendar year), a self-insured plan, a service benefit plan, a managed care organization, a pharmacy benefit manager, or other party that, by statute, contract, or agreement, is legally responsible for payment of a claim for a covered outpatient drug, in enrolling an individual or in making payments for benefits to the individual or on the individual's behalf, may not take into account that the individual is enrolled under a prescription drug plan under Medicare, or is eligible for or is provided coverage for
