One Strike You're Out, Part II Act - Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to authorize a public housing agency (PHA) to deny criminal offender assistance in the same manner and subject to the same conditions as an owner of federally assisted housing may deny occupancy in such housing under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1992.Amends the Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 to authorize owners of federally assisted housing to: (1) deny occupancy to applicants who are or were engaged in criminal activity during the preceding three-year period; and (2) require such applicants to submit evidence sufficient to ensure that they have not engaged in such criminal activity during such period.Amends the PHA lease procedure with respect to termination of tenancy to provide that any activity engaged in by the tenant, any member of the tenant's household, or any guest or other person under the tenant's control (regardless of whether the tenant had actual knowledge of such activity) threatens the health or safety of, or right to peaceful enjoyment of, the premises by, other tenants or employees of the PHA or other manager of the housing, threatens the health or safety of, or right to peaceful enjoyment of their residences by, persons residing in the immediate vicinity of the premises, or is criminal activity (including

Transnational Criminal Organization Illicit Spotter Prevention and Elimination Act This bill amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to establish enhanced penalties for: knowingly transmitting to another person the location, movement, or activities of a federal, state, local, or tribal law enforcement agency with the intent to further a federal crime relating to immigration, customs, controlled substances, agriculture, monetary instruments, or other border controls; destroying, altering, or damaging any fence, barrier, sensor, camera, or other physical or electronic device deployed by the federal government to control the border or a port of entry; conspiring to circumvent such border controls; and carrying or using a firearm or possessing a firearm in furtherance of such a crime. The bill revises and expands criminal penalties for alien smuggling crime.

Medicare Safety Net Access Act of 2002 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to provide for: (1) supplemental reimbursement for Federally qualified health centers participating in Medicare managed care; (2) revision of Federally qualified health center payment limits; (3) coverage of additional Federally qualified health center services; and (4) a safe harbor for certain collaborative efforts that benefit medically underserved populations.

Community Partnership Act of 2015 This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to establish within the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) the Office for Community Partnerships, to be headed by an Assistant Secretary for Community Partnerships. The Assistant Secretary is responsible for: leading DHS efforts to counter violent extremism across all DHS components and offices that conduct strategic and supportive efforts to counter such extremism; developing a digital engagement strategy that expands DHS efforts to counter violent extremist messaging; serving as the primary DHS representative in coordinating countering violent extremism efforts with other federal agencies and nongovernmental organizations; serving as the primary DHS-level representative in coordinating with the Department of State on international countering violent extremism issues; identifying and recommending new research and analysis requirements to ensure the dissemination of information and methods for federal, state, local, tribal, and territorial countering violent extremism practitioners, officials, law enforcement, and nongovernmental partners to utilize such research and analysis; developing a plan to expand philanthropic support for domestic efforts related to countering violent extremism; and administering such assistance directly or through cooperative agreements.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on December 8, 2015. Saving America's Pollinators Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to suspend the registration of a neonicotinoid pesticide unless the EPA determines that there is a reasonable certainty of no harm to pollinators from the pesticide applied on agricultural crops. A pesticide is exempt from this suspension if the EPA determines that: (1) there is no risk to pollinators from the pesticide, and (2) the risk of exposure to the pesticide to pollinators is low. The EPA may suspend the registration of a neonicotinoid pesticide if it determines that: (1) there is a reasonable certainty of no harm to pollinators from the pesticide, and (2) the risk of exposure to the pesticide to pollinators is low.

Securing America's Facilities, Equipment and Rail: Taking Responsibility for American National Security in Transit Act or the SAFER TRANSIT Act This bill directs the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), in coordination with the Office of Management and Budget, to report to Congress on the plan to expedite the implementation of the Implementing Recommendations of the 9/11 Commission Act of 2007 to: (1) assign rail carriers to high-risk tiers; and (2) establish a rail security training program. The bill reauthorizes through FY2020: (1) the surface transportation security inspector program, and (2) the public transportation security research and development program. DHS shall develop a "Local Transit Security Instructor Training Program" at the Federal Law Enforcement Training Centers to provide training to local police officers regarding transportation security. The bill authorizes DHS to make grants to states, local governments, and Indian tribal governments to improve security on public transportation systems.

Energy-Efficient Roof Jobs Act This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow, for depreciation purposes: (1) a 20-year recovery period for qualified energy-efficient cool roof replacement property, and (2) the expensing of qualified energy-efficient cool roof replacement property. The bill defines qualified energy-efficient cool roof replacement property" as any roof system which: (1) is placed in service above conditioned or semi-proof space and which has a slope equal to or less than 2 feet, (2) replaces an existing roof system, and (3) is allowable as depreciation for a period of three years or less."

Nye County Higher Education Campus Conveyance Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, one year after the official metes and bounds of specified Bureau of Land Management land are approved, to convey to the University and Community College System of Nevada all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to such land for use as a campus for Nye County Nevada Education Campus in Pah Valley, Nevada.Directs the Chancellor of the University system to agree in writing to: (1) pay administrative costs associated with the conveyance; (2) use the Federal land conveyed to the College for educational or recreational purposes; and (3) release the United States from any claims or liabilities which may arise from uses of such land before enactment of this Act.Requires the College to erect an appropriate and centrally located monument to acknowledge such conveyance.

United Nations Rapid Deployment Act of 2001 - Directs the President to direct the U.S. representative to the United Nations (UN) to urge the UN to: (1) establish a United Nations Rapid Deployment Police and Security Force (UNRDPSF); (2) recruit personnel to serve in the Force; and (3) provide equitable and reliable funding for the Force.

Protect Marriage from the Courts Act of 2015 This bill prohibits federal courts from having jurisdiction to adjudicate or enforce any claim pertaining to the validity, under the Constitution of the United States, of a state law, or state administrative or judicial decision, that: (1) defines marriage as limited to the union of one man and one woman, or (2) refuses state recognition of or allows the state to refuse recognition of same-sex marriages performed and licensed in other states. The prohibition applies to courts created by federal law or the Supreme Court if any provision of this Act, or the application of such provision or amendment to any person or circumstance, is held to be unconstitutional.

Establishes the Consumer Price Index Review Committee to study and develop an implementation plan for improving the method for determining the Experimental Consumer Price Index for the Elderly (CPI-E).

Improving Food-borne Illness Surveillance and Response Act of 2008 - Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to strengthen and expand food-borne illness surveillance systems to: (1) inform and evaluate efforts to prevent food-borne illness; and (2) enhance the identification and investigation of, and response to, food-borne illness outbreaks. Defines food-borne illness outbreak" as the occurrence of two or more cases of a similar illness resulting from the ingestion of a common food.<n><n>Requires the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to: (1) enhance food-borne illness surveillance systems to improve the collection, analysis, reporting, and usefulness of data on food-borne illnesses; and (2) improve capacity for food-borne illness surveillance in states."

Fairness for Working Americans Act of 2004 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) increase the refundable portion of the child tax credit; and (2) prevent certain foreign corporations from avoiding U.S. income tax by acquiring domestic corporations in expatriation transactions.

Nonproliferation Assistance Coordination Act of 2001 - Establishes within the executive branch an interagency committee known as the Committee on Nonproliferation Assistance to the Independent States of the Former Soviet Union which shall have primary continuing responsibility within the executive branch for: (1) monitoring U.S. nonproliferation efforts in the independent states of the former Soviet Union; and (2) coordinating the implementation of U.S. policy with respect to such efforts.

Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to provide funds for FY 2006 through 2009 to the Bass Lake Joint Union Elementary School District and the Mariposa Unified School District in California for educational services for students who: (1) are dependents of persons engaged in the administration, operation, and maintenance of Yosemite National Park; or (2) live within or near the Park upon Federal property. Terminates the Secretary's authority to make such payments if the State of California or local education agencies do not continue to provide funding to the schools in those school districts at per student levels that are no less than the amount provided in fiscal year 2005. Sets forth limitations on the use and amount of such funds, including a maximum limit of $400,000 on payments in any fiscal year. Prohibits payments under this Act from coming from: (1) fees under the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965 and the Federal Lands Recreation Enhancement Act; (2) unexpended receipts collected through the recreational fee demonstration program and the national park passport program; (3) emergency appropriations for Yosemite flood recovery; or (4) authorized funding from the National Parks Omnibus Management Act of 1998. Amends the Omnibus Parks and Public Lands Management Act of 1996 to allow certain facilities to be located outside the boundaries of Yosemite National Park. Rancho Corral de Tierra Golden Gate National Recreation Area Boundary Adjustment

Affordable Medicines Utilization Act of 2011 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act, with respect to FY2012-FY2014, to require an increase in the quarterly Medicaid payment to a state by 50% of the generic drug utilization savings amount if the state's generic substitution rate for the most recent preceding fiscal year for which data are available is greater than its rate for the second most recent preceding fiscal year for which data are available.

Race to the Top Act of 2010 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to states or local educational agencies (LEAs) to enable them to implement comprehensive reforms and innovative strategies that lead to: (1) significant improvements in outcomes for all students; and (2) significant reductions in achievement gaps among subgroups of students.<n><n>Reserves specified funds for technical assistance, monitoring, outreach, dissemination, and prize awards.<n><n>Prohibits states that have received a grant under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 from receiving a grant under this Act during the period of its grant.<n><n>Limits grant awards to four years.<n><n>Prohibits LEAs from receiving more than one grant per grant period.<n><n>Requires LEAs to demonstrate to the Secretary that they are: (1) making progress, at a rate the Secretary determines will result in them fully implementing their plan, during the remainder of the grant period; or (2) making progress against specified performance measures, at a rate that the Secretary determines will result in them reaching their objectives of the grant period.

Higher Education Savings Plan Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt a taxpayer from the ten percent penalty for premature distributions from an annuity contract if such distribution is used within 90 days to pay qualified tuition and related expenses for the taxpayer, the taxpayer's spouse, or a child or grandchild at an eligible educational institution. Excludes such expenses from gross income.

(Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary of Energy to: (1) establish a program for the acquisition of certain commercially available fuel cell power plants and power generated therefrom for use at federally owned or operated facilities; and (2) provide funding for purchase, site engineering, installation, startup, training, operation, and maintenance costs associated with such acquisition, along with any other necessary assistance. Requires that all fuel cell systems and fuel cell stacks in power plants acquired, or from which power is acquired, be assembled in the United States. Sets forth site selection priorities, including sites with one or more of the following attributes: (1) location of the Federal facility or the generating power plant in an area classified as a nonattainment area under title I of the Clean Air Act; (2) computer or electronic operations that are sensitive to power supply disruptions; (3) need for a reliable, uninterrupted power supply; (4) remote location; or (5) critical manufacturing or other activities that support national security efforts.(Sec. 4) Directs the President, in coordination with designated Secretaries, to establish: (1) a demonstration program for fuel cell proton exchange membrane technology in areas of responsibility of those Secretaries regarding commercial, residential, and transportation applications (including buses); and (2) a comprehensive proton exchange membrane fuel cell bus demonstration program to address hydrogen production

Grants a federal charter to the National Academy of Inventors (a not-for-profit organization incorporated under the laws of Florida).<n><n>Declares that the purposes of the organization are as provided in its bylaws and articles of incorporation.<n><n>Prohibits the corporation from issuing stock or declaring or paying a dividend.<n><n>Requires the corporation to maintain its status as a tax-exempt organization if it fails to maintain such status.

Accelerating Kids' Access to Care Act This bill requires a state Medicaid program to adopt a streamlined screening and enrollment process for eligible out-of-state medical providers and suppliers. The process must: (1) permit the eligible provider or supplier to order all clinically necessary follow-up care, including for the prescribing of medications; and (2) be established in coordination with the Medicare program.

Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to establish a program for rural community service grants. <n>Authorizes the Secretary of Education to provide such assistance. Requires grant applications to contain assurances that an eligible institution will enter into a consortium that includes a community college, a rural local educational agency, a local government, a business or other employer, or a nonprofit institution. <n>Directs the Secretary to: (1) give priority to applications that propose to conduct joint projects supported by other local, State, and Federal programs; and (2) designate a peer review panel to review applications and make recommendations for funding. <n>Authorizes appropriations.

Super-Efficient Appliance Incentives and Market Transformation Act of 2007- Amends the Internal Revenue Code to revise the tax credit for production of qualified energy efficient appliances. Increases the credit amounts for dishwashers, top- loading clothes washers, and refrigerators.

Primary Care Workforce Access Improvement Act of 2011 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to conduct a pilot project under title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to test models for providing payment under Medicare to medical education entities for the costs of training primary care residents.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the House on September 25, 2017. Public Innovation Space Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Museum and Library Services Act to reauthorize appropriations for FY2018-FY2022 for the Institute of Museum and Library Service's Public Innovation Space Program. (Sec. 3) The bill requires the Institute to carry out a program of competitive grants to eligible partnerships to establish contributed at public libraries, including economic development, state, local, and private entities. An eligible partnership must contribute nonfederal matching funds equal to the amount of the grant awarded. The Institute may waive this requirement for any eligible partnership that it determines does not have adequate resources to meet it. (Sec. 4) The bill prohibits the use of grant funds for construction activities at a public library through this program.

American Samoa Economic Development Act of 1995 - Authorizes appropriations to the Secretary of the Interior for the Government of American Samoa for each of FY 1996 through 2005. Provides that such amounts shall be used for: (1) construction of capital assets of American Samoa; (2) maintenance and repair of such capital assets; (3) the operations of American Samoa; and (4) reduction of unbudgeted debt incurred by American Samoa in FY 1996 and 1997. Specifies the table of multiyear funding with respect to FY 1996 through 2005. Declares that appropriations shall remain available until expended. Requires the Government of American Samoa to establish a trust to administer the funds placed in such trust.

Working Families Flexibility Act of 1996 - Amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to repeal the limitation on the amount of compensatory time an employee may receive at a rate of not less than one and one-half hours for each hour of employment for which overtime compensation is required. Authorizes employers, under specified conditions, to provide compensatory time only: (1) pursuant to an applicable collective bargaining agreement, memorandum of understanding, or any other agreement between the employer and employees, or in the case of employees who are not represented by a collective bargaining agent or other representative designated by the employee, an agreement or understanding arrived at between the employer and employee before the performance of the work if such agreement or understanding was entered into knowingly and voluntarily by such employee; and (2) in the case of an employee who is not an employee of a public agency, if such employee has affirmed in a written or otherwise verifiable statement that the employee has chosen to receive compensatory time in lieu of overtime compensation. Prohibits an employer from directly or indirectly intimidating, threatening, or coercing an employee in order to: (1) interfere with such employee's rights under this Act to request or not request compensatory time off in lieu of payment of overtime compensation for overtime hours; or (2) require any employee to use such compensatory

Rural Equity Payment Index Reform Act of 2003 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to revise the work geographic index applied for payment under the physician fee schedule in order to establish a minimum work geographic index for 2007 and subsequent years.

Clean Up Government Act of 2011 - Amends the federal criminal code to: (1) subject mail and wire fraud offenses to criminal penalties; (2) increase criminal penalties for theft of public property and for fraud in connection with federal financial assistance programs; (3) extend the statute of limitations for theft of public property and for fraud in connection with federal financial assistance programs; (4) redefine the term official act" to include any act within the range of official duty, and any decision, recommendation, or action on any question, matter, cause, suit, proceeding, or controversy, which may at any time be pending, or which may by law be brought before any public official in such official\\'s official capacity or in such official\\'s place of trust or profit; and (5) expand the definition of "official act" to include a decision or recommendation that a government should not take action.<n><n>Directs the United States Sentencing Commission to review and amend its guidelines and policy statements applicable to persons convicted of specified federal offenses in order to reflect the intent of Congress that such penalties be increased in comparison to those currently provided."

Campaign Sunlight Act of 2012 - Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to direct the Federal Election Commission (FEC) to establish and operate the Campaign Accountability Site through which members of the public may view the contents of political advertisements. Requires the FEC to: (1) make such contents available for viewing in the same format through which the advertisement was disseminated, and (2) make the advertisement sources available on the website directly or through hyperlinks to the sources submitted to the FEC by the advertisement sponsor.

Green Energy Investment Zone Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the rate of the investment tax credit for energy property placed in service in a green energy investment zone by an eligible city with a population of at least 50,000. Defines green energy investment zone" as an eligible city located within a high job-loss metropolitan statistical area or a high job-loss micropolitan statistical area. Defines "high job loss" as an area designated as being among the lowest 1/3 of all metropolitan or micropolitan statistical areas on the basis of: (1) specified economic conditions; (2) the residential economic well-being factors; and (3) a comparison of changes from 1990 and 2000 (on the basis of the 1990 and 2000 censuses). Requires an election to treat qualified facilities located in high job-loss zones as energy property for purposes of the tax credit for producing electricity from certain renewable resources."

Digital Era Copyright Enhancement Act - Amends Federal copyright law to provide that, in a determination concerning fair use, no independent weight shall be afforded to: (1) the means by which the work has been performed, displayed or distributed under the authority of the copyright owner; or (2) the application of an effective technological measure to the work. <n>(Sec. 3) Prohibits a copyright owner from preventing the distribution of copies or phonorecords of a work by means of a library orARCHIVE exemption. <n>(Sec. 4) Authorizes a copyright owner to authorize the use of a particular copy or phonorecord in a digital format by means of transmission to a single recipient, where the owner erases or destroys his or her copy or phonorecord at substantially the same time. <n>(Sec. 5) Declares that performance, display, and distribution of a work by or in the course of an analog or digital transmission is not an infringement if: (1) the performance, display, or distribution is a regular part of the systematic instructional activities of a governmental body or a nonprofit educational institution; (2) the performance, display, or distribution is directly related and of material assistance to the teaching content of the transmission; and (3) the work is provided for reception by students officially enrolled in the

Derivatives Limitations Act of 1995 - Amends the Federal Deposit Insurance Act and the Federal Credit Union Act to prohibit an insured depository institution or credit union (including its affiliates) from engaging in any transaction for its own account which involves derivative financial instruments. Declares that nothing in this Act shall be construed as: (1) affecting an interest of an insured depository institution in any derivative financial instrument that existed on the date of enactment of this Act; or (2) restricting the ability of the institution to acquire reasonably related interests in other derivative financial instruments for the purpose of resolving or terminating an interest of the institution in any derivative financial instrument that existed on the date of enactment of this Act. Declares that nothing in this Act shall be construed to: (1) affect an interest of an insured depository institution in any derivative financial instrument that existed on the date of enactment of this Act; or (2) restrict the ability of an insured depository institution to acquire reasonably related interests in other derivative financial instruments for the purpose of resolving or terminating an interest of the institution in any derivative financial instrument that existed on the date of enactment of this Act. Declares that the appropriate Federal banking agency shall issue rules, regulations, and orders governing the exceptions provided for, including: (1) appropriate public notice requirements; (2) a requirement that any

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 16, 2015. Improved Security Vetting for Aviation Workers Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to: request from the Director of National Intelligence access to additional data from the Terrorist Datamart Environment and any or other terrorism-related information to improve the effectiveness of the TSA's credential vetting program for individuals with unescorted access to sensitive areas of airports; issue guidance to TSA Inspectors to annually review airport badging office procedures for applicants seeking access to sensitive areas of airports, including a comprehensive review of applicants' Criminal History Records Check and work authorization documentation during the course of an inspection; and conduct a pilot program of the Rap Back Service to determine the feasibility of full implementation of a service through which the TSA would be notified of a change in status of an individual holding a valid credential granting unescorted access to sensitive areas of airports across eligible TSA-regulated populations. The pilot program: shall evaluate whether information can be narrowly tailored to ensure that the TSA only receives notification of a change with respect to a disqualifying offense under the credential vetting program and in a manner

Amends Federal law to provide that the annual rate of pay for positions at each level of the Executive Schedule (currently, level I) shall be adjusted by an amount rounded to the nearest multiple of $100 (or if midway between multiples of $100, to the next highest multiple of $100) equal to the percentage of such annual rate of pay which corresponds to the percentage adjustment becoming so payable with respect to General Schedule employees within the District of Columbia. Specifies that if an adjustment is scheduled to take effect on the same date as an adjustment, the adjustment shall be made first. Treats such adjusted annual rate of pay as the annual rate of pay for the positions involved, except as otherwise provided.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 5, 2016. Tribal Forestry Participation and Protection Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Tribal Forest Protection Act of 2004 to direct the Department of Agriculture (USDA) and the Department of the Interior, as appropriate, to consider requests by Indian tribes for the use of their lands, assets, or resources in return for their participation in forest restoration projects on National Forest System and public land within their respective jurisdictions. The Tribal Forest Protection Act of 2004 is amended to direct USDA and Interior to: (1) give an initial response within 90 days after receiving a tribal request for the use of their lands, assets, or resources, and (2) deny a request within one year after receiving it. The bill requires USDA and Interior to: (1) complete all environmental reviews necessary in connection with the agreement or contract and proposed activities under the agreement or contract, and (2) enter into the agreement or contract with the Indian tribe within two years after receiving a request other than theirs. The National Indian Forest Resources Management Act is amended to provide that, in order to maximize the effective management of federal forest land and to assist in the restoration of that land in accordance with the principles of sustained yield, and to reduce insect, disease,

Welfare and Medicaid Responsibility Exchange Act of 1994 - Requires a State, in exchange for Federal funds for FY 1996 through 2000, to provide cash and non-cash assistance to low income individuals under the following programs: (1) the food stamp program under the Food Stamp Act of 1977; (2) the Medicaid program under title XIX of the Social Security Act; and (3) the special supplemental program for women, infants, and children established under the Child Nutrition Act of 1966. <n>Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make quarterly payments to each State during FY 1996 and 2000 in amounts equal to one-quarter of the applicable fiscal year's base expenditures and the amount that the Federal Government and the State would have expended in the State in the preceding quarter, as well as in the succeeding quarters, solely by reason of the increase in recipients which the Secretary and the Secretary of Agriculture would have occurred if such programs had not been terminated.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 17, 2015. Veterans Justice Outreach Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) Directs the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out a program to support veterans in contact with the criminal justice system by discouraging unnecessary criminalization of mental illness and other nonviolent crimes. Requires the VA to carry out the program in partnership with local law enforcement, judicial, and community-based treatment and legal assistance organizations. Authorizes the VA to conduct: training for police, prosecutors, courts, public defenders, and other community-based support organizations on matters relating to psychological trauma associated with military service and mental health and substance abuse services available from the VA; and support for courts and their officers, including physical presence in the setting, by facilitating mental health assessments, treatment planning, referrals to VA services, or other services as may be requested. Requires the VA to establish coordinators to provide outreach under the program and ensure that each coordinator is about psychological psychiatric and evaluation in relation to justice-based forensic matters. Requires the VA to report on such program to Congress.

Biodiesel Promotion and Quality Assurance Act of 2007 - Amends the Clean Air Act to direct the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to promulgate regulations to ensure that diesel fuel sold or introduced into commerce in the United States, on an annual average basis, contains the applicable volume of biodiesel determined in accordance with this Act. Requires the applicable volume for 2008 through 2012 to be biodiesel based on a formula that takes into consideration the impact of the use of renewable fuels on the environment, air quality, energy security, job creation, and rural economic development and the expected annual rate of future production of biodiesel. Requires at least 80% of the minimum applicable volume for 2008 through 2012 to be biodiesel.

Algae-based Renewable Fuel Promotion Act of 2010 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code, with respect to the cellulosic biofuel producer tax credit, to: (1) expand the definition of qualified feedstock" to include any cultivated algae, cyanobacteria, or lemna; (2) classify algae fuel as a qualified feedstock for purposes of the cellulosic biofuel producer tax credit; and (3) allow accelerated depreciation of property used to produce second generation biofuel."

Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to provide that nothing in ERISA shall be construed to supersede or otherwise alter, amend, modify, invalidate, or impair any cause of action under State law of a participant or beneficiary under a group health plan against the plan sponsor, the health insurance issuer offering coverage in connection with the plan, or any managed care entity in connection with the plan to recover damages resulting from personal injury or for wrongful death if such cause of action arises by reason of a medically reviewable decision.

Woodrow Wilson Memorial Bridge Preservation Act - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to be solely responsible for the maintenance, rehabilitation, and expansion of the existing Woodrow Wilson Memorial Bridge over the Potomac River between the States of Virginia and Maryland until all conditions under this Act are met. Designates the Woodrow Wilson Memorial Bridge Preservation Fund as the Woodrow Wilson Memorial Bridge Preservation Fund. Makes the Fund available to the Secretary for the maintenance, rehabilitation, and expansion of the existing Bridge to keep it in a condition sufficient to facilitate interstate traffic. Directs the Secretary, the Commonwealth of Virginia, the State of Maryland, and the District of Columbia to develop a transportation plan for the Capital corridor (Interstate Route 495) served by the Bridge project which shall establish what level of high occupancy vehicle lanes and transit service should be provided in the corridor and how such service should be accommodated on a replacement bridge.

Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 - Amends the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to require the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) to post on its website (while providing certain other information) detailed transition plans from each federal entity that is eligible for payments from the Spectrum Relocation Fund for costs related to the reallocation of frequencies from federal to nonfederal use.<n><n>Requires each federal entity's transition plan to provide certain public information about its spectrum relocation requirements including its: (1) current spectrum use; (2) geographic location of federal facilities or systems; (3) frequency bands used; (4) steps to be taken to relocate current spectrum uses; (5) interactions between eligible federal entities and NTIA needed to implement the transition plan; (6) authorized commercial licensee interactions; (7) plans and timelines for equipment procuring, field-testing, and deploying; and (8) relocation process risk factors. Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to appoint a technical panel to evaluate each transition plan.

Requires the President to instruct the U.S. Representative to the United Nations and all U.S. representatives in bilateral and multilateral fora to ensure that any resolutions relating to the issue of Middle East refugees, and which include a reference to the required resolution of the Palestinian refugee issue, must also include a similarly explicit reference to the resolution of the issue of Jewish refugees from Arab countries.

Higher Education Family Opportunity Act of 1998 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a deduction for postsecondary tuition and related expenses in lieu of the Hope Scholarship and Lifetime Learning tax credits. Limits the amount allowed to $10,000 over five years.

Manhattan Project National Historical Park Act - Requires the Secretary of the Interior to establish as a unit of the National Park System the Manhattan Project National Historical Park in the State of Tennessee, which may be comprised of specified areas or portions.

. Centennial Monetary Commission Act of 2013 [sic] - Establishes the Centennial Monetary Commission to: (1) examine how United States monetary policy since the creation of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in 1913 has affected the performance of the U.S. economy in terms of output, employment, prices, and financial stability over time; (2) evaluate various operational regimes under which the Board and the Federal Open Market Committee may conduct monetary policy in terms achieving the maximum sustainable level of output and employment and price stability over the long term; and (3) recommend a course for United States monetary policy going forward.

Global Anti-Semitism Awareness Act of 2004 - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the United States should continue to support efforts to combat anti-Semitism worldwide through bilateral relationships and interaction with international organizations such as the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE); (2) the President should direct the Secretary of State to establish a permanent office in the Department of State to monitor and combat anti-Semitism; and (3) the Department should thoroughly document acts of anti-Semitism that occur around the world. Amends the State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956 to direct the Secretary to establish within the Department an Office to Monitor and Combat Anti-Semitism to be headed by a Special Envoy for Monitoring and Combating Anti-Semitism.

Grants a Federal charter to the Black Veterans of America (a nonprofit corporation organized under the laws of Minnesota). Prohibits the corporation from discriminating on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, handicap, age, or national origin in establishing the conditions of membership in the corporation and in determining the requirements for serving on its board of directors or as an officer of the corporation. Prohibits the corporation from making any loan to any officer, director, or employee of the corporation. Prohibits the corporation from claiming congressional approval or authorization of the Federal Government for any of its activities by virtue of this Act. Makes the corporation liable for the acts of its officers and agents whenever such officers and agents have acted within the scope of their authority. Declares that the corporation shall keep correct and complete books and records of account and minutes of any proceeding of the corporation involving any of its members, the board of directors, or any committee having authority under its board of directors. Requires the corporation to report annually to the Congress concerning its activities during the preceding fiscal year.

Private Mortgage Insurance Technical Corrections and Clarification Act - Amends the Homeowners Protection Act of 1998 with respect to: (1) changes in the amortization schedule of adjustable rate mortgages; and (2) loan modifications.

Wounded Warrior Transition Assistance Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of a military department to give a member of a reserve component being evaluated by a physical evaluation board for separation or retirement for disability or for placement on the temporary disability retired list the option to remain on active duty in order to continue to receive military pay and allowances until such time as the member: (1) is cleared by the board to return to duty; or (2) is separated, retired, or placed on the temporary disability retired list or inactive status list. Allows a member to change the election at any point during the physical evaluation board process and be released from active duty. Terminates such requirements five years after the enactment of this Act.<n><n>Directs the applicable human resources command to return to active duty in the Armed Forces each member of a reserve component who: (1) wants to return to active duty; and (2) is determined by an appropriate physician to be unable to work due to a service-connected illness or injury and is not retired, placed on the temporary disability retired list, receiving incapacitation pay or health care and disability benefits through the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA).

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 5, 2016. Anti-Pyramid Promotional Scheme Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill prohibits any person from establishing, operating, promoting, or causing to be promoted a pyramid promotional scheme. Violations shall be treated as an unfair or deceptive act or practice in, or affecting, commerce under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The bill sets forth definitions relating to: "pyramid promotional scheme" as a plan or operation by which a person gives consideration to a participant for the right to receive compensation that is derived primarily from the introduction of another person into the plan or operation rather than from the sale of products to ultimate users; and "appropriate inventory repurchase agreement" as a program by which a plan or operation repurchases, upon request at the termination of a participant's business relationship with the plan or operation, current and marketable inventory purchased and maintained by the participant for resale, use, or consumption, and such plan or operation in its recruiting literature, sales manual, and contracts with participants, including the manner in which the repurchase is exercised, and disclosure of any inventory that is not eligible for repurchase under the program.

Medical Savings Account Availability Act of 2001 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) repeal the limitations on the number of medical savings accounts; and (2) increase the amount of the deduction allowed for contributions to such accounts.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 23, 2011. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>Central Oregon Jobs and Water Security Act - Amends the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act to: (1) revise the boundary of the Bowman Dam, Oregon; and (2) require the developer for any hydropower development, including turbines and appurtenant facilities, at Bowman Dam, in consultation with the Bureau of Land Management (BLM), to analyze any impacts to values of the Wild and Scenic River that may be caused by such development, including future need and emergency repairs, and to propose mitigation for any such impacts as part of any license application submitted to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC).<n><n>Amends a specified Act regarding the release of water from the Bowman Dam for the city of Prineville, Oregon, to: (1) increase the amount of water that may be released from the Dam during periods of the year when there is no other discharge; and (2) require the Secretary of the Interior, as necessary for any given year, up to seven cubic feet per second to serve as mitigation for the city's groundwater pumping. Authorizes the Secretary to make applications to the state of Oregon to protect these supplies instream. Requires the

Oil Region National Heritage Area Act - Establishes the Oil Region National Heritage Area in Pennsylvania.Designates the Oil Heritage Region, Inc., a locally based, private, nonprofit management corporation, as the management entity for the Area. Requires the management entity to develop a management plan for the Area.

Department of Veterans Affairs Employment Reduction Assistance Act of 1998 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, before obligating any resources for voluntary separation incentive payments, to submit to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget a strategic plan outlining the use of such payments and a proposed organizational chart for the Department of Veterans Affairs once they have been completed. <n>(Sec. 4) Authorizes the Secretary to pay a voluntary separation incentive payment to an employee only to the extent necessary to reduce or eliminate the positions and functions identified by the strategic plan. <n>(Sec. 5) Provides that a voluntary separation incentive payment be paid in a lump sum after the employee's separation and be equal to the lesser of: (1) the amount the employee would have been entitled to receive (without adjustment for any previous payment); or (2) an amount determined by the Secretary not to exceed $25,000. <n>(Sec. 6) Prescribes that a voluntary separation incentive payment be paid in a lump sum after the employee's separation and be equal to the lesser of: (1) the amount the employee would have been entitled to receive (without adjustment for any previous payment); or (2) an amount determined by the Secretary not to exceed $25,000. <n>(Sec. 7) Requires that an individual who has

Nursing School Capacity Act of 2005 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to request that the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences enter into an agreement to study and report to the Secretary and Congress on: (1) constraints encountered by schools of nursing in admitting and graduating the number of registered nurses necessary to ensure patient safety and meet the need for quality assurance in the provision of health care; and (2) developing recommendations to alleviate the constraints on a short-term and long-term basis. Requires the Secretary to ensure that such agreement provides that the study will include information on: (1) the trends in applications for attendance at schools of nursing that are relevant to the purpose of this Act; (2) the number and demographic characteristics of entry-level and graduate students currently enrolled in schools of nursing, the retention rates at the schools, and the number of recent graduates from the schools, as compared to previous years and to the projected need for registered nurses based on two-year, five-year, and ten-year projections; (3) the number and demographic characteristics of nurses who pursue graduate education in nursing and non-nursing programs but do not pursue faculty positions in schools of nursing, the reasons therefor, including regulatory barriers to choosing to pursue such positions, the effect of such decisions on the

Brownfield Cleanup and Redevelopment Revolving Loan Fund Pilot Project Act of 1997 - Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to establish a pilot project to provide a capitalization loan to one or more States that submit applications to the Administrator to establish or expand a State revolving loan fund for purposes of providing loans for voluntary environmental cleanups of eligible facilities. <n>Requires loan applications to include: (1) evidence that the State is carrying out a voluntary cleanup program for eligible facilities and will provide a matching share of at least 20 percent of the costs of such cleanup from either new or existing sources of State funding; (2) evidence that the State will provide a matching share of at least 20 percent of the costs of such cleanup from either new or existing sources of State funding; and (3) a description of the State's proposed revolving loan program and capability to manage the program. <n>Permits States to use interest income or loan repayments (in an amount equal to not more than ten percent of their revolving loan fund amount) for program administrative purposes. Specifies that the State's revolving loan program shall: (1) provide loans to both public and private parties conducting voluntary cleanups under the State's voluntary cleanup program who are unable to secure loans from private lending institutions or other means of financing; (2)

STEM Support for Teachers in Education and Mentoring (STEM) Act or STEM 2 Act - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to award competitive planning grants to states, Indian tribes or tribal organizations, nonprofit organizations, or institutions of higher education to develop effective state or tribal science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) networks that coordinate STEM education efforts by: (1) facilitating communication and collaboration among public and private STEM stakeholders, and (2) identifying STEM occupational skills needed in the future. Directs the Secretary to award competitive grants to states, Indian tribes or tribal organizations, local educational agencies, institutions of higher education, or nonprofit organizations to develop, implement, and evaluate STEM education training programs for existing teachers and in postsecondary schools for preservice teachers.

International Peacekeeping Reform Act of 1997 - Prohibits any funds made available to the Department of State to pay for assessed or voluntary contributions to United Nations (UN) peacekeeping activities from being available for obligation or expenditure to the UN to establish, expand in size, or modify in mission a UN peacekeeping operation unless, with respect to such operation: (1) the President certifies to specified congressional committees that the President has notified the appropriate congressional committees of the intent to support the establishment of such operation at least 15 days before any vote in the Security Council to establish, expand, or modify such operation; and (2) if the President determines that an emergency exists which prevented such notification, the notification shall be provided within 48 hours after such Council vote. Specifies certification requirements.

Military Reservists Small Business Relief Act of 1999- Amends the Small Business Act to direct the Small Business Administration (SBA), upon request, to defer repayment of principal and interest due on direct loans made to: (1) members of reserve components of the Armed Forces ordered to active duty during a period of military conflict; or (2) small businesses that received such loans before such reservists were ordered to active duty. Extends the loan deferral period from the date the reservist is ordered to active duty until the date that is 180 days after he or she is discharged or released. Authorizes the SBA to reduce the interest rate on any loan qualifying for a deferral.

Digital Television Consumer Education Act of 2007 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require retail distributors of analog-only television sets to place conspicuously in the vicinity of such sets a consumer alert in clear and conspicuous print that the television has only an analog broadcast tuner and will require a converter box after February 17, 2009, to receive over-the-air broadcasts with an antenna. Requires multichannel video programming distributors to inform consumers of the digital television transition and options for continuing to receive broadcast programming. Requires commercial television broadcast licensees, between May 1, 2007, and November 3, 2008, to report to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) on steps taken and plans to inform consumers of the information required under this Act. Requires the FCC to establish and maintain a digital television transition public outreach program.

. Medicare Fair Drug Pricing Act of 2015 (Sec. 2) This bill amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) to establish a process for drug manufacturers to petition for the rescinding of previous identifications of certain drugs as specified drugs" with respect to which there is limited ability for prescription drug plan (PDP) sponsors and Medicare Advantage (MA) organizations to negotiate manufacturer rebates, so that the failure to apply this requirement will have a significant fiscal impact on the program. The bill defines "specified drugs" as a single source or biological that is not a biological product licensed pursuant to an application under the Public Health Service Act, and not both manufactured by more than two drug manufacturers and manufactured by at least one such manufacturer as a generic drug; or that is selected by CMS and determined to be a covered part D drug with respect to which there is limited ability for PDP sponsors and MA organizations to negotiate manufacturer rebates, so that the failure to apply this requirement will have a significant fiscal impact on the program. The CMS must negotiate a price for a specified drug that is the maximum price that is agreed to"

Character Development Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award grants to local educational agencies (LEAs) to establish mentoring programs that link at-risk youth with responsible, individual adults who serve as mentors and are intended to: (1) increase at-risk youth participation in, and enhance their ability to benefit from, elementary and secondary education; (2) discourage at-risk youth from using illegal drugs, violence, using dangerous weapons, and criminal activity; (3) promote personal and social responsibility among at-risk youth; (4) encourage at-risk youth participation in community service and community activities; or (5) provide general guidance to at-risk youth. <n>Requires the Secretary to give priority to grant applications that: (1) describe a mentoring program in which 60 percent or more of the at-risk youth to be served are eligible for assistance under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965; (2) describe a mentoring program that serves at-risk youth who are at risk of dropping out of school or involved in delinquent activities and demonstrate the ability of the LEA to continue the mentoring program after the termination of the Federal funds provided under this Act; and (3) demonstrate the ability of the LEA to continue such mentoring program after the termination of the Federal funds provided under this Act.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a taxpayer an income-based credit ($3,000 maximum) for qualifying child disability education and training expenses paid on behalf of a dependent under the age of 18.

Complete America's Great Trails Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for the fair market value of any National Scenic Trail conservation contribution. Requires the Secretary of the Interior to study and report to Congress on the efficacy of such tax credit in completing, extending, and increasing the number of National Scenic Trails.

Global AIDS Research and Relief Act of 2001 - Authorizes the President to provide assistance, including through international organizations, the United Nations, the World Bank, and other multilateral and nongovernmental organizations, to combat HIV/AIDS and other infectious diseases worldwide.

Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require a cable operator, with respect to channel capacity, to: (1) carry signals for public, educational, or governmental (PEG) use from the point of origin to subscribers without material degradation and without altering or removing content or data; (2) provide such signals, to and make them viewable by, every cable subscriber without additional service or equipment charges; and (3) provide to the appropriate local government subdivision, free of charge, any transmission services and the use of any transmission facilities necessary to meet such requirements.Requires a cable operator in a State that adopts legislation affecting cable system franchising requirements relating to support for PEG use to owe a local government subdivision, notwithstanding such legislation, an amount for each year in which the operator provides cable service that is determined by the local government subdivision as the amount of specified cash payments, in-kind support, and free services that the operator provides for PEG use.

Improved Oversight by Financial Inspectors General Act of 2009 - Amends the Federal Deposit Insurance Act and the Federal Credit Union Act to require each federal banking agency Inspector General (IG) for a specified six-month period to: (1) identify losses estimated to be incurred by the Deposit Insurance Fund (DIF) with respect to insured depository institutions supervised by that agency; (2) determine the grounds identified by the agency or state bank supervisor for appointing the Corporation as receiver and whether any unusual circumstances exist that might warrant an in-depth review of the loss; and (3) prepare a written report to the appropriate federal banking agency and Congress on the results of the IG\\'s determinations. Defines material loss" as any estimated loss in excess of $200 million occurring after March 31, 2009.<n><n>Requires the IG, for each loss to the DIF that is not a material loss, to determine the grounds identified by the agency or state bank supervisor for appointing the Corporation as receiver and whether any unusual circumstances exist that might warrant an in-depth review of the loss.<n><n>Requires the IG to report to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System reviewing the Administration\\'s supervision of a state credit union which incurred a material loss with respect to an insured credit union: (1) ascertain why the credit"

Independent Contractor Tax Simplification Act of 1998 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that, for purposes of determining the employment status of individuals as employees, a service provider shall not be treated as an employee, a service recipient shall not be treated as an employer, and a payor shall not be treated as an employer if: (1) a service provider has a significant investment in assets and training, incurs significant unreimbursed expenses, agrees to perform the service for a particular amount of time or to complete a specific result and is liable for damages for early termination without cause, is paid primarily on a commission basis, or purchases products for resale; (2) the service provider has a principal place of business, does not primarily provide service in the service recipient's place of business, or pays a fair market rent for use of the recipient's place of business or does not have to perform service only for the service recipient and, in the current year or in the proceeding or subsequent years, has performed or has offered to perform service for other persons; and (3) the services by an individual are performed pursuant to a written contract between the service provider and the person for whom the services are performed, or the payor and such contract provides that such individual will not

Comprehensive Opioid Recovery Centers Act of 2018 This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Department of Health and Human Services to award grants for the establishment and operation of comprehensive opioid recovery centers. A comprehensive opioid recovery center is a facility that provides comprehensive treatment and recovery services for individuals with an opioid or other substance use disorder.

Amends the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to recognize Alexander Creek, Incorporated (a Group Corporation organized pursuant to such Act) as the Native village of Alexander Creek. Requires Alexander Creek to file in the State: (1) any amendments to its corporate charter that are necessary to convert from a Group Corporation to a Village Corporation; and (2) any amendments to its corporate charter and governing business documents that are necessary to fulfill the terms of the agreement authorized under this Act. Directs the Secretary of the Interior (the Secretary) to: (1) commence negotiations with Alexander Creek to fairly and equitably settle any aboriginal land claims and any other claims that Alexander Creek has against the United States; and (2) enter into an agreement with Alexander Creek relating to such claims within 13 months after enactment of this Act. Requires Alexander Creek to notify each member of the Village Corporation recognized pursuant to this Act that: (1) the member shall cease to receive benefits from the Cook Inlet Region Incorporated (the Regional Corporation for Alexander Creek), and (2) all future resource payments from the Region shall be made to the Village Corporation. Declares that the Region shall not be liable under any Federal, State, or local law or under Federal or State common law for damages arising out of or related to the cessation of payments to the members of Alexander Creek.

(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on March 14, 2016. Drug-Free Indian Health Service Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to promulgate regulations to implement a mandatory random drug testing program for certain employees of the Indian Health Service (IHS), including those employed within Indian reservations or on Indian lands. HHS must ensure that each such employee is tested at least once per year for marijuana, cocaine, opioids, Methamphetamine, and Phencyclidine. HHS must notify an employee selected for random testing on the same day, but prior to, such testing and include in notification an assurance that the employee was selected randomly and is under no suspicion of illegal drug use. An employee selected may obtain a deferral of testing if the employee is: (1) in a leave status; or (2) in official travel status away from the test site or will embark on official travel that was scheduled prior to the notification of selection. HHS may determine that an employee has engaged in illegal drug use based on: (1) a verified positive test result from a specimen submitted, (2) direct observation by a higher-level supervisor, (3) evidence obtained from an arrest or criminal conviction, and (4) the voluntary admission of the employee. HHS

Rural Broadband Enhancement Act - Amends the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to direct the Rural Utilities Service of the Department of Agriculture to make loans or other extensions of credit to eligible entities for the construction, improvement, or acquisition of facilities and equipment (including consumer equipment) for the provision of broadband service in eligible rural communities.<n><n>Defines eligible rural community" as any incorporated or unincorporated place that: (1) has not more than 20,000 inhabitants; and (2) is not located in an area designated as a Metropolitan Area by the Office of Management and Budget.<n><n>Authorizes appropriations. Limits the aggregate value of loans and other extensions of credit to $3 billion."

Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2010 - Amends the National Housing Act and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation Act to prohibit the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) (government sponsored enterprises, or GSEs) from purchasing, acquiring, lending on the security of, newly invest in securities consisting of, or otherwise newly deal in any Mortgage Electronic Registration Systems (MERS), except in certain circumstances where compliance with such requirement will cause a severe threat to the continued financial viability of such entity.

Establishes in the legislative branch the Afghanistan-Pakistan Study Group to: (1) conduct a forward-looking, independent assessment of the current and prospective situation on the ground in Afghanistan and Pakistan, its impact on the surrounding region, and its consequences for U.S. interests; and (2) examine four broad topic areas to include the strategic environment in and around Afghanistan and Pakistan, as well as security, political, and economic reconstruction developments in those two countries.

Amends Federal armed forces provisions to provide an increase in the retired military pay of a member who performs qualifying hazardous duty and who retires on or after the date of enactment of this Act.Requires the Comptroller General to study and report to Congress on: (1) whether members of the National Guard and reserves comprise a disproportionately large portion of any size or type of business; (2) the amount of Federal tax benefit that would be appropriate to compensate such a business for costs associated with employing such members; and (3) whether changes can be made to the small business loan program to assist such businesses.Directs the Secretary of Defense to report to Congress on the following programs which provide significant benefits for the Armed Forces: (1) the Reserve Officers' Training Corps; (2) the Civil Air Patrol; (3) the Young Naval Sea Cadet Corps; and (4) the Junior Marines of the Marine Corps League.

This bill requires the President to report annually to Congress regarding the governments of other countries that have knowingly failed to: close the representative offices of persons designated under applicable United Nations Security Council resolutions; expel North Korean nationals, including diplomats, working on behalf of such persons; prohibit the opening of new branches, subsidiaries, or representative offices of North Korean financial institutions within such governments; or expel any representatives of North Korean financial institutions. The President must also provide Congress with a briefing regarding: a list of each person or foreign government that directly provides specialized financial messaging services to, or enables or facilitates direct or indirect access to, such messaging services for any North Korean financial institution designated under a United Nations Security Council resolution or any other North Korean person on behalf of such a North Korean financial institution; and the status of efforts by the Department of the Treasury to work with the relevant authorities in the home jurisdictions of such specialized financial messaging providers to end such provision or access. The bill amends the North Korea Sanctions and Policy Enhancement Act of 2016 to: add to the list of foreign persons that knowingly employ North Korean laborers under specified circumstances; require the President, in determining whether a country has made sustained efforts to eliminate severe forms of trafficking in persons, to consider whether each national or citizen of such country meets

Rebuild American Manufacturing Act of 2013 - Directs the President to develop a comprehensive national manufacturing strategy. Requires the President to revise such strategy at least every two years. Includes among the goals of such strategy to: (1) increase the aggregate number of manufacturing jobs in the United States so that such number is at least 20% of the sum of all nonfarm jobs in the United States; (2) identify emerging technologies to strengthen the competitiveness of U.S. manufacturing in the global marketplace; and (3) strengthen the manufacturing sectors of the United States in which the United States is most competitive in the global economy. Requires the national manufacturing strategy to include: (1) a survey of persons with headquarters in the United States that maintain manufacturing facilities outside of the United States to identify the categories of products manufactured at such facilities and the number of manufacturing jobs located at such facilities; (2) a survey of federal agencies that provide assistance to U.S. manufacturers; (3) a survey of manufacturing goods produced in the United States and where such goods are produced; (4) the number of people in the United States employed by manufacturers operating in the United States; and (5) an evaluation of the global competitiveness of U.S. manufacturing.

(This measure has not been amended since it was passed by the Senate on September 10, 2012. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Syria Humanitarian Support and Democratic Transition Assistance Act of 2012 (Sec. 3) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the United Nations (U.N.) and other international organizations should continue to work with the government of Syria to provide humanitarian assistance to populations affected by the conflict there; (2) the United States should support efforts by the Friends of the Syrian People to increase pressure on the government of Syria to allow free and unimpeded access by the United Nations and humanitarian agencies to assess humanitarian needs; and (3) the Secretary of State should designate Syria as a country of particular concern with respect to international humanitarian efforts. (Sec. 4) Authorizes the President to provide humanitarian assistance to Syria.

Higher Education Fairness Act of 1997 - Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to provide for various specified student assistance measures, including: (1) family contribution for dependent students; (2) family contribution for independent students without dependents other than a spouse; (3) income protection allowances for independent students with dependents other than a spouse; and (4) revised income protection allowances for independent students with dependents other than a spouse.

Civilian Volunteer Service Reserve Act - Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish the Civilian Volunteer Service Reserve, a national volunteer service corps ready for service in response to domestic or international emergencies, or other circumstances determined by the President.<n><n>States that: (1) all citizens and legal residents of the United States over the age of 18 shall be eligible to serve in the Civilian Reserve; and (2) individuals who volunteer with the Civilian Reserve shall be enrolled for a five-year period, and shall be expected to serve in full-time active duty status for a total period of six months, when called to such service. Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) eligibility requirements; (2) registration; (3) the methodology of call to action; and (4) full-time active duty service and benefits.

Grants a Federal charter to the American Military Retirees Association (a nonprofit corporation and incorporated under the laws of New York) to: (1) encourage military retirees to band together to protect earned benefits; and (2) advocate for the protection of such benefits through active monitoring of legislation in Congress and the policies and proposals of the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs.

United States Independent Film and Television Production Incentive Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish a wage credit for qualified U.S. independent film and television production costs of 25 percent of the qualified wages paid or incurred per such production during a taxable year. Limits the first $25,000 of such wages to each qualified employee or personal service corporation.

Southern Border Security Assistance Act - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) providing financial assistance for law enforcement initiatives with our Mexican partners is important; and (2) Congress must provide immediate resources and equipment to state and local law enforcement entities that are currently responding to border violence and criminal activities on a daily basis. Authorizes the Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with state and local law enforcement entities, to award border security assistance grants to such entities located in the Southern Border Region in Arizona, California, New Mexico, and Texas, which shall be used to: (1) obtain law enforcement equipment and tools, including secure two-way communication devices, portable laptops and office computers, license plate readers, unmanned aerial vehicles, unmanned aircraft systems, manned aircraft, cameras with night viewing capabilities, and any other appropriate law enforcement equipment; (2) hire additional personnel, including administrative support personnel, dispatchers, and jailers, and provide overtime funding for such personnel; (3) purchase law enforcement vehicles; (4) provide for critical power generation systems, infrastructure, and technological upgrades to support state and local data management systems and fusion centers; or (5) provide for specialized training and for direct operating expenses associated with detecting and prosecuting drug trafficking, human smuggling, and other illegal activity or violence that occurs at or near the international border between

Prosthetic and Orthotic Parity Act of 2009 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to require a group health plan that provides both medical and surgical benefits and benefits for prosthetic devices and components and custom orthotic devices and related services to provide prosthetics and orthotic devices and related services under terms and conditions that are no less favorable than those applicable to substantially all medical and surgical benefits provided under the plan. Prohibits the prosthetics and orthotic devices and related services covered by this Act from being subject to separate or more restrictive financial requirements or more restrictive terms and conditions.

High Performance Schools Act of 2001- Establishes the High Performance Schools Program.Authorizes the Secretary of Energy, through the Program, to make grants: (1) to school districts to implement the purpose of this Act for new and existing school buildings; (2) to State energy offices to administer the program; and (3) to State energy offices to promote participation by school districts in the Program. Requires grants to be used to achieve energy efficiency performance that reduces energy use at least 30 percent below that of a school constructed in compliance with standards prescribed in Chapter 8 of the 2000 International Energy Conservation Code, or a similar State code intended to achieve substantially equivalent results.Makes school districts that have demonstrated a need for such grants in order to respond appropriately to increasing elementary and secondary school enrollments or to make major investments in renovation of school facilities and that have made a commitment to use the grant funds to develop high performance school buildings eligible for grants for: (1) administration; and (2) promotion of participation.

Veteran Care Agreements Rule Enhancement Act or the Veteran CARE Act This bill authorizes the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), if it is not feasibly able to furnish hospital care, medical services, or extended care at VA facilities or under contracts or sharing agreements entered into under other authorities, to furnish such care and services by entering into agreements with eligible health care providers that are certified under this bill. A "Veterans Care Agreement" is defined as an agreement between the VA and a provider that: (1) has enrolled and entered into a provider agreement under title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act, (2) is a physician or supplier that has enrolled and entered into a participation agreement under Medicare part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance), (3) is a provider of items and services receiving payment under a state plan under Medicare or a waiver of such a plan, or (4) is an Aging and Disability Resource Center, an area agency on aging, or a state agency, or a center for independent living.

National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force Act of 2012 - Establishes the National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force to serve as an independent source of advice, research, and policy recommendations to the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA), the Assistant Administrator of the Office of Women's Business Ownership of the SBA, Congress, and the President.

National Park Centennial Challenge Fund Act - Establishes in the Treasury the National Park Centennial Challenge Fund. Provides that the Fund shall consist of: (1) qualified donations transferred from the Donations to the National Park Service account; and (2) amounts appropriated from the general fund of the Treasury.Requires the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service, to develop a list of signature projects and programs eligible for funding from the Fund. Requires that such list be submitted to the President and to the congressional appropriations committees.Authorizes the Secretary to transfer qualified donations of cash, including cash to liquidate a letter of credit, received by the National Park Service. Appropriates to the Fund amounts equal to the qualified donations received and the matching amounts.

Air Traffic Supervisor Retirement Reform Act of 1995 - Amends Federal retirement provisions with respect to air traffic controllers to redefine the term controller" to include a civilian employee of the Department of Transportation or the Department of Defense holding a supervisory, managerial, executive, technical, semiprofessional, or professional position for which experience as a controller is a prerequisite."

Public Servant Priority Placement Act of 1995 - Requires the Director of the Office of Personnel Management to establish a Government-wide program and each executive agency to establish an agency program to facilitate employment placement for Federal employees who: (1) are scheduled to be separated from service under a reduction in force; or (2) are separated from service under such a reduction in force. Requires each such agency placement program to provide a system to require the offer of a vacant position in an agency to an employee of such agency affected by such a reduction in force action, if the position cannot be filled within the agency, the employee to whom the offer is made is qualified for the offered position, the classification of the offered position is equal to or no more than one grade below their classification of the employee's present or last held position, or the basic rate of pay of the offered position is equal to the basic rate of pay of the employee's present or last held position, and the geographic location of the offered position is within the commuting area of the employee's residence or location of the employee's present or last held position.

Sportsmanship in Hunting Act of 2008 - Amends the federal criminal code to impose a fine and/or prison term of up to one year on anyone who knowingly transfers, transports, or possesses a confined exotic animal for the purposes of allowing the killing or collection of a trophy. Makes an exception for the killing or injuring of an exotic animal in a state or federal natural area reserve undertaking habitat restoration.

Helping College Students Cross Line Act - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to award grants to institutions of higher education to establish programs of financial assistance for undergraduate and vocational students with financial need to assist in the completion of their degree or certificate programs. Requires students to be eligible for such awards if they: (1) are enrolled as undergraduate or vocational students at such institution on a not less than half-time basis; (2) are academically able to complete the degree or certificate program for which they are enrolled within an academic year; (3) are in good academic standing at such institution at the time of the distribution of the award; (4) in the case of a student who previously received an award, maintained good academic standing during the academic period for which they received such previous award; (5) have an outstanding tuition payment due to such institution and are unable fully pay the amount due; and (6) the institution determines that such student will discontinue the degree or certificate program for which they are enrolled due to an inability to pay tuition. Limits students' awards to $1,000 per semester or equivalent. Directs the Secretary to create, and each student receiving an award to complete, an online survey concerning financial literacy matters.

Directs the Secretary, as consideration for a conveyance of land under this Act, the recipient of the land, with the consent of the Sabine National Forest, to convey to the Secretary other land, existing improvements, or improvements constructed to specifications of the National Forest System. Authorizes the Secretary to accept a cash equalization payment in excess of 25 percent of the value of any exchanged parcel of land.Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) solicit offers for the conveyance of land; and (2) convey to the New Waverly Gulf Coast Trades Center, Inc., all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to a parcel of real property (including improvements thereon) consisting of approximately 57 acres of land located within the Houston National Forest, Walker County, Texas. Requires the Center to pay to the Secretary an amount equal to the fair market value of the property.

Federal Power Asset Privatization Act of 1995 - Directs the Secretary of Energy to: (1) sell all Federal electric power generation facilities and transmission facilities; and (2) retain an experienced private sector firm to serve as financial advisor to such sales. Requires the Secretary to terminate the operations of the Federal Power Marketing Administrations after such sales. Declares that it is the sense of the Congress that the purchaser of any such facilities should offer to employ former employees of the Federal Power Marketing Administrations in connection with the operation of the facilities following their purchase.
